title: Using Internet Links From Behind Bars
description: The Internet has given a platform to death-row inmates and other American prisoners to plead their cases and seek pen pals, sparking outrage among many families of victims and creating a new debate about the rights of the growing number of prisoners.

title: Friars Locked in Dispute Over Land
description: For more than a century, the Franciscan friars have made the Graymoor Spiritual Life Center, set in a hilly swath of forest here, their world headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHADA, MARIA
description: MACHADA-Maria. Taken on July 29. Beloved sister of George and proclaimer and follower of the Gospel of Jesus Christ. Friends may call at Barrett Funeral Home, 424 West 51st, NYC, Tuesday, August 1, 4:00PM-9:00PM. Memorial service to be held Monday, August 7, Times Square Church Annex, 1657 Broadway, 2nd Floor, 6:308:00PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to World Aid, Times Square Church, 212-541-6300.

title: REDBACK NETWORKS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ABATIS SYSTEMS
description: The phone equipment maker Redback Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Abatis Systems Corporation, a privately held Canadian Internet protocol services company, for about $676 million in stock. Under the agreement, expected to close early this fall, Redback will purchase Abatis for 5.2 million shares. Redback rose $8.50, to $130 on the Nasdaq National Market and has more than tripled in the last year. After the deal closes, Abatis, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, will become a unit of Redback, which had 12-month revenues of $130 million.

title: Metro Business; Bond Sale to Aid Hospital
description: Seeking to ensure the salvation of a Suffolk County hospital that was nearly shut down early this year, the New York State Dormitory Authority plans to sell up to $118.5 million in tax exempt bonds whose proceeds would be used to put the St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center on a sound, long-term financial footing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITCHMAN, GRACE C.
description: HITCHMAN-Grace C. Of Pine Bush, NY. Retired executive secretary for James Felt and Co., NYC, died Friday, July 28, 2000, at home. She was 95. Devoted daughter of Robert F. and Mary E. Wallace Hitchman. She was born October 9, 1904, in NYC. Survivors include her loving sister Rose F. Leonard, four nieces, one nephew, three grandnieces and four grandnephews. Visitation Tuesday, August 1, at the William M. Gagan Funeral Home, Pine Bush. Funeral Wednesday, August 2, at 10 AM, at the Church of the Infant Savior, Pine Bush. Interment New Prospect Cemetery, Pine Bush, NY. Memorial contributions to the Pine Bush Ambulance Corps, Box 407, Pine Bush, NY 12566.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, ROSAMOND GRENFELL
description: SHAW-Rosamond Grenfell. The Board of Directors of The Grenfell Association of America extend heartfelt condolences on the death of their beloved mother and grandmother. To Mrs. Shaw's surviving three children, Richard Shaw, Anne Benditt and Susan Phillips, and her four surviving grandchildren, David, Christie, Laura, and Richard. Mrs. Shaw was a dear friend and long-time supporter of The Association. She was the last surviving child of Sir Wilfred T. Grenfell, who was knighted by King George for his legendary medical, missionary, and philanthropic contributions to the people of Labrador and Newfoundland. The Association was founded to perpetuate and support Sir Grenfell's work and Mrs. Shaw will be deeply missed by all its Members.

title: Riley to Get Mason In the Deal For Jones
description: To the chagrin of the Chicago Bulls, Pat Riley appears to have gotten his man.

title: A Ranch in the Rockies for Famed Artists and Novices
description: Sheep dung once was up to the windows of what artists now call the seminar room. The seminar room's floor is far from level, and its walls are chinked spruce and fir logs, remnants of a late-19th-century forest fire. But this summer William Christenberry, a photographer, used this former sheep shed to show slides for his course called Interaction of Media: Photography, Painting and Sculpture.

title: Party's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern daylight

title: On Broadway, Where Actors Get Physical
description: Swinging onstage at Broadway's New Amsterdam Theater, Christopher Jackson belts out his opening number in the musical ''The Lion King'' while suspended by a rope 25 feet above the audience.

title: State Sues Landlord Over 'Whites Only' Web Ad
description: In what officials say is a case of old-style discrimination in the new realm of cyberspace, a New Jersey landlord posted an Internet advertisement to rent apartments to ''whites only,'' a lawsuit charges.

title: Testimony Is Delayed in Auction Suit
description: Justice Department antitrust prosecutors investigating Christie's and Sotheby's won a court order yesterday postponing the taking of testimony in a civil suit against the giant auction houses until at least Sept. 11.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: When Asteroids Grow Up

title: Motorola Sues to Stop Software Sales on EBay
description: Motorola Sues to Stop Software Sales on EBay

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN EDGES UP. The yen rose slightly but still hovered near a two-month low against the dollar after Japan's chief banking regulator resigned. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.40 yen, down from 109.71 on Friday.

title: CEPHALON SHARES DROP AS DRUG FAILS TEST
description: Cephalon shares lost nearly a third of their value yesterday after the company said its narcolepsy drug, Provigil, did not improve symptoms of patients with attention deficit disorder. Shares in Cephalon fell as much $22.4375 to $40.3125, after the company released the disappointing data from a study of 113 adults with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Provigil was approved in 1998 for use in treating the excessive daytime sleepiness that afflicts people with narcolepsy. Investors had hoped that Provigil, like other drugs used in treating narcolepsy, might prove also to be effective against attention deficit disorder -- which represents a much larger potential market.

title: City Plans More Spraying on Staten Island to Counter West Nile Virus
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city would re-spray all of Staten Island tomorrow and Thursday with the pesticide Anvil as a ''prudent measure'' against the West Nile virus.

title: Camp Zeist Journal; The Dutch Are Unfazed by a Scottish Incursion
description: The Netherlands is about as flat as countries get, so here in this corner of a foreign field that is for the moment Scotland, there are no Highlands.

title: Behind W, a Square Guy With a Parallax View
description: ''Old-fashioned'' is not an expression anyone in the superchic, see-you-later-Charlie world of fashion magazines would think of applying to Dennis Freedman, the creative director of W, who turned an aging uptown broadsheet into a visually exciting barometer of the here and now.

title: Time Warner and Juno in Internet Access Deal
description: August 1, 2000

title: Laser Eye Surgery's Turf War
description: Harriet Bass lay on a table at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, her right eye propped open by a metal ring, staring up at a red dot of light.

title: Excerpts From Platform Approved by Republican National Convention
description: Following are excerts from the platform approved yesterday by the Republican National Convention.

title: Peres, Defeated for President, Seems Finished With Politics
description: At the moment today when the announcement of Parliament's first ballot for Israel's next president made it all but certain that he had lost what was most likely the last big battle of his 60-year political career, Shimon Peres, Nobel Prize laureate, three-time prime minister and one of the most enduring standard-bearers for Middle East peace, remained in character.

title: When Politics Is a Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: American Influences Help Redefine Practice of Yoga
description: Many of America's masters recently descended upon the Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health here for a conference on ''The New American Yoga.''

title: Lukas Has Aces, but Not a Winning Hand
description: As boys back in Wisconsin, D. Wayne Lukas and Clyde Rice watched wild mustangs file off the trucks en route to the knackers who turned them into feed for the nearby mink farms.

title: Corrections
description: A Pop/Jazz music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday for the City Parks Foundation Concerts carried an outdated schedule. Ray, Goodman and Brown is the performing group for three concerts: today at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn; Wednesday at Linden Park in East New York; and Thursday at Von King Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. The concerts begin at 7 and are free.

title: Stephen King E-Tale Near Break-Even After Week
description: A week into the horror writer Stephen King's closely watched experiment with self-publishing on the Internet, Mr. King said yesterday that he is about to break even.

title: Interloper Ants Keep It All in the Family
description: In a quirk of evolution and genetics, Argentine ants are overwhelming native California ants while forming what scientists believe may be the biggest ant colony in the world, stretching more than 600 miles from San Diego to north of San Francisco.

title: Demonstrators, Denied Permission, March Anyway and Even Gain a Police Escort
description: Slowly and strategically, a thick blue line of city police officers retreated from downtown toward the Republican National Convention today, yielding before an illegal protest parade rather than facing a potentially violent street confrontation with the world watching.

title: Novartis Settles Patent Suit That It Filed
description: Novartis A.G. has settled a patent infringement suit against a rival, the SangStat Medical Corporation, over a drug intended to suppress the body's rejection of transplanted organs.

title: Pandora's Box in Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A credit line in Business Day yesterday with an article about the computer graphics technology convention in New Orleans misstated the surname of the photographer. He is Dave Stueber, not Stuebe.

title: The Republicans' Illusion of Inclusion
description: In Philadelphia this week, the Republican Party faithful are playing their parts, as master illusionists try to convince independent voters that this is a different kind of convention for ''a different kind of Republican,'' Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Injury to Williams Leaves Giants Scrambling
description: The Giants are gambling at a variety of spots in their revamped starting lineup, hoping they have the right player at the right post. From the offensive line to the defensive line to cornerback, the Giants are taking risks.

description: To the Editor:

description: A Start-Up Recruits People To Donate DNA to Science

title: Public Interests; G.O.P.'s Summer Of Love
description: Thousands of Republican activists walked into the maw of the Philadelphia convention yesterday to begin their reprocessing. They arrived here as well-to-do white conservatives, a number of whom think trigger locks are unconstitutional and Social Security is a socialist scheme. But by Thursday night they are going to be nothing but a big, squishy bowl of inclusion that likes big hugs all around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, GAY
description: LYNN-Gay (Stirling) of Newport, Rhode Island, and Scotland Cay, Abaco, Bahamas passed away Tuesday, July 25 in Boston. She was 63. Widow of William Harcourt Lynn, beloved mother of William and Margaret, grandmother of three, longtime resident of Rye, NY. An avid sailing racer, she pioneered for accessibility for the disabled in the sport of sailing and was one of the first women to be recognized as an International Sailing Judge and Umpire. In lieu of flowers please make a memorial contribution in her name to: U.S. Special Olympics, Sailing-Donor Development, 1325 G StreetSuite 500, Washington, DC, 20005.

title: American Women Struggle
description: A loss to Norway, a team the American women will face in the opening round in the Olympics, is not what they had in mind in the last game of their 19-day, five-game European trip. The Americans did not play like the Olympic or World Cup champions they are in the 2-1 loss on Sunday in Oslo.

title: Police Say Mother Kidnapped Her Baby
description: A woman who had lost custody of her newborn daughter because the infant had tested positive for cocaine kidnapped the week-old girl from a Manhattan hospital yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Grey Worldwide Resigns Kohler Account
description: Grey Worldwide in New York, part of the Grey Global Group, has resigned the account of the Kohler Company in Kohler, Wis., the plumbing products maker. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER STARTS OFFER FOR DETROIT DIESEL
description: DaimlerChrysler began its tender offer yesterday for a planned $583 million purchase of the Detroit Diesel Corporation, a diesel-engine maker. The $23-a-share offer expires Aug. 25, unless extended, DaimlerChrysler said. On July 20, the automaker said it would buy the roughly 18.1 million shares of Detroit Diesel that it did not already own for $423 million and assume about $160 million in debt. Detroit Diesel, a former General Motors division, was sold to Roger Penske, the former race-car driver, in 1988. DDC Holdings, a unit of the closely held Penske Corporation that owns 48.6 percent of Detroit Diesel's outstanding shares, agreed to tender all of them, Detroit Diesel said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Streaking Liberty Clinches Playoff Spot
description: The Liberty zipped behind-the-back passes, spoon-fed each other on the fast break and dropped 3-pointers as if there were no defense to beat.

description: To the Editor:

description: Memo From: President Clinton

description: NEW YORK

title: Institute Gets $12.5 Million To Listen for Faraway Life
description: Two gifts totaling $12.5 million have cleared the way for the development of what is being described as the world's most powerful radio telescope designed specifically to listen for signals that may be coming from civilizations elsewhere in the galaxy.

title: Editorial Observer; Ghosts of Conventions Past in Philadelphia
description: As they opened their four-day festival of benevolence in Philadelphia, Republicans of all stripes seemed convinced that Gov. George W. Bush's election was a sure thing in November. Yet the best possible reminder of the perils of optimism lay only a couple miles west of the First Union Center at an abandoned convention hall on the other side of the Schuylkill River.

title: Image and Reality on Education
description: The first of four theme nights at the Republican Party's meticulously planned national convention focused on what has become George W. Bush's signature issue -- education, particularly education for young, poor children. In terms of giving this convention a softer and more inclusive feel, this was a wise choice. Yet it also illuminated the central paradox of a conclave marking Mr. Bush's emergence as the party's trend-setter. On the one hand, the vast convention hall was positively awash in soaring language and inspiring individual success stories designed to highlight Mr. Bush's signature promise that no child, no matter how disadvantaged, would be left behind. On the other hand, the same delegates who cheered this vision in prime time had earlier ratified a platform that defines a narrower, less generous world in which the federal government has virtually no role to play in shaping the country's educational future.

title: Company Seeking Donors Of DNA for a 'Gene Trust'
description: Wanted: your genes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, TINA
description: FRIED-Tina (nee Gorman). On July 31, 2000, age 90. Wife of the late Henry B. Fried. Mother of Caryl and Skip Feldmann, and the late Robert Fried. Grandmother of Leslie (Jim) Cowen, Sara (Robert) Sheehan, Ahmiel (Coleen) Fried, and Zephania (Les) Eldred, great grandmother of Alex, and Madeline Cowen, Hanna, and Molly Sheehan, and Brittany, and Blaine Eldred. She taught us through example what the meaning of unconditional love. Memorial to be announced.

description: CURTIN-John G. Of Englewood, N.J. on July 29, 2000. Beloved husband of Bettie (nee Sarver). Dear brother of Sister Catherine Curtin, D.C., Miss Teresa Curtin and Brother Daniel Curtin, C.F.C.. Donations to Catholic Relief Services 209 W. Fayette St. Baltimore, MD 21201 or SEED or Hospice c/o Englewood Hospital Medical Center 350 Engle St. Englewood, N.J. 07631 would be appreciated. For information contact the Barrett Funeral Home Tenafly, N.J.

title: Bush Is Chided on 2 Issues
description: The Democratic Party released two new 15-second television commercials yesterday timed to the opening of the Republican National Convention that attack the Texas record of Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican's presumed presidential nominee, on health care and the environment.

title: Moment in the Sun for Bush; A Noon Minute for Congress
description: Even though many Republicans worry more about losing the House than capturing the presidency, Gov. George W. Bush's team has given the House campaign effort no prime time for the week and indeed just half an hour of throw-away time at midday today.

title: German Faults 'Silence' About Attacks on Immigrants
description: A renewed wave of anti-immigrant violence in Germany has prompted Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer to suggest that a silent majority may be abetting the crimes by not speaking out against them.

title: PROFIT RISES AT BRITISH BANK
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C. said pretax profit rose 28 percent in the first half of the year, to $5.2 billion. The results, which beat analysts expectations, come as HSBC is beginning to integrate its many recent acquisitions including Republic New York. HSBC said its earnings were buoyed by growth in markets across Europe, Asia, North America and Latin America despite intense pressure on margins in Britain. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Law Firm Plans Radical Revision of Summer Program for Students
description: It seems like an odd recruiting strategy in a tight labor market: tell prospective employees that they can expect to work longer hours and receive fewer perks than they would at rival companies. But that is precisely what a large Washington law firm will announce today as it tries to redefine the summer-associate program that virtually all firms use to woo law students.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: Chicago Law Firm Makes New York Deal
description: Winston & Strawn, the large law firm in Chicago, said yesterday that it would merge with the New York office of Whitman Breed Abbott & Morgan next month as they join the race to become one of the world's 20 largest law firms.

title: Q & A
description: Boy Twins, Girl Twins

title: Devoted to Playing The Small Classics; Chamber Music Groups Abound, Passionate and Little Publicized
description: It is a secret world of chance meetings between strangers, of quietly arranged hookups, of one-time encounters that can turn passionate or can even blossom into semipermanence.

title: I.N.S. Cited for Poor Checks on Citizenship
description: The Justice Department's inspector general issued a report today detailing the litany of errors committed by the Immigration and Naturalization Service as it rushed to naturalize one million citizens in 1995 and 1996.

title: Even More Mired Than Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Antibiotics, When Patients Want Action
description: The desire of patients for a tangible outcome from a trip to the doctor and the desire of harried doctors to move on to the next patient are two of the most powerful factors behind the misuse of antibiotics, according to a study by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

title: Sports of The Times; Griffey's Homecoming Is Half-Empty
description: MAYBE you can't go home again, as Ken Griffey Jr. seemed to be saying yesterday, but Barry Larkin was having no second thoughts about staying home after refusing to come play shortstop for the Mets.

title: For Israeli President, Soft-Spoken Sephardi
description: Moshe Katsav, Israel's new president, is a modest, soft-spoken man who was the country's youngest mayor at 24 and has since soldiered loyally in the right-wing Likud's political trenches.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The unemployment rate fell for the first time since 1995, as growth in informal employment offset job cuts elsewhere. The unemployment rate fell to 23.3 percent in October 1999 from 25.2 percent a year earlier, Statistics South Africa said. The rate fell to 36.2 percent from 37.5 using an expanded definition that counts as unemployed people who have stopped looking for work. South Africa has shed jobs in recent years in industries like manufacturing and construction, as the end of apartheid has opened the economy to competition from abroad. Job creation in the informal market -- largely unregistered businesses often run from homes or street pavements -- are beginning to compensate.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM SOARS. Palladium prices rose as talks between Russia and Japan on supply showed no sign of progress. In New York, palladium for September delivery rose $45.95, or 5.9 percent, to $818.95 an ounce.

title: New Clues To Nature's Lopsidedness
description: Particle discoveries, like home runs in baseball, get all the attention from casual fans of physics. The arrival of a new particle is exciting, important and easy to understand. But while physicists appreciate the Ruthian impact of discovering a new elementary particle like the top quark or the recent finding of the tau neutrino, they know that there is a less heralded realm of discovery that can do every bit as much to change the course of science. That realm involves laws of symmetry -- how nature obeys them, and especially how it breaks them.

title: State to Sue Over Uncertified Teachers
description: New York State's top education official surprised Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday by announcing that he would go to court today to ask a judge to enforce his order prohibiting Mr. Levy from allowing uncertified teachers to work in failing schools.

title: Teacher Trainees Who Left Other Careers Speak of a Higher Calling
description: Joe Valley was packing boxes for a living, working six days a week at a warehouse in Queens. James Heekin was running his own moving business in Westchester County. Lauren Caldarera was studying anthropology in Kenya, and Carol McKeown was a nanny for a famous talk-radio host in Manhattan.

title: People
description: Marc Stephenson Strachan, chief marketing and operations officer at Vigilante, New York, was named to the new position of president and chief executive. Also, Larry Woodard was named to the new position of managing director; he had been strategic planning director at the UniWorld Group, New York. Danny Robinson continues as chief creative officer at Vigilante, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the B Com3 Group.

title: When Politics Is a Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALABELLA, GENE
description: FALABELLA-Gene. July 29, 2000. I mourn the untimely loss of my adored associate and friend. My deepest condolences to his family. Barbara Braun Carol O'Neil & Assoc.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on July 10 about an incentive offered by Talk magazine to attract advertising from Bacara, a resort hotel in California, referred incorrectly to monitoring of Talk's advertising pages by the Publishers Information Bureau. The bureau indeed monitors Talk, and its figures differ from independent estimates by an industry executive that were used in the article. In February, the bureau counted 138.4 advertising pages, compared with 48.6 for the independent count, although the larger figure included a special advertising section. In March, it counted 48.8 pages, compared with 41.3; in April, 70.3 pages, compared with 70.8; and in June 36.2 pages, compared with 36.1.

title: Shares Gain Modestly, Awaiting July Employment Data
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, led upward by bellwether technology issues, which took a beating for most of last week.

title: Student Jailed in Ecstasy Drug Case Hangs Himself
description: Kenneth Gregorio and Brian Juliano did not fit the profile of the street-hardened drug dealer. As a criminal justice major at nearby Monmouth University, Mr. Juliano knew he and his classmate were in deep trouble on Saturday night when law enforcement officials charged them with the possession and intended sale of 49,000 tablets of Ecstasy, the dance-club drug that has become increasingly popular with young suburbanites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BJORLIN, ELIZABETH S.
description: BJORLIN-Elizabeth S. (nee Falise). Of Ridgefield, CT and Bedford, NY died at the age of 41 at her home in Ridgefield, on Friday, July 28, 2000 after a courageous three and a half-year battle against cancer. After graduating with honors from Smith College and a semester at Oxford University, Beth enjoyed a growing career at Pepsico (after previous positions at Reader's Digest and Nestle) where her intellect, charm, dedication and genuine concern for other people, so well known by her loving family, were significantly recognized and appreciated. She is survived by her husband, Scott and two beautiful and bright daughters, Kari (7) and Kristen (4), a brother, William MacIntyre Gill, two sisters, Katherine Falise Knapp and Christina Falise and her loving parents, Katharine S. and Robert A. Falise. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Wednesday, August 2nd at St. Matthews Episcopal Church in Bedford, NY (on Route 22-Canitoe Road). In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Norma F. Pfriem Breast Care Center, 267 Grant Street, Bridgeport, CT 06610.

title: William Maxwell, 91, Author and Legendary Editor, Dies
description: William Maxwell, a small-town boy from Illinois who edited some of the century's literary lions in 40 years at The New Yorker while also writing novels and short stories that secured his own place in American letters, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: SOFTBANK AND PRICELINE FORM VENTURE
description: Priceline.com Inc., which lets customers bid on line for airplane tickets, hotel rooms and goods like food and gas, will form a joint venture in Japan with Softbank, Japan's largest Internet backer, to let users bid for airplane tickets and hotel rooms on the Internet. The joint venture, Priceline.com Japan, will be formed next month, initially as a unit owned 100 percent by Softbank. Priceline.com will eventually take a 50 percent stake.

title: FORD AND QUALCOMM FORM VENTURE
description: In a deal that would bring wireless services like the Internet and entertainment to automobiles, Ford Motor said that it had entered a joint venture with Qualcomm. The new company, tentatively called Wingcast, will be based in San Diego, Qualcomm's home. Ford and Qualcomm have equity stakes, although terms were not disclosed. Ford expects more than a million of its new cars and trucks to be equipped for wireless services by the end of 2002.

title: Discrimination Inquiry Begun at Weapons Lab
description: A federal civil rights agency is investigating possible discrimination against Asian and Asian-American employees at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, said spokesmen for the laboratory and the University of California, which manages it.

title: Patriots Excel For Belichick; 49ers Fizzle
description: It was the start of a new National Football League season in a new millennium. Making their preseason debuts were a new New England Patriots head coach (Bill Belichick), a new San Francisco 49ers owner (Denise DeBartolo York), a new San Francisco 49ers quarterback (Jeff Garcia) and a new Patriots bold blue-and-silver uniform.

title: Displaced in Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: Tale of Bad Timing at AMF: Silk Stockings and Bowling Shows
description: When Goldman, Sachs led a buyout of AMF Bowling in 1996, some analysts wondered why a silk-stocking investment bank would risk sullying its image in such a pedestrian pursuit. But, after four years under Goldman's control, it is AMF's image that has suffered as the company has racked up losses and its stock price has sunk to 75 cents a share.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY SHOWS A PROFIT
description: The information storage company, Storage Technology, reported second-quarter earnings of $8.7 million, its first operating profit in nine months and one that surpassed Wall Street's expectations. The news lighted a fire under the company's shares, which rose $2.75, or 27 percent, to close at $12.875. The company said its second-quarter profit was 9 cents a share, before revamping charges, beating the average analyst forecast of 5 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Second-quarter revenue, however, fell 22 percent, to $513 million.

description: Leaving Barneys in Order

description: DAVIS-Howland, 84, of Tivoli, NY and NY, NY, July 29, 2000. Husband of Frances Fabyan Davis; father of Howland S., Robert L., George F., and F. Dennie. A memorial service will be 11:00am Tuesday at St. Paul's/Trinity Parish, Tivoli. Memorial contributions may be made to NY Institute for Special Education, 999 Pelham Parkway, Bronx, NY 10469 or to Saugerties Lighthouse Conservancy, PO Box 654, Saugerties, NY 12477 or to St. Paul's Church, PO Box 68, Tivoli, NY 12583. For information contact Burnett, Rockefeller & Hand Funeral Home, 7461 S. Broadway, Red Hook, NY.

title: Fire in Sequoia Forest Is One of 45 Across West
description: More than 1,500 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters and tankers continued to battle a 63,270-acre wildfire in the Sierra Nevada today, with the blaze still only about 15 percent contained and dangerous dry lightning forecast.

title: Meat-Eating 'Vegetarians'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAGE, WOLFGANG
description: GLAGE-Wolfgang. In Westport, CT, July 30, 2000. Retired management consultant for Tower Perrin. Husband of Cynthia Glage. Father of Alexander and Jolina Glage and Senta Teschner. Grandfather of Jake Teschner.

title: Yankees Stay in Dugout At the Trading Deadline
description: After the Yankees ultimately passed on all of the trade options they discussed before yesterday's deadline, their general manager compared the decisions to surfing: sometimes you go with the wave, Brian Cashman said, and sometimes you don't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YACHNES, ELEANOR
description: YACHNES-Eleanor, M.D. On July 29, 2000. Beloved mother of Candy Systra, Laura Systra and Andrew Yachnes. Loving mother-in-law to Michael, grandmother to Daniel and Alexander, aunt to Matt, Lucy and Emily Gertz, Paul and Linda Yachnes. Psychoanalyst and vigorous lover of life. She will be missed by family and friends. Services August 1, at 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH J.
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah J. May 21, 1952-August 1, 1992. These have been the longest, loneliest eight years of our lives. Time is no healer and the ache in our hearts doesn't go away. Our love and longing for you grows stronger each day. Love forever and ever, Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEZIL, ANTONINE
description: YEZIL-Antonine (Krajcunus), 79. Beloved mother of Michael, and grandmother of Serena, died July 30, 2000. She will be deeply missed by all who loved her. Private funeral services will be held at Our Lady of Hope Church, in Queens, on August 1, 2000.

title: Russia Eases Taxes, but Businesses Call Deeper Cuts Essential
description: For much of the last decade, Russia's government had promised that it would reduce the country's huge tax burden. Last week it finally did. But the changes, business owners say, do not go nearly far enough.

title: UNIFY TO RESTATE EARNINGS; EXECUTIVES PUT ON LEAVE
description: The Unify Corporation said yesterday that it would restate earnings for fiscal 2000 and possibly some of 1999, and placed two top executives on leave, after the company, a maker of electronic-commerce software, found revenue was improperly stated. Unify also said first-quarter earnings for 2001 will miss the 9-cent average estimate of three analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. The company will restate earnings for the year ended April 30, with a ''substantial'' revision in the fourth quarter. Unify, based in San Jose, Calif., will also restate earnings for some quarters of 1999, if necessary. The president and chief executive, Reza Mikailli, and the chief financial officer and acting chief executive, Gary Pado, are on administrative leave while the matter is investigated, the company said. Trading in Unify shares was halted before the start of regular trading today.

title: 2 Executives Are Named To Head 20th Century Fox
description: Two longtime executives at 20th Century Fox were named today to share the job of running the movie studio, succeeding Bill Mechanic, who resigned in June.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MODTECH HOLDINGS INC., -- Perris, Calif., a maker of movable modular classrooms, said it ended talks for a $30 million purchase of Miller Building Systems Inc., Elkhart, Ind., a maker of modular buildings, the second time in 10 months the companies had abandoned talks.

title: Excerpts From General Powell's Address to Republicans
description: Following are excerpts from Retired Gen. Colin Powell's speech at the Republican National Convention yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: VITAL SIGNS: HYPERTENSION; When the White Coats Befuddle Doctors
description: Doctors call it ''white coat hypertension'' when a patient's nervousness during an office visit results in a misleadingly high blood pressure reading. But sometimes the opposite is true, and a study published in The Archives of Family Medicine suggests that more people than thought may be escaping diagnosis because of what its authors called ''white coat normotension.''

title: Parties and Fetes Aplenty In the Seeking of Influence
description: Representatives Michael G. Oxley and Billy Tauzin have brought their cash-fueled competition for the chairmanship of the House Commerce Committee to the Republican convention. And corporations affected by the committee are betting on both men.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Devils' Owner Expecting Sale
description: John McMullen said yesterday he feels confident that Puck Holdings, an affiliate of the Yankee-Nets, will complete its $175 million acquisition of his Devils by Aug. 31.

title: SBC TO SELL WIRELESS UNITS IN LOUISIANA TO ALLTEL
description: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 United States local-telephone company, agreed yesterday to sell some wireless assets in Louisiana to the Alltel Corporation for about $400 million to clear the way for a joint venture with BellSouth. Alltel, based in Little Rock, Ark., said it would gain 160,000 cellular-phone and 300,000 paging customers in New Orleans and Baton Rouge when the purchase closes later this year, adding to earnings in 2001. The accord is contingent on the completion of the SBC-BellSouth venture, which is still under regulatory review. The sale resolves some of the antitrust issues created when SBC and BellSouth agreed in April to combine their wireless businesses and form the No. 2 United States mobile-phone carrier behind Verizon Wireless, SBC said.

title: Braves Beat Mets to Punch With Surhoff
description: It is a charge Steve Phillips has disputed for months. The Mets need more left-handed hitters, the refrain goes, because they have only one in their starting lineup.

title: POLICING POP/A special report.; Recording Industry's Strictest Censor Is Itself
description: Something seemed a little strange when the Los Angeles hip-hop radio station Power 106 played a song from an album by pop's biggest current star, the 27-year-old white rapper Eminem, that had not yet been released as a single. Trying to mask offensive lyrics, the station bleeped out a derogatory term for blacks but left in a derogatory term for gays.

title: Canadian TV Makes a Move Into Papers
description: Making a bold bet on the future braiding of television, newspapers and the Internet, Canada's second-largest private television network said today that it would buy about half of the country's larger daily newspapers from Conrad Black, the international press magnate.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: President Opens Attack On the G.O.P.
description: President Clinton took on the Republicans and their platform today in a series of Florida appearances that raised more than $1.2 million for his party and rallied support for his plan to expand Medicare to provide prescription drug insurance.

title: BMW EARNINGS RISE 67%
description: BMW, Germany's No. 3 carmaker, said first-half profit rose a greater-than-expected 67 percent, as growing demand for its 3-Series more than offset wider losses at the Rover Cars unit it sold in May. Net income rose to 319 million euros ($295 million) from 191 million euros a year ago. Group sales increased 15 percent, to 18.8 billion euros. BMW shares climbed as much as 6.1 percent to 38.66 euros, the highest level in almost two years. The company predicted 2000 net income would ''significantly exceed'' the 663 million-euro operating profit it posted last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTIE, ELIZABETH P.
description: CHRISTIE-Elizabeth P. On July 30, 2000 at age 89. Loving aunt of Marie von Glahn, great aunt of 8 and great great aunt of 10. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, Wednesday 11 A.M.

title: TOMMY HILFIGER SUES GOODY'S OVER TRADEMARK USE
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, a designer of casual clothing, said yesterday that it was suing to stop Goody's Family Clothing from selling counterfeits of its products. Tommy Hilfiger's licensing unit contends in the suit that Goody's stores infringe its logo by selling clothing with unauthorized imitations of the company's flag trademark. Goody's also sells clothing with patches, labels, embroidery and tags that imitate Tommy Hilfiger's jeans, the clothing designer contends. Officials at Goody's, which operates stores in the Southeast and Midwest, could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, FANNY
description: GLUCK-Fanny. On July 31st, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Gerard. Loving mother of Joel Gluck and his companion, Susan Kramer. Dear aunt of Lenore Elias & Doris Nathanson. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Impeachment of the President? A Party Convention Is No Time to Dwell on the Past
description: Bill Clinton was impeached, right? No one here at the Republican National Convention seems to recall.

title: Rene Favaloro, 77, a Leader In Early Heart-Bypass Surgery
description: Dr. Rene G. Favaloro, a pioneer in heart-bypass surgery and a revered figure in Argentina, was found dead on Saturday at his home in Buenos Aires. He was 77.

title: Platform Strives to Reach Right and Center
description: The Republican National Convention today approved a platform intended to both reassure the party's conservative base and signal to the broader electorate that the party had been transformed by Gov. George W. Bush's bid for the center.

title: Treatment For Cancer Advances In Trials
description: A novel form of cancer treatment, based on a defective virus that can grow only in cancerous cells, has passed another milestone by showing promise in treating patients with recurrent head and neck cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONSIDINE, JOHN J.
description: CONSIDINE-John J., Reverend Monsignor. The Department of Education of the Archdiocese of New York recalls with gratitude and high esteem the steadfast leadership of Monsignor John J. Considine in his role as President of the Association of Catholic Schools. Monsignor Considine brought wisdom and pastoral insight to the collective bargaining process. He provided guidance, direction and contemplation which form part of his legacy to all of our schools. We extend our sympathy to his sister, Veronica Carey and his family. Rev. Msgr. Thomas J. Bergin Vicar for Education The Archdiocese of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINDER, ALFRED
description: FINDER-Alfred. On July 31, 2000. beloved husband of Rosalie. Loving father of Laurie Finder, Barbara Hirschtritt and her husband Stuart. Adoring grandfather of Matthew, Zachary and Dee Dee. Loving brother of Frederick. Services will be held at the New Montefiore Cemetery, at 10:30 AM Tuesday, August 1.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the ''At the Movies'' column in Weekend on Friday about ''Kiarostami 101,'' a short by the film scholar Jamsheed Akrami about the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, misstated plans for it. Mr. Akrami is expanding the short; it is not being shown with Mr. Kia rostami's new film, ''The Wind Will Carry Us,'' at the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZGER, PAUL
description: DANZGER-Paul. Beloved father of Herbert, Joshua and Reuven Danzger & Naomi Holzer. Brother of Morris Danzger. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Shiva will be observed until Friday, 1:00 PM.

title: Democrat's Exit a Relief for New Jersey Republicans
description: New Jersey Republicans attending the national convention in Philadelphia today were so stunned by Senator Robert G. Torricelli's sudden withdrawal from the Democratic race for governor that they seemed not to know whether to celebrate or lament his exit.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, HARVEY
description: GREENBERG-Harvey. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the death of the brother of our esteemed member Shirley Sprengers and extends to her our heartfelt condolences.

title: The Big City; Paper Profits That Failed To Materialize
description: IT was hailed by President Clinton as a model for the nation. State and city politicians enthusiastically offered praise and money. There were ready customers for its product. Allen Hershkowitz's dream of building a mill in the Bronx for recycled newsprint was nothing if not appealing.

title: Riding the Wave in a Trading Frenzy
description: The trade deadline is supposed to be for contenders. Does that mean the Chicago Cubs, who traded for Rondell White, consider themselves contenders?

title: Grier to Conduct This Week
description: Delta David Grier is to replace Mikko Franck this week as conductor of the New York Philharmonic in four free concerts in area parks. The concerts, featuring music by Bernstein, Gershwin, Stravinsky and Alexander Arutunian, take place today in Central Park; tomorrow in Prospect Park; on Thursday in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx; and on Saturday at Westchester Community College in Westchester, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, STEVE
description: ROSEN-Steve. His colleagues and friends on Community Board Six, Manhattan, express their deep sorrow at the passing of its former Chairman and twenty year member, Steve Rosen.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a trial for copyright violation in the publication of a software code that unscrambles a digital videodisc referred incorrectly to the design of a T-shirt shown in court. The inscription depicted the software's source code, the original programming instructions. The object code -- the instructions translated into 0's and 1's -- was not shown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HANNAH
description: STEIN-Hannah. July 31. Cherished wife of Solomon for 59 years. Loving mother of Evey and Mark Groothuis, and Alan and Marsha Stein. Dear grandmother of Andrew, David, Steven and Audrey. Beloved sister of Leon Shore, Toby Brooks and the late Irving Schlissel. Services today, 12:00 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows.

title: Bracing for Animation's Big Leap; Convention Offers Glimpses of a More Vivid Entertainment Future
description: Fred Tepper grew increasingly voluble as he described the wonders of Project: Messiah, the character animation software that he was promoting at Siggraph, the leading annual conclave for specialists in computer graphics, virtual reality and interactive technologies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's all propaganda. It's all a TV show. It's not news, but it's hugely important information for the American people.''

title: EXECTIVE CHANGES
description: CITIGROUP, New York, named Michael Carpenter to head investment and corporate banking in North America, Europe and Japan. Victor Menezes, who had previously overseen the units with Mr. Carpenter, was named to run consumer and corporate businesses in emerging markets.

title: An Emblem of Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Again Seeks Talks With China
description: Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, issued another appeal today to the Chinese government to reopen negotiations with his government. But Mr. Chen's overture -- the latest of several since he was elected in March -- was all but lost in the face of his deepening political troubles at home and evidence of mounting impatience in Beijing.

title: Convention's Magic Hour Stays Tuned to Major Networks
description: Jeff Zucker, the executive producer of convention coverage for NBC News, wanted a live interview tonight from the First Union Center with one of the event's most sought-after guests: George P. Bush, the telegenic 23-year-old nephew of the Texas governor.

title: FASTER CHIP FROM INTEL
description: A 1.13-gigahertz Pentium III chip was unveiled by Intel, which regained bragging rights to the speediest processor from its rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. Intel had played catch-up since Advanced Micro introduced an 850-megahertz chip in February, then a 1-gigahertz chip a month later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNUKAU, WALLACE
description: KUNUKAU-Wallace. Our coach, teammate, and friend, Wally enriched the lives of all who knew him. He will always be remembered by the members of Gotham Volleyball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPIETZKY, FANNIE
description: KUPIETZKY - Fannie. Lincoln Square Synagogue mourns with sorrow the passing of Mrs. Fannie Kupietzky, beloved mother of our member, Jonah Kupietzky, and grandmother of our members, Steven Kupietzky, and Neima Novetsky. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: A Natural for Outdoors (and Street Corners)
description: ''Playing outdoors really isn't a problem in terms of the instrument,'' said Philip Smith, the principal trumpet of the New York Philharmonic, who is to play the Arutunian Trumpet Concerto with the orchestra tonight in Central Park and also at parks in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Westchester this week. Unlike a string player, who might worry about the effect of heat and humidity on his instrument's intonation, Mr. Smith has no concern about the effect of the weather on his gleaming brass trumpet. What he worries about is his lip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEERICK, DONALD J.
description: FEERICK-Donald J. He had no sounding that it was the twilight of his years when he turned his steps toward Daytop to walk among a Town's walking-wounded young and to offer his saving hands. A Man of infinite gentleness, Donald Feerick was on a spiritual mission. Oscar Wilde best captured it: ''And somehow life is bigger after all than any painted angel; could we see the God that is within us!'' The Board of Governors and the legions of Daytop young people mourn his passing and offer prayerful support to his beloved Meg and Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village, Inc.

title: Bush Rides the Character Issue as He Heads Toward Philadelphia
description: He rarely mentions President Clinton in his stump speeches these days, and his aides are constantly pointing out that the Republican convention will not be devoted to bashing the Democrats. But as Gov. George W. Bush marches toward his coronation in Philadelphia, it is clear that the president is not far from his mind.

title: Griffey and Larkin Say No to the Mets Once Again
description: The rumors became reality three hours before the Mets played the Cincinnati Reds last night, and in their clubhouse at Shea Stadium, Mets players chatted about the comings and goings around the majors. They did not add or lose any teammates yesterday at the nonwaiver trading deadline, and this, they hope, is the group that will carry them into the postseason.

title: 2 African Nations Said to Break U.N. Diamond Embargo
description: American and British officials accused the presidents of Liberia and Burkina Faso today of taking personal roles in trading arms for diamonds in violation of a United Nations embargo. The officials also said the two leaders had helped Sierra Leone rebels to continue fighting their civil war.

title: Surfing With Nary a Wave And Happy Faces Galore
description: Republican Party elders and tacticians seemed to be spending much of the day yesterday appearing on every channel with more than a dozen viewers, talking about how to project an upbeat, temperate persona for the Republican Party.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a ruling that awarded Spain the remains of two sunken sailing ships misstated the seat and jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which issued the ruling. It is based in Richmond, Va., not Norfolk, and covers West Virginia as well as Maryland, Virginia and North and South Carolina.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PROGNOSIS; A Higher Risk for Babies Born at Night
description: Very few babies die during the first week of life. But for some reason, the risk is higher for babies born during the night than those born during the day, according to a German study published on Friday in The British Medical Journal.

title: Absent With Leave, Lazio Is Denied a National Spotlight
description: On Thursday night, Republican delegates from across the nation will gather here to nominate George W. Bush as their candidate for president. But one particularly prominent Republican delegate from the state of New York has decided to skip the climactic night of his party's nominating convention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, JAMES K.
description: O'NEILL-James K. On July 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Kathleen (nee Puccala). Loving son of Margaret & Thomas. Dear brother & best friend Patrick. Loving uncle of Megan Rose. Reposing at O'Shea-Hoey Funeral Home, Inc. 29-13 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, N.Y. Wednesday & Thursday 2-5 & 79:30 P.M. Funeral Mass Immaculate Conception Church Friday 9:45 A.M. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Manhattan College/James K. O'Neill Scholarship fund, Att/Joe Valenti Manhattan College, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: Storage Technology Surpasses Estimates
description: August 1, 2000

title: Republicans Open Convention, Emphasizing Unity
description: The Republican Party put on its newly moderate and disciplined face at the opening of its national convention today as one of the party's most compelling figures, Colin L. Powell, challenged delegates to rally behind Gov. George W. Bush with a genuine commitment to minorities.

title: Yankees Can't Start Network, Court Rules
description: A state judge barred the Yankees yesterday from proceeding with a plan for a cable television network because the team failed to give Madison Square Garden Network a legitimate chance to retain its right to carry Yankee games beyond this season.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BBC Worldwide Names Leo Burnett
description: BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the British Broadcasting Corporation, has named Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the B Com3 Group, as the first agency to help develop its worldwide brands like the Teletubbies on an international basis. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million. Mary Collins, a spokeswoman for BBC Worldwide in London, said the decision came after a six-month review that had been narrowed to Burnett and Leagas Delaney in London. The account had previously been handled on a project basis; the work will be coordinated from the Burnett London office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ARTHUR
description: SCHWARTZ-Arthur. On July 31, 2000 at the age of 86. Beloved husband of Lucille, loving and devoted father of Steven, Alan, and John. Cherished grandfather of Laura, Jessica, Chad, Michael, Daniel, Jeffrey, and Jacquelyn. Devoted brother of William. Service on Tuesday at 10 A.M. at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: BARNESANDNOBLE.COM LOSSES WIDEN
description: The No. 2 Internet bookseller in the United States, Barnesandnoble.com, said its second-quarter loss more than doubled, to $45.4 million, and warned that spending on new products and services might result in a wider-than-expected loss for the year. The second-quarter loss, equal to 31 cents a share, compares with $22 million, or 17 cents a share, for the period a year earlier, even though sales jumped 77 percent, to $67.4 million, from $38.2 million. The results came after the close of regular trading and the company's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $5.125. The 52-week high was $23.50.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PERCEPTIONS; Man, Superman, Clark Kent and Woman
description: A new study of male body images found that the average young man wants to look like Superman and thinks that women want men to look like Superman, while women really want men to look like Clark Kent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SHIRLEY
description: SHAPIRO-Shirley. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhoood mourn the passing of the beloved sister of their devoted member, Rochelle Mogilner and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President
