title: When Politics Is a Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Torricelli, Opposed Within Party, Drops New Jersey Governor Bid
description: Just three weeks after throwing New Jersey's Democratic Party into chaos by making a bid for governor of New Jersey, Senator Robert G. Torricelli abruptly abandoned the race today after an array of prominent Democrats said they would not support him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VADAY, GILAD
description: VADAY-Gilad. July 27, 2000. His friends at Bigfoot mourn his loss. His untimely passing has left a void in our hearts that will not soon be refilled. Our sincere condolences go out to his family and to all who knew him. We were all blessed for having him in our lives and will remain so for having him in our thoughts. His friends and family at Bigfoot

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, AVIVA
description: KIRSCH-Aviva (nee Isobel Leader). Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the tragic and untimely death of Aviva (Isobel Leader) Kirsch, beloved daughter of Ruby and the late Dr. Sidney Leader, our Honorary President For Life, and sister of Steven Leader. We will miss her devotion to family, her loving heart, her passion for living, and her devotion to the traditions of the Jewish people. Our entire community sends loving support to Aviva's children, Gabrielle and Beth, to Ruby, Steven, and Barbara, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELMAN, DOUGLAS EDMUND
description: FOGELMAN-Douglas Edmund. Died on July 30th, 2000 at Huntington Hospital, NY after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born in Huntington Hospital on March 21st, 1960. Douglas was the beloved son of Suzanne and Prof. Martin Fogelman, cherished brother of Henry, Jeffrey and Martin, Jr. and sister-in-law Patricia, loving uncle of Kimberly, Ann and Martin III. Services 2 PM, Wednesday, August 2nd, Temple Beth-El of Huntington, 600 Park Ave., Huntington. Interment Mt. Golda Cemetery, Huntington Station, New York. Dr. Fogelman was dearly beloved by all who knew him. Donations to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: A Force Behind the 'Shadow Conventions'
description: CURIOUS facts for curious folks:

title: PRATT & WHITNEY GETS $200 MILLION JET ENGINE ORDER
description: The Pratt & Whitney unit of the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had won a $200 million order from the International Lease Finance Corporation for jet engines for eight Airbus Industrie aircraft. The value of the order could climb to $450 million if International Lease, a unit of American International Group, exercises options for 10 more Airbus A330 aircraft. Shares of United Technologies, based in Hartford, rose 93.75 cents, to $58.375.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Freeman J. Dyson; A-Bombs, Space Chickens and God
description: In the small world of literary science writing, there are few authors as prolific and original as Dr. Freeman J. Dyson, 76, the British-born theoretical physicist, astrophysicist and author of books on scientific matters.

title: Clark Wins Playoff For First Victory
description: Michael Clark became the sixth first-time winner on the PGA Tour this season when he rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt on the fourth playoff hole yesterday to defeat the veteran Kirk Triplett in the rain-delayed completion of the John Deere Classic in Silvis, Ill.

title: No Decisions, No Drama
description: Ronald Reagan used to preach what he called the 11th commandment: Speak no evil of other Republicans.

title: Excerpts From Laura Bush's Speech to the G.O.P. Convention
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by Laura Bush to the Republican National Convention last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Questions to Help Choose a Surgeon
description: For would-be Lasik patients, there is unfortunately no way to compare the results of different surgeons. The gushing testimonial of a friend may be misleading: Lasik's results are so good that the majority of patients of any surgeon will be happy with the outcome.

title: Resurrecting The Tale That Inspired and Sank Melville
description: In the early 1840's, as a whaling seaman not yet embarked on his prodigious literary career, Herman Melville read Owen Chase's ''Narrative of the Most Extraordinary and Distressing Shipwreck of the Whale-Ship Essex.'' Later he wrote in his own copy of the ''Narrative'': ''The reading of this wondrous story upon the landless sea, & close to the very latitude of the shipwreck had a surprising effect on me.''

title: Chavez Fails to Get Mandate for Absolute Power in Venezuela
description: With final results of the ''mega-election'' here on Sunday tabulated today, President Hugo Chavez has won an overwhelming personal victory, but his coattails were apparently not quite long enough to pull into Congress the followers needed to guarantee him absolute powers.

title: DE BEERS SEEKS INDUSTRIAL DIAMONDS
description: Moving beyond its historical dominance of vanity diamonds, De Beers, the South African mining company, made an unsolicited $306 million offer to buy Ashton Mining Ltd., the Australian company that is the world's largest supplier of industrial-use diamonds. The bid is the third takeover attempt of another diamond business this year by De Beers, which is facing increased competition and is trying to reposition itself in the industry. After years of managing stockpiles and controlling prices by purchasing surpluses, the company has been moving to acquire diamond sources. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOW, JOAN MARIE
description: SNOW-Joan Marie (nee McPadden). Joan died July 29, 2000 after a brave battle with cancer. She will always be remembered for her vibrance and her dedication to educating children. Beloved wife of the late James Gerard and loving mother of James, Martin, Mary Catherine, John, and daughter-in-law, Paula. Dedicated sister of Brian McPadden and cousin, Patricia Monteforte. Funeral Wednesday, 8:30 AM from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. Funeral Mass, 10 AM, St James Cathedral-Basilica. Interment St Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. The family respectfully requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made to charity. Some preferences: Calvary Hospital, Catholic Near East Welfare Assn, or the South Bronx Educational Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARNES, SIDMORE
description: PARNES-Sidmore You will always be remembered and always loved. Davi

title: U.S. to Field A Dream Team
description: Lindsay Davenport, Monica Seles and Venus and Serena Williams were named by the United States Tennis Association yesterday to the American women's team for the Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Meat-Eating 'Vegetarians'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Assignments For 3 Executives
description: Top executives are being named to assignments at three agencies.

title: Fibromyalgia: Real Illness, Real Answers
description: ''Is it a real disease?'' is the most frequently asked question about fibromyalgia, an ailment characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain. The cynical tone that usually accompanies the question suggests that many think this syndrome is all in a person's head, the result, perhaps, of an emotional disorder or an attempt to avoid the demands of work and life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SAMUEL
description: WEINBERG-Samuel. Of Dobbs Ferry, died on July 30th. Retired publisher for H.B.J. Publishing. Survived by his loving wife Muriel, and devoted children Beth Rose of Boston, MA., and Adam Weinberg of Dobbs Ferry. Service 12 noon today Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. Dobbs Ferry (exit 17 Saw Mill Parkway).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, HELEN FRANCES
description: GRAHAM-Helen Frances. On July 29, 2000. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Arthur V. Beloved mother of Maryjane, Arthur V., Jr and Angela, James and Sue, John and Leslie. Cherished grandmother of Deborah, Arthur III and Allison, MaryEllen, James Jr., and Rosa, Paul and Wendy, Joseph, John and Delfina, Edward. Dear great grandmother of Timothy. Funeral Wednesday, 9:15 AM from Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Mass St. Edmund's R.C. Church, 10:15 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting hours from 2-5 and 7-10 PM today.

title: Sitar Meets Steel Pan, Naturally
description: The Indo-Caribbeans of Trinidad, descendants of indentured workers brought from India from 1838 to 1917, have had a fairly occluded history; even those who don't speak Hindi have to a great degree maintained and protected their own Indian culture within the island. Fusions between the two cultures have been slow and subtle. So Mungal Patasar's band Pantar, which played at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Friday night, was an example of rather proactive world-musicking -- a will imposed on two cultures to grow closer.

title: Pearson Makes Bid for National Computer
description: Pearson P.L.C., which has been on an acquisition tear over the last two years, said yesterday that it was buying National Computer Systems Inc. for $2.5 billion in cash.

title: FRENCH RAIL SUPPLIER ISSUES WARNING
description: Alstom S.A. shares fell 15 percent after the world's biggest maker of rail equipment warned that ''technical problems'' would delay the introduction of some new heavy-duty gas turbines and could hurt earnings. The shares shed 4.64 euros, to 26.46, the biggest decline on France's benchmark CAC 40 index. The drop is the steepest in Alstom's two-year history as a publicly traded company. The delay could cause ''significant additional costs'' and weigh down Alstom's energy unit, the company said. The problems affect as many as 80 turbines and some customers may have to be compensated, said Nick Salmon, executive vice president of ABB Alstom Power, the company's power unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, WILLIAM
description: MAXWELL-William. Died on July 31, 00. Beloved husband of Emily, father of Kate and Brookie, grandfather of Ellis, brother of Blinn. Kate and Brookie will announce a memorial celebration of their parents' lives.

title: How Taxes Trickle Down
description: It's common for leaders of the Democratic Party to claim that Republican tax cut proposals ''favor the rich,'' but this shows a lack of understanding of the true consequences of today's high tax rates. When Republican leaders fail to challenge this claim, they implicitly endorse the assumption that high-income individuals currently bear the entire burden of high tax rates.

title: A Push for Security Gates That Invite Window Shopping
description: One does not find them on Savile Row or the Faubourg St.-Honore. They do not clang down at night along Rodeo Drive or Madison Avenue. And while 34th Street in Manhattan is hardly one of the world's grand window-shopping destinations, if some had their way, solid metal security gates would be just as unthinkable there.

title: First Lady Says G.O.P.'s 'Show' Is Concealing Its Extremism
description: As the Republican convention opened yesterday with appeals to a broad range of voters, Hillary Rodham Clinton warned voters not to be deceived by a what she described as a ''well-scripted show'' intended to conceal the party's extremist record.

title: NEW NUMBER FOR AD INFO
description: In another example of how marketers are capitalizing on new technology to deliver sales pitches, a company is developing a method for users of wireless telephones to be connected to advertisers without dialing an ''800'' number. The company, ewireless, of Highland Park, Ill., plans to introduce today in metropolitan Chicago a service named #333 with participating advertisers that include Chase Manhattan, Dell and FedEx. Radio commercials and billboards will direct drivers with wireless phones to dial #333; those who do will be connected to call centers to obtain information on the products and services sold by the advertisers. Dean Becker, chief executive at ewireless, said the calls would be free for the callers, and that the service would be expanded to other cities, including Boston and New York, by early next year. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: When in Doubt, Punt; Better Yet, Call Meggett
description: Their heads shook at the memories, and the curses were interspersed with rueful laughter. David Meggett fumbled three punts in the first preseason game of his career and let another one bounce into him before the opposing team recovered it.

title: Midwest Industry Pace Slows As Raw Materials Prices Rise
description: Manufacturing in the Midwest grew in July at the slowest pace in 18 months while more companies paid higher prices for raw materials, an industry survey showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAUGHTON, JOSEPHINE
description: NAUGHTON-Josephine. On July 29, 2000. Cherished wife of James Patrick, adored mother of Delia, Grace, James John and his wife Jeanette, proud ''Nonna'' of Matthew and Brian. Reposing at Conway Funeral Home, Northern Bouleavard at 83 St, Jackson Heights, N.Y.Monday and Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, August 2, 2000 at St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, at 82 St & 35th Ave, Jackson Heights. N.Y.

title: Pact Is Reached to Save a Rich Tropical Forest
description: Ending a conflict over the fate of a forest rich in both wood and wildlife, loggers, biologists and the government of Gabon have agreed to keep bulldozers and chain saws out of a 1,900-square-mile reserve with the highest density of large mammals ever recorded in a tropical rain forest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Residential Real Estate column on Friday about groups that manage condominium and co-op board elections misstated an incentive used by one group, the Honest Ballot Association, to encourage participation. Residents who vote early are entered in a lottery for a free maintenance payment; they do not all receive the free month.

title: CONVENTION SUMMARY
description: CONGRESSIONAL RACES GET SHORT SHRIFT

title: Excerpts From Talks by 3 Women at Convention
description: Following are excerpts from remarks delivered last night at the Republican National Convention by Conna Craig, Elaine L. Chao and Sharon Darling as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Gore Is Reportedly Narrowing Choices
description: Vice President Al Gore's list of running mate possibilities seems to be shrinking, based on playful sign language from his wife today during a beach stroll in North Carolina. As Mr. Gore, his wife, Tipper, and their daughters Karenna and Sarah walked along the surf on Figure Eight Island for a photo opportunity, reporters asked whether Mr. Gore had narrowed the field and how his convention speech was coming.

title: INSIDE
description: Renowned Editor Dies

title: Familiar Faces Ease Cheney Into His Role as a Candidate
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican choice for vice president, kept it short, sweet and subdued for a second day today in what is becoming his hallmark at the party's national convention.

title: When Politics Is a Family Affair
description: To the Editor:

title: Even More Mired Than Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: The Use of Pesticides
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: CONSEQUENCES; Clues to Ecstasy's Effects on Addicts
description: An autopsy of the brain of a chronic abuser of the drug ecstasy suggests that it may work by causing violent fluctuations in the brain chemical serotonin, according to a report last week in Neurology.

title: Israel's Fractious Parliament
description: In a series of votes yesterday, Israel's parliament made clear its uneasiness over peace talks with the Palestinians. But at the end of the day, Prime Minister Ehud Barak remains in office with a chance to revive the compromises discussed at the failed Camp David summit meetings if the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, shows more flexibility on Jerusalem. Polls show that Israeli voters are far more willing than their elected representatives to support reasonable compromises as the price of a durable peace.

title: A popular event disappears and Madison Avenue seems to be wondering: is the party over?
description: JUST as the curiosity of Sherlock Holmes was piqued by the dog that did not bark, Madison Avenue is wondering about the party that is not being thrown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSLOW, RUSTY
description: MOSLOW-Rusty (Myra). Died July 30, at age 60. Adoring daughter of the late Jennie and Philip Gessman. Loving sister of Louise Lopez. Beloved wife of Morton Moslow. Devoted mother of Deborah and Philip Solomon. She died as she always was a woman of courage, strength and valor.

title: Miller Debut: Funny Flashes With Some Mundane Asides
description: In the first half of his first game on ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' Dennis Miller twice remarked how much faster on-field action looked from the announcers' booth. The comedian sounded overwhelmed, if not mentally spent.

title: In the News Today: Wry Observations and Snide Remarks
description: When George W. Bush announced that Dick Cheney would be his running mate, Jon Stewart drily observed:

title: At Charter School, It's Summer Minus the Vacation
description: The assignment for Erikka Richardson's third-grade class was to write an essay on what the pupils did during their summer vacation. And the one thing that Ms. Richardson could be sure of was that the essays would be short.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RAYMOND K.
description: MARTIN-Raymond K., Sr. Of Briarcliff Manor, New York. On July 29, 2000, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Margery. Father of Raymond K. Martin, Jr. & Thomas O. Martin. Grandfather of Raymond K. Martin III, Philip T. Martin and Raymonda P. Martin. Member of Dutch Treat Club, Photographic Administrators, Inc., N.Y. Press Photographers Association. Services will be held at the Briarcliff Congregational Church, 30 South State Rd, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2 PM.

title: Disability Ruling Limits Nets' Maneuverability
description: The Nets had hoped to have deeper pockets entering today's free-agency signing period. Instead, they have been reduced to counting their loose change.

title: Political Survival, With a Slap in the Face
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak survived a parliamentary no-confidence vote mounted by opponents of his peace efforts today, but his heavily favored candidate for Israel's president, Shimon Peres, suffered a stunning defeat in the twilight of a long career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIEVES, MARION
description: KIEVES-Marion. We mourn the loss of our co-worker and dear friend. May the memory of her caring for others bring comfort to her family and friends. She will always be our very special diamond that will shine forever. We love you and miss you. Underneath It All

title: In Death-Defying Act, Butterfly Thrives on Poison Vine
description: The rap sheet could scarcely be more shocking. Poisoning with cyanide. Cannibalism. Molestation of minors. But wait, there are extenuating circumstances. The perpetrator is highly intelligent, with a brain more than twice as large as normal. He is remarkably elegant, if that's an excuse. He leads an unusually industrious life. And he is not a party to this society's moral code, being but a butterfly with perhaps one of his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, LUCILLE
description: SANDS-Lucille, nee Pollane. Widow of Manny, loving mother of Patricia and Jeffrey, beloved mother-in-law of Rita, adored grandmother of Jessica & Hillary, passed quietly on July 31, 2000. Life member of Hadassah and past regional vice president. A founding member of Bellerose Jewish Center and past president of its PTA. Her gift for seeing joy in all things will always be remembered and treasured. She was a woman of valor.

title: Time Warner to Let Internet Provider Use Cable System
description: Time Warner Inc. has made its first deal to allow an independent Internet service provider access to its cable system, a move that was made as the company seeks to be granted regulatory approval for its planned $121 billion acquisition by America Online Inc.

title: Senior Chinese Official Sentenced to Death in Corruption Case
description: China today sentenced a former central government official to death for taking almost $5 million in bribes, the highest-profile case yet in the country's marathon anticorruption drive.

title: Energy's New Grid; In Deregulation, Electricity Buyers Find It Harder To Connect the Dots
description: Last summer, an accident at a local utility curtailed power to Owens Corning's plant in Kansas City, Kan., sending it scrambling to find alternative energy. It was a costly, nerve-racking experience.

title: Egos in a Dream House 'Without Ego'
description: A PLACE IN THE COUNTRY

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Expressing a Wish For a Settlement

title: On Fashion's Catwalks: Milan, 7th Ave., Brazil(?)
description: When the gurus of high fashion came here from all over the world a few weeks ago for a peek at MorumbiFashion, Brazil's biggest and most prestigious fashion show, they were wondering if this was the industry's next international capital.

title: Replacing Mary Fisher, And Pushing Abstinence
description: The Mary Fisher speech had become a fixture at Republican conventions. She spoke passionately in 1992 and 1996 about living with H.I.V., and offered to do a repeat performance in Philadelphia. The response from the Bush campaign was, well, no direct response.

title: A Contagion's Bite Has Its Limits
description: The West Nile virus has now taken over the No. 1 spot in the unofficial list of infectious threats from far-off places. The Hong Kong flu held the position three years ago and the Ebola virus three years before that. As before, the driving force is fear, and observers are enmeshed in controversy over what action to take.

title: EARNINGS SOAR AT CHIP MAKER
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest build-to-order chip maker, reported second-quarter net income of 13.35 billion new Taiwan dollars ($429.75 million) on sales of 31.81 billion new Taiwan dollars. The company said sales in the first half of this year rose 118 percent from a year earlier, to a record 64.9 billion new Taiwan dollars ($2.1 billion). The company said net income surged 133 percent in the first half from a year earlier. (Bloomberg News)

title: Tree-Killing Asian Beetle Spreads to New Area of Queens
description: For the second time this summer, the Asian long-horned beetle has been found in an area previously thought to be uninfested, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday. The beetle, which has destroyed nearly 3,000 city trees, was discovered last week in the Queens Zoo in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Accounts
description: Sizzler International, Culver City, Calif., to Glass McClure Advertising, Sacramento, Calif., to handle the account of the restaurant chain, which had been at Evans, Hardy & Young, Santa Barbara, Calif. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: A New Alternative to Tonsillectomies: Shrink, Don't Cut
description: It is no longer routine, as it was in the 1950's, for children to have their tonsils removed to prevent persistent infections. But for the estimated 500,000 Americans who still do undergo tonsillectomies each year, one thing has not changed: the procedure is a painful one that leaves people with difficulty swallowing for up to two weeks.

title: I Can See the Eye Chart Now, and Even the Letters!
description: Surgery that would let me give up my glasses forever had always sounded too good to be true, like one of those ads promising that you can earn $10,000 a month by sitting around the house doing nothing. I had been discussing it with my eye doctor for years, and for years, the doctor had told me the technology was not yet advanced enough.

title: FIRST UNION SELLS BRANCHES IN TENNESSEE TO FIRSTAR
description: The First Union Corporation, the sixth-largest United States bank, which is struggling to stop falling profit, said it was exiting Tennessee by selling its branches, with $1.7 billion, in deposits to the Firstar Corporation of Milwaukee. Terms were not disclosed. The Charlotte-based First Union is selling all of its 41 branches in Tennessee, including $474 million of loans after it announced a revamping in June to shed less-profitable units. First Union has only about 3 percent of the state's deposits. First Union's 450 employees in Tennessee will become Firstar employees when the purchase is completed in the fourth quarter. Firstar has about $74 billion in assets and about 1,200 branches in Ohio, Wisconsin, Missouri, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Minnesota, Tennessee, Arkansas, Kansas, Arizona and Florida.

title: Diamonds Are Forever Fueling Civil Wars
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: USFREIGHTWAYS UNIT TO ACQUIRE LOGISTICS COMPANY
description: The USF Worldwide Logistics unit of the USFreightways Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Ultimex Global Logistics P.L.C., a British transportation and logistics company, to expand its operations in Britain. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Chicago-based USFreightways, a provider of transportation services, reported $2.4 billion of revenue for the last 12 months. The privately held Ultimex Global has about $20 million in annual sales. It will be renamed USF Worldwide Logistics U.K., a USFreightways spokesman said.

title: Even the Sky Is No Limit For the Giants' Maynard
description: Often, Brad Maynard is not seen at Giants training camp as much as he is heard.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, BEATRICE
description: DAVIS-Beatrice, 96, devoted wife of the late Sam, beloved mother of Malcolm and Ilene, George, Theodore and Cindee, adored grandmother & loving greatgrandmother, sister of Edith Epstein. Bea was a wonderful and giving ing mother and person. She was full of fun, an active Red Cross volunteer during World War II at St. Albans and North Shore Veterans Hospitals. Active in UJA, Hadassah, Zionist Organization and Hebrew Institute of Israel. Her memory will live in our hearts forever. Services Thursday, August 3, 12:45 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam.

title: HENRY SCHEIN TO TAKE A CHARGE AND CUT 300 JOBS
description: Henry Schein Inc., which last year warned of slowing growth in its dental-equipment business, said yesterday that it would eliminate 300 jobs in a revamping aimed at increasing profitability. The job cuts represent about 5 percent of Henry Schein's total work force and will be taken at all levels. The company, the largest supplier of dental and medical equipment in the United States and Europe, expects to complete the realignment by the end of the year. Henry Schein will take a charge of $8.4 million, or 20 cents a share, in the second half to cover severance pay, plant closings and outside fees. Shares of the company, based in Melville, N.Y., rose $2.6875, to $16.75 yesterday.

title: A Word or Two for the Egg-Wise
description: WHENEVER the subject of raw eggs comes up, questions come flowing in. Although the government says no one should eat raw eggs, public health advice must be ''one size fits all,'' and the risk is not the same for everyone.

title: South Korean Figures Show Conglomerates Still Deep in Debt
description: It has been nearly three years since the South Korean government ordered the nation's largest business conglomerates to reduce their staggering debts. But official statistics released today showed that the debt levels of most of the conglomerates remained significantly higher than what the government considers acceptable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RAYMOND K., SR.
description: MARTIN-Raymond K., Sr. Of Briarcliff Manor, New York. On July 29, 2000, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Margery. Father of Raymond K. Martin, Jr. & Thomas O. Martin. Grandfather of Raymond K. Martin III, Philip T. Martin and Raymonda P. Martin. Member of Dutch Treat Club, Photographic Administrators, Inc., N.Y. Press Photographers Association. Services will be held at the Briarcliff Congregational Church, 30 South State Rd, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A map of Burundi and neighboring African countries in the World Briefing column yesterday, with a report about the killing of 53 villagers, omitted Lake Victoria. The lake straddles the borders of Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, GORDON WATKINS, M.D.
description: DOUGLAS-Gordon Watkins, M.D. Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York University School of Medicine, and Director of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Bellevue Hospital, 1956-1986, founding member of The Bellevue Obstetrical and Gynecological Society. A superb surgeon, teacher, researcher and true innovator and pioneer in the field of women's health care. A compassionate and caring physician who was fiercely loyal to his staff and to Bellevue Hospital. So many owe so much to him. His passing marks the end of an era. We express our condolences to his family. Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, New York University School of Medicine The Bellevue Obstetrical and Gynecological Society

title: Max Showalter, 83, Character Actor for Films, Broadway and TV
description: Max Showalter, a prolific character actor in movies and theater and on television, died on Sunday in Middletown, Conn. He was 83 and lived in Chester, Conn.

title: Turning Grilled Flavors Inside Out
description: WHEN it comes to grilling, Americans achieve flavor through a free-handed use of rubs, pastes and marinades. Asians take a more internal approach. They grill their kebabs on skewers made of flavorful grasses and herbs.

title: Miller and 'Monday' Lag Early in Game
description: If ABC wanted to generate a buzz by bringing Dennis Miller to ''Monday Night Football,'' it got it.

title: Giuliani Says He Is Being Treated With Hormones for Prostate Cancer
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani acknowledged for the first time tonight that he has been undergoing hormone treatments for his prostate cancer for two and a half months. He seemed to indicate that the hormones were a preliminary therapy and added that he would make a final decision about his treatment within a few weeks.

title: Record Companies Explore Online Music Subscriptions
description: In a potentially fundamental change to the way music has been packaged, at least three major record labels plan to begin selling songs over the Internet in a subscription format by the end of the year, enabling users to listen to or download a range of tracks for a flat fee.

title: Guiliani Is Model Republican at His First National Convention
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani behaved like a good Republican today as he went to a fund-raiser for Representative Rick A. Lazio, held a joint news conference with Mr. Lazio and gave interviews to two networks -- all while attending his first national political convention.

title: Prescription Drug Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckonings; Man Without a Plan
description: Sometimes you just have to concede defeat. I read the Republican platform carefully, hoping to find some substance -- say, in the section on retirement security. But there is no there there.

title: Charm Might Not Be Enough
description: Across the country, municipalities are building baseball stadiums, both for major and minor league teams, that attempt to recapture the charm and nostalgia of old-fashioned parks. Camden Yards in Baltimore and Riverfront Stadium in Newark are two examples. For a taste of authentic charm, baseball fans can look to Wahconah Park in Pittsfield, Mass.

title: Advice to G.O.P.: Veer to the Center; A Chance for Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: A Parade That's a Tradition
description: You might mistake the Republican convention for an ethnic festival or a forum on women's rights,'' The New York Times said in a news story that seems to capture the scene in Philadelphia this week. Except this dispatch, reported by Maureen Dowd, didn't come from the convention that is nominating George W. Bush, but the one that nominated his father 12 years ago.

title: Ex-Manager Urges Coke's Black Workers to Hire Lawyers
description: A former Coca-Cola benefits manager who has criticized the company's treatment of black workers said yesterday that he would urge those workers to retain lawyers to help them determine whether they should accept a settlement reached in June between Coke and four black employees who sued the company or file their own suits.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: What a Dinner Could Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHMAN, PAULINE FRANCES
description: RICHMAN-Pauline Frances, February 29, 1905-August 2, 1999. ''Mom''/''Paula'' -Remembered today and every day with love. You are in our hearts forever

title: Metro Business; New York State Fines Insurer $500,000
description: A company that operates two large health insurance plans in upstate New York has been fined $500,000 for violations that included deleting thousands of valid claims from its computer system and systematically underpaying claims in one category, the State Insurance Department said yesterday.

title: CADBURY SCHWEPPES BUYS SOUTHERN TEXAS BOTTLER
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that the Dr Pepper/Seven Up Bottling Group, its United States unit, bought the Grant-Lydick BeveragesCompany, a southern Texas bottler, for an undisclosed sum. Grant-Lydick is the largest distributor of Big Red soft drinks in the United States and the ninth-largest distributor of 7Up soda. The company's net sales in 1999 were about $79 million.

title: Unexcited Viewers See Grand Old Packaging
description: Some faithful Republican homes here glow with the blue light of faithful Republican television-watching these convention nights. But no one could say that even the most stalwart of stalwarts are sitting on the edges of their leather couches. Perfect scripting, it seems, comes with a price: lukewarm attention, and minimal effect.

title: Democrats Join With Allies In Piling on Bush's Record
description: Accusing the Republican Party of using its convention to mask Gov. George W. Bush's stands on controversial issues, Democrats and groups with close ties to them are unleashing commercials that criticize his record in Texas as well as his positions on gun control and abortion.

title: Supporting Cast
description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: Rice's Comments on Bush: 'Uncommonly Good Judgment'
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks delivered last night at the Republican National Convention by Condoleezza Rice, Governor George W. Bush's foreign policy adviser, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PROFIT RISES AT SCOTTISH BANK
description: Royal Bank of Scotland, which recently acquired National Westminster Bank, said that profits during the first half of the year had increased 11 percent and that the expected savings from the acquisition were being realized. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: The Networks' Tricky Business of Covering the Scripted Emptiness
description: The broadcast networks have not given the Republican National Convention one minute more than they have to, and they are absolutely right. The most telling television image, after all, has been that of Peter Jennings against a blank blue screen. As he has several times during ABC's coverage, last night Mr. Jennings gave audiences full disclosure that whenever he looks as if he is in a sky box, he is really in a small room on the convention floor, projected against video of the crowd outside the room.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I understand why people look at us in this way. But it doesn't say on our foreheads, 'Serb,' and 'Croat.' ''

title: Abe Hirschfeld Gets 1 to 3 Years In Plot to Kill Longtime Partner
description: Abe Hirschfeld, the flamboyant parking garage developer, has never been one to go quietly. Nor did he yesterday when a Manhattan judge sentenced him to one to three years in prison for plotting to kill his business partner.

title: Bristol-Myers Diabetes Pill Is Approved
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company won Food and Drug Administration approval for a new diabetes pill that combines two older diabetes medications, the agency said.

title: Quarterly Profit Falls 22% at Perot Systems
description: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer services company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, said its second-quarter profit fell 22 percent because of lower revenue from two of the company's biggest contracts.

title: Prescription Drug Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Informix Corp., Menlo Park, Calif., which offers software infrastructure services for the Internet, to the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, to handle its account, which had been inactive. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Campaigns' Strategies: Negative vs. Negative
description: For all its focus on a nicer, blander image, there is one thing the Bush campaign wants to be negative about -- negative campaigning from the other side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, STEVEN
description: GROSS-Steven. The Board of Director, Volunteers and Staff of the American Heart Association mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague. Through his fervent commitment, creative spirit and generosity, Mr. Gross and his family have enhanced the fight against heart disease and stroke. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Janice and members of the Gross family. Morgan B. Stark, Chairman Charles A. Dennis, MD, President Michael L. Weamer, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, GEORGE
description: HARRIS-George. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of George Harris, beloved father of Joan Cooper. We extend our deepest condolences to Joan and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: ONYX SHARES RISE ON GENE THERAPY TREATMENT
description: Shares of Onyx Pharmaceuticals Inc. rose as much as 37 percent yesterday after the company's experimental gene therapy treatment appeared to shrink tumor growth in a small study of patients with head and neck cancer. Onyx shares rose $4.06, to $14.9375. The findings, published in Monday's issue of Nature Medicine, come from the second of three phases of study required by the Food and Drug Administration for new drugs. The drug appeared to enhance the effects of chemotherapy, and helped shrink tumors by at least half in 63 percent of the cases evaluated in the study, according to an international team of researchers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Justice Department report on the Immigration Service's 1996 citizenship program referred incorrectly in some copies to the cases of immigrants with criminal convictions. Four such immigrants -- not 140 -- have lost their citizenship. The service says it has sent 140 cases -- out of 600 known -- to the Justice Department; the rest of the 140 are pending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGLIN, SHERLEE S.
description: SEGLIN-Sherlee S., 86. Died July 31, 2000 in Harrisburg, PA. A volunteer for the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, Manhattan, she is survived by a daughter, Donna L. Popky of Harrisburg; and sisters Ruth Hyman of Manhattan and Janet Bank of Miami & a grandson. Graveside services will be at 2:00PM Wednesday in Acacia Cemetery, Queens. Memorials may be made to the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, 120 West 106th Street, New York, New York 10024.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: An online ad-server hopes to stimulate its growth with $57 million from investors.
description: A COMPANY in a crowded market for online advertising services is hoping to help accelerate its growth with investments totaling $57 million from sources that include major agency and media companies like the WPP Group, the Reuters Group and America Online.

title: Jets' Green Optimistic He'll Make An Impact
description: Progress is measured in very small increments for Yatil Green these days. Make a cut without feeling a knee collapse. Get through another set of double practices without disaster. Make a catch that might finally garner some notice.

title: Faltering Steps Of a New Sitcom
description: Michael Richards, who played Kramer on ''Seinfeld,'' has not had an easy time producing his new sitcom. Called ''The Michael Richards Show,'' the comedy is about a bumbling private detective, played by Mr. Richards. It will make its debut on NBC this fall.

title: Roger Batzel, Nuclear Chemist And Livermore Lab Director, 78
description: Dr. Roger E. Batzel, a nuclear chemist and former director of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, died on Saturday at a hospital in San Ramon, Calif. He was 78 and had homes in Danville and Mount Shasta, Calif.

title: Layden Works Another Shift at the Ewing Rumor Mill
description: The annual Patrick Could Be Traded scuttlebutt is making the rounds, especially with the litany of high-profile players changing teams this summer. But Scott Layden, the Knicks' general manager, reiterated yesterday what the franchise has felt all along: If Ewing goes, the Knicks go downhill.

title: Finding Buried Treasure, Random House Plans Archive for Literary Legacies
description: When the nation's largest publisher, Random House, took up new temporary quarters in Manhattan this summer, it suddenly became clear how random is its system for preserving a rich literary legacy that embraces authors from William Faulkner to Toni Morrison.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Rewiring Roosevelt Field For Retailer Alert System
description: Retailers at Roosevelt Field mall in Garden City, N.Y., used to be in a bind whenever they detected a shoplifter or someone writing bad checks: The only way they could alert one another was through a telephone system that would automatically relay a recorded message from one store's telephone to another.

title: Study Disputes Success of the Brady Law
description: There is no evidence that the Brady law requiring background checks of handgun buyers contributed to a reduction in homicide rates after it went into effect in 1994, according to a study published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: The Price of Electricity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAKAUER, LEONARD
description: KRAKAUER-Leonard. Husband of Olga. Beloved father of Gary and Heidi Krakauer and Charline and Michael Fredericksen. Cherished grandfather of Kiera, Mariel and Rachel. Loving brother of Dr. William. Also survived by Olga's son, Peter Benzaia. May his memory be for a blessing. Services Friday, 2 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Thailand Rubber Industry to Destroy Trees
description: Thailand, the world's top producer of natural rubber, plans to destroy more than 2 percent of its rubber trees annually as efforts at stockpiling have failed to bolster prices from near 30-year lows, officials said.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON ALZHEIMER'S DRUG NEARS APPROVAL
description: Johnson & Johnson's treatment for Alzheimer's disease, Reminyl, is close to Food and Drug Administration approval, the agency said, bringing the company a step nearer to selling the drug in the United States. Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had received a so-called approvable letter from the F.D.A. The letters spell out final issues to be resolved before the agency will allow a drug to be marketed; such issues often involve product labeling. A study financed by Johnson & Johnson found that the drug, which has the chemical name of galantamine hydrobromide, improves all three types of disabilities that Alzheimer's patients commonly suffer.

title: Bush Concentrates on Clinton, but Keeps an Eye on Gore
description: After four days of subtle digs at President Clinton, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas took him on directly today and said the president was ''so desperate to have his legacy intact by getting Al Gore elected, he'll say anything.''

title: SOUTH KOREAN TRADE SURPLUS FALLS
description: South Korea's trade surplus fell by almost two-thirds in July as export shipments slowed for the summer holiday and rising oil prices increased the import bill. The trade surplus shrank 62 percent from a month earlier and 58 percent on the year, to $823 million, the Ministry of Commerce, Industry and Energy said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, MARTIN S.
description: ACKERMAN-Martin S. 8/2/93. Time does not heal our broken hearts; it only intensifies the magnitude of our loss. Always, Diane and Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, SUSIE
description: CHEN-Susie. July 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lin Chen, Chairman of Summit Import Corporation and President Kam Man Food Corporation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 81 Street, Friday, August 4th, 2 to 8PM. Service Saturday, August 5, at 10AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: ASIA PHONE DEAL COMPLETED
description: Hong Kong's flagship telephone company passed into the hands of a two-year-old Internet upstart, as a court approved the acquisition of Cable and Wireless HKT by Pacific Century Cyberworks. The decision, effective Aug. 17, ends a six-month tale that began when Pacific Century undertook a $38.1 billion bid for Cable and Wireless. The company's founder, Richard Li, left, said he would streamline the merged entity's eight divisions into three. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Pinochet Reportedly Stripped of Immunity in Secret Court Vote
description: The Chilean Supreme Court voted in secret today to strip Gen. Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity, according to local radio and web site accounts. The decision would remove the last legal obstacle to a full-scale criminal investigation of the former dictator and would permit his trial on charges of kidnapping, murder and torture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ARTHUR
description: SCHWARTZ-Arthur. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Arthur Schwartz. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Lucille, and their family. Richard Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: INGRAM MICRO PROFIT SLIDES
description: Ingram Micro Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell by more than a third as the big computer distributor made changes to its pricing system and the way it tracks inventory. Net income fell 34 percent to $33.2 million, or 22 cents a share, from $50.3 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 7.2 percent, to $7.3 billion from $6.8 billion. Ingram Micro is shifting its strategy as it recovers from several quarters of sluggish demand. Ingram Micro shares rose 62.5 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $18.75.

title: For Republicans, a Night to Bolster Bush
description: Senator John McCain shed his rebellious image to play the admiring party stalwart at the Republican National Convention tonight, commending Gov. George W. Bush to independents and Democrats and -- addressing one of the governor's most pronounced vulnerabilities -- saying he would ably defend the nation's interests abroad.

title: Times Company in Venture With Starbucks Coffee
description: The New York Times Company and the Starbucks Coffee Company said yesterday that they had agreed to the sale of The New York Times newspapers in Starbucks stores for three years in exchange for The Times's advertising promotion of Starbucks. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Backstabbing In a Hammy Way

title: THIRD WAVE TECHNOLOGIES FILES FOR INITIAL STOCK SALE
description: Third Wave Technologies Inc., a maker of products that analyze genes, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public stock sale. Third Wave sells the Invader operating system, a technology that detects genetic variations. Identifying such variations in individuals allows scientists to develop new drugs and better treat patients. Losses at the company, which says it is still developing its technology, widened to $9.2 million in 1999, from $5.4 million the year before. Third Wave, based in Madison, Wis., plans to use the proceeds from the offering for general corporate purposes, including working capital and research and development activities.

title: Rise in Customers and Prices Lifts Cigna's Profits by 11%
description: The Cigna Corporation, the nation's third-largest health insurer, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 11 percent, beating expectations, as it signed more customers, held costs down and raised premiums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, ABRAHAM
description: BLOCK-Abraham. Beloved husband of Beatrix. Loving father of Mark and Pamela, Maureen and Jonathan Katz. Dear brother of Seymour and Phyllis, Doreen and Sam Baron. Services 12:15PM, August 3, 2000 at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, G.O.P. Theme Is Like Old Times
description: The day after the Republican National Convention opened with a call to ''leave no child behind,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton marveled at how familiar it all seemed.

title: THE BOSS; A Team Father
description: My first wife, Jill, and I adopted 14 children between 1983 and 1993. We had been married 11 years and already had three birth children. At first, I resisted adopting; I couldn't fathom it. Jill was initially the driving force, but then I became the aggressor. I learned everything I could about adoption and threw myself into it.

title: The Laureate Distilled, to an Eau de Vie
description: ''I don't expect to be very kinetic,'' Stanley Kunitz said, with a dry little laugh. A reporter was asking Mr. Kunitz what he would be doing in his new appointment as the nation's 10th poet laureate, which was announced on Monday.

title: CHINA DEBT CONVERSION SAID TO ADVANCE
description: China's state-owned asset management institutions, created last year to assume the nonperforming loans burdening state banks, have signed debt-for-equity swap deals with 485 financially distressed enterprises as of July 25, the official news agency Xinhua reported. Under such deals, the asset management firms take the debt that the enterprises owe to state banks and convert it to equity, which the asset management firms hope to sell later. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Digital Music, Chapter 2
description: By coincidence, as a federal judge ruled last week that the Internet music file-sharing company Napster was operating in violation of copyright law, EMI Music Distribution was just putting its own commercial downloading program into action.

title: BANKING OFFICIAL REMOVED
description: Brazil's central bank removed the banking supervision director, Tereza Grossi, while prosecutors investigate her role in the bailout of two banks last year. Ms. Grossi is accused of overlooking potential illegalities surrounding the $900 million bailout of Banco Marka and FonteCindam. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Toys 'R' Us Loses Ruling
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the largest United States toy retailer, lost a court bid to overturn a Federal Trade Commission finding that it tried to prevent rival discounters from selling popular toys. The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit upheld the commission's finding that Toys ''R'' Us used its market influence to keep the top-selling toys away from discounters like Costco and the BJ's unit of Waban Inc. In September 1997, the commission prohibited Toys ''R'' Us from imposing restrictions on purchase contracts with toymakers.

title: Bosnian Woman, Describing War Ordeal, Faints in U.S. Court
description: A civil lawsuit against the former leader of the Bosnian Serbs began in a federal courtroom in Manhattan yesterday with a witness fainting on the stand as she described her captivity, rape and torture during the Balkans conflict in the summer and fall of 1992.

title: Israel's Leader Faces Turmoil on All Sides
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's political problems deepened today as his right-wing opponents, sensing blood with their stunning defeat of Shimon Peres, his presidential candidate, vowed new efforts to bring down his government.

title: ICANN CLOSES MEMBER DRIVE
description: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers said yesterday that 158,000 Internet users signed up during its first at-large membership registration period. The program is intended to give Internet users a voice in the nonprofit technical group's policy making structure for administering the Internet's domain name and numbering systems. ''Now the task is to find good candidates who will engage in constructive debate about Icann's activities and specific policies,'' Esther Dyson, chairwoman of the group, which is known as Icann, said. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: For 2000, the G.O.P. Sees Education in a New Light
description: Seated in a mock classroom in front of the stage, 20 children banged out a beat on their desks, chanted multiplication tables and rapped, ''Read, baby, read.''

title: Convention Summary
description: McCAIN OFFERS WORDS OF ASSURANCE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELMAN, DOUGLAS EDMUND
description: FOGELMAN-Douglas Edmund. Died on July 30th, 2000 at Huntington Hospital, NY after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born in Huntington Hospital on March 21st, 1960. Douglas was the beloved son of Suzanne and Prof. Martin Fogelman, cherished brother of Henry, Jeffrey and Martin, Jr. and sister-in-law Patricia, loving uncle of Kimberly, Ann and Martin III. Services 2 PM, Wednesday, August 2nd, Temple Beth-El of Huntington, 600 Park Ave., Huntington. Interment Mt. Golda Cemetery, Huntington Station, New York. Dr. Fogelman was dearly beloved by all who knew him. Donations to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: Not Your Mother's Mayonnaise: A Great French Sauce for Summer
description: IT was 1993, and I had my first kitchen job, at a restaurant in Boston. I listened in as the sous-chef and a cook bent over a blender, the sous-chef slowly giving instructions. With the machine whirring, egg yolks were dropped in. Then oil, in an erratic, drippy stream. A sunny yellow sauce rapidly formed. I asked what it was.

title: Three Biggest Real Estate Firms To Combine Listings on Internet
description: For home buyers in New York City, buying property often means dealing with a confusing array of real estate agencies, jumping from broker to broker in an exhaustive search to find the perfect home at the right price.

title: EURO-ZONE JOBLESSNESS FALLS
description: As Europe's expanding economy encouraged businesses to hire more people, unemployment in the 11 countries that adopted the euro as a single currency last year dropped to 9.1 percent in June, its lowest level in almost eight years, from 9.2 percent in May. The group includes Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Austria, Ireland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Finland and Sweden. Among them, Spain had the highest unemployment, at 14.1 percent, while Luxembourg, with 2.2 percent, and Austria, with 3.3 percent, had the lowest unemployment rates. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Hampton a One-Man Highlight Reel as Mets Foil Reds
description: See Mike Hampton pitch. See Mike Hampton bat. See Mike Hampton field. See Mike Hampton sweat in the dugout before the Mets complete a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: P.& G. Reports Earnings in Line With Lowered Forecasts
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, troubled by rising costs, management turmoil and credibility problems on Wall Street, reported fourth-quarter results yesterday that were in line with lowered forecasts. The company also advised that earnings growth in the first half of its new fiscal year would be sluggish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREEN, GERARD (JERRY)
description: BREEN-Gerard (Jerry). On July 31, 2000, peacefully at home, surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Bonnie (Grisar) and loving and devoted father to his children Emelia Gabrielle & Dylan Gerard. Loving son of Marie V. Breen and the late Daniel J. Breen. Son-in-law of Ben & Vivian Grisar. Faithful and grateful brother of John (Jack), Daniel, Kevin, Tommy, Kim and Anne. He was loved by his nieces and nephews, Derek, Sean, Collin, Danny, Michael, Shannon, Kristen, Kevin, & Sammy Breen, Kathleen, Daniel and Stephen Reiser, Jenna and P.J. Grisar and Allison Mikuliwich. He is also survived by his aunts, Catherine Giltenan, Ann Murphy, Rose Malone, and uncle John Malone and many cousins. Gerard was a graduate of SUNY at Oneonta. He received his Juris Doctor degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1984 and his LLM from Pace University and was an attorney for the New York City Police Department. Jerry faced his illness and untimely death with the same courage that he had when he pursued his passion for rock climbing. His life has been an inspiration to all who had the privilege of knowing him. His memory will live in our hearts forver. Reposing at Weigand-Pensa Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave, Baldwin. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday at St. Christopher's R.C. Church, Baldwin, 10:30 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Orientation at the Top

title: After Session, Ford Is Taken to Hospital
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford was taken to a hospital around midnight Tuesday with a sinus infection, after leaving the Republican National Convention, where he had been honored in an emotional tribute.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell after a report showed manufacturing in the 11-nation currency region expanded at a slower pace in July than in June. In New York, the euro settled at 92.05 cents, down from 92.69 cents.

title: Torricelli Unified Democratic Leaders, but Against Himself
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli's move to seize the Democratic nomination for New Jersey governor began with a swaggering boast: He declared that he alone had the stature to force bickering Democratic factions to unify and prepare to retake control of the State House. And he said he could do it all in a matter of weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, TINA (NEE GORMAN)
description: FRIED-Tina (nee Gorman). On July 31, 2000, age 90. Wife of the late Henry B. Fried. Mother of Caryl and Skip Feldmann, and the late Robert Fried. Grandmother of Leslie (Jim) Cowen, Sara (Robert) Sheehan, Ahmiel (Coleen) Fried, and Zephania (Les) Eldred, great grandmother of Alex, and Madeline Cowen, Hanna, and Molly Sheehan, and Brittany, and Blaine Eldred. She taught us through example the meaning of unconditional love. Memorial to be announced.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY

title: Toys 'R' Us to Build the Biggest Store in Times Sq.
description: In an expensive bid to re-establish itself as the top retailer in its field, Toys ''R'' Us announced yesterday that it would open the world's largest toy store amid the tourist-choked streets and neon-infused ballyhoo of Times Square.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal; So That Tyrants Won't Rest, Haitians Keep a Vigil
description: Every Wednesday, a crowd gathers in the Plaza of Martyrs here for a ritual as unsparing and inescapable as the brutal midday sun. They circle a statue of a slender man releasing a dove to the heavens hoping that their pleas, too, will rise above the din and indifference.

title: Its Own Stock Battered, Softbank Abandons Spinoff Plan
description: The Softbank Corporation, one of the world's biggest investors in Internet start-up companies, abandoned a plan today to sell shares in five subsidiaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, FLORA
description: GORDON-Flora. On July 31, 2000. Wife of the late Benjamin Gordon, she will be remembered by her children, Ruth Panken & Stephen; grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and friends who valued her gentleness, vitality, and commitment to a more just world.

title: Livery Cabs Testing Silent Alarm System
description: In an effort to curb attacks against livery drivers, satellite tracking systems are being tested in 40 livery cabs, enabling drivers to summon the police with a silent alarm.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: In Place of Mortimer's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKWOOD, VERA
description: LOCKWOOD-Vera. The producers, cast and company of ''Over The River And Through The Woods'' mourn the passing of their friend and colleague, Vera Lockwood. She will be fondly remembered for her glowing portrayal of Aida Gianelli.

title: Public Offering By SpeechWorks
description: Shares of SpeechWorks International Inc., which makes software that lets people browse the Internet with a telephone, more than tripled after it raised $95 million, more than expected, in its initial public offering.

title: Fact and Fancy in Tequila
description: PERHAPS no drink is as rich in myth and ritual as tequila.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: A New Chance For New Music; Why the Philharmonic Needs a Young American
description: The New York Philharmonic's courtship of the conductor Riccardo Muti has ended, amicably, it appears, but with no success. It had been no secret that the orchestra was hoping to entice the perfectionist Italian maestro to take over the music director's post when Kurt Masur steps down in 2002. But Mr. Muti, who has a sure sense of his own desirability, was playing hard to get. He was essentially unwilling to scale back his European commitments, especially as the artistic generalissimo of La Scala.

title: B.A.T. PROFITS RISE
description: British American Tobacco P.L.C., manufacturer of brands that include Lucky Strike, Kent, Dunhill and Rothmans, said first-half pretax profits rose 6 percent, to $1.04 billion, as its global sales increased 23 percent, to 396 billion cigarettes. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: In New Drug Battle, Use of Ecstasy Among Young Soars
description: Even as casual drug use has dropped nationwide, some of the nation's most prominent drug experts warned today that the use of a psychedelic drug known as Ecstasy has risen sharply, particularly among young people, raising fears that a major new front has opened in the government's efforts to curb illegal drugs.

title: Concorde Investigators Establish Crash Events
description: PARIS  Accident investigators discussed last week's crash of an Air France Concorde for the second day on Tuesday, after establishing four virtual certainties about the disaster but without establishing any definitive link between the events that doomed the supersonic aircraft.

title: Corrections
description: The E-Commerce Report in Business Day on Monday about the migration of workers from Internet start-ups to more established companies misstated the Friday stock price for NBC Internet Inc. It closed at $9.75, not $22. (Yesterday's closing price was $11.25.)

title: A New Nuclear Reactor Sheds Only Some Light on Brazil
description: The southeastern region of Brazil felt a surge of nuclear power a few weeks ago. This was notable because the surge had been awaited for more than 20 years.

title: Blender? What's a Blender?
description: TOO often, cucumber soup is made with no more thought than ''Let's throw it in the blender with some yogurt and salt.'' To me, that's not soup but a kind of bizarre milkshake. A real cucumber soup has backbone.

title: Appointment System for Stricter Emissions Test Gets Mixed Ratings
description: Seventeen-year-old Brian Hogan had never had his car inspected before, so for him it was no big deal that there was no waiting line when he showed up for his 11 a.m. appointment at the state inspection station here.

title: Right Touch, and Top, for Espresso
description: NICHOLAS O'CONNELL worked like a surgeon, his movements small, precise. He reached for his tools, handled them like crystal and was so quiet he barely seemed to breathe. His task complete, he changed roles. He looked up, his suit still crisp, every blond hair on his head in place. His inner host emerged. And he handed me his masterpiece: a cappuccino.

title: INSIDE
description: Tobacco Industry Faulted

title: Cider With Soul
description: CALVADOS is fine, apple juice palatable. But fermented cider I have always thought was a bad idea: cloying, heavy and as much joy to drink as maple syrup.

title: U.S. IS PROPOSING NEW WAY TO FIGHT GLOBAL WARMING
description: Preparing for renewed international negotiations on cutting levels of heat-trapping gases that may be warming the climate, the United States is proposing that countries get just as much credit for using forests and farmers' fields to sop up carbon dioxide, the chief warming gas, as they would for cutting emissions from smokestacks and tail pipes.

title: Lazio Drops In on Philadelphia, Saying His Job Is in New York
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio stopped by his party's convention for a few brief hours today, seizing the chance to raise money for his Senate campaign and to rally supporters.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BROWN SHOE CO., St. Louis, operator of the Famous Footwear and Naturalizer shoe-retailing chains, said it bought the closely held Mil-Mar Shoe Co., Milwaukee, to add 26 shoe stores in Wisconsin, Illinois and Iowa. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Business Travel; Hal Rosenbluth has paid out plenty in refunds for delayed flights, but he isn't complaining.
description: DELAYED four hours in Boston. Flight canceled abruptly in Atlanta. Stuck overnight in Dallas. Left Sunday morning, got here Monday. Still waiting for the sales team to roll in from Chicago.

title: CALENDAR
description: Fair Shakes

title: I.O.C. Panel Clears Way For New Tests in Sydney
description: The medical commission of the International Olympic Committee yesterday approved the use of a combination of urine and blood tests to detect the use of the performance-enhancing drug EPO at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia.

title: THE CHEF; Michel Richard
description: SOME people might call my tomato terrine a tomato pudding, but it is more a salad, with very thin layers of highly seasoned tomato slices and bread. It's the perfect first course in summer.

title: ASTRAZENECA EARNINGS RISE
description: Europe's largest drug company, AstraZeneca P.L.C., said its first-quarter earnings rose 19 percent. Pretax profit jumped to $2.4 billion from $2 billion a year earlier. AstraZeneca shares rose 47 pence, to 2,923 pence. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Working Mosquito Surveillance, Rock Style
description: ZOWIE! Are those some kind of sunglasses on the city's ace mosquito tracker or what? Retro-style Cutler & Gross, with rhinestones, that her rock 'n' roll husband bought her in London. Plus Versace jeans. Plus anaconda flats, from Bally. Dr. Varuni Kulasekera will not be wearing those flats when she goes mosquito hunting, she'll change into ankle boots, but her outfit still raises the question: Why?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, AVIVA (NEE ISOBEL LEADER)
description: KIRSCH-Aviva (nee Isobel Leader). On July 30th, 2000. Loving mother of Beth, Gabrielle and her husband Jim. Beloved daughter of Ruby and the late Sidney Leader. Dear sister of Steven and Barbara Leader. Devoted aunt of Jaclyn and Allison. Service Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDINI, DOLORES (DEE) MONTANO
description: BANDINI-Dolores (Dee) Montano. On July 5, 2000. Memorial service Unitarian Church, Westport, CT., August 11 at 12 Noon. Information: 203-854-1775.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the sale of several large daily newspapers in Canada by the press baron Conrad Black to CanWest Global Communications misidentified one paper in the deal. It is The Edmonton Journal, not The Edmonton Sun.

title: Federal Meddling or Local Empowerment? Congress and Educators Disagree
description: August 2, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTISON, BERWYN F.
description: MATTISON-Berwyn F. Former Executive Director of The American Public Health Association, died July 30, 2000, in Glens Falls, New York at age 90.

title: Demonstrators Try to Steal Some Thunder At Convention
description: Scores of protesters were arrested in a running cat-and-mouse contest with the police across downtown thoroughfares today as they sought to disrupt the Republican National Convention with illegal hit-and-run demonstrations.

title: Bertha Holt, 96, a Leader In International Adoptions
description: Bertha Holt, whose family's struggle to adopt Korean orphans in the 1950's led to a movement that found American homes for thousands of children from overseas, died on Monday at her home in Creswell, Ore., after a stroke on July 24. She was 96.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow and S.& P. 500 Gain, But Nasdaq Slumps 2.2%

title: Heat Wave Nearly Causes Rolling Blackouts in California
description: A lingering heat wave throughout the West drove demand for electric power in California to near-record levels today and brought the state close to a full-scale power emergency. Such an emergency would have prompted rolling blackouts, in order for power administrators to keep the state's giant, overburdened electricity grid from crashing completely.

title: American Is Buying 9 Jets From Boeing
description: American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said today that it had ordered nine jetliners from the Boeing Company valued at as much as $1.14 billion to give it more planes that can fly international routes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, JAMES K.
description: O'NEILL-James K. On July 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Kathleen (nee Puccala). Loving son of Margaret & Thomas. Dear brother & best friend Patrick. Loving uncle of Megan Rose. Reposing at O'Shea-Hoey Funeral Home, Inc. 29-13 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria, N.Y. Wednesday & Thursday 2-5 & 79:30 P.M. Funeral Mass Immaculate Conception Church Friday 9:45 A.M. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Manhattan College/James K. O'Neill Scholarship fund, Att/Joe Valenti Manhattan College, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: New Twists on the Mideast Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWILDE, SUSAN
description: DeWILDE-Susan. To our sensational Susan, what will we do without you? We'll take you with us wherever we go until we're together again. Love, Fran, Janet, Maureen & Pat

title: Behind the 'M' And the 'W,' A New Style
description: TO Stephen Lyle, fixing up the bathrooms at his new restaurant, Village, was less a chore than an archaeological dig. The chef and his aides carefully stripped and chipped away layers of plaster and drywall to unearth the ancient subway tile, dating from the 1920's or 30's. The phone-booth-size marble stalls were so small they had to be expanded in the women's room. A tiny window in the men's room, looking down from the building's second story onto Ninth Street, had been boarded up. They restored it.

title: Editorial Observer; The Republican Party's Exercise in Minstrelsy
description: The African-Americans and Latinos being paraded across the stage at the Republican Convention are intended to give a hip, multicultural feel -- and dispel the pervasive notion that the G.O.P. is largely a party of, by and for white Americans. But subtract the minority props -- the break dancers and the gospel choir and the beaming schoolchildren -- and what you have is the same ultra-white party that shocked many Americans' sensibilities at the 1992 and 1996 conventions. The deluge of black and Latin faces on display in Philadelphia is deceptive, given that the party's delegates and senior managers are as white as they have ever been.

title: Bush's Confusing Message On His Plans for Education
description: GOV. GEORGE W. BUSH wants credit for improvements in education in Texas. But his message has been confusing.

title: World Business Briefing
description: August 2, 2000 World Business Briefings

title: Advice to G.O.P.: Veer to the Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPIETZKY, FANNY
description: KUPIETZKY-Fanny. The Yeshiva University family marks with sadness the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, wife of the late Rabbi Jacob H. Kupietzky, mother of Rabbi Jonah, a loyal YC and RIETS alumnus, who together with his wife Fran are YU Guardians and RIETS Fellows and who established the Rabbi Jacob H. Memorial Rabbinic Scholarship, RIETS Fellows and YU alumni Nachman (and Elke), Channy (and Dr. Abe) Greenberg, and Moishe (and Arlene) all of whom established the Keren Nachlas Yaakov Foundation Rabbinic Scholarship at RIETS for the study of Kodshim, grandmother and great grandmother. Her matriarchal presence will be sorely missed by the family and the community. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Israeli Foreign Minister Levy Resigns
description: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, PAULA WATJEN
description: ROCKEFELLER-Paula Watjen. 94, died peacefully in her sleep on August 1, 2000 at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut. She was the daughter of the late A. Wilhelm and Katie F. Watjen of Bremen, Germany and New York. Wife of the late John Sterling Rockefeller and sister of the late Eduard H. Watjen of Ascona, Switzerland. She is survived by her sister, Alice Watjen, of Zurich, Switzerland; two daughters, Christina DuBois of Stockbridge, Massachusetts and Paula Greene of Leominster and London, England; six grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Services are to be held on Monday, August 7, 2000 at 3:00 P.M., St. Matthews Church, Bedford, New York. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to The Mianus Gorge Preserve, 167 Mianus Road, Bedford, New York, 10506.

title: Jammin' Against the Darkness
description: Charlie Ward and Allan Houston were at the NBA Store on Fifth Avenue yesterday to promote Jammin' Against the Darkness, a community outreach program that features Christian music and N.B.A. players speaking about their professional, personal and spiritual lives to people of all ages.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; MIPS Stock: Class Warfare Vs. Rationality
description: In an irrational world, a rational investor may be at a severe disadvantage.

title: Columbia Sets Pace In Profiting Off Research
description: When Fredric D. Price, the president of a nutritional-supplements company, sought a partner to create an online information company, NutritionU.com, he approached a Columbia University professor, Dr. Richard J. Deckelbaum.

title: Outside the Hall, Fund-Raising and Unmuffled Yawns
description: From the convention podium, Colin L. Powell fired a salvo at moneyed special interests. On the street, the police massed loudly in expectation of protesters against all manner of capitalistic evils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, LAWRENCE H.
description: ALEXANDER-Lawrence H. Dearly beloved husband, the light of my life, mourned deeply by Margaret, his wife of 35 years. He was a truly unique man of outer as well as inner beauty; multi-faceted in his interests, a force in the field of education, a true gentleman. He leaves behind for me a void impossible to fill. He also leaves precious memories of the joys we shared through the years. Rest in peace, my dearest one!

title: Chinatown Is Really Vietnamtown Around the Edges
description: WHAT I like most about jury duty are those two-hour lunch breaks with all of Chinatown before me. The opportunity to sample a grilled turnip cake here or a stick of Chinese pork jerky there is irresistible. And when I am finished with the street food and ready to sit down, a favorite place is Nha Trang, one of the Vietnamese restaurants nestled like grains of rice on Baxter Street.

title: No Engine Parts Found on Concorde Flight Path
description: French investigators said yesterday that they had not found any engine parts in the trail of debris shed by an Air France Concorde on its brief flight before crashing near Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris on July 25.

title: Units Reorganized At Grey Global
description: Units of the Grey Global Group in New York are being reorganized.

title: Change of Posts At FCB Worldwide
description: Richard Gagnon has been named executive vice president and media director at the New York office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications. He succeeds Ellen Oppenheim, who is taking an extended personal leave of absence, the agency said. Ms. Oppenheim, 46, is one of the best-known media directors specializing in the print media. Mr. Gagnon, 38, had been the senior vice president and media director overseeing FCBi, the direct marketing and interactive unit of FCB.

title: Nets Are in a Bind
description: Rod Thorn's voice was hoarse from all the talking yesterday, but there were no handshakes and no signatures at the Nets Champion Center in New Jersey on the first day of the free-agent signing period.
