title: The Few, the Rich, the Rewarded Donate the Bulk of G.O.P. Gifts
description: Republican officials insist that their financial base is primarily small donors, but the party has received more than $90 million from a relatively small pool of wealthy individuals and corporations, some of whom have shielded their generosity from public view.

title: The Injustice Of Incivility In Civic Duty
description: IT had been a long time since the last foray into the Criminal Courts Building in lower Manhattan, but a brief visit yesterday confirmed that it had lost none of its charm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREER, JAMES KELLY
description: GREER-James Kelly, 52. Of Hollywood, FL, died June 25, 2000 at home. Born November 9, 1947 in Munich, Germany. A talented piano technician, Jim had a stellar reputation in the music community of Florida and in New York, where he spent many years learning his craft. He loved classical music, especially the words of Mahler and Bruckner. Jim's zest for life was unforgettable, as was his passion for the ideas and people he believed in. He will be sorely missed. Left behind who mourn are his three sisters plus nieces, nephews, cousins and many, many dear friends. A memorial service was held July 22 in Florida.

title: Tea by Two
description: It hardly seems the stuff consumer thrills are made of: a weak, watery tea, brewed the old-fashioned way, with hardly any sugar and even less caffeine. Marketing? There is almost none. Edgy television ads and celebrity endorsements? Zero.

title: Feasts Are for All Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidating Power in Venezuela
description: The voters of Venezuela, craving radical change, have reaffirmed their confidence in Hugo Chavez, a president who promises a ''peaceful revolution.'' Mr. Chavez flattened the country's traditional political parties in elections in 1998, vowing to end the corruption and economic mismanagement that have brought a once-prosperous country to misery. His election this week under a new Constitution to a full six-year term -- the first of two, he hopes -- capped his efforts to strengthen presidential authority. But Venezuelans should be suspicious of how he plans to use his new powers.

title: GTE Settles a Dispute With Competitors
description: The GTE Corporation, a unit of Verizon Communications, has agreed to pay $2.7 million to end an inquiry into accusations it refused to let local phone competitors place equipment in GTE offices without constructing special facilities.

title: U.S. Sergeant Gets Life in Murder of Kosovo Girl, 11
description: A United States military court in Germany sentenced an American soldier today to life in prison without parole for the murder of an 11-year-old Kosovo Albanian girl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HOWLAND
description: DAVIS-Howland. The Board of Trustees of The New York Institute for Special Education (founded in 1831 as The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind) records with deep regret the death of its beloved and distinguished member. Mr. Davis was a dedicated friend of the Institute and he ably assisted in guiding its growth as a trustee and member of nummerous committees for over 45 years. His guidance and friendship will be sorely missed. Our sympathy is extended to his wife Frances and to his family. The Board of Trustees and Employees of The New York Institute for Special Education

description: Tobacco industry documents show that cigarette makers took part for years in a sweeping campaign to influence and undermine the World Health Organization's anti-smoking efforts worldwide, the agency contends in a new report.

title: In Ballot Fights, a Mix Of Routine and Theater
description: The hearing room in Lower Manhattan was crowded and more than a little stuffy. Lawyers holding folders fat with documents waited to do battle in behalf of their clients, the city's politicians and their would-be challengers. The prize they were fighting for in an exhaustive three-day sprint was a place on the primary ballot in September.

title: Few Watched, and Not for Very Long
description: Television ratings for the first night of the Republican National Convention indicated that only a small fraction of the total television audience watched the prime-time portion of the event.

title: U.S. Tennis Team Chosen
description: The United States Olympic men's tennis team will range from Andre Agassi, who owns the career Grand Slam, to Jeff Tarango, better known for his tantrums than for his play.

title: To Send It Back or Not? Some Guidelines
description: THE phone call came from Jean-Claude Baker, who runs Chez Josephine on 42nd Street. A customer had ordered a $100 bottle of wine, then announced that it was ''no good'' and demanded his money back.

title: Syria Is Sued by Family of Man Killed by '96 Bomb in Jerusalem
description: The family of an Israeli-American man killed in a 1996 terrorist attack in Jerusalem filed suit in New York yesterday against Syria, contending that it provided critical support to Hamas, the militant Palestinian group whose members carried out the suicide bombing attack.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest on Saturday about the purchase of Transamerica Leasing, which leases cargo containers, by a rival, Interpool, misstated the ownership of the companies. The Dutch insurer Aegon owns Transamerica Leasing; Interpool is independent.

title: BIOMETRICS SOFTWARE MAKERS TO MERGE
description: In a $150 million deal that would combine two leading providers of handwriting-based electronic signatures, the Communication Intelligence Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the privately held PenOp Ltd. for stock representing about 5 percent of Communication Intelligence equity. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXELROD, EDWARD I.
description: AXELROD-Edward I. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Roslyn Estates, NY, on July 31, 2000. Dearly beloved husband of Carla. Devoted father of Stuart, Neil and Adam. Cherished grandfather of Wendy, Melissa, Amanda and Richard. Adored father-in-law of Barbara and Marilyn. Loving brother of Alice (Jack) Vance and the late Pauline (Ben) Glasser, Renee (Ben) Kane, Alfred (Ruth) Axelrod and Hyman (Naomi) Axelrod. Loving uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Retired CEO and President of Zoe Chemical Corporation, member of Boca Woods Country Club (FL), former charter member of The Woodcrest Club, Syosset, NY. Contributions to Hospice By the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL. 33486, are appreciated.

title: INTEL TO BUY TRILLIUM FOR $300 MILLION
description: The Intel Corporation agreed to buy the closely held Trillium Digital Systems Inc. for about $300 million in cash and stock, giving the largest computer chip maker more software for building networking products. Intel did not say how much it would pay in cash. It will issue shares for Trillium that are not registered under Securities and Exchange Commission guidelines and must be held for a certain period of time before they can be sold. Trillium, based in Los Angeles, has operations in Vancouver, British Columbia. Trillium makes programming software and hardware that corporations can use in building networks to handle various protocols. Trillium products help communications systems recognize where signals are coming from and what they mean. The shares of Intel fell $2.125, to $64.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCHE, JOSEPH
description: MANCHE-Joseph. On July 29. Devoted husband of the late Pearl. Loving father of Arnold (Bonnie) and Kenneth (Julie). Cherished grandfather of Bradley, Alison, Debra and Peter.

title: After the Wonder Years, the Scary Teenage Years
description: Their puppyish faces alone are enough to show that the students in ''American High'' are not actors. In television dramas the supposed teenagers (especially the boys) have the chiseled features of professional actors in their 20's, a fact conspicuous everywhere from ''Dawson's Creek'' to the summer series ''Young Americans.'' But in ''American High,'' the 14 seniors who were filmed throughout their last year of high school have the out-of-proportion features of adolescents. It's not baby fat we're seeing but the soft, unformed look of people who have not quite grown into their faces.

title: Living in the Lap of Bankruptcy, Financier Is Charged With Fraud
description: Back in the early 1980's when many Americans first started putting their money in the stock market, Robert E. Brennan was probably the most prominent pitchman drawing them in, inviting television viewers across the country to take a flier on hot, little-known stocks.

title: Republican Delegates Gather For Countdown to Nominations
description: Republican Delegates Gather

title: Nonpartisan Choice to Head Budget Office
description: Ronnie Lowenstein, acting director of the city's four-year-old Independent Budget Office, was chosen as its director yesterday, ending a competitive process in which two financial experts were apparently passed over because of past ties to partisan politics.

title: Childhood Abuse and Adult Stress
description: Women who were physically or sexually abused in childhood show exaggerated physiological responses to stressful events, a new study has found. And this abnormal stress response, the researchers found, appears especially pronounced in women who also have symptoms of clinical depression.

title: Liberties; New Century, Old Grudges
description: O.K. Now we're in business.

title: Clinton Nudges Arafat
description: President Clinton has said that it is time for the Palestinians to take a step forward in the Middle East peace talks ahead of a Sept. 13 deadline, according to a White House transcript made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINSER, BARBARA L. (MRS. HANS)
description: ZINSER-Barbara L. (Mrs. Hans). The Horticultural Society of New York has been honored & graced to have had Barbara as a member of the Board of Directors, serving in numerous capacities including Secretary, Treasurer, and on the executive, development and finance committees. She served on our Board for 36 years, or more than one-third of the 100 years of the Society's existence! She will always be a treasured part of the lore and legacy of the Society. She brought to the Society the interests of her father, also a longtime Board member, an incisive and quick intelligence, and her own singular brand and sense of humor. The Board and the Staff will miss her deeply.

title: Off the Band Wagon
description: Is everybody at CBS happy to finally have a breakthrough hit like ''Survivor?''

title: NICKEL STRIKE IN CANADA
description: The Sudbury, Ontario, nickel operations of Falconbridge Ltd., one of the world's largest producers, have been shut down by a strike of 1,260 workers after contract talks collapsed. Members of the Canadian Auto Workers union have rejected proposals that include more subcontracting and job transfers. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLEDGE, JOHN W., SR.
description: RUTLEDGE-John W., Sr. A resident of New Canaan for over 30 years. Died Sunday, July 30, 2000 at Norwalk Hospital. He was the husband of Mary Jo McKinley Rutledge. Born on March 12, 1923, in Eureka, California, he was the son of the late William E. & Ellen Jordan Rutledge. He was the former President of the Bulova Watch Company, in New York City, and was the Senior Vice President and Director of the Xerox Corporation in Stamford, CT. Mr. Rutledge was a graduate of Northwestern University, with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1943, and a Master's in Business from Harvard University. He later earned a Master's in Arts Degree in Archaeology from Yale University in 1985. He was a Veteran of WWII serving in the United States Navy, with rank of Lieutenant JG serving aboard the USS Missouri. In addition to his wife Mary Jo, of New Canaan, Jack is survived by two daughters Ellen Valenti, and Amy Jebrine of Stamford, one son John W. Rutledge Jr. of Darien, one sister Katherine Van Slambrouck, of San Jose California, and two brothers, Edward J. Rutledge, of Glenview, Illinois, and Robert J. Rutledge of Williamsport, PA. Three grandchildren Courtney W. Rutledge, Megan D. Rutledge, and Olivia M. Jebrine also survive. He was predeceased by his brother Paul J. Rutledge. A memorial Mass of Christian Burial will be held in the St. Aloysius R.C. Church in New Canaan 11:00AM on Friday August 4, 2000. There will be no calling Hours and interment will be private. The family has requested in lieu of flowers, donations be considered to the New Canaan Library, 151 Main Street, New Canaan or the New Canaan Nature Center, 144 Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, Connecticut 06840. The F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan is handling the funeral services.

title: Mixed Signals In 3 Reports On Economy
description: The first drop in orders in 19 months restrained manufacturing in July but consumer spending rebounded in June, two reports showed today.

title: War on Diamonds
description: Diamonds have become unfashionable as never before among Western powers struggling to snuff out civil wars in Africa. Appalled by pictures of children with limbs hacked off by diamond-smuggling rebels in Sierra Leone and humiliated when those rebels kidnapped international peacekeepers in May, the United States, Britain and several other countries are making control of the diamond trade a foreign policy priority.

title: Hands-On Politics 101 For an Untested Cheney
description: At a breakfast on Monday for Wyoming's delegates to the Republican National Convention here, Dick Cheney looked uneasy when it came time to pose for a photograph with the crowd from his home state.

title: To Appreciate Cheney, Come to Wyoming
description: Since he became the Republican vice presidential nominee, Dick Cheney has been depicted as some kind of right-wing kook. His detractors have scoured his record in Congress and plucked out a few votes with no reference to their context. They toss out conclusions about him that have no relation to his splendid reputation among his former colleagues, Republican and Democrat alike. But if his detractors continue to focus on only a few of his thousands of votes, let's at least be upfront with the facts.

title: Serial Rapist Gets 155 Years; Judge Suggests His Crimes Contributed to Diallo Shooting
description: Before sentencing a serial rapist to 155 years to life in prison, a Bronx judge suggested yesterday that the man's crime spree might have contributed to the fatal police shooting of Amadou Diallo. One of the officers in that case said after the shooting that they had approached Mr. Diallo because he fit the general description of the rapist.

title: Gooden's Bronx Revival Continues
description: Dwight Gooden's revival continued last night, which meant that one of the most surprising developments of a long season continued for the Yankees. Gooden pitched seven competent innings for one of the best teams in baseball and made it difficult to fathom how he was unemployed before George Steinbrenner offered him one more chance.

title: TERAYON AGREES TO BUY MAINSAIL FOR $163 MILLION
description: Terayon Communication Systems Inc., the No. 2 maker of modems for cable television lines, agreed to buy the closely held Mainsail Networks Inc. for about $163.8 million in stock to add networking gear. Terayon will issue 3.2 million shares for Mainsail, based in Fremont, Calif. Shares of Terayon, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose 18 cents, to $51.1875. Mainsail's gear helps deliver phone calls, data and video on the same high-speed connection, a process that lowers costs for providers of telecommunications services.

title: Baking Like a Professional: In Paper
description: IT'S a wonder no one ever thought of it before. For years, commercial bakers have baked their pies and tarts, their panettones and sweet breads in disposable paper pans. That saves them thousands of miles of shelving that would otherwise be crammed with metal pans.

title: Show Goes On Despite Drizzle, Mist and Miking
description: There is something new under the sun, er, moon, uh, clouds. The Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center opened its 34th season on Monday evening with its first outdoor concert, free in Damrosch Park.

title: Opera Singers' Love Bridges Borders of Hate
description: Until last month, the names of the young opera singers Marijana Mijanovic and Kresimir Spicer were virtually unknown. Now they are ''the couple of the summer,'' according to the Marseille newspaper La Provence. That is partly because of their performances as Penelope and Ulysses in the new production of Monteverdi's ''Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria'' at the noted opera festival here. But it is also because they are a real-life Romeo and Juliet: she is a Serb, he is a Croat, and they live together in Amsterdam.

title: Levy Offers Higher Salaries To Staff the Worst Schools
description: With pressure mounting to rid New York City's most troubled schools of uncertified teachers by September, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced a plan yesterday to lure experienced instructors from private and parochial schools by increasing the starting salaries they can earn if they transfer into the city's poorest schools.

title: Holyfield Deflects Jabs on Title Fight
description: Evander Holyfield has spent a lifetime building a reputation as a warrior, a true champion. But as he pursues another title in his long career, he finds himself answering questions of just how worthy his pursuit is.

title: Mercer Reaches Agreement
description: The Chicago Bulls agreed to contract terms with the free agent Ron Mercer, their first significant acquisition after several high-profile players rejected the team's offers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a man who took hostages on a plane at Kennedy International Airport and demanded to speak to someone from the Argentine Consulate misspelled the surname of the consul general. He is Guillermo J. McGough, not McCough.

title: Priceline.com Is Selling a $190 Million Stake to Two Investors
description: In a deal as complex as his patented method of selling airplane tickets, Jay S. Walker, the founder of Priceline.com, agreed yesterday to sell $190 million of his shares to Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Ventures and John C. Malone's Liberty Media Group.

title: Silent Fraternity: Police Officers With H.I.V.; Many, Fearing Ostracism, Hide Their Condition From Others on the Force
description: There is a new fraternity growing within the clannish New York Police Department, but most of its members are so ashamed by what they share that they have never met and do not even know one another's names.

title: Dept. of Yawn Control
description: AT the moment, I have jet lag. I want to sleep when I should be awake; I'm wide awake when I should be asleep; and I crave breakfast at the most unreasonable hours. It is an unexpectedly familiar feeling -- not because I'm some international jet-setter, but because I suffer from a form of jet lag even when I haven't gone anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU MOULIN, ELEANOR C. (NEE LEWIS)
description: du MOULIN-Eleanor C. (nee Lewis). On August 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward du Moulin of 58 years. Loving mother of Cathy & Jerome Morea, Ann and Richard du Moulin. Adoring grandmother of Christopher, Douglas and Carrie Morea, Lora Ann, Edward, Matthew and Mark du Moulin. Devoted sister of Dorothy Garbowitz. Arrangements private. Memorial service Saturday, August 19 at Knickerbocker Yacht Club, 11 AM, 433 Main St., Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Francis Hospital, 100 Port Washington Boulevard, Roslyn, New York 11576, or Make-A-Wish Foundation, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, New York 11050, would be appreciated.

title: Pupils Prosper From an Investment
description: Twelve years ago, Merrill Lynch chose 251 first graders at random from some of the toughest neighborhoods in 10 cities and made them a pledge: graduate from high school by 2000, and we will pay all your college expenses.

title: Bruce J. Ennis, 60, Lawyer Who Fought for Civil Liberties
description: Bruce J. Ennis, a First Amendment lawyer and former legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union, died on Saturday at a hospital in Boston, where he had been taken from his summer home on Martha's Vineyard. He was 60 and lived in Washington.

title: Courting of Voting Bloc Poses Question of Motive
description: Tonight, for the second night in a row, one of the principal speakers at the Republican National Convention was a black person. Tonight, it was Condoleezza Rice, the chief national security adviser to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas; on Monday night, it was Colin L. Powell, who may be secretary of state if Mr. Bush is elected president.

title: PRUDENTIAL INVESTMENT IN KOREAN TRUST
description: In a rare attempt by a foreign company to increase its stake in South Korea's debt-ridden nonbank financial industry, Prudential Life Insurance Company plans to invest $500 million in a local investment trust company. Prudential signed a preliminary agreement with CJ Investment Trust and Securities, a unit of South Korea's largest food manufacturer, Cheil Jedang Corporation. The pact covers an initial investment of $100 million, with the balance to be invested over the next two or three years. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, ANITA
description: HAAS-Anita. Of NYC, after a courageous struggle with cancer. Beloved daughter of Ilse Cierer Haas and the late Erich. Business manager at Office of Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals with Disabilities (VESID). Memorial service at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, August 6, at 4 PM. Contributions in her name to SHARE or Calvary Hospital. Anita will be sorely missed for her wonderful sense of humor and love of life.

title: Chavez Says He Will Crush Political Foes In Venezuela
description: President Hugo Chavez said today that he would use troops to crush street protests and to remove an opposition party governor who has accused the governing party of fraudulently altering the outcome of elections last weekend.

title: Mathis Shows Heart on Field and T-Shirt
description: The first time Lothar Matthaus saw Clint Mathis in a MetroStars practice, he told Coach Octavio Zambrano something the club already knew, that Mathis was a rare breed, a soccer player with the knack for scoring goals.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: College Takes to Street to Drum Up Enrollment
description: Call it the big sell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLAKOFF, ANNE (NEE LADER)
description: POLAKOFF-Anne (nee Lader). Of Fort Lee, on July 31, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Cherished aunt of Joan Lader and Carol Loigman. Services were held at Mt. Neboh Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York on Tuesday. For information please call ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-9533.

title: Past Rivalries Color Present
description: The former president had been biting his tongue, sacrificing his anger to his heir's ambitions. The current president had been rocking on his heels, letting his disciple fight his own battles.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Defense Debate Begins
description: The Republican Convention in Philadelphia set aside its nurturing themes about children last night and returned to the traditional G.O.P. territory of defense policy and military strength. Popular war heroes like former Senator Bob Dole and Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf implied that the Clinton administration had let veterans down and allowed defenses to erode. But a strangely subdued note was struck by the keynote speaker, Senator John McCain, the self-described ''distant runner-up.'' His generous but obviously unenthusiastic praise of Gov. George W. Bush was punctuated with intimations of his own mortality. His maudlin address seemed designed to echo Gen. Douglas MacArthur's farewell and perhaps to suggest a subtext of ''I shall return'' if Mr. Bush falters in November.

title: Unstuffing Those Stuffy Staff Meetings
description: Jerry McLaughlin hates corporate boardrooms.

title: Scientists Warn of Inaction As AIDS Spreads in China
description: During all the years that Yang Zhiyin was selling his blood, he had never heard of AIDS. All he knew was that he was desperately poor, and selling blood on the black market was what farmers did in his village when they needed cash. For much of a decade, Mr. Yang said, he rolled up his sleeve to the blood dealer's needle ''many many times.''

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREED, ANNIE R.
description: CREED-Annie R. At the age of 36. Beloved daughter of John F. and Anne M. Creed. Memorial Mass 2 PM, Thursday, August 3, at the Convent of the Sacred Heart. 1 East 91st Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Annie may be made to the Catholic Big Sisters.

title: First-Time Event Appears Assured For Hambletonian
description: DeWayne Minor will register a first in the Hambletonian on Saturday, win, place or just show up. The 43-year-old Minor will be the first African-American to drive in the richest event in harness racing, which this year has several newcomers and lacks an outstanding horse for the $1 million 75th edition.

title: Party's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern daylight

title: 32 Injured as City Bus Hits Traffic Agent and Crashes Into Midtown Building
description: A city bus driver lost control on 34th Street yesterday evening, crossed two lanes of oncoming traffic and struck an on-duty traffic enforcement agent before driving onto the sidewalk and smashing into a building, the police said.

title: Car Sales Rise, Except at G.M. And Chrysler
description: General Motors and DaimlerChrysler said today that their sales fell in July, leaving both automakers unable to reduce their bloated inventories of unsold minivans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles. But Ford and foreign automakers announced strong sales last month and balanced inventories.

title: Unplugged
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEEHAN, FLORENCE E.
description: MEEHAN-Florence E. Of Glen Cove, L.I., formerly of Heritage Village, CT. On August 1, 2000. Age 87. Beloved wife of the late Joseph G. Dear siser of the late C. Edwin, Herbert and Robert Sundius. Visitation Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, New York, on Friday, 3-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Witnesses to Turnpike Shooting Said to Back Troopers
description: The criminal case against two state troopers that is at the heart of New Jersey's racial profiling scandal has been rocked by the discovery of two new witnesses who support the accounts of the troopers, who are accused of attempted murder for shooting three unarmed minority men on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: BRAZIL DECISION ON BENEFITS POSTPONED
description: The Supreme Court of Brazil postponed until next Thursday a widely awaited decision that could force the government to pay up to $30 billion in back benefits to contributors to the national workers' fund. The government has been accused of short-changing contributors to the fund from 1987 to 1991, during a period of financial crisis. Only three of the 60,000 cases pending have reached the Supreme Court, which could set a precedent with the decision.

title: The Landmarks Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Gives 30-Year Bond a Reprieve, and Price Falls
description: The 30-year bond received a reprieve yesterday, and its fate is now probably in the hands of the next administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, SUSIE
description: CHEN-Susie. July 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lin Chen, Chairman of Summit Import Corporation and President Kam Man Food Corporation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 81 Street, Friday, August 4th, 2 to 8PM. Service Saturday, August 5, at 10AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: In Free-Spirited Play, a Departed Spirit Lives
description: THE ghost of Looking Glass Studios hovers about me as I explore Deus Ex. The specter of that celebrated game developer, which closed its doors in May, whispers in my ear as the story folds conspiracy upon conspiracy. It cackles softly as I fumble for equipment to master the game's electronic locks and struggle to recall passwords. It curls about my ankles like an unseen cat as I stand in darkness and debate my next direction. I have many choices and, in most of them, the ghost follows close upon my heels.

title: Cold and Gray, but It's Still a Day at the Beach
description: For the first few soggy, gray days of her family's two-week vacation that started here on Saturday, Barbara Cagliostro had a simple question: Where is everyone?

title: The Nerd as Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Orders Refinement Of Death Penalty Reviews
description: The Supreme Court of New Jersey upheld the state's death penalty review process today while at the same time finding that it was ''inherently unreliable'' in assessing whether race plays a role in determining who is prosecuted for a capital crime and ultimately sentenced to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ROBERT (BOB)
description: MORRIS-Robert (Bob). The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Robert (Bob) Morris, husband of Linda Morris, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President

title: Israels Leader Faces Turmoil on All Side
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 1  Prime Minister Ehud Barak's political problems deepened today as his right-wing opponents, sensing blood with their stunning defeat of Shimon Peres, his presidential candidate, vowed new efforts to bring down his government.

title: Go.com Reports Quarterly Loss and Higher Revenues
description: Go.com Reports Quarterly Loss and Higher Revenues

title: Online Agreement Near for Writers' Group
description: A group representing freelance writers, which is seeking to establish the legitimacy of a central clearinghouse through which writers can be paid for the resale of old articles -- the same way musicians are paid for the resale of old songs -- is close to signing an agreement that would give new stature and visibility to the clearinghouse.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Patrick T. McGahn Jr., 72, Lawyer for Casinos
description: Patrick T. McGahn Jr., a colorful casino lawyer and South Jersey Democratic Party leader who helped bring gambling to Atlantic City, died Sunday in Somers Point, N.J. He was 72.

title: Kids Grow. Why Not Their Desks?
description: CHILDREN have always come in a wide range of sizes. And finally, their desks and chairs do, too. With the proliferation of computers for games and homework, children's rooms are beginning to look like miniature home offices. Like adults, children need properly proportioned desks and chairs for comfort and safe posture. Elbows should stay at waist height when the child uses a keyboard. The monitor should be at eye level. Feet should be flat on the floor. The furniture here is adjustable in small increments so it can grow along with its users.

title: Airline to End Some Flights
description: Continental Airlines said today that it would end flights to Santiago, Chile, and to Santa Cruz, Bolivia, because Peru refused to let it pick up passengers for those flights in Lima.

title: Discovering the Music: Freedom or Theft?
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader Crashes, And Bashes, G.O.P.'s Party
description: It took the presence of Ralph Nader consumer advocate, professional gadfly and himself a candidate for president of the United States -- but something finally happened here tonight that, one assumes, was not in the Republican Party script.

title: Who Needs Portable DVD?
description: To the Editor:

title: STEEL ALLIANCE CONFIRMED
description: The world's two largest steel makers agreed to buy more shares in each other to minimize direct competition in Asian markets. The Pohang Iron and Steel Company and Nippon Steel are raising to 3 percent their intended purchases of each other's shares within 18 months, the two companies said in a joint statement. Samuel Len

title: A Message to Web Designers: If It Ain't Broke, Don't Fix It
description: WHEN Salon.com revamped its Web site in May, readers greeted it with hundreds of e-mail complaints. They criticized the horizontal scrolling, the small type and the headlines that no longer linked directly to articles.

title: Op-Art
ADVANTA WARNS OF LOWERED EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS
description: The Advanta Corporation, based in Spring House, Pa., warned yesterday that earnings this year would be lower than expected because of government restrictions that limit the amount of loans the company can make. Advanta, a mortgage and home equity lender, said earnings for the year would probably be $2.18 to $2.38 a share. Analysts in a First Call/Thomson Financial survey were forecasting $2.67 a share. In June, the company agreed to limit the loans it could make to customers with poor credit. Advanta said it expected to issue fewer mortgages as a result.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose almost 2 percent after an industry report showed the biggest drop in inventories in six months. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose 47 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $28.26 a barrel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our crowd needs to get into the battle, keep their mouths shut and help this man win.''

title: Article 2000080392998669060 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Women Wielding Power in a Wide-Open Hollywood
description: It's great that Turner Classics Movies has revived many rare old films that were written, directed or produced by women for its Women Film Pioneers series. So I'll take it as a backhanded compliment to women (and interested men, of course) that the cable network is broadcasting many of these 37 films in the middle of the night. Someone must be assuming that all of us know how to program our VCR's.

title: West Hopes to Curtail Diamond Trading, but Without Money and Troops
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 1  Diamonds have become unfashionable as never before among Western powers struggling to snuff out civil wars in Africa. Appalled by pictures of children with limbs hacked off by diamond- smuggling rebels in Sierra Leone and humiliated when those rebels kidnapped international peacekeepers in May, the United States, Britain and several other countries are making control of the diamond trade a foreign policy priority.

title: NORTEL HANDS OFF SYSTEMS MANAGEMENT
description: Two days after announcing disappointing quarterly financial results, the Computer Sciences Corporation said yesterday that it had won a $3 billion contract to provide technology services to Nortel Networks of Canada for the next seven years. Nortel, North America's second-biggest maker of telecommunications equipment after Lucent Technologies, will essentially turn over responsibility for its internal computer systems to Computer Sciences, which will manage computers on more than 75,000 desktops worldwide for Nortel.

title: Article 2000080390179487139 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, BEATRICE
description: DAVIS-Beatrice, 96, devoted wife of the late Sam, beloved mother of Malcolm and Ilene, George, Theodore and Cindee, adored grandmother & loving greatgrandmother, sister of Edith Epstein. Bea was a wonderful and giving mother and person. She was full of fun, an active Red Cross volunteer during World War II at St. Albans and North Shore Veterans Hospitals. Active in UJA, Hadassah, Zionist Organization and Hebrew Institute of Israel. Her memory will live in our hearts forever. Services Thursday, August 3, 12:45 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam.

title: Promises of Changes, But Unspoken Details
description: It is all so murky, the rhetoric here, that you might think yourself back in the presidential campaign of 1952, when Dwight D. Eisenhower promised, ''I shall go to Korea,'' but supplied no details about what he would do to end the war once he got there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAKAUER, LEONARD
description: KRAKAUER-Leonard. Husband of Olga. Beloved father of Gary and Heidi Krakauer and Charline and Michael Fredericksen. Cherished grandfather of Kiera, Mariel and Rachel. Loving brother of Dr. William. Also survived by Olga's son, Peter Benzaia. May his memory be for a blessing. Services Friday, 2 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: AUTHORITIES RAID BERTELSMANN
description: The European Commission said it raided Bertelsmann and four other German book publishers as part of an investigation into whether the companies orchestrated a boycott of Internet booksellers. Commission officials, together with representatives of the German Cartel Office, carried out ''surprise inspections'' at the Munich office of Bertelsmann, the Aufbau-Verlag in Berlin, KNO and K&V book wholesalers in Stuttgart and the German association for the book trade in Frankfurt.

title: Man and Sitter Held in Rape Of Baby Girl
description: A 4-month-old infant was raped in her baby sitter's apartment in Passaic last week, and a teenage relative of the sitter's was ordered held in $200,000 bail today on charges of aggravated sexual assault, the authorities said.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, BLANCHE
description: FORREST-Blanche. Loving wife of over 40 years to Irving. Wonderful mother, beloved grandmother and devoted school worker for over 30 years. Will be lovingly missed by her children Ken and Ellen, Neil and Alisa and her grandchildren, Kim, Craig, Andrew, Jenny and Matt. Services on Friday, at 10AM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a production of ''Cymbeline Refinished'' by the New Jersey-based Theater Company, opening tomorrow in Riverside Park in Manhattan, omitted the area code from the information telephone number. It is (201) 867-1575.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell after the president of the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank suggested the central bank might leave interest rates alone. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.97 yen, down from 109.02.

title: Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: U.S. and Jordan Move to Cut Trade Barriers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The United States and Jordan are close to reaching an agreement to cut trade barriers, the top American negotiator said today.

title: Metro Matters; 2 More Voices In Dissonance Over Police
description: WE'RE used to hearing Public Advocate Mark Green and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani disagree about the city's Police Department. And the Rev. Al Sharpton and Police Commissioner Howard Safir. And many other local public figures with opinions about what is right and wrong about city policing.

title: Blemished Goods For Bargain Hunters
description: IT was common knowledge in the 1970's that my mother-in-law trafficked in broken Godiva chocolates that she bought in unmarked plastic bags at insanely low prices from an outlet store near her home in Reading, Pa.

title: Colin Powell's Critique: Part II
description: Some in our party miss no opportunity to roundly and loudly condemn affirmative action that helped a few thousand black kids get an education,'' Colin Powell told the Republican convention this week, ''but you hardly hear a whimper when it's affirmative action for lobbyists who load our federal tax code with preferences for special interests.''

title: MetroStars Let Down in Last Minute of Overtime
description: The absence of the MetroStars' leading middle defenders was evident tonight as several costly mistakes on defense led to a 3-2 overtime loss to D.C. United at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: CALIFORNIA ON EDGE OF FAILING TO MEET ELECTRICITY NEEDS
description: Four years after it led the nation into a sweeping deregulation of the electric industry, California is at the brink of a breakdown in its power supply.

title: The Ear of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: Massacres in Kashmir May Be Effort to Sabotage Peace Initiative
description: In a killing rampage remarkable even for the bloodied mountains and forests of Kashmir, at least 93 people were slain late Tuesday and early today in six separate massacres.

title: NETS
description: The Nets remain in talking mode a day after meeting with 6-9 forward Aaron Williams, a free agent who played last season with the Washington Wizards. The 29-year-old Williams, who has played with six N.B.A. teams in six years, met with the Knicks Tuesday afternoon, then crossed the Hudson to meet with Nets' officials. Williams averaged 5 rebounds and a career-high 7.6 points per game last season in 19.1 minutes a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ANNE (NEE WILLIAMS)
description: SULLIVAN-Anne (nee Williams), 74. Died Monday, July 31, 2000. A native of Orange, New Jersey. Attended Milburn High School and Earlham College in Richmond, Indiana. She was a social worker in Newark, New Jersey, drove a school bus for handicapped children, and was a long time board member of the Essex County Mental Health Association. A lifelong avid bridge player, she enjoyed her membership in the Newcomer's Bridge Club. In 1947, she married John/Sean Sullivan (professionally O'Sullivan), a New York actor, ABC TV director and playwright, who has had a long association with the Barter Theatre of Abingdon, Virginia. Surviving, besides her husband, two daughters Louise Bagby and Ann (Nancy) Ward; two sons Sean J. W. Sullivan, Jr., and Padraic Sullivan; grandsons Daniel Ward, Andrew Ward and Ethan Sullivan. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, Thursday, August 3, in the Sinking Springs Presbyterian Church, Abingdon. Interment in Forest Hills Memory Gardens, Abingdon. Memorial contributions to the American Heart Association.

title: Capt. Billy Joel, Designer Man
description: THEY say a boat is a hole in the water you dump money into, and Billy Joel has emptied his wallet many times.

title: FORECAST LIFTS MOTOROLA
description: Shares of Motorola rose $1.8125, to $36.8125 yesterday, after officials said the company expected to meet analysts' profit and revenue forecasts for this year and next. Speaking late Tuesday at the company's annual meeting with Wall Street analysts in Chicago, Motorola's president, Robert Growney, said estimates of $47 billion in sales and earnings of $1.43 a share next year were ''achievable'' and that the company was sticking with its forecast for profit of $1.05 a share on 39.5 billion in sales for 2000. David Barboza

title: DEAL SEEN FOR POWER COMPANY
description: One of Britain's largest utilities, Scottish Power, is in the final stages of negotiations to sell the Australian electricity distributor Powercor Australia to the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing for $690 million in cash and $640 million in assumed debt, an executive close to the discussions said. Powercor, which sells electricity to more than 575,000 customers, will add to Mr. Li's growing expansion in Australia, where he owns power cable and gas pipeline assets. Scottish Power acquired Powercor last year when it bought PacifiCorp, a United States utility, for $10.8 billion. Alan Cowell

title: CINAR HIRES ADVISER
description: Hinting of a possible sale, Cinar, the troubled Montreal animation company, said it had hired Merrill Lynch as a financial adviser. Cinar, creator of the Emmy-award winning ''Arthur'' series, suspended stock trading March 9 after allegations emerged that it had earned millions of dollars in Canadian government tax credits for falsely reporting American script writers as Canadians. James Brooke

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Recruiters Ask For Equity And Get It
description: When Relativity Technologies began a search this spring for a new president, its equity was in great demand. Even before negotiating with job candidates, it had to deal with the demand for a stake from the executive search firms.

title: Bulldozer and Cash for Canadian Press Baron, but Hold the Sunset
description: So what is Conrad Black going to do with his bags of money now that he has sold most of the crown jewels of Canada's newspapers in one fell swoop?

title: 'Burbs, Fresh From the Frigidaire
description: The Shelburne Museum in Vermont is known for its re-creations of 18th- and 19th-century buildings (it has a one-room schoolhouse) and evocations of early America, like horse-drawn carriages. This summer, the museum opened ''The Fabulous 50's: Welcome Home to Postwar Vermont,'' for which it restored a 1952 six-room ranch house on its 45-acre property. ''In the 1950's, there were waiting lists for dishwashers, blenders, refrigerators and cars,'' Sloane Stephens, managing curator of the museum, said. The consumerist bent is reflected in the true-to-life Vermont kitchen, above, with its 1949 Frigidaire. And those tilted cabinets? They are authentic too, the way the owner built them in 1952. Information: (802) 985-3346 or www.shelburnemuseum.org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORNBERG, ELY MARC
description: ZORNBERG-Ely Marc. Devoted son of Florence and Edward, Brother of Eric and sister-in-law Debbie, brother of Gwen, Loving Father of Joshua and Alma. He will be missed by the entire family. Services will be held on Friday, Aug 4 at 12:30pm at Plaza Memorial, 91 St at Amsterdam Ave, NYC

title: Rather Be in Philadelphia? G.O.P. Convention's Online
description: In the media tents off the floor of the Republican National Convention here, in a corner dubbed Internet Alley, the crowd is young, the style is geek chic and the latest in computer gadgetry is on display. It's all part of a not-so-quiet Internet revolution, say those who work here, that has the potential to shake up the world of politics.

title: Navy Lets I.B.M. Supercomputer Be Its Umbrella
description: Navy Lets I.B.M. Supercomputer Be Its Umbrella

title: New Rewritable Drive Offers Relief From the Slow Burn
description: Until recently, computer users measured out their lives in downloading times. Now there's an even slower, more agonizing measurement of time discovered by those who copy or create their own CD's: burning time.

title: Metro Business; Radio Chain Hires Adviser
description: Nassau Broadcasting Partners L.P., which operates 32 radio stations in the Northeast, has retained Salomon Smith Barney to help it consider alternatives after withdrawing a proposed initial public offering, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JERRY B.
description: COHEN-Jerry B. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the brother of its devoted member, Joyce Weitz. May his entire family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Rabbi Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: New York's Hotel California; Out on Bail, Mob Suspects Find They Can't Really Leave
description: The leak in the ceiling had been there for weeks, a nasty bruise of moldy plaster and peeling paint. Though Anthony Spero had been trying his best to get a handyman in, there wasn't a guy in all of Staten Island who would take the job.

title: Top Adviser to Japan's Premier at Center of a Political Scandal
description: The government of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori was slammed by its second political scandal in a week when one of his top advisers admitted accepting millions of yen in questionable donations.

title: Biding Time, Conservatives Hold Breath and Brimstone
description: These are complicated times for social conservatives. They feel they are winning on their core issues at this Republican National Convention, but some of them clearly miss the red-meat rhetoric and partisan edge of conventions past, replaced this week by the Bush campaign's relentless appeal to the center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHNER, PETER
description: FLEISCHNER-Peter, 91, originally of St. Gallen, Switzerland, died peacefully in his sleep on July 27, 2000. He was the loving spouse of Didi Fleischner. He is survived by his daughters Catherine and Molly, and his brother Robert Fleischner. Memorial service will be held August 5 at 2PM at the Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: U.S. Ship in First China Port Call in a Year
description: QINGDAO, China, Aug. 2 (AP)  A United States Navy cruiser arrived here today for the first port call by an American warship in China since NATO bombed the Chinese Embassy in Yugoslavia last year.

title: An Architect Earns the Right to Build the Blues
description: ALONG with a room, the usual luxury amenities and a gift shop stocked with beautiful books on Paris, guests at Sofitel, the new hotel on West 44th Street, are rewarded with an unexpected privilege. They get to participate in the education of an architect. His name is Yann Leroy. He is a partner at the New York firm Brennan Beer Gorman. He is 41. And Sofitel is his solo, stand-alone-building debut in Manhattan.

title: Like Music To the Eyes
description: SITTING in the 5.1 surround sound studio installed in his newly renovated apartment on Hudson Street, Carter Burwell, a film composer, was talking about romantic comedy.

title: Palestinian Summer Camp Offers the Games of War
description: It is summer camp time for 25,000 Palestinian teenagers, and strikingly unusual camps they are, too. As run by the men who handle psychological warfare for Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, they allow no horsing around in the dorm, no fun-in-the-sun by a cool clear lake, no rousing sing-alongs beside a roaring campfire.

title: News of Arrest Renews Survivors' Pain
description: Lawrence Watkins went through more than a year of tears, condolences, sleepless nights, speeches and letter-writing before his memory began the merciful act of burying his daughter's murder.

title: Go.Com Says Losses Grew in 3rd Quarter
description: Go.com Inc., the Internet unit of the Walt Disney Company, said today that its loss widened in the fiscal third quarter as the company spent heavily to refocus its business on entertainment.

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Begin Pursuit Of Fortson
description: Determined to toughen up by adding another power forward to their roster, the Knicks will entertain Danny Fortson, the 6-foot-7-inch free agent from the Boston Celtics, today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a Critic's Notebook article about the New York Philharmonic's search for a music director misstated the affiliations of the conductor Robert Spano. He will join the Atlanta Symphony in the 2001-2 season; he is not there now. He is also remaining as conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonic; he has not left.

title: A Hand That Helps Explain A Hall of Fame Admission
description: One of the best-loved characters in the world of bridge half a century ago was Harry J. Fishbein, the proprietor of the famous Mayfair Club in New York City. He will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame at ceremonies in Anaheim, Calif., next Thursday.

title: Your Car Can Double As a Paid Advertisement
description: If you thought that the surface of every public space -- including stadium walls, shopping carts and airplane seats -- had already been appropriated for advertising, you were mistaken. A company called AutoWraps has found yet another canvas that until recently was untouched by commercialization: your car.

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, SOLOMON
description: FELD-Solomon. Died August 1. Beloved husband of Bebe Feld, loving father of Alan (Fran), Michael (Barbara), Rick (Randi), and Randy. Also, grandchildren Daniel, Rebecca, Aaron, David, Allison and Jonathan. Zionist and educator, principal of the Solomon Feld Religious School at Wantagh Jewish Center. Services at 1PM, today August 3, at the Wantagh Jewish Center, Wantagh, N.Y.

title: Unusual Setting, But Fish Still Bite
description: Thoughts of hungry striped bass hung in the air, bright as the nearly full moon rising in the afternoon haze over Long Island. Though not a swirl or splash could yet be seen, Rob Maass and John Waidman stood supremely confident, casting bucktails from shore into a quiet backwater.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Jorge Flores, 88; Influenced a Coup in Brazil
description: Jorge Oscar de Mello Flores, a businessman who worked behind the scenes to influence important political events in Brazil, died on Monday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 88.

title: Senator Torricelli Retreats
description: Perhaps the best that can be said of Senator Robert Torricelli's leap into the icy preliminaries of next year's gubernatorial race in New Jersey is that he leapt out again so quickly. Three weeks after declaring plans to run for governor, the ambitious senator suddenly decided to keep his job in Washington. Many of the state's most powerful Democrats had refused to desert his rival James McGreevey, who almost defeated Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in 1997. Their reasons ranged from fair play to political revenge against Mr. Torricelli to the results of a quick weekend poll that showed Mr. McGreevey more popular.

title: India Jolted as One Legend Abducts Another
description: The legendary outlaw Veerappan, a lean man with a twirling, jet black mustache, has ranged through the vast jungles of South India for a generation, slaughtering elephants for their ivory tusks, smuggling out perfumed sandalwood and playing Robin Hood to the forest dwellers, the authorities say.

title: The Rural Life; A Month of Damp Flannel
description: The second cutting of hay has been postponed in the Berkshires because the farmers can't get into the fields. If August goes on the way July has, the horses will have to eat hostas, which have never looked more prosperous. Everything fungal is also having a high time of it. On yet another wet morning, with the rain disguised temporarily as fog, the bees hung in sodden mats from the hive entrances. The sky has been the color of auto primer all week long. The old metaphors for night's arrival fail. It does not ''come,'' it does not ''fall.'' The sun does not ''set.'' The clouds merely obtrude themselves until darkness is complete. The dogs, who are photosensitive for food, expect 5 o'clock supper at noon.

title: Hospitalized After Suffering a Stroke, Former President Ford Is Expected to Fully Recover
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford was admitted to the neurological intensive care unit of Hahnemann University Hospital here today after suffering what doctors said was at least one small stroke over the last three days.

title: MASCOTECH TO BE SOLD TO HEARTLAND INDUSTRIAL PARTNERS
description: The metal products maker MascoTech Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the privately held buyout firm Heartland Industrial Partners L.P. for up to $803 million in stock. The deal, worth more than $2 billion including the assumption of debt, is expected to generate $17 to $18 a share. The price represents at least a 50 percent premium to MascoTech's Tuesday close of $11.50. The stock closed yesterday at $16, up $4.50, or 39.1 percent. The transaction, which would privatize MascoTech, based in Taylor, Mich., requires shareholder approval.

description: Max is trying to give the Kid some hope.

description: RABENOU-Elsa. Passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan on August 1 at the age of 90. Widow of prominent art dealer Khalil Rabenou and loving mother of Esther Mahboubian, Yris Solomon, Parviz Rabenou and grandmother of seven grandsons and three great-grandchildren. Service will be held Thursday, August 3, 2000, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. Interment will follow at Cedar Park Cemetery in Emerson, N.J.

title: Bosnian Woman, Describing War Ordeal, Faints in U.S. Court
description: Acivil lawsuit against the former leader of the Bosnian Serbs began in a federal courtroom in Manhattan yesterday with a witness fainting on the stand as she described her captivity, rape and torture during the Balkans conflict in the summer and fall of 1992.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REUBEN, GLADYS H.
description: REUBEN-Gladys H. of Cambridge, Ma. on July 31, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Allan H. Reuben Esquire of Philadelphia. Devoted mother of John D. Reuben & his wife, Lena, Patricia Reuben Abreu and her husband Aldo and Catherine E. Reuben Esquire and her significant other Scott Glanzman. Loving sister of Judge and Mrs. Gregory R. Baler. Dear grandmother of Michael and Max Reuben and Marisol Abreu. Remembrances in her memory may be made to Renovation Fund for Early Childhood Learning Laboratory, Fund Number 94138, Boston University School of Education, 605 Commonwealth Ave. Boston, MA 02215, Attn: Rachel O'Boyle.

title: For Isles, a Bridgeport Farm
description: Beginning next season, the Islanders will not have to ship their prospects off to Chicago or to Massachusetts. The team announced yesterday that a new American Hockey League franchise in Bridgeport, Conn., would become the Islanders' primary development affiliate.

title: Discovering the Music: Freedom or Theft?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARGARET V.
description: SMITH-Margaret V. On July 30, 2000, aged 87, in Hoffman Estates, IL. Lived in New York about 1938-1970 (principally Sea Cliff); then in Arlington, Texas. An accomplished artist. Survived by her daughter Margo L. Smith, son-inlaw Terrence B. Kersjes, and others. Interment: Mt. Emblem Cemetery, Elmhurst, IL.

title: Pearson to Head XFL Entry
description: Drew Pearson, the former Dallas Cowboys receiver, will be named today as the general manager of the New York/New Jersey XFL franchise that will play at Giants Stadium, a league official said.

title: Polonia Returns To Yanks Again
description: Luis Polonia was in the backseat of a limousine heading from Newark Airport to a hotel in midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon and trying to figure out the best way to celebrate his third return to the Yankees.

title: A Doctor Says He Can Cure His Party's Ills
description: THE doctor will see you now. So will the only undisputed homegrown Democratic candidate for United States senator from New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTMAN, JULES I.
description: LICHTMAN-Jules I., 84. Of West Orange, NJ, and Palm Beach, FL. on August 1, 2000. Loving husband of Shirley (nee Kay). Devoted father of Dorothy, Kay, Jane and John and Barbara Lichtman. Dear brother of the late Cecil. Cherished grandfather of Jason, Maggie, Colby, John Daniel and Victor. Adored great grandfather of Julia. President of J. Lichtman and Sons and The Lichtman Foundation. Funeral service Thursday, August 3, 2000 at 12PM at Oheb Shalom Congregation in South Orange, NJ. Interment Oheb Shalom Cemetery, Hillside, NJ. Donations may be made to St. Barnabas Development Foundation, 94 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 07039.

title: Priceline.com Is Selling a $190 Million Stake to Two Investors
description: In a deal as complex as his patented method of selling airplane tickets, Jay S. Walker, the founder of Priceline.com , agreed yesterday to sell $190 million of his shares to Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Ventures and John C. Malone's Liberty Media Group .

title: U.S. Sergeant Gets Life in Murder of Kosovo Girl
description: BERLIN, Aug. 1  A United States military court in Germany sentenced an American soldier today to life in prison without parole for the murder of an 11-year-old Kosovo Albanian girl.

title: General Motors Raises Stakes in Fuel Economy War with Ford
description: General Motors challenged Ford today to a battle over which company can deliver bigger improvements in fuel economy, particularly for sport utility vehicles, the least efficient vehicles of all.

description: It is your decision, America.

description: To the Editor:

title: Speakers Being Given Absolute Freedom to Stick to the Script
description: Like nearly all the speakers who have taken the sprawling and colorful stage at the Republican convention here, Melissa Hart, a candidate for Congress from Pennsylvania, made sure to submit an early draft of her remarks to aides to Gov. George W. Bush for review and approval.

title: South Africa Veils Crime Data, Faulting System
description: South Africa's minister of safety and security has ordered an indefinite moratorium on the release of crime statistics, saying the system for collecting such information here in one of the world's most crime-plagued countries is flawed and unreliable.

title: Mrs. Clinton Criticizes Lazio on 'Multiple Choice' Abortion Stance
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton received the endorsement of Planned Parenthood today and used the occasion to exhaustively criticize her Senate opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, for his position on abortion and for what she implied was his petulant reaction to her attacks.

title: A Sliver of Paradise Blooms in Harlem
description: ANCIENT Persia with a touch of jazz has sprung to life at the new Malcolm X Plaza in Manhattan, where there are paving stones in Islamic geometric patterns, flowers that once bloomed in Persian gardens and a grove of trees in the middle of what used to be concrete and asphalt. (If the city art commission approves, there will also someday be green Art Deco-style benches that hark back to the Harlem Renaissance.)

description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Vows Gain On Gas Mileage
description: General Motors challenged Ford to a battle over which company can deliver bigger improvements in fuel economy, particularly for sport utility vehicles.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about prisoners' access to the Internet misstated the surname of a woman who discovered that her father's killer uses a Web site to seek pen pals. She is Jennifer Johnson Martinez, not Lopez. The article also misstated the given name of an Arizona legislator who sponsored a bill prohibiting inmates from using third-party Internet services. She is Jean McGrath, not Jane.

title: Ford in Talks to Build a Small Car in China
description: The Ford Motor Company is deep in negotiations with the Changan Automobile Group to build an affordable passenger car in China, the latest in a series of signs that the country is loosening its grip on the auto industry ahead of its expected entry into the World Trade Organization later this year.

title: U.S. to Investigate 21 Deaths Tied to Tires on Sport Utilities
description: A federal agency said today that it was investigating 21 deaths in crashes of sport utility vehicles that may have occurred because the tires disintegrated.

title: Former Champion Next In Judah's Drive to Top
description: The limousine stopped, and Zab Judah stepped out. It was time for work.

title: Mayor Favors Plans to Ease Housing Shortage
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed yesterday that more must be done to relieve New York's housing shortage, and he promised to explore proposals from three prominent politicians for major new subsidized construction.

title: A Center With a Song in Her Heart
description: Tari Phillips spun her head from side to side, whipping her four pigtails behind her as she launched into song:

title: Sports of The Times; The Orioles Pack Up The U-Haul
description: MIKE BORDICK was the first to go. He was sent away last Friday. Mike Timlin followed him out the door the next day, and so did Charles Johnson and Harold Baines. Last Monday Will Clark and B. J. Surhoff joined them. In 75 hours, a long weekend, the Baltimore Orioles chopped 74 years of major league service from their roster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ALEX
description: SMITH-Alex. On August 1, 2000, peacefully at home at the age of 94 years. Husband of Marsha. Father of Judith. Grandfather of Matthew, and younger brother of Eva now 97. Services will be held Thursday, August 3 at 10AM at the Sigmund Schwartz Gramercy Chapels, Second Ave and 10th St.

title: Once-Towering Figure Is Focus of Irish Inquiry
description: Each weekday morning, he is chauffeured in a pale blue Mercedes to the doors of Dublin Castle. It would seem a fitting mode of travel for a former prime minister of Ireland, a man of regal bearing whose very face, with those hooded eyelids and that dramatic sweep of silvery hair, is as identifiable in this country as the castle itself.

title: New-Home Sales Fell in June; Other Economic Signs Mixed
description: Sales of new homes fell in June to the lowest level in two and a half years as a rise in borrowing costs engineered by the Federal Reserve made it more expensive for people to buy, government figures showed today.

title: Online Privacy Move Raises New Antitrust Concerns for Microsoft
description: August 3, 2000

title: GLOBAL CROSSING BEATS ESTIMATES
description: Shares in Global Crossing Ltd. soared more than 12 percent yesterday after it said its second-quarter cash flow exceeded expectations. Although the company's $365.4 million quarterly loss was also larger than expected, Global Crossing added $2.5625, to $27.875, in trading yesterday. Cash flow at Global Crossing, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, was $1.415 billion, compared with the $1.295 billion forecast. Global Crossing's chief executive, Leo J. Hindery Jr. told analysts that the company now views its previous estimates of cash flow and sales for 2000 as ''understated'' as it presses forward with plans to make nearly all of its fiber optic cable systems around the world operational by next year. Simon Romero

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AVADO BRANDS, Madison, Ga., named Ronald N. Magruder chief executive at its Hops Restaurant Bar Brewery brand, succeeding Tom Schelldorf, who left.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: H & R BLOCK INC., Kansas City, Mo., a preparer of income tax returns and related services, said it was changing its logo and would put the branding name of H & R Block Financial Advisors on many of its business units as it tries to emphasize its transition from a tax preparer to a financial services company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LITE, ARLENE
description: LITE-Arlene. Today is your birthday, your memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Your husband and childre

title: FIRST AMERICAN AND TRANSAMERICA FORM PARTNERSHIP
description: The First American Corporation, the biggest United States title insurer, said yesterday that it had formed a partnership with Intellitech, Transamerica's real estate information unit, to create the largest property database in the nation. Transamerica, a subsidiary of Aegon N.V., the No. 2 Dutch insurer, will receive $22.5 million from First American and a 20 percent stake in the partnership. First American, based in Santa Ana, Calif., said the venture would have annual revenue exceeding $100 million, and contain information on more than 85 percent of property sales and mortgage-financing transactions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ELAINE
description: ROBBINS-Elaine. Beloved wife of Morris. Cherished mother of Gale Narva (Ken) and Debra Flatow (Paul). Devoted sister of Marty Farber (Neila) and Toby Monfred. Adored grandmother of Sylvie, Max, Carly, Jennifer and Rachel. Loving aunt to her nieces and nephews. Devoted friend to many. Tender, kind and spirited, she will live in our hearts forever. Services are at Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon, N.Y. Friday, August 4 at 12 noon. Donations to Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Design as a Growth Business
description: Most window boxes span one window. I-Beam, a Manhattan design firm, has an indoor window box that runs 41 feet beneath 11 windows. In the fall it is planted with sod, above. (Who mows it?) In summer, it holds basil, petunias and impatiens. Suzan Wines and Azin Valy, the partners in the firm, set up their office in a 500-square-foot loft on West 29th Street in 1998 and discovered that the space was so bright they could garden indoors. Ms. Valy designed the planter box (actually 10 contiguous boxes) and wood cabinets, which hide radiators and provide storage. The plexiglass planter boxes are 4 1/2 inches deep and extend 16 inches into the room. The cost for the cabinets, planter boxes, soil and seeds was around $4,300. Growing basil for pesto costs almost nothing.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Showy Matron

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Delays an Execution

title: For Mac Users, Help From an Unlikely Quarter
description: IT'S never easy living as a Mac user in a Windows world, but it is a lot easier than it used to be. Microsoft, maker of Windows, was once thought to be Apple's greatest enemy. I will admit to referring to Microsoft as ''the Borg'' (taken from the dominating alien race on ''Star Trek: The Next Generation'') in those dark days of '97 when Apple's future looked shaky. But then things got better.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week
