description: Judge Sets F.B.I. E-Mail Scanning Disclosure

title: Going Online To See Bus Systems (Not System Buses)
description: W. E. Moore started one of the earliest public transportation lines in Britain in 1815, with three donkeys and a cart. The company first delivered packages in an area centered around the English town of Colchester and started carrying people around 1865. Horse-drawn passenger service started in 1881, and a Clarkson steam passenger bus began running in 1914. The company lasted more than 150 years and was eventually purchased in 1963.

title: Driver of Runaway City Bus Says He Blacked Out
description: A 25-year-old bus driver who lost control of his bus on 34th Street Tuesday night, seriously injuring a traffic enforcement agent and smashing into a building, told the police that he blacked out shortly after he pulled the bus away from a stop near Ninth Avenue, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEASON, REV. WILLIAM JOHN, S.J.
description: GLEASON-Rev. William John, S.J. Dear uncle of Joseph and Geraldine Kennedy, Jeanne Donovan and Tricia Killip. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road, Bronx. Visitation Thursday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Murray Weigel Hall Chapel Friday 11:30AM. For information contact Farenga Brothers, Inc. Directors 718-654-0500

title: Metro Business; Mortgage Lender Cuts Jobs
description: Delta Financial Corporation, a subprime mortgage lender based in Woodbury, N.Y., announced yesterday that it would cut its staff by about 17 percent, or about 200 people, in an effort to improve its cash flow during a slump in the subprime industry. The company has come under increasing scrutiny from regulators in recent months because of its lending practices.

title: 'Evidence' and an Alibi
description: To the Editor:

title: Andres Martinez Named Times Editorial Writer
description: Andres Martinez, an editorial writer for The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, has joined The New York Times as an editorial writer. His appointment to the editorial board was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, the editorial page editor.

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Are on the Defensive Ahead of Employment Report
description: The Nasdaq stock market stumbled yesterday as skittish investors sought safety in blue chip stocks or headed for the sidelines waiting for Friday's report on the job market in July.

title: Anarchists of the World, Unite in Your Literary Roots!
description: The appearance of some self-proclaimed anarchists among the protesters at the Republican convention is tantalizing but perplexing. With radical effusions so out of style, what are we to make of these figures from beyond the fringe? They summon us back to a time and place when anarchists were taken seriously, Russia in the 19th century, and to the great novelists who grappled with the phenomenon.

title: After 'Sensation' Furor, Museum Group Adopts Guidelines on Sponsors
description: Responding to criticism over the financing of last year's ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and shows like it, the American Association of Museums announced yesterday that it had adopted new ethical guidelines on how museums should oversee displays of art borrowed from private collections.

title: On Avenue C, Renewal and Regret
description: WHEN the Scottish movie ''Trainspotting,'' about young heroin addicts, hit theaters in 1996, some critics called it an advertisement for drug use. But for the residents of 713 East Ninth Street, just east of Avenue C, the film was an opportunity.

title: As Games Rivet TV Networks, Cable Upstarts Sail Into Drama; FX, MTV, and Others Add Original Films and Series
description: FX is one of those cable networks that many channel surfers glide past because it offers reruns of enduring hits like ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' ''The X-Files'' and ''Married with Children.''

title: STRONG GAINS AT ALLIED IRISH BANKS
description: Ireland's largest bank, Allied Irish Banks, reported a 12 percent increase in first-half earnings to 480 million Irish pounds, or $562 million, on the strength of its business in the booming domestic economy and demand for financial services in Poland, where the bank has significant operations through its ownership of Bank Zachodni. But a cloud hangs over the bank because of an inquiry by Ireland's tax authorities into whether it owes taxes on bogus nonresident accounts, which analysts speculate could exceed 100 million Irish pounds, or $117 million. Brian Lavery

title: Romance Leavened With Highbrow Folklore
description: Afro-Peruvian music, which imported older African rhythms into Spanish and Andean song, became popular all over Peru during the 1970's and 80's, when many South American countries were discovering their cultural roots. By the mid-90's it even crept into highbrow American musical culture, via the album ''The Soul of Black Peru,'' an anthology put together by the Luaka Bop label. Susana Baca, one singer featured on that collection, has since gained a small but deep American art-music following through a few American-released Luaka Bop albums that have stripped down her music to its rhythmic-melodic essentials and added guest musicians from the jazz and rock worlds like Marc Ribot and John Medeski.

title: All the Comforts of Dome
description: ''6,000 Years of Housing'' was first published in 1981, but a new edition, published last month, has added the 20th century to the discussions of ancient huts and yurts. The book, by Norbert Schoenauer, an emeritus professor of architecture at McGill University, notes that many primitive cultures built dome-shaped structures of leaves, bark, mats or skins. ''There are no vertical walls, windows or smoke holes, but only an entranceway without a door,'' he said. For today's cities, he urges a mixture of single-family homes, high-rise apartments and buildings sized in between. (W. W. Norton, $50.)

title: Giants and the Jets Decide to Cancel Their Joint Practice
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel said this morning that he had called Jets Coach Al Groh and canceled the joint practice scheduled between the teams Tuesday at West Point.

title: Adviser to Some Hollywood Stars Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: The money manager who promised Hollywood stars and other artists a safe investment haven pleaded guilty yesterday to fraud and admitted to misappropriating some of his clients' funds.

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend on Friday about the Absolute Ensemble's concert at Joe's Pub in the East Village misidentified the bassoon soloist in Michael Daugherty's ''Dead Elvis.'' He was Martin Kuuskmann; David Rozenblatt was the drummer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUN, HELEN S.
description: HEILBRUN-Helen S. August 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Norman Heilbrun and the late Morten E. Kapp. Devoted mother of Barbara (Paul Mitarachi) Kapp, Roberta (William) Harris and Peter (Robyn) Heilbrun. Loving grandmother of Andrew (Lori), Stuart (Constance) and Jeffrey Kapp, Marta Heilbrun, Sarah Kate Heilbrun, David Harris and Benjamin (Hillary) Harris. Loving greatgrandmother of McKenzie Kapp and Crosby Kapp. Loving sister of Joseph Simons. A memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family with date and time to be announced later this year. In lieu of flowers donations to Temple Beth Zion or Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra. Amherst Memorial Chapel, Inc.

title: Genome of Cholera-Causing Microbe Is Decoded
description: The genome of the bacterium that causes cholera has been decoded, paving the way for devising better vaccines and drugs against a major killer, which has caused seven pandemics since 1817.

title: Parched U.S. Faces Worst Year for Fires Since Mid-80's
description: Prolonged hot and dry weather this summer, especially in the West, has made this the worst year since the mid-1980's for wildfires around the country. And with no major meteorological changes in sight, many more fires are expected before temperatures drop in the fall.

title: Toilets That Work
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Illustrated-Book Publishers Are Combining
description: Harry N. Abrams Inc. agreed to pay about $6 million to acquire the assets of Stewart, Tabori & Chang, combining two prominent publishers of illustrated books.

title: Russia Trying To Get Assets Of Top Critic
description: A senior Russian official said today that the government-controlled company Gazprom is in negotiations to acquire the entire media empire of Vladimir V. Gusinsky, the Kremlin's most outspoken critic.

title: Cheney on Bush: 'He's a Man Without Pretense, Without Cynicism'
description: Following is the acceptance speech of Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, as delivered last night at his party's convention and recorded by The New York Times:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Taking Some Favorites Back Indoors
description: After opening the 34th season of the Mostly Mozart Festival with a free outdoor concert on Monday at Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park, the conductor Gerard Schwarz took the festival orchestra back to its traditional indoor site, Avery Fisher Hall, to begin the season proper with a sold-out gala concert on Tuesday night. Two of the works, Mozart's ''Prague'' Symphony and the overture to Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' were repeated from Monday's concert. Playing outside in the thick humidity with heavy amplification must have taken a toll, for the orchestra's performances of those two works in the hall were somewhat careless and poorly balanced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREED, ANNIE R.
description: CREED-Annie R. At the age of 36. Beloved daughter of John F. and Anne M. Creed. Memorial Mass 2PM, today, August 3, at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Annie may be made to the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: DYNEGY IS ACQUIRING EXTANT FOR $152.5 MILLION
description: Dynegy Inc. of Houston, one of the largest American energy traders, agreed to acquire the closely held Extant Inc. for $152.5 million in cash and stock to begin selling space on high-speed fiber optic lines to telecommunications companies. Dynegy will pay 1.25 million common shares and $60 million in cash. Extant, based in Aurora, Colo., is developing a fiber optic network and software that allows telephone, Internet and cable TV providers to link and exchange data.

title: STRONG GROWTH AT BALTIMORE TECHNOLOGIES
description: A leading Irish developer of encryption software, Baltimore Technologies P.L.C., reported higher-than-expected revenue of $38.5 million and a smaller-than-expected loss of $6.6 million for the first half of the year. The results at the company, which is closely watched as a developer of Internet security for financial transactions, suggested it was far closer to profitability than had been thought, and its shares rose $2, to $21.3125, on the Nasdaq market. Software license sales, an indicator of the company's foothold in the market, were up 500 percent and accounted for more than half of revenue.

title: Gap Net Falls Short of Revised Estimate
description: Gap Inc. said today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings missed already lowered forecasts because July sales were almost unchanged at Banana Republic and fell at Old Navy stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEMLER, ANNE F.
description: SHEMLER-Anne F. On August 2. At the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Howard and Linda Beth. Motherin-law of Christl and Ken. Devoted grandmother of Briana, Alex, David and Stephen. She was a world class bridge player with a life masters ranking. Service Friday, 10:00 AM at Riverside, 21 W. Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Two Charged in '99 Stabbing Death of Student in Brooklyn
description: In a murder case that drew national attention but seemed to be growing colder by the month, the police have charged two men with the fatal stabbing of Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old graduate student, on a Brooklyn street a year and a half ago.

title: Cell Phones and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution Foes Dealt a Defeat In Kansas Vote
description: Voters in Kansas have repudiated the state school board's removal of human evolution from the state science standards, making it all but certain that the decision will be overturned.

title: Israeli Foreign Minister Quits as Opposition to Barak Rises
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak took another battering today in the wake of the Camp David summit meeting when his foreign minister resigned over Mr. Barak's willingness to compromise with the Palestinians on Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINSSER, BARBARA L. (MRS. HANS)
description: ZINSSER-Barbara L. (Mrs. Hans). The Trustees of Robert College of Istanbul honor the life of their friend and colleague, Barbara Zinsser, and express their sadness at her death. As an active member of the Board for 45 years her insightful mind and her willingness to approach all problems in a constructive way provided invaluable guidance to the College and the Board. She will be greatly missed. The Trustees extend their deepest condolences to her daughter, Leslie Armstrong, and her family.

title: Mr. Bush's Next Speech
description: When Gov. George W. Bush addresses the Republican Convention tonight, in the most important speech of his career, he will face an oddly difficult challenge of his own making. For four days Philadelphia has echoed with uplifting talk about diversity, inclusion, family values and ''compassion.'' Last night the vice-presidential nominee, Richard B. Cheney, added a strong dose of partisan combativeness by turning Vice President Al Gore's 1992 attack line -- ''It's time for them to go'' -- back on the Democrats. But what is still missing is any discussion of the specific policies and programs that Mr. Bush intends to present to the country. Even Republican policies that the delegates hold dear -- tax cuts, distrust of government, privatizing Social Security -- have scarcely received mention from the podium. Mr. Bush's task tonight is to go beyond broad themes and begin to add some substance to this campaign.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

description: KIRSCH-Aviva (nee Isobel Leader). On July 30th, 2000. Loving mother of Beth, Gabrielle and her husband Jim. Beloved daughter of Ruby and the late Sidney Leader. Dear sister of Steven and Barbara Leader. Devoted aunt of Jaclyn and Allison. Service Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Overlooked Royals Pitcher Makes Yankees Take Notice
description: The first time Blake Stein visited Yankee Stadium two years ago, he kept his jacket on while he sat nervously in the bullpen because he did not want any raucous fans to see the name on his Oakland Athletics uniform. Some of Stein's teammates warned him that the fans would orally harass him if they found out who he was, so Stein kept his jacket buttoned and tried to remain anonymous.

title: ONLINE DEBT MARKET TO BE SET UP
description: Bear Stearns, Credit Suisse First Boston, Lehman Brothers and Salomon Smith Barney said yesterday that they would start a new company to build an electronic trading system for mortgage and other asset-backed securities. The system, to be introduced late this year or by early 2001, is intended to increase liquidity and cut costs for institutions trading mortgage and asset-backed securities. Robert Hurtado

title: More Jobs in Construction Sought for Minority Workers
description: New York City's building trade unions have struck an unusual agreement with a private developer to give at least 10 percent of new construction apprenticeships to graduates of the city's vocational high schools, officials said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Sci-Fi Film Fest in a Setting That's Slightly Bent
description: At most film festivals, the movies are new and the theaters old. But for the Sci Fi Channel's ''Exposure: Future of Film Festival,'' tomorrow through Sunday, a Manhattan design firm called Big Room transformed space at 135 West 18th Street into four new temporary theaters, including Matrix, rendered below, which has 100 seats and a grid of luminescent wires. ''It looks like a digital landscape,'' said Julian LaVerdiere, a partner in Big Room. The festival will have 31 new and classic science fiction films, including ''Trekkies,'' and 73 shorts. Movies will also be shown at the Chelsea Clearview, 260 West 23rd Street. Filmschool (FLMSCL), a film festival producer, organized the event. Tickets are $5 daily, or $12 for all three days. Information: (212) 413-5878, or www.exposurefest.com.

description: President Clinton today delayed what would have been the first federal execution in nearly 40 years as the Justice Department issued new clemency procedures for inmates on federal death row.

description: Q. I am a computer novice and would like to sell items on the eBay auction site. How do I add pictures of the items I wish to sell?

description: AS manufacturers of wireless phones, handheld computers and other Internet gadgets scramble to make Web information accessible without the need to boot up a computer, some companies have a different plan. They are adapting the Web to the one device that virtually everyone has: the telephone.

title: A New Caveat for eBay Users: Seller Beware; Putting Your Family Heirlooms Up for Bids May Make You a Target for Credit Card Fraud
description: CONNIE BACON, a regular seller on eBay, thought that she had brokered an excellent deal. On behalf of a consignment shop in Charleston, S.C., she had sold a Rolex watch for $13,500 in an online auction, and everything had gone smoothly.

title: Don Weis, 78, Film and Television Director
description: Don Weis, an award-winning director whose long career embraced both film and television, died on July 26 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 78.

title: Plunging Ratings Touch Off Debate on Why Public Is Losing Interest
description: In 1984, ABC shocked news purists by inserting a rerun of a canceled series, ''Hart to Hart,'' in the middle of one night's convention coverage. The same year an ABC News executive, Jeff Gralnick, labeled the conventions ''dying dinosaurs.''

title: Pinochet Reportedly Stripped of Immunity in Secret Court Vote
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 1  The Chilean Supreme Court voted in secret today to strip Gen. Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity, according to local radio and web site accounts. The decision would remove the last legal obstacle to a full-scale criminal investigation of the former dictator and would permit his trial on charges of kidnapping, murder and torture.

title: The Commonplace, Ennobled by the Needle's Touch
description: American women have long applied fine needlepoint to pillows, tapestries and patchwork quilts. But a new trend arose at the 1876 Centennial in Philadelphia: the embroidery of everyday items like doilies, dresser scarves and dish towels. Patterns showing birds, flowers and the like were usually from magazines like Harper's Bazar (as it was then spelled), said Deborah Harding, the author of ''Red and White: American Redwork Quilts'' (Rizzoli, $39.95). The designs also found their way onto quilts, above, and were embroidered in red because the most colorfast thread of the time was red: Turkey red.

title: Now Yelling at Your PC Can Actually Be Useful
description: Frustrated Web surfers who yell at the computer when they can't find something online now have a little friend who won't take it personally. One Voice Technologies has just released IVAN, a voice-activated onscreen servant of sorts, who never loses his cool.

title: Protest Against Farm Squatters Stops Zimbabwe
description: The parliamentary elections are over, but in the rustling fields, black squatters are still occupying a thousand white-owned farms. And even the governing party acknowledges that ''criminal elements'' have been causing havoc on some farms.

title: Essay; The G.O.P.'s Conventional Wisdom
description: The purpose of a political convention used to be to select a presidential candidate. That ended a generation ago, but three other purposes remained:

title: An Ugly Move by Big Tobacco
description: The World Health Organization has issued a report detailing an ambitious, often covert effort by the tobacco industry to curb global anti-smoking initiatives, dating back to the late 1980's. The campaign's strategy consisted of having ostensibly independent surrogates attack the credibility of international health organizations and spin the concern with smoking as a first-world issue not worthy of the developing world's attention.

description: A Texas jury has found that a New York lawyer defrauded several hundred relatives of a 19th-century priest more than six decades ago and now owes them millions of dollars in oil royalties and interest, according to a decision announced today in Brownsville.

title: China Blocks Chen's Effort to Compete for the U.S.
description: Eight years after she won the first Olympic race-walking competition for women as a Chinese athlete, Yueling Chen hoped to win another medal, this time as a United States citizen, at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.

title: Software Tells Wireless E-Mail To Please Get to the Point
description: Long e-mail messages are rarely welcome by busy computer users. But they can be almost unbearable when viewed through the tiny screens of wireless gadgets.

description: Representative Rick A. Lazio returned to New York yesterday from the Republican National Convention, and, among other stops, appeared on the radio talk show of Bob Grant, who once drew criticism for derogatory remarks about blacks and Hispanics.

description: ADASKO-Mary Hardy on July 29. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Isaac. Loving mother of Herbert Hardy Adasko and the late Laura Adasko Lenzner. Chopey, 501 East 79 Street, Apt 5E, New York, New York 10021.

title: Power From the People Breaks the Hold of Batteries and Plugs
description: WHILE living in Iowa two years ago, I saw the sky turn green. A number of events rapidly followed: the tornado sirens blared, my husband and I took shelter downstairs, and the Weather Channel visuals blipped off the television set. Then the electricity went out, and I frantically wondered if I had remembered to recharge the radio's batteries so we could monitor the tornado's movement.

description: MUSICAL lyrics, perhaps more than most art forms, range from the inspiring to the inane. With an eye on the latter, lyric generators have turned up on the Web, supplying characteristic lyrics for songs in the musical genre of your choice.

title: More Spraying as More Infected Birds and Mosquitoes Turn Up
description: The number of birds and mosquitoes testing positive for West Nile virus in New York State is accelerating rapidly, state health officials reported yesterday, in a finding that is inspiring yet more rounds of pesticide spraying in New York City, Suffolk County and other areas.

description: GETZOFF-Seymour. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Seymour Getzoff, beloved father of Susan Kouffman. We extend our deepest condolences to Susan and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENNIS, BRUCE J.
description: ENNIS-Bruce J. The American Civil Liberties Union mourns the passing of Bruce J. Ennis, former Legal Director of the ACLU and a longtime friend and colleague. Bruce devoted his career to defending the rights of the most vulnerable among us, serving as the NYCLU's first Director of the Mental Patients' Rights Project and the first lawyer in the country to work full time on the rights of the mentally ill. After entering private practice in the 1980's, Bruce was one of the few, elite lawyers who argued frequently before the U.S. Supreme Court. In 1997 he successfully argued Reno v. ACLU, which established landmark protection for internet speech. He was a kind and generous mentor who will be missed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Harris Files Suit Against AOL Over Blocking of E-Mail
description: Harris Interactive Inc., the nation's largest online market research company, has filed a lawsuit against America Online and other e-mail service providers contending that those companies unlawfully blocked e-mail from Harris to its survey participants.

title: G.M. to Build Plant in Suburb Of Buffalo, Saving 600 Jobs
description: General Motors will build a $500 million high-tech engine manufacturing plant at its complex in the Buffalo suburb of Tonawanda, saving 600 well-paying jobs through the largest private-sector investment in western New York State in many years, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.

title: No Engine Parts Found on Concorde Flight Path
description: French investigators said yesterday that they had not found any engine parts in the trail of debris shed by an Air France Concorde on its brief flight before crashing near Charles de Gaulle Airport outside Paris on July 25.

title: Journalists Are Making Very Much Of a Little
description: Perhaps it was when the musician Kenny Gamble stepped to the microphone and yelled -- ''Peace, everybody!'' -- and then, dissatisfied with the lackluster response from the Republican delegates, forcefully added: ''Did you hear me? I said, peace!''

title: Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam, 92, Is Dead
description: Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam, a Holocaust survivor whose gentle charisma nurtured the exuberant postwar rebirth of the Bobov Hasidic sect in Brooklyn and around the world, died at Maimonides Medical Center yesterday after a long illness. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMANN, KERMIT S.
description: HABERMANN-Kermit S. Of Tamarac, FL, on August 1, 2000. Former executive in the metals industry. Beloved husband of Edna for 56 years; loving father of Glenn (Barbara), Jerry, and Elliott (Shari) Habermann; cherished grandfather of Brett, Jarrett, Jessica, Matthew, Rachael and Torrie. Services today August 3, 2000, 1:00 PM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Information 800-992-9262.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Public Lives page on July 25 about an appearance by Billy Joel at a master class at Southampton High School on Long Island misspelled the given name of a pianist who played songs by Mr. Joel. The pianist is Hyung-Ki Joo, not Hyuang-Ki.

title: Gods in Business Suits: Bayreuth's Updated 'Ring'
description: To a Bayreuth Festival torn between tradition and the call of modern times comes Jurgen Flimm's new production of the ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' Mr. Flimm, known to Germans as a theater, not an opera, director, brings to Wagner's weeklong tetralogy a kind of low-key iconoclasm. If the temple is not torn down, it is at least redecorated.

title: The Clock Is Ticking for the Class of 1998
description: Al Groh has a calendar. And if you read it carefully, you know the significance of the Jets' preseason game at Lambeau Field in Green Bay on Friday night for at least two of his players.

title: St. John's-Kentucky Game To Open Play
description: St. John's will start its season on Nov. 9 when it plays Kentucky at Madison Square Garden in the sixth annual Coaches vs. Cancer Classic.

title: Snapple Beverages hopes to see Mango Madness and Pink Lemonade catch on in candy form.
description: IN a critical report released last year, the Center for Science in the Public Interest referred to soft drinks as ''liquid candy.'' Now there's a minitrend toward producing what might be called solid soft drinks.

title: Rightist Shocks Canadians By Flirting With Separatists
description: Stockwell Day's summer vacation in Quebec was going well. Every day, the rising star of Canada's right appeared on French language television, chatting in francais with his language immersion teachers, fielding reporters' questions about his politique fiscale, or posing for photographs with the eternal friend of language students, le dictionnaire Larousse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDENBERG, SYLVIA
description: HEIDENBERG-Sylvia. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mrs. Sylvia Heidenberg, and esteemed member and extend to her family its deepest sympathy. Arthur I. Frankel, President Saul Friedland, Secretary

title: Split Develops On Leadership Of Sect in China
description: Falun Gong followers in Hong Kong and the United States are squabbling over assertions by a woman in the southern Chinese territory that she is the ''true master'' of the spiritual movement, having taken over from its founder, Li Hongzhi, who has dropped from view.

title: Watch Your Back, Harry Potter; A Wizardly Comuter Game, Diablo II, Is a Hot Seller
description: It came out just recently, a highly anticipated sequel to a best seller filled with stories of wizards and sorcerers. Revenue has topped $50 million so far, reviews have been good, and fans, who waited impatiently for their new heroes to arrive, are thrilled.

title: MODEL EFFICIENCY
description: Palm Inc. has announced its new celebrity-endorsed P.D.A. And what public intellectual did the company choose for this honor? Was it Stephen Hawking? No. Stephen Jay Gould? Close. The Palm Vx Claudia Schiffer Edition, named after the German runway model and actress, will go on sale in the fall. Buyers may also want to download www.utilware.com

title: All Over but the Clanging, And That's Quieter Lately
description: Composure was the last thing anyone wanted from Einsturzende Neubauten on Tuesday at Irving Plaza. Nonetheless, that's what this German band first offered. The sextet stood motionless, surrounded by its instruments, many fashioned from steel blades and industrial tools. Blixa Bargeld, the group's handsomely cadaverous singer, sucked smoke from his cigarette and sighed, ''Silence is sexy.'' Everyone paused. Then the clanging began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDINGER, EDITH MARKS
description: BALDINGER-Edith Marks. In her 101yr she died peacefully at home. Wife of the late Carl Marks and the late Irving Baldinger; Cherished Mother of Edwin and Nancy Marks, Marjorie Boas Levins and Jack Levins and the late Robert S. Boas; Loving Grandmother of Richard Boas, Susan and Mark Claster, Andrew and Carol Boas, Carolyn Marks Blackwood, Linda and Richard Katz, Constance Marks Miller and James Miller; And Loving ''G.G.'' to 13 great grandchildren, Daniel, Katherine, Gabriel, Matthew, Benjamin, Hallie, Bari, Rebecca, Esther, Jessie, Laura, Samuel and Sophia. Her family wishes to express deep gratitude to her devoted friend and caretaker, Gay Munroe. Edith was beloved, and a joy and inspiration to all who were blessed to know her. Funeral services will be held 11:30 AM Friday, August 4, 2000 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELMAN, DOUGLAS, M.D.
description: FOGELMAN-Douglas, M.D. NYU/ Bellevue Department of Psychiatry mourns with deep sadness the untimely loss of our colleague and friend, Douglas Fogelman, M.D. His commitment to knowledge, his work, students and patients will be rememered. Our condolences to his fiancee Laura and his family.

title: Detroit's Use of Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Tightens Rules on the Use of Recycled Medical Devices
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would begin requiring that recycled medical devices originally intended to be used only once meet the same regulatory standards that they did when manufactured.

title: Keeping Up With Mom and Dad and Their Elder-Care Provider
description: FOR adults with aging or infirm parents, determining what type of care their parents need can be a complicated, multilayered process. Several new sites, like AccentCare.com and CareThere.com, help families do that and even keep daily or weekly track of the care their relatives are receiving.

title: Scientists Warn of Inaction as AIDS Spreads in China
description: BEIJING  During all the years that Yang Zhiyin was selling his blood, he had never heard of AIDS. All he knew was that he was desperately poor, and selling blood on the black market was what farmers did in his village when they needed cash. For much of a decade, Mr. Yang said, he rolled up his sleeve to the blood dealer's needle "many many times."

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about tile in restaurant dining rooms omitted an architecture firm that designed Guastavino's along with Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates. It is Conran & Partners.

title: So That Tyrants Wont Rest, Haitians Keep a Vigil
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Every Wednesday, a crowd gathers in the Plaza of Martyrs here for a ritual as unsparing and inescapable as the brutal midday sun. They circle a statue of a slender man releasing a dove to the heavens hoping that their pleas, too, will rise above the din and indifference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, PAULA WATJEN
description: ROCKEFELLER-Paula Watjen. 94, died peacefully in her sleep on August 1, 2000 at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut. She was the daughter of the late A. Wilhelm and Katie F. Watjen of Bremen, Germany and New York. Wife of the late John Sterling Rockefeller and sister of the late Eduard H. Watjen of Ascona, Switzerland. She is survived by her sister, Alice Watjen, of Zurich, Switzerland; two daughters, Christina DuBois of Stockbridge, Massachusetts and Paula Greene of Leominster and London, England; six grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Services are to be held on Monday, August 7, 2000 at 3:00 P.M., St. Matthews Church, Bedford, New York. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to The Mianus Gorge Preserve, 167 Mianus Road, Bedford, New York, 10506.

title: Hotjobs Hands Account To Weiss Stagliano
description: Hotjobs.com, the job-search Web site, is awarding its creative assignment, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million, to Weiss Stagliano Partners in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DU MOULIN, ELEANOR C. (NEE LEWIS)
description: du MOULIN-Eleanor C. (nee Lewis). On August 1, 2000. Beloved wife of Edward du Moulin of 58 years. Loving mother of Cathy & Jerome Morea, Ann and Richard du Moulin. Adoring grandmother of Christopher, Douglas and Carrie Morea, Lora Ann, Edward, Matthew and Mark du Moulin. Devoted sister of Dorothy Garbowitz. Arrangements private. Memorial service Saturday, August 19 at Knickerbocker Yacht Club, 11 AM, 433 Main St., Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Francis Hospital, 100 Port Washington Boulevard, Roslyn, New York 11576, or Make-A-Wish Foundation, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, New York 11050, would be appreciated.

title: Alvin R. Tresselt, 83, Author; Wrote About Nature for Children
description: Alvin R. Tresselt, a children's book author who won praise for describing and explaining nature to the young, died on July 24 at his home in Burlington, Vt. He was 83.

title: Cousins Knows How to Rush, And Sell a Few Trailer Homes
description: Jomo Cousins remembers where he was when football season began a year ago.

title: Bullpen Stays Solid, Closing Out 8-1 Stand at Shea
description: Six weeks ago, John Franco was called into a tie game at Shea Stadium. He allowed one run, recorded one out and left with the bases loaded. Then Armando Benitez came in and gave up a grand slam. That was the last time either of those Mets pitchers allowed an earned run.

title: Internet in San Francisco Employs 40,000
description: Internet in San Francisco Employs 40,000

title: Workshops, Tours And Exhibitions
description: Photographing Gardens

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Landing Gear Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: A Confident Son of Politics Rises
description: Just six years ago, when George W. Bush ran for governor of Texas, even his parents expected him to lose.

title: Economic Scene; Market messes happen. And inefficiencies have consequences.
description: BACK in the 1970's, the efficient-markets hypothesis was an article of near religious faith. As an economics student, I certainly bought the argument whole. ''There is no other proposition in economics which has more solid empirical evidence supporting it,'' Michael Jensen, a leading proponent of this school of thought, concluded in 1978.

title: Democrats Rejoice in Unity After Torricelli's Withdrawal
description: Having outrun an attempt by Senator Robert G. Torricelli to sprint past him toward the Democratic nomination for New Jersey governor, Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge took a symbolic victory lap today at a news conference in Trenton, showing off the state and county party leaders who have rallied to his side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINES, NORMAN
description: REINES-Norman. Died 11:11PM, July 29, 2000 at home, Princeton, N.J. Age 67. Survivors are his wife, June, children, Francine, Alicia & Paul, grandchildren, Isabelle and Phoebe and late brother Harold and his family. We love you.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the sale of $190 million in Priceline.com shares to Liberty Media and Vulcan Ventures misidentified the seller. It was Jay S. Walker, the company's founder, not Priceline itself. A picture caption with the article misstated the location of Walker Digital, where Mr. Walker was shown. It is in Stamford, Conn., not Norwalk.

title: Beds, Baths And by Golly: 3 Stores Arrive
description: Over one month, three home furnishings stores -- Interieurs, Waterworks and Room -- will have opened in Manhattan, the first two because they outgrew their previous locations and the third because it wanted to be more than just a Miami shop with a catalog. ''One-third of our customers are in the New York, New Jersey, Connecticut area,'' said Amy Crain, near left, the owner of Room. Last week, her new 2,500-square-foot store, designed by S. Russell Groves, a Manhattan architect, opened at 182 Duane Street (Hudson Street). She designed the cream-colored Sophie sofa at rear ($3,400, plus fabric).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DJINGHEUCIAN, BETTY F.
description: DJINGHEUCIAN-Betty F. October 25, 1923-August 2, 2000. Beloved widow of Vahe. Sister of Flora and Martha. Aunt to Deborah and Edward L., Edward Fried, Allan, Philip and Robert and their wives and children. All our love and hopes for your eternal peace. Services will be held at Gramercy Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York City on August 4th at 1 P.M.

title: Chairman of Con Ed Blames Power Producers for Rise in Electric Bills
description: For customers in New York City and Westchester County, trying to get a candid explanation for a sharp increase in electricity rates has been a complicated game of who's to blame, with the parties involved pointing fingers at one another. The explanation was no less elusive yesterday as state legislators questioned regulators, power producers and Consolidated Edison.

title: On the Grand Day for Bush, American Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH-CHENEY TICKET NOMINATED AND THE ATTACKS ON GORE BEGIN
description: Burning to reclaim the White House after eight years on the outside, the Republican Party tonight nominated George Walker Bush for president and sent forth his running mate with the most stinging and unabashedly partisan assault of the convention.

title: Cell Phones and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Newpapers Sue Ad Agencies
description: The Hispanic Newspaper Network in Van Nuys, Calif., has filed a lawsuit seeking $1 billion in damages against two units of the WPP Group in New York -- Ogilvy & Mather and J. Walter Thompson -- and Young & Rubicam in New York, which agreed to be acquired by WPP in May.

title: A Sisterly Rivalry and Memories of a Spooky Death
description: DROWNING RUTH

title: Making Up Is Hard To Do
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Chelsea Piers, Where Grown-Ups Play, Too
description: With each stop, the final destination of the M23 bus became clearer. Some passengers got on with golf clubs, others with hockey sticks, a few with bowling balls. We were trundling to Chelsea Piers, the once-crumbling Hudson River docks that in 1995 opened as a self-proclaimed athletic paradise.

title: An Architect Eyes His Toughest Job
description: For four decades, Glen Sather has made this spectacular resort town his summer home. The Bull River flows lazily behind his backyard and the snow-capped Canadian Rockies try to touch a vast, blue sky that seems to have no horizon.

title: Hamstring Injury Can't Sideline Bailey
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 13.

title: Palestinian Summer: The Wrong Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Weis, 78, Film and Television Director
description: Don Weis, an award-winning director whose long career embraced both film and television, died on July 26 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 78.

title: European Antitrust Charges Levied Against Microsoft
description: August 4, 2000

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS IN WEB VENTURE
description: American Express and the Ventro Corporation announced that they would start an e-marketplace for business-to-business transactions. The joint venture, MarketMile, will promote online buying of products and services, a market that the two companies estimate at more than $1.4 trillion and one that is rapidly moving to the Internet. Since 1997, American Express, which will own 65 percent of the new company, has invested in an array of Internet start-ups, but MarketMile is the company's first standalone e-commerce start-up.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: E7TH.COM, New York, named Jay M. Margolis chairman and chief executive, succeeding Todd Ricci, who remains with the company as chief strategic officer. Mr. Margolis had been chief executive at Esprit de Corp.

title: Foreign Affairs; The World According To Bush
description: Give George W. Bush credit. He may still believe that the Greeks are Grecians. He may still leave the impression that he has not read the World section of the newspaper for the last 20 years. But it doesn't matter, and Al Gore is not going to be able to use W.'s global gap against him in this election.

title: Offering Up Good Cheer and the Humanist Values, All Rendered in Cliches
description: Judy Chicago's ''Resolutions: A Stitch in Time,'' an installation at the American Craft Museum, is an excellent candidate for worst New York museum show of the year. Ms. Chicago's first solo venture in New York since 1987 and first museum show since her famous ''Dinner Party'' installation was exhibited at the Brooklyn Museum 20 years ago, this show is aesthetically vacuous, conceptually inane and morally disingenuous.

title: Woman's Arrest Led to Brother as Suspect in '99 Murder
description: For 14 months after Amy Watkins died with a knife in her back on a tree-shaded sidewalk in Brooklyn, David Jamison managed to escape the notice of dozens of detectives hunting for her killer.

title: Finding Futility in Trying to Lay Blame in Killings
description: After their lives were changed by a 14-year-old slayer, the parents of the three girls he killed in a school shooting here sued more than 50 people who they said shared responsibility for the deaths.

title: Military Totals Its Costs
description: The cost to the Pentagon for sending an array of weapons and other military equipment for an exclusive viewing by members of Congress and their guests as they were gathering for the Republican National Convention is in at more than half a million dollars.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: You Hear That Sigh? It Sounds Like Relief
description: After the nominees had spoken and the themes of the Republican National Convention had coalesced on its final day -- we're not your grandma's Republican Party, let's wash the Clinton-Gore stain out of the White House, the sky's the limit -- the cable television pundits and Internet commentators seemed visibly relieved that they finally had a firm idea of the agenda they will be bickering about for the next three months.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, BERNIE
description: BARROW-Bernie. Gone seven long years. Forever in our hearts. Love, Joan and the children

title: Gore's List for a Running Mate Drops to 7 Names, Mostly Senators
description: Winding up a weeklong vacation by the sea, Vice President Al Gore said today that he had narrowed his list of potential running mates to six plus one ''wild card.''

title: As Precaution, 7 Power Users Cut Electrical Demand Briefly
description: The New York Power Authority called upon seven of its biggest customers in New York City to voluntarily reduce their electrical load today in preparation for hot, muggy weather, but later canceled the request after the day remained overcast and cool.

title: Sports of The Times; At Sydney, the First Toss Goes to the Women
description: LITTLE did Dawn Ellerbe know, when they handed her a strange metal contraption featuring a ball and a chain, that they were giving her a chance to be an Olympian.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Poor Crash Results for 2 Popular Cars
description: TWO of the nation's most popular new vehicles, the Chrysler PT Cruiser and Ford Focus ZX3, have fared badly in government crash tests.

title: When Life Is Ridiculous and You Are Living It
description: There is plenty of laughter in Marc Maron's ''Jerusalem Syndrome,'' but this unusual theatrical concoction by one of the leading practitioners of alternative comedy in New York City is not a joke. Ambiguity is expected of Mr. Maron: one reason he and a few like-minded comics adopted the label alternative in the mid-1990's was to signal audiences that they were not quick-laugh artists like most stand-up comics. Mr. Maron in particular has often explored fairly sophisticated ideas in sizzling exchanges with his audience. But ''Jerusalem Syndrome'' takes his approach into very different territory.

title: After a Long Process, Bush Gets to the Point With Words That Fit His Style
description: If it had been up to his speechwriter, Gov. George W. Bush would have opened his remarks tonight by thanking the delegates here for ''the honor of this hour.''

title: 'The Magic City'
description: Brent Sikkema

title: SUPERCONDUCTING PATENTS LICENSED
description: The Intermagnetics General Corporation said it had licensed a portfolio of 120 patents and pending patents for superconducting materials and devices from Lucent Technologies. The deal clears the way for Intermagnetics to try to develop superconducting products for the utility industry using yttrium barium copper oxide, a ceramic compound developed by Lucent. Yttrium compounds are among the most promising in the field of new materials that lose all resistance to electricity when cooled by liquid nitrogen. Intermagnetics shares rose $1.9325, to $15.25. Barnaby J. Feder

title: BUSH, ACCEPTING G.O.P. NOMINATION, PLEDGES TO 'USE THESE GOOD TIMES FOR GREAT GOALS'
description: Introducing himself to a nation that barely knows him, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas pledged tonight to ''confront the hard issues -- threats to our national security, threats to our health and retirement security'' that he said the Clinton administration had consistently ducked.

title: Gill Poised to Leave the Nets and Join the Lakers
description: The Nets' quandary at shooting guard may soon escalate from bad to horrible. Kendall Gill, the club's most versatile player and obvious replacement for the injured Kerry Kittles, is close to joining the Los Angeles Lakers, an official with an Eastern Conference team said.

title: Befuddled By Offense, Giants Play Catch-Up
description: On the first night of Giants training camp last month, the offensive coordinator, Sean Payton, handed out the diagrams of 45 new plays and told his players to memorize them. On just about every night since, Payton has tacked on 15 to 20 additional plays.

title: Glaucoma Drug Approved
description: Novartis A.G. said today that its new glaucoma drug, Rescula, won Food and Drug Administration approval. Glaucoma, or high eye pressure, affects about four million people in the United States and five million in Europe, Novartis, based in Basel, Switzerland, said. The company has also asked European authorities to approve the drug. Rescula would compete with Xalatan, the world's top-selling glaucoma treatment, which is produced by the Pharmacia Corporation and had $507 million in 1999 sales.

title: Judge Voids Law Certifying Kosher Food
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has struck down New York State's century-old kosher food laws, saying that their requirement that such food be prepared according to Orthodox Jewish law violated the Constitution's First Amendment prohibition on religious involvement by the state.

title: A Prewar Beauty? Oh, the Thrill of the Chase
description: SEX AND REAL ESTATE

title: Out of Sight, a Scientist Is Also Out of His Mind
description: The beginning of ''Hollow Man'' is witty enough. An innocent rat skitters along the floor of an apparently empty steel cage toward a dish of water, only to be snatched up and devoured by an unseen predator, whose voracious maw is outlined in the hapless rodent's blood while the rest remains invisible. Cut to Kevin Bacon in his apartment, burning the midnight oil in front of his computer. He stops to do to a Hostess Twinkie what the spectral animal (who turns out to be a gorilla named Isabelle) has just done to the rat, and then his computer screen, which has been performing some kind of 3-D molecular modeling, flashes a dire warning: ''STATUS: UNSTABLE.''

title: Baby Hurt After Falling From Car and Being Hit
description: A mother backing up her car in a town house complex here struck her 16-month-old baby Wednesday in an accident that seemed to turn on a bizarre confluence of missteps, the police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, NAT
description: SMALL-Nat. Husband of Shirley, father of Edward and Steven, died July 15 in Florida. Memorial service at Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, Sunday, August 6, 3 PM.

title: Public Interests; Under the Big Tent
description: What can you say about a Republican Convention that spends as much time talking about AIDS as abortion, and frets more about urban blight than gun control? That it's a changed party? A conflicted party? A sneakier party?

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; White Outfits, Black Balls and That Perfectly Green Grass
description: All that stood between me and victory was 90 feet of immaculate green grass. At the far end, a cluster of black balls huddled around my target: the jack, a white ball the size and shape of a cue ball. To win, I had to curve my ball through the globes and nudge the jack. Misjudge it by more than an inch and I'd lose. I might as well have been trying to sink a putt from the rough with a broomstick.

title: Voices of Experience, Rocketing to the Rescue
description: ''Space Cowboys'' begins in 1958, with jaunty western guitar music on the soundtrack and black-and-white vistas of the big sky and empty land around Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert. The first scenes follow the adventures of a group of reckless young pilots who crash their expensive military plane, bicker and fight among themselves and lose the chance to be the first Americans in space to a chimpanzee named Mary Ann and a new civilian agency called NASA.

title: It Seemed Like a Perfect Match, at First
description: If nothing else, the television movie ''One Kill'' offers the most unusual language of love.

title: PROFIT GROWS AT GOLD FIELDS LTD.
description: Helped by improved efficiency at its mines and a decline in the value of the South African rand, Gold Fields Ltd., the world's third-largest producer of gold, reported that quarterly profits more than tripled to 370 million rand, or $53 million. The performance was considered especially strong in light of the languishing price of gold. Gold Fields has agreed to merge with the Franco-Nevada Mining Corporation of Canada and move its primary stock listing from Johannesburg to Toronto, but the merger has yet to be approved by South Africa.

title: Novartis Ended Use of Gene-Altered Foods
description: Novartis A.G., one of the world's leading agricultural biotechnology companies, acknowledged yesterday that it had eliminated genetically engineered ingredients from all of its food products.

title: A Play That Long Wanted to Be a Movie
description: When ''Psycho Beach Party,'' Charles Busch's raucous theatrical spoof of ''Gidget,'' ''Beach Party'' movies and teen slasher films, opened Off Broadway in 1987, it hilariously upended constricting notions of ''normal'' teenage American life peddled by Hollywood in the 1950's and early 60's. The only frustration was that while Mr. Busch's hilarious trivia-savvy script was obviously meant to be a movie, the fun could be enjoyed only on the stage.

title: 2 Texans, Not 1
description: Republicans have chosen a ticket that seems certain to win one state -- Texas -- almost effortlessly. But at the December balloting of the Electoral College, could the Texas electors really vote for both George W. Bush and Dick Cheney? They will have to ask themselves where Mr. Cheney is an ''inhabitant.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDINGER, EDITH MARKS
description: BALDINGER-Edith Marks. In her 101yr she died peacefully at home. Wife of the late Carl Marks and the late Irving Baldinger; Cherished Mother of Edwin and Nancy Marks, Marjorie Boas Levins and Jack Levins and the late Robert S. Boas; Loving Grandmother of Richard Boas, Susan and Mark Claster, Andrew and Carol Boas, Carolyn Marks Blackwood, Linda and Richard Katz, Constance Marks Miller and James Miller; And Loving ''G.G.'' to 13 great grandchildren, Daniel, Katherine, Gabriel, Matthew, Benjamin, Hallie, Bari, Rebecca, Esther, Jessie, Laura, Samuel and Sophia. Her family wishes to express deep gratitude to her devoted friend and caretaker, Gay Munroe. Edith was beloved, and a joy and inspiration to all who were blessed to know her. Funeral services will be held 11:30 AM Friday, August 4, 2000 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: Racial Gap in Schools Splits A Town Proud of Diversity
description: Set above the leafy banks of the Hudson River, this cluster of villages north of New York City has long cultivated a reputation as an idyll of diversity and tolerance. Blacks and whites mingle easily in the shops lining the quaint main street. Interracial families seek out the town as a place where they can live without incident.

title: The Man From Midland
description: It will be 96 days before Republicans know if Gov. George W. Bush was right to bypass standard G.O.P. ideological fare and center this convention on the twin themes of inclusion and personal testimony. But in his well-crafted, highly autobiographical acceptance speech last night, Mr. Bush sought to incite a public appetite for change based on a claim of bringing a new style of leadership to the White House. With flashes of wit and biting ridicule, Mr. Bush derided Vice President Al Gore as the risk-averse partner in an administration that ''has coasted through prosperity.'' Ending his embargo on direct attacks, he said: ''They had their chance. They have not led. We will.'' The underlying invitation was for voters to take a leap of faith on the promise that Mr. Bush will develop into a more effective, resolute and likable leader and role model than Mr. Gore.

title: Russians Join U.S. to Seek New Sanctions On Taliban
description: The United States and Russia have agreed to work together to draft and win support for expanded sanctions against Afghanistan, officials said today. The cooperation aims to force the ruling Taliban to end support of Islamic terrorists, the officials said.

title: Polished Aristocrats, Prow to Stern
description: The American romance with sports champions may have started in the 1920's. ''In golf there was Bobby Jones, tennis had Bill Tilden, in boxing there was Jack Dempsey, horse racing had the great Man o' War, the Yankees had Ruth and Gehrig, and speedboat racing had Gar Wood,'' writes Anthony S. Mollica Jr. in ''Gar Wood Boats: Classics of a Golden Era'' (MBI Publishing, 1999).

title: South Africa Veils Crime Data, Faulting System
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 2  South Africa's minister of safety and security has ordered an indefinite moratorium on the release of crime statistics, saying the system for collecting such information here in one of the world's most crime-plagued countries is flawed and unreliable.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar after the European Central Bank kept its benchmark interest rate on hold. In New York, the euro settled at 90.70 cents, down from 91.26 cents on Wednesday.

title: Bordick Shows A Serious Style Is the Fun Part
description: Growing up in Maine, Mike Bordick obeyed a simple rule for when to play baseball.

title: Around the World
description: Whether you're a world traveler or a homebody, you can sample the world's foods without leaving New York City. These possibilities represent 12 cuisines. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: While the Party Is Elsewhere, Lazio Keeps Making the Rounds
description: With the focus of the political world on Philadelphia, Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday dined on kosher pizza in Brooklyn, did some radio interviews, raised some money, then planned to head home to Long Island.

title: Blue Jays End Their Losing Streak
description: Frank Castillo won his seventh straight decision as the host Toronto Blue Jays ended their six-game losing streak, 3-1, over the Texas Rangers last night.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Notebook; Mrs. Clinton Stumping On Lazio's Home Turf
description: The Clinton 2000 campaign dubbed it the Long Island tour, with the candidate pitching what she was calling the ''Long Island livability plan.''

title: Yugoslavs Hold 4 Westerners in Arms Case
description: The Yugoslav Army said today that it had arrested two Britons and two Canadians in Montenegro, accusing them of possessing weapons and explosives, in what appeared to be another effort to stimulate fears of Western encirclement before elections next month.

title: The Great Outdoors, Minus the Trees; Camping With an Urban Twist
description: Larry Ruffner and his buddies live to lounge in the great outdoors. From April until October, Mr. Ruffner and his friends spend their days roasting weenies, drinking beer and swatting mosquitoes in a lushly forested campground near their western Pennsylvania home.

title: Companies Ended Soft Donations But Still Play the Influence Game
description: When General Motors became the first corporation to voluntarily stop writing large checks to political parties in 1997, the automaker's executives sent a powerful message that they were disgusted by the political culture of cash and influence.

title: Few Frills but Plenty of Pleasures
description: The singer Daryl Sherman and the pianist Dave McKenna have a lot more in common than the fact both happen to come from Woonsocket, R.I. Both are staunch jazz traditionalists whose music looks back to 1930's and 40's prototypes. In their new show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, the pair (but especially Ms. Sherman) project a kind of willful innocence.

title: Puerto Rican Parade May Ban Some Rap
description: Two months after the violent aftermath of the National Puerto Rican Day Parade, the parade's directors are considering a ban on some floats carrying rap performers whose music, they say, glorifies violence and attracts unruly throngs that tarnish the march's image, a leading board member said yesterday.

title: Hans-Peter Feldmann
description: 303 Gallery

title: Resistance to E-Commerce Makes Online Book Bargains a Rarity : German Publishers Fight Web Tide
description: Trying to maintain a fixed price for books in the Internet age may seem like the fable of King Canute vainly trying to hold back the waves.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone; in August some galleries are open by appointment only. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: JARDINE MATHESON BUYBACK
description: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., whose businesses include hotels, property and trading, is making a tender offer to buy back as many as 165 million shares, or 20.4 percent of its total, for as much as $908 million. The Hong Kong-based company, using about $900 million from the sale of its stake in Robert Fleming Bank, will invite shareholders to sell their stock back to the company for $4.80 to $5.50 a share; today's closing price was $4.56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, ROBERT L.
description: BERNARD-Robert L., Dr. 11/18/ 60-8/4/97. Dearest Robie, loved, cherished and missed. Your Family

title: A Public Man, and Those Who Lost the Most
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dysfunctional Welcome For Not-So-Dear Old Dad
description: ''Elizabeth has a heart the size of a mountain,'' Gail says about one of her sisters in ''Better Living.'' In this movie, everyone has a heart the size of a mountain, and most of the characters make as much noise as a rock slide. If you've missed the kind of bellowing in a comedic context that disappeared with the Norman Lear sitcoms -- called scream theater in the 1970's -- then this is the movie for you.

title: On the Vice Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: West Nile Found in Dead Birds in Five More Upstate Counties
description: Dead birds testing positive for the West Nile virus were found in five more counties in upstate New York, indicating a statewide presence of the mosquito-borne virus, the State Health Department announced yesterday.

title: A Many-Splendored Minimalist
description: AS far as I'm concerned, it can't be demonstrated too often that the aesthetic principles considered basic to modernism are neither very recent nor especially Western. It's as comforting as it is humbling, the idea that the 20th century didn't create modernism from scratch, that it's not a relatively local, possibly exhausted aberration whose death one may celebrate or mourn. Whatever it is, the desire for simplicity, directness and abstraction is part of our very humanity and repeatedly finds expression.

title: 'Sonic Matters, Sonic Kollaborations'
description: Printed Matter

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: G.M. Set to Expand Engine Block Line
description: General Motors said today that it would spend about $160 million to build a new line of aluminum engine blocks at an Ohio plant as the company, the world's largest automaker, turns to lighter, more efficient engines.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD TO SELL UNIT TO GROUP LED BY SNIA
description: The American Standard Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its DiaSorin Inc. medical unit to a group led by Snia of Italy. American Standard, the maker of air-conditioning systems and plumbing fixtures, said it would focus on its main businesses. American Standard, based in Piscataway, N.J., said in October that it would sell DiaSorin, which makes blood-testing products and other analysis systems. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New, Tamil-Friendly Constitution for Sri Lanka?
description: After years of procrastination, Sri Lanka's governing coalition proposed today in Parliament that a new Constitution be adopted to give greater political autonomy to the minority Tamil population in an attempt to help end the 17-year-long war waged by separatist rebels for a Tamil homeland.

title: Views of Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Citrus Canker War Fought Yard by Yard
description: For 40 years, more than half her life, Kitty Field nurtured her trees. There was one orange, one lime, one grapefruit, and the blossoms and fruit filled the yard with fragrance and color. It just looked like Florida somehow, and she and her husband, Ernest, grew old under their leaves.

title: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Set Hong Kong Immigration Office Afire
description: For the mob of mainland Chinese immigrants who massed in the 13th-floor lobby of Hong Kong's immigration tower on Wednesday afternoon, the time for filling out forms or even howling in protest had passed.

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Metro Business; Trump Permit Is Upheld
description: In another victory for Donald J. Trump in a long-running legal battle, an appeals court yesterday upheld the dismissal of a lawsuit seeking to prevent him from building the world's tallest residential tower near the United Nations building.

title: Canada Goes Aboard Ship To Retrieve Its Weapons
description: Ending a naval wrangle that highlighted the logistical weakness of the Canadian military, Canadian troops swung down from a helicopter today to board an American merchant ship that for almost three weeks had held three Canadian soldiers and 10 percent of Canada's armored might hostage on the high seas over nonpayment of a shipping bill.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: W. R. Steinberg, 87; Led Union
description: William R. Steinberg, a retired union leader who represented ships' radio officers and helped organize a low-cost housing program for retired union members, died Tuesday in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 87 and formerly had a home in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Issues Bolstered By Federal Reserve Move
description: Bond prices rose yesterday but ended well off their highs of the day after technology stocks recovered from an earlier slide and investors reversed a flight to quality into government securities.

title: No, but I Heard the Soundtrack
description: NEW movies come in on waves of hype and anticipation, followed, if they're lucky, by swelling word of mouth. When the waves recede, they leave behind something tangible: soundtrack albums. If summer is a prime time for movie releases, it's also a good time to look back over recent albums, some of which are better than the movies themselves.

title: Protest Against Farm Squatters Stops Zimbabwe
description: NORTON, Zimbabwe, Aug. 2  The parliamentary elections are over, but in the rustling fields, black squatters are still occupying a thousand white-owned farms. And even the governing party acknowledges that "criminal elements" have been causing havoc on some farms.

title: INSIDE
description: Suharto May Face Trial

title: Clinton Sidesteps Senate to Fill Civil Rights Enforcement Job
description: President Clinton today appointed Bill Lann Lee to become the Justice Department's chief enforcer of civil rights laws, in a blunt challenge to Republicans who have criticized Mr. Lee, a Chinese-American lawyer, but who are eager to portray themselves as more welcoming to minorities.

title: I.B.M. TO SELL VIGNETTE WEB SOFTWARE
description: I.B.M. and the Vignette Corporation announced an agreement to sell each other's Web commerce software. Minimum-sales guarantees in the contract could bring I.B.M. as much as $1 billion in revenue in the next three years, said Mike Azzi, an I.B.M. spokesman. Other terms were not disclosed.

title: Ford Gives The Top S.U.V. A Full Makeover
description: AMERICA'S best-selling sport utility, the Ford Explorer, is getting its first total redesign since it arrived on the market in 1990.

title: Islanders Sign Forward
description: Left wing Taylor Pyatt, the No. 8 overall pick in the 1999 draft, was signed by the Islanders yesterday to a three-year contract.

title: WILLIAMS TO BUY DOW STAKE IN COCHIN PIPELINE
description: The Williams Companies, the No. 2 United States natural gas pipeline operator, agreed to buy the 32.5 percent stake of Dow Chemical in a pipeline that delivers fuels like propane and butane to the Midwest and Ontario for an undisclosed price. The 1,900-mile Cochin pipeline system originates in Alberta and ships natural gas liquids, or fuels extracted from gas after it leaves the well. The purchase would link Williams's gas liquids business in the United States with assets in western Canada it is buying from TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. The TransCanada acquisition, also announced today, would give Williams about six billion cubic feet a day of gas-processing capacity. Shares of Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., fell $1, to $43.8125.

title: CNA FINANCIAL DROPS PLAN TO SELL INSURANCE UNITS
description: The CNA Financial Corporation, the second largest insurer of businesses, said it had dropped plans to sell its life insurance units because potential buyers were unwilling to meet its price. The company, controlled by the billionaire investor Laurence Tisch and his family, has decided ''not to sell these businesses for less than they are worth to CNA,'' said Bernard L. Hengesbaugh, chairman and chief executive. In March, Chicago-based CNA hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to sell its individual life, long-term care and retirement services units to focus on its main business of insuring companies against property and other losses.

title: Hilton's Earnings Climb 14%
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, the owner of Doubletree, Hampton Inn and Hilton hotels in the United States, said today that its second-quarter profit rose 14 percent on stronger demand for rooms at big-city hotels.

title: Barak Meets Mubarak to Clarify Peace Hopes
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel met today with President Hosni Mubarak, saying he wanted to clarify for the Egyptian leader his desire to reach a peace agreement with the Palestinians once they show ''responsibility.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the dedication of a cemetery by Russians and Poles in memory of Polish military officers massacred during World War II misidentified the country that controlled the site, Katyn, at the time of the killings. In 1940, the area was part of the Soviet republic of Ukraine, not in Poland.

title: National Gallery Adds Turrells
description: To beef up its contemporary-art holdings, the National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired four early works by the installation artist James Turrell.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Ethical Museum Exhibitions
description: In its new ''Guidelines on Exhibiting Borrowed Objects,'' the Association of American Museums is intent both on creating a sense of ethical coherence in museum practices and reasserting the uniqueness of museums themselves. The guidelines, announced earlier this week, were written largely in response to questions about financing, undue influence and possible conflicts of interest in staging the ''Sensation'' exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art last year. The art in that show was owned by Charles Saatchi, who also contributed $160,000 anonymously to the Brooklyn Museum and stood to gain if the show increased the value of the artwork.

title: Canada Broadens Its Case Against Suspected Hacker
description: Prosecutors broadened their case against a suspected teenage hacker today, adding dozens of charges that accuse the boy of paralyzing several of the most popular Web sites in the United States beginning on Feb. 7.

title: Man From Wyoming
description: To the Editor:

title: What Mideast Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: KULICKE & SOFFA SHARES DROP AFTER ORDER DEFERRRALS
description: Shares of Kulicke & Soffa Industries fell as much as 39 percent after the company said delayed orders might hurt profit this quarter and next. The company's shares fell $5.50, to $16.625, in Nasdaq trading after dropping as low as $13.5625. The forecast also dragged down the shares of similar equipment makers, including ASM Lithography Holding N.V., Applied Materials Inc. and the Credence Systems Corporation. Scott Kulicke, the chairman and chief executive of Kulicke, the world's No. 1 maker of chip-assembly equipment, told analysts in a conference call that he saw no evidence that the deferral meant a downturn in the semiconductor industry.

title: State Department Aides Seek $300 Million to Better Security
description: Three months after Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright declared herself ''humiliated'' by lax security at her department, manifested in one case by the loss of a laptop computer with classified information, officials there are seeking $300 million to upgrade headquarters and hire 900 new employees, most of them security agents.

title: Article 2000080490332658901 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Changes in Ford Explorer Aim at Protecting Other Motorists
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its next generation of Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, scheduled to go on sale in January, would be extensively changed from current models so as to reduce the danger to other motorists during collisions and decrease the risk of deadly rollovers.

title: DNA Testing Clears 2 Men In Newark Library Rapes
description: Prosecutors here have dropped charges against two men accused in separate rapes inside the Newark Public Library in 1998, after DNA testing found that a third, unknown man had committed both crimes.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Bull Market Multiplier: A Little Revenue Went a Long Way
description: BULL markets may not cause companies to fiddle with their books, but they certainly increase the rewards to be gained from creative accounting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bessemer Trust to Acquire Two Units of a Rival Firm

title: Dispute With Handbag Maker Taken to Store
description: Nieves Pena watched in admiration a year and a half ago as her mother voted to unionize the garment district factory in which she worked, one that made handbags for Kate Spade.

title: Drug Maker Fires Back At Maine Over Law
description: Maine certainly fired the first shot. Under a law passed in May, it became the first state to threaten the pharmaceutical industry with price controls on prescription drugs, and it created a program to negotiate lower prices for about half its residents.

title: Alaska Airlines Will Ground 18 Jets Because of Inconsistent Tests on a Vital Part
description: Alaska Airlines decided late Thursday night to ground 18 of its 34 MD-80 aircraft, the same model as the plane that crashed off the California coast in January when a part in the tail broke.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM PLUNGES. Palladium fell on speculation that Russia, the world's largest producer, would resume exports to Japan. In New York, palladium for September delivery fell $63.05, or 7.4 percent, to $792.10 an ounce.

title: Even Afflicted Children Have Tantrums
description: One encouraging element of ''The Tic Code,'' a small, sincere film with an educational agenda, is its refusal to make its plucky 11-year-old hero, Miles (Christopher George Marquette), a 100 percent adorable movie moppet. A stubborn, hypersensitive youth who knows how to throw a mean tantrum, Miles insists on playing a vaguely ghoulish question-and-answer game, ''Which would you rather,'' with his mother, Laura (Polly Draper), that gives her the creeps.

title: Bessemer Trust to Add Key Businesses of Rival
description: One of the oldest firms in the business of managing money for wealthy families, the Bessemer Trust Company, will announce today that it is buying the private-client and institutional-equity groups of a rival, Brundage, Story & Rose, executives of the firms said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Supported by City, Developers of Mall Sue Main Opponents
description: In an escalating battle over the proposed construction of a $500 million shopping mall here, the City of New Haven and the mall's developer filed a lawsuit today against the project's three main opponents: the neighboring town of Milford, its largest mall and the company that owns it.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a summer camp at Nablus, in the West Bank, where 25,000 Palestinian teenagers are trained in games of war, referred incorrectly to the shift in control of the towns and villages where the youths live. It was Israel that ceded the areas to Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority, not the reverse.

title: CENTRAL BANKERS LEAVE RATES UNCHANGED
description: The Bank of England and the European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged at their regular policy-making meetings, reflecting continued divergence between the British and euro-zone economies. For the sixth consecutive month, the Bank of England held its benchmark rate at 6 percent. In Frankfurt, the European Central Bank maintained its benchmark rate at 4.25 percent. The decisions were expected, but economists expect both central banks to raise rates later this year. Alan Cowell

title: Ford Is Said to Be Better; Bush Allowed in for Visit
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford's doctors said today that they were ''very pleased'' with his medical progress since he was admitted to Hahnemann University Hospital on Wednesday because of a stroke, and they expressed confidence that he would make a full recovery.

title: Taking The Party Outdoors
description: It is summer in New York, this year a season that jumps from muggy heat to damp chill without warning. There is relatively little dance in pleasantly climate-controlled theaters. So what do those mad creatures called dancers do?

title: Out of Her Dreams and Into a Dive
