description: In ''Coyote Ugly,'' three of the supermodel bartenders -- Zoe (Tyra Banks), Rachel (Bridget Moynahan) and Cammie (Izabella Miko) -- are poring over an issue of Playboy and making fun of the Playmate's favorite movie, ''Saving Private Ryan.'' At this point, there's a cosmic shift in the universe, a rumbling that disrupts the plates of karma. Those same women leap on a bar and douse themselves with water -- presumably so their leather pants can get even tighter around their slender hips -- for a bunch of leering drunks. So having a movie as superficial as ''Coyote Ugly'' make fun of someone's shallowness is like having Ronald McDonald criticize your taste in clothes.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Among other things, Danube has taught New York that quark is a cheese as well as a subatomic particle. This is not useless information, certainly not at Wallse, Kurt Gutenbrunner's very appealing little Austrian restaurant in the far West Village, where a quark dumpling with red-currant-stuffed apricot halves leads the list of homey sweets. It's been a long wait for Mr. Gutenbrunner, an Austrian who once cooked at the renowned Tantris in Vienna and was David Bouley's original choice to run the kitchen at Danube. When that project seemed to be stalled, he decided to open his own place.

title: Reno Promises Action on Carnivore
description: Reno Promises Action on Carnivore

title: 2 Old Names In Georgia Vying to Fill Senate Seat
description: The unexpected race to replace the late Senator Paul Coverdell has become a contest between two of the best-known names from Georgia's political past, both of whom are nearing 70 years old.

title: A Big Man Chasing 'Cool' One Conquest at a Time
description: There is no Steve in ''The Tao of Steve,'' the light-as-a-marshmallow romantic comedy directed by Jenniphr Goodman. But there is a universal ideal represented by a spiritual concept proposed by the main character, Dex: the pursuit of the perfection attained by all-American cool guys like Steve McQueen, Steve McGarrett (''Hawaii Five-0'') and Steve Austin (''The Six Million Dollar Man'').

title: Store to Home, By Satellite
description: Visitors to Blockbuster stores on Sept. 1 may be startled to notice kiosks displaying DirecTV, which beams movies by satellite. Why would the country's largest provider of videocassettes open the door to a competing type of movie delivery? Several types, in fact.

title: Developments In Two Reviews
description: There were developments yesterday involving two large reviews.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES TO CLOSE BRITISH MANUFACTURING PLANT
description: AEP Industries Inc., the world's largest maker of plastic stretch packaging film, said it would close its plant in North Baddesley, England, resulting in the loss of 32 manufacturing jobs. The company, based in South Hackensack, N.J., will take a charge of $4.32 million for the closing, which will occur by mid-2001.

title: SECURITAS TO ACQUIRE BURNS FOR $457 MILLION
description: The Swedish security-services giant Securitas A.B. agreed yesterday to acquire the Burns International Services Corporation for $457 million in cash. Shares of Burns, based in Chicago, rose $7.86, to $21.10. The combined company is expected to have sales of about $5.3 billion and about 210,000 employees. Securitas has made several recent acquisitions in the United States security field including Pinkerton, American Protective Services Inc. of Oakland, Calif., and First Security Services of Boston. Burns is the largest provider of security and related services based in the United States, with 58,000 employees and more than 320 offices. Securitas, a security concern based in Stockholm, has annual revenue of $4 billion.

title: Two Pests at Once
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD PROFITS FOR OIL GIANT
description: High crude oil prices and cost savings pushed second-quarter operating profits at Royal Dutch/Shell to a record high, almost doubling to $3.15 billion from $1.61 billion a year ago, the company said. Shell, the world's second-largest publicly traded oil company, says it is saving $3 billion a year under a cost-cutting program. Alan Cowell

title: Europe Begins Proceedings in Its Case Against Microsoft
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 3 -- The European Union added to Microsoft 's legal woes today, opening an antitrust case accusing the company of abusing its market position in operating systems to dominate the market for server software.

title: 2 Reports Show a Slower Pace of Growth
description: Factory orders for goods other than aircraft were little changed in June and the pace of business outside of manufacturing slowed in July, government and industry reports showed today.

title: Fire Destroys Catholic Church and Leaves Two Injured
description: A seven-alarm fire gutted a Roman Catholic church here today, leaving two firefighters with minor injuries and about 3,000 families without a house of worship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECHANIC, SAMUEL
description: MECHANIC-Samuel, Fannie, and Sylvia G. ''and until we meet again, may God continue to hold thee in the palm of His hand.'

title: Will That Be Paper or Pixel?; Kodak Rushes To Extend It's Brand to All Things Digital
description: The Kodak name is showing up in a lot more places these days.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam of the Bobover sect yesterday included an incomplete reference from family friends to the members of his family who survived the Holocaust. Although several relatives were killed, his mother, a brother and six sisters -- not just his eldest son -- survived.

title: NAPSTER.COM SEES VISITORS SURGE
description: After Napster.com was ordered by a federal judge to stop permitting its users to trade copyrighted music files, traffic on the site surged. Averaging 220,000 visitors a day, Napster was the 19th most active site for the week ending July 30.

title: A Rolling Locomotive, a Light-Filled Manse: The American Panorama
description: In high summer, when pleasure is at the prow, people who love looking at pictures often remember the art museum at Smith College in Northampton, Mass. Not only is the collection quite remarkable in itself, but it represents a collective effort over many generations by the faculty of the college, by the successive directors of the museum and by discerning, devoted and strong-minded alumnae.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Holy Smoke

title: Split Over Bangladeshi Event Believed to Prompt Threats
description: For almost all of New York's handful of Bengali-language newspapers, Tuesday was a harrowing day involving the city police, the postal police, F.B.I. agents, hazardous materials experts and, for some, showers in tents set up outside their evacuated offices. Yesterday, they were left wondering what the fuss had been about.

title: TOYOTA DISAGREES WITH ORDER CONFIRMATION BY G.M.
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said General Motors was premature in announcing that Toyota would use G.M.'s OnStar communications system in its vehicles. Toyota is in discussions with G.M. to use OnStar on ''a few new models'' but no agreement has been signed, Toyota said in a statement. OnStar, a G.M. subsidiary, uses global-positioning technology and wireless communications to allow owners to track a stolen vehicle, call for roadside help or gain access to navigation information. On Monday, Ford Motor introduced a competing service with Qualcomm Inc. Nissan has said it will use Ford's service in its Infiniti luxury vehicles.

title: Quarterly Earnings Climb 20% at Clorox
description: The Clorox Company said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 20 percent as the company, the largest United States bleach maker, cut costs and sold more Liquid-Plumr drain cleaner, Ultra bleach and Brita water filters.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Next Stop, Bratislava

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about Shimon Peres's defeat in a parliamentary vote for the presidency of Israel misstated the length of the term. Moshe Katsav, the winner, will serve a single term of seven years, not five. The article also overstated the legislative experience of Yosef Lapid, a supporter of Mr. Peres. He is a first-time member of parliament, not a veteran lawmaker.

title: People
description: David Melancon was named to head a new Denver office of Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, as managing director. He had been chief marketing officer at netLibrary, Boulder, Colo.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on July 27 about potential health risks of cellular telephone use misstated government agencies' findings. They have said that available evidence does not indicate whether cellular phones are safe or unsafe; the agencies have not said the phones are safe.

title: Suharto Is Formally Charged With Corruption
description: Sick, bewildered and besieged at his home by angry protesters, former President Suharto was formally charged today with corruption during his 32 years of unchecked power in Indonesia.

title: International Merger Wave Catches Europe's Law Firms
description: Pushed by globalization and a boom in corporate law involving mergers and acquisitions, law firms in Europe are undergoing some mergers and acquisitions of their own.

title: Army Weighs an Expanded Role For National Guard Combat Units
description: The Army is proposing to give the National Guard a greatly increased role in combat, which would mean that tens of thousands of part-time soldiers would almost certainly be mobilized and sent to fight if war broke out on the Korean Peninsula or in the Persian Gulf, senior Pentagon officials say.

title: Constance Stuart Larrabee, 85, Photographer
description: Constance Stuart Larrabee, a photographer who recorded the vanishing tribes of southern Africa, the World War II battlefields of Europe and her life on Maryland's tranquil Eastern Shore, died on July 27 at her home in Chestertown, Md. She was 85.

title: Metro Business; HIP to Sell Unit To H.M.O. Group
description: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its troubled Florida subsidiary to a group of health companies.

title: Reformists in Iran, Despite Pressure, Speak Out More Boldly
description: It was a Rip van Winkle moment.

title: Corrections
description: The front-page Man in the News article yesterday about George W. Bush misstated his family relationship to President Franklin Pierce. The relationship is through Mr. Bush's great-grandfather Scott Pierce, but Mr. Bush is not a direct descendant. None of Pierce's children survived to adulthood.

title: The Politics of the Inquisitor
description: Though George W. Bush admits he is not an avid reader, his wife is a serious lover of literature. Laura Bush has read widely, from Greek tragedy to William Faulkner to Truman Capote. When asked to name her favorite book, on the long list she has read, she selected the ''The Grand Inquisitor'' section of Dostoyevsky's ''The Brothers Karamazov.'' This is an interesting and suggestive choice, of a chilling and troubling chapter in a challenging novel.

title: Toy Site Sued Over Privacy Concerns
description: Toy Site Sued Over Privacy Concerns

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday tracing the decline in television viewing of Republican conventions since 1960 referred incompletely to the networks that were excluded from the ratings for this week. Monday's ratings did not reflect CBS and NBC, which both showed convention coverage as a part of regular programs. Tuesday's ratings did not include CBS. PBS, which does not report ratings overnight, was not the only network excluded from the ratings.

title: N.B.A. Coach Finds Joy in Women's League
description: BACK then, he coached the greats, from Bob Lanier to Shaquille O'Neal. He traveled on the Orlando Magic's private jet, stocked with lobster, steak and Shaq's very own seven-foot bed.

title: Privacy Plan Likely to Kick Off Debate
description: The goal of the plan announced by President Clinton's chief of staff, John Podesta, sounded admirable: to overhaul the nation's privacy laws, harmonizing a patchwork of inconsistent rules and extending to e-mail and mobile phone messages the same strict safeguards against government snooping that now apply to telephone calls.

title: Taiwan's Leader Considers Purchase of Updated Jet Fighters
description: Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, said today that the island should begin considering new fighter aircraft purchases, warning that in five years China could threaten Taiwan's ability to control the skies over the Taiwan Strait, a key factor in repelling a mainland invasion.

title: Summer Rite: Sewage Overflow Shuts Beaches
description: As if two gray weeks of nearly nonstop rain were not grim enough, there was even grimmer news for sun worshipers this week. Heavy rains inundated waste treatment plants in three Westchester towns and a sewer main ruptured here in Greenwich, spewing more than two million gallons of mostly untreated sewage into Long Island Sound, forcing health officials to close at least 20 beaches.

title: Front and (Very Much) Center
description: Close your eyes and Gov. George W. Bush tonight could have been Bill Clinton without the punch -- or Al Gore without the precision.

title: For Yankees, Triumph in 9th Worth the Wait
description: It was not raining when the Yankees and the Royals were supposed to start playing at 7:05 last night. But it started raining an hour later and kept pouring for two and a half more hours, turning Yankee Stadium into a quagmire, sending hundreds of unhappy fans home and forcing Roger Clemens to be another bystander who had to wait and hope for baseball.

title: Rightist Shocks Canadians by Flirting With Separatists
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 2  Stockwell Day's summer vacation in Quebec was going well. Every day, the rising star of Canada's right appeared on French language television, chatting in francais with his language immersion teachers, fielding reporters' questions about his politique fiscale, or posing for photographs with the eternal friend of language students, le dictionnaire Larousse.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Codgers With Joints. Not the Achy Kind.
description: The rulers of Britain may have embarked on an aggressive campaign of modernization -- what with the Millennium Dome, the transformation of the House of Lords and all that throbbing techno music -- but a segment of the entertainment industry remains stubbornly wedded to ancient notions of the British character. The once-mighty empire remains, if recent movies are to be believed, a nation of absent-minded vicars, codgers and goosey, tea-swilling ladies who populate cozy crofts and seaside villages and manufacture eccentricity for the export market.

title: SPRINT OFFERS VOICE DIALING
description: In a move aimed at advancing the use of voice-based technology, Sprint PCS, the wireless division of the Sprint Corporation, will make voice-activated dialing and information services available on its national wireless network. Using technology developed by Nuance Communications, customers will be able to initiate calls or gain access to directory services by speaking into their phones, at monthly fees of $10 for individuals and $5 for businesses. In addition, Sprint is working with Ford Motor to make voice-activated services available for vehicles. Simon Romero

title: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Kansas, Evolving
description: The earth is billions of years old, and will again be so in Kansas, despite reckless attempts by the State Board of Education to deprive its children of modern scientific thinking. Voters put an end to the madness by expelling conservative board members who had gutted statewide science standards last year to eliminate evolution as an explanation of the origin of species and the Big Bang theory to explain the start of the universe. The balloting was a triumph for common sense, and a resounding defeat for creationists whose religious zeal threatened to imperil their schoolchildren's education.

title: Absent Swing Districts
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The First Decade'
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: Salomon to Buy U.S. Treasury Interest
description: Salomon Smith Barney offered yesterday to buy $94.5 billion worth of the interest portion of Treasury securities, known as strips, from institutional and retail owners.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Cone Needs Fast Start to Stop Doubts
description: David Cone will depart from Tampa, Fla., with Orlando Hernandez, Allen Watson and the pitching instructor Billy Connors today and return to Yankee Stadium with several questions still hovering. Cone is scheduled to make his next start against the Seattle Mariners tomorrow and it is fair to wonder if it might be his last start of the season.

title: Masked Men And Grinches
description: Rick Baker's makeup and animatronics studio is on a scruffy commercial strip at the foot of the back side of the Hollywood Hills, but inside it's all fantasy and artifice. A creepy mock graveyard includes headstones for many of the creatures created by Mr. Baker, a four-time Oscar winner, as well as some members of his current staff. Upstairs, the entrance to his office is down a tall, narrow corridor of Gothic arches, at the end of which stands a huge, hooded wraith. In the office, another Gothic marvel filled with antiques, skulls and other creepy artifacts, sits Mr. Baker, wearing a T-shirt and denim pants, his salt-and-pepper pony tail hanging over the back of a wood chair.

title: Rockport is trying to change its stodgy image with a redesign of its shoes and a new campaign.
description: AN offbeat new campaign embraces the philosophy of the comedian Jeff Foxworthy in declaring: ''No shirt. No shoes. . . . No problem!'' And what in the world are the shirtless hunks and hunkettes peddling in the ads? Shoes.

title: Memorable At-Bat And Magic Moment
description: Luis Polonia said it was the only at-bat of his 11-year career that he truly remembers. Paul O'Neill was panicked about whether he would catch the soaring line drive. Andy Pettitte put a towel over his head and prayed.

title: Policing Gone Astray
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Outlines His Goals: 'I Want to Change the Tone of Washington'
description: Following is a transcript of Gov. George W. Bush's speech accepting the Republican presidential nomination last night in Philadelphia, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Helene Ritzerfeld, 86, Executive In Top German Publishing House
description: Helene Ritzerfeld, an internationally known executive of a major German publishing house, Suhrkamp Verlag, died on July 22 at her office desk in Frankfurt. She was 86 and lived in Frankfurt.

title: To Political Clan, Convention Is Just Like Old Times
description: The hottest convention in town is perhaps not the obvious one made up of 15,000 journalists and an occasional Republican, but rather a more private one unfolding away from the television lights, one to which admission is based not on politics but on blood and marriage.

title: Writer Joins Growing Ranks of Egypt's Accused
description: Ali Salem recently wrote the script for an unfinished 10-minute public service announcement that encourages his fellow Egyptians to shed their cynicism and vote in elections.

title: 'Na'er Do Wells'
description: DNA Studios

title: Loss Is Higher at British Cable Operator
description: Telewest Communications, the No. 2 cable television company in Britain, said today that its loss widened in the second quarter and that it expected to lower prices and revenue forecasts for both high-speed Internet and digital TV services.

title: The Props Talk Back: Young Performers Mix Bush's Message With Their Own
description: The Republican audiences this week have been prosperous and mostly white and the stage always a Gap ad of vivid ethnicity. But sometimes, the models have thoughts of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORNBERG, ELY MARC
description: ZORNBERG-Ely Marc. Devoted son of Florence and Edward, Brother of Eric and sister-in-law Debbie, brother of Gwen, Loving Father of Joshua and Alma. He will be missed by the entire family. Services will be held on Friday, Aug 4 at 12:30pm at Plaza Memorial, 91 St at Amsterdam Ave, NYC

title: Sotheby's Posts Drop of 5.2% in Earnings
description: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the world's No. 2 auction house, said yesterday that second-quarter profit fell 5.2 percent while revenue rose.

title: Technique Uses Rocks to Study Earth's Early Atmosphere
description: Scientists have developed a new technique to analyze the chemical composition of ancient rocks for hints about what the air was like billions of years ago. The information could help them decipher the evolution of Earth's earliest life forms.

title: Viacom's Profit Drops Because of Expenses of Buying CBS
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell because of good-will expenses for its $50 billion purchase of the CBS Corporation.

title: Suspect Dies in Custody
description: A 27-year-old drug suspect died yesterday after apparently falling ill in a holding cell in the Manhattan Criminal Court building, the police said.

title: Where Freezing Is Pleasing
description: Gus, Ida and Lily are like any teenagers during the summer: they love their frozen treats. Don't offer them anything as mundane as ice cream, though. They prefer honey and chocolate on something really tempting, like red snapper or frozen mackerel.

title: Groh Makes Big Request: Hold Applause for the Jets
description: Jets Coach Al Groh all but held up an enormous stop sign this week. Stop, he nearly implored, making so much of the impressive debuts of the 2000 class of rookies.

title: STAKES RISE IN IRON ORE FIGHT
description: In the latest round of a bidding war for the Australian iron ore producer North Ltd., the mining company Rio Tinto P.L.C. of Britain raised a hostile bid by 25 percent for the 85.5 percent of North it does not own. The Rio Tinto bid, which at 4.75 Australian dollars or $2.78 a share, is worth about $1.75 billion, leapfrogged a bid from Anglo American P.L.C., which had offered 4.20 Australian dollars. North recommended the Anglo bid to investors on July 21 but said its board would meet to consider a response to the sweetened offer from Rio. Alan Cowell

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; After 20 Years, It Still Comes Out Swinging
description: ''Raging Bull'' is not simply the greatest boxing movie ever made; Martin Scorsese's 1980 masterpiece is arguably the finest American film released in a decade when Hollywood retreated from the tragic realist vision of American life enshrined in Francis Ford Coppola's first two ''Godfather'' films.

title: OUTPUT STRENGTHENS IN BRAZIL
description: Industrial production in Brazil rose 7.6 percent in June compared with a year earlier, reflecting increased manufacturing of durable goods to meet demand from consumers. Television and stereo production showed the greatest growth, followed by motorcycle and automobile manufacturing. Production of industrial machinery rose 30.7 percent. The increase suggested that a slowdown this spring in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy, was ending.

title: SHARES FALL AT BIG FRENCH BANK
description: Shares in the second-largest French bank, Societe Generale, dropped nearly 10 percent, to 65 euros, or about $57.94, after the bank reported disappointing second-quarter results. The bank earned 752 million euros or $689 million, up 6.7 percent from 705 million euros a year earlier, and far below the 53 percent profit growth in the first quarter. The bank's chairman, Daniel Bouton, said that the slowdown was a result of a ''seasonal element,'' but that the bank expected a significant profit gain for the full year.

title: Dispatch on the Poe War
description: To the Editor:

title: TXU TO BUY NORWEB ENERGI FROM UNITED UTILITIES
description: The TXU corporation, the No. 4 United States utility, agreed to buy Norweb Energi from United Utilities P.L.C. for $:486 million ($726 million) to widen its customer base in Britain and reduce costs in the region. TXU Europe, a unit of Texas-based TXU, will pay $:310 million in cash and take on Norweb's power purchase agreements worth $:176 million. It also granted United's services unit, Vertex, contracts with Norweb and Eastern Energy, a British unit of TXU, worth 650 million [pounds] over seven years.

title: DSM TO ACQUIRE CATALYTICA FOR $800 MILLION
description: DSM N.V. of the Netherlands agreed yesterday to buy Catalytica Inc. for about $800 million in cash and debt to strengthen its position as the world's biggest supplier of high-profit pharmaceutical ingredients. DSM plans to keep Catalytica's drug division and spin off the combustion systems and advanced technologies units. Investors in Catalytica, based in Mountain View, Calif., will gain stock in the new business and be paid $9 to $10 a share, depending on taxes associated with the spinoff. DSM will pay about $750 million in cash and assume about $50 million in debt.

title: Beyond Asian Stereotypes, This Comic Settles Scores
description: There are moments in the filmed concert of Margaret Cho's successful and hilarious one-woman show, ''I'm the One That I Want,'' when her cheeks puff up, her eyes crinkle, her mouth curls into a wicked little smirk and she swings out at the injustices of the world like an Asian-American Roseanne.

title: Late Bloomers to Have Their Day in Jim Dandy
description: Between the bleak, soggy weather here and the buildup for Sunday's Whitney Stakes, perhaps the best race of the summer for older horses, an important race for 3-year-olds on Saturday, has been overlooked. A field of seven is set for the Jim Dandy, and even though the entrants lack accomplishment in Triple Crown races, each has an opportunity to begin a championship run in a wide open division.

title: Monsanto Plans to Offer Rights To Its Altered-Rice Technology
description: In a bid to foster support for biotechnology and save lives, the Monsanto Corporation will make available patent rights to genetically altered rice that could help stave off malnutrition in poor nations, the company's president said tonight.

title: Residential Real Estate; On Greenwich St., Converting 1929 Office Tower to Apartments
description: A Manhattan development company is hoping to repeat the success it had in an office-to-rental conversion in the financial district with 88 Greenwich Street, an Art Deco former office tower built in 1929 that is being turned into 458 apartments that opened for leasing last month.

title: POOR EARNINGS FUEL SAFECO'S DISMISSAL OF 2 EXECUTIVES
description: The Safeco Corporation ousted its chief executive and the president of its property-casualty unit yesterday after several years of disappointing earnings. The company, based in Seattle, said Roger Eigsti, 58, chairman and chief executive, would leave on Dec. 31, and Randy Stoddard, 52, president of Safeco Property and Casualty, would quit immediately. Mr. Stoddard's duties will be assumed by Boh Dickey, Safeco's president and chief operating officer. Safeco, the 16th-largest United States property-casualty insurer, has consistently reported weaker- than-expected earnings in recent years because of intense pricing competition and worsening loss trends.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WALTER INDUSTRIES INC., Tampa, Fla., which builds and finances houses and makes industrial products, said it would cut 5 percent of its work force, or about 375 employees. Robert G. Burton, chief executive, resigned after about three months in the post.

title: Uri Gordon, 65, Dies; Aided Israeli Newcomers
description: Uri Gordon, an Israeli official and Zionist leader who played important roles in the resettlement of thousands of Ethiopian and Russian Jews in Israel in the 1980's and 90's, died on Sunday in Israel. He was 65.

title: Article 2000080493552280010 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Stung, CBS Changes Its Plan
description: Officials at CBS News said yesterday that they would slightly revise their coverage plans for the first night of the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, after television critics and their own employees complained about the way the opening night of the Republican gathering in Philadelphia was handled.

title: S.E.C. Rule On Disclosure Still Unsettled
description: Despite an outpouring of support from individual investors and consumer groups, federal securities regulators are still scrambling to revise a proposed rule against selective disclosure of corporate information before it comes up for a vote next week.

title: RENO PROMISES ACTION ON CARNIVORE
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said she would determine what was delaying a government review of a new F.B.I. computer system that can search and intercept private e-mail. The system, called Carnivore, enables federal agents to sort through large quantities of e-mail messages. Privacy and civil liberties groups have complained that the system enables the government to monitor an unlimited amount of e-mail, but the F.B.I. says it intends to monitor only the e-mail messages of criminal suspects. Ms. Reno called last month for a review of whether the system was being used ina manner consistent with privacy rights in the Constitution and federal law. Raymond Hernandez

title: Silicon Valley's Primal Spirit Lives On, in a Part of Beijing
description: Anyone searching for the soul of China's Silicon Valley can find it here, up four flights of concrete stairs, past walls with peeling paint and ledges strewn with beer bottles, down a darkened hallway and inside what was once the student activity room at Qinghua University Dormitory No. 20.

title: Album of the Week
description: ''IN GRIOT TIME: STRING MUSIC FROM MALI'' (Stern's Africa). Appreciating studio-made popular music from other countries can be like hearing a language you're not very familiar with; each particular culture's aesthetics of instrumentation, electronics, mixing and pop appeal present obstacles to understanding foreign music on its own terms.

title: Retail Sales Up on Bargains Offered by Clothing Chains
description: Sales in stores open more than a year rose 3.7 percent in July as clearance sales enticed shoppers and helped make room for fall fashions and back-to-school items, new figures showed yesterday.

title: 49ers' Rookie Hopes Time Is on His Side
description: The San Francisco 49ers' rebuilding task starts at quarterback. This can be brutal.

title: An Iconoclast to Whom the Personal Is Always Political
description: If you happen to be on basically O.K. terms with the world, meaning that the world is doing all right by you, the alert, irritated, combative work of the American artist Martha Rosler may not be your cup of tea.

title: Tom Clancy Leaves Agent Of 18 Years To Join Ovitz
description: In another sign of Michael Ovitz's return to power as a Hollywood deal-maker, Mr. Ovitz has persuaded the best-selling thriller writer Tom Clancy to defect from his longtime agent Robert Gottlieb at the William Morris Agency.

title: Love, Modern and Mythical
description: There is a faintly bittersweet atmosphere at the Santa Fe Opera this summer, the company's 44th season and its last under the directorship of its founder, John Crosby. Mr. Crosby, 74, has asked the company not to make too much of his retirement, and that wish is largely being honored. When the subject is mentioned, it is mostly in the context of plans for next season, to be directed by his successor, Richard Gaddes.

title: Shares End Broadly Higher To Recover From Early Skid
description: Stocks pulled out of an early skid and rallied to finish broadly higher yesterday, with the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index posting a hefty 2.8 percent gain after being down as much as 3.8 percent in the first half hour.

title: XFL Lands Loudly At a Store Near You
description: In the further adventures of the league that cried ''smash mouth!'' the XFL yesterday unveiled its official football. The red, silver and black ball will arrive in stores before games are first played next February.

title: What Do Women Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mari Eastman
description: Bronwyn Keenan

title: A New Rival to N.T.T. For Japan's Local Callers
description: Japan Telecom, one of this country's largest telecommunications companies, plans to offer local phone service, which would put it into direct competition with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the former government phone monopoly.

title: $45 Million Grant Awarded to Buy Supercomputer
description: The National Science Foundation announced yesterday that it had made a $45 million award to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center to buy from Compaq what the computer maker says will be the world's fastest nonmilitary supercomputer when it is installed next year.

title: SOUTH KOREA HOLDS RATES STEADY
description: South Korea's central bank decided to leave interest rates unchanged for the sixth consecutive month, despite evidence of inflationary pressure. Economists said the bank was wary of unnerving financial markets that already were on edge because of debt problems at the nation's largest conglomerate, the Hyundai Group. Samuel Len

title: Privacy Plan Likely to Kick Off Debate
description: August 4, 2000

title: U.S. Beach Closings Soar With Focus on Pollution
description: The number of pollution-related beach closings and advisories increased by 50 percent nationwide from 1997 to 1999, according to a report released today by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They had their chance. They have not led. We will.''

title: Sound Bites Defeat Substance, Again
description: George W. Bush had an on-screen audition for the role of president last night, commandeering a chunk of prime time, as presidents do, to deliver an extended speech. In the surprise-free zone of this convention, the only question was how convincing a performance would he give.

title: Study Backs Freight-Train Tunnel in New York Harbor
description: A proposed rail-freight tunnel under New York Harbor that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has adopted as a favored project would cost up to $2.3 billion but would pay for itself through increased business along a revitalized Brooklyn waterfront, according to a city study.

title: Check, Please
description: What was the name of the best restaurant in ancient Epicurean Rome? How were the prices? And the waiters, did they understand the meaning of service or did they thumb the plates unmercifully on the way to the table? Somehow these questions arise at the thought of the new, eponymous restaurant run by the acclaimed chef Alain Ducasse in the Essex Hotel on Central Park South in Manhattan, a place that also brings to mind J. Pierpont Morgan's advice about the cost of keeping a yacht. The prix fixe dinner at Alain Ducasse is $160, with a la carte appetizers in the $50 range and entrees that reach $74. At these prices, it's tempting to say that it's only a meal, after all. But it's also tempting to say that it's only money.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Matching the Pianist To Debussy and Chopin
description: Maurizio Pollini's reputation for hard thought can easily divert attention from the sheer sonic beauty of his pianism, rather as Debussy's reputation for misty drift can obscure the rigor and the intellectual adventurousness of his music. The two -- player and composer -- are well matched in a recording of the first book of the Debussy preludes (Deutsche Grammophon 289 445 187), on which Mr. Pollini produces captivating poetry that always has a mind to it.

title: What Makes the Son Run?
description: As a presidential son of 40 years ago, I naturally take special interest in the careers of others who have been in similar situations. On the whole, I find it hard to understand why a member of a president's family, aware of the often unjustified criticism presidents endure, would voluntarily seek to occupy the presidency. But those who do should be considered on their own merits, not as reflections or psychological extensions of their fathers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSLER, ALAN CHARLES
description: ROSSLER-Alan Charles. On August 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Noonan). Cherished father of Anne Marie Robertson (son-in-law Charles Robertson), Peter Rossler, Stephen Rossler and devoted grandfather of Andrew Robertson. Mass of Christian burial St. Michael's Church, 765 Coop City Blvd, Bronx, Monday, August 7, 10AM. Reposing at the McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville 914-337-6770, Saturday 7-9, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINSSER, BARBARA L.
description: ZINSSER-Barbara L. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Barbara L. Zinsser, who passed away on August 1st, will be held at the Calvary Episcopal Church at Park Avenue South and 21 St on September 21, 2000 at 5:30 PM. Contributions in our mother's memory may be made to Robert College of Istanbul, 276 Fifth Ave, Suite 905, New York, NY 10001; American Farm School, 1133 Broadway, 16th Floor, New York, New York 10010; or The Horticultural Society of New York, 128 W. 58th Street, New York, NY 10019. Leslie Armstrong, Judith Zinsser, Katherine Zinsser

title: Modest Job Growth Helps Major Market Indexes Rise
description: Stocks ended higher yesterday after the Labor Department reported that private job growth had been slower than expected last month.

title: When Artistry Upstages Period Instruments
description: Some early music ensembles are rather self-righteous about using only historically authentic instruments. But the most gratifying of such ensembles are those that enable you to forget that period instruments are being used at all, because the playing is itself so musical and interesting. That's what happened during Thursday night's concert by the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment at Alice Tully Hall, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: EBay Launches New Real Estate Category
description: EBay Launches New Real Estate Category

title: More Than Ready Faces A Tough Haskell Field
description: Ever since More Than Ready took his first step onto a racetrack, friends and relatives of the horse's owner, James Scatuorchio, have been asking: ''When can we see him run here in New Jersey?''

title: Lazio Says if Foe Refuses Soft Money, He Will, Too
description: With Senator John McCain at his side, Representative Rick A. Lazio pledged yesterday that he would pick up the senator's signature issue, campaign finance reform, and refuse the largely unregulated campaign contributions known as soft money -- if Hillary Rodham Clinton, his opponent, made the same pledge beforehand.

title: A Sharp Student Split On G.O.P. Spectacle
description: Political science students at New York University recognize obscure de Toqueville quotations and argue the merits of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty vs. the Strategic Defense Initiative. So when the Republican National Convention rolled around, they were an astute audience, eager to analyze what George W. Bush set out to accomplish and how well he succeeded.

title: Raw Deal for Doctors in Poor Areas
description: The federal program that pays doctors saddled with huge student loans a bonus to practice in poor rural and urban areas needs a major redesign or millions more dollars. What Congress should not tolerate is a repeat of this year, when more than 90 percent of the doctors who joined understaffed clinics were told in midyear, without warning, that the program had run out of money and that they would receive nothing beyond their meager salaries. The administrative blunder threatens to undermine the worthy program by driving away future applicants.

title: INTERNET MERGER TALKS
description: Italy's third largest Internet service provider, Tiscali, is in preliminary talks to acquire its rival in the Netherlands, World Online, executives close to the negotiations said. Such an acquisition would make the combined company Europe's second-largest Internet service provider behind T-Online, the Deutsche Telekom Internet unit. The executives said that a deal was not imminent and that both companies were examining alternatives. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWELL, MARLA
description: NEWELL-Marla. On August 4, 2000. The Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue mourns the untimely passing of its First Vice President, former President, and beloved friend. Our heartfelt condolences to husband Roger, and son and daughter Paul and Sonya. We will continue to be inspired by the legacy of her keen judgement, depth of knowledge, strong moral values, and devotion to Judaism and to our synagogue. Services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, August 6, at 11:15 AM. Cantor Irwin Gelman President Roselle Mironer

title: AGILENT AGREES TO BUY DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY
description: Agilent Technologies Inc., a test and measurement company spun off by Hewlett-Packard, agreed to buy the closely held Digital Technology Inc. and Dynamic Digital Technology Private Ltd. Terms were not disclosed. Dynamic, based in Calcutta, and its sister company, Digital Technology, based in Bedford, Mass., have 34 employees and operate as one company, making software that tests networks. The acquisition will add to Agilent's line of testing equipment. Agilent, based in Palo Alto, Calif., builds testing equipment ranging from medical devices like ultrasound machines to complex products that test semiconductors during manufacturing.

title: Convention Demonstrators Are Held on Very High Bail
description: With bail being set as high as $1 million for protesters accused of blocking streets during the Republican National Convention, defense and civil liberties lawyers today questioned whether the city court action was a punitive measure intended to discourage the next round of civil disobedience, planned for the Democrats' convention in Los Angeles.

title: Utrecht Journal; An Evangelist City Built On a World Foundation
description: In a vast and utilitarian exhibition center, 7,000 people have assembled in what is probably one of the most ethnically diverse, but purposefully homogenous, encampments on earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, PATRICIA
description: CLARKE-Patricia. On August 3, 2000. Retired history teacher Newtown High School. Beloved wife of Richard an international mother of Armando, Edward, Christoph, Klaus, Bruno, Jorge, Alex, Salvador, Luke and Jan. Dear daughter of Jayne Mangan. Loving sister of Maureen and Greg. Reposing Cusimano and Russo, Inc., 2005 W. 6 Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:15 AM, Saint Simon and Jude RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Pentagon Disputes Bush Comment on Readiness
description: Pentagon officials today rebutted Gov. George W. Bush's assertion that 2 of the Army's 10 active divisions were not able to report for duty.

title: Aetna Posts 17% Profit Fall; Cites Progress on Changes
description: Aetna, the nation's largest health insurer, reported a 17 percent drop in second-quarter profits yesterday as more people sought increasingly costlier treatment. But it said it was moving along on sweeping changes aimed at improving business.

title: Religion Journal; Endorsing Ecumenism at an Evangelical Gathering
description: When the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association planned a conference here this week for evangelists from around the world, it signed up a raft of prominent speakers, many of them very well known among evangelical Protestants.

title: HOMECOM COMMUNICATIONS SELLING INSURERATE UNIT
description: HomeCom Communications Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its InsureRate unit to a group of investors that includes management as it focuses on Internet banking software and Web consulting. HomeCom, based in Atlanta, said 35 jobs would be cut because of the sale, allowing the company to reduce costs and increase cash flow. The Internet software maker also said its chief financial officer, Jim Ellsworth, had resigned and would be replaced by Tim Robinson. Mr. Ellsworth left the company to become chief financial officer of InsureRate. The company said it expected to complete the transaction this month.

title: AIRLINE TAKEOVER IN CHINA
description: China's biggest airline, the Southern Airlines Company, said its parent company would take over Zhongyuan Airlines, the first airline merger since the government called July 21 for an industry consolidation to deal with overlapping routes and half-empty planes. Craig S. Smith

title: Philippines Faces Long Guerrilla War : On Mindanao, a Victory but No Peace
description: CAMP SARMIENTO, Philippines  The bullet-spattered walls of the local mosque, the crumpled heaps of flimsy homes, the craters by the dirt road all testify to the ferocity of the attack a month ago on what was once the military headquarters of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front.

title: Free of Missteps And of Suspense
description: Watching the Republican National Convention from his living room, James Greer, a 54-year-old lawyer and an independent, found himself awash in pleasantness.

title: Britain's Queen Mother Marks 100th Birthday
description: Surrounded by three generations of the royal family, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother celebrated her 100th birthday today waving to cheering well-wishers from the Buckingham Palace balcony where she had marked the end of World War II and helped lead national rejoicing on other occasions.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Shows in Which the Real Is Fake and the Fake Is Real
description: Watching Greg, the Ivy League graduate, earnestly pretend a coconut is his cell phone in the middle of the jungle, or Richard, the scheming corporate consultant, strip naked in honor of his birthday; watching Mega, the black nationalist, sarcastically tell one-legged Eddie that he supports ''cripple rights,'' or Karen, the troubled housewife, confess her affair with her stepfather's nephew -- watching these ''real life'' moments from the television shows ''Survivor'' and ''Big Brother'' (or the latter's 24-hour-a-day live Web site), I felt an all too familiar twinge.

title: Addicted to Talking
description: While sitting in a coffee shop the other day, I had an epiphany. Surrounded by men and women cuddling their cell phones, it struck me that these little metallic instruments are this millennium's cigarette.

title: Journal; The G.O.P.'s Age of Aquarius
description: Who says the G.O.P. is against welfare? The show it put on here was nothing if not a bountiful assistance program, providing food, drink and shelter for 15,000 journalists who found themselves seriously underemployed at a political convention without fisticuffs. In keeping with Republican orthodoxy, the bill for this welfare program was picked up by the private sector -- the journalists' employers -- and not the taxpayer. What is compassionate conservatism if not life on an expense account?

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in the Writers on Writing series on Monday by Hans Koning, about his commitment to serious fiction, misspelled the title of a novel of his. It is ''Kleber Flight,'' not ''Kleber Plight.''

title: Rangers Trade for Toughness
description: The Rangers got tougher yesterday, acquiring the physical right wing Sandy McCarthy from the Carolina Hurricanes for Rob DiMaio and Darren Langdon. The Rangers also received a fourth-round pick in 2001.

title: GORE FIRES BACK, HOPING TO DAMPEN CONVENTION SPIRIT
description: After suffering days of Republican barbs in silence, Vice President Al Gore returned from vacation today swinging back hard, accusing the Republicans of running a showy, but insubstantial convention and strongly claiming credit for having helped create the nation's roaring economy.

title: Anarchism, the Creed That Won't Stay Dead; The Spread of World Capitalism Resurrects a Long-Dormant Movement
description: Since Karl Marx bested the anarchist leader Mikhail Bakunin in a struggle to shape world revolution a century and a half ago, anarchism has undergone a half-dozen resurrections and almost as many deaths.

title: Military Contract for G.E.
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said it had selected General Electric to provide engines for an updated version of its Galaxy transport aircraft for the Air Force, a contract that could be valued at up to $2.6 billion. Lockheed, the world's largest military contractor, expects to be awarded the work by the Air Force in the first quarter of 2001. The contract calls for General Electric to supply 504 jet engines and spare parts over 10 years.

title: A Year Out of Bankruptcy, Barneys Is Still Looking for Sure Footing
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Gore Writing His Speech By Himself
description: With the Democratic National Convention just a few days off, Vice President Al Gore spent part of his beach vacation in North Carolina writing his own speech accepting the presidential nomination.

title: Glavine Wins 7th Straight
description: Tom Glavine, helped by a season-high four St. Louis errors, won his seventh straight start as Atlanta won, 6-4, last night in St. Louis.

title: Wave of Illicit Drugs Rolls In, And a Slice of Suburbia Reels
description: The sign, in front of the high school here, is an unavoidable warning to anyone driving through this sprawling township on the Jersey Shore.

title: Bowing to the Middle, Keeping to the Right
description: With his convention speech, Gov. George W. Bush created a synthesis new to Republican politics: conservative policies described in ways that his campaign believes swing voters will love.

title: Ferreting Out North Korea's Nuclear Secrets: U.S. Intelligence Experts at Odds
description: Behind the growing debate over whether to build a new national missile defense against countries like North Korea lies an old and bitter dispute over how to interpret the frustratingly limited intelligence data on one of the world's most secretive nations.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Board Sues Web Impersonators of Chief
description: The New York Stock Exchange filed a lawsuit yesterday against 10 unidentified people on charges of impersonating its chairman and chief executive, Richard A. Grasso, on a popular Internet message board.

title: HYUNDAI REVISES REVAMPING PLAN
description: Bowing to pressure from creditors, the Hyundai Group of South Korea said it expected to release a new plan to spin off its auto-related business units. The company said the proposal would include splitting off the Hyundai Motor Company from the group, after lowering the 9.1 percent stake held by the Hyundai Group founder Chung Ju Yung to less than 3 percent, as the government has been requesting. Mr. Chung, meanwhile, was hospitalized suffering from what company officials called fatigue. Samuel Len

title: Marketing Firm Agrees to Credit Ruffled Patrons
description: BrandDirect Marketing Inc., a large telemarketing company here that operates numerous discount shopping clubs, has agreed to pay $1.9 million to the states of Connecticut and Washington and to credit customers with $11 million in club membership fees, settling a federal lawsuit over allegations that it violated consumer protection laws, the state attorney general said today.

title: Tacoma Journal; Its Air Cleaned, Its Tech High, a City Rebounds
description: When EssentialMarkets.com was looking for a place to establish headquarters a year and a half ago, executives at the Internet start-up thought first of the better-known software capitals of the Pacific Northwest.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose as an unexpected drop in inventories caused concern about a possible shortage of heating oil this winter. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose $1.30, or 4.5 percent, to $29.96.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Representative Rick A. Lazio's appearance on ''The Bob Grant Show'' misstated the call letters of the radio station that carries it. The station is WOR-AM (710), not WWOR.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Pentagon's costs for shipping military equipment to a display near the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia misstated the amount spent by the Navy. It was $146,796, not $246,796.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Bush family members at the Republican National Convention misidentified a sister-in-law of George W. Bush. She was Margaret Bush, the wife of Marvin Bush -- not Columba Bush, the wife of Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.

title: Attack Is Sharp but Defense Falters
description: Keyshawn Johnson must be cringing. Two games into the preseason, the Jets' starting offense seems unstoppable.

title: INSIDE
description: Job Growth Cools Down

title: Abroad at Home; For Gerald Ford
description: The posturings and hypocrisies of the Republican Convention were pushed aside, in my mind, by the news that President Ford had suffered a small stroke. It made all the talk in Philadelphia seem even emptier.

title: A Role for the Concorde, Even With Its High Costs
description: The crash of the Air France supersonic Concorde brought down a plane that by common measurements can hardly be profitable, given its high maintenance costs, daunting fuel bills, little passenger space, and no cargo. Yet any decision to permanently ground the Concorde could have deep financial implications for the two airlines that run it.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin and Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Speed Computer Exports Relaxed
description: High-Speed Computer Exports Relaxed

title: Taking a Scientist's Approach to the Problems of Politics
description: SO how does a physicist who expanded on Einstein's theory of relativity with a treatise called Supersymmetric Flipped SU (5) find himself running for president?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORNBERG, ELY
description: ZORNBERG-Ely. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club extend our heartfelt condolences to our members Ed and Flo Zornberg on the loss of their dear son, Ely. Jay M. Rosen, President Corey B. Rabin, Secretary

title: Dayne Will Get the Ball Early and Often Tonight
description: There is always a new player or two making his debut in a team's first preseason game, and this year the Giants are hardly being furtive about who will be in the showcase during tonight's game against the Chicago Bears at Giants Stadium.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Major Market Indexes Rise On Slower Job Growth Data

title: Internet Sales Could Cost States $11 Billion in 2003
description: Internet Sales Could Cost States $11 Billion in 2003

title: Aided by 'Millionaire,' Bush Tops Dole's TV Ratings
description: Nearly 18 million people watched the coverage of George W. Bush's acceptance speech on ABC, CBS and NBC on Thursday night, compared with the 17.8 million who watched the coverage of Bob Dole's on the major networks on the final night of the 1996 Republican convention, according to Nielsen Media Research data.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MERESMAN, HELEN CHAFETS
description: MERESMAN-Helen Chafets Lovingly remembered today and everyday

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MERCATOR SOFTWARE INC., Wilton, Conn., the maker of software that links incompatible computers, said it had agreed to market products and build software with Tibco Software Inc., Palo Alto, Calif. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: IVAX TO PURCHASE WAKEFIELD PHARMACEUTICALS
description: The Ivax Corporation, one of the largest makers of generic drugs, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held respiratory-medicine marketer Wakefield Pharmaceuticals Inc. to expand its sales force as it prepares for new drug approvals. Financial terms were not disclosed. Wakefield, based in Alpharetta, Ga., has a sales staff of more than 50 people, Ivax said. Miami-based Ivax had sales of $656.3 million last year. The purchase will help Ivax sell its growing line of proprietary products like the Easi-Breathe asthma inhaler, currently sold in Europe and awaiting regulatory approval in the United States, the company said.

title: With Phone Strike Near, A New Offer
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest wireless and local phone company, moved yesterday to avoid a strike by more than 86,000 telephone workers from Maine to Virginia by submitting a proposal addressing some of its unions' main contract concerns.

title: Recruiting Freshmen
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROBER, BESSIE (NEE SHAVELSON)
description: PROBER-Bessie (nee Shavelson). Wife of the late Abraham Prober. Mother of Susan Prober Siegel (Daniel). Services ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ, Sunday 12 noon. Donations to American Cancer Society or charity of your choice. For information please call 1-800-322-0533

title: Coaches Questioned His Injuries, Hernandez Says
description: Orlando Hernandez said yesterday that there are Yankees coaches who doubted the severity of his injuries when he was placed on the disabled list last month.

title: Some Fence-Sitters Are Staying Put
description: Maurice Vanegas is precisely the kind of person Gov. George W. Bush has been straining to speak to this past week. He is Latino and a small-business owner, he hews to the political center, and he is undecided about his vote this November. But after watching the Republican convention, Mr. Vanegas is also a skeptic.

title: The Joy of Making Music Never Fades
description: To the Editor:

title: Year's First Human Case of West Nile Is Found as Outbreak Widens
description: A 78-year-old Staten Island man has the unlucky distinction of having the nation's first known case of West Nile encephalitis this year, health officials said today. Meanwhile, birds found dead from the disease from the Atlantic almost to Lake Erie led the state health commissioner to declare the first statewide outbreak of the virus.

title: China Objects to Taiwan Leader's U.S. Visa
description: China criticized the United States today for giving Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, a visa to stop in Los Angeles next week on his way to the Caribbean and expressed indignation at the island's annual effort to join the United Nations.

title: Dr. Richard K. Hill Child Psychiatrist, 64
description: Dr. Richard K. Hill, a child psychiatrist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died Thursday in New York. He was 64 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Watching, Listening, Hoping for a President
description: Tamara Allen wanted to like what she saw. She was in the market for a president. She voted for Bill Clinton in two elections, and for Ronald Reagan before that. But she reacted to the Republican National Convention with disappointed venom.

title: India Plans to Double IT Workers to Meet Global Demand
description: India Plans to Double IT Workers to Meet Global Demand

title: RIO TINTO WINS NORTH
description: Trumped by Rio Tinto's counteroffer, Anglo American P.L.C. ended its bid to acquire North Ltd., the Australian mining company that is one of the world's biggest producers of iron ore. Anglo, the South African mining conglomerate, bid $1.8 billion last month, topping Rio Tinto's original offer for North and setting the stage for what would have been an important acquisition for Anglo as it seeks to expand outside South Africa. But this week, Rio Tinto countered with an offer that was nearly 11 percent higher and Anglo's board decided the company could not justify raising the price further. Henri E. Cauvin

title: Editorial Observer; The Republicans Call a Cease-Fire on Cities
description: The Republican Party signaled a shift in attitude toward cities when it chose Philadelphia for this week's national convention. The party in recent years has used big urban centers as metaphors of moral decay and examples of faulty Democratic stewardship. But the choice of Philadelphia revealed the G.O.P.'s intent to abandon an anti-urban rhetoric that had proved alienating to moderate suburban voters.

title: Job Growth Slows, Suggesting Fed May Not Raise Interest Rates
description: American companies added fewer jobs in July than economists had expected, reducing the chances that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates when it meets later this month, analysts said.

title: MISTAKEN IDENTITY
description: Kerry Sanders looked nothing like Robert Sanders, an escaped convict. His fingerprints, had they been checked, would not have matched the fugitive's. He simply shared a last name and a date of birth, and those were enough to keep him in prison for two years. A report by Benjamin Weiser in The Times Magazine.

title: Op-Art; More Weird Weather Coming Your Way
Call Him, But Don't Call Him Al
description: IF you were among the 11 New Yorkers who watched the Republican National Convention gavel to gavel, you no doubt noticed that a running theme was the need to restore dignity to the White House.

title: DANA, MAKER OF TRUCK AXLES, IS AWARDED BIG CONTRACT
description: The Dana Corporation, the world's largest maker of light-truck axles, won a contract from the General Motors Corporation for as much as $150 million a year, an analyst, David Garrity, said. Dana would not identify the size of the contract, for car and cargo-van axles starting with 2003 models, or the automaker involved. The order will be filled by plants in Missouri and Virginia.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Blacklisted Screenwriters Get Credits
description: The Writers Guild has announced that the writing credits on 14 films released from 1951 to 1964 will be corrected to include the names of several screenwriters blacklisted by Hollywood studios. The current credits on the films either omitted a blacklisted writer's name or used a pseudonym.

title: Chief of Bed-Stuy Economic Group Quits
description: The president of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation resigned abruptly this week after criticism that his organization -- the nation's oldest economic development corporation -- was failing in its mission of reviving central Brooklyn's economy.

title: Challenging Mr. Milosevic
description: Slobodan Milosevic is running for another term as Yugoslavia's president in an unfair election that he will most likely win by any means necessary. Nevertheless, the opposition should run against him. No one believes that Mr. Milosevic will leave office simply because voters tell him to. But if the opposition can unite on a single presidential candidate for the elections, in late September, it can at least revitalize its popular support and shake some of the apathy that is paralyzing Serbia.

title: Corrections
description: In some copies, a picture of Jeb Bush with the Florida delegation carried an incorrect credit. The photographer was Andrea Mohin of The New York Times.

title: Internet Body Accepting Proposals for Domain Name Alternatives
description: Internet Body Accepting Proposals for Domain Name Alternatives

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDMAN, JANE PIERSON
description: ERDMAN-Jane Pierson. On August 4, 2000 at her home. Mrs. Erdman was the wife of the late William H. Loving mother of Joy Amy Pierson and Brad & Tammy Felenstein. Devoted grandmother of Grant and Laura Felenstein. She was cherished and will be missed. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 6th at the Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel at 12:30 PM in Hartsdale, NY.

title: Mexico's Best Drops a Queen To Turn a Declarer's Head
description: Some of the greatest players in the history of the game will be named to the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame in Anaheim, Calif., on Thursday. In the living category, Sidney Lazard and Ira Rubin have been elected. Among deceased players, Lou Bluhm, Harry Fishbein and Charles Solomon are being honored. The Von Zedtwitz Award for deceased players will go to Meyer Schleifer, and the Blackwood Award, for various contributions to the game, to George Rosenkranz.

title: NISSAN SELLS DRIVE SHAFT MAKER
description: As part of its efforts to focus on the core business and reduce its heavy debts, the Nissan Motor Company will sell a unit that makes drive shafts for all of its domestic vehicles to GKN Japan Ltd., a subsidiary of GKN P.L.C. of Britain, a leading maker of automotive parts. Nissan will raise 9 billion yen, or about $83 million at current exchange rates, from the deal. The troubled Japanese car manufacturer has been selling assets including land, manufacturing operations and stakes in affiliate companies to raise cash and return to

title: With Cone's Return, Gooden Goes to Bullpen
description: With the reliever Ramiro Mendoza out indefinitely and David Cone returning to the rotation today, Dwight Gooden will move into the Yankees' bullpen for the foreseeable future.

title: Man Arrested In Killings Of Six Women
description: The police arrested a homeless panhandler yesterday in the killings of six women in Brooklyn whose deaths stirred fear among residents of Williamsburg and nearby areas that a serial killer was in their midst.

title: U.S. Fears Montenegro May Be Target For Milosevic
description: The United States is increasingly worried that Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav leader, will move militarily against Montenegro, the junior republic in Yugoslavia, forcing Washington and NATO into the awkward position of deciding how to react, Clinton administration officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITHERS, ELEANOR VEY THIBAUT
description: SMITHERS-Eleanor Vey Thibaut, 90. Of Hot Springs, Va. Died Tuesday, August 1 at her residence. She was born October 25, 1909, Brooklyn, N.Y., the daughter of Richard E. and Helen Cranford Thibaut. She was preceded in death by her husband Charles Francis Smithers. She is survived by a daughter Mary Vey Smithers of Antiqua, Guatamala and Hot Springs, a niece Jacqueline Eubanks of Stuart, Fla, a stepson Charles F. Smithers, Jr. of New York, three grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. A service will be held Sunday, 4PM August 6 at her residence. A private interment will be in Woodlawn Cemetery in New York. Memorial contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11225. For more information call McLaughlin Funeral Home at 540-839-2961.

title: The Dream of College
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Penalty: No Ivy Title
description: The Ivy League has ruled that Brown's football team is ineligible to win the league championship because it illegally gave financial aid to players.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Philadelphia Diary column about a speech by Jeb Bush's son, George P. Bush, misstated his age. It is 24, not 23.

title: A Dream Becomes Real, Writ Large on the Page
description: Growing up in Uganda, Moses Isegawa was an insatiable reader, savoring books by writers as diverse as Philip Roth, V. S. Naipaul, Timothy Mo and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. From the age of 14, he dreamed about becoming a novelist himself. ''I thought it must be magical to be a writer,'' he said recently. ''To tell a story and somebody deep in a village in Uganda reads it and can identify with the place and the characters -- I never lost that idea of the magic and the excitement of literature.''

title: Alaska Airlines Grounds Jets To Recheck Tail Mechanisms
description: Alaska Airlines said today that it had canceled 48 flights in the past two days after grounding 17 of its 34 MD-80 aircraft for inspections. Those planes are the same model as the one that crashed off the Southern California coast in January, killing 88 people, when a part in the tail section malfunctioned.

title: Arrest in Killing of Woman, 81
description: A Queens man who was interviewed by television stations this week after his 81-year-old neighbor was slain outside her apartment door has been arrested in the killing, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Knicks Give No Guarantees to Fortson
description: Danny Fortson got to ride in a black limousine, but that was about it. There was no star-studded video presentation as there was for Grant Hill, no yachting excursion as there was for Brian Grant, and no promise of a major role on the team.

title: Moliere With Sight Gags, Mugging and Other Clowning
description: Farce, as Moliere knew, is a very serious business, and anyone attempting to ''adapt'' the French master with modern gimmickry will find a lot of bumps along the way. Keith Reddin, who has reworked ''The Imaginary Invalid'' into an extended skit called ''The Perpetual Patient,'' hits just about every pothole.

title: VIVENDI REVENUE RISES
description: The French conglomerate Vivendi, which recently said it was acquiringSeagram, reported that revenue in the first half-year increased 9 percent, to 19.4 billion euros, or $17.5 billion, largely as a result of growth in its television and cellular phone businesses. Revenue at Vivendi Environment, the group's water, waste management and transportation units, which were spun off as a separate company in July, increased more than 41 percent from acquisitions. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASANUMA, HIROSHI
description: ASANUMA-Hiroshi. The Rockefeller University community mourns, with deep sadness, the loss of our distinguished colleague and beloved friend, Hiroshi Asanuma. Dr. Asanuma was a pioneer in the study of how the brain controls muscle movement and the learning of motor skills. A valued member of the Rockefeller University community for more than twentyfive years, he will long be remembered for his contributions to the scientific understanding of the neurophysiology of movement as well as for his deep commitment to graduate education and his skill as a physician. Dr. Asanuma will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard Fisher, Chairman, Board of Trustees David Rockefeller, Hon. Chairman and Life Trustee, Board of Trustees

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Helen Quinn, 76, the Queen Of Standees at the Met Opera
description: Helen Quinn, who for more than 30 years presided firmly over the Metropolitan Opera patrons who lined up every Saturday morning to buy standing-room tickets for the next week's performances, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a suit against the Syrian government by the family of an Israeli-American man killed in a 1996 terrorist attack in Jerusalem misstated the position of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kanaan, one of two Syrian defendants. He is the chief of military intelligence, not commander of the Syrian forces in Lebanon.

title: Surprising Burst of Speed In the Sunset of a Career
description: Twenty-four delightful and exhausting hours later, Darrell Waltrip's right hand was killing him. Waltrip, flexing his hand and balling it into a fist again and again, said he could deal with the pain that only politicians on whistle-stop tours can really know.

title: Where Finding Space Is Just a Start; Unwanted Adventures Await Droves Who Move to City
description: Finding the apartment was the easy part. The problems started when the fellows moved in.

title: A Park for Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Fred W. Hooper, 102, a Leading Owner and Breeder in Thoroughbred Racing, Dies
description: Fred W. Hooper, who became one of the giants of horse racing after he won the Kentucky Derby in 1945 with his first thoroughbred, Hoop Jr., died yesterday in Ocala, Fla. He was 102 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEIR, L. DEAN
description: SPEIR-L. Dean, 87. Of Dorset, VT. Formerly of Madison, NJ. Beloved husband for 60 yrs. of June Singleton Speir. Survived by 5 children, Lawrence, Gordon, Caryl, Marvin and Linda; eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial service 2 P.M. Sunday, August 6, at the United Church of Christ, Dorset, VT. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or Manchester Vermont Rescue Squad.

title: Board's Criteria Shorten School Manager List
description: When executives of Inside Broadway, a nonprofit arts education program, learned that the New York City Board of Education planned to turn some of the city's worst-performing schools over to private hands, they decided to take a chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESNICK, JEANNE ABERMAN
description: BRESNICK - Jeanne Aberman, died August 4, 2000 at age 94. Much loved mother of Barbara, Paul, and Gail Goldman, Grandmother of Laurie, Emily, Rabinder, Lewis and Polly. New York Interior Decorator, good friend, generous heart, great lady who will be very much missed. Memorial service Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn L.I., Sunday, August 6, 2000. Donations may be made to Christian Life Center, 2699 W.Commercial Blvd., Ft. Lauderdale, FL, in honor of Sharon Taylor, devoted caregiver.

title: EURO-ZONE INFLATION PRESSURE
description: Producer prices for manufactured goods in the 11 European countries that adopted the single currency rose 5.6 percent in June, the 16th consecutive month with an increase. Economists said growth was creating inflationary pressure and manyexpect the European Central Bank to raise interest rates next month. John Tagliabue

title: Whitney Is Next Stop for Running Stag
description: In search of fun and pots of gold, three jolly Englishmen have traveled to France, Germany, Dubai and Hong Kong, as well as Massachusetts, Kentucky and New York. They fly, of course, but it is a horse that leads them to these locales. His name is Running Stag, and he has logged more miles than many heads of state, hitting new soil with ground-burning speed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, HENRY J.
description: O'BRIEN-Henry J. On August 3, 2000. Loving brother-in-law of Elizabeth Philips. Dear brother of Margaret Ackley, Ernest O'Brien, Alice Freehill, Jane White and the late John and Alma O'Brien. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday 7-9PM and Sun 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass will be held at our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Elmsford, NY at 11AM on Monday. Interment to follow at the Gate of Heaven cemetery.

title: SUMMER AT P.S. 19: A special report.; 5 Weeks to Alter the Course Of Education in Young Lives
description: Shukria Akhtar wants to be a doctor when she grows up. Tidy in the loose tunic, slacks and scarf prescribed by her Muslim religion, she seems temperamentally well suited for the job. She is gentle, caring and patient. There is one hitch: she is 10 years old, going into fifth grade, but still reading and calculating at kindergarten level.

title: Yahoo to Release Info on Accused Leaker of Apple Secrets
description: Yahoo to Release Info on Accused Leaker of Apple Secrets

title: PFIZER HALTS TESTS OF DRUG FOR 2 TYPES OF CANCER
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it had halted two advanced tests of an experimental drug after studies did not show the expected benefits in patients with prostate and lung cancer. Pfizer said it would continue tests of the drug, called prinomastat, in other types of tumors and would focus on patients in earlier stages of disease. The drug was in so-called Phase 3 trials, the last and most extensive of three stages of required testing. Prinomastat is a compound made by Pfizer's Agouron unit.

title: No Kidding: Does Irony Illuminate Or Corrupt?
description: One person who was glad when ''Seinfeld'' ended was Jedediah Purdy. He is also, no doubt, eagerly awaiting Bart Simpson's retirement. Mr. Purdy is the home-schooled West Virginia wunderkind who last year, at the age of 25, published ''For Common Things,'' an earnest, impassioned homily that urged us to rediscover civic virtue, both in government and in our private lives, and that blamed for our current malaise nothing less than irony itself.

title: Concorde Crash Inquiry Looks at Runway Debris
description: Investigators looking into last week's crash of an Air France Concorde said today that they had found a 16-inch strip of metal on the runway that did not belong to the plane, and that they have also found a large gash in a piece of tire debris.

title: Sony Postpones PlayStation2 European Launch Due to Supply Problems
description: Sony Postpones PlayStation2 European Launch Due to Supply Problems

title: Netscape to Remove Feature in SmartDownload
description: Netscape to Remove Feature in SmartDownload

title: Arabs Strive for New Consensus On an Israeli-Palestinian Treaty
description: On the face of it, Arab support for the Palestinian position has never been so unified. One after another, Arab kings and presidents have said they stand behind Yasir Arafat's claim to East Jerusalem and the right of return for Palestinian refugees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, IRMA
description: SHERMAN-Irma. Passed away peacefully at home on August 2, 2000. She had a long and wonderful life with her family and friends. Beloved wife for forty-seven years of Julius H. Sherman; loving mother of Valerie, Amy, James and Cornelia; mother-in-law of Richard, John & Robert; devoted grandmother of David, Alexander, Lily, Julia, Michael, Emily and Jack; sister of Lydia; aunt of Candace, Stephen & Merrill. Services on Sunday, August 6, 2000 at 11:30 A.M., at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice. She is loved and will be missed until we are all together again.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I came out of this with anything, it's that I want a debate. Bad.''

title: Clinton Plans a Day Trip to Bolster Colombia
description: President Clinton will make a one-day trip to Colombia this month to support its struggle against narcotics and spotlight the $1.3 billion aid package that Congress approved last month, the White House said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEDER, MARTIN A.
description: ROEDER-Martin A. On August 3, 2000. Cherished husband of Dorothy (Friedman) for 61 years, adored father of Katherine Roeder, Thomas and Susan Roeder, beloved grandfather of Sarah and Louisa Roeder, Kenneth Hartog and Erik Hartog & Pamela Heller. Son of the late Judge Jehial M. Roeder and the late Evelyn Finegold Roeder. Mr. Roeder was Of Counsel to Herzfeld and Rubin and former managing partner of Guggenheimer and Untermeyer. He had a degree from the Sorbonne in Paris, a BA and LLB from Columbia University and Columbia Law School of New York. He served on the boards of the Emanu-el Brotherbood and the Tax Management Institute of New York University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 7-9PM with services Tuesday 11:30AM. Interment private.
