In lieu of flowers contributions to The Jewish Repertory Theater of the 92nd St. YM-YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

title: N.A.A.C.P. to Spend $7 Million In Bid to Mobilize Black Voters
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, seeking to play a more active role in the presidential elections this year, is planning to mount a multimillion-dollar campaign to mobilize and register black voters.

title: TEXTRON'S AUTOMOTIVE UNIT TAKES EUROPEAN PARTNER
description: The automotive unit of Textron Inc., North America's largest maker of instrument panels, and Valeo S.A.. the No. 2 European car-parts producer, agreed to jointly make dashboard systems and related parts. Financial terms were not disclosed. The companies plan to combine technology and engineering resources in the venture, which is set to begin in a few months. The companies will make so-called cockpit modules that include instrument panels, switches, electronics, heating systems and steering columns. The market for such systems is expected to grow to 10 million a year by 2004 from about three million now, the companies said. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., also makes Cessna airplanes. Valeo, based in Paris, makes air-conditioning systems, electronics and other auto parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, HOWARD
description: SHELDON-Howard. Age 90, in Greenwich Hospital on August 3, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Fay, cherished father of Gay Goldman and her husband Carl, adored grandfather of Lewis, Leslie and Patricia. Dear great-grandfather of Leah and Jason Goldman, Noah Lack, and Quinn Perini. A compassionate and loving man, who practiced law till the age of 80, he will be greatly missed. Service on Monday 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Swimmer Remembers The Fuhrer
description: THERE had been a commotion, Adolph Kiefer remembers, and everyone stopped what he was doing and looked around. There were German soldiers and an entourage surrounding Adolf Hitler entering the training-pool area in the Olympic village in Berlin. This was shortly before the start of the Games in 1936. Kiefer recalls Hitler taking a seat at poolside and watching some of the training session, and then the German Fuhrer asked to meet him and two other swimmers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNODGRASS, JAMES F.
description: SNODGRASS-James F. On August 3, 2000 at age 78. He is survived by his brother, John Snodgrass. A memorial will be held on August 13, 1:00 PM at the artist's studio on Staten Island.

title: Officials Unable to Identify Source of Deadly Bacteria
description: New Jersey health investigators have been unable to pinpoint the source of E. coli bacteria that fatally poisoned a 20-month-old boy from Parsippany this week, officials said yesterday.

title: Web-Based Calls No Threat to Telephone ... Yet
description: Web-Based Calls No Threat to Telephone ... Yet

title: Late Field Goal Lifts the Patriots
description: Adam Vinatieri's 28-yard field goal with two seconds remaining lifted visiting New England to a 13-10 victory over Detroit last night in a preseason game.

title: Chips Off the P.& G. Block; Can a Start-Up Clean Up With Cast-Off Brands?
description: Todd Wichmann and Richard Owen barreled into the Procter & Gamble headquarters last month and were about to head upstairs when the security guard stopped them.

title: ALCOA BUYS BACO CONSUMER PRODUCTS OF LONDON
description: Alcoa Inc., the world's biggest aluminum maker, said yesterday that it had bought the London-based Baco Consumer Products Ltd. for an undisclosed price to increase its sale of household plastic wrap and aluminum foil in Europe. Basco's principal investor is the closely held Luxfer Holdings P.L.C. of Britain. The company is Britain's biggest seller of aluminum foil and plastic bags. Alcoa, which acquired Reynolds Metals, the maker of Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil, in May, wants to sell more of its consumer products in Europe.

title: A Times Sq. Sinatra Gets Under Their Skin
description: The Rev. Francis Patrick Duffy got a spot in Times Square in 1936 for his heroics on the battlefield and the streets of Hell's Kitchen. George M. Cohan followed in 1959 as a tribute to one of show business's greatest song and dance men.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERKOWITZ, EMILY. (A
description: BERKOWITZ-Emily. (a/a) Berk/d. On August 3, 2000. Dear daughter of the late Isaac Rose Berkowitz. Cherished sister of Sara Ilian and the late Cele Rothbart and Renee Thomashauer. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Dear friend of Fredrica Eidelsberg. Services Monday, August 7, 10:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: German Publishers Square Off to Keep Online Book Discounters at Bay
description: German Publishers Square Off to Keep Online Book Discounters at Bay

title: Dream Ride In Hambletonian
description: Even though he has driven 8,493 winners, Dave Magee has never had a horse fast enough to compete in the Hambletonian. As the pilot of Dreamaster, the early-line favorite, Magee will try to capture the ultimate event in harness racing in his first attempt on Saturday afternoon at the Meadowlands.

title: 5 Are Injured in Queens Club by Man With Knife
description: Two men were seriously injured and three others were slashed by a knife-wielding attacker in a crowded Queens nightclub described by the police as a trouble spot, the authorities said yesterday.

title: South African Townships' Poor Brave a Deadly Journey Just to Get to Work
description: Every day when Oscar Picane heads off to work, he leaves behind a wife who worries she will never see him again. He is not a police officer or a soldier or a miner, or even a gangster. He is a bus driver here in this sprawling township south of Cape Town, doing a job that has become, for the moment at least, the deadliest occupation in a country with no shortage of dangerous jobs.

title: Article 2000080591083370672 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGG, EVERETT C., M.D.
description: BRAGG-Everett C., M.D. Passed away at his home on August 2, 2000, at the age of 86 years. Everett was the devoted husband for 59 years of Mary Bragg (nee Holt). Loving father of Everett E. (Sherrill) of Lima, Peru, James B. (Deborah) of Darien, CT. and Malley (Thomas) Heinlein of Sawkill, NY. Proud grandfather of 6 grandchildren and 1 great-grandchild. Dear brother of Oliver B. Bragg of Sterling, VA. Everett was a graduate of Cornell University and Cornell Medical School. He was a professor and orthopedic surgeon at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City. He was also the head of orthopedic surgery at St. Francis Hospital in New York. In 1979, Everett became an Orthopedic Surgeon Consultant at Milwaukee Industrial Clinics which later became the Occupation Medical Clinics. Contact Feerick Funeral Home, 414-962-8383.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Rattlesnake Bites Again, This Time in the Wallet
description: Nathan A. Schomber probably learned a lesson at a wilderness park last month, when he picked up a rattlesnake and was bitten. And a further lesson when he had an allergic reaction to the antivenin and spent several days in an intensive care unit.

title: Amazons Revenue Largely in Stocks
description: Amazon's Revenue Largely in Stocks

title: Posada Erupts In No. 2 Slot As Yanks Win
description: The idea formed within the imagination of the bench coach Don Zimmer. He and Manager Joe Torre and the hitting coach Chris Chambliss gathered outside Torre's office and discussed the framework of the Yankees' lineup last night, and determined Derek Jeter would lead off. They were not sure who would bat second.

title: Man Is Killed By F Train
description: A man was struck and killed by a subway train early this morning on the tracks at a station in Queens, a fire official said.

title: 'Carmina Burana' Quits the Monastery for Wall Street
description: Lynne Taylor-Corbett admits that her first reaction was ''No!'' when she was asked to create a new version of Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana'' for the Carolina Ballet in Raleigh, N.C., where she was recently named to a five-year term as principal guest choreographer. In the 1950's and 60's, monks seemed to thunder across just about every ballet stage in Europe and the United States to the immensely popular Orff setting of racy Latin songs from a German monastery. But that was the choice of Raleigh audiences surveyed by the Carolina troupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAFFATONE, ANTHONY NEIL
description: MAFFATONE-Anthony Neil, December 24, 1943-August 2, 2000. The Producer Circle mourns the sudden loss of our friend and colleague Tony, whose wise, honest counsel and uncompromising integrity we shall so profoundly miss. Our deepest condolences to his family. Martin Richards, Sam Crothers, Maryanne Dittmann, Monique Bell, Dan Gallagher, Michael Milton.

title: Unilever Announces Plans to Reorganize Into Two Divisions
description: Unilever P.L.C., the global consumer goods giant that has been on a buying spree in the United States, announced a major reorganization of top management today. The move would split the company into two divisions, one focused on food brands like Lipton Tea and Ragu spaghetti sauce and the other on consumer products like Dove soap and Elizabeth Arden cosmetics.

title: First West Nile Case Of Year Is Confirmed
description: A 78-year-old Staten Island man has the unlucky distinction of having the nation's first known case of West Nile encephalitis this year, health officials said. Meanwhile, birds found dead from the disease from the Atlantic almost to Lake Erie led the state health commissioner to declare the first statewide outbreak of the virus.

title: Thomas R. Ottenstein, 70; Built Belittled Tower at Gettysburg
description: Thomas R. Ottenstein, the developer whose observation tower overlooking Gettysburg's historic fields drew tourists and wrath until it was felled by government fiat last month, died Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 70 and also had a home in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Reed's Strong Start Stops Johnson
description: Randy Johnson is everything Rick Reed is not. Scraggly curls dangle from Johnson's Arizona Diamondbacks cap and fastballs sizzle from his left arm. The right-handed Reed closely crops what little hair he has, and his fastballs have none of Johnson's zip.

title: I.B.M. and Siebel in Marketing Accord
description: I.B.M. said today that it would work with Siebel Systems to market software for managing customer relations to businesses that employ less than 1,000 workers.

title: Firms in $13.5 Million Settlement Of U.S. 'Yield Burning' Charges
description: Banc One Capital Markets and seven other securities dealers have agreed to pay a total of $13.5 million to settle the latest federal case accusing firms of overcharging municipalities for Treasury securities in a practice known as yield burning.

title: For Some, She's a Giver; to Others, a Thief
description: Fidela Caparas, 54, was driven to generosity. She was the head bookkeeper for a Manhattan magazine publisher, and she managed to wire millions to her native land, the Philippines, to help hospitals, churches and others in need. But prosecutors say she was most generous to herself, using phony paychecks to steal more than $10 million from her employer.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Ruling Highlights Divergences On 'Kosher'
description: A ruling by a federal judge that New York State's kosher food laws are unconstitutional highlights the intersection of centuries-old biblical and rabbinical strictures with modern state sanctions.

title: ATG Withdraws Offering
description: The ATG Group withdrew its planned initial public offering of up to $200 million of common stock, according to a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company gave no reason for the withdrawal. The company had planned to use the proceeds to finance capital spending, potential acquisitions, redeem stock and other general corporate purposes. ATG, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., offers bundled Internet, broadband data and traditional voice communications services.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with the Movie Guide misidentified the Eddie Murphy character shown from ''Nutty Professor II: The Klumps.'' It was Granny Klump, not Mama Klump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOOTER, ERIC
description: NOOTER-Eric. On August 3, age 50. Devoted and cherished husband of Patty Dann; adoring and delighted father of Jacob; beloved brother of Marjon, Eva and Nine, of Holland. Family, friends and colleagues at the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee mourn the untimely loss of a brilliant, athletic, passionate and charming Dutchman who called pinecones pineapples, and who crossed the globe as a husband and returned a father. ''Rust in vrede,'' dear friend. Services will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 91st St., on Sunday, August 6, at 9:30AM.

title: Polls Show Gain for Bush After Convention; Democrats Are Skeptical
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas got a clear bump upward from his acceptance speech and the Republican convention generally, but its dimensions and duration were uncertain.

title: 'Energized' Bush Carries Convention Themes Westward
description: Gov. George W. Bush came roaring out of the Republican National Convention today by plane, train and automobile, intent on sustaining whatever momentum he had seized from the four-day extravaganza in Philadelphia, and focused on a group of swing states the Democrats won in the last two presidential elections.

title: The Night Bush Presented Himself to America
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000080592412228014 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Fired-Up Liberty Nears Title
description: Coach Richie Adubato of the Liberty did not need added incentive to motivate his players last night. They entered their game against the Orlando Miracle with an 11-game winning streak and a spot in the Women's National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: It's All in the Details
description: SPARE me the spread of the bronzed, muscle-bound lifeguard and show me something I may not know about before visiting Sydney, such as the saltwater sea pools, built barely out of reach of the breakers, at many of the city's ocean beaches.

title: Surprising Season by the Young A's Can Be Traced Directly to G.M.
description: No, Jason Giambi said, he was not responsible for his team's acquisition of his brother, Jeremy, earlier this year.

title: Parlor Music, With Panache
description: 'STEPHEN HOUGH'S NEW PIANO ALBUM'

title: United Cancels 156 Flights as Pilot Shortage Disrupts Airline
description: A shortage of pilots forced United Airlines to cancel 16 percent of its flights at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago yesterday, creating a wave of delays across the country that inconvenienced thousands of passengers.

title: Non-Art for Non-Art's Sake
description: THE MADONNA

title: For Bears to Produce, It's Up to the Rookies
description: When a team has been where the Chicago Bears have recently been -- four straight losing seasons, a 6-10 record last year with a different offensive lineup starting each game and a defense ranked 29th -- help is required. The Bears have not been to the playoffs since 1994. Given the Bears' hefty history, that is a pitiful drought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNIEWIND, HELEN BALL
description: SCHNIEWIND-Helen Ball. In Lexington, MA July 31, 2000. A private burial service will be held in Locust Valley, N.Y., at the end of October. Memorial gifts may be sent to Vassar College, Box 725, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. 12604-0725.

title: The Empty Nests of Seven Mile Island: Where Did the Egrets Go?
description: The seven-mile-long barrier island that is home to Avalon and Stone Harbor also includes a large area of swampy marshland with tree cover where a variety of shore birds historically nested each season. This year the birds did not return there, and experts are unsure why they did come back, where they have gone or whether they will return. Tedor Whitman, director of education at the Wetlands Institute, a nonprofit organization founded to promote conservation, research and education about the local coastal habitat, talked recently about the birds.

title: Bullpen Spoils Cone's Return
description: Defeat has drained his celebrated will, but David Cone could feel thousands of others trying to will him to victory yesterday, from the stands, from the Yankees' dugout. He merely held Seattle scoreless in the first inning, and Yankee Stadium fans, renowned for their mercilessness, stood and cheered earnestly, a show of tender respect that nearly moved Cone to tears.

title: Proposal to Ban Sale Of Diet Drug to Minors
description: IT is an herbal supplement called ephedrine and it is marketed as a sure-fire way to lose weight, build muscle or get high without using illegal drugs.

title: The Doctor
description: Hem lengths of lab coats have long conferred status at the hospital, distinguishing medical students (who wear them at the hip) from physicians (who wear them just above the knee). But lately, different cuts have come to signify style status as doctors, particularly those in cosmetic fields like dermatology, become more image-conscious. Some are scrapping the stodgy, boxy polyester lab coat with cheap plastic buttons for custom-made versions with better fits and quirky touches. One doctor had an opera coat copied, another had his name embroidered mechanic-style on the breast.

title: A High-Pitched Dance of Love and Death
description: FELICE SCHRAGENHEIM was a high-spirited, educated, sensual, witty and wily young woman, whose dangerous misfortune was to have been born Jewish in pre-World War II Germany. During the war she lived in Berlin under an assumed name and worked at a Nazi newspaper, feeding information to the underground resistance. She was involved with a circle of sophisticated Jewish lesbians whose dancing-on-the-volcano lives flouted convention, and sometimes safety.

title: E-ZPASS CAMERAS REDUCED
description: The number of cameras that will be mounted to catch big trucks trying to cheat the E-ZPass toll collection system on the turnpike and parkway has been reduced to 101 from 380. The New Jersey Turnpike Authority, which is overseeing E-ZPass installation, said last week that it decided to order fewer cameras because few trucks use the southern end of the roads. The change saves $5 million of the $7 million originally budgeted for the cameras. Karen DeMasters

title: All Hail Caesar...And Serling, Benny, Coca, and Hope
description: ''Life is putting Prozac to the test,'' says the mobster and family man Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) in a clip from ''The Sopranos.'' In the opinion of David Chase, that HBO show's creator and lead writer, life should do as much for television. Mr. Chase gets the most from the medium. Early in his career he wrote movies, but television was more about people. ''You could explore characters and not be so plot-driven,'' he says on ''Influences,'' a new series starting tonight at 7:30 and running for eight Sundays on Bravo.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: From Suitcases on Wheels To Tear-Free Onion Slicers
description: THEY all laughed when Edison recorded sound,'' Ira Gershwin wrote in 1937. They also laughed at Bernard Sadow and the funny-looking suitcase on wheels he tugged into Macy's one morning.

title: The Lost City, Revisited Yet Again
description: SOMETIMES prophets who cry out in the wilderness are heard. Even heeded. In the realm of urban preservation, Nathan Silver is among that rare and happy breed.

title: A Tale of Two Holocausts
description: THE HOLOCAUST INDUSTRY

title: Board's Powers In a Co-op
description: Q I am one of the original incorporators of the Three Twenty Five Cooperative on Central Park West. When our co-op was formed in 1965, the incorporators approved a bylaw stipulating that there shall be 20 ''authorized memberships'' in the co-op and that each member shall have one vote. The number of memberships has remained unchanged since then. Recently, however, the board has said that it can reduce the number of memberships without any participation of the stockholders. This would seem to be at odds with another bylaw provision that requires a majority vote of stockholders to amend the bylaws. Does the board have the power to reduce the number of memberships in a co-op even though the bylaws state categorically that there shall be 20 authorized memberships? . . . Anita Lande, Manhattan.

title: Bernadette Gochuico, Michael Zuo
description: Dr. Bernadette Ruzol Gochuico, a daughter of Dr. Norma R. Gochuico of Merrick, N.Y., and the late Dr. Ramon G. Gochuico, was married yesterday to Michael Ding Zuo, the son of Yulan Wang and Zheng Zuo of Shenzhen, China. The Rev. Robert A. Romeo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Cure of Ars in Merrick.

title: BRIEFING: TRANSPORTATION; TRAIN HORNS IN JERSEY CITY
description: Hudson-Bergen Light Rail trains last week stopped blowing their safety horns at two Jersey City grade crossings, at Halladay Street and Pacific Avenue. Residents had complained that the trains, which pass by every eight minutes during rush hour, had become a nuisance since service started in April. The trains will lower speeds at the both crossings to 15 miles per hour from 35 m.p.h. Kushanava Choudhury

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEDER, MARTIN A.
description: ROEDER-Martin A. On August 3, 2000. Cherished husband of Dorothy (Friedman) for 61 years, adored father of Katherine Roeder, Thomas and Susan Roeder, beloved grandfather of Sarah and Louisa Roeder, Kenneth Hartog and Erik Hartog & Pamela Heller. Son of the late Judge Jehial M. Roeder and the late Evelyn Finegold Roeder. Mr. Roeder was Of Counsel to Herzfeld and Rubin and former managing partner of Guggenheimer and Untermeyer. He had a degree from the Sorbonne in Paris, a BA and LLB from Columbia University and Columbia Law School of New York. He served on the boards of the Emanu-el Brotherbood and the Tax Management Institute of New York University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 7-9PM with services Tuesday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Jewish Repertory Theater of the 92nd St. YM-YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

title: 'The Taming of the Shrew' on Stage at Boscobel
description: AFTER the jubilant opening-night performance of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' at the Boscobel Restoration here, one woman, holding her daughter by the hand, promised to take her to the Broadway revival of ''Kiss Me, Kate.'' This is a sweet idea. It is provocative, too.

title: Indian Museum's Collection Is a Loss for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Motown Sound: a Great Beat, Still Danceable
description: FANS of oldies music have learned by now to read the fine print of advertisements before seeing their favorite groups in concert. In many cases, the people they see on stage are not the same ones who recorded the groups' hit singles. Three years ago, after the Four Tops performed live on a morning television show in London, a woman called the station to dispute the group's identity.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a blood drive at the Westchester County Police Academy in Valhalla misidentified a blood donor. He was Detective Dolph Tutoni, not Detective John Peters.

title: How Coke Pushed Rivals Off the Shelf
description: DRIVE around this exceptionally hot and thirsty place in midsummer, when the mercury regularly tops 100 but people still have to sell watermelons from their trucks and take their places on the production lines at Lone Star Steel and get their chores done along the plain-looking downtown streets, and you begin to understand why it turned into prime territory for the latest skirmish in the cola wars.

title: Stacey Wong, Anthony Breaks
description: Stacey Wong was married yesterday to Anthony Armstrong Breaks at the Sutton Place Hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Ystebo performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Melinda Hough, Scott Sims
description: Melinda Morrell Hough and Jon Scott Sims were married yesterday by the Rev. Leslie C. Smith at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about accusations by workers at the Umatilla Chemical Depot in Oregon that the Army had concealed leaks of toxic gases gave a misspelled surname at one point for a lawyer who represents a group of workers. He is James E. McCandlish, not McClandish.

title: It's Colonel Mustard in the Kitchen
description: YOU can call him Paul Fischer. Or you can call him Paul. Or you can call him Mr. Fischer. But if you really want to get to heart of the matter, call him Mister Mustard. Really. He doesn't mind. Everybody calls him that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBB, LAWRENCE FORREST
description: EBB-Lawrence Forrest. Of Washington, DC. On Friday, August 4, 2000, at the National Rehabilitation Hospital. Beloved husband of Kim Ebb and father of Nancy, David, and Peter Ebb. Devoted father-inlaw of Gary Ford, Winnie Ebb, and Frances Green. Loving grandfather of Mike and Dan Ford and Sam, Max, Joe, and Sara Ebb. Private inurnment. There will be a memorial service in September. Memorial contributions may be made to the Boston Latin School Association, 41 West Street, 6th flr, Boston, MA 02111. The family thanks Dr. Simlote and the staff of the National Rehabilitation Hospital for their thoughtful care and support.

title: Young, Smart and Teaching? It Can Happen
description: IN certain circles, mostly among the younger, good-schools crowd, the conversation skips a beat when he says what he does. There are murmurs of curiosity, maybe. But no applause.

title: The Next Chapter
description: Fully one-quarter of my hometown is now Hispanic. As I read the wedding announcements in the paper and see the unions of Pennsylvania Dutch-German and Hispanic names, I'm reminded of my grandparents (Goldbach and Rivera). Perhaps, as Ruben Martinez (The Way We Live Now, July 16) suggests, love will change attitudes where the law has failed.

title: The Challenge of Being An Education President
description: Few Americans understand how hard it is for the federal government to exert any leverage on educational change. Most important places for imposing reform reside within of state governments. Nevertheless, responding to political dynamics, presidential candidates put education planks in their platforms. But their ideas, while perhaps attractive to voters, as well as to special-interest constituents, are probably useless in practice.

title: How Now, Bronx Cow? An Oddity Puzzles Even the Police
description: Everyone else had a cow. Why not the South Bronx?

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: When Is a Wart Hog A Canned Pork Product?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIAYS, VIRGINIA LANGSHAW
description: BIAYS-Virginia Langshaw, age 86, of Delray Beach, Florida, died at her Abbey Delray South residence on July 31, 2000. Before moving to Delray Beach in 1988, Virginia and her family lived in Manhasset (Long Island), New York City, and Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Known to friends and family as ''Ginny,'' she was a loving and devoted wife for fifty-two years to John Sheridan Biays (Lt. Col. USAR-Ret.) who passed away in 1994. While raising her family, she became an active volunteer for several organizations, including Christ Church Episcopal and Beaches Hospital. She is survived by her daughter, Carol Biays Cushmore of Edina, MN; her son, John S. Biays, Jr. of Boca Raton FL; her grandson, Christopher Biays Cushmore; her niece, Deborah Langshaw Simon of Kennebunkport, ME; and her nephew, Michael Wood of Kansas City, MO. A graveside service will be held at Arlington National Cemetery on August 15 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, her family suggests memorial contributions be made to one's favorite charity. Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

title: Bush's Jesus Day Is Called Insensitive and a Violation of the First Amendment
description: Four months ago in Texas, Gov. George W. Bush signed a proclamation declaring June 10 to be Jesus Day, and urging all Texans to ''follow Christ's example by performing good works in their communities and neighborhoods.''

title: Farm Work by Children Tests Labor Laws
description: Fourteen years old and barely 4-foot-6, Amelia Gomez spends her days stooped over, pulling weeds and picking red peppers, often complaining that the pesticides give her rashes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, ARTHUR, MD
description: RESNICK-Arthur, MD, 82. Died July 24 at Monmouth Medical Center. He was a specialist in oral rehabilitation. He obtained his BS in Pharmacy from St. John's in 1939; DDS from University of Pennsylvania in 1943; lectured at St. John's College of Pharmacy from 1948 - 1964; Associate Clinical Professor at The College of Dentistry, New York City; Co-founder, Fellow of NYU Academy of Oral Rehabilitation; Captain in U.S. Dental Corps, Master of Academy of General Dentistry. Member; Military Surgeons USA; Royal Society of Health; International College of Dentists. Surviving are his wife, Vicki Trop Resnick, daughter Jill, sister Ruth, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: In a Rainy Summer, Clouds Over Six Flags
description: SIX FLAGS amusement parks are best known for their scary roller coasters that turn riders upside-down, and this summer investors may well feel that they have been along for the ride. The stock has had a negative total return of 43.29 percent so far this year, and its price has fallen to $16.375 from its 52-week high of $39.1875, set last August.

title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do
description: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.

title: Yankee Paco Wins Hambletonian on Stamina
description: The favorite got locked in around the turn and the front-runner faded in the stretch in today's $1 million 75th edition of the Hambletonian. That allowed Yankee Paco to take control in the stretch and capture the most prestigious event in harness racing this afternoon in ideal conditions at the Meadowlands Racetrack.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Hunting With Hemingway

title: At the G.O.P. Convention, Carmakers Toot Horns ...
description: It was the battle of the cars at the Republican National Convention, between G.M. and DaimlerChrysler. On Sunday night, G.M., which gave $1 million to the convention's host committee, held a party for 2,000 people. It featured Hank Williams Jr. and a replica of the Batmobile. DaimlerChrysler, which had given the host committee $250,000, held a reception honoring Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma that featured the Temptations and a gold Phaeton, a futuristic concept car.

title: Moving From the Ivory Tower to the Office Tower
description: LABOR Day may seem a long four weeks away for most Americans, but for recent college graduates who took the summer off before beginning a lifetime of work, the holiday, also known as the day of reckoning, is approaching like a runaway train.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on July 16 about public tours of Westminster Palace in London included an incomplete account of their history supplied by a spokesman for Parliament. The palace, which houses Parliament, has indeed been open for public tours before while Parliament was in recess. From 1974 to 1979, they took place on Saturdays year round. Those beginning tomorrow are the first daily ones open to the public.

title: An Ever-Changing Course: Taking Admissions Tests On Computer
description: WITH nearly everything becoming electronic and digital, it may be no surprise to discover that the hum of hard drives has replaced the scent of freshly sharpened pencils for students taking many of today's standardized admissions tests.

title: Sarah Ford, Paul Younger V
description: Sarah Lynne Ford and Paul Hammond Younger V, both 27, were married on Tuesday in Eureka Springs, Ark., by Morris Pate, a justice of the peace there. Yesterday, at the Crescent Hotel in Eureka Springs, the bride and bridegroom held a second ceremony, which was led by Dr. Richard Nault, the dean of students at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, from which the couple graduated magna cum laude.

title: Don't Blame Egypt; Blame Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Alissa Raphaelson, David Sukoff
description: Alissa Toby Raphaelson, the daughter of Susan and Ralph B. Raphaelson of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to David Harvey Sukoff, a son of Arlene and Steven K. Sukoff of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Marc A. Gellman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah in Melville.

title: In Sex Crimes, Evidence Depends On Game of Chance in Hospitals
description: One woman was attacked last spring in Central Park by two strangers who beat and sexually abused her until she broke free and ran to safety on Manhattan's West Side. The attackers were convicted of aggravated sexual abuse and are serving long prison terms.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, KENNETH
description: WEISSMAN-Kenneth. You are the love of my life. You are forever with me. You are gone one year too long. All my love, your wife, Audrey Shachnow-Weissma

title: July 30-August 5; In India, a Reality Drama for Real
description: The line between fantasy and reality is perhaps never as pliable as in the minds of people who love the movie screen, or so it seemed in India last week. There, a real-life mustachioed villain seized a fantasy-life hero and kept millions of people and their officials in suspense about what might happen next.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAREK, DAVID
description: KANAREK-David. The Yeshiva University family mourns the untimely passing of a wonderful young man, the beloved son of Joseph and Robin Kanarek and brother of Sara, and cherished grandson of Bella Kanarek and YU Benefactors Carl and Dorothy Bennett, who established the Carl and Dorothy Bennett Chair in Pastoral Counseling at our Wurzweiler School of Social Work in tribute to Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz, and the Carl and Dorothy Bennett Scholarship Fund at our Sy Syms School of Business. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: The Play's the Thing, Again
description: If it could be said that there is a tide in the affairs of literary studies, it might now be ventured that there are indications -- hints, clues, suggestions -- that the flood tide of theory in the academy has begun to ebb and questions of value and aesthetics have begun to creep back in.

title: Of Gods and Soles: Hindu Images on Shoes Lead to Protest
description: Forget Miami's Cubans. The New York City Hindu lobby is a force to be reckoned with.

title: Among the Bad Boys
description: BOSS CUPID

title: July 30-August 5; A New Climate Strategy
description: Girding for talks that could shape a global treaty to avert harmful climate warming, the United States said it cannot meet targets only by cutting back on burning coal and oil, which emit heat-trapping carbon dioxide. It must get credit for the country's forests and fields, which can sop up the same greenhouse gas.

title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do
description: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.

title: Emilie Christie, Thomas Burack
description: Emilie Christie and Thomas Shakman Burack were married yesterday by the Rev. John T. P. Jackson at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Lancaster, N.H.

title: Ruling Clouds Scouts' After-School Access
description: FOR as long as anyone can remember, the Boy Scouts of America have been using public school buildings for their troop meetings. But in at least two Long Island school districts, this longtime tradition may soon be broken.

title: At the Top of the Flavor Chain
description: Aftabuddin Rayman smokes alone, in windowless rooms, deep into the night.

title: Endpaper; When a Dad Says Goodbye to His Daughter
description: IT is 5 a.m. as we drive toward the airport, and I am struggling to come up with something meaningful to say to my younger daughter as she leaves for a preorientation wilderness hike sponsored by Tufts University, the Boston-area college she will soon enter as a freshman.

title: Making Like The Sun
description: Some New Yorkers slipcovered themselves in sunny yellow, an optimistic approach to two relentlessly gray weeks of rain. Dandies on Fifth Avenue wore yellow Dick Tracy hats that matched their suits. Kevin Berlin, a sculptor, chose a T-shirt and jeans printed with giant lemons. A posse of Hamptons road warriors sported parrot-yellow bikes and matching helmets. And Madeline escaped the gloomy weather by trading her traditional blue coat for a yellow one.

title: How One Man Served a Fugitive's Time
description: Kerry Sanders, who suffered from schizophrenia, often lived on the streets of Los Angeles. Robert Sanders, a career criminal, escaped from a prison in the Bronx. They looked nothing alike. Their fingerprints, of course, did not match. They simply shared a last name and date of birth.

title: Hospital Moving Pediatric Units, Some Parents Say Too Far Away
description: The St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center is moving its pediatric emergency and inpatient units 55 blocks north, from 59th Street and 10th Avenue, to 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, angering many parents in mid-Manhattan who say they will have to travel too far for care for their children.

title: Belarus Is Warned to Conduct a Fair Election
description: A senior official of the Council of Europe has warned Belarus that the human rights body will refuse to send observers for parliamentary elections planned in October if the government of President Alexander G. Lukashenko fails to ensure that the vote is free and fair.

title: July 30-August 5; German Silence Is Challenged
description: A bombing that wounded nine immigrants, six of them Jews, prompted Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, to suggest that a silent majority of Germans may be abetting such crimes by not speaking out against them.

title: Let's Move On
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Long Island; Huntington's Housing Plan: Too Little or Too Much?
description: HOUSES that moderate-income families can afford have become elusive in the Town of Huntington, where the median price in the resale market is $338,000 and the price of new houses is often half a million dollars or more.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00: Phenomenon; 'Hi, Mr. Doe, Governor Bush Calling . . .'
description: REACH OUT AND TELEMARKET SOMEONEWhen ABC announced and then retracted plans the other week to leave thousands of ''personal'' voice-mail messages -- recorded by Norm MacDonald and promoting the new Friday-evening lineup -- the official line was that the network had come to see that the plan would intrude on people's privacy. According to some telemarketing experts, however, the problem was that no one would have bought the premise that Norm was really speaking to them. ''It wasn't believable,'' says Mason Duchatschek, president of AMO Employer Services in St. Louis, who has been consulting on telesales for about a decade. For voice-mail marketing to work, he says, it must at least sound live. Paul LeBon, the author of ''Escape From Voicemail Hell: Boost Your Productivity by Making Voicemail Work for You,'' agrees. ''If you're going to cold-call, you've got to script it so that the message is personalized, like sending information about word-processing systems to a screenwriter.'' And you can't be a nuisance. ''When I was with American Airlines,'' LeBon says, ''there were people dialing any number at random, leaving messages in air-traffic control. That's dangerous!''

title: Mets Soaring Despite a Slight Injury to Piazza
description: The Mets are getting outstanding pitching from their rotation and their bullpen. Their hits have been well-timed, their defense is sparkling. The Mets took another game from the Arizona Diamondbacks tonight, 6-2, and they have won 10 of their last 11 to move three games behind the first-place Atlanta Braves in the National League East.

title: The Energy Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; Heartstrings of a Great Work
description: I SIT on the edge of my seat in the alto section of chairs ringing the piano and podium, my eyes scanning my well-worn copy of the choral score of the Brahms ''German Requiem.'' I glance around as the few empty seats at the Westchester Chorale's final ''Sing'' of the summer season fill rapidly. An expectant buzz grows and then subsides, as old friends greet one another and newcomers like myself.

title: Amanda Hayman, William McGovern II
description: Amanda Michelle Hayman, the daughter of Linda C. Hayman of New York, was married yesterday to William Francis McGovern II, the son of Mary Lynne and Kenneth W. McGovern of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Barnabas J. Keck, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shady Methodist Church in Shady, N.Y. The Rev. Harriette Zoller, a Methodist minister, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARFUNKEL, CARRIE
description: GARFUNKEL-Carrie. We miss you more each year. In loving memory. Your children and Grandchildren

title: Germany's Classic of Classics, All 21 Hours
description: TWO souls do dwell, alas!, within my breast,'' cries the title character of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's ''Faust.'' Struggling between his thirst for pure knowledge and his desire for earthly pleasures, he finally chooses youth over embittered old age, signs a pact with the devil and embarks on the epic drama that is the cornerstone of German literature -- a text, some say, that is a key to understanding the German soul.

title: ...Forbes Raises Some Capital...
description: Steve Forbes, who has spent nearly $70 million on two bids for the Republican presidential nomination, now spends much of his time running Forbes magazine. But not all of it.

title: Dumplings and Paprika Among the Chicken Wings
description: On the menu at the Hopewell Inn -- which is decorated with a girl at a well -- there are chicken fingers among stuffed cabbage and pirogis. This tells you that in a restaurant with a smattering of standard American fare, the real treats are the Hungarian and German specialties.

title: What's the Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bermuda Tries Eco-Tourism
description: DANIEL'S HEAD VILLAGE, a new resort in western Bermuda that is the island's first major foray into environmental tourism, is itself a giant recycling project: it sits on a windy 19-acre promontory owned by the government that once served as a Canadian military base.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: MADAME

title: Talking About Race
description: Any reputable anthropologist will tell you that ''race'' has no scientific basis but is an artificial, societal construct. Most of the people you interviewed equated skin color with race, so they regularly referred to ''blacks'' and ''whites'' without recognizing that in keeping alive these bite-size but false distinctions, they have contributed to the irreconcilable polarization at the heart of racism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, ALICE JOINER
description: CONNOLLY-Alice Joiner. Beloved teacher and matriarch of three generations, died of natural causes in her home on City Island at the age of 93 on July 23, 2000. In 1931 she married Clement Connolly (d. 1990), her husband of 59 years, and is survived by three children, Dr. C. Stephen Connolly of New York; Mary McDonald of Chicago, and Dr. John Connolly of Northampton, MA. She had eight grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. A service is scheduled for 11AM Friday, August 11, at St. Mary's Star of the Sea Church on City Island. Donations may be made to the Alice J. Connolly Scholarship Fund at P.S. 175.

title: Karen Kaufman, Ian Harris
description: Karen Beth Kaufman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Kaufman of Newton, Mass., was married yesterday to Ian Kenneth Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harris of New York and London. The Rev. Daniel Chesney Kanter, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Harvard Club in Boston.

title: AFTER MIDNIGHT IN NEW BRUNSWICK
description: New Brunswick last week scrapped a proposal to put a midnight curfew on live music and dancing at the 80 bars in the city, the home Rutgers, the state university. The ordinance had been proposed because of complaints from residents about unruly people leaving the bars at the 2 a.m. closing. It was thought that the ban would thin the crowds. But bar ownerss and other businesses objected to the change and the ordinance was tabled at a City Council meeting. Karen Demasters

title: Dover Classics
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Business: Money & Medicin; Breaking the Code of Lab Bills
description: It is a familiar sequence of events to anyone who has spent much time in a doctor's office. You have blood taken, you call for the results, you get on with your life and then weeks, months or even years later, you receive a bill from the laboratory or an explanation-of-benefits letter from your insurance company.

title: Consumed
description: SO . . . Do you or don't you wish to enter the Land of Chocolate?'' Rei Prabhakar asked as I took a seat at his tiny restaurant here. I watched as he knelt beside his customers, observed his true-believer expression, and wondered where I was headed here at Karen and Rei's. As I looked around, I saw other waiters similarly poised on a knee beside their tables.

description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

description: REIMANN-Marga Sofia. On August 2, 2000. Much beloved sister of Clementine Tabatchnik, Jenny Benson and Hanni Wangenheim. Adored aunt of Martina and Dr. Daniel Jackson. Dearest great aunt of Catherine Jackson-Walley and proud great great aunt of Rebecca Jackson-Walley. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWETI, HARRIETTE S.
description: TWETI-Harriette S. Died suddenly on August 2, 2000 in Teaneck, New Jersey of a heart attack. Beloved mother of Mira, Nathan and Caleb; beloved wife of the late Chaim Tweti; beloved daughter of the late Bertha Griffel. Her free spirit, love of life, the arts and her commitment to matchmaking will be missed by all her knew her. Funeral services were held on Thursday August 3, 2000 at The Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. For more information regarding Shiva, call 212-362-6600. Interred at Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Avenue, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, EDMUND J.
description: JOYCE-Edmund J. On August 5, 2000. Retired Deputy Chief, NYPD. Beloved husband of Peggy (nee Browne). Loving father of Jeanne Burke, Edmund Jr., and Margaret Dalton. Dear brother of Joseph, Margaret Killian, Helen Buchheit, Marie, Theresa and Veronica. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Reposing Dennis S. O'Connor, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Thomas More Church, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Visiting Sunday, 7-10, and Monday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Commercial Property/The Manhattan Market; Office Rents Are Up Sharply in the Second Quarter
description: OFFICE rents, which have been rising steadily for several years, spiked upward in the second quarter of this year, leading some real estate executives to express concern that vital service providers, such as smaller law and accounting firms, may be driven out of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILKIN, HOWARD
description: MILKIN-Howard. NYC filmmaker, editor, television producer. Died in Paris July 18. Born Jan. 16, 1934. Films include Academy awardwinning ''Interview with Five Mylai Veterans,'' Flaherty award-winning ''Sunday,'' and Detroit Institute of Art film on Tony Smith's sculpture. Television work includes WNET ''Music and Art of the Renaissance'' and ''Lay My Burden Down.'' Survived by his loving wife of 44 years, Alice, his loving son, Marc, and granddaughter, Emma. Memorial service Sunday, August 13, 2 PM, Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72 St.

title: Texaco Reports Progress In Minority Hiring
description: Texaco increased the number of minorities in its work force last year, exceeding goals set in the wake of a 1996 racial discrimination lawsuit, according to a new report filed at the Federal District Court in White Plains.

title: Rock en Espanol Is Approaching Its Final Border
description: ROCK may have been born as American music, but at middle age it is also the music of the Americas, as quickly becomes apparent during an afternoon spent in a recording studio here with Aterciopelados, Colombia's most popular rock band. The duo is rushing to finish mixing tracks for its new compact disc before heading off for a summer tour of the United States.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth, McGwire and Newark's Canseco
description: It's not an old record, but it's been shredded. Last Wednesday, Ozzie Canseco, a first baseman and designated hitter for the Newark Bears -- and twin brother of Jose Canseco, who now plays for Tampa Bay -- broke the Atlantic League single-season home run record with his 34th dinger. In a day game against the Nashua Pride at Riverfront Stadium in Newark (the Bears won, 10-9), Canseco first tied Juan Thomas of the Atlantic City Surf, who hit 33 in the league's inaugural season in 1998, and then he surpassed him with his second long ball of the afternoon. And since there were 53 more games left in the schedule, the new record was sure to grow much larger. Canseco, 36, who had three brief stints in the big leagues -- and is still being scouted by American League teams -- started as a pitcher but moved to other positions after he tore a rotator cuff. As of midweek he was hitting .319, leading in slugging percentage with .702 and leading in R.B.I. with 93.

title: Talking About Race
description: Mexicans making sushi; a redheaded white boy joining a Chinese gang and shooting up a bank; Asian sex kittens with their white boyfriends. No wonder we Asians were summarily excluded from President Clinton's Dialogue on Race. Why weren't we allowed our voice in your issue on race? We also have kitchens and living rooms, and we do speakee English.

title: Maintaining Slate Roofs: New Options
description: FEW homeowners would argue with the premise that a slate roof adds beauty and value to a house. But while such roofs are often thought to be virtually indestructible -- some have been around for a couple of hundred years -- even the best slate roofs age, leak and eventually have to be replaced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LEO
description: STERN-Leo. On July 28th at age 81. Beloved husband of Lydia. Dear cousin of Ida, Kenny, Sharon, Leah and Evan Fried. He will be missed by many friends. Funeral services private.

title: Water Isn't the Only Hazard
description: Tyler Hill was teeing off at the first hole, a grudge match with his brother and his father.

title: Chicano Radio's Fading Signal
description: IT might have been almost any Saturday night in the last decade: a string of tail lights blazing like coals in the blue dusk; the air resinous with the scent of chaparral where the Foothill Freeway ribbons along the slopes that cradle the city's sprawl; and the voice. Ratcheting out of the car radio, nasal and husky at the same time, the Spanglish cadences straight from the barrios along Whittier Boulevard, the tone falling midway between a hedge clipper and croon.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; ...And Tiny Hats Enter the Ring
description: A few months ago, Mattel decided to promote the new Barbie by announcing that she would run for the presidency. But at the Republican convention, GetSetClub.com, a Web-based doll maker in Philadelphia, ambushed her by showcasing its own candidate, Vanessa, an African-American doll said to have a college degree and a history of struggles and successes. According to GetSetClub, she is running as a candidate of the Surprise Party.

title: Selling Gear to Pollution Fighters
description: THROUGH the gap that separates the Church of the Comforter and the Park Street Methodist-Episcopal Zion Church here, you catch a glimpse of a warehouse on Sparrow Lane.

Mulderig of Mountain Top, Pa., and the late Frank W. Mulderig. The Rev. Gordon L. Huff performed the ceremony at St. Matthew Lutheran Church in Moorestown, N.J.

description: Rick Delaney and Zo Charlton, Austin, Tex., May 11, 2000

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the prospects for the continued independence of the Campbell Soup Company misspelled the surname of an analyst at Prudential Securities who said the company was being hurt by changing consumer preferences. He was John McMillin, not McMillan.

title: New Sale by Globecomm
description: Globecomm Systems Inc. of Hauppauge (Nasdaq: GCOM) announced that an undisclosed multilateral organization had exercised its option to purchase an additional 48 mobile satellite earth terminals with an aggregate value of $4.4 million. The option is part of a contract announced in March, and follows initial installations over the past three months.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: GEORGIA SAVINGS -- The beachfront Cloister on Sea Island, Ga., is offering summer rates from Aug. 15 to Sept. 26 of $204 a person a night, double occupancy. Guests receive the best room available at check-in, so savings can range from $50 to $200 a night. The rate is good Sunday through Wednesday and includes three meals a day. Guests under 19 sharing a room with their parents stay and eat free. Through Labor Day, parents can enjoy free time while children ages 3 through 12 partake of the Junior Staff program, which includes field trips, tennis lessons and other activities. Golfers can also get unlimited greens fees at three courses with cart and range balls for $113 a day; one course requires hiring a caddie, at an extra charge. For information and reservations, contact (800) 732-4752.

title: A Sleuth Hot on the Trail of Beach Erosion
description: IN the midst of a treasure hunt for missing lifesaving stations that will help him track beach erosion on the East End, Stephen Leatherman dropped his backpack into the sand at the top of the dunes. Then he zipped off the legs of his khaki pants and waded into the Atlantic Ocean in his shorts.

title: Evil, Begone! My Jewelry Says So!
description: UNTIL recently, Nadja Swarovski wore a bracelet of rose quartz beads said to bring the wearer luck in love. ''But it was no use at all,'' she complained. So these days Ms. Swarovski, the New York representative of an Austrian crystal company founded by her family, puts her faith in a wide mesh cuff that might have come straight out of ''Gladiator.''

title: Stephanie Ragolia, Robert Crafa
description: Stephanie Jane Ragolia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Ragolia of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Theodore Crafa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Crafa of Northport, N.Y. The Rev. Kevin Keelen performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: A Bellflower for Everyone and Everywhere
description: EVERY year, at the end of January, I come down with the gardener's version of Seasonal Affective Disorder. Last year I treated this affliction by buying a botanical print at an antiques show. The print is a graceful illustration of several members of the bellflower (Campanula) family, as rendered by Dorothea Loudon, more commonly known simply as Mrs. Loudon, a prominent 19th-century English illustrator. The print's colors and shapes are so alluring that I felt compelled to investigate and invest in various Campanulas.

title: Access to Taxis
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on wheelchair-accessible taxicabs in many United States cities (''Fitting Taxis for Wheelchairs,'' July 2) didn't go far enough. All major cabs in British cities such as London, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Manchester are so equipped. No special vans for them. Just intelligently designed purpose-built taxis.

title: Megan Maroney, Peter Ward
description: Megan Elizabeth Maroney, a daughter of Margaret Solin of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Thomas Maroney of Asheville, N.C., was married on Thursday to Peter Gerard Ward, a son of Breege Ward of Dublin and the late Ray Ward. The Rev. Dermot McNiece performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Blessington, Ireland.

title: Making Good Neighbors, Part I
description: CONSTRUCTING a simple fence, in a straight line on relatively level ground without a gate, is within the skill level of an intermediate do-it-yourselfer. The hardest part is making an accurate layout, estimating the needed materials and setting the posts.

title: The World; Everyone Asks for Arab Unity. Getting It Is Harder.
description: POLITICAL slogans tend to long outlive their authors in this part of the world and none is more enduring, or more musty with age, than the 1950's-vintage catch phrase ''Arab unity.''

He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Getting Under My Skin
description: I haven't lived Don Terry's (July 16) life and don't pretend to have experienced similar struggles. But my response as I read was, ''I know this feeling.'' I've known separation, isolation, confusion; haven't we all? I'm gay, I'm Jewish, I fail to live up to American ideals in so many ways. Who knows which of these, if any, is most salient? There is something (but only something) about talking about race that's not about race at all; it's about what stops us from being together; it's about yearning and love and sadness and, perhaps most of all, fear.

title: Mystical Ireland
description: To the Editor: The timeliness of Lisa Fugard's ''Rare Flowers and Ruined Choirs'' (July 9) can only be explained by the influence of mystical Ireland. For on July 10, the High Court of Ireland ended a saga begun in 1991, when it ordered the Office of Public Works to restore to its former condition the area at the Burren where the agency had started construction on an interpretive center, parking and tourist facilities within the Burren itself.
