description: UPTON-Imogen Richards. Of Plainfield, NJ, formerly of NYC and Litchfield, CT, died August 3, 2000. Graduate of Brearley School and Bryn Mawr College. Memorial service at Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, August 11th, at 11 A.M. For information call Memorial Funeral Home 908-322-4350.

title: A Gas Giant Bets Heavily On a Surge In Demand
description: WILL natural gas prices stay high? Consumers hope not, but the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, for one, is betting that they will.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELZ, PHILIP
description: BELZ-Philip. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing, in Memphis, of a longtime and deeply cherished friend, a distinguished worldwide philanthropist and communal leader, and patriarch of his family and community. He was an honorary YU trustee and honorary alumnus. He and his late wife, Sarah, were YU Benefactors who advanced the musical heritage of the Jewish people through the establishment of the Philip and Sarah Belz School of Jewish Music at our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. They also established in their names Yeshiva College's Department of Music and a Belz School scholarship fund. Mr. Belz's devotion to Yeshiva University was legendary and he will be sorely missed by his fellow trustees, the faculty, and students of YU. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son, YU trustee and Sy Syms School of Business Board member, Jack A. (and Marilyn) Belz, YU Guardians and Sy Syms School of Business Founders; great-grandson, Andrew J. Groveman, Yeshiva College Board member; grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Cantor Bernard Beer, Director Philip and Sarah Belz School of Jewish Music

title: Park Plans Put Model Planes And Golf on Collision Course
description: As rain came down on the small makeshift runway in Ferry Point Park on Thursday morning, John Pimentel, a 70-year-old retired tool-and-dye maker with a pilot's license, gave his airplane one last system check, looked carefully over the controls and gave the prop engine a hearty rev. With a gentle push of a lever, the plane accelerated across the pockmarked strip until it was airborne.

title: Tracing an Affair That's Remembered In Different Ways
description: I LIVED a powerful love story, I understood nothing about it, and I needed to delve into my questions in a film,'' said the Belgian director Frederic Fonteyne, by way of explaining his tender, unconventional and emotionally charged movie about middle-aged romance, ''An Affair of Love.''

title: Jenifer Wells, Mark Megalli
description: Jenifer Nelle Wells, the daughter of Nelle and William Wells of Columbus, Ga., and Mark Megalli, a son of Viviane Wassef Megalli and Dr. Maguid Megalli of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday. Bishop J. Kevin Boland of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Savannah, Ga., performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: July 30-August 5; A Civil Rights Probe
description: The Los Alamos National Laboratory, where the atomic bomb was developed during World War II, has come under investigation by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, a federal civil rights agency. The agency is looking into possible discrimination against Asian and Asian-American scientists, some of whom have charged that security measures put in place after the arrest of Dr. Wen Ho Lee, a former Los Alamos scientist charged with mishandling nuclear data, have focused unfairly on them. The commission began a similar investigation of another weapons laboratory, Lawrence Livermore, last year. James Glanz

title: For Promoter, Ska Turns the World
description: AS Martha and the Vandellas sang, ''Summer's here and the time is right for dancing in the street.'' And if Scotto Savitt has his way, there will be lots of dancing, even well beyond the summer.

title: Staten Island Becomes Center Of the West Nile Virus Battle
description: Staten Island is now the epicenter of the West Nile virus, according to the borough president, although many residents are not taking extraordinary precautions to avoid becoming infected.

title: A Basement Lab Becomes the Focus of Radiation Fear
description: In 1964, a chemical spill in the basement of St. Albans Naval Hospital's nuclear medicine laboratory left traces of radioactive contamination.

title: Honor for World War II Veterans: Diplomas
description: DANIEL J. MOONEY of Bridgeport, a World War II veteran, and two of his grandsons shared a common distinction this June. They all received their diplomas, but while his grandsons were young men graduating from high school and college, Mr. Mooney, at 76, was getting his diploma from Central High School, following a hiatus of 57 years.

title: Miami Is Back on Top, But Without the Bluster
description: The Miami Hurricanes are back. Tell them that at your own risk.

title: A Deft Touch
description: Beringer's loving treatment of its minor wines shows why it is one of California's top-tier producers.

title: For Former Israeli Allies in Lebanon, Refugee Life
description: Even the crescent moon, redolent of Islamic religious symbolism as it hangs limpid over the Mediterranean on a hot summer's night, seems like a curse now to the embittered Lebanese Christian refugees making makeshift lives at this lovely old kibbutz a few miles south of the Lebanese border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROFFMAN, EDWARD AXEL
description: ROFFMAN-Edward Axel, 78, of Orefield, PA died Saturday, July 22, 2000 in Lehigh Valley Hospital, Allentown, PA. He was the husband of Brigitte (Milz) Roffman. He was a furniture designer and chairman of the board of directors of Edward Axel Roffman Associates, Inc. New York, for 45 years, retiring in 1990. He was an army veteran of WWII. Mr. Roffman graduated from Ecoles D'Art in France and Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in NYC. Survived by wife Brigitte (Milz) Roffman of Orefield, PA; sons Frederick S. of Pelham, NY and Andrew E, of Bronxville, NY; brother Lawrence of Richmond, VA; stepdaughter Julia L., wife of Timothy P. Noble of Buffalo, NY and grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Attention: Alumni Affairs Office, 30 Cooper Square, New York, NY 10003-4610. Memorial service will be held on Friday, August 18, 2000, 5PM at St Peter's Church, NY, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENHOF, MIKI
description: DENHOF-Miki. On August 2, 2000. Of East Hampton and New York City. Retired Art Director of Conde Nast. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, August 8, 7-9 PM, with services Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Leo Baeck Institute, Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011.

title: Don't Blame Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Star-Gazing at a Higher and Sharper Level
description: Amateur astronomers and other sky watchers will have a new West Coast spot to stargaze from when the Chabot Space and Science Center, an 86,000-square-foot facility in the hills of Oakland, Calif., opens Aug. 19.

title: Roughing It
description: Mountain City

title: Gun-Free Boundaries Proposed Near Schools
description: A LAW to establish gun-free zones around every school in the county drew support at a public hearing Monday and is expected to win approval by the Board of Legislators next month.

title: Anne Decker, Steven Toomey
description: Anne Van Campen Decker, the daughter of Marianne Decker and Francis K. Decker Jr. of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Steven Paul Toomey, the son of Shirley and Paul Toomey of Bolton, Conn. The Rev. William Findlay, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Quogue Chapel in Quogue, N.Y.

title: The Nation: Pumping the Big Tent; The Rock Doesn't Kiss Babies
description: BY the evidence of flying headbutts, figure-four leglocks and The People's Elbow, you might not see The Rock as a G.O.P. kind of guy. He is usually in black underwear, talking trash, wiggling eyebrows as expressive as John Belushi's, in his role as the World Wrestling Federation's hunkiest heel and its reigning champion.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bronckless Boroughs

title: On the Hudson River: Its History in Boats
description: WE see boats as lenses,'' said Robert Panetta, a history professor at Marymount College in Tarrytown, in talking about the lavish, profusely documented exhibition ''Boats on the Hudson: Navigating Through History.'' He organized the exhibition with Ellen Keiter, curator of exhibitions, at the Hudson River Museum here. ''They're a way to look at the history of the river,'' he said.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Elizabeth Gilbert; 'Coyote Ugly,' No Grit
description: IT was definitely a mistake to have only one pint of Jack Daniel's before seeing that,'' Elizabeth Gilbert said to her friend Jana. This was a few minutes after the end credits rolled at the Monday night Ziegfeld premiere of ''Coyote Ugly.'' The heavily hyped new Disney movie is based on a 1997 GQ article by Ms. Gilbert about her experiences tending bar at the real Coyote Ugly in the East Village. She was out of sorts after watching the film, which transformed the gritty, tiny, blue-collar dive into an outsize, airbrushed party palace. Usually armed with a quick and cynical wit, Ms. Gilbert could only mutter, ''It's so weird,'' as she wandered toward the exit.

title: July 30-August 5; A New Drug Front
description: The nation's law enforcement community reported that it was suddenly facing another potential front in its longstanding war on drugs: a psychedelic drug nicknamed Ecstasy. It has gained wide appeal among young people, particularly those on the nightclub circuit, and in the last 10 months, agents for the United States Customs Service have seized a record 8 million doses at the nation's airports and other ports of entry.

title: A Dancer Discovers A World of Profit And Daredevil Feats
description: AT a recent dance forum, Elizabeth Streb introduced herself with considered clarity: ''Ten years ago I thought of myself as someone who had a dance company. Today I think of myself as someone who creates wild actions and movement moments in a show that I sell.''

title: Corrections
description: The Stocks in the News chart on the DataBank page last Sunday referred incorrectly to the company whose stock price fell after it said second-quarter earnings would be much lower than analysts' forecasts. It is Lands' End, not Land's End.

title: The Nation; The Donors Rule, But in Name Only
description: IT began with Team 100, a name for a political club that was purposefully subtle and maybe even a bit coy. One had to imagine what the 100 stood for: Senators? Dollars? Nickels?

title: Where Everyone Is a Mentor to Everyone Else
description: THE annual three-week Sundance Theater Lab near Provo, Utah, is not exactly summer camp, but it does give playwrights, directors, choreographers, composers and solo performers a chance to get away and experiment. The program is part of the Sundance Institute, which presents the annual Sundance Film Festival, and was founded by the actor Robert Redford and others in 1981. The culmination of the theater lab is partially staged readings by professional actors of the works in progress.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Stock Tips From a Pair of Experts
description: LIKE an alchemist, Rick Lazio turned $15,000 into $36,000. And Hillary Clinton famously performed her own feat of magic on $1,000. Poof! It was $100,000. Both waved away the significance of their fantastic financial feats by calling them beginner's luck. But let's get real. Beginner's luck? Hello! Even your most blessed beginner doesn't have luck like this so, please, don't try to pull the wool over this boy's eyes. We're not talking luck here.

title: July 30-August 5; Soldier Sentenced for Murder
description: A United States military court in Germany sentenced an American soldier to life imprisonment without parole for the murder of an 11-year-old Kosovo Albanian girl. Staff Sgt. Frank Ronghi, 36, pleaded guilty to sodomizing and murdering Merita Shabiu while on peacekeeping duty in the Balkans. Sergeant Ronghi's sentence was the most severe one open to a military court holding a trial in Germany, where the death penalty does not exist. Roger Cohen

title: Peppery Plea For Tolerance From a Chef In Montreal
description: When Montreal's huge gay pride parade rolls through downtown on Sunday, organizers expect more than 100 marching groups and 500,000 people, either watching or walking. Oddly, the parade will march without the one Montrealer whose recent coming out caused the biggest media debate over homosexuality that French Canada has seen in years.

title: Seeds of a Tower, and a Debate, in Plans for Retail Complex
description: The Williamsburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn's tallest building, may soon have a neighbor sharing its skyline.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Uggams in Comedy

title: A Dot-Com's Smell of Success Is Just the Options Burning
description: OUR multimillion-dollar dot-com folded, and all I got was this lousy T-shirt. Everyone at Posh&Sticks got one, the day our enigmatic -- let's face it, odd -- name was announced last January. Now, it is a bittersweet souvenir from the rush for the elusive e-commerce mother lode. Don't get me wrong: I loved the name and was proud to wear it on my chest. We gave this our best shot, but we are toast.

title: Yes, It's A Rodeo, Right Here In New Jersey
description: EVEN the parking lot hints that this is not the regular New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, SHIRLEY
description: GRAF-Shirley, A life-long New Yorker of 82 years and integral part of the city's entertainment industry, news industry, and city government died Wednesday. Before retiring in 1983 she served the City of New York as an exective in the office of budget, spanning the administrations of Lindsay through Koch. In 1948 Shirley ''went on the road'' with Gloria Swanson, traveling with her summer stock show and ghostwriting a newspaper column under Swanson's byline. Her three nephews, Jeff, Ron, and Mike Graf, survive her. Burial services will be held in Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing. For details: 302-798-6119, or www. greysnapper.com/shirley.html

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Talking About Race
description: I am putting this issue (July 16) away with other important things I hope my granddaughters learn about in the future. As a child of the 60's, my generation was supposed to make a difference. We didn't do enough. Maybe my granddaughters and the children of the new century will.

title: An Uninvited Guest at the Beach
description: The red bell and orange tentacles of the lion's mane jellyfish -- most common to New Jersey and other locations along the East Coast -- stir fear and awe as it gracefully pulses with the currents.

title: A Chance To Hear A Legend's Debut
description: WHO would have suspected, this late in the game, that there were any crucial gaps left to fill in the discography of the German baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau? The very model of the serious postwar vocal artist, Mr. Fischer-Dieskau turned 75 in May. From the very dawn of his career, microphones seemed to spring up where'er he walked. For him as for legions of other performers ''legendary,'' honorable or merely retired from the scene, the opening of the archival floodgates in the CD era has brought an all but engulfing tidal wave of documentation, much of it previously impossible for any but the most resourceful, connected and determined fanatic to find.

title: A Magazine Seeks Management Potential
description: Employers are so anxious for access to the latest crop of M.B.A.'s that a venture capital firm and a leading executive recruiter are counting on them to support a giveaway magazine aimed at university students.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: CLINTON

title: Sara Starr, Peter Weltchek
description: Sara Lurene Starr, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Starr of Little Falls, Minn., was married in a nondenominational ceremony on Friday to Peter Richard Weltchek, the son of Paul Weltchek of East Hampton, N.Y., and the late Edith Zanditon Weltchek. Marita Fridjhon, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated at the Flood Mansion in San Francisco.

title: Four Attractive Siblings
description: Beringer's loving treatment of its minor wines shows why it is one of California's top-tier producers.

title: Help Doctors Who Help the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Streets Be Too Clean? Yes, Some Say
description: On a recent Monday morning, many Park Slope car owners awoke to find a decade of prayers answered. Under new street cleaning regulations posted along the curbs, their parked cars would have to be moved only once a week from each side of the street, instead of twice.

title: For Collins, Point Made Without A Score
description: Kerry Collins was one of the few Giants with little to prove in their first preseason game tonight. He is guaranteed to be the starting quarterback when the team opens its season in a month and he worked on fine-tuning his game.

title: Campuses to Serve Students K through B.A.
description: ABOUT 150 students on the University of California campus in San Diego wear uniforms to class, have never taken the College Boards and can probably forget about spots on the school's basketball team.

title: Holly Mitchell, Samuel Dellenbaugh
description: Holly Thompson Mitchell, a daughter of Dorothy and John P. Mitchell of Chatham Township, N.J., was married last evening to Samuel Greenwood Dellenbaugh, the son of Joanna and Geoffrey G. Dellenbaugh of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Franklin Vilas performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chatham.

title: Four Kitchens In Sydney That Go for the Gold
description: SYDNEY, a diverse city of some four million inhabitants, offers a variety of cafes and restaurants to suit all tastes and budgets, satisfying even the most exigent and adventurous of diners. Visitors can sample the foods of 50 different nationalities, from Laotian larb to Mexican mole, from English pork pies to Vietnamese pho.

title: Melinda Frank, Andrew Waskow
description: Melinda Maxwell Frank and Andrew Vincent Waskow were married yesterday in Lyme, N.H. Timothy Caldwell, a justice of the peace, officiated at Culver Hill Farm, the home of Dr. and Mrs. John Ketterer, an uncle and an aunt of the bride.

title: Partners at the Intersection of Two Cultures
description: GERMAINE ACOGNY was sitting in a Viennese cafe four summers ago, smoking her pipe, when a blond woman with a broad, animated face sauntered in. Ms. Acogny recognized her as Susanne Linke, the gutsy German dancer she had once seen on television performing an anguished duet with a claw-foot bathtub.

title: Montana to Young to Garcia: Golden Arms, but Also Cold Shoulders
description: If there is anyone who understands the difficulty of following a legend, it is the quarterback Steve Young. In the early 1990's, Young and Joe Montana were in a heated battle for the starting job in San Francisco. Montana was struggling to overcome injuries and refused to be a backup. He eventually finished his career in Kansas City, and just last weekend was inducted into the Hall of Fame. Young went on to win a Super Bowl with the 49ers and will also someday be inducted.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Seeking a Keeper of Traditions

title: Boorishness Knows No Race
description: Mr. Applebome writes of his reluctance to confront a black motorist about his booming rap music, but Mr. Applebome seems to have no such qualms about his gratuitous slap at the elderly. As someone who has just turned 70, I must point out that his protest that he is not ''a totally clueless, hopeless, addled, over-the-hill geezer'' points to another great divide, which he doesn't bother to hide.

title: Sidewalk Toilets Get City Money. That's the Easy Part.
description: In a new effort to put public toilets on New York streets, the City Council has set aside $5 million in its latest budget for 50 or more high-tech toilets.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz CL500; My Car Is Smarter Than Your Car
description: A MERCEDES BENZ brochure of the 1980's described the marque's philosophy thus: A Mercedes should not inspire aggressive driving, but if you find yourself in a bind -- say, roaring into a tight turn too fast -- the car will get you through. That, at least, was the gist. The Mercedes was an automotive Clark Kent, serious and sedate, but ready to fling off its eyeglasses and soar to the rescue.

title: For Better or Worse
description: STATE OF A UNION

title: The World; The West Sees One Mugabe, but Africa Sees Another
description: TO the West, he is an aging despot with bloody hands, a brutal race-monger who terrorizes white farmers and black critics and fuels the violence that still churns through the countryside. But on this continent, many Africans are painting a strikingly different portrait of President Robert Mugabe.

title: Leslie Bathgate, Andrew Heaney
description: Leslie Knowles Bathgate, a daughter of T. Pamela Bathgate of Rumson, N.J., and Lawrence E. Bathgate II of Bay Head, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Peter Heaney, the son of Joan M. Heaney of Upper Brookville, N.Y., and the late Peter F. Heaney. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr. performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head.

title: July 30-August 5; After Camp David, Thin Ice for Barak
description: Israel's fractious parliament gave a little breathing room and a thumb in the eye to Prime Minister Ehud Barak and his embattled efforts to reach a compromise on Jerusalem with Yasir Arafat and nail down the terms of a final peace accord this summer.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Six Crooked Highways

title: Don't Count Torricelli Out Just Because of His Misstep
description: Say what you will about Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the Man Who Would Be King, but the guy sure knows how to keep politics interesting.

title: The Laid-Back Olympics
description: AS the helicopter whined to life and we lifted up and away on a cloudless morning last month, the low winter sun threw long, sharp shadows across Sydney's terrain. We were flying toward a land known for 20,000 years as the place between two worlds.

title: Kirstin Schantzenbach, Brandon Sutcliffe
description: Kirstin L. Schantzenbach, the daughter of Elaine Crocker of New York and William K. Schantzenbach of Lancaster, Pa., was married yesterday to Brandon Hall Sutcliffe, the son of Cathy and S. Lynn Sutcliffe of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Henry Stewart Irvin, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Ralph Crocker, in Weston, Conn.

title: Sage Daly, Christopher Wirth
description: Sage Clarkson Hurry Daly, a daughter of Ann Fuller of Big Horn, Wyo., and Dr. John S. F. Daly of Chesterfield, N.H., was married yesterday to Christopher Winslow Wirth, the son of former Senator Timothy E. Wirth and Mrs. Wirth of Boulder, Colo., and Washington. The Rev. Roger Daly, a United Church of Christ minister and the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church in Crested Butte, Colo. His wife, the Rev. Sandra Daly, also a minister of the United Church of Christ, took part in the service.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00: On Language; Bumfuzzled?
description: President Clinton's staunch refusal to give up his own regional vernacular has frequently left members of the Fourth Estate confused -- or flummoxed, bumfuzzled or ferhoodled (as they say in some regions of this country). Reporters were baffled when Clinton proclaimed that his staff members were there to work for the American people and ''not to throw off on each other.'' And when he said of a dissenting major general that ''he doesn't know me from Adam's off-ox,'' many were admittedly in a swivet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWELL, MARLA
description: NEWELL-Marla. Beloved wife of Roger, mother of Sonya and Paul, and friend to many died August 4, 2000. Raised on the Grand Concourse and later residing in Greenwich Village, she was a devoted and esteemed member of the Board of Trustees and past President of the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue. Services will be held on Sunday, August 6, at 11:15 A.M., in The Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to either the American Liver Foundation or the CSFA.

title: Judah Retains Title With Knockout of Former Champion
description: Zab Judah was tested tonight, but he was also victorious.

title: U.N. Peacekeepers Arrive to Guard Israel-Lebanon Border
description: United Nations peacekeeping troops finally began spreading out in force along Lebanon's border with Israel today, after weeks of haggling over just where the border is and 22 years after their presence was first authorized.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 6, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, WILLIAM C.
description: HALL-William C. Age 63. Of Beaufort, SC, formerly from Bayport, NY, on July 29, of a brainstem tumor. Loving husband of Carol; dear father of Kerry, Brent and Jocelyn and spouses William Flye, Dr. Theresa Hall and Benjamim Suglia. Adored grandpa of Austin, John, Caitlin, Connor and Gage. Mr. Hall, an insurance broker with Marsh & McLennan, Inc., for 31 years, five of those at BowringLtd. in Hamilton, Bermuda. He then joined AEIA as National Marketing Manager, until retirement. Donations to the Bayport United Methodist Church or Sayville Cabinet for the Sick would be appreciated.

title: The Big Bebopper
description: MYSELF WHEN I AM REAL

title: The One-Room Schoolhouse
description: SCHOOL doesn't start until the Mullets arrive. Today, they are late, so we wait.

title: Verizon and Unions Fail To Agree on Contract
description: In a dispute which may affect the entire wireless communications industry, Verizon Communications failed to reach a contract agreement with its unions by a midnight strike deadline last night.

title: The Reluctant Imperialist
description: Bernard Kouchner is smaller than expected, tanned like a 60's rock star settling into lithe middle age. He's wearing a lime-green open-necked shirt, a well-cut sport jacket, trim slacks and dark glasses. He's walking along a dusty road between wheat fields in Kosovo with Lt. Gen. Juan Ortuno, the Spanish commander of the NATO troops, and two Kosovar politicians beside him, while a TV crew retreats slowly backward, recording their advance. Although it has been about a year since NATO called off its bombing campaign and the Serbian Army trooped out of Kosovo, Finnish soldiers keep telling the camera crew to stick to the path: the benign-looking fields may be mined.

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, HENRY J.
description: O'BRIEN-Henry J. On August 3, 2000. Loving brother-in-law of Elizabeth Philips. Dear brother of Margaret Ackley, Ernest O'Brien, Alice Freehill, Jane White and the late John and Alma O'Brien. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY on Saturday 7-9PM and Sun 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass will be held at our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Elmsford, NY at 11AM on Monday. Interment to follow at the Gate of Heaven cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, HAROLD
description: SINGER-Harold. In loving memory of a caring husband to Nancy; father to Andrew, Candy and Sue; brother to Jeanne Berger; grandfather to Hannah and uncle to Ellen and Ronni. We will miss this kind and gentle soul.

title: Personal Business; If the Maitre D' Won't Get You a Table, Try Your PC
description: So you find yourself in Manhattan for a long weekend when suddenly, on Friday afternoon, you are overcome by a desire for a world-class meal. Why not call Lespinasse, that temple of Francophile fantasies, where a bowl of soup (albeit with truffles) can set you back $35?

title: Her Voice and Career Both Soar Past High C
description: LINDA EDER'S followers are not your run-of-the-mill music fans. Many are Jekkies -- those obsessed with Broadway's ''Jekyll and Hyde,'' the musical in which Ms. Eder attained national recognition playing the prostitute Lucy Harris.

title: Rightist Violence: A German Silence
description: To the Editor:

title: Discord in Fiji Islands Alters Cruise Schedules
description: As Fiji struggles to establish a new government, cruise lines remain concerned about the safety of some of the country's ports. Fiji has been in turmoil since mid-May, when indigenous rebels, objecting to leadership by people of Indian descent, seized government officials and held them hostage until July 13.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Gazetteer chart on July 9, with an article about living in Bedford Park, in the Bronx, was published in error. The house that was on the market, and described in the caption, was 2969 Valentine Avenue, not No. 2869, which was shown.

title: On Stage, a Dancer's Busy Life
description: FRANK ROOT can breeze through Fairfield, his hometown, without being recognized, but there is hardly a Broadway dancer who doesn't know him. He has worked steadily as a supporting actor and director for more than 20 years, including choreographing as many as 7,000 dancers in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Currently, Mr. Root is performing in ''George M!'' at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in the supporting role of George M. Cohan's father, Jerry.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of vital statistics on Page 14 of the Travel section today with the What's Doing column, about Los Angeles, misstates the metropolitan population in some copies. It is 9,213,533, not 19,213,533.

title: E-Publish or Perish
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Click to Be Subsumed; On the Language of Cervantes, the Imprint of the Internet
description: CINDY FLORES DAVALOS, a 24-year-old Mexican with neon pink hair, speaks native Spanish and minimal English. But in her job as the editor of a women's ''channel'' at Elsitio.com, an Internet company here, she operates in a linguistic netherworld experts call Cyber-Spanglish.

title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do
description: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.

title: Alexandra Geis, Benim Foster
description: Alexandra Lynn Geis and Benim Foster were married yesterday at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, Conn. Judge Kevin M. O'Grady of State Probate Court in Westport, Conn., officiated.

title: Article 2000080691098230205 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Fighting Darker Side Of Southampton
description: KATHY KRUEL has been pleading with the Southampton Town board for years. She lives in Flanders with her two children, and a parade of prostitutes and drug dealers on her street motivated her to collect photographs and testimony from other residents, and to organize clean-ups and neighborhood watches.

title: The Bulbs of Summer
description: I ONCE disdained cannas, but that was before I met Cleopatra. And before encountering Aaron, I was among those who looked down on caladiums.

title: Rustin's Youth Wing
description: To the Editor:

title: Waterfront Fire Safety Is Examined
description: Less than a decade ago, a section of waterfront here known as Harsimus Cove, a 40-acre expanse of trucked-in sand, lay like a bizarre, man-made Sahara amid the skyscrapers that had risen in the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMENDE, KURT F.
description: AMENDE-Kurt F. Of Alexandria, VA; Center Moriches, NY, and St. Thomas, V.I. passed away August 4, at his Center Moriches residence. Mr. Amende retired from the U.S. Army after 26 years, a colonel in the Engineer Corps. He was currently a Marine Engineering Consultant. He is survived by his wife, Louise; his children, Lynn, Roger and Kurt Amende Jr; his sisters, Charlotte Boyle and Mariana Wheeler; and one grandchild, Catelyn Amende. Reposing Tuesday, 11 AM-1 PM, at Wesche Funeral Home Inc., 495 Main Street, Center Moriches. Cremation private.

title: Mr. Putin's Political Gyroscope
description: Vladimir Putin, the new Russian president, has been a man in motion since his inauguration in May. He has curbed the power of Russia's regional governors, confronted the business moguls who control large pieces of the economy, proposed a flat tax and fired a gaggle of generals. But just where Mr. Putin is headed remains uncertain. So far much of the action seems more clearly aimed at rebuilding a strong central government than at advancing democracy and reform.

title: They're Leaving On a Jet Plane
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Potter and Hilton: At Times, Morality Comes With a Broomstick
description: The words that never fail to thrill me in a Harry Potter book are these: ''Mount your brooms!''

title: Trials Run Right
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Rebecca Banks, Peter Jurdjevic
description: Rebecca Alexandra Banks, a daughter of Rosemarie Banks and Dr. Nelson Lee Banks of Dunkirk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Jurdjevic, a son of Deborah and Velimir Jurdjevic of Toronto. The Rev. Cynthia S. Wickwire Lundquist, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Fredonia, N.Y.

title: Personal Business: Diary; Study Finds Gender Gap In Workplace Discipline
description: Women are significantly less effective than men in doling out discipline to subordinates at work, according to a new study.

title: Online Library Gives Patrons Greater Access
description: THEY are not the libraries your grandparents visited to borrow a book, read a magazine or check out a phonograph record. (Remember LP's?)

title: Business School; Entrepreneurs
description: IN the staid environs of America's top-tier management schools, it was was once considered unseemly, if not impossible, to start a business while studying to run one.

title: From the Sea To the Sound, Water Views Are Calming (And Costly); There Are a Few Bargains, but Buyers Wanting a Beach Should Bring Money
description: WAS there ever a problem that couldn't be eased when contemplated in the presence of a water view? Probably not, which may explain why a home on the water has become the ultimate acquisition of the Long Island suburban dream.

title: Dab, Dab: Dandy Wipes
description: In a time of luxury everything, the lowliest items are being dressed up and taken out. Even the humble Handi Wipe is going posh, with a new selection of upscale towelettes, manufactured by cosmetics companies for women who want a fancier freshen-up.

title: A Female Warrior in the Ring
description: IT wasn't as if Ann-Marie Saccurato was out of shape. At 23 she is a personal trainer who teaches kick boxing and spinning at the New York Sports Club in White Plains.

title: Much of Latin Pop, Aging and Sterile, Isn't Keeping Pace
description: LAST year was a great year for Latin music, and by extension Latin culture, in the United States, if one accepts that the enthusiastic reception of Latin music by non-Latinos was a true indication of the music's health. What happened, in fact, was that some of Latin music's most popular artists -- Ricky Martin in Latin pop and Marc Anthony in salsa -- made records in English that were huge sellers in the United States. As might be expected, the English-speaking press took notice.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Eliza Sorensen, Zachary Wald
description: Eliza Ridgely Sorensen, a daughter of Leigh and Arthur Sorensen of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Zachary O Wald, a son of Ellen Wald Ginsberg of Sands Point, N.Y., and the late Richard I. Wald. The Rev. Bethany Nourse Golden, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMEZ, REINOSO, TEOFILO I.
description: GOMEZ-REINOSO-Teofilo I. August 4, 2000. A native of Cuba, he was both a noted lawyer and judge. A graduate of New York University, where he received his masters degree in philosophy. He is survived by his brother Manuel Gomez-Reinoso. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, August 7, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, August 8, 10 AM, St. Thomas More Church, East 89th St, NYC. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Sara Bayles, Matthew Michaelis
description: Sara Kathryn Bayles and Matthew Alan Michaelis were married yesterday by the Rev. Stanley Johnson, an Episcopal priest, at the Siasconset Union Chapel in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Napster: Unplugged?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chicago's Trading Pits, This May Be The Final Generation
description: WHEN the Chicago Board of Trade opened for trading at 9:30 a.m., Earle Combs IV, known as Chip, was doing what he loves to do -- jostling for position in the soybean pit with his arms raised high.

title: Vacationers, Beware The Ides Of August
description: IT'S summertime and the living is easy, or at least it is supposed to be. Every August, exhausted policy makers, tired traders and burnt-out journalists flee their high-powered jobs for two weeks of R&R; in the Hamptons, at Martha's Vineyard or on the Maryland shore. Pity these poor power players; they're just looking for a few days of sun and sand with the kids before returning to the frenzy that will begin again the day after Labor Day. But if the 1990's are any indication, August can be the cruelest month for those who cherishinternational calm and stable currency markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREYDUN, BATSHEVA MALKA
description: FREYDUN-Batsheva Malka. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Batsheva Malka Freydun, beloved sister of Rabbi Yedidya Azrahian, spiritual leader of our sister congregation, Sephardic Society of Manhattan. May he & his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: In the Region/Westchester; Median House Price Tops $400,000 for the First Time
description: FOR the first time, the median price for a single-family house in Westchester has exceeded $400,000, primarily because of a highly competitive market, multiple bids and a greater number of sales of high-priced properties.

title: Cruise Ships and The Disabled
description: IN the spring of 1998, Tammy Stevens of Jacksonville, Fla., who uses a wheelchair, booked a three-night cruise to the Bahamas aboard Premier Cruises' Oceanic, a 35-year-old ship sailing out of Port Canaveral. Although she said she was assured by her travel agent and the line that her cabin aboard the Oceanic, also identified as the Big Red Boat I, was wheelchair-accessible, she found it was not

title: Sports of The Times; Valentine's Bond With Bush Was Forged Through a Firing
description: IT is not as if George W. Bush needed to convince Bobby Valentine that he could manage the country. Valentine is a registered Republican who last voted for the other ticket in 1972, for George McGovern.

title: History Written in Stones, Gold and Even Elephant Hair
description: Elizabeth Doyle has always had a passion for precious rocks. She majored in geology at Amherst and studied at the Gemological Institute of America. In May, with a sister, she opened a store on 189 Orchard Street, near Houston Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, specializing in estate and antique jewels. ''It's not what I envisioned,'' Ms. Doyle said, ''but it's exactly what I want.''

title: Help Doctors Who Help the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pro in Grand Roles Takes On Maria Callas
description: IT has been 32 years since Lorraine Serabian sang ''Life is what you do while you're waiting to die'' in the Broadway musical ''Zorba.''

title: The Next Chapter
description: I grew up in a small, lower-middle-class, all-white, Catholic town. Most of the population was of Russian, Polish or Slovak descent. The residents weren't concerned with race issues, but they feared, if Polish, say, that their children would marry a Russian or Slovak or an Italian or Irish kid.

title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do
description: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.

title: Home Sweet Hotel
description: THE high school assignment seemed simple enough: draw or paint your dream house and don't hold back. And so my classmates up in the Buffalo suburb of Amherst, N.Y., dutifully submitted renderings of elaborate Southern plantations, festive pink and blue Caribbean bungalows and sprawling Spanish haciendas.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00: Expert Opinion: Exercise Regimens; Fit to Serve
description: In 1978, George W. Bush's first campaign ad showed him jogging through Lubbock, Tex. It didn't help him. The only folks who run around here, his opponent joked, are trying to get away from someone. Two decades later, when the cardiovascular health of Bush's vice-presidential running mate, Dick Cheney, is front-page news, it's hard to imagine the public electing someone who doesn't jog -- or at least make all the right claims about physical fitness. (Bush's spokeswoman, Karen Hughes, in fact, made sure to emphasize that when Bush called Cheney to offer him the position, Cheney was on the treadmill and could not answer the phone.) But who could beat whom in a real race?

title: Graduates' Trash Becomes Freshmen's Treasure With a Program That Recycles Dormitory Castoffs
description: FOUR years ago, Lisa Heller, then a speech instructor at the University of Richmond, was astounded by all the perfectly good futons, lamps and even computers being tossed curbside when new graduates vacated their dormitory rooms.

title: Talking About Race
description: I have spent nearly my entire career as a kindergarten teacher in public schools. While some parents won't talk to one another across cultural and racial walls, their children have no problems communicating, playing and enjoying one another. How is race lived in America? In kindergarten, it is lived together.

title: Ellen Pendleton, John Troyer
description: Ellen Bond Pendleton, a violinist, and Dr. John Karl Troyer, a biotechnologist, are to be married today by the Rev. Jennifer J. McKenna at the Second Presbyterian Church in Baltimore.

title: Crime
description: Nobody writes about the bad old days down South like James Lee Burke. ''I remember the slot and racehorse machines, their chromium and electric glitter among the potted palms in the old Frederic Hotel on Main Street, and the cribs on each side of the train tracks that ran the length of Railroad Avenue,'' he tells us in PURPLE CANE ROAD (Doubleday, $24.95), capturing in a single sentence the feeling of the undead, only-sleeping past that keeps stirring to life in his crime novels.

title: POSTINGS: Nine Stories and 350 Rooms; Hotel to Rise On the Hudson In Jersey City
description: For years the pier jutting 800 feet into the Hudson River along Jersey City's shoreline has served as a giant parking lot for the Harborside Financial Center office complex. That will soon change.

title: Personal Business; The Workstation As Archaeological Dig
description: Corporate America may be moving toward the paperless office, but many employees are still caught up in the daily paper chase. Desks remain buried under mounds of files, books, newspapers and unopened mail. How does this cubicle chaos affect job performance, either yours or your employees'? And what mysteries have been solved when messy desks are finally cleared? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. E-mail: onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Suit of High-Priced, High-Tech Armor to Fend Off Latter-Day Highwaymen
description: WE were speeding along in what the Mercedes-Benz executive at the wheel had promised would be a two-part demonstration of a new S-Class sedan -- 0-to-30 acceleration, followed by 30-to-0 braking. He did not tell us about the third part, involving three guys with .44 Magnums who surrounded the car as it screeched to a halt.

title: Robin Halpern, Michael Cavanaugh III
description: Robin Elizabeth Halpern, the daughter of Elizabeth Murrell Halpern of Hampden, Me., and the late Gordon A. Halpern, was married yesterday to Michael Thomas Cavanaugh III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cavanaugh Jr. of Holyoke, Mass. The Rev. Elaine Beth Peresluha officiated at the Unitarian Universalist Society of Bangor, Me. The Rev. Joseph J. Koury, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Redskins' Boss Makes Enemies and Super Bowl Plans
description: There are always stories about Daniel Snyder, the Washington Redskins' owner. Some are true. Some are tall tales. They swirl around him as if he were living an Aesop fable. The moral of the stories is, well, mixed. He is a savior, a braggart, a genius and the big bad wolf all wrapped up in one.

title: Index This
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00: Questions for Bruce Baller; Strange Attractors
description: Q: Three weeks ago, you and a team at Fermilab finally found the long-sought particle called the tau neutrino. An old French mathematician once said that a theory is not complete until you can explain it to the first person you meet on the street. Why is finding the particle so important?

title: Tribute to Mora
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Little Room To Tinker In Latin America
description: THE wave of economic reforms that has washed over Latin America first touched shore in Chile. That small nation, with an economy roughly the size of New Jersey's, was the first to tear down import barriers, liberalize exchange-rate policy, bolster the domestic savings rate and otherwise whip itself into shape for the new global economy.

title: Manhattan Real Estate Brokers Dot-Commed Into Cooperating
description: Nearly three decades ago, real estate agents across the nation began to make life easier for home buyers by sharing listings. Buyers visited just one broker, who could tell them about everything on the market, even properties represented by other brokers.

title: MAHOPAC: OFFICIALS AND FIREFIGHTERS SUED
description: After the malfunction of a Ferris wheel last summer at the annual Fireman's Carnival in Mahopac, a father, godfather and grandfather have sued firefighters and officials in the Sheriff's Department. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Carmel, contends that a deputy sheriff used excessive force when he tried to stop the plaintiffs -- Michael Barile, Michael Bunyea and William LaScala -- from entering the firehouse to search for Mr. Bunyea's 12-year-old daughter, Nicole, who had been on the ride but was not injured. The suit says the deputy sheriff threw Mr. Bunyea against a firetruck and onto the ground. Mr. Barile is Nicole's godfather, and Mr. LaScala is her grandfather. The men were charged with assault after trying to enter the firehouse. Although all charges were dropped, the plaintiff's lawyer, Joseph J. Tock, said the arrests damaged their reputations. They are seeking $21 million in damages. Elsa Brenner

title: The View From/West Hartford; Once a Home for Milk Trucks, Now a Theater in the Round
description: WEST HARTFORD, virtually equidistant between Boston and New York, has long capitalized on its proximity to more live culture than a lifetime supply of yogurt. Now, with construction under way on the Park Road Playhouse, the town is about to gain the first live theater of its 146-year-old history.

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Lives; International Relations
description: The passport I hand through the slit in her glass shield runs suspiciously backward, the right-hand cover its front, and above the curved swords of its Urdu lettering she reads, ''Islamic Republic of Pakistan.'' Words to make a visa officer tremble.

title: PAROLE CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Andrew B. Consovoy, the chairman of the New Jersey Parole Board, under pressure to explain a recently disclosed backlog of cases and under investigation by the state attorney general in connection with favorable treatment for several inmates with organized-crime ties, resigned last week. The governor's office gave no reason for his departure. Mr. Consovoy, who has a history of heart trouble, has been on medical leave since mid-June, shortly after he was summoned to the governor's office for a meeting with her chief of staff. Since then, the attorney general's office, which is defending a lawsuit by inmates still awaiting the parole hearings that they were entitled to months ago, found about 2,800 inmates beyond their parole-eligibility dates who had not received hearings or were still awaiting a decision or release. LAURA MANSNERUS

title: Just Fine, Thank You
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANKEL, BERTHA
description: FRANKEL-Bertha. Dearest Mom, 8 years have gone by. Miss you and think of you always. Your loving Daughter.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of resources for travelers on July 9 with an article about the Burren in County Clare, Ireland, misidentified the publisher of ''The Burren: a Companion to the Wildflowers of an Irish Limestone Wilderness'' by E. Charles Nelson. It was published for the Conservancy of the Burren by Samton Ltd. (Dublin), not by the Collins Press (London). The name of the publisher for a second book, ''Wild Plants of the Burren and the Aran Islands,'' also by Dr. Nelson, was omitted. It was the Collins Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, HAROLD
description: FRANKLIN-Harold. August 4, 1920 to July 25, 2000. 79, of Del Ray Beach, FL., formerly of NYC . Author, playwright, poet, acclaimed book designer. Preceded in death by his loving wife Fran. Survived by daughters, Bethann and Laura. Will be missed by all he touched.

title: Displaying Art to Seduce Viewers
description: FIFTY-EIGHT works of art, wrapped in brown cardboard, stood lined up on the floor against the freshly painted, unadorned walls in the galleries at the Katonah Museum of Art here. The works had traveled from their homes -- in museums, with artists and in private collections -- in climate-controlled trucks.

title: Phoebe Barkham, Jordan Korfine
description: Phoebe Barkham, the daughter of Elizabeth and Graham Barkham of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Jordan Laurence Korfine, the son of Sheila Korfine of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Martin Korfine. Rabbi Albert Sturmer is to officiate at Doral Arrowwood, a resort in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PHOENIX

title: '85 Murder Case Tests Limits Of Patient Confidentiality
description: Seventeen years ago, an angry young doctor who had been fighting with his wife went to consult Michael H. Stone, a psychiatrist known for treating the violent rages and fragile self-esteem of borderline personality disorder.

title: Alone With Gore, Almost Unrestrained
description: Al Gore's Hank Williams imitation is certainly surprising, and he did it at dinner, by request -- with his mouth full of food, actually. ''Have you ever seen a robin cry,'' he twanged, ''when leaves begin to fall.'' Then, on a roll, he sang a few lines of Garth Brooks's ''I've Got Friends in Low Places.''

title: From the Doo-Wop School of Design
description: MARYANN SCHROPSDORFF was dressed for a little nostalgia. She had a neat blue-and-white Hawaiian-print shirt, trim jeans and soft-soled saddle shoes. Her boombox played songs like Johnny Ray's ''Cry'' and various Elvis Presley hits. For some, this may be the dog-eat-dog, make-a-hard-buck, dot-com era. But for Ms. Schropsdorff and her colleagues at the Doo-Wop Preservation League, it is always the optimistic, futuristic 1950's.

title: Aiming for Converts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place Where Everybody Knows Your Byline
description: This is what Anton Chekhov said about news reporters in a letter to a friend written around 1888: ''The word newspaper-writer means, at the very least, a scoundrel. I am one of them. I work with them. I shake hands with them. I'm even told that I've begun to look like one. But I shan't die as one.''

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Virgin Atlantic Allows Incoming Cellular Calls
description: Virgin Atlantic Airways says passengers can now receive calls made to their cellular telephone number during flights.

title: Sports of The Times; Greed and Sheer Gall Catch Up to Brennan
description: THEY busted him in the shower. It was a gambit right out of ''The Sopranos,'' collaring a man when he is most vulnerable, soaping himself and singing ''Con Te Partiro,'' and thinking he's a regular Andrea Boccelli.

title: To Play Police-Pay Roulette, Bet on New Suffolk Numbers
description: LAST month, when an arbitrator awarded Suffolk County police officers a contract that raises salaries by 20 percent over four years, officials across the Island who are facing their own negotiations shook their heads in disbelief and dread.

title: Ad Agency's Partners
description: FH&P, a marketing and advertising agency in Hauppauge, has changed its name to FEN&R to mark the naming of new partners. Joe Friedman is senior partner, now joined by Jim Ellis, Lynellen Nielsen and David Rogan.

title: Works That Appear Soft but Are Posed in Stone
description: THE Victorian house was what you might expect of a sculptor with Barbara Segal's sensibilities: nooks and crannies, stained glass windows, the Hudson River and Palisades a stone's throw from the front porch. The house was quiet on a recent summer morning, with 11-year-old David away at camp, and Steve Mack, Ms. Segal's husband, at his job as a contractor.

title: From Worst to First
description: While most New York fans have been focusing on the pennant runs of the Yankees and the Mets, those who have ventured to Giants Stadium this spring and summer have been treated to an even more stirring drama. That is where the MetroStars, the area's entry in Major League Soccer, have pulled off one of the most heartening turnarounds in recent local sports history. The MetroStars have gone from league laughingstock to a dominant power. Going into this season's final stretch, the team holds a commanding lead in its Eastern Division.

title: Access to Taxis
description: To the Editor: Isn't it shameful that other cities have accessible taxis and New York doesn't?

title: Move Over, Fire Island, Here Comes Asbury Park; Urban Gays Lead Way in Reviving This Run-Down Resort
description: ON MOST Saturdays in summer, Anthony Perrotta awakens to the clatter of breakfast dishes, the slamming of screen doors and the ceaseless chatter coming from the first floor of his four-bedroom 1920's stucco home overlooking Sunset Lake. The weekly ritual has begun: friends and neighbors drop in to discuss where everyone will be for lunch, whether it's a beach day, who will be host of a cocktail or dinner party, and what time they'll stop by the club at night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTEN, MICHELE
description: KESTEN-Michele. On August 1, 2000. Loving mother of Frederika and Christina, dear sister of Annie and Catherine Pujade, adoring grandmother of Marlowe. She will be profoundly missed by her extended family and friends.

title: Nicole Eldridge, Jeffrey Marcus
description: Nicole Elizabeth Eldridge, a daughter of Joyce and W. Lawrence Eldridge of West Newton, Mass., was married last evening to Jeffrey David Marcus, the son of Gerri and Averill Marcus of Miami. Rabbi Frank Waldorf officiated at the Gamble Mansion, a historic house in Boston.

title: Footnotes
description: 1a. Baltimore: Babe Ruth, Billie Holiday, Spiro Agnew and ''The Star Spangled Banner'' were born there. Edgar Allen Poe died there. And John Waters still rules there. He has stuck by his town with a vengeance, conceiving all of his films -- Female Trouble,'' ''Hairspray,'' etc. -- for their Baltimore locations. ''It's a city that always inspires me,'' says Waters, who once dubbed it ''the hairdo capital of the world.'' (b) Products like Bumble & Bumble Hairspray ($9 at Bumble & Bumble, 146 East 56th Street) help build the beehive and artichoke styles that adorn Waters's heroines.

title: Sharon Falco, Jonathan Lustgarten
description: Dr. Sharon Falco, a psychiatrist, and Dr. Jonathan Henry Lustgarten, a neurosurgeon, were married last evening at the Pen Ryn Mansion, a historic house in Bensalem, Pa. Rabbi Shimon Berris officiated with the Rev. Michael Colagreco, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A Tree Grows Where?; In Several Sites Around the State There Are Giant Sequoias. Really.
description: ON the grounds of the Naval Undersea Warfare Center in New London, where scientists invented sonar, stands an exotic artifact that seems as if it lost its way. But 34 years ago, someone did indeed plant a giant sequoia tree at the center. With not a mountain in sight, its usual habitat, the tree thrived and now stands 40 feet tall.

title: A Defense of a Moratorium On Oyster Bay Land
description: I am writing in response to Councilman Anthony Macagnone's letter [July 30] criticizing my call for a limited moratorium on development of land in the special groundwater protection area in Oyster Bay.

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: $372,000 WORTH OF GRANTS AWARDED
description: Twenty-four state grants totaling $372,212 have been awarded to community and environmental organizations in New York City and Westchester County to promote stewardship of natural areas, encourage community involvement in environmental protection and educate the public about the value of natural resources. Among the grants are $16,500 to the Bronx River Restoration Project in the Bronx for volunteer water-quality monitoring, habitat restoration and community outreach programs along the Bronx River; $15,000 to the Greenburgh Nature Center in for habitat restoration and educational programming; and $15,000 to the Mohansic Elementary School in Yorktown Heights for an outdoor classroom for environmental courses. Elsa Brenner

title: 5B Technologies' Profit Built on Record Revenues
description: The 5B Technologies Corporation of Jericho (Nasdaq: FIVE) posted record revenues of $7.5 million in the second quarter, more than triple the $2.3 million of the year earlier. Consolidated revenues more than doubled, to $9.5 million from $4.1 million.

title: Sydney Has Champions in Arts, Too
description: AUSTRALIA has well-deserved credentials as one of the great sporting nations of the world, but its reputation in the arts is a more recent phenomenon. For visitors to the Olympic Games, the Sydney Olympic Arts Festival, with its roster of dance, music, art, theater and film, offers an enticing bonus, a way to appreciate the rich and diverse culture of this antipodean nation and place Australia's artistic achievements in an international context. The six-week-long festival actually starts a full month before the Games commence, to set the stage and to showcase the full scope of arts offerings.

title: The Lure of Raw Space
description: IN the 10 years that Anna and Peter Bakst waited to buy their dream house, Mrs. Bakst regularly clipped architectural and decorating ideas from magazines. So by the time they finally bought, they pretty much knew exactly what they wanted. Which is why after buying a 4,200-square-foot condominium in SoHo in 1997 they were content to wait almost a year to move in while the contractor transformed a virtually empty space into a home for themselves and their two young sons.

title: Who Are We? Um, We're Working on That
description: Strategists at S.M.E. Power Branding, which specializes in athletic branding, have cured Elon College in North Caroline of its identity crisis. In May, after four months and $40,000 in focus groups and consultations (read: institutional gestalt therapy), the college, which has graduated to Division I athletics, selected a new identity - the Phoenix.

title: WATCHING 'SURVIVOR' WITH: Margaret Cho; Boning Up on Back-Stabbing
description: MARGARET CHO was a virgin. That was why her friends gathered Wednesday night in her suite at the Paramount Hotel to initiate her into the world of those who can spell Gervase -- a universe that does not include contestants on the television series ''Survivor.''

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00: The Ethicist; Tattoo You
description: I am an anesthesiologist. Last week, I had a young male patient on the table for an apendectomy. As I was pushing the drugs to put him to sleep, I noticed a Nazi flag tattoo enveloping his upper arm. Being Jewish and having a grandmother who lost her entire family to the Nazis, I was disturbed. What level of care must an ethical physician provide to a patient he finds offensive? -- Anonymous, Atlanta

title: A Different Kind of Cow Story (Really)
description: NO one believed me when I told them about Mabel, not even when I said she wasn't one of those street cows in ''Cow Parade.'' She was an indoor cow and lived with me.

title: Genevieve Lohman, Robert Lynch Jr.
description: Genevieve Nicole Lohman, the daughter of Charlotte E. de La Poole of New York and Terence J. Lohman of Denver, was married yesterday to Robert Henry Lynch Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynch of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. John O. Lind, a great-uncle of the bride, led the nondenominational ceremony at the Outpost, a lodge in Keystone, Colo.

title: For Casey, Penn State Football Is Focus
description: Rashard Casey does not talk or act like a man who is worried about going to jail after being charged with assaulting an off-duty police officer in a racially charged street fight last spring. Casey, a senior and the first-string quarterback of the Penn State football team, said today ''If I could talk, I'd talk'' about that incident outside a nightclub in his hometown of Hoboken, N.J., on May 14.

title: Coming Soon to a Beach Near You
description: ONE pair of scientists observed that it resembles a mop hiding beneath a dinner plate. And a famous author took license by exaggerating the threat of its sting: ''Behold the lion's mane!'' cried Sherlock Holmes as he revealed the murderer in an Arthur Conan Doyle story, declaring the jellyfish deadlier than a cobra.

title: A Cautionary Tale From NewZealand
description: WHEN Trevor Mallard became New Zealand's Minister of Education several months ago, one of his first steps was to bolster direct government assistance to troubled urban schools.

title: Some Survivors Find Their Own Rewards
description: As a famous actor, Danny Glover is used to getting all sorts of charity requests. So, when Orel Lee Brown, a widowed mother of two, asked him to speak to a group of her students in a drug-infested area of Oakland, Calif., he took the request in stride. When an opening finally came up in his schedule and Mr. Glover went to see Ms. Brown, he was amazed -- and moved -- by what he encountered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDORS, ELLEN BESS
description: ANDORS-Ellen Bess. Died after a long, brave home-based battle with cancer at Cabrini Hospice Unit on Wednesday, August 2. She was 54. Ellen was a dedicated teacher, a brilliant computer programmer, a Ph.D anthropologist, a fabulous cook, an avid gardener, a sometime piano player, a devoted mother. But, above all, she was a tireless fighter for social justice and used all her considerable talents and intelligence on the many causes that caught her attention. She leaves behind her beloved daughter Nora Maya Andors, her grieving father and two brothers, Irving Andors, Stephen and Leon, her beloved and caring aunt Rachel Andors, a supportive and loving group of friends including Carol Buck, Sue Harris, Janet Mayes and Kaarli Tasso. A memorial gathering will be held at her home in the Fall.

title: The Changing Face of Catholic Education
description: THEY slouch into chairs, faces rumpled and downcast, a sluggish clot of high school juniors in Gonzaga Prep's 8 a.m. religion class. Members of a generation stuffed with Pokemon and Simpsons reruns, they are about to get their daily dose of Roman Catholic Church history, focusing today on the eighth century.

title: The Battle in Cyberspace
description: In the summer of 1997, Dr. Cyndi Wilson Porter, an assistant chemistry professor at Lakeland College in Sheboygan, Wis., was asked to teach a class online. She hesitated at first -- she loved the feel of a classroom, the camaraderie of live communication. She did not want to be an anonymous piece of software somewhere beyond the computer screen.

title: Consumed By Race
description: What am I to make of the fact that more whites buy Cool Whip, but more blacks buy apple juice? This clumsy attempt to demystify blacks and whites to one another reminded me of how, when I was young, white friends who knew that I was close to many black people would ask, ''Do they have any furniture in their living rooms?''

title: Administration Plans Cuts In Some Drug Payments
description: In an effort to save money for Medicare, the Clinton administration is planning to cut payments for anticancer drugs administered to patients in doctors' offices. This could affect hundreds of thousands of elderly patients.

title: Sara Jorgensen, Michael Klotz

The Rev. Dr. Paul S. Johnson performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Princeton, N.J.

description: A Pop/Jazz music listing on Page 37 of Arts & Leisure today for the City Parks Foundation Concerts in New York misstates the day of a performance by Grupo Caribe. It is Aug. 15, not Thursday.

title: Resort Recyclables
description: Palm Springs is known for its population of dapper white-loafered, blue-haired snowbirds. Less known is that when they fly back north they molt, leaving behind bits of wardrobe and some very rich vintage shops. One, the Angel View Prestige Boutique at 454 North Indian Canyon, is stocked with Dior, Escada, Versace and, recently, a 40-pound Bob Mackie beaded gown. Charles Deichert, the general manager of the shop, which benefits the Angel View Crippled Children's Foundation, attributes his inventory to donors who don't want to be seen in the same dress more than a few times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, JOHN JAMES
description: HIGGINS-John James. Of Yonkers, NY. Former New York Times retired engineer. Born in Drumkeerin, County Leitrim, Ireland. Beloved husband of Eleanor (nee Leddy). Devoted father of Michael, Maureen Brunner, Bridget and John. Loving brother of Michael, Annie Cullen and the late Sr. Fenton, Patrick and Frank. Dear grandfather of Thomas, Aileen, Michael and Kathleen. Cherished father-in-law of Thomas, Dory and Cheryl. Reverend Monsignor John A. Gallagher, Ph.D., pastor offered the Funeral Mass at St. Paul the Apostle Church July 17. Burial in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Learning to Predict Allergy Season
description: STUDENTS from two Westchester high schools headed back to school last month to do research on weather and pollen, hoping to forecast the duration and intensity of next year's allergy season.

title: Plan Future Blooms
description: Bearded iris should be divided every four years after flowering; this can be done through early August. Cut out and discard any sections damaged by rot or iris borer. Dip healthy three- to four-inch pieces of rhizome in a mild bleach solution or dust with fungicide and replant so that the top of the rhizome is just covered with soil.

title: White Plains Hospital Offers Online Visits
description: Patients at White Plains Hospital Center can now open their own Web pages to let family members know how they're doing. A Manhattan-based company, VisitingOurs.com, is spending $40,000 to build nine computer kiosks around the hospital with access to its Web site, which can also be visited from any computer with Internet service.

title: A Pathway for Wheelchairs Becomes a Door to Dissent
description: Would it be a wheelchair-friendly doorway or a scar on a historic building? That is the question before the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which is considering a proposal to alter the entrance to the first apartment building in the Carnegie Hill Historic District.

title: Yonel Letellier and Nadia Khalilpour
description: THE tango aficionados of New York -- a small but passionate group -- say that the tango can change your state of mind, the way you walk and how you dress. Women who once wore jeans and T-shirts start tango dancing and convert to gowns with slits and fishnet stockings. In a way, fishnets are the perfect metaphor for tango -- it is the dance form in which you reveal the most. Partners dance close, to music of grief, homesickness and hope.

title: The World: Vanilla Flavored; Serving Up the Campaign Message, However Bland
description: SUSAN ESTRICH, the manager of Michael S. Dukakis's unsuccessful 1988 campaign for president, was rattling off ways Al Gore could use the Democratic convention to rebut George W. Bush's accomplished performance last week when she stopped short and laughed at herself. ''Most people won't be listening to any of this!'' she exclaimed.

title: Times When Less Is More Profound
description: HITLER killed them.'' That's the answer Jay Rosenblatt used to get as a boy whenever he asked his grandfather about the rest of his family.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Whole Lot of Commentary Going On
description: Benjamin Zucker's first novel, BLUE (Overlook, $40), is at once a spiritual challenge and a gorgeous typographical object. Echoing the style of the Talmud, the book presents a continuing narrative in the center of each right-hand page, where a passage from the Mishna -- ancient commentary on the Torah -- would ordinarily be placed. The protagonist of this core text, a New York gem merchant named Abraham Tal, specializes in giving advice to others. Unfortunately, he appears to be incapable of taking decisive action in his own life, most notably in the matter of setting a date to marry Rachel Beller, his girlfriend of many years. He is constantly at odds with his brother and partner, Tuviah, in a sibling rivalry that recalls numerous biblical antecedents. The central story is wreathed with commentaries, including those of Abe's mother and father, the impatient Rachel and a host of others both living and dead: Rabbi Nachman of Breslov, Chief Crazy Horse, Modigliani, Isaac Luria, Bob Dylan and dozens more. Their remarks all begin with a word or phrase taken from the main text; the words attributed to them are a mixture of direct quotations, in italics, and the author's expertly constructed inventions of what they might have said. The left-hand pages all bear illustrations -- dazzling reproductions of Vermeers and Van Goghs, photographs of Kafka, Talmudic texts -- that preside over the profusion of stories, judgments and opinions on the facing pages. More than a novel, ''Blue'' may in fact be a collective meditation on character. Is Abraham Tal's inaction wrong, or is he merely waiting for something as yet unannounced? Is he a coward, or simply a man seduced by a vision of the infinite? The color blue, whether in a painting by Monet, Kafka's ''blue notebooks'' or the amazing 204-carat sapphire that graces the book's jacket, functions as a symbol of eternity. In the struggle to comprehend a secular life that somehow and always includes the divine, these many commentators, like Luria and his fellow cabalists in the holy city of Safed, all seem to be ''floating in their own prayer.'' William Ferguson

title: William Mercer, 73, D.J. Known as Rosko, Is Dead
description: William Roscoe Mercer, known for decades to New York radio listeners simply as Rosko, died on Tuesday. He was 73 and lived in New York.

title: Wall Street Plays a Guessing Game
description: A series of economic reports last week calmed some investor's inflation jitters but left others wondering whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again.

title: 2nd-Quarter Results Are Mixed at Veeco
description: Veeco Instruments Inc. of Plainview (Nasdaq: VECO) announced mixed second-quarter financial results after factoring in its $33 million acquisition of CVC Inc. this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCHE, JOSEPH
description: MANCHE-Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Manche, associated with The Times from 1966 until 1997.

title: Bookend; Giveaways
description: The one real perk of book reviewing is the chance to read a novel early, in a state of innocent grace -- that is, before the flurry of reviews in which your fellow critics ruin the novel for you by revealing its entire plot. Anyone who enjoys fiction (not only mysteries and thrillers, but literary fiction) partly for the pleasure of finding out what happens next, as well as any writer who writes at least partly for such rapt and dedicated readers, will doubtless have noticed that an increasing percentage of book reviews have found a foolproof way (paragraph after paragraph dutifully retelling the narrative from beginning to end) of making sure that the reader will never enjoy that particular pleasure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HAROLD JAY
description: KRAMER-Harold Jay. The Board of Trustees of The Princeton Symphony Orchestra regrets the passing of our loyal and generous supporter, Harold Jay Kramer.

title: An Active Night Scene Is a Major Attraction
description: OCEAN AVENUE, on a Saturday night in late July: the opera at Convention Hall has just let out and hundreds of mostly gray-haired men and women scurry to their Volvos and BMW's to drive back to the suburbs.

title: Liberties; What on Earth Were They Thinking?
description: Prince Albert is in a can.

title: Music, Minus Those Pesky Composers
description: THE Lincoln Center Festival's five-concert Electronic Evolution series last month surveyed the history of electronic music, starting with the 1920 invention of the theremin, the electronic instrument that looks like a radio transmitter and was once a staple of sci-fi movie soundtracks. These rewarding concerts showed where electronic music has come from.

title: Ciscos Quarterly Profit Seen Falling on Acquisition Expenses
description: Cisco's Quarterly Profit Seen Falling on Acquisition Expenses

title: Near Asheville, Biltmore Is Building a 213-Room Inn
description: A hundred years ago, shortly after George W. Vanderbilt built a 250-room French Renaissance country estate outside this western North Carolina city in the Blue Ridge Mountains, he carefully sketched out plans for a 50-room inn on the property.

title: Talking About Race
description: Unlike most coverage, your issue wasn't mere antiracism cant. I'm all for a racism-free society, but the way the media have been going about it is all wrong. Instead of shouting out slogans, we should express our true feelings regarding race without holding back. If someone feels anger toward a certain race or religion, we ought to let him voice it and then try to educate him, not yell at and scold him for having those feelings.

title: The G.O.P. Isn't the Only Party to Dissemble on Race
description: A lot of people have made fun of the charade of inclusiveness last week at the Republican Convention, as one black or Hispanic speaker after another trooped to the podium. But George W. Bush is likely to benefit from the rainbow parade for a simple reason. The Democrats have made their own mockery of inclusion.

title: The Enterprise of Recreation
description: FROM the days of the so-called Bronx Riviera, the bathers shown above were patrons of the Beach Shop at Orchard Beach in 1940. The image can be seen in a Parks Department exhibition that covers 130 years of commercial enterprises in the city's parks. Not only have these park concessions provided amenities to the public; they have also enriched the city: net revenues have risen from $2.5 million in 1978 to more than $42 million in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEINMAN, SAMUEL
description: KLEINMAN-Samuel. Beloved husband of Harriet, loving father of Gail Botkin, grandfather of Jackie, David, Scott Botkin; Marnie and Brett Auerbach and great-grandfather of Brandon, brother of Martha Liebenthal. We shall miss you forever.
