description: ''Sometimes I go on radio shows with Russian Jews in New York. They ask me how I can live in Germany. But the Holocaust is in the past. You cannot live endlessly thinking the people on the street are related to that madness.''

description: The first noticeable difference was the uniforms, an old-style color scheme and a revived helmet logo. The next difference was the field. It was grass.

title: Former Soviet Jews Find Uneasy Peace in Germany
description: Violetta Botwinikova is a new-wave Berliner, brisk and chic, a 24-year-old entrepreneur, Moscow-born, Jewish -- and very much at home in an adoptive land that changed history by producing a killing machine for Europe's Jews.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-06-00; Evil Inc.
description: Over the past decade or so, Americans turned the tobacco industry into the great common foe, a true corporate villain. Sure, there were plenty of people who enjoyed a little tobacco, but Big Tobacco was an all-purpose whipping boy: big profitable companies, run by arrogant fat cats whose products were not just addictive and lethal but also smelly. The industry practically took the place of the Soviet Union: who wanted to be known as soft on cigarettes?

title: Kathleen Collins, Tucker Walsh
description: Kathleen Mary Collins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy F. Collins III of Walpole, Mass., was married yesterday to Tucker Matthew Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Stephen Walsh of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The Rev. John P. Culloty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Church in Norwood, Mass.

title: Laying It On Thick
description: ''I'm Raven, I'm a Satanist and I'll be doing your makeup.'' It is a line no actress wants to hear when facing the mirror. But in ''Cecil B. DeMented,'' the latest John Waters comedy, Honey Whitlock, a kidnapped Hollywood starlet, will never be ready for her close-up as long as she looks like Melanie Griffith. No surprise, then, that Ms. Griffith, right, doesn't look like herself for very long in the film, which opens Friday. With her hair bleached beyond blond (''You're going off the deep end of the Clairol color chart,'' her hairstylist says) and her eyelids painted kohl black, Honey goes from Left Coast banal to the height of terrorist chic. Van Smith, the costume designer, said the film marks a return to the radical makeup he provided for the earlier Waters films ''Pink Flamingos'' and ''Female Trouble.''

title: Blurring the Distinctions Among Familiar Ideas
description: Eugene Brodsky

description: IT was May 1984. Annemarie O'Sullivan, 17, as good an athlete as North Salem High School has produced, was watching the Olympic track and field trials on television with her younger sister Deirdre.

title: Maria Palmiery, Ramil Bhatnagar
description: Maria Venus Palmiery, the daughter of Crispina Palmiery and Dr. Ponciano Palmiery of Florham Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Ramil Soy Bhatnagar, the son of Soledad Bhatnagar and Dr. Rajesh Bhatnagar of New York. The Rev. Alex Enriquez performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at noon in the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark. Pandit Baljeet Shastri led a Hindu celebration later in the day at Birchwood Manor, a banquet hall in Whippany, N.J.

description: I'D like to begin by thanking New Jerseyans for being the languid, lifeless lunkheads that you are.

description: Fidelity Investments ousted the Janus Capital Corporation as the top-selling mutual fund family in June, the Financial Research Corporation, a Boston consulting group, reported last week.

title: Reckonings; Don't Ask Alan
description: Onstage, the song and dance went perfectly. Offstage, however, George W. Bush's top economic adviser flubbed his lines. On Wednesday The Financial Times ran an interview with Lawrence Lindsey in which the former Fed official made much of his relationship with Alan Greenspan, and appeared to claim that Mr. Greenspan endorses Mr. Bush's economic plan. By the next day Mr. Lindsey was furiously back-pedaling, conceding that he had in fact never discussed the plan with the Fed chairman, and further opining that ''It's not for Chairman Greenspan to endorse one tax plan or another tax plan, or to endorse one candidate or another.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on July 26 about the selection of Dick Cheney as George W. Bush's choice for vice president misidentified Bruce Buchanan, who teaches courses on the presidency at the University of Texas and has closely followed Mr. Bush's career. He is a professor of government, not a historian.

description: ROTKOWITZ-Peter. 8/1/00, age 80. A vital man is gone. Beloved husband of Sadie; adored father of Stewart (Barbara), Fern (Roger), Norman. Cherished grandfather, great-grandfather and friend.

description: THE DAUGHTERS OF SIMON LAMOREAUX

title: The Ticket Buyers' Games
description: TIME, something that many Olympic athletes compete against, has turned out to be a friend to Americans thinking of going to the Summer Games in Sydney next month. Those who have waited before buying package tours to the Games, which officially open Sept. 15 and continue to Oct. 1, will find cheaper plans than were available several months ago -- in some cases, the savings are about 50 percent.

title: For Baseball Fans, Time on Their Side
description: THE baseball fan who has everything doesn't have this.

title: Opting for Hometown Angle At a Slow-News Convention
description: For WLTV, the Univision station in Miami, covering the Republicans in Philadelphia was like getting a seat at a national banquet. Each day, the outlet was given the access it needed to tailor its Spanish-language newscast via interviews with, among others, Al Cardenas, the chairman of the Florida delegation, and Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Republican from Miami-Dade County.

title: Madeleine Bodkin, Marc Rice
description: Madeleine Elizabeth Colquhoun Bodkin was married yesterday on Fire Island to Marc Nicholas Rice. The Rev. Martin B. Copenhaver, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Church at Point o'Woods, with Msgr. John F. Corr taking part.

title: Boorishness Knows No Race
description: Thundering, profane rap music is as much an assault on personal space as is a recording of ''The Three Tenors'' coming from the neighbor's deck speakers when your own task is a nap in the hammock.

title: The Nation; The Road Less Traveled To the Oval Office
description: BACK in 1832, the Anti-Masons were growing so concerned about secret societies and ruling elites in young America that they ran a candidate for president, William Wirt of Maryland, a former United States attorney general.

title: Talking About Race
description: I am a black American living abroad. The reasons for my self-imposed exile couldn't have been made more clear than they were in the astounding articles in your series. They stirred up emotions that are still difficult for me to sort out. I felt anger and sadness, but also a glimmer of hope for the few that are still trying, despite the odds, to reach across the seemingly intractable racial divide that is America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ETHEL. (NEE STEINBERG)
description: WEINSTEIN-Ethel. (nee Steinberg). Born New York City, August 21, 1902, died on July 28, 2000. Wife of the late Mannie. Loving mother of Judy Suben and the late Betsy Teja. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Sad Yet Elated, A Prague Troupe Lives Chekhov
description: OVER the years, I have seen Chekhov's plays performed on many stages -- in London, Moscow, St. Petersburg, Paris and throughout the United States. I have seen all the late great ''Cherry Orchards'': the Romanian-born Andrei Serban's silver-boughed one at Lincoln Center in 1977, Peter Brook's carpeted version at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1988, Peter Stein's Wagnerian one (in German) at the Moscow Art Theater in 1993. Also, Oleg Yefremov's ''Three Sisters'' in Russian, at both the Moscow Art Theater in 1997 and at BAM in 1998, and every other Chekhov play he directed. To name only a few. I am a Chekhov translator, so it's an occupational hazard, as well as a passion. I have also directed the four major plays, several more than once.

title: Where Olympic Dreams Live
description: FAR from the spotlight, the four will be living a dream at the United States Olympic swimming trials, which start a weeklong run in Indianapolis on Wednesday. For the two youngest, it is a chance to dip their toes into the waters of competition at the highest level. For the oldest, it is a last chance to realize an Olympic dream. For the fourth, it is a personal and medical triumph.

title: July 30-August 5; Drop That Doubloon
description: If you drop a dollar bill on the sidewalk and do not pick it up quickly, it is safe to say you have lost your rights to it. If your sailing ship drops into the sea, though, is it still yours?

title: Streetscapes/Sea Gate, Brooklyn; Beachfront House, Shining White and Made of Steel
description: EVER since they bought it in 1967, Pete and Niki Spanakos have enjoyed living in their brilliantly white all-steel house in Sea Gate, Brooklyn. The beachfront house, believed to have been designed in 1936 by William Van Alen, architect of the Chrysler Building, is known in the neighborhood as ''the sugar cube.''

title: Napster: Unplugged?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FROM BOMBA TO HIP-HOP

title: Putting a Value on a Sense of Self-Worth
description: IN 1978 Sister Jeannine was teaching English at St. Mary's School in Manhasset. She lived for those moments when she could introduce her young charges to the glories of the theater, be it a Shakespeare classic or a bubble-gum musical like ''Bye Bye Birdie.''

title: Cone Does Nothing To Erase the Doubts
description: The vein in the right side of David Cone's neck was the first indication. It was bulging. It was bulging because Cone's eyes were moist and he was trying to prevent tears from flowing. Cone tried so hard to suppress the tears that his jaw tightened and the vein stuck out like a blue branch.

title: A Science Museum Embraces Art Through Anatomy
description: SINCE the Exploratorium was founded here 31 years ago as an innovative ''museum of science, art and human perception,'' it has taken pride in breaking traditional museum rules. Mixing science exhibits and artworks with little concern about which is which, the Exploratorium encourages a giddily high level of interactivity, inviting visitors not just to stand and contemplate but to touch, pump, spin or otherwise mess around with most of the 600-plus items on display.

title: The Soft-Money Conventions
description: There were two parallel conventions in Philadelphia last week, one a televised coronation of the Republican ticket inside the First Union Center, the other an endless parade of off-camera fund-raising events in hotel suites, private clubs and restaurants throughout the city. In these genteel settings and others -- including a string of private railroad cars provided by the Union Pacific Railroad and a quiet Pennsylvania trout stream, where House Speaker Dennis Hastert found that donors were biting more readily than the fish -- corporations and wealthy individuals unloaded millions of dollars in an effort to buy influence with a Bush-Cheney administration and with Republicans in the next Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, HOWARD
description: SHELDON-Howard. Age 90, in Greenwich Hospital on August 3, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Fay, cherished father of Gay Goldman and her husband Carl, adored grandfather of Lewis, Leslie and Patricia. Dear great-grandfather of Leah and Jason Goldman, Noah Lack, and Quinn Perini. A compassionate and loving man, who practiced law till the age of 80, he will be greatly missed. Service on Monday 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, MURIEL
description: RESNICK-Muriel. On July 26, 2000, having recently celebrated her 80th birthday surrounded by her family. Totally devoted to her husband of 60 years, Spike (Dr. Herman) and her daughter, Amy. She was a wonderful sister, aunt, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend to many. She kept us laughing and we can only assume she's up there in heaven raising some hell. For information on her burial, call Margo at 713-385-6764.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JEROME
description: KATZ-Jerome. Beloved husband of Rosalyn. Devoted father of Harriet Katz and Joel and Mary Katz. Loving brother of Mortimer and Irving Katz, Shirley Cohen and the late Alice Barsky. He graduated from New York Law School in 1938 and was a member of the American Arbitration Association specializing in labor arbitration. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Friends of Helen Keller National Center, Sands Point, NY 11050, will be greatly appreciated.

title: The Law's Spirit, Over Its Letter
description: IT happened 30 years ago, but it's still one of David T. Link's favorite stories.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 23 about the play ''Spinning Into Butter'' misstated the original publication date of the children's book ''The Story of Little Black Sambo.'' It was 1899, not 1921.

title: COUNTY AND POWER AUTHORITY REACH ACCORD
description: The county has reached agreement with the New York Power Authority on issues related to the sale of Indian Point 3 to the New Orleans-based Entergy Corporation. The authority has promised to pass on more than $1.2 million in energy savings to the county as well as to reduce energy costs for the more than 100 schools, towns and other government agencies that buy power from the authority. Entergy has also agreed to work with the county to correct problems that have been raised about safety, environmental concerns and other plant issues. Elsa Brenner

title: July 30-August 5; Kansas Chooses Evolution
description: In a blow to creationists, Kansas voters rejected the state school board's decision last year to remove evolution from the school science curriculum, paving the way for that decision to be overturned.

title: Coming to the Beach: A Sticky Lion's Mane
description: ONE pair of scientists observed that it resembles a mop hiding beneath a dinner plate. And a famous author exaggerated the threat of its sting: ''Behold the lion's mane!'' cried Sherlock Holmes as he revealed the murderer in an Arthur Conan Doyle story, declaring the jellyfish deadlier than a cobra.

title: The Waters Edge
Take Me Out To the Rock Fest
description: ON a glowing mid-July evening at Giants Stadium in New Jersey, Derek Pedersen, 11, was settling in to enjoy his first rock concert. Waiting for the show to start, he leaned shyly on the shoulder of his mother, Leslie Pedersen, 43. But later, as the Dave Matthews Band took the stage and built to a crescendo of rhythmic guitar and violin, he climbed aboard his 21-year-old sister's shoulders, threw his arms into the air and swayed rhapsodically with the rest of the crowd.

title: New Pharmacy Laws Are Sought For the Posting of Drug Prices
description: Public Advocate Mark Green, calling state rules that require pharmacies to post their drug prices outdated and virtually useless, said yesterday that a survey by his staff had found the posted prices wrong at virtually every one of the 65 drugstores they visited.

title: Bronx Journal; An 'Outlet' Store With a Difference: Cappuccino
description: Sue Greenberg folded herself into a chair in the cafe at ABC Carpet and Home Warehouse Outlet in the southeast Bronx and ordered chicken francais and a glass of white wine. The executive assistant to the store's president, Ms. Greenberg talked about how the cafe, which opened a year ago, enhanced the store, which stands out in the gritty neighborhood like a woman at a Promise Keepers powwow.

description: Extinct Humans By Ian Tattersall and Jeffrey H. Schwartz. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: A Peter N. Nevraumont Book/ Westview Press. $50.

title: From the High-Energy Bloomsbury Crowd
description: THE legends and lore of the Bloomsbury Group, especially the messily entangled lives of its members, have outrun its actual achievements. Only Virginia Woolf and John Maynard Keynes are widely known today for their serious work as well. But as ''The Art of Bloomsbury''at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven makes clear, Bloomsbury artists made art with an enviable thoroughness. In the exhibition, that art is presented with almost equal thoroughness.

title: Having Their Day: From Plain Peaches to Dessert Stars
description: AS the author George Du Maurier wrote, ''An apple is an excellent thing -- until you have tried a peach.'' Indeed, biting into a juicy, ripe peach is one of the great treats of summer. So is eating a cooked peach with vanilla ice cream.

title: At Play Among Dolphins and Dunes
description: WHEN we headed up the Australian coast for Port Stephens, a resort two and a half hours north of Sydney, we had definite expectations: miles of lovely and empty beaches, magnificent sand dunes, famously clean waters inhabited by trophy fish and sociable dolphins. It was all there as promised. But there was also something not on our list: rain.

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: Longtime Neighbors, Newfound Friends
description: After reading your issue on race, one bittersweet entry kept ringing in my head. Betsy Harper (What They Were Thinking, July 16), a white woman, refers to Gladys West, a black woman, by her first name. I wonder how many years will have to pass before Gladys West will feel comfortable calling Betsy Harper ''Betsy'' rather than ''Ms. Harper.''

title: A Library Means Traffic In Cold Spring Harbor
description: As a longtime resident of Cold Spring Harbor, it was with great interest that I read your article regarding the new state park being established in our neighborhood [''Cold Spring Harbor Finds Land for Park,'' July 23].

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Whetting Her Brush
description: Alice Neel (1900-84) once said that had she not been an artist, she could have been a psychiatrist. Her psychological and artistic acumen are evident in the numerous portraits she painted during her six-decade career. ALICE NEEL (Abrams, $45), edited by Ann Temkin, a curator at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, underlines her commitment to portraiture, often despite changing trends in art. The book surveys Neel's range of subjects and unconventional approach to depicting children and families, along with her bold handling of sensitive subjects, from pregnant women to male frontal nudity. The essays present three portraits of the artist: as a woman seeking to forge meaningful connections between her art and personal life; as a product of the New Deal era who shared the democratic ideals of the Federal Art Project, in which Neel participated from 1935 to 1943; and as an opinionated chronicler of the New York art world in the 1960's and 70's, when she portrayed luminaries like Henry Geldzahler and Andy Warhol with a candor that has been compared to vivisection. Neel is also shown to be a keen social observer, who captured the gesture and dress of her day and achieved her declared goal of getting the ''person plus the zeitgeist.'' The composite view is rounded out with anecdotal accounts by sitters who posed for Neel and recall her working methods and tendencies, including talking incessantly during portrait sessions. What emerges from this study is the image of a colorful woman who unflinchingly bore witness to her age. Suzanne Ramljak

title: Tracey Lewis, Don Elligan
description: Tracey Yvette Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Don Gregory Elligan, a son of Deborah Elligan of Chicago and the late Duke Elligan. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister of Riverside Church, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Spinning the Washing Into a 'Family Sport'
description: The newest Clean Rite laundry, a 10,000-square-foot space on Eastern Parkway near Atlantic Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, is not a classic mom-and-pop laundry. But the store, with 218 washers and dryers, is aimed at moms and pops: there is a CD-filled jukebox and a children's area with DVD movies, videos and board games. John Sabino, the company's president, describes the 24-hour laundry as ''a family sport.'' With this, the company's 37th location, it hopes to brighten a block that now contains many boarded-up buildings and vacant lots.

title: By Winning, Graeme Hall Prompts A Big Sigh of Relief From Trainer
description: With a heartbreaking 24 hours behind him and another harrowing 24 ahead, Todd Pletcher summoned a comfortable truism he learned as a boy from his father, J. J., as they knocked along the back stretches of the Southwestern racing circuit. One of three talented 3-year-olds in his barn, Graeme Hall, had just galloped home a surprise winner in the Jim Dandy, earning a relieved shake of the head from Pletcher, his 33-year-old trainer.

title: A Professional Hand For Elegant Gardens
description: HALF a century ago, Beverley Nichols, an English journalist, defied common sense and the advice of his friends and bought a small country estate. Upon inspection he found that the property came with a number of fixtures, the most permanent of which was Oldfield, the gardener, who had worked on the place for more than 40 years, and outlasted the two previous owners.

It's a setup line. He's silly, smug and about to get walloped.

title: A Jerusalem Settlement Everyone Can Live With

In addition, crucial questions will have to be answered involving the Golan Heights, water rights, freedom of movement, Israeli settlements in the West Bank and Gaza, the characteristics of a Palestinian state and the joint maintenance of security.

These essays by the cranky, urbane humorist, first published between 1930 and 1958, zing targets large and small, from Hollywood to Raymond Chandler and Groucho Marx. ''Perelman misses no mad word we write or say, and its image and essence he translates back to us with an artistry acute, brilliant, devastating and . . . funny,'' Eudora Welty wrote in the Book Review in 1958.

title: Introduction

Most readers thought the series contributed to the public dialogue; some fumed at inattention to their own ethnicity; a few despaired that the series would never end.

title: Friendly Stop on the Way to Massachusetts
description: THE Yellow Victorian is a yellow-painted, gingerbread-accented 1880 frame house with white trim in Riverton, near the Massachusetts border. The house is charming, well suited to the attractive, tree-lined little town where Lambert Hitchcock built his first chair factory in 1826 and where reproductions are still being produced in the same building. Visitors to town should find the restaurant a snug little spot for lunch or dinner, before or after a tour of the chair factory showroom or a visit to the Hitchcock Museum. Meals are served in three small, homey rooms. In addition, there is one table in an entrance room that doubles as a gift shop and two more tables on the front porch.

title: VALHALLA: COMMUNITY COLLEGE FREEZES TUITION
description: For the fifth consecutive year, Westchester Community College will hold tuition steady at $98 a credit, or $2,350 a year for a full-time student. The average community college tuition in the State University of New York system is $2,480 a year. Under the $83 million college budget approved for 2000-01 by the county's Board of Legislators, there will be money to expand the main campus in Valhalla and open centers in Ossining and Yonkers. The county has increased its contribution to the college this year to $14.9 million, an increase of 5.6 percent. Elsa Brenner

description: Deerhurst Resort, a luxurious lakeside 425-room hotel in the Muskoka region of Ontario, a two-and-a-half-hour drive north of Toronto, has opened for this season after a $12.3 million expansion.

title: Man Cleared by DNA Tests Led Police to Murder Suspect
description: An investigator credited DNA science yesterday with helping the police make an arrest in the strangulation murders of six women in Brooklyn. Not only did it ultimately link a homeless man to the crimes, he said, but it also cleared another homeless man in the case -- a man who then began cooperating with a detective and helped find the murder suspect.

description: MAGNIFICENT promises are always to be suspected.

This cute, cozy restaurant and natural-food market, at 23 North Ferry Road (631-749-0053), offers a rare combination: food that tastes good and is good for you as well.

title: Talking About Race

Race can be ignored only if people have similar economic and cultural backgrounds. Yes, Virginia, there are classes in America, and they don't like one another. Racism in America is simply the way humanity lives.

The featured politician was Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a Miss Moderate from the political center, where Gov. George W. Bush of Texas supposedly wants to herd the Grand Old Elephants.

title: Maine Lobstermen Protest Dumping of Dredge
description: New York and Connecticut lobstermen are not alone in fearing that their precious resource is being threatened by man-made contaminants. Maine, the nation's largest lobster source, has not suffered the alarming die-off that decimated the Long Island Sound lobster fishery this spring, but Maine fishermen, environmentalists and town officials have seen enough red flags to voice their concerns.

title: How Modern Design Remains Faithful to Its Context
description: IN the absence of alternatives, there may be no more important project under way in New York right now than David Childs's restoration of Lever House, the International Style skyscraper on Park Avenue at 54th Street. Designed by Gordon Bunshaft and completed in 1952, Lever House was the first glass curtain wall tower to rise in New York. It remains among the 20th century's major landmarks.

Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Adapting to College Life In an Era of Heightened Stress
description: THE first week of her freshman year at Cornell University, Kate Wilkinson of Plymouth, Mass., made a big mistake. She agreed to play Trivial Pursuit with several other students in her dormitory. Kate was embarrassed that she did not know what element was converted to plutonium in the first nuclear reactor, what onetime Yugoslav republic is shaped like a boomerang or even the longest American war. Far worse, everyone else did (or seemed to).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWMAN, MICHAEL EDWARD
description: BOWMAN-Michael Edward. Died July 27, 2000. Born June 6, 1934, in Waltham, Massachusetts and attended local schools including Our Lady's High School of Newton, MA. He graduated from Princeton University in 1957, where he was a member of the Cottage Club and Captain of the 1956 football team. After Princeton he served in the Navy Air Force and then started his business career in sales with St. Regis Paper, followed by the New Yorker Magazine. Subsequently, during his Wall Street career, he was a First Vice-President in charge of equity trading at White Weld and Co. He recently moved back to Massachusetts. He is survived by his two sons, Michael Jr., of New York City, and Jonathan, of Short Hills, New Jersey; two sisters, Roberta and Susan of the Boston area; and two brothers, James of New York City and Edward Charles, Jr. of Waltham, MA. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 12, at 10:30 AM, at Our Lady's (Help of Christians) Church, 573 Washington Street, Newton, MA (617-527-7760) with burial in Calvary Cemetery, Waltham, MA. Contributions in the memory of Michael E. Bowman may be made to the Princeton University Class of 1957 Scholarship Fund and sent to: Recording Secretary, Princeton University, Box 140, Princeton, NJ 08544.

title: Food; The Death of French Food, Part Deux
description: Some places play such a crucial role in your life that if you return, memories from previous stays force themselves through you, triggered by the simplest mnemonic. I don't remember a thing that happened in Lincoln, Neb., where I spent a week, nor a single person I met in Cologne. But I remember on my third or fourth visit to Paris running into my cousin at lunch in Montmartre and realizing that I had been in love with her for about 25 years. Fortunately, her husband, whom she loved, was with her.

Two countries now bear his name, as does the currency here in Venezuela, his native land, now officially known as the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela. Throughout the region, no figure is more universally revered or quoted.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S funny how most women in movies of the 60's look slightly preposterous in the bouffant flips and false eyelashes of the day - except Catherine Deneuve, who looks spectacular in Luis Bunuel's BELLE DE JOUR (1967). Ms. Deneuve plays Severine Serizy, a bored french newlywed who takes an afternoon job at a tasteful little brothel and learns a lot about herself. Or does she? What's real and what's fantasy in this film isn't always clear (although I'm pretty sure the duel, muck-throwing and horsewhipping scenes exist only in Severine's mind). N'importe pas. It's just Bunuel's way of having fun with us, brilliantly - Tuesday at 10:30 p.m. and Tuesday/Early Wednesday at 4 a.m. on Bravo.

title: Malaysia Is Tense Awaiting Verdict in Former Official's Case
description: Friday was to have been a day of reckoning for the leader of Malaysia's reform movement, Anwar Ibrahim. Given the furies that have swirled around Mr. Anwar for the last two years, it could have been a day of reckoning for his country as well.

title: July 30-August 5; Questions on Brady Law
description: A study in The Journal of the American Medical Association says there is no evidence the 1994 Brady Law, which mandates background checks of handgun buyers, has contributed to the recent sharp decline in homicide.

title: Halley Love, Peter Bysshe
description: Halley Margaret Love, a daughter of Margaret M. Love and James Fulford Love of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday to Peter Laurence Bysshe, a son of Elizabeth B. Bysshe and Robert Mercer Bysshe of Granite Springs, N.Y. The Rev. Wade Reck performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y.

title: A National Theater Chain Adds 2 Links in New York City
description: Regal Cinemas, with more than 400 theaters in 32 states, has moved into New York, opening two theaters last month in Battery Park City in Manhattan and in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Challenge for Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/West Islip, Long Island; Waterside, With a Range of Prices
description: RISING on a high tide of economic good times for Long Island, the generously proportioned, traditionally middle-income hamlet of West Islip on Suffolk County's South Shore has experienced an upward surge in housing prices that surprises veteran real estate professionals.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 6, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Debating The Mozart Theory
description: EVER mind that Mozart's concertos strike peaceful chords in music lovers. In academia, the battle lines are drawn, and the next salvo in the Mozart wars is about to be fired.

title: Haskell Offers Next Test For a Healthy Dixie Union
description: The disappointment of Dixie Union's fifth-place finish in the 1999 Breeders' Cup Juvenile was still with the trainer Richard Mandella when he made his way to the barn at Gulfstream Park the morning after the race. But even more bad news awaited Mandella: Dixie Union had just run the worst race of his career after having won the Hollywood Juvenile Championship, the Best Pal and the Norfolk, and had sustained a chipped knee that would need surgery.

description: JAY S. WALKER didn't play Kevin Costner's dad in ''Field of Dreams.''

description: '21' CLUB

description: LUCIFER'S LEGACY

title: Op-Art; Souvenirs From the Convention
Water, Water Everywhere, And That Means Funds, Too
description: With Internet funds hemorrhaging cash and wireless funds careening after an earnings warning from Nokia, America needs a cool new mutual fund sector. How about water? It's eternal. It's cool. And this most basic of life's necessities even has its own mutual fund.

title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do
description: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.

title: HURRICANE EVACUATION PLANS
description: As hurricane season nears, the state is updating evacuation plans. A new wrinkle this year will be scrolling information on the Weather Channel giving Jersey Shore residents weather and road-condition reports and information on evacuation plans. The information will be fed by the State Emergency Management Office to the network. Local emergency management offices are now updating hurricane evacuation routes and contingency plans, which will be announced later this month. Karen DeMasters

title: MY FIRST JOB; Lessons Gained Standing Up
description: John A. Kanas, 53, is chairman, president and chief executive of North Fork Bancorp, a holding company based in Melville, N.Y. North Fork is trying to take over Dime Bancorp, a move that would make North Fork one of the largest banks chartered in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the program ''American High'' misstated the given name and title of an executive at 20th Century Fox Television and referred incorrectly to his position. The executive is Gary Newman, not Barry; he is a co-president, along with Dana Waldman, not the sole head of Fox.

title: PRESIDENT'S VETO SETS UP A BATTLE ON MARRIAGE TAX
description: Two days after Republicans wound up their political convention with promises of tax relief, President Clinton set up an election-year battle today by vetoing as too costly a tax break for married couples that is the cornerstone of the Republican effort.

title: A Taste for Frequent-Flier Miles
description: I AM my mother's daughter: I love the idea of getting something for nothing. In the 1960's, mother went from bank to bank, bringing home a new appliance each time she opened a $25 savings account. By the 70's, we were both collecting the green stamps grocery stores handed us with our purchases and redeeming them for toys for my young girls.

title: Among the Mooks
description: Jimmy Iovine, co-chairman of Interscope Geffen A&M;, slips the videocassette in the player and plunks down in a comfy chair. He's screening an early episode of ''Farmclub.com,'' a weekly music show he's producing on the USA network.

title: Miki Denhof, 88, an Innovative Art Director for Magazines
description: Miki Denhof, one of the first women to be the art director of a magazine, and a noted mentor of fashion photographers, died on Wednesday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIKLIN, SCOTT F.
description: RIKLIN-Scott F. 1/16/52-8/6/96. Beloved son and brother. Always missed; forever in our hearts. Mom, Dad, Jeff, Matt

title: In Free-Agent Market, It's 'Wait Till Next Year'
description: The money is dwindling fast. With one nine-player trade down and apparently none to go, many of the alleged blockbuster deals are being committed to rumor. Solid but unspectacular free agents like Danny Fortson and Aaron Williams have been given presidential suites by teams hoping to procure their services for minimal charge.

title: Back Down to Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: A Park Where Helmets Are Required
description: For young people in Hastings-on-Hudson, it is a dream come true: their own skateboard park. Last month the Village Board voted to replace a basketball court in Riverview Park with the first skateboarding course in southern Westchester.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the increased importance of the London art scene referred incorrectly to the date on which Ben Jonson killed a fellow actor in a duel. It was 1598, not the 1680's.

title: After Loss, Groh Says the Defense Must Eliminate Its Lapses
description: Coach Al Groh was biting off his words Friday night, seething at the Jets' 37-24 defensive self-destruction against the Packers at Lambeau Field in Green Bay, Wis. The 409 yards of offense allowed, the missed tackles and the touchdowns on which Marcus Coleman and Aaron Glenn of the Jets were torched were all thrown into Groh's caldron of criticism.

title: Wendy McConnel, Kris Sirchio
description: Wendy Meredith McConnel, the daughter of Nancy and Matthew McConnel of Searsmont, Me., was married yesterday to John Kristin Sirchio, a son of Wanda G. Hill of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Cosmo Sirchio. The Rev. Bryan J. Sirchio, a brother of the bridegroom and a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Vesper Hill Children's Chapel in Rockport, Me.

title: Style; Baltimore Babylon
description: 'Nothing bad ever happens at the movies,'' says John Waters, whose sardonic smile is bracketed by his pencil-thin mustache. ''That's why you go.''

title: An Insult to Icons
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Churches And Neighbors Part on Projects
description: Churches are as integral to life in Harlem as trattorias to Little Italy, dive bars to the East Village and chain stores to the Upper West Side.

title: Boorishness Knows No Race
description: The poignant ''Opinion'' by Mr. Applebome shows two things:

title: The Chambers Hotel And Chambermen
description: To the Editor:

title: What Would You Do? Readers Speak
description: A column July 23 by Peter Applebome described a situation at a gas station in which he and his 9-year-old daughter were exposed to loud rap music with X-rated lyrics booming from the car of a black man wearing a prison guard uniform. He debated asking the man to turn the music down but decided not to. He asked readers what they would do. Here is a sampling of the many responses.

title: POSTINGS: Investment Companies Rent Apartments; $3,500 a Month At 56 Pine St.
description: Two investment banking companies, Salomon Brothers Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers, have leased all 78 furnished apartments in the Cambridge Club, a renovated building at 56 Pine Street in Manhattan's financial district.

title: RYE: TEACHER HONORED
description: Laura Klein, a fourth-grade teacher at Osborn Elementary School in Rye has won the 1999 Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, the government's highest honor for elementary and high school teachers. Ms. Klein, who has been teaching for 13 years, three of them at Osborn, will receive a $7,500 grant for her school, which she plans to use, in part, to start a ''family math night'' program. Peter Beller

title: College Tuition On Rise
description: As students get ready for the start of the college year, they -- or their parents -- will find that the cost of higher education in the state is getting higher. All of the public and private four-year colleges in New Jersey are raising tuition this fall.

title: Bush Accused of Stealing Clinton's Oratory
description: White House aides grumbled today that Gov. George W. Bush's acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention had been presidential -- too presidential, actually, as they accused Mr. Bush of stealing not only President Clinton's ideas, but his words as well.

title: How Clean Is the Surf? It's Often Hard to Know
description: THREE years after the Environmental Protection Agency launched a broad program to better protect the public from the hazards of sewage and other pollution at beaches, there has been only scattered progress on a number of fronts.

title: Who Cares, as Long as It's Natural?
description: IF there's a sure-fire way to sell something these days, it's to claim the thing is natural -- even if it's a cigarette.

title: JESUIT COLLEGES TEACHING ETHICS ONLINE
description: Despite all the high-minded claims about the Internet's potential for transforming business, education and much more in today's society, much of what is on the World Wide Web today still tends toward the prurient. Is there room in cyberspace for a discourse on ethics?

title: BUSINESS; Hospital Chain's Critics Call Recovery Incomplete
description: AS he built the nation's second-largest hospital chain and achieved stellar profits in a battered industry, Jeffrey C. Barbakow, the chief executive of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, has taken a lot of heat. Over the last seven years, people from Philadelphia to Los Angeles have watched Tenet buy their community hospitals, streamline operations and cut back on staff. Labor relations have suffered. Union leaders and some public health advocates question whether Mr. Barbakow's economizing will harm patient care, especially for the poor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABENOU, ELSA
description: RABENOU-Elsa. Passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan on August 1 at the age of 90. Widow of prominent art dealer Khalil Rabenou.

title: A Musical Emerging From a 1964 Murder
description: IT was an urban nightmare that ended in murder. Many people remember the date -- March 13, 1964 -- and the place, Kew Gardens, Queens. And everyone recalls the number: 38 people who ignored the cries of the victim.

title: Japanese Ryokan
description: To the Editor: Having returned recently from a walking tour of rural northern Japan, and after seeing Perri Klass's article on traveling in Japan, ''To See Japan, Try Rail Pass and Ryokan'' (July 23), I offer two suggestions for safety in ryokan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, DR. JOHN S.
description: BELL-Dr. John S. (Retired Professor of English, NYCTC). On August 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Richard, Jonathan, Ian and Melissa. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Kyle and Robert. Brother of Alexander and Patricia. Mass Tuesday, 12 noon, at St. John's Episcopal Church. Visitation Sunday, 7-9, and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97th Street.

title: Two Other Tigers on a Celtic Course
description: With the spotlight on the P.G.A. tour and Tiger Woods all summer, other, less-known golf tournaments have been largely overlooked. But the Stone of Accord Tournament last month at the Old Head course in Kinsale, Ireland, was also a display of American golfing prowess.

title: July 30-August 5; Bungled, but not Political
description: One year before the 1996 presidential election, the Immigration and Naturalization Service launched a program to naturalize 1 million immigrants. The timing raised eyebrows. Now a Justice Department report has found that while the agency bungled the job, and as many as 180,000 immigrants became citizens without proper background checks, officials did not improperly meddle with the program to beef up voter rolls by election day. Lizette Alvarez

title: Jean Griffin, Sven Borho
description: Jean Ellen Griffin and Sven Heinz Borho were married Friday at a house they rented in Makena, Hawaii. The Rev. Lenni K. Pokipala, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Once a Chef, Now With His Own Place
description: IT'S the American dream. Riccardo Traslavina fled Pinochet's Chile with the help of Amnesty International when he was 17. He landed in New York City and later went to the East End to labor in the kitchens of the restaurants there. With hard work and a lot of talent, he attained the position of sous chef at Nick & Toni's in East Hampton and was picked to be the chef of their Honest Diner. He went on to be executive chef at 95 School Street in Bridgehampton and the Laundry in East Hampton.

title: Distilling the Truth In the Ecstasy Buzz; Much Talk, and Dissent, on Drug's Rise
description: Every other week, it seems, the authorities convene another news conference to announce another sweep, another bust, another gigantic distribution network crushed. Stick your head out the window these days and you cannot help hearing about Ecstasy.

title: Where Setting Is Spacious for Italian Fare
description: LESS elaborately muraled than its sister restaurant Rustica in Greenburgh, Terra Rustica has its arty touches and more room. Each table top presents a painted gem. It seems as though a class from the Art Students' League was unleashed there. As a result, seating takes time as diners linger, surveying this table or that, wondering whether to eat in the shadow of Il Duomo or in the shade of Giverny.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Developers Meeting Demand for Warehouse Space
description: WAREHOUSE distribution buildings, some as large as city blocks, are sprouting across New Jersey. Hoping to lasso the state's bullish industrial market, developers are constructing such buildings with -- or without -- specific tenants in place.

title: A Stroll Down Queen Street
description: VISITORS to the Olympics who need an antidote to the events and the crowds can spend a few hours wandering along Queen Street in Woollahra. The quiet, tree-lined area is filled with antiques stores and a few smart restaurants. Much of Sydney has become overwhelmed with new building and brash architecture, but Woollahra, one of the early settlements of the colonial city, has retained its original terrace houses, shady trees and village atmosphere.

title: I.B.M. Taking Part In a Bach Project
description: International Business Machines and the State Library in Berlin, in collaboration with eight other institutions, have joined together to develop the Bach Digital Project -- a Web site devoted to the works and life of Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: Word for Word/A Killer's Schoolmates; Guns, Mayhem and Grief Can Flourish When Good Friends Do Nothing
description: ONE of the enduring mysteries of the school shootings in places like Littleton, Colo., and West Paducah, Ky., is how so many people could have known so much but done so little to prevent bloodshed. The Columbine High School massacre, in which 15 people were killed, took place in April 1999. This May a 13-year-old boy fatally shot a teacher in Lake Worth, Fla.

title: In the Jury Room
description: I was raped by an African-American man 16 months ago. A diverse and multiracial jury last month found him guilty in less than two hours. By delivering that verdict the jury restored my faith in our ability to see beyond color and race.

title: Grant for Gypsy Wagon
description: The 19th-century Gypsy Wagon in the collection of the Museums at Stony Brook is about to be refurbished with the help of a $37,949 grant from the Institute of Museum and Library Services, a federal agency that supports museums and libraries.

title: G.O.P. Arrows Meant for Gore Travel Through Clinton First
description: They sounded a cry for lower taxes in Pontiac, Mich., and rallied people in Durand with the promise that President Clinton was on the way out. A crowd of several thousand people in East Lansing got a pledge that the military would be strengthened. A smattering of people in Holly and Fenton got only waves and smiles as the train rattled by.

title: Teens on the Road
description: To the Editor: My husband and I had the same reaction to Jill Abramson's piece on traveling with teenagers ''In Search of Phat'' (July 23).

title: Q & A
description: Dancing in Paris

title: Consumed By Race
description: You have neatly sorted out consumer habits by race (July 16). Question: What am I? I bought both grits and cottage cheese when I lived in California; now I consume neither. I subscribed to Ebony in the 60's and read People now. Of the 43 grocery products mentioned, I don't even buy 23 of them. As for the other 20, I don't buy any of the brands listed. Answer: An individual.

title: Poles Make a Feast Of Cold War Leftovers
description: THE eye-watering fumes of fresh paint waft into the office in a former airport hangar, where Zofia Kargul-Smalewska, president of Gielda C.D., a small exhibitions company, is organizing the annual auto show this summer in this small city in western Poland. She expects 10,000 people to show up for the three-day event, kicking the tires of new and used cars and watching drag races and motorcycle demonstrations on a former Soviet air force base that was decommissioned after the cold war.

description: To the Editor:

title: Work Forced

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, MINNA (SHAPIRO)
description: FISHMAN-Minna (Shapiro). On August 4 at her home after a nine year battle. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Fishman; mother of Larry; grandmother of Kate and Daniel; great-grandmother of Kyle and Mark. Staff member of Hadassah until retirement. Service at Beth David Cemetery, Monday, August 7, 1:30 PM. Sitting shiva at home Monday and Tuesday. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter, in lieu of flowers.

title: G.O.P. Aims For Revenge On Defector In Congress
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes didn't want to talk about it initially: the television advertisement that his Republican foes spliced together to try to humiliate him. Why dignify it?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMEZ, REINOSO, TEOFILO I.
description: GOMEZ-REINOSO-Teofilo I. August 4, 2000. A native of Cuba, he was both a noted lawyer and judge. A graduate of New York University, where he received his masters degree in philosophy. He is survived by his brother Manuel Gomez-Reinoso. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, August 7, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, August 8, 10 AM, St. Thomas More Church, East 89th St, NYC. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAD, BERNARD JOHN
description: GRAD-Bernard John. On August 4, 2000, in Elberon, New Jersey, in his 92nd year. Much beloved husband of the late Marian Newfield Grad, loving and caring father of Peter Grad and Susan Grad Baerwald of Los Angeles, and their spouses, Laurie Burrows Grad and Paul Baerwald. Adoring Pop of Nick, Josh and Sam. Predeceased by his cherished brother, Howard. The family wishes to express deep gratitude to our friend and devoted caretaker Joan Charles. Bernie was a skilled and respected architect for over 50 years, heading one of New Jersey's most prestigious firms, The Grad Partnership, with his brother Howard and his father Frank Grad. A graduate of Newark Academy in 1927, he studied at Ecole des Beaux Arts in Fountainbleu, France, and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1932. A fellow of the American Institute of Architects, Bernie received an honorary Doctoral Degree from the New Jersey Institute of Technology, where he also served as a member of the Board of Overseers. He was chairman of the Advisory Commission for a Publicly Supported College of Architecture in the State of New Jersey and a Director of the Howard Savings Bank, the Newark Chamber of Commerce and The Newark Boys' Club. He wrote a book entitled ''Adventure into Architecture,'' which was published in 1968. Among his architectural achievements were the New Jersey Cultural Center, the New Jersey Justice Complex, Meadowlands Byrne Arena, college buildings for Rutgers, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Monmouth University, and corporate offices for Prudential, Mercedes Benz, Nabisco, IBM, New York Life and New Jersey Bell, as well as many office buildings, prisons and military facilities in the United States and abroad. Benrnie was a feisty, outspoken guy who gave his friends and co-workers great pleasure and received many rewards from them in return. He cherished, amused and enriched his family with his life lessons, his love and his stories. He will be greatly missed by all of us. Services at Temple Beth Miriam in Elberon, New Jersey, on Monday, August 7, at 10 AM.

title: Jets' Hayes Catching Passes, and Praise
description: Four Sundays away from the opening of his rookie season as head coach, Al Groh today virtually proclaimed the Jets' starting receivers a problem-free zone.

title: A Forum for Media Feedback and Back Talk
description: Establish a Web site with lots of links to other sites, and they call you an aggregator.

title: Bush Stand Is Used to Turn Election Into a Showdown
description: One expectation of anyone running for governor of Texas is that he or she must grab a gun and shoot something. So in 1994, George W. Bush, then the Republican candidate for governor, borrowed a 20-gauge shotgun and invited a group of reporters on a dove hunt.

title: Cheney Reorients to Political Role and 'Tough Fight'
description: In stump speeches that echoed his combative address to the Republican National Convention, Dick Cheney today repeated his promise of a ''tough fight'' to ''restore honor, integrity and decency to the Oval Office.''

description: UPDATE

title: Scientists to Announce Discovery of 10 Planets
description: Astronomers are announcing this week that they have discovered 10 new planets and have found tantalizing hints of another multiplanet system.

title: Gore and Advisers Gather To Select a Running Mate
description: With just hours to go until his self-imposed deadline of noon on Tuesday, Vice President Al Gore huddled with close aides and family members tonight to make his decision on a vice presidential running mate.

title: In the Spotlight, Dixie Union Races to Victory at the Haskell
description: In retrospect, said the trainer Richard Mandella, perhaps he should have made a bigger deal over the injury Dixie Union sustained during last year's Breeders' Cup Juvenile, in which he finished fifth to Anees after chipping a bone in his knee.

title: Teachers Facing Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: As magazines enter their heftiest season, stunts help reach the overwhelmed reader.
description: REVERSE-BOUND pullout and a stand-alone sound like stunts that gymnasts will attempt next month as they compete for medals at the Summer Games. Well, those stunts are planned for September, but look for them from magazine publishers in America rather than Olympic athletes in Australia.

title: Arranging Environmental Groups' 'Corporate' Marriage
description: IT'S not so odd that a graduate of the 80's with a master's degree in economics and some supply-side credentials should now find himself negotiating a big merger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKY, BURTON
description: LASKY-Burton. On August 4. Beloved husband of Diana. Beloved father of Andrew. Loving son of Louis. Dear brother of Harvey and Jesse. A great man, who always did what was right. He possesed an amazing body of knowledge and a genuinely noble soul. Service Monday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial, 91st St. and Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWILER, WILLIAM RAY
description: SWILER-William Ray. A resident of Rolling Green Village, Greenville, SC, died at age 87 on August 3, 2000. Born in Harrisburg, PA, he was the son of William and Ellen Swiler. A 1934 graduate of Lafayette College, Easton, PA, with a degree in mining engineering, he received a Master's Degree from the Montana School of Mines in 1935. He worked underground for 10 years for Anaconda Copper Company in Butte, MT, and in Conda, ID. He then worked as a salesman and District Manager for Joy Technologies, a manufacturer of mining and construction machinery, until his retirement in 1978. He is survived by four children and their families: William Grant Swiler, wife Betty, their son William and daughter Kristin S. Brog, husband David and their son David Harrison of Salt Lake City, UT; Robert John Swiler, wife Linda, their sons: Lance, wife Virginia, their son Cameron Davis, and Sean of Charlotte, NC; James Bradley Swiler, wife Miriam, his sons Mika and Chad, and daughter Andrea of Florence, SC; Gayle Swiler Halas, husband John, their daughters Barbara Jean and Theresa of San Antonio, TX.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, RICHARD K., M.D.
description: HILL-Richard K., M.D. On August 3, 2000 at age 64. Beloved husband of Dr. Ann Hill. Devoted father of Dr. Kirsten Avery, Christopher, Amy and Thomas Hill. Dear brother of Robert Hill. Services private. Interment South Dakota.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day on July 27 about the second-quarter earnings of DaimlerChrysler misstated the company's plan to cut costs. The company is considering the elimination of some -- not all -- of its administrative jobs, which total 5,000 to 6,000 worldwide.

title: Buyout Fund Will Purchase McKechnie
description: The Cinven Group agreed today to buy McKechnie P.L.C., a military and auto products maker, for $:434 million, or $654 million, in cash, the latest British company to be snapped up by a buyout fund as a strong pound hurts earnings.

title: Historic Seminary in Turkey Is Ready but Empty
description: The marble floors are polished to a high gloss. The latest scholarly journals are arranged with care in the famous library. The sparse dormitories are spotless, and in one huge hallway, two Ping-Pong tables stand ready, nets taut.

title: When Ivy and Dollars Intertwine
description: To the Editor:

title: With 3 Indian Tribes Vying in Catskills, Casino Is in Doubt
description: Four months after the federal Interior Department approved plans for an Indian casino in Monticello, N.Y., three separate developers with three different tribes are battling to bring gambling to the Catskills.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: The 'Kid' Splashes To Victory In Whitney
description: It said so right there in the past-performance charts: Lemon Drop Kid did not like running around a wet track. Through a dreary week of rain, his trainer, Scotty Schulhofer, worried that Saratoga Race Course would come up spongy on Whitney day. When the showers began to fall an hour before the race today, Schulhofer thought he was cursed.

title: VERIZON WORKERS FORM PICKET LINES AS TALKS CONTINUE
description: Thousands of workers fanned out to picket sites throughout the East yesterday as negotiators for Verizon Communications and its unions pressed forward with efforts to end a strike by about 86,000 telephone employees.

title: A Street's Baptismal Waters Touch Hundreds in East Harlem
description: As the heat was beginning to rise from the pavement late yesterday morning, 115th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues was bathed in white. Hundreds of people, dressed from head to foot in white cotton dresses or slacks and shirts, were arriving by the busload and gathering in the center of the street for a baptism by fire hose.

title: Erudite and Groovy
description: Al Gore is an intellectual. In case we doubted his credentials, a recent New Yorker profile of the vice president made this clear. Mr. Gore referred to ''the Cartesian revolution,'' Reinhold Neibuhr's work and Thomas Kuhn's theory of paradigms. Wonky to the point of weirdness, Mr. Gore loves nothing more than a dorm-room bull session. To Nicholas Lemann, The New Yorker writer, he held forth with uncanny fluency on ''the origins of our modern world view, and its curious reliance on specialization and ever-narrower slices of the world around us into categories.''

description: To the Editor:

description: The diversity of cultures and languages among Asian-Americans may cause headaches for schoolteachers and census takers, but rarely does it affect matters of life and death.

title: Britain Fights Tide of Anti-Pedophile Attacks
description: Britain said today that it would urgently press for stricter laws on child molesting but resisted widespread calls for public identification of released violators that have been associated with current vigilante attacks across the country.

title: Egypt Says Democracy Backer Spied for U.S.
description: A state prosecutor today expanded the list of accusations against Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a prominent democracy advocate, to include espionage for the United States, his lawyers said.

title: Judah Got Last Punch and Last Word
description: After his impressive victory on Saturday night, Zab Judah still wanted the last word.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the purchase of National Computer Systems Inc. by Pearson P.L.C. misstated Pearson's relationship to Simon & Schuster. Pearson acquired Simon & Schuster's educational publishing operation in 1998; Viacom owns the Simon & Schuster trade publishing operation and the name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERT, MICHAEL
description: LIEBERT-Michael. Beloved and devoted son of Rose, passed away August 4, 2000. Michael was President of Carlebach Synagogue and an active participant in the Jewish community. He leaves behind his loving mother, wife Roberta, aunt Muriel Toffel, and a tremendous circle of friends. His mother's heartbreak is only softened by knowing how much love Michael generated in those who knew him. He will be missed by all.
