description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, EMILY COLIN
description: FISHMAN-Emily Colin. On August 5, 2000, at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Mother of Elinore Stone and Adele Gorelick, and mother-in-law of Albert Stone. Adored grandmother of Steven and Marcia Stone, Jessica Gorelick and great-grandmother of Jonathan Stone. Services Monday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 20 about a University of Tennessee professor who made charges about improprieties in academic work by varsity athletes misstated the number of students at the Knoxville campus. It is 26,000, not 40,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNIEWIND, HELEN BALL
description: SCHNIEWIND-Helen Ball. In Lexington, MA July 31, 2000. A private burial service will be held in Locust Valley, N.Y., at the end of October. Memorial gifts may be sent to Vassar College, Box 725, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. 12604-0725.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, SAMUEL
description: KLEINMAN - Samuel. Beloved husband of Harriet, loving father of Gail Botkin, grandfather of Jackie, David, Scott Botkin; Marnie and Brett Auerbach and greatgrandfather of Brandon, brother of Martha Liebenthal. We shall miss you forever.

title: Greek Legend No Match For Bel Canto Heroics
description: One has to admire Santa Fe Opera's willingness to gamble. After all, in an eight-week season offering only five productions, every questionably bankable show accounts for a significant portion of the schedule. This summer the company is staging two high-risk works, the American premiere of Hans Werner Henze's ''Venus and Adonis'' and Rossini's ''Ermione,'' a rarity that lay unperformed from its 1819 premiere until its modern revival in 1987. A third work, Strauss's ''Elektra,'' though not uncommon, is well down the operatic hit parade.

title: Compressed Data; Ice-T's Take on Napster, The Law and Morality
description: Oliver Stone may have an equal in the music business.

title: Giving Online Audiences News They Want
description: Here is how Jonathan Klein, a former high-level executive at CBS, sees the future of news:

title: Sometimes You Sneak It By And Other Times You Can't
description: Virtually all the stars of American bridge and a handful from the rest of the world will compete in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Anaheim, Calif., starting Friday. Some will be there early because they have qualified for the playoffs in the Grand National Teams, which start Wednesday.

title: Essay; Exegesis of Acceptance
description: The well-accepted acceptance speech of George W. Bush is worthy of an exegete's eye.

title: In Daley's Hand, Gore Aides See a Glass Half Full
description: Six weeks after taking charge of Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign, William M. Daley has not yet figured out where everybody works in the sprawling and frenetic Gore headquarters here.

title: Democrats in a Fierce Fight Over Seat and District Lines
description: William L. Clay, who created a stir more than 30 years ago when he became Missouri's first black congressman, is creating another one by retiring, setting off a free-for-all for a seat that has not been open since 1968.

title: Mexico City Journal; In a City Where Good Luck Meets Hope, Signs of Magic
description: The map of one of the world's largest metropolises is a kind of literary masterpiece. The street guide reads as if a writer from the school of magical realism had translated the encyclopedia, cut his work into confetti and sprinkled it over the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, ROBERT ''BOB.''
description: GLADSTONE - Robert ''Bob.'' Longtime broadcaster, on August 3, in California at age 72, of heart failure. He is survived by his devoted wife Barbara, loving daughters Wendi and Dayna, and brother William. There was a private service and cremation. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Humane Society, US. ''There is a special providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be now, 'tis not to come; it if be not to come, it will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come: the readiness is all...'' (W.S.)

title: Putting a Face to the Badge at Camp
description: As commander of the Stamford Police Department's youth division, Sgt. Jon Fontneau handles the grim cases in which children are the perpetrators or the victims of child abuse, sexual assaults, drug abuse or violence, their young lives either terribly wasted or horribly exploited.

title: 'Fair Use' Comes Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENHOF, MIKI
description: DENHOF-Miki. On August 2, 2000. Of East Hampton and New York City. Retired Art Director of Conde Nast. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, August 8, 7-9 PM, with services Wednesday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Leo Baeck Institute, Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011.

title: Miffed Chinese Sue Japan Companies
description: When Tang Weijiang slid a promotional compact disc into his friend's computer last month, what he saw ruined his day, and now he is asking Canon Inc. to pay $12 million in compensation.

title: Barnyard Battlefield in Hamptons; Chickens, Pigs and Llama Don't Fit In, Neighbors Complain
description: Gines Serran-Pagan has a farm. And on this farm he has some barns. And in those barns he kept some pigs and chickens and rabbits and sheep and goats. And a llama. But the pigs got loose and ate the neighbor's grass. The chickens flew the coop and ate the neighbor's flowers. The rooster crowed at all hours and disturbed the neighbor's sleep. The llama, the neighbors said, just plain stunk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, SEYMOUR (TED), D.D.S.
description: HALPERN-Seymour (Ted), D.D.S. Age 77. On August 5, 2000. Loving husband of Bernice (Rogoff). Devoted father of Peter and Sue (Bill) McKibben and proud grandfather of Sophie McKibben. Cherished brother of Gerald and Arthur (deceased). Services Tuesday, August 8, 2000, at Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBNER, HERBERT, M.D.
description: RIBNER-Herbert, M.D. Rabbi, Neurologist, Author. Died July 16 in Jerusalem. Survived by wife Betty; children Dr. Hillel (Elizabeth), Eytan (Irene) and Dr. Dena (Mark); grandchildren Lisa, Danielle, David, Avigayil, Yehudit, Nathaniel, Maya, Boaz & Aderet. Healer of souls and of illness, who with his heroics in World War II, late-life entry into Medicine and Aliyah to Israel taught us that all dreams can be achieved during one's lifetime. May his Memory be for a Blessing.

title: People
description: Walter Coyle was named senior vice president and media director at Pedone & Partners, New York, succeeding Valerie Muller, who was named director for print services at Mediacom, New York, part of the Grey Global Group. Mr. Coyle had been vice president and group media director at Deutsch, New York.

title: Election Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: E-Commerce Report; Hopes of changing the government's business culture to make Uncle Sam the big Web buyer.
description: LAST December, when the government was in the throes of Year 2000 anxiety, e-commerce initiatives barely crossed the minds of many federal officials. Not that e-commerce executives particularly cared: with their companies' stock prices climbing and much larger markets in their sights, they could afford to look past the government as a place to do business.

title: Mosquito Madness
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Liberty, Time to Regroup, Not to Celebrate
description: Richie Adubato acknowledged that the Liberty played the most forgettable of games tonight against the Miami Sol. Yet in the postgame glare of defeat, the coach felt the Women's National Basketball Association game could have been salvaged if not for an official's blown call.

title: That's Wallace in Labonte's Rearview Mirror, Gaining in Points Race
description: Here comes Rusty Wallace. He is surging in the juicy stock car subplot known as the Winston Cup Series points race and now dares to tell the world about his dream of winning another championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROBERT W.
description: KING-Robert W. On August 4, 2000, at age 81. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Cynthia Betts, Sara Gervasio, John E. King, Mary Braley and William W. King. Step-father of Susan DeVoge and Deborah Dunn. Adored grandfather of 12. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 68 PM, and Wednesday, 12-3 PM. Memorial service at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. at 55th St., Wednesday, 6 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., 5th Floor, NYC 10017.

title: Karadzic Still Plays Hide-and-Seek With U.N. in Bosnia
description: The high, forested mountains of southeastern Bosnia are a place to hide, and, according to current local lore, it is there, in the steep gorges or trails and high passes into neighboring Montenegro, that Radovan Karadzic has been hiding.

title: Blacklisting the Dalai Lama
description: Geopolitics has tainted the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders planned for New York City later this month. The meeting, paid for mainly by private foundations, will be held at the United Nations a week before a similar gathering of world political leaders. It will bring together more than 1,000 religious figures. But under pressure from China, organizers have not invited the Dalai Lama, spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989, to attend any of the meetings on the grounds of the U.N. Other attendees and the conference's financial backers should oppose his exclusion.

title: Argentina Searches Its Soul Over a Suicide
description: It has been more than a week since Rene G. Favaloro, Argentina's most esteemed surgeon and a pioneer in the heart bypass operation, committed suicide. But the outpouring of grief seems to be compounding day by day, opening a channel of despair so profound that Argentines are raising the deepest of questions about themselves and their country.

title: In America; Bush's Education Record
description: Whenever George W. Bush talks about his achievements as governor of Texas, the item at the top of his list is education reform, especially the remarkable improvement in test scores by the state's public school students.

title: CNN.com Restores Jerusalem to Israel
description: In February, executives at CNN.com made a change to their weather home page that at the time, they said, seemed innocent enough. On a list of cities that allows users to click on a heading to get weather reports around the world, they moved Jerusalem out from under the heading of Israel.

title: Cloak, Dagger and Mouse: A Columnist Defects to the Web
description: When Hugo Dixon resigned from The Financial Times last December to start his own Web site, heads turned both inside and outside the newsroom. After all, Mr. Dixon had become the newspaper's franchise columnist -- the lead writer and editor of the much-heralded Lex column. Each day, he provided smart commentary on the merger of the day or a company's recent earnings report.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Venus Williams's Power Proves Too Much for Seles
description: The seedings have yet to be announced, and the sages have yet to weigh in. Even so, with the United States Open set to begin in three weeks, a favorite has emerged among the women. Her name is Venus Williams.

title: Bits of History Are Stolen From San Antonio Missions
description: Someone is stealing pieces of this city's past, and whatever the motives, the thefts have stunned local church officials, stumped the police and saddened heritage-conscious people.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The smart guy who doesn't confess, who knows better than to give evidence against himself, gets the deal. But the guy who is retarded, who doesn't understand all the words of his Miranda warning, he gets death.''

title: It Takes a World Wide Web to Raise a Village
description: Overlooked in last month's Group of 8 discussions about the challenge of a growing ''digital divide'' between the information rich and the data deprived was the work of Bernard Krisher, a 69-year-old former journalist who is trying to bring the Internet to one of the poorest regions in Asia.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Championing Workers and Culture, Too
description: On the makeshift stage of an art gallery on the West Side of Manhattan, a hobbled woman with thick glasses confronts a swaggering, foul-mouthed bully with arguments about why he should not rob her.

title: New Economy; The response to Deutsche Telekom's bid for VoiceStream brings into focus an unwritten tenet of U.S. trade policy.
description: IT used to be that the way America threw around its military might was what perturbed our allies. Now, it seems, it's the way we do business that rankles.

title: Executing the Mentally Retarded Even as Laws Begin to Shift
description: Oliver Cruz can barely read and write. He has an I.Q. of either 64 or 76, depending on the test. He flunked the seventh grade three times. He was rejected by the Army after failing the entry exam three times, and unable to decipher a job application, he did the menial work that came his way, cutting grass, cleaning houses and taking tickets for a traveling carnival.

title: Where Do Criminals Get Their Guns?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBB, LAWRENCE FORREST
description: EBB-Lawrence Forrest. Of Washington, DC. On Friday, August 4, 2000, at the National Rehabilitation Hospital. Beloved husband of Kim Ebb and father of Nancy, David, and Peter Ebb. Devoted father-inlaw of Gary Ford, Winnie Ebb, and Frances Green. Loving grandfather of Mike and Dan Ford and Sam, Max, Joe, and Sara Ebb. Private inurnment. There will be a memorial service in September. Memorial contributions may be made to the Boston Latin School Association, 41 West Street, 6th flr, Boston, MA 02111. The family thanks Dr. Simlote and the staff of the National Rehabilitation Hospital for their thoughtful care and support.

title: Torre Considers Skipping Cone Start
description: Joe Torre met with David Cone yesterday and reiterated that he would stay in the starting rotation. But the manager also conceded the possibility that Cone would skip his next scheduled start.

title: Odiorne Wilde Picked For Sandwich Account
description: The Burger King Corporation has named Odiorne Wilde Narraway & Partners in San Francisco to handle a new creative assignment, to introduce a sandwich named XL Deluxe aimed at consumers ages 18 to 34.

title: Arts Crusade Folds Its Tent At Harvard; A Playwright's Experiment In Democracy Didn't Rally the People
description: Three years ago an experiment in artistic democracy began. And last week it ended.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about preparations by Dutch and Scottish officials for the trial of two Libyans accused in the Lockerbie bombing used an outdated name for a soft drink reputed to replace whisky among Scottish officers barred from using alcohol while armed. It is Irn-Bru. While it was first marketed as Iron-Brew in 1901, manufacturers adopted the phonetic spelling after World War II because the drink was not brewed and did not meet labeling regulations.

title: Compressed Data; A News Service Caters To Nonprofit Groups
description: When the University of California at Berkeley announced two weeks ago that physicists had peeled the tips off carbon nanotubes -- an advance that may assist in the development of micromachines -- major newspapers did not put the arcane news on their front pages. But at least they knew about the development.

title: Acceptable Nursing Home Care
description: For decades, hundreds of thousands of frail older Americans have suffered unnecessary neglect, injury, abuse, malnutrition and even death while in the paid care of licensed nursing homes. Congress and the states have passed laws in response, and the federal government, which spends $39 billion a year on nursing home care, has subjected the industry to a complex web of regulations, annual inspections and an exhaustive reporting system designed to govern the quality of care.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Grand Rabbi Shlomo Halberstam of the Bobover sect on Thursday misstated the title of a documentary in which he is shown dancing. It is ''A Life Apart: Hasidism in America,'' not ''A World Apart: Hasidic Life in America.''

title: Thompson Hopes to Touch Gold at End of the Pool
description: She is tied with the speedskater Bonnie Blair for most Olympic gold medals won by an American woman -- five -- but Jenny Thompson's swimming career carries the slight whiff of unfulfillment. This sense of incompletion is barely perceptible, but it hovers about the pool, wafting like a trace of chlorine.

title: Accounts
description: Coty U.S., New York, part of Reckitt Benckiser, to Frierson Mee & Kraft, New York, to handle the Calgon bath products account, which had been at Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, majority owned by MDC Communications. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: 'Big Brother' Host Seeking Credibility
description: CBS's announcement earlier this summer that Julie Chen, the news reader on ''The Early Show,'' would be a host on ''Big Brother,'' one of the network's two summer reality programs, sent ripples of anger through the network's news division.

title: Equity Offerings Set for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Mitchell's Knee Sprain Puts Giants in Tight Spot
description: The worst-case scenario that quarterback Kerry Collins and the Giants' coaching staff feared Saturday night did not materialize yesterday. Tests on Pete Mitchell did not reveal a season-ending injury, but the Giants' only experienced pass-catching tight end will be out of action for the Sept. 3 opener against the Arizona Cardinals, and possibly longer.

title: Texas as the Texans Like It
description: Politically, Texas is caught in crossfire because our governor, George W. Bush, is running for president. Every shortcoming, real or imagined, has been cited by his detractors as proof of government failure or a heartless culture. Despite Governor Bush's warning in his nomination speech on Thursday not to ''mess with Texas,'' the broadsides will continue because of the way America elects presidents. A majority of Texans will be voting for Mr. Bush, and the Electoral College will issue no transferable credits to Al Gore.

title: 6 Die as 20 Are Shot and 4 Stabbed in Violent City Night
description: Detectives were seeking suspects yesterday after one of the most violent nights in New York City this year, a series of altercations or gunfights in which 20 people were shot and four others stabbed. Six of the victims died. The police made only one arrest in the homicide cases, and were unsure last night whether the suspect would be charged with murder.

title: From Timbuktu Riffs To Shuffle of the Blues
description: The Malian guitarist, singer and bandleader Ali Farka Toure announced his retirement at his concert at Town Hall on Friday night. Speaking in French, he said that he was 61 years old and that it was time for a younger generation of musicians to be heard. If it was a farewell concert, then he went out rocking.

title: When Ivy and Dollars Intertwine
description: To the Editor:

title: America in the World
description: These are heady yet baffling times for the world's sole superpower. Less than a decade after the demise of the Soviet Union, the United States is a military and economic colossus. No nation in history has possessed the wealth, military might or technological edge over its rivals that America has today. Yet as the presidential campaign enters its final months, the country seems uncertain about its role and perplexed by the changing array of threats that it faces. There should be vigorous debate about these matters in the days ahead, starting with an assessment of America's critical national interests.

title: Piazza Is Expected To Be Out 3 to 5 Days
description: A magnetic resonance imaging test on Mike Piazza's left knee today revealed a mild sprain of his medial collateral ligament, which will probably keep him out of the Mets lineup for three to five days.

title: Tehran Student Days Revisited
description: More than 50 years after their high school graduation, a group of men huddled around a television set showing old Technicolor footage of the streets where they grew up.

title: IRAN LEADER BARS A BILL RESTORING FREEDOM OF PRESS
description: Quashing a cherished goal of President Mohammad Khatami and his reformist allies, Iran's supreme religious leader today sided conclusively with the country's conservatives and ordered Parliament to scrap a bill aimed at restoring a free press.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEDER, MARTIN A.
description: ROEDER-Martin A. On August 3, 2000. Cherished husband of Dorothy (Friedman) for 61 years, adored father of Katherine Roeder, Thomas and Susan Roeder, beloved grandfather of Sarah and Louisa Roeder, Kenneth Hartog and Erik Hartog & Pamela Heller. Son of the late Judge Jehial M. Roeder and the late Evelyn Finegold Roeder. Mr. Roeder was Of Counsel to Herzfeld and Rubin and former managing partner of Guggenheimer and Untermeyer. He had a degree from the Sorbonne in Paris, a BA and LLB from Columbia University and Columbia Law School of New York. He served on the boards of the Emanu-el Brotherbood and the Tax Management Institute of New York University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 7-9PM with services Tuesday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Jewish Repertory Theater of the 92nd St. YM-YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

title: FirstEnergy Said to Be in Talks To Acquire GPU for $4.4 Billion
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation is in talks to buy GPU Inc. of New Jersey, a person close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Article 2000080790080995085 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORNBERG, ELY MARC
description: ZORNBERG-Ely Marc. The NY Chapter of Hadassah notes with deep sorrow the passing of Ely Marc, beloved son of Florence and Dr. Ed Zornberg. Those wishing to honor Ely's memory may contribute to a special fund attention Shalom Fanny Zornberg Group at NY Chapter of Hadassah, 575 Lexington Ave, NYC 10022 Arline Kempner, President Lois Shallit, Exec. Dir.

title: Digital TV Era Still Remains Out of Reach
description: As the changeover to digital television was starting, government leaders and industry executives described the transition as one of those rare touchstone events that would, in time, change the lives of every American.

title: The Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Echoes Europeans In a Phone Market Fight

title: Winning the Rematch That Wasn't, Mantei Ends Met Streak
description: Matt Mantei remembers how exhausted he felt when he took the mound at Shea Stadium in the 10th inning last Oct. 9. As the Arizona Diamondbacks' closer, Mantei was used to short outings, and he was into his third inning of work when the Mets' Todd Pratt came to the plate leading off.

title: Van Cliburn Does a Reprise At Tanglewood
description: It is not often that Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' Symphony is chosen to open a program, as it was for the Boston Symphony's concert here at Tanglewood Friday night. The symphony's ominously quiet opening works better if an audience is already settled, and the desolate conclusion, in an effective performance, leaves little more to be said or even hoped for.

title: Sir Alec Guinness, Elegant Actor, Is Dead at 86
description: Sir Alec Guinness, the elegant and versatile British actor known to older audiences for films like ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and to a whole new generation for his role as Obi-Wan Kenobi in ''Star Wars,'' died late Saturday at a hospital in West Sussex, England. He was 86.

title: INSIDE
description: Glimmers of New Planets

title: Executive Changes At Four Agencies
description: Executives at four agencies are changing posts.

title: Online Superstore Pushes Into Digital; Barnesandnoble.com Stakes Turf Despite Bloodied Stock and Losses
description: Stephen Riggio remembers telling executives at Barnes & Noble that the Internet was the future of bookselling in 1994, before Amazon.com had even begun. But he has never gotten much credit for it. By the time he founded Barnesandnoble.com, in 1997, Barnes & Noble had become watchwords for letting an Internet upstart eat your lunch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIMM, ROBERT THOMAS
description: PRIMM-Robert Thomas. On August 4, 2000. Husband of Geraldine Viohl Primm; father of Debbie Primm Mills, Pam Primm Zangrillo and Stephanie Primm; brother of Mary Elizabeth Young; grandfather of four and uncle of seven. Visitation at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Rd., Darien, CT. on Tuesday, August 8, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Services will be held at the Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT, August 9, 11 AM. Memorials: American Cancer Society or Bennett Cancer Center of the Stamford Health System. Interment private.

title: When Ivy and Dollars Intertwine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, EDWARD J.
description: McGRATH-Edward J. Died at home in Marlborough, NH; born and raised in Bronxville, NY. He worked for A.N. Nelson, Inc., for his 35 year career. In retirement, Ed and his wife Myrtle owned and operated Hardscrabble Antiques, the name of their company reminiscent of their home street in Chappaqua, NY, where they resided for 30 years. Ed was an active volunteer with The Refugee Support Team in Keene, NH, assisting refugee families in the area. He will be missed by his wife of 41 years, Myrtle Rodgers McGrath, their four daughters, three grandchildren and many friends. Visiting Wednesday, 7-9 PM, McGrath Funeral Home, Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY. Funeral mass Thursday, 10 AM, St. Joseph's in Bronxville. Donations may be sent to Covenant House in NYC.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Monday about the belief among lobstermen that the deaths of lobsters in Long Island Sound have been caused by pesticide spraying to fight the West Nile virus misspelled the surname of one lobsterman. He is John Makowsky, not Makowski.

title: Cheney Is Orienting To His Political Role
description: Dick Cheney repeated his promise of a ''tough fight'' to ''restore honor, integrity and decency to the Oval Office.''

title: Hernandez's Tortured Body Language Needs No Translation
description: Orlando Hernandez has a familiar pose whenever a game starts to crumble around him. He slouches his body, pins his right hand on his waist like someone who is impatiently waiting in line for a driver's license and peers out to where another damaging hit has just landed. ''How did that happen?'' El Duque seems to be saying to himself.

title: Billion-Dollar Fund Managers at Odds Over Use of a Name
description: Thomas F. Marsico was a star money manager at Janus Capital before he left three years ago to form his own company. But his name, it seems, has found its way back to his old employer. Or at least his domain name.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot, August 7th. And the wondrous memories linger on... Children, Grandchildren and Joyc

title: Oprah Goes to Press With Ideas on Living Life Well
description: ''Gore should ask Oprah to be his vice presidential nominee,'' I heard an amateur pundit -- one of legions, I'm sure -- declare last week. Think of what follows as theatrical speculation then, set against a backdrop of some of the dreariest political performances we've yet been subjected to.

title: Patents; The spread of e-mail is sparking wide interest in inventing accessory products.
description: ELECTRONIC mail has become ubiquitous, so it comes as no surprise that independent inventors as well as advertisers and consumer electronics and telecommunications companies are working on new ways to exploit this form of communication.

title: Buchanan's Opponents Steel For Tough Convention Fight
description: Months of bickering and conflict are expected to reach a climax of sorts this week, when the Reform Party gathers to nominate a presidential candidate at its national convention in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Lewinsky Interview Did Have Its Costs
description: In November 1998, ABC News struck gold: Monica S. Lewinsky, after flirting with other news organizations, agreed to give her first interview to Barbara Walters.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly refunding including five- and 10-year notes and a 30-year bond. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $10 billion of five-year notes, followed by $10 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $5 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.

title: A Bronfman May Make Bid For Liquor Unit
description: Charles Bronfman, the co-chairman of the Seagram Company, which is being sold to Vivendi of France, is considering making a bid for his company's liquor division, home to brands like Absolut vodka, Captain Morgan rum and Chivas Regal scotch.

title: Children of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASSEN, DR. E. J.
description: BASSEN-Dr. E. J. Adored husband, beloved brother. 100 years old today. Your wife, Lupe

title: Sports of The Times; Where Fans Flock And Dollars Fly
description: TRAPPED in the Bronx, or thoughts from the deepest, darkest recesses of George Steinbrenner's mind:

title: Urban Venuses Easy at Play On Bucolic West 48th Street
description: Toni Taylor and her Pi Dance Theater took to a patch of lush grass in the Clinton Community Garden on Saturday afternoon and summoned up all the pleasure of the unexpected in a city where surprise is a constant. Passers-by stopped to peer into the garden on West 48th Street, one of them with a chortling green parrot on her shoulder.

title: Beauty and the Concorde
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIFELD, JEAN WHITLOCK
description: FREIFELD-Jean Whitlock. Beloved wife of Charles. Passed away July 31; in her 87th year. Laid to rest.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Monday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign appearance at the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Harlem misstated the title of a hymn sung by the choir. It was ''Order My Steps,'' not ''All of My Steps in the World.''

title: Viral Invaders
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: An annual industry forecast expects spending, led by the Internet, to reach $249 billion in 2004.
description: IN its annual forecast, Veronis Suhler, the investment banking firm, predicted that the popularity of the Internet as an advertising and information medium will continue to increase rapidly in the short term, though not to the exclusion of more traditional media like magazines and newspapers.

title: Clues to an Alien Virus; Scientists Begin to Crack the Mysteries of West Nile
description: West Nile virus appears to be settling in for the long haul.

title: The Lieberman Candidacy
description: Vice President Al Gore's decision to choose Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate is certainly the most dramatic move he has made in his presidential campaign, and may turn out to be one of the smartest. It is not just that Mr. Lieberman has been an effective senator. Of far greater significance is that he was the first Democratic senator to denounce President Clinton for ''disgraceful'' and ''immoral'' conduct in the Lewinsky scandal and for his failure to speak truthfully to the American people about his behavior. In a very real sense, therefore, Mr. Lieberman's selection announces a redoubled effort on Mr. Gore's part to separate himself from Mr. Clinton's personal shortcomings. It also provides him with insulation on the character issue at a time when the Republicans, as Richard Cheney made clear in his speech at the Philadelphia convention, plan to make an issue of the erosion of presidential dignity during Bill Clinton's eight years in office.

title: INSIDE
description: Reform Party Leaders Split

title: New Attacks Raise Fears About Anti-Semitism in Germany
description: Two Jewish cemeteries have been desecrated in the western German state of Rhineland-Palatinate and an explosive device has been found outside a Jewish family's home in Bavaria, the police said today.

title: Krone Adds Another First To Her Accomplishments
description: Julie Krone began in Michigan as a barefoot 5-year-old bareback aboard Stony Baloney, whom she called her Wonder Pony. As an 18-year-old, she hopped a fence at Tampa Bay Downs to take out her first jockey license. She won riding titles in New Jersey and Florida, and 119 stakes races in every important hub of horse racing, and became the first and only female jockey to win a Triple Crown event when she coaxed Colonial Affair home in the 1993 Belmont Stakes.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: ROCKLAND COUNTY

title: Ignoring the Message of Brittle Bones
description: Doctors routinely overlook a serious sign of osteoporosis, the condition that leaves older people -- primarily women -- susceptible to repeated, often immobilizing bone breaks, according to a study being released today.

title: NORCROSS INVESTMENT GROUP MAKES OFFER FOR U.S. VISION
description: The Norcross Investment Group offered yesterday to buy the 76.3 percent of U.S. Vision shares it did not already own for about $23.8 million. Norcross, a private investment company that now owns 23.7 percent of U.S. Vision, offered to pay $4 a share in cash. U.S. Vision sells glasses and contact lenses and offers eye examinations at retail outlets, mostly in department stores. U.S. Vision, based in Glendora, N.J., operates about 700 sites in 48 states and Canada, according to Hoover's Inc. The shares of U.S. Vision rose 62.5 cents, or 22 percent, to $3.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: West Nile Virus Seems Settled In
description: West Nile virus appears to be settling in for the long haul in North America. Since last fall, scientists have been scrambling to understand the virus's origin and destiny as it spreads, decimating some new hosts, like crows, leaving others, like pigeons, untouched, and occasionally spilling over into people. Thousands of hours of sleuthing, testing and analysis are only now offering preliminary clues.

title: 11% Visitor Rise Makes City No. 2 U.S. Tourist Destination
description: New York City welcomed an estimated 36.7 million visitors last year, an 11 percent rise from the previous year, generating billions of dollars in sales for city businesses and supporting several hundred thousand jobs, but also intensifying congestion on city streets and sidewalks, officials said yesterday.

title: Computer Associates Reshuffles Its Senior Management
description: Searching for a way to bolster its sagging stock, Computer Associates International reassigned senior managers yesterday and said it intended to use spin-offs or other strategies to tap the value of fast-growing units that are currently overshadowed by the company's main businesses.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Whole New World
description: In the 1976 election campaign, Jimmy Carter vowed to withdraw U.S. troops from South Korea. When Mr. Carter won, the first words he had to eat were his vow to withdraw U.S. troops from South Korea, as Congress and the allies revolted against him.

title: Portugal's Dinosaurs Get Their Due at Last
description: At the urging of eminent Portuguese paleontologists, the government is acting to protect the country's rich array of dinosaur fossils and tracks, threatened now by the forces of erosion and development.

title: Communicators Saying Little On Walkout
description: Want to watch public relations executives from the nation's biggest communications companies become uncomfortable? Ask them about their unions.

title: New Tactic in Physics: Hiding the Answer
description: Despite its image of arcane intellectuality, particle physics is fast becoming a field with plenty of heart-pounding, high-stakes suspense. The reasons lie not so much in the field's recent string of discoveries as in how some of them were made.

title: A Look Just Over the Horizon
description: August 8, 2000

title: BROADCOM ACQUIRING SILICON SPICE
description: A leading maker of chips that allow digital communications to flow faster, Broadcom, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Silicon Spice, a privately held company, in a stock swap valued at $1.19 billion. Silicon Spice is developing chip technology and software to make it easier to move high-density voice and data from traditional telephone networks to the Internet by companies like Cisco Systems, which is an investor and a customer. Silicon Spice is the 12th and most expensive acquisition since June 1999 for Broadcom, which is based in Irvine, Calif. Last week it agreed to buy Altima Communications for about $595 million in stock to gain greater access to small and medium-sized businesses. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

title: South Korea Replaces Top Economic Officials
description: Worried about the slow pace of financial reforms in South Korea and the stubbornly high debts of its big businesses and banks, President Kim Dae Jung replaced almost half of his 19-member cabinet today, including the nation's top economic officials.

title: California's Power Lag
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Journal; With Bunkers Manned, Vodka War Is in Stalemate
description: No shots have been fired yet, but there is a war going on under the leafy summer canopy that shades the streets in the Lefortovo district of the Russian capital. Here, on 20 acres of factory grounds, thousands of workers are daily engaged in the production of one of Russia's most essential commodities -- vodka.

title: You Can Dance and Sing All You Like, My Lords; Others Are Calling the Tune
description: Matching productions of Mozart's three mature Italian comedies -- ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' ''Don Giovanni'' and ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' -- at Glyndebourne here this weekend emphasized the works' differences more than their similarities. The director, Graham Vick, and the designer, Richard Hudson, have placed them all in the same wide white space defined by three slender iron pillars, and there is a link, too, in the mix of 18th-century and 20th-century elements in the costumes. This degree of uniformity, though, only points up the productions' contrary purposes.

title: Prices Starting to Stabilize For Housing in Manhattan
description: The fever has broken.

title: Ballet Theater Shows Off a Nation's Students
description: Students chosen from ballet schools around the nation showed off what they had learned at the American Ballet Theater Summer Intensive program in a performance on Friday afternoon at Pace Downtown Theater. This year's program had 150 dancers aged 12 to 19, all of whom performed at one time or other in a well-organized program of old and new choreography.

title: Sense of Pride Among Jews Is Tempered With Concern
description: Regardless of political leanings or depth of spirituality, American Jews expressed great pride yesterday that one of their own, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, had been picked by Vice President Al Gore to be his running mate.

title: Universities and Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: The Safir Tenure
description: During Howard Safir's tenure as New York's police commissioner, crime dropped precipitously in all categories and the murder rate fell to its lowest level since 1964. But incidents like the torture of Abner Louima and the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, coupled with the widely held perception in many neighborhoods that the department's aggressive policies unfairly singled out minorities, brought police-community relations to a new low point.

title: An Artist Who Travels With You (on Tape, That Is)
description: I first heard the voice, an insinuating, whispering voice in my head, in Switzerland. Inside the new Kunstmuseum in Lucerne, in the middle of an exhibition called ''Mixing Memory and Desire,'' somewhere between Joseph Reinhardt's late-18th-century paintings of Swiss peasants and a maze of 21st-century installation art, I heard it. I had climbed into a black-curtained booth, a theater in miniature called ''Playhouse,'' and had sat down to watch a singer projected on a tiny stage. I put on the headphones that were waiting on the chair.

title: West Nile Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Fund-Raiser At a Noisy Rental

title: Minus Shooting Guard, Nets May Have No Shot
description: The Nets have 10 players on their active roster, and Lucious Harris is the only shooting guard.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the discoveries of planets outside Earth's solar system misstated the number found. It was 9, not 10; one planet was observed independently by two teams of astronomers.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Behind the Gross-Out Humor, The Teenage Movie in Hiding; Adolescents Are Being Shortchanged on Candor
description: If the movie box office, like the pop music charts, is ruled by the taste and purchasing power of high school students, why are there so few credible representations of adolescent life on today's movie screens?

title: If the Shoe Doesn't Fit ... Make It
description: A few days earlier, Ms. Falco's ''Sopranos'' co-star Lorraine Bracco could also be found at a favorite sale of the well-dressed -- the semi-annual Manolo Blahnik clearance in Manhattan. There, frenzied women with size 7 feet convince themselves they can fit into a 6 so they can go home with pink and white mules at $150 a pair.

title: Yanks Get Canseco, but the Question Is Why?
description: The Yankees wanted Jose Canseco in the past and could not get him. They finally got him yesterday, acquiring the slugger on waivers. But they don't really want him or need him; they just wanted to make sure he wasn't going to play for somebody else.

title: Admitted Killer of 8 Women Receives 8 Life Terms Without Parole
description: Kendall L. Francois, who admitted murdering eight women here over a two-year period, was sentenced today to spend the rest of his life in prison.

title: Pataki Signs Bill Requiring Con Ed Rebate
description: Putting the blame for a February nuclear accident squarely on Consolidated Edison, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill today requiring the company to repay customers more than $100 million collected to pay expenses from the accident and prohibiting it from collecting tens of millions more.

title: UICI AGREES TO SELL ITS CREDIT CARD BUSINESS
description: UICI agreed yesterday to sell its United CreditServ credit card business to an undisclosed international financial services company for about $134 million. UICI, a Dallas-based company offering health, financial, insurance and other services, declared the financially troubled United CreditServ a discontinued operation on Dec. 31. The company said the sale of substantially all of United CreditServ's noncash assets includes the unit's credit card receivables portfolios and its Sioux Falls, S. D., servicing operations. UICI or its subsidiaries will retain most liabilities associated with its credit card business, including $134.6 million in certificates of deposit. Shares of UICI rose 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $8.5625.

title: Chief Resigns At Ameritrade
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation said today that its chief executive, Thomas K. Lewis, had resigned about three months after taking charge of the company, an online brokerage firm, whose stock has stumbled this year.

title: Views on Lasik Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; West Took Dead Aim At Talent, Too
description: DURING a round of golf in the summer of 1995, Jerry West and Rick Pitino were discussing a kid who was going into his senior year in high school in Pennsylvania. Pitino, then coach of Kentucky, said he was determined to recruit the kid. West, the executive vice president of the Los Angeles Lakers, said: ''Forget about it, Rick. He's going pro right out of high school. And we're going to get him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINANT, JANINE LOUISE
description: WINANT-Janine Louise. On August 6, 2000. Of Coventry Farm in Princeton, New Jersey. Wife of the late John G. Winant. Graveside services will be held Friday, August 11 at 11:30AM at Princeton Cemetery, Princeton. Memorial contributions to the ASPCA, The Humane Society of the United States, National Wildlife Federation or the NJ Audubon Society.

title: Agencies Disclose Several Deals
description: Several agencies are making deals for undisclosed terms.

title: Republicans Like Gore's Choice but Liken Him More to Them Than to Gore
description: Republicans praised the selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as Vice President Al Gore's running mate today but quickly seized on votes that differed from Mr. Gore's positions and said Mr. Lieberman's conservative record would not help the ticket with core Democratic voters.

title: Cisneros Leaving Univisison To Run Housing Company
description: Henry G. Cisneros, the former housing secretary in the Clinton administration who became the president and chief operating officer of the largest Spanish-language television broadcaster in the United States, announced yesterday that he was leaving the company, Univision Communications Inc., to run a concern that will build affordable housing in downtown urban areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNIAK, EDWARD
description: CHERNIAK-Edward. On August 7. Beloved husband of 62 years to Ida. Devoted father to Arline, Phyllis and Steven. Devoted father-inlaw to Sam, Paul and Stephanie. Loving grandfather to Jamie, Lauren, Michael, Harlan and Spencer. Funeral services Tuesday, 1PM at ''Gutterman's, Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SARA ZOX
description: FRIEDMAN-Sara Zox (Sally), 59. Of NY and Sagaponack. Passed away at home after a courageous battle with cancer. A wonderful and giving friend to all who knew her, she had three beautiful daughters: Katherine, Elizabeth and Claudia and a devoted husband of 35 years, Jerry. She was the adoring daughter of Leah Zox Goldman of Columbus Ohio, and the late Joseph Zox. She is also survived by her sisters Nancy Brown (Robert) and Ellen Wedeles (Roy) and her brothers Benjamin Zox (Julie) and David Zox. Funeral services will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 1076 Madison Avenue, Wednesday, August 9 at 9:30AM. Friends may visit with the family Tuesday evening, August 8 from 7PM-9PM at the funeral home. A private interment will be held in Easthampton. Sally will be missed by all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELZ, PHILIP
description: BELZ-Philip. The entire Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of Reb Shrage Feivel Belz, our esteemed Board Member and loyal friend of over three decades. He and his late wife, Sarah, were Chai Founders whose generous support enabled Boys Town to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. Mr. Belz's commitment to Jewish continuity is evidenced by the many causes benefitting from his legendary tzedakah. As a tangible expression of his commitment to this ideal, he made his son and daughter in-law, Jack and Marilyn Belz, Chai Founders, who continue to offer assistance to Boys Town's 1,000 students. ''Let me hear your voice for your voice is pleasant'' (Song of Songs). The voice of Philip Belz's soul will continue to sing. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Lieberman on Lewinsky Affair: 'Embarrassing for All of Us as Americans'
description: In a Senate speech on Sept. 3, 1998, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, sharply criticized President Clinton's conduct in the Monica Lewinsky matter, but he voted against convicting the president in the impeachment trial, giving his reasons in a statement released on Feb. 11, 1999:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DENSEN, PAUL
description: DENSEN-Paul. Your birthday today. We miss you. We love you. Sarah, Mark and Robert

title: SINGAPORE TELECOM IN INDIA
description: Moving to gain a foothold in India's potentially vast market, Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. will pay $400 million for a minority stake in the largest privately owned telecommunications company in India, Bharti Group. The deal is part of a strategy by Singapore Telecom, the country's former monopoly telecommunications provider, to remain competitive as deregulation and new rivals eat into its profits at home. Singapore Telecom's efforts earlier this year to buy stakes in Cable and Wireless HKT Bhd. of Hong Kong and Time Engineering Bhd. of Malaysia were thwarted by political reservations about its largest shareholder, Singapore's government. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Article 2000080891673641657 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: An Effort by U.S. to Change the I.M.F. Is Set Back
description: Poor countries are fighting a proposal by the leading industrial nations to increase the cost of borrowing from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, dealing a blow to a campaign by Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers to change the lending agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AZUMBRADO, ANNE
description: AZUMBRADO-Anne (nee Huzar). August 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late John T. Mother and grandmother: Michele, Bobbi, Cory. Four granddaughters and sister Mary. Services at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 718-253-5900.

title: Three Leading Candidates For Commissioner's Job
description: The departure of Police Commissioner Howard Safir, one of the most loyal and prominent members of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's inner circle, would leave vacant a city post that is coveted in law enforcement circles but available under imperfect circumstances.

title: Indonesia's Quirky Leader Apologizes and Pledges Order
description: A newly humble President Abdurrahman Wahid apologized today for falling short of expectations as Indonesia struggles to build a working democracy and said he would name an executive minister to bring order to his flailing administration.

title: CBS TURNS DOWN OFFER
description: CBS Sports has turned down an offer to buy the same major league baseball television rights that NBC has controlled for the past five seasons.

title: ELECTRICITY UNIT SOLD
description: An Edinburgh-based electricity holding company, British Energy P.L.C., said it had sold Swalec, its retail electricity and gas supply business, to the British electricity provider Scottish and Southern Energy P.L.C. for $316.1 million. British Energy said it wanted to focus on wholesale contracting and direct sales to customers.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: After 7 Years Off, Swimmer Returns at 33
description: Some people leave tickets for Elvis at sporting events. The swimmer Dara Torres leaves them for Alfonse M. D'Amato. The man once known wryly as Senator Pothole has apparently became Senator Swimming Hole.

title: Domain Name Disputes Settled
description: Domain Name Disputes Settled

title: Views on Lasik Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Plead Not Guilty In Salt Lake Bribe Case
description: The two chief organizers of Salt Lake City's bid to be host to the 2002 Winter Olympics pleaded not guilty yesterday to federal charges that they had conspired to bribe members of the International Olympic Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DAVE
description: GOLDBERG-Dave. Died August 6 at his home in Tamarac, FL. He was 87 years old. He was a pioneer in the swimwear industry in the 1950s, and the company bearing his name is still one of the leading swimwear firms in the country. The many licenses the company had over the years included Coca Cola Girls, Gottex Girls, Sasson, and currently Monte Carlo Beach Club, Beach Scene and Bay 1. He was a past president of the Industrial Association of Juvenile Apparel Manufacturers and, in addition to the many charitable organizations he supported, several years ago he was honored by UJA as the swimwear industry's ''Man of the Year''. He had an indomitable spirit and inspiring vision, and he had the respect of all who knew him. He will be sorely missed and will live on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched. He is survived by his wife, Rose, his brother Irving, his daughter Marilyn and her husband Richard, his son Allen and his wife Patty, and by his four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A graveside ceremony will be held at Cedar Park-Bethel Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey, 201261-7878, at 11:00 AM on Tuesday, August 8. The family will sit at the home of Marilyn and Richard Dickstein, Muttontown, NY on Tuesday and Wednesday, August 8 and 9. Contributions may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America, 8800 Venice Blvd, Los Angeles, CA. 90034.

title: New Clues for Treating a Child's Seizure
description: When children have seizures, doctors are sometimes put in quandaries: should they assume the seizure is epilepsy and begin medicating? Or should they wait and hope it is just an isolated occurrence?

title: In the Mideast, a Bridge Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHINESE PLEDGE ON STOCK SALES
description: Finance Minister Xiang Haicheng of China said the government was committed to sell much of its stake in companies listed on the country's two stock exchanges. The money raised would be used to finance social security, he was quoted as saying in China Business Weekly. On average, the government owns about 70 percent of the shares in China's listed companies. Mr. Xiang said the state would initially cut its ownership to 51 percent, and later to 30 percent -- effectively privatizing much of the economy. The share sales could bring the state as much as $27 billion, he said. But Mr. Xiang gave no timetable for the politically charged plan, which has been talked about for years without action. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: When Black Patients Get Slighted
description: A new study offers still more evidence that when it comes to health care, black and white patients do not always get equal treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HYMAN
description: LEVINE-Hyman. Of Riverdale, NY, on August 7. The beloved husband of the late Schura. Devoted father of Paul (and Ethel); loving grandfather of Alec (Meegan) and Mark. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ on Wednesday, August 9 at 1:00 PM. Should friends desire, contributions to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services would be appreciated.

title: Named After a Dish, It's a Spicy Carnival
description: Nobody can resist a carnival for long, or so it seemed at Kitchrie 2000 on Sunday night at Damrosch Park.

title: IPARTY TO BUY 33 RETAIL STORES FROM BIG PARTY
description: The IParty Corporation, which sells party goods over the Internet, plans to buy 33 retail stores in New England and Florida from the Big Party Corporation for an undisclosed price. Big Party, which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, operates 54 United States stores and had sales of about $69 million in 1999. IParty, based in New York, plans to acquire the inventory, fixed assets and leases of Big Party stores in Maine, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Florida. The purchase will give IParty, which sells balloons, costumes, decorations and gifts, its first ''brick and mortar'' shops.

title: Shining Land Not So Far From Topsy-Turvydom
description: For those of us helplessly in love with the marches of John Philip Sousa, his stage works are phantoms. The New Grove Dictionary of Opera has no entry for Sousa at all, although pieces like ''The Glass Blowers,'' played on Saturday afternoon at the Glimmerglass Opera, were busily performed and warmly received during the first quarter of the 20th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, WILLIAM H.
description: KRAUSS-William H. Age 87. Services were held for Bill Krauss on August 7, 2000. Devoted husband of Frieda for 62 years, loving father of Steve, Dan, Bob, and Ronnie, adored grandfather of Dina, David, Lawrence and Jennifer.

title: NYT Article
description: Technology Briefings

title: ABC to Correct Report That Challenged Benefits of Organic Foods
description: ABC News said yesterday that a report challenging the assumed benefits of organic food was partly based on research that did not exist. It said it would make a correction on Friday night's ''20/20'' program.

title: City School System to Offer Online Courses to Teachers
description: The New York City Board of Education is planning to provide online training for the city's 78,000 teachers starting next fall, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday.

title: Performing as if on a Dare In a Raw Endurance Test
description: Concerts by the tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins are to be experienced the way surfers experience the beach: they wait around for the tide to gather force, and at a certain moment the watery muscle hurtles them along. But this sort of momentum can't be willed; you can't expect the big one every time out.

title: New York City to Pay $1 Million For Improper Pollutant Disposal
description: Admitting that for years it improperly disposed of household appliances containing ozone-depleting chemicals, New York City has agreed to pay a fine of $1 million to the federal government and to spend $3 million on garbage-collection equipment to reduce air pollution, the federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLUTH, SIMON
description: KORNBLUTH-Simon. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member Simon Kornbluth. May the Almighty console the family with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: In Search of the Deep Breath Chemical
description: The biochemistry of breathing deeply, the one thing an asthmatic cannot do in the midst of the attack, may hold a key to helping doctors treat people who have asthma.

title: Israeli Rabbi Sets Off a Political Firestorm Over the Holocaust
description: The 80-year-old spiritual leader of a major religious political party outraged many Israelis with a sermon over the weekend in which he said the six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust died because they were reincarnations of sinners, and he sought today to calm the storm.

title: Q & A
description: Red Hot Chili Peppers

title: Credit Bush Doesn't Deserve
description: At the Republican Convention last week, Colin Powell boldly challenged his party to be inclusive and follow the leadership of George W. Bush in Texas. As a model of inclusive reform, he touted Texas' 10 percent plan, which grants automatic admission to the flagship public colleges to all state students graduating in the top 10 percent of their high school classes.

title: NEW LOWER-COST PALM
description: Palm Inc., the 3Com spin-off whose hand-held computers have struck a chord with mobile executives and students alike, released its fall lineup of new models, including the lowest-priced version the company has produced to date. The model, the m100, sells for $149 and includes an updated software program that lets users store handwritten notes. They come in basic black, but can be modified with $20 faceplates in five colors. Another new model, the wireless Palm VIIx, offers four times the memory of the popular Palm VII and costs about $450. Palm hopes the new models will help it retain its lead over Handspring and other competitors. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WURMFELD, MICHAEL S.
description: WURMFELD-Michael S. Memorial service Thursday, August 10th, 4:45PM, United Nations Chapel, 777 U.N. Plaza, 44 St/1st Ave, NYC.

title: In the Mideast, a Bridge Too Far; Enlist Carter's Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Shoplifting on a Grand Scale: Luxury Wear Stolen to Order
description: From the look of it, a person with identity issues had done some heavy shopping. Tossed on a bed in a Brooklyn apartment were a $600 Vuitton Broadway satchel, two $600 burgundy quilted polyester nylon skirts from Chanel, a $545 scarf with the block-lettered Chanel logo worked into the weave and two pairs of blunt-toed $425 Prada Nero shoes for men. None of the garments matched. But that did not matter. The apartment was a way station on a convoluted route of distribution, and the clothes did not yet have owners. Unless, that is, you count the retailers they were stolen from.

title: How Culture Molds Habits Of Thought
description: For more than a century, Western philosophers and psychologists have based their discussions of mental life on a cardinal assumption: that the same basic processes underlie all human thought, whether in the mountains of Tibet or the grasslands of the Serengeti.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DODGE, DORIS
description: DODGE-Doris, 76, died of heart failure on August 1, 2000 while on holiday at Squam Lake, New Hampshire. Her husband, David, four children and four grandchildren and her many close friends deeply mourn her death of a great lovely lady. Memorial service to be announced.

title: William Rossa Cole, 80, Author And Editor of Children's Books
description: William Rossa Cole, an anthologist, editor and writer of children's books and light verse, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Picket Lines Swell and Telephone Disruptions Spread in Strike
description: A strike by more than 86,000 workers of the nation's biggest telecommunications employer intensified yesterday as problems with local consumer telephone service -- some of it a result of vandalism -- began to spread and picket lines swelled in a 13-state region stretching from Maine to Virginia.

title: John Hohenberg, 94, Former Pulitzer Prize Official, Dies
description: John Hohenberg, who began his journalism career as a teenager by snatching an interview with the president of the United States and went on to become administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes, died Sunday morning at his home in Knoxville, Tenn. He was 94.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Bull Retreats In Downgrade Of Web Shares
description: Henry Blodget's words used to add rocket fuel to the new economy. Yesterday, Mr. Blodget, Merrill Lynch's star Internet analyst, re-entered the atmosphere, downgrading 10 of the 29 companies he recommends.

title: United States Is Worried About an Increased Threat of Nuclear Conflict Over Kashmir
description: Behind President Clinton's blunt warning last spring that South Asia was the world's most perilous region lay an assessment from American intelligence agencies that the likelihood of a war between India and Pakistan that could erupt into a nuclear conflict had increased significantly, according to officials with access to the secret intelligence.

title: Senator Often Stands To Right of His Party
description: In his two terms in the Senate, Joseph I. Lieberman has often taken positions at odds with Vice President Al Gore and important constituencies of the Democratic Party on school vouchers, affirmative action, regulation of managed care, capital gains taxes and product liability.

title: Hernandez Is Tough To Replace
description: Life at the top is not rosy for the MetroStars right now. After going nine games without a loss to solidify their position at the top of Major League Soccer's Eastern Division, the MetroStars suffered their second consecutive loss on Sunday in Chicago, a 3-1 decision to the Fire.

title: A Painful Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Have Plenty of Clout in Television Rights
description: More than any team in sports, the Yankees have taken extraordinary advantage of the lucrative and escalating value of their television rights.

title: New Hulk of the Road: 7,000 Pounds of Ego
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan Pact Resolves Battle Over Limits on Indian Fishing
description: The federal government, the State of Michigan and five American Indian tribes in northern Michigan signed an agreement today aimed at rebuilding fish populations in the upper Great Lakes and improving strained relations between whites and Indians in upstate Michigan.

title: In Selecting a No. 2, No Detail Too Small
description: In the days before George W. Bush announced his selection of Dick Cheney as his running mate, Vice President Al Gore and his advisers sensed an unexpected opportunity. Aboard Air Force II and in Mr. Gore's campaign headquarters here, there was a consensus that Mr. Bush and his aides had bungled their selection process, that the Republicans had come across as leak-prone, rushed and uncharacteristically amateurish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAD, BERNARD
description: GRAD-Bernard. The Board of Trustees of Monmouth Health Care Foundation expresses its sadness at the passing of our very special benefactor of Monmouth Medical Center and extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. Judi Dawkins, Chairman Bridget Murphy, Director

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Miracles happen.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Bush family members who attended the Republican National Convention misstated the occupation of Marvin Bush, the former president's son, and the location of his business. He is a co-founder of an investment firm in McLean, Va., not a management consultant in Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRA, FRANK
description: MARRA-Frank The officers, sales associates and employees of The William B. May Company offer our deepest sympathy to our president and friend Peter R.Marra on the loss of his father. We also extend our heartfelt condolences to Peter's mother, Eleanor, and his entire family. May you find comfort in recalling treasured memories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REESE, JOSEPH M.
description: REESE-Joseph M. On August 4, 2000. Beloved son of Clara and the late Joseph J. Devoted brother of Marion Taylor, Elaine Nicholson, Joan Cegelka and Ronald. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Former employee of Vincent & Farrell Associates, member of 115th Precinct Council, Founder and President of Alpine Tenants Association, member of Jackson Heights Neighbor Association, former Board member of Community Board #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNHILL, MICHAEL
description: BURNHILL - Michael, MD. Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PPFA) staff and volunteers deeply mourn the loss of Michael Burnhill, MD, a lifelong champion of reproductive rights and women's health in this country and internationally. An obstetrician/gynecologist and pioneer in contraceptive technology, Dr. Burnhill was a PPFA vice-president for medical affairs for the past five years, while continuing his private practice. He first joined Planned Parenthood in 1972 as medical director of Planned Parenthood of New York City when it began to offer abortion services. He was a noted author, researcher and educator who took great pride in training physicians and nurse practitioners as a means to expand access to reproductive health care. We will miss his wisdom, warmth and passion, and will remember his relentless courage on behalf of women all over the world. We extend to his family and friends our heartfelt sympathy as well as our best wishes for happy and proud memories. The family has requested that contributions in his name be sent to PPFA (810 Seventh Ave, New York, New York 10019), which will establish a special fund in Dr. Burnhill's honor. Mary Shallenberger, Chair Gloria Feldt, President Planned Parenthood Federation of America

title: INSIDE
description: Fears of a Nuclear War

title: KPMG Consulting in Filing Gives Details of Stock Offering
description: KPMG Consulting said yesterday that its initial public offering would raise as much as $2.83 billion, only $60 million of which would be available for the company to use in building its business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMANN, LARRY T.
description: HARTMANN-Larry T. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of Larry, father of Rick Hartmann, Atlantic's Golf Professional. We extend our heartfelt sympathy toLarry's wife Dorothy, his son Rick and wife Claudette, his son Jack and wife Lisa, and Larry's grandchildren, Loren and Graham. Robert E. Morrow, President Harvey L. Radler, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATES, JOHN ROBINSON
description: CATES-John Robinson, MD of 3 Pomander Walk died on the night of August 5th. John was a Psychiatrist, an actor, a painter, a loving friend and a devoted father. John is survived by Andrew John, Edward David, MD, and Alicia Jennifer. He died of complications following heart surgery. John was born on August 13, 1918 in Newnan, Georgia. He completed a six-year Medical degree from Emory University in Atlanta. He served in WW II as a ship's Doctor on a destroyer in the North Atlantic. After the war Johnny's heart was captured by New York City. It was here that he pursued a career in psychoanalysis, raised his three children and did much more. In retirement he pursued his passions for acting, as a member of the Actors Equity Union, and for painting, at the Art Students League. Friends and family will remember John for his caring heart, his graceful step and for his willingness to live life despite the rules. There will be a memorial service at 11:30 Thursday, August 10, at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers we are arranging for a plaque at the New York Conservancy Garden, details at service.

title: White-Coat Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Market Watch column in Money & Business on Sunday about plans by James H. Clark, the founder of Netscape and co-founder of Healtheon/WebMD, to buy stock in Healtheon, referred incompletely to regulations on stock purchases by insiders. While a Securities and Exchange Commission spokesman indeed said there were no prohibitions, that comment applied only to the context of Mr. Clark's plan. Insiders may not buy stock based on possession of material nonpublic information. But trading on the basis of insider information was not an issue in the column.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell on expectations that a weekly inventory report tomorrow will show a large gain in supplies. In New York, crude oil for September delivery fell $1.05, or 3.5 percent, to $28.91 a barrel.

title: A Town Divided
description: To the Editor:

title: Late Mets Lightning: Bell Ties It, Then Abbott Wins It
description: Derek Bell crossed home plate and walked slowly to the Mets' dugout, staring purposefully into the stands at Enron Field. The Houston Astros' new home is enemy territory for Bell, a former Astro, who was booed heavily tonight, and he was scanning for his biggest ally: his mother, Chestine, for whom he always tries to hit a home run.

title: SAFIR IS TO RESIGN AS HEAD OF POLICE, CITY OFFICIALS SAY
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir, whose department won accolades for routing crime and scorn for its unraveling relationship with many of the black and Latino citizens it served, is expected to announce today that he is leaving the job by the end of this month, officials said.

title: Ethical Politics, And Intellectual
description: To the Editor:

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Not available

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Retirement Center to Offer Comfort After Convents
description: After years of serving others, many older Roman Catholic nuns look forward to a few comforts of their own when they retire to their convents. Instead, they often find themselves with aches and pains from the heavy doors, long hallways and endless steps to the chapel.

title: Cohen Delays His Finding On Building Missile Shield
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen postponed his recommendation today to President Clinton on whether to proceed with a limited national missile defense, citing ''a number of difficult issues'' that still have to be resolved.

title: A Man of Steady Habits -- Joseph Isador Lieberman
description: On Sept. 3, 1998, Joseph I. Lieberman stood up in the United States Senate to speak about Bill Clinton. They had been friends and Democratic allies for 30 years, but the president had finally admitted having an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky. Anger, resentment, a sense of betrayal: the bitter emotions had wracked the nation, and were about to find a powerful voice in the Senate.

title: His Weirdness Attracts Types Even More Weird
description: BEN, IN THE WORLD

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen on speculation that reports this week will provide further evidence of growth without fanning inflation. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.06 yen, up from 108.52 on Friday.

title: Metro Business; DKNY Planned for SoHo
description: Donna Karan International plans to open a DKNY store in SoHo, to complement the company's flagship store on Madison Avenue.

title: Russia Asks U.S. to Reconsider Steel Limit
description: The Russian government has asked the United States to reconsider an agreement that limits Russian steel exports into this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, ROCHELLE
description: FORREST-Rochelle. Age 80. Passed away suddenly on August 3rd in Deerfield Beach, Florida (formerly of White Plains). She was the beloved wife of the late and cherished Norman; devoted mother of Robert and Juliet and dear sister of Muriel. A New York memorial service is planned some time in September. Her luminous spirit will shine forever in our hearts and in the minds of all who knew her.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRW INC., -- Cleveland, sold two electronic-sensor units, formerly part of TRW's auto-parts division, to Measurement Specialties Inc., Fairfield, N.J., for $17.7 million as it sheds businesses to reduce debt.

title: An Archie For 2000, With a Taste For Lechery
description: It's too bad, really, that ''Sammy,'' David Spade's new animated sitcom, didn't make its appearance about 30 years ago. That was the moment in history when loutishness could be lovable, as Norman Lear showed us with Archie Bunker. Alas, Mr. Spade's Sammy, who makes his debut tonight on NBC, is a lout born too late.

title: Reading Glasses, as Inevitable as Death and Taxes. Or Are They?
description: The quick fix of laser surgery may be freeing more and more people from eyeglasses and contact lenses, but no matter how successful the surgery, their liberation is only temporary. Sooner or later the need for reading glasses descends on all adults -- and from those devices there is still no quick escape.

title: Safety Lapses Found for Children in Cars
description: Researchers who analyzed thousands of car crashes report that many parents are not using child car seats and booster seats correctly and that proper protection drops sharply for children 3 to 8 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALISH, MARC
description: KALISH-Marc. On August 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Melissa. Loving father of Dani Jose Falkoff, Alexander, Zachary and Chloe Kalish. Cherished grandfather to Max and Carly. He will live in our hearts forever. Services Wednesday, 2:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARRAF, MOUSSA
description: SARRAF-Moussa. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE PRIMARIES

title: Man Who Would Be King Can Only Long for Italy
description: The heir to the Italian throne has never visited his family's former realm. Barred by a 1948 constitutional amendment that forbids direct male descendants of the last king of Italy from setting foot on Italian soil, Prince Emanuele Filiberto di Savoia, 28, has to content himself with gazing at the shores of Sardinia through binoculars from Corsica, where his family has a summer home.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Surgery for Giants' Mitchell
description: Giants tight end Pete Mitchell will have arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Tuesday, a procedure that Coach Jim Fassel said was as much to explore the joint as to repair damage to it.

title: New Hulk of the Road: 7,000 Pounds of Ego
description: To the Editor:

title: MICROSOFT'S BOARD APPROVES SHARE BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the world's largest software company, said yesterday that its board had approved a share-buyback program to acquire stock for its employee stock-option and stock-purchase programs. The program took effect yesterday, and Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., said the number of shares to be purchased would be based primarily on the level of employee stock options exercised. Shares of Microsoft were up 87.5 cents yesterday, to $70, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKEN, EMANUEL
description: HACKEN-Emanuel. On August 6, 2000. A graduate of Prague University, he was a pediatrician in Europe and then became a psychiatrist after coming to the U.S., a Fellow of the APA and former Deputy Director of Rockland State Hospital; published composer and multilingual writer. Beloved husband of the late Vera. Loving father of George and father-in-law of Tana Cohn. Cherished grandfather of Diane and Erica and great grandfather of Jaron and Shane. Services Tuesday 11AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Two headings in the ''Most Wanted'' chart grouping in Business Day yesterday were reversed. The top five winners and losers in technology stocks appeared in the first box of the second row, followed by the winners and losers in media stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTELL, ADAM ETHAN
description: TARTELL-Adam Ethan. Age 44. Pediatric dentist, died suddenly of a heart attack on August 1,2000. Dr. Tartell graudated from West Hempstead High School, Cobleskill College, Hofstra University, NYU College of Dentistry and in 1985 the Eastman Dental School, University of Rochester. He practiced Pedodontia and resided at 142 Flower Avenue West, Watertown, NY. He is survived by his wife, Sharon and children, Benjamin, Zachary and Clair, his parents, Dr. Robert and Mrs. Lottie Tartell, West Hempstead, and two brothers, Ross, Wilton, Conn. and Marc, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Corrections
