description: A report in the Philadelphia Diary column last Tuesday about a speech on AIDS at the Republican National Convention misstated the source of the fortune made by Max Fisher, a Republican donor whose daughter Mary Fisher spoke about AIDS at the 1992 and 1996 conventions. He made his fortune in the oil business and as an investor, not in the auto body business.

title: BRAZIL CARMAKERS ACCUSE ARGENTINA
description: A trade group representing car manufacturers in Brazil accused the Argentine government of reneging on a crucial element of an accord on auto exports, throwing the future of the accord into doubt. The Brazilian government is expected to demand that Argentina revise a decree published last week that increased the percentage of Argentine-made auto parts that a car must have to be traded duty-free inside the Southern American Common Market, Mercosur, to 55 percent from 30 percent. Brazil's automakers say the rule could hinder auto trade between the nations because Argentine cars would become more expensive and fewer would be exported to Brazil. Under the terms of the trade accord, that would reduce Brazil's exports of cars to Argentina.

title: Pressing the Cause of the Forgotten Slaves
description: CORPORATIONS beware: if you were born before 1865, Deadria C. Farmer-Paellmann is looking for slaves in your archives and may have bad news for you.

title: FRENCH CABLE STAKE SOLD
description: Britain's No. 1 cable television company, NTL Inc., and Morgan Stanley Private Equity agreed to buy France Telecom's 49.9 percent of Noos, France's biggest cable operator. for 1.35 billion euros ($1.2 billion). NTL, which is based in New York, will buy 27 percent and the investment arm of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company will buy 22.9 percent of Noos. Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. is the majority owner of Noos, which has 736,000 subscribers. France Telecom expects a pretax gain of 534 million euros on the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKY, BURTON
description: LASKY-Burton. On August 4. Beloved husband of Diana. Beloved father of Andrew. Loving son of Louis. Dear brother of Harvey and Jesse. A great man, who always did what was right. He possesed an amazing body of knowledge and a genuinely noble soul.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSIN, MARION
description: KOSSIN-Marion. Of Teaneck, NJ, on August 7, 2000, beloved wife of the late Dr. Leon Kossin, devoted mother of Warren Kossin, Sara Tractenberg, Roni Epstein, dear sister of Rose Goldberg, loving grandmother of Howard, Beth, Charles, Lawrence, Steven, Elyse, Cheryl and great-grandmother of Matthew and Samantha. Services at ''Wien & Wien'', corner of Park and Passaic, Hackensack, NJ, on Wednesday, August 9 at 11:30 A.M.

title: As Japan Deregulates, Quality-of-Life Laments; Mom and Pop Do Battle With Discounters
description: Sales started sliding at the Katos' small sake shop here a decade ago, when trucks began coming into the neighborhood and selling cut-price beer and other alcoholic beverages off their tailgates.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Saturday about an effort by Arab leaders to find a consensus on outstanding differences between the Palestinians and the Israelis misstated the Arab position on the issue of refugees. The Arab nations have long contended that Palestinian refugees are the responsibility of Israel, not of the rest of the world. The article also misstated the number of peace agreements signed by Israel with Arab countries. It is two -- not just with Egypt but also with Jordan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Tracing 37 Million Years in Half an Inch
description: Fault lines trace how the Earth cracks and slides at its surface. How rocks a few miles down move is less clear.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ruling by Arbitrator Splits Arthur Andersen in Two

title: Broad-Based Rally Extends to a 3rd Day
description: Stocks climbed for a third day yesterday on optimism that the economy is slowing enough that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again in 2000.

title: Darwin in Kansas
description: To the Editor:

title: LINUX FINDS A TINY HOME
description: Pushing beyond its server computer roots, the free Linux operating system has found its way into the smallest computer yet: a machine the size of a matchbox. I.B.M. researchers plan to announce that they have developed a complete version of the Linux software that runs on a prototype computer only 2.2 inches by 1.89 inches by 0.48 inch. The computer, which the researchers said could be worn like a watch, has a central processor, eight megabytes of nonvolatile memory and another eight megabytes of dynamic random access memory. The new I.B.M. machine is slightly smaller than a similar commercial computer already made by Tiqit Computers in Palo Alto, Calif. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Eastman Kodak Company's push into digital products misspelled the name of its new untearable photographic paper. It is DuraLife, not Duralite.

title: Metro Business; Omnipoint Agrees To Clarify Ad Claims
description: Omnipoint Communications, the mobile telephone carrier, has agreed to clarify advertising claims about customer access to its system and the security of calls, according to the New York State attorney general, who had accused the company of misleading advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, JULIE
description: PINCUS - Julie. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted, long-time member, Julie Pincus. Julie and his beloved wife Anne, have been members of Rodeph Sholom for over 40 years. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife, his children, Edward and Jane, Martin and Pat, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDER, ELLIOT L.
description: FRIEDER-Elliot L. Beloved husband of the late Leonie. Loving brother of Jehudith (Rosel) Hermoni, Hannah Lehrman and Sol. Beloved uncle of Lea Pridor, Myriam Beer-Lehrman, Elisheva Goren, Daniel A. Lehrman, Chaim Hermoni and their families. Also survived by the Kranzler family. Services at 12 noon Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: G.I.'s to Be Sent to Train Africans for Sierra Leone
description: In a shift of policy, the Clinton administration plans to send hundreds of American soldiers to Nigeria this month to train and equip West African battalions that will then be dispatched to Sierra Leone to bolster beleaguered government troops and United Nations peacekeepers there.

title: A Math Sleuth Whose Secret Weapon Is Statistics
description: In a time when full-time academic appointments are hard to come by, some mathematics Ph.D.'s may consider the career path taken by Dr. Charles Brenner, 55, one of the world's first fully employed freelance mathematicians.

title: Lieberman Can Run With a Foot in 2 Races
description: Joseph I. Lieberman's life will never be quite the same now that Al Gore has tapped him to be his running mate, but one thing seems likely to remain unchanged: Mr. Lieberman can continue to run for re-election to the Senate, a race he is an overwhelming favorite to win, while also running in the tougher race for vice president.

title: NYT Article
description: Netscape Security Hole Affects Users

title: Views on Lasik Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees' Latest Move Subtracts, Not Adds
description: George Steinbrenner's Rotisserie baseball executives woke up last Thursday, found out that Jose Canseco was available on the waiver wire and inexplicably pounced on him. So the Yankees started the process that forced them to add the player that Steinbrenner has always adored, a player with bulging biceps, with Page Six possibilities and with a flickering marquee name.

title: City Traffic Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ENREV CORP., -- Norcross, Ga., named Lou Salamone to the new post of chief financial officer. He had been senior vice president and chief financial officer at Applied Graphics Technologies.

title: GAS COMPRESSION SERVICES BEING BOUGHT BY A RIVAL
description: Universal Compression Holdings Inc., a gas compression equipment provider, agreed yesterday to acquire a privately held rival, Gas Compression Services Inc., for $12 million in cash and $46 million in Universal common shares. Universal will also assume $53 million in Gas Compression Services debt and operating leases. Universal and Gas Compression Services, based in Traverse City, Mich., are compression services companies that cater to the natural gas industry. Shares of Universal rose 50 cents, to $30.1875, on the New York Stock exchange.

title: As the Defense Takes Heat, Jones Takes No Prisoners
description: It was the first sweltering day of Jets training camp, and it was clear that a defense scorched is a defense boiling mad.

title: Promotion at Salomon
description: The Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup has promoted Jay Mandelbaum to vice chairman and chief executive of its worldwide brokerage business. Salomon Smith Barney plans to expand its network of branches outside the United States. Mr. Mandelbaum, 37, reports to Michael Carpenter, chairman and chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney.

title: Bail Reduced for Man Accused of Leading Philadelphia Protests
description: A man accused of being the ringleader of the illegal street protests during the Republican National Convention had his bail reduced from $1 million to $100,000 yesterday, as defendants contended that the Philadelphia police were guilty of jailhouse brutality and city officials maintained there was a criminal conspiracy to shut down the city.

title: Campbell at Apex of the Giants' Tight End Triangle
description: Dan Campbell, a Giants rookie tight end last year, changed his uniform number over the winter from 86 to 89. He knew he was going to get more playing time this season, and he figured some fans would notice he was wearing the number of his boyhood idol, Mark Bavaro.

title: Luxury Parking, Bargain Shopping
description: ''This place gives me deep real estate envy,'' James LaForce, a fashion publicist, said of the waterfront estate of Ken and Basia Nahoum in the Hamptons, at the third annual Super Saturday benefit for the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund. ''But I just try to breathe through it.''

title: Bear Stearns Settles Case Accusing It of Bad Advice
description: The Bear Stearns Companies has closed the books on one of the darker chapters in its history as an investment bank by writing a check for $30 million.

title: LIEBERMAN WILL RUN WITH GORE; FIRST JEW ON A MAJOR U.S. TICKET
description: Vice President Al Gore picked Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut to be his running mate today, putting a Jew on a national ticket of a major party for the first time and choosing the first prominent Democrat to chastise President Clinton openly for his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: News Is Carefully Timed To Steal G.O.P.'s Thunder
description: Like a select number of other journalists covering the Gore campaign, Claire Shipman of NBC News received the official word yesterday about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's selection as Vice President Al Gore's running mate before even Mr. Lieberman did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISTRITZKY, ALEXANDER
description: BISTRITZKY-Alexander. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Eva Bistritzky, on the passing of her beloved husband, Alexander. His late mother, Schifra, a Silver Founder of the Medical Center, served as an exemplary role model to this special man. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEDER, MARTIN A.
description: ROEDER-Martin A. On August 3, 2000. Cherished husband of Dorothy (Friedman) for 61 years, adored father of Katherine Roeder, Thomas and Susan Roeder, beloved grandfather of Sarah and Louisa Roeder, Kenneth Hartog and Erik Hartog & Pamela Heller. Son of the late Judge Jehial M. Roeder and the late Evelyn Finegold Roeder. Mr. Roeder was Of Counsel to Herzfeld and Rubin and former managing partner of Guggenheimer and Untermeyer. He had a degree from the Sorbonne in Paris, a BA and LLB from Columbia University and Columbia Law School of New York. He served on the boards of the Emanu-el Brotherbood and the Tax Management Institute of New York University. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 7-9PM with services Tuesday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Jewish Repertory Theater of the 92nd St. YM-YWHA, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANNING, JOHN M.
description: LANNING-John M. Jr. On August 5, 2000 of Maplewood, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Susan Browne Lanning. Devoted father of Elizabeth Ann of Manhattan and Amanda Ashton Lanning of Maplewood. Loving son of John M. and Eleanor Lyness Lanning Sr. of Chestnut Hill, MA. Dear brother of Ellen Lanning Masica of Carmel, IN. Loving uncle of Andrew; Caroline; Allison; Amanda and devoted Jeremy. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ on Friday, August 11 at 10:00 AM. Interment St. Rose of Lima Cemetery, Short Hills. Visitation will be held at The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, Wednesday, 7-9 PM and Thursday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Donations to the John M. Lanning Jr. Scholarship Fund c/o Fordham University Development Office: 113 W. 60th Street, NY, NY 10023-7484. Att. Judith Katz would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROBERT W.
description: KING-Robert W. On August 4, 2000, at age 81. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Cynthia Betts, Sara Gervasio, John E. King, Mary Braley and William W. King. Step-father of Susan DeVoge and Deborah Dunn. Adored grandfather of 12. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 68 PM, and Wednesday, 12-3 PM. Memorial service at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. at 55th St., Wednesday, 6 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., 5th Floor, NYC 10017.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARCIA, RIVERA, OSCAR
description: GARCIA - RIVERA - Oscar. Dear Father of Felicia and Partner of Andree, died on August 5, 2000, after a brief and heroic battle. Funeral services Thursday, August 10, at 11 AM in the Chapel Of The Church Of The Heavenly Rest at 90th Street and 5th Avenue.

title: Fallon Minneapolis Chosen by Citigroup
description: Citigroup in New York said yesterday that it had chosen Fallon Minneapolis, part of the Fallon Worldwide unit of Publicis Groupe S.A., as the agency of record to handle the Citibank consumer business in the United States, including retail banking and credit cards.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Piazza Improves Range of Motion
description: Mike Piazza, the Mets catcher, showed better range of motion today after mildly spraining the medial collateral ligament in his left knee crossing first base on Saturday. But the Mets held him out of baseball activities like squatting, pivoting and hitting, and Piazza is expected to miss two to four more games.

title: Murder Rate In New York Sliding Back
description: New York City's murder rate, after a surge that alarmed the Police Department and brought about an expensive and aggressive street enforcement campaign, has begun to slide back down.

title: PLUS: GOLF -- World Championships Invitational; Woods Commits To Play In Tourney
description: Tiger Woods has committed to play in the World Golf Championships Invitational, scheduled for Aug. 24-27 at the Firestone Country Club's South Course in Akron, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOUNTY, ROBERT
description: MOUNTY-Robert. On August 6, 2000. Father of Dr. Judith L. Mounty (Robert B.) Weinstock, Ann Mounty (Steven Simon), Ian Mounty and Jennifer Mounty. Brother of Seymour Mounty, Bernard Mounty and Shirley Mounty. Grandfather of Matthew, Luda & Hannah Jo, also by two nephews and two great nieces. Relatives and friends are invited to services Wednesday, 10:00 AM at Riverside Chapels, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Interment Mt. Jacob Cemetery, Collingdale, PA. Family will return to his late residence. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: 2 Connecticut Reactors Sell for $1.3 Billion
description: Dominion Resources said yesterday that it was buying two nuclear reactors at Millstone Point, near New London, Conn., for $1.3 billion, from Northeast Utilities. The buyers said the price was a record.

title: Strawberry Undergoes Operation For Cancer
description: For the second time in two years, Darryl Strawberry, the former Yankee slugger, underwent surgery yesterday to remove a cancerous tumor in his abdomen. The surgery marked the beginning of another and much tougher round in his fight against colon cancer, cancer experts said.

title: Gore's Choice for His Running Mate:Moderate Senator Who Scorned Clinton : Selecting Lieberman Is Seen as Bold Move; Religion May Be Issue
description: WASHINGTON  In a bold if not risk-free political stroke, Vice President Al Gore has selected Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate, making him the first Jewish candidate on a major-party presidential ticket.

title: A Crash Course On Classroom Struggle; Science and Math Specialists Learn Tips in Teacher Training Program
description: Gary Carlin hands out a sheet titled ''Teacher's Laboratory Guidelines.'' It is a kind of cheat sheet for new teachers. Like a cookbook, it walks them step by step through the teaching of a 40-minute high school science lab.

title: Both Parties Plan to Empty Wallets to Draw Voters to Polls
description: Both the Republican and Democratic Parties say they plan to spend record amounts of money on get-out-the-vote operations this fall, showing that both sides expect the battle for the White House and Congress to be so tight that slight changes in voter turnout could carry the day.

title: Nuclear Sites May Be Toxic In Perpetuity, Report Finds
description: Most of the sites where the federal government built nuclear bombs will never be cleaned up enough to allow public access to the land, and the plan for guarding sites that are permanently contaminated is inadequate, the National Academy of Sciences said today in a report.

title: A Big Push for Learning 'Differences,' Not Disabilities
description: Charles Schwab, the billionaire businessman who runs one of the world's most successful brokerage firms, is dyslexic. But, he insists, that does not mean he is disabled. ''I look at it as a difference,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, LEONA
description: ROBINSON-Leona (nee Lempert). Beloved wife of the late John Robinson. Loving mother of Michael and Elizabeth. Adored grandmother of Daniel and Sophia Heydebrand. Fond sister of Theresa Lempert. Services private.

title: Andersen Split Into Two Firms By Arbitrator
description: Ending one of corporate America's most bitter family feuds, an international arbitrator cleaved the world's largest consulting firm from the world's largest accounting firm yesterday.

title: Telephone Cables Are Targets of Vandals
description: Thousands of New Yorkers have lost their telephone service since early Sunday, as vandals slashed telephone cables in what the police department is investigating as possible acts of sabotage in support of a workers' strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, DAVID
description: ALEXANDER-David. Of Jerusalem, Israel, formerly of Brooklyn, New York, died on August 7th in Jerusalem. Beloved husband of Florence for 60 years. Loving father of Arthur, Kenny and Robyn. Cherished brother, grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be sorely missed.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: CITIGROUP AND WELLS FARGO IN NEW VENTURE
description: Electronic exchanges have been set up to let the corporate equivalent of day traders buy and sell everything from rolled steel to rolled bandages, but how can companies make sure that they get their orders delivered before the dealer in, say, Indonesia is paid? Well, banks have been solving such problems for centuries in the form of letters of credit, and yesterday, two big banks, Citigroup and Wells Fargo, announced a partnership to bring such services to Web-based commercial exchanges in conjunction with i2 Technologies, which makes industrial exchange software; Enron, the energy company that also runs data networks; and S1 Technologies, a banking software company. The venture, called FinancialSettlementMatrix.com, will offer electronic payments, short-term purchase loans and related transactions. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BIEMA, MARY
description: Van BIEMA-Mary (nee Epstein). Beloved wife of Gerhard, mother of David and Michael and grandmother of Joshua and Alex. She received an AB from Vassar College and MLS from Columbia University in Library Science, and was a Librarian at the Mannes College of Music for 15 years. She was an active member of the Tenafly New Jersey League of Women Voters. She loved music and words. We will miss her whimsy and playfulness, her curiosity and her caring. Memorial details will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, Development Office, Vassar College, Box 725, 124 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604, in Honor of Mary Van Biema.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, WILLIAM
description: COLE-William (Rossa). Died at home in Manhattan on August 2, of heart disease. Age 80. He spent his life among books which he loved, as editor, writer, poet, critic and publicist. He served in the U.S. Army in W.W.II. He was wounded in action overseas and worked on army publications. Bill was a charming, witty man, well known and well-liked. Twice married and divorced, he enjoyed the company of men and women alike. He was passionate about his Irish roots and drank his fair share of Irish whiskey. Survivors include his daughters, Cambria and Jeremy and his sons Williams and Rossa.

title: The Father of His Country Is an Impostor on a Coin
description: When Frank Wallis flips one coin, it is a quarter if it lands on heads and a dollar if it comes up tails.

title: Public Interests; High Noon at Gore Gap
description: My early years in journalism were spent searching for colorful things to say about Joseph Lieberman.

title: A Bold Move For Identity
description: After striving for more than a year to outrun President Clinton's restless shadow, Vice President Al Gore today made his boldest bid yet for autonomy.

title: Concorde Crash Draws Focus to Compensation
description: PARIS  Families of the victims of the Concorde jet that crashed outside Paris two weeks ago will this week receive initial compensation payments of 42,000 Deutsche marks to take care of "immediate needs."

title: From a Pea-Size Lump, Years of Uncertainty
description: One evening last summer, Jonah M. came to see me at my clinic. Because he had a walk-in appointment, I figured he had a minor problem -- maybe a sore throat, a sprained ankle -- that I could help him with right away. When he sat in my examination room, his face was flushed. ''I have a lump on my testicle,'' he announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, BENJAMIN M.
description: BANKS-Benjamin M., M.D. Dr. Benjamin M. Banks died on August 6, 2000, at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 93. He was predeceased by his wife Alice, to whom he was married for sixtynine years. He is survived by his children, Dr. Peter and Naomi Banks, and Joanne and Norman Matthews, his siblings Dr. Henry and Judy Banks, and Pearl and William Kaufman; and his grandchildren: Gary and Lisa Matthews, Drs. Jeffrey and Joan Matthews, Pam and Seth Farber, and Daniel Banks and Deborah Banks. He had 10 great-grandchildren: Craig, Scott, & Jake Matthews, Jonathan, David and Adam Matthews, and Allison, Andrew, Michael, and Matthew Farber. Dr. Banks was a distinguished physician, teacher, and researcher. A first generation American who grew up in Boston's North End, he was graduated from Harvard College (1926), cum laude and Junior Phi Beta Kappa and Harvard Medical School (1930). His post graduate training in Medicine was at Boston's Beth Israel Hospital and in Gastroenterology at the Mayo Clinic. In 1933 he began more than fifty years of medical practice in Gastroenterology in Boston & clinical teaching at Harvard Medical School. He volunteered for active duty in the Army Medical Corps nine months before Pearl Harbor. For 5 years, he served as Chief of Medicine at Walter Reed General Hospital in Washington, the Schick General Hospital in Clinton, Iowa, and the 142nd General Hospital in Calcutta, India. He achieved the rank of full Colonel and received the Legion of Merit award for his contribution to the care of military patients. By his example, he created an academic medical dynasty of which he was very proud. His son, Dr. Peter Banks, is Professor of Medicine at Harvard and Chief of Clinical Gastrointestinal Services at the Brigham and Women's Hospital; his grandson, Dr. Jeffrey Matthews is Associate Professor of Surgery at Harvard Medical School and Chief of the Division of General and Gastrointestinal Surgery at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center; and his brother Dr. Henry Banks is Dean Emeritus and Professor Emeritus of Orthopaedics at Tufts University School of Medicine. Dr. Banks was a member of the American Gastroenterological Association, the International Bockus Society. He was a Trustee of Temple Israel in Boston, Chairman of the Boston Chapter of the American Jewish Committee, and former Vice President of the Greater Boston Brandeis Club. In 1967, by appointment of Governor Volpe, he served as member of the Public Health Council of Massachusetts for five years. His funeral is at Temple Israel of Boston on Tuesday, August 8 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Peter A. Banks Education Fund, C/O Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: Venture Capital Investment Remains Steady
description: Even as the public stock markets cooled, the level of venture capital investment nationwide was little changed in the second quarter, the National Venture Capital Association reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JILER, MILTON W.
description: JILER-Milton W. On August 7, 2000, at age 92. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of John Jiler and father-in-law of Elizabeth Hovey. Grandfather of Jacob and Stella. Dear brother of William, Lillian, Helen and Peggy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, 7-9 PM with service Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Hive Sweet Hive

title: FAST TRACK FOR CANCER DRUG
description: A Princeton, N.J., biotechnology company, Medarex, said it had begun clinical trials of a drug to treat prostate cancer only 12 months after identifying the target in the body on which the drug will act. It usually takes several years to formulate a drug and test it on animals before starting trials in people. Medarex's unusual speed stems from its use of genetically altered mice that can produce human antibodies in as little as two to three months. The antibody, which then is tested in animals, is used as the drug. Shares of Medarex rose $5.94, to $88.31. Andrew Pollack

title: COMCAST TO BUY BACK $500 MILLION OF ITS STOCK
description: The Comcast Corporation, the country's third-largest cable provider, said yesterday that it would buy back up to $500 million of its stock. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 1.6 percent of Comcast's stock outstanding. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Shares of Comcast, which is based in Philadelphia and had $6.2 billion in revenue last year, were down 68.75 cents at $32.375 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Yanks Go From Civil to Cranky to Surly
description: Seattle Manager Lou Piniella stepped from the visitors' dugout before the national anthem yesterday, made eye contact with his counterpart across the field and dramatically doffed his cap and bent a knee in respectful tribute. Yankee Manager Joe Torre and his staff responded in kind.

title: Logging's Shift South Brings Concern on Oversight
description: In a major shift, timber companies have stepped up logging operations in the South, where they face less regulation than in the carefully monitored forests of the Pacific Northwest.

title: Gore and Lieberman Make Tolerance the Centerpiece
description: Determined to transform a potential liability into a defining asset, Vice President Al Gore today formally introduced Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut as his Democratic running mate and portrayed his selection of Mr. Lieberman, an Orthodox Jew, as a measure of his devotion to tolerance and his willingness to break barriers.

title: Ethical Politics, And Intellectual
description: To the Editor:

title: To Speak With One's Own Voice
description: In the midst of World War II, when my Uncle Seymour was about to have his bar mitzvah, my grandmother went to the rabbi of their Bronx synagogue with a request. At the climax of the ceremony, when Seymour would march through the sanctuary bearing the Torah scrolls, the rabbi should follow, holding aloft a portrait of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: States and Cities Flout Law On Underground Fuel Tanks
description: While private industry spent millions to meet a 1998 federal deadline to upgrade leaking underground fuel tanks -- the nation's leading cause of ground water pollution -- state and local government agencies continue to operate thousands of antiquated tanks in danger of leaking chemicals into water supplies, records show.

title: BID FOR NORWEGIAN COMPANY
description: The British-Norwegian construction and engineering company Kvaerner made a $506 million offer for the Norwegian oil-services company Aker Maritime to build its oil and gas business abroad. The new combined oil and gas unit would have annual sales of about $2.5 billion and about 21,000 employees in 40 countries, Kvaerner said. Kvaerner bid 0.79 of a share for each Aker share, or 94.8 kronor based on Friday's closing price. The bid ended weeks of speculation about the companies after Aker Maritime took a surprise 26.4 percent stake in Kvaerner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDELL, HENRY
description: WENDELL-Henry. On August 5, 2000 of Manhasset, NY at the age of 73. Loving husband of Shirley. Caring father of Terry Wendell, Caron Wendell (Chester), Jack Waterman (Jodie) and Joanne Bergstrom (Bob). Dear brother of Marshall (Nancy). Devoted grandfather. Services were held Sunday.

title: British Airways Reports 65% Drop in its Earnings
description: British Airways reported a 65 percent decline in quarterly earnings today, attributing the poor performance to the effects of the strong British pound and the rising price of jet fuel.

title: DOW CHEMICAL TO EXPAND U.S. MANUFACTURING
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it planned to spend more than $325 million to build a United States plant and expand another to increase its production of a chemical used to make insulation and padding. Dow, the No. 2 United States chemical maker, said it would build a new plant somewhere in the United States Gulf Coast region and expand a plant in La Porte, Tex., to increase its production of the chemical by more than 50 percent by 2004. Expansion of the Texas plant will begin this year, while selection of a site and construction on the new plant will take place next year. Dow said the expansions were needed to keep up with its demand for polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanate, which is used for a number of industrial products.

title: To Many Social Conservatives, an Ally
description: In Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Vice President Al Gore has managed to choose as his running mate an Orthodox Jew whom many Christians, and especially conservative evangelicals, regard as an ally on a number of social and moral issues.

title: Headaches, With and Without the Pain
description: A headache without the head pain might sound contradictory, but the condition, described in a new journal article, could lend insights into an ailment known as the cluster headache.

title: In Exchange of Fire, Suspect Is Shot Outside Plaza Hotel
description: A burglary suspect pulled a gun on security guards in an elevator of the Plaza Hotel last night, then ran out across Fifth Avenue firing at them until one shot him in the arm, the police said.

title: Sharing the Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: French Outpost at New Hotel
description: This October, Ian Schrager will open his fourth New York hotel, the Hudson, on the western fringes of Midtown, which will distinguish itself from his other odes to permanent midnight with cut-rate rooms starting at $95 a night. The 1,000-room hotel will feature shopping, too. Mr. Schrager said last week that he had signed a deal for the first New York store operated by the owners of Colette, the Parisian boutique that puts Jeremy Scott T-shirts, Fendi skirts and odd paper products in congress with fashion editors and hordes of young Japanese tourists.

title: The Big City; The Negatives Of Recycling In New York
description: DURING the 1990's, defenders of the city's costly recycling program deflected criticism with a mantra: just wait until Fresh Kills closes. Once the city lost that cheap place to dump trash, they predicted, recycling would become the most practical alternative.

title: RECORD HIGH TAIWAN EXPORTS
description: Taiwan's exports surged in July to a record as global demand for the island's electronics products showed no signs of abating. The government said exports rose 36.5 percent in July, to $13.6 billion, while imports rose 41.9 percent, to $13.5 billion. Taiwan's trade surplus fell to $125 million in the month from $467.3 million.

title: Oakland Joins the Bay Area Boom
description: The construction cranes and cement trucks are taking over the downtown here, like the artillery of a conquering army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, THELMA
description: HERTZ-Thelma. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Elinor Ceresney and Martin Hertz, Mother-in-law of Ian Ceresney and Ellen Hertz. Grandmother of Brian and Allison and Adam and Tracey Hertz, Dr. Cynthia and Jonathan Cohen, Andrew and Rachel and Margo Ceresney. Great-grandmother of Yael, Sarah, Stephanie, Morgan and Daniel. Sister of Martha Wolkoff.

title: City Issues Slate of Safety Rules for Large Parades
description: City Hall officials yesterday issued a set of safety rules for large parades in response to accidents that killed three revelers at last year's West Indian American Carnival parade.

title: NYT Article
description: Palm Introduces New Models

title: A Common Syndrome Seldom Discussed
description: Jean's problem started in high school, with repeated bouts of abdominal cramps, a perpetual bloated feeling and the need to visit the bathroom dozens of times a day for long periods at a time but without much relief. Now through college, married and working, Jean has to get up hours ahead to get in enough bathroom time for her chronically constipated bowel before she goes to work.

title: Women Lifting Lids on Life, and What They Find
description: There is more than a little merriment in two one-act plays about the deaths of parents, combined under the title ''She Keeps Time,'' and none of it is gallows humor. Allison Eve Zell's ''Come to Leave'' and ''Pickling'' by Suzan-Lori Parks were written independently and with different intentions, but bringing them together in a staging by Scenic Route Productions and the Queen's Company, with both plays directed by Ms. Zell, creates resonances that make you notice details in both that might be missed in separate performances.

title: Vetoing Press Freedom in Iran
description: In every recent election, Iranians have overwhelmingly voted for politicians who promise to loosen theocratic controls and establish the rule of law. But hopes for seeing that reform agenda enacted into law diminished on Sunday when Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, forbade Parliament to revise a restrictive press law. By thwarting the elected Parliament, Mr. Khamenei mocks democratic principles and invites more radical challenges to clerical rule in the future.

title: A Quest for Better Vision: Spectacles Over the Centuries
description: The first eyeglasses were made by medieval monks who carved bits of quartz into magnifying glasses, riveted them together and perched them on their noses to magnify the tiny handwriting of manuscripts, historians say.

title: SFX Entertainment Acquires Cotter
description: SFX Entertainment Inc., the No. 1 producer of concerts and live events, has purchased the Cotter Group, a motor sports marketing and public relations firm. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: HIGHER CIGARETTE TAXES URGED
description: Raising taxes on cigarettes is key to reducing smoking, especially among the poor, the young and the poorly educated, according to a report by the World Bank and the World Health Organization on the economic aspects of tobacco. Raising taxes on tobacco does not cause job losses or increased smuggling, according to the three-year 5,120-page study by 40 economists and other specialists. The study calculated that a 10 percent increase in cigarette prices would lead 42 million people to quit smoking and prevent about 10 million tobacco-related deaths. Gro Harlem Brundtland, head of the W.H.O., has been seeking a global treaty limiting tobacco advertising and marketing. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Big Apple Circus Cries Foul at Ringling's New Holiday Show
description: And now, ladies and gentlemen and children of all ages, direct your attention to the stupendous holiday war between two big-top circuses.

title: AMETEK BUYS PRESTOLITE'S BATTERY AND MOTOR UNITS
description: Ametek Inc., a maker of parts for appliances and electrical motors, said yesterday that it had bought the Prestolite Electric Inc. units that make switches, industrial battery chargers and direct-current motors for $60 million in cash. The purchase will help Ametek move beyond selling motors for floor-care, technical and other applications. The Prestolite businesses being acquired had 1999 sales of $71 million and employ more than 500 people worldwide, Ametek said. The shares of Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., which had sales of $925 million last year, rose 37.5 cents, to $21.1875.

title: Those Shocking Electric Bills
description: Many New Yorkers stared at their electric bills this month in confusion and disbelief. The cost of electricity distributed by Consolidated Edison in June went up about 40 percent over last year. July's bills are expected to be 30 percent higher than a year ago -- all despite a summer so temperate that even fans cooled lazily on their lowest speed.

title: Affordable Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISWOLD, MERTON L.
description: GRISWOLD-Merton L., Jr., M.D., ninety-five, of Plainfield, NJ, died on Sunday, August 6, 2000 at his home. Born in Uxbridge, Massachusetts, September 25, 1904. Received his BA from Amherst College in Massachusetts in 1925, his M.D. from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1929. Captain in the Army Medical Corps 1942-'45 in the South Pacific. Plastic surgeon on medical staff of Muhlenberg 1945-1987. President of New Jersey Symphony Orchestra 1987-1993. Amateur violinist and photographer. Survived by his wife Mary Victoria (Stevens) Griswold; children Victoria of Plainfield and Ann of London and Peter of Nutley, NJ. Also surviving are two grandchildren Germaine Griswold, and Keith Griswold. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, August 11, 2000 at 11:00 AM at the Unitarian Church of Plainfield, 724 Park Ave. Donations in his memory may be sent to: New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, 2 Central Ave, Newark, NJ 07102, or The Plainfield Foundation, 209 West 2nd Street, Plainfield, NJ 07060 or The Muhlenberg Foundation, Randolph Road & Park Ave, Plainfield, New Jersey 07061. For further information, contact Higgins Home for Funerals, 908-756-0017.

title: Like Rival, Lazio Follows Money Trail Out of State
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate candidate who emphasizes his New York roots and longtime residency as a characteristic distinguishing him from his opponent, the first lady, has confronted a political reality. The votes may come from New York, but a lot of cash for the race may lie in places like Denver, Cincinnati and Dearborn, Mich.

title: Not Your Average Joe
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: No Headline
description: Sister M. Isolina Ferre, a Catholic nun from a wealthy family in Puerto Rico who was awarded the Medal of Freedom by President Clinton last August for over half a century of charity and peacemaking, died on Thursday in her native city of Ponce. She was 85.

title: An Ally of Big Business Balances a Friend of the Earth
description: At a Democratic fund-raiser last month at the Upper West Side duplex apartment of the singer Paul Simon, Vice President Al Gore was introduced by Connecticut's senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman.

title: Swimmers Finding Comfort In a Different Kind of Skin
description: When the United States Olympic trials begin here Wednesday, swimmers will make as much news for what they are wearing as for what records they may set in qualifying for the Summer Games next month in Sydney, Australia.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: In Upstate New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The front-page Man in the News article and a thumbnail biography yesterday about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman misspelled his middle name and the surname of his first wife. His middle name is Isadore, not Isador. His wife was Elizabeth Haas, not Hass.

title: CUBIST WILL PURCHASE CANADIAN BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY
description: Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a privately held Canadian biotechnology company, TerraGen Discovery Inc., for about $31 million in stock. Cubist said it would issue 608,000 shares in exchange for all outstanding shares of TerraGen. It hopes that TerraGen's strengths in antimicrobial drug discovery and its expertise in small-molecule drugs from natural products will enhance Cubist's own drug development efforts. Cubist, based in Cambridge, Mass., develops anti-microbial drugs to combat serious bacterial and fungal infections that have become resistant to current treatments. Shares of the company rose $1.42, to $52.17.

title: Lieberman, My Ally
description: I have often been asked how it is that Joe Lieberman and I are frequent allies in the Senate. We wrote, along with former Senator Dan Coats, legislation to provide vouchers to disadvantaged children in the public schools of the District of Columbia. We have repeatedly joined in calling on Hollywood to stop producing vulgar and violent entertainment. We cosponsored a law providing humanitarian help to religious groups being persecuted in southern Sudan. Away from Capitol Hill, we are honorary co-chairmen of the Healthy Culture Initiative, which promotes charities and social projects -- including those that are faith-based -- in local communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HAROLD
description: LEVINE-Harold. Mr. Levine was born in New York City, N.Y. to Jacob Levine and Dora Weinstein Levine. He was a member of Boynton Beach Kiwanis Club and a veteran of the United States Army having served during World War II. He had worked in sales with Acker & Jablow Textile, Inc. of New York. Survivors are wife Harriet Simon Levine, of the home, daughter & husband Donna L. & Dr. Mark T. Shapiro, of Greensboro, son & wife Jay Robert & Debra Levine, of New York, grandchildren Brett Simon Shapiro, Randall Sigmond Shapiro, both of Greensboro, Fallon Deidre Levine, of New York City, N.Y. Graveside service at Mt Ararat Cemetery will be held 2pm today. In lieu of flowers memorials can be made to Hospice of Greensboro 2500 Summit Ave. Greensboro, NC, 27405.

title: Police Seek Worker in Slaying At a Nursing Home in Queens
description: A 40-year-old man on the housekeeping staff of a state-owned nursing home in Queens shot and killed his supervisor in her basement office yesterday, the police said.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARVIN, JOHN T.
description: MARVIN-John T. Of Manhattan, died suddenly Tuesday morning at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was 70. Born and raised in New Haven, John Marvin graduated with the highest honors from Taft School and Yale University, Class of 1950. He earned a Master's Degree at Stanford University and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific. After the Navy, he lived and worked in New York City. He was a Senior Vice President and money manager at Schroder & Co. He was the beloved husband of Leslie M. Marvin and beloved father of three children Alexander (Carey) Marvin of Longwood, FL, Melissa E. Laico of Warwick, NY, and Christopher Marvin of Weston, CT. He was cherished by his two step-children Anne S. Van Derzee and Jefferson M. Van Derzee. There will be a memorial service to celebrate John's life at 4:30 PM, Thursday, August 10 at St. Jane's Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. & 71 St.

title: Chocoholics, Beware: Extreme Temptation Ahead
description: At the new branch of La Maison du Chocolat in Rockefeller Center, they don't call the confection at left a candy bar. But how else do you define a large portion of chocolate filled with white coconut? At the store, 30 Rockefeller Plaza (on 49th Street), this curiously American style treat reveals its Parisian roots. Called a bouchee, it is made of superb bittersweet chocolate filled with fresh coconut, which is embedded in a white chocolate and vanilla ganache. La Maison recommends eating it with a fork, which is how it is served in the store's cafe. But fingers do the job just fine. La Maison du Chocolat, which has another store at 1018 Madison Avenue (78th Street), sells bouchees ($4.25 each) in other shapes, with pistachio, nougat, raisin and milk chocolate fillings. But the coconut gets my vote.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOODRUFF, STAN
description: WOODRUFF-Stan. August 9, 1996. Always in our hearts and mindsYou will never be forgotten. Your loving famil

title: Thanks, Waiter, I'll Bone It Myself
description: Whole fish cooked on the bone is moister than a fillet, and the bones do enhance the flavor. But most people who order a whole fish in a restaurant ask the waiter to bone it. Too often, the fish comes back after some minutes, almost cold. It is quicker to do the job yourself, and easier than you might think. Cut a long slit the length of the fish about half an inch from the top, or dorsal, edge. Make another slit perpendicular to the first just before the head, and a third at the tail. You can then lift off the top fillet, and after that lift off the head and bones. And there you have it, ready to eat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DAVE
description: GOLDBERG-Dave. Died August 6 at his home in Tamarac, FL. He was 87 years old. He was a pioneer in the swimwear industry in the 1950s, and the company bearing his name is still one of the leading swimwear firms in the country. The many licenses the company had over the years included Coca Cola Girls, Gottex Girls, Sasson, and currently Monte Carlo Beach Club, Beach Scene and Bay 1. He was a past president of the Industrial Association of Juvenile Apparel Manufacturers and, in addition to the many charitable organizations he supported, several years ago he was honored by UJA as the swimwear industry's ''Man of the Year''. He had an indomitable spirit and inspiring vision, and he had the respect of all who knew him. He will be sorely missed and will live on in the hearts of all whose lives he touched. He is survived by his wife, Rose, his brother Irving, his daughter Marilyn and her husband Richard, his son Allen and his wife Patty, and by his four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A graveside ceremony will be held at Cedar Park-Bethel Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey, 201261-7878, at 11:00 AM on Tuesday, August 8. The family will sit at the home of Marilyn and Richard Dickstein, Muttontown, NY on Tuesday and Wednesday, August 8 and 9. Contributions may be made to the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America, 8800 Venice Blvd, Los Angeles, CA. 90034.

title: Productivity of Workers Rose At 5.3% Rate in 2nd Quarter
description: The productivity of American workers increased sharply in the second quarter, pushing labor costs down, the government said yesterday. The report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates later this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, ROSLYN
description: ORENSTEIN-Roslyn. On August 7, 2000, at age 67. Beloved wife of Israel Orenstein, devoted mother to Dr. Hadassah and Shira, and mother-in-law to Dr. Eddy Barth, & Daniel Kahn, loving grandmother to Amitai, Yoav, Talya, Yael, Naomi, Kayla, Zoe, Aliza, and Lielle. Dear sister of Abraham Shapiro, and Sheila Schneider. Funeral services on Wednesday at 1 PM at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Ctr, L.I.

title: Indonesian Leader Turns Over Daily Tasks to Vice President
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 9  Battered by a hostile parliament for his haphazard managment style, President Abdurrahman Wahid said today he would hand over daily government administration to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri.

title: The Liberty Clinches Home Court in Playoffs
description: The Liberty claimed its second straight Eastern Conference title last night with a 57-44 victory over the Cleveland Rockers before 18,663 frenzied fans at Madison Square Garden. But you would not have known it by the atmosphere in the locker room after the game. No music was playing and no one was celebrating; the players quietly patted their teammates' backs for a job well done.

title: From Out of a Pit, the Essence of Almond
description: IT is the perfect dessert for someone who likes to fool guests. It looks like ordinary ice cream, the color of butter, with the flavor of almonds.

title: Earnings Surge At BP Amoco
description: BP Amoco P.L.C., the third-biggest publicly held oil company, said profit in the second quarter more than doubled because of rising oil and natural gas prices, takeovers and lower costs.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After Andersen War, Accountants Think Hard About Consulting
description: Now that the Andersens are finally splitsville, are accountants going to forsake everything but the single life, limiting themselves to poring over a company's books and offering tax advice?

title: Tapenade, A Stand-In For Basil
description: LIKE pesto, tapenade is an all-purpose sauce based on a single pungent ingredient. The Provencal olive paste can be used as a dip for raw vegetables, a spread for bread or a flavorful partner for anything from grilled shrimp or fish to chicken. I especially like to add it for heft and taste to an easy salad of tomato, basil and mozzarella. And then the salad itself can be taken to another level by spooning it onto grilled bread to make a quick bruschetta or even onto pasta as an uncooked sauce.

title: Just in Case You Thought Having Rock Star Parents Would Be Totally Spank
description: For several reasons, ''Live Through This,'' the dramatic series that has its premiere tonight on MTV, ought to come with a sort of reverse parental advisory. Something like ''May not be suitable for viewing by people who were at or near the original Woodstock.''

title: Michael Meyer, 79, Dies; Ibsen and Strindberg Translator and Scholar
description: Michael Meyer, whose translations of the plays of Ibsen and Strindberg are performed throughout the English-speaking world and who wrote monumental biographies of both Scandinavian playwrights, died on Thursday. He was 79 and lived in London.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHMALER, ERIC J.
description: SCHMALER-Eric J. When you left us one year ago you changed our lives forever. We all love and miss you.

title: World Tour For a Diva Long Banned From Singing
description: In Pacific Coliseum sports stadium, the Iranian pop diva Googoosh was about to begin her second public performance in more than 20 years. Dressed in an elegant simple blue silk dress reminiscent of her days as a Tehran cabaret star, and encircled by replica pillars from the ancient Persian site of Persepolis, she paused reflectively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLENBACH, JOSEPH R.
description: KALLENBACH-Joseph R. On August 6th, 2000. Survived by one sister, Phyllis Clark of Charlotte, N.C., thirteen nieces and nephews, two very close friends, Stephen King and Paula LiBasci, and his wonderful poodle Gigi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRA, FRANK
description: MARRA-Frank The officers, sales associates and employees of The William B. May Company offer our deepest sympathy to our president and friend Peter R.Marra on the loss of his father. We also extend our heartfelt condolences to Peter's mother, Eleanor, and his entire family. May you find comfort in recalling treasured memories.

title: Bell's Big Night to Remember
description: For seven years, Derek Bell came to Shea Stadium as a visiting player and tried to ignore the swirl of excitement around him. He wasted no time adapting when he became a Met in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHMAN, REBECCA
description: ROHMAN-Rebecca. On August 7, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Mother of Linda, step-mother of Michael, sister of Belle Tarlow, aunt of Victoria DeBruin. Will always be remembered.

title: Iran's Conservative Press Court Claims New Victim
description: TEHRAN  Iran's conservative leadership on Tuesday closed the country's last major progressive newspaper, just days after the supreme leader, Ayatollah Sayed Ali Khamenei, declared that the progressive press threatened the national interest.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sales at Cisco Systems Increase 61% in Quarter

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2000080990697604677 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: End of a Malaysian Drama, and Very Likely of a Career
description: The widely expected sodomy conviction of Malaysia's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, which was announced early today, could snuff out the career of a charismatic leader who was seen as one of the rising stars in Asian politics.

title: SYMBIAN OFFERING PLANNED
description: Europe's biggest hand-held computer maker, Psion P.L.C., said it planned a public offering of Symbian Ltd., an alliance Psion created with mobile phone makers to develop its operating system for wireless devices. Psion's partners are Ericsson of Sweden, Nokia of Finland, the Motorola Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan. Psion said shares of Symbian, valued at up to $8 billion, would be sold once its software had begun to sell in volume. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: In Selecting a No. 2, No Detail Too Small
description: In the days before George W. Bush announced his selection of Dick Cheney as his running mate, Vice President Al Gore and his advisers sensed an unexpected opportunity. Aboard Air Force II and in Mr. Gore's campaign headquarters here, there was a consensus that Mr. Bush and his aides had bungled their selection process, that the Republicans had come across as leak-prone, rushed and uncharacteristically amateurish.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTVACO CORP., New York, a paper and packaging company, said it bought the closely held DuBois Holdings Ltd., a European maker of plastic holders for digital video discs. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Flush With Cash, New York Gets Highest Credit Rating in 9 Years
description: New York City's credit rating was upgraded yesterday by Moody's Investors Service to its highest level in nine years, a change that officials estimated could save the city several million dollars.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I feel like it's a power suit when I put it on; I feel like a superhero a little.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, MARY TAKAMI (NEE HUNT)
description: O'CONNOR-Mary Takami (nee Hunt). On August 6. Cherished mother of Kathleen Takami Mangano and Mimi Takami, loving daughter of Roderick V. Hunt, devoted sister of Alice Rosanes, Roderick T., Michael and Joseph Hunt, beloved Nana of Matteo, Yoshi and Blue. Visitation is on Wednesday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9:30 PM at Bernard F. Dowd, Inc. Funeral Home, 165-20 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, NY 11432. Mass of the Resurrection, Thursday, 9:30 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, Jamaica, NY. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth, New York.

title: Cisco Sales Rise 61% in Quarter as Company Continues to Gain From Internet Growth
description: Cisco Systems Inc. reported a 61 percent gain in sales for its fiscal fourth quarter today, as the company continued to be the leading supplier of the necessary hardware for the build-up of the Internet. It was the company's 10th consecutive quarter of accelerating year-over-year revenue growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLACZKIN, BEATE
description: KLACZKIN-Beate. Beloved friend and ''sister'' to Edith Reich and adored ''aunt'' to Merrill, Lewis and Marion. Graveside service at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, Queens, at 1 P.M., on Wednesday.

title: Gore and Running Mate Hail 'Common Ideals'
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Al Gore warmly introduced his running mate Tuesday in Tennessee, saying Senator Joseph Lieberman, as the first Jew on a U.S. major-party presidential ticket, offered Americans an opportunity "to tear down a mighty wall of division."

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot
description: An off-duty police officer with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was shot in the back last night in Queens near Flushing Meadow Park, the agency said.

title: Decisions on Running Mates Rarely Prove Decisive
description: Vice President Al Gore's selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate on Monday, the frenzy of speculation that preceded it and the outpouring of analysis that has followed it raise a number of insistent questions.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro dropped after economic reports bolstered the view that foreign investors will continue to invest in United States assets. In New York, the euro settled at 90.20 cents, down from 90.84 cents.

title: A 70's Musical Revival Sheds Flower Children But Keeps the Faith
description: The hippies are gone, and so is Jesus' Superman jersey (it's been replaced by a white T-shirt with a sunlike emblem on it), but ''Godspell,'' in its newest incarnation at the Theater at Saint Peter's Church in Midtown, still has the giddy rapture that made it a hit both off Broadway and on in the 1970's.

title: The Little Museum That Could; Dahesh Tries to Shake Founder's Mystical Image and Move Into the Mainstream
description: When the mystical Lebanese writer Salim Moussa Achi died in 1984 at age 75, he left an eclectic legacy of unfashionable art and devoted disciples who told tales of his miraculous powers to ''cleanse'' leprosy or pluck a live bird from a painting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOWITZ, SYLVIA
description: DANOWITZ-Sylvia. February 1, 1896 to August 3, 2000. Dear mother, grandmother, great grandmother. Rest.

title: Mercata Wins Patent on Buying Technology
description: Mercata Wins Patent on Buying Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERICKSON, MAUREEN MULLER
description: ERICKSON-Maureen Muller. A resident of Croton-on-Hudson, NY. died at her residence, on August 8, 2000. She was a partner in Muller Assoc. a real estate development and management Co. in Croton. She was a graduate of Marymount College in 1960. She is survived by her mother Eileen Muller and her brother Stewart Muller. Funeral Mass will be held Friday at 10 AM at St. Augustines Church in Ossining. Visiting hours on Thursday 7-9PM only at The Church. For further information Edward F. Carter Funeral Home in Croton, New York.

title: An Oil to Make Scallops Gallop
description: It takes only a few drops of grilled almond oil from Huileries de Lapalisse in France to give seared sea scallops, grilled chicken salad, slices of ripe pear or a piece of aged pecorino cheese a touch of extraordinary flavor and aroma. The oil is a condiment and is meant to add a finishing touch, much like Asian toasted sesame oil. It costs $6.49 for a 250-milliliter bottle (almost nine ounces) at Fairway markets.

title: ALTAVISTA TO SELL ITS OWN ADS
description: AltaVista said yesterday that it would take over sales of advertising on its site in the United States from DoubleClick. AltaVista, which used to be DoubleClick's largest customer, began selling ads itself last year to customers in the United States and now sells them on about 800 Web sites that also advertise on AltaVista.com. DoubleClick shares fell $3.8125, or 9.9 percent, to $34.8125.

title: Fair Disclosure on Wall Street
description: Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has fought consistently to strip Wall Street insiders of ill-gotten advantage. His latest target is ''selective disclosure'' -- release by corporate executives of important financial information to a select group of securities analysts or institutional investors. Those warned, for example, of falling earnings can rush out and advise their clients to sell shares. By the time ordinary investors hear the bad news, the stock price has already sunk.

title: Stock Option Splitsville
description: In just the last decade, stock options have gone from being icing on the cake in many executive pay packages to being the cake itself. The Internet revolution alone has created an army of overnight millionaires, and the number of Americans holding at least some options has soared to an estimated 10 million today from 1 million in 1992.

title: Sports of The Times; The Shot Heard Round The League
description: THE old pro may never do anything as spectacular in the rest of her career, but Teresa Weatherspoon will always have The Shot.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM RISES. Palladium prices rose on concern that Russia, the world's largest producer, would not be able to meet strong demand. In New York, palladium for September delivery jumped $33.60, to $772 an ounce.

title: IMC GLOBAL SAYS IT WON'T SELL UNITS UNLESS BIDS IMPROVE
description: IMC Global Inc., the world's third-biggest salt producer, said yesterday that the bids for its salt and chemicals units had not been as high as expected and it indicated it might abandon plans to sell if it does not get higher offers. The company said it might be difficult to get more than $1 billion in net proceeds from selling the businesses. IMC, based in Northbrook, Ill., is still talking with potential buyers and still favors selling the assets, although a final decision will depend on price, the company's chief executive, Douglas Pertz, said. IMC's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $14.6875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Charter School Begins: Sisulu and the Gladiator
description: AS school districts from New York City to Dallas to Inkster, Mich., experiment with handing over the worst schools to private managers in a last-ditch effort to save them, the experience of the Sisulu Children's Academy in Harlem may offer some insight into how well this new tactic will work.

title: NBC's Online Unit to Lay Off 20 Percent of Its Employees
description: NBC Internet, the online affiliate of the NBC television network, said yesterday that it would lay off 170 people, some 20 percent of its total work force of 850.

title: Article 2000080991797849831 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITTAY, EVELYN
description: KITTAY-Evelyn. Of Lauderhill, FL. on August 8, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother, grandmother, aunt, cousin, and wonderful friend to many. Graveside services will be held at New Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ, on Thursday, August 10 at 11:00 AM. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: BASF PROFITS SURGE
description: Europe's biggest chemical company, BASF A.G. of Germany, posted a strong rise in second-quarter profit, but its failure to raise its full-year forecast and higher-than-expected revamping costs caused its stock to drop. BASF said quarterly profit quadrupled from a year earlier, to 448 million euros ($407 million), driven by a strong recovery in chemical volumes and prices in major markets. Sales rose 24 percent, to 8.97 billion euros. The company is investing heavily in Asia, where the economy is recovering.

title: Inadequate Gun Data
description: To the Editor:

title: $25 and Under; Driver, Follow That Cab (for Some Fine Indian Fare)
description: A GREAT urban myth is that cabdrivers know the best places to eat. Well, guess what: It's no myth, at least when it comes to northern Indian and Pakistani cabby hangouts, where I've had some very exciting meals in the last few weeks.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: ROCKLAND COUNTY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIOLO, WALTER A.
description: MAGGIOLO-Walter A. On Monday, August 7, 2000, of Arlington, VA. Surviving are cousins and a host of friends. Mr. Maggiolo was a Mediator, Arbitrator and Educator, having retired from the Federal Mediation Consiliation Service. Friends may call at The Murphy Funeral Home of Arlington, 4510 Wilson Blvd., on Thursday, from 2 to 4:00PM and 7 to 9:00PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:00AM, Friday, in St. Ann's Catholic Church, 5300 North 10th Street, Arlington, VA. Interment National Memorial Park.

title: FirstEnergy Acquires GPU in $4.5 Billion Cash-Stock Deal
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation, an Ohio-based utility company, agreed yesterday to acquire GPU Inc. of Morristown, N.J., for $4.5 billion in cash and stock.

title: On the Trail of Truants, and Their Social Problems
description: Dorothy Onyango, a New York City attendance teacher with a distinct pigeon-toed gait, trudged past two addicts and up the stairs of an apartment building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, to call on a 13-year-old truant who had missed six days of summer school.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Pinochet Ruled No Longer Immune From Prosecution
description: The Chilean Supreme Court issued its ruling today to divest Gen. Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity, removing a giant legal hurdle to charging the former dictator with involvement in the kidnapping, torture and murder of thousands of people during his 17-year rule.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry on Auditor Role
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether PricewaterhouseCoopers, the auditing firm, acted properly in auditing the books of a real estate investment trust while it was helping the firm complete a number of acquisitions.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day on July 24 about an announcement by the technology entrepreneur James H. Clark that he had bought a million shares of Microsoft stock referred imprecisely to a comment made about him later, at the same industry conference, by the venture capitalist John Doerr. Mr. Doerr's speech described two categories of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs -- missionaries and mercenaries. It was in response to a question from the moderator that Mr. Doerr said Mr. Clark would probably consider himself a mercenary; Mr. Doerr did not characterize Mr. Clark that way unprompted.

title: The Volatile Post-Convention Bounce
description: The country is now in a period of polling instability that occurs every four years just before, during, and just after the two political party nominating conventions.

title: Newark Gives Travel Agents a Peek at the Future of Tourism
description: This is not a place that immediately leaps to mind when people think of tourism destinations.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Oxnard and San Luis Obispo, Calif.

title: After Some Adjustments, Angelic Sound
description: The Choir of King's College, Cambridge, traces its charter back to 1441, when Henry VI founded the college and let it be known that he wanted a student choir to sing the daily services in his chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKWOOD, HENRIETTA
description: LOCKWOOD - Henrietta Ellery Sedgwick from Bedford, New York, died August 4, 2000 in her 94th year. She was an honorable member of the New York Botanical Garden, vice-president of the Garden Conservancy and former vice-president of the New York Horticultural Society. She was also a founding member of the Rare Plant Group of the Garden Club of America. Gardening was her lifetime passion and her beautiful interesting garden was often open to benefit public organizations. Small but mighty she was a ceaseless inspiration to the many friends and family she leaves behind. She was predeceased by her husband, John E. Lockwood, whose career spanned from working with Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes to becoming senior partner of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy and legal counsel to John D. Rockefeller and his family. Both Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood were very involved with the school of American Ballet, of which Mr. Lockwood was chairman. Funeral services will be announced.

title: Little Change for Russian Business, Putin Promises Aside
description: The government's recent campaign to intimidate some of this nation's most powerful business leaders is meant at least in part to show them that President Vladimir V. Putin is firmly in control. But beneath the surface, executives say, it is business as usual in Russia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the former leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, who is a fugitive from arrest for war crimes, misidentified the organization that controls the peacekeeping force that is seeking him in Bosnia. It is NATO, not the United Nations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 1 about laser eye surgery misstated the title of an optometrist who often handles the patient care before and after Lasik surgery. He is Dr. Arkady Selenow, not Mr.

title: Fury of a Volunteer Firefighter Scorned
description: They light the fireworks on the Fourth of July. They pull people out of burning buildings. They teach children not to play with matches. By one estimate, they save taxpayers $37 billion a year.

title: A Charmer Who Became a Senator
description: As much of the nation gets its first glimpse of Joseph I. Lieberman, back in Connecticut, friends and family members have spent the last 48 hours recalling a different sort of Joe: The talentless Little League outfielder, the magnetic high school prom king, the shrewd college newspaper editor and the ambitious young campaigner.

title: Untraded, Soriano Carries On
description: Alfonso Soriano has played his own personal game of Survivor this summer. Every time the Yankees called a tribal council to discuss trades for a major league player, it seemed Soriano's name was being written on slips of paper. Whether it was in talks for Juan Gonzalez, Sammy Sosa, Denny Neagle or Rondell White, it was Soriano that the other team wanted included in the deal.

title: Walk in the Woods Moves Sides Closer to a Deal on Friars' Land
description: A dispute between a friary and the federal government over an 18-acre parcel of forest in Garrison, N.Y., is on its way to resolution after the parties were brought together to discuss their differences on a hike.

title: Oregon Steps Out of California's Shadow
description: EVERY few years, I like to come here to the Willamette Valley to check up on the Oregon wine business.

title: McCaffrey Voices Confidence in Mexico's Anti-Drug Efforts
description: In one of his last official visits here as the United States director of drug policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, praised the transition team of President-elect Vicente Fox and said he shared Mr. Fox's opposition to the American drug-certification program.

title: Clinton Visits Idaho Site To Give Thanks and Aid
description: From above, the scene resembled a war zone: pillars of smoke, flashes of fire and vast expanses of charred remains.

title: Curtain Up on Two Crisp Characters
description: CRISPNESS and portability rarely go together in hot food. But Thalia Kitchen, the new takeout arm of Thalia, in the theater district, contributes two excellent additions to the carryout repertory. Both dishes can also be eaten at Thalia's bar.

title: Computer Science Departments Are Depleted as More Professors Test Entrepreneurial Waters
description: August 9, 2000

title: Dr. Michael Burnhill, 72; Led in Women's Care
description: Dr. Michael Seth Burnhill, a leader in women's health care, family planning and reproductive health, died Friday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 72 and lived in Belle Mead, N.J.

title: Planes Collide in New Jersey, Killing 10, Setting Homes Afire
description: BURLINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 9  At least 10 people died today when two small planes collided in midair, sending the wreckage spinning on to a subdivision below, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Organic Bar and Grill

title: Lieberman Pick Will Help Her, First Lady Predicts
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton moved yesterday to turn Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's presence on the national ticket to her political advantage, saying she wanted him to campaign by her side this fall. She predicted that Mr. Lieberman's presence on the New York ballot would increase turnout among Jewish voters and lift her own Senate candidacy, an assertion that was immediately disputed by Representative Rick A. Lazio, her Republican opponent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, MARY A.
description: TRUMP-Mary A. Wife of the late Fred C. Trump. Mother of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump Jr. Mother-in-law of Blaine Trump and James Grau. Grandmother of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great-grandmother of Andrea Trump, Christopher Trump and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue at 29th Street, on Friday, at 11 AM. Interment is private. Contributions in memory of Mary A. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, New York 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Officials Weigh Ideas for Using Landfill on S.I.
description: Now that the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island is getting out of the garbage business, borough officials are coming up with ideas about how to use the land. The first idea on their list? Building highways, streets and bridges atop the 2,200-acre landfill.

title: Focus on Child of Holocaust Survivors
description: The selection of her husband as Vice President Al Gore's running mate thrust Hadassah Lieberman onto the national stage today and into the type of highly public role she has worked hard to avoid as a political spouse.

title: Jets' O'Sullivan Has Tough Act To Follow as the Long Snapper
description: Dennis O'Sullivan was an impressionable rookie last year. The first thing he heard in the Jets' training camp was: ''Make sure the holder doesn't have to twirl the laces.''

description: A Movable Feast Of a Wedding

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

description: Call it a New York state of mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, MARY (KELLEY)
description: FLYNN-Mary (Kelley), 94, died Thursday, August 3 in Burlington, VT. Surviving are daughters Mary Kaudern (Bertil) of Pearl River, NY; Ann Flyntz (John) of Sparta, NJ; Rita Villa of Burlington, VT; and sister, Betty Lagrua of VA. Predeceased by husband Daniel Flynn in 1975. A Mass, August 11th at 11:00AM in Epiphany Church, Second Avenue, NYC. Burial in Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, NJ. Hours are Thursday 68:00PM at Andrett Funeral Home, Second Avenue, NYC. Memorials may be made to Covenant House.

title: Boom . . . Boom
description: David Justice remembers hitting the ball in the bottom of the ninth inning last night. He remembers touching second base, and the two girls happily running onto the field.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Warehouse Is Now for Art Directors
description: For many years, the ground-level space at 106 West 29th Street was a ramshackle warehouse for hair care products, which seemed appropriate for the neighborhood on the fringes of the garment district.

title: Rieslings, Fruited and Plain
description: IN legend and in fact, German wine terminology is practically indecipherable to Americans. Driven by precision but weighed down by bureaucracy, German wine labels nowadays convey information that is often contradictory and gives little hint as to what's actually in the bottle.

title: Ecstasy and Marijuana
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer of the Knicks' Discontent Continues
description: What has been a cruel summer for the Knicks and their general manager, Scott Layden, could become a nightmare as soon as today. While the Knicks battle the lowly Golden State Warriors for the rights to Danny Fortson, their most hated rival is on the verge of becoming the power team in the Eastern Conference.

title: Gore and Lieberman Make Tolerance the Centerpiece
description: Determined to transform a potential liability into a defining asset, Vice President Al Gore today formally introduced Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut as his Democratic running mate and portrayed his selection of Mr. Lieberman, an Orthodox Jew, as a measure of his devotion to tolerance and his willingness to break barriers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SARA
description: FRIEDMAN-Sara. We will miss our loving sister and aunt, Sally. We celebrate her love of life and the strength and courage with which she lived it. Ellen and Roy Wedeles, Thomas and John

title: Ethel Brown Fitzgerald, 68, Educator and Schools Examiner
description: Ethel Brown Fitzgerald, a former New York City teacher and school administrator, lawyer and musician, died July 19 at a hospital in upstate Amsterdam. She was 68 and lived in Fonda, N.Y., and Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERT, MICHAEL
