description: LIEBERT-Michael. Our dearest Michael, our lives will never be the same without you. We always considered you a cherished member of our family, brother, uncle, Godfather and friend. Your life has been an inspiration to us all. Our hearts are with Rosie & Roberta. Susan, Jeffrey, Aaron, Lauren and Diana

title: Diageo Said to Discuss Bid for Seagram Spirits
description: Diageo P.L.C. of Britain has held preliminary talks with Bacardi Ltd. and several others about forming a joint venture to make a bid valued at more than $7 billion for the spirits business of the Seagram Company, executives close to the discussions said today.

title: Ex-Chairman of Cronos Charged by S.E.C.
description: An ex-chairman of the Cronos Group, which leases marine cargo containers to shippers, was charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with causing the company to conceal more than $10 million in payments that Cronos made to him.

title: Lieberman on Joining the Democratic Ticket: 'I Am Humbled and Honored'
description: Following are excerpts from the announcement yesterday by Vice President Al Gore that he had named Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate, as recorded by The New York Times. Also speaking in an appearance at a Nashville war memorial were Mr. Gore's wife, Tipper, Senator Lieberman's wife, Hadassah, and Senator Lieberman.

title: FOUR GUILTY IN ACCESS-CARD SALES
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that four people pleaded guilty to felony charges of violating laws against the unauthorized decryption of satellite programming. Seven others are facing charges after a 22-month investigation into the sale of counterfeit and pirated satellite television access cards. The cards, which draw a black-market price of about $325 to $425 each, allow users to obtain satellite TV pictures at no monthly cost. John Files (NYT)

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Stottlemyre Leaves to Undergo Tests
description: Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach, left the team Monday during a game against the Seattle Mariners and might be out for at least 10 more days as part of his treatment schedule for bone marrow cancer.

title: Joyce Season to Start With a Hip-Hop Opera
description: The Joyce Theater will open its 2000-1 season on Sept. 26 with Rennie Harris Pure Movement, a Philadelphia-based company that will present a hip-hop opera called ''Rome and Jules'' based on Shakespeare's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The theater's resident company, Ballet Tech, will close the season on Aug. 18, 2001. Thirty-three companies will perform, and 75 premieres are scheduled.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Yogurt This Is Not
description: I teach every day, seven days a week. I'm on stage three or four nights a week in different shows. I do things that 16-year-old girls can't do. I didn't start yoga until I was about 50, and I'm 79 now.

title: Yet Another Argument for Nap Rooms in the Workplace
description: Here is a nugget you might want to pass on to your boss: A new survey shows that workers believe they do their best brainstorming about their jobs when they are not actually working.

title: Fuel Bills Empty Poor Pockets, Left Unfilled by Boom
description: Every weekday, Darrell Messersmith helps his wife, Donna, into their 1989 Chevrolet Caprice, loads her wheelchair and cane into the trunk and drives 22 miles to a hospital in Grinnell. Since having a stroke in May, Mrs. Messersmith, who is 54, has spent a few hours there each afternoon learning to walk and talk again.

title: Help Is on the Way After the Mets Fall Apart in Houston
description: The Mets will get better on Wednesday, when Darryl Hamilton comes off the disabled list and Mike Piazza, perhaps, returns to the lineup after missing three days with a sprained knee.

title: For Ducasse, a Bumpy Beginning
description: THE transition has been stunning and fast. Seven weeks ago, Alain Ducasse was France's gift to New York, a chef with eight Michelin stars, opening the ultimate in luxurious restaurants. The anticipation surrounding the restaurant, Alain Ducasse at the Essex House, had it booked for months, and had produced a six-month waiting list with 2,700 names.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: His Mission? To Protect His Own Hide, Mostly
description: FLASHMAN AND THE TIGER

title: EARTHLINK ACQUIRES IBS SUBSCRIBERS
description: A provider of Internet services, IBS Interactive, agreed to sell its subscribers that access the Internet over phone lines to EarthLink for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: A Milestone You Call This? Get Real
description: WHAT a country! It has come to accept the idea that a Jew can aspire to a national office that one former occupant, John Nance Garner, is popularly said to have described as not ''worth a pitcher of warm spit.''

title: In the Ural Mountains, Youngsters Who Dare to Dream
description: Perm, a Russian city in the Urals, is not a household name in the United States. But it has historical significance for ballet lovers throughout the world. From Perm, where he was born and grew up, Serge Diaghilev went on to found the Ballets Russes. Years later, at the end of World War II, came the establishment of the Perm Ballet Academy, considered the third major ballet school in Russia after those attached to the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow and the Kirov Ballet in St. Petersburg.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE PRIMARIES

title: WOMEN PASS MEN IN INTERNET USE
description: For the first time, women users of the Internet outnumbered men online, at least in the first quarter of 2000, making up just over 50.4 percent of all users, according to a survey to be released today by Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications. The biggest increase during the period -- 125 percent -- was among teenage girls, while the number of women 18 to 24 years old dropped during the quarter. The survey also showed women and men behave differently online. Women tend to spend their time online on the same few sites, rather than surfing. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: More Texas Executions
description: There are two executions scheduled in Texas this evening, but only one is being denounced by groups ranging from the American Bar Association to the European Union. That is because the condemned inmate Oliver David Cruz is mentally retarded, and it demeans the nation's judicial system to execute a person so mentally deficient.

title: The Trivialities of Despots, Recounted Without Frivolity
description: Hitler loved chocolate eclairs, pornographic cartoons and American movies (his favorite was ''The Lives of a Bengal Lancer'') and revered Richard Wagner as an artistic god. He couldn't stand tobacco and had problems with stomach gas. Mussolini was extremely fastidious, loved athletics, had several mistresses and became obsessed with bowler hats. Stalin, whose name, a pseudonym, meant ''man of steel,'' loved smoking cigarettes and playing practical jokes. Franco loved hunting (in one year he bagged 8,420 partridges) and watching television. His last words were a complaint about how hard it was to die. Both Stalin and Franco were short men who stood only 5-foot-4.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Pataki Signs Bill Requiring Con Ed Rebate
description: Putting the blame for a February nuclear accident squarely on Consolidated Edison, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill today requiring the company to repay customers more than $100 million collected to pay expenses from the accident and prohibiting it from collecting tens of millions more.

title: The Western Fires
description: The American West is a checkerboard of fires this summer, with some 66 large wildland fires currently burning in 11 Western states, many of them out of control. Every so often a year comes along when conditions favor combustion. The forests and rangeland become as dry as mouse nests, and when thunderstorms pass by, bringing lightning without rain, ignition is inevitable. It happened in 1988, when more than 1.5 million acres of Yellowstone National Park went up in flames. And it is happening again now, thanks to unusually dry vegetation, hot temperatures, low humidity and rainfall, and winds that can fan a small blaze into a conflagration. So far, some four million acres are burning or have already burned, nearly twice the average annual acreage burned in the last 10 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFFE, JOSEPH, PH.D.
description: JOFFE-Joseph, Ph.D. Of Maplewood, New Jersey, died Monday, August 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Bertha Pashkovsky Joffe. Devoted father of Robert D.; Paul L. and Richard T. Joffe. Also survived by three grandchildren and two step grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. For info: The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, NJ 07040.

title: LEESON ELECTRIC TO BE PURCHASED FOR $260 MILLION CASH
description: The Regal-Beloit Corporation, a maker of gearboxes, motors and generators, agreed yesterday to buy the Leeson Electric Corporation for about $260 million in cash. Regal-Beloit also plans to buy back as many as two million of its own shares from time to time, or 9.5 percent of its stock outstanding. The closely held Leeson makes electric motors and is based in Grafton, Wis., near Milwaukee. Leeson had sales of $175 million for the year that ended on June 30. Regal-Beloit, based in Beloit, Wis., had 1999 sales of $544.6 million. Regal-Beloit's shares rose 81.25 cents yesterday, to $16.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUES, HENRY G.
description: NEUES-Henry G. On August 8, 2000. Son of the late Mae and George Neues. Recipient of the Medal of Freedom. Retiree of Sandia National Laboratories. Funeral mass Wednesday at 9:30 AM in the Chapel of St Dominic's R.C. Church, Oyster Bay, L.I. Interment Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village N.Y. Please call the Francis P. Devine Funeral Home in Oyster Bay for further info.

title: Texas Board Refuses to Halt Execution of Low-I.Q. Inmate
description: The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles has turned down a request for clemency from Oliver Cruz, who was sentenced to death for the rape and murder of an Air Force enlisted woman. Mr. Cruz, who defense psychologists say is mentally retarded, is to be executed at 6 p.m. today.

title: Robin Day, 76, BBC Grand Inquisitor, Dies
description: Sir Robin Day, a BBC broadcaster widely known as the ''grand inquisitor'' for a relentless and searching interviewing technique that revolutionized British television news, died on Sunday night. He was 76.

title: STRIFE AT BRAZILIAN AIRLINE
description: Employees at Vasp, a large and heavily indebted Brazilian airline, postponed a daylong strike after company officials agreed to address union demands for government intervention. The national airline employee's union wants the airline restructured, and Wagner Canhedo, Vasp's majority shareholder, removed as president. In the last six months, Vasp has returned 17 aircraft to creditors and dismissed almost half of its 8,000 employees to try to reduce its $1.5 billion debt. In an effort to hold off the strike, Mr. Canhedo agreed to pay all wages and pension fund contributions until the end of August. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Designated Hitters All in a Row
description: Scene I: One winter morning before the 1982 season, Dave Collins, his wife and his agent have breakfast at a New York hotel with George Steinbrenner. The Yankees' owner, having decided to transform the team from power to speed, is recruiting the fleet-footed, base-stealing outfielder.

title: 2 Officers Resign as Dial Says Profits Will Be Off
description: The Dial Corporation, which makes Dial soap and Armour canned meats, said yesterday that its top two executives had resigned and it warned that it would miss earnings expectations for the third time this year.

title: Thai Secrets, for Cooks With Time
description: THE challenge for Su-Mei Yu, a Chinese woman who was born in Thailand and grew up there, was to explain Thai cooking and to try to simplify it for the American home cook without compromising its authenticity. In her book, ''Cracking the Coconut: Classic Thai Home Cooking'' (William Morrow, $30), she does a first-rate job of getting to the heart of this complex and compelling cuisine, for which there are so few good cookbooks, and making it understandable. But simplify it? That's another matter.

title: The Politics of Adulthood
description: America wants to grow up. Underneath the barbs and platitudes, that is the theme of this presidential campaign. Maybe it came out of polls. But probably not. It has the ring of an unexpected truth, the kind of thing a speechwriter, or even a candidate, sometimes intuits and finds a way to express.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Another Yalie at, or Near, the Top

title: MEN'S SCORES
description: BASEBALL

title: Liberties; A Match Made in Heaven
description: As though this presidential campaign did not already have enough father-son drama, now comes the mother of all contests between Father and Son.

title: Liebfraumilch, Farewell: Germany's Drinking Dry
description: AT Georg Breuer, a leading wine estate in this small town on the Rhine, I tasted three bottles of Rudesheim Berg Schlossberg, 1998, '97 and '90 vintages. Each had aromas that were almost floral, and each was powerfully dry. The youngest was almost mouth-puckering, but with age, the wines seemed to mellow, emphasizing their extraordinary balance.

title: Diners and Dinner, Exchanging Glances
description: ANYONE who misses the gaudy sign for Ping's Seafood on Mott Street gets the message a few steps inside the restaurant. Near the door, a high-rise of stacked fish tanks offers the menu headliners, a stellar cast that includes but is by no means limited to lobsters, eels, scallops, sea bass and shrimp. One evening, I stood transfixed by a school of small goblinlike fish with the features of a toad. In the tank just above, looking like a princess in an aquatic fairy tale, a single, delicate prawn stood upright, took little mincing steps, and waved its delicate pink feelers, as though flustered.

title: Sex appeal still overpowers sports skill when it comes to the marketing of female athletes.
description: THE lightning struck first in 1996, when the United States women's soccer team won the gold at the summer Olympic Games, a traditional generator of sports heroes. Then it happened again, a year ago. After a month of matches, the United States women's soccer team -- composed largely of Olympic athletes -- beat China in a spectacular finale and captured the 1999 Women's World Cup. Before, during and after, the nation watched, rapt, as it rarely had for any women's team sport. Players like Mia Hamm became media darlings, their names known to all. And Madison Avenue sat up and paid attention.

title: NATIONAL ORIGINS/Pine Barrens, N.J.; In the Fields, A Rhapsody In Blue
description: THE inland heart of South Jersey is a vast national preserve, a million acres of former ocean bottom, now a primeval terrain of craggy pines and impenetrable forest scrub. It's strangely beautiful and fragrant flatland, but not a place anyone would expect to reap great harvests.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about a two-year review of the slaying of a Mexican cardinal in 1993 referred incorrectly to the conclusions of two bishops who took part in the investigation. Unlike some Roman Catholic leaders, the two bishops shared the view of prosecutors that the killing of the cardinal, Juan Jesus Posadas Ocampo, occurred when drug traffickers mistook him for a rival, and was not intentional.

title: Record Auto Profits Bolster Hyundai, and Embolden Creditors
description: The Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, reported record profits in its automotive business today, an unexpected piece of good news from a company known lately more for its heavy debts, drag on the national economy and defiance of pressure to change.

title: Sri Lanka Drops Plan for Pro-Tamil Constitution
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga's long-awaited peace plan for this war-torn nation -- embodied in a new constitution that would have given greater automomy to the Hindu Tamil minority in this majority Buddhist Sinhalese nation -- seemed to have foundered Tuesday.

title: Buchanan's Bid for the Presidential Nomination Splits the Party Leadership
description: With nastiness boiling over to screaming and shoving, the Reform Party split apart today, as a faction opposed to Patrick J. Buchanan's presidential candidacy stormed out of a meeting of national party leaders and vowed to proceed on its own, perhaps as a new party.

title: Review Under Way For Phone Venture
description: BellSouth in Atlanta and SBC Communications in San Antonio, have begun a review for a joint venture of the merged North American wireless operations of the two companies, a deal which is still under regulatory review.

title: United Airlines Cancels More Flights
description: United Airlines canceled more than 200 flights nationwide today, disrupting service for thousands of passengers for the fourth consecutive day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVACK, GORDON B.
description: SPIVACK-Gordon B., 71, of New Haven, CT, world-renowned antitrust attorney, died on Sunday, August 6, 2000. Mr. Spivack was born in New Haven on June 15, 1929, son of Jacob and Sophie Spivack. From 1986 until the time of his death, Mr. Spivack was a Senior Partner at Coudert Brothers, an international law firm in New York. Mr. Spivack attended Yale College from 1946-1950. He then served in the U.S. Army from 1950-1951. In 1952 he returned to Yale University to obtain a law degree graduating magna cum laude. Mr. Spivack began his career at the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice on the Honor Program under the then Attorney General, Herbert Brownell, and quickly rose to the top career position as Chief of Field Operations where he supervised 350 trial attorneys. In 1967 he left the Justice Department to teach Antitrust Law and Civil Procedure at Yale Law School, where he remained until 1970. In 1970 Mr. Spivack joined the Lord, Day & Lord law firm as senior partner to establish an antitrust practice which grew to twenty lawyers plus support staff. When Mr. Spivack decided to leave the firm to join Coudert Brothers in 1986, the full complement of attorneys involved in antitrust matters elected to go with him. While at Coudert Brothers and Lord, Day and Lord, Mr. Spivack represented in significant cases and investigations such firms as The CocaCola Company, Schweppes, Champion International, Chevron, Hearst, NBC, Union Carbide, Texas Utilities, Fischbach & Moore, Air Liquide, Kelco, Cargill, among others. In 1978, he was appointed to serve on the President's Commission for Revision of Antitrust Law and Procedures. Mr. Spivack is survived by his wife, Dolores Travers Spivack; two sons, Michael David Spivack, of Miami, FL and Paul Stephen Spivack of New York City; two grandchildren; and a brother, Irving Spivack, of Woodbridge, Ct.

title: Suit Alleges Conspiracy To Fix Prices Of CD's
description: Twenty-eight states, including New York and Connecticut, filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday against major record distributors and record-store chains , accusing them of a conspiracy to fix prices of compact discs.

title: Crossing the Tightrope From Algeria to France
description: In the front of the audience for the concert by Faudel, some people waved Algerian flags; others sang along in French. Near the back, a group of white-robed women ululated between songs and loudly cheered some of Faudel's Arabic lyrics. It was a victorious crossover for rai, the music that came out of Algeria and has thrived with the French pop audience.

title: The Quest to Lift The Impossible Lid
description: Stubborn jar lids have inspired many tricks to get them off, like slamming the jar upside down on a hard surface or wrapping the lid with rubber bands or plastic wrap for a better grip. Jar Pop, a plastic gadget from Denmark, makes these unnecessary. This tool, which looks like a bottle opener, tackles the hard part, breaking the jar's vacuum seal. After that, any jar can be unscrewed easily. Gristede's supermarkets sells them for $1.99.

title: Scourge of Stars, Rich Spouse's Nightmare
description: YOU ready for the show? Because the set is waiting for you. The office door of Philip Marlowe, Private Detective, is on one side; the office of Sam Spade, Criminal Investigator, is on the other, and in the center, befitting the star, is the name of Raoul Felder, in gold. Trompe l'oeil, the doors of Marlowe and Spade, though Europeans have been known to get confused.

title: Iran, Persisting in Drive, Closes Last Reformist Paper
description: Iran's last major reformist newspaper was closed by the hard-line judiciary today, two days after the country's supreme leader intervened to block legislation aimed at restoring a free press.

title: Shares Tumble on Phone Company's Weak Earnings Forecast
description: Shares of Verizon, the nation's No. 1 local phone company, had been under pressure for weeks. Yesterday, they plunged.

title: Faulting India, Rebel Group In Kashmir Ends Its Cease-Fire
description: The pros pect of peace in Kashmir a flicker of hope that had burned unsteadily for the past two weeks -- appeared to die out completely today when the militant group Hizbul Mujahedeen called off its cease-fire.

title: Safir Formally Resigns; Plaudits and Criticism Follow
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir formally announced his resignation yesterday, relinquishing command of the largest police department in the nation to work as a salaried consultant for ChoicePoint Inc., a corporate investigations firm in Atlanta.

title: SCHLUMBERGER AGREES TO BUY DATA MARINE OF SCOTLAND
description: Schlumberger Ltd., an oil field service company that is expanding into meter-reading and electronic-commerce technologies, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Data Marine Systems Ltd for an undisclosed price. Data Marine, based in Aberdeen, Scotland, owns and runs a satellite network that transmits seismic and other data from oil fields. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Schlumberger, the world's No. 2 oil field services company, would pay almost $100 million for Data Marine. Schlumberger would not confirm that figure. Shares of Schlumberger rose $1.30 each, to $79.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE BOSS; Reality on Yellow Bricks
description: My grandfather was Harry Warner, one of the pioneers of the film industry. My father was Mervyn LeRoy, who produced and directed more than 95 movies, including ''The Wizard of Oz.'' I grew up on the back lot of the Warner Brothers studio.

title: Fassel Cools Off, But Giants Play Hard
description: Coach Jim Fassel has backed off his threat to make immediate changes on the Giants' special teams, perhaps because it would require dipping into the thin first and second teams.

title: STUDY CALLS HAND-FREE PHONES SAFER
description: A new study commissioned by Britain's Department of Trade and Industry to measure the safety of hands-free devices for mobile telephones determined that the devices pose less risk to consumers by offering substantial reductions in radiation exposure compared with that of regular hand-held mobile phones. The new study conflicted with one by Britain's Consumers Association, which reported that hands-free devices exposed consumers to more radiation. Britain is one of the biggest markets for mobile telephones. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: The Wild and the Tame In Berries and Cream
description: The intensity of wild strawberries, fraises des bois, separates Creme Cremaillere's newest flavor from other strawberry ice creams. The rich, satiny and not oversweet custard-based ice cream, made at La Cremaillere, a restaurant in Westchester County, also contains tame strawberries to round out the flavor and provide pieces of berry, said Robert Meyzen, the owner. The wild strawberries come from France already pureed, so the ice cream is available all year. It's $3.50 to $4 a pint at markets, including Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory, Amish Markets, Gourmet Garage markets and Mrs. Green's Natural Markets in Westchester and Connecticut.

title: Business Travel; For those whose jobs require them to fly a lot, a look at the numbers can be pretty sobering.
description: ALL summer long, weary business travelers have been grimly playing the numbers game. Here's a question from the most recent round: How many flights did UAL's United Airlines abruptly cancel last Saturday, Sunday and Monday? The answer: 814.

title: Gibson McCabe, 89, Ex-Newsweek Publisher
description: Gibson McCabe, a former publisher and president of Newsweek who defended the editorial independence of the magazine from irate advertisers during the Vietnam War, died Saturday at Baptist Medical Center in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., from complications after a fall. He was 89.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about stylish restrooms in Manhattan restaurants misstated the name and scheduled opening date of a restaurant that is to be where Asti used to be, on East 12th Street. It is Strip House, not New York Strip. It opens on Sept. 6, not this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart yesterday with an article about Howard Safir's plan to resign as New York City police commissioner misstated the comparative numbers of killings in 1998 in New York and Chicago. New York had 628 killings that year, fewer than Chicago, a city less than half its size; the number was not 628 fewer than Chicago's.

title: At the Corner of Shakespeare and Verdi
description: To the Editor:

title: Choice of Jewish Candidate Is Noted in Slurs on Internet
description: The selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut for the Democratic ticket has prompted a barrage of anti-Semitic comments in online chat rooms and on Internet message boards, leading at least a few online services to start deleting offensive postings.

title: Treasuries Up on Labor Data And the Sale of 5-Year Notes
description: Bond prices rose yesterday after a better-than-expected government report on productivity and labor costs and a good start to the Treasury's quarterly debt sales.

title: Columbia's Mack Goes to Other Side of Line
description: Two years ago, Kirby Mack was selected to the All-Ivy League team as a fullback. Yet, as he approaches his final season with Columbia, Mack may never carry the ball again for the Lions.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridgestone Said to Plan Big Recall of Tires
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said yesterday that it would hold a news conference today in Washington, after a meeting of company representatives and regulators who have been investigating safety complaints and dozens of fatal accidents involving sport utility vehicle and pickup truck tires.

title: 6.5 Million Firestone Tires Recalled Because of Link to Fatalities
description: Contending that "nothing is more important to us than the safety of our customers," the Bridgestone Corporation announced today that it would voluntarily recall 6.5 million Firestone tires that have been linked to numerous accidents and 46 fatalities nationwide.

title: THE CHEF; Michel Richard
description: MELON with port is a traditional combination in France, the wine served in half a Cavaillon or other melon, but I always thought it could be improved. The color is not appealing to me, because the beautiful pastel shades of the melons are lost in the deep red-purple of the wine. Port is also too strong, overwhelming the taste of the fruit. To me, this wine goes better with chocolate.

title: EXPANSION BY SOUTH AFRICAN UTILITY
description: The chairman of Eskom, South Africa's state-owned power utility, said the company intended to acquire interests in electricity providers in other African countries, including neighboring Zimbabwe. Eskom, one of South Africa's biggest state-run enterprises, says it wants to be competitive in an energy industry that will soon be dominated by large multinationals. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELFMAN, IRVING L.
description: HELFMAN-Irving L. On August 7, 2000. Loving husband of Annette. Cherished father of Michelle Shaked, and Dr. Alan S., their spouses Ary and Joan. Adored grandfather of Max, Lia & Jordan. Loving brother of Arthur, Mildred & the late Leila. Funeral services 2PM Wednesday, Brettschneider Funeral Home, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. For information call 212-254-3818.

title: Firefighters Feeling Strain Across West
description: Surrounded by swirling wood smoke, and with forest fires crackling on a hillside just over the horizon, Craig Bobzien waved an arm over acres of equipment and exhausted firefighters in the Bitterroot Valley fire camp near here.

title: Revival Time in Nashville
description: If Al Gore wins this election, he may well look back on yesterday's boisterous gathering in Nashville as the moment the campaign became truly his own and not merely an extension of the Clinton presidency. The presence of Senator Joseph Lieberman on the rostrum, standing side by side with Mr. Gore in matching white shirtsleeves, seemed to stir both men and give the Gore campaign a jolt of energy and passion. This was partly the result of Mr. Lieberman's own boyish delight at having been chosen as Mr. Gore's running mate and his obvious relish for the political combat ahead. But the mere fact that Mr. Gore had made a groundbreaking choice was itself an important event, giving the campaign a sense of completeness and purpose it had missed.

title: INSIDE
description: Reform Party Leaders Split

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: G.I.'s to Be Sent to Train Africans for Sierra Leone
description: In a shift of policy, the Clinton administration plans to send hundreds of American soldiers to Nigeria this month to train and equip West African battalions that will then be dispatched to Sierra Leone to bolster beleaguered government troops and United Nations peacekeepers there.

title: A Moment for a Man, a Faith and a Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Nectarine Told the Shopper
description: Stickers on produce now do more than tell the checkout clerk the price. Some point the way to information. No, you don't have to squint at tiny type. The stickers on some nectarines, for example, direct you to www .nectinfo.com, a Web site run by California fruit growers. Log on and you learn that nectarines ripen best in a paper bag, that they should be refrigerated only after they are ripe and that white-fleshed nectarines ripen faster than yellow-fleshed varieties, but the yellows ripen sweeter. Then you can try some of the recipes.

title: Gangster Shootout in Tokyo Violates an Unspoken Pact
description: Residents of this normally safe city were horrified Monday at a shootout in an upscale business district but breathed a sigh of relief today after the police arrested six members of one of Japan's largest organized crime syndicates in the case.

title: Mary MacLeod Trump Philanthropist, 88
description: Mary MacLeod Trump, a philanthropist who supported charities near her home in Jamaica, Queens, and elsewhere, died on Monday at 88 at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, her family said.

title: Rush-Hour Bomb Attack Kills 8 in Central Moscow
description: A bomb exploded in a pedestrian underpass at Pushkin Square in the center of Moscow at the height of rush hour this evening, killing 8 people, wounding 11 and sending dozens more fleeing smoke and flames that scorched the large underground plaza.

title: Hundreds Left Sweltering in a Harlem Tower
description: Hundreds of people in a 30-story public housing tower in Harlem were led from their steamy apartments yesterday after a malfunctioning transformer in their building forced city housing officials to turn off electrical power, shutting off air-conditioning, fans and elevators on one of the hottest days of the year.

title: The Islanders' New Owners Get Some Nasty Paper Cuts
description: There may be no need for alarm. But if you look at the stock tables, those fabulously rich hockey naifs who bought the Islanders for $185 million aren't so rich anymore.

title: Prices Starting to Stabilize For Housing in Manhattan
description: The fever has broken.

title: Phone Talks Said to Stall, With Strike in Third Day
description: Contract negotiations took a turn for the worse yesterday, the third day of a strike by more than 86,000 employees of the nation's largest local telephone company, dimming hopes for a quick resolution, according to people close to the talks.

title: Studios Hope for Quick Decision in DVD Hacker Case
description: Studios Hope for Quick Decision in DVD Hacker Case

title: Torre Is Rebuffed By Steinbrenner
description: Joe Torre said Monday that he was ''surprised'' by the waiver acquisition of the slugger Jose Canseco, a less than enthusiastic response that drew a subtle rebuff from George Steinbrenner.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN HIRES ADVISER ON POSSIBLE SALE OF UNIT
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, the world's largest maker of hydraulic equipment, said yesterday that it had hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to advise it on a possible sale of its Wynn Oil specialty chemicals unit. Wynn Oil makes chemicals and equipment for the automotive industry and was acquired through Parker Hannifin's $497 million takeover of Wynn's International Inc. last month. Shares of Parker Hannifin fell 6 percent on June 14, the day after it announced its planned acquisition, on investor concern that an increased presence in the automotive industry would slow growth. The company's shares rose $2, to $36, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange; the shares have dropped 30 percent this year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the 100th birthday of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother misidentified three members of the British royal family. It reversed the identifications of Prince Andrew's daughters Eugenie, who was third from left, and Beatrice, fourth from left, who was standing in front of her father. And the woman at the far right was Princess Michael of Kent, not the Duchess of Kent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DETTWYLER, ETHAN REID
description: DETTWYLER-Ethan Reid. August 2, 2000. Died at birth. ''He went to live with beautiful God, whose heart is broken, too.'' He is survived by his parents, Rick and Hillary, and by his big brother, Spenser. Services will be held 12 Noon today at Ivandell Cemetery, Route 100 North, Somers, N.Y. Donations may be made to Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Neonatal Unit, Mount Kisco, New York, in Ethan's name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JILER, MILTON W.
description: JILER-Milton W. On August 7, 2000, at age 92. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of John Jiler and father-in-law of Elizabeth Hovey. Grandfather of Jacob and Stella. Dear brother of William, Lillian, Helen and Peggy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, 7-9 PM with service Thursday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: U.S. Acts to Protect Embattled Horseshoe Crab
description: Federal authorities announced plans today for a 1,800-square-mile sanctuary from Delaware Bay out into the Atlantic to protect the rapidly dwindling stock of horseshoe crabs that are vital to the pharmaceutical industry and to the annual migration of a dozen species of shorebirds.

title: A Bond That Sharp Criticism Could Not Break
description: The gesture spoke volumes about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's longtime friendship with President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, ELOISE
description: JACOBS-Eloise. Passed away on August 8th, 2000 at the age of 96, after a long illness. Beloved widow of Milton Jacobs. Best friend of the late Hazel Hartman. Loving aunt, great aunt and cousin. She lives on in our hearts and through the good deeds she accomplished in life. May she rest in peace.

title: Brass Knuckles Over 2 Broadway; M.T.A. and Landlord Are Fighting It Out Over Rent and Renovations
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is on rent strike. It stopped paying rent on its office space at 2 Broadway, claiming in a lawsuit that its landlord defaulted on his promise to renovate the building.

title: Creative Executive Leaves DDB Shop
description: The top creative executive at the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, has left the agency. Steve Landsberg, 42, chief creative officer, left to pursue ''an unusual opportunity that he could not divulge at this time,'' said John Berg, president at DDB New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACKAMP, JUDITH A.
description: LACKAMP-Judith A. died peacefully on August 4, 2000 in her home. A native of Cleveland, OH, Judy lived in NYC for nearly 40 years. Judy is survived by her brother William A. Lackamp, niece Lori Shoemake and husband James, grandnieces Devon and Emily. She touched our lives in many wonderful ways. She lived her life with grace and dignity. God took her with her grace and dignity intact. Remember what she said, ''Do something nice for someone, it will make you both feel good.'' We all felt good in her presence and blessed to have her in our lives. She will remain lovingly in our hearts forever. Contributions may be made in her honor in lieu of flowers to Bide-a-Wee Animal Shelter, Box 5664 GPO, NY, NY 10087-5664 and/or Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, 296 9th Ave., NY, NY 10001. Memorial service will be held on August 25th at The Union Club, 101 East 69 St., NYC from 5:00 PM to 7:00 PM.

title: Reckonings; For Richer, for Poorer
description: After working hard for many years, you and your husband have retired with a decent income from pensions and investments. Then, sadly, he dies. Is it fair that you should suddenly face higher tax bills, because your deductions have been cut in half and you are now in a higher tax bracket? In 1969 widows didn't think so.

title: Lasers, and Pagers, and Cells  Oh My!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, MARY A.
description: TRUMP-Mary A. Wife of the late Fred C. Trump. Mother of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump Jr. Mother-in-law of Blaine Trump and James Grau. Grandmother of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great-grandmother of Andrea Trump, Christopher Trump and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue at 29th Street, on Friday, at 11 AM. Interment is private. Contributions in memory of Mary A. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, New York 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEICHER, BEATRICE
description: GLEICHER-Beatrice. Sisterhood of Park East Synagogue expresses heartfelt condolences to Evelyn Mintz, our dedicated Vice President, on the loss of her beloved mother, to whom Evelyn's devotion was exemplary. May she be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Maguy Naparstek, President Beverly Greenberg, Chairman of The Board

title: Layoffs May Be at a Record Low, Survey Finds
description: With the American economy enjoying its longest economic expansion on record, the number of permanent layoffs declined over the last three years, the government reported yesterday. The rate may now match the lowest in the 20-year history of the survey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, HERMOINE KANTOR
description: BARNETT-Hermoine Kantor. Beloved wife of the late Harold, cherished mother of Walter, adored mother-in-law of Gabrielle and devoted sister of the late Samuel Kantor. Teacher to many at P.S. 199. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, August 11 at 11AM.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS TO CUT IMMUNEX STAKE
description: Immunex Inc. said yesterday that the American Home Products Corporation planned to reduce its 55 percent ownership in the company, a biotechnology concern, by selling as much as $2.7 billion of Immunex stock. American Home, based in Madison, N.J., which makes the No. 1 prescribed drug in the United States, Premarin, will sell up to 50 million Immunex common shares, according to a filing by Immunex with the Securities and Exchange Commission. American Home also plans to sell Immunex a plant in Rhode Island that it recently purchased from Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. Immunex said it would pay $250 million to $300 million for the plant. Seattle-based Immunex also plans to sell up to 20 million newly issued shares of its own stock.

title: McSorley Trial To Begin Sept. 25
description: The former Boston Bruins defenseman Marty McSorley's assault trial for hitting Canucks forward Donald Brashear in the head with his stick is scheduled to begin Sept. 25 in Provincial Court in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, SYLVIA K.
description: CLARK-Sylvia K. Of Hillsdale, New Jersey, on August 8, 2000. Survived by her children Merri & husband Carlos, Suzanne, Loren, and stepdaughter Kay. A woman of intelligence and determination who lived her life surrounded by family and friends, and is now reunited with beloved first-born son Lee, husband Lawrence J. Clark, and parents Vera and Jerome Klarsfeld.

title: With California Stops, Bush Presses Bid for Clinton Voters
description: Making his seventh campaign trip to California since he won the state's Republican primary early this year, Gov. George W. Bush today spoke a little Spanish, described his education and tax proposals as efforts to help less affluent Americans and headed straight for counties with relatively large percentages of moveable, malleable voters in the center of the political spectrum.

title: Healtheon/WebMD Quarterly Loss Narrows, Beating Consensus
description: Healtheon/WebMD Quarterly Loss Narrows, Beating Consensus

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply After a Report on Inventories
description: Crude oil prices surged past $30 a barrel yesterday after an industry report showed that United States inventories were at their lowest levels since 1976.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a new emphasis on dry wines in Germany for shipment to the United States misspelled the name of an importer. He is Terry Theise, not Thiese.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Salinas and Lodi, Calif.

title: Good and Bad in the Creator of Bluegrass
description: CAN'T YOU HEAR ME CALLIN'

title: 15 Awarded Highest Civilian Honor
description: Presi dents hand out plenty of perks ambassadorships, invitations to state dinners and specially made boxes of M&M's bearing the presidential seal.

title: SEED SETBACK FOR MONSANTO
description: The Regional Federal Court in Brazil upheld an injunction that blocks Monsanto from selling genetically modified soybeans in the country until a comprehensive environmental impact study can be completed. The initial injunction was handed down in 1998 in response to legal action brought by the Brazilian Consumer Defense Institute in alliance with Greenpeace. Monsanto can appeal the decision to the Supreme Tribunal of Justice, Brazil's Supreme Court. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Asian-Americans and AIDS
description: Recent studies show that Asian-Americans, especially new immigrants, are largely uneducated about AIDS. More than any other ethnic group, Asian-Americans do not get diagnosed with AIDS until the disease is already in its later stages. This reflects a dearth of Asian-language educational materials. Conservative cultural beliefs also hamper open discussions about AIDS. Stepping up AIDS education efforts would help increase understanding. But the most influence lies with community leaders, who can encourage public dialogue on AIDS and acceptance of the disease.

title: There's No Room On Torre's Couch
description: Joe Torre's office at Yankee Stadium fits a desk and a couch comfortably, but it probably felt a little cramped when he invited the burly Jose Canseco and Glenallen Hill to his office Tuesday, along with the smallish Luis Polonia.

title: MICROSOFT NAMES .NET CHIEF
description: Microsoft said yesterday that Robert Muglia, a longtime executive, would head its new .Net Internet strategy. In June, Microsoft shifted its focus from desktop software to services offered on the Internet. Mr. Muglia will be group vice president of the .NET Services Group, which will develop the software and services that will make up the new .Net business. Also yesterday, Microsoft said that David Cole would lead the personal services platform division, which will provide network services for the new business; Brian MacDonald would develop premium services for the .Net effort; and Kai Fu Lee, now at Microsoft's research laboratory in Beijing, would head a new user interface technologies division. John Markoff

title: WAL-MART BUYS SHOPSMART STAKE
description: The Asda Group, a British supermarket chain owned by Wal-Mart Stores, and America Online's British unit, AOL UK, said yesterday that they had acquired a 22.5 percent stake in ShopSmart.com, an online shopping directory in Britain. AOL UK will market Shopsmart.com online, and Asda will promote the Web site in its stores. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheney Says Church-Based Charities Deserve Federal Support
description: In his first solo campaign swing as the Republican vice presidential candidate, Dick Cheney took his ticket's message of ''compassionate conservatism'' to a homeless shelter here today, and promised that a Bush administration would expand federal support for religious-based social service groups.

title: I.M.F. Expects Investments in Emerging Countries to Decline
description: Private investment in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe will drop during the next year as investors seek safe havens because of concern the United States economy and stock market will slump, the International Monetary Fund predicted in a report released today.

title: Lilly Set Back In Patent Case Over Prozac
description: A federal appeals court ruling yesterday cleared the way for the sale of a generic version of Prozac, the world's top-selling antidepressant, as early as next summer, about two years earlier than expected.

title: In Prison, Raising Dukes And Discovering a Gift
description: It's not easy being in prison when your nickname is The Toy Store Bandit. It might make you want to fight.

title: Moscow Arrests Suspects but Can't Link Any to Fatal Bombing
description: Russian law enforcement officials said today they had detained a number of suspects in their investigation into the terrorist bombing of an underground pedestrian walkway that killed 7 and wounded 97 on Tuesday evening. But they said that so far none could be directly linked to the bombing in the heart of the Russian capital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ARMSTRONG HOLDINGS, Lancaster, Pa., named Michael D. Lockhart chairman and chief executive. Mr. Lockhart was most recently chairman and chief executive at General Signal.

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Printed Page Beats PC Screen For Reading, Study Finds
description: SOME skeptics may believe a thing only when they see it in writing, but is the writing more believable when it is seen on paper rather than on a computer screen?

title: A Report on the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: PC 101: Pitfalls To Avoid
description: STUDENTS in the freshman class of 2000 were born at the same time as the original I.B.M. PC. They have never known a world without microprocessors. They grew up with cable TV and Nintendo, learned to program the VCR before they could ride a bike, became virtuosos with call-waiting and three-way conference calling and took for granted answering machines, microwave ovens, audio CD's, pagers, fax machines and cell phones. They came of age with the Internet and the World Wide Web.

title: Jerome Smith, 47, of K. C. and the Sunshine Band, the Hit Disco Group
description: Jerome Smith, the original guitarist for the disco party kings K. C. and the Sunshine Band, died on Friday after a construction accident, The Associated Press reported. He was 47 and lived in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, LESLIE
description: GLASS-Leslie. Leslie Glass, who was a popular Penthouse Pet, lost her valiant struggle against cancer on August 5, 2000. Her beauty left us breathless and her dedication to helping abused and homeless animals enriched us all. Bob Guccione, the publisher of Penthouse Magazine, and the entire General Media family extend their sincerest condolences to her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations in Leslie's name can be made to the Kathy Keeton Foundation in support of cancer research or Pets for Pets, an organzation Leslie formed to help abused and homeless animals. For more information, please contact General Media at 212-702-6000 ext. 1465.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERT, MICHAEL
description: LIEBERT-Michael. A man who had no acquaintances, only friends. A true inspiration, Michael will be remembered for his dignity, courage, wisdom and smile. His capacity to love knew no boundaries. Our heartfelt sympathies to Roberta, Rosie and all others who are feeling his loss so profoundly. Mitchell, Lois, Jesse and Brian

title: Excerpts From 2 of Lieberman's Books
description: Following are excerpts from two books by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. The second, ''In Praise of Public Life,'' was written with Michael D'Orso.

title: SAPIENT TO BUY HUMAN CODE, A MEDIA DEVELOPER
description: The Sapient Corporation, an Internet-commerce consulting company, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Human Code Inc. for $103.8 million in stock to add expertise in interactive media strategy and creative services. Sapient will pay about 755,000 of its common shares for Human Code, based in Austin, Tex. At the closing price yesterday of $137.50, down $8 a share, that would be about $103.8 million. Sapient said it would also assume Human Code's stock options but gave no details. Sapient, based in Cambridge, Mass., said the acquisition would allow it to offer clients sound, video and three-dimensional interactive programs via the Internet. Human Code develops programs for interactive learning, electronic commerce and games.

title: On 'Tippecanoe' and Other Songs, Too
description: THIS is about memory: Oscar Brand's, and America's. Mr. Brand remembers how, before soft money and sound bites, before attack ads and tightly scripted conventions, presidential candidates were something to sing about. He remembers songs like ''Tippecanoe and Tyler, Too,'' and before one can interrupt -- Mr. Brand, you're only 80, and that's not old enough for you to know this stuff firsthand -- he is doing ''Get on the Raft With Taft.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Phone Strike Drags On As Contract Talks Continue

title: Artist vs. Artist, Vision vs. Vision; 2 Groups Battle for Control of City-Owned Cultural Center
description: Talk about ugly. The performing artists and the visual artists are barely speaking to one another. Two mediation sessions have collapsed. Accusations have ricocheted off the peeling walls of the building where the artists pursue their muses. In the bathrooms and hallways, the graffiti reads: ''Corruption. Scandal. Violence.''

title: National News Briefs; Executive Is Sentenced In Internet Sex Sting
description: A former executive of the Infoseek Corporation who was arrested last year in an Internet sex sting was sentenced to five years of probation and ordered to pay a $20,000 fine.

title: Choosing Quick Hits Over the Card Catalog
description: Choosing Quick Hits Over the Card Catalog

title: Talks, Exhibitions, Tours and a Festival
description: Home Hazards

title: U.S. Vision Rejects Offer
description: U.S. Vision Inc. has rejected as unacceptable a $23.8 million offer from the Norcross Investment Group to buy the 76.3 percent of the company it does not own. U.S. Vision, based in Glendora, said a representative of 54 percent of the company's stock had said those shareholders would vote against the offer. A buyout would require approval of a majority of the shareholders. On Tuesday, in a letter to U.S. Vision's board, the closely held investment company offered to pay $4 a share in cash. Norcross owns 23.7 percent of U.S. Vision's almost 7.79 million shares outstanding.

title: Mixing Mac and Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: Annual Awards For Family TV
description: The second annual Family Television Awards were presented last week by a coalition of advertisers that are interested in stimulating the production of prime-time television programs intended to appeal to broader multigenerational audiences.

title: Wine Account Switching Agency
description: Zuckerman Fernandes & Partners parted ways with Clos Du Bois wines, owned by Allied Domecq Wines U.S.A., after five years of working on the account. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Mixing Mac and Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Seller Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 New Players For U.S. Soccer
description: Desperate for points after two disappointing matches last month, Bruce Arena, the coach of the United States men's national team, yesterday shuffled his 18-man roster for next week's critical World Cup qualifying match against Barbados.

title: McDaniel Stands By Fellow Cornerbacks
description: The Giants are thin at nearly every position, and units that routinely tap their depth are especially weakened.

title: Amtrak Gains Riders in July And Expects Record Year
description: Amtrak's ridership hit a 10-year high in July, and the number of passengers for the year is poised to set a record, railroad officials said today, crediting extensive investments to improve reliability and service.

title: Political Memo; Levy Is Sparring With an Old Ally Over Direction of the City Schools
description: In his efforts to raise standards for school districts throughout New York State, Richard P. Mills, the state's education commissioner, had no stronger ally than Harold O. Levy.

title: On Convention Eve, a Party Torn Asunder
description: Patrick J. Buchanan arrived here today full of optimism and bravado, predicting that he would claim the Reform Party presidential nomination, despite a bitter split that could leave the party nominating not one, but two, candidates for president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, MAURICE
description: GRUBER-Maurice, 87. Of Oakhurst, NJ died Tuesday, August 8 at Monmouth Medical Center. He was born and raised in Long Branch, NJ and until recently, maintained homes in New York City and Oakhurst. He was married to Marian Ansbacher for 43 years before her death in 1993. Mr. Gruber served as a finance officer for 5 years during World War II. He made his career as an investment banker and private investor. He served as a consultant to the Board of Directors of Georgia Pacific. He was a former member of the Board of Directors of New Jersey National Bank, now part of First Union. Mr. Gruber was a benefactor of Monmouth Medical Center, Jewish Community Center, Federation of Monmouth County, and he served on the Board of Trustees of Monmouth College. He was a member of the Ocean Beach Club, Hollywood Golf Club, and Deal Golf and Country Club. He is survived by his wife Suzanne Raffel; a sister Yetta Gilinsky; a brother Sam; a stepdaughter Lois Levy; four grandchildren Diane and Bob Baxter; Nancy and Marc Lobell; three great-grandchildren Andrew Baxter; Marshall and Marian Lobell; and numerous nieces and nephews; all of whom loved him very much. Services are being held today, 2PM, at Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels, 2130 Highway 35, Ocean, NJ. Burial will follow at Temple Beth Miriam Cemetery in Neptune, New Jersey. Memorial contributions may be made to Monmouth Medical Center Health Care Foundation, 300 2nd Avenue, Long Branch, N.J. 07740.

title: INVESTMENT DROUGHT IN VIETNAM
description: Illustrating how foreign companies have soured on Vietnam, its state-run media reported that the country had approved $440.5 million in foreign investment in the first seven months of this year, a 44 percent drop from a year earlier. Last month, Vietnam signed a trade agreement with the United States that commits it to gradual changes that many hope will reverse the trend. But the International Monetary Fund has called for more urgent change: allowing unprofitable state-owned enterprises to fail, easing capital controls and strengthening banks. Wayne Arnold

title: NYT Article
description: Study Finds That Research Centers Are Key to High-Tech Growth

title: A 'Solid Recovery' Is Seen in Report on Brazil Economy
description: Brazil's economy grew 3.92 percent in the second quarter compared with the period a year earlier, the government said today in a report that suggested that the country's recovery from its devastating currency crisis in early 1999 was accelerating.

title: Now You Can Miss Your Show From Just About Anywhere
description: In what the company calls ''the ultimate remote control,'' owners of ReplayTV-based digital video recorders may soon be able to operate their recorders at home from anywhere in the world through the Internet. For example, a New Yorker traveling in Texas would be able to log on to the www.myreplaytv.com Web site, view hometown program listings, set the recorder to capture a show, view the amount of recording time left on the disk and make sure that the show is being recorded. Of course, that's assuming that the system works as described yesterday. ReplayTV concedes that it has not been tested outside the laboratory.

title: Fewer Inflation Alarms in New Fed Survey
description: The economy has slowed, dampening demand and keeping consumer prices in check, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic survey.

title: An Old-Fashioned Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Intolerance and an Attempt to Make Amends Unsettle a Chicago Suburb's Muslims
description: When a mosque offered to buy a church building and move into this suburb southwest of Chicago a few months ago, there were those who worried that it might not be universally welcomed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMIY, ABDOL HOSSEIN, M.D.
description: SAMIY-Abdol Hossein, M.D. On August 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Shahla. Loving father of Ahmad Ali and Golnaz Samiy. He is also survived by the Samiy and Khosrowshahi families. Service on Saturday, August 12, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations can be made to CAPCure Association for the Cure of Prostate Cancer, 1250 4th Street, Suite 360, Santa Monica, CA., 90401. Contact Jan Haber at 310-458-2873.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: The Modern Student: Batteries Not Included; For the Back-to-School Set, Electronic Gadgets Abound. Some of Them Can Even Be Used for Learning.
description: ROHNERT PARK, Calif., 60 miles north of San Francisco, is mostly white and middle class, but it is no Lake Wobegon. At the local high school, most of the students are academically average. SAT scores hover around 1025, and the dropout rate is low. Some of the sports teams shine, while others struggle. The homecoming dance in the fall and the prom in the spring are the year's two social high points.

title: Eugene R. Black, 75, Banker Who Was Active in Theater
description: Eugene R. Black, an investment banker, government adviser and off-Broadway playwright, died on April 24 in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: T-MOBILE SALE DELAYED
description: The German phone company Deutsche Telekom A.G. said it was delaying the share sale of its T-Mobile cellular phone unit to focus on the $50 billion purchase of the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation. Telekom, which had planned to sell the T-Mobile shares in September or October, said the pending acquisition of Voicestream made the compilation of the public offering prospectuses ''considerably more complex.'' Telekom has not said how much of the mobile unit it plans to sell, but analysts expect it to be as much as 10 billion euros ($9 billion) worth of the unit.

title: Thomas Wolff, Math Expert, Dies at 46
description: Dr. Thomas H. Wolff, a professor of mathematics at the California Institute of Technology who proved several important theorems in the study of mathematical functions and was regarded as a top expert in his field, died on July 31 in an automobile accident near Bakersfield, Calif. He was 46.

title: With Clouds as Neighbors: Family Retreat in the Andes
description: FRIENDS are envious when they hear that my wife, Rynn, and I have built a family retreat in the Ecuadorian Andes, with two mature orange trees in the yard and flocks of parrots flying by.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: Metro Matters; Gore's Choice: A Sober Joy In Validation
description: AT least as interesting as Al Gore's calculations in choosing a conspicuous Jew as his running mate has been the emotional response of New York Jews of every stripe and station.

title: NYT Article
description: Survey Finds More Women Than Men Online

title: Muscle Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Relocating After a Divorce, An Arts Group Seeks a Niche
description: Perhaps it was a marriage too good to last: a struggling Episcopal parish and an exuberant performing arts center, bound together to restore and protect an endangered Gothic Revival church in the heart of Brooklyn Heights.

title: In a Coup, Former Underlings Banish the Bedspread
description: DESIGNERS increasingly believe that the blanket makes the bed, even in summer (perhaps especially in summer, if the air-conditioner is blasting all night). Angel Zimick, a clothing designer who also creates bed linens and towels, dresses her beds in layers of blankets made of couture fabrics, believing them to be more decorative than bedspreads. ''Blankets add layers of texture and pattern to the top of the bed,'' she said.

title: Shifting Gears From Ballads To a Jolting Free-for-All
description: There's some explaining to do about the brilliant band playing at the Village Vanguard this week. At the moment New Directions is basically the alto saxophonist Greg Osby's quartet under another name, with Mark Shim on tenor saxophone. The group's original purpose when it formed last year and included the vibraphonist Stefon Harris was in part, to promote the Blue Note record label. It showed off the recent Blue Note signees Mr. Shim, Mr. Harris, and the pianist Jason Moran, alongside their frequent collaborator and ringleader Mr. Osby, by touring and recording together with a repertory of well-known tunes pulled from Blue Note records' back catalog -- a rather neat corporate idea.

title: Metropolitan Life Earnings Up 18% in Quarter
description: Metropolitan Life Insurance, the No. 1 United States life insurer by assets, said its second-quarter operating earnings rose 18 percent as cost cutting and strong life insurance sales offset losses in auto and home insurance.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS TO SELL YEAST UNIT FOR $125 MILLION
description: The Universal Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its yeast division, Red Star Yeast and Products, to Lesaffre et Compagnie of France for $125 million in cash. The Paris-based Lesaffre is a privately owned company and produces yeast and yeast extracts. Red Star Yeast supplies yeast to the commercial bakery market in North America. Universal Foods makes pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and household products. Shares of the Milwaukee-based Universal Foods rose $1.5625 each, to $20.6875.

title: Hamilton And Mets Cover Angles
description: A center fielder ran up a five-foot hill in the deepest part of any major league park in pursuit of a home run. The flight of a line drive stopped suddenly when the ball landed in the first row of nearby bleachers. A triple got wedged beneath the padding in the right-field corner.

title: Fund-Raisers for 2 Clintons Set for Eve of Convention
description: Vice President Al Gore has for months been planning the Democratic National Convention as a coming-out party for his presidential campaign and a long-awaited opportunity to step out of President Clinton's imposing shadow.

title: PAPER MAKER'S PROFIT DOUBLES
description: A Finnish forestry and paper company, the UPM-Kymmene Corporation, said its first-half profit had more than doubled because of higher prices and growth in delivery volumes. Profit before extraordinary items was 995 million euros ($896 million), up from 465 million euros a year earlier. Its revenue was 4.55 billion euros, up from 3.9 billion. Operating profit for the first half rose to 1.021 billion euros from 553 million in 1999.

title: A Pinch-Hitter Deluxe Is Thinking Team First
description: It is the classic question for an athlete in a team sport, and Darryl Hamilton was conflicted. Individual or team? When Hamilton was rehabilitating his toe injury in New York, he could not decide if he really wanted his replacements to succeed.

title: Con Ed's Rising Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Howard Safir's intention to resign as New York police commissioner referred incorrectly to his studies at Brooklyn Law School. He attended but did not graduate.

title: A Hometown Gets a Day to Cheer
description: The committee planning the 40th reunion in mid-November of the Stamford High School class of 1960 did not get much done at its meeting on Tuesday night. The committee members were far too distracted by the thought that their classmate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, might very well become the next vice president of the United States.

title: Metro Business; Funds to Rebuild Cities
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has announced that the state is allocating $55 million in federal funds to 111 municipalities for housing, redevelopment and infrastructure projects.

title: Iran Assembly Pushes on Women's Rights
description: Iran's reformist Parliament, fresh from a slap by the country's supreme leader, who ordered it to drop a bill for press reform, showed its determination today to forge ahead with social change and grant women additional rights by raising the marriage age.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN FIBER GETS INVESTMENT FROM LUCENT
description: American Fiber Systems Inc., a closely held designer and maker of fiber optic networks for midsize United States cities, said yesterday that it had received an investment of an undisclosed amount from Lucent Technologies Inc. American Fiber Systems, based in Rochester, makes networks that link the switching operations of local telephone, Internet, utility and long-distance phone providers. Lucent, the No. 1 telephone-equipment maker, has invested in 23 companies through its Lucent Venture Partners unit since the venture-capital subsidiary was formed in 1998. Lucent Venture Partners invests primarily in optical data, wireless-networking and semiconductor companies.

title: New York's Police Commissioner
description: The resignation of Police Commissioner Howard Safir, New York City's 39th police chief, provides the opportunity to praise him for his dramatic success over the last four years in cutting crime rates to their lowest levels since the 1960's. It also offers a chance for Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to choose the right successor to conclude his own term as mayor. Mr. Giuliani should pick someone who can not only keep crime rates low but also deal more expertly with the frictions between police and minorities that Mr. Safir leaves behind. It must be someone who can reassure all New Yorkers that keeping down crime does not involve a tradeoff in civil liberties.

title: Gordon Spivack, 71, Antitrust Lawyer and Ex-Justice Official
description: Gordon B. Spivack, a prominent antitrust lawyer and former senior Justice Department official, died at his home in New Haven on Sunday. He was 71.

title: OFFER FOR QUEBEC CABLE COMPANY
description: The huge pension fund of the province of Quebec and Quebecor Inc., a newspaper and electronic media publisher based in Montreal, have made a new all-cash offer of 4.9 billion Canadian dollars, or $3.3 billion, for Groupe Videotron, Quebec's largest cable company. At 45 Canadian dollars a share, it is 4 Canadian dollars less than the two companies proposed to pay in March -- but that offer was half cash and half stock. The new offer is higher than a rival bid from Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto, which valued at 4.9 billion Canadian dollars when it was made in February but is now worth 4.2 billion. Timothy Pritchard

title: Advanced Micro to Describe a Chip That Will Take On Intel
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. plans to release design details of its new 64-bit processor on Thursday, a chip that is intended to compete head on with the Intel Corporation's forthcoming Itanium. Advanced Micro said it expected the new chip to help it gain sales in the workstation and server market.

title: STUDY SAID TO FIND U.S. MISSILE SHIELD MIGHT INCITE CHINA
description: A highly classified intelligence report warns that deploying an American national missile defense could prompt China to expand its nuclear arsenal tenfold and lead Russia to place multiple warheads on ballistic missiles that now carry only one, according to officials who have reviewed it.

title: A selection of events and sites on the Web
description: A selection of events and sites on the Web

title: No Rise in Child Abuse Seen in Welfare Shift
description: When Congress abolished welfare as a permanent safety net four years ago, there were alarming predictions about the prospect of an already overwhelmed foster care system's being flooded by a new wave of abused children. But according to the early findings of two studies, the changes do not appear to have had such dire effects across the country.

title: Where the Diners Must Choose Sides
description: What's better than one Thai restaurant? Two. Wallaporn Vattanatham, who is known as Dang, owns Sal adang, a popular Thai restaurant in Pasadena. When she opened another restaurant across the street, she went for a fusion menu, and surroundings to reflect two cultures. Saladang Song (loosely, Dang's Retreat II) is by Tolkin & Byram & Associates, an architectural firm. It fuses Thai and Southern California methods and motifs and has an open courtyard, top, with walls, above, that are 22 feet high and are made of alternating concrete panels and laser-cut screens patterned like ancient Thai fabrics. 383 South Fair Oaks Avenue; (626) 793-5200.

title: Small Organ, Big Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Number in Prison Grows Despite Crime Reduction
description: After an eight-year drop in crime, the population of the nation's state and federal prisons grew last year at the lowest rate since 1979, 3.4 percent, the Justice Department reported yesterday.

title: Dangerous Kashmir
description: The Clinton administration is right to be concerned about the military confrontation between India and Pakistan over Kashmir, a conflict that American intelligence agencies now judge to be one of the world's most perilous. The dispute over who will control India's only Muslim-majority state has already provoked two wars. That was before New Delhi and Islamabad acquired nuclear bombs and medium-range missiles. Now any resumption of full-scale conflict carries the risk of starting a nuclear war between the two nations.

title: Soft Money Pours In For First Lady's Race
description: The national Democratic leadership, clearly concerned that Hillary Rodham Clinton is facing a tough Senate race in New York, has already channeled nearly $3 million into the state -- much of it from large, unregulated contributions known as soft money -- and is girding to spend far more.

title: Choosing Quick Hits Over the Card Catalog
description: WHEN Sam Vanderpol, a 15-year-old sophomore at Newton North High School in the Boston suburb of Newton, has trouble with his homework, he often turns to the Web for answers. ''I tried to use the Web for math once because I had forgotten a formula,'' he said. ''But I couldn't find the right sites.'' After an hour and a half, he gave up.

title: Article 2000081093169939572 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: When Women Called the Tunes; Rediscovering the Players Who Kept Things Swinging After the Men Went to War
description: They called Viola Smith the Female Gene Krupa for the way she would hurl her drumstick onto her drum, then jump up in the air and catch it as it bounced. Clora Bryant dazzled them with her trumpet solos. Roz Cron was known for the beautiful, clear tone and distinct phrasing of her alto sax and clarinet.

title: An investment bank drops the traditional.
description: THEY don't sell consumer goods. Although they are financial institutions, they don't have street-level branches, tellers or A.T.M.'s. Many people have no idea what they do, and few people will ever interact directly with one.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page obituary of the theatrical producer David Merrick on April 27 and three later articles, including one on July 19 about a memorial tribute at the St. James Theater, misstated the date of his death. It was April 25, not April 26. The David Merrick Arts Foundation reported the error in a fax to The Times on Friday.

title: Con Ed to Replace All Generators at Indian Point 2 Plant
description: After enduring months of withering criticism of its safety and financial practices, Consolidated Edison announced today that it would replace the steam generators before reopening the troubled Indian Point 2 nuclear plant.

title: Tread Failures Lead to Recall Of 6.5 Million Firestone Tires
description: The company that makes Firestone tires said today that millions of tires it had produced since 1991 seemed unusually prone to flinging off their treads, sometimes with catastrophic results. Facing 50 lawsuits, 46 deaths, 80 injuries and a federal investigation, the company said it would provide free replacements for the 6.5 million tires still on the road.

title: Carvin Swims From Deep Waters to Front of Pool and a Ticket to Sydney
description: Chad Carvin was a high-energy kid even before he started walking. At 8 months, he climbed atop the refrigerator, his mother said. By age 3, he was hang-gliding on the garage door. At 4, he had to be dragged off the roof.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The euro fell for a third day against the dollar as investors sought better returns outside the euro region. In New York, the euro settled at 89.93 cents, down from 90.20 cents on Tuesday.

title: TARGETED GENETICS TO ACQUIRE GENOVO, A RIVAL
description: The Targeted Genetics Corporation, a maker of gene- and cell-therapy products, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Genovo Inc., for $67 million in stock, gaining drugs in development and access to agreements with other biotechnology companies. Targeted Genetics also agreed with Biogen Inc., a major shareholder in closely held Genovo, to develop as many as four gene-therapy products and assist on an existing Biogen product. That accord, replacing one Biogen had with Genovo, is valued at as much as $125 million. Targeted Genetics will issue 6.63 million shares for Genovo, which is based in Sharon Hill, Pa.

title: Man in Stock Fraud Case Is Charged With Plotting to Kill Judge Who Raised His Bail
description: A New Jersey man awaiting trial on charges that he was involved in a scheme that bilked investors of $100 million was indicted yesterday on charges that he conspired to murder the Manhattan judge who has kept him behind bars since April.

title: Metro Business; John Wiley Leases Office in Hoboken
description: John Wiley & Sons, a leading publisher of scientific, medical and technical books based in Manhattan, has signed a lease for office space in Hoboken, N.J., where it plans to move its headquarters and 800 of its employees.

title: Things You Do to Keep Your Art Alive
description: Toward the end of the first scene of ''Beggar on Horseback,'' the character Dr. Rice gives his friend Neil a pill. It's not clear what's in the pill, but whatever it is it produces one bummer of a trip for the audience that has to sit through Neil's hallucinations for the next hour and a half.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a new retirement center for nuns in Hartsdale, N.Y., misidentified one nun, shown with Sister Margaret Gaffikin. She was Ann Coberg, not Mary Paschal Hill.

title: Ruling Clears Way For Generic Prozac
description: A federal appeals court ruling cleared the way for the sale of a generic version of Prozac, the world's top-selling antidepressant, as early as next summer, about two years earlier than expected.

description: SEOUL  The North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, apparently signaling a shift in the North's long-standing insistence that U.S. troops leave South Korea, has opened the way to having at least some of them stay here, analysts said Wednesday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Janus Capital Executive Quits Amid Turmoil
description: When executives of the phenomenally successful Janus family of mutual funds started feuding publicly with the management of their parent company last year, some investors feared the dispute would drive out top talent. Yesterday, Jim Craig, the No. 2 executive at Janus Capital, said he would leave but insisted that his resignation was unrelated to the feud.

title: 11 Killed as Small Planes Collide; Debris Sets New Jersey Home Afire
description: Two small planes collided in the sky over a southern New Jersey subdivision yesterday morning, killing all 11 people on board and raining bodies onto a soccer field and through the roof of a garage. One plane crashed through the roof of another two-car garage and exploded, setting fire to the home of a couple who were showering and dressing for work.

description: Greg Buxton is searching for sunken treasure of an elusive nature -- not gold or artifacts, but memories of 778 lives lost and largely forgotten in the depths of the Black Sea.
