title: Life's a Bowl of Whiffle Balls
description: Affluence and increased traffic noise are adding to the demand for fountains in Los Angeles. Jenna H. D. Beaufils designs them for others, but she made a whiffle ball fountain, above, for herself. (''For fun,'' she said, ''and as a reaction to the more permanent classic fountains'' she does.) The fountain, made of whiffle balls in a clear acrylic bowl with a recirculating pump, is $350. Her custom (and more permanent) fountains are available at Fountainhead, (323) 913-0915, for $800 to $25,000.

title: Researchers Harness DNA for Tiny Motors That Could Widen Use of Genetic Code
description: Portending a possible role for DNA beyond biology, a team of researchers at Bell Laboratories and Oxford University has fashioned molecular-sized motors out of the chemical that stores the genetic code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, JESS
description: BAUM-Jess, 74. Of Lake Worth, Florida, passed away August 7, 2000. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Baum graduated from New York University ''Summa Cum Laude''. He had served in the United States Armed Forces as Master Sargeant, serving his country in WWII. He had later worked in sales in the fashion industry and coaching little league. He was known as ''the greatest'' by all of his family and friends, who will miss him dearly. Mr. Baum is survived by his wife of 50 years, Lila Koreff Baum, and his son, Jonathan, also of Lake Worth, Florida. The funeral services will be in private. The funeral services are entrusted to Dorsey Funeral Home, 3525 South Congress Avenue, Lake Worth, Florida 33461.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's introduction of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman in Nashville as the first Jewish candidate on a major national party ticket referred incorrectly to Mr. Gore's comparison to John F. Kennedy. Kennedy was the first Catholic elected president; the first one nominated was Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York, the Democratic candidate in 1928.

title: New Jersey Transit, Reallocating Funds, Expects No Fare Increase 'in the Foreseeable Future'
description: State transportation officials said today that New Jersey Transit riders would not face a fare increase this fiscal year, despite earlier concerns that the agency might be short of money.

title: Corn-Husk Hem, Sweeping the Floor
description: The Los Angeles Craft and Folk Art Museum has opened an exhibition of handicrafts from Slovenia, which broke away from Yugoslavia in 1991. Rok Kvaternik, an entrepreneurial publisher based in Ljubljana, selected works by 100 top artisans. Some are based on continuing Slovenian traditions like egg dying, while others reinterpret traditional handicrafts in stone and wood, ceramics, fibers and leathers. At far left is a dress made of layered corn husks (traditionally woven) by Stanislava Vauda ($870). Janez Golob's wooden bowls are hand-turned. The exhibition runs through Sept. 3; 5814 Wilshire Boulevard, (323) 937-4230. Some of the crafts can be ordered from the museum store, (323) 857-4677. A painted Easter egg is $7, a hand-turned wooden bowl $90.

title: HIGHER PROFITS AT UPSTART AIRLINE
description: The second-quarter profit for Canada's low-fare air carrier, Westjet Airlines Ltd. of Calgary, more than doubled as a result of Westjet's extending its service into eastern cities and higher passenger loads that reflected fears of a pilots' strike at Air Canada, the nation's major airline. Profit for the latest quarter jumped 154 percent to 7.4 million Canadian dollars ($5 million), or 17 cents a share, handily beating the estimate of 12 Canadian cents a share by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Revenue rose 77 percent, to 80.1 million Canadian dollars. Westjet increased its capacity by 54 percent in the first half to compete in new markets, and it plans to double the size of its 17-plane fleet. Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, VIRGINIA L.
description: CAMPBELL-Virginia L. Of Chatham, NJ on August 7, 2000. Beloved sister of Ruth Bowden of Chatham. Loving aunt to Frank Bowden, Margaret Bowden and Virginia Kopelman. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Patricks RC Church, Chatham, New Jersey, on Saturday, August 12, 2000 at 9:00 A.M. Friends may call at Wm. A Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Friday from 2-4PM and 7-9PM. For further information go to www.bradleyfuneralhome.com

title: Jets' Martin Is a Role Player Who Can Play All the Roles
description: The Jets have run a bruising drill every day during training camp. It is a scrimmage designed to test, over and over, pounding after pounding, a goal-line situation. And nearly every day Curtis Martin squirts free, emerging from the maelstrom like a hiker finding daylight from behind a thicket of trees.

title: N.R.A. to Condemn Democrats During Convention
description: The National Rifle Association said today that it planned to run newspaper and television advertisements during the Democratic National Convention next week attacking the party for wanting ''to destroy the Second Amendment,'' in what the association's leaders called an effort to divide the Democrats' conservative and liberal wings over gun control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHDEV, VED, MD.
description: SACHDEV-Ved, MD. An internationally renowned professor and practitioner of neurosurgery and neuroanatomy passed away peacefully on August 8, 2000 at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City where he worked and taught for thirty years. Dr. Sachdev dedicated his life to the healing of others with skill and profound kindness. He was 68 years old. Having survived the partition of India and Pakistan which resulted in exile from his birthplace and family home and loss of his eldest sister Dr. Sachdev went on to study Medicine at Amristar Medical College of the University of Punjab. He then served as a Surgeon Lieutenant for the Indian Navy after which time he completed residencies in both Otolaryngology and Neurosurgergy in both India and England. Dr. Sachdev also earned the title of Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons from England in 1963 after which time he came to the United States at the age of 39 and completed an additional neurosurgical residency at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City. Dr. Sachdev quickly rose to a senior position in the Neurosurgery Department at Mt. Sinai where he acquired a reputation for both professional excellence and benevolence. During the course of thirty years practicing neurosurgery in Manhattan, he was named one of the ''Best Doctors in New York'' and one of the ''Best Doctors in America'' by New York Magazine for many years. Dr. Sachdev's legacy survives in all the students and residents he mentored at the Mt. Sinai School of Mediccine, including his two daughters, Ulka and Rivka. Despite a busy private practice, Dr. Sachdev cherished all opportunities to teach his residents and medical students, earning him a Best Teacher and Mentor Award by the neurosurgical residents at Mt. Sinai Hospital in 1992-1993. He approached education with an impressive fund of knowledge and, most notably, a sense of humor and charisma. From an early age, Dr. Sachdev had a star quality. In his earlier years of practicing medicine in India, Dr. Sachdev was the director of the Dramatic Club at the Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research in Chandigarh, India. He was known for his powerful public presence and easily captured people's attention. Dr. Sachdev was sincerely loved by all of those whose lives he touched. He is survived by his beloved wife Ranjit; his daughters, Rivka and Ulka; and his son-in-law, Michael. He is also survived by his brothers Dr. Krishan Sachdev and Dr. Janak Sachdev and by his sister, Mrs. Prem Parkash. Dr. Sachdev's beloved youngest sister, Vinod Nayar, is deceased. A visitation will be held on August 10, 2000 at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, NY (914-725-1137). Funeral services will be held at the same location at 10:30 a.m. on August 11, 2000. A fund is being established for a lecture series in Dr. Sachdev's name through the Neurosurgery Department at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: New Palms Emphasize Price, Power and Color
description: Just as the stores are stuffed with all the new fashions for fall, the fresh hot gadgets are beginning to roll out into the marketplace as well. Earlier this week, Palm Inc. announced its new product lineup, which includes a low-priced entry-level version of the Palm organizer, a RAM infusion for the company's wireless model and two new limited editions of the Palm Vx.

title: No Lectures or Teachers, Just Software
description: THE red phone on your desk rings in the middle of the night. The voice you hear is that of the White House chief of staff, alerting you to a crisis in the Eastern European country of Krasnovia. You're needed at the White House, pronto. ''We'll send a limo,'' he says, and hangs up. After an emergency meeting with the president, you're given a classified intelligence report and access to the country's foremost diplomats, policy analysts and military leaders. You are to submit a report in time for a presidential address that evening. The president is waiting to act on your recommendation.

title: Ford to Offer Stability Gear For S.U.V.'s
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would offer computerized stability systems on all of its sport utility vehicles and pickups by the 2005 model year, to improve the handling of the tall vehicles and reduce the frequency of rollovers.

title: Educational Company Says Its Scores Rise
description: Performance on standardized tests by students attending Edison Schools, the country's largest for-profit manager of public schools, improved at a faster rate last year than in the previous four years, even as the company enrolled more poor and minority students.

title: 'Jitney' Is Moving; 'Laramie' Will Close
description: August Wilson's drama ''Jitney'' is moving to the Union Square Theater, where performances are to start Sept. 19. The production, which opened at Second Stage Theater on April 25 and will continue there through Sept. 10, had to make room for the Second Stage's new season.

title: National Party Pumps Money To First Lady
description: The national Democratic leadership, clearly concerned that Hillary Rodham Clinton is facing a tough Senate race in New York, has mounted an unusually early effort to promote her candidacy. It has already channeled nearly $3 million into the state -- much of it from large, unregulated contributions -- and is girding to spend far more.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the process of choosing Al Gore's running mate misspelled the surname of Mr. Gore's foreign policy adviser. He is Leon Fuerth, not Furth.

title: 2 Babies, 1 Heart, 90 Minutes for a Miracle
description: When Sandra and Ramon Soto, a couple in their 20's from Puerto Rico, called Children's Hospital in Boston last year, it was to seek help for a desperate accident of nature. Mrs. Soto, a special-education teacher, was pregnant with twins. But the two tiny girls were fused at the chest and abdomen, locked in the classic embrace of Siamese twins. And only one had a heart.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Buchanan Coup Attempt
description: Eight years after the establishment of the Reform Party by Ross Perot, the party's machinery has apparently been seized -- or disabled -- by Patrick Buchanan, longtime scold on the Republican right. As a presidential candidate, Mr. Buchanan has little to offer the American public except the politics of resentment. But if he gets the Reform Party's presidential nomination this week, his tirades against free trade, affirmative action and abortion may draw votes away from Gov. George W. Bush, unless they help Mr. Bush by making him seem more moderate. In any case, it is enough to make one nostalgic for Mr. Perot, the eccentric Texas billionaire who founded the party.

title: TALKS ON RADIO DEAL END
description: The largest broadcaster in Mexico, Grupo Televisa S.A., said it had broken off talks to take over the nation's largest network of radio stations, Grupo Radio Centro, on concern that regulators would block the purchase. The combined company would have had 30 radio stations and nearly half the national radio audience, including 17 stations in Mexico City. The decision to break off talks dashed Televisa's plans to dominate the radio industry, as it does television. The Aguirre family, which controls Radio Centro, has been trying to sell its radio holdings for some time to concentrate on its telecommunications start-up, Maxcom.

title: Corrections

title: FINANCE MINISTER PLEDGES ACTION

Mr. Jin, the former planning and budget minister, was appointed finance minister as part of a broad cabinet shakeup. He is under intense pressure to require big conglomerates like Hyundai and Daewoo to pay billions of dollars in loans. Mr. Jin projected that the nation's economy would grow 8 percent this year, in line with a forecast of the previous cabinet. Samuel Len

title: Appeal Costs Davis in the Vanderbilt
description: Robbie Davis stood near the scales waiting to find out whether the stewards were going to let him into the winner's circle. He had been there twice already today, and as he wrangled the sprinter Intidab over the finish line a head in front of Successful Appeal it looked as if he had another good day in the books: a victory in the Grade II, A. G. Vanderbilt Handicap.

title: Essay; Two Kangaroo Tickets
description: For the first time since the 1920 election when Harding and Coolidge faced Cox and F.D.R. -- we have a competition between two ''kangaroo tickets.''

title: REED ELSEVIER PROFIT SLIPS
description: After two years of poor results, Reed Elsevier, the British-Dutch publisher that owns Lexis-Nexis and Variety, said it would meet its full-year earnings forecasts after a fall in first-half profits was lower than expected. The company is investing in online ventures as it pursues efforts to reduce costs. It said Internet spending had reduced first-half adjusted pretax profit to $:351 million ($529 million) from $:371 million a year earlier. Analysts had forecast profits of $:324 million to $:340 million. Reed Elsevier also said it was considering making an offer for Harcourt General, a textbook publisher, which was put up for sale in June. Alan Cowell

title: Architects Grow Reliant on the 40-Pound Pencil: The Computer
description: THE power of ones and zeroes is invading the centuries-old field of architecture, helping today's designers and artisans create structures that would otherwise be much more difficult -- or even impossible -- to build.

title: L.P.G.A. at 50: Progress Without Parity
description: Like a generation of baby boomers celebrating their 50th birthdays, the Ladies Professional Golf Association has taken a hard look in the mirror and, for the most part, likes the image it sees.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing It Your Way: Sorting and Copying
description: Doing It Your Way: Sorting and Copying

title: A Fashionable Hotel Settles a Job Bias Case
description: Nine bellhops all but one of them members of minorities -- who were fired from the trendy Mondrian hotel on the Sunset Strip in 1996 and replaced by whites will be paid $120,000 each under a settlement announced by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today.

title: A Garden Guru Who Knows When to Stop
description: DAVID SEELER is a practical man. When the landscape architect needed 25,000 tons of fill to build a ha-ha, or hidden fence, down the road from his house here, he decided to give his wife a pond for her 55th birthday.

title: For the New College B.M.O.C., 'M' Is for 'Machine'
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: What's the Longest Ride at Disneyland? The One Across the Parking Lot
description: The new parking structure at Disneyland in Anaheim can lay claim, for now, to being the world's largest. (A bigger one is already going up at Detroit Metropolitan Airport.) Completed this month, the Disney structure has 10,000 parking spaces and is 1,174 feet in length, longer than the Chrysler Building is tall. Walt Disney Imagineering chose a surprising design architect for this quotidian building, Harry Wolf (consulting for the architect, Walker Parking Consultants), an auteur of spare, geometric buildings. The goal, says Tom Kozlowski, director of master planning for Disney Imagineering, was to design something utilitarian in ''the tradition of great public works.''

title: Invite the Dalai Lama
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Trip With Vow To Travel High Road
description: Vice President Al Gore and his new Democratic running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, introduced each other to the folks back home today in a pair of appearances that sought to ground two men with disparate stories in the common embrace of family and community.

title: Role Playing Without Sacrificing Action
description: SOMETIMES the past is worth repeating. The original Diablo, released late in 1996, had its roots in the classics. Blizzard Entertainment's designers conceived it as a more lavish version of graphically spartan role-playing games like Hack and Rogue from the early days of computer gaming.

title: Lucent Service Provider Executive Resigns
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said this week that Patricia Russo would resign as executive vice president and chief executive of the service provider networks group, as the corporate chief executive, Richard A. McGinn, reorganizes the company after a profit warning.

title: Where Rubber Meets the Road; Recall of Firestone Tires Is Aimed at Damage Control
description: When Bridgestone/Firestone announced a recall yesterday of some 6.5 million Firestone tires, it was the company's first admission that the tires could pose a serious danger. But it was also a first step toward damage control.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, GELAL (GERRY)
description: KENT-Gelal (Gerry), 83. On August 8, 2000, at home in Manhattan of complications of Parkinson's Disease. Most beloved husband of Helga. Born in Istanbul, Turkey, he was graduated from the Academy of Fine Arts in Istanbul. He immigrated to the U.S. and served in the U.S. Army during the Second World War. Mr. Kent received a MS degree in architecture from Columbia University in 1947 and practiced architecture in New York with Emery Roth & Sons where he worked on many important Manhattan buildings. He is survived by his wife Helga in New York and a sister Suzan in Istanbul.

title: Arrest of Banker in Graft Case Poses a Test of Bosnia's Resolve
description: The arrest of a prominent Bosnian banker and former government minister is being watched by foreign officials here as a test of the government's resolve to fight corruption.

title: Decor by the Megabyte
description: Will Unit 26 do better than other Web sites selling contemporary designs for the home? The jury's out, but the new London-based company's site is as sleek as its products, by established and emerging artists and designers. Shown here are a blown Murano glass vase by Amy Cushing (26 inches high, $643) and a wenge-veneered birch screen by Andrew Tye (six feet high, $2,820). The site, promoted as ''The New Art Democracy,'' was founded by Anil Malhotra, a businessman who liked art but found the conventional art world intimidating. At www.unit26.com.

title: A Takeover With Problems For Japanese Tire Maker
description: Ever since the Bridgestone Corporation bought Firestone in one of the many high-profile Japanese takeovers of the 1980's, the United States tire maker has been a problem child.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: Nervous About Using Napster? Used CD's Are Bargains Online
description: TRADING in your compact discs can be a humiliating experience. As you stand at the counter, trying to recover some cash for a musical experiment gone awry or a summer hit that started to sound silly in the fall, you often learn that your $16.98 investment is now worth a couple of bucks -- or nothing at all.

title: Mogadishu Journal; Somali Business Thwarted by Too-Free Enterprise
description: There are five competing airlines here; three phone companies, which have some of the cheapest rates in the world; at least two pasta factories; 45 private hospitals; 55 providers of electricity; 1,500 wholesalers for imported goods; and an infinite number of guys with donkeys who will deliver 55 gallons of clean water to your house for 25 cents.

title: Pettitte Carries On Without Stottlemyre for Support
description: The faces they present for the outside world are similar. Andy Pettitte offers a smile and greetings delivered in a soothing Louisiana drawl, and if you read his lips on the mound in the worst of times, the words are G-rated.

title: ABC Reprimands Reporter Over Organic Food Report
description: ABC News executives said yesterday that they would reprimand John Stossel, the news correspondent, for a report challenging the assumed benefits of organic food that was based in part on evidence that did not exist. The producer of the segment, David W. Fitzpatrick, is to be suspended without pay for one month, they said.

title: Indonesian Leader to Cede Daily Duties to His No. 2
description: Battered by a hostile Parliament for his haphazard management style, President Abdurrahman Wahid said today that he would hand over daily government administration to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri.

title: WEB SITE IS SUED
description: Several news media concerns have sued GoSMS.com, a Web site based in Israel that sends subscribers headlines via cell phone, saying that much of the content offered by the company is being taken without permission from their Web sites. Among the plaintiffs in the suit filed in Federal District Court in New York six weeks ago were the CNN unit of Time Warner Inc., the Washington Post Company, Gannett Inc. and The New York Times Company. Bruce Keller, a lawyer for the media companies, said yesterday, ''There is no legitimate argument to the wholesale copying of content from The New York Times Web site and the Web sites of other major media organizations, particularly when those companies license that content to competitors of companies like GoSMS.'' Yuval Golan, chief executive of GoSMS, could not be reached for comment yesterday. Felicity Barringer

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: ROCKLAND COUNTY

title: The South Comes of Age On Religion and Politics
description: Max Heller had been mayor of Greenville, S.C., for seven years when he decided to run for Congress in 1978 and discovered the limits of religious tolerance in the South of the post-civil rights era.

title: A New Home Laser Printer At a Low Inkjet-Printer Price
description: Computer users seeking a laser printer at those low, low inkjet prices will find just the thing on the market later this month. Samsung Electronics is rolling out the ML-4500, a small, versatile laser printer for the unusually low street price of $199.

title: 26 Points of Light Will Show the Way For the Democrats
description: The Democratic National Convention, beginning here on Monday, has not prompted an extensive beautification of the city. But some projects have been speeded up for the delegates' arrival.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Glasses That Light Up the Day May Also Lighten Gloomy Spirits
description: FOR people who become depressed when the days grow short, a condition called seasonal affective disorder, one treatment is to sit in front of bright light for an hour or more each day. But a common complaint of patients is that they do not have time to do that regularly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SARA
description: FRIEDMAN-Sara. The administration and medical staff at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center joins with the Department of Dentistry in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Sara Friedman, beloved wife of our retiring Chairman of Dentistry, Jerome Friedman, M.D. To the entire Friedman family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Sigurd H. Ackerman, M.D. President & CEO Wendy Z. Goldstein Executive Vice President & COO Lawrence Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: August 10, 2000 Tony Cenicola for the New York Times Go to article

title: Police Say Tensions on Job Led to Killing of Supervisor
description: The tension between Steven Robinson and his supervisor in the housekeeping unit of a Queens nursing home had been building for more than a year, his family and co-workers said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARKER, SIDNEY
description: PARKER-Sidney. The love we shared, the life we lived oh, no, they can't take that away from your loving family. Happy Birthday.

title: INFORMIX TO CUT WORK FORCE AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: The Informix Corporation, a database-software maker, said yesterday that it would dismiss about 430 employees and take a third-quarter charge as part of a reorganization. The job cuts account for about 10 percent of the work force. The charge will total $75 million to $90 million and cover the cost of eliminating redundant jobs and operations while merging five business areas into two groups. Last month, the company's board replaced the chief executive, Jean-Yves Dexmier, with Peter Gyenes, who ran Ardent Software Inc. Informix bought Ardent in March. The company's second-quarter earnings fell 78 percent because of competition and the slow execution of a plan to sell more Internet software.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Telling the Japanese not to hunt whales is like telling the British to stop having their afternoon tea or denying French people their pate.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, J. MORSE
description: SMITH-J. Morse. The Partners and Staff of Proskauer Rose LLP mourn the loss of J. Morse Smith, a close friend for some 30 years. He will be missed by all who knew him and especially by those of us who had the great pleasure of working with him. We extend our sympathies to Morse's wife, Marilyn, to his sons, Matthew, David and Christopher, and to his colleagues at H.J. Baker & Bro., Inc., which company he lead with vision and heart.

title: No. 3 Bank in Britain May Buy a Top Mortgage Lender There
description: Britain's third-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., said today that it was negotiating to acquire Woolwich P.L.C., a leading British mortgage lender, for about $:5.5 billion ($8.3 billion). A deal could be reached by the end of the week, executives close to the talks said.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Rooted on the Edge of the Heartland
description: Rock 'n' roll demands some degree of self-exile. The music's idiosyncratic champions do not fit easily into families, whether biological or ideological. Yet many still want to claim a legacy to root their visions, and especially as they grow older, many seek images in red, white and blue.

title: The Hanging Gardens Of West 23rd Street
description: FROM May through September, it is not unusual to see pedestrians pause before the landmark Chelsea Hotel on West 23rd Street to stare at the balcony scene of flowers cascading from pots, planters and window boxes in front of one of its third-floor apartments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, JEANNETTE
description: BLUESTONE-Jeannette. On August 8, 2000. Beloved wife of Dr. Leon Bluestone. Loving mother of Terry Ann, Renee and mother-inlaw of Jeffrey Loving and David Schneider. Cherished grandmother of Loren and Olivia. Dear sister of Charlotte Picot, Charles and Paul Bialo, dear aunt and friend to many. We will always love you and miss you. Services Thursday at 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In America; Smiles All Around
description: It's a clever strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENOWITZ, WALTER
description: PRENOWITZ-Walter. On August 7, 2000 at age 93. Mathematics Professor Emeritus of Brooklyn College. Beloved husband of Marie and the late Sophie. Father of Edward and his wife, Gina. Grandfather of Amy and Eric. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, 1:30 PM.

description: Subterranean Attacks
