description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUTTER, BEATRICE WEINBERGER
description: SUTTER-Beatrice Weinberger. August 10, 1992. Beloved mother, always in our hearts. Larry and Bett

title: Woods Decides to Play A Week Before a Major
description: Tiger Woods is taking a different approach this week, but he wants the same results.

title: Ample Room for Play, and Everything in Its Place
description: A CHILD'S room is a stage where children squawk like parrots, transform themselves into Hansel and Gretel or paint, fresh from their imaginations, a picture of a red tree on a cobalt blue ground. The more visible the toys, the easier it is for a child to play.

title: Between the Conventions, Lieberman Is Topic A
description: To the Editor:

title: Population Trends Heighten West's Fire Woes
description: After a steep hike to the top of a hill overlooking Dixon Creek near here, Bobby Kitchens pointed today to a mound of rubble surrounded by blackened trees, smoking stumps and, everywhere, a two-inch layer of gray soot.

title: Formative Years at Yale
description: College life in the 1950's was once described as the bland leading the bland. Certainly on every campus there were professors with disquieting thoughts and more than a handful of students who worried about the world's future as much as their own. But most students in the 50's considered their education more for gain than for growth.

title: Extent of Telephone Strike May Have Surprised Target
description: As Verizon Communications prepares to enter its fifth day of bargaining with its striking unions, the question arises: Has Verizon received more than it bargained for with this strike?

title: Three Executives Form Own Agency
description: Sal Catalano, Jason Lellos and Jeff Silverstein -- three executives from FUEL North America in New York, part of Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG -- have left to form their own agency specializing in integrated marketing and brand consulting. Catalano Lellos & Silverstein in New York has eight employees working for clients like CarDay.com.

title: Article 2000081091633724608 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: CONOCO TO SELL FUEL ONLINE
description: Conoco said yesterday that it would sell fuel on the American Petroleum Exchange, an Internet-based wholesale market for gasoline and diesel fuel. The exchange, which is scheduled to open in early September, will function as a reverse auction, with customers listing their fuel needs and suppliers, like Conoco, bidding for the contracts. A Conoco spokeswoman said the company had not set aside a specific amount of fuel to sell through the exchange, noting that volume would be determined by demand. Neela Banerjee

title: Corruption and Repression Afflict the Region : Central Asian Regimes Backslide on Democracy
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  Last of three articles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDERNESS, BENJAMIN STILWELL
description: HOLDERNESS-Benjamin Stilwell. Died August 8, 2000. Mr. Holderness was born at West Point, NY on September 5, 1915. He was a graduate of the Salisbury School, Salisbury, CT and received a BS from Yale University in 1939. During WWII he served as a pilot in the US Army Air Corps, ''Fireball Airline.'' He was married in 1942 to Zoe C. Thorne of Bedford Village, NY and moved to Bedford in 1950, where they raised four children, John, David, Timothy, and Mary. In 1945, Mr. Holderness founded Aqua Gun Company and was a pioneer in underwater photography, scuba diving and equipment design. He is survived by his wife, four children and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Bedford in September.

title: Insurance Investigation Faults Nassau Leaders
description: The Nassau County executive and other officials turned a blind eye while connected Republican businessmen concocted a health insurance deal that cost the county $40 million, an independent investigator said in a report released today.

title: Computer Versus Tutor
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRMUNN, SADIE
description: FIRMUNN-Sadie. On August 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Edward; loving mother of Anita Harris and mother-in-law of Douglas Harris. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Brad (Sandy). Services private. She will forever be in our hearts.

title: Wieden Executive Joins Fallon Agency
description: A top creative executive at Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., is leaving to join Fallon Minneapolis.

title: Republicans Seeking Parity In TV Convention Coverage
description: In the race to be president, every second counts. At least that was the message Republican officials sought to convey yesterday in demanding that the three major television networks devote ''not a minute more'' air time to the Democrats' convention next week in Los Angeles than they had to the Republican gathering in Philadelphia.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. *denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 7.

title: Kosovo Polje Journal; His Serbian Flock Scattered, the Priest Reflects
description: The Rev. Radivoje Panic has had more than his share of parishes.

title: Government Moves to Block A New Form of Tax Shelter
description: The Treasury Department took another step today in its long-running effort to curb the use of tax shelters, acting to shut down a sophisticated new tax-reduction technique that it said was being marketed to corporations and wealthy individuals by some of the big accounting firms.

title: An Era Of Exotic Mirages
description: MUSEUMS, with their deep storage and archival mission, have long served as quiet graveyards for discarded art. But these days they seem to be functioning more like rehab centers.

title: Sticker Shock: Should There Be a Law?
description: BUMPER-TO-BUMPER warranties are a given. Bumper-to-bumper free speech is not.

title: Metro Business; Aetna Is Changing System of Payments
description: Aetna U.S. Healthcare will change its payment system for all its primary care doctors in Connecticut in an effort to improve relations with physicians in Connecticut, Aetna officials said yesterday.

title: Pilot Woes: Why Employee Ownership Didn't Help UAL
description: AT least two lessons can be learned from the current United Airlines fiasco, in which the airline's profits are plunging as it cancels flights and apologizes profusely to customers.

title: Cable Offshoot Branches Out
description: As the new digital technologies continue to transform the movie business, established companies are looking for ways to protect their franchise while taking advantage of new opportunities. One example is IFC Films, an offshoot of the Independent Film Channel cable network, which was itself an offshoot of Bravo, the upscale cultural channel that started up in 1980.

title: Thomas Foran, 76, U.S. Attorney Who Prosecuted Chicago Seven
description: Thomas Aquinas Foran, a Chicago trial lawyer best known as the pugnacious prosecutor in the Chicago Seven conspiracy case of 1969 and 1970, died on Sunday at his home in suburban Lake Forest, Ill. He was 76.

title: French Nazi Memorabilia Case Presents Jurisdiction Dilemma
description: In Europe, where memories of World War II are still fresh in the minds of those who lived through it, the sale of Nazi and Fascist memorabilia often sparks indignation.

title: Polo Ralph Lauren Sues Jordache Over Sport Emblem
description: Forget the horses and the wooden mallets. This polo match is taking place in a courtroom, not on a field.

title: S.E.C. Approves Regulation Against Selective Disclosure
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a new rule yesterday that bans companies from giving important information to analysts and professional investors before disclosing it to the public.

title: The Battle of the Bandwidths; Space Is Coveted as Wireless Expands
description: Traveling recently through Morocco, Lowell W. Paxson marveled when he used his cell phone to view a street map enabling his driver to find an obscure restaurant there.

title: Testing the Durability of Welding as a Creative Form
description: Rumors of the death of painting circulated widely during the 1970's, only to be disproved by subsequent decades. But it seems that a less publicized but possibly better founded rumor of death has been in play recently: that of welded sculpture.

title: Touring the Boroughs
description: When conversation turns to dining out in New York City, Manhattan is sometimes the assumption. But there are five boroughs in town, each offering its share of interesting restaurants. Here are a dozen from a long list of inviting possibilities in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: U.S. Child Poverty Rate Fell as Economy Grew, But Is Above 1979 Level
description: Child poverty rates fell significantly in many states in the current economic boom, but nationwide, and in all but a handful of states, child poverty is still higher than it was 20 years ago, according to a study released today by the National Center for Children in Poverty at Columbia University.

title: Tire Technology Has Bred Consistency and Compatibility
description: No one yet knows what caused a disproportionate number of Firestone tires to fail on Ford Explorers, or why many of the failed tires seem to have come from one Firestone plant in Decatur, Ill. But when it comes to tire design, manufacture and composition in general, experts are unanimous about one thing: Tires on the road today are safe, when they are used as intended.

title: Lieberman Choice Opens Door to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Piazza Takes Peek Toward Future
description: Mike Piazza rapped his knuckles on the wooden locker stall, chasing away the baseball gods who would zap him for the statement he was making.

title: Brazil Raises $4.04 Billion In Oil Company's Stock Sale
description: Overcoming weeks of pessimism and low expectations, the Brazilian government raised $4.04 billion today from the sale of 180 million ordinary voting shares of the state-owned oil company Petroleos Brasileiros, or Petrobras.

title: DUPONT SAYS IT IS EXPANDING INTO MONEY MANAGEMENT
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the world's largest chemical company, is diversifying into managing other people's money. The company is following the lead of other industrial companies, including General Electric and AMR, lured by the potential steady income of money management. DuPont said yesterday that it would initially offer two portfolios to institutions, like pension funds, and that it had no immediate plans for mutual funds. It can expand with little added expense, however. Its in-house investment operation, DuPont Capital Management, already manages DuPont's $18 billion employee pension with a team of 49.

title: Coca-Cola Rolls Out 'Enjoy' Commercials
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it was beginning a new television advertising campaign for its Coca-Cola Classic brand using the slogan ''Enjoy.''

title: In Their Own Worlds: Giant Hybrids of Fact and Fantasy
description: ''Unnatural Science'' at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is a well-done exhibition. The first serious theme show to be organized in the vaulting refurbished factory spaces of Mass MOCA, which opened to the public last year, it is thoughtfully installed, coherent yet diverse, and presents most of its participants to good advantage.

title: Conoco Bids to Develop Nigerian Oil Field
description: Conoco Inc., the fourth- biggest United States oil company, said today that it and its partners -- the Phillips Petroleum Company and USX-Marathon Group -- had bid $164 million for the right to jointly develop an oil field off Nigeria's coast.

title: Starting Off With Sex, Ending Up With Love
description: ''An Affair of Love'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series under the title ''A Pornographic Affair.'' Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 24. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Defying Gore and the Party, Congresswoman Is Going Ahead With Playboy Event
description: A California congresswoman who is an ally of Vice President Al Gore announced today that she was going ahead with plans to hold a fund-raiser on Tuesday at the Playboy mansion in Los Angeles, despite pleas from Mr. Gore's campaign and Democratic leaders to move the event.

title: 9 Subway Agents Made Cash On Spent Cards, Police Say
description: With a certain twist of the wrist and some underhanded salesmanship, it is possible to make a lot of money from discarded MetroCards, the reusable electronic tickets that have pushed the New York City subway token into near-obsolescence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKERLIE, JOHN V.
description: McKERLIE-John V. 77, of Ft. Pierce, FL (formerly of Far Rockaway, NY) on August 8, 2000. Retired professional civil engineer. Beloved husband for 55 years of Gloria. Loving father of John Jr., Helen Marie Natt and Patti Channon. Dear brother of Judy Harris and Patricia Rapkoch. Proud grandfather of six grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Visiting Friday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Arthur F. White Funeral Home Inc., 234 Broadway, Bethpage, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 AM at St. Martin of Tours RC Church (Bethpage). Interment following at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMIY, ABDOL HOSSEIN, M.D.
description: SAMIY-Abdol Hossein, M.D. On August 9, 2000. Beloved husband of Shahla. Loving father of Ahmad Ali and Golnaz Samiy. He is also survived by the Samiy and Khosrowshahi families. Service on Saturday, August 12, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations can be made to CAPCure Association for the Cure of Prostate Cancer, 1250 4th Street, Suite 360, Santa Monica, CA., 90401. Contact Jan Haber at 310-458-2873.

title: The Anti-Woodstock, Coolly Captured
description: When last year's 30th-anniversary incarnation of the Woodstock festival ended in a welter of mayhem, sexual abuse and overall bad vibes, a few commentators chided the Limp Bizkit generation for falling so far from the ideals that had supposedly inspired the original festival. But the betrayal of the peace, love and flowers ethic, according to one of the 60's enduring myths, didn't require three decades. Less than six months after the first Woodstock, the first -- and definitive -- anti-Woodstock took place in December 1969 at the Altamont Motor Speedway, outside of San Francisco, where the Rolling Stones concluded their North American tour with a hastily organized free concert.

title: 'Inside Art'
description: The ''Inside Art'' column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: No More Mr. Regular Citizen: It's Back to the Bad Old Days
description: ''Money changes everything,'' Cyndi Lauper once sang in her cover of the Brains' original, and as Sally, a bar owner in ''The Opportunists,'' she gets to watch that aphorism take on a sad and poky life. Money could change the life of Vic (Christopher Walken), her boyfriend and the picture's protagonist, an ex-felon who might as well sport a ''Born to Lose'' T-shirt.

title: A Union-Created Group Attacks Bush on Health Care Issues
description: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, through a group it created called American Family Voices, has joined the political advertising wars with a 30-second television spot titled ''Invest.'' The advertisement takes George W. Bush to task for several decisions he has made as governor of Texas and tries to link them to large contributions to him and the Republican Party from the insurance, nursing home and drug industries. The slickly produced advertisement does not urge viewers to vote against Mr. Bush or for Vice President Al Gore, but asks them to call Mr. Bush's office or visit the sponsoring group's Web site.

title: SPIKE IN BRAZIL INFLATION
description: The inflation rate in Brazil reached a five-year high in July, reflecting government price increases in gasoline, electricity and telephone service. The government's benchmark inflation index rose 1.61 percent last month, compared with an increase of 0.23 percent in June. In the last 12 months, inflation totaled 7.1 percent, higher than Brazil's target of 6 percent for 2000. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Cablevision Systems Plan for Offering
description: By The Associated Press

title: SUN EXTENDS VIGNETTE ALLIANCE
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., whose computers run corporate Web sites, and the software maker Vignette Corporation will expand their marketing alliance and develop Internet-commerce software tailored to run on Sun computers. Sun will also introduce people to Vignette products through Sun's network of customer learning centers. Financial terms were not disclosed. Vignette's shares rose $1.625, or 4.5 percent, to $37.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHMAN, REBECCA
description: ROHMAN-Rebecca, August 7. Beloved wife of the late Richard. Mother of Linda, step-mother of Michael, adoring grandmother of Annie, mother-in-law of Alex Schwartz, sister of Belle Tarlow, aunt of Victoria DeBruin. A gentle, loving person who will remain in our minds and hearts.

title: Flag Prompts Request to Move Out of Georgia
description: When the executive committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association meets in Indianapolis today, it will consider a request to move three of its basketball championships from Atlanta because Georgia uses the Confederate battle symbol as part of its state flag.

title: Fear Spreads as Spanish and Basque Blood Flows
description: It is not hard to find the spot on the sidewalk here where Jesus Maria Pedrosa was gunned down in June as he walked home on a quiet Sunday after watching a basketball game with friends.

title: A Lady and Lots of Steam, But Still O.K. for 3-Year-Olds
description: Thomas and the Magic Railroad

title: Putting And Karma Put Austin In the Lead
description: When Woody Austin comes to the Buick Open, his game somehow comes together.

title: On the Path to Create a School of Thought
description: GREGORY JAVAN MILLS is talking about the collection he has spent 20 years assembling: 5,000 films starring black actors or made by black producers and directors. There is ''Tamango,'' with Dorothy Dandridge as a slave who has a love affair with her master. There is ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads,'' an early film by Spike Lee. There is ''Harlem Rides the Range,'' an all-black western from the 1940's.

title: AVIS PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $100 MILLION OF STOCK
description: Avis Group Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $100 million in common stock in an effort to improve its share price. The buyback would represent about 4.21 million shares, or 13 percent of its 31.3 million shares outstanding. The buyback will be financed with cash flow from operations, the company said. Avis, the No. 2 car-rental company after Hertz, had revenue of $4.1 billion last year. Shares of Avis, which is based in Garden City, N.Y., rose 93.75 cents, to $24.6875.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Approves Regulation To End Selective Disclosure

title: Russians Say Anti-Mine Group Aids Rebels
description: With Russian casualties mounting from land mine attacks in Chechnya, the Federal Security Service today accused a London-based mine-clearing organization of providing military training and assistance to rebel forces still engaged in attacks and ambushes against Russian security forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, MARY
description: FRIEDLAND-Mary. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLAN, MILDRED CINER
description: BERLAN-Mildred Ciner. On August 9, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Oscar. Dear sister of Helen Kass. Much loved aunt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Newark's efforts to increase tourism by giving a two-day tour of the city's neighborhoods to 40 travel agents misstated the name of the older neighborhood of Victorian houses they visited. It is Forest Hill, not Forest Heights.

title: RUSSIA RAID TOUCHES ANOTHER OLIGARCH
description: The federal tax police in Russia seized documents from the Sibneft Oil Company, in which a close friend of Boris N. Yeltsin's family, Roman Abramovich, is a major shareholder. President Vladimir V. Putin, elected in March, is trying to distance himself from the country's richest men, who wielded great influence in the government of Mr. Yeltsin. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Fulfilling the Job Description: Thin, Catty and Self-Obsessed
description: ''Intern'' takes such relentless glee in skewering the pretensions of the fashion industry that it's difficult to choose the nastiest bit in a movie crammed with mean-spirited caricatures and catty bons mots. My favorite happens to be the moment when Jocelyn Bennett (Dominique Swain), a sleek young intern at Skirt magazine, takes a cup of iced cappuccino to Antoinette De la Paix (Anna Thompson), a grim, bony-faced editor.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article on Tuesday about Janet Cardiff, who incorporates her voice into artworks, misidentified her hometown. It is Lethbridge, Alberta, not Ontario.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Portland, Ore.; Seattle

title: Repentant Clinton Reviews His Presidency
description: Four thousand church members bowed their heads today and prayed for a sinner in their midst -- a man who, like them, was struggling in his life with right and wrong.

title: Soft, Cute and New on the Farm; Far From Andes, Alpacas Turn Heads and Even Profits
description: Screech. Slam. Ooh. Ahh.

title: A Trap of Welfare And Child Abuse
description: I have represented abused and neglected children in court for decades, and, like many others in close contact with the child welfare system, I never bought the predictions that welfare reform would send more parents into the pathology of abuse. I thought the opposite, because I expected the birth rate for teenagers on welfare to go down once the system stopped encouraging births. That would mean fewer families under intense stress.

title: Bridgestone To Register Record Charge
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said today that it would record a $350 million one-time accounting charge to its earnings to cover the costs of an extensive recall of problem tires produced by Firestone, its troubled United States subsidiary.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about growing opposition to the execution of mentally retarded prisoners misstated the timing of the execution of Mario Marquez in 1995 on the day George W. Bush was inaugurated as governor of Texas. The execution occurred in the morning, before the inauguration, not in the evening. Mr. Marquez's petition for clemency was rejected by Lt. Gov. Bob Bullock after he consulted Mr. Bush's aides.

title: Decrease in Petroleum Costs Kept July Import Prices Level
description: Prices of imported goods were unchanged in July as a decline in the cost of petroleum offset increases for autos and some raw materials, government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, ALBERT C.
description: THOMPSON-Albert C. Of Huntington Station, on August 10, 2000. Loving husband of Barbara (nee McLaughlin). Beloved father of Myles and Doreen. Cherished father-in-law of Liana. Dear brother of Arthur C. and Robert C. Associated with Custom Travel in Amityville. Reposing Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at M. A. Connell Funeral Home Inc., 934 New York Ave, Huntington. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 AM at St. Elizabeth's Church, Melville. Interment at Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn. Donations to Good Samaritan Hospice, 655 Deer Park Ave., Babylon, NY 11702 or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, New York 10131-0112 are appreciated.

title: For Old Money, A New Home On Wall Street
description: Coin collecting is one field that is, literally, child's play. The United States Mint reports that millions of Americans collect coins, new and old, and that of these, tens of thousands are children who are on the prowl for historic American gold, silver and copper coins. Now there is a new source in Manhattan for coins, as well as historical American documents.

title: Concorde Panel Says Metal Strip Probably Caused Tire to Burst
description: French investigators looking into the crash last month of an Air France Concorde said today that a 16-inch piece of metal found on the runway probably caused a tire to blow out, sending debris from it through fuel tanks and starting a fire that erupted as the plane took off.

title: A Fickle Electorate
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Said to Find U.S. Missile Shield Might Incite China
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  A highly classified intelligence report warns that deploying an American national missile defense could prompt China to expand its nuclear arsenal tenfold and lead Russia to place multiple warheads on ballistic missiles that now carry only one, according to officials who have reviewed it.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GAS PRICES RISE. Gasoline prices rose 5 percent, the biggest gain in 10 weeks, on concern the fuel will be in short supply in coming weeks. In New York, gasoline for September delivery rose 4.4 cents, to 92.64 cents a gallon.

title: Lights! Camera! Artillery! This Is All-Out War!
description: When was it that the films of John Waters stopped seeming so subversive and began feeling like nostalgia-drenched fables of rebellion with a warm and fuzzy tinge? Or is just that the times have changed enough for us to realize that Mr. Waters's movies have always essentially been cheery twisted sitcoms improvised by a goofy extended family in an imaginary suburban attic? Snug in their Saturday afternoon play world, the actors gleefully pluck whatever garish costumes catch their eye from a giant trunk and turn the pop culture wars of the last half-century into sophisticated children's theater.

title: Sinatra Statue? Not on Our Traffic Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Schein Subpoenaed by States on Pricing
description: Schein Pharmaceutical Inc., a generic-drug maker, said today that New York, Florida, Nevada and other states had issued subpoenas seeking information on its drug-pricing practices.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: It's Hard to Rear an Angel, Especially in Devil Town
description: The new thriller ''Bless the Child'' is runny with heartbreak; it's a supernatural soap opera. Maggie (Kim Basinger) is a dedicated psychiatric nurse who has a warm, flattering light on her even when she rides in the back of a Manhattan bus. When her angry younger sister, Jenna (Angela Bettis), shows up with a newborn daughter, old family conflicts flare. Maggie growls at Jenna for being a drug addict, and Jenna snaps back that at least she was able to give birth, leaving her barren sister speechless. Then Jenna leaves altogether, abandoning Cody, her little girl, at Maggie's apartment.

title: In Reversal, China Lets Chen Race For U.S.
description: Yueling Chen, the first Chinese woman to win an Olympic gold medal in track and field, was granted a waiver by Chinese sports officials yesterday to compete in race-walking for the United States at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.

title: Ex-Leader Admits Defrauding Police Group
description: The former No. 2 man in the New Jersey State Policemen's Benevolent Association pleaded guilty today to defrauding the organization and its members of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRE, SISTER M. ISOLINA
description: FERRE-Sister M. Isolina. The entire community of Bank Street College of Education mourns the loss of Sister M. Isolina Ferre, a former trustee and friend of the College, whose inspiring leadership and devotion to the disenfranchised earned her one of the United States' highest honors, the Medal of Freedom. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and loved ones. Augusta Souza Kappner, President Elizabeth S. Pforzheimer, Chair Bank Street College of Education

title: Pfizer Chief to Retire, Leaving Successor Hard Act to Follow
description: William C. Steere Jr., the chief executive of Pfizer Inc., will retire at the end of the year and will be replaced by Henry A. McKinnell, a 29-year manager of the drug company, who has long been seen as its next top executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HAROLD
description: LEVINE-Harold. The officers and staff of Acker & Jablow Textiles express their deep sorrow at the passing of our longtime friend, Harold Levine. He was an astute, devoted and loyal associate of the company and was a very integral part of our growth. Harold was a gentleman in the truest sense and will be greatly missed. Our most sincere condolences to his wife, Harriet; children, Donna and Jay; their spouses, Mark and Debra; and grandchildren, Brett, Randall and Fallon. Al Steinberg, Steven Steinberg,

title: Aw, All They Want Is a Chance to Play
description: ''You're not even a has-been; you're a never-was!'' a striking pro football player cracks about Shane Falco (Keanu Reeves), the honorable, stoic fill-in quarterback -- yes, scab -- in ''The Replacements.''

title: Retail Plan for Armory Upsets School Advocates
description: A City Hall plan to rebuild the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx as a retail complex drew more than 200 protesters to the huge, fortress-like building yesterday, where they called for new school rooms instead of chain stores on the site.

title: Where Hindenburg Fell, Midair Crash Revives Talk of Curse
description: A grim hush fell over the Airship Tavern this afternoon as the enlisted men and naval engineers put down their beers and glanced at the overhead television, its screen showing the wreckage of a shattered aircraft that took the lives of six of their co-workers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Going Without Saying: More Bumpers Are Bare
description: ''My other car is a broom.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, LEONARD
description: BERG-Leonard, 73. Loving father of Mitchell & Nancy. Grandfather to Elizabeth, William and Laura. Lifelong cherished twin brother of Fred. Dearest daddy, brother, grandpa and friend. We pray that you are now at peace. We love & miss you and will always carry you in our hearts and memory. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Alzheimer's Association of New York City, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th floor, NY 10017.

title: Legislatures Of the World Call Congress 'The Rudest'
description: More than 170 speakers of legislatures around the world plan to meet here for the first time later this month to celebrate a little-noticed byproduct of the spread of democracy: the growth and strengthening of national parliaments.

title: Toyota Tells British Suppliers to Use Euros Instead of Pounds
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it had instructed British components suppliers to do business in euros instead of pounds. The move reflected the distress among automakers and other manufacturers here over the pound's high value relative to the euro, a situation that has made British exports to Europe expensive.

title: Germany Decides Online Sex Workers Have Rights
description: August 11, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROSNEY, NEIL
description: KROSNEY-Neil. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Baiting Club mourn the untimely passing of our longtime member and dear friend, Neil Krosney. He served with distinction as our Past President and Chairman of our Board of Governors for many years. As someone who truly enjoyed EBC the empty lounge in front of his cabana will serve as a constant reminder of a friend lost before his time. Our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. He will be sorely missed. Robert Fagenson, President Jane Guadagno, Secretary

title: Moguls Rattled by Gore's Choice of Critic of Entertainment Industry
description: The entertainment industry is facing the Democratic National Convention here next week with some last-minute jitters. Vice President Al Gore's choice of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as his running mate has chilled wealthy Hollywood Democrats, who are upset that Mr. Lieberman is one of the Senate's most vocal critics of Hollywood.

title: Ali Is Coming Back: Once on NBC and Once on HBO
description: ''Twice Born,'' a 43-minute cinematic valentine about his life, had just concluded when Muhammad Ali rose slowly from his seat to proclaim, ''Time for a comeback.''

title: U.S. Acts to Tighten Protection of Wetlands
description: The Clinton administration today proposed new rules to protect environmentally sensitive wetlands from development, a response to what administration officials called a recent rash of destruction.

title: Aid Is Pledged to Help Yonkers End U.S. Oversight of Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday pledged $10 million to help Yonkers end 14 years of federal control of its school system imposed by a court-ordered desegregation plan.

title: Bush Is Joined By McCain On a Tour Of the West
description: With an eye toward independent-minded voters here and elsewhere on the West Coast, Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain today joined forces on the campaign trail for the first time in the 2000 presidential race, burying their once-bitter rivalry under a resolve to put a Republican in the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, J. MORSE
description: SMITH-J. Morse. Of New Canaan, Connecticut, 71, died at his home on Tuesday night. He was the Chairman and CEO of the family company, H.J. Baker & Bro., Inc. of Stamford which is currently celebrating its 150th year. He was the son of the late Henry V.B. Smith and the late Nancy Calder Smith. A descendant of several old Knickerbocker families, his family traces its origins in New York to the early 1620's. Mr. Smith graduated from Deerfield Academy and attended Syracuse University. He served in the Korean War where he was wounded at Heartbreak Ridge, receiving the Purple Heart. Morse began his career with H.J. Baker in 1952, bringing the business into new areas of activity with his late brother Rutger. He was an avid boater and member of the Country Club of New Canaan. Morse is survived by his wife Marilyn Williams Smith, his sons Matthew, David and Christopher, and his step-children Jack, Michael, Jeffrey and Laura Williams. He is also survived by his brother Malcolm and six Smith grandchildren and seven Williams grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan on Sunday, August 13 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Waveny Care Center of New Canaan or a charity of your choice.

title: In Love in Wartime Berlin, And Defying Understanding
description: Opposites attract, according to conventional wisdom and movie mythology, though platitudes are inadequate to explain why Felice Schragenheim (Maria Schrader), a Jew living undercover in Nazi Berlin, would fall in love with Lilly Wust (Juliane Kohler), an Aryan poster girl married to a German officer and the mother of four strapping blond boys.

title: Vishay Stock Buyback
description: Vishay Intertechnology, a maker of transistors and other electronic components, said today that it planned to buy back as many as five million of its shares. The repurchase represents about 4.4 percent of the company's shares outstanding as of June 13 and would total about $131 million based on the company's closing share price today of $29.75.

title: Starting Off With Sex, Ending Up With Love
description: ''An Affair of Love'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series under the title ''A Pornographic Affair.'' Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 24. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Article 2000081192401889080 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Birth of a Candidate: Al Gore Goes Into the Family Business
description: For years -- since college, anyway -- Al Gore had been telling friends that the very last thing he would ever do with his life was go into politics. That was fine for his father, he would say, but not for him.

title: Corrections
description: A credit line was omitted in Business Day on Aug. 2 for a picture of the Honest Tea Company's founders and officers, Barry Nalebuff and Seth Goldman. The photographer was Justin Lane.

title: Jets Shuffling Quarterback Deck Against the Ravens
description: Five series are all that separate Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde from his lost season. Just 34 plays, 17 in each of the first two preseason games, to shake off the rust, work out the leg and feel out the new receivers. But Coach Al Groh is apparently comfortable enough with the first-team offense, which has scored on three of the five Testaverde-led possessions, and secure enough with the limited work Testaverde has had, to juggle the quarterback rotation for Saturday's game against Baltimore.

title: Bomb Kills 10 In Kashmir; Rebels Claim Responsibility
description: First came a grenade, going off near a bank and luring the police and journalists to inspect the damage. Then, 15 minutes later, a car bomb exploded within feet of the crowd, killing at least 10 people today in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital.

title: Ambivalence in China On Expanding Net Access
description: China's unease with the Internet is growing as the country embraces the new medium to modernize its economy yet worries about the Web's spread beyond government control.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just want to enjoy today for today. Tomorrow I'll wake up and still be 2-10.''

title: EQUENOM TO START GENE STUDY
description: Sequenom Inc. and the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas will undertake what the company says is the largest study to date aiming to link genetic variations to disease. Sequenom and the university will study the DNA of 3,500 patients to detect which of 750,000 variations in the genetic code of those patients contribute to cardiovascular disease. The study will cost about $20 million and the university and the company will share any intellectual property resulting from the effort, said Toni Schuh, Sequenom's chief executive. The San Diego company makes machines that test for DNA variations.

title: DNA Frees Inmate Years After Justices Rejected Plea
description: The United States Supreme Court ruled that Larry Youngblood did not need to be released from prison just because evidence that might have exonerated him on child molestation charges had been damaged. But this week, 12 years later, DNA testing of evidence in the case set him free.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: America One Acquired by Ellison
description: The billionaire club of America's Cup contenders appeared to become one member stronger yesterday.

title: A Team Is an Extension of the Fans
description: The relationship between a fan's ardor and violence has remained something of a mystery for psychologists, despite a raft of studies and books on sports hooliganism in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SAMUEL
description: KOHL-Samuel. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: 'Pastoral Pop!'
description: Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris

title: To Vote for Nader, or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARSHAK, BEN
description: MARSHAK-Ben. It's your birthday today. We miss you. We love you. You are in our thoughts everyday. Love Janet, Edward and Alma

title: Patricia Moyes, 77, Writer Who Created Sleuthing Pair
description: Patricia Moyes, the British mystery writer who created Detective Chief Superintendent Henry Tibbet and his ''merry and plump and comforting'' wife, Emmy, died on Aug. 2 at her home in Virgin Gorda, in the British Virgin Islands. She was 77.

title: Standing With the Centrists In a Play for the New South
description: Vice President Al Gore surrounded himself with centrist Democratic governors from Southern states today and delivered a stem-winding populist speech in an effort to demonstrate that the South was still in play in this year's election.

title: No Cameras, Just Straight Talk
description: There has been a good deal of talk from the Gore campaign and pundits questioning the seriousness of Gov. George W. Bush's desire to reach out to minority and poor communities. Some have suggested that this effort is newfound, an act or a false religion. But I know Mr. Bush is sincere about the Republican Party becoming more inclusive of minorities, because just over a decade ago, when I was a junior staff member on his father's campaign staff, he talked to me at length about that very same commitment.

title: Two Big Online Toy Sellers to Merge Units
description: Toys ''R'' Us and Amazon.com said yesterday that they were merging their online toy-sales units, an acknowledgment that selling toys on the Internet has been too hard for each of them alone.

title: Man Shot in S.U.V. Crashes, Killing Bystander, Then Dies
description: A man who was shot through the window of his Range Rover outside a downtown nightclub early yesterday managed to drive away but lost control after two blocks, the police said, and struck a Swedish-born director of award-winning television commercials. Both men died.

title: Weaker Inmates on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKWOOD, HENRIETTA ELLERY SEDGWICK
description: LOCKWOOD - Henrietta Ellery Sedgwick. Her commitment to The Horticultural Society of New York in general and her support of our library in particular, spanned many decades. To say that Netta will be missed falls too far short of what we feel institutionally and personally. She was imbedded in the warp and the woof of The Society, and like a strong silk thread in a tapestry, she will be always be there, always remembered, always an integral part of what holds The Society together, keeps it grounded in its history and therefore able to move forward.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In the Oil-Rich Nigeria Delta, Deep Poverty and Grim Fires
description: As the rain clattered on his aluminum roof, Akierou Awe sat in a gloomy corner of his mud-brick house and spoke softly of the fuel-pipeline explosion that killed three of his sons last month, not far from his village in this oil-soaked corner of Africa.

title: Raytheon Wins Contract
description: The Raytheon Company said today that it had won a $1.4 billion subcontract from a fellow military contractor, the Lockheed Martin Corporation, to design and make radar equipment. The subcontract falls under a $4 billion contract that Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., received from the United States Army to develop a battlefield defense system. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., had $19.8 billion in revenue last year. Lockheed's revenue was $25.5 billion.

title: Finding Another Loophole, a New Secretive Group Springs Up
description: Turning to a second legal loophole after another was closed, one of the nation's largest unions, a leading supporter of Vice President Al Gore, has quietly created a group that this week is televising an advertisement harshly critical of Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Canseco Swings Into Action With Homer in His First Start
description: Jose Canseco limped across the clubhouse with an ice pack strapped across his left heel, more ice attached to his lower back, and probably would have lost a race to any of the young sons of Yankee players who were prancing around. But Canseco is not expected to run fast. He is expected to hit.

title: Girls Critically Ill After Falling in Pool
description: Two toddlers were fighting for their lives last night after they wandered out of a house in Carle Place on Long Island and fell into a swimming pool, the police said.

title: Moscow Arrests Suspects but Cant Link Any to Fatal Bombing
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 9  Russian law enforcement officials said today they had detained a number of suspects in their investigation into the terrorist bombing of an underground pedestrian walkway that killed 7 and wounded 97 on Tuesday evening. But they said that so far none could be directly linked to the bombing in the heart of the Russian capital.

title: Two Lollipops, and Take a Little Off the Top, Please
description: I know there are young children who sit still when their hair is being cut. But not my son, Jake. Jake is one of those children who have what the parenting guides might call ''scissor issues.'' He is 5, and we have tried many ways to get him to sit still long enough for a trim.

title: Mix and Match: Agencies Reshuffle
description: Agencies are merging and acquiring.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Aug. 2 about the New York Philharmonic's search for a music director misstated the affiliation of the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen. He is with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, not the Los Angeles Symphony.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: DIMAC TO CUT JOBS AT ONE OPERATION AND ADD AT ANOTHER
description: The Dimac Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April, said yesterday that it would cut about 370 jobs at its direct-marketing operation in St. Louis and move all production to Central Islip on Long Island. The cuts account for 18 percent of employees at Dimac, based in Bridgeton, Mo. The company designs marketing programs, including artwork, copy layout and printing. The company will add 145 jobs at the Central Islip plant, which it said was closer to many of its largest clients. It expects to complete the move by the end of the year. The company will keep 147 people in St. Louis in sales, accounting and other nonproduction jobs.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Crusading for Consumers All Around the Town
description: The boisterous cries on behalf of New York City's lowly consumers were heard from the Bronx to the Battery yesterday.

title: Hollywood Is Rattled By Lieberman Choice
description: As the Democratic National Convention nears, Vice President Al Gore's choice of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as his running mate has chilled wealthy Hollywood Democrats, who are upset that Mr. Lieberman is one of the Senate's most vocal critics of the entertainment industry.

title: PLEDGE ON SOFTWARE REVIEW
description: The Justice Department will ask a major university to review a government e-mail surveillance program that is seen as both a great boon to law enforcement and a serious threat to privacy. Attorney General Janet Reno said yesterday that the program, used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and called Carnivore because it can quickly gobble up and digest huge quantities of e-mail messages, will be studied in depth, and that the university's recommendations will be shared with the public. Ms. Reno said she would weigh the results before the department determines how Carnivore will be used in the future. David Stout (NYT)

title: Cone Ends Summer-Long Slump, With Lots of Help
description: David Cone needed one more strike to complete the fifth inning of a lazy game in which the Yankees already led the Athletics by nine runs. Yet there were so many of the 41,011 fans standing and clapping and screaming that it felt as if Yankee Stadium had been transported to a taut game in October.

title: City Hall Split on Who Should Take Over 1 Police Plaza
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top aides are deeply divided over the selection of his next police commissioner, with one camp arguing that the job should go to a popular insider, while others say that he should choose an outsider who will shake up the police force even at this late date in the mayor's tenure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANCE, MADLYN L.
description: VANCE-Madlyn L. June 30, 1912 to August 9, 2000. Dear wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt and great aunt. Rest. We love you very much. Donations may be made to Planned Parenthood or National Hospice Organization. Carole & Larry, Lou & Nancy

title: Army's Reserve Forces
description: To the Editor:

title: From Trial to Taunts, Lewis Tackles the Pressure
description: It took only a short time before Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis got a taste of what his return to the National Football League was going to be like after the nationally televised trial in which he was accused of killing two people.

title: Japan, Feasting on Whale, Sniffs At Culinary Imperialism of U.S.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 9  To understand why Japan expanded its whale hunt ing activities last month, despite in ternational opposition, come to din ner at Taruichi, a festive whale-meat restaurant in Tokyo's trendy Shin juku district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, LAWRENCE A.
description: ROSS-Lawrence A. Loving husband of Elizabeth. Father of Polly and Gregg Ribatt. Grandfather of Emily Ribatt. Brother of Ruth and Robert Layton. Uncle of Charles and Ursula Layton, Elizabeth and Benjamin Shepherd, Alice and Peter Layton, David and Helen Dwyer and Douglas Dwyer. Passed away on Tuesday, August 8, 2000. His music shall play in our hearts forever. Memorials should be made to the Cancer Care Unit, Boulder Community Hospital, 1100 Balsam Ave., Boulder, CO, 80304. Funeral on Friday, August 11, at 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street.

title: Phone Giant Is Said To Resolve an Issue At Center of Strike
description: Verizon Communications agreed to make it easier for unions to organize some of its employees now in nonunion jobs in the company's wireless division, people close to the talks said, resolving an issue at the heart of the strike by more than 86,000 workers.

title: Behind the Enduring Cliches of Asia and the West
description: THE MISSIONARY AND THE LIBERTINE

title: Chavez, Defiant, Tells OPEC to Show its Power : Venezuelan Visits Iraq, Angering Washington
description: President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela traveled to Iraq on Thursday, becoming the first head of state to visit the country since the 1991 Gulf War.

title: A Festival Is Tackling . . . Did They Say Beethoven?
description: What can possibly be left to say about Beethoven at this late date? A great deal, it must be hoped, for the Bard Music Festival is devoting the next two weekends and a third in October to the composer, and these are truly talkative affairs.

title: To Vote for Nader, or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Chasing Fortson
description: While the Miami Heat works on completing a deal to acquire Brian Grant, the Knicks -- spurned in their efforts to land Grant -- turned their attention once again to Danny Fortson.

title: Accord Is Seen On Key Issue In Phone Strike
description: In a development that could hasten the end of the strike by more than 86,000 employees of Verizon Communications, the company and its unions resolved an issue at the heart of their dispute yesterday, people close to the talks said.

title: Jaap Marais, 77, Implacable Proponent of Apartheid, Dies
description: Jaap Marais, a fiery orator and right-wing political leader whose 30-year-battle to uphold strict government-enforced racial segregation continued even after apartheid had ended, died on Tuesday night. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LICHTENDORF, SUSAN SIEGEL
description: LICHTENDORF-Susan Siegel. A year has passed, but the memory of her unforgettable spirit lives on. With boundless love, Arthur and Victoria

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, RINA
description: HARRIS-Rina. On August 9, 2000. Beloved wife of I. Alan. Loving mother of Lorraine Arnfeld and Deborah Schluger and stepmother of Evan A. & Jonathan N. Harris. Adored grandmother of Nina and Aaron Arnfeld, Zachary Schluger, Jessica and Lindsay Harris. Devoted to all, and we will all miss her caring, support, wisdom and love of our free America beyond words. Service Friday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business; Bank Unit to Open Office
description: Dresdner RCM Global Investors, the fund management unit of Germany's third-largest bank, agreed yesterday to lease 6,500 square feet on Madison Avenue for its first New York office.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Cider House Rules

title: Bibleman, In God's Armor
description: Action figures often hurl invective, but seldom do they pause in mid-light-saber swipe for a bit of spiritual uplift. So it is with Bibleman, who in the video ''Shattering the Prince of Pride'' interrupts his duel with the prince to call attention to Proverbs 29:23, about a man's pride bringing him low.

title: INDONESIAN MINISTER RESIGNS
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia accepted the resignation of his chief economic minister, Kwik Kian Gie, left, who said he was stepping aside to give the president a free hand in naming a new cabinet. Mr. Kwik, a key political aide to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri, had been under criticism for his economic management since he became part of Mr. Wahid's first cabinet eight months ago. Under intense criticism for his style of leadership and in particular for his economic management, Mr. Wahid has announced he will name a new, more professional, governing team. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Diners who have mastered the Brasserie's glass staircase can apply their skill at a new, even more flamboyant catwalk, the orange-carpeted semi-spiral at Brasserie 8 1/2. The name has nothing to do with Fellini. It's an allusion to the restaurant's location, a floor below 9 West 57th Street. There's nothing half about the design, by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer. The staircase, in an enormous circle cut out of the ceiling, leads to a bar and lounge perfectly suited to a space station. The dining room, with deep tufted-leather booths, velvet-lined walls and a cast-glass ceiling, leads to a brightly colored back-lighted glass panel by Fernand Leger. Restaurant Associates, which runs both the Brasserie and Brasserie 8 1/2, seems to be drunk on design. Their latest production makes the Brasserie look almost timid.

title: Residential Real Estate; A Listing-Service Battle Is Joined
description: The Battle of the Brokers has begun.

title: COX SAYS IT SOLD $412 MILLION IN SPRINT PCS STOCK
description: Cox Communications, the cable television operator, said yesterday that it sold $412.6 million in Sprint PCS stock in June and July. The company sold 7.8 million Sprint PCS shares for an average price of $52.90 each, Cox said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cox owned 113.5 million Sprint PCS shares on June 30, valued at $6.07 billion at yesterday's closing price. Cox and other cable operators have been selling their stakes in other companies to raise money to upgrade their networks for new services like high-speed Internet connections and digital television. Sprint PCS, the wireless-network operator, is owned by the Sprint Corporation.

title: Keeping Beaches Clean
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Inflation Alarms in New Fed Survey
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (Bloom berg News)  The economy has slowed, dampening demand and keeping consumer prices in check, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic survey.

title: Dell Computer's Second-Quarter Earnings Beat Expectations
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported record revenues and earnings yesterday, beating analysts' estimates for its second fiscal quarter by a penny. But the company's revenue growth rate slowed for the third consecutive quarter, and some analysts questioned its continued ability to lead the industry.

title: In Shift, Mrs. Clinton Stresses Behind-the-Scenes Influence
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton tries to rebut the favorite attack line of Representative Rick A. Lazio, that she has never held public office and has no record for a Senate campaign, she and her husband and their staffs are aggressively trying to reverse the reclusive image that she projected after her failure on health care reform. Now Mrs. Clinton says that rather than retreating, as the White House maintained, she was in fact working hard behind the scenes proposing, writing and lobbying for certain legislation, budget appropriations and administration policies.

title: Foreign Affairs; Uniting Jerusalem
description: It's been a few weeks since the Camp David slumber party broke up, and while the two sides have been holding secret talks to try to get things back on track, it's been slow going. Jerusalem remains the major stumbling block.

title: Major University to Be Asked to Review F.B.I.s Carnivore
description: Major University to Be Asked to Review F.B.I.'s 'Carnivore'

title: AOL PULLS MUSIC SEARCH ENGINE
description: This time, America Online officials said they knew what their online music unit, Nullsoft, was doing. They just thought better of it yesterday, when the company removed a search engine for digital music that had been available on Nullsoft's Web site for about a month. Like other MP3 search engines, Nullsoft's made no distinction between which music files in its search results were being legally distributed and which were not.

title: Saturn Electronics Calls Off Stock Offering
description: Saturn Electronics and Engineering Inc., a contract manufacturer for automotive and other industries, canceled its initial public offering today, the day it was to sell shares.

title: NASA Sending 2 Rovers to Mars In Twin Trips Landing in 2004
description: Wanting to make the most of an especially favorable launching opportunity in three years, NASA officials have decided to send not one but two large roving vehicles to the surface of Mars on separate missions.

title: The Long, Costly Encore
description: Al Gore has got to be thinking ''Get the hook.'' After all, Los Angeles is a show-business town, and Democrats from across the country are heading there for what is supposed to be Vice President Gore's show. But President and Mrs. Clinton are blatantly hogging the spotlight from Saturday until next Tuesday. As has so often been the case in the Clinton administration, the thirst for campaign money and other donations seems to be overriding both good manners and political prudence. The bottom line is that Mr. Gore does not get to be the star of his own show until it is half over, and by that time the Clintons will have decamped with millions of Democratic dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTADT, SIDONIE JUDITH
description: EISENSTADT-Sidonie Judith. Age 94, died on August 8, 2000, at the home in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, that she shared with her nephew Steven and his family for the past year. A graduate of the Columbia School of Social Work, she served the NYC Department of Social Services at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House until her retirement in 1971. She then embarked on her volunteer career as a guide at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She was a beacon in the lives of the many she knew and loved. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Lighthouse for the Blind.

title: A branding effort that showcases workers faces some delicate issues when they go on strike.
description: PITY the poor communicators at Verizon Communications.

title: 'Soft Money' Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCENT VENTURE IN SINGAPORE
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. and Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd. of Singapore said yesterday that they would invest $700 million in the next five years in a joint effort to develop new semiconductors for the next generation of wireless Internet devices. Analysts said the tie-up, which joins Lucent's capacity for design with the Singapore company's advantages in manufacturing, was part of an industrywide move toward making more sophisticated and profitable chips. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: From a Workout on the Water to a Rhapsody on Blue
description: Chris Nilsson rowed for New Zealand at the 1972 Olympics. He has a full head of silver hair, a dashing eye patch and hands as thick as hams. When Mr. Nilsson, a former Oxford coach, talks rowing, people tend to listen.

title: 2 Lawmakers Raise a Storm With Plan to See Taiwan Chief
description: Two lawmakers, one a Republican and the other a Democrat, hope to meet with Taiwan's new president during his overnight layover in California on Sunday despite warnings from the State Department that the transit visa granted to him precludes public events, officials said today.

title: Weaker Inmates on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Said to Be Near Deal For N.T.T. Unit to Buy Verio
description: Clinton administration officials are close to resolving national security concerns and allowing NTT Communications of Japan to buy Verio Inc., a United States Internet service provider, people involved in the negotiations said today.

title: ONLINE AUCTION DEAL IN DOUBT
description: Europe's largest online auctioneer, QXL P.L.C., said it might have to reconsider its acquisition of Ricardo.de A.G., a German rival, because of new information it had received about Ricardo.de. QXL declined to disclose the information. While both QXL and Ricardo.de said they hoped the deal would be completed, shares of Ricardo.de fell. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Indonesian Leader to Cede Daily Duties to His No. 2
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 9  Battered by a hostile Parliament for his haphazard management style, President Abdurrahman Wahid said today that he would hand over daily government administration to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri.

title: Kick Off Shoes, Kick Up Heels
description: Children often find the adult world sober and dull. Imagine, then, their pleasure at discovering a profession in which grown-ups not only go barefoot and wear funny clothes, but also run, twirl and leap with abandon.

title: Article 2000081194015915161 -- No Title
description: Ruling Clears Way

title: To Vote for Nader, or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrest of Banker in Graft Case Poses a Test of Bosnias Resolve
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzego vina, Aug. 8  The arrest of a prominent Bosnian banker and for mer government minister is being watched by foreign officials here as a test of the government's resolve to fight corruption.

title: HYUNDAI EXPANDS NORTH
description: The cash-short Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate, said it would begin construction this year on an industrial complex in the North Korean city of Kaesung, which lies just north of the heavily fortified border separating the two countries. Hyundai said it was seeking to move many labor-intensive industries to the complex to capitalize on North Korea's cheap labor force.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASES, FRED
description: THOMASES-Fred. Died Thursday August 10,2000 at the age of 92. Loving husband of Florence Josephson Thomases through 66 years of marriage. Adored father of Robert, Matthew, Jeffrey & Susan. Devoted grandfather of Holly, Andrew, Ken, Caroline, Josh, Ben, David, Danny, Greg, Lili, Phoebe, Shannon, Tom, Tony, Amy, Stephanie & Justine. Beloved brother of Jerry Thomases and Pearlie Gold. Lifelong benefactor, community leader, textile industry executive and internationlly known for his innovations. Trustee of Temple Emanu-El, Englewood, The New Jersey Community Center on the Palisades in Tenafly and National Board Member of American ORT. Dedicated to the founding and development of the State of Israel. Resident of Englewood, N.J. for 56 years. Services will be held on Friday, August 11 at 1 PM, at Temple Emanu-El on Tenafly Road in Englewood, N.J. For more information call ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 1-800-522-0588.

title: Article 2000081190556418658 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: 2 Sides in UAL Dispute Talk to Senator
description: The chairman of UAL, James E. Goodwin, and the leader of its pilots' union, Rick Dubinsky, met today with Senator Richard Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, who pushed for a quick end to a labor dispute that has contributed to thousands of flight cancellations at United Airlines.

title: Summer School Attendance Disappointing, Levy Says
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday released what he called disappointing attendance figures for the last day of summer school classes. He blamed some parents, saying thousands withdrew their children, forcing them to be held back a grade.

title: Recreating Last Moments Before a Midair Collision
description: A federal investigator today described the last few moments before a midair collision of two small planes that killed 11 people on Wednesday morning: The smaller plane was flying east, almost directly toward the sun, and beginning a left turn toward the northeast. The other plane was heading south, at the same altitude.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: REUNION INDUSTRIES, Pittsburgh, a machine parts and products manufacturing company, is selling its Irish plastics unit, Data Packaging, to an undisclosed Irish corporation for about $13.4 million.

title: Carrie Mae Weems 'The Hampton Project'
description: Williams College Museum of Art

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEMEROFF, KENNETH M.
description: NEMEROFF-Kenneth M. August 11, 1945 - May 31, 1990. Kenny would have been 55 years old today. A man of warmth, intelligence and honor. He alway said, ''his word was his bond.'' He was a mensch. He was also the love of my life and my best friend. Happy birthday. Love, Eileen

title: A Convention's Worth Of (Pretend) Candidates
description: IN a sly, perfectly timed nod to reality, the TNT film ''Running Mates'' presents Tom Selleck as a candidate, James Pryce, who goes to the Democratic convention at the Staples Center in Los Angeles (where the actual Democratic convention begins on Monday). He has sewn up the presidential nomination, and the event will be, as the film puts it, ''a virtual coronation.''

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sports of The Times; For Cone, Security Is Temporary
description: ALBATROSS. That was the word David Cone volunteered after beating the Oaklands yesterday, his first victory since all the way back on April 28.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend last Friday about movie soundtrack albums misidentified the setting of the film ''Groove.'' It takes place in San Francisco, not in England.

title: Embracing the Legacy of Freedom's Gate
description: As the first ferry of the morning pulled away from Liberty Island, I found myself nearly alone on deck. Gone were the throngs with backpacks and video cameras that had boarded with me in the Battery, clutching tickets allowing them to ascend into the statue's crown. Instead of an admission card, I was holding photocopies of some postcards, written in Yiddish and dated in the spring of 1912. I was bound for the next stop, Ellis Island, and an appointment with an ancestor.

title: Lieberman Choice Opens Door to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend last Friday about a joint venture agreement by two galleries misidentified the American partner of the London gallery Artemis Fine Arts Inc. The new venture, Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, is a partnership with the St. Louis gallery Greenberg Van Doren Inc. It does not involve Lawrence Rubin Greenberg Van Doren Fine Art of New York.

title: The Big City; Prison Mistake Shows Why Reform Lags
description: IF you discover that you've imprisoned the wrong man for two years, would you be remorseful? Would you discipline or fire the employees responsible for the mistake? Would you announce that you have taken steps to avoid imprisoning more innocent people?

title: I.B.M. AND SOLECTRON SIGN CONTRACT WORTH $1.8 BILLION
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Solectron Corporation said yesterday that they had extended their 22-year alliance with a 10-year $1.8 billion information-technology services contract. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will provide consulting and electronic-business services to Solectron, which provides electronics-manufacturing services to equipment makers that design and sell networking equipment and other electronic products. I.B.M. has also agreed to help Solectron upgrade its Internet-related network.

title: GOOGLE OFFERS MOBILE WEB SERVICE
description: Web-enabled cell phones can now be used to view any of the estimated 1.6 billion pages on the Web with a new service from the Google search engine. The Google service, which was introduced last week, translates standard Web pages into wireless markup language, the programming language used by most cell phone browsers. Mobile searchers who go to the Google site can enter the address of any Web page and it will be translated and displayed. Some Nextel Communications phones began displaying the Google search option on Aug. 1. Marty Katz (NYT)

title: Ex-Disney Executive Gets Detention in Teen Cybersex Case
description: August 11, 2000

title: New York Police Dept. Starts $10 Million Recruiting Ad Campaign
description: Hoping to attract a diverse class of recruits by portraying a compassionate side of policing, the Police Department began a $10 million recruiting campaign yesterday, and said it would begin saturating New York City with advertisements in the weeks ahead.

description: Lucas Schoormans

title: Youth Is Wasted on the Deluded
description: Here's something different: a youth comedy so relentlessly sordid and depressing that it's likely to send its audience straight into the arms of the nearest psycho-pharmacologist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOHENBERG, JOHN
description: HOHENBERG-John. August 6, 2000. The Pulitzer Prize Board extends its profound sympathy to the family of John Hohenberg, distinguished journalist, author, and administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes from 1954 to 1976. With wisdom, skill and unstinting energy, he devoted himself to maintaining the highest standards of excellence in journalism and the arts. Edward Seaton, Chairman, Pulitzer Prize Board Seymour Topping, Administrator Columbia University

title: Fuad Serag Eddin, 89, a Figure In Egyptian Politics for 50 Years
description: Fuad Serag Eddin, a mainstay of Egyptian politics who fought British colonial rule before the 1952 revolution and headed the largest opposition party, the Wafd, against successive Egyptian governments, died on Wednesday after having a heart attack in a hospital here. He was 89.

title: Fassel Seeking Progress In Test Against Jaguars
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel is unsure what to expect from his injury-plagued team when it plays tonight in Jacksonville, Fla. He just hopes he does not see the same things he saw a week ago.

description: Wait Begins in Tire Recall

description: Technology Briefings

description: NEW YORK

description: August 11, 2000

title: It Isn't Just a Game: Clues to Avid Rooting
description: It has long been assumed that ardent sports fans derive excitement and a sense of community from rooting for a big-time team. But a growing body of scientific evidence suggests that for some fans, the ties go much deeper.

title: French Nazi Memorabilia Case Presents Jurisdiction Dilemma
description: Carl Kaplan is on vacation. The CyberLaw column will resume on September 1.

description: Tossing Out Wings and a Ring

title: Gill Likes Nets' Green Over Purple and Gold
description: Last Friday, Kendall Gill was so prepared to sign with the Los Angeles Lakers, he gushed about wearing purple and gold while playing alongside Shaquille O'Neal and the rest of the defending champions of the National Basketball Association.

title: Milestone for Milestone: 10 Years of Gems
description: Few films have used natural light and landscape to evoke an emotional state with the insight and exquisite subtlety of Hirokazu Kore-eda's 1995 film, ''Maborosi,'' a movie that distills the profound disquiet of its main character, Yumiko (Makiko Esumi), a young widow raising a little boy.

title: SCI SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY CIRCUIT BOARD PLANT IN ISRAEL
description: SCI Systems Inc., one of the world's largest makers of electronic components, agreed yesterday to buy Telrad Networks' circuit board assembly factory in Ma'alot, Israel. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Telrad, a telecommunications company held by Koor Industries of Tel Aviv, also agreed to make more than $500 million worth of products for SCI. SCI, based in Huntsville, Ala., will employ more than 200 workers at the factory for the life of the multiyear contract. The factory also makes printed circuit board assemblies for Nortel Networks.

title: Somali Business Thwarted by Too-Free Enterprise
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Aug. 7 -- There are five competing airlines here; three phone companies, which have some of the cheapest rates in the world; at least two pasta factories; 45 private hospitals; 55 providers of electricity; 1,500 wholesal ers for imported goods; and an infi nite number of guys with donkeys who will deliver 55 gallons of clean water to your house for 25 cents.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AFRICA PRIVATIZATION PLAN ADVANCES The South Africa Government presented its most comprehensive plan yet for the privatization of the largest state- owned companies, saying it would sell off stakes in the nation's power utility, rail system and port operator and offer shares in the telephone compa ny and national airline. While the strategy has been in the works for months and many major points have been discussed, the announcement signaled an effort to consolidate the plans and accelerate the process. Officials would not dis close the timetable for each of the entities, saying only that they hoped the process would be com pleted by 2004. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: PRIVATIZATION PLAN ADVANCES
description: The South Africa Government presented its most comprehensive plan yet for the privatization of the largest state-owned companies, saying it would sell off stakes in the nation's power utility, rail system and port operator and offer shares in the telephone company and national airline. While the strategy has been in the works for months and many major points have been discussed, the announcement signaled an effort to consolidate the plans and accelerate the process. Officials would not disclose the timetable for each of the entities, saying only that they hoped the process would be completed by 2004. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone; in August some galleries are open by appointment only. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
