description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; A Polish Election Vexed by Communist Spies
description: Until yesterday, Poland's presidential election on Oct. 8 seemed unlikely to turn on agriculture, pensions or any other subject Poles seriously worry about. The most important issue was the identity of ''Alek'' and ''Bolek'' -- code names belonging to supposed domestic spies of 15 and 30 years ago, culled from deep in the secret police archives. Under a 1998 law, signed by President Aleksander Kwasniewski, informers who do not come clean about their past cannot hold high government posts -- and ''Alek'' was alleged to be President Kwasniewski himself, an overwhelming favorite to win re-election if allowed to run. ''Bolek,'' moreover, is allegedly one of his competitors and the hero of Poland's liberation from Communism, former president Lech Walesa.

title: Tire Recall Brings Some Panic and a Large Need for Patience
description: Michael Matha was fuming as he sat outside a Firestone tire and service center yesterday in Medford, N.J..

title: Thompson and Torres To Suit Up in Sydney
description: They entered the pool resembling speedskaters more than swimmers, wearing bodysuits from neck to ankle, for the first major showdown at the United States Olympic trials.

title: Vermont Ruling Redefines Campaign Finance Law
description: A federal judge today threw out parts of the sweeping election-money overhaul that took effect in Vermont this year, setting the stage for the latest major legal challenge to the country's campaign finance system.

title: STRONG RESULTS AT THOMSON
description: A Canadian publisher, the Thomson Corporation, which has almost completed the sale of its newspapers, reported strong sales and profit growth for the second quarter from its continuing businesses -- selling electronic information to professionals. Profit from the database units rose 33 percent to $74 million, or 12 cents a share, on an 18 percent gain in revenue, to $1.46 billion. Profit from the discontinued newspaper division was flat at $30 million, or 5 cents a share.

title: RIFT ON BUCHANAN LEADS TO A SPLIT IN REFORM PARTY
description: Eight years after Ross Perot burst into American politics, his Reform Party split today into separate conventions that will each produce a nominee claiming to be the party's true presidential candidate and the rightful recipient of $12.6 million in federal campaign money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, DR. GABRIEL F.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Dr. Gabriel F. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a loyal friend and respected member of the Jewish community who was president of the Harry and Jane Fischel Foundation, a YU Guardian; beloved husband of Bobbye S.; father of Frederic S. (and Phyllis Lefton) Goldstein; and brother of Simeon H.F. (and Naomi) Goldstein, Dr. Naomi (and Rabbi Shear Yashuv) Cohen, and the late Rebbitzin Josephine (and Rabbi O. Asher) Reichel. Our Harry Fischel School for Higher Jewish Studies was established through a grant from the Fischel Foundation in 1945. We extend our heartfelt condolences to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELLMAN, JEANETTE
description: ELLMAN-Jeanette. With you in our hearts today on your eightieth birthday. Love forever, your husband, children and grandchildren.

title: Japan's Central Bank Governor Faces Test Over Interest Rates
description: The Bank of Japan's impending decision on whether to raise interest rates for the first time in 10 years theoretically is a matter of economic judgment based on facts and data. Instead, it has become a contentious political issue, pitting the central bank governor against an alliance of other high-ranking officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTZIN, WILLIAM H.
description: LIPTZIN-William H. Of Boca Raton, FL and North Bellemore, LI. Passed away August 10. Beloved husband of Raye and loving father of Howard (Kyle Johnson) and Nancy Borg (Howard). Cherished grandfather of Corey and Jamie Borg and Isaak Liptzin. Brother of Ruth Ivler (David). Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 13 at 11:30AM at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island, 516-921-5757.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell against the dollar on speculation that the Bank of Japan will not raise interest rates today. In New York, the dollar settled at 108.62 yen, up from 107.90 on Wednesday.

title: Accounts
description: UseTheExperts.com, Westlake Village, Calif., a Web site that links consumers to local businesses, to the Los Angeles office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, MARY A.
description: TRUMP-Mary A. Wife of the late Fred C. Trump. Mother of Maryanne Trump Barry, Elizabeth Trump Grau, Donald J. Trump, Robert S. Trump and the late Fred C. Trump Jr. Mother-in-law of Blaine Trump and James Grau. Grandmother of Dr. David W. Desmond, Fred C. Trump III, Mary Trump, Donald J. Trump Jr., Christopher Trump, Ivanka Trump, Eric Trump and Tiffany Trump. Great-grandmother of Andrea Trump, Christopher Trump, William Trump, and Robert Desmond. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Avenue at 29th Street, on Friday, at 11 AM. Interment is private. Contributions in memory of Mary A. Trump may be made to the Trump Pavilion at Jamaica Hospital, 90-28 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, New York 11418 or the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, 270-05 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York 11040.

title: America Online Takes Down Search Engine on Winamp
description: August 11, 2000

title: When Tires Start Blowing Apart
description: There are too few public facts to know for sure whether Bridgestone/Firestone or Ford Motor Company waited too long to recall tires that may have caused hundreds of accidents, 80 injuries and 46 deaths in the United States alone. But what is known is deeply troubling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAKARCHI, AHUVA
description: SHAKARCHI-Ahuva. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Ariella Schiller upon the loss of her mother, Mrs. Ahuva Shakarchi. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

description: August 11, 2000

title: After Protest, Egyptian Rights Activist Is Freed
description: Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a human rights activist who has been under investigation for his pro-democracy projects, was released on bail today after being held in prison for 45 days without being charged.

title: Germany's Immigration Debate
description: A bomb apparently targeted at foreigners went off at a Dusseldorf train station recently, injuring nine immigrants, six of them Jews, as they returned home from a German-language class. A few days later, with great fanfare, a 25-year-old Indonesian software specialist became the first recipient of a new visa Germany plans to give to foreigners with computer skills. The juxtaposition underscored one of the main challenges facing German society and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government -- the nation's need to be more welcoming to immigrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SAMUEL J.
description: KOHL-Samuel J. We mourn the loss of our dear brother. Rest in peace, Sam. Ann, Ruth, Paul and Len

title: Lazio Disputes Mrs. Clinton On Quiet Accomplishments
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's assertion that she played a quiet but major role in several policy and legislative efforts by the Clinton administration cannot be trusted and stems from a bid to ''reinvent'' herself for voters, Representative Rick A. Lazio said yesterday.

title: Canada Tries to Make Clear Its Diamonds Are Different
description: Sidewalk pennants that proclaim Yellowknife the Diamond Capital of North America help explain why Canadians are working to ensure that their gems are not confused with the ''blood diamonds'' of Africa.

title: For Third Parties, a Chance To Play Spoiler or Also-Ran
description: The five-party system of Democrats, Republicans, Greens and two Reform parties is something new in American politics, and right now it is helping Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in important ways.

title: Lieberman Confirms Plan to Stay in Race for Senate While Seeking Vice Presidency
description: Joseph I. Lieberman, the United States senator who on Monday became Al Gore's vice-presidential running mate, has confirmed his initial preference to continue his Senate re-election campaign, his spokesman said today.

title: Assault May Be Linked to Upper West Side Break-Ins
description: A man who suffered head injuries on Thursday in an assault in his Upper West Side apartment may have been attacked by the same person responsible for break-ins at seven other residences in the area, including several incidents that ended in violence, the police said.

title: 12 Stuck an Hour in Trade Center Elevator
description: Twelve people were trapped for an hour inside an elevator between the 78th and 79th floors of the World Trade Center yesterday morning, after the elevator overshot a floor, hit a concrete ceiling and then plummeted 15 feet, the authorities said.

title: Dell Shares Slide, Revenue Worries Street
description: Dell Shares Slide, Revenue Worries Street

title: As Opportunity Knocks, Police Turn In Badges
description: The departures are the talk of station house hallways. In a matter of days, the New York Police Department will be losing its commissioner, Howard Safir, and his second in command, Patrick Kelleher. Within weeks, the deputy commissioner who directs narcotics enforcement will be leaving, as will the chief who supervises police hiring.

title: ARREST WARRANT FOR GERMAN
description: French investigators looking into the possibility that kickbacks were paid by the French oil company Elf Aquitaine for the purchase of a dilapidated oil refinery in the former East Germany have issued an international arrest warrant for Dieter Holzer, a businessman with links to German intelligence who is suspected of having paid millions of dollars in bribes. Mr. Holzer has admitted to receiving $23 million in ''commissions'' in the 1992 deal by Elf for a refinery in Leuna, in eastern Germany, but he denies paying any of the money as kickbacks. Elf has since been acquired by the French oil company Total.

title: Breeders Is Finale For Lemon Drop Kid
description: Lemon Drop Kid, who won the Belmont and Travers Stakes last year and who is a leading candidate for Horse of the Year this year, will stand at Lane's End Farm in Kentucky when he is retired after the Breeders' Cup Classic Nov. 4.

title: AMERICAN RE BID FOR UNITED NATIONAL IS HALTED
description: The American Re Corporation, a unit of Munich Re Group of Germany, said yesterday that its planned $350 million acquisition of the United National Insurance Company had fallen through because of delays in getting regulatory approvals linked to Holocaust-era insurance claims. Tom Walker, a spokesman for American Re, said United National called off the deal on Thursday because of delays in getting approval of the transaction by the Pennsylvania Insurance Department. He said the department had been reviewing the transaction since September 1999, but made clear that it was Munich Re's refusal to join the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims that was the stumbling block.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, DANIEL SCHUBB
description: KELLER-Daniel Schubb. 53. Died of lung cancer August 10,2000 in NYC. He was born in Los Angeles but spent the past 20 years in NY working as a psychologist specializing in substance abuse research. He is survived by his beloved wife, Rebekah, daughter Anya, mother Shirley, sister Beth Jensen and brother John. Memorial service Sunday 10am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, STEVEN A.
description: BERGER-Steven A., 54. Of Aberdeen, NJ, on August 9, 2000. Survived by his wife, Barbara; sons Bill and daughter-in-law, Debbi and Ken; parents, Joanne and Al Berger; sister, Karen Warren and brother-in-law, Lon; brother, Rick and wife, Kathy; and many other relatives. Funeral services noon Sunday at the Freeman Manalapan-Marlboro Funeral Home, 344 Route 9N, Manalapan, NJ 07726, (732-972-8484). Burial will follow in Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. Donations in his memory to United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County, 380 Washington Street, Roosevelt, NY 11575, will be appreciated.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KELLOGG CO., Battle Creek, Mich., the world's largest cereal company, disclosed in a filing that it paid $33 million in cash for Kashi Co., La Jolla, Calif. Kellogg did not reveal the terms when it announced the purchase in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSLER, BEN
description: WEISSLER-Ben, 92, originally from Ft. Lee, N.J, died Thursday evening, August 9, in Boca Raton, FL, where he resided. He is survived by his wife Natalie, son Barry, and stepchildren Carol Bleeker and Dr. Harvey Rosen. He was grandfather to Alex Bleeker, Steven Weller and Cindy Rosenberg. He was great grandfather to Kevin and Daryn Rosenberg, David and Michael Weller, and Andrew and Katherine Rosen. He was father-in-law to Fran Weissler and Dr. Letitia Rosen. Ben was a lover of life who will be truly missed. Services to be held at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel Sunday, August 22 at 11am in Del Ray, FL

title: COMEBACK FOR BIG THAI DEBTOR
description: High oil prices and a debt-for-equity swap could restore the bankrupt Thai Petrochemical to profitability this year, its chief executive, Prachai Leophairatana, predicted. Thailand's bankruptcy court declared Thai Petrochemical insolvent in March after a two and a half year battle between Mr. Prachai and creditors. Court-appointed administrators are now drafting a restructuring plan that Mr. Prachai said would probably lead to lower debt payments for the company, Thailand's biggest delinquent debtor. Together with solid Asian demand for petroleum products, he said, lower payments could lead to a full-year profit. Wayne Arnold

title: The Money Hustle: Gore's Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, EDWARD
description: BRODSKY-Edward, 70. Beloved husband of Cynthia. Cherished father of Peter and Leslie, William and Karen and James. Darling grandfather of Noah and Skye. Brother of Phillip and Harriet Brodsky. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, August 13 at 1:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76 Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Leukemia Research Fund, Long Island Jewish Center, New Hyde Park, New York 11040, attn: Dr. Kanti Rai.

title: For American Jews, Hope and Uncertainty
description: Much has now been written about how the selection of Joseph Lieberman as a vice presidential candidate breaks the last taboo and shows how we Jews are now full members of the American mainstream. To me, it has proved something quite different: just how vulnerable and insecure we remain. And, depending on how things play out in November, it may show how insecure and vigilant we still should be.

title: Central Bank In Japan Raises Interest Rates
description: Forcefully asserting its view that Japan's economy is now growing firmly after years of false starts, the central bank raised interest rates today for the first time in a decade, defying strong pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero.

title: Bingo, Blood and Burial Plots In the Quest for Food Stamps
description: In California, New York and 27 other states, people applying for food stamps are asked if they own a burial plot. Nebraska and Nevada want to know if applicants have sold their blood, and for how much. Hawaii demands garage-sale receipts, South Dakota wants documentation of bingo winnings, and Minnesota, on Page 20 of a 36-page eligibility application, asks if anyone in the household earns money from a paper route.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Al Gore's earliest political campaign gave a misspelled name at several points for the newspaper on which he worked before deciding to seek office. It is The Tennessean, in Nashville, not Tennesseean.

title: Representative Yields on Playboy Party
description: Yielding to pressure from Vice President Al Gore and other Democratic Party leaders, Representative Loretta Sanchez tonight agreed to move a Hispanic fund-raising event from the Playboy Mansion to Universal Studios.

title: Austin Has Short Game On Target
description: After starting the day in first place, Woody Austin played well enough to stay there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARMBRUNN, OLGA C.
description: WARMBRUNN-Olga C. Died at home on August 11, 2000 at age 87. Wife of the late Hans Warmbrunn. Mother of Illia Thompson, Eva Herndon and Arlene Saxonhouse. Grandmother of Hamid and Malina Bean, Lance Thompson, Keith and Robert Herndon, Lilly Saxonhouse Krenn, Noam and Elena Saxonhouse. Ten great-granchildren. Contributions in Olly's memory may be made to: Self-Help Community Services for Holocaust Survivor Programs, 440 9th Ave, NY, NY 10003 or National Council of Jewish Women, Forest Hills Section, 72-40 Juno St, Forest Hills, NY 11375. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Democrats Learn From Republican Playbook
description: When it comes to figuring out the dos and don'ts of running a convention, the Democrats seem to have picked up a few pointers from the Republicans.

title: Sorenstam Leads a Local Favorite
description: Leave it to Annika Sorenstam to show up and threaten to spoil Karrie Webb's bid to defend her du Maurier Classic title. Sorenstam, Webb's chief rival at the top level of the L.P.G.A. tour, fired a second consecutive 69 for a one-shot lead after 36 holes at the Royal Ottawa Golf Club.

title: Moving Heaven and Earth For the City of Angels
description: He helped lead the charge to lure the Democratic National Convention. He helped finish the fund-raising for a grand new concert hall. He helped recruit the new school superintendent. He founded one art museum and has plans to vastly expand another, and to revive a historically anemic downtown. He's the mayor's best friend, and helped bankroll campaigns to elect a new school board and pass a new city charter. And, oh, did we mention, he's the richest man in town, worth more than $5 billion?

title: Dollars Make Sense, So Gill Is Still a Net
description: Kendall Gill was in Los Angeles, ready to sign with the Lakers, when he entertained dozens of advice-filled phone calls. Shaquille O'Neal was a frequent recruiter, but ultimately, Gill listened to the man in charge.

title: Union Seeks More Incentives To Staff Troubled Schools
description: The union representing New York City teachers jumped into the debate yesterday over how to rid troubled schools of uncertified teachers, asking the city to expand a costly incentive program intended to draw veteran teachers into those schools.

title: EBay Says Glitches May Continue to Hamper Auctions
description: EBay Says Glitches May Continue to Hamper Auctions

title: Flag Debate Is Accelerated By Rights Group's Action
description: A quiet effort to negotiate a new state flag for Georgia that eliminates its Confederate symbol has suddenly become very public, after a leading civil rights organization asked the National Collegiate Athletic Association to move its planned basketball championships from Atlanta if the flag was not changed.

title: SOUTHWEST SECURITIES AND MATRIX END MERGER TALKS
description: The financial services holding companies Southwest Securities Group and Matrix Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that they had abandoned an acquisition plan that was announced last month. Both companies said they had decided ''to proceed independently'' but declined to elaborate. Dallas-based Southwest had planned to buy Matrix for about $110 million in stock. Its subsidiaries include Southwest Securities Inc., Mydiscountbroker.com and Westwood Management. Matrix, based in Denver, provides financial services through divisions that include Matrix Capital Bank and Matrix Financial Services. The stock of Matrix fell 35 percent, losing $3.8125 a share, to $6.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Southwest were up $2.8125, to $29.8125.

title: ASIAN CABLE NETWORK
description: Southeast Asia's biggest telephone company, Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., said it was in talks with PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia to build an underseas phone cable. Singapore Telecom is spending $2 billion to build a 10,500-mile network connecting seven Asian markets.

title: Time for a Convention Update
description: At one time America's presidential conventions earned the nation's attention for the important purposes of choosing leadership tickets and defining party principles. But today's political extravaganzas survive for the more modern purpose of providing a few video images and catch phrases that can be marketed throughout the fall. Distilled down to their essence, the Republican and Democratic conventions this summer are photo opportunities built around balloon drops, confetti storms, sound bites from acceptance speeches, and climactic tableaus of the nominees with their families, defeated opponents and Congressional allies. Even in a political system built to accommodate change, the role of national conventions has evolved -- some would say declined -- rapidly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSH, CHARLES ODELL
description: MARSH-Charles Odell. On August 9, 2000. Beloved son of Margaret Hamilton Patrowich and the late Charles Odell Marsh. Loving brother of Dr. Anna Catherine Gilliam-Ballard. Survived by many loving relatives in South Carolina. Cherished companion of Gayle Rhoda Kurtz. Visitation Saturday, 4-6PM John Krtil Funeral HomeYorkville Funeral Service Inc., 1297 1st Ave, NYC. Interment South Carolina. Charles was associated with the International Center of Photography for many years and was also a talented, freelance artist. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Czech Police and Army Get Ready for Protests at I.M.F.-World Bank Meeting
description: Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut have already ordered replacement glass. So has Tesco, a British supermarket chain, and it is thinking of shutting down for the duration. McDonald's talks hopefully of its local ownership and wants to keep its outlets open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUMP, MARY
description: TRUMP-Mary. The Board of Directors of The Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York notes with great saddness the passing of Mary Trump, mother of Board of Governors Members Donald J. Trump and Robert Trump. Mary was a gracious and charming lady who as a caring philanthropist improved the lives of so many New Yorkers. Her selfless dedication will be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her children Donald, Robert, Maryanne Barry and Elizabeth Grau, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. To have known Mary was to have loved her. We shall truly miss her. Jerome Belson, President Michael Kerr, Co-Chairman Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairman Nicholas LaPorte Jr, Exec Dir

title: The Money Hustle: Gore's Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, HERMAN
description: TUCKER-Herman. Beloved father of Dr. Toby (Dr. Barry) Hecht, Rabbi Gordon (Dr. Amy Cohn) Tucker, loving brother of Sylvia Rosencranz, cherished grandfather of Ethan (Ariela Migdal) Tucker, Spencer and Jonathan Hecht, Becky and Micah Tucker. Services Sunday 12 noon, Temple Israel of White Plains, 280 Old Mamaraneck Rd at Miles Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, MILDRED
description: FISCHER-Mildred. 0n August 11th. Beloved wife of the late Howard. Devoted sister of Gertrude Berger and Irene Neumann and caring aunt of nieces, grandnieces and grandnephews. Interment Sunday 11:30 AM at the Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: CHINA COMPUTER SALES SURGE
description: Computer sales in China are growing faster than in any other market in Asia, itself the region with the fastest-expanding computer market in the world, according to a survey by the Gartner Group and Dataquest. The survey shows that Legend Holdings Ltd. of China has overtaken the International Business Machines Corporation as the top computer vendor in the region, where consumers bought 4.1 million computers in the latest quarter, up 26 percent from the corresponding period last year. Craig S. Smith

title: Firestone Scrambles to Meet Demand for Replacement Tires
description: As confused consumers kept phones ringing off the hooks yesterday at dealers across the country, Bridgestone/Firestone struggled to cope with the demand for replacement tires unleashed by its recall of 6.5 million tires for sport utility vehicles.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday about the planned retirement of William C. Steere Jr., chief executive of Pfizer, misstated the increases in the company's sales and stock price during his leadership. Sales have doubled since 1992, not nearly tripled; the shares have increased more than 400 percent in the last five years, not 500 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about efforts by the financier Charles Schwab to champion the term ''learning difference'' over ''learning disability'' referred incorrectly to his actions and those of his Schwab Foundation for Learning. While Mr. Schwab has pledged substantial financial support to an organization that uses the term ''learning difference,'' he is not spending the equivalent of hundreds of millions of dollars on such a campaign. His foundation, with an endowment of $280 million, embraces both terms.

title: Power Trip As Piazza Charges Up The Mets
description: Mark Gardner threw a fastball that tailed inside on Mike Piazza, and immediately Gardner knew. Everyone knew. Gardner slammed his hand against his right leg, glanced toward left field and then looked away. But Piazza's towering shot in the fourth inning stayed in the air so long that Gardner peeked one more time, watched the two-run homer land in the picnic area and shook his head.

title: U.S., Seeing Threat of Disease, Halts Trade in Argentine Beef
description: The United States and Argentina have temporarily halted trade in Argentine beef because of concerns of a possible outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease here.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY

title: Sports of The Times; Dusty Baker, The Giants, And Dignity
description: IN the midst of preparing for the opening game in a series against the Mets -- tickets to get, coaches to coordinate for a meeting -- Dusty Baker paused yesterday at Shea Stadium to contemplate a question about his second passion, music.

title: Anxieties Over Quarry Dust Split a Small New Jersey Town
description: Just over the ridge from the handsome homes and sloping lawns, the old marble quarry churns away as it has since the early 1900's, producing ornamental stones and pebbles, powdered limestone fertilizer and ingredients for floor tiles, caulks and paints, abrasive cleaners, bowling balls and golf ball covers.

title: Nader Ad Breaks Formula
description: Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate for president, unveiled his first television commercial this week, the first truly irreverent candidate commercial of the 2000 election. A takeoff on the Mastercard ''priceless'' advertising campaign, the 30-second commercial is running on cable and on local broadcast stations in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Sacramento and Santa Barbara, Calif.; Portland, Ore.; Seattle; New York; and Washington.

title: MusicBank Bets on Working With Recording Industry
description: August 11, 2000

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I goofed.''

title: Movements in the Making, Weaving, Sliding, Gliding
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival has become a place to see interesting dance in the making, in the relatively informal afternoon performances. That was the case with ''Speaking in Truth: Female Choreographers'' presented on Wednesday afternoon at Lincoln Center plaza.

title: Buchanan Chooses Black Woman as Running Mate
description: As the latest twist in a political convention filled with them, Patrick J. Buchanan today shattered the emerging image of the Reform Party as a haven for white conservatives by selecting as his running mate a black woman who taught public school for years in South Central Los Angeles.

title: Soros Concedes Goof in Book. Global Economy Didn't Collapse.
description: George Soros, one of the world's most successful speculators and richest men, has come as close as anyone to personifying the spread of global capitalism and the power of international financial markets. So, in 1998, when he wrote a book predicting the imminent ''disintegration of the global capitalist system,'' his views caused quite a stir.

title: Witches Express Relief As Vexing Case Is Closed
description: To the relief of witches throughout Connecticut, the case of Kerri Lynn Patavino appears to be closed once and for all.

title: Bush Calls on Gore to Denounce Clinton Affair
description: Gov. George W. Bush called on Vice President Al Gore today to emphatically state his disapproval of President Clinton's sexual conduct in office and to send Americans a clear message that he would maintain a high level of integrity if elected to the presidency.

title: AT&T Pays Hefty Premium to Buy 32% of Net2Phone
description: August 11, 2000

title: Asian-American Health
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rescue Plan for Camden
description: When bankrupt cities are taken over, it is usually by state-appointed control boards that dictate fiscal policy until the cities return to solvency. The board that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey has proposed for the dysfunctional city of Camden may be tough by New Jersey's standards but no tougher than the control boards that revived the prospects of municipalities like New York City, Chelsea, Mass., and, most recently, Washington. Camden's difficulty in governing itself was underscored recently when the City Council asked the state to assist in running the city attorney's office, which has been incapacitated by scandal. Instead of digging in their heels, state legislators who represent Camden should embrace the Whitman plan and improve on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONDILLER, ELIZABETH
description: FONDILLER-Elizabeth. 6/29/26-8/ 11/00. Her words, her deeds and her choice of profession reflected her lifelong dedication to helping others achieve their goals and pursue their dreams. She began her career as an artist and art teacher. Her thirst for knowledge led her on to degrees in occupational therapy and social work. She was a woman of great strength, creativity, compassion, and intellectual depth and diversity. She leaves behind a loving daughter, Jill, many friends and relatives, and her infinite collection of chatchkes. She will be greatly missed by everyone whose life she touched. Betty, we love you. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Funeral Home, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday, August 13th at 2:30PM.

title: Responsible Wheels
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter Chappell, Photographer of Nature, Is Dead at 75
description: Walter Chappell, whose finely detailed, impeccably printed photographs of landscapes, natural forms and the human body were known for their mystical intensity, died on Tuesday in Santa Fe. He was 75 and lived in El Rito in northern New Mexico.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC IN TALKS TO PURCHASE MEDINOL
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, a leading maker of products used to clear and keep coronary arteries open, said yesterday that it had begun talks to buy its major supplier, Medinol Ltd. Israel-based Medinol supplies Boston Scientific's NIR stent, a mesh tube used to prop open once-clogged coronary arteries, according to The Boston Globe, which first reported the talks. Boston Scientific said last month that it expected sales for the second half of 2000 to be ''relatively flat'' compared with 1999 sales. Boston Scientific shares rose 6.25 cents, to close at $16.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TV'S BOOM BOX
description: New technology provides the ultimate in television convenience: viewers will be able to watch anything they want whenever they want. But it also watches viewers, and it could destroy prime time and shatter the power of the mass market. A report by Michael Lewis in The Times Magazine.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Thursday showing the growth in leisure time since 1880 misspelled the surname of an economic historian. He is Robert W. Fogel, not Vogel.

title: Still Life With Lazio, and a King
description: This is a 30-second advertisement, ''Superimposed,'' produced by the Liberal Party, its first in the Senate race. The party had planned to endorse Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is a close friend of Raymond Harding, the party chairman. But after Mr. Giuliani dropped out, the party threw its support behind Hillary Rodham Clinton over the Republican nominee, Representative Rick A. Lazio. The ad is a response to one by the Republican Leadership Council, a Washington group that helps finance moderate candidates. That ad spliced images of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan against shots of Mr. Lazio, implying that Senator Moynihan, a Democrat, supported Mr. Lazio. Mr. Moynihan unsuccessfully sought the ad to be dropped. It is another example of ads that are paid for with largely unregulated contributions that do not directly solicit votes for individuals but do promote their candidacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASNICK, ANNETTE
description: GASNICK-Annette. Died peacefully on August 8 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Jack. Mother of Steven (Andi) and Marc Rothstein. Grandmother of Tiffany. Stepmother of Ellen Gasnick and sister of Gloria D'Antonio.

title: Finances Force Daily Soup to Sell 8 Stores and Close One
description: The Daily Soup Company, one of the city's better-known high-end soup operations, has sold eight of its nine stores, has shut the ninth and plans to offer its fare at less costly kiosks and other small sites as well as through food markets.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, CHRYSANTHI
description: PAPPAS - Chrysanthi. Beloved wife of the late Lambros. Loving mother of Anastasia Nicholas and Chris and mother-in-law of George & Helen. Cherished grandmother of John, Chris-Ann, Irene, Kalli and Dean. Reposing at Papavero Funeral Home 72-27 Grand Ave, Maspeth. Funeral liturgy St. Paraskevi and St. Haralambos Greek Orthodox Church, Monday 10 AM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, SYLVIA K.
description: CLARK-Sylvia K. Congregation Ezrath Israel, the Actor's Temple mourns the loss of a very dear friend and congregant of many years. We express our condolences to her loving family. Robert Goldman, President Noach Valley, Rabbi

title: G.M. Proposes An Online Site For Car Sales
description: In the biggest concession by an automaker that the Internet is transforming its business, General Motors has proposed a joint venture with its dealers to establish a Web site offering cars made by other manufacturers as well as its own.

title: News on Budgets, Homeownership and Jobs Is Wonderful, but It Isn't Helping Gore Yet
description: With less than three months until Election Day, Vice President Al Gore faces a crucial and perplexing question: why does his presidential campaign not seem to be benefiting from an economy that is as good as it gets?

title: Informers in the East
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore Confronted by a New Issue: Playboy
description: Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman came to this small factory town outside Philadelphia today to praise working women. They visited Little Souls, a company owned by women that makes handcrafted dolls, where they called for equal pay and expanded day care benefits. Both paid elaborate homage to their own wives, daughters and mothers.

title: GOLDMAN REAL ESTATE FUND WANTS TO BUY OUT PARTNER
description: A real estate fund of the Goldman Sachs Group is in talks to buy out the stake held by its partner, Wellsford Real Properties Inc., in a $572 million joint venture in office properties, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The investment bank's Whitehall Real Estate fund said any sale by the New York-based Wellsford, whose stake in the venture is 41.4 percent, would probably take the form of cash, assets or a combination of both. No agreement has been reached. The venture, called Wellsford/Whitehall Group, was formed in 1997 to buy and develop office properties in the Northeast. At the end of 1999, it owned 41 properties with a total of 4.9 million square feet of space in New Jersey, Massachusetts and Maryland. The venture's assets totaled $572 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, ELIZABETH I.
description: PARKER-Elizabeth I. (Liz). Suddenly on August 8, 2000 in the city of New York, Liz crossed over to eternity. She leaves to mourn her untimely passing her 5 children: Scott Harrison, Denise Davis, Lisa Parker, Terry Parker and Sharon Bennett. Also to mourn her passing are 9 grandchildren. Services will be held Monday, August 14, 2000, 11AM from St. Luke Baptist Church, 133-21 232 St., Laurelton, N.Y. Viewing Sunday, August 13, 2000 from 2 to 5PM and 7 to 9PM. Roy L. Gilmore's Funeral Home, Inc, 191-02 Linden Blvd, St. Albans, New York. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Sales Pick Up With No Sign Of Inflation
description: Retail sales rose in July at the fastest pace in five months, while prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers were little changed, reports released today showed.

title: At Home Abroad; Five Minutes to Midnight
description: The most dangerous place in Europe today is Montenegro, the small republic tied to Serbia in the Yugoslav Federation. Slobodan Milosevic could intervene there at any time, overthrowing the freedom-minded Montenegrin government and once again challenging the West.

title: KOHLBERG, MERCHANT BANKER, AGREES TO PURCHASE OF BI
description: A merchant banking firm, Kohlberg & Company, has agreed to buy BI Inc., which makes electronic monitoring bracelets and systems used by corrections agencies to monitor home arrest programs, for more than $65 million in cash. Kohlberg is paying $8.25 for each BI share. The shares soared 70 percent, gaining $3.28 each, to $7.91, in Nasdaq trading. Kohlberg will also assume about $20 million in BI's debt. BI, based in Boulder, Colo., also provides supervisory services for misdemeanor and felony probationers. It will continue to run as an independent company solely focused on corrections.

title: Article 2000081293505996581 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: The Subtlety of Hogwarts? Give a Wizard a Break!
description: The first readings are over, the tired eyes glazed, the mammoth tomes laid aside. Blessedly, Phase 1 of this year's Harry Potter frenzy has concluded. But hold on. Relief may be premature. For now, it seems, it is time to settle in for Phase 2: Potter deconstruction.

title: When Saving the Queen Was the Wrong Thing to Do
description: Some 3,000 players began 10 days of play here today in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships, but the focus of attention was on the final stages of the Grand National Teams (Flight A).

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Wednesday about Texas executions erred in saying that the Supreme Court has ruled that executing minors under age 16 violates the Constitution. In 1988, in a 5-to-4 decision overturning an Oklahoma statute, four justices agreed that executing a person who was 15 years old at the time a crime was committed would be unconstitutional; a fifth justice concurred on narrower grounds.

title: John C. Harsanyi, 80, Is Dead; Won Nobel Economics Award
description: John C. Harsanyi, who won the 1994 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for his work on game theory, died on Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Queens Murder Suspect Shoots Himself, Police Say
description: A Queens man who earlier this week shot and killed his supervisor in the housekeeping unit of a state-owned nursing home shot himself yesterday morning, perhaps by using the same gun, the authorities said.

title: A Meeting of Faiths
description: To the Editor:

title: Rooms Without a View; Despite Decades of Violations, Hotel Keeps Its Doors Open
description: Michael Ouellette lives in an illegal room in Manhattan. His cell-like home of 8 feet by 13 feet has no window for light and air, as required by New York City statute. Two other rented rooms are also windowless, and he disputes the legality of three more.

title: Annual Event May Be Canceled
description: A sanctioning crisis within the governing body of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden may cause the cancellation of the 117th annual event.

title: FURTHER QUERIES IN YAHOO CASE
description: A French court seeking to decide whether Yahoo violated French law by allowing Nazi memorabilia to be sold on Web sites accessible through its American portal ordered a team of three international experts to examine whether it is possible to make such sites originating in the United States inaccessible in France. In May, the court upheld a complaint about Yahoo Web sites advertising Nazi paraphernalia like uniforms and weapons. But Yahoo appealed the verdict, arguing it is technically impossible to identify Web users by national origin and block their access to sites.

title: HYUNDAI LOSS WIDENS
description: The world's No. 2 maker of memory chips, the Hyundai Electronics Industries Company of South Korea, said its first-half losses tripled from a year earlier as it booked charges from failed investments. The company lost 374 billion won ($335 million) in the six months, compared with 125 billion won in the corresponding period in 1999. Hyundai took one-time charges from sales of a factory and changes in inventory valuation, canceling record operating profit.

title: News Corp. Said to Agree To Purchase Chris-Craft
description: The News Corporation, which owns the Fox television network, has agreed to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, the TV-station company, for $3.5 billion, a person close to the discussions said last night.

title: Night of Crazy, Lost and Impossible Love
description: Love, politics, shopping, sacrilege and tequila were all on the agenda for ''An Evening at Salon Mexico'' on Thursday night at Central Park Summerstage. It was a New York showcase for Liliana Felipe, Astrid Hadad and Eugenia Leon, who are mainstays of a El Habito, a long-running cabaret in Mexico City where old-fashioned cabaret singing and performance art intersect.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 5 about the 100th birthday of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother misspelled the surname of a woman from St. Louis who was visiting London and praised the celebrations. She is Connie Nisinger, not Missinger.

title: BANKERS PICKED FOR N.T.T. SALE
description: Japan's Ministry of Finance selected four investment banks to manage a sale of shares in the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, one of the most coveted deals in the securities industry. The winners were Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs in Tokyo, Nikko Salomon Smith Barney and Nomura Securities, each of which will earn tens of millions of dollars in fees when the government, which currently owns 53 percent of the former telephone monopoly, sells as many as one million shares valued around $12 billion sometime in the fall. The brokerage houses were chosen from a final list of 10 firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, RONALD
description: ROSENTHAL-Ronald. On August 10th, 2000. Beloved husband of Susanne. Dear father of Peter (Nancy). Loving grandfather of Aaron and Wylie. Uncle of Marion Maitlin, Ronald Frederick, Margaret Selfin, Andrea Katz, Larry Maitlin & David Maitlin. Services Sunday, August 13, 10:15AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, N.Y.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: A obituary on Wednesday about Dr. Michael Burnhill, a leader in family planning and women's health care, omitted a survivor. She is his mother, Lillian Birnberg of Cocoanut Creek, Fla.

title: Binge Led to Death of Herbalife Founder
description: The chief executive of Herbalife International Inc., Mark Hughes, died after a four-day drinking binge, according to a full report by the Los Angeles coroner.

title: Cheney Is Said to Be Receiving $20 Million Retirement Package
description: The energy services company that Dick Cheney served for much of the last five years as chairman and chief executive has agreed to let Mr. Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, retire with a package worth an estimated $20 million, according to people who have reviewed the deal.

title: The Jets Put Rookie Through Tough Act
description: The shouts come as furiously as the plays for Shaun Ellis. The rookie defensive end, the Jets' first pick in their extraordinary draft class, barely has time to recover from another defensive drill in another exhausting practice before he is expected to work on special teams.

title: QUORUM HEALTH GROUP PUTS ITSELF UP FOR SALE
description: The hospital management company Quorum Health Group Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Goldman Sachs & Company as a financial adviser to help it explore the possibility of a sale. Quorum's stock was up 62.5 cents in Nasdaq trading, to $13.50. At that price the company has a total value of more than $960 million. Quorum, based in Brentwood, Tenn., also said it expected to report earnings of 79 cents a share for its fiscal year that ended in June, a penny under Wall Street's expectations.

title: Fertility Doctor Loses License During Review
description: The New York State Department of Health yesterday suspended the medical license of a well-known fertility specialist with a busy, celebrity-favored practice who is facing retrial on insurance fraud charges.

title: A New Drive Gathers Steam To Avert Trial For Pinochet
description: Since being stripped of his senatorial immunity on Tuesday, Gen. Augusto Pinochet and supporters have started a campaign to gain support to help him avert a trial on charges of kidnapping, murder and torture.

title: First Lady Goes on Campaign Swing, to California
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton brought her campaign for the Senate to the hills of Los Angeles this evening, starting three days of California campaigning with an appearance on the ''Tonight'' show with Jay Leno, a way-out-of-town swing that will end with a prime-time speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles Monday evening.

title: The Gore Balancing Act: Embracing Clinton While Standing on His Own
description: For months now, Al Gore has been searching for the proper degree of separation from Bill Clinton. He has used measured words and occasional policy differences both to try to distance himself from the president and to demonstrate that he is his own man, worthy of the presidency in his own right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURDOVAL, DONALD J.
description: SURDOVAL-Donald J. Of Saddle River, NJ, on Thursday, August 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Fitzpatrick). Devoted father of Lisa A. of Saddle River, NJ; Catherine A. of Nanuet, NY; Donald J. of Sparta, NJ; John G. of Sydney, Australia; and Brian G. of Hoboken, NJ. Loving grandfather of Donnie, Kaitlin, and Alison Surdoval. Funeral Mass 10 a.m. Monday at St. Gabriel's RC Church, Saddle River, NJ. Interment, Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, NY. Visiting 7-9 p.m. Saturday and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Sunday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 East Chester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Anaheim's Left-Handers Deal Hernandez Defeat
description: It was 1998 and the worst start of Orlando Hernandez's career. It also could have been the best thing that happened to him. Their lineup stocked with left-handed hitters, the Anaheim Angels peppered El Duque for 13 hits and 10 runs in three and one-third innings here two years ago, incontrovertible evidence that Hernandez had to change his approach and pitch inside more.

title: Walter Maggiolo, 92, Labor Dispute Mediator
description: Walter Andrew Maggiolo, a top trouble-shooter for the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in the 1950's and 60's, died on Monday in Arlington, Va. He was 92 and lived in Arlington.

title: Good Start Turns Awful For Giants
description: As a Stanford assistant coach in 1982, Jim Fassel watched as California defeated Stanford on the game's final play with a crazed kickoff return through a host of defenders and the Cardinal marching band.

title: From Frisky to Folky With Copious Soul
description: As the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center has shrunk in time in recent years, it has expanded in scope, offering a greater variety of events, not all of them having much to do with Mozart. The three Mozart songs in the recital by the German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, for example, served mainly as interlude.

title: A Classroom Tool for Opening Up Shakespeare: The Sitcom
description: Richard Keller Simon, the chairman of humanities at California Polytechnic University and the author of ''Trash Culture,'' has an unusual way of teaching Shakespeare. In a recent article in The Chronicle of Higher Education titled ''Much Ado About 'Friends': What Pop Culture Offers Literature,'' he outlined his unorthodox method. Following are excerpts:

title: Article 2000081293953766567 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: As the Music Soars, a Child Takes Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding the Beats in Brecht, In a Different Time and Place
description: A long, long time ago, before the triangle below Canal Street became TriBeCa and when a coffee house was something very different from Starbucks, young men and women in black turtlenecks and berets used to gather in downtown basements and bars to smoke foul cigarettes and listen to jazz and poetry, some bad and some not so bad, and see experimental plays. It was the milieu that produced, for better or worse, the Beat generation, progressive jazz and later, Sam Shepard.

title: Children of West Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemens's New Deal Is Most Unusual
description: Roger Clemens will sign an unusual multiyear contract extension that obligates him to play two years for the Yankees, for $30.9 million, and perhaps allows both sides to address peripheral issues.

title: Seeing Doubt and Betrayal, He's Civil, Not Catatonic
description: Trebly post-rock, the recherche decadence of Britpop, new American ruralism, electroshock metal, dirty novelty songs on MP3 -- O.K., the fashions keep changing. But among all these shiny new models, what's going to happen to the American bar band, the dependable Buick at the back of the lot?

title: When 'May I Help You' Is a Labor Issue; The Customer-Service Assembly Line
description: It could have been one of those minor triumphs that make a phone rep's day: Dawn Barbour, a customer service agent for Verizon -- then Bell Atlantic -- had just made an angry customer stop ranting, solved his problem and even elicited a kind word.

title: The Torch Didn't Pass To George W. Bush
description: The last Democratic Convention in Los Angeles nominated John F. Kennedy in 1960. Some in George W. Bush's camp say this race is Kennedy-Nixon all over again, but with Governor Bush as the fresh face challenging the two-term vice president. Mr. Bush even included footage of Kennedy in the video that preceded his nomination speech.

title: In Bid to Buy the Next Derby Winner, the Cost Keeps Getting Higher
description: In gauging the health of any industry, one of the most accurate methods is to follow the money. In horse racing that means following a buff, combed and yet-to-be-raced yearling into the Humphrey S. Finney Sales Pavilion. Then, listen to the auctioneer's sing-song pitch and keep an eye on the tote board. Sometimes the buyers themselves are surprised at the final flash of numbers.

title: New York Beats New Jersey
description: Juan Almonte hit a home run last night as New York beat New Jersey, 2-1, in a round-robin game at the Little League regional championships in Bristol, Conn. It was the third straight victory for the New York team, which is composed of players from the Rolando Paulino Little League in the Bronx. The New Jersey team, from Pequannock, had won its first two games by shutouts.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Everett, Wash.; Prescott, Ariz.

title: Journal; Al Gore's Chicken Soup
description: So righteous, so brave, so bold. The verdict is in: Al Gore is the best thing to happen to the Jews since Oskar Schindler.

title: TXU PLANNING TO SELL 50% OF UNIT FOR $960 MILLION
description: The TXU Corporation, the fourth-largest United States utility, said yesterday that it would sell 50 percent of its TXU Communications unit to an unidentified group of institutional investors for $960 million. TXU said it would use money from the transaction to reduce debt. All of TXU's communications assets will be transferred into the new company, to be called Pinnacle One, in exchange for a 50 percent interest in the joint venture. Including alliances with other providers, TXU Communications has a fiber optic network spanning more than 2,800 miles. Shares of Dallas-based TXU rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $35.078, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Belfast Journal; Murals of 'Troubles' Draw Passions, and Tourists
description: Along the way, the tour guide pointed out some of the more benign landmarks in this city of Old World charm and fairly recent terror. To the right was the ancient Crown Liquor Saloon; farther on, the gargantuan City Hall. And there, listing a bit, the Albert Clocktower.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, BERNARD
description: HIRSCHHORN-Bernard. Fortytwo years since you left and as I persist into longevity, my memory of you remains vivid and vibrant with gratitude. Herber

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, MARY
description: FRIEDLAND-Mary. On August 10th. Beloved wife of the late Noah. Devoted mother of Joyce Bush and the late Harriet Okun. Adored grandmother of Amy, Marcy and David Bush and Andrew, Robert and Jodi Okun. Loving great grandmother of Five. Service Sunday, August 13 at Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 4 about threatening letters that were sent to several Bengali-language newspapers and a Bangladeshi organization in New York, referring to two competing conventions planned for the Labor Day weekend, both named Fobana 2000, misstated the day the letters were received. It was Aug. 2, not Aug. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, HANI
description: EINHORN-Hani. August 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Max Einhorn, loving mother of Eleanor and David Lanter and Flora and Daniel Einhorn, grandmother of Felice Javit, Julie Einhorn, Emily Einhorn, Marvin and Robert Lanter, great-grandmother of Sammy Javit and Isabel Javit. Funeral on August 13, Beth Israel, Delray Beach, Florida at 12 P.M.

title: Recycling, Our Gift to Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Shades of Simms, Perhaps, in Collins
description: The first pass Kerry Collins threw was off his back foot. Normally, that is a no-no, but few Giants coaches complained because Collins performed the awkward maneuver with splendid grace. His pass floated perfectly into the waiting hands of wide receiver Amani Toomer for a 19-yard gain. Collins made a tough throw look easy.

title: Nader on Nader
description: To the Editor:

title: Swimmer Completes His Odyssey By Punching a Ticket to Sydney
description: Oleg Krayzelburg had one piece of advice for his son, Lenny, before the United States Olympic trials: ''Break world records.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPELMAN, IRVING
description: KOPPELMAN-Irving. Ours was a special quality of a lifetime friendship. Our saddened hearts will always be filled with endearing memories and recollections. God grant you peace with Ruthie. Edna and Bill Sweder

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: News Corporation to Buy Chris-Craft for $3.5 Billion

title: Seeking Out a Just Way To Make Amends for Slavery; The Idea of Reparations for Blacks Is Gaining in Urgency, But a Knot of Questions Remain, Like: Which Blacks?
description: In recent years the issue of reparations has exploded among nations wrestling with the past. Scholars are beginning to see the German payout of $60 billion to Jewish victims of the Holocaust, the United States decision to pay reparations to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II and even Japan's awkward efforts to settle with Korean ''comfort women'' as bedrocks of a new political landscape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITCH, STANLEY
description: DEITCH-Stanley. To Gail, Steven and Laura, we share the sorrow of your loss. Stanley was a loving and wonderful man who Steven first met 37 years ago. As families, we have shared so much. Stanley was always there for all of us. Always loving caring and humorous. As difficult as it is, now you must look forward. That is what Stanley wants for you. All our love, Lesley, Steven and Geoff

title: Sailing Far From the Edmund Fitzgerald
description: Gordon Lightfoot may be 62 and none the better for wear, but he could be a movie star. The singer-songwriter, who played his first New York City show in 32 years on Wednesday at Town Hall, has the same laconic appeal that allows wrinkling leading men like Peter Fonda and Nick Nolte to maintain careers. He's a rugged guy who knows how to melt. The slow thaw defines his music and his enduring charm.

title: Renewed Outcry on Haitian Fugitive in Queens
description: Haitian-American leaders, outraged by the increasingly visible presence in Queens of a man accused of killing thousands in Haiti, are renewing a call to send the man back there for trial.

title: Missionary to England: Pakistani-Born Bishop
description: For centuries the Church of England's cathedral here has greeted pilgrims as the next-to-last stop on the road to Canterbury. Signs inside still bid travelers welcome, indicating the route's enduring popularity.

title: Help Wanted for Tough Job at U.N.: Refugee Commissioner
description: The highest-ranking United Nations official responsible for refugees plans to retire at the end of the year, and a race is on to find a replacement within the next month or two.

title: The Money Hustle: Gore's Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Unconventional Mayor Steps Into Convention Spotlight
description: RICHARD J. RIORDAN is not central casting's idea of a big city mayor. He has no ''How'm I doin'?'' chutzpah, no big stick. He is no speechmaker and is terrible on television. Even some of his allies refer to him with a mix of affection and exasperation as ''Mayor Magoo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGEL, KENNETH
description: KRIEGEL-Kenneth. August 11, 2000. Loving husband for 42 years of Peggy. Beloved father of Emily, father-in-law of Kenneth Dearden, grandfather of five-month-old Grace. Devoted brother of the late Allan Kriegel and brother-in-law of Phyllis Kriegel. Loving uncle of David and Nancy Kriegel. Graduate of Columbia College and Harvard Business School. His wit will be with us always. Memorial gifts to Englewood Library, 31 Engle St., Englewood, NJ 07631. Services at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, NJ on Sunday, August 13 at 2PM.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: A Great Day for Greene and Jones in Zurich
description: Back on foreign yet familiar ground, Maurice Greene and Marion Jones continued doing what they have done for much of the last three seasons: winning and waving to the crowd. But the American stars' victories tonight at the Weltklasse, the world's most prestigious and lucrative one-day track and field meet, were hardly business as usual.

title: Recycling, Our Gift to Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVITT, EDITH S.
description: LEAVITT-Edith S. ''Taffy.'' On August 9, 2000. Cherished wife of the Honorable Peter M. Leavitt. Beloved mother of Karen & Amy. Sister of Susan Mirsky and Jane Brown. Treasured niece of Marjorie Fine. Loving aunt and friend to all. Editor and Occupational Therapist. She will be profoundly missed. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM at Temple Beth-El, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her memory to: Cure for Lymphoma Foundation, 215 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10016-6023.

title: As Mideast Stays Peaceful, Arafat Is Advised to Keep Talking
description: Less than three weeks after the Camp David push for a final Middle East peace settlement ended without agreement, perhaps the most promising development, by the reckoning of many on both sides, is what has not happened.

title: Anarchism's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTROLUX SEES SLOWER GROWTH
description: The biggest maker of household appliances, Electrolux A.B., said slower sales growth in the United States and higher raw material costs would trim profit gains in the second half. The company's shares fell to a 16-month low. ''We're a bit more cautious about the second half'' in light of higher raw material prices and delays in European cost-cutting, the company's chief executive, Michael Treschow, said. ''There are signs United States demand will flatten out,'' he added. The company makes Eureka vacuum cleaners and Frigidaire refrigerators.

title: INSIDE
description: G.M. Plans to Sell Online

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASES, FRED
description: THOMASES-Fred. Textile industry executive, on August 10, 2000. Loving husband of Florence Josephson Thomases, through 66 years of marriage. Services were held yesterday, August 11, 2000. Contributions in his memory may be made to the following charities: The Solomon Schechter School, 275 McKinley Ave., New Milford, NJ 07646; Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ 07647; and Scholarships & Welfare Fund of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: They've Walked a Mile in Their Shoes
description: Leslie Macpherson fumbled with her tool belt as she walked into the room crammed with wires. She had never seen so many in her life. Blue ones, white ones. Wires as thin as toothpicks, wires as thick as thumbs. Thousands of them.

title: Democrats' Efforts to Regain Senate Control Are Hindered a Bit by the Selection of Lieberman
description: However much the selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has helped the presidential prospects of Vice President Al Gore, it has dimmed the Democrats' flickering hopes of regaining the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, MAURICE
description: GRUBER-Maurice. The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the death of longtime member and friend, Maurice Gruber. He was a strong supporter of local charities and will be missed. We send our sincere condolences to his family. Sandy Paskin, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, HERBERT
description: ROTHSTEIN-Herbert. Passed away on August 10th. Beloved husband of Sara. Loving father of Carole and Janet Gould (Kenneth). Cherished grandfather of Jennifer Lynn and Andrew Keith. Loving brother of Miriam Tauber. Funeral services will be held August 13th at 9:30 AM at Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, 718-645-9800.

title: Body is Discovered in Gym
description: A woman was found shot to death yesterday morning at a gymnasium in Woodside, Queens, the police said.

title: NO SAFETY ISSUES SEEN BY U.S. BOARD IN EGYPTAIR CRASH
description: Reinforcing suspicions that a suicidal co-pilot was responsible for the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 last fall, the nation's top air safety investigator said today that there were no safety issues in the crash that would require a public hearing to resolve.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: BIDDER LEAVES GERMAN AUCTION
description: Germany's fifth-largest mobile phone operator, Debitel A.G., pulled out of the auction for high-speed mobile phone licenses in Germany as bidding rose above 32 billion euros ($29 billion). The company, backed by Swisscom A.G., bid in 126 rounds before dropping out. Unlike other bidders, Debital operates using rented capacity. If it had won a license, it would have to build a network from scratch.

title: BARCLAYS WILL ACQUIRE WOOLWICH
description: Britain's third-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., agreed to acquire Woolwich P.L.C., a British mortgage lender, for 5.4 billion [pounds], or $8.1 billion. The deal is part of the Barclays strategy to bolster its mortgage business and its Internet presence, an area in which Woolwich has excelled. The deal values Woolwich at 352 pence a share. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: French Concords Ordered to Remain Grounded
description: France's transportation minister reiterated today that Air France's five remaining Concordes would stay grounded for the time being because of continuing uncertainty about why the supersonic jet caught fire last month and crashed north of Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTABLE, ELIZABETH
description: BASTABLE-Elizabeth ''Betty'' (nee Brown). 86 yrs old, died August 10, 2000, at Ft. Lauderdale, previously of Lakewood, NJ, and Flushing, NY. Mother was a graduate of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart and being a mother was her vocation. She had been a devoted member of the 3rd Order of St. Francis for over 52 years at St. John's Chapter in NYC. Along with Neil, she was a faithful volunteer and Eucharistic Minister at St. John's Nursing Home in Lauderdale Lakes for 18 years. ''All for His greater glory'' was mother's guiding principle. Betty was the beloved wife of Cornelius (Neil) for 64 years, and the loving mother of one son, Neal (Pam) and four daughters, Rosemary (Frank) McGarry, Marian Napoli, Peggy (Jim) Parker and the late Elizabeth (Betty) Comiskey. There are also 17 loving grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Visitation Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY (718-359-6300). Funeral Mass Monday, August 14, 2000, 10:15 AM, at St. Andrew Avellino Catholic Church, 35-60 158th St, Flushing, New York. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers Masses for the deceased are desired.

title: Wackenhut Set to Build New Prison in South Africa
description: The Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, a world leader in private prison construction and management and a frequent target of industry critics, completed an agreement today to build and operate a 3,024-bed maximum-security penitentiary in South Africa.

title: Liberty and Mystics Resume Their Feud in First Round
description: The Liberty has no love lost for the Washington Mystics. Just games lost.

title: As Fires Rage, Administration Is Given Blame for Not Acting to Prevent Them
description: With wildfires still burning out of control across a dozen Western states in what may be the worst fire season in a generation, a fierce debate in timber politics has begun to rage over who might be to blame.

title: Jewish views on separation of church and state grow more complex when it comes to politics.
description: While many American Jews waxed enthusiastic about the vice-presidential candidacy of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, more than a few have also raised eyebrows at his very public expressions of religious faith and his advocacy of a closer partnership between government and religion.

title: AIRLINE MERGER TALKS EXTENDED
description: Two major European airlines -- British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines -- have extended the exclusivity period of their merger negotiations. ''The parties recognize that a business rationale for a potential merger exists,'' the companies said. KLM says it is planning to file a formal merger proposal with the European Union by the end of September.

title: Appeals Court Overturns $50,000 Penalty for Lawyer's Conduct
description: A federal appeals court has reversed a $50,000 sanction against a Manhattan lawyer for his conduct during a civil trial last year, finding that the lawyer's behavior did not justify the penalty.

title: Recycling, Our Gift to Tomorrow
description: To the Editor:

title: May-December Romance? Or Simply Hot and Cold?
description: If it were 1940, ''Autumn in New York,'' a flagrantly old-fashioned, triple-hankie tear-jerker that might have starred Bette Davis and Cary Grant, would probably be lauded as a serious, high-minded romance, the quintessence of ennobling adult entertainment. But time has played nasty tricks on a genre that aims straight for the tear ducts. Nowadays when audiences sense that a movie as shameless as ''Autumn in New York'' intends to ennoble them with tears and redemption, only the most diehard sentimentalists will fail to smell a rat.

title: Microsoft Finishes Work on Most Powerful Windows 2000
description: Microsoft Finishes Work on Most Powerful Windows 2000

title: Japan's Bank Drops Zero-Interest Policy
description: Japan's central bank raised interest rates for the first time in a decade, defying strong pressure from government officials to keep borrowing costs close to zero.

title: Praising the Lord Too Loudly Irks the Neighbors
description: Call it the Harlem Bible Belt.

title: Wendy Abels, Douglas Eisenberg
description: Wendy Suzanne Abels, the daughter of Edith and Elvin Abels of Los Angeles, was married last evening on Vail Mountain in Colorado to Douglas Foster Eisenberg, a son of Betsy Sevin Eisenberg and Philip M. Eisenberg of Manhattan. Cantor Uri Neil officiated.

title: Fresh Kills, Chapter 2; Sure It's Just a Dump Now, but Think About the Possibilities
description: Given enough time, fantasies about the Fresh Kills landfill could overtake one's life. The space has housed a garbage dump for 52 years, but in January the landfill is supposed to close, and public officials, college professors and Staten Islanders have been embroiled in debates over what to do with the 3,000 acres left behind.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Parent-friendly policies in the workplace are fundamentally linked to the status of women in the workplace. Although I plan to remain child free, I will support efforts by the government and employers to accommodate parents because such initiatives arguably promote the professional advancement of women and encourage men to assume a greater share of parenting responsibilities.

title: Jennifer Smolkin, Gregg Menell
description: Dr. Jennifer Held Smolkin, the daughter of Evelyn Held and Charles Smolkin, both of Baltimore, is to be married this evening to Gregg Alan Menell, a son of Phyllis Menell and Dr. Howard Menell of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen is to officiate at the Park Ridge (N.J.) Marriott Hotel.

title: Commercial Property/Long Island City, Queens; Crossing the Queensboro Bridge as a Resettler
description: AS their lease drew to a close at 160-170 Varick Street on the lower west side of Manhattan, executives of Colahan Saunders Corporation, a commercial printing company, knew they were going to have to move. Their landlord, Trinity Church Real Estate, was converting its portfolio of buildings from largely industrial uses to offices, at rents industrial tenants could not afford.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Trying to Forget the Manager Who Got Away
description: IT was the start of a new fiscal year at our media and marketing research firm, and though I hadn't heard from my West Coast manager for a few days, I wasn't worried. After all, I had a well-oiled team in place, and this manager did excellent work. When we finally made contact, the news was good. Sales were brisk, he said, and the new hires were settling in.

title: Hertz Raises Rates And Others Follow
description: Car rental rates jumped last month, with Hertz taking the first step and the other national companies following immediately. Hertz, usually the industry pacesetter, announced a $3 daily increase for noncorporate renters, effective July 14. The weekly rate for cars reserved 21 days in advance rose $10, and the weekly rate for reservations made at shorter range generally went up $20. Lauren E. Garvey, a spokeswoman, said that rises in vehicle prices, wages and interest rates required the increases, although the company had record earnings for the most recent quarter.

title: The Name On a Check For Rent
description: Q I have been living in a rent-stabilized apartment for more than 25 years and for most of that time the lease was in my name only. I married about eight years ago and added my wife's name to the lease. Since she did not change her former name, the lease is now in both my name and her name. For approximately four years we have been paying the rent under my wife's name. Recently, however, the landlord called and said he will no longer accept checks in my wife's name. He also eliminated my wife's name from our monthly rent bill. Is it legal for our landlord to refuse a rent check with my wife's name after accepting it for all these years? . . . Walter H. Lamont, Manhattan.

title: To Sprawl, or Not to Sprawl
description: SOME things down here refuse to change. In the 1980's, anticipating the completion of Route 55, speculators from the north bought 38 acres next to Roger Ruske's farm here, paying $2,800 an acre. The highway arrived, but not much else. Last year, Mr. Ruske bought the property -- for $1,100 an acre.

title: Once Bowling, Now Baseball, At a Bank Building
description: There used to be a section under the bank building on West 74th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue that was used as a bowling alley, where employees socialized. It was also once a print shop, and most recently, used as storage space. But on July 11, the day of the Major League Baseball all-star game, Stahl Real Estate, the company that owns the landmark location, began using the large basement space at 202 West 74th Street for a baseball center called Frozen Ropes. It is the first Frozen Ropes in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERBERG, LILLIAN CHESTNEY
description: ZUCKERBERG-Lillian Chestney. Passed away on August 6, 2000. Born on September 22, 1913, Lillian studied art on scholarship at Pratt Institute in the 1930s and later at the Art Students League in New York City. It was at Pratt that she met and later married Stanley Maxwell Zuckerberg on June 22, 1941. Separated briefly during World War II, when Stanley was part of the 58th Bombardment Wing of the XXI Bomber Command, they were soul mates in art and life. They both worked as illustrators in the 1940s and 1950s. Their illustrations can be found on the covers of the classic paperback romance novels of that time and inside the pages of popular magazines such as ''Saturday Evening Post'', ''Colliers'', and ''McCalls''. Lillian's highly skilled, realistic, and fanciful paintings also decorated the pages of children's books, commercial advertising supplements, and cook books. Lillian specialized in illustrating children's books. One of her works was selected for the Classic Comics edition of ''Gulliver's Travels.'' Later in life she and Stanley turned to subject matter which resonated with their early lifepainting harbor and waterfront scenes from their travels through New England and Nova Scotia. She will be remembered with respect, admiration, and fondness by her nephew Dr. Richard M. Zuckerberg, and his wife Dr. Joan Zuckerberg, nieces Anya Zuckerberg, Betty Zuckerberg, and Judith H. Zuckerberg, and sister-in-law Sophie Zuckerberg.

title: Syracuse Looking to Mall For Tourists (and Money)
description: In many parts of the country, a proposal for a super-duper tourist-attracting mega-mall would be greeted with howls of protest, followed by reams of lawsuits.

title: POSTINGS: At N.Y.U. Law School on Sept. 7; Conference on Owning Homes
description: A conference on the possibilities for expanding home ownership in New York City and across the country is scheduled for Sept. 7 at the New York University School of Law.

title: Kane, Tied for the Lead, Is Dressed for Success
description: Lorie Kane is down to her last red shirt. The Canadian golfer's timing is impeccable, since the du Maurier Classic's final round is Sunday and she is tied for the lead with Annika Sorenstam after 54 holes.

title: Mortgaging the Farm for a Mop
description: STACEY LAVENDER isn't a cleaning fanatic, but she plays one at work. Ms. Lavender is the assistant buyer in charge of housewares at Restoration Hardware, the nostalgia-driven national chain, so she is responsible for the 38 cleaning products and tools the company now carries, like Italian-made squeegees in two sizes, Johnson flannel dust cloths, Seeds' Wood Dressing. Ms. Lavender said that the buzz in cleaning right now is microfiber and that Restoration Hardware will be doing a microfiber ''story,'' as the store calls its displays, in white, in January.

title: August 6-12; The National Missile Mess
description: As President Clinton nears a decision on building a national missile defense, an intelligence report warned that the decision could prompt China to expand its nuclear arsenal tenfold, while Russia could take destabilizing steps like placing multiple warheads on its ballistic missiles.

title: Aliens Arrive, Walking Funny
description: THE Malonys, a handsome family of six from Orange County, Calif., have arrived in Times Square. They are on vacation in Manhattan for five days.

title: Ideas & Trends: Glory and Grandeur; The Art of the Grand Old Cinemas, the Science of the New
description: MARCUS LOEW, who founded Loews Theaters in the early 1900's, once said: ''We sell tickets to theaters, not movies.'' That was certainly the case when the grand movie palaces of the teens, 20's and 30's lit up America.

title: Elisabeth Mayer, Jason Cooper
description: Elisabeth Amy Mayer, a daughter of Harriet and Richard Mayer of Manhattan, is to be married this evening to Jason Matthew Cooper, a son of Denise and Arnold Cooper of Manalapan, N.J. Rabbi Niles Goldstein is to officiate at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Empire State Lights, Decoded: India Independence Day Already?
description: Next weekend, the Empire State Building's lights will be green, white and orange. Some may wonder why.

title: Early Impressions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Richness Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cultural Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: We asked online readers of Lisa Belkin's article whether our culture dotes on children too much. Here are some responses from , a New York Times Web site (www.abuzz.com).
