title: Jessica Seessel, Richard Larson
description: Jessica Parham Seessel, the daughter of Diane and Tom Seessel of Hopewell, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard James Larson, a son of Sheila Cullen of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Herbert Rosenberg, a retired Dobbs Ferry village justice and friend of the bridegroom, officiated in his home there. Later, Mr. Rosenberg led a celebration of the couple's marriage at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Arrow in a Consortium To Buy VEBA Electronics
description: Arrow Electronics Inc. of Melville (NYSE: ARW) plans to purchase the VEBA Electronics Group of Germany as part of a consortium put together by Schroder Ventures, a British investment group. Arrow and VEBA are ranked first and third, respectively, among distributors of electronic components. Second-ranked Avnet, based in Phoenix, is also in the consortium.

title: For Comedian, Old Jokes, Loyal Fans
description: IT'S the season for Jersey corn, so Cozy Morley can hardly be blamed for bringing his version to the Sands Casino-Hotel.

title: Investing; KPMG Consulting Arm Looks Ready to Fly Solo
description: IN the busy market for initial public offerings -- especially for volatile Internet-related companies -- analysts tend to be wary, which makes their enthusiasm for a planned $2.83 billion stock sale announced last week by KPMG Consulting Inc. all the more remarkable.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Original Lieberman
description: IN the exhaustive analysis of Al Gore's selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman as his running mate, one factor has been strangely overlooked: Mr. Lieberman's uncanny resemblance to Sam Jaffe.

title: Testaverde Gets a Scare, And Jets Are Humbled
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde had felt nary a breeze in the first two preseason games, so effective was the protection that kept defenders from placing even a finger on him. And Testaverde was not pleased. He had prepared himself for contact, had marked the first hit as the next stepping stone in his grueling recovery from a ruptured Achilles' tendon. He was looking forward to being hit, he said, jesting only a bit.

title: Don Ettlinger, 86, Who Wrote For Film, Theater and Television
description: Don Ettlinger, a writer for film, television and theater, died on Monday at a hospital in Nyack, N.Y. He was 86 and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title: Giants See The Good After Loss To Jaguars
description: For a coach who had just watched two of his rookies fumble away a preseason victory in the game's final seconds, Jim Fassel did not appear too shaken in the wake of the Giants' 16-13 loss Friday night.

title: Jacqueline Hutchinson, Christopher Burls
description: Jacqueline Karen Hutchinson, the daughter of Elaine Hutchinson of Brooklyn and John Hutchinson of Curacao, was married yesterday to Christopher Joseph Burls, a son of Carol Burls of Baton Rouge, La., and William Burls of Dallas. The Rev. Kirkton J. Lashley, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn.

title: Crisscrossing the Wide Map of American Music
description: A FEW nights after Nick Spitzer was ousted from his job as a disc jockey, his friends on the Philadelphia rock station WMMR-FM gave a farewell party. They had listened over the previous two years as Mr. Spitzer had spun Bessie Smith and Merle Haggard during afternoon drive-time, and they knew that the program director had been ridiculing the choices as ''nostalgia music.'' Now, in December 1973, Mr. Spitzer had resigned rather than be consigned to the 2 a.m. shift, when his taste could do little damage to ratings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHDEV, VED, M.D.
description: SACHDEV-Ved, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hosptial mourns the passing of our long-standing and beloved colleague. Dr. Sachdev began his prominent career in neurosurgery and neuroanatomy at Mount Sinai in 1970. He dedicated himself to the teaching and practice of medicine and was highly regarded for his clinical and academic skills. He will always be remembered for his commitment to his patients and to the institution as well as for his kind and gentle nature. Our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Stanley Tuhrim, M.D., President Terry Weill, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 13, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Taking Art To Those 'At Risk'
description: THE county's Department of Social Services and the Westchester Arts Council will collaborate on a $50,000 project to bring dance, theater and other arts to people on public assistance.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the book ''Lost New York'' omitted a credit for an exterior photograph of the old Singer Tower on lower Broadway. It was used by courtesy of the Columbia University School of Architecture.

title: On to Los Angeles, Still Leaning Left
description: My phone is pulsating like a blender. The calls are from my press buddies. They're all coming, you know, to cover the Democrats. Years ago we'd be talking pegs, angles. Who's gonna defect in some platform fight? What caucus will Reagan try to charm to steal the nomination from Ford? Will Jesse apologize tomorrow night for the Hymietown thing? Dukakis definitely won't pick Bentsen; I got it nailed.

title: Up-Island
description: AS you head north on Long Beach Boulevard, the four- and five-lane 1960's-style drag strip that forms the spine of Long Beach Island, the land suddenly seems to broaden at the end of Surf City.

title: Capturing Sag Harbor In a Time of Solitude
description: James Britton

title: SOAPBOX; The Shore Delegation
description: IF delegates to the Republican National Convention had ventured beyond the red-white-and-blue hoopla of the convention floor to Philadelphia's neighborhoods in search of some local color, they might have noticed an eerie, empty quiet. ''Where did everybody go?'' they may have wondered. I hoped our city's volunteer hosts told them that their convention conflicted with prime time for an essential ritual of summer for many Philadelphians; we were voting with our sandal-wearing feet Down the Shore.

title: 15 Years and Millions Later, Bombing Plagues Philadelphia
description: Gerald Wayne Renfrow thought the nightmare hit its climax 15 years ago on a gruesome day when -- he still barely believes it -- he and his neighbors watched the city police bomb and burn down his solid working-class neighborhood, killing 11 people in a confrontation that became a firestorm.

title: INVESTING WITH: Thomas J. DiBella; Aetna Small Company Fund
description: INVESTING is much more fun than public accounting, says Thomas J. DiBella, who made the career switch almost 10 years ago and now runs the $239.5 million Aetna Small Company fund. ''It's a lot more exciting to predict the future than to record the past,'' he added.

title: Criminal Class
description: Wainewright

title: August 6-12; Greens Joke and Reformers Fight
description: It is easily the wittiest candidate commercial of the 2000 election. In a parody of MasterCard's ''priceless'' television campaign, Ralph Nader's first spot takes aim at the ways the major-party candidates finance their runs for the presidency.

title: Wireless Web (With Strings Attached)
description: BY now, it's almost a consensus among Internet pundits that the future of the Web rests in the hands -- or, perhaps more appropriately, the palms -- of those who make wireless Internet devices and software. Why would consumers want to be shackled to a desktop computer, the thinking goes, when they could roam freely with a hand-held device that gives them everything they need?

title: Ideas & Trends; And Now for Something Completely Different . . .
description: WHILE Ron Wyden was campaigning for the Senate in Oregon in 1996, a local newspaper ran a letter denouncing him as an ''Ashkenazi'' -- clearly a code word for Jew. It set off an uproar and some soul-searching in Oregon. How dare a responsible paper publish such anti-Semitism? But what happened next was instructive: the editors apologized, explaining that they had never heard the term and were unaware it could give offense.

title: Princeton Enclave Is Fading
description: A dozen years ago, when George Cumberbatch opened a soul food restaurant here, he called it ''Downtown Deluxe.''

title: To Protect Island Integrity
description: VINCENT GALLUCCIO of Westhampton, a newcomer to the East End's wine industry, and Richard Olsen-Harbich, a 20-year veteran of it, share a goal: premium wine.

title: Steering the Stars Through 'A Perfect Storm'
description: In the movie ''The Perfect Storm,'' when the actress Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio is seen piloting the fishing boat the Hannah Boden, the person really steering is Capt. Larry J. Walsh Jr. who was a swordfish fisherman operating out of Barnegat Light for 22 years. Captain Walsh, who stopped fishing two years ago after an injury, got the movie job on the recommendation of his friend Kirk Larson, the captain of the Lindsay L., a scallop boat that sails out of Barnegat Light and appeared in the movie as the Hannah Boden. Captain Walsh worked on the film in Gloucester, Mass., from August to October 1999.

title: A Modest Creator Of Quiet Dreamers
description: ALEC GUINNESS, who died last weekend at the age of 86, was the last of the great knights who found their early fame in the legendary pre-World War II English theater. But the others -- Michael Redgrave, Ralph Richardson, Laurence Olivier, John Gielgud -- shared a grandeur of technique, a high-romantic flamboyance, that was never Sir Alec's province.

title: Reading Between the Lines
description: As Asian fever, cowboy cool, 60's modernism and vintage kitsch are all touching down on the fashion tarmac, a new fleet of books is taking off, on the quirkiest notions of chic. Style monitors have ventured to far-flung corners and brought back Ferlin Husky's dog-sled-embroidered jacket add Suzie Wong's signature cheongsam deress. The coffee table is groaning.

title: Vegetable Dishes Requiring Little or No Cooking
description: IN peak season, farmstand-fresh vegetables often stand on their own. In each of these salads, they're used fresh, with minimal cooking, and given a touch of tangy flavor with a light vinaigrette and a bit of cheese. The cheese also fortifies the various mixtures enough to make them suitable first courses. But beyond that, the preparation is simple, permitting the vegetables to shine.

title: These Unlikely Neighbors Won't Have Much to Say
description: Is the scramble for a European foothold spurring an unlikely chumminess among American buyout firms? Later this year, according to people who know those involved, the London representatives of both the Texas Pacific Group, founded by David Bonderman and James G. Coulter, and the Blackstone Group, led by Pete Peterson, plan to move into the same seven-story building, called Stirling Square, in the fashionable St. James's district that already houses Henry Kravis's company, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Given that the three firms will be competing for the same slices of the European action, this could mean more attention to secrecy. Most of the principals aren't commenting. But a person familiar with the set-up vouchsafed, ''We won't be talking too much in the elevators.'' Alan Cowell

title: WIND AND WATER
description: A fortuitous accident of geology shaped the coastline of Connecticut into a chockablock mixture of bed-rock (glacial debris made of gneiss and granite) and drift (gravel, sand, silt and clay). About 22,000 years ago, when the Wisconsin glacier covered much of what is now Connecticut's shoreline, it extended 115 miles beyond the south shore of Long Island. Ah, those were the days.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on July 30 about proposed rent increases in Peter Cooper Village misattributed a quotation from a critic of the increases. It was not Soni Fink but another Peter Cooper resident, unidentified, who said: ''My husband fought in World War II, and he got this apartment as part of the benefits for returning vets. And now this is the thanks we get.'' The article also misstated the percentage by which Ms. Fink's rent would rise. It would be 22 percent, plus standard lease renewal increases, not ''nearly half.''

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column in The Times Magazine last Sunday rendered the the Web address incorrectly for the Dictionary of American Regional English (DARE). It is http://polyglot.lss.wisc.edu/dare /dare.html.

title: Living Up to the Memories of a Poetic Old Skyline
description: THIS is a plea on behalf of ethos, the set of cultural values that underlies the forms of artistic expression -- or eidos, if you'll excuse the Sunday morning anthropology lesson I'm about to foist on you. The ethos of ancient Egypt, for example, was theocratic hierarchy. Its eidos was the pyramid. Nice forms, pyramids. Not so nice, the beliefs that gave rise to them. But it's enlightening to know about the beliefs nonetheless.

title: Doing Grass One Better
description: ARE you a poor fool who mows the lawn on a hill so steep you have to pull the mower back up on a rope? And then your back goes out and you have to be hauled off on a stretcher?

title: Just How Safe Is 'Wireless' Pollution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marley Kaplan and Bernard Dushman
description: IF anyone tried to play a chess game the way I've lived my life, they wouldn't win,'' said Marley Kaplan, the executive director of Chess-in-the-Schools, a program in New York City that promotes chess as an educational tool. ''A lot of my adult life has not been thought out in such a strategic way.''

title: Easy-to-Grow Bulbs That Never Sleep: Lilies
description: THERE is something about lilies in a garden. With careful selection of them, bloom can be seen from the beginning of the summer months to earliest fall.

title: A Golfer From Iona Prep With a Near-Perfect Swing
description: IT was a new experience for Tim Connors, the Iona Prep golfer who won every individual and team championship available to him as a junior this past season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, WILLIAM WARD
description: JACKSON-William Ward. On August 3, 2000, at his longtime residence in Short Hills, NJ. He is survived by his devoted wife Suzanne (Zani) Zipse Jackson, his loving daughter Hollace Jackson Tullman and his son-in-law Jeffrey S. Tullman, and his two cherished grandchildren, Matthew Tullman and Gillian Tullman. He was predeceased by his first wife, Rae Applegate Jackson. A private service with immediate family at his request was held on August 11, 2000. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Institute.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Something New

title: Sea Carnivores Move In At Las Vegas Casino
description: An aquarium featuring some of the most feared predators of the sea -- venomous tropical fish, carnivorous water monitors (a type of lizard that measures up to seven feet long) and 10 species of shark -- recently opened at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Givers
description: AFTER Tanya Theriault spent spring break of her senior year of college in New York City, she was sure that she would not be applying to medical school. At least not right away. She had found a job that she felt compelled to take, even though it was grueling and carried no salary.

title: A Starry Troupe That Pays Its Way
description: WHAT renowned American classical ballet company garnered enough engagements in 1999 to employ its dancers for an impressive 41 weeks? The Joffrey Ballet, maybe? American Ballet Theater? No, it was Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, fondly known as the Trocks, home of bulldozing stars like Olga Supphozova and Ida Nevasay neva. The company, opening at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, will present two repertory programs consisting primarily of Slavic chestnuts, including the New York premiere of an impeccably affected ''Raymonda's Wedding,'' coached by Elena Kunikova. Because of an advance sell-out of their last Joyce engagement, the Trocks are extending this year's New York summer season to a full two weeks.

title: Favre Waits for More Fuel in His Rocket Arm
description: It is interesting how quickly fans forget. It was not long ago when Brett Favre, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, could have run for mayor in that city. Super Bowl appearances in the 1996 and 1997 seasons had revitalized football in Packersville, and Favre's rocket arm was the biggest reason for it.

title: Tennis Justice: Court at South St. Seaport Gets a Reprieve
description: The tennis courts on Piers 13 and 14 below the South Street Seaport were to close in May, because the city, which owns the property, was hoping to redevelop it for other uses.

title: Pace Offers Workshops On Computer Skills
description: Adults interested in honing their computer skills can register for noncredit computer workshops at the Pace Computer Learning Center at 1 Martine Avenue in White Plains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELECHENKO, JEANETTE
description: VELECHENKO-Jeanette. On August 10, 2000 in Flemington, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Alexander, devoted mother of Andrew M., Darlene and Darius Transky. Funeral Mass Monday, August 14, 2000 at 10 AM in St. Michael's Ukrainian Catholic Church, Hillsborough, NJ. Interment to follow in Prospect Hill Cemetery, Flemington. Friends may call at the Robert L. Ford Funeral Home, 38 Highway 31, Flemington, NJ, Sunday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: The Roar of the Beer Suds, the Smell of the Fish
description: The bars in the Fulton Fish Market bring to mind the drinking establishments of the Alaskan Panhandle. The men are coarse and rough. The language is salty and blasphemous. And when the fish are in, pockets are filled with money.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONE WOMAN SHORT By Nelson George. Scribner, paper, $12.

title: Saving Gamblers from Themselves
description: Norman looked out over the gambling floor at Resorts Atlantic City, a cacophony of clanging and a blur of ostentatious colors.

title: Sports of The Times; Ticket Too High? Call It Therapy
description: PAID $37 to park my car in Manhattan the other night. Was there only three hours, but should have left the car to rationalize the overnight fee.

title: Back to Hong Kong, Where the Action Is
description: WHEN Stanley Tong left his hometown for Hollywood in 1996, Hong Kong's film industry was headed for a crack-up as spectacular as anything in a Jackie Chan movie.

title: OPINION; Confessions of an Overfisherman
description: AT sunrise, my father and I embarked from the pebble-laced shoreline of Long Island Sound. After attaching his motor to the back of the rented boat, he guided the boat through the small waves to the rips and reefs and other fishing holes around Bayville.

title: CRIME DECREASES
description: Crime in New Jersey decreased by more than 6 percent last year, reflecting a national decline of 7 percent, and making it the sixth year in a row that the number of violent crimes in the state went down, according to the New Jersey State Police Uniform Crime Report issued last week. The number of murders declined from 321 in 1998 to 287 last year, the lowest number of murders in 33 years. Rape declined 13 percent, and robbery and aggravated assault both dropped 6 percent. Nonviolent crimes that are tracked are burglary and theft, both of which declined, and motor vehicle theft, the only crime that showed an increase, up 1 percent. Every county, with the exception of Mercer and Gloucester, saw a decline in violent crimes.

title: Exiled Laotian Prince Seeks a New Role
description: Nearly 20 years ago, an 18-year-old prince, heir to a doomed Asian royal line, commandeered a small boat and sailed unnoticed with his brother and their nanny across the Mekong River from Laos to Thailand. Laos had become a Communist nation, in the orbit of neighboring Vietnam, and the prince, Soulivong Savang, feared being co-opted or killed.

title: Brenda Reilly, 62, Coach and Administrator
description: Brenda Reilly, a teacher, sports administrator and three-sport coach in a career of almost three decades at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain, died of cancer at a hospice in Branford, Conn., on Aug. 5. She was 62.

title: Show Time for Al Gore
description: In political analysis, the conventional question to ask at this point in the electoral calendar is this: What does a presidential candidate need to get from his party's national convention? Past candidates have used conventions to show they are strong enough, wise enough or steady enough to lead the nation. But it is hard to think of an exact precedent for the problem confronting Al Gore as he prepares to accept the Democratic nomination.

title: Faith Healer
description: The Better Man

title: WEST NILE VIRUS
description: The West Nile Virus, which was first identified in the United States in dead birds found in New York City and Westchester County last September, has been found in 89 dead crows in seven northern and central New Jersey Counties, according to the state Department of Health and Human Services, which is conducting screening of crows, chickens and mosquitoes. No infected people had been found as of Thursday, according to the health department. The infected crows were found in Bergen, Middlesex, Union, Hudson, Passaic, Monmouth and Essex Counties. Karen DeMasters

title: National Bridge Finals
description: Two star-studded teams faced off today in the final of the Grand National Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. The defending champions, all from Florida, include Michael Seamon, Joseph Shay and three world champions: Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell and Robert Levin. Opposed to them are a Californian squad that includes Lew Stansby, Chip Martel and Peter Weichsel, all world champions; and Rose Johnson Meltzer, Ron Smith and Kyle Larsen.

title: Trying to Gain Favor For a Feared Species
description: IN 1997 Helene Grimaud, a pianist, and J. Henry Fair, a photographer, bought a six-acre parcel off Route 35 here with a plan: to create a natural habitat for wolves while promoting wolf conservation through education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHTERMAN, YETTA BESSIE
description: LACHTERMAN - Yetta Bessie. Born 1909. Died August 10, 2000, in Chicago, IL. Wife of the late Max. Mother of Paul (and Alita) of Park Ridge, IL, William (and Teddy) of Tulsa, OK. Sister of late Ida Landau and late Anna Brenner. Also survived by Selma and Saul Landsberg, of Tucson, AZ, and Danny and Goldy Landau of NYC. Graveside services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Beth David Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, you may donate to your favorite charity in her honor. For information call ''Weinstein-West End Chapel,'' 1-800-452-9597.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDLER, RUTH L.
description: BANDLER-Ruth L. Passed away in her 98th year on August 9, 2000. She was the devoted wife of the late David Bandler. Beloved mother of Susan Stern (Richard) and James Greenwald (Marilee). Loving step-mother of Ellen Fertig and David Bandler, Jr. Dear sister of Robert Leberman (Barbara). Grandmother of Michael, John and Scott Stern; Thomas Greenwald and Paul and Daniel Fertig. Great-grandmother of Lisa and Jenny Stern. It was her request that there be no funeral. She will be dearly missed and lovingly remembered. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: A Way to Cover Those Bare Ankles
description: Everyone has Vinca minor (sometimes called periwinkle or myrtle), and those who don't probably should. It covers the ground, acting as a natural mulch, succeeds in shade and hides dying foliage of spring bulbs and ugly ankles of taller plants. On top of that, it requires almost no care.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00; Dead Air
description: Political junkies, chew on this demoralizing fact: Al Gore and George W. Bush have already spent $150 million, and their campaigns get built-in coverage from the networks, yet not only have they failed to produce a spectacle as compelling as the World Wrestling Federation's ''SmackDown!'' they can't even muster the ratings of ''The King of Queens'' reruns.

title: The Reality of Ecstasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Out-of-This-World Philanthropy
description: Paul G. Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, and Nathan Myhrvold, the former chief technology officer, don't limit their philanthropic ventures to this planet. Together, they are donating $12.5 million to the SETI Institute, the world's largest private organization searching for intelligent life beyond Earth. SETI, based in Mountain View, Calif., will use the money for a telescope to seek out signals from space. The telescope will have technology that lets it examine up to a dozen stars simultaneously.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: LUNCH WITH ELIZABETH DAVID

title: Marcy Dworkin, Steven Geller
description: Marcy Gail Dworkin, the daughter of Linda Dworkin of Secaucus, N.J., and Lawrence Dworkin of New York, was married yesterday evening to Steven Keith Geller, the son of Herbert Geller of North Bellmore, N.Y., and the late Arlene Geller. Rabbi Robert A. Raab performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Too New to Know
description: HALF-JEW

title: HARRISON: SOFTBALL TEAM WINS TITLE
description: The Harrison 10-and-under Little League Softball Team won the state championship in Ridgewood, Queens, on Tuesday. The 11 girls, members of an all-star team, beat a team from Cicero, N.Y., 12 to 2. Harrison went undefeated in its divisional tournament, which included six Westchester towns, before beating a team from Ozone Park/ Howard Beach to win the sectional title on Staten Island. In the state championship it also beat teams from Brewster and Lido Beach/Long Beach. For the ten-and-under division, the state championship is the highest level of competition. Peter Beller

title: GORE SAYS SPEECH WILL GIVE DETAILS OF HIS OWN AGENDA
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that in his acceptance speech to the Democratic National Convention he would embrace President Clinton's success in presiding over the hardy economy but send an unmistakable message: ''I'm running on my own agenda, on my own voice and through my own experiences.''

title: 2 More on Staten Island Are Ill With West Nile Virus; Infected Crow Is Found in Bronx
description: Two more Staten Island residents, a 63-year-old woman and a 64-year-old man, have been sickened by the West Nile virus, bringing the number of human cases confirmed this year to three, New York City health officials said yesterday.

title: Berlin Story
description: EDUARD'S HOMECOMING

title: Liberties; Prudes And Playboys
description: Dreaming of a convention gleaming with purity, Gore aides and Democratic officials bullied and blackmailed Representative Loretta Sanchez of California until she tearfully canceled her fund-raiser at the Playboy Mansion.

title: Banff Takes Measures To Cope With Crowds
description: IN the genteel days of railroad tourism, the Canadian Rockies had predictable, limited flows of visitors who came to gawk at dramatic mountain crags that were marketed around the world as the second Switzerland. But now Banff National Park, the oldest park in Canada's system, has a busy, largely four-lane highway transecting it and an international airport only 90 minutes away, in Calgary. Flying to Calgary from Tokyo or piloting motor homes from Michigan, an estimated 4.4 million people visit the park every year, with another 4 million indulging in what park officials call ''windshield tourism'' as they drive through on the Trans-Canada Highway.

title: Lili Dyer, Nicholas Benson
description: Natalie Scott Dyer, a daughter of Natalie and Elisha Dyer of Washington, Conn., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Vance Benson, a son of Shirley and Raymond E. Benson of Weybridge, Vt. The Rev. Cheryl P. Anderson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at a house belonging to the bride's parents.

title: Memories Of East 91st Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Dobbs Ferry Dropping Nonresident Parking
description: SEVENTY-FIVE Westchester residents who commute to Manhattan from the Dobbs Ferry railroad station will be without parking spaces starting this Tuesday.

title: The Tour Caddie
description: At the P.G.A. Championship at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Ky. this week, all eyes will be on Tiger Woods as he begins his quest for his fifth victory in a major tournament. But neither Woods nor any other golfer will be going it alone. Even though golf is not considered a team sport, the players depend heavily on their right-hand men: the caddies. The tour caddie is not merely a club bearer. He also brings an intricate understanding of the game, which includes knowing the correct yardage from every lie on every hole and being an on-site sports psychologist. To help understand what is involved, Andy Portilla, a veteran tour caddie and former club professional, provides a window into the life and work of a PGA Tour caddie.

title: Recalling the Life of Ralph Fasanella
description: THE paintings of one of Westchester County's most important 20th-century artists are currently on display at the Hudson River Museum in an exhibition titled ''Fun City: Celebrating the Life of Ralph Fasanella.'' Characterized by muddy pinks, cold grays, lime greens and robust blues, Mr. Fasanella's art memorializes the plight of the underclasses. He depicts the common Jane or Joe -- how they lived, what they experienced and what made them remember who they were and where they came from is the message in his paintings.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 30 with an article about excursions from Amsterdam misidentified an inset of St. Bavo's church in Haarlem, the Netherlands. It showed the pipes of an organ, not columns. (The organ is known because Mozart played on it.)

title: Book of Hours
description: LITTLE SAINT

title: How Big a Role on a Global Stage?; The Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Boom Box
description: It is interesting how new technology arrives. On the one hand, there is something arbitrary about invention; on the other, every society seems to get the technology it deserves. Take ours, for example. The current phase of American capitalism began on Nov. 9, 1989, with the formal collapse of socialism. Suddenly, there was no need to flavor the free market with a dash of something else. The little pockets of socialism that had been tolerated when socialism posed a threat now, overnight, seemed horribly retrograde. Why have your capitalism diluted when you can have it straight? Since then, as if by some marvelous coincidence, a lot of new technology has arrived to enhance market forces. The Internet is one such technology. It creates new markets and new competition in old markets and helps to put a better price on everything. In a few short years, it has pretty much gutted the principles of corporate socialism -- jobs for life, employee and customer loyalty, all for one and one for all -- and replaced them with Lord knows what.

title: Clintons Promise Not to Step Into Gore's Spotlight
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she and President Clinton would stay at the Democratic National Convention just long enough to proclaim their support for Vice President Al Gore, and then drop completely from sight, doing nothing, she promised, that might steal attention from the celebration surrounding Mr. Gore's presidential nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, PAULINE (NEE LEIBNER)
description: KLEIN-Pauline (nee Leibner). On August 10, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Philip; loving mother of Estelle Yoss, Doris Silverman, Harold Klein and his wife Marcia; dear grandmother of Meryl, Eric, Rhonda, Ilena, Mara, Gillian, Stefan, Cheryl, Donna, and Stephanie. Great-grandmother of 16. We will all miss her. Graveside service Sunday, 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Park Land Is There If You Look for It
description: Re: ''Cold Spring Harbor Finds Land for Park'' [July 23], I must respond to the assertion that state officials ''found out purely by accident that the property was already state-owned,'' and ''park officials are now combing the maps looking for more.''

The results can be artistically provocative, the best of such productions making theatergoers gaze in wonder at both dance and the world from which it comes.

Treasured niece of Marjorie Fine. Loving aunt and friend to all. Editor and Occupational Therapist. She will be profoundly missed. Services Sunday, 10:30 AM at Temple Beth-El, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in her memory to: Cure for Lymphoma Foundation, 215 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10016-6023.

title: Kristina Kaplan, Jeremy Wallison

title: August 6-12; Germany's Jewish Question
description: After two Jewish cemeteries were desecrated in the western German state of Rhineland-Palatinate and an explosive device was found outside a Jewish family's home in Bavaria, German politicians reviewed a possible ban on the small rightist National Democratic Party on the ground that it is a threat to democratic stability. The Constitutional Court, however, has not upheld any such ban since the 1950's. The government and Jewish leaders said an advertising campaign for tolerance, called Show Your Face and featuring sports and entertainment celebrities, would start in the fall. Roger Cohen

title: DEVILS DEAL FINANCED
description: YankeeNets, the parent company of the New York Yankees and the New Jersey Nets, has secured the financing to complete its $175 million purchase of the New Jersey Devils hockey team by next Friday. Under the deal, which was first announced in March, Puck Holdings, an affiliate of YankeeNets, will buy the hockey team from John McMullen. A small group of private investors, yet to be completed, will hold stakes in the team. Delays in the deal were caused by new investors having to pass the National Hockey League's background checks, according to a spokeswoman. Peter Beller

description: A running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night, Aug. 4, through Thursday night, Aug. 10.

description: ONE of the biggest fig leaves of all times has been removed. And what can at last be seen by everyone, after centuries of censorship, is a remarkable collection of erotic antiquities in the National Archaeological Museum of Naples.

title: August 6-12; Walking Out Over Wireless
description: In a dispute over organized labor's future in the New Economy, more than 86,000 workers went on strike against Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone and wireless company. The union wants concessions from Verizon making it easier to organize in the company's fast-growing wireless division. The strike affected 25 million people in 12 Eastern states and Washington, D.C. Verizon was formed by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation. Simon Romero

title: A Man-Made Arcadia Enshrining Male Beauty
description: VASARI'S life of Michelangelo reports that the artist believed the male body was ''something divine,'' an idea so powerful that for 200 years it was thought appropriate to make nude monuments to Napoleon and Beethoven. For several centuries, artists regarded the male rather than the female nude as the noblest subject they could treat. In the 19th century, when the naked female triumphed decisively over the naked male in art, it turned out to be a pyrrhic victory, with women not so much ennobled as reduced to sex objects.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Belkin's article was pretty evenhanded, right up to those last three paragraphs when she shrugged her shoulders and said, in effect: Hey, childless ones, whether you like it or not, our kids are your problem.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Belkin's article on the growing backlash against children expressed many of my own views. I feel very much as Jason Gill does. I had to tear the cover off the magazine because my hand itched to slap the face of that screaming brat.

Together!'' The 25-foot boat began riding little waves off the beach at Avery Point in Groton. ''Together! Nice!'' he said as the rowers headed out into Long Island Sound.

But the studio has made more than 40 licensing deals for Harry Potter products ranging from candy to soap, which will gradually appear before the first Harry Potter movie, scheduled to open Nov. 16, 2001.

Beside it is a gravel driveway leading up a hill, where a squad of giant water jars from Java preside like fat sentinels, flanked by a 20-foot-tall chair, bright white and skinny as a reed, and a fishing-line sculpture resembling the prow of a ship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURDOVAL, DONALD J.
description: SURDOVAL-Donald J. Age 67, of Saddle River, NJ, on Thursday, August 10, 2000. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Fitzpatrick). Devoted father of Lisa A. of Saddle River, NJ; Catherine A. of Nanuet, NY; Donald J. of Sparta, NJ; John G. of Sydney, Australia; and Brian G. of Hoboken, NJ. Loving grandfather of Donnie, Kaitlin, and Alison Surdoval. Mr. Surdoval was a First Lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps and served during the Korean Conflict. A graduate of Manhattan College in 1954, he was a self-employed CPA for Surdoval Assoc. in Waldwick, NJ, since 1980. He was former VP and Controller of Norton Simon, Inc., of New York, NY, for 12 years. He also served on the Board of Directors at Calvary Hospital in Bronx, NY, for 25 years. He was past Treasurer of the Lion's Club and a member of the Knights of Columbus, both of Saddle River, NJ. He was also a member of many CPA associations: AICPA, NJSCPA and NYSCPA. Funeral mass 10 AM, Monday, at St. Gabriel's R.C. Church, Saddle River, NJ. Interment Cemetery of the Ascension, Monsey, NY. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Sunday, at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 East Chester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Q & A/Daniel C. Esty; Long-Term Optimist for the Environment
description: DANIEL C. ESTY, director of the Yale Center for Environmental Law and Policy, thinks the environment will not be taken seriously around the world, until it is given a number. ''What is important gets measured,'' Mr. Esty said, but that kind of analytical approach is rarely focused on the natural world.

title: Teuscher Wins Medley, and a Second Chance
description: By her sophomore year of high school, Cristina Teuscher was an elite international swimmer. Her graduation present in 1996 was a gold medal in the 800-meter freestyle relay at the Atlanta Olympics. She could have attended any of the major swimming powers, such as Stanford or Southern Cal, which were more than willing to give her a full-scholarship ride through college.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Shortage Of Minority Teachers
description: Patricia Boyle's July 2 letter in reference to the article on the shortage of minority teachers in Connecticut classrooms (''White Faces at the Blackboard,'' June 11) merits a response. Her statement that ''black teachers feel more comfortable in urban classrooms as do white teachers in suburban settings'' reflects the segregationist mentality that serves to confirm the need for minority teachers in all classroom settings.

title: STATE EMPLOYEES
description: One of every 63 people in New Jersey works for the state government, a ratio higher than in any other state of equivalent or larger population, according to numbers released last week by the United States Census Bureau. The ratio falls in the middle of all states, however. Karen DeMasters

title: Basketball Star Picks UConn
description: The recruiting battle for Ben Gordon, the Mount Vernon High School basketball star, ended last week when the 6-foot-2, 180-pound Gordon gave a verbal commitment to the University of Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTLINGER, DON
description: ETTLINGER-Don. Our hearts go out to Katrina, Karen, Annabelle, Torey, Nick, Mark and his family. Don was a ''oner'' as the crossword puzzles would say. We miss his being dreadfully. His brilliant wit, love of life, tenderness, empathy enriched us all. Joan Simon Crowell and Family

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; One Hat, Three Languages
description: To some, it lent a touch of style. Others thought it looked like a flowerpot. For Georges Batrakani, the Greek Catholic French-speaking Syrian businessman in Robert Sole's wonderfully evocative novel BIRDS OF PASSAGE (Harvill, $26), manufacturing the tarboosh -- or fez, as it is better known here -- was a method of acquiring wealth in early 20th-century Cairo. Sole, a French journalist who was born in Cairo, follows four generations of the Batrakani family in Egypt, using their triumphs and tragedies to recreate a place and time long gone. Sole deftly weaves the family's history into a tapestry of a colorful and complicated era in Egypt, one marked by ethnic and religious diversity, world wars, occupying powers and, finally, the nationalism and independence that will lead to the tarboosh's demise there -- and to the departure of the Batrakanis and many other families. Told through the eyes of a grandson who makes good use of a relative's diary, the novel, ably translated from French by John Brownjohn, has characters as exotic as the setting. Among them are Georges himself, a Levantine who, in the eyes of a friend, ''hovered between two cultures, juggled with three languages and possessed no well-defined status of his own.'' Maggi, Georges's sister-in-law and occasional lover, is as sensuous as anyone in Lawrence Durrell's ''Alexandria Quartet.'' And Ferdinand, Georges's overweight brother, gives a memorable demonstration of the proper way to eat molokhiya, a garlic-flavored dark green soup. If this literary concoction is so rich that one occasionally loses track of the name of a sultan or a revolutionary, never mind. The dish is ravishing. Peter Khoury

title: Elmhurst Journal; Elks (the Clubs) Becoming Extinct
description: There is a building in central Queens that is a temple to the working man. It is a fading neo-classical castle of brick and plaster. It is five stories high and one floor down, and the American flag that flies above it is the only American flag that can be seen clearly on Queens Boulevard for a mile in either direction.

title: Another View Of Assisted Living
description: In the article ''A Place of Their Own, With a Difference'' (July 9), the writer paints a positive picture of the growth of assisted-living facilities. Many of us who have gone through the process of finding a place to live on behalf of an elderly relative have different stories to tell.

title: Grand Theft Auto
description: TAKEN FOR A RIDE

title: Hospitals Are Discovering Their Inner Spa
description: A SMILING concierge in the lobby directed Debra Paget toward the eighth-floor lounge, a sumptuous room, where she plunged into a cushy banquette. Sitting with a friend amid fountains, pink orchids and filigreed screens, she might have been at the Four Seasons Hotel, waiting for a waiter to bring her a cocktail. In fact, Ms. Paget was waiting to see her gynecologist, whose office was tucked at the rear of the lounge behind a high ash-panel wall.

title: Put Through the Mill, Yet Gilbert and Sullivan Still
description: The adaptability, elasticity even, of Gilbert and Sullivan is in evidence in Manhattan these days as two groups present nontraditional versions of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance.''

title: From a Size 22 to a String Bikini
description: THERE are women for whom weight is not an issue, for whom extra pounds are at worst an annoyance, not a self-image-threatening disaster. Grisela Rivera, a 31-year-old telephone cable splicer, is not one of them.

title: The Jewish Tipping Point
description: Divided by allegiance and an aisle, David Gottesman and Si Wachsberger awaited the vote of the Beachwood, Ohio, Planning and Zoning Commission on agenda item 96-63. Normally, half a dozen spectators might sit through the commission's business of density, setbacks and demolition permits. Tonight 400 packed the recreation room of City Hall, scrambling to grab the last empty seats, milling three-deep along the rear windows. Television crews assembled along one wall.

title: Rebecca Pomerantz, Lawrence Shinder
description: Rabbi Rebecca Jennifer Pomerantz, the daughter of Rabbi Fredric S. Pomerantz and Mrs. Pomerantz of Closter, N.J., is to be married today to Lawrence Brian Shinder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Shinder of Monsey, N.Y. The bride's father, the rabbi of Temple Beth El of Northern Valley in Closter, performed the ceremony in his synagogue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERNAY, JEAN, PIERRE
description: VERNAY-Jean-Pierre. December 5, 1938-August 13, 1988. Remembered always with love. Bill and Lenny

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: U.S. Remains Destination Of Choice For Investors
description: THE United States has been living through extraordinary economic times for so long now that fresh milestones sometimes pass with a yawn. With growth rates over 5 percent, subdued inflation, low unemployment, high productivity and strong corporate profits -- all with the expansion already a decade old -- it is hard to surprise people with good news.

title: A Wider Insurance Net
description: The Association of Independent Accounting Professionals in Hicksville announced an agreement with Access CoverageCorp., an Internet provider of business insurance in Charlotte, N.C., to deliver insurance and services to the association's 3,000 members and their clients, mostly small businesses.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about playing golf in the Netherlands misstated the name of a street in Amsterdam on which the author encountered a golfer. It is Nieuwe Doelenstraat, not Nieuwe Doelenstrasse.

title: These Homes Have a Castle, Where Children Are Injured
description: As Antoinette Purcell stepped out the back door of Betances Houses, a public housing development in Mott Haven, she made a sweeping motion with her hand like a television spokesmodel.

title: Where They Prefer Misfits
description: IN the show ''Wanted: X-Cheerleaders,'' a squad of 10 real-life ex-cheerleaders rant and cheer about women's issues. Their routines, which feature flying pompoms, kicks and jumps, are at once authentic cheerleading drills and carefully choreographed movement.

title: Columnist Suspended for Comparing an Official to Hitler
description: There is probably no more efficient way for a newspaper columnist to spark a rhetorical tempest than to compare a person with whom they have a dispute to Hitler. It is also a good way to get your column suspended, as the writer, Frank Borzellieri, has found out.

title: If These Floors Could Talk
description: IN its heyday, Studio A-4 was called the Snake Pit. Admission 50 cents.

title: THEATER; Spain Dusts Off a Master and Finds He's Sexy
description: I HAVE written 30 plays,'' reported Cervantes, ''and they were all received without cucumbers.'' The author of the epic novel ''Don Quixote'' was referring to the critical whistles and lobbed vegetables delivered by rambunctious groundlings who crowded 17th-century Spanish theaters.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: I have never opened an issue of the magazine as eagerly as I did the one with Lisa Belkin's cover story (July 23). I'm only 27, but I have endured reactions that ranged from the quizzical to the downright vicious when I mention that I entertain the idea of remaining child free. I like to think I'd be doing society a favor by remaining childless: ecologically, I'm less of a burden (limiting my consumer consumption to myself), and economically, I'm more productive.

title: F.A.A. Is Faulted Over Warnings on Possibly Faulty Airline Cables
description: On May 18, the Federal Aviation Administration issued what appeared to be an important safety notice for the world's airlines. Federal investigators had learned that a manufacturer of cables that work key controls in many widely used jetliners might not have properly tested its cables. Samples checked by investigators, the notice said, had failed to meet minimum requirements for strength.

title: Children's Books
description: HARRIET, YOU'LL DRIVE ME WILD!

title: Valhalla Software Developer Acquires Israeli Company
description: Cognet Corporation, a Valhalla-based developer of software management technologies for corporate computing and personal communications devices, has acquired the software producer myITcorp in a stock purchase agreement valued at $7.5 million.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Mercedes-Benz SLK320; Show-Stopping Top Gets Engine to Match
description: THE last time I drove a Mercedes-Benz SLK, I couldn't lower the retractable hardtop. Not because it didn't work; it was buried under a half-foot pile of snow.

title: Snug as a Dog in a Baby Carrier Is the Latest Refrain for Pet Lovers
description: Annie Rosenberg is a good employee. She never laughs when her boss at Albees, the baby store on the Upper West Side, wears her poodle to work.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: COLLEGE. An intellectual challenge. An experiment in self-reliance. An opportunity to meet people from all over the world and share a four-year adventure with them. Above all, a time to go shopping.

description: The Dortmund Supertournament this year had an unusual touch: one of the participants was a computer, Deep Junior 6, created in Israel. It performed creditably in such a distinguished company of grandmasters, scoring 4 1/2-4 1/2.

title: The World; From Chile's Army, Little but the Sound of Fury

The soldiers' medals, uniforms and goose-stepping also evoke that era, making the force appear profoundly anachronistic, even in a nation as traditionbound as this one.

title: PeoplePC Cuts 3 Million Shares Off IPO
description: PeoplePC Cuts 3 Million Shares Off IPO

description: IT has been 13 years since executives at Discovery Channel first assembled a weeklong block of shows focusing on sharks, sharks and more sharks. Great whites, hammerheads, blues, lemons ad nurses are mong the species that play starring and supporting roles during Discovery Channel's annual sharkathon.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY

title: After the Deluge, Cars for Sunny Skies
description: IF you live in the Northeast or Upper Midwest, you may be shopping for an ark. Who can think of convertibles when gray skies seem to bring showers almost daily?

title: August 6-12; Wahid's Last Hurrah
description: In his state-of-the-nation speech to the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly, President Abdurrahman Wahid issued a tough-minded rebuttal to critics who say he has not done enough to address Indonesia's many troubles. However, Mr. Wahid, who is blind, fell asleep as the speech was being read by an aide. Other aides fed him candy to wake him whenever he drifted off. Several days later, Mr. Wahid announced he would cede day-to-day administration of the government to Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputi. Seth Mydans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, EDWARD
description: BRODSKY-Edward, 70. Beloved husband of Cynthia. Cherished father of Peter and Leslie, William and Karen and James. Darling grandfather of Noah and Skye. Brother of Phillip and Harriet Brodsky. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, August 13 at 1:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76 Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Leukemia Research Fund, Long Island Jewish Center, New Hyde Park, New York 11040, attn: Dr. Kanti Rai.

title: An Artist Whose Canvas Is a Cluttered Taco Stand
description: ROSEMARY JAMISON, a Texan who came to New York in the 1960's in search of a bigger canvas for her art, opened a restaurant here and has been filling it ever since with things like fake shark heads and black lights, bird cages and oil paintings, Life Magazines, pool ladders, armless mannequins and oddities of all sorts.

title: Wall St. and the Politics of the Status Quo
description: WALL STREET'S political views are usually summed up with the simple logic that is a staple of junior high math. If all wealthy people are Republicans, and all bankers and traders are wealthy, then all bankers and traders are. . . .

title: Can You Read This?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foliar Feeding
description: Dahlias and many summer-flowering bulbs are heavy feeders and benefit from regular foliar feeding with an organic fertilizer high in potassium and phosphorus. Container plants require fertilizing to replace nutrients leached out of the soil by watering: every two weeks for annuals and tender plants until frost, and once a month for shrubs and perennials through August is sufficient. PATRICIA JONAS

title: Republic's Growth Plans Divide Community
description: LOOKING down from the control tower at Republic Airport in East Farmingdale, the airport manager, Stephen D. Williams, pointed to the 200-foot separation between Runway 1/19 and its neighboring taxiways, and the 500-foot space that separates the airport's other runway, 14/32, and its taxiways.

title: INSIDE
description: Lebanon Border Tension

title: A Bounty of Shoreline For Castles of Sand; Where the Welcome Mat Is Always Out for Everyone
description: IN Connecticut, a beach -- like a wave -- is catch as catch can. Indeed, to anyone whose ideal beach is on Nantucket or Maui, the Nutmeg State offers what must seem like a dip in a bathtub. Adding to their unassuming quality, the state's beaches front the nearly waveless, partly freshwater Long Island Sound, not the wide-open salt-laden curls of the Atlantic or Pacific oceans.

title: Our Towns; The New Millennium Fashion Question: 'Who Does Your Eyes?'
description: THE wall is hung with pictures of the near-famous. The newscaster Jack Ford. The Yankees coach Lee Mazzilli. The radio host Bob Grant. The radio D.J. Dan Neer. You almost expect to see a Jackie Mason publicity shot inscribed, ''Love That Corned Beef!!!''

title: Painting the Town
description: Serendipity Green

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIT, HELEN ZINAIDA
description: BLIT-Helen Zinaida. Died on August 9, 2000, at age 84. A beautiful, intelligent and extremely caring woman, she touched the hearts of all who knew her. We will always remember her with love. Barbara, her daughter Zachary, her grandson

title: Where Have All the Children Gone?
description: LEGEND has it that the reason school is out in the summer is that long ago, children were needed to work in the fields.

title: Introduction
description: Lisa Belkin's cover article on the backlash against children brought an avalanche of mail. It was high time for a debate, readers said, though many conceded points to both the haves and the have-nots. The real problem, as more than a few saw it, is parents who spoil their kids.

title: A Relocation, but the Quality Stands Pat
description: CRIES of ''We've lost our lease'' were heard in Floral Park earlier this year. Villa d'Este, a 31-year-old mainstay, was moving to new digs a few blocks away on Jericho Turnpike.

title: Treasury Sale Holds Up, Despite Shrinking Debt
description: With the federal government's debt shrinking -- politicians differ as to just how much -- the Treasury has been decreasing the size of its quarterly auctions, leading some bond market experts to fear that demand from investors could outstrip the dwindling supply.

title: Visions of Kerouac
description: To the Editor:

title: Annika Roesner, Aaron Kennon
description: Annika Kristina Roesner, a daughter of Kristina and Karl Roesner of Goteborg, Sweden, was married yesterday to Aaron John Kennon, the son of Glynnis Kennon and Dr. Irwin Kennon of Rehoboth, Mass. The Rev. Mikael Ringlander performed the ceremony at Orgryte Gamla Kyrka, a Lutheran church in Goteborg.

title: Children's Books; The Wisest Bear
description: The cave is washed in candlelight and the grown-ups are padding around in slippers, but Baby Bear is wide awake. Grandma Bear confidently plops into a rocker with the baby, sings a little song -- and nods off. So Grandpa takes the baby to a window and croons a lullaby. No luck. Mama steps in, but not even her song can get Baby Bear dozing.

title: His Acting Lessons in Haddonfield Pay Off
description: WHEN Gervase Peterson first informed his acting coach, Nick Dana, that he planned to spend more than a month on a desert island with 15 strangers trying to pick each other off to win $1 million, Mr. Dana told him he was crazy.

title: Kristin Noonan, Matthew Hall
description: Kristin Elizabeth Noonan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Noonan of Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Matthew Parke Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Hall of Concord, N.H. The Rev. Lee A. Bluemel, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: Liberty's Johnson Makes Some Magic of Her Own
description: Vickie Johnson quickly patted Michael Jordan's shoulder as she left the MCI Center court, giddy from her brush with greatness. But tonight, Jordan, a part-owner of the Mystics, was a casual observer. Johnson was the one with the spellbinding touch.

title: Amy Bittle, Andrew Zahalsky
description: Amy Elizabeth Bittle, the daughter of Rena Shapiro of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Peter Bittle of Ossining, N.Y., is to be married today to Dr. Andrew Jeffrey Zahalsky, a son of Linda and Elliot Zahalsky of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Harold Markman is to officiate at the Sheraton Civic Center Hotel in Poughkeepsie. The bride's mother, the cantor at Temple Beth-El in Poughkeepsie, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Giambi Helps A's End Skid
description: Jason Giambi set another milestone yesterday as the host Oakland Athletics ended a six-game losing streak.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Thriller Set on Island and Made by Islanders
description: AS the rain-soaked summer wears on, a cadre of scholars have immersed themselves in sinister goings-on at the Vanderbilt Planetarium here.

title: Style & Entertaining; Salt Of the Earth
description: In design, just as in cooking, Eberhard Mller and Paulette Satur have no patience for pretense. ''A lot of architects we interviewed tried to give us columns and balustrades,'' Satur recalls, deeming such neo-Shingle Style proposals ''too fancy for the North Fork.''

title: BALLY'S EXPANSION
description: Bally's Park Place will open a 9,400-square-foot addition containing 340 slot machines on Labor Day weekend. The room, called Coyote Kate's Slot Parlor, is an expansion of Bally's Wild Wild West Casino, which opened in 1997. The addition will also include a bakery, a retail store, and such western memorabilia as a bearskin coat worn by Wyatt Earp. The expansion cost about $25 million. The parent company, Park Place Entertainment, also spent $5 million to add meeting rooms its Caesars Atlantic City. The addition will connect Wild Wild West Casino to Caesars by an escalator. Angela Starita

title: Is Putnam the Safest County? Uh, Not Exactly
description: AS the parting shot in a one-page news release, it almost went unnoticed: ''Putnam County is considered the safest county in the state of New York.''

title: Shelley Neumeier, J. T. Farley III
description: Shelley Caroline Neumeier, the daughter of Carol Jean Oldham of San Anselmo, Calif., and Edward James Neumeier of Kentfield, Calif., was married yesterday at the Serai, a hotel on Bali, to James Thomas Farley III, a son of Johanna and James Farley Jr. of Washington. The Rev. I Wayan Mastra, a minister with the Protestant Church of Indonesia, officiated.

title: A Grateful Patient, on a Mission
description: Harry Pearce, vice chairman of General Motors, is taking his leukemia battle from the hospital room to the boardroom. Two years after his leukemia was diagnosed, and treated with a bone marrow transplant, Mr. Pearce, who is in remission, is taking on a second personal battle: to help raise funds to fight leukemia, lymphoma and myeloma -- all blood-related cancers.

title: For the State, a Move Into the History Books
description: IN line at the supermarket, they're talking about Joe. In boardrooms and classrooms, the buzz is about Joe. At churches and synogogues, the topic of conversation: Joe.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Belkin raises many intriguing points, but I want to focus on just one: the alleged unfairness of workplace accommodation to people with children. Our child is grown and starting his career. While he was growing up, I tried to come home at a reasonable hour and to spend weekends on family things rather than office work. Sometimes, I am sure, it meant that others covered my matters and helped move things along.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00: The Ethicist; Co-op Snoop
description: I am a member of my co-op board. A prospective buyer's tax return showed that she had deducted the entire cost of her Ivy League M.B.A., a clear violation of the tax laws. I am appalled by her deceit and wonder if it is a legitimate reason to reject her application. Should I report her to the I.R.S.? -- Anonymous, New York

title: Within the Walls of Lucca, Both Mystery and Music
description: LUCCA in September can make one forget the Renaissance ever happened. Situated just above the knee of the Italian boot barely 20 miles from the Mediterranean Sea, this Tuscan city of 87,500, long prosperous and well pleased with itself, uses the beginning of autumn to celebrate what it was and what in good part it still is.

title: Article 2000081391517311746 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Popular Standards Serve a Pianist Well
description: THE pianist Stuart Hemingway always figured he'd get around to recording his own work. He didn't realize, however, that he would take until after his 58th birthday for it to happen.

title: Speaking of Success, In a Woman's Voice
description: INSIDE our newsroom in St. Petersburg, Fla., is a filing-cabinet drawer emblazoned with a yellow smiley face. We call it the Happy Drawer -- home to the good stuff.

title: Blue-Collar Rebels
description: To the Editor:

title: At Goodspeed, the Dancing Feet of 'George M!'
description: THE tale of George M. Cohan's impact on musical theater is still waiting to be told. And it will go on waiting until real musical theater collaborators can tell it, or more precisely, show it. If you think that will happen, don't bet on it.

title: Haitians Cry 'Assassin' Outside Queens Home
description: High-pitched wails and angry shouts pierced the damp quiet of a Queens neighborhood yesterday morning as about 30 people gathered at the home of a former paramilitary leader from Haiti to protest his presence in the United States.

title: This Is Extremely Sporting
description: SEE. See Lee. See Lee Dansie, a champion street luger with a Mick Jagger haircut, come streaking through the fog toward the Pacific Ocean on a flying bit of metal, shoes smoking.

title: Mallory Call, Stephen Chinn
description: Mallory Anne Call, a daughter of Judy E. Call and James R. Call of Larchmont, N.Y., was married on Friday to Stephen Andrew Chinn, a son of Nancy Chinn of Oakland, Calif., and the Rev. Calvin Chinn of Alameda, Calif. The bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Karen Mikhael, Lewis Porter
description: Karen Mikhael and Dr. Lewis Porter are to be married today at the bride's home in New Canaan, Conn. Patrick Tiani, a justice of the peace in New Canaan, will officiate.

title: Bush and McCain Focus on Military
description: Having campaigned with Senator John McCain of Arizona to appeal to swing voters, Gov. George W. Bush enlisted him yesterday to try to reach out to veterans and other Americans concerned about the country's military might.

title: BOOKEND; Not eBay, but an Amazing Facsimile
description: OLD HEBREW STONE TABLETS **NICE** Antiquities: Miscellaneous: Lapidary Materials Seller: golden--calf--antiques Currently: $5 Location: Tel Aviv

title: WATER SUPPLY GRANTS
description: State grants totaling $6 million will be allotted to improve drinking water supply programs in 36 counties and New York City. Westchester will receive $233,000; Putnam, $218,000; Dutchess, $374,000; and Rockland, $115,000. The grants will be used to help local health departments bolster inspections of water systems, disinfect groundwater supplies, treat surface supplies and set standards for contaminants (radon, arsenic, and volatile organic chemicals). Elsa Brenner

title: Editorial Observer; On Being Young, Idealistic and Politically Ambitious at Yale in the 60's
description: For all the talk of the importance of average families in the election this year, it turns out to be a grand year for elites. The last time a presidential race featured a candidate from Harvard (Al Gore), Yale (George W. Bush) and Princeton (Ralph Nader) was 1912 -- the year of Woodrow Wilson, Teddy Roosevelt and William Howard Taft -- when the Ivy League was more clearly a place of privilege than it is today.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about career counseling and life planning programs offered by WEBS, a service of the Westchester Library System, misstated the information number. It is (914) 674-3612.

title: One Rating Over Another
description: After Andreas Schmidt, a pharmaceuticals analyst at Merrill Lynch, downgraded shares of Schering A.G., the German drug giant, for the intermediate term -- up to one year -- they dropped 4 percent, closing at 64.91 euros on Wednesday in Frankfurt. They ended the week at 63.9 euros.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSON, RUTH MUSMAN
description: DICKSON-Ruth Musman. Of Coral Gables, FL, formerly of Valley Stream, New York, passed away peacefully at home on August 11, 2000. Beloved wife for fifty-three years of Harry; devoted mother of Barbara Sussman (Bill) of Miami, FL and Judy Dickson of Hartford, CT; cherished grandmother of Melissa and Liza Sussman. For more information, contact Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Miami, Florida, 305-531-1151.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDERMAN, MYRA Z.
description: LINDERMAN-Myra Z., 61, formerly of Edison, NJ, resident of North Miami Beach, FL, passed away on August 7th, 2000. Her strength, courage and dignity are to be admired by all who knew and loved her. Myra's spirit will live in our hearts and minds forever. She was the beloved wife of the late Errol. Is survived by two loving daughters, Monica (Steven) Goldstein and Georgia (Michael) Gottlieb of Boca Raton, FL; mother, Anne Greenberg of Aventura, FL; three brothers, Robert (Lucille), Jeffrey (Lita) and Melvyn (Rona) Greenberg of New Jersey; two cherished grandchildren, Erin and Danielle; many nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to Susan B. Komen Cancer Fund or charity of your choice. Services were held in Florida.

title: A Friendship From Another Time
description: ONE of the striking things about the baby boom generation is that we're the first generation to think of the good old days as cul de sacs, split levels and car pools.

description: A Rum Affair

description: CARACOL BEACH

description: THERE are now official surveys to confirm that tourists are taking over New York City.

description: Score Educational Centers brought its after-school program to Harlem last month, when it opened at 121 West 125th Street (between Lenox Avenue and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard).
