description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASES, FRED
description: THOMASES-Fred. Temple Emanu-el of Englewood, New Jersey extends its deepest sympathy to Mrs. Florence Thomases and her children and grandchildren on the death, at the age of 92, of the head of the family, Fred Thomases. He was a central figure in our congregation and in the Jewish and civic communities for nearly 60 years. His good deeds were without number. We mourn the end of an exemplary life, and we rejoice in what he taught us. May his family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Geoffrey Haber, Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, Rabbi Emeritus Israel Singer, Cantor Kurt Silbermann, Cantor Emeritus Marlene Erlebacher, President Allen Brown, Executive Director

title: Workouts That Fit the Lives Of Harried Commuters
description: EVERY weekday evening, as the northbound train stops at Larchmont and exhales a crowd of weary commuters, a dozen or so head for the New York Sports Club less than a quarter mile away.

title: New Web Choices For Visitors to Japan
description: The Japan National Tourist Organization has redesigned its Web site, www.jnto .go.jp, and launched a site specifically for North Americans, www.japantravelinfo .com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HISER, ELIZABETH
description: HISER-Elizabeth. The staff of Miavita mourn the tragic loss of our esteemed and beloved colleague Betsy Hiser. Our hearts go out to her children, Jessica, Will and Peter, and to her family who have lost a treasure and shining light. Betsy walked tall among us. She was a leader and the embodiment of the healthy lifestyle she so earnestly wanted to help others achieve. We are honored to have shared her light and wisdom and will endeavor to spread her words and knowledge to others, as she would have wished.

title: One to Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE NAKED AND THE DEAD, by Norman Mailer. (Picador USA, $16.). Norman Mailer was a young World War II veteran with a story to tell in 1948 when this hefty novel, his first, was published. On page 6 of The Book Review, David Dempsey, found it "the most ambitious novel to be written about the recent conflict'' and "the most ruthlessly honest.'' " 'The Naked and the Dead' is not a great book,'' this early evaluation concluded, "but indisputably it bears witness to a new and significant talent among American novelists.'' The novel has been reissued in a 50th anniversary edition with a new introduction by Mailer. Picador has also reissued WHY ARE WE IN VIETNAM? ($13) a Mailer novel from 1967, when he was well established as Celebrity Writer. Vietnam itself is not mentioned until the last page of the novel, which chronicles the Alaska hunting trip of two soldiers-to-be, who set out to prove their virility in various ways. Anatole Broyard said in these pages that it "may be a third-rate work of art, but it's a first-rate outrage to our sensibilities.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAYER, MARSHALL PAUL
description: BAYER-Marshall Paul, March 30, 1959 to August 11, 1984. Love is forever. Ima

title: When Foreign Movies Mattered
description: FOR five weeks, through Sept. 14, Film Forum is showing some wonderful foreign classics made in the years 1945-65, everything from ''Children of Paradise'' and ''Open City'' to ''The Seventh Seal'' and ''Breathless.'' The series is titled ''The Golden Age of the Foreign Film,'' a challenging claim; it sounds almost too good to be true.

title: Lives; Portraits of the Artists
description: Rene Magritte, Giorgio de Chirico and Balthus -- the most poetic of all 20th-century artists -- have long been the companions of my dreams. The mystery of their visual sleight of hand, the originality of their passion and the intimacy of their surprising games. . . . I wanted to thank them for all the ways they had moved me. But how? All I could think to do is what I do. And so I set out to take their pictures.

title: Bitter Rivals Leaving Town As They Feud Over Money
description: Battered and sundered into competing factions, the Reform Party fought through the final hours of a bitter national convention today, then limped out of town as two parties, each with its own ideology and nominee.

title: BRIEFING: ENERGY; GPU TO MERGE
description: GPU Inc., the energy company based in Morristown, has accepted a $12 billion bid to merge with FirstEnergy Corporation, based in Ohio. FirstEnergy will provide $4.5 billion in cash and stock and assume $7.4 billion in GPU debt. The investor-owned electric company will serve more than 4.3 million customers nationwide; GPU serves 2.1 million customers in the United States, a million of them in New Jersey. The companies expect that the merger will be completed within 12 months. Natani Blumenkehl

title: How Big a Role on a Global Stage?; The Allies and the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: I almost didn't pick up your magazine because of that cover. But I'm glad I did. I just hope parents read the article so that they will understand that their bundles of joy may be something quite different to people who don't need that kind of love for validation.

title: Ideas & Trends: Your Move; And Now for Something Completely Different . . .
description: NO matter whether you think Al Gore should be the next president, give him this much: He has transformed the vice presidency, the subject of generations of derision, into more than the butt of jokes. Not content to languish at state funerals, Mr. Gore has been the most productive and industrious vice president in modern times.

title: IF YOU GO
description: HAMMONASSETT STATE PARK is at Exit 62 of Interstate 95. A connector road goes directly into the park from the Interstate exit. Admission: $5 for state residents during the week ($8 for out of staters) and $7 on Saturday, Sunday and holidays ($12 for out of staters). Camp sites are $12 a night, with reservations required (877-668- CAMP).

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section last Sunday about entrepreneurs in business schools misidentified the school that Steve Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, left in 1980 to join the company. It was Stanford, not Harvard.

title: Where the Geese and the Cantaloupe Play
description: A PLACE IN

title: Erika Meisel, Robert Schwartz
description: Erika Sharon Meisel, the daughter of Gloria Bader Meisel and Dr. Barry A. Meisel of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Robert Alan Schwartz, a son of Dr. Arnold Schwartz of Stamford, Conn., and the late Myna Schwartz. Rabbi Chaim Stern officiated at the Renaissance Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Motown acts appearing in Danbury misidentified the group that recorded the three hits ''It's the Same Old Song,'' ''Reach Out, I'll Be There'' and ''Standing in the Shadows of Love.'' It was the Four Tops, not the Temptations.

title: The Addictive Spectacle of Maternal Reality
description: NINE years ago, before ''Survivor,'' before ''Big Brother,'' before ''The Real World,'' even, I was introduced to reality programming of the most intimate sort. It was thrilling and disturbing. It made me want to look away. It made me want to look back again. I think it even made me nauseous. But then everything made me nauseous, because I was pregnant. This was the final week of Lamaze class and my spouse and I and our classmates were finally watching the Movie.

title: Taiwan Chief Drops Plan For Meeting In California
description: Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, today abruptly canceled an informal reception with several members of Congress planned for Sunday in California after vigorous protests from China and expressions of concern by the State Department.

title: One Cruise With a Taste Of 3 Nations
description: I AM a sucker for the Great Lakes. I vacation on them. I swim in them. I walk their beaches and scuba dive in them. I even live on one -- Lake Erie. But one of the few things I'd never done on the Great Lakes was take a cruise.

title: Vacation Bible Schools Under Pressure
description: AT the vacation Bible school run by Faith Lutheran Brethren Church in Briarcliff Manor on Monday morning, Elaine Hansen, a retired music teacher, gathered youngsters around a piano in the sanctuary and belted out a spirited rendition of ''Shine, Jesus, Shine'' with them.

title: BRIEFING: MUSEUMS; PRINCETON CLOSING
description: Princeton University's 144-year old Museum of Natural History will become dormant this Labor Day weekend. The building housing the room, Guyot Hall, will be renovated, and the museum itself is out of date, according to the university, which will relocate the museum in the building and update the exhibits. Kushanava Choudhury

title: For Real Road Warriors
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Mrs. Clinton's Interview
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Hillary Rodham Clinton at her hotel in Century City today.

title: Mrs. Lieberman: A Child of Holocaust Survivors
description: They came over on wobbling merchant marine ships, refugees with a few valises apiece that contained all they owned in the world.

title: Personal Business; Planning a Trip for 125? Send In the Specialty Agent
description: SHARON S. TURNAU, president of Landmark Travel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., knows what it means to be flexible.

title: A Foot in Realism And in Abstraction
description: OVER his career, Will Barnet has shown himself to be very comfortable with pendulum swings. A retrospective at the Montclair Art Museum shows Mr. Barnet, 89, to be a dedicated realist painter but also a disciple of abstraction -- sometimes both at once.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: If there's more than a modicum of truth in your article, the national community is in danger of ever-greater balkanization. It does take a village to raise a child, and it disturbs me that people like Jason Gill want no part in it.

title: Do They Make Fountain Pens for Parrots?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wonders of the Wetlands
description: A barred owl in swampland at the Delaware Water Gap, ice-encased grasses in a New Jersey freshwater marsh, and a beaver in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County are among images that explore the diversity of plant and animal life abundant in wetlands throughout the United States.

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; Eating Out at the Octagon
description: First things first: I did not try the gyro. That would have been too much pressure for this little man. Gyros, as proclaimed on full-color posters in every Greek diner, are ''America's tastiest sandwich.'' And Jersey City's Gyro Stop advertises the ''Best Gyro in Town.'' Intimidated by such superlatives, I am bowing out of the debate, and will leave it to the specialists.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Belkin's article about the ''childrunnn'' ends like this: ''And, in several decades, when the children are grown, we can all live side by side again, in child-free retirement homes.''

title: In Congress, Gore Selected Issues Ready for Prime Time
description: The Democratic freshman class that was elected to the House of Representatives in 1976 was a remarkable one, loaded with bright and ambitious young reformers who blended the idealism of their generation with the cynicism bred by Watergate and Vietnam. Many would go on to bigger things -- Richard A. Gephardt to the top of the House Democratic leadership, Leon E. Panetta to the White House as chief of staff, Barbara A. Mikulski to the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESILVER, GEORGE BURNHAM
description: DeSILVER-George Burnham. Of Naples, Florida, formerly of New York City and Northwest, CT died August 6th, 2000 after a short, but valiant, struggle with cancer. He was a quiet, good and loving man, whose dedication to civil liberties, equality, and human rights followed the commitment of his distinguished parents, Margaret and Albert, and led to his years of service at the United Nations with the international League for the Rights of Man. His kind spirit will be missed by his family and many friends. He leaves his devoted wife of 49 years, Claire; his daughter, Susan and her beloved companion, Ronald Anthony; granddaughter, Margaret; brother, Carll Harrison, and his wife, Colette. He was predeceased by his dear son, George Steven, who died in 1988. A Cremation will be held in Naples; his remains will be interred in the DeSilver family plot at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice of Naples, Inc., 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, Fla. 34105.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for RAVI NATHAN; When Bad Weather Is Good Business
description: FOR Ravi Nathan, the weather is not kindling for small talk. Sunshine does not necessarily lift his spirits, nor does rain always sour his mood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, WILLIAM
description: APPEL-William. Of NYC, NY. 95. Died July 14, 2000. Respected, loved uncle, husband and friend; Accountant and insurance broker. Survived by nieces and nephews. He will be greatly missed. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Unmarried Couples and Property
description: WHEN Pina Olson and her life partner decided to buy a Manhattan apartment together in October 1998, they put money aside to hire a lawyer to draft an agreement that would spell out what would happen in the unlikely event that they eventually parted. As it turned out, Ms. Olson said, the agreement was never drafted.

title: House and Garden of Folk Art
description: NOBODY lives quite like they do -- his art, her art, their folk-arty house and quirky garden in Washington are part of a whole. The folk artist Tommy Simpson and the weaver-embroiderer Missy Stevens live, work, play and generally hold court in a house distinctly their own. You might call it a folk-art production.

title: August 6-12; Tire Trouble
description: They can't find the flaw in the design or the materials or the manufacturing process, but the makers of Firestone tires say some of their products are falling apart on the highway. As a result, they are recalling 6.5 million tires used on Ford S.U.V.'s and a variety of other pickups with 15-inch wheels.

title: Rustic Retreat on Gitche Gumee
description: LAST September, on a family trip to Longfellow's ''shining Big-Sea-Water'' -- Lake Superior in Minnesota -- we hiked, bicycled, canoed, sailed, visited historic sites and gobbled lake trout and heavenly homemade doughnuts. We even swam in the icy water.

title: Oyster Bay Development: Moratorium Debate . . .
description: Even as the Republican Town Supervisor of Oyster Bay, John Venditto, and the Democratic Councilwoman Bonnie Eisler work together for a bipartisan water protection plan, Councilman Anthony D. Macagnone weighs in on the side of development at any cost [Letter, July 30].

title: THE GUIDE
description: Playhouse's Birthday

title: In Seattle, a Cobbler's Legacy Is Being Repaired
description: A FOUNDATION whose enormous real estate portfolio is the unlikely legacy of a onetime cobbler is bringing new life to one of its most prominent assets -- the neglected turn-of-the-century brick buildings in Pioneer Square. The buildings were once hotels, offices and stores built after the Great Fire of 1889 destroyed the wooden buildings and wharves of Seattle's original business district.

title: Oyster Bay Development: Moratorium Debate . . .
description: We were dismayed to learn that Councilman Macagnone opposes a temporary moratorium in the special groundwater protection area, and surprised that he apparently thinks the business community would not support such a moratorium. We recently sponsored a meeting of business, residential and environmental leaders in our community, at which it was generally agreed that a moratorium and a comprehensive land use plan are urgently needed.

title: When Flying Was Fun
description: Back in the "Coffee, Tea or Me?" days, flight attendants were called stewardesses, and they had mystique. So did air travel. In "Airline: Identity, Design and Culture," Keith Lovegrove, a design consultant, recalls those heady days. Examining the fashion, food and design of air travel, he recalls the hot pants and knee boots worn by Southwest Airlines stewardesses in the early 70's and celebrates the beauty of the sushi served in club class on Nippon Airways flights. He also marvels at the $2 million makeover that a hot young designer, Marc Newson, gave a private jet a couple of years back. The $42 million plane looks like an airborne version of Canteen, a SoHo restaurant designed by Mr. Newson, but it is no more exotic than an animal-print 747 "tiger lounge" bar built for Boeing as a prototype in 1972. The book (teNeues Publishing; $24.95, paperback) takes off in October.

title: Michelle Effron, David Levine
description: Michelle Sara Effron, a daughter of Tova and Barry Effron of White Plains, is to be married today to David Harris Levine, the son of Ruth and Jules Levine, also of White Plains. Rabbi Chaim Marder will perform the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: What Is Stephen King Trying To Prove?
description: Stephen King is addicted to writing. It isn't a matter of liking to write or even loving it. He needs it, chemically, the way years ago he needed his cocaine and his beer, sometimes a case a day. ''Writing is just this great big conduit, this outflow pipe that keeps the pressure nice and even,'' he says. ''It just pours all this [expletive] out. All the insecurities come out, all the fears -- and also, it's a great way to pass the time.''

title: Archipelago of Legends and Play
description: TUCKED in the backyard of a rapidly developing suburban community on Johnson's Island in Lake Erie, 206 gleaming white marble tombstones rise in perfect rows from carefully manicured grass. The stones are marked with names, military ranks and the occasional ''unknown,'' but no dates. These sons of the Confederacy rest while one of their own -- in the form of a bronze statue -- stands guard. Oddly, the statue does not face south. Instead, it looks out over the lake to Canada, less than 10 miles away.

title: Ideas & Trends; Guns: The Law As Selling Tool
description: WE must help protect our children, in our schools and streets, by finally and strictly enforcing our nation's gun laws,'' Gov. George W. Bush of Texas declared in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia. In other words, Mr. Bush was saying, we don't need more laws to do the job.

title: Builder Rebuffs Suffolk On Low-Cost Housing
description: The Suffolk Legislature voted last week to give the developers $1.8 million if they agreed to add affordable family housing to a much-debated plan for the former Long Island Developmental Center in Huntington.

title: Chipping Away Old Paint For Colors of the Past
description: IT was just a small paint chip lifted from the woodwork of a rear porch of Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. The sample was examined, imbedded in resin and, along with other samples from around the residence, shipped off to the conservation laboratory at the Savannah College of Art and Design in Georgia. The chips would be sliced across and the cross section would be analyzed and photographed microscopically.

title: The Shadow Man
description: RODINSKY'S ROOM

title: Why the County Must Spray
description: I HAVE been increasingly dismayed by the substance of the public debate over the steps taken to control the West Nile Virus.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 13, 2000
description: Weeks

title: The Nation; From 4F to Eternity
description: SOME in Times Square aren't thrilled by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to erect a statue of Frank Sinatra on the traffic island at 44th Street and Broadway. Critics say the Crossroads of the World is too congested for the bronze likeness of a singer with little connection to Broadway.

title: Another Surprise From Motley Crue
description: They are not called the Motley Crue for nothing. The poster boys for substance abuse play their music hard, and like their women easy. And they take no prisoners.

title: Oil Prices Falling? Don't Count On It
description: AFTER a sharp run-up, which helped put gasoline back onto front pages in the spring after a long absence, oil prices have subsided and politicians rail no longer about supposed industry gouging.

title: U.N. Criticizes Lack of Help By Lebanon
description: Lebanon's very limited deployment of soldiers and police into the south, far from stabilizing the situation along its border with Israel, is raising new uncertainties 10 weeks after Israel ended its 22-year occupation of the region.

title: Time's Hands Go Back On National Debt Clock
description: For 11 years, the National Debt Clock glowered from its perch on the Avenue of the Americas and grimly flashed to passers-by the government's growing financial woes, racking up an average of $10,000 a second in national debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHONEY, DAVID J., III.
description: MAHONEY-David J., III. 40, of Royal Palm Beach, Florida, passed away suddenly on August 10, 2000, at his home. David, originally of New York City and Bridgehampton, NY, was an area resident since 1992. He was the owner and CEO of Flips, Inc., a local internet service providing company. He leaves his wife, Patricia M. Mahoney, Wellington, FL; three children, David J. (D.J.) Mahoney, Casey Mahoney and Dillon Mahoney, all of Wellington, FL; sister, Barbara Ann Mahoney, Water Mill, NY; aunt and uncle, Helene and Robert Mahoney, Bridgehampton, NY; stepmother, Hildegarde Mahoney, Palm Beach, FL, and Lausanne, Switzerland; two stepbrothers, Arthur (Monique) Merrill, Muttontown, NY, Robert (Christina) Merrill, Locust Valley, NY; five nephews and three nieces. Funeral services will be held in Florida. For further information contact Tillman Funeral Home, West Palm Beach.

title: Waiting in the Wings, The Understudy Role
description: PATTY GOBLE of Danbury understands as well as anyone the mixed blessing of understudying a leading role on Broadway. Ms. Goble has been understudying the actress Marin Mazzie since 1996, first as Mother in ''Ragtime'' and then as Lilli Vanessi in ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' currently playing at the Martin Beck Theater on West 45th Street.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; In Upscale Fairfield, New Houses Mean New Schools
description: BY 2010, an estimated $825 million will have been poured into school construction in Fairfield County's upscale towns of Darien, Fairfield, Greenwich, New Canaan, Ridgefield, Stamford, Weston, Westport and Wilton. Since the early 90's a boom in school building has trailed a housing boom that has brought 15,000 new residents to the county, most of them settling in the affluent towns.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: If childless adults want to eliminate ''subsidies'' like the standard tax deduction for dependents, so be it. It wouldn't be the first time that parents have been cast as a special-interest group. Witness the gutting of local school budgets by taxpayers without children. These days, things like band uniforms and school sports programs that were once financed as a matter of course are now paid for with car washes and bake sales.

title: Police and Protesters Ready; Politicians Hope for the Best
description: The police say they are ready. They've chopped down trees that could be set on fire, uprooted newspaper racks that could be used as battering rams and fenced off a good-size patch of downtown Los Angeles with tall silver swaths of chain-link in an effort to keep any protests at the Democratic National Convention from getting out of hand.

title: Hilary Henkind, Jeffrey Plattus
description: Hilary Michele Henkind, the daughter of Barbara Henkind of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Lewis Henkind of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married this morning to Jeffrey Scott Plattus, a son of Marian Plattus of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Robert Plattus. Rabbi Wendy Pein will officiate at the TriBeCa Rooftop in Manhattan.

title: In the Spirit of Shakespeare
description: WITH its late summer opening by the Kings County Shakespeare Company, ''A Midsommer Nights Dreame'' is intended to rouse spirits and the spirited. The company, now in its 17th year, is using the text of the First Folio, hence the spelling. This production is directed by Liz Shipman, who characterizes it as ''a proper fairy tale'' in which the spirit world shadows the urges, desires and dreams of the human world.

title: A Shaper of Taste
description: To the Editor:

title: Christina Donato, John Saler
description: Christina Connie Donato, a daughter of Eugenia and Louis Donato of Medford, N.J., was married yesterday to John Rudofker Saler, a son of Odelle Winthrop of Hallandale, Fla., and the late Morton Saler. Alan K. Silberstein, the president judge emeritus of the Philadelphia Municipal Court, officiated at the Union League club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Claire M. Green and the Rev. Joseph McOscar, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Rejuvenating The Humble Prune
description: A SIMPLE facelift wouldn't have been enough for prunes. This ubiquitous dried fruit, long a favorite of the over-65 generation, needed a name change to create a more youthful image and to appeal to shoppers, especially women, in the 35-to-50 age range.

title: Natasha Harvey, Christopher Swann
description: Natasha Harvey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus I. Harvey Jr. of Woodstock, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher Danforth Swann, the son of Mary C. Walker and Judge William K. Swann III, both of Knoxville, Tenn. The Rev. James Harrison performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Woodstock.

title: Mighty Cool, Them Spurs
description: Rhinestone cowboys and fringed cowgirls kick up their boot heels in "Hillbilly Hollywood: The Origins of Country & Western Style" (Rizzoli, $39.95), a close look at what the author, Debby Bull, calls "famous people you've never heard of." She refers not only to the wranglers who ventured to Los Angeles from the range in the 1930's through the 50's but also to Nathan Turk, Nudie Cohen and Manuel Cuevas. The three were expert tailors who specialized in the expertly cut, extravagantly beaded and em broidered stage clothes worn by the likes of Roy Rogers, Gene Autry, Patsy Cline and El vis Presley.

title: Put Through the Mill, Yet Gilbert and Sullivan Still
description: The adaptability, elasticity even, of Gilbert and Sullivan is in evidence in Manhattan these days as two groups present nontraditional versions of "H.M.S. Pinafore" and "The Pirates of Penzance."

title: Terra Cotta Building Finally Finds Itself on Terra Firma
description: Preservationists sighed with relief a week ago when the president of Silvercup Studios, which produces the television shows ''Sex in the City'' and ''The Sopranos,'' announced his purchase of a little building made of terra cotta and his intention to restore it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINSKOFF, HENRY H.
description: MINSKOFF-Henry H. In loving memory of a beloved husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. Deeply missed, forever in our hearts. Marjorie, Jim, Jean, Alan, Richard, Michael, Donna, Noah, Tasha, Henry, Laura and Natasha

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.

title: Asbury Music Awards Return to Stone Pony
description: LOCAL bands that make a living on the Jersey Shore do not live the glamorous lives of Bruce Springsteen and Bon Jovi. But thanks to Scott Stamper, co-owner of the rock nightclub, The Saint, there will be at least one night where they feel like superstars. At the Eighth Annual Asbury Music Awards.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Twin Girls Treasure Escape From a Summer Indoors
description: Jazzlyn Farrell's mother does not let her ride her bike beyond the block she lives on, a narrow two-way street in Queens. So she makes a loop, back and forth between 105th Street and 106th.

title: Kenya Johnson, Michael Johnson
description: Kenya Latrell Johnson, a daughter of Josephine and Walter Johnson of Brooklyn, and Michael George Johnson, the son of Nancy and George Johnson of St. Albans, Queens, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard J. Lawson performed the ceremony at the New Canaan Baptist Church in Brooklyn.

title: August 6-12; Bringing the War Home
description: Russia's summer lull was shattered by a terrorist bomb that exploded on Tuesday in a busy pedestrian tunnel beneath Pushkin Square, killing eight and wounding nearly 100. Within hours, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov claimed responsibility lay ''100 percent'' with Chechnya, the breakaway republic where rebel leaders had been vowing to strike Russian cities. Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, however, said it would be premature to blame the Chechens, and though police quickly rounded up suspects, none was immediately connected to the bombing. Patrick E. Tyler

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, LEON
description: GRAY-Leon. On August 6, 2000. A most generous man. He will be greatly missed by Edith and Anne Marie, by sons, Anthony and Michael, by grandchildren, Cameron and Stephanie and by the many others who knew and loved him.

title: Seeking a Niche That's Large but Hard to Find
description: MORE than a century's worth of tradition haunts the corridors of Swezey's, but the president, William L. Knapp, doesn't think for a moment that tradition brings customers through the door.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MIRIAM'S SONG

title: G. Warren Schloat Jr., 86, Children's Book Author and Animator
description: G. Warren Schloat Jr., a writer and illustrator of children's books who also worked on several of the classic films from the Walt Disney Studios, died on July 30 at a hospital in Escondido, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: None of the child-free people in your article reported that they use their time, energy and resources for any purpose other than self. It is their quiet time with a glass of wine that children threatened; children did not crimp their style, say, for working as Doctors Without Borders or in soup kitchens.

title: The Nation: Necessary Knowledge; Science Expands, Religion Contracts
description: IT'S not quite the Scopes trial, but a raucous Republican state school board primary election in Kansas this month sent a signal about the place of science in 21st century America, and about how quickly the relationship between science and religion is changing.

title: In a Setting Inspired by Cartography
description: THIS winsome farmhouse, atop a Bedford hill, has discarded the French lace curtain look it has worn for the last decade. Bright yellow, brick red and strong blue provide the background for the new occupant's eclectic assemblage of maps and other chartings of land and water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MARTIN D.
description: SOLOMON-Martin D. Of Deer Park, NY, formerly of Long Beach, on August 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Diane. Loving father of Daniel, James and Bradley. Fond stepfather of Theresa and Matthew Martin. Cherished brother of Dorine Shanbron and brother-in-law, Barry Shanbron. Service was held on Wednesday, August 9, in Woodbury.

title: A Compassionate Man
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Los Angeles, Back on the Money Map
description: FOR one bright but ultimately fleeting moment in the 1980's, the financial industry here was as hot as Malibu in August.

title: A Context for Spending
description: Consumers follow the three S's -- spend, save and share -- in that order, emphasizing the first, says Nathan Dungan, vice president of stewardship and brand development at Lutheran Brotherhood, a financial services group in Minneapolis. Americans ''are caught in a web of hypnotic consumption,'' he said. ''We're at an all-time low in savings and there's little energy invested in sharing.''

title: F.Y.I.
description: Album's Winding Road

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ASLEEP

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: A VIRTUAL unknown compared with ''Rebecca,'' MY COUSIN RACHEL (1952) isn't even on video. This elegant Daphne du Maurier costume drama is heavy on atmosphere, with a melodramatic score and romantically bleak black-and-white Cornwall scenery. But it was and is most notable for the performance of a 26-year-old British actor making his American film debut. Richard Burton won a best newcomer Golden Globe Award and an Oscar nomination for his role as a rich young man whose cousin (the man who reared him) dies mysteriously during an extended stay in Italy. Olivia de Havilland is convincingly charming and evil, alternately, as the cousin's new bridge and now widow, whom Burton's character suspects of having killed him. But then, oops, he falls in love with her. Henry Koster directed - Saturday at 9 p.m. on Channel 13.

title: This Is Serious Art
description: Once derided as kitsch, mass- produced paintings of exotic beauties and cutesy pets are now considered highly collect ible. And in "Just Above the Mantelpiece: Mass Market Masterpieces," Wayne Hem ingway, a fashion designer, reassesses tal ents like Vladimir Tretchikoff, J. H. Lynch and Margaret Keane, whose big-eyed waifs define the genre. Due in October from Booth- Clibborn Editions ($49.95), the book features 300 works from the author's own collection. As co-founder of the British label Red or Dead, Mr. Hemingway was an arbiter of cool in the early 90's. His imprimatur is sure to lend new cachet to supermarket art  and in creased value to his own tacky cache.

title: For Women Great and Small, Briefs Can't Get Much Briefer
description: ON a recent Friday lunch hour in Kmart's underwear department in Flushing Meadows, Queens, it was obvious where the action was. The aisles of billowy white panties were deserted. The racks of hip-hugger briefs stood virtually untouched. But a half-dozen women -- from chubby teenagers in capri pants to middle-aged moms pushing full carts of housewares -- were bravely shopping where few women had, until recently, shopped before: the thong section.

title: Even at Age 9, John's Call Wins a Wet Sword Dancer
description: They bought him eight years ago for $4,000 in the hopes that he would be an athletic steeplechase horse. They thought his name was Stuart's Affair. By the time he became a 2-year-old, however, Thomas Voss discovered two things. First, the colt could not jump. Second, he had the wrong horse.

title: Peanuts, Popcorn, Bobble-Head Dolls?
description: Hand-painted figurines with bouncing heads are working wonders for Major League Baseball this year. Just ask the Minnesota Twins, who have been in last place in their division and have the second-worst attendance in the majors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERLAIN, DOROTHY E.
description: CHAMBERLAIN-Dorothy E. July 10, 1906-August 7, 2000. Life-long Columbia University law librarian. Agnes Scott AB '27, Columbia MLS '28. Past secretary Women's Faculty Club, ALA, AALL. Theatre, art, opera, symphony and travel devotee. Survived by her sister Margaret C. Gere, nieces and nephews. Memorial service in September. For further information, 718-275-4144.

title: NEW COUNTY PUBLICATIONS
description: The county has published two booklets to help residents understand more about environmental issues. ''Frequently Asked Questions'' includes six fact sheets, each dealing with a different water pollution topic. The other publication, ''From Town to Tap,'' is a newsletter that features stories about successful restoration efforts. Both publications can be viewed on the county's Web site: ''Frequently Asked Questions'' is at westchestergov.com/planning/environmental/default.htm, and ''From Town to Tap'' is at westchestergov.com/planning/watershed/default.htm. They can also be requested from the County Planning Department by calling (914) 285-4422. Elsa Brenner

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00: ShopTalk; Put Me In, Dad
description: Until last month's United States Olympic track-and-field trials, Joe Clark was perhaps better known as the principal at Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J., portrayed by Morgan Freeman in ''Lean on Me.'' But now he's also the father of two current Olympians, Hazel Clark, 22, and Joetta Clark Diggs, 37, and the father-in-law of a third, Jearl Miles-Clark, 33, who took the top three spots in the women's 800 meters at the trials. Yoel Judah is the father of seven boxing sons, including the I.B.F. world champion junior welterweight Zab Judah, 22, who recently made his second title defense. Here, Clark and Judah discuss what goes into being a good ''Little League'' parent.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HOME AND EXILE

title: Pitfalls Along Road For Budding Models
description: WHEN Bridget McDermott, at 16, was approached by a talent scout at the Roosevelt Field Mall last September and asked if she would like to be a model, her immediate impulse was to say yes.

title: Corrections
description: A film listing on Page 34 of Arts & Leisure today includes an outdated reference to the Manhattan theater for ''Ran.'' Its opening on Friday has been moved to the U.A. Union Square 14, at 13th Street and Broadway.

title: The Blurred View From Weehawken
description: The waterfront of this small town with the big view has been a scene of bitter contention since Aaron Burr mortally wounded Alexander Hamilton in their famous duel of 1804.

title: Loosening Up at Lord & Taylor
description: ALTHOUGH dressed in a flowing, almost-formal black pants outfit by Yeohlee, Jane T. Elfers, the 39-year-old merchant promoted recently to be president of Lord & Taylor, says she is instituting a new more relaxed dress code for executives -- and that she is leading by example. ''See?'' she said, jovially pointing to her feet, which were stuffed into a pair of pointed black pumps. ''No hose.''

title: Corrections
description: The news quiz in the special Education Life section last Sunday misstated the subject of the movie ''Semi-Tough.'' It is professional football, not college football.

title: Making Good Neighbors, Part II
description: LAST week, this column focused on the preliminaries for building a fence. When you have the necessary materials, you can begin construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, OWEN
description: ROSENBERG-Owen. Beloved son of Jerome & the late Irene Tinkoff. Stepson of Andrea. Loving brother of Anne and Barry. ''Rudy's best friend''. You will be missed by hundreds. ''We all love you''. Services were held Monday at BoulevardRiverside Chapel, Brooklyn. Shiva was held at Anne Rosenberg, 311 East 85th Street, New York City.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Belkin alluded to the relegation of childless voters to the margins of the political process. On every issue from tax reform to gun control, political ads are filled with touchy-feely slogans and pictures that pander to parents. This sends a strong message to childless voters: we don't want you. Is it any wonder that younger Americans, many of whom haven't yet started families, are increasingly staying away from the polls?

title: August 6-12; The Truth Is Out There
description: Astronomers this week added nine to their tally of planets known to orbit other stars, bringing the total to more than 45. Among the newly discovered planets is one orbiting the star Epsilon Eridani, located only 10.5 light-years from Earth.

title: Some 23rd Street Riders Giving Buses That Bend a Stiff Reception
description: Early next month, New York City Transit officials plan to deploy a fleet of articulated buses on the 23rd Street crosstown line, and riders are rattling in their seats.

title: Responding to Responses On 'What Would You Do?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ARCANA

title: Wendy Mindel, Nicolas Rubinstein
description: Wendy Lynn Mindel, a daughter of Susan Mindel and Dr. Joel Mindel of New York, was married last evening to Nicolas Eric August Rubinstein, the son of Susan and Frederic Rubinstein of Jupiter, Fla., and New York. Rabbi Matthew Gewirtz officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: OUTDOORS; A Glorious Show of Striped Bass Without a Catch
description: Mort said, positively, absolutely, ''There is no bait in the surf at Amagansett, and no fish.'' So with the bones in my right hip feeling like someone had rasped away all of the cartilage, I wasn't much up for fishing. I had slipped in May, gone under in a river, smacked my head on a stone. Now it was August and I would get a titanium hip in three weeks.

title: Habitats/Park Avenue Near 39th Street; Furnishing a New Home With Colors of Her Life
description: SHE might not like the description, but some people consider Bride Whelan something of a seer whose medium is color. Tell her whether red, blue or green speaks most forcefully to you, and she'll describe your personality, your style, your values. She will insist, however, that there's nothing psychic about her abilities, that ample evidence from science, history and psychology explains the link between personality and color.

title: Mao Knew This Would Happen
description: Between the red plastic coversof "China Chic," Vivienne Tam creates what she calls a visual memoir, which she uses to examine the cultural influence of China on world style. Ms. Tam, a fashion designer who was born in Canton, China, and now lives in New York, goes way beyond embroidered silk. The richly illustrated volume, due in No vember (Regan Books/Harper Collins; $50), brings together tradition and pop culture  wedding ceremonies and "The World of Suzie Wong," Ming furniture and Mao jackets  as it explores East-meets-West style. Each chapter introduces a different Chinese character, followed by a personal anecdote. Child's Heart, the symbol of child and woman, provides an occasion for the tale of how Ms. Tam was smuggled into Hong Kong when she was 3. Chinglish is the hybrid language she spoke as a teenager.

title: Has a Familiar Market Ghost Returned?
description: The markets received a familiar configuration of economic data last week: a tame report on wholesale inflation that was coupled with a retail sales report showing that American consumers had returned to the profligate spending seen earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALTON, PHILIP B.
description: DALTON-Philip B., 77 of Sarasota, Florida. Retired President of GAF. Husband of the late Elaine K. Dalton, died August 1, 2000. He was born July 21, 1923 in New York City. During World War II he served overseas in the U. S. Navy in 1944, he graduated University of Illinois and in 1947 received an M.A. in organic chemistry from Columbia University. In 1949 he was employed as a research chemist at Colgate Palmolive. He is the author of many patents, one of which later became known as AJAX. In 1954 he went to GAF Corporation. When he retired in 1979 he was their President and Chief Operating Officer. He was a member of the American Chemical Society, Society of Chemical Industry, Hemisphere Club, Economics Club of New York, American Association for the Advancement of Science and an associate member of Hadassah. Survivors include his two daughters, Linda Dalton of Sharon, MA. and Barbra Dalton Reckhow of New York City; sonin-law Wayne Reckhow of New York City; and five grandchildren Lori MacGregor of New York City, Alyssa Dalton Reckhow, Grant Dalton Reckhow, Taylor Dalton Reckhow and Jensen Dalton Reckhow of New York City. No services are planned at this time. National Cremation Society, Sarasota Chapter is in charge. Memorial donations may be made to Sabra Chapter of Hadassah, 3750 S. Osprey Ave., Sarasota, FL. 34239

title: Reckonings; End Of The ZIRP
description: We interrupt America's political silly season to bring you a special bulletin: something important and disturbing just happened in Japan.

title: A Call to Curb The Cost of Electricity
description: To the Editor:

title: If Real Conventions Lack Spunk, Try a Fake One
description: A HANDSOME Democrat is arriving in Los Angeles to accept his party's nomination for president. The craven reporters, the hyperambitious advisers, the mercenary fat cats are on hand, too, eager to claim their political pound of flesh.

title: Angels in America
description: AIDS DOCTORS

title: Joyce's Fishy Fable
description: To the Editor:

title: Altamont: End, and Beginning
description: WHAT gets called the 60's had any number of endings, most of them elusive or much debated. But for those who understood the decade (or era, or moment) as more a cultural than a political phenomenon -- a last, late Romantic pastoral -- the end came quite precisely and inarguably: Friday night, Dec. 6, 1969, at the Altamont Speedway not far from San Francisco, as the Rolling Stones, distracted and distraught, worked their way through ''Under My Thumb.''

title: Own a Hermit Crab? It Probably Came From Here
description: That ceaseless scratching, clapping and clicking coming from a warehouse here, just inland from Long Beach Island, is the sound of the Jersey Shore's unofficial pet -- the hermit crab. More precisely, it is the sound of about 100,000 of the critters.

title: Saying Goodbye
description: THOUGH it was two decades ago, I can vividly recall the shock. It was my first morning home on the Upper West Side after a summer visit to London. As I had day after day for many years, I went to buy a morning paper at my favorite newsstand at 79th Street and Broadway. But I was soon shaken out of my slumber: the newsstand had vanished.

title: Yes, the Euro Will Rebound. Someday.
description: WILL the euro ever rally?

title: Noisy Restaurants, Noisier Schools
description: Patricia Brooks has touched upon a much bigger issue than our personal comfort in her article on noisy restaurants (''To Din or Not to Din: Restaurateur's Call,'' July 16). After all, most of us can exercise our free choice and simply stay away from an establishment that assails our ears with loud music or provides reverberant conditions that make conversation unintelligible.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Filling the Area's Need for Large Conference Centers
description: THE 148,000-square-foot New Huntington Townhouse here on Jericho Turnpike just east of Route 110 provides banquet space that no other Long Island caterer can match in size.

title: Southampton Village Talks About City Status
description: In the belief that it is paying Southampton Town $8 million in taxes for unnecessary services, Southampton Village is investigating the possibility of seceding and becoming a city itself.

title: Violence by a Muslim Sect Stuns Malaysia
description: It was the trial of the century in Malaysia. But on the morning after this country's former deputy prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim, was found guilty of sodomy last Tuesday, the newspapers here gave more ink to another hearing, held in a court up country.

title: Sonya Posmentier, Jess Row
description: Sonya Bhatia Posmentier, the daughter of Loveleen and Eric Posmentier of Manhattan, is to be married today to Jess Francis Row, a son of Constance and Clark Row of Edgewood, Md. Bruce Blair, the abbott of the New Haven Zen Center, is to perform a ceremony that will incorporate Hindu and Jewish traditions at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The First Bourgeois Paradise
description: When the Impressionists immortalized Argenteuil in the late 19th century, they became the first avant-garde artists to celebrate the suburbs. Claude Monet lived and painted in the town from 1871 to 1878, and painters like Alfred Sisley, Auguste Renoir, Edouard Manet and Gustave Caillebotte joined him in Argenteuil, eight miles north of Paris, to depict boats on the Seine, lush gardens and factory smokestacks. In THE IMPRESSIONISTS AT ARGENTEUIL (Yale University, $50), Paul Hayes Tucker writes that the combination of rural and urban elements perfectly suited the Impressionist aim of portraying modern life with its attendant contradictions. At the same time, Tucker, who teaches art history at the University of Massachusetts, Boston, also implies it was the presence of Monet that lured other artists out of the city for a bit of friendly competition, though Monet clearly had the last word on Argenteuil. The paintings depict few tensions between city and country, however. Monet and his colleagues transformed industrial structures like the town's railroad bridge into neo-Classical monuments to French civilization and hid urban sprawl behind flower bushes. Tucker tries to locate mysterious symbols and murky relationships stirring just beneath the surface of these bright and airy canvases, but in the process he misses a greater irony: in ostensibly bucking academic demand for timelessness in art, the Impressionists instead created an enduring vision of bourgeois paradise. Anna Rohleder

title: Lure of Country Roads Instead of Shopping
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONDILLER, ELIZABETH
description: FONDILLER-Elizabeth. 6/29/26-8/ 11/00. Her words, her deeds and her choice of profession reflected her lifelong dedication to helping others achieve their goals and pursue their dreams. She began her career as an artist and art teacher. Her thirst for knowledge led her on to degrees in occupational therapy and social work. She was a woman of great strength, creativity, compassion, and intellectual depth and diversity. She leaves behind a loving daughter, Jill, many friends and relatives, and her infinite collection of chatchkes. She will be greatly missed by everyone whose life she touched. Betty, we love you. Funeral services will be held at Plaza Funeral Home, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday, August 13th at 2:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITEHOUSE, EUGENE
description: WHITEHOUSE-Eugene. August 12, 1900 to November 23, 1948. ''Outside the leaves were falling And they cried 'too soon, too soon.''

title: Loretta Young, Glamorous Leading Lady of Film and Television, Dies at 87
description: Loretta Young, the Academy Award-winning actress whose high cheekbones, pale skin and luminous eyes made her a reigning Hollywood beauty of the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday in Los Angeles. She was 87 and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: The Senate's Philosopher-King
description: THE GENTLEMAN

title: Saved by Rita Hayworth
description: Manuel Puig and

title: Putnam's Growth Poses a Threat To the Charms Of a Rural Road
description: THERE was a time when the advertising slogan of the Putnam County Visitors' Bureau, ''Where the Country Begins,'' seemed the perfect description of Route 22, the main road here.

title: The Cigna Campus At Bloomfield
description: I am very concerned about the efforts that are underway to save the two buildings at Cigna's Bloomfield campus due to their architectural style and significance (''A Fight Over, of All Things, an Insurance Office,'' July 16). In fact, it has been suggested that both Bloomfield and the world would be a lesser place if these buildings were removed. While the significance of these buildings can be debated, the real issue is the future of Bloomfield.

title: The Nasdaq-ing Of Capitol Hill
description: Most of the Democrats gathering this week in Los Angeles for their national convention don't know yet who John Witchel is. But he and his friends are planning to crash the Democrats' party with a straightforward message: they want in. ''We already drive every significant sector of the economy,'' Witchel says. ''The keys to the kingdom are squarely in our hands. I'm here to say there's a next generation of Internet executives, and we're ready to become national political players.''

title: The Fossil and the Gavel
description: Forty years ago Alfred Siefker and two teenage buddies, like him interested in paleontology, were digging around a rock quarry off Toennelle Avenue in North Bergen. They uncovered a piece of shale with an imprint of what looked like a giant firefly. It turned out to be a 200-million-year-old fossil of a flying vertebrate that raised a scientific furor because it showed that animals flew far earlier than had been thought. It was named Icoarosaurus Siefkeri, for Mr. Siefker, and put in the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. But now Mr. Siefker, 56, is ailing and needs money for medical bills. So the fossil will be offered for sale by Butterfields Auctioneers in a simulcast auction in San Francisco and Los Angeles on Aug. 27. The minimum bid is $250,000. Mr. Siefker hopes the fossil, known as the Icarosaurus Siefkeri, will end up in a museum, said David Herskowitz, director of the natural history department at Butterfields. KAREN DEMASTERS

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Windsor Terrace; A Quiet, Accessible Corner of Brooklyn
description: AS it runs under Brooklyn, the F train buzzes with sounds of the city: the rhythmic ker-chunk of music from headphones and the voices of riders speaking to one another in any number of languages. But by the time the conductor says ''15th Street, Prospect Park,'' the train has arrived at one of northern Brooklyn's leafier neighborhoods, Windsor Terrace.

title: Office Space: It's All Relative
description: In San Francisco, office vacancy rates are near zero, and rents have tripled in two years. But not that far away, Bakersfield, Calif., is struggling with a 17 percent vacancy rate, up from 9.4 percent last year, as oil companies have dumped space on the market.

title: Poorest Schools Lack Teachers And Computers
description: Almost half the money from federal education programs is going to the poorest schools in the country, but those schools continue to lack qualified teachers and technological resources, including computers with Internet access, says a new report from the Department of Education.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Jason Gill made me laugh. He brought back fond memories of the days when two girlfriends and I tormented the kid-hating neighbor whose backyard abutted the yard of my friend's home.

title: Backyard Fun With a Titleist on the Rug
description: THE house, a 10,000-square-foot postmodern abode, isn't finished. The sweeping front lawn has yet to be sodded. No matter. Fred and Ruth Schwalbe brought their golf clubs to their new Quiogue weekend and summer home months ago. Their 1,500-square-foot personal putting green, after all, has been in place since last fall, just a 9-iron from the tee at the corner of the garage, 100 yards away. Pristine white sand fills its traps, lush bluegrass covers the berms and mounds surrounding the artificial bent-grass putting turf. Who needs a kitchen? With four cup locations to sink a golf ball into, the Schwalbes are busy this summer working on their putts.

title: Nassau Unfazed by Mosquitoes, So Far
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY has been spraying pesticides to battle mosquitoes that might be carrying the West Nile virus for about a month now. So has New York City. But Nassau County, despite being wedged between the two, has so far held off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ESTHER (NEE GOTTESMAN)
description: KATZ-Esther (nee Gottesman). Wife of the late and beloved Harry Katz, died peacefully in Boca Raton, Florida, August 10, 2000. A woman of remarkable strength and intelligence. She was the true embodiment of family values. Her love and caring presence will be missed greatly by all who knew her. Mother of Aron and Phyllis Katz, Albert and Virginia Katz, and the late Richard Katz; sister of Abe Gottesman; grandmother of Martin and Marcellina Katz, Margaret and Stephen Cann, Rebecca Katz and Rachael and Nick Carey; great-grandmother of Alejandro and Francisco Katz, and Harrison and Simon Cann. May God grant you peace. Services will be held at 9:45 AM on Tuesday, August 15, 2000, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76, Manhattan, NY.

title: Busy Newark Losing Monorail
description: AS air travel set a record earlier this summer -- with major domestic airlines flying fuller planes than at any time since World War II -- Newark Airport, the New York area's busiest, was putting its monorail on sick leave. The system was partly shut for repairs on July 8 and will be completely closed after Labor Day, possibly till the end of the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 30 about the film ''The Tic Code'' misidentified the theater where Marsha Norman's play ''Trudy Blue'' was produced in 1999 and where Ms. Norman, the article's author, met Polly Draper, the writer and producer of ''The Tic Code.'' It was the MCC Theater, not the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: The View From/New Haven; A Filmmaker Unearths Stories of the Struggle for Civil Rights
description: KARYL K. EVANS, an independent filmmaker, specializes in bringing little-known histories to life. In 1995, she produced and directed a documentary on the Amistad revolt, two years before the Hollywood version was released and well before ''Amistad'' was a household word. Her latest effort is called ''African Americans in Connecticut: Civil War to Civil Rights,'' a documentary whose premiere was last month on Connecticut Public Television and which will be televised again in August.

title: Holyfield Defeats Ruiz for Fourth Heavyweight Crown
description: With a unanimous decision tonight over John Ruiz, Evander Holyfield has done something that nobody, not even Muhammad Ali, has ever accomplished. He has won the heavyweight championship for the fourth time.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Alexis Johnson, Chelsea Wicht, Tracy Bowman, Rita Anderson, Milaca, Minn., June 22, 2000

title: Oldies Return to Concert Series
description: AT Playland in Rye, tradition long dictated summer concerts filled with harmonious greasers and their snappy backup singers, those bands affectionately known as ''oldies.''

title: Hold the Granola, Please
description: IT'S not as if we had a secret hankering for cholesterol. But, often as not, like Mount Everest -- and in more ways than one -- it was simply there. I'm talking, of course, about the Full English Breakfast.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Catherine Deneuve; One Kind of Beauty, Coolly Measuring Another
description: THE red diamond is worth half a million. It's just half a carat and looks like a piece of faceted beach glass. ''It's minuscule,'' Catherine Deneuve says. ''I blow, and it's gone.''

title: Artistry in the Shadows
description: Can art consist of two related photographs that together suggest, but do not tell, a story, or a compilation of photocopies that are developed partially by chance?

title: Computer Associates Promotes Kumar to C.E.O.
description: Computer Associates International (NYSE: CA) promoted its president, Sanjay Kumar, to the post of chief executive, succeeding Charles Wang, who remains chairman. The promotion of Mr. Kumar, 38, who is also the chief operating officer, will allow Mr. Wang to concentrate on spinning off the company's technology into new companies.

title: Angel Chen, Peter Usamanont
description: Angel Chen, the daughter of Johnny Chen of Manhattan and the late Lydia Zee Chen, was married on Friday to Peter Kitti Usamanont, the son of Vanvisa and Sam Usamanont of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Pamela Taylor Fogel, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: A Couple's 'Crazy' Adventures
description: In 1969, when Lin and Larry Pardey set out from Southern California aboard the 24-foot Seraffyn, their engineless self-built wooden cutter, they traveled on the winds of modest expectations. ''We'd never had a reasonable holiday in our working lives and we just wanted to do something that was all about sailing,'' Larry said. ''The thought of cruising around Mexico for a few months with time off was just cool.''

title: Where the Skies Are Smoky All Day
description: As air tankers loaded with fire retardant droned overhead, a group of us gathered at the Teller Wildlife Refuge in Montana's Bitterroot Valley to discuss the role of fire in the natural ecosystem. A rash of fires in the valley has turned the Big Sky into the Red Sky, a bloodshot whirl of smoke and fancy colors. The main highway, U.S. 93, has become a runway for fire vehicles -- dilapidated school buses transporting 20-person crews, brush buggies rigged with small fire hoses, heavy fire engines with thousands of gallons of water, water tankers, and on and on.

title: . . . And Macagnone's Reply
description: It appears that my letter has been misinterpreted as suggesting that I am against preserving the environment. This is hardly the case. What I am against is government's habit of making itself larger at the expense of the taxpayer.

title: Gini Kopecky, Marc Wallace
description: Gini Kopecky, a magazine editor, and Marc Wallace, a freelance writer and producer of television documentaries, were married last evening in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink officiated at the Manor House restaurant.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: The child free should be careful about getting what they ask for. Elinor Burkett writes, ''Every time someone takes off for that sick child or that school conference, then someone else has to pick up the extra work.'' It is a small step to go from objecting to a parent leaving early to pick up a sick child to objecting to an observant Jew asking not to be scheduled to work on Saturday or to a blind person arriving at work early and leaving early to miss the rush-hour crowds on public transit. All accommodations to personal needs are a potential inconvenience to other workers.

title: Gore, Invoking Spirit of 'Silent Spring' Author, Talks of Defending Environment
description: If there is an issue in which Vice President Al Gore feels he has a decided edge over Gov. George W. Bush, it is the environment.

title: Corporate Donors Now Big Backers Of the Democrats
description: The Democratic convention starting on Monday in Los Angeles will be a display of wealth, power and influence as gaudy as the Republican show in Philadelphia.

title: Elizabeth Lavine, Peter Russell
description: Elizabeth Scott Lavine and Peter Stephen Russell are to be married this evening by the Rev. Dr. Pamela D. Blair, an interfaith minister, at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: THIS IS THE SUNFLOWER. By Lola M. Schaefer. Illustrated by Donald Crews. Greenwillow. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A cumulative rhyme describes the life cycle of a sunflower: from full bloom to the ripe seeds harvested and scattered by birds, and so on to next summer's sunflower patch. The watercolor illustrations are bold, and the 17 birds shown nibbling on one double-page spread are identified at the end.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIS DAVID
description: COHEN-Harris David. January 25, 1967 to August 13, 1985. Fifteen sad years since the accident. We will never forget you. Our memories are beautiful, our hearts are broken. Much love, Mom, Dad, Jonathan and Lisa

description: To the Editor:
