title: Medora Plimpton, Spencer Harris
description: Medora Ames Plimpton, the daughter of Freddy Medora Espy Plimpton of Bridgehampton, N.Y., and George Plimpton of New York, was married yesterday, to Spencer Knight Harris, a son of Donna and Robert Harris of Alstead, N.H. The Rev. Cece Wick, an interfaith minister, officiated at the couple's farm in Starksboro, Vt.

title: August 6-12; ABC's Inventive News Report
description: ABC News admitted that a report it showed twice on ''20/20'' challenging the benefits of organic food was based, in part, on nonexistent evidence. The producer of the segment, David W. Fitzpatrick, was suspended from his duties for one month, without pay. John Stossel, the correspondent on the report, was reprimanded. He was told to apologize. Jim Rutenberg

title: Style & Entertaining; Salad Days
description: 'Paulette used to go to Bergdorf's, but now she goes to meetings of the cauliflower association,'' says Eberhard Mller, the executive chef and part owner of Lut ce, the formidable Manhattan restaurant, as he holds forth in the kitchen of the nouvelle farmhouse he and his wife, Paulette Satur, built two years ago on 20 green acres on the North Fork of Long Island.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00: On Language; Franken--
description: The hottest combining form in populist suspicion of science was coined in a letter to The New York Times on June 2, 1992, from Paul Lewis, professor of English at Boston College.

title: Claude Hope, Who Nurtured the Impatiens, Is Dead at 93
description: There was a time when the shady patches of America's gardens were virtually a horticultural no-man's land: drab expanses where gardeners planted the laconically blooming hosta and hoped for the best, or just threw up their hands and put in ferns or coleus.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: JAMAICA

title: OLYMPICS: 82 Pounds of Steel; Girded by Past Struggles, Loroupe Runs for Kenyan Gold
description: Seven times Africans have won the Olympic marathon, but they have been a barefoot Ethiopian running through the torchlit night in Rome, and a South African miner racing into daylight after the darkness of apartheid. An Ethiopian woman has won, too, cheered on by expatriate taxi drivers in Atlanta, dropping to her knees at the finish line and kissing the track.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about several major brokerage firms that reacted to pressure from Internet listing services by planning New York City's first multiple listing service misstated the number of firms that signed up. It was four. Thirty was the number of firms that had expressed interest.

title: Jennifer Minton, Daniel Quigley
description: Jennifer Whitehorn Minton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Minton of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Pfohl Quigley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard V. Quigley of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. Dr. Edwin M. Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., with Msgr. Edward Scharfenberger taking part.

title: Reviving Hospitals' Health
description: To the Editor:

title: August 6-12; Tomayto, Tomahto, Potayto...
description: Psychologists have long assumed that while people in Beijing might ponder different topics than those in Oklahoma City, their ways of gathering information and making sense of the world were indistinguishable.

title: How Big a Role on a Global Stage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Barrels of Flavor
description: The other day, La Caravelle, the three-star Manhattan restaurant, bought '99 Muga white Rioja to sell by the glass, a tipoff that the producer has fielded a winner.

title: August 6-12; Despite Protests, Another Texas Execution
description: Oliver Cruz, a mentally retarded 33- year-old with an I.Q. of 64, was one of two men executed on Wednesday in Huntsville, Tex. ''The execution of persons who are mentally retarded serves no principled purpose and demeans our system of justice,'' Martha W. Barrett, the president of the American Bar Association, wrote to Gov. George W. Bush. The European Union also had called on Mr. Bush to spare Mr. Cruz, saying the execution of the mentally retarded violated international human rights norms.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-13-00: Questions for David Boies; Download Interrupted
description: Q: You led the victors in Westmoreland v. CBS and Uncle Sam v. Microsoft, to name just a couple of the big victories. And you left the top-dog law firm, Cravath, to represent the Yankees -- only the winningest team in baseball. Then you go and lose the first round to the Recording Industry Association of America in its copyright infringement case against Napster. How were those 30 hours as a loser?

title: RYE: INCREASED SCHOOL SECURITY
description: The Rye School District has adopted new security measures to protect children and staff. Two-way communication will be installed in all classrooms. Only students, faculty and staff will be allowed to enter doors other than the main entrances in the morning. Parents or other visitors must enter the main entrance, sign in and get a visitor's pass. During recess and lunch, teacher aides will have access to the school by means of a key or a keypad, and teachers and support staff will need identification cards with a picture of themselves. Also, students in middle and high school will be issued locks for their lockers, with school officials having access to the lockers. Superintendent Edward Shine said the new measures were not being adopted in response to a particular incident, but reflected concern about violence in schools across the country. Elsa Brenner

title: Who Is Vainest of All? Venezuela
description: It has always been an open secret here, though one that is not supposed to be shared with outsiders. So when a recent consumer survey of 30 countries concluded that Venezuelans, men and women alike, are the most vain people in the world, the results were considered a bit embarrassing, but hardly surprising.

title: Plum I. May Test 'Mad' Sheep
description: NO animal ever leaves the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the Department of Agriculture laboratory sequestered off the tip of the North Fork. But until recently, pigs, cattle and other large creatures that the scientists use to study diseases arrived alive.

title: Angele Albrecht, 57, Dancer Praised for Work With Bejart
description: Angele Albrecht, a widely known ballerina who won acclaim with Maurice Bejart's Brussels-based ballet company, died on Aug. 1 in a hospital in Munich. She was 57 and had lived in Munich since 1986.

title: Down to Earth In the East 70's
description: BELLA BLU

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Streetscapes/129 Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights; 1906 Building, Once an Athletic Club, Now a School
description: WHAT was once one of Brooklyn's most important clubs is now St. Ann's School, founded in 1965 at 129 Pierrepont Street with unconventional goals and described in its brochure as ''an amusement park'' in which the amusements include Aristophanes, Darwin and Baudelaire. Now the school is in the middle of a $1 million facade renovation for the building, which was completed in Brooklyn Heights in 1906 for the Crescent Athletic Club.

title: Children's Books
description: SPACE RACE

title: Reykjavik
description: On his way to the nether world, the narrator of Jules Verne's ''Journey to the Center of the Earth'' makes quick work of Reykjavik, ''a town of two bleak, depressing Avenues'' where most people are busy drying and salting cod. Travelers from William Morris to W. H. Auden tended to agree, briefly condescending to Iceland's capital before heading for the hinterlands in search of sagas, volcanos or geysers.

title: Nadeau Peeks Out From Gordon's Shadow
description: He first jumped into a Go Kart when he was 4, and Jerry Nadeau was hooked. He loved driving cars so much that he often slept in one to scare up enough money to keep chasing his dream.

title: An Influx Of Tourists To Far North Of Canada
description: With tee-off times set for midnight, the summer solstice golf tournament was fast approaching when Rebecca Jaud faced an increasingly familiar problem for this Arctic city: no rooms at the inns.

title: Suffolk Chardonnays
description: A truly metropolitan appreciation of the panorama of American wines requires experience in Long Island's reds and whites.

title: Beautiful to Hear, and to See
description: PERHAPS more than for any other people, music has been an integral part of the lives of Africans. Whether it has been the chants of boatmen on the Niger, or the sound of the kora (a kind of lute) played by a griot as he recites the history and genealogy of a people, or the brassy horns and vibrant rhythm sections of a contemporary band in a Lagos nightspot, Africans -- and their descendants in the diaspora -- always seem surrounded by music. So it hardly comes as a surprise for a museum curator to decide that traditional African instruments should not only be listened to but looked at.

title: Grenada Recipe: One Guest House, Pinch of Nutmeg
description: IT was hot in my room at the Windward Sands Guest House in Grenada, so I walked over to the window to turn on the air-conditioner. In the dim light, I couldn't make sense of the words on the control panel.

title: N.J. TRANSIT FARES
description: New Jersey Transit says it will find ways to make up a $39 million loss in state funding other than raising fares for bus and train riders. Fares have not been raised in 10 years. The cuts, in transit operating money, came in the latest state budget last month. The agency will seek money from other state and federal sources, a spokesman said. Karen DeMasters

title: Soriya Kowalsky, Brad Cohen
description: Soriya Daniella Kowalsky, a daughter of Mimi and Seymour Kowalsky of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married today to Dr. Brad Kenneth Cohen, a son of Debra and Morton Cohen of Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Yakov Saacks will officiate at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: 'Race' Was Unspoken Word In Article on Playground
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about professional gardeners misspelled the surname of a landscape designer. He is Andy Durbridge, not Turbridge.

title: Form, Color and More From 25 Artists
description: THE main gallery at the Stamford Art Museum and Nature Center features contemporary art as often as not. But the center runs another gallery, down the driveway from the main building, where current art is always on. Art-X, as the space is called (the X is presumably for annex or exhibition), has been operating for 15 years, but was closed from 1990-1993 for budgetary reasons. An exhibition featuring a sampling of work from everyone who has exhibited at Art-X in the past five years commemorates the reborn space. But the show is not at the museum.

title: More Options for Miles Without Flying
description: Several new partnerships have been formed that allow travelers to earn frequent flier miles without boarding an airplane. America West has joined forces with MCI WorldCom, and Continental Airlines has changed its long-distance alliance from M.C.I. to AT&T. United Airlines has formed a partnership with Abercrombie & Kent, a tour operator specializing in adventure travel, and Best Western is Northwest Airlines' newest hotel partner.

title: From a Nursing Home, Dedication to the Arts Blooms Anew
description: HIS star cast member just died of cancer. Another cast member is still hospitalized. The director, whose last professional gig was as a photo double for Wilford Brimley in Cocoon II, is laid up in a nursing home bed, recuperating from an operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGER, JOSEPH A.
description: MAGER-Joseph A. Of Fair Lawn, NJ, died on August 10, 2000. A World War II Army Veteran. Original owner of Continental Cookies. Survived by his wife Naomi, his daughter Lesley Rona and his son Harold Wayne. Services are today 10:30 AM, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. #

title: Clocks and Carousels, Paintings, Too
description: FOR many nutmeggers, Bristol, New Britain and other center-of-the-state towns are terra incognita. ''You're going where?'' a friend responded when we said that we were planning a two-day outing to explore the sights there. ''You'll be back by dark,'' his wife predicted.

title: Drexel Alumni Move Onward
description: WHEN Drexel Burnham Lambert filed for bankruptcy in 1990, it was the end of an era in Los Angeles. No other Wall Street firm commanded the attention that Drexel's high-yield bond operation there did as it transformed not only the way that corporate America financed acquisitions but the character of the city as well.

title: Mother Fixation
description: LOOKING FOR MARY

title: Exclusive Key Club Quietly Renews Its Membership
description: AUGUST is the quiet month, the deceptively still month, the month when it seems as if nothing is happening in New York. But in truth a million behind-the-scenes plans are being laid for the season ahead. It is when competitive parents prepare lists of schools to tour after Labor Day, when ambitious actors mail out their resumes for fall auditions, when sophisticated travelers reserve plane tickets for the holidays. It is a month, in other words, to get a leg up.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: John Waters; Shockingly Good Taste
description: THE wooden Venetian blinds, well-chosen collection of photography, nice Oriental rugs. Shocking! Could this tasteful Greenwich Village apartment possibly belong to John Waters? This is, after all, the writer-director of ''Mondo Trasho,'' the godfather of sicko cinema, who created scratch-and-sniff cards for ''Polyester'' -- a movie he filmed in something called odorama.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Gap in Test Scores Becomes a Talking Point
description: ONCE it was the great taboo.

title: Tinka Markham, Andrew Piper
description: Katharine Rix Markham, the daughter of Stephanie Reed Hastings of Fryeburg, Me., and the late James M. Markham, was married yesterday in North Conway, N.H., to Andrew Kerr Piper, a son of Ann and Thomas L. Piper III of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Jack H. Haney officiated at Christ Church Episcopal, with the Rev. Richard Fabian, an Episcopal priest and the bride's godfather, taking part.

title: Jessica Buchanan, Philip Rawlins
description: Jessica Ray Buchanan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Buchanan Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Philip Christensen Rawlins, a son of Bonnie Rawlins of New Orleans and the late P. J. Thomas Rawlins Jr. The Rev. Charlene S. Alling, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me. The Rev. Dr. Gary A. Wilburn, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Few, The Bold
description: In the Hamptons, the sartorial style of a few men is changing party dressing for outdoor benefits. At last week's Southampton Hospital party, attended by 1,200 guests, 80 percent of the men wore the Hamptons uniform of navy blazers and white trousers, bottom row. A few men turned heads in their colorful chinoiserie and toile de Jouy cotton print trousers, but not since the Shep Miller men's shop on Job's Lane in Southampton introduced vibrant-color trousers and jackets as a Hamptons look in the 1940's have so many men dared to wear such colorful pants, these made by Steven Stolman's Southampton shop. And farther off the beaten path is the young man, far right, in a sarong.

title: Business; In a Humming Economy, A Rising Din of Defaults
description: WITH the economic expansion setting records for longevity, much of American business is reveling in prosperity. But all is hardly well. For reasons that include profligate lending and underwriting in the second half of the 1990's, many large businesses, and even entire industries, are suffocating from their debts.

title: Corrections
description: A review of two Rudolph Giuliani biographies in the Book Review on July 30 referred incompletely to the last time an elected mayor of New York City went on to higher office. After Mayor Fernando Wood's election to Congress in 1866, Mayor John Thompson Hoffman was elected governor of New York in 1868.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROSNEY, NEIL
description: KROSNEY-Neil. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Baiting Club mourn the untimely passing of our longtime member and dear friend, Neil Krosney. He served with distinction as our Past President and Chairman of our Board of Governors for many years. As someone who truly enjoyed EBC the empty lounge in front of his cabana will serve as a constant reminder of a friend lost before his time. Our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. He will be sorely missed. Robert Fagenson, President Jane Guadagno, Secretary

title: An Author Who Goes Along for the Ride

title: August 6-12; Surfer Girl
description: For the first time in the Internet's brief existence, more women than men are going online, according to a survey by Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications. During the first quarter of this year, 50.4 percent of Internet users were women, and there was a 125 percent increase in teenage girls online. The survey also found that women, unlike men, don't surf so much as find sites that help them save time or money, and return to them.

description: The first residents are moving into a new high-rise for seniors built in Yonkers by a division of the Hyatt hotel company in partnership with Forest City Daly developers. The 17-story building has 310 apartments, with mostly independent living units, a personal care section and an area for Alzheimer's sufferers.

title: Exploring Korean-Japanese Offerings
description: ALTHOUGH Korean restaurants are proliferating in Flushing and Manhattan, until a few months ago on Long Island they had been as rare as Elvis sightings in Seoul. The few that tried sputtered and quickly closed. Now there are two on Jericho Turnpike in Syosset and another just opened down the road in Commack.

The core members of the Yankees had never seen anything like it before, and laughter overwhelmed them.

title: Your Kids Are Their Problem
description: Here's a novel thought: if you can't afford a child, don't have one. The key word is choice. People choose to breed, just as they choose to buy Ferraris, for selfish reasons. The only difference is that people who buy Ferraris don't pick other people's pockets to pay for them.

title: ELECTRONIC BOOKING SYSTEM
description: The county is offering to include local police departments in an electronic booking system that captures, transmits and stores arrest information, including fingerprints, palm prints and face shots. Departments that choose to be connected will be able to use either ''live scan'' equipment, which records fingerprints and palm prints without ink, or ''card scan'' equipment, which digitizes fingerprint and palm print data, using a single set of inked impressions. A digital camera puts face shots directly into the system. The county's Department of Public Safety is covering the cost of the new network. Other departments are only responsible for buying booking and investigative work stations, which hook into the network, at a cost of $18,000 to $75,000. Departments may qualify for state and federal financing. Elsa Brenner

And those were just some of the businesses on Main Street.

title: In an Old Hotel, a Return to Elegant Style
description: THE name Hot Tomato's is almost the antithesis of the place in which this year-old New Haven restaurant is situated. The very name suggests casual and contemporary, yet the main dining room, reached by a dramatic winding staircase, is the epitome of elegance. It is the original (1912) formal dining room of the attached Taft Hotel (now residential only), and has been dazzlingly refurbished, with its ornate columns, bas-relief plasterwork and high coffered ceilings restored to their original beauty.

title: MUSIC; Amid the Drone, a Feud Over Who Composed It
description: THE sense of faith and elation felt by Dorothy, the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion and the Scarecrow when they finally locate the Wizard of Oz -- the force, they're told, who can solve their problems -- is quickly quashed when pesky little Toto pulls back the curtain. There hides a cowering figure transmitting the illusion of power, perpetrating the myth of the omnipotent Oz. Yet before he floats off in his balloon, he tells the group that it's the ideas that hold the power, not the physical incarnation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINCLAIRE, HARRY ADDISON
description: SINCLAIRE-Harry Addison. 78, of Washington, DC, and recently of Such Delights Farms in Middleburg, VA, died after a long illness August 5. Mr. Sinclaire was born in Rutherford, NJ, July 9, 1922. He was a graduate of George School '39; Amherst College '43 and Cornell University Medical College '46. He served in the U.S. Navy Medical Corps. He was associated with New York Hospital for many years. From 1951 to 1982 he was medical director of Mobil Oil. He previously resided in Darien, CT, Lawrenceville, NJ, and London. He was generous, kind, thoughtful and loving. Survivors are his wife, Louise Carlson Sinclaire of Washington, DC; his two sons by a previous marriage, Peter of Santa Fe, NM, and Bruce of Cohasset, MA; two beloved grandchildren, Graham and Mollie; his sister-in-law, Jane Carlson of Richmond VA; and nieces, Amanda Albano and Sheridan Forbes. He was predeceased by his daughter, Stacey; his brother, James; and his parents, James Kennedy and Louise Andrews Sinclaire. A memorial service will be held at the Princeton Friends Meeting in late summer. The family requests that memorial donations be made to The David Bourns Scholarship Fund at George School, PO Box 4438, Newtown, PA 18940.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HETSKO, JOSEPHINE STEIN
description: HETSKO-Josephine Stein. 89. Died Tuesday, August 8, in Allendale, NJ. Mrs. Hetsko, a native of Scranton, PA, resided in Ridgewood, NJ for over 40 years with her husband of 64 years, the late Cyril F. Hetsko. Mrs. Hetsko attended the Universities of Pennsylvania and Michigan, and graduated summa cum laude from New York University. In addition to raising four children, Mrs. Hetsko was a substitute teacher in Ridgewood Public Schools in the 1960's and 1970's. Mrs. Hetsko had a lifelong love of theater. Included among her accomplishments were producing, directing and acting in the Ridgewood High School Jamboree (she co-produced the 1960 Jamboree with her late husband) and the YWCA Cabaret. She was also a devoted member of various community theater groups including the Joe Jefferson Players, the Hillside Players (of the West Side Presbyterian Church, where Mrs. Hetsko had served as Deaconess, and had been a member since moving to Ridgewood in 1953), and numerous theater productions of the Ridgewood College Club and the Ridgewood Women's Club. Mrs. Hetsko was an energetic, and gregarious community volunteer. She was the first woman to run as a candidate for Village Commissioner in Ridgewood. She was also active for many years in Cub Scouts and Girl Scouts, and was awarded the Thanks Badge, the most prestigious adult award in Girl Scouting. Mrs. Hetsko was a member of The Explorers Club of New York City. She and her late husband frequently traveled to remote areas of the world, and lectured on their experiences in Bhutan, Tibet, China, Ladakh and Mongolia. Mrs. Hetsko is survived by two daughters, Jacqueline Kaufer of Ridgewood, NJ, and Cynthia Rainey of Lawrence, KS; two sons, Cyril M. Hetsko, M.D., of Madison, WI, and Jeffrey F. Hetsko, Esq., of Atlanta, GA; five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made to: Jamboree Scholarship Fund, c/o Betty Gregg, 15 Howard Place, Waldwick, NJ 07643.

title: A Vaunted Musical Tradition Seen Through Fresh Eyes
description: WE'VE been trying to figure out what to call this thing for 50 years,'' Frank Salomon said of the venerable Marlboro Music School and Festival, which ends its 50th season here today with a public concert. Three South American bands -- La Ley from Chile, Los Amigos Invisibles from Venezuela and Illya Kuryaki and the Valderramas, from Argentina -- performed at Central Park Summerstage on Saturday afternoon, latching on to 1970's and 80's styles with respect and mockery. The concert was the lead-in to the first Latin Alternative Music Conference, a music-business convention in New York City through tomorrow.

title: A Small Case Of Identity Crisis; Overlooked Rockland Divides Over Question Of Growth vs. Quiet Charm

title: When Conventions Mattered
description: It is a long distance from the political conventions that nominated Al Smith and Franklin D. Roosevelt to the weeklong infomercials that are called conventions today. Once conventions were battlefields where real fights were waged over platforms, personalities and power. Vice-presidential choices were not made beforehand; the selection of the presidential nominee was seldom sure until the convention had run its course. Conventions had lives and logic all their own. And they mattered.

Yet the signature song from ''Oklahoma!'' set the right tone for this performance by E's band, Eels, which unfolded like a musical set at an alternative rock show.

But in the process he revealed a new and potentially contentious one, saying proposals to raise the retirement age for Social Security and Medicare should be ''kept on the table'' for further discussion.

title: Fighting About the Teacher Shortage
description: New York State's education commissioner, Richard Mills, and New York City's schools chancellor, Harold Levy, have been wrangling for months over a new state regulation requiring the city to hire only certified teachers in low-performing schools beginning this fall. The commissioner is right to pressure New York City, given its habit of hobbling its poorest students with unqualified teachers and chaotic, dysfunctional schools. But given a statewide shortage that is making certified teachers difficult to come by, the city could easily fall just short of full compliance, no matter how hard it tries.

title: BUYandHOLD Shifts Account
description: The BUYandHOLD.com Securities Corporation in New York, an online broker that is part of BUYandHOLD.com Inc., consolidated its account at DiMassimo Brand Advertising in New York, by naming that agency to handle its business-to-business advertising, which had been at Weiss Stagliano Partners. DiMassimo has handled consumer, branding and direct response advertising since both agencies were named to handle the account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million, two-and-a-half months ago.

title: Article 2000081493225757271 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRTH, MORRIS A.
description: WIRTH-Morris A. Surrounded by his wife Jean, sons Bob, Billy, and John, passed away peacefully on the morning of Saturday, August 12, after a brave battle with cancer. He was 76. In addition he is survived by his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, as well as Vasilia Hughes, and his most cherished grandson Alec. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and a prominent lawyer who represented Israeli interests in the U.S. for more than 35 years, Morris took great pleasure in generous helpings of political and philosophical discourse, frequently told jokes, and always delicious meals. But he lived to help others, whether with needed advice or unflinching support. The family will receive his friends and loved ones at the Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, on Monday, August 14, from 5-8 PM. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, Tuesday, August 15, at the Park Avenue Christian Church/ Universal Synagogue, 1010 Park Ave. Friends are also welcome at the interment service Tuesday at 3 PM, at the Westhampton Cemetery through Follett Funeral Home, Westhampton Beach, LI. ''So many dear friends-well wishers whose prayers will help and whose support of Jean and the kids is my greatest comfort.''

title: Publicis Revamping Its U.S. Business
description: Publicis Groupe in Paris is reorganizing its American operations under Robert H. Bloom, chairman and chief executive of what is being called Publicis in the U.S., by forming three regional centers from eight separate offices.

title: Floridians Take Grand National Team Title
description: In a battle of world champions, Florida defeated California to capture the Grand National Team title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Saturday night. The Floridians were Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell and Robert Levin, whose many honors include the World Bridge Federation's Bermuda Bowl, as well as Michael Seamon and Joseph Shay.

title: Yankees Coast as the Angels Flail at Clemens's Fastballs
description: Roger Clemens came to the big leagues as a power pitcher, and after agreeing to a contract that will endure beyond his 40th birthday, Clemens said he intended to finish his career as a power pitcher. When he cannot throw hard, he will not throw at all.

title: Washington Feels Time Is Short for Restarting the Mideast Talks
description: The White House has calculated that the effective deadline for a final Middle East peace settlement during the Clinton presidency is the end of September, a senior administration official said today.

title: Saudi Arabia Blocks Access to Yahoo Site
description: Saudi Arabia Blocks Access to Yahoo Site

title: The Bright Line Gore Needs to Draw
description: Judging by polls and media reaction, Al Gore engaged the public's interest before the Democratic Convention with his choice of Joseph Lieberman at least as well as George Bush did before the Republican event by choosing Dick Cheney. But Mr. Gore has to take a very different tack this week in Los Angeles than the Republicans did in Philadelphia. If the objective of the G.O.P. was to soften differences between the parties, Mr. Gore's goal has to be to make the distinctions abundantly clear.

title: Essay; Bill's Third Acceptance
description: My Fellow Democrats:

title: The Indispensable State
description: Seemingly overnight, California has become for Democrats what the South once was in national elections -- their indispensable electoral building block. So it is fitting for them to celebrate in Los Angeles what they hope will prove a seamless transition from the Age of Clinton to the Age of Gore.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: EVENTS

title: Wieden & Kennedy Fills New York Spot
description: Amy Nicholson was named creative director at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, succeeding Michael Prieve, who began a sabbatical in May and plans to return to the Portland office in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAYSTMAN, FRIEDA
description: TRAYSTMAN-Frieda. Of NYC, NY. Died August 13, 2000. Retired from Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCoy. Survived by loving nieces Kathy Traystman and Martha Welch, and sister-in-law Helen Traystman. Private arrangements by family. Donations in her memory to The Ivan L. Rubin Foundation, Inc, 160 West 16th St, New York, NY 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, THOMAS E.
description: CURTIS-Thomas E. Real estate developer, banker, and founder of the Curtis Supermarket chain, died Friday of a stroke. Born in Boston, Mr. Curtis developed more than two million square feet of commercial space in Southeastern Massachusetts. He was a community leader and contributed greatly to a variety of charities. After losing his eldest son Tom Jr., an AllAmerican sailor at Georgetown University, Tom Sr. became active in promoting the GU Sailing Team with grants, gifts and scholarships. He also established an educational scholarship at St. Anselms College, the alma mater of his eldest daughter Kathleen, who died in 1993. Tom and his wife Marjorie resided in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and summered in Hingham, MA. Beloved husband of Marjorie E. (Pearce) Curtis. Loving father of Brian P. Curtis of Hingham, MA, Elizabeth A. Curtis of New York, NY, Dianne M. Curtis of Hingham, Sarah C. Hanlon of Hingham, and Jonathan P. Curtis of Hingham. Devoted brother of Mary, Richard, David, Alan, Jean, and Dorothy. Loving ''papa'' of 14 grandchildren. Funeral Mass in St. Paul's Church, Hingham, Wednesday, August 16, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lincoln Sailing Center, P.O. Box 492, Hingham, MA 02043.

title: Liberty Holds All the Cards Against the Young Mystics
description: In the stifling air of the MCI Center, 16,331 high-pitched screams brought the energy to a boiling point. With less than four minutes left in the first game of the Eastern Conference playoffs Saturday night in Washington, the Liberty and the host Mystics were deadlocked at 58-58.

title: In America; Gore's Crucial Week
description: If the Republican convention was an infomercial, the Democratic convention is a minefield.

title: THE ENERGY RUSH -- A special report.; Promise and Peril in New York Power Plans
description: Just off 20th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, behind a steel and brick fence guarded by dogs, sits an old hulk of a power plant that was built when cars had fins and Uncle Miltie was the king of prime time. The plant, designed to burn coal, then oil, had become a symbol of power generation at its dirtiest and least efficient by the time it was closed in 1993.

title: Democrats Ready the Stage For Their Post-Clinton Era
description: The Democratic National Convention will adopt a platform on Tuesday that, like its Republican counterpart, makes a broad effort to reach voters in the middle, calling for schools to be more accountable for student performance, stricter control of the nation's borders, expanded global trade, a stronger military and the death penalty.

title: Sustained By Fiction While Facing Life's Facts
description: I was told I had cancer on a beautiful blue day in July. I was out on Cape Cod, finishing the first draft of a novel when the telephone rang. I had thought it was about time for me to have a bit of good luck, and when I heard my surgeon's voice I assumed I was safe. In novels people were called into offices for bad news, and anyway, it was far too gorgeous a day for tragedy. Roses were in full bloom. Bees rumbled by the windowpanes, lazy with pollen and heat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEITER, JEANNE F.
description: KEITER-Jeanne F. Of Madison, NJ, on August 11, 2000. Wife of the late William Keiter. Daughter of Alice M. Flauss. Mother of Nancy Keiter, Susan Mellen and John Keiter. A memorial service will be held at the Grace Episcopal Church, 4 Madison Ave, Madison, NJ, on Wednesday, August 16, at 11 AM. For information go to www.bradleyfuneralhome.com or call Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham, NJ.

title: Testaverde's Status Is Uncertain for Opener
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde will miss at least the next week of practice and will not play in the final preseason game Friday against the Giants because of a sprained big toe on his left foot. But Jets Coach Al Groh remained hopeful that Testaverde, who was injured in the Jets' loss to the Baltimore Ravens on Saturday night, would be ready when the Jets open the regular season against Green Bay on Sept. 3.

title: Gypsies and the Holocaust
description: Gypsies and Jews were the only two groups that the Nazi regime sought to exterminate completely. Six million Jews were murdered, and perhaps half of Europe's one million Gypsies. Yet of the $60 billion the German government has paid in reparations since World War II to Holocaust victims, only a tiny percentage has gone to Gypsies. The German government and German companies who employed slave or forced labor recently set up a $5 billion fund for these workers and other victims. Gypsies are eligible, and the fund also provides $12 million for social programs to benefit them. But the fund administrators must take special care to see that the money reaches Gypsies, lest this group be slighted again.

title: Holyfield Regains Part of Title but Goes Backward
description: A right hand late in the third round stunned his opponent, who began to wobble. A visit to the canvas seemed imminent. But at this pivotal moment in Saturday night's World Boxing Association heavyweight championship bout against the unheralded John Ruiz, 37-year-old Evander Holyfield could not do what he almost surely would have done during his best years. He could not put his opponent away.

title: Before Attack on Officers, Arsenal and Combat Dress
description: For years, the authorities and some of his neighbors say, Arthur Alalouf lived a reclusive life in Gravesend, Brooklyn, sulking in his parents' home at 16 Parkway Court.

title: Apology Highlights ABC Reporter's Contrarian Image
description: Last Friday evening on the TV news magazine ''20/20,'' John Stossel, the square-jawed consumer and environmental correspondent, was forced to do something relatively rare for ABC News or any other network news operation: deliver an apology on the air for inaccuracies in a news feature.

title: Delegates Heading Into Cyberspace
description: Picture the scene this week on the convention floor in Los Angeles: Democratic delegates galore with banners and balloons, funny hats and confetti. And computers. And Palm Pilots, digital cameras, wireless beepers, ''smart cards'' and all sorts of other high-tech gadgets meant to showcase the party's technological prowess and burnish its party-of-the-future image.

title: New Economy; The Internet in Japan is riding a wireless wave, leaving phone-line companies in the dust.
description: TO understand how different the development of the Internet has been in Japan than in the United States, consider the plight of Hiroaki Kobayashi.

title: Beckjord Finishes For a Fourth Time
description: Suprabha Beckjord, 44, of Washington completed the Sri Chinmoy 3,100-Mile Race for the fourth time when she finished Saturday night in 54 days 15 hours 51 minutes 34 seconds. She is the first four-time finisher of the race, which was held in Queens and was founded in 1977.

title: The Giants' Barrow Finally Returns to Practice
description: The injury was supposed to be minor, one of those day-to-day situations that are so common in training camp, where everyone struggles to remain healthy. But Mike Barrow had not practiced since he sprained his right knee in practice Aug. 2 in a collision in the end zone with safety Sam Garnes and wide receiver Ike Hilliard. Finally, Barrow returned to practice today, a day ahead of schedule and just in time to provide some relief to the Giants.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about the Ford Motor Company's plan to distribute cash and shares to stockholders misstated the amount of money allotted and the number of shares that will be outstanding. The company is distributing $5.7 billion in cash, not $6 billion. The shares outstanding will be 1.893 billion, not 1.9 billion.

title: Disability Redefined
description: To the Editor:

title: Recycling Is Effective
description: To the Editor:

title: Dongguan Journal; For Hong Kong Men, Mistresses on the Mainland
description: A banner identifies the bustling warren of streets in this southern Chinese city as the New Garden Village Meat and Vegetable Market. And, indeed, one can find meat and produce in many varieties -- fresh or cured, hanging from hooks or still squawking in cages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIVY, ISABEL
description: KIVY-Isabel. Died peacefully in her sleep at home on Saturday, August 12, 2000, at the age of 100. Wife of the late Julius Kivy. Mother of Dr. Peter Kivy and Dr. Elaine Genkins. Grandmother of Karen Fairbank, Esq, Steven Genkins, MD, and Amy Genkins, Esq. Great-grandmother of David and Sarah Fairbank, Daniel and Julian Genkins and Gillian and Jesse Horwitz. Mrs. Kivy was a strong, capable and talented woman. She devoted her life to the welfare of her family. Mrs. Kivy, an honor graduate of Hunter High School, highly valued intellectual endeavors and was strongly committed to the education of her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A dancer in her youth and an artist throughout her life, Isabel Kivy was admired by all who knew her and will be missed by everyone whose life she touched.

title: THE DEMOCRATS: PARTY'S SCHEDULE
description: All times are Eastern daylight

title: Networks may make even more cuts in convention coverage in 2004.
description: ON a muggy night in Philadelphia, Rick Kaplan sat in the CNN control booth in an advanced state of bliss. His floor correspondents were killing themselves to get good material. The Texas delegates, bowing their heads in prayer during a speech by a gay congressman, made for a nifty TV moment. And a marquee speech by Senator John McCain proved to be just this side of cryptic, excellent late-evening fodder for Jeff Greenfield and the other analysts on the skybox anchor desk.

title: Hakkinen's Pass in First Turn Sets Up Victory
description: With his two biggest rivals preoccupied by a war of nerves, Mika Hakkinen came from behind for the second race in a row to get through the first corner first at the start of today's Hungarian Grand Prix. And on the narrow, dusty and twisty Hungaroring, where it is next to impossible to pass, that is half the job of winning.

title: Both Halves of Reform Party Prepare for Legal Challenge
description: As the presidential nominees of the two Reform Parties left Splitsville this week to campaign across the rest of the country by bus, their associates began plotting legal strategies to seize the $12.6 million in federal campaign money that is awaiting the real party's true nominee -- as soon as a court decides what and who they are.

title: Alliance to Send Video-on-Demand on Web
description: Intertainer and Akamai Technologies plan to announce today an alliance to deliver video-on-demand to the computers of consumers with high-speed Internet connections. The service is now available in two markets and will be broadly available by the end of the year, the companies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPPO, PHILIP G. III
description: NAPPO-Philip G. III. 41, of Manhattan and Patterson, NY, passed away on August 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Hubbell Nappo. Loving son of Philip G. Nappo and the late Elsie Nappo. Cherished brother of Nancy Euchner, and dear uncle to Gregory, Richard and Marshall Euchner, and Lindsay and Samantha Stein. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, on Tuesday, August 15, 5:30-7:30 PM, with a service of Thanksgiving immediately following. There will be an additional viewing on Wednesday, August 16, from 5-6 PM, with funeral services immediately following at the Second Congregational Church of Greenwich, CT, 139 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to Tres Dias of Fairfield County, PO Box 2516, Danbury, CT 06813-2516.

title: License Fee Wins
description: Pat Day shot License Fee out of the gate and never looked back in winning the Grade III Ballston Spa Breeders' Cup Handicap over a mile and a sixteenth on soft turf yesterday at Saratoga. License Fee, a 5-year-old mare, earned $125,700 for Winstar Farm and paid $8.40 for a $2 bet to win.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREEN, DANIEL M., JR.
description: BREEN-Daniel M., Jr. Jan. 31, 1959-Aug. 14, 1998. Can't believe it's been 2 years already. Steven is married; Kevin has a son; Taylor is expecting a sibling. We are all well and happy but less so without you. My new job is great-thanks again. Love from all of us. Howard

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Monday about the Institute on the Arts and Civic Dialogue, a performing program at Harvard founded by the playwright Anna Deavere Smith, referred imprecisely to its end. It has closed, at least for now, because its three-year grant will expire this year, not because its offerings did not rally audiences.

title: A Tale of 2 Babies, And More Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dance Icon Sees a Lovely Now in the Mirror
description: Katherine Dunham is getting ready for a photo shoot. The radiant star of countless international dance tours and Broadway and Hollywood musicals from the 1940's on, scrutinizes the face staring back at her in the mirror. She combs her hair, now short and gray, and expertly applies her makeup. A friend helps her into a long blue-black velvet dress studded with small dark stars, created for her by a young Haitian designer named Cyril. Books are everywhere. The television is tuned permanently to CNN.

title: AIDS Cuts a Swath Through Africa's Teachers
description: Among the precious few classrooms in this village in West Africa, one squat two-room building is no longer in use. A green bicycle chain looped around the door handles bars entry.

title: Hutchison Buys 51% of Andala In Permit Quest
description: Hutchison Whampoa , a holding company owned by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, has bought 51 percent of Andala, giving the Italian company money to bid for a mobile phone license, Andala said in a statement today.

title: With All Eyes on Kane, Mallon Wins du Maurier
description: While all of Canada was caught up in the drama of one of its own daughters trying to win the final du Maurier Classic, the veteran Meg Mallon saw her own long-awaited opening and lunged for it.

title: Quiet on the Jets, Tampa in a Buzz: Johnson Rants
description: The offense of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers hit a small lull last week during a dreary preseason game against Miami. Suddenly, wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson, always the life of the party or the huddle, saw something that would perk things up. Dolphins cornerback Jerry Wilson, barely 5 feet 10 inches, was guarding, all by himself, the 6-4 Johnson. The best defensive backs in the game, some built like small forwards, have a difficult time matching up with Johnson's combination of power and size.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, ROBERT B.
description: COSTELLO-Robert B. On August 5, 2000, in Boston, Massachusetts. A renowned and admired editor, writer, and lexicographer, known for his brilliance, wit, and sensitive soul, Bob touched many and will be deeply missed and remembered by all, especially his loving daughter Kate C. Boyle, his devoted sister Barbara LeRoy and brother John J. Costello, Jr. and nieces and nephews Betsy, John, Elizabeth, James, and Richard, and longtime companion Carl A. Rossi. Contributions in his name may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1-800-227-2345.

title: Livery Drivers Take Chance With Robbers (and Police)
description: Manuel Santana, who drives for a car service in Washington Heights, has known for months that city officials are requiring livery cars to be outfitted with bulletproof partitions or security cameras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOSVERN, MONROE
description: BLOSVERN-Monroe. Almost 90 years old. Died August 12, 2000. Beloved and loving husband, father and grandfather. A passionate fisherman and a devoted friend. His family and friends will miss him deeply. Services Thursday, Augsust 17, at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ESTHER (NEE GOTTESMAN)
description: KATZ-Esther (nee Gottesman). Wife of the late and beloved Harry Katz, died peacefully in Boca Raton, Florida, August 10, 2000. A woman of remarkable strength and intelligence. She was the true embodiment of family values. Her love and caring presence will be missed greatly by all who knew her. Mother of Aron and Phyllis Katz, Albert and Virginia Katz, and the late Richard Katz; sister of Abe Gottesman; grandmother of Martin and Marcellina Katz, Margaret and Stephen Cann, Rebecca Katz and Rachael and Nick Carey; great-grandmother of Alejandro and Francisco Katz, and Harrison and Simon Cann. May God grant you peace. Services will be held at 9:45 AM on Tuesday, August 15, 2000, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76, Manhattan, NY.

title: Lieberman Injects Bit of Yiddish, Clintons Stay Late and Connecticut Is Noticed
description: Maybe Jackie Mason should worry. After all, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate seems to enjoy using Yiddish words like ''chutzpah'' and Jewish-style phrases that have not often been heard on the national campaign trail.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Releases Data on Tires That Firestone Recalled

title: Stottlemyre Planning His Return to Dugout
description: Manager Joe Torre said this afternoon that he was not counting on Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, to return to the Yankees during the coming homestand. But Torre also said that Stottlemyre, who is being treated for bone marrow cancer, had mentioned the possibility of resuming his duties during the road trip that begins Aug. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORE, CHESTER A.
description: GORE-Chester A. 8/14/18-4/19/97. In our thoughts and hearts on your birthday and every day. We love you. Eloise, Gerie and Alle

description: GOULD-Michael Terence. Of Old Saybrook, CT, and NYC, on August 11, 2000. Son of William J. and the late Marie Flynn Gould. Brother of Catherine Beta, William, Gregory and John Gould. Fiance of Patricia Lynn Ingellis. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday, August 16, at 10 AM.

description: The Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest business group, said today that its founder, Chung Ju Yung, would sell a 6.1 percent stake in the Hyundai Motor Company by the end of the year, ending months of defiance of government demands for reorganization.

description: COHEN-William ''Bill.'' Former proprietor of The Inner Circle and Damon's restaurants. Dear great-grandfather. Fond brother of the late Irene Krantz and Molly Block. Services Nassau North Chapel, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck, 12:45, Monday.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

description: BOOKEY-Theodore. On August 11, 2000. Former partner of Bookey & Greenman for over 40 years. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Seth and Sanford, and father-in-law of Lynne. Dear brother of Elaine Slotnick and Jack. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Every Ride's an Audition for Bus Driver's Shtick
description: Let Tony Palombella tell you: In 17 years on the circuit, he has worked some pretty tough rooms, boy. There was the Bx40, which was murder, and the Bx9, no cakewalk. ''Very hard crowd in the Bronx,'' he said. ''Hard to get a laugh.''

title: Unusually Severe Crackdown On Political Dissent in China
description: Police activity has been increasing in several parts of China as the country undergoes a tightening of social controls ahead of the Oct. 1 National Day holiday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Prince Emanuele Filiberto di Sa voia, the exiled heir to the Italian throne, who is campaigning for the right to visit his homeland, misstated the relationship of two members of the Savoy dynasty. Mafalda was the daughter, not the sister, of King Vittorio Emanuele III.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, CAREN SUE, PH.D.
description: FRIED-Caren Sue, Ph.D. Of Paramus, NJ, on August 12, 2000. Beloved wife of Dr. Alan Pomerantz. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien,'' corner Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, NJ, today, August 14, 2000, at 11:30 AM. For information, 1-800-322-0533.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

description: LERNER-Mike. Lerner Group, Inc, conveys heartfelt condolences to Selma, Sharon, Jack, Laurie, and their families on Mike's passing. He was a dear friend and inspiration to us and will be missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. We'll always remember him. Anita Grossberg, President

description: Among the speakers on this evening's program:

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Snap! Kiss That Niche Market Goodbye; Nurtured by TV, Black Comics Are Breaking Boundaries at the Box Office
description: The slogan for the remake of 'Shaft'' -- ''Still the man'' -- turned out to be more than an idle boast. The picture topped the box-office charts in its first week of release, coming in at $21 million. ''Shaft'' was preceded by ''Big Momma's House,'' the Martin Lawrence comedy, which made $25 million its first week. Both were followed by ''Scary Movie,'' directed by Keenen Ivory Wayans, which hosed its competition with $54 million, the biggest opening ever for an R-rated movie. Then ''Nutty Professor II'' opened at $42 million, the largest first-weekend take for an Eddie Murphy movie.

title: A Space Detour for Streaming Internet Traffic
description: Listening to NetRadio.com's Woodstock 69 music channel or KBAC-FM, Santa Fe's jazz and eclectic radio station, or some other music program over the Internet is gaining popularity among people who spend lots of time online. But delivering simultaneous streams of music to thousands or even millions of listeners over an ever more clogged Internet has become increasingly frustrating. If the audio stream hits too many traffic jams, the listener may find his Internet radio program stuttering or stopping midway through a song.

title: Democrats Hope Beefed-Up Convention Will Distinguish Them From G.O.P.
description: From the sea of see-through iMac computers on the convention floor to a center-stage program of prominent officials engaged in issue ''dialogues'' with ordinary people, the Democratic National Convention that opens on Monday is intended to be, in look and feel, a brainier and meatier antidote to the Republicans' feel-good Philadelphia spectacle.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

description: New Focus on Mideast Pact
