title: An Indian Stew of Corruption, Human and Social
description: AN OBEDIENT FATHER

title: At Clinton's Twilight, Memories of Reagan's Farewell
description: When you watch President Clinton at the Democratic convention, it may look as if he is stealing President Ronald Reagan's script from 1988. As Mr. Reagan did then, Mr. Clinton plans to bless his No. 2 officially on Monday evening. As Mr. Reagan did then, Mr. Clinton is expected to implore Americans to build on the triumphs of the current administration.

title: Internet in Japan Is Riding a Wireless Wave
description: A Space Detour for Streaming Internet Traffic

title: Destin Journal; New Economy Eclipses A Sliver of Old Florida
description: The sand dunes of Okaloosa Island, like snowbanks, line both sides of U.S. Highway 98 between Fort Walton and Destin, and they are so pretty that people weave off the road, looking at them. The golden sea oats waft in the summer breeze, and gnarled pines, blasted by hurricanes that hit or barely missed, lean from sand so purely white that the sun flashes off it like a mirror and hurts the eyes.

title: Kinko's and FedEx Plan Document Service
description: Kinkos.com, an online start-up, has announced a deal with the Kinko's chain of copy shops and FedEx to create a service that promises to deliver finished presentations and reports within a few hours of receiving the data.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Jakarta Switch: Parliament Noisy, Streets Quiet
description: The ''Hang Suharto!'' protesters were out in the streets, as always. But so was a small rally demanding clean air, another involving a local land dispute and another promoting breast-feeding.

title: As innovation lags behind and the mainstream moves in, Net entrepreneurs look for ways out.
description: LIKE many senior-level Internet executives, Christine Harmel, chief executive of Interactive Resource, a firm in Manhattan that matches Web site developers with clients, was present at the birth of e-commerce. Working on the Net since 1995, Ms. Harmel, 32, has experienced years of 80-hour workweeks and has watched the industry transform itself from a stomping ground for young workaholics who wanted to change the world, into a stomping ground for young workaholics who want to change their tax brackets.

title: Poll Finds Delegates to the Left of Both Public and Party
description: The Democratic delegates arriving here to nominate Vice President Al Gore for president think of themselves as moderates, but their views on issues from affirmative action to an activist federal government are more liberal than those of the public or even Democratic voters generally, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: From Man to Ape: Troubling Images From Senegal
description: ''Le Coq Est Mort'' (''The Rooster Is Dead'') is on the face of it a fairly simple piece. The 70-minute work, performed by Company Jant-Bi this afternoon in the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, begins with a brisk processional of men dressed in business suits and carrying attache cases. They begin to bond, to fight and to drink together, eventually shedding all but their trousers to regress to that essence of primitivism or the natural world, the lolloping ape.

title: Serena Williams Edges Davenport
description: Serena Williams rallied to defeat Lindsay Davenport for the fifth time in a row yesterday in the Estyle.com Classic in Manhattan Beach, Calif. It was Williams's first hardcourt tuneup for the defense of her United States Open title.

title: Trombone Agency Changes Hands
description: Trombone Associates in New York, an agency that focuses on travel and tourism, has changed ownership. Mario Trombone, 72, chairman, and Ilse Trombone, 62, president, are retiring and selling the agency to Joseph R. D'Alto, Odette Fodor-Gernaert and Dan Starkey, who become partners. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Days of Hope for Seton Hall Recruits
description: It is 10 minutes past 8 o'clock last Wednesday night and all eyes are on the door to the gym at St. Rose's High School in Belmar, N.J. The task for Andre Barrett, Eddie Griffin, Marcus Toney-El and Damion Fray this night is not to lift Seton Hall University toward any basketball championship. It is to save the Jersey Shore Basketball League the embarrassment of pulling people out of the stands to play in a playoff game that was to begin at 8.

title: Murdoch Deal Could Revamp New York TV
description: Media analysts and network executives said over the weekend that the sale of TV stations owned by Chris-Craft Industries to the owner of the Fox network, the News Corporation, was likely to create a host of opportunities for the News Corporation -- and raise almost as many questions.

title: Harold Pierson, 66, Dancer and Teacher for Philadanco Company
description: Harold Pierson, a dancer, actor and educator, died on Aug. 1 in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lively Local Races Are Adding Zest to the Ballots of September
description: While the United States Senate race in New York is the biggest drawing card for the November election, several high-pitched, energetic contests are also generating a lot of interest in next month's primary.

title: Linux Backers Plan Assault On Microsoft
description: A group of key Linux software developers and major computer manufacturers are planning to announce on Tuesday at a Silicon Valley computer conference the first effort to compete directly with Microsoft's Office suite of applications for the personal computer.

title: Bush Defends Settlement For Cheney
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas this weekend defended the generous retirement package that his running mate, Dick Cheney, received from his former employer as a standard practice for a company executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTCH, FRANCES (GAUCHMAN)
description: SCOTCH-Frances (Gauchman). 82, of Long Meadow, MA; formerly of Brookline, died Saturday. Her husband Theodore died in May. She was the mother of Dr. David S. Scotch of Westport, CT, and Elaine Fialky of Long Meadow, MA; mother-in-law of Barbara Scotch and Gary Fialky; sister of Max Gauchman of Brookline and Nechama Grossman of Israel; grandmother of Jeffrey and Joshua Fialky, Jonathon and Peter Scotch; great-grandmother of Justin and Hannah Scotch. Funeral and burial are Monday. Contributions can be made to Jewish Geriatric Services, 770 Converse St, Long Meadow, MA 01106, or American Cancer Society, 53 Capital Ave, West Springfield, MA 01089.

title: Quarterfinals Set In East Regional
description: Teams from the Bronx, Pequannock, N.J., and Lyme/Old Lyme, Conn., qualified for today's quarterfinals in the East Regional Little League tournament in Bristol, Conn. The winner of Thursday night's regional final will advance to the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa., from Aug. 20 to 26.

title: In Reality Show Derby, NBC Has 2 New Entries
description: After a lengthy delay, NBC will announce this week that it has acquired the rights to ''Chains of Love,'' a reality show that will literally chain four men to one woman for a week.

title: Leiter Makes It Easy For the Soaring Mets
description: Al Leiter spotted a photo of a pitcher a few days ago, and he looked it over with admiration. As the pitcher released the ball, his arm was like the minute hand on a clock at the top of the hour. That is impressive, said Leiter, who felt his release point was off in a sloppy outing at Houston last week.

title: 3,500 Rally To Condemn Death Penalty
description: More than 3,500 protesters, from gay rights to animal rights activists, marched through Los Angeles today, the eve of the Democratic National Convention, demanding the end of capital punishment and a new trial for a death row inmate, the convicted murderer Mumia Abu-Jamal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OST, EDWIN M. JR.
description: OST-Edwin M. Jr. Of Short Hills, NJ. On August 11, 2000. Beloved husband of Dorothy Ost (nee Birrell), devoted father of Margaret A. Ost of New York City, Elizabeth O. White of Rye, NH, and Frederick P. of Mendham, NJ, loving brother of Elizabeth Spencer and Elsie Ost. Also survived by three grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Graveside services will be private.

title: Article 2000081492037701966 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Power Politics, and the Power of Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, HERMAN
description: TUCKER-Herman. Whose wisdom and guidance helped us to persevere in the early difficult years of Audiovox. We will miss the special relationship of the last 44 years. John and Jane Shalam and All your friends at Audiovox Corp.

title: Ford Says Firestone Was Aware of Flaw In Its Tires by 1997
description: The Ford Motor Company released documents today showing that in 1997 Bridgestone/Firestone began receiving numerous complaints of injuries and property damage involving certain Firestone tires that were not recalled until last Wednesday.

title: After 4-Year Wait, Walker Wins His Way Onto Team
description: Four years ago, Neil Walker missed a spot on the United States Olympic swimming team by one-hundredth of a second, a margin so small that it inevitably produced disappointment that was huge and inconsolable.

title: An Author Seduced by Hollywood's Glimmer
description: On Aug. 3, Robert Gottlieb, one of the most powerful agents in the book business and the head of the William Morris agency's New York literary group, received a letter from Tom Clancy, his old friend and biggest client. His message: he was ending their 15 years of business together. From now on, his book deals would be handled by Michael Ovitz.

title: A Bluesman at the Crossroads (on Seventh Ave.)
description: The blues flow with his fingers. The index, middle and third do all the work. Pressing skin to steel strings and wood, they make the city night wail with the music of the bluesman and his Manhattan blues band.

title: Steven Jobs Finds Fault With Portrayal in Book
description: Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder and chief executive of Apple Computer, is not a happy man at the moment.

title: Touch of Comedy on Campaign Trail
description: It was the Al and Rob show, an unlikely new comedy duo now making occasional appearances on the campaign trail to the White House. Starring Vice President Al Gore, a politician with a famously wooden public demeanor, and Rob Reiner, the actor and director known for sly satire, the team came to the Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital here to talk about the serious subject of children without medical insurance.

title: Park Arrives With Victory At the Glen
description: His boss left on an airplane late this afternoon without him. Steve Park would have to find a much slower way to get back to North Carolina.

title: Patents; Designers try to put some needed pizazz into the bland-but-functional modern bank branch.
description: REMEMBER the last time you stopped in your tracks at the sight of the display in a bank branch window, lingering to window-shop or even drawn irresistibly through the door and into the bank to browse?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VREELAND, NANCY STOLKIN
description: VREELAND-Nancy Stolkin. 57, of Los Angeles, CA, on August 4, 2000. Survived by husband Thomas Reed Vreeland, mother Ruth March, sister Kathy Meyers and brother John Stolkin. Memorial services will be held at 3 PM, on Sunday, August 20, at the Los Angeles Central Library. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Nancy S. Vreeland Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, UCLA School of Medicine, 10833 Le Conte Avenue, Room 27-139, Center for Health Sciences, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1741, or to the Nancy S. Vreeland Literary Fund, Los Angeles Central Library, 630 West 5th Street, Los Angeles, CA 90071.

title: RUSSIANS WONDER IF PUTIN ACCEPTS LIMITS TO POWER
description: Earlier this summer, the newly elected Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, flew to Tatarstan to take part in the planting festival known as Sabantui. There he donned a Tatar hat, stuck his face in a vat of yogurt to bob for coins and then engaged a Tatar girl in arm wrestling.

title: How an Illinois County Cleared the Welfare Rolls
description: Holly E. Cain, manager of the local welfare office, used to post job openings for welfare recipients just inside the front door of her agency here. She nearly put herself out of business. Welfare disappeared from this county. For more than a year, there have been no new cases, no old cases, no one on the rolls receiving cash assistance.

title: Digging Into the Past
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIDENBERG, SYLVIA
description: HEIDENBERG - Sylvia. Temple Emanu-El of Englewood, New Jersey extends its deepest sympathy to the families of Robert and Susan Heidenberg, Susan Laden, Richard Heidenberg and Laurence Lazar. She was an esteemed figure in our congregation and in the Jewish and civic communities. May her family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Geoffrey Haber, Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, Rabbi Emeritus Israel Singer, Cantor Kurt Silbermann, Cantor Emeritus Marlene Erlebacher, President Allen Brown, Executive Director

title: Group in Town Built on Freedom Fights New Law
description: Freedom is no mere slogan to the residents of Lawnside, N.J.

title: Stormy Clouds Chase Everyone From the Place
description: Connoisseurs of outdoor dance performances don't mind rain. Some of the most memorable shows at the late and much lamented Delacorte Dance Festival in Central Park resulted when dancers were forced to compensate for showers and slippery stages.

title: Rising Waters, and Sinking Hearts, in New Jersey
description: Elena Lazzaro and her husband were the first to build a home on their block of River Road, on the banks of the Musconetcong River, 37 years ago.

title: Treasury Prices Move Higher On Optimism About Inflation
description: Bond prices rebounded before the Treasury Department pays out billions of dollars in coupon payments today that could be reinvested in government securities.

title: Baffling Disorders Often Stem From Immune System Failure
description: Abby Bernstein feels as if she has been told that she has just about every ailment in the book. Over the past 12 years, dozens of medical specialists have informed her that she has the flu, drug allergies, mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus, a gallbladder problem and even food poisoning.

title: Reliance Group Hints of Bankruptcy Filing
description: Reliance Group Holdings, the insurer controlled by the financier Saul Steinberg, said yesterday that it probably would not be able to repay $735.1 million of debt maturing at the end of the month and might seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Giants Rookie Still Confident Despite Muffs
description: Just a week ago, there were times Ron Dixon literally skipped back to the Giants' huddle.

title: Unilever Names U.S. Chief Executive
description: Unilever N.V., the giant maker of food and soap products, named Charles Strauss as president and chief executive of the company's United States operations yesterday.

title: Frantic Russian Effort To Rescue Crew of Sub
description: A Russian submarine plunged to the seabed in the Barents Sea on Sunday during a naval exercise, possibly after an explosion on board, officials said today.

title: Ellison Will Challenge for the America's Cup
description: Representatives for Larry Ellison, the chief executive officer of Oracle Corporation, officially announced yesterday his challenge for the America's Cup in New Zealand in 2003. Ellison, traveling in Europe, was unavailable for comment.

title: Mideast Peace Requires a Divided Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutthroats Galore but No Doctors in Sight
description: Oh, those wacky rich people and their colorful nicknames. The hero of the new TNT series ''Bull'' is the grandson of a prospering investment firm's founder. The grandfather, Robert Roberts, is so imperious, heartless and soulless he is called the Kaiser behind his back. The grandson, Robert Roberts III, is nicknamed Ditto. Even his friends call him that, which seems a misfortune serious enough to offset all the silver spoons positioned in his mouth at birth. Ditto is also not a bad word to describe this routine drama.

title: Gore and Lieberman Voice Populist Themes
description: Without even a nod to President Clinton, who delivered his valedictory speech to Democrats in Los Angeles tonight, Vice President Al Gore struck populist themes today in two appearances and pledged to ''stand up for what's right'' for the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKEY, THEODORE
description: BOOKEY-Theodore. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck George N. Abrahams, President

title: BANNER ADS STILL DOMINATE
description: AdRelevance, a division of Media Metrix, said in a report released yesterday that 97 percent of all Web sites still carried standard banner ads, even though more Web sites are carrying multiple types and sizes of online advertisements. The AdRelevance Rate Card and Ad Dimensions Report, which analyzed nonnegotiated rate card prices between January 2000 and June 2000 for banner and button advertisements on more than 400 sites, also found that rate card prices for standard banners have declined slightly in the last six months and that a majority of sites offer discounts on full banner rates. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: Cranberry Bog Settlement Draws Environmentalists' Fire
description: An agreement among state environmental officials and a politically prominent cranberry farmer is drawing mixed reviews, trumpeted by regulators as ''the largest settlement ever'' with someone who ran afoul of wetlands protection laws and scorned by environmental groups as a ''sellout.''

title: U.S. Agency Finds Steel Is Dumped By 8 Nations
description: A United States government trade agency ruled today that unfairly low-priced imports of construction steel from China, South Korea and other countries may be hurting American companies, although it cleared Japan and Russia of the accusation.

title: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: MUSCLE GROUPS; Stretching: Myths, Legends and Facts
description: Scientists have gained new insight into what happens when athletes stretch, but the actual advice handed out by coaches, trainers and even physicians is a hodgepodge of myths and outdated assumptions, according to an article in the August issue of The Physician and Sportsmedicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, LINDA
description: FOX-Linda. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses sincere condolences to our members, Joe and Gloria Fox, on the loss of their beloved daughter. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Tzion and Yerushalayim. Joel Felderman, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Collector Joins Artifacts Panel, Stirring Debate
description: The White House has touched off a furor in the rarified world of archaeology by announcing the appointmentof Shelby White, a wealthy New York collector of antiquities, to a seat on a government committee formed to help combat illicit international trade in such objects.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a crackdown on political dissent in China misstated the change in China's economic growth rate last year, when a slump contributed to unrest in parts of the country. The rate of growth dipped from about 8 percent to about 7 percent; it did not fall by 7 percent.

title: In France, originality means using tabletops to sell products.
description: SIEMENS, the German electronics giant, has reserved 8,000 of the choicest tables in France this summer.

title: A Jewish Museum Struggles to Be Born; Berlin's Efforts to Honor Lost Millions Are Mired in Dissent
description: The idea seemed simple, pleasing in its balance: bring the German capital back to Berlin 55 years after the fall of Hitler's Reich and mark that return with several major cultural projects commemorating, in different ways, the Holocaust and Germany's lost Jews.

title: Killer Virus Is Linked To Asian Flying Foxes
description: Researchers in Malaysia have confirmed a link between fruit bats and a recently discovered virus that killed more than 100 people last year and compelled authorities to slaughter roughly a million pigs.

title: A Reprehensible Whale Hunt
description: Over the years, Japanese whalers have killed thousands of whales in the name of scientific research. But this has merely been a cover for commercial whaling aimed at satisfying Japanese eating habits, in defiance of a 1986 moratorium on commercial whaling that Japan itself signed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPPO, PHILIP G. III
description: NAPPO-Philip G. III. 41, of Manhattan and Patterson, NY, passed away on August 12, 2000. Beloved husband of Elizabeth Hubbell Nappo. Loving son of Philip G. Nappo and the late Elsie Nappo. Cherished brother of Nancy Euchner, and dear uncle to Gregory, Richard and Marshall Euchner, and Lindsay and Samantha Stein. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, on Tuesday, August 15, 5:30-7:30 PM, with a service of Thanksgiving immediately following. There will be an additional viewing on Wednesday, August 16, from 5-6 PM, with funeral services immediately following at the Second Congregational Church of Greenwich, CT, 139 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. Contributions in his memory may be made to Tres Dias of Fairfield County, PO Box 2516, Danbury, CT 06813-2516.

title: Acupuncture Helps Some Quell Need For Cocaine
description: Acupuncture appears to help some cocaine addicts escape their dependence on the drug, according to a report published today by researchers at Yale University.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO LAY OFF 3,745 AT TRUCK UNIT
description: DaimlerChrysler's Freightliner unit said yesterday that it would lay off 3,745 United States and Canadian workers, or 19 percent of the total, as the truckmaker cuts production because of slower North American truck demand. Freightliner said the layoffs would be at plants in Portland, Ore., 770 workers; Cleveland, N.C., 1,304; Mount Holly, N.C., 825; Gastonia, N.C., 154; and St. Thomas, Ontario, 692. The United States cuts will start on Oct. 20 and the Canadian layoffs on Dec. 4. Freightliner expects North American heavy-truck sales to fall as much as 25 percent this year from 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, EDWARD
description: BRODSKY-Edward. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member Edward Brodsky. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Alisa Doctoroff, President

title: Algerian Arraigned in Explosives Smuggling Case
description: Mokhtar Haouari, an Algerian charged with helping a group trying to smuggle explosives into the United States, was arraigned in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday afternoon after arriving from Canada.

title: Fighting Oral Cancer, by Looking for It
description: At a recent visit for a periodic dental cleaning, my periodontist took a few extra minutes to examine the roof and floor of my mouth, upper reaches of my gums and my tongue for white or red patches that were possible signs of an oral cancer or precancer.

title: Trying to Keep Big Contributors in a Giving Mood
description: The party that closed a city block outside the restaurant Spago in Beverly Hills last night was not a fund-raiser, Democratic officials contended today. Nor was the reception for big-money donors at the Giorgio Armani boutique, they asserted. Nor was the late-night dessert reception with President Clinton for the party's most generous givers.

title: Bradley Urges His Delegates To Back Gore
description: In the last symbolic act of his failed presidential campaign, former Senator Bill Bradley released his 390 delegates to Vice President Al Gore today, telling them that ''Al Gore will stand for the things we fought for in our campaign, and he deserves our support.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, THOMAS E.
description: CURTIS-Thomas E. Real estate developer, banker, and founder of the Curtis Supermarket chain, died Friday of a stroke. Born in Boston, Mr. Curtis developed more than two million square feet of commercial space in Southeastern Massachusetts. He was a community leader and contributed greatly to a variety of charities. After losing his eldest son Tom Jr., an AllAmerican sailor at Georgetown University, Tom Sr. became active in promoting the GU Sailing Team with grants, gifts and scholarships. He also established an educational scholarship at St. Anselms College, the alma mater of his eldest daughter Kathleen, who died in 1993. Tom and his wife Marjorie resided in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and summered in Hingham, MA. Beloved husband of Marjorie E. (Pearce) Curtis. Loving father of Brian P. Curtis of Hingham, MA, Elizabeth A. Curtis of New York, NY, Dianne M. Curtis of Hingham, Sarah C. Hanlon of Hingham, and Jonathan P. Curtis of Hingham. Devoted brother of Mary, Richard, David, Alan, Jean, and Dorothy. Loving ''papa'' of 14 grandchildren. Funeral Mass in St. Paul's Church, Hingham, Wednesday, August 16, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lincoln Sailing Center, P.O. Box 492, Hingham, MA 02043.

title: Mixed Blood Makes Balkan Outcasts
description: Afrim and his family have been on the move through the ruins of their former country for three years now, often living apart, unable to find one place where they can live together safely. Victims of their mixed blood and their own mixed marriage, Afrim and Safeta are each half Albanian and half Serbian from Kosovo, as are their two children, Rina, 13, and Rron, 11.

title: Sunbeam to Sell Oster Unit As Quarterly Loss Widens
description: The Sunbeam Corporation, the maker of small appliances, posted a wider second-quarter loss today and said it would sell its Oster barber, beauty and animal-grooming products business. Shares of Sunbeam fell 16.7 percent.

title: The Big City; Accountability At Prisons Run Privately
description: WHEN inmates rampaged in 1995 at a privately run detention center for immigrants in Elizabeth, N.J., many critics said it demonstrated the dangers of letting corporations run prisons. In retrospect, though, you could draw a quite different conclusion.

title: Thoughts on Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Team From Bronx Rallies to Victory
description: A team from the Rolando Paulino Little League in the Bronx scored two runs in the fifth inning last night in rallying to beat Delaware, 2-1, and advance to today's semifinals of the East Regional Little League tournament in Bristol, Conn.

title: A Daily Rhythm, a Lifetime Passion
description: After first light, though not by much, the encampment of archaeologists wakes to the cooing of doves in the pines, the barking of dogs and the early call to prayer from a mosque down the valley.

title: MORE INVESTORS GO ONLINE
description: The number of households investing online has risen sharply since January 1999, a new survey by J.D. Power & Associates shows. And more of those households are shopping around -- the number with accounts at more than one brokerage has surged.

title: A Correction: Eugene R. Black
description: Eugene R. Black, an investment banker, government adviser and Off Broadway playwright, who died at 75 on April 21. He is shown in New York in 1963. A picture of his late father, also Eugene R. Black, appeared erroneously with his obituary on Thursday.

title: Thoughts on Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Police and Demonstrators Clash Outside Convention Hall
description: The long-awaited dance between protesters and the police turned into a violent confrontation tonight when some in the audience at a concert outside the Staples Center threw rocks and bottles at officers, who responded by firing rubber-coated bullets and pepper spray at the demonstrators and moved in on horseback to disperse them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STYNES, CHRISTOPHER PETER
description: STYNES-Christopher Peter. Of Little Neck, died peacefully in his sleep at home on Sunday, August 13, at the age of 46. Loving husband of Diane, father of Ian and Danielle Stynes, son of Brendan and the late Rosalie Stynes, brother of Jim and Frank. Visitation will be Wednesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at Fairchild's in Manhasset, and funeral services Thursday, 10 AM, at St. Anastasia's Church in Douglaston. Chris, we will always love you and miss you.

title: Torricelli, Chastened, Acts as Unifier
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, in perhaps the most improbable speech of his two-decade career, conceded today to New Jersey delegates who are here for the Democratic National Convention that he had misjudged their support in trying to usurp James E. McGreevey's place as the party's likely candidate for governor next year.

title: Like His Father, Jesse Jackson Jr. Raises Voice for the Left
description: At Democratic conventions past, the Rev. Jesse Jackson wrote a compelling piece of the story line. The 1988 convention in Atlanta, for instance, was consumed with the question of how warmly Mr. Jackson would embrace Michael S. Dukakis, who had defeated him in the primaries.

title: VITAL SIGNS: NUTRITION; A Menu for Fighting Rickets Resurgence
description: Infants being fed with breast milk only, particularly black infants, should be given vitamin D supplements, according to a study that reports a resurgence in cases of rickets, a bone-weakening condition caused by a deficiency of the vitamin.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHALLOP, ARTHUR
description: SCHALLOP-Arthur. Of N. Bellmore, NY, passed away on August 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Arlene, devoted father of Larry, Amy and Steven. Cherished ''Poppy'' of Amanda and Benji Schallop and Emily, Noah and Moriah Greenstein. Brother of Robert Schallop. Our love for you and the treasured memories we shared shall be in our hearts forever. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM on August 15 at Gutterman's Chapel, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTER, RUTH
description: GARTER-Ruth. beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of Larry, Myrna, the late Mitchell and their spouses, Carolyn, Stewart and Pearl. Cherished grandmother of Bonnie and Fred, Mindy and Aaron, Adam and Lisa, David, Robyn, Liza and Russell. Greatgrandmother of Scott, Jonathan, Matthew & Michael. Adored sister and aunt. Services, ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30 PM, Tuesday.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Beyond the Pain of Gastric Reflux
description: A new article in The Annals of Internal Medicine reports an association between drugs that have a side effect of allowing gastric reflux and the rates of a rare but deadly kind of gastric cancer whose incidence has been on the rise.

title: 2 More in Iran Are Detained In Crackdown On the Press
description: The crackdown on reformers in Iran continued over the weekend with the detention of two writers. A popular satirist, Ibrahim Nabavi, and a newspaper columnist, Mohammad Qoochani, were interrogated by a hard-line court and detained.

title: Seeing Clearly
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIANCE GAMING TO SELL UNITED COIN MACHINE UNIT
description: The Alliance Gaming Corporation, whose shares have plunged 69 percent in the last year, agreed yesterday to sell its United Coin Machine unit to an investment group for $118 million in cash and preferred stock to reduce debt. The UC Acquisition Company of Nevada L.L.C., a closely held partnership of Michael S. Luzich and an Iowa-based group led by Daniel Kehl, will pay $112 million in cash and $6 million in preferred stock that will be redeemed over a five-year period. Both Alliance and UC Acquisition are based in Las Vegas.

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; A Hernia Repair Job That Lasts Longer
description: Using mesh to repair hernias that result from surgery is more effective than repairing them with stitches, according to a Dutch study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: The Secrets of Croesus' Gold; Archaeologists Learn How Ancient King Made His Money, Literally
description: In the ruins of Sardis, capital of the Lydians of yore, archaeologists are striving to separate fact from legend, seeking glimpses of what it meant in antiquity to be ''rich as Croesus.'' But they are also finding much more: monumental remains of the passage of time and fortune for a major city under subsequent Persian, Greek, Roman and Byzantine rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, WALLACE H.
description: MILLER-Wallace H. On August 12, 2000, loving husband of Patricia Ann Miller, beloved father of Sharon G. Miller and Robert J. Miller, cherished grandfather of Isaac Stryker and Elliot Stryker, loving brother of Phoebe Rothkopf. Contributions in his memory may be made to The ALS Association, 27001 Agoura Road, Suite 150, Calabasas Hills, CA 91301-5104. For information contact Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, New Jersey, 201-843-9090.

title: First Union to Sell Credit Card Business
description: Taking steps to reverse two years of profit declines, the First Union Corporation said today that it would sell its credit card business to the MBNA Corporation and take a $1 billion pretax gain as a result.

title: Another Title for Bridge Pair
description: One of the world's great bridge partnerships captured yet another title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Sunday night. Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, a charismatic star originally from Pakistan, won the Life Master Pairs with Michael Rosenberg of Wykagyl, N.Y., a Scotsman reputed to be the best technician in the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, ABRAHAM
description: TWERSKY-Abraham, 92. Of West Orange, New Jersey. Formerly of The Bronx, New York. Beloved husband of the late Anna (nee Bernstein) and the late Isabelle (nee Arsham). Devoted father of Naomi Zahurak & David Twersky. Loving brother of the late Yochanan Twersky. Cherished grandfather of Suzanne, Michael, John, Gary, Richard, Michael and Anna. Adored great-grandfather of Daniel, Hannah, Skiler, & Christopher. Services will be held at the Bernheim, Apter Goldsticker Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey, today, August 15, at 1:30 P.M.

title: Bush's Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, SAMUEL J.
description: KOHL-Samuel J. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the family our heartfelt smpathy. David H. Lincoln, Sr. Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: INTERNET TRAVEL MERGER
description: A British Internet seller of short-notice travel and entertainment, Lastminute.com P.L.C., agreed to buy Degriftour Group, a French Web retailer of air tickets and packaged tours, for $:58.9 million ($88.4 million) in cash and stock. Lastminute said the purchase would help it become profitable as soon as 2003, a year earlier than previously expected. It will pay $:27.1 million in cash and issue 19.7 million new shares, valued at $:31.8 million at Friday's closing price. The two-year-old Lastminute, which is based in London, has Web sites in French, German and Swedish and plans to start a Spanish one.

title: Sports of The Times; Flag Issue Needs Help Of Athletes
description: IN January 1994, when the Confederate flag issue was beginning to percolate, a group of about 20 sportswriters covering Super Bowl XXVIII in Atlanta decided to be part of a solution, not the problem. We planned an impromptu, low-key demonstration to protest the presence of the Confederate flag outside the Georgia Dome. There was something irksome about having to walk back and forth with those stars and bars waving overhead.

title: In Japan, What's on the Plate Is Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the most difficult days of the last years, when we faced the toughest issues -- of war and peace, of taking on powerful special interests -- he was always there.''

title: Metro Business; 60 Broad Street Sells For $156.5 Million
description: The Lend Lease Corporation and Cogswell Realty Group have acquired a downtown Manhattan building for $156.5 million, two years after it sold for $62 million.

title: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Moves on Sierra Leone

title: Bush to Pardon Inmate After New DNA Tests
description: Gov. George W. Bush said today that he would pardon a Texas inmate convicted a decade ago of rape, after new DNA evidence convinced even prosecutors and law enforcement officials that the man should be freed.

title: 10 Nations to Build One Giant Telescope
description: Astronomers have signed an agreement to build a radio telescope that would, in effect, be 100 times as large as today's largest.

title: Rethink Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter's Reappearance And Barbra's Hospitality
description: Four years ago, Jimmy Carter conspicuously avoided the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. His relationship with the incumbent presidential candidate, Bill Clinton, was testy. Put bluntly, the two former Southern governors were both competitive and uneasy with each other. ''I've always had good relations with Vice President Gore,'' said Mr. Carter, picking his words carefully as he spoke over a cellular phone yesterday afternoon from a limousine as he rode to a reception.

title: PECO ENERGY TO BUY STAKE IN VIVENDI POWER UNIT
description: The Peco Energy Company, owner of Philadelphia's electric utility, agreed yesterday to buy 49.9 percent of the North American power plant unit of Vivendi S. A. for $680 million. Vivendi's Sithe Energies Inc. owns generators in New York, New Jersey, Maine and Massachusetts. Its 27 plants produce about 3,800 megawatts of electricity. Peco, which is merging with the Unicom Corporation of Chicago, is expanding to offset revenue lost after regulators ended its monopoly in eastern Pennsylvania. Vivendi is selling the power plant stake to focus its utility business on supplying water and hauling trash.

title: As Peace Plan Falters, Sri Lanka's War Has No End in Sight
description: This war-haunted nation's president, blinded in her right eye by a suicide bomber's attack, still talks of peace. But many ordinary Sri Lankans are more convinced than ever that no end to the country's 17-year conflict with the Tamil rebels is near.

title: GERMAN BANK WILL NOT OFFER CASH
description: Germany's second-largest bank, HypoVereinsbank A.G., said it would call off its stock bid of 7.7 billion euros ($7 billion) for Bank Austria A.G. if Austria's takeover commission orders it to make a cash offer to compensate minority shareholders. The commission, which can block what would be Austria's biggest acquisition, is examining whether the proposed transaction complies with a law requiring most investors buying more than 30 percent of a publicly traded Austrian company to bid for all the shares and provide a cash alternative. HypoVereinsbank's chairman, Albrecht Schmidt, sought to acquire Bank Austria to strengthen his bank's position in central and eastern Europe.

title: Editorial Observer; In L.A., Mrs. Clinton Is Ready for Her Close-Up
description: The setting for the Clinton rally in Hollywood Sunday afternoon was more reminiscent of the first couple's Arkansas past than their New York future. It was the small-town Main Street created for the Sony Pictures Studio, a place where Hillary Rodham Clinton slipped somewhat too easily into her old supporting role as first lady. After more than a year of establishing her own political identity in New York, with only five months to go in the Clinton presidency, she was once again doing her dutiful first lady act, performing a downbeat opening routine for her highly oratorical husband.

title: Not Far From Home, Pettitte Rules Rangers
description: Andy Pettitte ambled into the clubhouse this afternoon and saw about a dozen of his teammates watching the movie ''American Pie.'' Pettitte glanced at the screen once and then retreated to his locker.

title: Skulduggery And Satire On the Good Ship Peking
description: It's a stunning moment, at the end of the Gorilla Repertory Theater's production of ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' staged outdoors on a three-masted ship docked at the South Street Seaport, when an effigy of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is pitched summarily overboard.

title: Accounts
description: Office.com, New York, a unit of Winstar Communications, a Web site that offers content and services to small businesses, to the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle advertising, which had been at Cliff Freeman & Partners , New York, and Darwin Digital, New York, part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. Billings were estimated at $30 million. Eric Jones, a spokesman at Office.com, confirmed a report of the decision this week in Adweek.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about controversy over the reporting of ABC's consumer and environmental correspondent, John Stossel, misspelled the surname of a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute who has defended Mr. Stossel. The defender is Walter Olson, not Olsen.

title: Seeing Pessimism's Place in a Smiley-Faced World
description: Dr. Barbara Held has had just about enough of accentuating the positive and eliminating the negative.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, FRED
description: FRIEDMAN-Fred. We had so many great days, just not enough years. Love, Linda, Erik and Adam

title: Flight 800 Report to Show No Exact Cause
description: Four years after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off the coast of Long Island, the National Transportation Safety Board is preparing to approve an unusual final report on the crash, one that will identify only the penultimate cause.

title: Toys 'R' Us Profit Is Down By 75% in Second Quarter
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the largest United States toy chain, said today that fiscal second-quarter profit fell 75 percent on declining sales in its United States stores and a loss at its Internet division.

title: Democrats Hopeful in a Washington Race
description: It might be a stretch to say that Washington Democrats are paying rapt attention to next month's primary for United States senator, in which the state insurance commissioner, Deborah Senn, and former United States Representative Maria Cantwell, now a wealthy Internet executive promoting her experience in the ''new economy,'' are battling for the right to take on the three-term Republican incumbent, Slade Gorton.

title: Scientists Watch Cities Make Their Own Weather
description: Atlanta is so big and hot that it makes its own weather, and scientists have the pictures to prove it.

title: HEICO TO SELL TRILECTRON UNIT TO ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS
description: The Heico Corporation, which provides parts and services to aircraft and aerospace companies, agreed yesterday to sell its Trilectron Industries unit to Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $52.5 million in cash. It will also assume about $4.3 million of long-term debt for the business, which Heico acquired in 1996. Heico said it expected to report a gain of $9 million to $11 million in its fourth quarter from the transaction. Illinois Tool Works, based in Glenview, Ill., had sales of $9.3 billion in 1999. Shares of Heico, based in Hollywood, Fla., rose 43.75 cents, to $17. Illinois Tool shares fell $1.0625, to $58.1875.

title: Leaky Basement Pipe Blamed in Blast That Killed Three in Brooklyn
description: The gas explosion that leveled one town house, destroyed a neighboring one and killed three people in Brooklyn last month was probably primed by a leaky pipe in the first house's basement and ignited by someone flipping a light switch, fire marshals said yesterday.

title: Article 2000081592863811711 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIOTT, SISTER MARIAN FRANCIS
description: HARRIOTT-Sister Marian Francis. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity for 50 years, died on August 14, 2000, at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. An educator for many years, Sister taught for 23 years in the parochial school system and for 20 years in the Yonkers Public School System. Her giftedness as a teacher of English and drama was recognized when she was awarded the coveted PTA Jenkins Memorial Award in 1994. A graduate of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, Sister Francis had a Masters of Fine Arts degree from Catholic University, as well as a Master's Degree in Drama Media and Technology from the New School of Social Research. Contributions in lieu of flowers in Sister Francis' name can be made to the Retirement Fund of the Sisters of Charity, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Reposing at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY (one block north of Tuckahoe Road) on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass at Sacred Heart Church, 1110 Shonnard Place, Yonkers, NY, on Thursday at 10:30 AM. Interment at Kensico Cemetery.

title: In Summer, Italy Loves Sex Surveys; It's Just Talk
description: The peak of summer, Italian-style, was reached in banner headlines in several of today's leading newspapers, which rated beach resorts by the likelihood of vacationers' having sex there.

title: Thoughts on Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Glittery Scene, Much Nothing About a Do
description: Everybody wanted to go behind the scenes today at the Democratic National Convention, at least during the long hours before President Clinton's address. (Tom Brokaw described it as ''the political equivalent of Elvis's last concert.'')

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATERMAN, WILLIAM B.
description: WATERMAN-William B., Dr. Age 82, of Southern Pines, North Carolina, formerly of New York City and West Hartford, Connecticut died Saturday at his home due to complications from leukemia. His family mourns the loss of a beloved husband and caring father. Dr. Waterman is survived by his wife, Marjorie; a sister, Marianna Shepard of Essex, CT; children, Suzanne Kathryn Lijek of Arlington, MA, Laura Stagg Jackson of Hinesburg, VT, Richard William Waterman of Sudbury, MA and Guy Randall Schultz of Boca Raton, FL and seven grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Patricia Thompson Waterman. Dr. Waterman was graduated from St. George's School, Harvard University ('41) and the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University. After discharge from the army as a Captain in the Medical Corp and a residency at Roosevelt Hospital, he practiced internal medicine in New York from 1950 to 1963. From 1963 until 1980 he was Associate Medical Director of Aetna Life in Hartford, CT. Dr. Waterman was a Fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine and a member of the American Medical Association, the Hospital Graduates Club, the New York Academy of Sciences and the New York, Connecticut and Hartford County Medical Societies. A private service will be held at Swan Point Cemetery in Providence at an unspecified date.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, a National Stage To Promote a Candidate, or Two
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton celebrated her husband's years in office and proclaimed her faith in Al Gore to an audience of thousands of cheering Democrats tonight. She also used the moment to advance her bid for the Senate as she luxuriated in a level of attention unimaginable for a candidate conducting her first campaign for public office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINBERG, SYLVIA WEINSTOCK
description: WEINBERG - Sylvia Weinstock. July 30, 1913-August 15, 1993. Dear Mom, we think of you and miss you every day. Love forever. Gail and Lauri

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, LAWRENCE CHASE
description: BROWNE-Lawrence Chase. On August 13th, 2000, of Brooklyn, New York, and Belle Terre, Long Island. Beloved husband of Deborah (nee Hatfield). Loving son of Dorothy C. Browne. Cherished father of Erica W. Grivas, Dorothy M. Browne, and Jennifer R. Browne. Mr. Browne was a partner of Maloof and Browne of New York City. Donations may be made to The Arthur Ashe New York Junior Tennis League of Long Island City or The Jose Carreras Leukemia Foundation of Seattle. Reposing at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, 4839 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, Long Island. Visiting Friday 7-9. Funeral service Saturday, 12 noon at O.B. Davis. Cremation private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUREVITCH, FANNIE
description: GUREVITCH-Fannie. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of Fannie Gurevitch, sister of our esteemed Rabbi Emeritus, Judah Nadich. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Sr. Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, BERNICE D.
description: ELKIN-Bernice D. On August 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David Elkin. Loving mother of Faith Bobrow and Eileen Gilbert & their husbands, Philip and Jerry. Adored grandmother of Emily, Amanda, Diane, Rachael & David. Loving sister-in-law of Ruth Muss. Bernice Elkin was an extraordinary woman, a true teacher who taught by the examples of righteousness, charity and goodness. She will truly be missed by all of us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, CHARLES
description: JACOBS-Charles. Loving husband of Geri and devoted father to Lisa, Jeff and Christine. Survivor of the Holocaust. In our hearts forever. Funeral services on August 15th, 10 AM, Parkside Funeral Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Holocaust Museum, Battery Park City, New York.

title: Liberty Makes No Mistake This Time
description: As the Liberty's lead mounted last night against the Washington Mystics, Tari Phillips's mind churned back to Game 1 in their Women's National Basketball Association playoff series. The Liberty squandered an 18-point lead on Saturday before converting to a zone defense to confound the Mystics and escape with a victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LEAH
description: GOLDBERG-Leah. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Leo Goldberg upon the loss of his mother, Mrs. Leah Goldberg. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, WERNER A.R.
description: SCHUSTER-Werner A.R. Of West Islip, Long Island, on August 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Veronica Deloach, Stephan Schuster and the late Werner H. (Butch) Schuster. Dear brother of Carmen Dehner, Reinhard Schuster and Manfred Schuster. Proud grandfather of Alexis and Dan Jr. Kind father-inlaw of Dan Deloach Sr. Reposing at the Frederick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Causeway). Funeral Service Saturday 12:30 PM, St. Luke's Lutheran Church, Bay Shore, Long Island. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, Long Island. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Designs Are All Suited Up, But May Have Nowhere to Go
description: Marisa Acocella is a 30-something cartoonist for The New Yorker, whose subjects are often those size-zero women you see writhing in their Pradas amid the suburban style-moochers and aging Seventh Avenue designers in the mock-bistro coziness of Pastis. In other words, Ms. Acocella understands fashion even as she reviles it. She understands, for example, that suits are back in fashion, and that many women, possibly even she herself, will want to wear one, but she rejects the conventional reasons -- power, glamour, a sense of security -- being given in the fashion world.

title: The Greatest Player Nobody Knows
description: ''Why do you want to interview me?'' Todd Helton asked. ''I'm not that interesting of a person.''

title: GROUP TO ANNOUNCE QUANTUM COMPUTER
description: An I.B.M. physicist plans to announce today that his San Jose, Calif.-based research group has succeeded in developing an advanced quantum computer. The device, composed of five computing elements, or ''quantum bits,'' is based on a molecule composed of five flourine atoms. The machine is still far from being able to perform useful real-world calculations, the company said. Still, the prototype developed by Isaac L. Chaung of I.B.M. and a group of researchers at the University of Calgary is able to solve in one step a mathematical problem that requires repeated cycles in conventional computers. John Markoff (NYT)

title: EIEIHOME.COM TO BUY WIRELESS STOCK XCHANGE
description: EieiHome.com Inc., a provider of home-buying information over the Internet, agreed yesterday to buy the Wireless Stock Xchange Inc. for about $255.8 million in stock to add services for refurbishing cellular phones. EieiHome.com will exchange 33 million shares for all of Wireless Stock Xchange's shares. Wireless Stock Xchange shareholders will have a 67 percent controlling interest in eieiHome.com, which will change its name to the Wireless Stock Xchange Inc. The closely held Wireless Stock Xchange buys cell phones and other wireless equipment from a nonprofit foundation. It plans to refurbish the devices and sell them. The shares of the New York-based EieiHome.com doubled to $7.75 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARDINALI, MARY T.
description: CARDINALI-Mary T. August 15. Dearest, sweetest mother, we think of you, talk of you, love you. Forever with us. Barbara, Morty, Elise, Hilton

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Israeli politican and diplomat Eliahu Ben-Elissar yesterday omitted two survivors. They are a brother, Nathan Gottlieb of Englewood, N.J., and a sister, Diane Weinstock of Denver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'REILLY, SISTER MARY JOSEPH, O. CARM
description: O'REILLY-Sister Mary Joseph, O. Carm. On August 13, 2000 in her 89th year. Native of Louisburg, County Mayo, Ireland. Over 50 years of devoted service with The Carmelite Sisters For The Aged And Infirm. Survived by brother, Patrick, in England, nephews, Rev. John Collins, CSP, James Collins, Rev. Michael Hunt, CSP, David Hunt, and niece, Ann C. Hunt, three grand nephews and two grand nieces. Reposing at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue (at 72nd Street) Wednesday from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:30 A.M. at Holy Family Chapel, Mary Manning Walsh Home. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. For further information contact the John Krtil Funeral Home at 212-744-3084.

title: Inquiries Find Little Abuse By Tax Agents
description: Two years ago, Congress, warned in hearings that the Internal Revenue Service was bullying many innocent Americans, passed a law requiring that the agency fire workers who harassed taxpayers.

title: Gawrsh! Goofy and Elmo Are Wanted for Robbery
description: In a sign that nothing in New York is free of a Disney influence these days, Goofy is on the lam, wanted for a break-in robbery in the Bronx. And the bumbling, buck-toothed character has an accomplice, either Elmo of Sesame Street or Dr. Seuss's Grinch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAYSTMAN, FRIEDA
description: TRAYSTMAN-Frieda. Of NYC, NY. Died August 13, 2000. Retired from Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCoy. Survived by loving nieces Kathy Traystman and Martha Welch, and sister-in-law Helen Traystman. Private arrangements by family. Donations in her memory to The Ivan L. Rubin Foundation, Inc, 160 West 16th Street, New York, New York 10011.

title: 2 Arrested in Bloomberg Extortion Case
description: On March 24, a strange e-mail message popped up on the computers at the Bloomberg corporate offices in New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Stage Late Rally As Concerns Ease on Rates

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee fell on concern that high inventories in the United States are overwhelming demand from processors. In New York, coffee for September delivery fell 1.85 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 78.8 cents a pound.

title: Clinton's Address to Party: Extolling 8 Years of Change in America
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: A Peanut Butter Is Reintroduced
description: M& M/Mars, part of Mars Inc., said yesterday that it was reintroducing the TWIX Peanut Butter brand, bringing it back after three years. Shipments to retailers will begin this month.

title: Profits Surge at Big British Advertising Firm
description: WPP Group, which will become the world's largest advertising firm with its acquisition of Young & Rubicam Inc., reported a surge in profits and revenue today and forecast that the boom in advertising spending would last through the end of the year, buoyed by the Olympics and the presidential election in the United States.

title: Churning Out the Proteins
description: This is the machine that makes proteins.

title: Partying Puts Squeeze On Speechwriting
description: President Clinton delivered seven speeches before he finally delivered the speech that brought him here. But the president, who has delivered so many famously long and unedited speeches and rarely let small things like an official schedule get in his way, had to start canceling events because he had not left time to actually finish the Big Address.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Safer Nuclear Waste

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about murals in Northern Ireland that reflect the conflict between Catholics and Protestants misidentified the guerrilla group that killed Billy Wright, a Protestant commando who is honored in one mural. It was the Irish National Liberation Army, not the Irish Republican Army.

title: In Assembly Race, Power of Incumbency Vies With a Household Name
description: After years of unsuccessful campaigns in the rough-and-tumble politics of East Harlem, usually losing by a hair, Nelson Antonio Denis finally won a seat in the Assembly in 1996. Establishing himself as a reformer and an articulate debater, he coasted easily to re-election two years later.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DROPS. The yen fell against the dollar after Japan said corporate bankruptcies rose for a ninth consecutive month in July. In New York, the dollar settled at 109.51 yen, up from 108.69 on Friday.

title: Negotiators in Telephone Strike Make Little Progress
description: In the ninth day of the 12-state strike against Verizon Communications, negotiators made little progress yesterday as unions and the company debated the effect on workers of the recent merger that made Verizon the nation's largest telecommunications employer.

title: CLINTON, OPENING CONVENTION, SAYS GORE WILL PROTECT LEGACY
description: President Clinton savored what he called ''this moment of unprecedented good fortune'' and, in a nostalgic valedictory tonight, implored Americans to protect his achievements by electing Al Gore to succeed him.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: An Artist Honored By Man and Beast

title: A Ranger, Ledee Still Misses New York
description: Ricky Ledee wept and could not sleep after the Yankees traded him to the Cleveland Indians for David Justice six weeks ago, ending an association with the organization that he had loved since he was 16 years old. Since the fateful night, Ledee was traded a second time, to the Texas Rangers on July 28.

title: Elliott Returns to the Field
description: Jumbo Elliott went through his first practice with the Jets today since surgery last March.

title: Host of Party That Wasn't Won't Speak at Convention
description: Representative Loretta Sanchez withdrew today as a featured speaker at the Democratic National Convention, saying that her clash last week with party leaders over her plan to hold a fund-raiser at the Playboy mansion had already focused ''too much press'' on her and the party.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: BROADCOM BUYING NEWPORT IN STOCK DEAL
description: In the latest of a series of takeover bids, Broadcom agreed yesterday to acquire the chip maker NewPort Communications. Broadcom will issue about 5.5 million shares of its Class A common stock in exchange for all outstanding shares of NewPort, which is privately held. The deal was worth about $1.32 billion based on Broadcom's closing price yesterday of $240.75, up $15.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, PAUL M.
description: BERNSTEIN-Paul M. 1929-1990. With much love and enduring respect, we remember our founding partner, Paul M. Bernstein on the 10th anniversary of his untimely passing. Paul's dedication to the practice of law at the highest professional level inspired so many people. His spirit lives on in those of us who were privileged to know him. The Partners of Bernstein Litowitz Berger & Grossmann LLP

title: Technology Puts Gridlock To Business Use; Fancy Cars and Gadgets Help Keep Road Rage at Bay
description: When he is planning his workweek, Jared L. Gurfein, a Manhattan lawyer, arranges some of his most important conferences not for an office or lunch appointment, but for bumper-to-bumper traffic.

title: JENNY CRAIG SHARES FALL AS FOUNDERS WITHDRAW OFFER
description: Shares of Jenny Craig, the weight-management company, fell sharply yesterday after the company said on Friday that Craig Enterprises, a company formed by its founders, Sid and Jenny Craig, had withdrawn its offer to acquire the company at $3.75 a share. On the New York Stock Exchange, the shares of the company, based in La Jolla, Calif., were down $1.0625, to $1.875. Craig Enterprises said it had withdrawn the offer because of a substantial decline in sales and pretax income from Jenny Craig's Australian operations since the offer was made. Craig Enterprises said it was considering whether to make a new proposal in view of this development.

title: BANKRUPTCIES SURGE IN JAPAN
description: The number of corporate bankruptcies in Japan rose 21.4 percent in July from a year earlier, to 1,617 cases, with a record debt of 4.26 trillion yen, or about $39 billion, according to Teikoku Databank, a Tokyo-based credit research organization. The figures reflected the collapse of a department store chain, the Sogo Company and its affiliates, which contributed nearly $27 billion, or 69 percent of the total amount of debt, said Teikoku. Company failures could grow even faster, especially in light of the decision by the Bank of Japan last week to guide short-term interest rates higher for the first time in a decade. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: TAIWAN GROWTH SLOWS
description: Taiwan's economy posted growth in the second quarter that was slower than expected as a sliding stock market crimped domestic consumption, import growth accelerated and government spending fell. Gross domestic product grew 5.4 percent from a year earlier, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said. That lagged the government's earlier forecast of 5.5 percent and the 6.2 percent expected by economists. In the first quarter, the economy grew 7.9 percent. The government also lowered its full-year growth forecast to 6.6 percent from 6.7 percent.

title: Valhalla Will Be Harder for P.G.A.
description: When Valhalla Golf Club played host to its first major championship, the weather was hot, but the course received lukewarm reviews. That was in 1996, when Mark Brooks won the P.G.A. Championship by one stroke over Kenny Perry -- two solid players, but hardly legends. Meanwhile, the course was criticized for being too easy, with 46 players finishing under par.

title: New Confidence Is Fueling Thompson
description: Four years ago, Jenny Thompson entered the United States Olympic swimming trials as an overwhelming favorite, only to see her hopes for the Atlanta Games capsized by waves of stress and self-doubt.

title: Party's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern Daylight

title: NYT Article
description: I.B.M. Says It Will Offer Computers With Red Hat's Linux Software

title: Frieda Hardin, 103; Inspired Military Women
description: Frieda Mae Hardin, who joined the Navy during World War I, when women were still denied the right to vote, and at a widely noted ceremony 79 years later symbolized the achievements of all the women in the armed forces, died last Wednesday in Livermore, Calif. She was 103.

title: Chiron to Acquire PathoGenesis for $700 Million
description: Seeking to bolster its portfolio of products, the Chiron Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $700 million in cash to acquire the PathoGenesis Corporation, a developer of antibiotics. Chiron will pay $38.50 a share, almost 18 percent higher than the PathoGenesis closing price of $32.75 on Friday.

title: Once Again, Lucas Gets Nod to Pull the Jets Through
description: Quarterback Ray Lucas, the original survivor, went back to leading the Jets today. Just as he did during the second half of last season. Just as he will do Friday night against the Giants. And, if Vinny Testaverde does not recover quickly from an injury, just as he might do in the Jets' season opener against the Packers at Green Bay in three weeks.

title: Nervously Battling Nonstop Flight Phobias
description: ON the phone, now: Carol Cott Gross, who runs the self-help group Fly Without Fear and who has called to say it's been a tough summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, BURTON
description: BERNARD-Burton. Loyal husband of 58 years to his devoted wife Norma. Beloved father of Harold, Cathy and Mitchell. Loving grandfather of Nicole, Molly, Alex, Bradley, Jake, Amanda and Hannah. He was a wonderful man. Loved by all who had the good fortune to know him. We will miss him forever. Services Wednesday, 11:00 AM at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

title: Warn Africa On Diamond Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Djibouti Journal; Somalia's 'Hebrews' See a Better Day
description: The sultan of the Jews in Somalia is a handsome, silver-haired man named Ahmed Jama Hersi who does not know the first thing about Judaism. He is a Muslim, as were his ancestors back at least 800 years. But he and his people are treated badly, cursed as descendants of Israelites. The name of the tribe is Yibir, or Hebrew.

title: ALLIANCE NEWS LIFTS AKAMAI
description: Akamai Technologies shares rose 13 percent yesterday, to $71.375, after the company signed an alliance with Intertainer, the entertainment-on-demand broadband network based in Culver City, Calif., to broadcast movies and video over the Internet to personal computers with high-speed Internet connections. The companies said that the service would be widely available by the end of the year. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, HERMAN
description: TUCKER-Herman. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with deep sorrow the death of Herman Tucker, beloved father of our distinguished board member Rabbi Gordon Tucker of Temple Israel Center, White Plains. Throughout his life, Mr. Tucker was dedicated to his family and the Jewish people throughout the world. We extend our sincere sympathy to his children, Rabbi Tucker and Amy Cohen, and Dr. Toby Tucker Hecht and Barry Hecht; his sister Sylvia Rosencranz; grandchildren Ethan, Ariela, Becky, Michal, Spencer, and Jonathan; and all the members of the family. May his memory endure as a blessing. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRTH, MORRIS A.
description: WIRTH-Morris A. Surrounded by his wife Jean, sons Bob, Billy, and John, passed away peacefully on the morning of Saturday, August 12, after a brave battle with cancer. He was 76. In addition he is survived by his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, as well as Vasilia Hughes, and his most cherished grandson Alec. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and a prominent lawyer who represented Israeli interests in the U.S. for more than 35 years, Morris lived to help others. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, Tuesday, August 15, at the Park Avenue Christian Church/ Universal Synagogue, 1010 Park Ave. Friends are also welcome at the interment service Tuesday at 3 PM, at the Westhampton Cemetery. ''So many dear friends-well wishers whose prayers will help and whose support of Jean and the kids is my greatest comfort.''

title: De Beers Mining Buys Winspear Diamonds in Canada
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African giant of the global diamond industry, won control of a promising diamond company in Canada today, agreeing to its demands for a higher price after a seven-week takeover struggle.

description: Remember scab football? Remember the fun? Those golden moments? The talent? The dignity?

title: STATIC LINGERS ON EBAY
description: EBay, the largest Internet auction company, said the intermittent technical problems that have hampered its Web site for the last two weeks might continue for another 10 days. The company posted an apology for the problems on the site, explaining that they stemmed from a system upgrade that eBay began Aug. 2. The problems caused some features to be inaccessible and others to function slowly. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

description: GlobalWorks.com in New York and Liquid Digital Information Systems in New York, said yesterday that they had merged to form GlobalWorks in New York, a branding and communications consultancy. Terms were not disclosed.

title: News Corporation to Pay $5.3 Billion for Chris-Craft
description: The News Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, which owns 10 television stations, for about $85 a share in stock and cash.

title: Bound by Belief
description: Not all evangelical Protestants take their political signals from the organized religious right, but the majority do vote Republican. The entry of Senator Joseph Lieberman into Campaign 2000 won't change that, but it has brought to light some surprising interplays between orthodox Jews and evangelicals. And it has made Jews, who altogether make up only 2 percent of the population, and evangelicals, who approach 25 percent, the two most visible groups on the scene of religion and politics.

title: Metro Business; SBC Wants Out of Cable
description: SBC Communications Inc. has asked Connecticut regulators to let it shut down its cable television business in the state, where it has 30,000 customers in 26 cities and towns.

title: Safety Commission Recalls 91,000 Go-Karts After One Death and Two Injuries
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that about 91,000 motorized recreational carts were being recalled for safety reasons and that people who had them should stop using them immediately.

description: To the Editor:

title: Michael S. Reynolds, Biographer Whose Career Was Hemingway, Dies at 63
description: Michael S. Reynolds, the author of a five-volume biography of Ernest Hemingway, died on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEET, EMANUEL (''MANNY'')
description: SWEET - Emanuel (''Manny''). The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member Manny Sweet. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his dear wife, June Sweet, and to all his family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Norman Zirkin, President

title: Scientists Find New Method Of Producing Nerve Cells
description: Scientists have prodded bone marrow cells to turn into nerve cells, raising the tantalizing possibility of an easily accessible source of replacement cells to treat brain and nerve injuries and diseases.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Soros Fund Cuts Back Technology Stocks
description: The financier George Soros, as promised, sold his stake in a number of technology stocks in the second quarter.

title: TAX CUT IN ISRAEL
description: The Israeli government cut taxes on a wide range of consumer and capital goods in a move the finance minster, Avraham Shochat, said would help lower the country's rising tax burden. Mr. Shochat said at a news conference that a tax known as the purchase tax would be cut on 630 goods from rates that are now as high as 85 percent to as little as 5 percent. In some cases the tax will be eliminated altogether. The tax cut comes as the Israeli economy enjoys its fastest pace of growth since 1995, a development that has caused state tax revenue to soar 17 percent in the first seven months of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, EVELYN
description: PRESS-Evelyn. Beloved wife of Dr. Joseph H., loving mother of Dr. Robert A., Mark L., and Steven, cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Michelle, Alison, Carolyn, Alex and Julia. Services were held on August 14, 2000.

title: In Your Own Words -- Please
description: The terrifying report hopped from sky box to sky box like the West Nile virus: Al Gore was writing his own acceptance speech. Eek! cried the talking heads and the pundits. The speech will be dull, boring. It will be -- gasp -- specific.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMANSKY, HANNAH
description: LEMANSKY-Hannah. Age 89, at Deerfield Beach, FL. Survived by Jules, beloved husband for 64 years, son Edward (Ruth), daughter Susan (Joel) Agee, grandchildren Gina and Wendy, sister Henrietta Morgan.

title: Not All Water Damage Is Equal in Eyes of Insurers
description: The lucky ones in the flooded hamlets of northern New Jersey may turn out to be the people who suffered the most.

title: Digging for Satchmo's Roots In the City That Spawned Him
description: In this not-quite-centennial year of Louis Armstrong, there may not be a better way to see this city than through the eyes of his latest and perhaps most obsessive biographer, Tad Jones, a 48-year-old music writer and fifth-generation New Orleanian. It is a ghostly business, conjuring a legendary life and vanished landmarks from yellowed archives, shuttered ruins and renamed streets, but a labor of love for Mr. Jones, who is deep into the most exhaustive excavation yet of Armstrong's hometown roots and the influences that made him, in the reverent words of Bing Crosby, ''the beginning and the end of music in America.''

title: PORTUGAL VETOES CEMENT OFFER
description: The Portuguese government has rejected a Swiss-led bid to take over Portugal's largest cement company, Cimpor. The Swiss cement giant Holderbank and Portugal's second-biggest cement producer, Semapa-Sociedade de Investimento e Gestao, had offered to buy at least 67 percent of Cimpor for 4 billion euros ($3.61 billion), or 20.5 euros ($18.50) a share. As a condition for their offer, the bidders said the 10 percent limit on a single shareholder had to be lifted. The Portuguese Finance Minister, Joaquim Pina Moura, rejected the proposal late on Friday.

title: Setting an Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Leads Son Through Indian Complexities
description: The great Indian sarod player Ali Akbar Khan performed with his 18-year-old son, Alam Khan, at his concert at Damrosch Park as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival. Mr. Khan the son, sure and agile on the sarod, started giving public performances two years ago; Mr. Khan the father gave him what seemed like an extended lesson in Sunday night's concert.

title: INTEL TO SELL DIGITAL CAMERA
description: Intel plans to introduce a simple digital camera that will sell for $149.95. The Intel Pocket PC Camera, which begins selling today, allows consumers to take Internet-ready photos and record short video clips at or away from the personal computer. The eight-ounce camera comes with eight megabytes of memory, capable of taking 128 pictures at 640 by 480 pixels, or two minutes of video. Attached to a PC, it can be used to make video phone calls, create Web pages, send e-mail postcards, create PC movies, edit photos and play PC Camera games. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

title: Thoughts on Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: AETHER SYSTEMS TO ACQUIRE CERULEAN TECHNOLOGY
description: Aether Systems, a provider of wireless data products and services, agreed yesterday to acquire Cerulean Technology, which provides wireless mobile software in the public sector, for about $150 million in cash and stock. Under terms of the deal, up to 50 percent of the purchase price can be paid in Aether stock. Cerulean's PacketCluster wireless applications are used by over 45,000 users at some 700 public safety agencies like police and fire departments. Cerulean is based in Marlborough, Mass. Aether provides wireless data products and services. Shares of Aether, based in Owings Mills, Md., were down $6.9375, at $142.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: NORWEGIAN PHONE STAKE SOLD
description: The top Danish phone company, Tele Danmark, and its main shareholder, SBC Communications of San Antonio, agreed to sell their joint 40 percent stake in NetCom of Norway to its Swedish rival, Telia, ending a two-month deadlock. SBC, which owns 42 percent of Tele Danmark, said it would book a pretax gain of about $500 million in the third quarter from the sale, while the Danish company will make a gain of 1.7 billion Danish kroner ($206 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCH, JOHN B.
description: RUSCH-John B. On August 13, 2000. Husband of Gina, father of Derek, brother of Frederik, Robert and Hedevig Kootz. Son of the late Lis and Robert.

title: Op-Art
10 Physics Questions to Ponder for a Millennium or Two
description: ''Who of us would not be glad to lift the veil behind which the future lies hidden; to cast a glance at the next advances of our science and at the secrets of its development during future centuries?''

title: Knicks Lose Out on Fortson
description: The Knicks' summer-long pursuit of Boston's Danny Fortson is apparently over. Fortson was the centerpiece of a four-team deal yesterday that will send the bruising power forward to the Golden State Warriors, according to a Western Conference official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: In Mrs. Clinton's Speech: Praise of Gore's Leadership
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks last night by Hillary Rodham Clinton at the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, as recorded by The New York Times:
