title: Public Interests; Al Gore Marches In
description: Al Gore has been hovering outside California waiting for the Clintons to depart, like a host tapping his foot at the door while the longest-winded guest at the party launches into one last anecdote by the coat rack. But now the convention is his, his, his, and we are going to hear more about Mr. Gore over the next three days than you might have thought humanly possible.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REACTIONS; Exploring the Circuitry of Sleepwalking
description: To help figure out just what goes on in the head of a sleepwalker, a team of Swiss researchers hooked a teenager to a device that measures brain activity, turned out the lights and waited.

title: A Delay That Fell Right, At Least for Mrs. Clinton
description: The Democratic convention program was running behind by 20 minutes tonight, which happened to be just long enough to ensure that Hillary Rodham Clinton's speech to the delegates was broadcast live in prime time on all three of the major broadcast networks.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Valentine and Phillips Running Up Numbers
description: Players can increase their off-season value by giving strong performances the year before they become free agents. Management, therefore, often tries to tie up those players with long-term contracts before they hit the open market. The Mets have several important players who will be free agents this winter -- and two special cases.

title: A Baby Works Her Magic on an Expert
description: In the warmth of daylight, as I held our brand-new first child, the night before seemed far away. It was the day after we brought Bess home from the hospital -- her insurance-mandated 48-hour stay had expired all too quickly -- and it was time for my wife and me to begin our new role as parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRODMAN, GERALD
description: KRODMAN-Gerald. Beloved husband of Zelda, loving father of Debra and Stephanie, and father-inlaw of Daniel. Adored grandfather of Michael, Nica and AJ. Wonderful brother to Eli and his wife Toni. Loving brother-in-law to Lolly and Stuie and adoring uncle to Wendy and David. Dear uncle to Dan, Steven and his wife Donna, and great uncle to Jocelyn and Melissa. Services Wednesday, 2PM at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINNEL, FRANK BROWN
description: GINNEL-Frank Brown, 87. Of Bedford Hills. Died peacefully at home on August 12 after a brief illness. Husband of the late Helen W. Ginnel. Father of Nancy G. Duncan, Helen G. O'Reilly and Daniel H. Ginnel. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Attended Columbia University. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He founded Ginnel Real Estate in 1951, served as President of the Westchester Realty Board. Services will be held on Tuesday, August 15 at 11:30AM at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, N.Y. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Foundation, 400 East Main Street, Mount Kisco, N.Y. 10549.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about Canada's diamond industry misstated the title of Stephen Kakfwi, the top official in the Northwest Territories, where diamonds are mined. He is the territorial premier, not the provincial premier; the region is not a province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: WALDMAN-Charlotte. Died on August 13, 2000 in Rancho Mirage, California at age 90. She is survived by her son, David, her daughter-in-law Diane and her grandsons, Alan and Robbie. Funeral services to be held at Knollwood Park Cemetery. Ridgewood, NY, August 15, 2000 2 PM.

title: U.N. to Establish a War Crimes Panel to Hear Sierra Leone Atrocity Cases
description: The Security Council agreed today to set up a war crimes tribunal for Sierra Leone, where brutal rebel armies have tortured civilians, amputated their hands and destroyed villages to intimidate innocent civilians.

title: Nicholas II And Family Canonized For 'Passion'
description: The Russian Orthodox Church today announced the canonization of Russia's last czar, Nicholas II, and his immediate family for their ''humbleness, patience and meekness'' when they were imprisoned and executed by the Bolsheviks 82 years ago.

title: HONDA EXPANDING IN BRITAIN
description: Bucking a trend among Japanese and other automakers, the Honda Motor Company said it would expand its British car production capacity to 250,000 a year by 2002. Honda is spending $700 million on the expansion, including a new plant capable of producing 100,000 cars annually near its existing factory at Swindon. Nissan and Toyota, along with Ford and BMW, have complained that the strength of the pound against the euro makes their European exports from British plants too expensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, FRANCES
description: ROSENSTEIN-Frances. Of Freehold, NJ and West Palm Beach, FL, on August 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Loving children Susan and Lewis Hogge and Theodore and Carole Rosten. Adored grandchildren Lauren (Goch) Boaz and Danielle and Peter Rosten.

title: Difference in MetroStars Is Obvious to Matthaus
description: Returning to action after a long absence because of back problems, 39-year-old Lothar Matthaus proved that he can still be one of the MetroStars' best players when he is healthy. Conversely, his teammates showed Matthaus in the 2-1 overtime victory over New England on Saturday that they are a good team, and his criticism of the club in the German news media early in the season may have been justified then, but is certainly not now.

title: Virginia Admiral, 85, Painter and Writer
description: Virginia Admiral, an American painter and writer who studied with Hans Hofmann, died on July 27. She was 85 and lived in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HETHERINGTON, HENRY J.
description: HETHERINGTON-Henry J. Beloved husband of Kathryn. Devoted father of William, Michael, Kathryn and Henry P. Loving gransdfather. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday 10AM Sacred Heart R.C. Church, Suffern. Friends may call on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Scarr Funeral Home, Route 202, Suffern, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 4 about mergers among law firms in Europe and about the success that American law firms have had in European mergers and acquisitions misidentified a United States firm that did much of the work on the merger between Daimler-Benz and Chrysler and on the possible link between the Frankfurt and London stock exchanges. It is Shearman & Sterling, not Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Thursday with the obituary of Eugene R. Black, an investment banker, government adviser and Off Broadway playwright, was published in error, and the article misstated the date of his death. The date was April 21, not April 24. The picture showed his father, also named Eugene R. Black, who died in 1992. A picture of the younger Mr. Black appears today, on Page B6.

title: New York Names Names of Biggest Parking-Ticket Scofflaws
description: It is the kind of most-wanted list that could make more than a few car owners sympathize with the criminal element: the 21 New Yorkers who owe the most in unpaid parking tickets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSHUSEN, AGNES RUSS
description: WILSHUSEN-Agnes Russ. She was 89. Died August 12, 2000, in Troy, NY. Widow of William Wilshusen; sister of Helen Blaschke, Lillian Johnson Pamentel, and Louis Russ; sister-in-law of Otto Blaschke, Anne Russ, John Johnson, Frank Pamentel; survived by nieces & nephew Lillian Blashke, Joyce Diwan, Betty McDonald, John Johnson and grandnieces & nephews Devin, Molly, Alex, Ann, John. Longtime Flushing resident; retired from General Motors; volunteer at Flushing Hospital and Queens Botanical Garden; member of Redeemer Lutheran Church, Bayside. In lieu of flowers, please donate in her name to Queens Botanical Garden or Redeemer Lutheran Church. Reposing at Howard L. Hallet, Inc. (Gleason Building), 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Services are at 8 PM Tuesday & 9:30 AM, Wednesday. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: Metro Business; Meetings on Empire Zones
description: New York State will hold three meetings for officials who hope to have economically troubled areas of their municipalities designated as economic development zones, in which the state provides financial incentives to businesses that move to or expand in the areas.

title: Tire Company Is Encouraged To Broaden Recall Plans
description: Plaintiffs' lawyers and safety advocates called on Bridgestone/Firestone today to considerably widen the scope of its recall of tires for sport utility vehicles and pickups. They contend that the tire maker and Ford Motor were misleading the public about the safety of many Firestone tires and of Ford Explorers equipped with them.

title: Circus in Bryant Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, ALBERT HAYDEN
description: DWYER-Albert Hayden. Of Demarest, NJ, former general counsel and vice president of the Children's Television Workshop and a CBS attorney for nearly two decades, died on August 8, 2000 at the age of 79. He was the beloved husband of Laura Campbell Dwyer, father of Albert H. Dwyer, Jr. of Houston, TX., and William C. Dwyer of Santa Cruz, CA, and grandfather of four. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 P.M., August 19 at the Church of the Atonement, Engle Street at Highwood Avenue, Tenafly, NJ. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Church of the Atonement or the Alzheimer's Association, Greater New Jersey Chapter, 400 Morris Avenue, Denville, NJ 07834.

title: In Japan, What's on the Plate Is Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VISTEON CORP., -- Dearborn, Mich., the world's No. 3 auto-parts maker, said it would form a business group to expand sales of products that provide in-vehicle Internet access and other communications and entertainment services.

title: Traffic Jam Leads to Gunfire Outside Empire State Building
description: An argument in traffic at the foot of the Empire State Building led a man to open fire on a sport utility vehicle yesterday, the police and witnesses said. The gunman and his three companions then fled to the 14th floor of the building, where they were arrested, the police said. No one was hurt.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Workers Question Evidence in Tire Recall
description: A day after the Ford Motor Company singled out a factory here that makes Firestone tires as the main source of a problem that led to the recall of more than 6.5 million tires last week, workers and union officials said today that they were not to blame for the faulty tires.

title: Plan for Missile Defense Survives, but in Competing Versions
description: In the waning days of the cold war, one of the main disputes on national security between Republicans and Democrats involved missile defense.

title: Mr. Clinton's Valedictory
description: In an emotional farewell to the party that he reshaped and led for eight turbulent years and to the political arena he will clearly miss, President Clinton last night offered a passionate defense of his record and a steadfast argument that Vice President Al Gore is ready to take over. As students of convention staging will no doubt remember, the president chose an oddly hokey gladiatorial entrance. For fans of presidential oratory, the speech was a reminder of Mr. Clinton's skills as an advocate who can both speak from the heart and argue a case through a series of logical points. The Democrats' enthusiastic reception was testimony to their mixed feelings -- an eagerness to move beyond Mr. Clinton and his outsized personal problems as well as genuine gratitude for his success in modernizing their party.

title: WIRELESS AUCTION BIDS SURGE IN GERMANY
description: Bidding for new licenses to offer ''third generation'' wireless telephone and data services in Germany reached 78 billion marks ($36.25 billion), exceeding the huge sums reached at a similar auction in Britain last spring. The intensity of the bidding is much greater than many had expected. Seven bidders are vying for five big licenses: Deutsche Telekom, Vodafone Airtouch, Mannesmann Mobilfunk, Mobilcom, Viag Interkom, E-Plus and Group 3G. Edmund L. Andrews

title: A Blowout Brings Mets To Earth
description: Mike Bordick heard the rumblings in the fifth inning, when the Mets still had no hits off the San Francisco Giants right-hander Russ Ortiz. Let's break this thing up, the Mets said in their dugout, and that sounded like a good idea to Bordick.

title: Political Shadow Dancing
description: The transfer of power is one of the key tests of democracy. At the governmental level, the United States has managed it exceptionally well ever since George Washington, hero of the war that brought the nation into being, handed over to John Adams in 1797.

title: Cardinal Urges End to Abortion
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles called today for an end to abortions as he delivered the invocation at the opening of the Democratic National Convention.

title: Foreign Affairs; Shah Khamenei
description: Watching Iranian politics today is a lot like watching the Weather Channel during hurricane season. The weatherman comes on and points to a group of clouds somewhere in the mid-Atlantic. He tells you it's not a hurricane just yet, but if you study the cloud patterns you can see the storm forming. If the current winds and temperatures persist, he concludes, it will definitely be upgraded from tropical storm to hurricane.

description: Percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, ERIK SCOT
description: NELSON-Erik Scot. August 7, 1970-August 12, 2000. Son of Jenyne and Gary Nelson and brother of Erin Nelson. Graduate, Eden Prairie High School (1989 Governor's Scholar), Columbia University (B.A. History 1993 Cum Laude, Benito Gaguine Scholarship for Academic Achievement) and the University of Minnesota Law School (J.D. 1999, Cum Laude; Managing Editor, Law Review). Cambridge University, Clare College (1991-1992, History). Analyst, Wertheim Schroders (NY, 1993-1995) and Schroders (London, 1995-1996). Associate, Dewey Ballantine LLP (NY, 1999-2000). Celebration of Life Service, Friday, August 18th, 3 PM, Spirit of the Lakes United Church of Christ, Minneapolis, MN (612-724-2313). Contributions in his name to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society of America (800-955-4572).

title: Lazio Proposes a Pact Against Soft Money
description: With a bit of stagecraft intended to take some attention away from his opponent in the Senate race, Representative Rick A. Lazio signed a ''pact'' yesterday that calls on Hillary Rodham Clinton to join him in renouncing unregulated campaign contributions.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Shuffling the Deck at Pearson; But Are the Moves Too Fast to Follow?
description: The folks back in Texarkana, Tex., should be proud of Marjorie Scardino. True to her Lone Star State roots, Mrs. Scardino, the chief executive of Pearson P.L.C., thinks big.

title: NYT Article
description: Japanese Online Stock Trading Accounts Rise 8.3% in July

title: City Inspection Procedures Faulted in Fatal Brooklyn Fire
description: Ashley Sims, 13, went for a sleep over at her best friend's home in Brooklyn on July 22. It was the last time her family saw her alive.

title: Will Faith Be an Issue for Voters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Emery and Postal Service in Partnership
description: Emery Worldwide plans to announce a partnership today with the Postal Service to offer residential delivery service by parcel post to manufacturers and catalog companies.

title: A New Saint Nicholas
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: With Safety in Doubt, British Ground Concordes
description: British Airways grounded its entire fleet of Concorde supersonic airliners today after French and British investigators said they would urge the withdrawal of the airplane's airworthiness certification following last month's fatal Air France Concorde crash near Paris.

title: S.& L. to Sell Some Assets
description: The Commercial Federal Corporation, the fourth-biggest savings and loan in the Midwest, said it planned to sell $2 billion of investments and loans to increase profits. The company will also pay off debt with high interest costs, sell its leasing company and some real estate, and buy back about 10 percent, of its outstanding shares. The actions will result in charges of $118 million to $138 million before taxes.

title: Rookie Badgers Strahan, And the Giants Smile
description: The three-time Pro Bowl player shouted something at the undrafted, unknown rookie as the practice play ended.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Jesse Jackson's appearance at the Democratic National Convention carried an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for the son with him. It was Jonathan, not the eldest Jackson son, Jesse Jr.

title: Amateur Seeking An Elusive Title
description: Jerry Courville Jr., in quest of the only Metropolitan Golf Association title that has eluded him, shot a four-under-par 67 yesterday and took the first-round lead in the Met Life/M.G.A. Open at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: S.A.A. REINTRODUCES NIGERIA-U.S. FLIGHTS
description: One of Africa's biggest airlines, South African Airways, began regular service between Lagos, Nigeria, and New York, ending a stretch of almost six anda half years without direct flights between the commercial capital of the oil-rich nation and the United States. S.A.A. won the right to operate the route for troubled Nigerian Airways several months after American aviation authorities lifted a ban on flights between the United States and Murtala Muhammad International Airport in Lagos. The ban was imposed in August 1993 after the airport was found not to meet international security standards. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: TREX MEDICAL WILL BE BOUGHT BY HOLOGIC FOR $55 MILLION
description: Hologic Inc., a maker of devices that measure bone density, agreed to buy the United States assets of the Trex Medical Corporation, a medical imaging manufacturer, for $55 million to expand sales of women's health care equipment. Hologic, which is based in Bedford, Mass., will pay $30 million in cash and issue $25 million in secured three-year notes for Trex. Trex makes general X-ray machines, as well as biopsy and mammography equipment to detect and diagnose breast cancer. Trex is based in Danbury, Conn., and had United States sales in 1999 of $178.5 million, 74 percent of its total sales.

title: Diversity in News and Entertainment
description: Rupert Murdoch proposed this week to add to his already vast media holdings by buying WWOR Channel 9 in the New York City region and nine other television stations across the country from Chris-Craft Industries. The purchase would give his company, News Corporation, ownership of stations that reach more than 35 percent of the viewing public in the nation, violating a rule of the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. Murdoch plans to satisfy the commission by selling as many stations as necessary.

title: Terms of Endearment in the Booth
description: If nothing else, Dennis Miller's presence on ''Monday Night Football'' is loosening up Al Michaels.

title: Clinton Makes His Last Hurrah
description: To the Editor:

title: In Flooding's Aftermath, a Slapdash System of Dam Repairs Emerges
description: A state-required inspection in 1991 of the Seneca Lake Dam, which gave way during intense flooding in northwestern New Jersey on Saturday night, found that it was in need of repairs, but they were never undertaken by its private owners, state officials said today.

title: On Campus, It's Not a Game
description: ONE autumn day in the 1970's, when Harold L. Enarson was president of Ohio State University, he attended a football game in which Ohio State was pitted against one of its traditional rivals.

title: White One Isn't Only House The Democrats Have Eye On
description: The stage does not look like the Capitol, but there have been more senators, representatives and Congressional candidates speaking at the Democratic National Convention than can be found on the floor of either chamber most of the time.

title: AMF Bowling Has 7 Weeks To Redo Debt
description: AMF Bowling, the world's largest operator of bowling alleys, has been given seven weeks to come up with a plan for reorganizing its debts or risk being pushed into bankruptcy court.

title: Defense Argues Ethnicity Made Scientist a Suspect
description: In the first of two days of potentially pivotal hearings in the case of the scientist accused of mishandling important nuclear weapons secrets, defense lawyers offered evidence today suggesting that he had been singled out for prosecution largely because he is Chinese-American.

title: London Journal; A Sex Scandal of the 60's, Doubly Scandalous Now
description: It was a scandal that riveted Swinging Sixties London and left behind a tantalizing question that has gone unanswered for nearly 40 years. At its center was Margaret, Duchess of Argyll, a rich and seductive society beauty who inspired Cole Porter's ''You're the Top.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, BURTON
description: BERNARD-Burton. Consummate husband of 58 years to his devoted wife, Norma. Beloved father of Harold, Cathy and Mitchell. Loving father-in-law of Bonnie and Adrienne. Cherished grandfather of Nicole, Molly, Alex, Bradley, Jake, Amanda and Hannah. He was a unique and wonderful man, loved by all who had the good fortune to know him. We will miss him forever. Services Wednesday, 11:00 AM, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; STRONG GROWTH IN MEXICO
description: The Mexican economy grew at an annual rate of 7.6 percent in the second quarter, the Finance Ministry reported. The better-than-expected increase in economic activity was fueled by a consumer spending spree resulting from falling unemployment and higher real wages, rising oil prices and the continuing dynamism of the United States economy -- Mexico's principal export market. President Ernesto Zedillo, above, who hands over the presidency to Vicente Fox on Dec. 1, said the data reinforced his promise that the transfer of power would be the first in Mexico in 25 years that would not be accompanied by an economic crisis. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: EAGLE WIRELESS TO PURCHASE CLEARWORKS.NET FOR STOCK
description: Eagle Wireless International Inc., a communications equipment maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy ClearWorks.net Inc. for about $137.5 million in stock to sell entertainment delivered to homes on fiber optic lines. The company will exchange 0.8 share, valued at $6.25, for each share of ClearWorks.net. Eagle Wireless makes wireless communications equipment and software as well as set-top boxes that provide Internet access through televisions. ClearWorks.net, which is based in Houston, installs fiber optic wiring in homes and sells so-called bundled digital services.

title: Ex-Executive Contends BET Evaded Taxes
description: A former chief financial officer for Black Entertainment Television is set to file a lawsuit in Washington today contending that the company; its chairman, Robert L. Johnson; and its president, Debra Lee, made extensive efforts to evade the payment of some taxes.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas fell after a tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico missed offshore gas rigs. In New York, natural gas for September delivery fell 8.4 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $4.234 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Technology Briefings
description: HARDWARE SONY CHOOSES TRANSMETA CHIP Sony said yesterday that it would use computer memory chips made by the Transmeta Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., in one of its popular models of laptop computers. Sony is a major customer of Intel, the dominant maker of computer memory chips. But it said it would equip the CI model of its Vaio line of laptops with Transmeta's central processing units, which offer more effective power saving. Sony said the chip was a good fit for the Vaio CI, since it is designed as a go-anywhere computer with a built-in video camera. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Democrats Best G.O.P. On the Air
description: The first night of the Democratic National Convention got more minutes on network television and pulled in more viewers, both on the networks and on the cable news channels, than did the first night of the Republican convention last month. The farewell speech by President Clinton was largely responsible for the increases.

title: Retro or Nostalgic, the Work Never Stops Moving
description: The British art scene is so heady with hype, gimmickry and self-promotion these days that it comes as something of a relief to discover the long-lost world of kinetic art at the Hayward Gallery on the south bank of the Thames.

title: Radio-Show Caller Arrested In Lieberman Death Threat
description: A caller to Howard Stern's radio show was arrested yesterday at his home on Long Island and charged with saying on the air that he wanted to kill Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic candidate for vice president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBERT, MARC G.
description: COLBERT-Marc G. Of Teaneck, NJ on Tuesday, August 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Simone, devoted father of Peter, John and Susan, loving grandfather of Elliot, Jacob and Zoe Colbert & Laura & David Gleason. Memorial services 3 PM Friday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBRECHT, SHEILA BROWN
description: LeBRECHT-Sheila Brown. Of Easthampton, New York, on Saturday, August 12th, 2000, after a short illness. At her request there will be no memorial service. Contributions in her memory may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of President Clinton's speech to the Democratic National Convention, as recorded by The Times for some late editions yesterday, rendered his concluding passage incorrectly. Mr. Clinton said, ''And, remember, whenever you think about me, keep putting people first.'' (He did not say ''whatever you think about me.'')

title: Henrys All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Mahomes: Mr. Any Role On Mets Staff
description: YOU'RE starting tomorrow,'' someone said to Pat Mahomes Monday in the Mets' clubhouse.

title: APPLE NAMES A BOARD MEMBER
description: Apple Computer named Arthur D. Levinson, chairman of Genentech, to its board. Mr. Levinson, 51, became chief executive of Genentech in 1995 and chairman in 1999. He has a doctorate in biochemistry from Princeton University.

description: August 16, 2000

title: Strutting Past the Ingenues; Women of Experience Grab the British Spotlight
description: ''Look at me!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, EVA BEER
description: ARONSON-Eva Beer. On August 14, 2000. Beloved wife of Herbert, and adoring mother and motherin-law of Richard, Emary, and Lisa. Born in Vienna, she was a true New Yorker, devoted to students and colleagues at Interboro Institute. Services at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 W. 68 St, New York on August 17 at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Robin Hood Foundation, 111 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10006.

title: Who pays attention to television and radio commercials? Whispercode is watching.
description: THEY are everywhere, cluttering the radio dial and the broadcast and cable television channels as never before: commercials, lots of them, jammed by eager advertisers into what seems to be every available second of programming time.

title: MANAGEMENT: Cornering the Corner Office; Chief Executives Have More Staying Power These Days
description: Durk I. Jager lasted 17 months at the helm of Procter & Gamble, resigning last month after the shortest tenure of any chief executive in the company's 163-year history. The board of Mattel asked for the resignation of the company's leader, Jill E. Barad, this year after only three years. M. Douglas Ivester, after years of being groomed for Coca-Cola's top job, quit in February after two years in it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIMSTON, BLANCHE
description: DIMSTON-Blanche. God would never have made such lovely days and given us such deep hearts to enjoy them unless we were meant to be immortal. (May '74)

title: WINE SALES SITES TO MERGE
description: In another sign of consolidation in the Internet retailing sector, two privately held Internet wine retailers said yesterday that they would join forces. The two, Wine.com, with offices in Napa and Palo Alto, Calif., and WineShopper.com of San Francisco, declined to specify terms. The online retailer Amazon.com has invested at least $30 million in WineShopper.com.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the retracing of Louis Armstrong's roots in New Orleans by the writer Tad Jones misspelled the surname of a jazz writer and Armstrong biographer for whom Mr. Jones also conducted research. He is Gary Giddins, not Giddens.

title: Kashmir Endures Its Holiday of Contradictions
description: Independence Day, as observed here today in the unhappy summer capital of India's unhappiest state, was an eerie kind of national holiday, with almost everyone staying indoors, partly out of fear for their lives.

title: CIBA CHEMICALS' PROFIT IS UP
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals, which makes chemicals for products ranging from Colgate toothpaste to Mercedes car parts, said first-half profit almost tripled, helped by cost cuts and revampings. Income from continuing operations at the company, Switzerland's No. 2 chemical maker, climbed to 215 million Swiss francs ($125 million), or 3.24 francs a share, from 73 million francs, or 1.09 a share, in the period a year earlier. Ciba said second-half growth would slow compared with levels for the first six months, partly because of a stronger period last year. The outlook helped push down the shares, which trade at about half their 1998 high. Analysts said the company's jumps in profit had partly been driven by the weakness of the Swiss franc -- a benefit that may disappear in the second half.

title: NORTEL BUYING EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Nortel Networks said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sonoma Systems, a privately held maker of high-speed data devices, in a stock deal valued at $540 million. Under the terms of the deal, about $60 million worth of shares is payable only if Sonoma meets certain unspecified goals in the year after the deal closes.

title: Presenting a Masterpiece in Political Theater, With a Scene From 'Camelot'
description: All she had to do was walk on stage, ''Camelot'' playing behind her, to create the most emotional moment of the Democratic convention. Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg was poised in her brief speech. She was there to introduce her uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, but more important to evoke all the memories of her relatives. ''When my brother and I were growing up,'' she said, every day someone told them how inspiring their father had been. Her style evoked her mother: the simple hair and dress, the sense of allowing the television audience access to her famously private life. That she seemed unaccustomed to speaking to such an audience only reinforced the aura.

title: Rescue efforts start
description: By SABRINA TAVERNISE with DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Celebrating the Clinton legacy
description: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

title: TOYS 'R' US SAID TO DROP TRACKING FIRM
description: Toys ''R'' Us has ended its ties to an online data tracking concern that provoked privacy suits against the Internet sales site of the biggest United States toy retailer, one of the plaintiffs' law firms said. Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in San Diego, one of the law firms that sued toysrus.com, said the company had ended its contract with CoreMetrics, a firm that tracks Web site usage. Milberg Weiss's suit sought hundreds of millions of dollars in damages on behalf of visitors to the toysrus.com Web site. CoreMetrics and toysrus.com denied wrongdoing. Jennifer Davis, a spokeswoman for Toys 'R' Us, which is based in Paramus, N.J., declined to say if the company had in fact terminated the CoreMetrics contract.

title: Metro Business; R.D. White Is Barred From Buying Stock
description: The R. D. White & Company brokerage firm has been barred from the securities industry by regulators on charges that it underpaid individual customers on $2.9 million in repurchases of new stock after initial public offerings.

title: Poor Children, Single Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: NO EASING OF IRISH INFLATION
description: The annualized inflation rate in Ireland last month rose to a 15-year high of 6.2 percent, up from 5.5 percent in June. A 17 percent increase in tobacco prices was the single largest contributor to the growth, followed by housing and transportation. In an attempt to assuage continued agitation from trade unions over the issue, the government said that the increase was not unexpected and that it would consider taking further anti-inflationary measures. The government already has imposed some limits on housing prices to cool the inflation rate, which is the highest in the European Union. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: In Convention Hall, Traditional Surprise
description: For devotees of convention tradition, one quadrennial thing to watch for is the much anticipated, rarely provided, never announced and hardly ever spontaneous ''surprise visit'' by a candidate to the arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUREVITCH, FANNIE
description: GUREVITCH-Fannie. The entire Heschel School community extends its heartfelt sympathy to Rabbi Judah Nadich, esteemed former member of the Board of Trustees, on the loss of his sister, Fannie Gurevitch. We send our condolences to the entire Nadich/ Levin family. Ria Gruss, Vice President Alan B. Slifka, Vice President Roanna Shorofsky, Director

title: Ross Lee Finney III, 67, Author Of Widely Used Math Textbooks
description: Ross Lee Finney III, a mathematician whose textbooks have instructed millions of high school and college students, died on Aug. 3 in Carmel Valley, Calif. A former resident of Lincoln, Mass., he was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIOTT, MARIAN FRANCIS (FRAN)
description: HARRIOTT - Marian Francis (Fran). Loving daughter of Jeannette (nee Scherf) and Albert, and beloved member of the Sisters of Charity for 50 years, died on August 14, 2000, at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. An educator for many years, Francis taught for 23 years in the parochial school system and for 20 years in the Yonkers public school system. Her giftedness as a teacher of English and Drama was recognized when she was awarded the coveted PTA Jenkins Memorial Award in 1994. A graduate of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, Francis had a Masters of Fine Arts degree from Catholic University, as well as a Master's Degree in Drama, Media and Technology from the New School of Social Research. She served as a Docent for the National Trust at Kykuit and Lyndhurst estates for the past five years. Contributions in lieu of flowers in Sister Marian Francis' name can be made to the Retirement Fund of the Sisters of Charity, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Reposing at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY (one block north of Tuckahoe Road) on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass at Sacred Heart Church, 110 Shonnard Place, Yonkers, NY, on Thursday at 10:30 AM. Interment at Kensico Cemetery.

title: Getting Away With Murder (Probably)
description: WAINEWRIGHT THE POISONER

title: THE DEMOCRATS
description: A SYMBOLIC STOP -- President Clinton nudged Vice President Al Gore to center stage at a Michigan rally, literally and politically. PAGE A23

title: As Peace Plan Falters, Sri Lankas War Has No End in Sight
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. 12  This war-haunted nation's president, blinded in her right eye by a suicide bomber's attack, still talks of peace. But many ordinary Sri Lankans are more convinced than ever that no end to the country's 17-year conflict with the Tamil rebels is near.

title: In Rioja, the Grape Is Old, the Style All New
description: TWELVE years ago, the last time I was in Rioja, Spain's best-known red wine region, many winemakers were frustrated by their apparent inability to crack the American market. They put much of the blame on rules that require them to make their wines exclusively from local grapes, principally tempranillo and garnacha, which is called grenache here and in France. The Riojans looked enviously toward Miguel Torres in the Penedes, near Barcelona, and to Piero Antinori in Italy, both moving beyond local varieties to make exciting wines from cabernet sauvignon, the noble grape of Bordeaux and California.

title: FORECAST: MORE ADS ONLINE
description: Jupiter Communications, an Internet research firm, plans to release a report today forecasting that online advertising revenue will reach $16.5 billion by 2005. The report predicts a 30 percent annual growth rate in total online advertising spending, from $3.5 billion in 1999. According to a Jupiter survey, marketers plan to increase spending on Internet advertising at a higher rate than advertising in any other medium, with nearly three-quarters planning increases in the next 12 months, compared with 43 percent who said they would increase their magazine spending and 37 percent who plan to increase their spending on cable television. This anticipated growth could propel the Internet to fourth place as an advertising medium, behind broadcast television, radio and newspapers. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Navistar Cuts 1,100 Jobs, Citing Truck Order Drop
description: Responding to a slowdown in heavy-truck orders in North America, the Navistar International Corporation said today that it would lay off 1,100 employees, or about 15 percent of its white-collar work force.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Knoblauch Is Still Aching
description: Chuck Knoblauch threw from the second-base hole to first base as part of his rehabilitation for his right elbow in Tampa, Fla., on Monday, a distance of about 60 feet. Then Knoblauch woke up this morning and felt lingering soreness in his elbow, so he did not even pick up a ball.

title: Polish Cooking That Takes a Lesson From the Feather
description: IT was not exactly what I expected to see on entering Polanka, a Polish-American restaurant in Lower Manhattan. A D.J. with a rig the size of a Volkswagen was just inside the entrance, spinning soul tunes from the 60's and 70's. At the bar, women were grooving in their seats, singing the words to ''Lean on Me'' as if they were several drinks into their high school reunion. And as we sat down, a waitress greeted us as if the bouncing and singing were part of the furniture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATANIA, ANDREA
description: CATANIA-Andrea, on August 14, 2000. Professor of Law at Seton Hall University School of Law. Loving sister of Lynn Voeffray and Claudia Catania. Treasured aunt of Maxwell and Gavin Cady. Services Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Seton Hall University School of Law for a scholarship fund in memory of Andrea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDAL, JOSEPH
description: HANDAL-Joseph, 83. Textile executive and philanthropist, died Saturday, August 12, after a prolonged and valiant struggle with cancer. Cherished companion of Kathleen Wyman, loving brother of Hilda, beloved father of Dick, Don, Jim and Gary, devoted grandfather of Allison, Doralice, Jennifer, Alexis and Sarah; and step-grandfather to Andres, Javier, Tasha and Christian. Caring father-in-law to Lisa and Karen. Mourned by former wife Margot, extended family members, coworkers and countless friends. All who knew him will remember his intelligence, humor, generosity, humility and concern for others. Memorial service: 1:00 PM, Friday, September 1, 2000, Church of Saint Paul the Apostle, 405 West 59th Street, NY, NY. Contributions to: American Red Cross in Greater New York, 150 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10023.

description: Cendant Official Makes Bid To Regain Control of Avis

description: The muralist, painter and author Tom Lea is probably the only person, dead or alive, who can say he has been threatened by Pancho Villa, interrupted by Chiang Kai-shek and regaled by Franklin D. Roosevelt. Oddly enough, Mr. Lea was mostly forgotten until he was quoted this month by Gov. George W. Bush.

description: August 16, 2000

title: Gore Grabs Torch From Clinton, Hoping to Avoid Burns
description: With a bear hug and a slight nudge, President Clinton pushed his understudy, Al Gore, to center stage today, relinquishing the limelight to the man he hopes will succeed him.

title: Ivax Says Bristol-Myers Deal Aims to Delay a Generic Drug
description: Ivax, a drug company that has fought for years to sell a generic version of Taxol, the top cancer drug in the United States, said yesterday that a little-known company had received a patent related to the drug, which could keep Ivax's lower-cost drug off the market for as long as two and a half years.

title: Trenton Court Strikes Down Abortion Law
description: Rejecting the State Legislature's attempt to join the growing list of states that restrict abortion for teenagers, the New Jersey Supreme Court today struck down a law requiring parental notice for unmarried girls under age 18.

title: Gore's Speech? By Gore, A Very-Insider Insists
description: Robert Shrum, the Gore strategist who has written some of the most eloquent Democratic speeches of his generation, said yesterday that Mr. Gore was ''literally, truly and unquestionably'' the author of the acceptance speech he will give to the Democratic convention tomorrow night. With no help at all from Mr. Shrum, who wrote much of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's ''dream shall never die'' speech that ignited the 1980 Democratic convention in New York?

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: BROOKLYN

title: Where Few Bistros Have Gone Before
description: DINING on the lower reaches of the Upper East Side often seems an all-or-nothing proposition. It's either high-end restaurants like March, JoJo, Daniel and Aureole, or a sobering procession of limp trattorias, third-rate sushi shacks and the occasional Hunan house of horrors. In one of the world's most expensive swaths of real estate, it's easier to find pizza by the slice than a decent bistro. In culinary terms, this part of town is like a pillared mansion with a few rusty washing machines on the front lawn.

title: WRITERS SUE OVER COPYRIGHTS
description: Taking a cue from the recording industry lawsuit against Napster, freelance writers have turned to the courtroom to fight what they assert is Internet-based piracy of their works. A group of four freelance writers filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in San Francisco on Monday against three online database operators. The suit asserts that Northern Light Technology, Gale Group and Bell & Howell Information and Learning compiled databases of copyrighted materials, then resold works over the Internet without reimbursing authors. Lawyers for the four plaintiffs hope to qualify the complaint as a class-action suit. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Hamed Preparing To Defend Title
description: If Prince Naseem Hamed, the undefeated World Boxing Organization featherweight champion, is anything but confident as he prepares to defend his title against Augie Sanchez, it is not showing.

title: I.B.M. NEWS LIFTS RED HAT
description: Shares of Red Hat rose 10 percent yesterday after the company announced partnerships with I.B.M. and Motorola. Red Hat and I.B.M. agreed to develop new versions of I.B.M. software tailored to run on Red Hat's Linux operating system. Red Hat sells a commercial version of Linux, the maverick operating system. Also yesterday, Red Hat announced a partnership with Motorola's embedded computer division in Canada to include Red Hat's operating system in components it sells to telecommunications companies. Red Hat shares, which have fallen from a December high of $151.31, rose $2.1875, to $24, yesterday.

title: THE CHEF; For Anyone Who Loves Tomatoes, Welcome to Paradise
description: MOST chefs wait for the morning produce delivery. I walk out the back door of my farmhouse and pick my own. My wife and I own an 18-acre organic farm nestled amid the vineyards of the North Fork of Long Island. We run a small business supplying organic produce to restaurants, including mine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, BERNICE D.
description: ELKIN-Bernice D. On August 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David Elkin. Loving mother of Faith Bobrow and Eileen Gilbert & their husbands, Philip and Jerry. Adored grandmother of Emily, Amanda, Diane, Rachel & David. Loving sister-in-law of Ruth Muss. Bernice Elkin was an extraordinary woman, a true teacher who taught by the examples of righteousness, charity and goodness. She will truly be missed by all of us.

title: Demand Drives Oil Prices To Decade-High Levels
description: NEW YORK  Crude oil prices touched 10-year highs Tuesday thanks to a strengthening world economy that is increasing demand for energy.

description: Percent

title: WORTHINGTON TO BUY THREE GALVANIZED STEEL OPERATIONS
description: Moving to expand its galvanized steel operations, Worthington Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three independent galvanizing operations in Pennsylvania, collectively known as the Techs, for $300 million. The three Pittsburgh-based limited partnerships, MetalTech, NexTech and GalvTech, produce a total of one million tons of galvanized steel a year. With the acquisitions, Worthington's average annual growth rate will be about 5 percent, the company said. Worthington, a steel processor based in Columbus, Ohio, has annual sales of $2 billion.

description: KAY-Irving. Age 84, of Clifton, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, August 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Hazel, father of Sanford and Andrew, grandfather of Amanda & Jason. Services by Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Paramus, NJ.

description: Christopher Hinkaty was named to the new post of director for interactive services at Gotham, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He had been an account supervisor there.

Fleetwood, Christian V. Fleetwood, Carmen Fleetwood Paul, and Charlotte C. Fleetwood and grandfather of four.
