title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, RICHARD G.
description: MURPHY-Richard G. On August 13th, 2000. He was 83. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he had been a resident of Larchmont since 1919 and also attended Fordham School of Business. Mr. Murphy worked in the municipal bond business starting in 1936 with B.J. Van Ingen & Company until his retirement in 1985 from Shearson American Express. He was the beloved husband of the late Jean (nee Hanson) and is survived by eleven children and thirteen grandchildren. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont on Saturday, August 19, 2000 at 11AM. A reception will follow. Coxe & Craziano Funeral Home, 914-698-5968.

title: Sharon Interrupts Lawmakers' Recess to Aim Barbs at Barak
description: Israel's main opposition party used a depleted special session of Parliament today to push through a resolution aimed at impeding new peace talks with the Palestinians, but Prime Minister Ehud Barak's government brushed the move aside as political grandstanding.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Clinton Makes His Last Hurrah
description: To the Editor:

title: That Old Guard of Modernism Is Still Kicking
description: It seemed like old times at the Tanglewood Music Center's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, which ended its five-day run on Monday evening. After several years of pointedly broadening the festival's palette to include everything from Minimalism -- music that was long unwelcome here -- to recent cross-cultural trends, like last summer's focus on Asian-American composers, this year's festival is devoted mostly to new music's old guard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, GEORGE
description: WELLS-George, 88. Of Hayden Lakes, ID, died August 12, 2000 at Life Care Center of Coeur D'Alene following a lengthy illness. He was born March 19, 1912 in Colon, Panama where his father was one of four departmental heads on the construction of the Canal. Mr. Wells attended public school in Montclair, New Jersey and preparatory school in Massachusetts. He graduated from Yale University in 1933 and Harvard Business School in 1935. He then attended New York City Law School for one year. Following two years in the New York offices of Air Reduction Company, he joined the Union Carbide Corporation where he spent 35 years in various plant and general management capacities. He was president of Union Carbide's former international division from 1958 until 1963, traveling extensively around the world. In 1964, he became a general vice president of the corporation. He married Zazilia Grabner of Ebensee, Austria on August 16, 1968. He retired from the corporation in 1974. After his retirement, they moved to Incline Village, Nevada where they lived for 5 years. In 1979 they moved to Hayden Lake, Idaho. He is survived by his wife of 33 years, Zazilia Wells at home; brother, Thomas M. Wells of Montclair, NJ and by a prior marriage a son, Bradley H. Wells of San Francisco, CA and daughter, Sarah Robertson of Connecticut; three granddaughters; 2 stepchildren, Stuart of Spokane, WA and Virginia of South Australia; A funeral service will be held 4:00 P.M. Wednesday, August 16, 2000 at Yates Funeral Home, Hayden Chapel with Pastor Eric Ranum officiating. A reception will follow at the Yates Hayden Gathering Center. Interment will be at Pines Mausoleum in Spokane, Washington at a later date. Yates Funeral Home, Hayden Chapel is in charge of arrangements. . The family prefers memorials to North Idaho Cancer Center, 700 Ironwood, Coeur D'Alene, Idaho 83814.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: COLLABOREX, Fairfax, Va., named Mike Meyer president and chief operating officer. He had been chief executive at Cap Gemini America.

title: UMPQUA PLANS TO ACQUIRE VRB BANCORP FOR $51.5 MILLION
description: The Umpqua Holdings Corporation, owner of the South Umpqua Bank in Oregon, agreed to buy VRB Bancorp, owner of Valley of the Rogue Bank, for $51.5 million in stock to gain customers in the southern part of the state. Umpqua will pay 0.8135 share, or $6.20, for each VRB share, 20 percent more than VRB's closing price Monday. Umpqua said it expected to save about $1.5 million and expected the transaction to add 5 percent to per-share earnings next year. It expects to take an acquisition-related charge of about $2 million this year. South Umpqua Bank has $411 million in assets while Valley of the Rogue Bank has $330 million. The two banks have 27 branches.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AUSTRALIA; EXCHANGES CONSIDER UNION
description: The Australian and New Zealand stock exchanges confirmed they were discussing a merger, which would create a joint market worth more than 40 billion Australian dollars ($23.2 billion). The move comes as the New Zealand exchange is confronting an exodus of companies that want to list in Australia or Singapore. A merger would require a change in the corporate structure of the New Zealand exchange, which is owned by 460 broker members. The Australian Stock Exchange is itself a publicly traded corporation. Nina Bick (NYT)

title: As Some Fight A Park Plan, Its Supporters See Elitism; Many in Brooklyn Hts. Fear Hordes of Visitors
description: The flags hanging from the windows of homes lining the only cobblestone blocks in Brooklyn Heights all bear the same Revolutionary War motto, ''Don't Tread on Me.''

title: Industrial Output Advanced 0.4% in July
description: Industrial output rose in July, as production of computers and productivity-enhancing business equipment offset declines for automobiles, appliances and electricity, Federal Reserve data showed today.

title: Passenger Steers Bus to Safety After Driver's Heart Attack
description: Shedrick Lawrence told his wife yesterday morning that he did not have time to cook his own sausage because he had to catch the bus to his new job. They yelled at each other. He ran out of their apartment in Baldwin, N.Y., on an empty stomach, clutching a brown bag lunch of leftover spaghetti.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, JANETTE
description: EISNER-Janette 88, of Hallandale, FL passed away August 15, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Survived by her loving children: David (Dorothy) Eisner, & Judith Schuldenfrei. Grandchildren: Jonathan, Suzanne (Craig), & Michael. Greatgrandchildren: Joshua & Ilana. Services in FL. The family requests memorial contributions to The American Cancer Society.

title: Goldman Sachs Names Ogilvy & Mather
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group, to handle its global branding and advertising account. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Heading for the Hills With a Caribbean Beat
description: Actors who play musicians sometimes hang on to the role afterward, the way Gary Busey and Dan Aykroyd did. But no one has followed through like the Colombian pop singer Carlos Vives, who played a sold-out concert on Saturday night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKE, MARSHALL
description: WOLKE-Marshall. The World Council of Masorti/Conservative Synagogues mourns the passing of our past president, Marshall Wolke. During his administration he was able to lay the foundation for our global outreach programs. May his luminous memory be a constant blessing to the entire community of Israel. Rabbi Alan Silverstein, President Dr. Benjamin Kreitman, Rabbi of the Council

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKRENT, ODETTE
description: OKRENT-Odette. The National Board of Directors and the Membership of American Red Magen David for Israel record with profound sorrow the passing of Odette Okrent, beloved mother of Jacqueline Goldman, longtime, dedicated member of the Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Jacqueline, Nathan, their children and grandchildren. May the memories of her life be as a blessing to the family. Stuart A. Jackson, Chairman/Treasurer Robert L. Sadoff, MD, National President Benjamin Saxe, Exec. V.P. Robert L. Schwartz, National Director

title: Viacom to Buy the Rest of Infinity's Shares
description: Viacom, the world's third-largest media company, said yesterday that it would buy the shares of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation that it did not already own for $15.5 billion in stock.

title: A Different Sabbath
description: To the Editor:

title: State Dept. Admonition for Taiwan Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)  Indirectly criticizing a Republican member of Congress, the State Department today reminded Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, that he can make brief stops in the United States only if they are totally private.

title: SOME DISCONTENT AT CENTRIST THEME OF GORE'S TICKET
description: Faced with an undercurrent of grumbling about the centrist tone of its ticket and platform, the Democratic Party devoted much of its convention today to reassuring its liberal base, sending its vice-presidential candidate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, before black delegates to declare his unequivocal support for affirmative action.

title: U.S. Disputes Iraqi Claims Over Damage In Bombing
description: American officials said today that a warehouse bombed by American and British warplanes on Friday in southern Iraq held antiaircraft weapons and other military equipment, and not supplies of food as the Iraqis claimed.

title: Transfer of Power
description: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about an effort by Linux software developers and computer manufacturers to compete with Microsoft's Office applications misspelled the surname of the chairman of the Eazel Corporation. He is Mike Boich, not Boiche.

title: INSIDE
description: Curbing Phone Surveillance

title: Giuliani Faults Failure to Force Sprinkler Work at Fatal Fire Site
description: New York City officials ''blew it,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday, when they failed to determine if a Brooklyn landlord had complied with an October order to repair a defective sprinkler system. A young girl died in a fire in the building last month.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the scaling back of network television coverage of the Republican and Democratic political conventions misstated the name of a series that NBC showed on the Republicans' first night. It was ''Third Watch,'' not ''First Watch.''

title: Val Dufour, 73, Star of TV Soap Operas
description: Val Dufour, an Emmy Award-winning star of television soap operas, died on July 27 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 73.

title: A Down-Home Ramblin' Persona From Brooklyn
description: To look at the weatherbeaten 69-year-old singing cowboy known as Ramblin' Jack Elliott, you would never guess that he began life as Elliott Adnopoz, the son of a middle-class Jewish doctor.

title: Hebron Sovereignty
description: To the Editor:

title: Player's Dream Takes a Detour in the Bronx
description: Martin Lee walked slowly out of the brick building that served double duty as a players' changing and shower room and the public bathroom. His face was reddened, from sickness and exhaustion, and flies buzzed around his head as he offered a slight smile.

title: SONY CHOOSES TRANSMETA CHIP
description: Sony said yesterday that it would use computer memory chips made by the Transmeta Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., in one of its popular models of laptop computers. Sony is a major customer of Intel, the dominant maker of computer memory chips. But it said it would equip the CI model of its Vaio line of laptops with Transmeta's central processing units, which offer more effective power saving. Sony said the chip was a good fit for the Vaio CI, since it is designed as a go-anywhere computer with a built-in video camera. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Suit Filed Over Leak Of Report On Mexican
description: A college professor in Ohio has drawn the unwelcome attention of one of Mexico's most powerful families.

title: Article 2000081692658915263 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Cendant Seeks to Regain Control Over Avis Group
description: Henry Silverman, the chief executive of the Cendant Corporation, made a bid yesterday to regain control of Avis Group Holdings, the nation's second-largest rental car company, at a price the market immediately deemed too low.

title: Con Ed and Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Makes His Last Hurrah
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit Baffled, Flushing Greets a Candidate
description: With an eye toward reaching constituencies not traditionally thought of as Republican, Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday took a subway line nicknamed the immigrant express to Flushing, Queens, a predominantly Asian community that his party is courting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, MITCHELL
description: FEIN-Mitchell. 84. Lost his battle with Parkinson's disease Saturday, August 12. Brilliant engineer, loving husband, father and grandfather. He was kind, political and very generous. He will be missed by his colleagues, his community and his family. He is survived by his wife of fifty-one years, Gertrude, a son, David of Hillsdale, NJ, a son Jeremy, of Denver, CO, a daughter, Lisa Gilford of NYC and two grandchildren, Max and Molly. In accordance with his wishes, Mr. Fein's body has been donated to Columbia University for Parkinson's research.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Bridge column on Monday misstated the dates for the first world charity game organized by the World Bridge Federation. It is Aug. 22 and 23, not this week.

title: Edward Skillin, 96, Commonweal Editor, Dies
description: Edward S. Skillin, a former editor and publisher of Commonweal, a lay magazine of Roman Catholic opinion, died on Monday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 96 and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: Court Curbs Agents' Ability To Monitor Cellular Phones
description: A federal appeals court today struck down parts of a government order that broadly expanded the ability of law enforcement agents to monitor cell phone conversations of criminal suspects.

title: Clinton Makes His Last Hurrah
description: To the Editor:

title: Hall, in Spirited Style, Establishes U.S. Record
description: The 50-meter freestyle is the most elemental of all swimming races, the closest thing to a track sprint, a crouched start, a frothing slice of arms, an urgent white-water finish. Most of the time, there is room to breathe only once.

title: Senator Bradley released his delegates to Vice President Gore
description: By JAMES DAO

title: A Sad Record of Submarine Disasters
description: The Soviet Navy sent a powerful submarine to sea in the late 1980's, determined to strike some fear into the American Navy.

title: Tire Deaths Are Linked To Rollovers
description: Government data released this evening showed that virtually all the recent deaths linked to Firestone tires now being recalled occurred when sport utility vehicles, most of them Ford Explorers, rolled over after the tires failed.

title: Program Recognizes Teachers' Extra Efforts
description: John Caffrey had been teaching English for 31 years when he heard about a new way to gain recognition for his skills, one available to teachers nationwide. The hitch: applicants had to pass a rigorous and time-consuming assessment that included videos of their teaching, samples of their students' work and essays analyzing their classroom techniques.

title: Woods Sets His Sights on Nicklaus's Record
description: A year ago, Tiger Woods turned the P.G.A. Championship into a turning point in his remarkable career.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption yesterday with a picture in some editions showing President Clinton speaking behind a pair of microphones misstated the location. He was at the opening of the Democratic National Convention. (Earlier he had been photographed at a luncheon with members of teachers' unions.)

title: Warring Populisms
description: Depending on your point of view, it was either old-time religion night or dinosaur time at the Democratic National Convention. Two of the party's great roarers, Senator Ted Kennedy and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, were on hand to remind the faithful of the party's traditional New Deal values. John F. Kennedy's only surviving child, Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, reminded voters of that golden era when Democrats like her father could depend on a solid base of blue-collar voters. Earlier in the day Vice President Al Gore was in Michigan, the heart of union country, to warn that ''the powerful interests are going to fight against us with everything they've got'' to prevent the Democratic ticket from defending working families.

title: Chancellor Blames Albany For Shortage of Teachers
description: Further straining his relationship with State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy filed court papers yesterday that forcefully blamed Mr. Mills for the shortage of certified teachers in the city's 99 lowest-performing schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCH, JOHN
description: RUSCH-John. The Board, staff and participants of Union Settlement Association offer our condolences to his wife, Gina Rusch for the loss of her husband. He made a tremendous contribution to the communities in which he lived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAYSTMAN, FRIEDA
description: TRAYSTMAN-Frieda. Of NYC, NY. Died August 13, 2000. Retired from Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCoy. Survived by loving nieces Kathy Traystman and Martha Welch, and sister-in-law Helen Traystman. Private arrangements by family. Donations in her memory to The Ivan L. Rubin Foundation, Inc, 160 West 16th Street, New York, New York 10011.

title: A Daughter Becomes a Valuable Adviser
description: Karenna Gore Schiff reached into her purse and pulled out a clump of typewritten pages. They were pockmarked by harsh X's through several paragraphs, dashes through words and arrows to the margins.

title: Burmese Salads, With the Thermostat on Cool
description: ON my first day in most Southeast Asian countries I invariably have the following conversation:

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Portuguese Wines Uncorked
description: PORTUGAL is renowned for port and Madeira, and for fizzy roses like Lancers and Mateus. It is also known for supplying many of the world's wine corks. But this country also has a thriving table wine industry, which is so little known it is a paradise for bargain hunters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLANCY, MICHAEL
description: CLANCY-Michael. 08/16/'60-07/04/ '98. Your family and friends will never be completely happy again. Does heaven have enough angels yet? Love, your mother, sisters Kathleen, Julia, Kerry and brother James.

title: Unusual Line Of Business For Lawyers
description: Before the recent spate of publicity about deadly accidents involving Firestone tires, Tab Turner, a Little Rock, Ark., lawyer, rarely received more than a call or two a month seeking his advice about legal claims related to defective tires.

title: Rich Meat, Sweet Fruit
description: LAMB with peaches sounds Middle Eastern, but I first came across the combination in a contemporary German cookbook. It is a logical pairing and tastes glorious, with the sweetness of the fruit cutting through the richness of the lamb. But the challenge lay in finding an efficient way to make it, since the original required two separate cooking methods, with a resting period in between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEHN, RICHARD ALLEN
description: PLEHN-Richard Allen. On August 14, 2000. Survived by his devoted wife, Lois Plehn, and four children, Cynthia and her husband Edward Greenwald of Los Angeles, CA, Pamela, Richard and Tina and soon-to-be son-in-law David Max, of New York City. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Wednesday, August 16, 6-9PM, with service at Frank E. Campbell Thursday, August 17, 1:30PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Department of Public Health at Cornell University Medical School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKERNAN, WINIFRED (NEE KILMARTIN)
description: McKERNAN-Winifred (nee Kilmartin). On August 14, 2000. Native of Curry, County Sligo, Ireland. Formerly of Elmhurst, Queens. Beloved wife of the late Joseph P., devoted mother of the late AnnMarie Himberg, and the late Joseph P.; Thomas, Kathleen Cameron and Ellen Yeaw; dear sister of Anne Duffy; fond grandmother of Joseph, Jennifer, Timothy McKernan, Ronald and Donna Yeaw, and Kaitlin and Jamie Cameron. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Receiving visitors Wednesday and Thursday from 24 and 7-9PM. Mass Friday 10:30AM at St. Margaret's Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Party's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern Daylight

title: Prelates Of Russia Set Doctrine On Issues
description: The Russian Orthodox Church adopted a social doctrine today that condemns genetic engineering, homosexuality, euthanasia and abortion, approves of the concept of private property and reconfirms the church's close relationship with the military.

title: PAN-EUROPE'S LOSS
description: United Pan-Europe Communications, Europe's No. 2 cable company, said its full-year loss would be narrower than forecast as a result of lower operating expenses. U.P.C.'s loss before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and stock-option costs could be smaller than 375 million euros ($342 million) instead of an earlier forecast of 400 million euros, the chief financial officer, Charles Bracken, said. ''As we build our subscriber numbers, you're seeing unit costs go down,'' Mr. Bracken said. ''We've started to get better-than-expected operating efficiencies, and we're continuing to reduce overhead and costs in our systems.'' The Dutch company's shares, which had fallen 40 percent this year on waning investor appetite for unprofitable companies, rose 4 euros, to 29.25 euros. The company reported that its second-quarter loss widened to 368.2 million euros, or 0.84 euro a share, from 72.9 million, or 0.19 euro, in the similar period a year earlier. U.P.C.'s second-quarter revenue rose to 238 million euros from 83.1 million in the comparable period in 1999.

title: Edward Brodsky, 70, a Lawyer Who Handled Securities Cases
description: Edward Brodsky, a nationally prominent courtroom lawyer who specialized in securities cases and criminal law cases, died on Friday in New Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, N.Y.

title: Earnings Rise At Brazilian Plane Maker
description: Benefiting from vibrant demand for regional jets, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. reported a 35 percent gain in second-quarter earnings today on a 54 percent surge in sales.

title: Fauchon Opens A Market in Midtown
description: FAUCHON, the legendary Parisian market, has made its debut in New York. Its first American shop opened Monday at 442 Park Avenue, at 56th Street, in the Drake Swissotel.

title: Business Travel; Air traffic systems in Europe are also under increased demand, but there are alternatives.
description: THE Daily Mail of London noted in an article this week that some airlines in Europe are ''manipulating timetables'' -- arbitrarily adding minutes to schedules to buy time against flight delays. One flight from London to Paris that took 50 minutes in 1975 now is scheduled for 95 minutes. That's five minutes longer than the same flight took in 1947, the newspaper said.

title: Editorial Observer; Two Candidates, Seeking Votes With Salsa
description: Still exulting in President Clinton's performance, delegates and party faithful celebrated on Monday night at the Latino Committee 2000's block party in downtown Los Angeles, featuring the queen of salsa, Celia Cruz. The bash felt like a neighborly small-town festival, to the extent that an event brought to you by AT&T, SBC Communications and Verizon -- to mention only the phone companies chipping in -- can manage to feel neighborly.

title: Stolen Calls to Psychics Land Cleaning Woman in Hot Water, Police Say
description: A cleaning woman who was upset about breaking up with her boyfriend made $6,131 worth of phone calls to psychic hot lines from an employer's home here, the police said. She got plenty of relationship advice, they said, but no warning that she would soon be behind bars.

title: RealNetworks Starts Subscription Service
description: August 16, 2000

title: Founder of Corel Resigns From Chief Executive Post
description: Michael Cowpland, the founder of the Corel Corporation, abruptly resigned today from all his executive positions at the ailing Canadian software developer, and put its future in the hands of a new chief executive and a revamped board. He said he would remain a director.

title: Classic Tales (In Video And Velvet)
description: The Salzburg Festival has long adhered to the historic idea of an arts festival as a place apart from the workaday music world. Here artists collaborate in near-ideal conditions, freed to an amazing degree from the scheduling and budget constraints that during most regular seasons necessitate cutting corners and adjusting expectations.

title: Negotiations Are Continuing As Telephone Strike Drags On
description: Unions representing more than 86,000 customer service workers and technicians at Verizon Communications continued to wrangle with the company over several issues yesterday, extending a telephone strike now in its 11th day.

title: Lycos Tops Esimates and Posts Profit Vs. Year-Ago Loss
description: Lycos Tops Esimates and Posts Profit Vs. Year-Ago Loss

title: Russian Chestnuts Done to Nutty Perfection
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is back at the Joyce Theater, where it opened on Monday night in the first of two programs. That is the good news. The bad news is that the all-male ballet company, affectionately known as the Trocks, departs from the Joyce on Aug. 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRTH, MORRIS A.
description: WIRTH-Morris A. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Baer Marks & Upham LLP mourn the loss of our partner and friend after a brief battle against the ravages of cancer. Morris had a distinguished fifty-year career in the practice of law and was most readily identified with over thirtyfive years of legal representation of the State of Israel. Morris was a marvelous person, a student of the law, a teacher of the law to young colleagues at our office and a trusted friend and confidant. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Jean, his sons, Bobby, Billy and John, his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, Vasilia Hughes, and the apple of his eye, his grandson, Alec. We will miss him dearly.

title: Australians Pushing Away From the Table
description: Chalk up another victim of America's eat-on-the-run workplace culture.

title: Pitcher Overcomes Injury
description: A career-threatening injury could shake a young pitcher. Greg Wooten, however, has become even more confident after missing parts of two seasons because of ''Tommy John''arm surgery.

title: COURIER WILL BUY DOVER PUBLICATIONS FOR $39 MILLION
description: The Courier Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Dover Publications Inc. for $39 million, adding special-interest books to its list of titles as it seeks buyers on the Internet. Dover, which had revenue of $32 million last year, sells more than 7,000 publications at bookstores and by mail order. Based in Mineola, N.Y., it reprints books on subjects from architecture to math. Courier identifies buyers on the Internet with special interests and tells them where they can find a particular work.

title: Duval Will Miss P.G.A. Because of Back Pain
description: David Duval, the world's No. 3-ranked player, withdrew from the P.G.A. Championship today because of back pain that has plagued him since July. Duval played in pain at the British Open, and he was forced to withdraw from the International two weeks ago. It is uncertain if Duval would play at next week's World Golf Championship NEC Invitational in Akron, Ohio.

title: 50 Years Later, Reunions Bring Joy to Koreans
description: Under the watchful gaze of North Korean minders, 100 families separated for the last five decades today began the arduous process of rebuilding relationships torn apart by war.

title: Seeking to Clone Schools of Success for Poor
description: Banging on desks and stomping their feet, the students chant daily -- not just multiplication tables and state capitals but big thoughts, too: ''Knowledge is power, power is freedom, and I want it.'' Their teachers carry cell phones, on call for homework help at all hours. Parents sign contracts enumerating daunting demands -- if they slip up, their children can be punished.

title: A Navy in Need
description: The story of the Russian nuclear submarine sunk at the bottom of the Barents Sea with a 116-man crew is terrifying, but it should not be a surprise, especially to the Russian navy. Though the submarine, the Kursk, is one of Russia's newest, and though the details of what went wrong are still sketchy, the only surprise is that this is Russia's first serious submarine accident in more than a decade.

title: President Clintons speech
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's speech to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's speech at the Democratic National Convention referred incorrectly in some copies to Senator Robert G. Torricelli's relationship with Patricia Duff, with whom he watched the speech. The two are not married.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTT, LIDIA (NEE STEINHAUS)
description: KOTT-Lidia (nee Steinhaus). Died on August 14, 2000 in Santa Monica, CA at the age of 81. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Her ashes will be scattered over the Pacific Ocean in accordance with her wishes. She has left us in deep sorrow. Jan, Teresa, Michael, Tara, Mathew, Lidia Jean, Shannon and Alexander

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASES, FRED
description: THOMASES-Fred. The Officers and Staff of American ORT mourn the passing of our friend and supporter, Fred Thomases. His dedication to the Jewish people, children and education is his legacy to the students of ORT. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Florence Thomases, her children and grandchildren. Robert L. Sill, President Brian J. Strum, Exec. VP Paul I. Bernick, Exec. VP Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORSNEY, JEAN
description: TORSNEY-Jean. On August 14, 2000. Cherished daughter of the late George & Katherine Torsney, beloved wife of John Kent, dear sister of Bernard Torsney, George Torsney, Rose Schmidt and the late Patricia Gannon. Also survived by seventeen loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, NY. Funeral Mass St. Raphael's R.C. Church, Thursday, 10AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: A Trend Toward Ambidextrous Investments
description: Tonight, the lobbying firm Patton Boggs was host for a cocktail hour and supper buffet at the Sunset Room in Hollywood. That was not much of a surprise: the chairman of the firm, Thomas H. Boggs Jr., is the son of the legendary Democratic Congressional leader Hale Boggs of Louisiana.

title: Lieberman Preparing For Moment In Spotlight
description: Pledging to avoid ''nasty'' partisan attacks on the Republican presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said in an interview today that he would use his convention address Wednesday night to start ''a conversation with the American people.''

title: Armas Adds Olympics To His World Cup Duty
description: Chris Armas, one of the top midfielders in the country, has been a standout for the United States national team and the Chicago Fire of Major League Soccer, and today he was added to the Olympic team.

title: In Summer, Italy Loves Sex Surveys; Its Just Talk
description: ROME, Aug. 14  The peak of summer, Italian-style, was reached in banner headlines in several of today's leading newspapers, which rated beach resorts by the likelihood of vacationers' having sex there.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELDZAHLER, HENRY
description: GELDZAHLER-Henry. July 9, 1935-August 16, 1994. The Greeks used to say that there is not a short life or a long life. There's only the life that you have. And the life that you have is the life that you're given, the life you work with. It has its own shape, describes its own arc, and is perfect. Kay Bearma

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Dukakis Cousins Go Separate Ways

title: All of the Calories, None of the Virtue
description: AFTER years of being conditioned to choose fruit juice over soda, most people may be surprised to hear that the majority of fruit juice drinks are only marginally more nutritious than a soft drink.

title: PROFIT AT JULIUS BAER
description: Switzerland's biggest private bank, Julius Baer Holding, said first-half profit rose 80 percent as it attracted new customers who shunned the likes of UBS amid management upheaval and constant reorganization. Net income at the 110-year old company climbed to 249 million Swiss francs ($145 million), or 229 francs a bearer share, from 139 million, or 127 francs, in the period a year earlier, beating analysts' expectations and sending the stock up 9 percent. Drawing on its expertise of managing money for the wealthy, family-controlled Baer has outshone rivals by adding distribution channels and eschewing major purchases. UBS has lost customers amid several reshuffles since a 1998 merger that created the bank.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ELECTRONIC ARTS CORP., Redwood City, Calif., which makes software for interactive games, said it planned to split its stock two shares for one. The split will double the number of shares to 142 million while halving the value of each share. The new shares will be issued on Sept. 8 to shareholders of record as of Aug. 25. The shares traded at $91.875, apiece, up $2.3175.

title: U.S. Weighs Rule Changes On Conflicts In Drug Study
description: The huge influx of money into biomedical research is creating unacceptable conflicts of interest for scientists and is eroding the public's trust in the data, scientists and officials said today at a government conference.

title: TRADING APPROVAL EXPECTED FOR AMBEV
description: The largest beverage manufacturer in Latin America, Companhia de Bebidas das Americas of Brazil, or AmBev, could receive approval this week from the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States to sell shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares, in the form of American depository receipts, could start trading in early September. Stockholders in Companhia Cervejaria Brahma, which already trades shares on the Big Board and the Sao Paulo Bovespa, will be given AmBev shares in exchange. AmBev was formed by the $7 billion merger last year of Cervejaria Brahma and Companhia Antarctica Paulista. The company makes 18 brands of beer, 37 soft drinks and 7 brands of bottled water.

title: CONSECO INTENDS TO RAISE $2 BILLION OVER NEXT YEAR
description: Conseco Inc. said in a government filing that it expected to raise $2 billion over the next 12 to 15 months from selling assets and overhauling its consumer-lending unit. Analysts have said Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., needs to raise the $2 billion to regain its investment-grade credit rating. Conseco has debt of $1.4 billion due by Sept. 30, and said in the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the extension of its bank line of credit will be required because of the time needed to sell the assets and complete the revamping. The company has no plans to issue new equity.

title: DNA Tests Lead to Resetting of an Execution
description: Ricky Nolen McGinn, the only inmate ever granted a stay of execution by Gov. George W. Bush, is headed back to the death chamber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AINBINDER, ARTHUR ''ARTIE''
description: AINBINDER-Arthur ''Artie'', 89, of Delray Beach, FL, Formerly of Peekskill, New York. Died August 13th in Long Beach, New York. Survived by Teddy, Lois and Leonard. Loving grandfather, great-grandfather and uncle. Services today in Delray Beach. Contributions to the American Cancer Society or the Heart Fund.

title: Where the Fieldworkers Wear Lab Coats
description: A GROUP of chefs from the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain were sitting on a flatbed pulled by a 1964 John Deere tractor. It plodded along the field, grumbling the entire way. Off in the distance, a woman was crouched over a row of herbs with a crisp white lab coat on her back and a wicker basket at her side. She was harvesting with scissors.

title: Reckonings; Still a Baby Boom
description: America's economic miracle -- which Bill Clinton claimed as vindication in his Monday speech, but George W. Bush insists was an act of God -- didn't begin when Mr. Clinton took office in 1993. And no, it didn't begin with Ronald Reagan either. In fact, it didn't really start until 1996 or so. In other words, this boom is still in its infancy; and like all infants, it remains vulnerable. Mr. Clinton's greatest achievement is that during his second term he avoided the fiscal irresponsibility that might have strangled our ''new economy'' at birth -- irresponsibility that his opponent in the 1996 election would have practiced. Will his successor emulate his example?

title: Convention Events Schedule
description: Following are the principal events scheduled for 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. Pacific daylight time Wednesday at the Democratic National Convention:

title: Cook's Problems Disappear In Opener
description: Dennis Cook was careful yesterday not to complain about his recent workload. On Monday, after a four-day layoff, Cook became the only Mets reliever this season to allow six runs in a game. He retired only one of the eight batters he faced and saw his earned run average rise to 6.50. Manager Bobby Valentine said Cook's lack of work probably affected his rhythm and fastball.

title: Article 2000081691350038807 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: 2 More in Iran Are Detained In Crackdown On the Press
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 14  The crackdown on reformers in Iran continued over the weekend with the detention of two writers. A popular satirist, Ibrahim Nabavi, and a newspaper columnist, Mohammad Qoochani, were interrogated by a hard-line court and detained.

title: Indonesia Leader, Under Siege at Home, Has Mideast Peace Plan
description: In the face of seemingly intractable separatist and sectarian conflicts of his own, President Abdurrahman Wahid plunged into Middle East politics today, offering a complicated formula he said could resolve the deadlock over the status of Jerusalem.

title: Rockies Make a Mess, Letting the Mets to Sweep Up
description: The night had gone so poorly for Todd Zeile that he was receiving mock cheers from the Shea Stadium crowd for catching a routine ground ball. The cheers quickly became sincere.

title: Los Angeles Keeps Its Eyes On Protesters and the Police
description: Long before the Democratic National Convention opened, the Los Angeles Police Department was haunted by unhappy images from the past, from the 1992 riots here to the violent protests at last year's World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWITKIN, ANNA SHENDEROFF
description: SWITKIN-Anna Shenderoff. Died peacefully on August 15. Pianist, teacher in Juilliard and Manhattan School of Music. Beloved sister of Rose S. Rosen. Dearest aunt of Fred, Robert, Nancy and Stacey, and great-aunt of Jesse, Ana, Jacob and Alessandra.

title: U.N. to Establish a War Crimes Panel to Hear Sierra Leone Atrocity Cases
description: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 14  The Security Council agreed today to set up a war crimes tribunal for Sierra Leone, where brutal rebel armies have tortured civilians, amputated their hands and destroyed villages to intimidate innocent civilians.

title: Charles Gibbs, 105, Diabetes Group Leader
description: Dr. Charles Brooke Flint Gibbs, a Rochester internist who was the last survivor of the founders of the American Diabetes Association 60 years ago, died on Aug. 4 in Rochester. He was 105.

title: The Case of the Elusive XO
description: DINING out has its pleasure and its mysteries, and XO sauce is both.

title: A Meeting of the Mind-Sets
description: OF all the dizzying transformations of the workplace, the one that pleases me most is how the nerds have taken charge. My parents (bookworms themselves) always promised that this would happen, and that promise kept me going during the years when I sat with the debate squad in the high school cafeteria, pretending not to notice the snubs from the cheerleaders and the football team.

title: Police Arrest Suspect in East Side Sex Assaults
description: A homeless man who the police said had been haunting the Upper East Side in search of women walking alone was charged last night with sexual abuse and attempted robbery.

title: Cone Has Reason to Smile as Yanks Win a Laugher
description: David Cone was sitting in the steamy third-base dugout in the first inning tonight, contemplating the importance of his start against the Texas Rangers. Cone realized that he had to follow his first victory in 104 days with another positive effort or all of the doubts and the questions about him would creep back.

title: Rams Paying Price of Holding the Title
description: The Super Bowl rematch here at Adelphia Coliseum on Monday night turned into a super squashing by the Tennessee Titans, a 30-3 embarrassment for the St. Louis Rams in a game where the Titans looked pumped and the Rams looked uninterested.

title: Passed Torch, Some Say, Leaves Its Glow Behind
description: Just as Robin Wilson settled into her sofa to watch President Clinton's speech to Democrats on Monday, her telephone rang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BERNARD
description: COHEN-Bernard. In his 89th year, August 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Etta for almost 60 years; devoted father of Steven (Janet) of Princeton, NJ; grandfather of Sherry and Jason, and brother of Morty. Formerly of Baldwin, NY, and Coconut Creek, FL. A member of the U.S. Army in World War II. A greatly respected childrenswear buyer and merchandise manager for Hearns, Mays, Mangels and Jefferson Stores. Service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Judge Orders Man Deported For Serving as a Nazi Guard
description: An 85-year-old Rockland County man faces deportation for having served as an armed guard in a concentration camp where 42,000 Jews and other prisoners were tortured and killed.

title: Bush Won't Be a Dukakis
description: Once before, an incumbent vice president who had loyally served a popular two-term president ran against a successful governor with little national campaign experience. By midsummer, he, too, found himself faced with a deficit in the polls, struggling to define himself beyond the shadow of the president he served.

title: Basil Vodka to Peach Sake: Infusing Spirits With Daring
description: REMEMBER spiked watermelon, that simple summer cooler? You take a whole ripe watermelon, gouge a chunk out of the rind and upend a bottle of ice-cold vodka into it until the melon has absorbed all the liquor. Slice it and serve.

title: Compaq Unveils New Internet Gadgets
description: August 16, 2000

title: Our Towns; My Summer Of Sciatica, A Royal Pain
description: NOTHING quite underscores the driving force of suburban life like sciatica.

title: JAPANESE TRAVEL AGENCY
description: Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, Japan's biggest carriers, said they would create a domestic online travel agency with 11 other airlines operating in Asia and Travelocity.com, the largest United States Internet travel site.''It's like a one-stop travel portal,'' said an All Nippon spokeswoman, Kate Opekar, describing the venture, which will start providing travel services to Japanese consumers before the end of the year. Annual sales are forecast at more than 60 billion yen ($549 million) in five years, according to All Nippon and JAL, which will hold a majority stake in the company.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A top accounting executive asks the S.E.C. to amend a new proposal on auditor independence.
description: THE chairman of Ernst & Young, a major accounting firm that has been supporting the Securities and Exchange Commission effort to tighten rules on auditor independence, said yesterday that the S.E.C.'s rule proposal goes too far and would create too much uncertainty about what activities were permitted.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Home for Machinery of the Internet
description: The Durst Organization, developer of the recently completed Times Square office building at 42nd Street and Seventh Avenue and the owner of a portfolio of Manhattan properties, plans a new speculative project on the block bounded by 11th and 12th Avenues and 57th and 58th Streets.

title: DONALDSON LUFKIN AFFILIATE PLANS TO ACQUIRE ADVANSTAR
description: DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, an affiliate of the Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. brokerage firm, said yesterday that it agreed to acquire the privately held business information publisher and trade show operator Advanstar Inc. for more than $900 million in cash and stock. Advanstar, which had $328 million in sales last year, has been owned since 1996 by Hellman & Friedman Capital Partners III. Both companies are based in New York.

title: An Actor's Schedule Leaves No Time to Star
description: FIVE years removed from his last lucrative acting job, Thurman E. Scott still refused to bite when the television serial people swung by his place, the Actors Theater Workshop, pitched him a role and promised to tailor their taping schedule to his schedule.

title: COMPAQ DIPS INTO NEW ARENA
description: As if the computer business was not cutthroat enough, Compaq Computer has decided to enter another industry with rabid competition and elusive profits: consumer electronics. Yesterday, Compaq introduced several devices meant to be grown-up toys this holiday season, using a new iPaq brand. There is a $249 sleek silver portable MP3 player, a $599 kitchen-white Internet access terminal, and a $499 round black pod that will run a home network. Compaq hopes the devices will produce revenue beyond their purchase prices. The MP3 player's software directs users to find downloads at CMGI's Icast site, which pays Compaq for new users. And the Internet terminal requires users to sign up for the $21.95-a-month MSN service from Microsoft, which shares revenue with Compaq. One source: an ad box that is permanently located in the bottom right corner of the screen. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Liberties; All Shook Up
description: Only a man with an impressive wingspan could have done it. And only a man who had lassoed Arafat and Barak, and Gerry Adams and David Trimble, would have tried.

title: Monster.com Narrows Review to 4 Finalists
description: Monster.com in Maynard, Mass., the job-search Web site operated by TMP Worldwide, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its American account to four finalists. Billings were estimated at $75 million to $90 million.

title: 40 Years Later, Invoking Spirit of New Frontier
description: Invoking the themes that her father offered here 40 years ago this summer, Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg stepped out of her guarded private life and onto the stage of the Democratic convention tonight to lend the family name to Al Gore's presidential campaign and to thank the nation for its support through what had been another difficult year for the Kennedys.

title: Led by Pack of Kennedys From Stage Left, Liberal Wing Takes Center Stage
description: Forty years after John F. Kennedy accepted the Democratic nomination in this city, his daughter, brother, niece and nephew sought to revive the liberal hearts of his party tonight by recalling the slain president's legacy and tying Vice President Al Gore to it.

title: High Court Urged to Hear Microsoft Appeal Quickly
description: Declaring that the outcome of the Microsoft antitrust case could affect nearly every person who uses a computer, the Justice Department urged the Supreme Court yesterday to hear the company's appeal quickly so ''that justice is not denied through delay.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Lox in a Cone: Sliced Thin It's Not
description: FOR many New Yorkers, a brunch without lox is like a candlelight dinner without matches. So when it was Ilya Grozovsky's turn to be the host of a brunch in his Midtown office, he thought he would impress his colleagues with lox. And sugar cones.

title: Protesters With No Message Except, 'Let's Not Go Home'
description: In the end, the confrontation between young people and the police that took place in the parking lot outside the Democratic National Convention on Monday night came down to what it often comes down to: a standoff between police officers who want to go home and young people who don't want to go home.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL RECEIVES FEDERAL APPROVAL TO BUY AMFM
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. won federal approval to buy AMFM Inc. for $23 billion, creating the nation's largest radio broadcasting company after agreeing to sell 122 stations in 37 markets. Federal Communications Commission approval is the final action required for the deal, which was announced last October. The markets where the companies must shed assets include Albany; Austin, Tex.; Cleveland; and Phoenix. The merger will create a media company with more than 850 stations.

title: New York Advances to Play New Hampshire in Finals
description: As happens so often in a Little League game, a coach's son was the hero of tonight's semifinal in the East Regional Little League Tournament at the A. Barlett Giamatti Complex.

title: Addition of Brisby Will Finally Give the Jets a Big Target
description: Vincent Brisby, one of seven players from Bill Parcells's first New England draft still active, is headed for the Jets.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dominican Power Shift Lifts a Father's Hopes for Justice
description: After 12 years, Ted Buczek has learned not to get too hopeful about seeing Pablo Almonte Lluberes stand trial in the slaying of Mr. Buczek's son, a New York City police officer who was shot during a chaotic chase on a dark street in Washington Heights.

title: Stocks Head Mostly Lower on Weakness in Retail Shares
description: Stocks declined yesterday on weakness in retail shares after Home Depot reported earnings that fell short of the most optimistic expectations.

title: THE BOSS; It Takes a Solid Foundation
description: My parents were born in Puerto Rico. My father comes from a very hard-working, very large family -- all in all, there were 18 brothers and sisters, and they helped maintain the little family farm. He came to New York City in the early 1930's as a stowaway, looking for a better life.

title: PROFITS FALL AT ASHANTI GOLDFIELDS
description: One of Africa's biggest mining companies, Ashanti Goldfields, said second-quarter pretax profit plummeted 54 percent, to 7.9 million, hurt by a decline in the price of gold. Hurt last year by bungled bets on the future price of gold, Ashanti nearly collapsed into bankruptcy but its crisis eased after securing new lines of credit and selling a stake in a Tanzanian mine to AngloGold. Ashanti operates mines in Ghana, Guinea and Tanzania and Zimbabwe. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Levy's Spokeswoman Leaving for Publishing Job

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Thank you so much for being alive!''

title: School Construction Jobs to Add Seats for 13,700 Pupils
description: When school reopens in four weeks, there will be room for 13,686 new seats in new schools, new wings and leased classroom space, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOLN, PETER G.
description: LINCOLN-Peter G., Clinical psychologist in private practice in Manhattan and active member of the New York State Psychological Assn. Formerly with St. LukesRoosevelt Hospital Center and Lincoln Institute for Psychotherapy. Graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1965, and recipient of a doctorate in clinical psychology from NYU Graduate School of Arts and Science. Father of Justin Lincoln, Sloatsburg, NY, and Kara Lincoln, Seattle, WA; son of Jerome and Ray Lincoln, Elkins Park, PA; brother of Joseph Lincoln, Penn Valley, PA and Lisa Lincoln, NYC; life partner of Mary McCorry, NYC. Predeceased by his son, Kai Lincoln. We mourn his passing on August 6, 2000. All who knew him are invited to a memorial service that will be held on Saturday, September 9, 2000 at 1:00 P.M. in the auditorium of The New York Society for Ethical Culture at 2 West 64th Street. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021, toward the devel. of a hospice for its long-term patients.

title: Clinton Makes His Last Hurrah
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunken Submarine Sends S O S As Russia Pushes Rescue Effort
description: Battling stormy seas and time, Russian seamen failed twice to hook up a rescue capsule to the nuclear-powered submarine lying broken and powerless on the floor of the Barents Sea with 116 men aboard, officials said early today.

title: Gypsies Still Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Nortel to Buy Sonoma Systems
description: August 16, 2000

title: 'Survivor' Star: One Man Is an Island Villain
description: He is the subject of much outrage and derision on the Internet; critics have called him a manipulative Machiavellian egomaniac; and he seems to be especially irritating to David Letterman, who has labeled him ''that naked fat guy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHENBAUM, A. HYMAN, M.D.
description: KIRSHENBAUM-A. Hyman, M.D. On August 14, 2000 at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Judith Iseson Kirshenbaum and devoted father of Wendy Lipstadt (Nat) & Barry Kirshenbaum (Corinne Benchimol, M.D.). Proud grandfather of Adam and Jordan Lipstadt and Matthew and twins, Lauren and Stephanie Kirshenbaum. For many years was associated in the Department of Neuro Surgery at Beth Israel Hospital. Through his skills as a surgeon he brought healing to thousands. Modesty was his mark, but his service and devotion to friends and community brought him honor, repute and love. He was the rock of our family, our center of gravity. Without him, we are bereft. His life, and our memories will be the inheritance of his children's children. Funeral services at Lincoln Square Synagogue on Wednesday, August 16 at 1 PM. Shiva will be observed at home.

title: Former Argentine President Warns of Economic Peril
description: At a time of deepening concern about the Argentine economy, former President Carlos Saul Menem has predicted that Argentina faces a devaluation and a depression unless President Fernando de la Rua either changes economic direction or adopts the dollar as the national currency.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: In Paris, a Bit of Home

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose as traders bet that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates in the coming weeks. In New York, the euro settled at 91.32 cents, up from 90.49 cents on Monday.

title: Tragedy at Sea
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Like It or Not, North Koreans Tour a Mall in Seoul
description: On their first full day in South Korea after half a century, 100 North Koreans -- in two controlled groups of 50 -- experienced the capitalistic excess of a giant shopping mall today.

title: Albright to Try to Shed Light on Missing Argentine Children
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pledged today that she will work to declassify United States government documents that may shed light on the kidnappings of hundreds of children from dissidents captured by the Argentine military during the dictatorship that governed here from 1976 to 1983.

title: METLIFE AGREES TO ACQUIRE GRAND BANK
description: MetLife Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the nationally chartered bank Grand Bank N.A.; terms of the deal were not disclosed. MetLife said the acquisition was in line with its plan to enter retail banking in early 2001. MetLife plans to rename the concern MetLife Bank once the deal closes. Grand Bank, based in Kingston, N.J., offers banking services to individuals and small businesses in the Princeton area. As of June 30, the bank had total assets of $80 million, deposits of $52 million and shareholder equity of $7.3 million. MetLife provides individual life, property and casualty insurance products and savings, retirement and other financial services.

title: What Joe Lieberman Can Do
description: It was a long time in coming, but last night Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut finally moved to center stage at the Democratic convention. Mr. Gore's arrival in Los Angeles and Mr. Lieberman's emotional speech accepting the vice-presidential nomination sought to move the party beyond its tributes to the Clinton era and to present a new ticket with its own agenda and less baggage. Mr. Lieberman's speech was a blend of personal reminiscence and condemnation of Republican policies on schools and health care. It was a forceful effort, clearing the way for Mr. Gore's all-important address tonight.

title: Nader's Parody Ad Draws Lawsuit From MasterCard
description: MasterCard International Inc. sued Ralph Nader's presidential campaign today, saying a Nader advertisement that parodied one of the company's commercials violated its copyright and trademark.

title: Who's the Disciple?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congressman Squares Off With Brooklyn Challenger
description: Standing next to the entrance of a Brooklyn subway station on a recent sweltering morning, Representative Edolphus Towns shook hands with the last in a trickling stream of rush hour workers and paused to make an observation about his campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHLEFFAR, IRVIN EZEKIEL (ZEKE)
description: SHLEFFAR-Irvin Ezekiel (Zeke). Died August 15 at 89, after a long illness characterized by the same good cheer, courage, and grace with which he lived. Beloved husband of the late Ida, survived by adoring daughters Susan (Gary) Palestrant of Ossining & Jo Ellen (Robert) Winters of Philadelphia; cherished grandchildren Michael, Gregory, and Rachel; loving relatives and treasured friends. His unquenchable wit and love of life endeared him to all. Services Friday, 12:30 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon (914664-6800 for details). Memorial donations American Diabetes Assoc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOIACONO, JOHN C.
description: LOIACONO-John C. Age 36, died August 16, 2000 in NYC after a heroic battle with cancer. Funeral services Saturday at 10AM at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Fairfield CT. Interment Oaklawn Cemetery. Friends may call on Friday, 4-8PM and Saturday, 8:15-9:15AM at the Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about the role of computers in architecture misidentified the architectural firm that created an animated film illustrating the concept for a new General Motors building. The film was created by Kaplan McLaughlin Diaz of San Francisco and overseen by one of the firm's project directors, Mark Miller. (It was later that Mr. Miller established a firm, Miller, Kelly Architects of San Francisco.)

title: IKEA Wins Eviction of Cybersquatter From Web Site
description: August 17, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKE, MARSHALL
description: WOLKE-Marshall. The United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism mourns the passing of Marshall Wolke, International President of the United Synagogue from 1981-85 and longtime leader of the USCJ Midwest Region. During his many years of service to our organization, he demonstrated a firm commitment to Jewish living and to the State of Israel. A kind and compassionate man, he will long be remembered as a respected teacher and community activist. We extend our condolences to his children Judy, Joe, and Jay and to their families. Stephen S. Wolnek, International President Rabbi Jerome M. Epstein, Executive Vice-Presiden

title: Corzine Is Given His Moment In Limelight, but Few Are There
description: Jon S. Corzine, New Jersey's Democratic nominee for the United States Senate, gave an energetic speech today on the floor of the Staples Center in his debut on the national stage. And hardly anyone saw it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: Guns Took Unusual Route to Newark; Ex-Manager of Warehouse Is Charged
description: Most illegal guns reach the streets of New Jersey after being bought legally in Southern states with relaxed gun laws, then smuggled north by car, federal officials say. But up to 120 9-millimeter and .40-caliber handguns took a more direct route, shipped via United Parcel Service from a warehouse in Virginia to homes in Newark by the former manager of the warehouse, according to charges filed this week in Federal District Court here.

title: Returning to Home Turf, Americans Win in a Rout
description: Barbados, a nation without a professional league, had a chance to embarrass the United States tonight, but the Americans avoided any upset with a 7-0 triumph in a World Cup qualifying game at Foxboro Stadium.

title: For These Trailblazers, Wheelchairs Matter
description: Over slick boulders and thick roots, across narrow bridges and through mud that coated their limbs, three hikers in wheelchairs and two on crutches won a 12-hour struggle up a mountain trail here Tuesday to reach a hut that naysayers had said they would never use.

title: City Zip Wins Again In 2-Year-Old Stake
description: City Zip zipped to the head of the class of 2-year-old colts in the East today when he won the Saratoga Special for his third straight stakes victory and his second in three weeks.

title: Specifying the Amount of Green
description: THERE are as many ways to bill a client as there are designers and architects. The confusion arises when the client doesn't know the real cost of things, whether bolts of fabric or a contractor's fee. Fabric, for instance, may have a list price for the public, and a net price that is 25 to 40 percent lower and that is available only to architects and designers.

title: Metro Business; Lease Deal Is Pending
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is close to signing a lease for a site in Lower Manhattan, an official with Brookfield Properties Corporation confirmed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATANIA, ANDREA
description: CATANIA-Andrea. On August 14, 2000. Professor of Law at Seton Hall University School of Law. Loving sister of Lynn Voeffray and Claudia Catania. Treasured aunt of Maxwell and Gavin Cady. Services Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Seton Hall University School of Law for a scholarship fund in memory of Andrea.

title: For Ferry Plans, 1 Nautical Mile Forward, 2 Back
description: Every so often a team of market researchers shows up at one or another Metro-North Railroad station to gauge commuters' interest in high-speed ferry service from Connecticut to New York City. And every once in a while, business and community leaders board a boat for a much-publicized test run, like the one in May from Stamford to East 34th Street, to show that the trip can be faster by water than by car or train.

title: Mary K. Wells, 79, Actress Known for Roles in the Soaps
description: Mary K. Wells, who acted in films, theater, television and radio and was part of a writing team that won two daytime Emmy Awards, died on Monday. She was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: DIAL SPENDS $116.8 MILLION ON 3 BUSINESSES
description: The Dial Corporation, maker of its namesake soap and Purex laundry detergent, paid $116.8 million to buy three businesses in the second quarter, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing. The company bought the Procter & Gamble Company's Coast soap business in the United States and purchased the Zout stain remover in the United States from an undisclosed seller. The purchase prices were not previously disclosed. Dial said a portion of the Zout price depends on sales for three years. Dial also completed its acquisition of Revlon Inc.'s Plusbelle hair-care business in Argentina for $46.5 million. Shares of Dial, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., fell 6.25 cents, to $10.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Japan's Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the speech by Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg at the Democratic National Convention referred incorrectly in some copies to her age when her father was assassinated. She was 5, not 6.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEHN, RICHARD A
description: PLEHN-Richard A. We respectfully offer our most sincere condolences to the family and close friends of Richard, whom we fortuitously knew for more than four decades. We sincerely believe that many of the unique qualities of this highly successful and generous person have been indelibly passed on to his children and will live on through them. The Roos, Carmel and Cohen Families and the Rest of His Friends at GVA Williams

title: GENESEE NEGOTIATES BREWERY SALE TO MANAGEMENT
description: The Genesee Corporation, the brewer of Genesee beer, said yesterday that it had decided to negotiate exclusively with its management to sell its Genesee Brewing unit. The company, based in Rochester, declined to release terms of a management buyout offer or a timetable for completing the negotiations. In May, the company, the No. 5 United States brewer, called off the sale of the unit to Platinum Holdings for undisclosed reasons. Sales at Genesee Brewing have fallen in the last three years from $127 million in the 1997 fiscal year to $103.3 million in 1999. The company's Class B shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $21.

title: Not Bowing to Youth, Torres Wins Trial at 33
description: Dara Torres won the women's 50-meter freestyle tonight in 24.90 seconds, becoming, at age 33, the oldest woman to win a race at the United States Olympic swimming trials. Her half-minute swim, however, was preceded by hours of instruction from an entourage of 10 experts who aided her in everything from her psychological state to her nutrition to the manipulation of her lymph system.

title: BUSH LEADS AMONG TECHNICAL OFFICERS
description: The statistical validity of the findings is clearly open to question, but there appears to be sobering news for Al Gore in CIO Magazine's latest quarterly poll of information technology executives. Among the executives who attended a conference the magazine sponsored in February, 24 percent favored Mr. Gore and just 16 percent endorsed George W. Bush. Among those attending a conference in San Diego this week, though, the Gore/Lieberman ticket was favored by 28 percent, while 46 percent preferred Mr. Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney. Barnaby J. Feder

title: INSIDE
description: McCain Faces Cancer Again

title: The Web Helps Military 'Brats' Find Long-Lost Friends
description: CAROL PASSAR lived in Pennsylvania for only a year, when she was 13, but she left behind her best friend when the military moved her family to yet another Army base in another part of the country. Nearly 40 years later, she was able to find her long-lost friend through an online registry for military ''brats'' like herself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, EDWARD
description: BRODSKY-Edward. The Board, Staff, and Friends of the Garden are saddened by the passing of Edward Brodsky, husband of our esteemed Board member Cynthia. As a pre-eminent member of the Bar and public servant, he made far-reaching contributions to the civic life of New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Gregory Long, President The New York Botanical Garden

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNTEY, BEVERLY WEBER
description: LUNTEY-Beverly Weber. Died August 14, 2000. She was born and grew up in Spokane, Washington. She graduated from the University of Idaho with a degree in Journalism and worked as a reporter for the Spokane Chronicle. She also took graduate work at Northwestern University and wrote a weekly column for the Spokane Chronicle for 20 years. She and her husband moved to New York in 1948. For many years, Beverly was Social Secretary for Mrs. William S. (Babe) Paley. Later, she filled the same responsibilities for Mrs. Fosberg, another of the famous Cushing sisters. Beverly has been active in the community, serving as President of the North Shore Branch of the American Association of University Women, member of the Sands Point Garden Club, the Plandome Women's Club, and an Elder of the Roslyn Presbyterian Church. She was an active participant in Womens Golf at the Sands Point Golf Club. She served on the Board of Helen Keller Services for the Blind and was Co-chairman of the Operating Committee. She was on the Board of the Unversity of Idaho Foundation. She participated for many years on the Student Loan Committee for Port Washington. She has been a member of the Shelter Island Yacht Club, the Gardiner's Bay Country Club and the Shelter Island Union Chapel for nearly 20 years. She was also a member of the Fiscal Advisory Committee for the Village Club of Sands Point. She is survived by her husband, Eugene H. Luntey, and her son Kirk of Ardmore, PA. The funeral service will be private with a memorial service planned for September. She wanted and had her flowers in her lifetime. Donations in her honor can be made to the Beverly and Eugene Luntey Scholarship Fund, Office of the President, LIU, 700 Northern Boulevard, Brookville, N.Y. 11548.

title: So Much Rumbling That He Fears for the Foundation
description: JEW VS. JEW

title: Chinese Immigrants Say Clinics Fill a Need for Inexpensive Care
description: The way Wayne Chang saw it, it was one thing to go to a Chinese medicine clinic for acupuncture or herbal treatments, quite another for a medical procedure.

title: A Metropolis of Poor Children
description: Every so often during a national convention, a politician says something that shines right through the accumulated oratory hanging like fog above the convention floor, creating an image that requires deeper contemplation. Though hardly known for his speaking skills, former Senator Bill Bradley did just that the other night when he told the Democratic convention that if all the 13.5 million poor children in America were gathered in one place, they would form a city bigger than New York -- and ''we would then see child poverty as the slow-motion national disaster that it is.''

title: Schwab to Allow Before-Hours Trading
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that it would begin letting customers trade stocks before United States markets open.

title: Testaverde May Start Against Giants Despite Toe Injury
description: Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde, making an unexpectedly rapid recovery from a turf-toe injury sustained in last Saturday's game, practiced sharply today and might play against the Giants Friday night. If he does play, Jets Coach Al Groh said that he would probably start and that his playing time would not be limited.

title: The New Key Speakers: Daughters and Chums
description: Karenna Gore Schiff, the candidate's daughter, tonight filled the role once played by governors, senators, former presidents and former first ladies by seconding her father's nomination to be president, praising him in remarks for balancing family and government work, and helping her with a dinosaur diorama after a long day of Congressional hearings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARD, LUCIENNE
description: REINHARD-Lucienne. Consist International would like to extend its heartfelt condolences to Albert and Mimi Reinhard and Shasa Weitman on the passing of their beloved daughter and sister Lucienne. Lucy, as affectionately known, was an exemplar of courage, dignity, and grace. Her will to live taught us the meaning of strength and fortitude. She will be missed and her memory will be everlasting. Natalio Fridman and the Consist family

title: So Which Is the 'Education Party'?
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Favorite Son, Allegiance on Display
description: While New Haven's most famous resident, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, appeared tonight before Democratic Party delegates and a national television audience, many supporters back in Connecticut gathered to watch and cheer him and share what they said was a visceral sense of pride.

title: Metro Business; Berkshire and GSB In Bank Merger Deal

title: Why Blacks Doubt Lieberman
description: At the Democratic convention this week, good manners reign supreme. Despite many doubts, most African-American delegates are supporting Al Gore's choice for a running mate, Senator Joseph Lieberman. Even Maxine Waters, the outspoken congresswoman from California, has announced that after talking to Mr. Lieberman about his views on affirmative action, she is now on board.

title: Even a Dorm Can Feel Like Home
description: SINCE college dorm rooms are plain vanilla boxes, only the details distinguish one student's room from another. Accessories like a slouchy lounge chair and a hefty CD rack can personalize the space and make it feel like home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIOTT, MARIAN FRANCIS (FRAN).
description: HARRIOTT - Marian Francis (Fran). Loving daughter of Jeannette (nee Scherf) and Albert, and beloved member of the Sisters of Charity for 50 years, died on August 14, 2000, at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. An educator for many years, Francis taught for 23 years in the parochial school system and for 20 years in the Yonkers public school system. Her giftedness as a teacher of English and Drama was recognized when she was awarded the coveted PTA Jenkins Memorial Award in 1994. A graduate of the College of Mount Saint Vincent, Francis had a Masters of Fine Arts degree from Catholic University, as well as a Master's Degree in Drama, Media and Technology from the New School of Social Research. She served as a Docent for the National Trust at Kykuit and Lyndhurst estates for the past five years. Contributions in lieu of flowers in Sister Marian Francis' name can be made to the Retirement Fund of the Sisters of Charity, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY. Reposing at the Flynn Memorial Home, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY (one block north of Tuckahoe Road) on Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass at Sacred Heart Church, 110 Shonnard Place, Yonkers, NY, on Thursday at 10:30 AM. Interment at Kensico Cemetery.

title: A Life in the Sun For 25 Cents a Square Foot
description: Beaucaire, on the banks of the Rhone, owes its exquisite beauty to the palmy years of the 17th and 18th centuries when all European trade heading for the Mediterranean Sea had to stop there. An architectural jewel in the heart of Provence, Beaucaire was pretty much left to decay when its fortunes turned some 150 years ago. Its tarnished reputation grew worse in the last 40 years as low-income housing began to creep into the city center. Now the town fathers are hoping to change this image by offering newly renovated historical buildings to artists and artisans for monthly rents of less than 25 cents a square foot. At those prices, why not go for 6,400 square feet of studio space, as Mark Stuart, an Australian artist, did. He has moved into a 17th-century building overlooking a tranquil square in the heart of town. And officials are also hoping to make it easy for artists and artisans to buy. Beaucaire's winding streets, basking in the hot southern sun, have Roman roots, medieval touches and an abundance of stunning mansions from the grand period of commercial glory. Under the plan devised by the local government, even foreign applicants can qualify. They just have to be officially recognized as artists or artisans. This could be life-changing information.

title: MEAD TO CLOSE PLANTS AND ELIMINATE 330 JOBS
description: The Mead Corporation, the biggest United States maker of school notebooks, said yesterday that it would close plants in Michigan and Indiana, eliminating 330 jobs to cut costs. The plants in Kalamazoo, Mich., and Indianapolis will be closed by the end of next year's second quarter. Some employees at the Indianapolis factory will be eligible to transfer to other sites. Mead said it had an overlap of distribution services because of more centralized distribution centers. The company will take pretax charges totaling as much as $6 million in the third and fourth quarters to cover the cost of dismissing employees and moving equipment to other company plants.

description: A Gallup poll taken in July discovered the obvious: the Harry Potter books are being read by everyone this summer. Well, almost everyone. Children in low-income families are much less likely to read Harry than their counterparts in middle- and upper-income families.

title: Low-Drama Convention Stirs Hunger for Punditry
description: By the late afternoon, most of the major World Wide Web news sites were no longer able to resist the struggle for life unfolding at the bottom of the Barents Sea. While cable-news channels continued to feature drama-free images from the Democratic National Convention, on the Internet the news from the stricken Russian submarine had taken the lead position on the CBS, MSNBC, Fox News and CNN sites. ''No Signs of Life'' was the Fox site's headline.

description: As health officials outlined plans yesterday to spray heavily populated areas of Brooklyn with pesticides for the first time this year to combat the West Nile virus, they also reported that traces of the virus had been detected in five live birds near Prospect Park and three dead ones in Manhattan and Queens.

title: Little Bottle Opener That Could
description: The jewelry designer Kathy Korvin is one of those chic Parisians who moved to Provence for a healthier life. Now she nips north to Paris on the high-speed train as little as possible, she says, yet business has never been better. This summer, everyone at picnics and outdoor tables seems to be carrying her credit-card-size, silver-plated bottle opener, right; $75, only from Kathy Korvin, 13, rue de Tournon, Paris. Perhaps soon at www.kathykorvin.com.
