title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEICK, WILLIAM JR.
description: FEICK-William Jr. Known to all his friends in various parts of the world as ''The Man who was larger than Life'' died peacefully August 14, in New York. He had homes in Palm Beach, Florida, and Toronto, Canada. Mr. Feick joined the USNR as Lt. (J.G.) in 1944 serving in the Pacific Theater-Amphibious Corp. for three years and later was a Captain in the LST China Theater. A graduate of Amherst College Class of '47, he joined the Crocker Bank in San Francisco in charge of corporate client relations eastcoast U.S. In 1956 he became Treasurer and Chief Financial Officer of The Flintkote Company in New York and in 1959 was named Vice President-Marketing. In 1963 he joined the investment advisory firm of MacKay-Shields Financial Corporation as a partner. Following the sale of the firm to New York Life Insurance Company, he became Managing Director of William D. Witter, Inc. an investment advisory firm, in 1987. Mr. Feick was a member of the Bohemian Club, San Francisco; Ekwanok Country Club, Manchester, Vermont; The York Club, Toronto; The University Club, New York; Shinnecock Hills Golf CLub, Long Island, New York; Long Island Wyandanch Club and the Everglades Club, Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Feick was a Trustee of Green Mountain College, Poultney, Vermont where he was honored with a degree of Doctor of Humane Letters. He served as Financial Chairman of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection, Venice, Italy. Mr. Feick is survived by his beloved wife, Posy; sons Kurt, Fritz and Alex; a sister Nancy Kendall of Marion, Massachusetts; 6 grandchildren, Andrea, Rainer, Greer, Grainne, Kaylee and Brant Feick; step-children Gayle Willson and Brian Boxer and step-grandchildren Blakely and Tiffany Willson. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Green Mountain College or The Peggy Guggenheim Collection.

title: Hospital Security Officers Sue City Over Replacements
description: The union representing New York City hospital security officers sued the city yesterday, claiming that the mayor has decided to replace them with private security guards in retaliation for their asking the State Legislature for permission to carry guns on the job.

title: Concorde Is Stripped of Certification to Fly
description: British and French aviation regulators withdrew airworthiness certification from the Concorde today, effectively ruling the world's only commercial supersonic airliner unfit to fly until it can be protected against the catastrophic safety flaws behind last month's fatal crash near Paris.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Defeating the Psychic Bidder
description: There were virtually no surprises at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Tuesday. Thirty-two teams, including all the top-ranked squads, survived in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship, which will end on Sunday. Play began on Monday with 133 teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGREGOR, JACK R.
description: McGREGOR-Jack R. On August 14, 2000. Former director of the M.H. de Young Museum, San Francisco, CA., and the Witte Museum, San Antonio, Texas. A memorial service will be held in the autumn in the Rothko Chapel, Houston, Texas.

title: Dance With Aliens and Save the World
description: WITH her pink pigtails, orange gloves and platform go-go boots and a green ray gun worn like a garter, Ulala the space reporter is enough by herself to make anyone want to play Sega's Space Channel 5. At its heart is a simple memory game, but that is its least important element. Here we have the ultimate victory of style over substance, a little arcade game encased in glittering color and driven by infectious dance beats.

title: PRUDENTIAL PLANS AN 80% STAKE IN MASTERLINK SECURITIES
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it planned to take an 80 percent stake in the Taiwan money manager MasterLink Securities for about $95 million. George Wang, the chairman of MasterLink, and the state-run Land Bank of Taiwan currently hold an aggregate 20 percent stake in the company. MasterLink manages 13 mutual funds, mostly equity-oriented, and has a total $1.6 billion under management. Newark-based Prudential, the largest life insurer in the United States, offers individual and group life insurance, as well as real estate brokerage and relocation services.

description: THE tiny island of Barbados has not a single yard of railroad track, exactly one airport and only one regular television channel. Put 11 Bajans on a field with 11 Americans, however, and who knows what could happen?

title: U.S., Fearing Swine Fever in Britain, Bans Imports
description: The United States ordered a temporary ban on swine imports from Britain today, joining several European countries that acted after the discovery of swine fever in the country.

title: I.B.M. TO OFFER JUNO OPTION
description: Shares of Juno Online Services surged 24 percent, to $6.125, yesterday after the company announced a promotional agreement with I.B.M., similar to those between other top Internet service providers and computer makers, that analysts said would probably be expensive for Juno. Juno, based in New York, said its free basic service would be distributed to buyers of I.B.M. computers, including NetVista and Aptiva desktop models and I Series ThinkPad portable computers. While Juno did not give the specific terms of the deal, analysts who cover computer makers and those who cover Internet service providers both said it probably involved sizable payments to I.B.M., in line with an industry trend.

title: Defense Preparing For Barrow Debut
description: Middle linebacker Mike Barrow was the Giants' biggest off-season acquisition, the key to a defense overhauled to stress speed and flexibility. But a sprained right knee has kept Barrow from playing in the preseason until now, and the dynamics of a revised Giants defense have been hard to decipher without him.

title: Tibor Kalman: Seeing, Disbelieving
description: SINCE Tibor Kalman was a friend of mine, I'm not able to write an objective review of ''Tiborocity: Design and Un design by Tibor Kalman,'' the New Museum of Contemporary Art's lively retrospective of the late graphic designer's work. But I'd feel idiotic if I didn't write a personal story before the show comes down, this weekend.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With oil prices increasing and the election season at hand, the cry goes up for OPEC to raise output.
description: THE price of crude oil increased again yesterday, even after an American Petroleum Institute report the day before said that inventories rose by an unexpected 7.4 million barrels last week and the federal Energy Information Agency cited a smaller, but still strong increase of 3.4 million barrels.

title: David H. Blee, 83, C.I.A. Spy Who Revised Defector Policy
description: David Henry Blee, a legendary American spymaster who played a critical role in dispelling the climate of paranoia that paralyzed the Central Intelligence Agency's espionage operations against the Soviet Union in the 1960's, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 83.

title: Sports of The Times; Other Players To Test Tiger At Valhalla
description: WHEN you think of Louisville sports, you think of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs, or Muhammad Ali, who now has a boulevard named for him. Or you think of all those Louisville Slugger bats; the new minor league baseball stadium, Louisville Slugger Field, with a statue out front of Pee Wee Reese, a local marbles champion who grew up to be the captain and shortstop of the ''Boys of Summer'' Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: 2 Tie for Lead In Met Life Open

description: Lost while driving in a unfamiliar city? A new Global Positioning System receiver slightly larger than a matchbox attaches to a wide variety of handhelds or laptops, enabling them to provide directions like a native and a moving map that monitors every turn.

description: A homeless man arrested in a series of sexual assaults on the Upper East Side has confessed to eight attacks on women in the last 11 weeks, officials said yesterday.

description: A Suffolk County jury returned a death penalty verdict today against a 39-year-old grocery store clerk convicted of a brutal attack on a female co-worker two years ago.

title: Differences Found in Care With Stepmothers

title: Getting There Is Challenge For Latin America E-Tailing
description: Any one of the 500 million people who live in Latin America can sign on to the Internet, given access to a computer and a phone line. They can buy a book, CD or anything else offered for sale on the Internet, given a credit card. And they can have their purchase delivered to their home or office, given luck.

title: Developers Are Sought For Parcels At Hospital Site
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking proposals from private developers for three sites on the campus of the Queens Hospital Center that are to become surplus property when reconstruction is completed next year.

title: Latin Rock Seeks a Global Moment
description: The Latin Alternative Music Conference, which presented performances and panel discussions from Saturday through Tuesday, set out to be the start of something big. About 700 musicians, recording-company executives, radio programmers, Web site operators and journalists registered for the conference, which was held at the New York Hilton and Towers. Many more people showed up to hear bands from Mexico, Chile, Argentina, Colombia, Venezuela and Austin, Tex. And just about everyone believed that the music they love has an audience eagerly awaiting it, if only they can make contact.

title: Harman in Stock Buyback
description: Harman International Industries, a maker of high-end stereo and audio equipment, said today that it would buy back up to two million of its shares in the next year. The move would be worth $130 million at current market prices. The Washington-based company also declared a stock split of two shares for one, payable Sept. 19 to shareholders of record on Aug. 28. The split will double the number of shares to 34 million. Harman traded today at $66, up $2.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, RUTH
description: ALPERT-Ruth. We extend our sincerest condolences to Gail Kramer, on the passing of her beloved mother. A true ''Woman of Valor'', Ruth embodied the qualities of elegance, warmth and kindness. As Silver Founders of the Medical Center, Gail and Seymour Kramer, have followed in her footsteps in their love and support of Israel and the Jewish people. May Gail, sister, Lynn Scheck, brother, Zane Alpert and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Sidney Adler, Treas. Lee Weinbach, Pres., Nat'l Women's Div. Michael S. Strauss, Chrmn., N.Y. Metrop. Bd.

But neither the clinic nor its doctors were licensed, the authorities said yesterday, after shutting it down and arresting six people.

title: A Ceramic Renaissance For a Town That Potters Made
description: The town of St.-Quentin la Poterie gets its name from the potters, as many as 80 in the 1800's, who set up factories there because of the excellent local clay. When plastic arrived, that industry disappeared -- until Charles Eissautier opened shop in 1983, bringing artisanal pottery back to St.-Quentin. Modern and traditional crockery, decorative objects, outdoor planters, glazed and unglazed, every piece is handmade. The planters are frost-resistant and will not crack in cold winters. Prices go from $7 for a pot 4 1/2 inches high to $215 for a 17 1/2-inch pot like the one above, plus shipping: www.Raison-de-Plus.fr or (011) 33-4-66-22-58-70, La Poterie Eissautier, 371, route d'Uzes, St.-Quentin la Poterie.

title: STRONG RESULTS AT DE BEERS
description: The world leader in the diamond business, De Beers, said its earnings more than tripled in the first half of the year, to $877 million, on a 44 percent surge in sales to a record $3.4 billion. The sales helped reduce the company's stockpile of diamonds, which it had historically used to control prices, by nearly one-third this year, to $2.7 billion. De Beers hopes to charge a premium for its diamonds in exchange for a guarantee that they are not ''blood diamonds,'' stones sold to finance African wars. Alan Cowell

description: THE temptation is to ignore this. To look the other way. To say there he goes again, not many people read his paper anyway, it doesn't matter.

title: Rangers' Rookie, Unfazed by Hex, Stops Yankees
description: He sprinted off the mound and jumped over the foul line after each inning. He sat in the same corner seat in the first-base dugout and placed his glove and his cap to his left. He buried his face in a wet towel and he tried to remain calm in a tense setting.

title: Hewlett-Packard Posts 23% Jump in Quarterly Profit
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported quarterly earnings today that beat analysts' estimates, driven primarily by strong sales of personal computers and printers. Its board also approved a stock split.

title: Pace of Consumer Inflation Registers Only a Slight Gain
description: Consumer inflation increased only slightly last month, the Labor Department said yesterday, reassuring analysts that the Federal Reserve would find no need to raise interest rates again when it meets Tuesday.

title: The Bike Computer: Coxswain and Trainer in a Small Package
description: WHEN you set out for a leisurely country bike ride, knowing the distance you've traversed to the hundredth of a mile probably isn't your first thought. And you might not want to know how much your heart rate increased during the 10 minutes you spent climbing a hill.

title: NOVELL PROFIT IS UP, BUT NOT SALES
description: Novell reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' estimates by a penny a share, but the networking software company's sales slipped relative to a year earlier. For the quarter ended July 31, Novell reported earnings of $8.6 million, or 3 cents a diluted share, down 82 percent from $49.3 million, or 14 cents a share, in 1999. Sales fell 17 percent, to $270.0 million from $326.8 million. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: Prisons Belong In Public Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: The G.O.P.'s Pay Gap
description: Democrats are saying this week in Los Angeles that the military is strong and fit, while campaigning Republicans contend that the Clinton administration has run America's defenses down. It's a complex issue, but in at least one aspect -- military pay -- Republican scorn is misplaced. The G.O.P. platform says Americans in uniform face a 13 percent ''pay gap'' relative to their civilian counterparts. But when President Clinton took office, the gap was already 11.5 percent, all accumulated in the Reagan and Bush presidencies.

title: In Retirement Deal, Cheney Could Keep Options in Office
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican nominee for vice president, retired from the Halliburton Company with millions of dollars worth of stock options that he cannot cash until long after the new administration takes office, the company announced yesterday.

title: RECORD PROFIT AT PETROBRAS
description: Capitalizing on soaring prices, the Brazilian state oil company Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, posted a record profit of $2.5 billion in the first half of the year, in contrast to a loss of $555 million a year earlier. The company's first-half revenue rose 82 percent, to $11 billion, from $6.1 billion last year. The Brazilian government sold $4.4 billion in Petrobras stock last week. Jennifer L. Rich

title: A Prince Idealizes His Love From Afar
description: The Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho had never considered writing an opera until 1992, when she attended the director Peter Sellars's production of Messiaen's ''St. Francois d'Assise'' here at the Salzburg Festival. She felt that she lacked a gift for music of narrative sweep, which she assumed opera demanded.

title: Four Executives Leave Barnhart/CMI
description: Four executives from Barnhart/ CMI Marketing, Advertising and Public Relations in Denver are opening an agency of their own, to be called Workhorse Advertising in Boulder, Colo.

description: It will be an emotional P.G.A. Championship for Jack Nicklaus, whose mother, Helen, died today at age 90, in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Aug. 8 with an article about West Nile virus misstated the origins of the house sparrow, which can harbor the organism. The bird was introduced to America from Europe; it is not a native species.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTHA
description: STEIN-Martha. On August 15, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Albert Stein. Loving mother of Eve Stein. Services Friday, August 18, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Wonder How You'd Look In Yellow Eye Shadow?
description: ALTHOUGH I do not wear makeup, I live with two experts on the subject. My 9- and 11-year-old daughters are so attuned to the nuances of cosmetics that they can tell from a distance of 20 paces if a woman gels her eyebrows.

title: . . . And Holders Of Crystal To Put Them In
description: Crystal candleholders from Herve Baume are a must-have for elegant houses in Provence (left, Photophore a Piedouche 3, hand-blown crystal, 11 1/2 inches high, $110). ''Simple in design, noble in material,'' said Mr. Baume, an antiques dealer and designer of garden furniture and accessories. He left Paris for Avignon 25 years ago to turn his refined eye on Provencal style. His Web site, www.herve-baume.com, will be ready in November. Until then, fax (011) 33-4-90-27-05-97 for a beautiful catalog, $25 (the price will be deducted from the first purchase); Herve Baume, 19 ter, rue Petite Fusterie, Avignon; (011) 33-4-90-86-37-66

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit yesterday with an Arts Abroad article about kinetic art at the Hayward Gallery in London misstated the location of the Van Abbemuseum, which supplied the illustration of Moholy-Nagy's ''Light-Space Modulator.'' The site, Eind hoven, is in the Netherlands, not in Sweden.

title: McCain Discloses New Case Of Malignant Melanoma
description: Malignant melanoma, a potentially severe form of skin cancer, has been diagnosed on the left temple and arm of Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican and former presidential candidate, his aides said today.

title: A Costly Defeat For the MetroStars
description: As Tampa Bay forward Mamadou Diallo's third goal of the game rolled into the net in overtime last night, the visiting MetroStars' night of woe was complete: defeat added to injury. And it left them steaming.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: HASBRO, Pawtucket, R.I., named Alfred Verrecchia, chief financial officer, to be president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Herbert Baum, who became chairman and chief executive at Dial Corp.

title: What Files to Back Up, And When and How
description: Q. I understand that backing up files on my Windows 98 computer is a good thing, but how do I figure out what I need to back up, as well as when and how to perform the task?

title: I.B.M. Dives Into Bioinformatics Arena With $100 Million Investment
description: August 17, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, R
description: FIELD-R. Henry, 92. On August 14, 2000 at King St. Nursing Home, Greenwich, CT. Originally from Providence, RI. In loving memory. Survived by loving wife, Nan, son Gregory, daughter Alexandra, stepchildren Malcolm Starr, Cynthia Starr, Elliot Goss, Dana Avison and numerous grandchildren. Served as Secretary at Gorham Manufacturing Company, investment counselor, as well as Rhode Island State Purchasing Agent. In addition, participated in numerous community and civic activities in various significant capacities. Retired from US Navy with rank of Lieutenant Commander and awarded Bronze Star Medal and two battle stars in relation to Iwo Jima and Okinawa campaigns. Memorial service is at the Zion Episcopal Church, 3PM, Saturday, August 19, Manchester, VT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Williams College.

title: In West, Logging Won't Reduce Fire Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Good Eye,' Charging By the Glance
description: IN her book-lined Greenwich Village apartment, Judith Young Mallin shuddered, recalling her intimidating brush with a top interior design team. For Ms. Mallin, an expert in Surrealist art, it was like entering a hall of mirrors.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Chemical Companies Form Online Venture
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, BASF A.G., the Dow Chemical Company and five other leading chemical makers said today that they were investing $100 million to create a joint venture for buying and selling chemicals over the Internet.

title: In Praise of the Mom-and-Pop I.S.P.
description: FOR the past four years, I have remained loyal to my Internet service provider. It is not EarthLink, nor is it MindSpring. And it is definitely not America Online.

title: Medical-Research Official Cites Ethics Woes
description: The chief federal official overseeing the safety and ethics of experiments with human subjects said today that conflicts of interest in medical research were so troublesome that ''the system may have gotten entirely out of control'' and might have to be reorganized.

title: Libraries and Catalogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Appliance With A Purpose
description: ABOUT half of all American households now have personal computers, a trend that is astonishing considering that PC's are expensive, complicated and unreliable, compared with other household appliances. Conversely, about half of all homes have managed to resist buying computers until now. That annoys the Microsoft Corporation, which hates the idea of the country being divided in two. (Microsoft hates the idea of anything being divided in two.)

title: Raymond J. Broderick, 86, Federal Judge
description: Raymond J. Broderick, a former federal judge who closed a Pennsylvania institution for the retarded and disabled and ruled that Philadelphia should not have paid for a platform for a visiting pope, died on Aug. 6 in a retirement community in Gladwyne, Pa. He was 86.

title: Love, Celestial and Corporal, Celebrated to a Reggae Beat
description: Prayer and party were never far apart when Buju Banton performed on Sunday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom. He sang a Jamaican version of the Lord's Prayer, and he preached the long-running message of conscious reggae: determination in the face of oppression, backed by Rastafarian faith. He also touted his sexual prowess, calling himself a ''love sponge'' and a ''champion,'' bounding across the stage while women in the audience laughed and squealed with delight.

title: CHINA EXPORT SURGE SLOWS
description: China's export growth slowed in July from its torrid first-half pace, signaling that a yearlong trade surge might have peaked. July's exports rose 24.1 percent from a year earlier, to $21.48 billion, according to figures from China's foreign trade ministry. Imports rose 40.1 percent, leaving a single-month trade surplus of $1.99 billion, much smaller than the $3.4 billion posted in July 1999. July's rise was the slowest of any month this year and came in below expectations.

title: Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend on Aug. 11, about the Austrian chef Kurt Gutenbrunner and his new Manhattan restaurant, Wall se, misstated the site of Tantris, a restaurant where he once cooked. It is in Munich, not in Vienna.

title: Candles Dipped in Tradition . . .
description: The handcrafted candles, left, narrower at the tip, are made by dipping, a technique of the Premontres monks, which forms even layers of wax from the wick outward. Ciergerie des Premontres is among the last French companies to make candles in the old style. Colors and sizes to order. An ivory candle, less than an inch in diameter and almost eight inches high, is about 20 cents. Visitors can see candles made. Shipping, (011) 33-4-90-95-71-14; e-mail to dubois.emmanuelle@voila.fr; Ciergerie des Premontres, 2, avenue Francois Atger, Graveson.

title: Man Charged in Break-In Is a Suspect in 8 Others
description: A man who the police suspect may have committed a string of violent Upper West Side break-ins was charged yesterday with trying to burglarize an apartment on West 95th Street. The break-ins, during which one couple was stabbed, another was bludgeoned with a flashlight and one man suffered a fractured skull, sent a wave of fear through the neighborhood.

title: Nippon's Wireless Unit Is Said to Be in Talks on U.S. Venture
description: The wireless arm of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone of Japan, the world's biggest communications company, is in preliminary negotiations to acquire a minority stake in the pending wireless joint venture between the BellSouth Corporation and SBC Communications Inc., two of the local Bell telephone giants, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Liberal for a Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: In Online Auctions of the Future, It'll Be Bot vs. Bot vs. Bot
description: THEY are called shopbots, buybots, pricebots or just plain bots -- the ''bot'' is short for robot. The name is playful, but the reality is all business because shopbots are meant to roam the Web all by themselves one day, efficiently buying and selling goods and services for people and companies.

title: CINAR SEEKS MORE TIME
description: Shareholders of the animated filmmaker Cinar Corporation, who have been unable to trade their shares for the last five months, were warned by the company that several more months might pass before revised financial statements were delivered to regulators. After accusations of tax fraud and the disclosure that $122 million was missing, the Montreal company was ordered to revise its accounts for the last three fiscal years. Most of the lost money has been recovered, and television programs continue to be made. But several lawsuits have been filed, and trading in Cinar shares has been suspended by the Nasdaq and Toronto stock markets. Timothy Pritchard

title: Lieberman, With a Hand From Jesse Jackson, Courts the Party's Liberal Wing
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman continued his efforts today to win the full support of the liberal wing of the Democratic Party as one of its prominent members, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, went before the New York delegation to praise the historic alliance between Jews and blacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING
description: LEVINE-Irving. 95 years old. Died August 15, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Susan Houston, Arthur Levine and the late Beth Siegel. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Elisabeth, James & Magda. Dearest brother of Betty Allen & Alice Sadowsky. Services Thursday, 10AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Rank and File Get Star Support

title: AT HOME WITH/Apple Parish Bartlett; Behind the Chintz Curtain, the Legacy
description: THE centerpiece on the table was a humble ceramic head of lettuce, just as Sister Parish, the grande dame of American decor, had placed it there decades ago. But on a recent afternoon, as the summer clouds finally parted to allow in the buttery northern sunshine, everything else in the room was on the brink of commotion. The chintz was about to hit the fan.

title: MITSUBISHI COVER-UP REPORTED
description: Japan's No. 4 automaker, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, withheld complaints about its vehicles that would have led to recalls in the last 30 years, the newspaper Yomiuri said, citing unidentified sources. Katsuhiko Kawasoe, president of Mitsubishi Motors, declined to comment on the Yomiuri report, adding that the company had already begun a review of procedures for dealing with product complaints. The paper said the company began hiding customer grievances in Japan after a 1969 law required carmakers to file recall notices with the government after receiving complaints.

title: The Corporate Redesign of a Stumbling AT&T Is Seen Next Month
description: With its stock price down sharply, AT&T will probably decide on a significant restructuring next month, possibly including a leveraged buyout led by John C. Malone of the company's consumer long-distance telephone business, people close to AT&T said yesterday.

title: Ethnic Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DEMOCRATS
description: A SLIP IN TIME -- Some Democrats have been grumbling that the convention schedule has been very loose, but others see that as a virtue that has helped their ratings. PAGE A21

title: Forest Service Is Scrambling To Find Enough Firefighters
description: Its bureaucracy stretched thin by the burdens of battling wildfires scorching the West, the United States Forest Service has begun bringing back retired workers, hiring employees' spouses and taking other unusual steps to increase the number of people available to fight the fires.

title: Starbucks to Absorb $20.6 Million Charge on Failed Investment in Living.com
description: August 17, 2000

title: NET STRONG AT HOUSEHOLD GIANT
description: The world's largest maker of kitchen and bathroom supplies, Reckitt Benckiser, reported strong earnings that benefited from a focus on top-selling brands like Lysol and from merger-related cost savings. Net income for the second quarter grew 15 percent, to $:71 million, or $106.5 million, excluding revamping charges and nonoperating items. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $:807 million, or $1.21 billion. Suzanne Kapner

title: In DVD Case, Judge Rules That Computer Code Can Be Regulated
description: In DVD Case, Judge Rules That Computer Code Can Be Regulated

title: Protesters Focus on the Los Angeles Police
description: A fourth day of street protests, this time against corruption and brutality in the Los Angeles Police Department itself, proceeded in relative calm today, with a few thousand demonstrators chanting slogans like ''L.A.P.D., you can't hide, we charge you with genocide'' as ranks of officers looked on impassively.

title: Juno Surges After Distribution Deal With I.B.M.
description: August 17, 2000

title: Cultural Revolution, Chapter 2; Expatriate Artist Updates Maoist Icon and Angers Old Guard
description: With a typically enigmatic installation that won high honors at the most recent Venice Biennale, the expatriate Conceptual artist Cai Guo-Qiang has unexpectedly achieved every artist's dream: he has provoked a debate, long overdue, in his officially stifled native country about the meaning of art, originality and the avant-garde.

title: Essay; Gore's Audible In Bishkek
description: In his you-never-had-it-so-good stemwinder the other night, Bill Clinton twice deftly stepped on applause lines for Joe Lieberman. Concentered all in self, the reluctantly departing president failed to impart a single behind-the-scenes anecdote to dramatize the leadership qualities of his loyal sidekick, Al Gore.

title: A Web-Based Courier Service For Those Who Just Can't Wait
description: In terms of speed, the New York Minute seems to have been eclipsed by Internet Time. Compared with the almost instant gratification of e-mail, waiting for an overnight courier to deliver a package can feel like waiting for a glacier to move.

title: Surfing the Web for Sites on the Real Thing
description: THERE are two excellent reasons to go Web surfing for the real thing. The first reason is if you live along the Southern California coast, or in Hawaii, or on the Outer Banks or anywhere else with wave action and you want to find out whether the surf's up and the sun's going to stay out.

title: Retooled Lieberman Sticks By Master
description: It was a new-model Joseph I. Lieberman, hastily retooled to the exigencies of a national campaign, who took the stage tonight as the presumptive Democratic vice-presidential nominee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, PATRICIA M.
description: SIMMONS-Patricia M. Of Brightwaters, Long Island on August 16, 2000. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Brad Simmons. Loving daughter of Florence McNally. Dear sister of Regina Boyle and Kevin McNally. Reposing at the Frederick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Causeway). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Friday 10:00 AM St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, Long Island. Visiting Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations be made in Patricia's name to St. Patrick's R.C. Church, 9 North Clinton Avenue, Bay Shore, NY 11706.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Aug. 1 about the effect of the Republican Party's efforts to keep its national convention free of discord misstated the source of the phrase ''do no harm.'' It is from Hippocrates' work ''Epidemics,'' not from the Hippocratic oath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUTH
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruth. In her 87th year. Beloved wife of Barnet for over 66 years. Adored sister of Helen Morganstein. Survived by her loving children, Arthur (Judy) and Robert (Renee) of NYC, and grandchildren, Dina and Michael Daniels, Debra and Evan Avidane and David Schwartz, and greatgrandchildren, Drew, Justin and Troy Daniels. Services Thursday, 1:15 PM, The Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Mr. Everything at the Conde Nast Cafeteria
description: SEAN J. KILLEEN, director of the most famously exclusive employee cafeteria in the world, hovered just behind the hot-entree station ''reading faces,'' as he put it. Eager faces, hungry faces, some of them bold-face faces, they belonged to the mob of impeccably groomed knowledge workers who were queuing up for the barbecued spareribs.

title: Indonesian Leader Disarms a Feuding Legislature With Laughter
description: With puns, jokes and a touch of naughty wordplay, President Abdurrahman Wahid lifted the mood of Indonesia's bitterly feuding legislature today, soothing it with the fundamental message of his presidency: debate and disagreement are acceptable, even healthy.

title: Treasuries Fall on Fear of Eventual Rate Rise
description: Bond prices fell yesterday on concern that yields did not reflect expectations that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again later this year.

title: Inch Here, Strike There And the Mets Tumble
description: The standing may not have shown much change, but the Mets were feeling pretty good about themselves entering last night's game at Shea. They had completed a doubleheader sweep for the third time this season on Tuesday. But the tiniest things can turn a team's momentum. It can be the starting pitcher, or even a matter of inches.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The dollar slipped against the euro as a consumer price report left intact expectations the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this month. In New York, the euro settled at 91.51 cents, up from 91.32 cents.

title: Federal Officials Say They Will Toughen Standards for Tires
description: Facing growing criticism that regulators should have spotted problems with Firestone tires sooner, federal officials said today that they were working on tougher tire rules, particularly for sport utility vehicles and other so-called light trucks.

title: Legal Firms Cutting Back On Free Services for Poor
description: Many of the nation's biggest law firms -- inundated with more business than they can often handle and pressing lawyers to raise their billable hours to pay escalating salaries -- have cut back on pro bono work so sharply that they fall far below professional guidelines for representing people who cannot afford to pay.

title: Filmmaker Opens a Door To Show Gore Being Al
description: Spike Jonze, the 29-year-old director of ''Being John Malkovich'' and one of the coolest filmmakers in Hollywood, picked up the phone several weeks ago and got what he called one of the biggest surprises of his life. The Gore campaign asked him to fly to Nashville and hang out with Vice President Al Gore and his family, and then make a movie about the Gores for the campaign.

title: Getting Better Every Year
description: Thirteen years ago, an Aix-en-Provence company called Carocim brought back traditional cement tiles, which had been hugely popular in the mid-19th century. They are made to last a lifetime. Christian Bertheas, the company's owner, says, ''The best advertising I have are the happy clients who see their tiles become more beautiful right before their eyes as a natural patina develops with wear.'' Carocim tiles (from $4 for a plain 8-by-8-inch tile to $6.50 for a frieze tile with elements imitated from Matisse; shipping extra) are in New York, to the trade only, at Studio 11, 250 West 50th Street; (212) 387-8786.

title: I.B.M. FOCUS ON GENE RESEARCH
description: I.B.M. said it would invest $100 million over three years to develop new products and services to help analyze the flood of data being produced by the Human Genome Project and other life sciences research. The company also said it would create a life sciences unit to sell supercomputers, database management systems and e-business services to pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies and research institutes. The genome project and related efforts are producing huge amounts of data that must be sifted for the information that could lead to new drugs. I.B.M. said the market for information technology products used in life sciences was expected to grow to more than $9 billion by 2003 from $3.5 billion today. Andrew Pollack

title: Democrat Would Also Broaden Security Agenda : 'Pre-emptive Diplomacy' Is the Key to Gore Policy
description: LOS ANGELES  If Al Gore is elected president, his foreign policy is likely to emphasize pre-emptive diplomacy and increasingly bring issues such as global epidemics and environmental damage into the national-security equation, according to the Democratic Party platform and Mr. Gore's foreign policy advisers.

title: Season of Surprises: British Plays Trade on the Unexpected
description: It really isn't spoiling anything to reveal the final lines of the two most recent plays by Alan Ayckbourn. They are, as a matter of fact, exactly the same, though spoken by different actors. And they are not concluding words that seem destined for immortality: ''Ah, well. That's life, I suppose.''

title: E-Mail Fans Are Friendly Folks, A Sociology Study Indicates
description: The more you use the Net, the more likely you are to be in touch with friends and relatives, whether in person, by phone or by e-mail. At least that's what Keith Hampton, an assistant professor in the department of urban studies and planning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Barry Wellman, a sociology professor at the University of Toronto, found after analyzing a survey of 40,456 North Americans.

title: Gore Eager To Provide Previews Of Address
description: As Al Gore tinkers with the final version of his address to the nation, his speech has come together in what he and his aides describe as a political self-portrait: heavy on personal biography, policy detail and a vision for the future, all composed in his own hand and in his precise syntax.

title: Phone Strikers Threaten End Of Pact Talks
description: In a development that could drastically change the direction of a 12-day walkout by more than 86,000 employees of Verizon Communications, representatives for nearly two-thirds of the striking workers said yesterday that they would break off negotiations if they did not reach an agreement with the company by midnight tonight.

title: Editorial Notebook; For Starters, Ignore All the Advisers
description: Now comes the moment when Vice President Al Gore gives his big speech, and most knowledgeable Democrats have the good sense to be scared to death. Mr. Gore's best attributes do not shine past the teleprompter, and over the years, the microphone has not been his friend.

title: Arranged Marriages, Minus the Parents
description: HARSHA KUMAR, a 29-year-old technology officer for an e-commerce company in Westborough, Mass., wanted to find a wife. And Mr. Kumar, who was born in India and educated in the United States, wanted to begin his search in a way that blended both Old and New World sensibilities.

title: Nipping at the Heels of Lazio, Stop After Stop
description: Among the demonstrators greeting Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, on a Harlem sidewalk today was a tall, bearish man dressed casually in khaki pants and a dark golf shirt and clutching a couple of slips of paper.

title: St. John's Journal; Cruise Ships Descend On Newfound Bonanza
description: In the workaday harbor here, normally plied by tugs, tankers and freighters laid up for repairs, Le Levant offered a startling contrast on a recent day: a sleek French cruise ship disgorging 50 affluent American tourists.

title: Ford Highlight Film Started Early
description: Childhood memories are quirky, sometimes not so much in what they leave in as what they leave out. I remember watching the fourth game of the 1950 World Series on television -- it was an October afternoon, a time on the calendar when kids across the country suddenly developed mysterious illnesses and had to stay home from school, and no one had even dreamed of playing a World Series game at night.

title: LIEBERMAN SETS STAGE FOR GORE AS DEMOCRATS SEAL THE TICKET
description: Albert Arnold Gore Jr., who steadfastly served as vice president through an often tumultuous eight years, was nominated for president tonight after his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, introduced himself to America with a forceful appeal on behalf of Mr. Gore and a muted rebuke of Gov. George W. Bush.

title: British Telecom Expected to Raise Stake in German Concern
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. is expected to announce Thursday that it will take control of Viag Interkom, a German telephone company, by doubling its ownership stake to 90 percent in a deal worth about 6 billion euros ($5.46 billion), according to executives close to the deal.

title: Woods Eyes Mark; Rivals Eye Woods
description: For anyone not named Tiger Woods, it has become even more difficult to win major championships.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH GETS 6 MONTHS OF CLARITIN EXCLUSIVITY
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it had won an extra six months of exclusive United States sales of its biggest product, the Claritin allergy drug, by conducting research on how the medicine works in children. The Food and Drug Administration rewards companies for conducting pediatric studies by keeping generic competitors off the market for six more months. A key Schering-Plough patent on Claritin could expire in June 2002. With the six-month extension, the drug would face generic competition in early 2003. Schering-Plough's shares rose $1.3125 each, to $41.8125.

title: April Subway Derailment Is Linked to Cracked Rail
description: Transit investigators have determined that a badly rusted rail that had cracked caused a subway derailment north of 59th Street in April, stranding 1,800 riders underground for more than two hours and leading to chaos throughout the subways. The problem with the rail had been noticed almost a year earlier but was never repaired.

title: Finding Ways to Rehearse Without Being Cursed; Musicians Improvise, and Go High-Tech, In Search of Places to Practice Their Riffs
description: For most New York musicians, practicing without the interruption of a broom handle banging on the ceiling is a perennial problem. Practice rooms are expensive, and there are only so many rooftops. So the solutions have become more and more creative, from using high-tech gizmos to funnel an instrument's sound into headphones to retreating to the privacy of a boat deck.

title: After 87 Years, a Proud Mom's Biggest Moment
description: On the day that her beloved Democrats were to nominate her beloved son for president, Pauline LaFon Gore sat in an elegant ballroom at the Regal Biltmore Hotel and greeted a long line of admirers who had come to pay tribute to the 87-year-old matriarch of the Gore family.

title: MERRILL SHUTTING SHOPPING SITES
description: Merrill Lynch still wants to help its small-business customers get good deals on office supplies. But it no longer is the place for individual investors to turn for bargains on blazers or to bid on Beanie Babies. Less than a year after leaping headlong into electronic commerce, Merrill is quietly pulling the plug on two World Wide Web sites designed to help its brokerage customers make consumer purchases, Shopmerrill.com and Merrillauctions.com Both sites are scheduled to shut down at the end of August. ''Basically, what we're doing is refocusing the e-commerce efforts on business-to-business instead of business-to-consumer,'' said James Wiggins, a Merrill spokesman. ''After experimenting for a while, we made a determination that there wasn't a huge demand for the shopping sites.'' Patrick McGeehan

title: Instant Aeries For TV's Eyes
description: Phil Alongi was eager to share a view of the Democratic convention from his favorite perspective. ''Over here,'' he said excitedly, motioning to a temporarily uncrowded corner on the convention floor near the Tennessee delegation. ''I want you to get the whole effect.''

title: Olives Unlimited
description: In Provence, a good vintage can refer to wine, or it can refer to olive oil. Oliviers & Company specializes in all things olive oil, including salad bowls, metal flasks, bottles and a choice of 25 vintage oils produced all over the Mediterranean neighborhood, from Provence to Tuscany, Andalusia, Crete and Sicily.

title: Proposed Bill to Fund Research Only : Britain Seeks to Clone Human Embryo Cells
description: In a major development in an continuing scientific and moral debate, the British government proposed Wednesday to permit the cloning of human embryo cells  but only for research and healing and not reproduction.

title: Russia Calls for Help From West As Hope for Sub Survivors Fades
description: Russian naval forces failed again today to dock a rescue vehicle onto the sunken and disabled submarine Kursk as President Vladimir V. Putin ordered his military commanders to accept Western offers of assistance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINGSWORTH, SCHUYLER
description: HOLLINGSWORTH-Schuyler. Of Chestnut Hill, on Tuesday, August 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Anne (Delano Grant) Hollingsworth. Devoted father of Schuyler Hollingsworth, Jr. and his wife Deborah, of San Marino, CA, Frazier Curtis and his wife Jacqui, of Littleton, CO, Amor Hollingsworth and his wife Fatima, of Fullerton, CA, and James Freeman Curtis and his wife Edie of Lincoln, MA. Also survived by a brother Amor Hollingsworth, Jr., his first wife, Pauline Curtis Hollingsworth, seven grandchildren, his three stepchildren, Katherine Marshall, of Washington, DC, Kim Marshall and his wife Rhoda Schneider of Brookline, MA, Laura Marshall, of Boulder, CO, and four step-grandchildren. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend a Memorial Service at Trinity Church (Copley Sq.) on Tuesday, August 22 at 11:00 A.M. Immediately following the Memorial Service, relatives and friends are cordially invited to attend a reception at the Harvard Club, 374 Commonwealth Ave., Boston at approx: 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138. Burial will be private. J.S. WatermanEastman-Waring Funeral Service, 495 Commonwealth Ave., Boston, MA. 02215, phone (617) 536-4110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAOLINI, ALBERT F.
description: PAOLINI-Albert F. Of Easton, CT, died peacefully at home on Tuesday, August 15th. He was the husband of Barbara Paolini. Retired president of Tilcon CT, Inc., Mr. Paolini was involved in the construction industry for over forty years, formerly serving as Senior Vice President of D'Addario Industries. During his career he served as an officer of many professional associations and was highly regarded as a skilled labor negotiator. A graduate of Peekskill Military Academy and Rutgers University, he was a standout athlete throughout his school years. He had a distinguished record as an officer in the United States Navy during the Korean Conflict, serving as a frogman with the elite UDT#

title: So Here's This Jewish Guy Who Gets Nominated . . .
description: No doubt about it, Joseph I. Lieberman is a trailblazer. Tonight he surely became the first vice-presidential candidate in American history to begin his convention speech with a mother-in-law joke.

title: Gymnastics Plan Is Defended
description: Bob Colarossi, the president of USA Gymnastics, spent much of today defending the subjective process in the selection of the women's Olympic team. While the men's team is comprised of the top four overall finishers from the combined results of both the nationals and the Olympic trials, and two additional gymnasts picked by a committee, the women's team is less structured.

title: Germany Produces Electronic Signature Bill
description: August 17, 2000

title: Cultural Sabotage Waged in Cyberspace
description: THIS summer, Frank DeGraff, a 19-year-old college student, decided that he wanted to invest money through the Web, so he started working three jobs. When he had saved $200, he went to RTMark.com and placed the money in one of the site's funds, the Education Fund.

title: So Which Is the 'Education Party'?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It wasn't easy, but I guess we figured it wasn't going to be, and that's why we did it.''

title: Arafat Reassesses Declaration of Statehood
description: Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestinian leadership was reassessing its plan to declare Palestinian statehood on Sept. 13.

title: Quarterly Profit Falls 14% at News Corporation

title: Lazio as a Sponsor of Bills
description: This is a 30-second advertisement, titled ''Effective,'' that Representative Rick A. Lazio's Senate campaign began showing in upstate New York markets yesterday and will be shown in the rest of the state today. It comes as Mr. Lazio continues a bus tour of the state that began yesterday and is to conclude on Monday. Mr. Lazio's aides said the advertisement, produced last month, was not timed to coincide with the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, where Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Lazio's opponent, spoke on Monday night. It is a response, they said, to what they consider to be Mrs. Clinton's distortion of Mr. Lazio's record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EYLES, DAVID
description: EYLES-David, 60. Retired vice chairman and chief credit officer of FleetBoston Financial Corp., died unexpectedly at his home in South Carolina on Monday, August 14th. Mr. Eyles began his banking career in 1961 when he joined Chemical Banking Corporation in New York City. In his 27-year career there, he rose to the position of Executive Vice President, Chief Credit Officer and Chairman of the Credit Policy Committee. In 1988 he joined Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh as Vice Chairman, member of the office of the chairman and chairman of the credit policy committee. In 1992 he joined Shawmut National Corporation as Vice Chairman, Chief Credit Policy Officer and a member of the senior policy committee. He joined Fleet in 1995, following its merger with Shawmut, where he served as Vice Chairman and Chief Credit Officer until his retirement last June. Mr. Eyles has long been active in Robert Morris Associates, the trade association for credit and risk professionals. Mr. Eyles served on the Board of Directors of the RMA for three terms. He was also Chairman of the Regulatory Relations and Communications Council at the time of his death. Mr. Eyles was instrumental in creating credit and risk guidelines that have become industry standards. Mr. Eyles was a graduate of the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, with a bachelor's degree in economics, and of the Harvard Business School's Advanced Management Program. Mr. Eyles was born in Redbank, New Jersey, and raised in Kingston, New York. His parents were Irving L. Eyles and Madelyn Gilbert Eyles. Mr. Eyles most recently lived in West Hartford, Connecticut, and DeBordieu, South Carolina. Mr. Eyles is survived by his wife of 39 years, Dagnija; his sister Eileen Hoffman of Kingston, New York; four children; Denise Daley of Fairfield, Connecticut; Lisa Beeson of Greenwich, Connecticut; Matthew Eyles of Indianapolis, Indiana; Christina Eyles of Washington, DC; and five grandchildren. Services for Mr. Eyles will be held at 1:00 P.M. on Friday, August 18th, at Trinity Episcopal Church, 120 Sigourney Street, Hartford, CT. Contributions in memory of Mr. Eyles may be made to the Children's Heart Fund, Children's Hospital, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston, MA. 02115.

title: AGILENT REPORTS RISE IN EARNINGS
description: Agilent Technologies Inc., the test and measurement equipment business spun out of Hewlett-Packard, reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that met analysts' estimates. For the quarter ended July 31, Agilent reported earnings of $155 million, or 34 cents a share, up 15 percent from $135 million, or 36 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Per share figures reflect an increase in the number of shares outstanding. Sales rose 28 percent, to $2.67 billion, from $2.09 billion in the third quarter of fiscal 1999. Taking into account the dilutive impact of outstanding stock options, Agilent had pro forma earnings per share of 33 cents, equal to the consensus estimate provided by First Call. Earlier this week, Agilent said its unprofitable Healthcare Solutions Group would begin a global reorganization program to reduce its regular work force of approximately 5,000, by about 450 people by the end of October. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

If the hurricane comes, everybody will blame, even hate, poor Richie (oh, the nightmares he has). And if the electric rates go up, everybody on Long Island gets to blame, perhaps even picket, our man Richie (oh, he says, the irony).

title: MOODY'S MAY UPGRADE BRAZIL RATING
description: Stocks and bonds rallied in Brazil on news that Moody's Investors Service was contemplating an upgrade of the country's debt rating, brightening prospects for lower borrowing costs. Moody's said an economic recovery had allowed Brazil to shrink its budget deficit, reducing the chances of a debt default. Moody's has rated Brazil B2 -- five notches below investment grade -- since the Russian debt crisis hit the emerging markets in September 1998. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

description: ''Steal This Movie!,'' Robert Greenwald's likable but muddled screen biography of the charismatic Yippie activist Abbie Hoffman, raises a ticklish question: how can a contemporary film ''do'' the late 1960's in a way that isn't a sentimental retread of countless documentaries that have trotted out the same old television news clips to push the same old nostalgic buttons?

description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation has dropped a lawsuit against the At Home Corporation that had sought to block the AT&T Corporation's buyout of several major At Home investors.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Gosh, He Hits the Ball A Long Way'
description: ON the tee of the 166-yard eighth hole at Valhalla, Tiger Woods lofted a 9-iron that stopped about 12 feet from the cup. Jack Nicklaus then hit a 6-iron. When his ball rolled up and bumped into Woods's ball, he looked over at Woods and smiled.

title: More Tune In To Democrats
description: More people watched the prime-time network television coverage of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's address to the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday night than watched a similar vice-presidential address by the Republicans' nominee two weeks ago.

title: SINGAPORE PHONE TO WELCOME FOREIGNERS
description: Southeast Asia's biggest phone company, Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., said it planned to lift the restriction for foreign shareholders and open itself to investors to help it expand outside Singapore. The company, which is 75 percent-owned by the Singapore government, said in a circular to shareholders that it was proposing to remove the current 40 percent limit for foreign shareholders. There is also a 15 percent limit for individual shareholders. Singapore Telecommunications, which has $3.5 billion in cash, has been aggressively expanding in Asia as Singapore opened up its phone market to more than 30 new companies in April.

title: Keeping the Graham Connection Open
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has not performed since the troupe suspended activities in May because of continuing friction between the Graham board and Ron Protas, the director of the company and of the Martha Graham Trust, which licenses Graham's dances. But dancers manage to find ways to dance. Current and former company members did just that on Wednesday evening in Union Square Park in ''Keeping the Channels Open,'' a program of their own work presented by the Summer in the Square 2000 festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, JOHN TIMOTHY, M.D.
description: DONOVAN-John Timothy, M.D. Native of Brooklyn, resident of Tenafly, N.J. for 45 years. Died at home August 17, 2000 of cancer. Patron of the arts, protector of nature. His enthusiasm, intellect and love of life inspired all who knew him. He was Assistant Attending Urologist at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and held private practice there for 36 years. After retiring, he became Adjunct Professor at Fairleigh Dickinson's New College, where he taught world history-his life-long passion-from 1990 to the present. As Captain in U.S. Armed Forces, he headed a MASH unit in Germany from 1950 to 1952. In 1970, he volunteered at the Albert Schweitzer Hospital in Haiti. In 1973, he researched, in Germany, the revolutionary Electrohydraulic Lithotriptor, which disintegrated bladder stones, and introduced this less invasive procedure to the U.S. and Mexico. His media appearances helped launch widespread use of the technique. In the mid 70's, he hosted the radio show ''Medical Horizons'' on WFDU-FM. Survived by his wife Eileen (nee McAllister) of 51 years, his six children, Timothy, Anthony, Sean, Moira, Duane and Tate, his daughters-inlaw Karen and Mary, son-in-law, Chip Allee, and 4 grandchildren, Ari, Marnika, Kyrie and Lia. Wake at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, N.J. Monday, August 21st 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Tenafly, Tuesday, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Hope House Ministries, POB 358, Port Jefferson NY 11777 or Englewood Hospice, 75 Demarest Ave, Englewood, New Jersey 07631.

title: A Small-Town Lawyer Takes On Tire Makers
description: When Bruce R. Kaster started suing tire manufacturers more than a decade ago, he worked alone facing legions of lawyers hired by corporate conglomerates.

title: Hair Follicles Identified as Probable Home of Skin's Stem Cells
description: Maybe it is not like discovering a new bone in the human body. But researchers have learned a new fact about human anatomy that could prove just as interesting: the hideout of the source cells that replace those lost every day from wear and tear on the skin.

title: Injury to Ammann Causes a Quandary
description: MetroStars goalkeeper Mike Ammann remained in St. Joseph's Hospital in Tampa, Fla., yesterday with three fractured ribs, a punctured lung and facial bruises as the team pondered playing the rest of the Major League Soccer season without him.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Q. When's a Sheep a City Animal? A. When It's on the Lam
description: Though the hero of ''Sheep in the Big City'' is a sheep named Sheep, there is nothing generic about this sly, mordant new series, which will have a preview on the Cartoon Network tonight at 9. (It will begin for real in November.) The show's model is unmistakably ''Rocky and Bullwinkle,'' with its hilariously puffed-up storytelling voice, several cliff-hanging episodes in each half-hour installment, puns and most of all a humor that is silly enough to appeal to children and satiric enough for adults.

title: BONUSES HURT ABN AMRO RESULTS
description: The big Netherlands-based banking group ABN Amro Holding N.V. reported a 13 percent gain in first-half earnings, to 1.63 billion euros, or $1.5 billion, although increased costs, notably for employee bonuses in investment banking, offset gains in fees and commissions. While commission income rose 45 percent, to 3 billion euros, thanks to strong global stock markets, and overall revenue rose 20 percent, to 9.2 billion euros, operating expenses rose 24 percent. Rijkman Groenink, who became chief executive in May, said ABN would take a one-time charge this year of 800 million euros for a reorganization. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUGMAN, JOSEPH
description: KLUGMAN-Joseph, 83. Beloved husband of Shirley. Cherished patriarch of a large and loving family who adored and respected him. Grandfather of Deborah (James), Rebekah (Matthew), David (Amy), Michael, Jennifer, Matthew, and Daniel, and enriching his later years, great-grandfather of Sarah, Morgan, Benjamin, Amanda, Timothy, Brennan, and Hannah. He brightened the lives of all who had the good fortune to know him and he has left a void in our lives. Interment Friday, 12:30, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: LECROY SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS SLOW-GROWING VIGILANT UNIT
description: The LeCroy Corporation, a maker of electronic signal analyzers based in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., said yesterday that it would sell its Vigilant unit because of slow growth. LeCroy mainly makes digital oscilloscopes that capture electronic signals, convert them into digital form and perform measurements and analyses. Vigilant, based in Burlington, Mass., designs technology that tests the performance of local area network channels. LeCroy has hired the investment banking firm SG Cowen to divest itself of Vigilant, which will be treated as a discontinued operation. LeCroy reported $124.1 million of revenue for the last 12 months. Its shares were down 12.5 cents, to $11.75.

title: GORE, IN DEBUT AS A PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE, SAYS, I STAND HERE TONIGHT AS MY OWN MAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17  A deputy no more, Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee tonight with a vow to work for all Americans, "especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind."

description: Though no one knows just what agonies have befallen the men on the Russian submarine Kursk, other seamen who have been trapped beneath the sea describe how quickly the air can turn toxic and serious physical and emotional deterioration can set in.

The company was founded in 1948, before Ms. Albrecht began her professional career, not after she danced for Balanchine.

title: More Latin Than Modernist, This Big Band's Got Rhythm
description: It's the rare big band that could withstand the peeling away of all its horns and reveal a superb rhythm section at its heart. Since Count Basie's waning years, the rhythm section has been generally the least interesting thing in a big band; grand, modernist edifices of harmony and counterpoint tend to be its calling card. But the rhythm section in Jason Lindner's group, which plays at Sweet Basil through Sunday night, proves that supposition wrong.

title: Napster Case Setting Precedents
description: August 18, 2000

title: Bush Agrees To Be in 3 Debates; Problems in Format Are Possible
description: Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush said today that he would participate in three presidential debates, an announcement clearly intended to blunt a drumbeat of criticism from the campaign of his opponent, Vice President Al Gore, that Mr. Bush was trying to avoid such face-to-face contests.

title: A Favorite Is Stumbling At the Trials
description: Blaine Wilson continued to dominate his sport with a mesmerizing performance tonight as the Olympic trials opened with the men's preliminary competition at the Fleet Center, but his mentor, 30-year-old John Roethlisberger, is in danger of losing his bid for a third Olympic team.

title: Old MetroCards as Origami, Not Litter
description: Of the nearly seven million New Yorkers who ride the subways and buses every day, perhaps only one, Michael Makman, thinks of making a boomerang or a frog or even a crown when he sees a discarded MetroCard.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about protests against the Los Angeles Police Department referred incorrectly to the recent corruption disclosures about the department's Rampart Division, where more than 20 officers have been implicated in the fabrication of evidence and the framing of suspects. The episode is the city's worst corruption scandal in decades, not merely in a decade.

title: Why Has the G.O.P. Kept Blacks Off Federal Courts?
description: Many commentators have noted the impact that the coming election will have on the direction of the Supreme Court. But a compelling issue for the federal courts is being overlooked. With the next president expected to appoint more than 20 federal appellate judges and close to 100 federal district court judges, the candidates and their parties should articulate the extent of their commitment to diversity on the federal bench.

title: Renewing the Lease on the Innocence of Youth
description: Revisiting ''Rent'' in its maturity -- more than four years after it opened at the Nederlander Theater on Broadway, four and a half since its premiere downtown -- is a little like meeting a cousin for the first time since he or she was an infant and seeing a human being, not just the promising future.

title: Robert Gilruth, 86, Dies; Was Crucial Player at NASA
description: Robert R. Gilruth, an early leader of the American space program and director of the Johnson Space Center during the Apollo lunar landings, died yesterday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 and lived near Warrenton, Va.

title: Stocks and Stumps
description: The retirement package awarded by the Halliburton Company to Dick Cheney, the Republican nominee for vice president, is nowhere near the largest ever given to a chief executive, but it is trailblazing nonetheless.

title: On the Run
description: Eating lunch or dinner on the run usually means settling for a burger or a hot dog on the street, but there are better options. Here are a dozen places that serve food fast and tasty. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: BIOGEN AND ELAN FORM PARTNERSHIP TO DEVELOP DRUG
description: Biogen Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., and the Elan Corporation, a Dublin-based pharmaceutical company, announced a partnership yesterday to develop and sell Elan's drug Antegren. The drug has shown promise in treating multiple sclerosis, a crippling nerve disease, and the digestive disorder Crohn's disease. The two companies will share revenue from the product, as well as research and marketing costs. In tests, the drug has worked well as a complement to Biogen's existing multiple sclerosis treatment, Avonex. The companies said Antegren might be useful in treating a range of diseases. Elan's American depository receipts jumped more than 10 percent, gaining $5.875 each, to $59.875. Biogen was up 25 cents, to $70.50. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Judge Halts Program to Crack DVD Film Codes
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a Web site operator cannot distribute a computer program used to crack codes that prevent the piracy of movies.

title: INSIDE
description: Skakel Faces Trial

title: Tallying Up the Price of Many Promises
description: In his speech tonight, Vice President Al Gore made many promises that would cost billions of dollars and many others that would cost little or nothing.

description: Russian naval forces failed again today to dock a rescue vehicle onto the sunken and disabled submarine Kursk as President Vladimir V. Putin ordered his military commanders to accept Western offers of assistance.

description: Sally Amato, a singer and actress who founded the Amato Opera with her husband, the conductor Anthony Amato, died on Wednesday at her home in City Island in the Bronx. She was 82.

Cherished great grandmother of Rachel, Daniela, Joshua & Hannah. Services today 1:30 at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Cast Into the Wilderness by Choice, He Found a Friend in the Landscape
description: So highly charged was Rockwell Kent's life that it often reads better than his art. A painter, illustrator and commercial artist, he was also a wilderness buff challenged by chilly climates, a hotblooded leftist who gave his work to the Soviet Union, a lover to many women and husband to several, a father of five, a prolific writer, a designer of books, textiles and ceramics, an architect handy with tools -- in short, an overachiever who in his span of 89 years (1882-1971) seems to have had it all and then some.

title: In Wake of the U.S. Trials, Swimmers Have Little Rest
description: The United States Olympic swimming trials ended Wednesday night, only a month before the 2000 Summer Games begin in Sydney, Australia. It was a scheduling decision that was both calculated and risky.
