title: REED ELSEVIER UNIT SAYS IT WILL SELL 2 PUBLISHING GROUPS
description: Cahners Business Information, a subsidiary of Reed Elsevier P.L.C., said yesterday that it would sell two publishing groups so it could focus on trade magazines with larger market shares. Cahners said it would sell its Cahners Travel Group, based in Secaucus, N.J., and its automotive and trucking group, as well as some Chicago-based publications in its building, food processing and manufacturing groups. Cahners offers business information to the entertainment, manufacturing and retail markets. Reed Elsevier's publishing operations include Cahners Business Information, Reed Business Information and Elsevier Business Information. Reed Elsevier also publishes more than 1,200 subscription-based scientific journals.

title: F.B.I. AGENT GAVE FAULTY TESTIMONY IN WEAPONS CASE
description: An F.B.I. agent admitted in federal court here today that he had provided inaccurate testimony last December on a critical point that made a Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets appear deceptive when he had not been.

title: Verizon Unions Revise Plan As Talks Go Past a Deadline
description: Negotiators for more than 86,000 striking workers and Verizon Communications continued to talk early today, past a midnight deadline that some union representatives had set to end formal talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEFTEL, HERBERT
description: SCHEFTEL-Herbert. Grandson of Ida and Isadore Straus who died on the Titanic, was known to his friends as ''Buzzie.'' Mr. Scheftal, who lived in New York City, Easthampton, Le Touquet, France, died at the age of 92 on August 16 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He attended St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School and received his BA/MA from Oxford University. In World War II he was a major and senior controller of the 64th Fighter Wing. For his services, he was decorated with the Bronze Star and the Croix de Guerre. Co-founder of the Pan-Am building, he was the officer and co-owner of three television stations in Connecticut, Illinois and Mexico, and six cable stations. He sold his Connecticut television station to Viacom International and became a consultant to that company. He was a past president and a current member of the Board of Directors of Greenwich House, the settlement house which services the city's underprivileged. Mr. Scheftel was a member of White's Club, London; Bucks Club, London; Knickerbocker Club, New York City; St. Cloud's, Paris; Travelers' Club, Paris; and Seminal Golf Club, Palm Beach, FL. He was a devoted husband to Yolande (formerly Fielding), cherished uncle of Susan (Richard) Finkelstein, adored great uncle to Sophie and Jesse, loving stepfather to Francoise Fielding and Cynthia Fielding-Singh and beloved grandfather of Stephanie and Kimberly Fielding and Priya and Vikram Fielding-Singh. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to St. James' Church or Greenwich House. For information on funeral arrangements, call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500

title: Like It or Not, North Koreans Tour a Mall in Seoul
description: On their first full day in South Korea after half a century, 100 North Koreans  in two controlled groups of 50  experienced the capitalistic excess of a giant shopping mall today.

title: WITH ITS STOCK DOWN, IVAX SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK SHARES
description: The Ivax Corporation, a maker of generic drugs whose stock fell 42 percent this week on a possible delay in a popular cancer drug, said yesterday that it would repurchase as many as 10 million shares. That is about 6.3 percent of Ivax's 158.6 million shares outstanding as of July 31. The company, based in Miami, said it had repurchased about 32.9 million shares since January 1998. Earlier this week, Ivax said regulatory approval for its generic version of the cancer drug Taxol might be delayed because of a new Taxol-related patent held by a small California drug maker. Ivax stock was up $1.50, to $26.50.

title: 'Big Quake' Found Less Likely Along Fault
description: The earthquake fault considered most likely to bring destruction to the San Francisco Bay area may actually be incapable of generating a large earthquake on its own, scientists say.

title: A Good Eye, Charging by the Glance
description: In her book-lined Greenwich Village apartment, Judith Young Mallin shuddered, recalling her intimidating brush with a top interior design team. For Ms. Mallin, an expert in Surrealist art, it was like entering a hall of mirrors.

title: UNITED RENTALS IN TALKS TO BUY W. R. CARPENTER UNIT
description: United Rentals, the largest United States equipment-rental company, is in talks to buy Horizon High Reach and Equipment, a supplier of forklifts and hydraulic lifts for the construction industry, for $90 million. Horizon, which had revenue of $90 million last year, is a unit of the closely held W. R. Carpenter North America of Fresno, Calif. Carpenter said there was no guarantee of an agreement. Carpenter's UpRight unit makes the hydraulic platforms that Horizon sells and rents. Since Jan. 1, United Rentals, based in Greenwich, Conn., has completed 40 acquisitions with combined annual sales of $250 million.

title: Lazio Urges Tax Cuts to Add Jobs Upstate
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate candidate, toured two high-tech businesses today to underscore what he said were bright spots in the upstate economy and to counter what he said were Hillary Rodham Clinton's portrayals of the region as an ''economic wasteland.''

title: Album of the Week
description: IDA: ''Will You Find Me'' (Tiger Style). Voices harmonize closely, somewhere between intimacy and claustrophobia, in the quiet, unhurried songs on ''Will You Find Me,'' the fifth album by Ida. Instruments are discreet, unwilling to break a silence unnecessarily; if a lone guitar or piano is all that's needed, Ida uses nothing else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHENBAUM, DR. A. HYMAN
description: KIRSHENBAUM-Dr. A. Hyman. Young Israel of the West Side mourns the passing of a longstanding, devoted member, Dr. A. Hyman Kirshenbaum. A distinguished neurosurgeon, he brought compassion and skill to his patients. He was faithful to G-d and Man. May the Comforter of Zion console his bereaved family-his wife Judy, daughter Wendy (Lipstadt) and son Barry and their families. Rabbi Emanuel Gettinger Sheldon Fine, President

title: Democrats Try to Shore Up The Pillar That Was Labor
description: Organized labor has always been one of the strongest pillars supporting the Democratic Party. Or, as John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., enthused on Sunday while addressing a cheering throng of union members here for the Democratic National Convention:

title: Rescuers Reach Crippled Russian Sub but Are Unable to Gain Access
description: Russian Naval Official Asserts

title: APLION INTRODUCES PRODUCTS
description: Communications systems based on Internet technology have many strengths, but discernment is not among them. That is because in cyberspace, each digital packet of data is generally treated identically to each of the others; at a company, the chairman's urgent e-mail message may well be delayed as an intern browses the Web for sports scores. Yesterday, however, a small private company, Aplion Networks Inc. introduced the first entrants in a line of products meant to change that. Aplion's first products are meant to sit on the edge of a business customer's network and help set priorities for use of the network. E-mail, for instance, could be given higher priority than Web surfing, for instance, or certain users could be given higher priority than others. Aplion, based in Edison, N.J., hopes that communications providers will buy its systems in an effort to offer more finely tailored data services to business customers. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Dog Days Sizzle for Theater's Off-Offbeat Pups
description: SAY what you will about the New York International Fringe Festival, it is, without a doubt, the only place in the city you can see a Hungarian adaptation of a Greek epic performed in (what else?) German.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about renewed interest in the painter and author Tom Lea misstated the site of an episode he painted -- the sinking of the aircraft carrier Wasp in World War II. It occurred in the Pacific Ocean, not the North Atlantic.

title: Gore, in Debut as a Presidential Nominee, Says, I Stand Here Tonight as My Own Man
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17  A deputy no more, Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee tonight with a vow to work for all Americans, "especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind."

title: Actors and Agencies To Resume Mediation
description: Two unions involved in the 15-week-old strike over compensation for work on commercials -- the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists -- said they would attend a mediation session in New York on Sept. 13. Negotiators for advertisers and agencies said they would attend as well.

title: For Deneuve, a Setting In Which She Sparkles
description: Named after the Parisian square that is home to the Ritz Hotel, several haute couture boutiques and some of the world's most expensive jewelry shops, ''Place Vendome'' provides a perfect setting for Catherine Deneuve, herself one of the French cinema's most precious gems.

title: With the Slowdown Ending, Can the Fed Stay Friendly?
description: IT is the summer of our content.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARONE, JOHN
description: BARONE-John. Of North Brunswick, NJ., 59, August 16. Retired salesman and champion amateur golfer. Survived by wife Mimi Kidd Barone and sister Michele Barone. Memorial Mass Saturday, August 19, 11AM, Holy Name RC Church, E. 47 St. betw. 1st and 2nd, NYC.

title: Albright to Try to Shed Light on Missing Argentine Children
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16  Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pledged today that she will work to declassify United States government documents that may shed light on the kidnappings of hundreds of children from dissidents captured by the Argentine military during the dictatorship that governed here from 1976 to 1983.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: TELLABS GETS NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Richard C. Notebaert, former chairman of the Ameritech Corporation, has agreed to become chief executive of Tellabs Inc., the medium-sized maker of communications equipment. Mr. Notebaert takes the reins on Sept. 18. Michael J. Birck, one of the company's founders and the current chief executive, will give up that title and become the company's chairman. Previously, Tellabs did not have a chairman, though Mr. Birck filled that role informally. Mr. Notebaert, 53, left Ameritech, one of the Bell local phone giants, when that company was acquired last year by SBC Communications Inc. The move to Tellabs may be fitting because Ameritech was based in Chicago while Tellabs is based in Lisle, Ill., a Chicago suburb. Tellabs has long been more respected for its technology than for its business acumen. The company is best known for its products that connect fiber optic communications rings to one another. From a business standpoint, however, the company's acquisitions generally have not been fantastically successful. Tellabs shares rose $1.0625, to $62.6875, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: 'Inside Art'
description: The ''Inside Art'' column willl resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: Tennis Team Choice Challenged
description: Just days before the United States women's tennis team was made public in early August, Coach Billie Jean King called Lisa Raymond, the No. 1 ranked doubles player in the world at the time, to tell her she would not be going to Sydney, Australia.

title: Scooter Fever in Europe
description: A PARISIENNE and her companion walked around a red BMW C1 parked on a sidewalk near Trinity Church. He leaned in to view the speedometer, with a top marking of 120 kilometers an hour, or about 70 m.p.h., then fiddled with the windshield wiper. She stood back, regarded the curved roof and nodded approvingly.

title: More Home Refinancers Opt for Extra Cash
description: An increasing number of Americans who refinance their homes are taking extra cash rather than a lower rate, says Freddie Mac, the nation's No. 2 buyer of mortgages.

description: BROWN-Walston S. Aug. 17 at 92. Retired partner of Willkie Farr & Gallagher. Survived by his loving and devoted wife, Dr. Ellen Regan Brown. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

description: The chase has begun.

title: In the Flamboyant Tradition of Richard Pryor
description: The self-proclaimed Kings of Comedy in Spike Lee's concert film ''The Original Kings of Comedy'' couldn't be more resplendent in the outfits they wear onstage. Filmed before a live audience on two nights in February in Charlotte, N.C., Steve Harvey, D. L. Hughley, Cedric the Entertainer and Bernie Mac swagger across the stage, urban legends in outfits that can best be described as Mack-tastic, suits that qualify as Players' finery. If there's any real competition among them, it's in their suits.

title: N.F.L. Hands Ravens' Lewis a Fine of $250,000, but Doesn't Suspend Him
description: The National Football League fined Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis $250,000 yesterday for lying to the police about his involvement in an incident that resulted in the stabbing deaths of two men outside an Atlanta nightclub after the Super Bowl last January.

title: G. C. Myers, 69, Demographer Who Profiled Aging Globally
description: George Carleton Myers, a sociologist and demographer who compiled and interpreted facts and figures about the elderly worldwide, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Burnsville, N.C. He was 69.

title: Picking Out Distinctive Voices in a Pluralistic Chorus
description: The one-off showcase titled ''Greater New York: New Art in New York Now'' at P.S. 1 last spring received a lot of attention. But the fact is, similar institutional group exhibitions of up-and-coming artists have long been an annual feature in the city's art season.

title: In the shadow of a recall, Firestone faces questions on how to celebrate its centennial.
description: TIMING, as they say, is everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNICI, GERTRUDE
description: IANNICI-Gertrude. We were saddened to learn of the passing of Gertrude Iannici, beloved and devoted mother of our dear friends, Jane and Joe Pontarelli. Rest in peace, valiant lady. Sam and Roni Jacobson

title: Mr. Gore Steps Forward
description: Vice President Al Gore accepted the Democratic presidential nomination last night with a forceful address designed to humanize him to the voters and to accelerate his drive to free himself from the understudy's role. Imploring Americans to take a fresh look at his life experiences and values, Mr. Gore issued a calculated declaration of independence from President Clinton. ''We're electing a new president, and I stand here tonight as my own man,'' he asserted, promising to fight against ''powerful forces'' on behalf of working Americans. And in a striking, unmistakable reference to the scandals of recent years, he drew a thunderous ovation by promising, ''I will work for you every day and I will never let you down.''

description: To the Editor

title: Surgery May Put Giants' Bennett Out for Season
description: When Sean Payton, the Giants' new offensive coordinator, sat down last winter to retool the team's playbook, he identified running back Sean Bennett as the offense's most underused player.

description: SHLEFFAR-Irvin Ezekiel (Zeke), DDS. Died August 15 at 89, after a long illness characterized by the same good cheer, courage, and grace with which he lived. Beloved husband of the late Ida, survived by adoring daughters Susan (Gary) Palestrant of Ossining & Jo Ellen (Robert) Winters of Philadelphia; cherished grandchildren Michael, Gregory, and Rachel; loving relatives and treasured friends. His unquenchable wit and love of life endeared him to all. Services Friday, 12:30 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon (914-664-6800). Memorial donations American Diabetes Assoc.

title: For the Families, Anger Mixes With Mourning
description: In this northern port city that lives off the Russian Navy, the mourning has already begun. Few now hold out any hope for the lives of the 118 men aboard the submarine Kursk, which has been trapped under the Barents Sea for six days.

description: SHER-Rose. On August 15, 2000. Poet, actress, playwright, performer, mother of Daniel, Richard and Mark. Also survived by grandsons Martin and Jonathan. Adored grandmother of Scott, Stephanie, Daniel and greatgrandmother of Jacob and Zachary. Services Friday, 12:30, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Tibor Kalman: Seeing, Disbelieving
description: SINCE Tibor Kalman was a friend of mine, I'm not able to write an objective review of "Tiborocity: Design and Un design by Tibor Kalman," the New Museum of Contemporary Art's lively retrospective of the late graphic designer's work. But I'd feel idiotic if I didn't write a personal story before the show comes down, this weekend.

title: Lucent Gets Sprint Work
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the phone networking equipment giant, said today that it had won a contract worth up to $200 million to expand Internet access capacity for the Sprint Corporation's network. Under the deal, Lucent will also provide next-generation Internet services to the phone company's customers. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., had $38.3 billion in sales in the year ended last September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLEHN, RICHARD A.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Day Gary Cooper Didn't Walk Down Main Street
description: There's no need to get in a snit about remaking a movie, however great. Every half-century or so, even a classic can use some dusting off. But ''High Noon''? Even people who have never seen the film probably have an image of Gary Cooper as the heroic marshal striding down Main Street, alone, to face a killer. Few movies have been so inseparable from the star, or so deeply embedded in the popular imagination. (Harry Thomason, who produced Bill Clinton's lone walk along a long corridor before his entrance at the Democratic convention this week, said he was inspired by that scene; unlike Mr. Clinton, Cooper was not shot from such a low angle that his body looked as elongated as a space invader's.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, GEORGE MORROW
description: SMITH - George Morrow. Of Bronxville, N.Y. on August 16, 2000. Husband of Betty. Father of Geof. Brother of Msgr William B. Smith. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxille, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial St Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, August 21 at 10 AM.

title: Charter School's Problems Yield Cautionary Tale
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki visited the newly opened New Covenant Charter School in Albany last September, he lavished it with praise, proclaiming it a model of the kind of educational change he intended when he pushed a charter school bill through the State Legislature nine months earlier.

title: GLOBALNET TO ACQUIRE TELESCAN
description: GlobalNet Financial.com Inc., an Internet provider of financial news and information, has agreed to buy Telescan Inc. for about $115.4 million in stock to broaden its offerings to European customers. GlobalNet will exchange 0.5 share for each share of Telescan, a Houston-based provider of online financial and investment research products and services. That values Telescan shares at about $6.59 each, 29 percent above their closing price Wednesday. Telescan said it had about 17.5 million shares outstanding. The company will keep its name and move its headquarters to New York or London. The combined company will have more than $60 million in annual revenue.

title: Lieberman Balances Private Faith With Life in the Public Eye
description: By watching Senator Joseph I. Lieberman carefully, Americans may receive a lesson in the rituals and the realities of living as an Orthodox Jew in America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, WALTER WARD
description: BREGMAN-Walter Ward. Of Roslyn, New York, on August 16, 2000. Devoted son of the late Louis I. and Bella (Breakstone) Bregman. Dear & loving husband of Miriam, cherished father of Judy, Jo Ann and Paul. Beloved father-in-law of Mark Welch, Jack Miles & Susan (Cassel) Bregman, dear brother of Marvin and the late Oscar, adored grandfather of Julie, Lindsay, Emily, Rebecca, Jake, Seth, Sarah and Alexander. After a long and valiant battle with cancer, he died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital. Always a leader, his dedication to his family and community was a model for all. Walter was a founding member of Temple Sinai. As its past vice president and chairman of its building committee, he was responsible for its many expansions. He also served as past president and chairman of the board of the Samuel Field YM&YWHA and as past president of the Old Westbury Country Club. His tireless efforts and charitable contributions in community service benefited countless others. A Lt. Colonel in the Army Corps of Engineers, he served in the Pacific arena during World War II. We mourn the loss of this much loved & generous man. Funeral services Friday, August 18, 12 o'clock PM, at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, New York. Interment is at New Montefiore Cemetery follows. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Samuel Field YM & YWHA, Little Neck, New York.

In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front Street, Uniondale, NY 11553.

title: GILMORE WINS MET OPEN
description: Mike Gilmore, after five top 10 finishes in the previous eight years, shot a four-under-par 67 for a 54-hole total of 207 that gave him his first Met Life/Met Golf Association Open championship yesterday at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: Injured Moceanu Forced Out of Competition
description: Only a hint of redness remained in Dominique Moceanu's brown eyes today as she calmly retraced the emotions she experienced the night before, when the leftover pixie dust she hoped to recapture from 1996 officially expired for her.

title: Ever a Student of Politics and Policy
description: After Al Gore ran for president in 1988 and lost, just as he turned 40, he organized a series of dinners at which he went around the room asking each person to tell him where he had gone wrong. What hadn't he known? What hadn't he done?

title: U.S., Fearing Swine Fever in Britain, Bans Imports
description: LONDON, Aug. 16  The United States ordered a temporary ban on swine imports from Britain today, joining several European countries that acted after the discovery of swine fever in the country.

title: Political Memo; Stunt Keeps a Focus on Lazio's Tax Returns
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio has attracted an unbidden guest at some of his campaign events this week: a Democratic lackey in an impressively garish Uncle Sam costume who taunts Mr. Lazio over his failure to release copies of his income tax returns.

title: Prowling the Corridors Of a Very Twisted Psyche
description: ''You're already exhausted,'' someone says to Catherine Deane (Jennifer Lopez), a child psychologist, early in the new suspense thriller ''The Cell.'' Catherine is slaving to break through to a little boy who is comatose from advanced schizophrenia, using an experimental technique that allows her to enter his subconscious. In this picture, it's called the ''neurological synaptic transfer system'' by Catherine's colleague Henry West (Dylan Baker). But Alec Guinness would have called it ''mumbo jumbo.''

title: Lee Sr. Cleared of Bribery; Convicted on Other Charges
description: In a mixed and complicated verdict today, a federal jury acquitted the founder of the International Boxing Federation of major bribery and racketeering charges, but convicted him on counts of money laundering, tax evasion and interstate travel to aid in racketeering.

title: $50 Billion for German Wireless Licenses
description: The most expensive auction in history ended here today, when six companies bid nearly $50 billion for licenses to offer a new generation of wireless communications in Germany, the largest economy in Europe.

title: Loss Leaves Liberty Staring at Elimination
description: The last time the Liberty left Lake Erie with a loss, on July 3, the players were so distraught by their lackluster effort that they had a team meeting immediately upon returning to Manhattan.

title: Scientist Differs With E.P.A. on Malathion
description: An obscure toxicologist at the Environmental Protection Agency who has become an outspoken critic of his agency's findings on malathion, the pesticide widely sprayed last year in New York's battle against the West Nile virus, presented his case today in the court of scientific opinion.

title: New Jersey Counties to Get U.S. Flood Aid
description: For the second time in a year, New Jersey counties have been declared federal disaster areas by President Clinton, after severe flooding in pockets of Sussex and Morris Counties over the weekend.

title: What Price 13 Hostages? Commerce In Sulu Sea
description: The entrepreneurs of the Sulu Sea are on to their biggest deal yet, and like deal-making anywhere, the last-minute bargaining appears to be intense.

title: Metro Business; Candle Factory Planned
description: A new company that will make scented candles and other wick and wax illuminations is investing $6.75 million to convert a vacant factory in Saugerties, N.Y., into its headquarters and production site.

description: A deputy no more, Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee tonight with a vow to work for all Americans, ''especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind.''

title: The Big City; The Apple And the Sins Of Journalists
description: THE topic of today's quiz is ''Ethical Quandaries of Two New York Journalists in the Supermarket Produce Aisle.'' The first is John Stossel of ABC's ''20/20,'' who did a report earlier this year comparing organic produce with regular produce. Most of it reflected conventional wisdom among scientists: organic food has no nutritional advantages and poses a greater risk of bacterial contamination because it is grown in manure.

title: AON IS BUYING ACCIDENT AND HEALTH UNIT FROM RELIANCE
description: Reliance Group Holdings, the New York insurer controlled by the financier Saul P. Steinberg, agreed in principle yesterday to sell its accident and health business to a unit of the Aon Corporation. The sale, for a price still to be negotiated, continues the dismantling of Reliance, which has been struggling with widening losses. The company has said it will probably not be able to repay $735.1 million of debt due at the end of the month and may seek bankruptcy protection. Aon, the world's second-largest insurance brokerage company, said its Combined Insurance Company of America unit had agreed to assume virtually all of Reliance's accident and health policies as of Aug. 1.

title: Attempted Murder Charged in Brutal Break-Ins
description: A suspect in a string of violent break-ins on the Upper West Side was charged yesterday with three counts of attempted murder and 11 other felonies, the Manhattan district attorney's office said.

title: Barnes & Noble Posts Loss for Quarter
description: Barnes & Noble Inc. said yesterday that it had a fiscal second-quarter loss of $8.46 million as it invested more money in Internet operations and had a loss at its video game unit.

title: Sugar Talks Between Mexico and United States Break Down
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 17  A protracted dispute over sugar trade between Mexico and the United States escalated today when the Mexicans rejected a United States proposal and requested a special arbitration hearing under a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Orthodontics Via Silicon Valley; A Start-Up Uses Computer Modeling And Venture Capital to Reach Patients
description: The business of straightening teeth has always been a small-scale, fairly low-tech affair -- a one-on-one interaction between orthodontist and patient, usually an adolescent.

title: The Idea of Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shooting Keeps Peace At a Distance In West Bank
description: If it had happened at another time, or to somebody less celebrated in his community, the death of Mahmoud Bazar Abdullah from an Israeli soldier's bullet early Wednesday might have been put down to the mischances and misjudgments that can happen whenever men and guns mix in hard places and hard times.

title: To Both the Left and the Center, Lieberman Revels in a 'Love Fest'
description: Demonstrating some of the political dexterity that has kept him in public office for 30 years, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman tried today to rally support from leaders of his party's liberal wing and then a few hours later had lunch with fellow members of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council.

title: The Lighter Side of the Candidate Still Largely Hidden From the Camera
description: ''If you entrust me with the presidency, I know I won't always be the most exciting politician,'' Al Gore said as he ended his acceptance speech with what seemed, after months of wrestling with the issue, a defiant acknowledgment of fact. Even in a speech declaring himself a man of the future, he was conspicuously uncomfortable as a media candidate. Watching his acceptance was like watching the televised version of a stage play, the kind in which the cameras stand back and put the television audience in the position of distant voyeurs.

title: Russians Point To a Collision In Sub Sinking
description: With growing evidence of catastrophic damage to the hull of the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk, Russian officials said today that ''irrefutable data'' pointed to a collision. They said the object or ship that collided with the Kursk has not been identified yet.

title: Trial Ordered For Skakel In '75 Killing
description: A juvenile court judge ruled today that Michael Skakel should be tried in the 1975 slaying of Martha Moxley, finding that there was ''reasonable cause'' to believe that Mr. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy's, bludgeoned the 15-year-old girl to death when they were neighbors in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Peres Praises China After Visit to Bolster Ties With Ex-Critic
description: Shimon Peres lavishly praised China today as he finished a two-day visit intended to bolster Israel's ties with this onetime adversary and shore up global support for continued peace talks.

title: Metro Business; Delta to Add Flights
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would introduce two daily nonstop flights between Tampa International Airport and La Guardia Airport starting Nov. 1.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It took Frank O. Gehry's Guggenheim to put the Basque region on the map. The building is so famous that visitors no doubt find it surprising to discover that, in addition to a building, the Basques have a distinctive cuisine. It finds an appropriately small home in Oliva, a corner restaurant with a handful of tables, a rough and ready decor and a nifty bone-colored menu imprinted with a giant letter O surrounding a plump, perfect olive.

title: Milt Rosen, 77, a Master of Zingers
description: Milt Rosen, a versatile writer whose work included television scripts, comedy one-liners and books, died last Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

title: Two Striking Phone Workers Burned as Power Cable Is Cut
description: Two striking Verizon phone workers were nearly electrocuted early this morning when they mistakenly cut through a 13,000-volt power cable that they thought was a phone line, the police said.

title: A Synagogue Rises in Rural America
description: Route 4, a rural highway that twists across Vermont's midsection, passes the sort of roadside signs one would expect in northern New England. Maple syrup, they advertise. Cheddar cheese. Bed and breakfasts.

title: JAPAN SEEKS NEW LOAN
description: Japan will ask 84 banks and insurers to offer their best prices for a loan of two trillion yen ($18 billion), the second installment in the country's program of bank borrowing. The Ministry of Finance borrowed one trillion yen in July from banks -- the first time it bought bank credit rather than sold bonds -- to cover a shortfall in subsidies to local governments. The ministry has approval from Parliament to borrow eight trillion yen from banks in the fiscal year ending in March 2001. Last month, 82 banks and insurers bid for the first loan, which had a maturity of six months.

title: Bankruptices Defy Growth In Furniture
description: Two recent failures by furniture sellers show that the furniture business is joining the retail clothing business in a much more competitive arena where poor execution is increasingly fatal.

title: Lawyers and the Pursuit of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Undergoes More Tests and May Have Surgery to Treat Melanoma
description: Doctors at the Mayo Clinic here examined Senator John McCain of Arizona today and recommended that he begin treatment immediately for the recurrence of a serious form of skin cancer, a McCain spokeswoman said.

title: Nortel Negotiates With JDS Uniphase on Fiber Optics Supply
description: Nortel Networks and JDS Uniphase are in talks on a multiyear supply agreement that would ease Nortel's concerns about JDS's proposed acquisition of a rival, SDL Inc.

title: Woods, With No Sign of Weakness, Shares Lead
description: The excellence of Tiger Woods has become expected, particularly at major championships. Was anyone surprised that Woods opened the P.G.A. Championship with a six-under-par 66? You could almost hear some of his competitors saying to themselves, ''There he goes again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISOFF, ESTHER
description: WISOFF-Esther. In her 95th year on August 16, 2000. Wife of the late Percy Wisoff, a retired teacher who educated students at PS

title: In Reversal of Speech Process, Gore Wrote and His Aides Then Whittled
description: When Al Gore sat down at his laptop to write no pressure, but everyone said it had better be the speech of his life -- he began by raiding some of his favorite speeches past, culling some material that had been written for him and some of his own stuff, like the eulogy he wrote for his father's funeral.

title: Rockland Wants a Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Cairo Journal; A Tentmaker's Wish: Make the Bazaar Splendid!
description: Nearly everyone agrees on one thing: the old woman who sells live ducks and chickens from a makeshift stall does not belong on Tentmakers Street. The squawking, to say nothing of the dirty feathers that fly regularly from the alarmed birds, upsets the tourists.

title: Judge Shelves Plan for Sale Of Online Customer Database
description: A federal bankruptcy judge set aside a Federal Trade Commission plan today limiting the ability of an online toy retailer to sell its customer database as part of its liquidation.

title: City Expands Spraying Of Mosquitoes On Ground
description: With the number of pools of infected mosquitoes climbing and the peak mosquito season approaching, New York City officials yesterday unveiled additional plans for the season's most comprehensive spraying campaign against the West Nile virus.

title: In Clinton Inquiry, Still No Afterword
description: The independent counsel investigating President Clinton has impaneled a new grand jury to hear evidence about Mr. Clinton's relationship with a White House intern, two and a half years after it was first disclosed.

title: Metal Strip in Crash Wasn't Concorde's
description: The French minister of transportation said today that a metal strip that punctured a tire on the Concorde that crashed north of Paris on July 25, killing 113 people, was apparently part of another plane.

title: The Real Education Reformer
description: The teachers' unions have apparently forgiven Senator Joseph Lieberman for his past support of school vouchers. But his deviation from the National Education Association party line goes much deeper than vouchers -- a record that will undoubtedly become clearer as the campaign moves ahead.

title: Sun Plans a 2-for-1 Stock Split
description: Sun Microsystems, one of the biggest makers of computers that run Internet sites, said today that it would split its stock 2 for 1. The shares have more than tripled in the last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBAUM, DR. PAUL S.
description: STEINBAUM-Dr. Paul S. Died August 16, at his home in Morristown, NJ, at age 85, after suffering a stroke in July. A family physician for fifty years, he practiced in Leonia and Ortley Beach, NJ, before retiring in 1994. During World War II, he was captain of the 726th Army Medical Company and also served in France. An ardent tennis player, skier, sailor, swimmer and everyone's handyman, he shared his enthusiasms with an extended family and friends of all ages. Survived by a sister, Evelyn Zinader Baum of Bayonne. Beloved by his wife of fifty-eight years, Esther Rosenberg Steinbaum, his children, Robert and Rosemary Steinbaum of Montclair, Jonnet and Peter Abeles of New York, and four grandsons, Marshall and Elliot Steinbaum, and Oren and Ethan Abeles. Funeral service Friday, August 18, at noon at the Dangler Funeral Home, 600 Speedwell Avenue, Morris Plains. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation Ahavas Sholom, 145 Broadway, Newark, NJ 07104 or to the Freylinghuysen Arboretum, 53 East Hanover Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: The Web Helps Military Brats Find Long-Lost Friends
description: CAROL PASSAR lived in Pennsylvania for only a year, when she was 13, but she left behind her best friend when the military moved her family to yet another Army base in another part of the country. Nearly 40 years later, she was able to find her long-lost friend through an online registry for military "brats" like herself.

title: A Man of Many Tasks
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17  Al Gore tried to accomplish a political feat so daunting tonight that even the maestro himself, President Clinton, might have had trouble pulling it off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIKELY, AUDREY
description: LIKELY-Audrey. Beloved mother of Roger Shelley (Nancy) and loving and dear friend of Lawrence Bickford. A memorial service will be scheduled shortly. Donations in her memory to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19 St, NY, NY 10003.

title: Alabama Stakes Showdown Is Set
description: The 120th Alabama Stakes for 3-year-old fillies drew a field of nine yesterday, but tomorrow's race at Saratoga still shaped up as a test and a tie breaker for Secret Status and Jostle, the two best fillies in the East.

title: TD BANK PROFIT RISES
description: Third-quarter profit at the TD Bank Financial Group, the big Canadian bank, rose 21 percent on a 41 percent increase in revenue, reflecting the acquisition late last year of Canada Trust. Profit was 511 million Canadian dollars ($347 million), or 80 Canadian cents a share, beating the consensus estimate of 72 cents by analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Revenue was 2.6 billion Canadian dollars. The president, Edmund Clark, said TD Bank had reached agreements to sell 13 branches and Canada Trust's MasterCard business, two conditions for federal approval of its takeover of Canada Trust. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Facing Child Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ROBERT W.
description: FRANK-Robert W. 85 years old, died on August 16, 2000. Retired accountant and avid student of history. Widower of Gertrude. Father of Paula Nadell and Larry; and grandfather to Amy, Mia, Eric, Suzanne and Pamela. Graveside services Sunday, 11:00 AM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: NEW VIRUS ATTACKS SWISS BANK
description: UBS A.G. said a new electronic-mail virus was aiming at software used by its online-banking customers. UBS, the giant Swiss bank, said the virus could affect a few customers and that it had installed anti-virus software. No clients have reported damage, UBS said. Like the ''I love you'' virus that attacked computers worldwide in May, this one spreads through files in Microsoft Outlook e-mail software. Malicious e-mail messages bear an attachment named ''resume.txt.vbs'' with ''resume'' in the subject field. When the attachment is opened, a resume written in German appears on the computer screen. The virus then searches the computer's files for passwords to UBS accounts, said Vincent Weafer, director of the antivirus research center at the Symantec Corporation, an Internet-security software maker based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL RISES. Heating oil rose on expectations that inventories may be too low to be replenished in time for the winter heating season. In New York, heating oil for September delivery rose 1.85 cents, to 88.73 cents a gallon.

title: Pension Fund Issues Scorecard
description: The $172 billion California Public Employees' Retirement System said this week that it had earned 10.5 percent on its investments in the year that ended on June 30,

description: Judge Overturns Deal on Sale of Online Customer Database

description: Lycos Sets Voice Deal With Mobilee

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Computer Virus Mutation
description: August 18, 2000

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Democratic efforts to court campaign donors during its convention week misspelled the given name of a singer who performed on behalf of Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont. She is Sheryl Crow, not Cheryl.

title: Online Firm to Give Jobs to Top Stock Pickers
description: August 18, 2000

title: Vintage Cars Offer Mileage At Auctions
description: When you are selling 800 vintage, classic and antique sports cars in one place, you are bound to come across a big party or two.

title: Honoring the Spiritual at a Shrine to the Material
description: The din of slot machines and the cries of croupiers cannot really be heard in the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center, although it is just down the trail from its parent, the colossal Foxwoods Resort Casino. Nevertheless their proximity on this 1,400-acre reservation points up the anomaly that -- only in America! -- a gambling casino has hatched a serious museum.

title: Bridgestone Alters Reimbursement Limit
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said today that it was dropping a restriction governing when consumers can be reimbursed for the cost of replacing up to 6.5 million Firestone brand tires that are being recalled amid a United States safety investigation.

title: Hold On To Your Hats
description: Ask a child to choose between a day at a museum and a day at an amusement park, and it's not hard to guess which will win. But this summer the New York area offers a place where thrills don't come at the expense of intellectual stimulation, or vice versa.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS CANADIAN INFLATION INCREASES Canada's inflation rate was stronger than expected in July, rising by 0.3 percent, or an annual rate of 3 percent, mainly because of higher costs for energy, food, air travel and hotels. Gasoline prices fell slightly, but hefty increases for natural gas produced a 0.9 percent rise in energy costs. Excluding food and energy, the Consumer Price Index rose at an annual rate of only 1.5 percent in July. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Group Objects to F.B.I. Release of Carnivore Information
description: August 18, 2000

title: Long Slump For Ventura May Be Over
description: Robin Ventura sometimes seems to be a victim of his past success. Whenever he contributes offensively, he is asked if he thinks he is coming around, if he feels good and might be taking off as a hitter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNEPFER, HATTIE
description: KNEPFER-Hattie. 91 of Yonkers, NY. Passed away August 16, 2000. Beloved wife of the late David. Survived by her loving children Arnold, Paul and Carolyn Knepfer. Devoted grandchildren Rachel, Tobey, Alan and Michael. Services at LeVaya-Garlick Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY on Sunday, August 20 at 2PM. She will be missed by all she touched.

title: Lily Pad Takeover
description: Q. On my small Virginia farm is a spring-fed pond 80 feet across. Where once about a fourth of the surface was occupied by pink and white lily pads, now the entire pond has been taken over, and the fish are dying. How best to cut back the lilies?

title: Relax, Would-Be Flipper, This Isnt The Poseidon Adventure
description: Ihave a secret. No, I'm not in a witness protection program. No, I didn't miss the $100 question on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." No, I don't tape every episode of "The New Hollywood Squares." No, it's worse, much worse. I don't know how to swim. There I said it. Toss me in the Hudson River, and like Luca Brasi from "The Godfather," I'll sleep with the fishes.

title: People
description: * Jimmy Siegel was promoted to executive vice president and executive creative director at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Mr. Siegel, who had been senior vice president and senior creative director, becomes the fourth top creative executive at the agency, reporting to Ted Sann, co-chief executive and chief creative officer.

title: A Long Way From Home, But New York Dreamin'
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the federal housing secretary who wants to be governor of New York, had just finished speaking to the Native American Caucus and was heading for the African-American Caucus when he was stopped by a delegate who had heard him speak to the California delegation.

title: South Bronx Little Leaguers Fall Just Short of Trip to Williamsport
description: A team from the South Bronx that was bidding to earn a trip to Williamsport, Pa., and trying to become the first Little League World Series champion from New York City in 36 years made one small misstep in the Eastern Regional final tonight at the A. Bartlett Giamatti training center.

title: Hampton's Injury Mars a Perfect Day
description: Robin Ventura detected the grimace when Mike Hampton hit a grounder in the third inning. The next indication was Hampton's trot to first base.

title: New Video Releases
description: Mifune

title: As Lifeguards Watch an Empty Pool, a Long, Cool Summer Seems Longer
description: It's been a quiet week at the Highbridge public pool in Upper Manhattan. And a quiet month and, for that matter, a quiet summer.

title: CANADIAN INFLATION INCREASES
description: Canada's inflation rate was stronger than expected in July, rising by 0.3 percent, or an annual rate of 3 percent, mainly because of higher costs for energy, food, air travel and hotels. Gasoline prices fell slightly, but hefty increases for natural gas produced a 0.9 percent rise in energy costs. Excluding food and energy, the Consumer Price Index rose at an annual rate of only 1.5 percent in July. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Islamic Rebels Make War in Central Asian Region
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  Dozens of Islamic rebels crossed into the former Soviet republic of Kyrgyzstan from neighboring Tajikistan today and waged fierce battles with government troops, the Kyrgyz president, Askar Akayev, said.

title: Led by Justice, Hill and Canseco, New Yanks Win, Just Like the Old Yanks
description: They are your parents' Yankees, Bronx bombers, with a little ''b.'' Only now the left-handed hitter with the swing suited perfectly for Yankee Stadium is David Justice, not Roger Maris. The potent and defensively challenged part-time slugger is not Johnny Blanchard, but Glenallen Hill.

title: Corporations Underwrite The Democrats' Convention
description: Barely an hour after Vice President Al Gore issued a call for reforming the ways political campaigns are paid for, he headed back to the fund-raising circuit for a concert that raised $5.2 million for the Democratic Party.

title: Indonesian Leader Disarms a Feuding Legislature With Laughter
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16  With puns, jokes and a touch of naughty wordplay, President Abdurrahman Wahid lifted the mood of Indonesia's bitterly feuding legislature today, soothing it with the fundamental message of his presidency: debate and disagreement are acceptable, even healthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOIACONO, JOHN C.
description: LOIACONO-John C. Age 36, died August 16, 2000. He had several assignments at GE Capital prior to joining Worth Media, LLC where he felt he had the happiest and most productive period of his professional career. He was recently named Chairman of the Worth Media Charitable Fund and Advisor to the CEO. Funeral services Saturday at 10 AM at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Fairfield, CT. Interment Oaklawn Cemetery. Friends may call Friday 4-8 PM & Sat. 8:15 -9:15 AM at the Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield, CT. Donations in his memory to the Worth Charitable Fund, care of Worth Media, 575 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10022

title: Corrections
description: Headlines and picture captions in some copies yesterday referred incorrectly to the formal status of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's nomination for vice president. The Democratic National Covention nominated him officially last night. When he addressed the convention on Wednesday, was not officially the nominee.

title: Evildoer, Kidnapper, Tamils' Hero, Rolled Into One
description: Veerappan, the legendary bandit who has humbled two Indian state governments with the kidnapping of a matinee idol, is notorious as an elephant poacher, sandalwood smuggler and ruthless killer who has eluded hundreds of police officers devoted for years to nothing but his capture.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO EDGES UP. The euro extended its rally ahead of a European inflation report today that is expected to reinforce expectations of an interest rate increase. In New York, the euro settled at 91.63 cents, up from 91.51 cents.

title: Metro Business; Corning to Build In Rochester Suburb
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would build an $80 million plant in the Rochester suburb of Henrietta, N.Y., that would produce components for fiber optic communication networks.

title: Kashmir 'Cease-Fire'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore, the Contender at Last, Proves to Be a Crowd Pleaser
description: If Bill Clinton's backstage walk to valediction on Monday was a heavyweight champion's last indulgent moment in the sun, Al Gore's arrival in the Staples Center tonight was a dogged contender's first chance to enter the arena alone. He strode through a sea of pennants down a side aisle with a posse of seconds trailing humbly in his wake.

title: St. Johns Journal Cruise Ships Descend On Newfound Bonanza
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland  In the workaday harbor here, normally plied by tugs, tankers and freighters laid up for repairs, Le Levant offered a startling contrast on a recent day: a sleek French cruise ship disgorging 50 affluent American tourists.

title: BRITISH CONTROL OF GERMAN COMPANY
description: Britain's biggest telephone company, British Telecommunications P.L.C., confirmed that it would take control of Viag Interkom, a German telephone company, by doubling its ownership stake to 90 percent in a deal worth as much as 7.35 billion euros, or $6.73 billion, in cash. The seller is E.On A.G., a German energy concern. Viag Interkom's price tag was raised yesterday after it won a third-generation wireless license from the German government. Peter Bonfield, chief executive of the British company, said the purchase showed its determination to become a dominant player on the Continent. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, BIRGITTA GREIFFE
description: BAUM-Birgitta Greiffe. Died suddenly after a short illness on August 16, 2000. Her memory will live forever in the hearts and minds of those she reached out to and loved. Her devoted husband, Robert cherishes each moment of their 44 years of marriage and their devoted son, Eric, who loves her so much, will carry forward the values and love that she deeply instilled in him and made the essence of our family life. Goodbye Mutti-Goodbye B.T. Donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: CUNY Agrees To Widen Public Access To Meetings
description: The City University of New York has agreed to widen public access to its board meetings, doing so with the attention and gravitas often given to high-level diplomatic meetings.

title: Gore to Delegates and Nation: 'My Focus Will Be on Working Families'
description: Following is the acceptance speech prepared for delivery last night by Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic nominee for president, at the Democratic Convention in Los Angeles:

title: U.S. Navy Is About to Retire One of Two Top Rescue Subs
description: Although the tragedy with Russia's Kursk submarine has placed an urgent spotlight on the need for rescue craft, the United States Navy is planning to retire one of its two best undersea rescue vehicles at the end of August in a cost-cutting move that could make it harder to save stricken American submariners, military officials said yesterday.

title: Parent of United Airlines Lowers Earnings Estimate
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, lowered its third-quarter earnings estimate yesterday, citing the thousands of canceled flights that have come amid a dispute with its pilots.

title: Instant Aeries for TVs Eyes
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16  Phil Alongi was eager to share a view of the Democratic convention from his favorite perspective. "Over here," he said excitedly, motioning to a temporarily uncrowded corner on the convention floor near the Tennessee delegation. "I want you to get the whole effect."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, SYLVIA
description: SANCHEZ-Sylvia. 43, of Smyrna, GA, formerly of NY died August 17, 2000. Funeral services will be held 10 AM, August 19, at Georgia Memorial Park Funeral Home. Burial will be in Georgia Memorial Park Cemetery, Marietta, GA.

title: He's Back! And There Goes Tokyo Once Again
description: Only a diehard fan of the long-running Japanese ''Godzilla'' series could love ''Godzilla 2000,'' the 23rd screen appearance of the indestructible fire-breathing monster that emerges from the sea to wreak awesome destruction. This is not to say that there aren't thousands (perhaps even millions) of cultists who won't adore it. Watching this transcendentally tacky movie, which wants us to laugh at it and with it at the same time, it is easy to see why the series threatens to be as enduring as its namesake.

title: Mourning Is Eager For Heat Newcomers
description: For three straight years, Alonzo Mourning has had to walk off his home court in Miami while watching the hated Knicks celebrate a playoff victory that ended the Heat's season. He does not want it to happen a fourth time, and based on the moves Miami has been making recently, there is a good chance it will not.

title: GERMAN INSURER ENTERS ITALY
description: Germany's second-largest insurer, Ergo Versicherungsgruppe, said it had bought 70 percent of Bayerische Vita of Italy for 644 million euros ($589 million). Ergo, which acquired the stake from Bayerische Beamten Versicherungsgruppe, will offer investors 9.67 euros a share for the remaining shares. The foothold in Italy's 70 billion euro insurance market is Ergo's first major foray outside Germany since its creation in 1997. It is playing catch-up to Allianz A.G., Germany's biggest insurer, which gets more than half its premiums abroad.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP., St. Petersburg, Fla., a utility holding company, said its shareholders had approved the company's acquisition by CP&L Energy, Raleigh, N.C.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD SHARES DROP
description: Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell 11 percent after analysts said fiscal third-quarter sales growth in the No. 2 computer maker's server division fell short of expectations. Hewlett-Packard fell $12, to $108. Late Wednesday, the shares surged 8.6 percent after earnings were released. The stock has fallen 21 percent since touching a record $136.1875 last month. While profit beat estimates because of higher sales of printers and related supplies, analysts are concerned that sales growth at the company's Unix server business lagged forecasts.

title: Making Pen and Ink Seem Passe: The Proliferation of New Ways to Draw
description: In ''Drawings 2000,'' the current show at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery, there are works on paper by no fewer than 111 artists. All were made this year.

Like the "I love you" virus that attacked computers worldwide in May, this one spreads through files in Microsoft Outlook e-mail software. description: They are still puffing up their chests about last year's preseason scrum and wincing over the regular-season shellacking. But the Jets are approaching tonight's game against the Giants like self-absorbed teenagers. Forget about them, the Jets say. It's all about us.

description: And what, you may ask, have we learned from the Democratic convention?

description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in striking down a state parental notification requirement for minors seeking abortion, has followed the court's longstanding tradition of interpreting the New Jersey State Constitution in a manner broadly protective of fundamental privacy rights.

title: Citing Islamic Law, Taliban Shut Bakeries That Aided Widows
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 16 (AP)  Saying Islam unreservedly forbids women to work, Afghanistan's Taliban government today shut down bakeries run by widows, who are among the poorest of the poor here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, FLORENCE
description: DICKMAN-Florence. Loving sister of Joseph Dickman. Devoted niece, aunt and friend. Services Friday, August 18, 9:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: British Panel Supports Cloning of Human Cells for Research
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP)  A panel of experts has urged the government to allow the cloning of human embryonic stem cells for scientific study of transplants. The government accepted the recommendation today and said it would submit legislation to adopt it.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Arranged Marriages, Minus the Parents For Some South Asians, Matrimonial Sites Both Honor and Subvert Tradition
description: HARSHA KUMAR, a 29-year-old technology officer for an e-commerce company in Westborough, Mass., wanted to find a wife. And Mr. Kumar, who was born in India and educated in the United States, wanted to begin his search in a way that blended both Old and New World sensibilities.

title: Relax, Would-Be Flipper, This Isn't 'The Poseidon Adventure'
