title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUEL, ROBERT T.
description: SAMUEL-Robert T. Of New York on August 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Leslie Ekenberg Samuel, loving father of Robert Trevor Samuel III and Melissa Dodd Samuel of Boston, MA. Dear brother of Nancy Stoer and David Samuel. Funeral Monday, 11 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, North Broadway, Irvington, New York. Contributions to Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. *denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 7.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Actor as Host And Advice Giver

title: Smiling Through the Mist at Life's Delights
description: It's difficult to think of any city, other than the urban behemoths like New York and Los Angeles, and maybe Washington, that has shaped modern living in the United States as much as this one.

title: From Singers to Swingers
description: From Singers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNTEY, BEVERLY
description: LUNTEY-Beverly. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Brooklyn Academy of Music mourn the passing of Beverly Luntey, a dear friend and wife of former, longterm Board member Eugene H. Luntey. Karen B. Hopkins, President Joseph V. Melillo, Exec. Producer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, THOMAS P.
description: ALLEN-Thomas P., August 15, 2000, after an extended illness. He will be lovingly remembered by his wife of 30 years, Carol Allen, by his colleagues at Stuyvesant Square at Beth Israel Medical Center, by many grateful patients, and by his close community of friends. His humor, gentleness and understanding will continue to enrich the world he left.

title: For Tiger and His Pals, Air Time Is Shared Time
description: At 2:17 p.m. yesterday, Eastern time, Tiger Woods birdied the 18th hole to tie Scott Dunlap for the lead in the P.G.A. Championship.

title: Article 2000081891993503895 -- No Title
description: By FRANK BRUNI

title: CISCO EXPANDING IN INDIA
description: Seeking to further benefit from India's growing prominence in high-technology industries, Cisco Systems Inc., the leading maker of computer equipment for the Internet, said it would invest $150 million over the next two years to expand its Indian research and development operations in Bangalore, making them Cisco's largest outside of the United States. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., has invested $75 million in India since 1996. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Sugar Talks Between Mexico and United States Break Down
description: A protracted dispute over sugar trade between Mexico and the United States escalated today when the Mexicans rejected a United States proposal and requested a special arbitration hearing under a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: QANTAS PROFIT UP 12%
description: The Australian airline Qantas Airways Ltd. said its second-half profit from operations increased 12 percent, aided by rising passenger and cargo traffic. Net income before one-time gains for the January-June period rose to 179.3 million Australian dollars ($106 million). Though market prices for fuel increased more than 44 percent in the last year, ''Qantas was able to reduce the impact by over 80 percent,'' saving more than 270 million Australian dollars, said its chairwoman, Margaret Jackson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, JEANETTE SAVILLE
description: HIGGINS-Jeanette Saville, 86. Passed away on August 11, 2000 in Laguna Hills, CA. She worked for Belk Stores as an executive secretary. She is survived by her nephew Duane Garrett, his wife Melinda and daughters Katrina and Myra, stepchildren: Roger Higgins, Carol (Michael) Tampa, Donna (Joe) Licari, Diane (Stan) Kosek, Betty (Jeff) Lane, and her niece Joette Higgins. Services will be held at 11:00 A.M. today at Pacific View Mortuary, Newport Beach, CA., (phone) 949-644-2700.

title: From Singers To Swingers
description: This week's DVD releases include ''Nashville,'' with a commentary by Robert Altman, and ''Planet of the Apes: The Evolution,'' Fox's umbrella title for the Charlton Heston epic and its four sequels (''Beneath the . . .,'' ''Escape From . . .,'' ''Conquest of . . .'' and ''Battle for . . .'') on five discs, along with a sixth disc with the documentary ''Behind the Planet of the Apes,'' about the making of the series. And on Tuesday will come ''The Tigger Movie,'' with assorted games and songs about the Pooh clan augmenting a sweet little film from Disneywith muscle enough to take in more than $40 million at the box office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARD, LUCIENNE
description: REINHARD-Lucienne. Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah records with profound sorrow the passing of Lucy Reinhard, MDS '65 graduate and former secretary of our school. Lucy was a woman of grace and a loyal friend who taught us how to love life and have Emunah against all odds. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi Mordechai Besser, Principal George Karasick, President Elliot Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: Crane Boom Buckles at N.Y.U. Construction Site, Sending One-Ton Slab Crashing to Ground
description: The arm of a crane at a Manhattan construction site buckled yesterday, sending a one-ton concrete slab crashing to the ground near Union Square, fire officials said. Two people were slightly injured as a result of the accident.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Oil Profits Are Finally Where They Ought to Be
description: Too many people are accusing the oil and gas industry of greed, blaming oil companies for both the runup in the price of gasoline, which has moderated since last spring, and for more recent rises in home heating and energy prices.

title: An Eye For Art To Dress A Room
description: YOU could say that art critics are almost always, inescapably, writing about installation art, or at least the art of installation. This is because they are usually writing about exhibitions, that is, groupings of artworks whose physical arrangement, or installation, is basic to their impact.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Wednesday showing a proposed park along the waterfront below Brooklyn Heights carried an erroneous credit. It was by Urban Strategies Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, YUNA Y.T.
description: CHEN-Yuna Y.T., 87. Granddaughter of Tan Chun-Lin, Governor General of Guang Dong and Guang Xi Provinces, daughter of Tan Yen-Kai, Chairman and First Prime Minister of Nationalist China, died peacefully while visiting her son, Harold Chen in Salt Lake City, Utah. Mrs. Chen, a graduate of Newnham College, Cambridge University, taught English in China and Linguistics at Georgetown and Johns Hopkins Universities before retiring to New York City. In addition to her son, Mrs. Chen is survived by daughters, Elaine Chen-Nash of Virginia, Tina ChenJosephson of Manhattan, Sana Chen-Powell of Hawaii and seven grandchildren. Funeral service will be held at 11:30 AM, Saturday, August 19th, at the Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave. at 81 Street.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone; in August some galleries are open by appointment only. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Russia's Unsafe Nuclear Submarines
description: The sinking of a Russian nuclear submarine in the Barents Sea is not just a tragedy for the sailors trapped aboard, it is a warning of the dangers of running a nuclear navy on the cheap -- the way an impoverished Russia must do everything these days. There is disagreement between American and Russian experts over whether the accident was caused by an explosion aboard the submarine or by a collision with another ship. But either way, the underlying cause may be more fundamental. Money is so short that submarines rarely put out to sea. They lack maintenance and the crews get little training. These problems, compounded by a longstanding disregard for safety, have caused accidents in the past and could have been contributing factors in this one.

title: Mogadishu Journal; A Peace-Starved City Weighs the Warlord Factor
description: The warlords of Mogadishu are a courteous bunch. They smile. They reason in soft tones. They even serve visitors cardamom tea and something sweet and orange resembling Tang. But it is not their good manners that you notice first.

title: Online Broker May Buy Out 2 Big Investors
description: Trying to distance itself from a troubled past, Datek Online, one of the nation's fastest-growing online brokerage firms, has agreed to raise about $500 million to buy out the company's two majority shareholders, according to people who have been briefed on the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEFTEL, HERBERT
description: SCHEFTEL-Herbert. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Sports of The Times; Ward Hopes To Step Past 'The Trade'
description: THERE was a day last week at Jets camp when Dedric Ward, the Jets' fourth-year wide receiver, was in a quiet, but upbeat, mood. Al Groh, the Jets' first-year head coach, had officially named Ward as the Jets' starting wide receiver alongside Wayne Chrebet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFORD, MARGARET M.
description: ALFORD-Margaret M. December 30, 1907-August 17, 2000, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Robert H. Alford. Devoted mother of Margaret Ann Alford of Manhasset, Mrs. Patricia Sears of Port Washington and James R. Alford of Manhasset. Grandmother of Mrs. Sarah Chandonnet of Glen Head and great-grandmother of Caroline Chandonnet. Before she married, Margaret was a fashion model who worked for one of the most exclusive Fur Designers and Salons of the time. The elegance, grace, poise and style of her modeling years remained with her well into advanced age. An avid reader, she was also a frequent European traveler. She often spoke of the beauty of Estoril, Portugal but really felt most at home in England-probably because it was her father's birthplace. Over the years, she accumulated an extensive and valuable collection of antique Pug Dog porcelains, and artwork, and was rarely separated from her loyal, devoted and faithful Pug, ''Oliver''. In repose at The Farichild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11:15AM, St. Mary's RC Church Manhasset, with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington.

title: AFTER CONVENTION, BUSH CHIDES GORE FOR DIVISIVE TONE
description: Roaring into Vice President Al Gore's home state on the morning after the Democratic National Convention, Gov. George W. Bush accused Mr. Gore today of delivering a convention speech that sowed divisions and fomented class warfare among Americans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a decision by President Chen Shui-Bian of Taiwan to cancel a meeting with American congressmen in California after protests by China and expressions of concern from the State Department misstated the year China fired missiles near Taiwan. It was 1996, before Taiwan's presidential election -- not 1995, during a dispute over a visit to the United States by Mr. Chen's predecessor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, VICTOR
description: SHERMAN-Victor. On August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Glenda; loving father of Beth and Nancy; father in-law of Andy and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Jessie and Sam. Friends may call Sunday 7-9pm, Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Funeral service Monday, August 21, 11:30 at Frank E. Campbell. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to NYC Chapter, Leukemia Society, 475 Park Ave. South, 21st floor, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

title: From Gore, the Tonic of Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, ALFRED J.
description: BERG-Alfred J. Beloved husband of the late Laura; Devoted father of Linda, Laura, Keith, Judy, Joanne, Michael, Geralyn and Timothy; Cherished grandfather of 10 grandchildren; and Loving companion of Arlene Riggs; Dear brother of Grace, Joan and the late David. Reposing Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86th St, Brooklyn until Monday 9:30 AM. Mass St. Mary Mother of Jesus Church at 10 AM. Viewing hours 2-5, 7-9:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEF, NINA R.
description: LIEF-Nina R. 0n August 18, 2000 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Victor Filler Lief. Dear mother of Carlotta and mother-inlaw of David Schuster. Adored grandmother of Amanda. Cherished stepsister of George Poliakoff. Services Sunday, August 20, 2 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Smuggling Ship to Become a Reef Off Florida
description: The Golden Venture disgorged its human cargo -- 286 desperate Chinese immigrants who had endured 100 harrowing days at sea -- into the cold and pounding surf off Queens at 2 a.m. on June 6, 1993. Ten died before reaching shore, others endured years in detention and the name of the freighter became synonymous with the willingness to profit from human aspiration and desperation.

title: Reviving the Mideast Summit
description: Israeli, Palestinian and American diplomats are exploring the possibility of a new summit meeting to complete the peace negotiations broken off at Camp David last month. Despite political opposition in Israel, Prime Minister Ehud Barak has resolved to push for a final-status agreement with the Palestinians before his Parliament returns in late October. The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, hints encouragingly that he will postpone his threat to proclaim an independent state if no agreement is reached by Sept. 13. But a new summit meeting only makes sense if there is a realistic hope of breaking the impasse over Jerusalem that halted the Camp David talks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARKIN, ALBERT J.
description: ARKIN-Albert J. April 17, 1909August 19, 1985. Dad, think of you so very often. Love, Joan

title: The Crime of Carrying Ideas to China
description: Burrowing through last Sunday's Times, I parked at Page 10 of the A section, lured by a promisingly long article on the importance of beauty queens in Venezuela (''Narcissism's Homeland Could Be Here'' was the subhead) and below that by a wry account, irresistible to this longtime fan of Cuban music, of a concert in Havana on Friday night, Aug. 11 (''Buena Vista Social Club, Little Known in Cuba, Is Glad to Be Home''). Imagining Ruben Gonzalez and Compay Segundo in concert at -- where else? -- Havana's Karl Marx Theater put me in such a good mood I felt up for a return to the less than amusing pages on the Democratic Party convention follies.

title: Slavery Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: For Nicklaus, Golden Finish Is a Shot Short
description: Near the 18th green, the sign on the scoreboard read, ''37 Golden Years at the P.G.A. Thank you, Bear.'' And now the applause was surrounding that Golden Bear, 60-year-old Jack Nicklaus, as he walked down the fairway on what he would describe later as ''maybe my last hole in a major'' tournament.

title: Lucas Steps In for Testaverde and Lifts Jets
description: Vinny Testaverde and his banged-up toe stayed on the soggy sideline tonight, resting for the season opener.

title: FINOVA GROUP FALLS AFTER CREDIT RATING IS CUT
description: The stocks and bonds of the Finova Group fell yesterday after the credit ratings of the company, a lender, were downgraded amid concerns employees will abandon the company. Finova shares fell $1.50 each, a drop of 17 percent, to $7.50, on the Big Board. Earlier, the shares fell to $6.50, trading at their lowest level since being spun off from the Dial Corporation in 1992. The company, which lends money to small businesses, has been seeking a buyer for three months, raising the concern that employees and customers will leave the company, which is based in Scottsdale, Ariz., for rivals, said Moody's Investors Service, a debt rating company. Moody's cut the rating on the Finova Capital Corporation's long-term debt to ''Ba1,'' which is junk-bond status and 11 notches below the highest rating.

title: Pernod Ricard Joins Diageo To Bid for Seagram's Liquor
description: Diageo P.L.C. of Britain, the world's leading liquor company, and Pernod Ricard S.A. of France announced today that they would team up to compete for the wine and spirits business of the Seagram Company. The move is likely to start a bidding war with Allied Domecq P.L.C., the No. 2 liquor concern, that could push the price toward $9 billion.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL UP. Heating oil kept climbing, paced by worries of a winter shortage and a heavy refinery maintenance schedule. In New York, heating oil for September delivery rose 1.18 cents, to 89.91 cents a gallon.

title: France and Britain Create Panel To Improve Safety of Concordes
description: British and French aviation regulators formed a committee today to examine ways to return the Concorde to service ''in safe conditions'' that would protect it against the flaws behind last month's crash near Paris.

title: CENDANT IS IN DEAL FOR SOME ASSETS OF AMERIHOST
description: The Cendant Corporation, a franchising giant, agreed yesterday to acquire the AmeriHost Inn and AmeriHost Inn and Suites brand names and franchising rights of Amerihost Properties Inc. to increase revenue. The financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Cendant, based in New York, is the world's largest hotel franchisor, with the Days Inn, Howard Johnson, Ramada and Super 8 brands. Amerihost Properties, with headquarters in Des Plaines, Ill., owns and manages hotels, including Days Inn, Howard Johnson and Ramada hotels. It said the Cendant franchising deal would enable it to focus on managing new AmeriHost Inn hotels. (Dow Jones)

title: Totalitarian Idealism: Could Some Of It Work?
description: DREAMWORLD AND CATASTROPHE

title: Neil Young, Burning Castles To Move Out of the Past
description: '' 'Southern Man,' what are you, kiddin' me?'' Neil Young said, between guffaws, from the stage at the Jones Beach Theater here, responding to one of a few shouts from the audience that he play some rock-and-roll. Mr. Young hadn't come to indulge in big meltdowns like that song. He'd done enough of them earlier this year, blowing away his buddies David Crosby, Stephen Stills and Graham Nash during the C.S.N.&Y. reunion tour. He had different plans for this summer outing, and as any Neil Young fan knows, it's no use trying to argue when this star has set the route.

title: Twins Chasing Same Goals At Trials
description: Just a month or so short of their 18th birthdays, and newly introduced to the shaving-cream market, Paul and Morgan Hamm are back to wearing matching clothes.

title: Fox Drops Irvin As an Analyst
description: Fox Sports Net announced yesterday that Michael Irvin, the former Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, will not join its NFL This Morning program.

title: As Peace Mission Deteriorates, U.N. Sends an Envoy to Congo
description: A Nigerian general who presided over his country's return to democracy last year is being sent to Congo by Secretary General Kofi Annan to try to salvage what is beginning to look like a doomed peacekeeping operation.

title: Napster Says Judge Erred in Preliminary Injunction
description: Napster Says Judge Erred in Preliminary Injunction

title: Man Is Killed After Shooting at an Officer
description: A New Jersey police officer shot and killed a man before dawn yesterday after the man fired a gun at him during a search in woods in Hunterdon County, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Swim Coach Calls for Increase Of Random Testing
description: The coach of the American women's Olympic swimming team said yesterday that he was concerned that the sport's world governing body had not conducted sufficient out-of-competition drug tests with the Summer Games approaching next month in Sydney, Australia.

title: Net2Phone Climbs 26 Percent on Report of Venture With Cisco
description: Net2Phone Climbs 26 Percent on Report of Venture With Cisco

title: Sociologists to the Barricades; Thinkers Who Would Be Doers See Social Injustice Wherever They Turn
description: It was a dire prospect that greeted the 5,000 or so sociologists who converged on two Washington hotels last week for the start of the 95th annual meeting of the American Sociological Association. Titled, with the flair for which their calling has become known, ''Oppression, Domination and Liberation: Challenges for the 21st Century,'' the event promised insights not only into the ''continuing problem'' of racism but also into ''other manifestations of social inequality such as class exploitation and oppression on the basis of gender, ethnicity, national origin, sexual preference, disability and age.'' It was a big tent.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; STRIKE PARALYZES VW PLANT
description: Workers at the Volkswagen plant in Puebla, Mexico, that produces the New Beetle walked out after wage negotiations collapsed, halting production. Union leaders are demanding a 35 percent wage increase and have rejected Volkswagen's offer of a raise in line with inflation, which is expected to be less than 10 percent this year. The plant, which employs 16,000 people, also makes Jettas, Golf convertibles and classic Beetles. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: Article 2000081993882138117 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: In a Swing State, Cheers and Doubts
description: As the confetti fell and the delegates thundered in Los Angeles, there was a far more modest eruption of glee at the Corcoran home here, where three generations of women were watching Al Gore's long-awaited televised pitch to the nation.

title: Editorial Observer; The Democratic Convention and the Ever-Changing Face of Los Angeles
description: For Democrats this week, a flood of nostalgia evoked a bygone time in politics when Lew Wasserman, head of the MCA studios, Frank Sinatra and other figures in the old Hollywood establishment hobnobbed at the 1960 convention with John F. Kennedy. Back then, the entertainment industry supplied the glamour for a political party trying to look hip and committed. But the real power in Los Angeles resided elsewhere.

title: Fassel Tears Into Error-Prone Giants
description: Before tonight's exhibition game with the Jets, when Giants Coach Jim Fassel wanted to praise his team's play in the preseason, he talked about how few mistakes the Giants had made.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SALTON INC., -- Mount Prospect, Ill., a kitchen and personal care appliance maker, agreed to buy the Relaxor brand and inventory from JB Research Inc. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: CINAR FOUNDERS DISMISSED
description: The husband and wife who founded the Cinar Corporation, a maker of animated films, have been dismissed but have refused to resign their board seats, as requested by a special committee of the board. Micheline Charest, left, and Ronald A. Weinberg were dismissed from their senior executive jobs on Thursday, although they had not been working since March, when it was disclosed that $122 million was missing from the Montreal company, best known for the Emmy award-winning ''Arthur'' children's television series. The two control 63 percent of the company's shares. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Kozmo.com Delays IPO, Talks to Buy Urbanfetch.com Continue
description: Kozmo.com Delays IPO, Talks to Buy Urbanfetch.com Continue

title: Skakel Judge Bound by Laws Never Intended For Adult Case
description: In making the crucial decision of whether Michael Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy charged with the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley, is to stand trial as a juvenile or as an adult, Judge Maureen D. Dennis must navigate a thicket of quarter-century-old juvenile justice laws never intended for application to a middle-aged defendant.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the treatment that may face Senator John McCain of Arizona for skin cancer omitted a word in a quotation from his speech at the Republican National Convention. He said, ''The years that remain are not too few, I trust, but the immortality that was the inspiration of my youth has, like all the treasures of youth, quietly slipped away.'' He did not say, ''The years that remain are too few.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERT, LOIS R.
description: LAMBERT-Lois R. June 10, 1921 - August 19, 1991. Always in our thoughts. Your Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWY, IRMA
description: LOWY-Irma. Resident of New York City, died in her 90th year at home after a long illness. She is survived by her daughter Ruth Lacey, her son Frank Lowy, and her three grandchildren Alexander, Evan, and Andrew. A camp director for over 20 years, she will be fondly remembered by her campers as Aunt Iwo. She was a kind and generous woman who will be missed by all who knew her. Donations may be made to her favorite charities: The Fresh Air Fund or God's Love We Deliver.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's appearance on NBC's ''Tonight'' show gave an incorrect first name in some copies for Jay Leno's wife, who sat in the audience with Chelsea Clinton. She is Mavis Leno, not Avis.

title: Piazza and Alfonzo Share Top Billing in Mets' Victory
description: Sports Illustrated christened Mike Piazza as ''The Man'' on its cover this week, but the Mets catcher does not feel pressure to carry his team. He is thrilled with his supporting cast, and he needs it to produce if he is going to reach the World Series for the first time in his career. ''You're only as good as the guys around you,'' Piazza said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELBAUM, SELMA
description: EDELBAUM-Selma. On August 17, 2000. Wife of the late Maurice Edelbaum. Beloved mother of Philip and the late Theodore, grandmother of Stacey Boretz, Evan and Laura. Great grandmother of Marissa, Nicole and Dana Boretz. Graveside services Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, on Sunday, August 20, at 1 P.M.

title: Lazio Faults Mrs. Clinton For Record In Health Care
description: After a visit to the birthplace of the women's suffrage movement, Representative Rick A. Lazio challenged Hillary Rodham Clinton on one of her core issues, women's health care, igniting a battle over which candidate had done more about breast cancer prevention.

title: Headstrong Rebel Who Became Her Father's Defender
description: BY her own admission, Alberta Lee was a contentious handful as a teenager and a willful, self-absorbed young woman whose lack of direction concerned her conservative immigrant parents.

title: OLYMPICS: For Defectors from Cuba, Rough Political Waters; Cuba's Objections May Keep Kayaker and Others Out of Games
description: When Angel Perez sneaked away with two friends from an altitude training center in Mexico City seven years ago, catching a bus to the Texas border, swimming across the Rio Grande and taking a waiting car to Miami, he thought he was free forever of the control of Cuban sports officials.

title: McCain 'Confident' Heading Into Surgery to Have Malignant Melanomas Removed
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona said today that he would have surgery on Saturday morning to remove two malignant melanomas that were discovered after a routine skin examination earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMASES, FRED
description: THOMASES-Fred. Beloved husband of Florence, loving father of Jeffrey, Matthew, Robert, and Susan, beloved grandfather, and long-time supporter of the Israel Cancer Research Fund. He was a man of generous spirit. Profound sympathy is extended to his family. The Officers, Board & Staff ICRF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATLING, EVA INGERSOLL
description: GATLING-Eva Ingersoll. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The Heckscher Museum of Art mourn with profound sadness the passing of Director Emeritus and Honorary Trustee Eva Ingersoll Gatling. Her professionalism and 15 years of dedicated leadership laid the foundation for all that has come after. A Discerning Art Historian, Visionary Leader and Caring Mentor-Her Dauntless Spirit will be missed. Catherine A. Jansen, Chairman John E. Coraor, Ph.D, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, MARTHA HUGHES
description: ADELMAN-Martha Hughes. 74 years, of Boca Raton, Florida. She is survived by her devoted husband, Emanuel. Mother of Robert and Rosemary Thompson. Stepmother of Janet Adelman and her husband Robert Osserman. Grandmother of Michael Caton, Brian and Stephen Osserman. Sister of Mary Louise and Bernard Conor, Ann Wolff, Hope and Jack O'Connor, Ed and Cathy Hughes, Kathleen Hughes. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Saturday, 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM with the funeral service beginning at 1:00 PM at the funeral home. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Queens Nightclub Closed After Attacks
description: A Queens nightclub, the scene of a series of violent incidents during the last few years, has been ordered closed as a public nuisance.

title: A New Democrat Reinvents Himself
description: This election is not about ideology,'' Michael Dukakis declared in his acceptance speech at the 1988 Democratic Convention. ''It's about competence.'' The Republicans grinned, and George Bush went on to win by making sure that ideology ruled the campaign.

title: Upset at Summer Nationals, As Defending Team Loses
description: Two top-seeded teams suffered defeat at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Thursday, and one of these results was an upset of historic proportions.

title: Lives That Have Been Changed Forever From the Aftereffects of a Mosquito Bite
description: It took many months, but Bob Benson says that he is fully recovered now, except for the rustiness hampering his golf game. Climbing the stairs is no longer a draining chore. Gardening is now a joy, not a hazard. And traveling means more than just shuttling between his home in Bronxville, N.Y., and the hospital: he flew to Denmark this summer for a one-month exchange program.

title: Toyota Raises 5 Models' Prices
description: The American unit of the Toyota Motor Corporation raised prices today on 2001 year models of two sport utility vehicles and three cars. The largest increase was on the Land Cruiser sport utility vehicle -- up $1,167, or 2.3 percent, to $52,895, from this year's model. Excluding the cost of features that had been optional and are now standard, the increase was $422, or 0.8 percent, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORAN, HELEN M.
description: HORAN-Helen M. 89. Of Woodbury, CT. on Monday, August 14, 2000. Beloved wife of Harold A. Horan for 67 years. She was the daughter of the late Michael and Ellen (Farrell) Feeney. Formerly of Brooklyn, she moved to Woodbury 25 years ago. She was the beloved mother of two sons, Robert A. Horan of Woodbury & Richard A. Horan of Indianapolis, IN. Also survived by 2 nephews, Thomas and Christopher. She was predeceased by a son, Harold F. Horan. Mass was held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Washington, CT. Burial in New North Cemetery, Woodbury, CT.

title: Erstad Steals One From the Yanks
description: You cannot see the whole field from the home bench at Yankee Stadium. There is a small rise that obscures the view of the left fielder, and the first base stands block the view of the right-field corner. From his corner seat in the dugout, Yankees Manager Joe Torre kept waiting for the fans to react and report on the doings of Anaheim left fielder Darin Erstad last night.

title: Kurds Warily Welcome Turkey's Changes in Human Rights Policy
description: Turkey's decision to end a 34-year holdout and sign two United Nations conventions this week guaranteeing the social and political rights of minorities was greeted with tempered enthusiasm among the country's Kurds.

title: Prosecutors Say Scientist's Meeting in Beijing Was Suspicious
description: Prosecutors sought to bolster their case today against a former Los Alamos scientist accused of mishandling nuclear weapons secrets by arguing that a visit to Beijing in 1988 had transformed him into a virtual spy for China.

title: Behind Every Park, a Story; New Signs Illuminate Lives That Go With the Names
description: You watched all 10 hours (so far) of Ric Burns's ''New York: A Documentary Film.'' You keep ''The Encyclopedia of New York City'' on your night stand. You are thankful that the New-York Historical Society has clung to its hyphen. So when out-of-town visitors come to stay on your couch, they are confident that you can answer all their questions.

title: Sydney-Bound Horses Face Toughest Animal Import Rules on Planet : Hooved Olympians Set for Longest Ride
description: FRANKFURT  At precisely 12:20 p.m. on Sunday, a Lufthansa 747 cargo freighter with 55 horses, 44 grooms and two veterinarians on board will taxi ever so gently away from a high-security warehouse at Frankfurt International Airport.

title: Burdened With Being Everywhere
description: We were two pedestrians, walking through downtown Berkeley, without even a single razor scooter in sight. But the young woman on my heels was handling our slow pace in a far more wired -- or rather, wireless -- mode than I. She was scrolling through her weekly schedule on the itty-bitty Palm Pilot screen and barking into her cell phone. I admired her. She'd turned the mundane necessity of traveling from Point A to Point B into a movable therapy session.

title: ENRON VENTURE IN JAPAN
description: The Enron Corporation of Houston plans to build a thermal power plant in Japan to supply electricity to industries. Enron is hoping to start construction within a year, said the financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun. Enron officials said it was premature to comment on its energy projects in Japan. Earlier this year, the company teamed with a Japanese leasing company, the Orix Corporation, to develop energy ventures in the deregulated Japanese power industry. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro fell for the first time this week against the dollar on concern that the European Central Bank would raise interest rates this month. In New York, the euro settled at 90.63 cents, down from 91.63 cents.

title: Religion Journal; Amsterdam Conference Sets Goals for Evangelists
description: When the Rev. Billy Graham's organization convened a conference of more than 10,000 evangelists from around the world in Amsterdam on July 29, the event was described as notable for its size and its extraordinary international composition, with people from more than 200 nations and territories represented.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, CONSTANCE DENGEL (CONNIE)
description: LEWIS-Constance Dengel (Connie), 75, of John's Island in Vero Beach, FL. Died at home on Wednesday morning, August 16, 2000. After a short remission her breast cancer had recurred as brain cancer. Though her relapse was sudden and unexpected, she passed away peacefully, painlessly, and with many loved ones at her side. Connie was born on March 15, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY, the second of three children to Edward and Veronica Dengel. She attended Sacred Heart Academy in Manhattan and upon her marriage to John T. Lewis, originally of Short Hills, NJ, in October 1956, they settled in Fairfield, CT. A champion wife, mother, golfer and friend, she is survived by her husband John; four children, Cindy Sweeting of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, John Jr., of New York City, Michael of Smithfield, VA and James of Weston, FL; a sister Roni of Montclair, NJ and seven grandchildren. A daughter, Anne Marie, died in 1991. After 38 years in Fairfield, she and John retired to Vero Beach in 1994. Long a fixture on the women's golf scene in Fairfield and Westchester Counties, Connie was a winner of many golf titles, including 12 championships at Brooklawn Country Club in CT. She was a past president of both the Women's Tri-County Golf Association and the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association. Connie exuded great warmth, class and humor to all. One could not find a better mate, mother, or friend. She will be deeply and widely missed. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10 AM on Monday, August 21 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, Covenant House, or the American Diabetes Association. For information contact, Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach.

title: Gore and Lieberman Take Their Message to the Banks of the Mississippi
description: Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman took to the Mississippi today, weaving the river's epic symbolism into a populist challenge against the political influence of oil corporations, health maintenance organizations and drug companies.

title: Judge Admits Disclosure of Clinton Inquiry
description: A federal appeals court judge in Chicago said today that he was the source of a report on Thursday that a new grand jury had been impaneled by the independent counsel investigating President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern.

title: Russian Admiral Acknowledges Explosion Inside Sub
description: The commander of Russia's Northern Fleet acknowledged today that a terrible internal explosion devastated the nuclear submarine Kursk before it went down last Saturday, confirming Western intelligence reports of huge underwater explosions.

title: Will Issues Be Answer?
description: When he accepted the Republican presidential nomination in Philadelphia two weeks ago, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas skipped lightly over a few issues -- taxes, Social Security, education, nuclear weapons -- and then got to his topic sentence: ''We must usher in an era of responsibility.''

title: From Gore, the Tonic of Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill at Odds With Plate Umpire
description: Paul O'Neill, the Yankees' right fielder, sharply criticized the home plate umpire Gary Cederstrom after last night's game against Anaheim, saying that Cederstrom had retaliated to some of O'Neill's actions by calling him out on strikes. ''That was the most intentional thing I've ever seen in my life,'' said O'Neill, who griped about a strike call in the fourth inning, and was called out on a pitch that appeared to be outside the strike zone. O'Neill turned and confronted Cederstrom, before being pushed away by Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager. Cederstrom did not eject O'Neill, but the rest of the game, he and O'Neill traded words and glares, even as the umpire left the field after the game.

title: PETROLEUM PLACE, INTERNET CONCERN, IN CANADA DEAL
description: Petroleum Place Inc., an Internet energy portal and market maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Applied Terravision Systems Inc. of Canada, a provider of integrated financial accounting and property asset management software and services, for $69 million in stock. Petroleum Place, based in Englewood, Colo., provides integrated Internet-enabled products and services, supporting online oil and gas asset databases, geotechnical data and negotiated transaction services. Applied develops enterprise information solutions that manage revenue-generating assets with complex ownership. (Bridge News)

title: For the Loyalists, A New Confidence
description: As they packed up their placards and headed home to where the hard work awaits, Democratic delegates and elected officials said today that they were confident that Vice President Al Gore had opened the minds of undecided voters with his convention speech on Thursday night, even if he might not have closed the sale.

title: Ages-Old Icecap at North Pole Is Now Liquid, Scientists Find
description: The North Pole is melting.

title: Eva Gatling, 87, Art Curator Who Led the Hecksher Museum
description: Eva Gatling, an art historian and curator who for many years was the director of the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, N.Y., died on Tuesday at the Westminister-Canterbury, a continuing care community in Virginia Beach, Va., where she had lived in recent years. She was 87.

title: Mrs. Clinton Takes a Busman's Holiday
description: Some Adirondacks getaway! Hillary Rodham Clinton barely had enough time to unpack her bags at the lakeside home where the first family is spending the weekend before she was off to a political rally to talk up her Senate bid.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLAN, MARK J.
description: CAPLAN-Mark J. Remembering You on Your Birthday, Today and Always. With Love Mom, Dad and Ron

title: A FASHION ODYSSEY
description: From the boot of Italy to a trip down the Nile to the glaciers far north, Fashions of The Times goes to 17 countries -- including Mali, Brazil, China, Cuba, South Korea, India and Wales -- to show women's clothes for fall. Part 2 of The Times Magazine.

title: Cleansing the Mind's Palate With Puerto Rican Rhythms
description: The new album by the saxophonist David Sanchez, ''Melaza'' (Columbia/Sony), is full of 16th-note runs, played by Mr. Sanchez and the alto-saxophonist Miguel Zenon, as they go through hairpin turns of Latin rhythmic accent; the writing is frequently complicated, in a jazz sense, and rather busy. Mr. Sanchez's set at the Blue Note late Wednesday night, on the other hand, was lighter on composition and seemed to be all about clearing the mind.

title: U.S. Delays Asylum Hearing For Leader of a Chinese Sect
description: Immigration officials have delayed until next month a decision on whether to grant asylum to the leader of a Chinese spiritual movement after Chinese officials appealed for his return and submitted detailed charges that he raped followers, people involved in the case say.

title: Citing Stephen King, Netlibrary files IPO
description: Citing Stephen King, Netlibrary files IPO

title: Lawrence H. Cooke, 85, New York Chief Judge, Dies
description: Lawrence H. Cooke, a former chief judge of New York State known for his homespun style and liberal rulings on such matters as the rights of criminal defendants and freedom of the press, died Thursday at his home in Monticello, N.Y. He was 85.

title: An Airport Hopes to Build Traffic, Even Just One Flight at a Time
description: When it was completed here two years ago to relieve the overcrowding at Lambert Field in St. Louis, the MidAmerica Airport was an airline passenger's dream: a brand-new terminal with free parking just 22 minutes from downtown.

title: City Receives 14 Proposals to Privatize Its Failing Schools
description: Fourteen companies and nonprofit organizations from around the country have submitted proposals to manage some of the worst-performing New York City schools under a privatization plan outlined last month by Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy.

title: Korean Families Part Again As Bittersweet Reunions End
description: Having begun to put back together the shattered fragments of their pasts, 200 North and South Koreans today separated from their families again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEN, UNA Y.T.
description: CHEN-Una Y.T., 87. Granddaughter of Tan Chun-Lin, Governor General of Guang Dong and Guang Xi Provinces, daughter of Tan Yen-Kai, Chairman and First Prime Minister of Nationalist China, died peacefully while visiting her son, Harold Chen in Salt Lake City, Utah. Mrs. Chen, beloved wife of Kuan-Cheng, a graduate of Newnham College, Cambridge University, taught English in China and Linguistics at Georgetown and Johns Hopkins Universities before retiring to New York City. In addition to her son, Mrs. Chen is survived by daughters, Elaine Chen-Nash of Virginia, Tina ChenJosephson of Manhattan, Sana Chen-Powell of Hawaii and seven grandchildren. Service is at 11:30AM, Sat., Aug. 19, Campbell Funeral Home, Madison at 81 St.

title: Respect Follows Success for Rockers
description: They are not anonymous anymore. But like their city, the Cleveland Rockers are still struggling to gain recognition and respect despite their recent success.

title: Laser Project Is Delayed and Over Budget
description: A giant laser being built at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory will cost nearly $2 billion more than the laboratory originally announced and will be delayed by at least six years, according to a report released on Thursday by the General Accounting Office.

title: When Minors Seek Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about RTMark, an online group that seeks to undermine corporations, misstated the given name of a college student who sent it money. He is Kenneth DeGraff, not Frank.

title: Compaq Chief Says PC Parts Shortage is Worst Ever
description: Compaq Chief Says PC Parts Shortage is Worst Ever

title: On a Summer Night, Nothing Is Strange or Foreign
description: Probably it ought to matter whether someone is wearing the silver wig of a dancer in a cheap club or the yellow hat, high and crested, of a Tibetan monk. On Thursday, however, all the world was on stage at the Damrosch Park Band Shell -- all the world and also some strange moon, for the main event was ''The Lunar Opera'' by Pauline Oliveros, in which a variety of professional and amateur musicians were encouraged to do their own things while acting as creatures from Lunarus in what was decidedly Ms. Oliveros's own thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZYGER, MAYER
description: ZYGER-Mayer, 85, on August 17. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Anne Easton and Pauline and Jimmy Folkoff. Adoring grandfather of Loren, Ali and Erica. Services August 20, 11:15 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to be made to the Holocaust Museum or American Cancer Society.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 17th-Century Composers as They Might Have Sounded to Themselves
description: In the early days of the period instrument movement, when accomplished players were comparatively few, listeners grew used to seeing the same musicians performing under the flags of several ensembles, each of which either explored a different corner of the repertory or helped bring to life a different leader's interpretive ideas. Now the pool of musicians able to turn out polished, technically first-rate performances on period instruments in the United States is large enough to support active early-music scenes on both coasts. Yet the urge to regroup apparently remains as strong among early-music players as among jazz musicians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, PETER
description: SELIGMAN-Peter. Beloved son of Bonnie and Robert Konigsberg. Loving brother of Stephanie and Paul Balint, Suzanne and Marc Reimer, Michael and Kim Konigsberg, Marc and Lynn Konigsberg, and Richard Konigsberg. Cherished grandson of Sylvia and Lester Kovar. Beloved fiance of Sara Senik. Services 11:30AM Sunday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: WELSH UTILITY BATTLE OVER
description: The big Japanese investment bank Nomura International withdrew from the takeover battle for Hyder P.L.C., a troubled Welsh utility, paving the way for Western Power Distribution of the United States to buy Hyder. Nomura said it would not appeal a decision by a British regulatory panel to allow Western Power's winning bid of 365 pence, or $5.48, a share, which Nomura had contended was made after the regulator's deadline. The deal values Hyder at $:565 million, or about $848 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIKELY, AUDREY
description: LIKELY-Audrey. Goodbye dear friend. You will always be in our hearts. Love, Hilda and Len Zahn

title: Setting Aside Friendly Face, Democrats Plot an Attack
description: After four days of giving a national television audience a generally positive look at itself and its candidates, the Democratic Party turned today to how to attack the Republicans and Gov. George W. Bush on a variety of issues, with a heavy emphasis on abortion.

title: Misguided Aid for Colombia
description: The Clinton administration is poised to begin sending hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to Colombia's military. But first it must either certify that that nation's armed forces meet certain human rights criteria or waive those requirements in the interests of national security. Washington will probably grant the waiver to get counter-narcotics aid flowing, arguing that Colombia's armed forces will soon begin to clean themselves up. This is dangerous, wishful thinking. A stream of new helicopters, American training and logistical support given without preconditions will remove any incentive for the military to begin respecting civilians. The United States will be financing, training and backing a military with a record of killing civilians, aiding brutal right-wing paramilitary groups and defying a well-meaning but weak civilian government.

title: Online Coverage Fell Short of the Hype
description: If any group was hoping for a ''bounce'' from the Democratic and Republican conventions, it was the scores of political Web sites that made their online debuts in Los Angeles and Philadelphia with lots of gizmos and hype.

title: Finding Some Words to Ponder While Listening for a President
description: The speech, confident and powerful, rang through the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles and, far across the country in South Florida, made Darren Gentry reconsider voting for George W. Bush.

title: Spotlight Is Shared, But Lead Is Woods's
description: Tiger Woods did not mind sharing the spotlight with Jack Nicklaus, but Woods wanted the lead for himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANDA, BRIJ B.
description: NANDA-Brij B. On August 17, 2000. Loving husband of Dino. Proud father of Neil and his wife Sonika. Caring grandfather of Noor and Jai. Beloved brother, uncle and close friend. Visiting and services at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue and 12th St. Garden City, Saturday 12-1:30PM. Cremation to follow at The Long Island Cremation Co., West Babylon, N.Y.

title: Managed Care Companies Seek to Build on a Legal Victory
description: Heartened by a federal court victory in Philadelphia last week in the managed care wars, lawyers for several major health insurance companies are seeking to consolidate a host of lawsuits accusing managed care companies of misleading customers. They also hope to transfer the suits from Miami to Philadelphia.

title: Defeated Mexico Party Faces Next Test in Chiapas
description: Although he calls himself a religious man, there is something mildly unholy about the way Pablo Salazar Mendiguchia delights in the prospect of killing the PRI.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Phone Surfing For a Few Yen; Japan Web Sites Navigate A Serene Revenue Stream
description: Spurred by growing Internet use in Japan, Kazutomo Hori in 1995 built Paradise Web, an Internet site that offered chat lines and bulletin boards. The service thrived, but Mr. Hori could not figure out how to get users to pay.

title: Broken Chair Ousts Mediate
description: The bizarre injury of the week belongs to Rocco Mediate, the winner of the Buick Open last Sunday. He had to withdraw today after his chair broke while he was sitting outside the contestant family dining area on Thursday.

title: Supporting The Post
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Northwest, Still Undecided
description: In one obvious sense, it would be hard to consider Martine Dedek or John Roderick ''swing voters'' in the coming presidential election. Young, unabashedly liberal, both proud participants in last fall's demonstrations here against the World Trade Organization, they both roll their eyes and offer a vigorous ''no way'' when asked if they would consider voting for the Republican candidate, George W. Bush.

title: U.S. Gymnasts Try to Catch Karolyi's Eye
description: The preliminaries of the women's United States Olympic gymnastics trials unfolded tonight with an early fall for a stunned but resilient Shannon Miller and with increasing signs of unease by those who wonder if personal preference will mean more than performance to Bela Karolyi.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Progress in Phone Talks, But No Overall Accord Yet
description: Negotiators for more than 86,000 striking telephone workers and Verizon Communications reached tentative agreement on several critical issues yesterday, but an overall settlement to the 13-day walkout remained bogged down in the details.

title: LOWER PRICE FOR AUCTIONEER
description: The British Internet auctioneer QXL agreed to buy a German rival, Ricardo.de, although it lowered its original offer by nearly three-quarters, to 171 million [pounds], or $256.5 million, after learning that Ricardo's fourth-quarter revenue had declined sharply. The deal values Ricardo at 32.9 euros, or about $29.94, a share, compared with QXL's original bid, made in May, of 42.6 euros a share. Ricardo will provide QXL with an entry into the German market, where a United States competitor, eBay, is the leader. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Icahn Building a Stake in General Motors
description: One of the most famous corporate raiders of the 1980's and 1990's, Carl C. Icahn, has begun accumulating a stake in General Motors, the world's largest company, in a move that will increase pressure on the automaker to spin off its most valuable asset, Hughes Electronics.

title: Auction Buyer Finds Skeleton in Car Trunk
description: The owner of a car salvage business in Flatlands, Brooklyn, discovered a human skeleton yesterday in the trunk of a car he had bought at a city auction, the police said.

title: Trapped Crew's Families Lash Out as Hope Fades
description: The weather lightened today, but tempers lashed out, on the day when authorities had said that 118 Russian sailors trapped under the sea would run out of air.

title: Tainted Jumper Returns To Boos and One Medal
description: He has been notably absent from major track and field competitions for more than a year, and he was notably absent from tonight's premeet parade of stars during which the likes of Maurice Greene and Gail Devers took a lap on the track at the Louis II Stadium in classic convertible cars.

title: Lawyers Say Drug War's Tactics Draw Addicts Into Serious Crimes
description: The first time the man in the camouflage pants asked Steven Flowers to score him some drugs, Mr. Flowers sent him packing. It was 2 a.m. and, sitting on the stoop of his Harlem apartment house, Mr. Flowers spat, ''I don't sell no crack.'' He even used a curse or two to make his point.

title: Study Proposes New Strategy to Stem Global Warming
description: An influential expert on global warming who for nearly 20 years has pressed countries to cut emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases now says the emphasis on carbon dioxide may be misplaced. Instead, he and a team of scientists have concluded that the quickest way to slow warming is to cut other such greenhouse gases first.

title: A Smuggling Operation With a Russian Twist
description: Over the last two years, a federal investigation into Russian and Italian organized crime in the ports of Newark and Elizabeth, N.J., turned up the expected mix of mundane mob staples: extortion, cigarette smuggling, money laundering.

title: Rote Lessons Don't Help Poor Children Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly Auction For German Phone Rights
description: Hours after they clinked Champagne glasses on Thursday evening, winners in Germany's $46 billion auction for wireless licenses began feeling the hangover today.

title: Foreigners at Convention Baffled by the Pervasive Role of Money
description: LOS ANGELES  Yoro Diakite, a former minister of mines and energy in Mali, was still counting his pennies on the eve of his departure, to see whether he could afford the few thousand dollars needed to travel from one of the world's poorest countries to witness a week of Democratic extravagance in one of the world's richest.

title: Giuliani Chooses a Police Leader, but Won't Say Who
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has chosen a new police commissioner, but as of yesterday afternoon, he was keeping the choice to himself, putting off the announcement until this morning to give the departing commissioner a final day of recognition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTDEGEN, JOSEPH F.
description: HARTDEGEN-Joseph F. On August 17, 2000. Beloved Husband of Catherine (nee Kane), Loving Brother of William J. and Frank J.; Devoted Uncle of Elizabeth Vran kovich, Paul, Kathryn, and Kristin Schoen. Funeral Monday 8:45 AM from The Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 AM at St. Thomas Aquinas RC Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: WASSERMAN-Seymour, M.D. 87 of Lake Worth, Florida on August 18, 2000. Graduate of Tulane University Medical School. Radiologist at Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, NY, Huntington Hospital, NY and Central Islip State Hospital, NY. Survived by wife Beatrice, daughter Vicki, son-in-law Kevin and granddaughter Brittany. Services 2PM Sunday, August 20 at Menorah Gardens Funeral Chapel. Donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTMAN, BERENICE S.
description: GERSTMAN-Berenice S., 92. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. on August 17 in Somerset, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Mrs. Gerstman was an elementary school teacher in the New York City school system for 35 years. She also taught gym, reading and served as acting principal. She was a trustee of Union Temple, Brooklyn. Mrs. Gerstman was a champion athlete, especially excelling in swimming competitions. She is survived by her sister Ruth Feuerstein, a niece Frances (Daniel) Gold, a grand niece Suzanne Gold, grand newphew Nicholas (Marcy) Gold and two great grand nephews.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE HSB GROUP
description: American International Group Inc., one of the world's largest insurers, agreed yesterday to acquire HSB Group Inc., parent of the venerable Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company, for about $1.2 billion in stock. The deal will bolster A.I.G.'s range of products by adding several specialty insurance lines. Under the deal, A.I.G. will exchange $41 in stock for each HSB share. Shares of HSB climbed $1.3125, to $40, on the New York Stock Exchange, while A.I.G.'s stock fell 62.5 cents, to $86.875. Hartford Steam Boiler, which will operate as a stand-alone company with its existing management, writes commercial insurance and provides engineering consulting services. The Hartford-based company specializes in insuring against equipment breakdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUL, ROBERT
description: SAUL-Robert. On August 17, 2000. loving husband of Nancy, cherished father of Elizabeth and stepfather of Barry Josephson. Devoted brother of Miriam and Mel Krant. Services Sunday 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Official Warns That Little Can Be Done to Stop Fires
description: The secretary of the interior said today that the wildfires raging across the West were likely to get worse and warned that with resources already stretched to the limit, little could be done to slow their progress.

title: Red Bullet Will Miss A Diminished Travers
description: After reeling off their respective victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in May, Fusaichi Pegasus and Red Bullet were being counted on by many to help reinvigorate the sport.

title: Phantom Rogues at the I.R.S.
description: Congress conducted hearings in 1997 and 1998 on abuse of taxpayers by agents of the Internal Revenue Service, inviting self-proclaimed victims to testify how they had been harassed. The chilling anecdotes, orchestrated by Republican leaders to buttress their call for a less intrusive federal government, persuaded Congress to pass new taxpayer protections. A provision of the 1998 law calls for the mandatory firing of agents who commit any one of 10 specific abuses.

title: U.S. Envoy Tries to Revive Mideast Peace Talks
description: The State Department's special peace envoy, Dennis Ross, opened new talks in Jerusalem today with Prime Minister Ehud Barak in an effort to break an impasse in the negotiations for an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, MARJORIE (ALEXANDER)
description: HARRISON-Marjorie (Alexander). Of Essex, CT, formerly Andover, Mass, died August 17. Memorial service will be August 24 at 11:00 A.M., St. John's Episcopal Church, Main Street. Essex, CT.

title: Harcourt Seeking Approval To Operate an Online College
description: In a bid to join a handful of private companies offering college-level courses over the Internet, Harcourt General hopes to receive approval on Monday to operate an online college.

title: From Gore, the Tonic of Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: COHOES BANCORP HOLDERS REJECT HUDSON RIVER OFFER
description: The shareholders of Cohoes Bancorp have rejected the company's plan to merge with Hudson River Bancorp. The companies' merger plans had been under attack since June, when the Ambanc Holding Company and the Trustco Bank Corporation, two New York rivals, made separate unsolicited bids for Cohoes. TrustCo also made an additional bid for Hudson River. Cohoes shareholders voted 47.52 percent in favor of the Hudson River merger, just under the 50 percent needed to gain approval. Hudson River planned to exchange 1.185 shares of its stock for each share of Cohoes, valuing the transaction at $108.4 million, or $13.55 a share, based on yesterday's prices. Ambanc is offering $16.50 a share for Cohoes. Trustco is offering $16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, ABNER I.
description: KAY-Abner I., 85. Of Lake Worth, FL. Passed away August 17, 2000. Beloved husband of Helen for 55 years. Loving father of Harold (Cynthia) Kay, Richard (Kathy) Kay and Jonathan (Patricia) Kay. Cherished grandfather of David, Jana, Jeffrey, Michael and Melanie. Graveside services 11:00 AM Sunday at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATSINER, FLORENCE
description: PATSINER - Florence. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Ruth and Al Young, Marilyn and Harvey Horowitz, Arthur and Fran Patsiner. Adored grandmother of Larry and Billy Young, Andrew Horowitz, Lisa and Michael Tambor, Daniel and Jenifer Patsiner. Services Sunday, 1 P.M., at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, CATHARINE
description: KELLY-Catharine. Age 90. Loving wife of the late Walter. Beloved mother of Jane Kelly. Family will receive friends Sunday from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian burial Our Lady of Angel's Church, Monday, August 21 at 9:45AM. In lieu of flowers donations to Covenant House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNICI, GERTRUDE FITZPATRICK
description: IANNICI - Gertrude Fitzpatrick. Passed away on August 17. Age 75. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Iannici. Survived by her beloved daughter and son-in-law Jane and Joseph Pontarelli. Dear sister of Michael Fitzpatrick (Jean), Jeri Crivilli (Louis), her beloved brother-in-law Joseph Iannici (Helen), many nieces, nephews and extended family. She was a women of great courage and inner strength. Jane and Joseph Pontarelli will be receiving family and friends at their home in Quogue, LI, NY on Sunday, August 20th from 5 to 9 PM at 31 Ogden Lane. Interment private, Monday at Calverton National Cemetery at 1PM.

title: Away From Father, Learning What He Learned
description: Anoushka Shankar's father, Ravi Shankar, learned what it was like to play Indian classical music for uncomprehending audiences at 1960's rock festivals like Monterey Pop and Woodstock. Ms. Shankar, who is 19, had her version of the experience on Thursday night at Central Park Summerstage, where she shared a bill with Roni Size's band Reprazent, a dance-music dynamo.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Progress Is Seen in Talks As Phone Strike Continues

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMMERS, WILLIAM GARTH
description: SYMMERS-William Garth. 89. Of NYC, formerly of Greenwich, Ct. on August 16, 2000. Beloved father of Barbara Bancroft, Susan, Bradford, Ann Reed, Deborah Symmers & Benjamin Keith Symmers. Devoted grandfather of eleven, great-grandfather of five. A memorial service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown on Saturday, August 19 at 2 P.M.

title: MALAYSIA WIRELESS UPGRADE
description: A large Malaysian cell phone operator, Maxis Communication, said it would spend as much as 3 billion ringgit, or $789 million, in the next two to three years to upgrade its network in preparation for third-generation mobile telephone services. Malaysia is planning to award licenses by the end of the year for the new services, which enable mobile phones to surf the Web at speeds faster than most current personal computers. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Cyclists Take to the Roads, and Mass Transit, in New Jersey
description: The bicycle lockers at the New Jersey Transit station here have gotten Jim Barrett out of his car. He pedals his old balloon-tire Schwinn the mile from his home to the station, and wasting no time searching for a scarce parking spot, he stores the bike safely and continues his daily commute by train.

title: Detained Editor's Brother Is Arrested in Beijing
description: The police have detained the younger brother of a Boston-based poet arrested in Beijing last week, apparently for his involvement in a literary journal that has sometimes published work by Chinese dissidents.

title: Cheney's Transition
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about the exhibition ''Drawings 2000'' at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery in Manhattan misstated the address. It is at 515 West 24th Street, not 34th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Loretta Young on Sunday misidentified ''Come to the Stable.'' It was a 1949 film starring Ms. Young, not an episode of her television series.

title: That All-English Dictionary Adds an All-American Coach
description: When the Oxford English Dictionary decided to open a North American office this year to document the evolution of American English from the thick of it, it engaged a young American lexicographer with impeccable credentials who also happened to be the author of a 288-page book on a certain unmentionable word.

title: Lawmakers Ask for Delay In Review of Nasdaq Rule
description: Senator Phil Gramm and Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to delay its review of a plan intended to give investors more information about Nasdaq stocks and trades at the best available prices.

title: Explosion Hit Sub, Russia Now Confirms
description: The commander of Russia's Northern Fleet acknowledged that a terrible internal explosion devastated the nuclear submarine Kursk before it went down last Saturday, confirming Western intelligence reports of huge underwater explosions.

title: For Independents, Much Skepticism
description: Roy Rosa watched the television images of Democratic conventioneers whirling like dervishes after Senator Edward M. Kennedy finished his speech on Tuesday night and asked, ''Don't these people realize they're going to lose?''

description: At least nine people were killed and dozens injured today as political protests swept across Mexico State, shattering the euphoria from last month's elections and dashing hopes for a peaceful political transition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, C. PHILIP
description: WILSON-C. Philip. The Officers and Faculty of the NYU Psychoanalytic Institute and the Officers and Members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York mourn the passing of our esteemed and beloved colleague Dr. C. Philip Wilson. His contributions to psychosomatic medicine are memorable. He was an inspiration and we will miss him deeply. We extend our condolences to his family. Dr. Michael Singer, Director NYU Psychoanalytic Institute and Dr. Leonard Barkin, President, PANY

title: Gore's Speech Sets Off Fall in Drug and Tobacco Shares
description: Stocks fell yesterday as drug and tobacco companies declined after Vice President Al Gore criticized them as he accepted the Democratic presidential nomination in a speech on Thursday.

title: BREWER REJECTS TAKEOVER
description: The maker of Banks's beer, Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, rejected a takeover offer from Botts & Company, a London-based finance company. ''The board has considered that this conditional offer approach both undervalues W.&D.B. and is too uncertain,'' Wolverhampton & Dudley said without disclosing the bid. Botts and Robert Breare, executive chairman of Noble House Leisure, have been working on a joint bid. The Daily Telegraph quoted unidentified people close to the situation as valuing the offer at $:566 million ($848 million).

description: WEINSTEIN-Rose P. The Alumni Association of Columbia College expresses its deepest sympathy to Board Vice President Edward A. Weinstein and his family on the passing of his mother Rose P. Weinstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBARD, MARION
description: GILBARD-Marion. Our beloved sister and aunt, astoundingly beautiful and elegant at 73, brimming with joy, having found love again after the loss of her beloved husband, Harris Gilbard, lost her battle with pancreatic cancer. Her easy going, warm hearted, generous nature was only surpassed by her courage. Her loving goodbyes to all of us as she stared death in the face were the final gifts of this most graceful spirit. Marion, we will miss you. Helen Rodbell Hank, Gerry, David and Brooke Alpert Alain, Ellen, Erica and Remy Roizen

description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Harllee Branch Jr., 94, Foe Of Government's Utility Role
description: Harllee Branch Jr., a top utility executive and outspoken critic of such government-subsidized competitors as the Tennessee Valley Authority, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Atlanta. He was 94.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the reunion of relatives separated by the Korean War referred incorrectly to the flight that took North Koreans to Seoul. The North Korean plane was not the first to land in the South since 1950. At least one other, a warplane flown by a defector, landed there in 1996. The article also misstated the term for traditional Korean dresses worn by some of the North Korean women. It is han bok, not han dok.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARDSLEY, R. GEOFFREY
description: BARDSLEY-R. Geoffrey. Of Stamford, CT., died August 14, age 72, while recovering from injuries sustained when struck by a vehicle June 7th. while training for a half marathon. Beloved husband of Elda Shantz Bardsley and father of Kathryn, Alex and Alyson. Born and raised in England, educated at Cambridge, he immigrated to the U.S. in 1956. Retired senior corporate executive specializing in international finance, who worked first for the Bank of England and then several New York banks, as well as Xerox Corporation and its subsidiaries, including Industrial Indemnity Finance Corporation, in San Francisco, of which he was president and CEO 1985-92. For the last 7 years, active volunteer and executive recruiter with International Executive Service Corps, personally acting as consultant on financial and development projects in Africa, Asia, and the former Soviet Union, as well as working with volunteers world wide. Marathoner, linguist, musician, gardener; driven and generous, he still had much to give. The world is poorer for his absence and he is painfully missed. A memorial service is planned for mid September in Stamford.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't know if anybody in history ever got to 90 degrees north to be greeted by water, not ice.''

title: Harlem Teacher Is Charged With Selling Drugs From Car
description: A special education teacher who gave out cookies to students and kept exotic pets in her Harlem classroom was charged yesterday with possessing and selling drugs from a parked car in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTKER, MARTIN
description: ROTKER-Martin. Beloved husband of Elaine. Dear father of Ronnie (Abraham) Deutsch, Allen, Steve (Joy), Glenn (Nancy). Survived by grandchildren Michelle, Benjamin, Jonathan, Rachel, Jennifer, Lindsay, Alicia, Harry and great-grandson Jordan. Funeral services, 1:00 PM, Sunday, August 20, Weinstein Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY. Interment, Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Democrats' Party Outdrew the G.O.P.'s
description: The Democrats appeared to be a slightly bigger draw on television in prime time during their convention this week than were the Republicans during their convention two weeks earlier. But the audiences for both events were down over all compared with 1996.

title: Groom-to-Be in Fatal Fall On Way to Get the License
description: With most of the arrangements for their wedding taken care of and their honeymoon to Bali all set, Peter Seligman and his fiancee set off yesterday morning on one last crucial errand: to get a marriage license. They left their East Side apartment before 8 a.m. and boarded a No. 5 train, heading downtown toward the marriage license bureau in the Municipal Building.

title: A Senate Candidate in a New Spotlight
description: WHEN Waterbury's Mayor, Philip A. Giordano, announced earlier this year that he would run against Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, state Republican party leaders and Gov. John G. Rowland tried to talk him out of it.

title: Q & A
description: Renting in Crete

title: Lives; King of the Mountain
description: 'You're not going to just leave that tiny girl up there all alone, are you?'' the stranger asks me, his tone grave. He's pointing an accusatory finger up at my daughter, Sasha, who -- giggling and triumphant, her hair aglow with the last rays of the evening -- has just scaled the summit of a gigantic rock. ''She'll fall.''

title: Rediscovering the Four Seasons
description: LONG ago, when I lived on the Upper West Side, I thought flowers came from the Korean store, communing with nature was a day in Riverside Park and the best way to know if it was raining was to turn on the radio.

title: Book Shows Maturity
description: When Edward Beltrami and Philip E. Palmedo brought out the first edition of ''The Wines of Long Island'' in 1993, their book signaled its principal theme with the subtitle ''Birth of a Region.''

title: Irish Music in Ocean Grove
description: The Great Auditorium in Ocean Grove will reverberate with the sounds of Irish music and dance next Saturday as three Irish ensemble groups celebrate the Celtic tradition.

description: Hadley Howe Longstreth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Longstreth of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Clark Gamble Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Peterson III of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. John R. Francis performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBARD, MARION
description: GILBARD-Marion. Of Boca Raton, on August 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harris; Loving mother of Andrew (Cheryle), Dale and Arnold Carlton; Cherished grandmother of Marlena, Edward, India and Rani and great grandmother of Tiffany; Adored sister of Helen (Shelly) Rodbell; Aunt of Gerry (Hank) Alpert and Ellen (Alain) Roizen; Special friend of Al Stalford. Marion will be remembered for her courage, grace, beautiful smile, friendliness, generosity and profound goodness and her unfailing love for family and friends, you will live in our hearts forever. Contributions may be made in her memory to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL, 33486. For information, contact Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL, 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ROSE
description: WEINSTEIN-Rose. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed members and benefactors, Sandra and Edward Weinstein on the loss of Ed's beloved mother. May the bereaved family be comforted by their cherished memories. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Naria Halliwell, Peter Levine
description: Naria Beth Anna Halliwell, the daughter of Anne Sommerfeld Halliwell and Steven Halliwell of Irvington, N.Y., was married there yesterday evening to Peter Thomas Levine, a son of Ellen Levine and Dr. Richard Levine of New York. Rabbi Edward Schecter performed the ceremony at Sunnyside, the historic Hudson Valley house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ANNE DE LA VERGNE
description: WEISS-Anne de la Vergne. The writer and editor Anne de la Vergne Weiss died at home in Chestertown, MD, August 13 at the age of 74. She was the daughter of Charles and Carol de la Vergne, of Kingston, NY. She is survived by her husband, Irving Weiss, four children, and five grandchildren. Anne Weiss met her husband when she was his editor at The Century Cyclopedia of Names. She was later co-author and editor with him of American Authors and Books, 1640 to the Present Day; The Thesaurus of Book Digests: 1950-1980; and Reflections on Childhood. As freelance writer, editor, and translator she contributed to the Funk and Wagnalls Standard Reference Encyclopedia; World Travel and Vacation Almanac; Grolier Encyclopedia International; McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of Science, and Magill Cyclopedia of World Authors. Her translation of The Adventures of Pinocchio, published on audiotape, was read by her husband on a week-long WBAI-FM children's program. She was at work with him on a complete translation of Malcolm de Chazal's Sens-Plastique for Sun and Moon Press. Her short stories appeared in literary magazines over the years. Anne Weiss was a graduate in American History of Barnard College, received her M.A. from Columbia University, and served as graduate assistant at the University of California at Berkeley. She taught social studies at Wallkill High School in Wallkill, NY, and was an adjunct faculty member in English at The State University of New York at New Paltz until she and her husband retired in 1985. Observances will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOKE, LAWRENCE H.
description: COOKE-Lawrence H. The Officers, Directors and members of the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York note with deep sadness the passing of the Hon. Lawrence H. Cooke, former Chief Judge of the State of New York. Chief Judge Cooke was an exemplary jurist, who had the common touch and ability to make all people feel welcome at the halls of justice throughout the State. He was a visionary who created the Taskforce on Women in the Courts to ensure equal treatment for all. We mourn the passing of a true friend and extend our condolences to his family.
