Deborah Kaplan, President

title: Oh Give Me a Home: A 'Creaturefuge' for Grizzlies
description: WHAT's next, 5-year-old environmental lobbyists in the halls of Congress?

title: Homeless Take Control of Their Lives on the Web
description: Back home in Puerto Rico, Angel Mora's family calls him Maestro, because he is so good with computers and because they are so proud of him.

title: Susannah Hearn, Nikolas Kerest
description: Susannah Marie Olivia Hearn, the daughter of Dr. Jana Srba Hearn and Dr. M. F. Hearn Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Nikolas Peter Kerest, the son of Naomi Waelsch Kerest and Joseph P. Kerest of Block Island in Rhode Island. The Rev. Frederick Lanz, an American Baptist minister, officiated at Sullivan House, a bed-and-breakfast on Block Island.

title: Under That Bramble: Look, It's History
description: CONNECTICUT has its share of historic Revolutionary War sites, some well marked, others hidden in dense brush. Then there are the stories -- some the stuff of pure legend, some well documented and others someplace in between.

title: Taking a Pass on the Dot-Com Life to Become Mozzarella Fellas
description: Two years ago, James Miller and Adam Lawdanski, then 29, set out to start a business. But unlike many others in their generation, they saw the future in decidedly low-tech terms. Their calling was mozzarella cheese. Using Mr. Lawdanski's experience working in the mozzarella field and Mr. Miller's managerial background, these friends from grade-school days in Manhattan borrowed and begged to raise money and opened up a store in Harrison. It's called La Bella Mozzarella. Bella is Italian for beautiful, and their logo features a feminine mozzarella, complete with a bow in her hair and come-hither eyelashes. In the pocket-size kitchen in the back of the store, they make ''handmade homemade'' mozzarella and sell it in the store and to shops, delicatessens and restaurants in New Jersey and Manhattan. They recently spoke about their store and their cheese.

title: The Deadbeat Odyssey; Down and Out in Beverly Hills
description: Whenever something bad happened, my great-grandmother's philosophy was that things could be worse. ''If you walked into a room and saw everyone else's troubles up on the wall,'' she would say, ''you would still go straight to your own.''

title: Flip Tax In the Sale Of a Co-op
description: Q In the sale of a co-op apartment, what is the rationale for the substantial flip tax paid by the seller? . . . Sol Milton, Bayside, N.Y.

title: Interiors
description: Sister

title: Correction
description: A picture on Aug. 13, with an article that discussed architectural projects in New York City in relation to the cultural values embodied by the Brooklyn Bridge, was published in error. It showed the poet Hart Crane (not Crane's friend Emil Opffer) standing on the roof of a Brooklyn building where Crane lived. The article also gave two erroneous addresses for the building. It was at 110 Columbia Heights, not 110 Columbus Heights or 110 Livingston Street.

title: When the Boss is a Stealth Bomber
description: AN anecdote in Kay Hammer's book, ''Workplace Warrior: Insights and Advice for Winning on the Corporate Battlefield'' brought me up short. It seems that Ms. Hammer once had a boss who set up a secret team of employees to develop a project that would replace work she had been doing. She didn't find out until the stealth project was presented as a fait accompli at a meeting of her entire division of 80 employees.

title: A Bright Star For Cottage Gardens
description: Over the past few years, blazing star (Liatris), a native North American plant, has emerged as a standout in sunny cottage gardens, formal planting schemes and inspired flower arrangements. The spicata species has tall (3 to 5 feet) spiked flower heads that appear bristly or wooly from a distance. Liatris ligulistylis is shorter, with more open flower spikes. The purple varieties of liatris are the most popular, although if you have an all-white garden, you can sometimes obtain white blazing star (Liatris spicata 'Alba') for the back of the border.

title: SOAPBOX; Why Revaluation Is Not the Answer
description: IN her July 16 Soapbox essay, Catherine Borgia urges countywide revaluation of property. But perhaps what is needed is an honest appraisal of the archaic practice of using the property tax to raise local revenue.

title: TESTING OF NEWBORNS
description: An advisory committee has finished hearings on expanding the tests given to newborns in the state, and expects to make recommendations to the state Department of Health and Human Services by this fall. Currently, newborns in New Jersey are tested for four disorders, which, if picked up early enough, can be treated, preventing brain and organ damage. New tests and equipment are now available to test for additional disorders. Karen DeMasters

title: Porch of Memory
description: To the Editor: I am nearing 85, and in the 45 years since I lodged at Lake O'Hara (''Yoho Trails Have Little Traffic,'' July 16), I have never met anyone who knew of the place. I am delighted to learn that it still exists and is not yet approached by a superhighway or defiled by electronic clutter.

title: August 13-19; It's Melting
description: An ice-free patch of ocean about a mile wide has opened at the very top of the world, a sight that has presumably never before been seen by human beings and is more evidence that global warming may be real. The last time scientists can be certain the pole was awash in water was more than 50 million years ago. ''It was totally unexpected,'' Dr. James J. McCarthy, an oceanographer and director of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University, said after lecturing aboard a tourist cruise on a Russian icebreaker earlier this month. He said that six years ago, the ice near the North Pole was six to nine feet thick. John Noble Wilford

title: The Populist Al Gore
description: Does a populist appeal have resonance in prosperous times? In his acceptance speech at the Democratic convention, Al Gore defined the difference between Republicans and Democrats in strict populist terms. ''They're for the powerful, we're for the people,'' he declared.

title: August 13-19; The Concorde Is Grounded
description: Following last month's fatal crash near Paris, Britain and France formally grounded the Concorde after investigators determined that a problem with its tires made the world's only commercial supersonic airliner unsafe. Investigators found that the crash, which killed 113, originated in a tire blowout that caused chunks of rubber to rupture a fuel tank. The Concorde will fly again only when its manufacturers devise safeguards against a repetition, aviation authorities said. Alan Cowell

title: Article 2000082092941659637 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Camping in Alaska: Just Rough Enough
description: I'M uncomfortable around animals that stand taller than I do and can eat me. I don't water-ski and I don't enjoy riding in tiny airplanes that do. I'm wary of icy sidewalks, so the thought of having lunch on a mountain of ice 1,000 feet thick tends to chill my appetite.

title: The Ingratiator
description: I am tiring of attempts to paint candidates as mediocre simply because they may be moderates. As for the ''candidate from 'Pleasantville,''' we've already seen what we get when we elect clever people whose lifelong plan is to hold higher office for its own sake. New York could do a lot worse than electing a ''nice, average guy'' who's ''a little smarter than usual.''

title: Lisa Silins, Andrew Tumpowsky
description: Lisa Lynn Silins, the daughter of Sandra and Edward Silins of Skokie, Ill., is to be married tonight to Andrew Keith Tumpowsky, a son of Audrey and Ira Tumpowsky of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand will officiate at Cafe Brauer in Chicago.

title: U.N. Reform Group Assesses U.S. Candidates
description: Vice President Al Gore would give more unqualified support to the United Nations and be more willing to sign international treaties than his Republican opponent, George W. Bush, an independent United Nations watchdog organization said this week.

title: QUICK BITE/Belmar; Beachfront Barbecue
description: It's not the South or even South Jersey, but a tangy Southern pulled pork or pulled chicken barbecue sandwich can be found at a tiny storefront on Ocean Avenue in Belmar, across the street from the boardwalk. The pork or chicken for the sandwiches is aged for several hours in a barbecue sauce that tastes of smoke. The secret to the sandwiches, and to the tender barbecue ribs, is the touch of vinegar in the Carolina-style sauce, said owner Lou Bottone, who opened Island Wraps, Seafood and BBQ in Belmar and Wanna Eat on the Bradley Beach boardwalk this past spring. He aimed the luncheonette-style stores at beachgoers who want to pop off the sand and find good food at a reasonable price. And a barbecue sandwich or ribs with a side order of waffle fries for a total of $6 is just that. For those not into meat, grilled yellowfin tuna sandwiches or platters and salads are available, as are turkey and roast beef in tortilla wraps, and fried shrimp and shrimp cocktails, and a few desserts. For less than $10, a patron can get more than enough to eat and wash it down with a bottle of water. On weekends, Mr. Bottone also makes beef brisket, which takes about six hours to prepare; it's available in a sandwich or on a platter. KAREN DEMASTERS

title: From a Bland Hayfield to a Burst of Color
description: THERE are parts of Long Island that have gotten lots of publicity lately because of the gigantic waves of cold hard cash that have been pounding the shoreline. The problem is not so much the waves as the enormous stone, wood and brick configurations that they leave behind. Fortunately there are still a few places where you can catch glimpses of the area's rural past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUL, ROBERT
description: SAUL-Robert. On August 17, 2000. loving husband of Nancy, cherished father of Elizabeth and stepfather of Barry Josephson. Devoted brother of Miriam and Mel Krant. Services Sunday 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JEANETTE
description: FRIEDMAN-Jeanette. On August 1, 2000. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Avra and Paul and his wife, Gillian. Cherished grandmother of Loren and Joslyn, Rebecca and David, Sarah and Emily. She gave generously of herself to her husband and family, and lived life with great curiosity, vitality, and joy. A private funeral was held.

title: PARENTAL NOTICE STRUCK DOWN
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court last week struck down the year-old state law requiring parental notice before an unmarried girl under 18 can obtain an abortion. Relying on the State Constitution, the court took a more expansive view of abortion rights than the United States Supreme Court, which has upheld most parental notice statutes. The New Jersey law passed both houses by overwhelming majorities, and Governor Whitman, departing from her generally supportive position on abortion rights, signed it. Laura Mansnerus

title: Where Dancers in Their 80's Turn Into Time Travelers
description: THE SETTING -- Wednesday afternoon in the auditorium of the Selfhelp Benjamin Rosenthal Senior Center, where 25 elderly couples dance with a faraway look in their eyes.

title: The Love Odyssey; Looking for Mr. Right
description: In her new film, ''Whipped,'' the adorable Amanda Peet wins over a harem of suitors. With this fall's sexiest evening wear as added ammunition, she offers seven tips for cruising and choosing -- like a man. .

title: Defibrillators
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article about in-flight heart emergencies ''Defibrillators: Airline Update'' (July 30): Before trying to send EKG's via satellite using seat-back phones, I suggest that the industry first make sure the phones are working and everyone is clear on how to make a call.

title: Town Sees Pressure By Suffolk On Houses
description: IN the view of Huntington Town officials, the Suffolk County Legislature is engaged in petty politics. But Suffolk lawmakers contend they are only trying to entice the town to address the crucial issue of affordable housing.

title: To Those in Construction, the Most Worthy Tool
description: IT'S easy to get people in the construction trades to laugh. All you have to do is ask them to narrow down the contents of their tool boxes to a single item.

title: Selena Crabbe, David Snow
description: Selena Robin Crabbe, a daughter of Patricia and Robert Crabbe of New Bedford, Mass., was married last evening to David Schwamm Snow, a son of Judith Snow of Darien, Conn., and Robert Snow of Mattituck, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. George Koury, a minister of the Church of Divine Science, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WARMBRUNN, OLGA C.
description: WARMBRUNN-Olga C. Memorial Sunday, August 27, 1 o'clock, Community Room, Kissena II, 137-47 45th Avenue, Flushing, New York

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-18

title: Definitely Dutch
description: To the Editor: Christopher Hall's article ''Unmistakably Dutch'' (July 30), about Leiden, the Netherlands, was quite informative. But here is another bit of the city's history: Leiden was the birthplace of the famous Leyden (Leiden) jar, an early device used to store small amounts of electricity for laboratory experiments. It probably did more to spread the name of Leiden than any other of the city's numerous accomplishments.

title: Elisabeth Gold, Scott Domansky
description: Elisabeth Ancona Gold, the daughter of Lana Walder of Short Hills, N.J., and Stewart Gold of Owings Mills, Md., was married last evening to Scott Philip Domansky, the son of Paula and Martin Domansky of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Marc Schneier officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: For the Guitarist Gil Parris, a Gig at the Sunnyside Jazz Festival
description: GIL PARRIS was trying to relax at home, but every five minutes or so the phone would ring. The word was obviously out that the 30-year-old guitar whiz was back here in town for a few days, so his friends, fellow band members and business associates were calling to say hello or schedule rehearsals and meetings.

title: NEW ROCHELLE: TEUSCHER 'PROVES HERSELF'
description: Cristina Teuscher of New Rochelle was the only Westchester resident to gain an Olympic berth at the weeklong swimming trials, which ended in Indianapolis Wednesday. After finishing third (only the top two make the team) in the 400-meter individual medley by 0.2 seconds, she qualified by winning the 200 individual medley by a whopping 1.6 seconds in 2 minutes and 13.36 seconds, a personal best by almost a second. ''It was important to prove to myself that I could get up after being down,'' said Ms. Teuscher, who could also end up on the 4 by 200 freestyle relay in Sydney. Chuck Slater

title: A Land So Wild, It's Getting Crowded
description: IT was not so long ago that most of Alaska was cloaked in anonymity, and the idea that more than half a million people a year would pay money to visit a waterlogged fishing village or come within smelling distance of a grizzly bear was laughable. Towns that had seen their last mines sealed, their timber mills shuttered and their fishing docks empty huddled against the elements, the people wondering whether one last boom would come their way.

title: Personal Business; Nepal, Borneo and Leg Room, on Thousands a Day
description: EASTER ISLAND. Papua New Guinea. The Galapagos Islands. The itinerary sounds like something Charles Darwin or Margaret Mead might have dreamed up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISINGER, BERNARD
description: WEISINGER-Bernard. On his 91st birthday, August 19, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Bettie (Mayers) Weisinger. Loving father of devoted daughter Suzanne (Dr. Jacques) Debrosse, Andrew (Dolly), and the late Chester (Marsha). Dear grandfather of Melanie, Michael, Joy (Steven), Ira, Bryan (Nancy), Jill (Steven), Jeffrey and Barry. Proud great-grandfather of nine. Will be greatly missed by all. Services Monday, 1 PM, at the Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Wall Street's Fundamentalists Face a New World
description: FAYE I. LANDES had some bad news for investors in Amazon.com.

title: PORT CHESTER: HIGH SCHOOL JOINS ANTI-VIOLENCE PROJECT
description: Port Chester High School is among 11 schools in New York selected for an anti-violence project sponsored by the state's Attorney General's office and the Upstate Center for School Safety in New Paltz. Other schools are in Buffalo, Hempstead, Middletown, Rochester and Syracuse. Each school is expected to have a team of students who will work with a faculty adviser to plan school-based programs to promote tolerance, civil rights and nonviolence and who will take part in a state conference on this issue this fall.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the career paths of former executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert referred incorrectly to the Milken Institute, where Michael R. Milken, former head of Drexel's junk-bond unit in Los Angeles, is chairman. The institute is an economic research organization; it is not involved in charities. The Milken Family Foundation, which had Mr. Milken as a co-founder in 1982, is a private charitable organization that supports education and medical research; Cap Cure, founded by him in 1993, is a public charity that supports prostate cancer research.

title: PROFITS FALL FOR TOY CHAIN
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., based in Paramus, said last week that fiscal second-quarter profit fell 75 percent on declining sales in its United States stores and a loss at its Internet division. Net income in the quarter ended July 29 fell to $3 million, or 1 cent a share, from $12 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier. Sales tumbled 9.5 percent, to $2 billion from $2.2 billion. Toys ''R'' Us, the largest United States toy chain, did not have new toys that matched the success of last year's Furby interactive doll and Star Wars products, resulting in a 2 percent decline in sales at stores open at least a year. The company also was hurt by costs to expand its Internet business. Toys ''R'' Us expects the online unit to break even in the fourth quarter of 2001 and be profitable in 2002. The unit, Toysrus.com, formed a 10-year partnership with Amazon.com last week for a Web site that sells toys, video games and eventually, baby products.

title: Sports of The Times; At 20-Something, Out on Their Own
description: IN the malapropisms of Bela Karolyi there is great wisdom.

title: Poland Spy Inquiry Said to Be a Failed Political Tactic
description: A special Polish court last week cleared the popular president, the former Communist Aleksander Kwasniewski, and a former president, the Solidarity hero Lech Walesa, of charges that they spied for the Communist secret police.

title: Miller on Monday
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Officials Are Sparring Over Ft. Totten Pollution
description: Members of an advisory board investigating pollution at Fort Totten are clashing over the board's operations. It is unclear if the dispute will affect the decision whether to clean up a portion of the fort grounds.

title: Knicks See Opponents Improve, And Again Discuss Ewing Trade
description: During their unsettling summer, the Knicks watched Grant Hill ignore their welcome mat, failed to land free agents like Brian Grant and Danny Fortson and watched their competition get stronger. As a result, an organizational policy shift has taken place, with the team pursuing deals to trade Patrick Ewing, according to an Eastern Conference official.

title: A Disaster Puts Putin in a Bind
description: The Russian submarine disaster in the Barents Sea has been more than a human tragedy. It has also been a test of the true character of President Vladimir Putin and his senior military. Judging just by their arrogant public handling of the crisis in its first days, he and his commanders have again confirmed the worst.

title: A Magical Space to Disappear for Four Years
description: I SPENT some time last week saying goodbye to the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Modern Art, at 11 West 53rd Street. One hot, sticky afternoon, I set my chair near the jets in the rectangular pool, to catch the breeze coming off the water, and to commune with my favorite sculpture there: Maillol's ''River,'' the Olympian-size nude lying by the water's edge, head almost touching its surface.

title: La Rose By Any Other Name
description: Jeffrey Kalinsky, the owner of the Jeffrey stores in Atlanta and New York, may be the Joseph La Rose of his generation. After all, he sold his first pair of shoes in the family shop when he was just 5. And today his stores display footwear as if it were religious statuary. Here, his ''shoes that flip the light fantastic'' for fall 2000.

title: Still a Thrill When B.B. King Comes to Town
description: THE blues guitar legend B.B. King had only two words to explain why his latest single ''Riding With the King'' has become such a hit: ''Eric Clapton.''

title: Julie Strauss-Gabel, David Feldman
description: Julie Ellyn Strauss-Gabel, the daughter of Neila and Ron Gabel of White Plains, was married last evening to David Matthew Feldman, the son of Gloria and Michael Feldman of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Millennium Broadway Hotel in New York.

title: Ideas & Trends; Mosquitoes as Bluebirds of Financial Happiness
description: COMMERCIAL enterprise springs from almost every tragedy, and the West Nile virus is no exception. Some of these ventures, however, seem a bit more dubious than others.

title: Amanda Williams, DeAndre Calhoun
description: Amanda Pedersen Williams and DeAndre William Calhoun were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Luis Leon, an Episcopal priest, at Washington National Cathedral. The Rev. Dr. James Stewart, a Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Risky Business
description: THE LEAP

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Page 27 of Arts & Leisure today by Irina Shostakovich, widow of the Russian composer Dmitri Shostakovich, reflects on his life and reputation 25 years after his death. The writer made the article available through friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, C. PHILIP, M.D.
description: WILSON-C. Philip, M.D. Of Manhattan and Old Lyme, CT, on August 17, 2000 at age 79 of cardiac causes. Pioneer in the psychoanalysis of eating disorders, he is survived by his wife of 49 years, Christine (nee Bagaloff) Wilson, children, Cynthia, Marc and Scott, daughter-in-law, Anne Allan Wilson, grandson, Eric, and brothers, Donald and Stephen. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NY NY on September 9th, 2000 at 11:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Endowment for the Advancement of Psychotherapy, M.G.H. Development Office, 100 Charles River Plaza, Suite 600, Boston, MA 02114.

title: A 'Heritage Corridor' Bends to Preservationists' Wishes
description: It might have been an African-American walk of fame along what many people consider the gateway to Harlem. But a plan to turn 110th Street, bordering Central Park, into a ''heritage corridor'' commemorating famous black Americans has been modified after some preservationists opposed the design.

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; A Hazy Look at Women's and Music's History
description: ELIZABETH fidgets at her husband's funeral. Only with the opening bars of the exit music, selected by the deceased, do emotions register on her face. It's the Boatswain's refrain from ''H.M.S. Pinafore'': ''He is an Englishman! He is an Englishman!'' Her eyes well up.

title: Get Out of Jail Free
description: AT END OF DAY

title: How Yonkers Eliminated A $26 Million Budget Gap
description: AFTER three months of hand wringing and the threat of layoffs because of a $26 million gap in this year's school budget, the Yonkers school system got a reprieve when Gov. George E. Pataki came to town with a $10 million check for the school district.

title: Making Roommates of Perfect Strangers
description: AT Roommate Finders, an apartment referral service, the on-hold telephone tune is the bouncy theme from ''The Odd Couple.''

title: Gays and the Boy Scouts: A Town's Responsibility
description: Re: the struggle by the Huntington and Smithtown school boards over possibly banning Boy Scout troops from using their facilities because the Scouts will not accept gay scoutmasters [''Ruling Clouds Scouts' After-School Access,'' Aug. 6].

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about advice to tourists misstated the population of New York City. It is estimated at 7.5 million, not approaching 9 million.

title: A Bid From Cendant Boosts Avis Shares 20%
description: The price of Avis Group shares (NYSE: AVI) soared last week after Cendant, the international hotel franchiser and Avis's former owner, made a $742 million offer for the company.

title: Stefanie Lieberman, Adam Hellegers
description: Stefanie Elaine Lieberman, the daughter of Dr. Beth Lieberman and Dr. Carl Lieberman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Adam Patrick Hellegers, a son of Louisa and Thomas A. Hellegers III of River Vale, N.J. Rabbi Laurie Katz Braun officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Style; Learning the Ropes
description: There's a very easy litmus test to differentiate the designers who are on a lifelong odyssey* of aesthetic-altering proportions and the designers who are just churning out shmattes. Here's what you do: Head over to Bergdorf Goodman, or Saks, or any store that carries the widest selection of designers you're curious about. Pick one designer outfit from each rack. Better yet (we don't want any cheating), have a sales clerk or a friend pick for you. Then heap them all in a ''Farenheit 451''-style pile in the center of the floor. Now, try to pick out each designer's work. No looking at labels. And no using cell phones for a lifeline. Not easy, is it? I'd suggest that history has left us with maybe 40 designers whose work, no matter what the season, is instantly recognizable. Some of those designers -- like Gianfranco Ferre or Norma Kamali or Geoffrey Beene -- are out of favor with trendy fashion, though the strength of their signatures is undeniable. As the Pegasuses and LVMH's and YSL-Gucci's acquire and desire labels, I would counsel them to hesitate before backing any name that can't pass the style pile test. Of course, the nine designers included here pass with flying colors. -AMY M. SPINDLER

title: Recording the Highlights of Life Stories
description: MOLLYSUE WEDDING loves listening to people talk, so it was logical for her to start a business like Tall Tales, recording and producing people's stories.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Internet Company to Open A Cybercenter in Yonkers
description: A bulletin issued Aug. 9 said Mayor John D. Spencer was set to announce ''the biggest investment in Yonkers since the turn of the century.'' This week, the news emerged that Qwest Communications International has leased the old Saks Fifth Avenue distribution center, at 555 Tuckahoe Road, and will spend $100 million to set up the center.

title: August 13-19; Because the Hut Was There
description: The United States Forest Service drew some derision last year when it told the Appalachian Mountain Club to make sure a hut the group was rebuilding in New Hampshire's White Mountains was wheelchair accessible according to federal rules. The Galehead hut is perched 2,000 feet up a boulder-strewn trail, doubters pointed out; a wheelchair would never make it.

title: MORRISTOWN
description: The 108-year-old First Baptist Church of Morristown, which was destroyed by arson in May, will be rebuilt in its original Victorian style rather than being replaced by a modern structure. The 115-member congregation voted last week to retain the style. No arrests have been made in the case. Karen DeMasters

title: INVESTING WITH: Dean E. McQuiddy; AmSouth Small Cap Fund
description: IN 1983, fresh from the University of Florida with a finance degree, Dean E. McQuiddy went to work for Barnett Banks, then the state's largest bank, as an analyst recommending stocks to portfolio managers. Soon, he helped create Barnett's Emerald Small Cap fund, and in 1994 took over management of the portfolio, consistently outperforming the benchmark Russell 2000 growth index through the end of 1997.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 20, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Solving Problems
description: AN INVISIBLE SIGN OF MY OWN

title: The Ingratiator
description: Regarding your title for the article on Rick Lazio: I look forward to reading an article on Hillary Clinton called ''The Prevaricator.''

title: The Champs Go Marching In
description: The 128-member Cadets of Bergen County Drum and Bugle Corps marched onto the field in College Park, Md., last weekend as one of the top 12 corps in the world and marched off as world champions.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00: Phenomenon; Gospel for Dummies
description: In a squat brick auditorium at Olivet Nazarene University earlier this month, Pamela Spivey -- a woman with bright pink curlers in her hair who speaks with a heavy Alabama drawl -- was getting meta with a dummy. ''It's like, Who's pulling our strings, y'all?'' she asked. ''Satan tries to pull our strings just the way we manipulate our little puppets.'' For effect, she gave the puppet, which looks like the head of a 90-year-old woman mounted on the body of a Betsy Wetsy, a tug. Her audience laughed approvingly. ''But in the end, if you give your heart to Christ, he will be in control of your life, because God is the head puppeteer.''

title: Love and Lightning: Messiaen's 'Regards'
description: THIS is very much Messiaen's year -- as most years now tend to be. Barely was there time to draw breath after the Brooklyn Philharmonic's presentation of three scenes from ''St. Francois d'Assise'' than the Lincoln Center Festival offered four big pieces in quick succession. And now comes a thoroughly spectacular recording of his greatest solo piano work, the ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jesus,'' played by Pierre-Laurent Aimard (Teldec 26868-2).

title: The View From the Bridge
description: The Ibar River runs across the high plains of Kosovo and passes slowly under the five bridges of Mitrovica. Here, more than a year after international peacekeepers arrived in the province, the United Nations has turned the narrow, dirty brown meander of the Ibar into a border: south is the Albanian side of town, north, the Serbian. Before the war, Albanians and Serbs lived in neighborhoods scattered on both sides of the river, and citizens were free to move back and forth over the Ibar. But the aftermath of war and a fragile peace have brought a new and segregated reality to the divided city. North of the river, north of Mitrovica, the farms and villages are almost exclusively Serbian, and yet farther north lies Serbia itself; the river is the frontier, and a symbol for both sides of the claims and counterclaims to land and history and belonging. And now, in Mitrovica, the purpose of the bridges spanning the river has been inverted; the tumbles of razor wire and the armed checkpoints and the idling tanks of international peacekeepers are positioned to make sure the Ibar is not crossed.

title: A Small Town Comes Up Big In Baseball
description: When the all-star team from this town on the outskirts of Manchester won the Eastern Regional championship on Thursday night in Bristol, Conn., and a ticket to the Little League World Series, it was hard to tell who was more excited -- the 11- and 12-year-olds who mobbed their pitcher on the mound or the parents in the grandstands.

title: The Titanic Odyssey; Cruise Control
description: North to Alaska with 900 shuffleboard maniacs and one fur-loving supermodel. A voyage of discovery.

title: A Tale of Two Pennies
description: IT'S time for more tales of absurdity from the Garden State. That's right: it's time for another look at some Least Important Moments in 20th-Century New Jersey History.

title: The Designer Odyssey; Town Without Pretty
description: It used to be so glamorous. Yeah, sure, they all complained about how hard they worked, but they seemed to always have time left over to party at Studio and look really good. Reporters visited Halston's showroom in the Olympic Towers and swooned at the celebrity quotient. The fashionable press filled columns with the sybaritic socializing of the models, actors and artists who were flocking to join designers at their Fire Island getaways. Newsweek put Diane von Furstenberg on the cover. Suddenly Seventh Avenue, heretofore seen as nothing more than a knockoff mill -- a shmatte factory -- seemed, well, pretty darn cool.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZYGER, MAYER
description: ZYGER-Mayer, 85, on August 17. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Anne Easton and Pauline and Jimmy Folkoff. Adoring grandfather of Loren, Ali and Erica. Services August 20, 11:15 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to be made to the Holocaust Museum or American Cancer Society.

title: French Cosmetics Company To Open Store at Mall
description: Sephora, the French cosmetics company, is scheduled to open a store at The Westchester Oct. 6, and cosmetics enthusiasts will no longer have to travel to Manhattan for the company's products.

title: Do You Really Call That Sound Music?
description: IN her 1965 review of ''The Sound of Music'' for The New York Herald Tribune, Judith Crist wrote, ''The movie is for the 5-to-7 set and their mommies who think their kids aren't up to the stinging sophistication and biting wit of 'Mary Poppins.' ''

title: Birds, Bugs and Beasts Do Badly at Golf
description: Re: ''Backyard Fun With a Titleist on the Rug'' [Aug. 13].

title: Word for Word/Who Wants to Watch TV?; Around the World, What It Takes To Be a Millionaire
description: BLAME the British. The simple game show they started in September 1998 has replicated like bacteria in warm agar. ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' has turned into a global subculture, with 27 licensed versions being broadcast in 29 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATSINER, FLORENCE
description: PATSINER - Florence. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Ruth and Al Young, Marilyn and Harvey Horowitz, Arthur and Fran Patsiner. Adored grandmother of Larry and Billy Young, Andrew Horowitz, Lisa and Michael Tambor, Daniel and Jenifer Patsiner. Services Sunday, 1 P.M., at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUEL, ROBERT T.
description: SAMUEL-Robert T. Of New York on August 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Leslie Ekenberg Samuel, loving father of Robert Trevor Samuel III and Melissa Dodd Samuel of Boston, MA. Dear brother of Nancy Stoer and David Samuel. Funeral Monday, 11 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, North Broadway, Irvington, New York. Contributions to Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591.

title: The Proustian Odyssey; Just Dessert
description: Daryl Kerrigan, or Daryl K, as her label is known, was dressed for her Proustian journey.

title: Old, New, Middling In Clinton
description: AMARONE

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELLSEY, PETER MICHAEL
description: BELLSEY-Peter Michael 5/14/53-8/20/90 BELLSEY-Ronald Eric 5/21/51-8/17/77 Remembered each day with love

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Her Infinite Variety

title: The Couture Odyssey, Part Two; Meeting My Maker
description: What most young women are left with after seeing ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' is a desire to live in Manhattan and be madcap. It is difficult to say precisely what constitutes a madcap life, except that, as the judge said of pornography, we know it when we see it.

title: Campaign Laugh Track
description: A running tally ranking the most joked-about politicians in late-night network TV monologues: Friday night, Aug. 11, through Thursday night, Aug 17.

title: IN BRIEF; McDonald's Wins a Suit On Southampton Outlet
description: The McDonald's Restaurant Corp. has won a suit in New York State Supreme Court against the Town of Southampton, overturning the town's denial of a permit for the company to build an outlet on 1.5 acres on the north side of Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BEDFORD PARK

title: They Laughed, They Cried, Maybe They Even Meant It
description: The question of the week at the Democratic national convention may have been whether the hopelessly impassive Al Gore could show television viewers a looser, emotional inner self -- that he feels even his own pain, to put it one way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELI
description: COHEN-Eli. Died August 17, Age 88. Retired from the National Committee on Employment of Youth and New York City Board of Education. Survived by his wife, Selma and five children; Katey York, Ellen Lerner, Bob Cohen, Peter and Marc Rosenbaum; and grandchildren Sasha, Nicholas, Timothy, Jessye, Sophia and Samantha. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 22 of The Times Magazine today about the International Festival of Christian Puppetry and Ventriloquism omits a byline. The writer is Jay Kirk.

title: The Speed Odyssey; Auto Erotic
description: Every year, zillionaires career their vintage cars around the boot of Italy to win the prestigious Mille Miglia. But nothing's faster than this season's racy leather sportswear.

title: Who's First
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Reinwald, Paul Dabbar
description: Andrea Estella Reinwald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Reinwald of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Michel Dabbar, a son of Michel E. Dabbar of Coronado, Calif., and the late Pearl Dabbar. The Rev. Thomason L. Newcomb, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Nimble Travel With Pedicabs
description: Peter Meitzler knew he had a fare after making eye contact with two women standing on a corner near the Flatiron Building on a recent Sunday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLANDER, GERTRUD
description: ENGLANDER-Gertrud. On August 16. Longtime ceramics teacher, Crafts Students League of the Y. Cherished mother of Bonnie Dwork and Anna. Loving motherin-law of Kermit Dwork; adored grandmother of John Dwork.

title: The Ingratiator
description: Lazio is a decent, hard-working fellow who has done good things for housing, for the poor and for the elderly. For the first time in my life, I am sending money to an out-of-state campaign. I only wish I were a New York resident so that I could vote for him.

title: Muti Was the Wrong Man for the Philharmonic
description: I WAS relieved not long ago when Riccardo Muti withdrew his candidacy for the conducting job at the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Muti is a very good musician and has a lot of the qualities this peculiar post requires. In his brief visits during the last couple of years, he won the approval of players, and these are a tough, experienced bunch not known for starry eyes.

title: Would New Energy Plant Mean Pollution or Lower Rates?
description: A proposal by a Swiss and Swedish company to give the Bronx its first electrical generating plant is dividing community leaders in the South Bronx. Some fear it may create more pollution without providing benefits for residents, while others, noting that the city's electrical capacity is stretched and that Con Edison's rates are rising, favor a new plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, LILLIAN
description: TAUB-Lillian. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University, its Board and staff, express our deepest sympathy to Melvin Taub, our Chairman Emeritus, and his entire family on the passing of their beloved mother Lillian. May happy memories of their years together sustain them in this time of sorrow. Alan L. Aufzien, Board Chairman Robert Topchik, President Stephen Lecker, Executive VP

title: Kristine Hooks, Stephen Holden
description: Kristine Donna Hooks, the daughter of Carol Hooks of Alexandria, Va., and John Hooks of Burke, Va., was married yesterday to Stephen Bruce Holden, a son of Susan and Stephen Holden III of Rye Brook, N.Y. Robert James Friedman, a retired judge of the City Court of White Plains, officiated at the Northgate at Dockside Harbor, a restaurant in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Kyle Thomes, Richard Love
description: Kyle Judith Thomes, a daughter of Sheila and Russell Thomes of New York, was married yesterday to Richard David Love, a son of Alice and John Love of Stanardsville, Va. Henry Basayne, a minister of the Humanist Society of Friends, officiated at the California Alpine Club on Mount Tamalpais in Mill Valley.

title: Tidy Up
description: Be sure container plants get adequate water: lush foliage may prevent rain from reaching soil and require that you hand-water.

title: He Just Said No to the Drug War
description: On a balmy night in Albuquerque, 80 homeowners shuffle into the cafeteria at Whittier Elementary School, where one wall is covered with a mural that suggests a stage. Standing before this ''stage'' is New Mexico's governor, Gary Johnson, a lithe, boyish figure in a checked blazer and clashing patterned tie. If you saw the sandy-haired, 47-year-old in a crowd, you wouldn't pick him out as a leader. But then he begins. There's no comic introductory patter. He's right into his sermon.

title: An Ice Cream Song Leaves A Bitter Taste in Some Ears
description: To some, the tinkling bell evokes childhood memories of cool, creamy treats on dusky summer evenings. To others, it is a menace, a repetitive electronic jangle that tests the sanity of city dwellers.

title: Orpheus, Rising From Caricature
description: IN 1956, Vinicius de Moraes's play ''Orfeu da Conceicao'' opened here, and the enthusiastic audiences that filled every theater in the country in which the play was staged reflected perfectly the significance and implications of the event. At that moment, de Moraes and Antonio Carlos Jobim were coming together in a first, decisive step toward bringing about the quiet revolution in samba that became known as bossa nova; for the first time in Brazil, a stage play had an all-black cast; and the play itself, by transposing to Rio's slums at Carnival time the Orpheus myth of a musician who loses his great love, was a defining moment in the very Brazilian project of making samba the medium of choice for expressing national identity.

title: An Impassioned Protest and Its Aftermath
description: WHEN Judge Edmund Fitzgerald of Yonkers City Court found two Yonkers civil rights advocates guilty of disorderly conduct on Aug. 10 and sentenced them to 90 hours of community service, Jamila Crawford wept in the courthouse hallway.

title: No Complications in McCain Cancer Surgery
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona sailed through five and a half hours of surgery for two malignant melanomas today without complications and with no immediate indication that the cancer had spread, his doctors said.

title: Gays and the Boy Scouts: A Town's Responsibility
description: The Scouts' ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy does not lead to witch-hunts to ferret out presumed homosexuals. It is only when an individual flaunts his homosexuality that the Scouts see a need to insulate impressionable youngsters from such role models.

title: U.S. Plans Tighter Rules On Medical Files' Privacy
description: After nine months of blistering criticism from doctors, patients and consumer groups, the Clinton administration says it has decided to beef up protections for the privacy of medical records, beyond what it proposed last year.

title: If at First You Don't Succeed, Celebrate!
description: HERE is a concept for a reality TV show that is sure to knock 'em dead: ''Who Wants to Be a Failure?''

title: OUTDOORS; Fly-Fishing Guide Goes Hollywood
description: The phone call came unexpectedly; he said that he was Aidan Quinn and that he wanted to book a day of guide/instruction as a birthday present for a friend and left it at that. We figured out a time block last August. I penciled it in on the calendar and when the window narrowed down, it was agreed he would call me back. Of course, I mentioned it to friends who immediately bandied about the names of possible candidates for Quinn's fly-fishing mystery man. The women and their much-vaunted intuition finally parsed it down to Brad Pitt.

title: Leah Clapman, Richard Fisher
description: Leah Meredith Clapman, a daughter of Barbara J. Clapman and Peter C. Clapman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Richard David Fisher, a son of Maree and Jaro P. Fisher of Washington. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at Crabtree's Kittle House, an inn in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Manholes of the Millennium
description: THERE isn't any construction going on at the New York Hall of Science, but you might be fooled into thinking so, given the bulky tool cart and orange flags roping off the Great Hall lobby. It's the Con Edison Millennium Manhole Cover Exhibition, through Sept. 3.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: LONG REMEMBER, by MacKinlay Kantor. (Forge/Tom Doherty, $14.95.) In this Civil War novel, Kantor (at right) tells the story of a man who tries to live as a pacifist in, of all places, Gettysburg, Pa., but is inexorably drawn into the fighting. This is ''a very fine book,'' Peter Monro Jack wrote here in 1934, ''a novel that tastes and smells of war.'' The war's Washington front is examined in ABRAHAM LINCOLN: A Press Portrait, edited by Herbert Mitgang (Fordham University, $19.95). The anthology, with a new introduction, draws on more than 100 newspapers and periodicals from the United States and Europe. Lincoln was a devoted reader of newspapers at a time when they had little pretense of objectivity. The passages ''illuminate as only contemporary writings can,'' Gerald Carson said in these pages in 1971.

title: The Long Shadow of Science Past; Long Island Labs, on the Defensive, Struggle for Community Confidence
description: Long Island has long had a deeply uneasy and sometimes bizarrely suspicious relationship with the scientific enterprises that have taken root on its shores.

title: Samantha Atkins, Kenneth Ahdoot
description: Dr. Samantha Weslee Atkins, the daughter of Linda Keep Atkins and Dr. Jerry Atkins of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth Michael Ahdoot, a son of Deborah Ahdoot of Port Republic, Md., and Dr. Habib Ahdoot of Alexandria, Va. Rabbi Bonnie Cohen officiated at the home of the bride's family in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: When Applause Isn't Welcome
description: BOB DYLAN wrote the words, but the music was a classical cycle in the purest sense: seven songs in one dramatic arc, performed by the soprano Sylvia McNair on the stage of Carnegie Hall.

title: Experience Captures Women's Bridge Title
description: One major title was won here Friday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but another remained to be decided.

title: Breathing Life, Posthumously, Into Japan's Art Scene
description: ON the Japanese art scene, as in real estate, finance and employment, the baburu (economic bubble) burst long ago. Today, the friends and contacts a Western visitor encounters here are sure to recollect, with incredulity and undisguised embarrassment, the heady days of the 1980's, when Japanese corporations spent tens of millions of dollars on Impressionist paintings at overseas auctions, and when new museums, public and private, seemed to pop up every month.

title: Finance, by an Ex-Punk Rocker
description: ONE thing you learn quickly about Ken Kurson, who as founder and editor of Green magazine has become the financial mentor for the Limp Bizkit set: he does not have an ounce of pretension. He is slightly rumpled, chronically bemused. During a conversation, a mischievous glint leaps out of his eye. He always looks ready to hop on his Vespa motorcycle to take a friend on his ''Sopranos'' tour of New Jersey. And that's precisely the point.

title: Lyme Sufferers Are Hoping A New Treatment Is Answer
description: A SMALL tube dangles from Lynn Tewksbury's arm, then disappears under the skin and snakes through a vein straight to her heart. Each night she hooks up the tube to a plastic pouch filled with antibiotics or a placebo -- she knows not which -- and sits down to watch television in her Islip Terrace home.

title: Taking Daughters to Work And Giving Mothers a Loan
description: Nell Merlino, the founder of Take Our Daughters to Work Day, came up with another big idea while she was attending a women's conference at the White House in 1997. To Iris Burnett, creator of the ''Erase the Hate'' tolerance campaign for USA Network, Ms. Merlino noted that, in financial terms, women were still being viewed as consumers but not as business owners.

title: Charge for a Safe
description: To the Editor: As I was leaving a Days Inn in Chicago recently, I discovered I had been charged $1 a day for the privilege of having a safe in my room, although I never used it. The desk clerk refused to deduct the charge from my bill. The reservations person at the 800 number referred me back to the hotel and then grudgingly gave me the number for customer service. The customer service person told me that the hotel is independently operated.

title: The Worm Turns Out to Be a Plague, Not Just a Nuisance
description: Three weeks ago, Parks Department officials said they could repair the wooden pilings beneath the Cromwell Recreation Center without closing down the building. Now they are not so sure.

title: All Aboard At Saratoga
description: The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., celebrated its 50th anniversary at its annual benefit on Aug. 11. A highlight was the exhibition of race paintings by the great British equestrian artist Sir Alfred Munnings (1878-1959). Even if the tradition of private horse-owning and breeding families is giving way to syndicates, the glamour of Saratoga lingers, with Marylou Whitney and Mollie Wilmot assiduously fanning the flames.

title: A Rescue Too Far
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jacquelyn Williams, Henry Florsheim
description: Jacquelyn Laney Williams and Henry Irvin Florsheim are to be married today by Rabbi Alan Block at their home in Brooklyn. The Rev. Lewis Marshall, an Episcopal priest, is to participate in the ceremony.

title: Our Towns; A Field Trip, a Teenager's Death and Questions of Responsibility
description: THERE is no question that Rob Pace did something reckless. A college-bound honor society student with an arrest for marijuana possession in his recent past, Mr. Pace, 18, went on a class trip to Great Adventure amusement park in April carrying drugs in his backpack.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. This photo shoot had more problems than the Mille Miglia has miles (you do the math). The annual vintage-car race begins and ends in Brescia, which is where the actress Kate Hudson (Goldie Hawn's daughter) was supposed to meet the crew. She never showed, leaving a lot of amazing designer clothes with no one to wear them. The model Nina Heimlich was imported from London to fill in. Problem solved? Not quite. The Aston Martin that had been promised wasn't available, as it was in the race. Its stand-in, a silver Porsche 550 Spyder (the James Dean model) from the Porsche museum in Stuttgart, Germany, was unceremoniously reclaimed and then returned to our team after heated negotiations. Another car that we were expecting broke down. A gull-wing Mercedes-Benz 300 SL was ultimately located, but the truck transporting it became lost, and it arrived four hours late. The shoot was then interrupted by pouring rain. When the photographer finally took his last shot, the Porsche unhooked from the camera truck and rolled downhill toward the Mercedes. The model in the driver's seat didn't know how to hit the emergency brake. Crew members sprinted to the Porsche and stopped it inches from the bumper of the Mercedes. Maybe Kate Hudson is clairvoyant.2. In 1926, two scions of Brescia nobility raced the train to Milan in their sports cars and decided to make a sport of it. They teamed up with a local auto enthusiast and a journalist and produced the first Mille Miglia on March 26, 1927. The race, on unpaved roads, was won by Nando Minoja in an O.M. (''officine meccaniche'') 665 Superba in 21 hours 4 minutes 48.2 seconds, at an average speed of 48 miles per hour.

title: Collaborating on an 'Eroica'
description: Beethoven composed the first ''Eroica.'' The Middle Mosel and Washington State collaborated on the second.

title: Ideas & Trends; Why Foresters Prefer to Fight Fire With Fire
description: NINETY years ago today, in the choking heat of a summer without rain in the northern Rockies, the sun disappeared from the sky and a sound not unlike cannon fire began rattling throughout Montana and Idaho. The Big Burn, as the three-million-acre firestorm of 1910 was called, eventually consumed entire towns, killed 87 people and burned a lesson into the fledgling United States Forest Service.

title: Pro Greed vs. Pro Bono
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, JUDGE DAVID N.
description: EDELSTEIN-Judge David N. United States Judge, S.D.N.Y. Beloved husband of Florence (Koch), and proud father of Jeffrey and Jonathan. David loved his family, his friends, his country and the law. Services: Park Avenue Synagogue, Monday, 11:30AM, 87th St. and Madison Ave.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Nation: The Wave; The Conventions Are Over. The Party's Just Starting.
description: FOR all the talk about the great race to the center this year, nobody who watched the two conventions, skimmed the parties' platforms or scrutinized the candidates' stands would mistake the Democrat for the Republican.

title: August 13-19; New Hope for Nerve Disease
description: Bone marrow cells that would normally turn into tendon, cartilage, bone, muscle and fat can also turn into nerve cells, scientists report. All that is needed is to add a simple mixture of chemicals to a broth that nourishes the marrow cells in the laboratory. While cautioning that the work is in its earliest stages, researchers say it may eventually offer a new source of nerve cells to treat spinal cord injuries or diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Gina Kolata

title: A Scene Stealer's Big Score
description: FAMKE JANSSEN -- like a roller coaster, tall and steeply curved -- is having herself a thrill ride of a summer. As Jean Grey, the telepathic, telekinetic protegee of Professor X, Ms. Janssen was part of the team that not only arrested the vengeful Magneto's quest for world domination in ''X-Men'' but had also raked in a superheroic $144 million at the box office in five weeks of release. Now, opening on Friday, comes Valerie Breiman's romantic comedy ''Love and Sex,'' a crowd pleaser at last winter's Sundance Festival.

title: The Couture Odyssey, Part One; Hey, Look Me Over
description: ''Let me tell you a story,'' the designer Emanuel Ungaro said the night I went to see him. It was the beginning of summer, and half of Paris was in a hurry to get out of town for the weekend. Ungaro wasn't going anywhere. He had come home from work and gone straight to bed with a cold. When he finally entered the room where I was waiting, his face looked as puffy as a French roll. His voice was warm. ''It's a true story,'' he said. ''A woman who is a client orders a dress, and when she wears it, her husband says, 'Your dress is so chic, but you look so bad in it.'''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, DONALD K.
description: SINGER-Donald K. On August 18, 2000. Survived by his wife of 50 years, Dottie, children Douglas and Diana Singer, Mary Ann and Charles Beier, William and Karen Singer, grandchildren Michael and Katie Singer. Executive at Bergdorf Goodman's and Bloomingdale's fur departments. Volunteered at Pleasantville Cottage. Received prestigious Volunteer of the Year Award for Westchester County. Member of Westchester and NYC Orchid Societies. Funeral services Sunday, August 20, 3 PM, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers to Leukemia Society of America.

title: Religion and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Imprisoning the Wrong Man
description: Kerry Sanders, a man with a history of mental health problems, served more than two years in a New York State prison because he shares a last name and a birth date with a violent criminal. Despite repeated protests from Kerry Sanders that he was not Robert Sanders, the escaped convict whom police were really after, no one at any stage of the criminal justice system took even the minimal steps needed to learn that the wrong man was in prison. Now the New York State Department of Correctional Services is refusing to own up to the negligence of its actions.

title: Better Living Through Science
description: Sometimes it seems that no one is content to leave any tiny part of the world the way Mother Nature made it -- not when there's a profit to be turned, at any rate.

title: Likely Stories
description: WATCH YOUR MOUTH By Daniel Handler. 232 pp. New York: Thomas Dunne Books/ St. Martin's Press. $23.95.

title: Sauces Made of Vegetables Add Crowning Touch to Pasta
description: IN the summer there are certain pasta dishes I like to serve over and over again and I don't tire of them. One is spaghetti tossed in a sauce made with lemon juice, olive oil and Parmesan, mixed so that it forms an emulsion. But it has no cream, and at the end, lemon peel and basil are stirred in. It's rich but not heavy, and friends constantly ask me for the recipe, which is based on one I came across in ''The River Cafe Cookbook'' by Ruth Rogers and Rose Gray (Random House).

title: Juliet Sorensen, Benjamin Jones
description: Juliet Suzanne Sorensen, the daughter of Gillian Martin Sorensen and Theodore C. Sorensen of New York, was married yesterday to Benjamin Felt Jones, a son of Barbara W. Jones of Falmouth, Mass., and the late Michael E. Jones. The Rev. Dr. Forrest Church, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bride's parents in Pound Ridge, N.Y

title: The Past Odyssey; Cherry Bombs
description: Viva Las Vegas is the largest ''rockabilly weekend'' in the world. This year, more than 3,500 of the faithful converged at the Gold Coast Hotel (off, off the Vegas strip) to live out their 1950's fantasies. For them, rockabilly is not just a lifestyle but also a religion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, BENJAMIN
description: FINE-Benjamin. Beloved father of Donald and Sheila Oxman; cherished grandfather and greatgrandfather. Dear brother of Ruth Levin. Services Monday 12 noon, Levayah-Garlick Funeral Home, Yonkers, NY.

title: In Kansas City Area, Up to Date Is Down to Earth
description: THIS suburb in the bistate Kansas City metropolitan area prides itself in being on the cutting edge when it comes to attracting growth-oriented business and industry to its modern corporate parks -- a philosophy that might seem to rule out much interest in a declining limestone mine.

title: 14 Years After Attack, An Attacker Is Set Free
description: In December 1986, three black men leaving a pizza parlor in predominantly white Howard Beach, Queens, were attacked by a pack of white teenagers screaming racial epithets and wielding a baseball bat. One victim was severely beaten, another outran his pursuers and the third was struck and killed by a passing car when he was chased onto the Belt Parkway.

title: Ford Chose Tires Now Being Recalled to Reduce Risk of Rollovers, Document Shows
description: An internal Ford Motor Company document obtained by lawyers suing the automaker and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. shows that the company considered using tires with higher pressure than the Firestone tires now subject to a recall, but decided against them because they increased the risk that Explorer sport utility vehicles using them would tip over.

title: Is It a House or a Synagogue?; And Other Questions That Have Jewish Tempers Flaring in the Five Towns
description: ALMOST any non-Orthodox Jew in the Five Towns can tell you about the boycott threats that their Orthodox brethren have made to shopkeepers who dare to open on the Sabbath.

title: Where Age 40 Doesn't Mean the End of Everything
description: IN recent years, Americans have become more accepting of older dancers. Whether this attitude is a result of aging baby-boomers or has been imposed by political correctness, it is expanding the concept of dancing. The United States now has several organizations that present performances by older dancers, Dancers Over 40 -- the traditional retirement age -- and the 40Up Project among them, or mingle the generations onstage, as does Liz Lerman's Dance Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, MARTIN GAY
description: PIERCE-Martin Gay. While mountain climbing in India. Of Atlanta, GA. Husband of Margaret; father of Curtis, Katharine, and Evelina; brother of Elizabeth Fuchs and Josiah. Grandfather of Clayton Pierce. Also survived by his parents, William Curtis and Elizabeth Pierce.

title: Kerry Abrams, Neil Glass
description: Kerry Abrams, a daughter of Linda and Archie Abrams of Lake Success, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Neil Scott Glass, the son of Zelda and Robert Glass of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg officiated at the Swan Club in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: For Many Immigrants, a Health Care System Underground
description: When investigators last week shuttered a large, unlicensed medical clinic in Flushing that they said offered Chinese and Western remedies, they provided a glance behind a curtain that shrouds an expansive underground health care system serving hundreds of thousands of the city's immigrants.

title: Clinton Maintains a Low Profile On His Adirondacks' Vacation
description: CNN has a correspondent and crew in place, just in case news breaks out in the woods. The other networks are following along as well, betting on the proposition that President Clinton, even while on vacation, will not be able to resist a camera and boom mike in his face.

title: Disc Graphics Net Falls Despite Rise in Revenues
description: Disc Graphics Inc. of Hauppauge (Nasdaq: DSGR), a specialty printing company, reported losses for the second quarter of $1.3 million, or 23 cents a share. For the first six months, losses were $1.8 million, or 33 cents a share.

title: In the Great Outdoors, in a Wheelchair
description: To the Editor:

title: Copenhagen
description: Amid its human-scale skyline, century-old cafes, pedestrian streets and lush gardens, Copenhagen still finds room for contradictions. That's to be expected from a city that nurtured both Hans Christian Andersen and Soren Kierkegaard.

title: All 118 on Sub Probably Dead, Russians Assert
description: The Russian Navy said on Saturday that all 118 members of the crew of the wrecked nuclear-powered submarine Kursk were now probably dead and that in the frantic initial hours trapped in the sunken vessel, survivors had signaled their comrades on the surface to send down air because their sealed compartments were filling with water.

title: Nixonian Machismo
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacey Reiss, Ross Intelisano
description: Stacey Reiss and Ross Bryan Intelisano were married yesterday at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass., by Justice Jeremy S. Weinstein of New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Steps to Install Molding and Trim
description: INSTALLING molding and trim around doors and windows and at the top and base of the walls is called finish carpentry. The pieces must be cut accurately and fitted together so they are aligned properly without noticeable gaps.

title: Builders Have Themselves To Blame for Court Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Demarest Quinn, Tate Isenstadt
description: Demarest Lloyd Quinn and Tate Davis Isenstadt were married yesterday on Cape Cod. Msgr. William A. Genuario performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville, Mass.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE DARK HOUSE

title: Definitely Dutch
description: To the Editor: Like Christopher Hall, I was drawn to Leiden but for very different reasons: as an English teacher I wanted to see the town that Jonathan Swift cited as the city where Gulliver got his education in physick.

title: The Continuing Battles Inside and Outside the Lines
description: Rivellino Jones of the misspelled name was refereeing a soccer game in Manhattan last week, a moral victory for Coach Marty Jacobson. Perhaps those other embattled friends of thelipsite@aol.com, Linda Bensel-Meyers and Billy Bean, could take heart from Jake, although hang in there is almost always the hardest advice to follow.

title: Self-Motivation Now Key for Liberty
description: Teresa Weatherspoon will watch videotapes of tigers today to tap her ferocity. Tari Phillips will watch game videos of her own mistakes to make her angry.

title: Gems Within '99 Bordeaux
description: Man proposes and Mother Nature disposes, so buying wine, in bottles or futures, is always a gamble. But the globalization of up-to-date vineyard and cellar techniques, with Bordeaux on the cutting edge, has so reduced risk that longstanding skepticism about the guidepost value of vintage charts has ratched up even higher.

title: Hamptons Restaurant With Split Personality
description: THE Independent is the Jekyll and Hyde of Hamptons restaurants. This split-personality spot opened in 1998 at 2468 Main Street in Bridgehampton (631-537-5110) and drew an instant yawn from restaurant critics who dismissed it as a yuppie meat market, where 20- and 30-somethings met and mingled, rather than a serious eating place. Three years later, it is still trying to walk both paths -- simultaneously catering to patrons of all ages at dinner time and posting a guard out front who keeps the hip youngsters in line and orderly as they wait to enter this often-crowded hot spot later in the evening.

title: American Hero
description: GRANT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTDEGEN, JOSEPH F.
description: HARTDEGEN-Joseph F. On August 17, 2000. Beloved Husband of Catherine (nee Kane), Loving Brother of William J. and Frank J.; Devoted Uncle of Elizabeth Vran kovich, Paul, Kathryn, and Kristin Schoen. Funeral Monday 8:45 AM from The Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:45 AM at St. Thomas Aquinas RC Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTEIN, RUTH
description: BLUESTEIN-Ruth. Loving wife of Bernard. Cherished mother of Sheila and Barry. Adored grandmother of Mitch, Brod, Nicole and Jodi. Devoted sister of Mil Tuffield and Herb Saltzman. Funeral services Sunday, August 20, 1 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Spanish Fare With a Mediterranean Accent
description: JUDGING by recent restaurant openings in the state, 2000 may be morphing into a year of celebrating Spanish cuisine. The newest arrival is Mecca in Norwalk. While the name evokes Arabia, most of Mecca's dishes are Spanish with a Mediterranean accent. The Ecuador ean owner and chef, Jaime Lopez, was formerly a chef at Meson Galicia (just around the corner) and at the Mediterranean Grill in Wilton. Several dishes on the short menu, in fact, seem borrowed from the Me son/Med Grill repertory.

title: A Newcomer Takes a Bow on Fire Island
description: THERE are many places to eat on Fire Island, but only a few at which to dine. The Bay Leaf in Cherry Grove, a newcomer this summer, is one of them.

title: STOCKTON TUITION REBATE
description: Richard Stockton College of New Jersey, which already has the lowest tuition of any of New Jersey's public colleges and universities, will give students a $2-per-credit rebate for the spring semester. The board of trustees fulfilled a promise that if the State Legislature gave the college a $1 million grant toward operating expenses, the school would return some of the money to the students. The board voted last week to lower the per-credit cost for the spring semester from $112 to $110, making tuition $3,343 for a semester. Karen DeMasters

title: Colombia Pledges to Investigate Killing of 6 Children by Troops
description: In a test of its commitment to improving its human rights record, the Colombian government has promised a full-scale investigation of an army attack on an elementary school hiking trip that left six children between ages 8 and 10 dead this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKRENT, ODETTE
description: OKRENT-Odette, age 97. Born in Paris, France. Educated at the Lycee Jules Ferry, Bachelor's degree in Philosophy. Beloved mother of Jacqueline Goldman, mother-in-law for 37 years of Nathan Goldman, both of Palm Beach, New York & Paris. Grandmother to Philip Engelhardt (Helen) of Menlo Park, CA and Michael Engelhardt (Myriam) of West Palm Beach, FL. Great-grandmother to Philip and Helen's children, Daniel, Bennet, Nicole and Lea; and Michael and Myriam's children, Alexis and Vanessa. Her kindness, gentleness and lifelong devotion to philanthropy set an example for the many generations of her family. She will continue to enrich their lives with the cherished memories she left in their hearts. A private burial service was held in New York on August 16th. In lieu of flowers to honor Odette, donations may be made to Magen David Adom, 277 Royal Poinciana Way, PMB 215, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

title: Fuzzy Little Test Tubes
description: Rarely have I so enjoyed an article on so gruesome a topic. Lawrence Osborne (July 30) provided facts along with personal insights and humor while presenting a moral dilemma. Catherine Chalmers's photographs made an eloquent statement, too. The article went right to my heart, though I have no answers.

title: Neil Young On a Good Day
description: Dan Winters's picture of Neil Young (now framed and on the wall over my desk) caught my eye, and your article was every bit as interesting as the picture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSSE, JANET COWAN
description: BOSSE-Janet Cowan, 70. Died at her home in New York City, on Sunday, July 23, 2000. Born in Detroit to Grace Avery and Glen P. Cowan. She grew up in Cleveland. After dancing professionally, she matriculated to Sarah Lawrence College, where she began a lifelong devotion to fine arts. Between 1965 and 2000, her art work was displayed at more than 70 exhibitions in the United States. She was a founding member and past president of Noho Gallery in NYC. She is survived by her brother, David A. Cowan of Ohio; and nieces and nephews. A memorial celebration will be held at Noho Gallery on August 27. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Healthcare Chaplaincy.

title: How Far From the Tree?
description: GENES, PEOPLES,

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00; The Fires This Time
description: It is still true that everybody talks about the weather without doing anything about it, but these days it's more than just talk at the general store. The buzz is not about the cold spell we happen to be having but about ''weird weather,'' the kind that might pose a threat to the planet, not to mention the way we live our lives. Open the Bible to Revelation and place it next to the Weather Channel's Web site: you will find some striking similarities. The torrential rains pelting the South may not come mixed with blood and fire -- how would you like to see those icons on the evening news weather map? -- but the worst wildfires in half a century have scorched more than four million acres of Western forests, 80-mile-an-hour winds just knocked out the power for much of Kansas City, Mo., and, of course, here and there people are being struck by lightning.

title: Brazilian Investors Moving To Stocks From Bonds
description: The long-awaited shift by Brazilian investors to stocks from bonds is finally under way.

title: Steal This Myth: Why We Still Try To Re-Create the Rush of the 60's
description: THE whole world is watching!'' chanted demonstrators outside the First Union Center in Philadelphia during the Republican National Convention this month. Many had not yet been born when that cry first sounded on the streets of Chicago, in 1968, as the police clubbed protesters during the tumultuous Democratic convention. This time the words were unwittingly ironic: most of the world passed up the opportunity to watch on television, whether because the convention itself was designed to be noncontroversial or because today's dissidents have not yet gained the fearsome reputation of their elders. The police had evidently declined the role of on-camera head-bashers. But the scene was yet another tribute to the enduring power of the 60's in the national imagination.

title: The State's New Watchdog Gets Down to Business
description: After being sworn in by a superior court judge who also happened to be his wife, Edward M. Neafsey began his duties last week as the state's first inspector general -- a watchdog assigned to make sure the state bureaucracy operates efficiently and free of corruption.

title: The World; The Hidden Hilarity of Diplomacy
description: At the United Nations, where one person's joke can strike 100 other people from 100 other cultures as incomprehensible, if not offensive, diplomats, ever cautious and circumspect, take refuge in the universal language of the political cartoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, PETER
description: SELIGMAN-Peter. We mourn with profound sorrow the tragic and untimely loss of our beloved Partner, colleague and friend. Peter was a gifted and deeply committed professional whose outstanding skills and brilliant instincts served his clients with unparalleled excellence. Peter's extraordinary generosity and support, uncommon decency and superb sense of humor are irreplaceable. We have lost a wonderful friend and the public relations industry, a shining star. Our deepest condolences go to his adored fiance, Sara Sinek and the entire Seligman family. May his memory serve as a blessing. Dan Klores Associates, Inc.

title: A Dancing Lantern
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime
description: Peter Decker, the Los Angeles police lieutenant and family man who has always been the soul of calm, compassionate humanity in Faye Kellerman's crime novels, blows his stack in STALKER (Morrow, $25) when his daughter, a rookie on the force, privately takes on one of his investigations and nearly gets herself killed. A colleague's assessment of Cindy Decker -- She's young, she's female, she's smart, and she has a big mouth'' -- doesn't begin to describe the career problems of this imprudent rebel, who alienates half the cops in her department and foolishly keeps it a secret when some unknown enemy starts stalking her.

title: EARNED-INCOME CREDIT
description: Governor Whitman signed legislation last week giving low-income families an earned-income tax credit, adding to the federal tax credit they already receive. Effective immediately, the credit will benefit almost 240,000 families with children and an annual income of $20,000 or less a year. When the tax credit is fully implemented by 2003, each family will receive a credit equal to 20 percent of its federal tax credit, up to $800. Angela Starita

title: Planning a City Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime on Metro
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Crime Takes a Vacation (Yours)'' (July 16): We visited Paris during the French Open a couple of months ago. The city was crowded with tourists and the lines were long and tiresome: in short, a paradise for pickpockets.

title: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Second Wind as a Broadcaster
description: FIRST careers are made by chance, second careers by choice. At least that's the way it worked out for Sam Albert, a former I.B.M. executive turned radio broadcaster.

title: Investing; Why Few Funds Are Lining Up To Buy Linux
description: REMEMBER Linus Torvalds? Last year, the Linux operating system he created was going to revolutionize the software industry, do more damage to Microsoft than the Justice Department and make investors rich. This year, Linux stocks have been in a prolonged downward spiral, and Mr. Torvalds has been replaced as a media favorite by Napster's founder, Shawn Fanning, the latest technologist viewed as most likely to wreak havoc on traditional businesses.

title: Robyn Dunn, Andrew Schwarz
description: Robyn Michele Dunn, a daughter of Paula Carr Centers of Lindstrom, Minn., and Stephen M. Dunn of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., was married yesterday to Andrew Allen Schwarz, a son of Patricia and Roy Schwarz of Hyde Park, Vt. The Rev. Wendy Manley, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bridegroom, officiated at the Presidio Chapel in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00: Questions for Luciano Pavarotti; The Tenor and The Tax Man
description: Q: You have just agreed to pay $12 million in back taxes to the Italian government, which claimed that your Monte Carlo residence was merely a tax shelter. Your response has been that people don't understand what it's like to live as you do. What, specifically, don't they understand?

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BIOGRAPHY OF A GERM By Arno Karlen. Pantheon. $22.

title: Ralph Kramden Would Approve, but the Residents Don't
description: Raccoons used to have it easier in Bensonhurst.

title: Chicago Journal; 'The Romance Is Back' Along a Revitalized River
description: The water bikes that glide along the river here invariably attract a good amount of attention. Office workers, people chatting on cell phones, tourists -- they all hang over the side of bridges to stare, take pictures and ask where they, too, can rent the curious contraptions.

title: The World; The Funny, but Fictional, Mullah
description: IN the classic Iranian children's tale, the fictional Mullah Nasreddin rode his donkey facing backwards but arrived at his destination all the same. He delighted in taking advantage of the villagers who, in their turn, poked fun at him. He ate a lot. He paid for nothing. The world, through his myopic and literal eyes, was a puzzlement.

title: Seven Galleries Feature Works by 24 Artists
description: IN its founders' minds, ''Collaborative Concepts'' is an idea, a belief that artists can work together for the good of all.

title: New Michelin Series Heads in All Directions
description: Michelin has come up with a new recipe for a series of guidebooks: to an exotic destination add one part Red (as in the Red Guide listings of recommended hotels and restaurants) and one part Green (descriptions of places of major and minor interest), then fold in a generous helping of practical information and vignettes about the local culture.

title: The Salsa Spiral
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Ballet Company's 50th Year

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, JACK
