description: FINKELSTEIN-Jack. Forever in my heart. Always in my thoughts, as my loving father. Natalie

title: A Ho-Hum Court Race Heats Up As Rival Clubs Become Odd Couple
description: As political races go, this one barely registers on the radar.

title: Laura Whitman, Thomas Danziger
description: Laura Bowne Whitman and Thomas Curtis Danziger were married yesterday. Justice Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Creek Club in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Claire Wolfteich, John Griffin Jr.
description: Dr. Claire Elizabeth Wolfteich and John Frederick Griffin Jr. are to be married today at St. Ignatius of Loyola Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Robert F. VerEecke is to perform the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: The Performers Behind the Costumes
description: AT the New York Renaissance Faire here, there is the Fair Maid Marian joining in a hand-to-hand brawl between the forces of Robin Hood and the Sheriff of Nottingham. A few steps farther into Sterling Forest, the first Queen Elizabeth and her courtiers greet her majesty's 21st-century subjects. Not far off two slightly crazed creatures, Thomas of Bedlam and the Faerie Trapper, show visitors the unpredictable nature of humors in disharmony.

title: The Perfume Odyssey; A Scent-imental Journey
description: This fall I want a new scent. The bright, clean fragrances, so fresh a few years ago, now feel thin, too pure. A new age of decadence has dawned and I want to be part of it. Don't speak to me about a signature scent -- wearing the same perfume my whole life. Let me dance to the music of time. And yet fragrance, more intimate than lingerie, must also express my inner core, awaken forgotten memories, call up a submerged aspect of self. How do I reconcile these apparently conflicting needs?

title: The Radicalization Of James Woolsey
description: My thanks to Andrew Cockburn (July 23) for this chilling account of United States bureaucracy at work. You would not expect someone of James Woolsey's professional stature to encounter the difficulties he did in dealing with the Central Intelligence Agency and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Fortunately, Woolsey is not afraid to say what he thinks.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lexus IS 300 and Acura 3.2 CL -- Who's That Knock, Knock, Knocking on BMW's Door?; A Fast Coupe That Gives Rivals a Run For the Money
description: SPORTY coupes come and go, but BMW's 3-Series reigns supreme, deftly deflecting all challengers to its throne. Now Acura has stepped up, drawn a bull's-eye on the Bimmer and taken aim.

title: GIULIANI APPOINTS JAIL SYSTEM CHIEF TO LEAD THE POLICE
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Correction Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik as New York City's next police commissioner yesterday, turning to a former narcotics detective and familiar member of his administration to command the nation's largest police department.

title: As Is the Daughter, So Is Her Mother
description: The novelist Ann Patchett (Lives, July 23) writes about her mixed feelings as a ''midlist author'' whose mother's first novel turned out to be a near best seller. If Patchett thinks she has it bad, she ought to consider the case of poor Rose Wilder Lane, a journalist and best-selling author of the 1920's. Lane encouraged her 60-something mother to write her autobiography. Nearly 70 years later, the Laura Ingalls Wilder ''Little House'' books continue to enjoy steady sales, and Laura's daughter Rose is better known as a character in her mother's books than for any of her writings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGLIN, THEODORE LEON
description: DEGLIN-Theodore Leon. 92. Of New York City, passed away on August 15, 2000. Mr. Deglin is survived by his wife of 39 years, Ann (Reirden). Twin daughters Kane Peterson of Westport, Ct., Dorian Scammon of Hopkinton, N.H. and six grandchildren. Viewing was at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81 St. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: A Softball Team's Dedication Pays Off
description: IT started a year ago.

title: Doing Justice to Prisons
description: Stun guns and electronic anklets may add a high-tech sheen to corrections work, but its underlying pursuit is an age-old struggle, Thomas McCarthy says.

title: Suffolk College Raising Annual Tuition by $100
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has increased annual tuition at Suffolk Community College by $100, to $2,330. The increase is reflected in the $105 million budget for the college for 2000-2001, which legislators approved earlier in August by a vote of 15 to 2, with one abstention.

title: Walkabout Companions
description: From walkabouts to histories, there are plenty of books for armchair travelers seeking a literary glimpse of life down under. Among the titles currently in paperback are the following:

title: The Defining Odyssey; Outskirts
description: When the designer Gianni Versace was murdered three years ago, all sorts of writers, after the shock, weighed in on whether he had been a great talent. But no one focused on his sense of humor. It was major. And it could be wicked. He especially got a bang out of things when they had to do with some kind of fashion foible. I never saw him laugh as much as when I first told him the tale of my gray corduroy skirt. It was an ash gray, asexual number that was unexceptional in every way, but it turned out to have an enormous influence on the rest of my life.

title: August 13-19; Law Firms Limit Aid to Poor
description: Despite record profits, many of the nation's biggest law firms have cut back on pro bono work so sharply that they now fall far below professional standards for representing people who cannot afford to pay. Flooded with business and pressed to bill more time to pay for rising salaries, lawyers at the top 100 firms now average 36 hours a year on pro bono cases, instead of the 50 hours urged by the American Bar Association. Greg Winter

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 20, 2000
description: Weeks

title: MY FIRST JOB; Golden Lessons Of the Catskills
description: Since 1993, Daniel Rappaport has been chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, a market for trading in crude oil, gasoline, home heating oil, propane, gold, silver, copper and platinum.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the Residential Sales report on Aug. 6, with an entry about a four-bedroom house at 21 Meadow Glen Road in Fort Salonga, N.Y., was published in error. It was a duplicate of one for the Gazetteer chart in the same issue and showed a four-bedroom house at 584 Center Briarwood Avenue in West Islip, N.Y.

title: Installing Molding and Trim at Home
description: INSTALLING molding and trim around doors and windows and at the top and base of the walls is called finish carpentry. The pieces must be cut accurately and fitted together so they are aligned properly without noticeable gaps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTOFF, HARRY
description: BURTOFF-Harry. Age 86, on August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Pearl Burtoff and Pearl Vogel. Loving companion of Blanche Rabinowitz. Devoted father of Eileen, Michele and Elliot. Adored grandfather of Erol, Eren, Robert and Dina. Dear brother of Clara, Jeanne and the late Dottie, Morris, Mae and Faygie. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Woods Stumbles but Manages to Remain in the Lead, Barely
description: The field made its run at Tiger Woods today, and for once, he did not run away.

title: Real-Life Heroines on Romance Classics
description: FASCINATING though they may be, sometimes you just can't bring yourself to watch yet another interview with Madonna (about her New Age), Jennifer Aniston (about her new husband) or even Hillary Clinton (about her New York). For these times, ''Cool Women,'' on the Romance Classics network, could be the antidote to celebrity burnout.

title: Party Time Again in Mount Kisco
description: In Mount Kisco, it seems, there's always a reason to celebrate.

title: The Stendhal Odyssey; Art Attack
description: The first time I was in Florence was more than 20 years ago. All I remember are the serene cloisters of the San Marco Museum and Convent and a lot of gelato. I assume that I went to the Uffizi Gallery, but I have no T-shirts to prove it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about advice to tourists misstated the population of New York City. It is estimated at 7.5 million, not approaching 9 million.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Lost Revolutions The South in the 1950s. By Pete Daniel. University of North Carolina, cloth, $45; paper, $19.95.

title: Hassen Mall, 78, the First Nonwhite Jurist in South Africa
description: South African Judge Hassen Mall, an Indian immigrant who was the country's first nonwhite jurist and a key figure in the nation's searching effort to lay to rest its apartheid past, died Friday. He was 78, his son said.

title: Students Play Scientist At a Real Chemical Lab
description: WITH their safety goggles on, the young men and women looked like the other scientists at the Ciba-Geigy Specialty Chemicals division here, except that jeans and sneakers, instead of khakis and safety shoes, peeked out from beneath their white lab coats.

title: Nathalie Brochu, Archibald Foster III
description: Nathalie Brochu, the daughter of Jose and Pierre Brochu of Quebec City, was married yesterday to Archibald McGhee Foster III, the son of Diana Worth Foster of New York and Mr. Foster Jr. of Wilmington, N.C. Diane Messier, a civil marriage officiant, performed the ceremony at Domaine Cataraqui, a historic house in Sillery, Quebec.

title: A Voice From the Met's First Season
description: HIDDEN in a grove of pines on a finger of land overlooking Lake George in the foothills of the Adirondacks is a shrine to a remarkable woman. Her lovely musical name was Marcella Sembrich, and though virtually forgotten today, this Polish-born soprano was once one of the glories of the operatic stage.

title: Introduction
description: Our cover article on the Republican candidate for senator from New York pushed many pro-Rick Lazio buttons. Readers said they did not regard his ''ingratiating'' nature as a character flaw. And our tale of lab mice and men prompted mail from those on both sides of the animal rights debate.

title: Even a $5-an-Hour Robot Has Attitude
description: AS if man's inhumanity to man were not enough, human treachery has now extended to the realm of machinery at Mount Sinai Medical Center where a small, innocent robot named Lil Jeff is regularly hazed by fellow employees.

title: Streetscapes/The Prasada, at 65th Street and Central Park West; Beaux-Arts, With Turn-of-the-Century Ebullience
description: THE PRASADA, at 65th Street and Central Park West, was built in 1907 as Central Park West was flowering as an apartment-house boulevard. Construction tarps have covered its curious, bare-looking top floor for months, and its expansive lobby was completely renovated last year, marking new chapters in the history of this unusual building.

title: A New Balance in the Battle of the Haves and Have-Nots
description: THE broad stock market indexes have pretty much fizzled this year. So why are many investors smiling?

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: QUEENS

title: Venezuela Finds Source of Wealth Is Also a Curse
description: Like motorists everywhere, Venezuelans love to complain about the price of gasoline, and they have been doing a lot of that lately. But one thing sets them apart from almost everyone else in the world: at less than 40 cents a gallon, gas is cheaper than bottled water here.

title: YONKERS: NO LONGER WATER TITLE HOLDER
description: Yonkers lost its claim to the region's best-tasting water, sharing third place in the annual contest held on the steps of the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. First and second places went to the Dix Hills Water District in Suffolk County and New York City, respectively. The other participants were the village of Maybrook in Orange County and the Bethpage Water District in Nassau County. The judges were about 100 pedestrians who were walking by. ''I really can't say why we didn't win,'' said Mary Anne Wyatt-Dolan, chief chemist for the Yonkers water system. Yonkers won last year and has won six times in the 1990's. One factor may have been the use of surface water, which can take on a grassy or fishy taste in summer from algae growing in reservoirs, she said. Suffolk uses ground water. But that would not explain the loss to New York City, which relies on the same water supply as Yonkers. Robert Worth

title: OPINION; What the 'Free Lunch' Costs
description: THE perennial tax-cutting rant of politicians, shrill at the best of times, becomes a deafening roar in a presidential election year.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SEE a movie based on a Jane Austen novel and you're sure of three things: glorious English scenery, beautiful 19th-century costumes and people speaking in full sentences. Roger Michell's PERSUASION (1995) seems a little less Technicolor than the rest of the bunch made in the 90's, but in many ways it's the most powerful. Amanda Root is heartbreaking as Anne Elliot, who refused a proposal of marriage years ago (because her family disapproved) and is sinking into door spinsterhood. Ciaran Hinds is Captain Frederick Wentworth, the man who proposed. He's back in town, surrounded by giggling young women who consider him a very desirable suitor. It's a Cinderella stroy in many ways, with an abundance of wicked-stepsister surrogates. Sophie Thompson is priceless as Mary Musgrove (''I am so ill I can hardly speak''), one of the most obnoxious - Sunday at 9 p.m. on Channel 13.

title: With Piazza a Spectator, Dodgers' Sheffield Supplies the Power
description: The most fun Mike Piazza ever had in baseball, he said, came last season, when the Mets won a playoff series. Another fun year was 1990, when he hit .250 for a Class A team that won its league title. When he set a single-season home run record for Los Angeles Dodgers in 1997, the year was a bitter disappointment: his team missed the playoffs and traded him the next May.

title: Michelle Russell, Raymond Dowe Jr.
description: Michelle Lyn Russell, the daughter of Linda and Thomas Russell of Northfield, Ill., was married yesterday to Raymond George Dowe Jr., a son of Marilyn and Raymond Dowe of New Hyde Park, N.Y. The Rev. Donald T. Fussner performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Baseball Must Come Clean on Its Darkest Secret
description: It won't be easy, but baseball has to find a way to crack down on steroids, which more and more big-leaguers appear to be using every year and which could threaten to turn the game into a freak show.

title: Dot-Com Wariness Found in Survey
description: The new what? Most Americans have heard of the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq index, but surprisingly few have heard or read about the new economy, according to a recent survey by Scudder Kemper Investments.

title: A Holistic Health Spa for Rover
description: When Jodi Richard, the wife of Dwight Merriman, chief technology officer and co-founder of DoubleClick, was providing swim therapy for Sara Muirhead's arthritic Rottweiler, Berin, last fall, Ms. Richard's vision of building a holistic health center for animals took on a new twist. Ms. Muirhead owns Naturally Raw, a New York producer of animal food that is billed as natural and especially nutritious.

title: Chewed Gum Is His Bread and Butter
description: Neil Matthews is an old pro at helping companies out of sticky situations. Growing up in Bristol, England, he worked for a company that scraped chewing gum off the floor of a disco.

title: The Nation; When a Kiss Isn't Just a Kiss
description: IN Vice President Al Gore's campaign to change his robotic image, nothing may have helped more than the big smooch. Mr. Gore stepped on stage at the Democratic Convention on Thursday and greeted his wife, Tipper, with a quick embrace and a kiss on the lips. But instead of letting go, as nice politicians are supposed to, he wrapped her tighter in his arms, closed his eyes and gave her a full-mouthed kiss that lasted a exceptionally long time. (Actually three seconds; we have tapes; we've counted.)

title: The Fresh Air Fund; It Takes Lumber and Nails To Make a Summer Camp
description: The steady chirping of crickets, the ''caw caw'' of crows and the distant laughter of children rowing boats along a lake are all that can be heard on most days at the Sharpe Reservation in Fishkill, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAULL, JOSEPH
description: PAULL-Joseph. Died August 15, 2000 in Florida. Age 89. Beloved husband of Ann. Father of Arlyne and Mel, Martin and Sue. Adored Grandfather of Madeleine, Charlie, Caryn and Keith, Bari and Alan. Proud great Grandfather of Lizzie and Jonathan. Loved and respected brother, and uncle. Joe was a retired Vice President of the Lamport Co. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to the BNAI ZION Foundation, Inc. 136 E. 39 St, NYC, NY 10016. Funeral today, 11:30 am at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside Bldg), 180 West 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the popularity of women's thong underwear misstated the location of a Kmart store in Queens that sells it. The neighborhood is Fresh Meadows, not Flushing Meadows.

title: Students Get a Taste of Acting's Raw Power
description: ONE night last month in this town in Northern Italy, a small group of American college students entered a whitewashed barn in the middle of a Tuscan field. It was late, about 10:30, and the strong heat of the day had finally dissipated. The students sat on folding chairs in the bare white room, the highly polished wood floor gleaming in the bright light.

title: Francine Hirsch, Mark Hessman
description: Francine Hirsch, the daughter of Lois and Mark Hirsch of Greenridge, Staten Island, is to be married today to Mark Hessman, the son of Erika Hessman and Dr. Lawrence Hessman of Andover, Mass. Rabbi Stephen Stern is to officiate at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEMKER, DOROTHY ROWDEN
description: LOEMKER - Dorothy Rowden. Died in Bridgeport, CT on August 10, 2000 of complications following pneumonia. She was born on February 27, 1901 in Woodsville, NH. A 1921 graduate of Simmons College, the culmination of her long and distinguished professional career was as Assistant Director and Secretary of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation a position she held for 20 years. She is survived by twin children Thomas R. Loemker of Fairfield, CT., and (Mrs. Edward) Elizabeth Furber of Southport, ME, 6 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren.

title: Allyse Weltman, Michael Caplan
description: Dr. Allyse Leigh Weltman and Dr. Michael Stuart Caplan, both medical residents in Washington, are to be married today by Rabbi Lester Polonsky at the Milleridge Cottage, a caterer in Jericho, N.Y.

title: Summer Is No Longer Bargain Air-Fare Season
description: AMERICANS who postponed vacations this summer hoping that airlines would announce major fare sales have had good reason to be disappointed: there haven't been any, at least nothing comparable to those a few years ago. And while most analysts attribute the paucity of summer discounts to continued high demand for flights, they note that the carriers' growing sophistication in knowing when to lower or raise fares on everything from individual flights to entire routes could spell the end to the periodic fire sales of years past.

title: An Acting Family Yields Another
description: JESSE BRADFORD was born into the acting world. ''My Mom was working a lot in commercials and doing voice-overs -- even when she was pregnant -- and the New York casting people were waiting for me to pop out,'' said the 21-year-old Mr. Bradford, whose father is also an actor. His first commercial was done at the age of 8 months for Q-Tips, and he has been in front of a camera ever since.

title: What Are We Going to Put On the Gallery's Walls?; Five Curators of Contemporary Art Make the Case for Their Choices
description: ART might be made in solitude, but its purpose isn't really fulfilled until it is seen by others. Getting one's work shown has always been difficult or a matter of luck: being in the right place at the right time.

title: 4 Charged in Shootout With Police Officer
description: Four men from Pennsylvania involved in a shootout with a New Jersey police officer on Friday were charged yesterday in the case, the police said. Another police officer fatally shot a fifth man.

title: Adopting the Itinerant Life of an Old-Time Tintypist
description: SOME 140 years ago, the job might have gone something like this: Word had come that the Union Army was moving north for a fight, up in Pennsylvania somewhere. You would have loaded up the small wagon with glass or iron plates, chemicals, food -- and your best samples, of course, in case the soldiers wanted to see the quality of your work. You would have set up at the bivouac, near the enlisted men, like all the peddlers, coffin makers, provisioners and hangers-on who move with an army, but you might just have been lucky enough to find space near the officers' tents. You wouldn't have been alone. There might have been a dozen other photographers in camp. But there was work enough for all, taking portraits from dawn till dusk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINGSWORTH, SCHUYLER
description: HOLLINGSWORTH-Schuyler. Of Chestnut Hill, on Tuesday, August 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Anne (Delano Grant) Hollingsworth. Devoted father of Schuyler Hollingsworth, Jr. and his wife Deborah, of San Marino, CA, Frazier Curtis and his wife Jacqui, of Littleton, CO, Amor Hollingsworth and his wife Fatima, of Fullerton, CA, and James Freeman Curtis and his wife Edie of Lincoln, MA. Also survived by a brother Amor Hollingsworth, Jr., his first wife, Pauline Curtis Hollingsworth, seven grandchildren, his three stepchildren, Katherine Marshall, of Washington, DC, Kim Marshall and his wife Rhoda Schneider of Brookline, MA, Laura Marshall, of Boulder, CO, and four step-grandchildren. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend a Memorial Service at Trinity Church (Copley Sq.) on Tuesday, August 22 at 11:00 A.M. Immediately following the Memorial Service, relatives and friends are cordially invited to attend a reception at the Harvard Club, 374 Commonwealth Ave., Boston at approx: 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Harvard College Fund, 124 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138. Burial will be private. J.S. WatermanEastman-Waring Funeral Service, 495 Commonwealth Ave., Boston, MA. 02215, phone (617) 536-4110.

title: The Gardens of Yesteryear Offer Inspiration for Today
description: OLD WETHERSFIELD is a particularly serendipitous setting for an exhibition called ''Lost Gardens of New England and Wethersfield.'' The show can be seen through Sept. 4 at the Wethersfield Museum as well as in a garden across the street, behind the Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum.

title: First on the Scene
description: To the Editor:

title: By Train or by Plane
description: To the Editor:

title: Philippine Leader, Facing Bad Reviews, Is Ready for a Change in His Image
description: ''If they want war, we will give them defeat,'' declared President Joseph Estrada not long ago in the latest version of his tough-guy political credo: ''Don't dare me.''

title: 'Work on the Songs Is Like a Research Into Oneself'
description: During his visit last month to the Workcenter of Jerzy Grotowski and Thomas Richards in Pontedera, Italy, a town on the road between Pisa and Florence, Lawrence Sacharow talked with Mr. Richards about Grotowski's theatrical legacy. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

title: Sister Mary Vincent Taught A Reservist Compassion
description: To the Editor:

title: Embellishing Chekhov
description: To the Editor:

title: Neil Young On a Good Day
description: Steve Erickson's article (July 30) caught the mystery and depth of the singer, songwriter, musician and poet Neil Young, especially his timelessness. His 30-plus years of genius music-making reminded me of what Buddy, Jimi and Janis might have become had they lived.

title: This Year It's Defense That's Worrying Giants
description: For years now, it has become almost routine to blame whatever is going wrong with the Giants on the offense. But in the 2000 season, as promised, these are the new-look Giants.

title: Adar Kaplan, Jacob Novak
description: Adar Naomi Kaplan, a daughter of Leslie Kaplan and Dr. Lawrence W. Kaplan of Old Westbury, N.Y., is to be married today to Jacob George Novak, a son of Melva Novak and Dr. David Novak of Toronto. The bridegroom's father, an ordained rabbi, is to perform the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Diamonds, Sugar, Misery
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurie Harrold, Edward Chu
description: Dr. Laurie Jill Harrold, a hematologist and oncologist, was married yesterday to Dr. Edward Chu, also an oncologist. The Rev. Maureen A. Gilmore-Hebert, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Water's Edge Resort in Westbrook, Conn.

title: In Fashion, They All Scream for Chloe Segivny
description: WHAT is it about the young indie actress Chloe Sevigny that has turned the fashion world into a pack of dogs howling about her as if she were a full moon, or a lamb chop? Is it that she's alternative? Not quite pretty? Is it that she wears vintage prairie dresses one day and Yves Saint Laurent the next and that at the same time she seems to care and not care about it? Could it be the odd dress by Alber Elbaz she wore to a New York City Ballet benefit last spring, or the fact that she pretended not to know who designed it when approached by a supplicating Andre Leon Talley, editor at large of Vogue?

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Leon Vannais and Lee Vannais, Belgrade Lakes, Me., July 1, 2000

title: Guatemala's Missing Children
description: Probably thousands of children disappeared in Guatemala's 36-year civil war, the vast majority taken by the security forces, typically after the army had attacked a Mayan Indian village and massacred many of its inhabitants. While most of the children were probably killed, there is reason to think that many of the younger children were adopted illegally by soldiers or taken to orphanages and later adopted by families in other countries, including the United States.

title: Profits Rise 85% At Reader's Digest
description: Reader's Digest, based in Chappaqua, announced an 85% increase in fourth-quarter operating profits compared with last year and a 54% increase for the fiscal year, ended June 30. In 1999 the company's profits increased 67%.

title: Fashions of The Times
description: A Fall Fashion Epic. Featuring a mythic shoemaker, a journey into the heart of plaid, a Proustian adventure with Daryl K, a reincarnated Peggy Guggenheim, supermodels in sports cars and a trunk sent around the world full of clothes as ravishing as a siren's song.

title: Soaring to the Heights, on a Rubber Band
description: HIS eyes sparkling like a little boy playing with a favorite toy, Bob Bender cranked the gear intently, winding the rubber band running through the fuselage of his homemade airplane tighter and tighter.

title: The Powers Behind the Auctions
description: WHEN people think of online auctions, they probably envision retirees selling bean bags from their basements and collectors trading baseball cards or limited-edition lunch boxes. After all, the founder of eBay, Pierre M. Omidyar, and its chief executive, Meg Whitman, are considered ingenious precisely because they created the first efficient global marketplace where consumers could sell directly to one another.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about new television technology that could profoundly alter viewers' habits misspelled the name of the company at which Tom Rogers, a former president of NBC's cable division, is now chairman. It is Primedia, not Primemedia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, GLORIA M. (NEE FELDMAN)
description: SACHS-Gloria M. (nee Feldman) of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Paul and Evan. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: How to Speak Australian
description: IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY

title: Where 'You Have a Hole in One' Doesn't Mean You Have a Cavity
description: It still surprises Dr. Steven J. Mondre that his dental patients have started arriving for appointments half an hour early and staying half an hour late. With a gleaming grin, he welcomes them to his cozy 16th-floor office at 57th Street and Lexington Avenue, but he knows they are not eager for a $95 teeth cleaning. They want the golf.

title: Automakers Paying The Price of Higher Rates
description: WHEN automakers brought out their 2000 models last fall, executives were jubilant. Their companies were enjoying record sales, and the Federal Reserve's two interest rate increases seemed to be having little effect; the manufacturers simply offset them by subsidizing their discounted auto loans more heavily.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I asked him if I could try it one day at practice. He just looked at me and said: 'Women can't do that.' ''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Drivers at the Short-Time Motel

title: FILM; In His Homeland, Filming War Is Itself a Battle
description: HEMMED in by Kosovo to the north, Greece to the south, Albania to the west and Bulgaria to the east, and lacking any outlet to the sea, Macedonia swelters in the sun, a dust basin. It is late July, a few miles from the Greek border; nothing moves; tobacco crops wilt in the fields. Behind a Byzantine church, men, their shirts caked in blood, are strewn on the bald mountainside. Shots ring out. Orders are shouted in English, Italian, Serbo-Croatian and Macedonian. Milcho Manchevski, the Macedonian director of the acclaimed, Oscar-nominated 1994 film ''Before the Rain,'' is at it again, putting the tortured history of his homeland on the screen.

title: Habitats/Westchester; Home Swap Gives Couple Conveniences of a Village
description: SOMETIMES, if the house you want isn't for sale, you have to entice the people to move by offering something they want even more.

title: My Dad's Cheating With Your Mom
description: THE LOST LEGENDS

title: Carina Yervasi, Leopold Charney
description: Carina Louise Yervasi, an assistant professor of French, and Leopold Joseph Charney, a Web site editor, were married yesterday at the King County Courthouse in Seattle. Judge Eileen A. Kato of the King County District Court officiated.

title: Correction
description: The Correspondent's Report column on Aug. 6, about detecting and disclosing water pollution at beaches in the United States, included an outdated reference to testing in Florida. A state law indeed exists; it was enacted in June to provide comprehensive testing by coastal counties, and participation in the program began on Aug. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, BURTON G.
description: KOENIG-Burton G. 73, of Coconut Creek, FL and Bayonne, NJ. Preceded in death by his beloved wife, Judge Gloria K. Koenig. Dearly loved son of the late Harry A. and Beatrice Koenig. Survived by brothers Marvin and Solomon, nephew George H., nieces Dr. Debra Cantor, Randi Koenig, and dear friend Mollie Starling. Marine Corps veteran of WW II. A courageous, charitable, loving family man. He will be sorely missed. Interment Sunday 1 PM, at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: Ideas & Trends: Chin Music; With Politics at the Plate, Baseball Went Ballistic
description: THIS season has witnessed a record number of hit batters and bench-clearing brawls, but so far nothing to match the most horrifying clash in baseball history. The racial tensions and tumultuous politics of the 1960's intruded on baseball 35 years ago Tuesday with a shock that many fans recall vividly today.

title: INSIDE
description: Tighter Rules on Privacy

title: Puzzlement In a Land Where Rates Seldom Rise
description: PUSHING on a string must get tiring. Or maybe just tiresome.

title: Executives to Teach Course In Communications
description: Executives from companies like Texaco, Citicorp and International Business Machines will teach all the courses in a new master's degree program in management communications offered by Manhattanville College in Purchase.

title: Developers Should Provide Shuttle Bus Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAINIS, BERNARD
description: KRAINIS-Bernard. August 18, in Great Barrington, MA, formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Betty (Szold) Krainis. Father of John R. Krainis of Freeport, ME. Step-father of David H. Lippman, M.D., and Deborah Morris of Great Barrington, and Judith Grant of Chapel Hill, NC. Grandfather of nine. Memorial service Sunday, September 3, at 2 PM, at Family Home, 41 West Plain Rd. Donations to Hospice Care in the Berkshires, 369 South Street, Pittsfield, MA 01201. Co-founder of New York Pro Musica Antiqua.

title: The Late, and the Very Late, Films of Kurosawa
description: TWO years after the death of the great Japanese director Akira Kurosawa at age 88, his memorial has finally kicked into high gear.

title: Summer Whites? Ha!
description: You don't need a calendar to know that Labor Day is near. Black is a tradition with some city dwellers as summer fades. For them, it signals the approach of that mythical autumn in New York, the time for fresh adrenaline, new conquests. ''Who died?'' August tourists used to say when they saw this funereal gear. But last week, many of the map-and-camera set were themselves slipcovered in black.

title: High Rate of Asthma For Hartford Children
description: A screening of Hartford children for asthma shows that 41 percent have the illness, which city officials and environmental activists believe is the highest rate in the country. Among the city's Latino youngsters, the rate is 48 percent.

title: Sometimes, Smaller Is Better
description: IT'S hard not to be smug when you're on a small-ship cruise of Alaska.

title: Worked Up Again Over Gross-Outs
description: WHAT'S an election year without a moral panic? Popular music, and pop culture in general, are set up to be prime targets this year, stuck in the crossfire of a battle for the righteous high ground. Republicans and Democrats are both positioning themselves as guardians of what George W. Bush, in his speech accepting the Republican nomination, called ''essential values.''

title: On and Off Links, Woods Is the Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Personal Business; Ready or Not, Welcome to the 401(k) Plan
description: MARGARET FULLER, manager of profit sharing at 7-Eleven Inc., is proud that three-quarters of the company's nearly 15,000 eligible employees now participate in its 401(k) retirement savings plan. Three years ago, only half had signed up.

title: August 13-19; Pussycats at the I.R.S.?
description: Two years ago Congress mandated the firing of any Internal Revenue Service worker who harasses a taxpayer. The first 830 complaints investigated found none met the standard for harassment, a congressional report showed, while some cases appeared to be false accusations made to derail audits and collections. The I.R.S. said it fired four employees for threatening an unwarranted audit, one for covering up a mistake, two for understating their income on tax returns and 102 others for not filing tax returns. David Cay Johnston

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about religion and science misidentified the affiliation of the God and Science Project. It is at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, not at Amherst College.

title: August 13-19; Czar Beatified
description: The Russian Orthodox church, continuing its recovery from 70 years of atheist Soviet rule, established a detailed social doctrine outlining the church's position on issues such as abortion, bioethics, homosexuality and private property. The document was accepted by the church's approximately 150 hierarchs, who met as the Council of Bishops, the church's second-highest body. But the bishops most symbolic action was their unanimous decision to canonize the czar and his family as ''passion bearers,'' for their humility in going to their deaths, a move long demanded by the church's rightwing. Sophia Kishkovsky

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPERBERG, IRVING
description: COOPERBERG-Irving. 18/Av/5757-Aug. 20,1997. Death cannot steal anything gained by the soul-love is forever. Lou

title: The C.E.O. Odyssey; Citizen Berge
description: When Pierre Berge hired Alber Elbaz two years ago to take over the design helm of Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche, the aging executive told the young designer one important thing: ''Coco Chanel gave women liberty, and Yves Saint Laurent gave them power.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Up From Sweet Potatoes
description: J. R. Salamanca's deft and sprightly new novel, THAT SUMMER'S TRANCE (Welcome Rain, $24.95), is full of theatrical flourishes. Indeed, the book's protagonist, Ben Oakshaw, was once a talented actor and is now the owner of a major Washington advertising agency; he has deliberately buried ''the true and terrible privation of his youth,'' which was spent on a Florida sweet potato farm, in ''a skillful impersonation'' of success so convincing that it almost -- but never completely -- quiets his sense of inadequacy and self-doubt. When Jill, his lover during his student days at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, writes and stars in a hit play that recreates their break-up, Ben fears his wife, Priscilla, will learn the truth about his messy past. Instead, the guileless, gracious Priscilla invites Jill and her companion, Tony, an older, somewhat enigmatic British journalist, to join the Oakshaws at their magnificent beach house at Cape Hatteras. Their visit unfolds at a seasonal, summer pace -- some 400 leisurely pages of intelligent and witty conversation generated by this privileged and seemingly satisfied four. The mood of ''That Summer's Trance'' is enhanced by Salamanca's abundant lyrical descriptions of water and weather, sky and shore; at one point, ''the pound and wash of the distant surf added to their conversation the ceaseless, darkling discourse of the sea.'' At another, ''the soft billows of the clouds were gradually . . . gathered into a vast, lustrous darkness, like a sable sea.'' There are undercurrents of passion, deception and self-delusion that never quite rupture the surface but subtly threaten this idyllic world. While the story is told from Ben's point of view, it is the charismatic, unconventional and somewhat unstable Jill who dominates. Salamanca maintains a nuanced tension between the two, and their partners, that keeps his ''actors'' a bit off balance, with twists of plot and perception right to the very end. Linda Barrett Osborne

title: GRAND UNION LAYOFFS
description: Grand Union Company, one of the largest food retailers in the Northeast, has laid off 170 people, most from its Wayne headquarters, in an effort to cut expenses associated with the 200-store supermarket chain. In the headquarters office, 100 of the 400 employees were laid off, said Sue Marsh, a company spokeswoman. Another 20 of the 70 administrative, maintenance and construction employees at the offices in Clifton Park, N.Y., were laid off as were 50 nonunion employees at the stores, where 13,000 people are employed. The struggling supermarket chain, which has stores in five Northeastern states, is working with financial advisors to devise a new financial plan. The layoffs, completed last week, are expected to save the company $8 million to $12 million a year. Sales were down 4.2 percent for the chain in the first fiscal quarter ending July 22, but showed some improvement in June and July, the company announced at the annual stockholders meeting Thursday. Karen DeMasters

title: No Need to Trim the Sails, for Now
description: Wall Street is expecting the gray heads at the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates alone when they meet on Tuesday - leaving analysts looking at a slow summer week.

title: At Hotels, the Butlers Are Doing It
description: WHEN I stayed at the St. Regis Hotel a few years ago, I opened the door to a young woman dressed in white tie and tails who identified herself as the butler. Since I had no idea what to do with her, I sent her on her way. A female butler. What a funny idea.

title: Study War No More
description: TOUCHING PEACE

title: The World; But Seriously, Take My Wife . . .
description: THERE is no such thing as a political movement based on jokes, President Abdurrahman Wahid once wrote. But Mr. Wahid himself may be the evidence to the contrary. He jokes to relieve tension, to instruct, to make a point. In fact, his address to parliament last week sounded a bit like a nightclub act.

title: One That Got Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Stop That Canoodling!
description: Once upon a cold war, presidential candidates competed to see who could be trusted not to blink, sitting across the table from a determined Soviet leader.

title: August 13-19; Rising Tire-Related Toll
description: Nobody has figured out yet why Firestone tires have been failing on Ford Explorers, but the government has raised to 62 its tally of deaths attributed to the tires in consumer complaints filed with regulators. Most occurred when the tires failed at high speed and the Explorers rolled over. State Farm, the nation's largest auto insurer, said that it began billing Firestone for tire incidents in 1997, and mentioned the problem to regulators in 1998. Keith Bradsher

title: The Obsessive's Odyssey; Checkered Past
description: All over Italy, Gubbio is known as having been, since Roman times, a place of madness. It is unique, and often uniqueness is mistaken for madness. Gubbio has sired mystics, sorcerers, priests and endless generations of masters of stone. In Gubbio, which clings to the side of a magical Umbrian mountain, there is a festival called the Ceri. And the Ceri is a day of unanimous euphoria for man transcending matter. Along steep, winding alleyways, three gigantic wooden candles (Ceri) are raced through the town in an atmosphere of orchestrated hysteria. The men who carry these candles are called ceraioli. The mixture of physical strain and intense concentration is believed to push them through spiritual barriers. They force themselves to push on and on. They cannot stop; no ceraiolo can.

title: The Brothers K
description: YOU never know what your kids are going to get into,'' Linda Kratt of Somerset County was saying the other day. If her voice contained equal parts of pride and befuddlement, it's easy to understand why: a few feet away sat her two sons, Chris and Martin, and in front of them at least a thousand young children were lined up, waiting for autographs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, WILLIAM
description: RUBEN-William. All of us at Carnival Corporation mourn the death of our very dear friend, colleague and trusted advisor, Bill Ruben. Bill joined Carnival Corporation's Board of Directors when the Company went public in July 1987. He has provided the Company with years of valuable service, sound business counsel, and unwavering friendship. We will miss him greatly and extend our sincere condolences to the Ruben family.

title: A Love Poem

title: The Photographers' Odyssey; Clothes Meet World
description: Every designer claims to be global these days. But will Diane Von Furstenberg play in Havana? We sent the planet's best-traveled photographers on assignment: shoot an iconic person in an iconic location. Here's how the looks fit with the landscape.

title: Scrawn to Brawn: Men Get Muscles, Or Pray for Them
description: IT started with Woodstock -- the video, not the event. Although old enough, barely, to have attended the original 1969 festival, I opted to skip the brown acid and spend that fateful weekend working my summer job. I've never regretted particularly that I wasn't on hand at the Yasgur farm for the grooviness, the mud and Jimi Hendrix's wah-wah pedal, although the rampant nudity sounded like fun. I had no idea how much fun until a friend invited me over recently to watch the documentary film on television.

description: Rough Point, the Newport, R.I., summer ''cottage'' of the tobacco heiress Doris Duke, has opened to the public for the first time. But the owners, the Newport Restoration Foundation, established by Miss Duke in 1968, are restricting visits to three 24-person tours a day, Tuesday to Saturday, through Nov. 4.

title: Of Lawyers, Clients And Professional Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: A Window, a World
description: IN case I don't return to New York, in case oblivion destroys, as it usually does, the passion aroused in me by the grime and splendor of New York, I'd like to note, like a painter sketching the features of his lover, the smells, colors and noises that identify the city for me as for no one else, and the way I relate to New York. For just as no one sees the same face or view precisely as another, the chemistry of each individual with his surrounding environment is unrepeatable.

description: There had been talk that Naseem Hamed, the World Boxing Organization featherweight champion, who is known as much for his entertaining entrances as for his right hook, wanted to tone down those garish walks to the ring. The flamboyant Hamed? Low-key?

For the driver along Sunrise Highway and the other thoroughfares where the flames met the road, the sight is a constant reminder of a time when smoke and fear filled Westhampton, Westhampton Beach, Remsenburg, Speonk, Eastport and Rocky Point.

When she strolled out in front of the cameras at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday night, Tipper Gore was sheathed in blue, her lustrous coat by Ellen Tracy lending her an aura of beatitude. Mrs. Gore was just the last of the candidates' wives who arrived for their respective spotlight moments decked out in tints of blue like so many blossoms in a Victorian nosegay.

Given a preview of these photos, John Richardson, the art critic and Picasso expert who knew Peggy Guggenheim and has stayed at her palazzo, offered these reality checks: first, she favored Fortuny, since the designer was conveniently located in Venice. Second, he dryly noted that Guggenheim never would have ended up with a gondolier in her bed. At the time, the gents famously moonlighted by preparing corpses for burial.

George W. Bush will emphasize education and Vice President Al Gore will trumpet himself as a champion of ''working families.''

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Westchester and Putnam Counties this week. Items may be submitted by mail, at least three weeks in advance, to Westchester Cultural Calendar, North Salem, N.Y. 10560.

title: August 13-19; Trial for Kennedy Nephew In 1975 Killing in Connecticut
description: A Connecticut juvenile court judge ruled that Michael Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy, should stand trial for the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, who was his 15-year-old next-door neighbor in Greenwich's gated Belle Haven enclave. The judge has yet to decide whether Mr. Skakel, who is now 39, should be tried as a juvenile or as an adult. Conviction by a judge in juvenile court could mean a sentence of less than four years; conviction by a jury in Superior Court could bring a life term. David M. Herszenhorn

title: INVESTING: DIARY; Concrete Nonconclusions, Tentatively, at Least
description: Among the millions of research reports put out by Wall Street firms, investors can often find some helpful hints. But some reports leave you wondering. Why was it written? Why was it distributed?

George W. Bush, in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Bennett A. Brockman performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn.

description: FOGEL-Arthur. The good brother to his sisters, Ruth Rosen and Marilyn Blank, and their families. Beloved brother, devoted uncle.

description: AMERICA REBORN

title: Jewish Life in Princeton
description: The Jewish Center of Princeton turns 50 this year, and it seemed appropriate to mark the anniversary by looking at the history of the Jewish community in Princeton, which goes back at least five times that long. ''Old Traditions, New Beginnings'' can be seen at both the Jewish Center (to early October, 435 Nassau Street, open Modays through Thursdays 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Fridays 9 to 3) and the Historical Society of Princeton (through March 2001, 158 Nassau Street, Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 4). The society's section, focuses on early arrivals, family life, social organizations, work and business pursuits, religious traditions and anti-Semitism. The earliest item is an account book dated 1737-1769. A section at the Jewish Center focuses on the growth of the religious community after World War II, including services at Princeton's first synagogue, B'nai Zion (a 1911 photo of the founders, Isador and Sarah Braverman is seen here) to construction of the center.

title: Where to Meet Maid Marian

description: UBS Warburg, the American division of UBS A.G., Europe's third-largest bank, has begun building an addition to the downtown Stamford building it completed in 1997, when it was known as the Swiss Bank Corporation.

title: For Birds of Passage, Spraying Worries
description: THE bird feeders at the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary in Oyster Bay are stocked and ready for the southward migration of scores of species over Long Island. But anticipation of exotic sightings has given way to trepidation about the possible effect that mosquito spraying to combat West Nile virus may have on the migrants.

title: With Retirements and Defections, Schools Rush to Fill Teacher Vacancies
description: SO much for Dr. Marjorie Castro's summer vacation. For Dr. Castro, the Croton-on-Hudson school district superintendent, summer hasn't been a day at the beach, or at the mountains, a lake or anywhere else.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Buildings for People
description: Called a ''gentle manifesto'' by its authors, ARCHITECTURE INSIDE OUT (Wiley, paper, $49.95), seeks for architecture to appeal to all the senses, not just the visual. Karen A. Franck, who teaches subjects like ''the erotics of architecture'' at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, and

title: Bookend; The Writer's Story, and the Lawyer's
description: YEARS ago, when I left the law to try my hand at another kind of fiction -- specifically, serious novels -- many of my barrister colleagues argued forcefully that I was making a mistake. What they feared was not so much that I wouldn't succeed (failure was a given), it was that I would be set adrift and flounder away unanchored -- the kind of shaky situation that drives lawyers nuts. Several books later, I'm not unaware of the extent to which the lawyers' perspective is different from that of the people who are their clients, spouses, lovers and friends.

title: The Nation; Choosing a Running Mate Matters. Or, Mattered.
description: VICE presidential candidates, like the Perseid meteor shower, briefly light up midsummer skies. Usually, that's as long as they matter because people vote for presidents, not vice presidents.

title: NEWARK AIRPORT CRIME
description: Newark International Airport may not yet have banished lost-luggage gremlins, but it has made some progress on human-inspired mischief. According to figures compiled by Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, crime -- including luggage theft, robbery, pickpocket incidents and car theft -- is down 31.4 percent at the airport for the first six months of this year in comparison to the same period of 1999. More modest declines were reported at LaGuardia and Kennedy airports. Ronald Smothers

title: Bonbon Voyage
description: I think it's safe to say that people booked on a lavish 12-day, 6-star cruise have done something right with their lives.Their presence on board suggests they have achieved wealth, cultivated a taste for fine foods, become accustomed to attentive service and accumulated ample leisure time. A cruise ship passenger can smile at circumstance the way a lifelong Greyhound traveler might find cause to lament it.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: MAP

description: To the Editor:

title: Scandinavia on The Delaware
description: CARL JOHNSON is a master carver. He carves dragons, acanthus leaves, relief sculptures, even gnomes and trolls. The retired engineer from Colts Neck has spent years perfecting the craft of Scandinavian carving, each draw of his blade a tribute to his Swedish -- and his wife's Norwegian -- ancestry.

description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Intense as Verizon Strike Enters Third Week
description: Talks Intense as Verizon Strike Enters Third Week

title: Fuzzy Little Test Tubes
description: Interesting article, and somewhat sympathetic to those lab animals that die in experiments of often dubious value. Osborne may have a heart, although his emphasis is on the researchers' needs. Independent of the questionable efficacy of the breeding and use of lab animals, the issue of morality stands out: how can we use sentient creatures for our purposes? Seems wrong.

title: Peekskill Family Files Suit Over Police Raid
description: POLICE officers searching for cocaine engaged in unconstitutional and illegal activity during an early-morning raid of a Peekskill home 15 months ago, the residents of the home are claiming in a lawsuit filed in federal court here.

title: Veteran Korchnoi Triumphs But the Ladies Win Anyway
description: In the ninth running of the Ladies versus Veterans Match, held at the Bayrischer Hof in Munich in early July, the Ladies triumphed, 27-23. The Veterans, roughly over age 55, still hold a 273-265 lead in the series. The overall high scorer this time was Viktor Korchnoi, with 7 1/2-2 1/2.

title: The Ingratiator
description: It's obvious why Gov. George Pataki wants Lazio to be the next senator from New York. With no strongly held beliefs, few opinions on any subject and no apparent intellectual gifts, Lazio would be easy for the governor to control. Why we, the voters, would want such a nonentity to represent us is a more difficult question, and I hope people will give it some thought before the election rather than afterward.

title: The Agony and the Odyssey
description: The idea, honestly, was modest. That the modest idea became a genuine odyssey -- a trip that changed everyone's idea of scale (as Julian Schnabel predicted it would), altered their aesthetics (as Miuccia Prada said it did hers) and boggled their concept of Egyptian grandeur itself (as Sandy Pittman went on and on about in an e-mail) -- was a fortunate accident. But all anyone wanted, at the outset, was one glamorous photo in front of the Pyramids, the kind you associate with another era of fashion. Just a model, a dress and a monument made five millennia ago. Why, we wondered, don't we see more of that in fashion?

title: The Socialite's Odyssey; An American in Venice
description: The heiress Peggy Guggenheim, collector of art and men, lived a louche life in ladylike clothes. How did Peggy amuse herself? By admiring beauty, of course.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00: The Ethicist; The Guilded Rage
description: The unions that represent actors in television commercials are on strike. I work at a recording studio, not party to the strike, that has been hired for sessions using nonunion actors. This makes me squeamish, to say the least. I have friends on both sides of the conflict, including many producers from small ad agencies. I could refuse to participate in nonunion sessions, thus alienating my boss. I could call the union and it would picket my studio, but that could imperil the livelihood of my boss and my producer friends. Or I could do nothing. What do you suggest? -- Brian Hallas, Brooklyn

title: Immigration Is Emerging As Early Issue In Italy's Vote
description: August usually produces a truce in Italian politics as party leaders head for the beaches along with everyone else. But with national elections looming next year, the center-right coalition leader, Silvio Berlusconi, fired an early strike this week, issuing the outline of a 25-point political platform from his vacation home in Bermuda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEF, NINA R.
description: LIEF-Nina R. The staff and board members of the Center for Comprehensive Health Practice (CCHP) mourn the death of Dr. Lief, our friend and colleague of 33 years. She was an American pioneer in teaching both parents and professionals about the role of parent-child interactions in the emotional and social development of young children. In addition to many journal articles and conference presentations, her innovative approach to parenting education is most fully documented in a popular three volume series on the first three years of life. Her career as a dedicated physician spanned seven decades. Dr. Lief was a diplomate of three American medical boards: pediatrics, psychiatry and child psychiatry. She was appointed to the faculty of New York Medical College when she joined our staff in 1967. The Early Childhood Development Center, which she initiated and directed, is a vital part of CCHP. We extend our condolences to Dr. Lief's family, and, on behalf of the thousands of families who have already benefited from her work, celebrate her life of vision and caring for children. Dr. Richard Brotman, Chief Executive Officer David Hutson, Operations Director Center for Comprehensive Health Practice

title: Beyond Canapes and Rubber Chicken
description: SUE NICOLAOU drove through Eisenhower Park, turning left at the roadside coat of arms identifying the Carltun.

title: Hoping to Make the Net Inviting for Older Users
description: Computers may seem to be as common as telephones these days, connecting users with information and with one another. But they are less common among the elderly, who often find computers daunting.

title: Health Care Bonds Pass a Credit Test
description: ALTHOUGH still under the shadows of a government investigation into its billing practices, HCA-The Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest hospital chain, made a successful foray into the debt markets on Friday.

title: STUDENTS SENTENCED FOR HAZING
description: After pleading guilty to hazing violations that led to the death in December of another student, seven former members of an underground fraternity at Iona College were sentenced to 30 hours each of community service. As part of the District Attorney's Clear Choices program, a drug and alcohol prevention effort, the seven will speak to other teenagers about substance abuse. The students were charged after the death of Kevin Lawless, 18, who had a 0.34 percent blood-alcohol level on Dec. 13, the final night of a 30-day pledge period for Sigma Tau Omega, a fraternity that had been banned from the Iona campus in the 1980's because of hazing and alcohol abuse. The students were also fined $125 each and given a one-year conditional discharge. Elsa Brenner

title: Angels' Erstad Hits With All He's Got
description: Darin Erstad decided to give himself a week away from baseball at the end of last season, a major concession. His instinct has always been to try harder, and he had just finished a frustrating season in which he batted .253, and he wanted to know why. He wanted to understand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEFTEL, HERBERT
description: SCHEFTEL-Herbert. Grandson of Ida and Isadore Straus who died on the Titanic, was known to his friends as ''Buzzie.'' Mr. Scheftel, who lived in New York City, Easthampton, Le Touquet, France, died at the age of 92 on August 16 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He attended St. Bernard's School, St. Paul's School and received his BA/MA from Oxford University. In World War II he was a major and senior controller of the 64th Fighter Wing. For his services, he was decorated with the Bronze Star and the Croix de Guerre. Co-founder of the Pan-Am building, he was the officer and co-owner of three television stations in Connecticut, Illinois and Mexico, and six cable stations. He sold his Connecticut television station to Viacom International and became a consultant to that company. He was a past president and a current member of the Board of Directors of Greenwich House, the settlement house which services the city's underprivileged. Mr. Scheftel was a member of White's Club, London; Bucks Club, London; Knickerbocker Club, New York City; St. Cloud's, Paris; Travelers' Club, Paris; and Seminole Golf Club, Palm Beach, FL. He was a devoted husband to Yolande (formerly Fielding), cherished uncle of Susan (Richard) Finkelstein, adored great uncle to Sophie and Jesse, loving stepfather to Francoise Fielding and Cynthia Fielding-Singh and beloved grandfather of Stephanie and Kimberly Fielding and Priya and Vikram Fielding-Singh. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to St. James' Church or Greenwich House. For information on funeral arrangements, call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABELSKY, HERBERT
description: GRABELSKY-Herbert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Herbert Grabelsky, associated with the Times from 1973 until 1982.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-20-00: On Language; Iron Fist
description: 'They wanted this iron fist to command them.'' That was the statement of Arthur Wellesley, the Duke of Wellington, about the need for discipline among the English troops sent to the Canadian frontier in the 1812 war with the United States. The victor over Napoleon at Waterloo became known as ''the Iron Duke.''

title: Shoe Shine
description: More than anything else, Joseph La Rose believed in women's shoes. For nearly 70 years, he devoted his life to pumps and wedges, flats and sandals. La Rose's brain translated anything beautiful -- a stained-glass window, the view from a plane, a flowering jacaranda tree -- into shoes. Dresses and coats and even handbags were interesting only insofar as they mirrored and complemented the greatness of a La Rose shoe. His eye was focused on footwear, and when he died of cancer at 88 last December, he was survived by his wife, Trudy, and more than 100,000 pairs of shoes, which were stockpiled at his store in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Althea Beaton and Malik Ducard
description: WHEN Malik Shabazz Ducard and Althea Allison Beaton met as undergraduates at Columbia University in the early 1990's, all they had in common was a class on African politics. ''We were in completely different circles,'' Ms. Beaton said. ''I was in the sorority circle. He was one of the militant students who 'took over buildings.' ''

title: A Fashion Odyssey
description: ''You ever want to be somebody else?'' Peter Fonda asks, playing the ''Easy Rider'' of the movie's title. ''I never wanted to be anybody else.''

title: No Shortage of Candidates for M.V.P. in Either League
description: No one has ever displayed a clearer definition of most valuable player than Chipper Jones did last September when the Mets, a mere game behind the Braves, played a three-game series in Atlanta. Hitting four home runs and driving in seven runs, Jones dominated the series, which the Braves swept to take a commanding four-game lead.

title: Beth Zasloff, Joshua Steckel
description: Beth Ellen Zasloff, a daughter of Tela and Joseph Zasloff of Pittsburgh, is to be married today to Joshua Steckel, a son of Barbara and Steve Steckel of Sharon, Mass. Rabbi Sharon Cohen Anisfeld will officiate at the Pine Cobble School in Williamstown, Mass.

title: They Also Dance Who Party the Night Away
description: RAVERS are getting a lot of attention lately, especially for a community that has been an underground phenomenon for more than a decade.

title: August 13-19; When the Nominee Knew
description: More than two and a half years after an independent counsel began investigating President Clinton's relationship with a White House intern, a new grand jury has been impaneled to review the case again, government officials said. The independent counsel, Robert W. Ray, convened the panel last month after saying he would consider whether Mr. Clinton could be charged with wrongdoing in the Monica Lewinsky matter once he leaves office. Democrats and Republicans piled criticism on the anonymous leak about the grand jury, disclosed just hours before Vice President Al Gore accepted the Democratic Presidential nomination. By David Johnston

title: August 13-19; Somalis Form a Government
description: Somalis inaugurated their first national assembly since the nation's central government fell in 1991. The next step will be selecting executive positions, which will be divided along clan lines, much like the assembly seats. More crucial will be the transfer of government back to Somalia from the neighboring country of Djibouti, where peace talks have been taking place since March. Ian Fisher

title: Austin, We Have a Problem
description: Earlier this summer, I went for a swim at Barton Springs, a freshwater pool that lies at the geographical and spiritual center of Austin. Under an oak tree, I found Stuart Stevens of the Bush campaign, typing on a Dell laptop. He was writing the script for the video that would be shown at the Republican National Convention. All around him, half-naked kids with ornate tattoos lolled on the grass, working on nothing except their tans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARGMAN, ETHEL
description: KARGMAN-Ethel. Beloved wife of the late Alex. Devoted mother of Judith Borell, Lewis and Richard. Loving mother-in-law of Martin M. Borell, Amy, Judie. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. She was active in many charitable organizations: Hadassah, B'nai Brith, City of Hope, A.D.L., and local community groups. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at ''Parkside Memorial Chapel'' 2576 Flatbush Avenue.

title: Metro-North Should Let Riders Voice Their Opinions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ingratiator
description: The main trait that makes Rick Lazio ''the anti-Hillary'' is his integrity, a term assiduously avoided by your writer, who, unable to skewer Lazio on his legislative record (Hillary Clinton has none), resorted to faint praise of his ''ingratiating'' and ''conciliatory'' personality.

title: Riding a Fad, Hitting a Bump
description: THE maitre d'hotel at Coup, a swanky New American restaurant in the East Village, smiled as he fingered the coat check. Coup is a place of daring high-modern style, and one can only imagine what finery has passed through its coat room. Yet even so, this article cut a figure: sleek of line, cutting edge in design, of the moment and yet blue-collar practical. ''I'm so glad you had this ticket,'' he said with a smile, ''to distinguish it from all the others back there.'' He handed over my scooter, and I rode off into the night.

title: Selections Bring Tears, and Need for Consolation
description: The freshly minted members of the United States men's Olympic gymnastic team were filtering out of the Celtics' locker room -- a shamrock-clad setting they borrowed during the Olympic trials this weekend -- when John Roethlisberger pulled Jamie Natalie aside tonight.

title: Roadwork Could Slow New Mexico Tourists
description: Visitors to some of New Mexico's major tourist destinations can expect delays from highway construction.

title: Increase in Test Scores Counters Dire Forecasts for Bilingual Ban
description: Two years after Californians voted to end bilingual education and force a million Spanish-speaking students to immerse themselves in English as if it were a cold bath, those students are improving in reading and other subjects at often striking rates, according to standardized test scores released this week.

title: The Ultimate Odyssey; A Pyramid Scheme
description: The 5,000-year-old adventure of heading down the Nile calls for a look Cleopatra would have loved to loot: gold.

title: The View From/New Haven; Plan to Expand School Has Neighbors Uneasy
description: THE Worthington Hooker School in New Haven has stood for a century as the anchor of the relatively affluent and ethnically diverse East Rock neighborhood. Academically, its students outperform those of other schools in the district, and its annual festival celebrating the myriad cultures of its students -- many the children of Yale University graduate students -- is a big event. It's a neighborhood school, and parents and school officials want to keep it that way.

title: Boomerang Lives
description: DREAM STUFF

title: Mother Fixation and Other Issues
description: THOSE doomsayers who have been forecasting the death of musicals are in a New York state of mind. All they have to do is get out of town. The myth of Broadway as the center of theater persists because myths are needed, more so by tourists from distant lands and the status-starved who are nearer, moneyed or just pretending.

title: The Radicalization Of James Woolsey
description: This is the kind of thing that breathes reality into Oliver Stone's fantasies. Woolsey got it right when he called it Fascism.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with an article about the renovation of the Pioneer Square district in Seattle mislabeled a roadway. It was the Alaskan Way Viaduct, not the Alaska Highway Viaduct. The map also included an outdated label. The Kingdome was demolished last spring.

description: To the Editor:

title: Investing; The Pocketbook Issues In the Future of Coach
description: INVESTORS who are awaiting the initial public offering of Coach Inc., the luxury leather goods maker, are likely to be disappointed, analysts warn, because Coach's parent, the Sara Lee Corporation, might well do better if it sells the unit than if it takes it public.

title: POSTINGS: Available Through a Federal Program; Discount Houses For Teachers
description: The federal government has come forward with a way to enable schoolteachers to buy a house at a bargain price -- if it's in the right place.

title: The Ingratiator
description: A pretty fair assessment of Rick Lazio. But in evaluating his ''character,'' let's not forget who his opponent is. And as for ambition . . . please. No one comes close to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: U.S. Officials Are Arguing Over Papers On Chile Coup
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and George Tenet, director of central intelligence, are at odds over the extent to which the United States should release documentation of its involvement with repressive Latin American regimes in decades past.

title: Son of Hartford With No Need to Leave
description: MANY artists move to New York City in hopes of making a splash in the art world. They figure to be near the prestigious galleries as well as the potential customers who will buy their work.

title: Commercial Property/Windsor Locks, Conn.; Bradley Airport Is Getting $200 Million Expansion
description: WHEN Robert F. Juliano arrived at the Connecticut Department of Transportation, Bradley Airport in Windsor Locks was a single terminal surrounded by tobacco fields. There were no security fences or checkpoints and only a few domestic carriers servicing the field, which is about 20 minutes north of Hartford.

description: Sirena Selena

description: To the Editor:
