description: To the Editor:

title: Just Up the Drive: a Historic House, and a Zoning Dispute
description: HARRIET BEECHER STOWE, author of the 1852 anti-slavery book ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' was surely no stranger to controversy. Abraham Lincoln, after all, called her ''the little lady who started the big war,'' meaning that her prose precipitated the Civil War.

title: Groh, the Film Buff, Works to Solve the Jets' Problems
description: Following their 27-24 defeat of the Giants on Friday, the Jets are in the unusual position of having two weeks to prepare for the regular-season opener, a scheduling quirk that affords them the chance to get several critical players healthy and to review reams of film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHEIN, SOL
description: GOLDSCHEIN-Sol. Age 86, on August 17, 2000, of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Steven and Carol, William, Allen, Liz. Adored grandfather of Sondra, Laurie, Benn, Eric and Nikki. Funeral Sunday, 1:30 PM, Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: The Good News: 'Big' Is Back
description: JOSH is 12 years, 11 months and 2 weeks old, going on thirtysomething. He threw a quarter into a make-a-wish machine at a carnival and his wish, to grow up fast, was granted. Josh is living proof that you should be careful of what you wish for. As soon as Josh gets his wish, he wants to get rid of it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 6 about the increasing number of parents and children who attend rock concerts together misspelled the surname of a star who has had one of this year's 10 largest-grossing tours. He is Bruce Springsteen, not Springstein.

title: Curing The Blahs Of August
description: GEOGRAPHY can play a big role in the August psyche of a gardener. In my travels at this time of year -- through northern New England, around Minneapolis and in the San Francisco Bay area -- I have consistently met gardeners who are proud to display their colorful borders.

title: Caitlin Gross, Christian Rockwell
description: Caitlin Alexandra Gross, the daughter of Linda and James Gross of Ithaca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian Andrew Rockwell, a son of Jean Browning Rockwell and Col. Frederick G. Rockwell Jr. of Falls Church, Va. The Rev. Vincent Curtin performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, with the Rev. Nicholas Lubelfeld, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILRUTH, ROBERT R.
description: GILRUTH-Robert R. The true leader of Project Apollo to land man upon the moon. From the early days at Langley Research Center to championing the method that yielded success. Technically advanced and a gentleman. Sympathy to Jo Gilruth and family. Saul Ferdman

title: Paint Me a Dinner
description: DENNIS FOY, a highly respected New Jersey chef, is also a painter. He has kept a studio in Point Pleasant Beach since 1982, finding rare minutes to paint while spearheading restaurants in Chatham, Summit and Manhattan. However, the white walls are left bare at Foy's, his month-old restaurant here.

title: Ellison Using Wealth to Seek America's Cup
description: Storm-tossed, soaked and seasick, Larry Ellison watched as his hired posse of professional sailors scrambled to repair yet another piece of broken equipment aboard his 80-foot maxi-yacht Sayonara. It was the final days of December 1998, and Ellison and his 22-man crew were battling fierce weather off the coast of Australia in the 54th running of the annual Sydney-Hobart Race.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; From Smoking to Saving
description: When Dr. William S. Clark and his wife, Elaine, quit smoking, they stashed whatever they would have spent on cigarettes in a jar. ''At the end of a year, we took a trip down to Bermuda on the money we saved from not smoking,'' he said.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: August 13-19; Curb on Phone Surveillance
description: A federal appeals court struck down many of the new technical standards imposed on telephone companies that had broadly expanded the ability of law enforcement agencies to eavesdrop on the phone calls of criminal suspects. The decision, prompted by complaints from phone companies and privacy-rights advocates, forces the government to reconsider the standards at a time when federal agents have struggled to keep up with rapid technological advances that have made it harder to monitor possible crimes. Stephen Labaton

title: Susan Hockings, Joe Kappock
description: Susan Catherine Hockings, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric F. Hockings of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Kappock IV, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kappock III of Hillsborough, Calif. The Rev. Jean R. Smith performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: Man in the News; A Street-Savvy Innovator; Bernard Bailey Kerik
description: In the five and a half years that Bernard B. Kerik held the proverbial key to the New York City jail system, first as the top deputy and then as commissioner of the Department of Correction, slashings and stabbings fell by 93 percent. Overtime pay plummeted by 44 percent. Trends were monitored, statistics compiled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLINS, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: WOLINS-William, M.D., F.A.C.P., August 20, 1909-July 15, 1962. ''Lives of great men all remind us We can make our lives sublime, And, departing, leave behind us Footprints on the sands of time.'' Happy Birthday Daddy. I love you. SuS

title: The Accidental Pilgrims
description: UNTIL I went to Rome this summer, the word pilgrim usually conjured up images of the dour early arrivals on American shores. I certainly couldn't conceive of myself as a pilgrim, the kind who makes a journey to a holy place for religious purposes. I'm a lifelong Catholic, but I don't have the kind of faith that I associate with people who go to great lengths to visit the four major basilicas of Rome for Holy Year indulgences.

title: Lightening the Luggage Load
description: LOST, delayed or mishandled luggage is one of the vexations associated with flying. Passengers who responded to a survey on the Web site www.frequentflyer.oag.com last month cited lost luggage as their second biggest aggravation -- behind being bumped from an overbooked flight, but ahead of missing a flight or having one canceled. While a certain amount of luggage seems always destined to be lost or delayed, several services in effect or in the pipeline will either help track bags in transit or offer the convenience of having bags picked up or delivered at a traveler's home or hotel.

title: On Tour, and on a Mission, to Keep Country Music Country
description: THE impact Loretta Lynn has had on country music goes beyond style and success. It is about the very foundation of a musical genre that is pure Americana. Ms. Lynn possesses an unadulterated country voice -- a pining, yearning instrument that imparts both vulnerability and strength.

title: Steps to Install Molding and Trim
description: INSTALLING molding and trim around doors and windows and at the top and base of the walls is called finish carpentry. The pieces must be cut accurately and fitted together so they are aligned properly without noticeable gaps.

title: 'Hidden Epidemic' Has No Basis in Fact
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shared Script
description: To the Editor:

title: Stachybotrys Is Now Just in the Dictionary
description: Egad! Three years ago, sprouting black wisps of a toxic mold that has been linked to skin rashes, heart palpitations, respiratory problems, headaches and chronic fatigue were found growing inside the walls and ventilation system of the Tottenville branch of the New York Public Library on Staten Island.

title: U.S. Officials Questioned Over Tribal Recognition
description: FOR two days state and municipal lawyers questioned researchers for the United States Bureau of Indian Affairs regarding the agency's decision to grant preliminary federal recognition to the Eastern Pequots and the Paucatuck Eastern Pequots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, WALSTON S.
description: BROWN-Walston S. Aug. 17 at 92. Retired partner of Willkie Farr & Gallagher. Survived by his loving and devoted wife, Dr. Ellen Regan Brown. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: A Site for Restaurant Patrons
description: WHEN Jim Gurfein started his Internet company, Restaurant Row.com, here in 1994, his premise was simple.

title: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill's Argument With Ump Escalates, and Torre Weighs In
description: Paul O'Neill leaned on the railing in front of the Yankees' dugout in the first moments after their extra-inning loss to Anaheim on Friday night at Yankee Stadium, glaring at the home plate umpire, Gary Cederstrom, as Cederstrom passed on his way to the dressing room.

title: Two Visions of Government
description: Ralph Nader sees no meaningful difference between the Democratic and Republican parties this year, and at least on a cosmetic level he has a point. Both parties have tried hard to project a centrist image while tranquilizing their activists. In Philadelphia, George W. Bush's inclusiveness pitch required keeping the Republican right wing offstage while throwing it a bone or two in the platform. The Democrats in Los Angeles reversed the process, giving the Kennedy-Jackson wing of the party plenty of air time but little consolation in the platform. Nevertheless, it is clear that there are measurable differences between the two candidates on domestic policy, and that on issue after issue the Democrats would still urge a more vigorous deployment of federal resources to solve national problems. These differences may not be enough to satisfy Mr. Nader's aggressively populist inclinations, but if the election were held now, they would give the voters a real choice.

title: Creed Headed for Camden
description: Creed has enjoyed quite a career, especially considering its short three-year duration. The group came seemingly out of nowhere, scoring one hit after another with four No. 1 singles from its debut, ''My Own Prison.''

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Gore and His Record
description: To the Editor:

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bark Is So Passe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, DANIEL
description: BROWNSTEIN-Daniel. July 29. Loving son of Mimi Bonchek Brownstein and Joel Brownstein of Buffalo, New York. Daddy of Leah Brownstein. Brother of Lisa, David, Rachel. Grandson of the late Gene and Samuel Boncheck, Anna and Joseph Brownstein. Nephew of Bina Berg-Klein.

title: The Collector's Odyssey; The Artifacts of Life
description: For some people, home is where the heart is. For Helen Marden, home is where the heart has been. Marden, a painter, mother of two and the wife of the artist Brice Marden, has been hitting the road regularly since she made a trip to Morocco after college. ''Traveling alone is one of the great pleasures in life,'' said Marden, who has also traveled extensively with her family. And the living room of the Mardens' Manhattan town house -- she calls it ''my cave'' -- has become a richly illustrated album of those journeys. Though the room contains furniture ranging from early American to Eames, and art by Franz Kline, Richard Tuttle and Marden herself, it mostly reflects Marden's longtime fascination with India. ''I could go there every year, and I'd be happy,'' she said. ''It's so ancient and it's so sensual.'' So it would seem, from the room's profusion of sinuously sculptured deities, sexually explicit Tantric paintings and ritual phallic symbols. But what is really seductive about the room is its evocation of a life well lived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWILLICH, AEDA Y.
description: ZWILLICH-Aeda Y. (Formerly Brooklyn Heights). Beloved aunt of Dr. Ellen and Michael Feingold, Maurine and Dr. Jerry Schribman, Myra and Burt Freedman. Dear cousins Renee and Bob Wolff. Loving aunt of Harriet and Vin Avolio, Dr. Carol Lewis, Dr. Naomi and Doug Thorpe, Amy and Rabbi Ron Kronish, Dr. Clifford Zwillich, Dianne Wallace and Lowell Schulman, and Murray Singer. Special friends Loretta Mohamed and Blossom Alexander. For information: ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533

title: Women Move Closer to Olympic Equality
description: Stacy Dragila was always a bit of a daredevil. She competed on the high school rodeo circuit in Northern California and, entering junior college in 1992, became intrigued by the risk and the airborne gymnastics of the pole vault. It was a relatively new event for women, however, and the first male pole-vaulter she consulted suggested she could not clear the gender bar.

title: Fuzzy Little Test Tubes
description: Animal rights advocates are not above using emotional arguments, so here's one from a different angle. My wife and best friend for more than half my life died from cancer 14 months ago. If you asked me how many lab rats I'd sacrifice to medical research so that I could have her with me today, the number would be infinite.

title: State Senate Race Features a Rare Republican Primary
description: In New York City, where two-thirds of the registered voters are Democrats, vigorous primaries between Republicans are few and far between. But there is such a contest being waged between two Republicans who are seeking a State Senate seat in a district that includes parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island.

title: On Asking Teenagers To Watch Their Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Pettitte Wipes Away the Angels, and the Bitter Memories of Friday Night
description: Andy Pettitte departed Yankee Stadium Friday in the sixth inning, before the Yankees' collapse, before they blew their five-run lead in the ninth. Pettitte saw the 11th inning in his living room, saw Anaheim's Darin Erstad slug the game-winning home run, and Pettitte became cognizant of the burden shifting onto his broad shoulders.

title: May Is in Contention, But Claims No Jitters
description: Sometime during Sunday's final round, Bob May will almost undoubtedly hear someone say this: Who's that guy playing with Tiger Woods?

title: At Their National Convention, Democrats Shined Spotlight on Local Races
description: The main event may have been in the big arena, but for Representative Joseph M. Hoeffel of Pennsylvania and dozens of other Democratic candidates from around the country, the action was all in a small cluster of television studios to the side.

title: The Assessment Cometh
description: A lot has changed in the 26 years since Jean and Ralph Shomer moved from Bergen County to the gracious Forrest Hill neighborhood here along Branch Brook Park so Mr. Shomer, now 82, could be closer to the coat factory he still owns.

title: Corrections
description: A credit line Sunday for a photograph of sailors in Times Square misspelled the name of a picture agency. It is Corbis/Bettmann, not Bettman.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Tim Connors, a golfer, misstated the record of the Iona Prep golf team. It was not undefeated; it lost one match, to Fordham Prep.

title: The Ingratiator
description: Rick Lazio is a candidate who's a nice guy. He votes his conscience, takes his time doing it and doesn't strictly follow any party line (James Traub, July 30). As a registered Democrat living on Long Island, I voted for Lazio every time. Even if I disagreed with some of his positions, at least I was voting for someone who did his best to represent and live his values.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMBERG, MEYER
description: SAMBERG-Meyer. 85, of Riverdale, NY. Died August 18. Graduate of City College, 1935. Received MBA at Columbia. Taught merchandising at Textile High School. Worked with architects and builders designing new lighting technology in the construction industry, representing universities and major new buildings. During WW II was civilian aide to the War Department in the Alaskan defense. He leaves his dear wife Sonya; daughters Ellen McCall, Karen Samberg; son Robert Samberg; grandchildren Sarah McCall (Ephron) and Jack McCall; greatgrandson Jordan McCall; sister Dorothy Shaw; nephews Ernest, Peter and Fred Shaw. Services Tuesday, August 22, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76, 10:30 AM.

title: All Aboard for a Museum That Rolls On and On
description: JEFF JEWELL, from Watertown, Tenn., (population 2,000), had never attended an art exhibition, and he had boarded a train only once before in his life, when Artrain rolled into town. When it left after a week, he left with it.

title: In Dutchess, Where Local Products Reign
description: THIS cozy country restaurant is certainly a destination for all seasons, but summer and fall find it in its prime. Set under mature trees and among the great swaths of manicured turf of Dutchess County, Allyn's offers delightful outdoor dining when the weather permits. At tables scattered on the lawn, guests can enjoy the lovely garden and the panorama of horse country -- neatly fenced paddocks on rolling green hills.

title: The Winding Road Of the Western Hero
description: IN the early 1950's, when the director Fred Zinnemann read the first draft of the screenplay of ''High Noon,'' he thought it ''nothing short of a masterpiece -- brilliant, exciting and novel in its approach. I could hardly wait to come to grips with it.'' He saw a classic meeting of good and evil, and the focused immediacy of it all happening by a minute or two after noon. He knew he had Gary Cooper as Will Kane, the man who has just married and retired as sheriff -- until he hears that an old enemy, Frank Miller, is out of the penitentiary and coming to get him.

title: Business; Real Estate Commissions Endure a Web Assault
description: WITH a few clicks of the mouse and about 160,000 listings to start, the National Association of Realtors promised in 1996 that its Web site, called Realtor.com, would increase efficiencies and cut the costs of selling homes.

description: MATTANZA

description: To The Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; Running Silent, Deep and Sometimes Deadly
description: THERE is a famous bit of publishing lore about how Tom Clancy's first novel, ''The Hunt for Red October,'' caught on in the mid-1980's. President Reagan read the tale of submarine disaster and derring-do and mentioned publicly that it was mesmerizing. The novel, published by the tiny Naval Institute Press, quickly became a runaway best seller.

title: Vocational School Training Program Fails, Audit Says
description: After an auspicious start seven years ago, a program meant to help vocational students find jobs after graduation has fallen into complete disarray, according to an audit by the city comptroller.

title: Batting the Breeze
description: David Carkeet is puzzled by the origins of the ''counterfactual'' present tense used in sports (On Language, July 23). ''If the ball clears the fence, we win'' -- but it didn't, so we didn't.

title: The Proper Purse
description: With fitted suits, pumps and pearls, this is a season of Park Avenue chic, and the handbag is its centerpiece. The new crop comes in ultraclassic shapes and sizes, from doctor bags to whisper-thin clutches, in luxe crocodile, pampered-prep tweeds and the two-tone shades of a vintage Rolls-Royce. The X factor is quiet opulence.

It is New Vision Studios, not Inner Vision. The column also misspelled the surname of New Vision's president. He is Joseph Weishar, not Weiscar.

description: IT'S crazy, it's absurd, it doesn't make sense. But it's true, it's profound, it's realer than real.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reckonings; Most Unkindest Cuts
description: There was a word missing from Al Gore's acceptance speech on Thursday. Not once did he describe his opponent's plans as ''risky.'' He still warned about the size of George W. Bush's proposed tax cuts -- about $1 trillion larger than his own over the next 10 years. But Mr. Gore has apparently decided to emphasize his populism more than his prudence, accusing the Republicans of offering tax cuts that benefit only the rich. Is he telling the truth?

title: Renaissance Cruises Eases Cancellation Pain
description: Renaissance Cruises, after an inquiry by the New York State attorney general, has changed its cancellation penalties to bring them into line with those of other cruise companies.

title: They May Not Get This in Des Moines
description: LORRIE and Bob and Cindy and Brandon are out on a date. There is laughter. A playful argument. Meaningful glances. Holding of hands under the tale, over the table, behind the table. And sharing of the clams and mussels.

description: GRANGE HOUSE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IANNICI, GERTRUDE FITZPATRICK
description: IANNICI - Gertrude Fitzpatrick. Passed away on August 17. Age 75. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Iannici. Survived by her beloved daughter and son-in-law Jane and Joseph Pontarelli. Dear sister of Michael Fitzpatrick (Jean), Jeri Crivilli (Louis), her beloved brother-in-law Joseph Iannici (Helen), deceased sister Nona Mayers, many nieces, nephews and extended family. She was a women of great courage and inner strength. Jane and Joseph Pontarelli will be receiving family and friends at their home in Quogue, LI, NY on Sunday, August 20th from 5 to 9 PM at 31 Ogden Lane. Interment private, Monday at Calverton National Cemetery at 1PM.

description: There is a barroom bard whose given name is Clarence Pope 3rd. He may be found in most any saloon at most anytime within the precincts of Manhattan. He is known as CP3.

title: Lifted by Music And Torn by Politics
description: TWENTY miles southeast of Vienna, vineyards sweep down from a line of low, wooded hills to a shallow lake, and Eastern Europe begins. Austria's present-day frontiers with Hungary and Slovakia may be a few miles farther on, but the shift from central, Alpine Europe is sudden, dramatic and unmistakable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SAMUEL G.
description: COHEN-Samuel G. Of Boynton Beach, Florida, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away August 12. Mr. Cohen was husband of the late Fay, father of Jay B. and the late Louise. Graveside service, 1:00 PM, Tuesday, August 22 at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; The Caddie Known Only by Tiger Woods
description: AS Tiger Woods strode onto the 13th tee yesterday at Valhalla Golf Club after his first double-bogey in a major tournament since the Masters, his caddie, Steve Williams, simply offered a reminder.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Mining for Housing Dollars in Pits of Sand
description: LOOKING more like a prehistoric reptile than machinery, an excavator is hard at work on the arid slopes of a former sand mine here on the northern service road of the Long Island Expressway, gouging out the sand and loading it into dump trucks.

title: Bush Pledges to Seek Federal Aid to Repair Indian Schools
description: After staging a rally today in his home state of Texas to underscore the strength of his political base, Gov. George W. Bush traveled to New Mexico, a state President Clinton won twice, to announce a proposal to repair crumbling schools on the nation's Indian reservations.

title: Sales Increase at Toymax But Earnings Stay Weak
description: Toymax International Inc. of Plainview (Nasdaq: TMAX) reported record first-quarter sales of $25.1 million, attributing the growth mainly to its acquisition of several businesses earlier this year.

title: The 49ers' Salary Cap Under N.F.L. Inquiry
description: Carmen Policy was president of the San Francisco 49ers from 1991 to 1999, and during that period the team captured Super Bowl XXIX and never won fewer than 10 games. Policy was considered a genius by many, able to massage the salary cap without breaking a sweat, and he quickly became one of the highest-profile executives in the sport. When his competitors whispered that he was bending the rules, those words were often ignored as jealous ramblings.

title: In Hands of a Master, Eventful Photographs
description: Arthur Leipzig

title: In Carriacou, Parrotfish And Pastel Cottages
description: THE market was the talk of downtown Hillsborough, Carriacou. The old building, with its rusty corrugated-iron roof sheltering a handful of hard-bargaining fruit and vegetable hawkers, had stood at the foot of the town dock for as long as anyone could remember. Now the city council wanted to tear it down and relocate the market about 100 yards down the street.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE MAGNIFICENT ACTIVIST

title: A Casbah for Clothes Is Bustling in California.
description: IT is just a short walk from the Staples Center, where the Democrats, the news media and assorted demonstrators spent the week playing out the politics of the information age. But the thriving Los Angeles fashion district has more in common with 12th-century Baghdad than the California of the new millennium.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Demand Grows for Temporary Executive Housing
description: BECAUSE of increasing demand from its corporate clients, one of the country's leading suppliers of temporary executive housing has tripled its presence in Westchester by leasing 44 apartments in a condominium complex near the Metro-North train station here.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Oradell, N.J.; Giving an Old Downtown a New Life
description: IN most downtowns, the opening of a new coffee bar or Tex-Mex restaurant would be a minor event. In the 2.4-square-mile Bergen County, N.J., Borough of Oradell, the recent arrival of Cool Beans, Badlands Tacos and the Little Dipper ice cream parlor on Kinderkamack Road symbolized a break with the restrictive past and the harbinger of redevelopment.

title: Friend's Best Man With Bag in Hand
description: THE other day, a wild-eyed woman with a Doberman accosted me on a Brooklyn street.

title: They Know How Your Garden Grows
description: HALF a century ago, Beverley Nichols, an English journalist, defied common sense and the advice of friends and bought himself a small country estate. Upon inspection he found that the property came with several fixtures, the most permanent of which was Oldfield, the gardener, who had worked on the place for more than 40 years, and outlasted the two previous owners.

title: MAMARONECK: HOME BUYERS' WORKSHOP SCHEDULED
description: The Washingtonville Housing Alliance, a nonprofit organization for affordable housing in the Mamaroneck area, will hold a home buyers' workshop in Spanish on Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. at the Mamaroneck Public Library. The workshop, aided by Citibank, will include information on obtaining a mortgage, legal aspects of home ownership and special mortgage products, including federal assistance programs and loans for first-time home buyers.

title: With Alabama Victory, Jostle Steps to Head of the Class
description: With 10 minutes to post time of the 120th running of the Alabama, Saratoga's showcase race for 3-year-old fillies, Jostle, the 2-1 second choice on the morning line, was inexplicably 7-1 on the tote board today.

title: FALTERING GIANT: A special report.; Against Tough Odds, Nigeria Bets on Reform
description: When President Clinton crisscrossed Africa on a six-country visit in March 1998, his plane overflew Nigeria in a pointed snub at the generals leading it. Ground down by misrule and miscreants, Nigeria, the continent's most populous nation, was an ailing giant perilously close to collapse.

title: Mary Romary, Samuel Wender
description: Mary Ellen Romary, the daughter of Darlene and O. Jules Romary of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married yesterday at the Boathouse in Central Park to Samuel N. Wender, the son of Dorothy and Norman Wender of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: August 13-19; A Run on Meat, and Not by Humans
description: From hemisphere to hemisphere and around the globe comes news about meat, and it's enough to put you off your feed.

title: Right Step by I.O.C.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Life and Times Of a Pool in Scarsdale; Once the Scene of Parties, Now It Serves a Solitary Swimmer
description: EVERY morning from May to September Arnold Davis, 76, steps out his back door onto the smooth concrete pool deck and, after testing the water, plunges in.

title: Pat Hearn, Art Dealer In New York, Dies at 45
description: Pat Hearn, one of the leading art dealers of the last two decades, a founder of the Gramercy International Art Fair and a pioneer of the art scene in the East Village, SoHo and Chelsea, died on Friday at her vacation home in Provincetown, Mass. She was 45 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Olazabal, With One 63, Needs Another to Win
description: In golf, 63 is a magic number the low score in the history of all four major tournaments. And with Jose Maria Olazabal of Spain shooting a nine-under-par 63 today in the P.G.A. Championship at Valhalla, it has now happened 19 times, including twice by Greg Norman.

title: August 13-19; A Threat to California's Oaks
description: Up and down the California coast, thousands of oak trees are dying of a fast-spreading new disease called sudden oak death syndrome. In just five years, it has spread from one to three species of oak and across 350 miles of coastline. Scientists fear it may move outside the state and afflict other species of trees, and the Department of Agriculture says it will discuss its options in fighting the disease next week. It appears to be caused by a species of funguslike organism closely related to the pest that caused Irish potato blight. Carol Kaesuk Yoon

title: Food; Cutting Remarks
description: The length of one's blade can be a measure of one's authority in the kitchen. Some virtuosos become human slice, dice and mince machines. Others, and I was one, take pity on a tomato bleeding under a light, short and dull blade and reach for ever heavier, longer, sharper knives. Either way, one learns the delicate balance between violence and nurture by mastering the use of something capable of both.

title: Scenes From a Hellish Marriage
description: CRUEL BANQUET

title: Katherine Kostakos, Nicholas Fengos
description: Dr. Katherine Kostakos and Nicholas James Fengos are to be married today by the Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

title: Back-to-School Travel Deals
description: ON a standing-room-only Amtrak train from New England to New York, I recently found myself nose to chest with a fellow passenger wearing a Hosteling International card on a lanyard around his neck. The lavaliere reminded me that youth migrations are upon us, as students flock back to college.

title: Getting to Know the Man Beneath the Hat
description: THE low-slung hat that hides much of Dwight Yoakam's face gives the impression he is the strong, silent type who keeps his thoughts to himself.

title: The Whole of Volatility Is Less Than Its Parts
description: IT may be difficult to imagine that any decade in American stock market history saw the magnitude or number of violent swings witnessed in the 1990's.

title: Now Close the Gap In Military Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Gal
description: OUR family was definitely the only one in town and probably in the nation not to have cable television, our boys informed us on a regular basis. Maybe so, but we thought we were doing them a favor. They already watched more than enough television, and cable didn't offer significantly more worthwhile programming than the networks. Cable has Animal Planet, the History Channel and ''The Sopranos,'' true, but it also has ''The Man Show.''

title: Last Call for the Posies
description: The Posies are regarded as leaders of the ever-resuscitating power-pop revival. They combine the influences of the Who, the Raspberries, the Beatles and Big Star, while adding deft harmonies, which many compare with the Hollies. (They have even recorded the Hollies' ''King Midas in Reverse.'')

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Luxury Rentals Rising on North Bergen Shoreline
description: WHILE much of the land along the 18-mile Hudson River shoreline has sprouted housing in the last few years, a 10-acre slice of waterfront in this Hudson County township has long sat dormant except for a stand of cattails that swayed to the river breezes.

title: If a Transaction Goes Sour, Where Do You Turn?
description: THE diamond advertised by ''mrwatch'' on eBay was precisely what Robert and Teri La Plant wanted.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Cattle and Flowers

title: Its My Party
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The President's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Troubles End Els's String of Seconds
description: One by one, disappointed players came off the course, knowing the year's final opportunity to win a major championship had passed them by.

title: Hey, Cyrano, Big Nose or No Nose, Stop Worrying; It's All in the Mind
description: In the light mist that suffuses the black-box stage of the Clark Studio Theater at Lincoln Center, the Aquila Theater Company's production of ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' begins with an engaging series of directorial ideas. Actors enter and begin building a makeshift theater out of rudimentary props: a platform on a pushcart, a closet-size proscenium with light drapes for a curtain.

title: A Video Game Maker Hits Reset; Electronic Arts Bets on Future of Web-Based Interaction
description: In the video game world, when players face bleak prospects -- a hero loses ''health points,'' or a spaceship's shield is depleted -- they have the ultimate recourse: hit the reset button.

title: Skin Cancer Experience Led McCain to Act Fast
description: When Senator John McCain had a routine checkup for skin cancer on July 27, a few days before the Republican convention, Dr. John F. Eisold, the attending physician of the United States Capitol, spotted a mole on his patient's left temple and told him, ''You ought to have that checked.''

title: Complaint to Spanish TV: Not Enough Americans; Few U.S. Plots for Growing U.S. Audience
description: On any given Saturday night, a television host known as Don Francisco holds sway in hundreds of thousands of American homes for four straight hours with a throwback to American variety shows of the 1950's, and more. The Miami-based television show ''Sabado Gigante'' (Giant Saturday) grabs viewers with a mix of musical performances, contests, comedy, interviews and audience sing-alongs.

title: Editorial Observer; Penetrating the Remote Amazon Rain Forest
description: Brazil's vast Amazon rain forest, almost half the size of the continental United States, has long been protected by its great expanse and the difficulty of traversing it. Huge bites have been chomped from its southern and eastern edges over the past three decades to make way for cattle ranches, farms, highways and human settlements. But the remote interior has remained untouched and largely inaccessible.

title: NORWEGIAN DIVERS OPEN SUB'S HATCH BUT FIND NO BODIES
description: A team of Norwegian divers managed to open the damaged outer hatch of the sunken Russian submarine Kursk early today and found the escape chamber was flooded but found no sign that any of the crew members were alive.

title: Bush Pushes for Veteran Health Care
description: MILWAUKEE -- Seeking to slow Al Gore's post-convention gains in the polls, George W. Bush is taking multiple swings at the Clinton administration on military affairs, proposing to spend $1.3 billion on pay raises, schools, and veterans' health care.

title: Defense in the 21st Century
description: The presidential campaign has embarked on an unhelpful debate between the candidates about Gov. George W. Bush's assertion that American military forces have been ''hollowed out'' during the Clinton administration. That is not true, and it deflects the conversation from a host of important defense issues that the candidates should be addressing. The United States has by far the world's most powerful military forces and invests more money in maintaining them and their weapons than the next 10 largest countries combined spend on their militaries. The question for Americans to consider is whether the armed forces are adapting quickly enough to fight the kinds of battles they are likely to face in the years ahead.

title: Bill Gates and Teammates Reach Finals at Tournament
description: There were three talking points as the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals reached their conclusion here today. One was the participation in the Mixed Teams of Bill Gates, Chairman of Microsoft and a bridge enthusiast. Teamed with him, and qualifying for today's final sessions, were Sharon Osberg of San Francisco, Howard Weinstein of Chicago and Sheri Winestock of Toronto. Gates, who plays bridge frequently online, was expecting to be teamed here with Warren E. Buffett; but Mr. Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, is recovering from surgery.

title: Sports of The Times; Tiger Triumphed The Hogan Way
description: AS a youngster, Tiger Woods taped a list of Jack Nicklaus's accomplishments on the wall of his room. And after having played with Nicklaus in the first two rounds of the 82nd Professional Golfers' Association Championship, he was asked: if he could play with two other golfers of history in a mythical foursome, who would they be?

title: Collins and Toomer Get Off on Right Foot
description: In the last step of a backpedal, his weight on his back -- or right -- foot, as Kerry Collins releases the football it seems more prayer than pass.

title: A Seaport Used to Pain Hurts Again
description: In this city that lives off the sea, people know about disaster. But even here, the tragedy of the sunken submarine Kursk, which entombed 118 sailors, has rattled residents and brought a hush to the streets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAX, GORDON B.
description: SAX-Gordon B., 8/21/58-3/11/96. ''The world stands out on either side/No wider than the heart is wide/Above the world is stretched the sky/No higher than the soul is high.'' We miss you. Rene

title: National Geographic Buys Stake in iExplore
description: The National Geographic Society is venturing into new terrain; it is buying a stake in an online adventure travel company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, JUDGE DAVID N.
description: EDELSTEIN-Judge David N. United States Judge, S.D.N.Y. Beloved husband of Florence (Koch), and proud father of Jeffrey and Jonathan. David loved his family, his friends, his country and the law. Services: Park Avenue Synagogue, Monday, 11:30AM, 87th St. and Madison Ave.

title: Treasuries Scheduled for Auction Today
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about research on the chances of an earthquake at the Hayward Fault in Northern California misspelled the name of a city along the fault. It is Fremont, not Freemont.

title: Sri Lankan Army Braces For Major Rebel Offensive
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka  The Tamil Tigers, the guerrillas fighting for an independent state in Sri Lanka, are poised for a major offensive intended to consolidate their hold on the Jaffna Peninsula, the commander of government forces on the peninsula warned over the weekend.

title: Code Name: Spy
description: Of all the unusual aspects of what is shaping up to be one of the most important espionage cases of the post-cold-war era -- the trial here of Wen Ho Lee -- none is more striking than the fact that it is not an espionage trial at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISOM, OLE C.
description: RISOM-Ole C. On August 19, 2000, of Roslyn Harbor. Beloved husband of Agnes, loving father of Christopher H. Risom, Camilla R. Pile and C. Nicholas Risom. Also survived by six grandchildren and two brothers, Jens and Niels Risom. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: E-Commerce Report; Advertisers are turning to specialists to handle their e-mail marketing campaigns.
description: AMONG Internet companies struggling to retain customers they have worked so hard to get, e-mail marketing is seen as the next best thing to being on the home page each time a customer goes online.

title: Victory For 'Dream' As Lukas Cries Foul
description: D. Wayne Lukas was furious after this afternoon's Grade I Ballerina Handicap. But after watching replays of the race, the winning trainer, Bill Mott, was not sure why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, BEATRICE
description: PAKULA-Beatrice. In Fairfield, CT, on August 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Arnold Pakula, devoted mother of Avonne and Myles Seideman of Westport, CT, adoring grandmother of Evan and Jennifer Seideman, Neal and Michelle Seideman, Lauren Seideman, and great-grandmother of Justin and Rachel Seideman. Interment services were held at Acacia Cemetery in Queens.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

description: Fox Spinoff Has Benefited Some More Than Others

title: Financial Times Objects To Portrayal of Reporter
description: Months ago, The Financial Times gave the producers of ''Bull,'' TNT's new series about Wall Street, permission to use its image in the program.

title: A Year Overflowing With Bach; A Conductor's Odyssey Includes 198 Cantatas in 60 Concerts
description: Large, ambitious projects often have their origins in seemingly inconsequential small moments. For the British conductor John Eliot Gardiner, it was a glance at a program of a concert he was about to present in 1996.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, ETTA M.
description: LANG-Etta M. On August 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Fred L. and Carole of Whippany, NJ, and Dr. Ronald J. and Danuta of New Rochelle, dear grandmother of Brian, Denise, Gabrielle and Benjamin, loving aunt of Judy & Berel. Services were held yesterday.

description: SCHEFTEL-Herbert. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

description: Software programs like Napster and Gnutella have achieved a reputation for fostering a communal spirit of sharing among millions of music-loving computer users.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: For Workers and Customers, Relief
description: Leo Hernandez had not been planning to wake up at 5:30 this morning to go to work. Old-timers at the phone company had told him that if a strike lasted more than two weeks, it would be a long one. Mr. Hernandez had been preparing to wait it out.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Gore Renews Push on Patients' Rights and Drug Prices
description: Comparing his increasingly populist pitch to that of Harry S. Truman, but leaving the ''give-'em-hell'' to his running mate, Vice President Al Gore renewed his attacks on drug companies and health maintenance organizations today and vowed to bring broader and fairer health coverage to all Americans.

title: In a Place Called Clinton, Gore Finds His Own Groove
description: In the Gore camp, there has been much talk about the need to gain separation from President Clinton, to set Al Gore apart as his own man with his own style, message and persona.

title: Tainted by Fraud Charges / Foreign Funding Is Withheld : In Cambodia, Mine-Clearing Group's Future Is in Doubt
description: PHNOM PENH  Weakened by a shortage of foreign funding following reports of graft and mismanagement, Cambodia's main organization for clearing mines and unexploded munitions soon may have to halt operations, officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFNER, HELEN KARIN
description: HAFNER-Helen Karin. 86, died peacefully May 20 in San Dimas, CA. Born in Duluth, MN, June 8, 1913, she earned a Ph.D. from the Sorbonne, Paris, France, in 1935, and an MSW from the University of Michigan in 1952. She taught at Manchester College, NY, in the Department of Education, specializing in courses in mental health and behavioral problems. A longtime resident of Greenwich Village, she was a supporter of the arts in NYC and befriended countless struggling performers. She was active in numerous volunteer organizations, taught intrapersonal process and was a dedicated teacher of spiritual, artistic and psychological training and methods. Her generosity of spirit and love of life was felt by all who came in contact with her. She is survived by a sister, Eleanor of LaMarque, TX, several nieces and nephews, and many other relatives and close friends. Memorial service will be at Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St., September 15, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the scholarship fund established in her memory (Brooklyn College Foundation c/o Gary Hafner, 54 Bette Circle, Vernon, CT 06066) or to Planned Parenthood.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUXTON, ALAN
description: BUXTON-Alan. August 21, 1996 Beloved husband, best friend. Sorely missed.

title: Some Large Accounts Move to New Agencies
description: Several advertisers have made some decisions on accounts.

description: QUEENS

title: After Clinton Signs Her T-Shirt, Woman Removes It in Jubilation
description: A young woman who joined hundreds of excited onlookers on Main Street on Saturday night to catch a glimpse of President Clinton stripped off her T-shirt in glee after the president signed it.

title: Essay; Parsing Gore's Speech
description: In his acceptance speech, Al Gore came across as earnest and knowledgeable. He did not descend into discomfiting sentiment, as he did twice before, and he overcame his habit of speaking in slow condescension.

title: Martin Excels in Big-Man Camp
description: The Nets chose Kenyon Martin as the No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft, assured that his broken leg would be healed in time for the season. Last week, Martin passed the first test.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBARD, MARION
description: GILBARD-Marion. Our beloved friend whose inner beauty will remain in our hearts forever. Irene, Manny, Joan and Donald Schaeffer and family

title: Comets Again Renew Their Berth in Finals
description: By now, after winning three straight league championships, the Houston Comets might seem blase about a chance at a four-peat. Not so today against the Los Angeles Sparks, who were left stunned at being swept from the Western Conference finals by a Houston team they dominated in the regular season.

title: The Politics of the Toga Era, Big, Bold and Often Bloody
description: With a busy percussionist pounding out portents, thunderclaps and sounds of war; a massive set of defaced, slightly skewed cement walls and an enormous disembodied hand to suggest a city shaken by cataclysm; a cast that plays the entire evening in a state of high dudgeon; and the whole production watched over by a mammoth, gold-painted bust of David McCallum (who plays the title role) dangling from a crane, the New York Shakespeare Festival's ''Julius Caesar'' has the garish bravado of a political convention.

title: Lucky Loser in Qualifying Becomes Tired Winner of the Bronx Classic
description: Hyung Taik Lee trudged to his car the afternoon of Aug. 11, tired and mildly depressed. Lee had just lost in the quarterfinals at a men's tennis Challenger event in Binghamton, N.Y., and missed making the main draw for his next tournament, the GHI Bronx Classic, by one spot. The qualifiers started play the next day.

title: Writing From the Heart But Drawing on the Mind
description: Amy Bloom is a psychotherapist. She is also a writer whose first book of short stories, ''Come to Me,'' was a finalist for the National Book Award in 1993 and whose most recent collection, ''A Blind Man Can See How Much I Love You,'' was recently published by Random House to critical praise.

title: A Fluke? Aliens? Angels? Hint: None of the Above
description: What's halfway between ''Touched by an Angel'' and ''The X-Files''? It's ''Mysterious Ways,'' a new series that NBC has been previewing on Mondays this summer, ahead of the show's run starting tomorrow night on the Pax network, NBC's family-friendly corporate cousin.

title: New Economy; An old-style deal maker takes up the cause of high technology with manufacturing over the Internet.
description: UNTIL recently, it was obvious which prominent Irwin Jacobs was the business executive exemplar of the new economy. That would be Irwin M. Jacobs, the computer scientist and electrical engineer who founded Qualcomm in San Diego in 1985. He built it into a thriving Fortune 500 company through pioneering innovations in cellular communications.

title: Global Arms Sales Swell to $30 Billion
description: International arms sales surged last year to nearly $30.3 billion, the highest level since 1996, and the United States solidified its position as the world's biggest arms dealer, according to an authoritative government report.

title: As Price of Progress, Turkish Villages Are Flooded
description: The minaret on the mosque was the last trace of the ancient village to disappear. Years after the homes and shops vanished, God's house stood as a mute witness before it, too, slipped beneath the waters of the Euphrates rising above the Ataturk Dam.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the start of scheduled service at the little-used MidAmerica Airport near St. Louis misstated the destination of the newest Pan Am flight there. It goes from MidAmerica to Gary, Ind., and continues to Pittsburgh and Portsmouth, N.H., not Portland.

title: Corrections
description: A credit line in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on July 27 for a report about a court hearing in the bankruptcy case of Toysmart.com misspelled the writer's surname. He was David J. Wallace, not Wallis.

title: Liberty Rides 19-0 Run to Knock Down Rockers
description: Yesterday's playoff game between the Cleveland Rockers and Liberty was not staged on the court in Madison Square Garden, but in the ring.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about studies on the care of children raised in families with stepmothers referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of Bowling Green State University, where an author of two such studies teaches. It is in Ohio, not Kentucky.

title: Harry Oppenheimer, 91, South African Industrialist, Dies
description: Harry F. Oppenheimer, the South African gold and diamond magnate who used his great wealth and considerable influence in the fight against apartheid, died on Saturday in Johannesburg. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENENHOLZ, SCHWEBEL, DEVORA
description: DENENHOLZ - Schwebel - Devora. It's been a sad year since our baby sister, Dovey, died. The love of our big Denenholz clan enfolds you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, WILLIAM
description: FURMAN-William. Age 91, on August 18, 2000. Loving husband of Mathilda and father of Roger. The kindest of persons with a sparkle in his eye, he had courage and principle, fighting for a decade in the anti-Nazi resistance movement within Germany. Family will receive friends on Tuesday, August 22, at 11:30 AM, and services will begin at 1:00 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, at 232nd St, Riverdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to either the International Rescue Committee or the Ethical Culture Society.

title: New Leader For the Police Fills a Need For Loyalty
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani rejected the advice of the departing police commissioner and the wishes of much of the rest of the department hierarchy. But the leadership team he installed in the city's highest profile agency makes perfect sense, if viewed through the mayor's prism.

title: A Classic Finish
description: Facing a courageous challenger who refused to give in, the world's best golfer showed the world just how good he is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENPREIS, PEARL
description: EHRENPREIS-Pearl. On August 19, 2000. Loving wife of Walter. Devoted mother of Susan and Sandra. Proud grandmother of Ariel. Beloved sister of Murray, George, Irving and Sy. Adored teacher for 37 years. She will always be in our hearts and minds. A memorial service will be held at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows on Monday, August 21, at 1:45 PM.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, JOSEPH J.
description: BLOOM-Joseph J. Beloved husband of Harriet; devoted father of Myron and Wendy; cherished grandfather of Adam, Ethan, Sara, Rachel, Amy, Debra, and Evan. Loving brother of Frieda, Aaron, and Bernie. Services Monday, 2 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Paul Bunyan Settling Into His New Cubicle
description: Zeldon Linn has worked on the railroads and in a sawmill. He has been a sergeant in the Army and a mechanic in a garage. At times for the last 15 years he has found work as a fisherman, crabbing and catching salmon in the Pacific Ocean off this struggling blue-collar town along the Oregon coast. At other times, he has found no work at all.

title: Bach Saw In Vivaldi A Chance To Fiddle
description: One of Antonio Vivaldi's ardent admirers was his contemporary Johann Sebastian Bach. In the first third of the 18th century music publishing on an international scale was in its infancy. Bach himself engraved his ''Clavierubung'' on copper plates, serving as his own production team, publicist and marketing director. When Vivaldi's scores made their way to Germany and came before him, Bach either copied them in his own hand or transcribed them, often in different keys and for different instruments. Frequently textures and counterpoint were ''filled out.'' Until a generation ago Vivaldi pieces in Bach's hand were misattributed by musicologists.

description: LEVINE-Mark. On August 18, 2000.
