title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CATHERINE M. (HEFFERNAN)
description: MURPHY-Catherine M. (Heffernan). 94, formerly of NYC, died on August 17, 2000, at the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, NJ. Predeceased by her husband Edward F. in 1952, and by her sister Marion T. Healey in 1997. Surviving is her niece Marion K. Healey Reilly and her husband Richard C. Reilly of Sea Girt, NJ. She also leaves great-nieces and nephews and many great-great nieces and nephews. Visiting will be on Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd, Wall, NJ. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Mark's RC Church, Sea Girt, NJ. Entombment will follow at St. Catharine's Mausoleum, Sea Girt, NJ.

title: A company's ad is rejected for coasting on the momentum of the Olympic Games.
description: IT'S called ''ambush marketing,'' and it refers to advertisers' attempts to capitalize on a sponsorship event without actually becoming sponsors. And with official sponsorships for the Summer Olympic Games selling for stratospheric sums, it is hardly surprising to officials at the United States Olympic Committee that the Games have frequently been targets of ambush.

title: Store Window Duets to Delight the Jaded
description: Anita Durst and Despina Stamos are onto something with Deli Dances in Times Square. The free series provides the ultimate in New York serendipity to passers-by in the area. On Friday at lunchtime, camera-toting tourists, shoppers and office workers joined dance fans on comfortable banquettes to watch shrewdly chosen modern-dance pieces in a simple black-box theater in an empty store on 42nd Street near Broadway. Outside, dancers performed in the store's display window, attracting quite a crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIS, DR. PRUDENCE B. (PRUDY)
description: CURTIS-Dr. Prudence B. (Prudy). On Sunday, August 20, 2000; of Elizabeth, NJ. Loving daughter of Anne B. Curtis; loving sister of Gale Curtis, Lorna Lee Curtis and Melissa Curtis; aunt of John Lee Curtis; brother-in-law of Robert Rogoshewski; longtime friend of Lucas Tsilifonis. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend the Service of Resurrection at First Presbyterian Church, Main Street, Orange, NJ, on Tuesday, August 22, at 11 AM. Memorials may be sent to the First Presbyterian Church, c/o Music Fund, Main St. and Scotland Rd, Orange, NJ 07050. A reception will follow in the Fellowship Hall. For more information, contact the August F. Schmidt Memorial Funeral Home, 139 Westfield Ave, Elizabeth, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANICK, HELENE M.
description: CANICK-Helene M. On Friday August 18th. Wife of Leon. Sister of Theo and Paul Siesage. Aunt of Kenneth and Lynn Sass, Judith Sass, Nigel and Susan Siesage, and Martin and Judith Vermond; and great-aunt to their children. Her friends here, and in England and Holland, will miss her.

title: Kerik Reaches Out to Minority Residents
description: A day after being named New York City's new police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik took the first step to fulfill his pledge to reach out to the city's minority residents, who are among the department's harshest critics.

title: Market Place; A Murdoch spinoff of Fox shares has been better for some than others.
description: THERE'S no business like show business.'' At least that is what the News Corporation's chairman, Rupert Murdoch, was trying to convince investors of when the company spun off 20 percent of Fox Entertainment Group, its entertainment unit, to the public in November 1998.

title: Wireless Internet Casts Its Shadow, and Substance, in New York
description: After the plates of spicy raw tuna and wasabi-crusted tofu were cleared from the table of a Greenwich Village restaurant one recent evening, discussion turned to probably the hottest topic among New York entrepreneurs these days: the wireless Internet.

title: Tourism Flowing Upriver to the Hudson Valley
description: Like more and more tourists these days, Glynis and John Seale, an English couple who live on the edge of the Cotswolds, decided to venture off the well-trodden sidewalks of Manhattan and make their way up the Taconic Parkway to travel the quiet back roads to a vineyard here in the heart of the Hudson Valley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, DAVID
description: FINE-David. Died in Tamarac, FL, on August 19. His life spanned three centuries and his contributions to his adopted country were many. Along with his late son Leon and late brother Norman, he built homes in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which are a tribute to his accomplishments. His word and his bond were greatly respected by business colleagues. Active in community causes, he was a Founder and Past President of Congregation Beth Israel of East Flatbush, a proud member of the Bayside Jewish Center and Member of the Board of Directors of the Tamarac, FL, Jewish Center. His life, together with that of his late, beloved wife, Anna, ardently revolved about his synagogue activities and other aspects of Jewish community life. He was a truly good and pious man. He is survived by his daughters, Renee F. Stave and Nadine F. Stock, grandchildren Gregg, Marjorie, Richard, Matthew and Wayne, and greatgrandchildren Elise, Yasmin, Soraya and Gianna. Services at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, on August 21, at 1 PM.

title: Reality Television Strikes a Stark Note in a New Show
description: Now this is reality TV.

title: On Medicare, Logical Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, PETER
description: SELIGMAN-Peter. Your life was taken too soon and we'll truly miss you, our nephew and cousin. Your success and accomplishments far exceed your years. A void will be felt by all those whose paths you've crossed. Our thoughts and love go to Bonnie, Bob, Sara, Stephanie, Suzanne, and all families. Susan, Fred, Eric and Brian

title: A Waterfront Park for Brooklyn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Makes Tire Recall Ad
description: Jacques Nasser, the chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, is making a television commercial to address Ford's handling of a tire recall affecting the Explorer, its sport utility vehicle.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR MOST WORKERS IN PHONE WALKOUT
description: The two unions representing more than 86,000 striking telephone workers reached a contract agreement yesterday with the nation's largest telecommunications employer, Verizon Communications, for about two-thirds of the strikers, indicating that organized labor still has a place in the New Economy.

title: Singapore Leader's Remarks on Anwar Case Unlikely to Harm Ties : Malaysia Shrugs Off Lee's Criticism
description: SINGAPORE  Muted Malaysian reaction to criticism by Lee Kuan Yew, the senior minister of Singapore, of the government's handling of the Anwar Ibrahim indicates that the fragile relationship between the two countries will not be seriously damaged by the comments, officials and analysts said Sunday.

title: Article 2000082190003025899 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: For Gore, Battle for South Begins Within Ranks of His Own Party
description: As if Vice President Al Gore did not have enough trouble in his native region, several prominent Southern politicians of his own party have been keeping their distance from him as they begin their own general election campaigns.

title: Sports of The Times; Female Gymnasts Braved an Audition, and a Trial
description: IT is never fun to be cut. In high school sports, the process can be as simple as scanning a list posted on the gymnasium wall.

title: Early Advocate of Seat Belts Now Heads Safety Agency
description: SUE BAILEY, the government's new highway-safety chief, insists she is not obsessive when it comes to safety on the roads. ''I'm not at all an anxious person,'' she says. ''I'm not compulsive.''

title: Campaign Aides Set Tone For Next Big Test in Race
description: A senior adviser to Vice President Al Gore accused Gov. George W. Bush today of trying to dodge -- or at least minimize the impact of -- presidential debates, while one of Mr. Bush's top aides said the governor was ready and willing but still mulling over the details.

title: Civil Liberties Head Protests Searches at Parks
description: The director of the New York Civil Liberties Union accused the city's police and parks departments yesterday of allowing unconstitutional security searches of people entering public parks to attend concerts and other privately organized events.

title: A Familiar Terror on the Road
description: Will we never learn? As the Firestone tire recall gives rise to a national storm of fear and blame, I fall into a funk of deja vu. I've been here before, terrified by defective products, seeing evidence of corporate callousness, and hearing the inevitable righteous cries for change.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is like a rock concert in some ways, huge masses of people getting really excited, but really, it's about spirituality, not entertainment.''

title: Lazio Finds New Friends In Democratic Stronghold
description: Vivian and Salvatore Frisicaro were wearing Hillary stickers, but when Representative Rick A. Lazio strode past them at the Pulaski Day parade here this afternoon, they did not voice fist-waving contempt or even just grimace like the longtime Democrats they profess to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, NEIL
description: OWEN-Neil. Age 48, died suddenly on August 18, 2000, while hiking the Appalachian Trail in Maine. Beloved husband, partner and best friend of Dee. Cherished brother of Roy and Nell. Devoted uncle of Matthew, Keri, Garth, Evan and Lee. Much loved brother in-law of Guy and Elisa. Treasured friend of Greg and Kenlyn. Neil's intelligence, humor and integrity touched the lives of innumerable friends, colleagues, clients and fellow mountain hikers. All those who knew and loved Neil will profoundly miss his wisdom and guidance. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 15, at 2:30 PM, at The Wainwright House in Rye, NY.

title: Say It: 'Impeachment'
description: Al Gore may have given the speech of his life accepting his party's nomination last week. But he avoided mentioning the elephant in the room: the impeachment of President Bill Clinton.

title: Critics Judge, and Are Judged, Across the Centuries
description: Just a few days ago I came across these lines from a letter Nietzsche wrote in 1884 about an essay by Ralph Waldo Emerson. Nietzsche was having it translated into German, he said, adding this lament: ''I do not know how much I would give if only I could bring it about, ex post facto, that such a glorious, great nature, rich in soul and spirit, might have gone through some strict discipline, a really scientific education. As it is, in Emerson we have lost a philosopher.''

title: Soda Company Offered for Sale By Bass Group
description: Britvic, one of Britain's largest soft-drink manufacturers, is for sale as part of Bass P.L.C.'s strategy to focus on its hotel business, executives close to Britvic said today.

title: Rome Journal; Love-In for 2 Million Youths, Heartily Blessed by the Pope
description: In the largest youth gathering ever held in the West, more than two million young people prayed, sang, swayed and got sprayed with water hoses today at a Mass celebrated by John Paul II on a hot, dusty, trash-strewn field in a suburb of Rome.

title: Knoblauch May Test His Elbow in Minors
description: Chuck Knoblauch, the Yankees' leadoff batter, may be within a week of returning to the team. He threw from 90 feet yesterday, taking ground balls and making throws from second base to first, and took batting practice.

title: A Learned Journal Aims to Defog Globalization
description: In the often rarefied world of foreign policy treatises, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is making a bet: that there are plenty of readers interested in a magazine about globalization and how it affects them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, VICTOR
description: SHERMAN-Victor. On August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Glenda; loving father of Beth and Nancy; father in-law of Andy and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Jessie and Sam. Friends may call Sunday 7-9pm, Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Funeral service Monday, August 21, 11:30 at Frank E. Campbell. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to NYC Chapter, Leukemia Society, 475 Park Ave. South, 21st floor, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SRYBNIK, JAY
description: SRYBNIK-Jay. The Board of Governors and members of the Seawane Club record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member, Jay Srybnik. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Evelyn and family. Michael H. Kerr, President

title: For Incumbent Legislator in the South Bronx, a Primary Rematch
description: Few local political races are laced with the kind of unvarnished acrimony seen in a primary contest being waged in the 32nd Senate District in the South Bronx between an incumbent state senator who is one of the Democratic Party's most loyal soldiers and his predecessor, an ardent enemy of the party organization.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNIK, SYLVIA
description: RESNIK-Sylvia. 93, of Miami, originally from New York, passed away August 19, 2000. Loving wife of the late Irving Resnik; beloved mother of Cynthia Resnik and Marilyn (Felix) Scott; loving grandmother of Neil Scott and Melissa Powell; and proud great-grandmother of Austin and Ethan Powell. A memorial service will be held Monday, August 21, 6:30 PM, at the Baptist Hospital Chapel, 8900 North Kendall Drive, Miami. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Catholic Hospice, L'Chiam Jewish Hospice Program, 14100 Palmetto Frontage Rd, Suite 370, Miami Lakes, FL 33016. For information, contact All Care Funeral Home.

title: Is Modern Rock Radio Getting Old?
description: From New York's K-Rock to Los Angeles's KROQ, FM radio stations with a so-called modern format have flourished the last few years by promoting the cutting-edge sounds of grunge, electronica and the latest hip-hop and rock hybrids.

title: To Ensure That the Poor Get Legal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Take Advantage of Dodgers' Giveaways
description: In the ninth inning of a close game, there was nobody sitting in the front row of seats beside the camera box near the Mets dugout at Dodger Stadium. So when Mark Grudzielanek hit a foul pop and Mets catcher Mike Piazza tumbled over the fence to catch it, he landed on concrete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIMEL, EUGENE
description: BEIMEL-Eugene. Age 77, on August 15, 2000, entered into eternal rest. Survived by five cousins. The family requests donations to the American Cancer Society, local chapter.

title: Is Faith Too Dominant?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lightning Puncher, Not Just a Clown Prince
description: The punches from the featherweight champion Naseem Hamed came so fast that even if you were staring at Hamed's hands, you missed them. One man blindsided by their speed was Hamed's opponent, Augie Sanchez.

title: Cancer Study Getting Help From the City
description: New York City is about to become the largest contributor to a broad medical study to determine the effectiveness of an experimental X-ray screening test for diagnosing and treating the early stages of lung cancer.

title: Most Recent Killing May Push Germans to Act on Hate Crime
description: The German word for hatred is ''Hass'' and Angelika Adriano spits it out with hissing venom. Hatred, she says, is what she feels for her husband's killers. ''Only hate.''

title: Born on the Bayou; Dying There, Too
description: PURPLE CANE ROAD

title: In America; This Is Class Warfare?
description: ''This is my tranquillity,'' said Jose Valles. ''Sitting here waiting for the bus. Because most of the time I am stressed. Why? I will tell you. Because I don't have enough money.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYLE, MICHAEL P., SR.
description: COYLE-Michael P., Sr. Of Hackensack on August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Ruth A. (nee McGinness). Devoted father of Dr. Michael P., Jr., Brian J. Esq., Dr. Kevin T., Dr. Dennis G., Terence S. and Mary K. Coyle. Also survived by 14 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral Liturgy Tuesday, 10 AM, at Holy Trinity R.C. Church, Hackensack. Entombment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Hackensack. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ (201-836-0202).

title: U.S. Official and Airlines to Meet About Delays and Cancellations
description: A record number of flight delays and cancellations has prompted officials in Washington to call an unusual meeting on Monday in the hopes of finding ways to ease conditions for beleaguered air travelers.

title: Dictionary Publishers Going Digital
description: A logomachy -- n. an argument about words -- is brewing on the Web.

title: Consumers' Views Split on Internet Privacy
description: In the continuing battle between Internet companies that want to use customers' personal information to deliver tailored advertisements and services and privacy advocates who want stricter controls over how this information is used, consumers themselves appear to be of two minds.

title: Cocaine Quietly Reclaims Its Hold as Good Times Return
description: There is a nice little jazz bar in the East Village. The drinks are a fair price and the mix of people is good. The only problem is that it's tough to get into the bathroom.

title: From Trash to Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Harry F. Oppenheimer Dies; Influential Foe of Apartheid

title: A Waterfront Park for Brooklyn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Out, But Dawes And Chow Make Team
description: Shannon Miller went twisting into the air during her first vault tonight but found herself too low in the air and too short on her landing. With a horrendous thud, her legs jammed into the padding like post-hole diggers.

title: An Aching Hampton Says He'll Skip Start
description: Mike Hampton said Saturday that if he felt better today, he expected to work a bullpen session. If things went well, Hampton might then be cleared to start on Tuesday in San Diego.

title: Leader's Job Description
description: To the Editor:

title: The Motivated MetroStars Make the Most of a Matinee
description: After losing three of their previous four games and also losing their premier goalkeeper on Wednesday to an act they felt should have been punished by the league, the MetroStars had plenty of incentive to perform at their best this afternoon.

title: Torre Opts to Accentuate Positive After the Latest Yankee Debacle
description: Joe Torre can share his unedited emotions with the world every day to condemn, confront or blame, as manager of the Yankees. But he seems to sift carefully through his thoughts, to identify the most presentable, and he might have required a giant mental colander after the Yankees gave away another game yesterday.

title: Patents; A virtual bazaar haggles with online shoppers; and new, catchier CD packaging is created.
description: IN the struggle to show a profit, Internet retailers seek any advantage that might make them stand apart in the competition to convert ordinary consumers into online shoppers.

title: Music Videos Enter the Digital Age
description: A go-go dancer wiggles as the music starts to play on the video for the song ''Nicotine & Gravy.'' The song's performer, Beck, appears briefly on screen, and then is soon replaced by a throbbing montage of photographs and glaring graphics.

title: Smith Had Odds Stacked Against Him
description: The ominous signs had been piling up during training camp for cornerback Otis Smith. He was coming back from a twice-broken clavicle -- first injured during training camp last season and again in the first game after he returned from the original injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZICKLIN, ROBERT
description: ZICKLIN-Robert. Died on August 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Carole. Devoted father of Adrienne and Diana. Grandfather of Benjamin. Cherished brother of Stanley and Gilbert. Closest of cousins to Larry and Rita, and loyal friend to many. A consummate New Yorker, he lived his life as a gift. We will miss him deeply. Service Tuesday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMBERG, MEYER
description: SAMBERG-Meyer. 85, of Riverdale, NY. Died August 18. Graduate of City College, 1935. Received MBA at Columbia. Taught merchandising at Textile High School. Worked with architects and builders designing new lighting technology in the construction industry, representing universities and major new buildings. During WW II was civilian aide to the War Department in the Alaskan defense. He leaves his dear wife Sonya; daughters Ellen McCall, Karen Samberg; son Robert Samberg; grandchildren Sarah McCall (Ephron) and Jack McCall; greatgrandson Jordan McCall; sister Dorothy Shaw; nephews Ernest, Peter and Fred Shaw. Services Tuesday, August 22, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76, 10:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHECTER, MARTIN H.
description: SCHECTER-Martin H. Fifteen years-August 21, 1985-August 21, 2000. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law, and grandfather. Always in our hearts. Your sons, Richard and Willia

title: Respect Aside, May's Revenge Falls Just Short
description: When they were growing up in Southern California as junior golfers, Bob May set records that Tiger Woods would break.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNER, REV. JOHN, O.F.M., CAP.
description: CONNER-Rev. John, O.F.M., Cap. The Capuchin Friars of the church and friary of St. John the Baptist, 210 West 31st Street, sadly announce the entrance of their brother, John, into Eternal Life on August 19, 2000, at the age of 48. His faith and living with cancer was an inspiration to all. Wake: Sunday, 7-9:30 PM, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, St. Clare Friary, 110 Shonnard Place, Yonkers, NY. Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Heart Church, Yonkers, on Tuesday, August 22, 2000, at 11 AM. Burial: St. James Cemetery, Manchester, CT, on Wednesday. Contributions may be made to St. John's Food Pantry, 210 West 31st Street, NY, NY 10001 or Catholic Charities, 1011 1st Ave., NY, NY 10022. For information, contact Whalen & Ball Funeral Home, Yonkers (914) 965-5488, www.obitdetails.com

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about new technologies in ortho dontics misidentified the firm that managed the most recent round of financing for Align Technology, which makes a clear-plastic alternative to braces. It was Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, not Robertson Stephens.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a bid for Avis Group Holdings by Henry Silverman, chief executive of the CendantCorporation, misstated the amount paid by Cendant in 1999 to settle accusations of accounting fraud. It was $2.8 billion, not $2.8 million.

title: David N. Edelstein, 90, Judge In Federal Court for 48 Years
description: Judge David N. Edelstein of United States District Court in Manhattan, who in 48 years on the bench presided over two of the Justice Department's most historic undertakings -- the antitrust action against I.B.M. and the ongoing effort to rid the Teamsters union of corruption -- died on Saturday. He was 90 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Privacy and Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cream of the Crop
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Do Races Differ? Not Really, Genes Show
description: In these glossy, lightweight days of an election year, it seems, they can't build metaphorical tents big or fast enough for every politician who wants to pitch one up and invite the multicultural folds to ''Come on under!'' The feel-good message that both parties seek to convey is: regardless of race or creed, we really ARE all kin beneath the skin.

title: Ways to Stop Extreme Allergic Reactions
description: A Brown University student who knew she was allergic to peanuts died after dining on chili that, unbeknown to her, had been thickened with peanut butter. A friend faces the same risk if she inadvertently eats celery. A Minnesota school boy who had been playing in a field with friends barely survived being stung by angry yellow jackets. A Pennsylvania man with a known allergy to bee stings died while snorkeling after being stung by jellyfish. And a New York health care worker had to find a new career after a near-fatal reaction to the latex in surgical gloves and medical equipment.

title: 'Working Families' Becomes a Theme Meant to Attract Female Voters
description: The phrase is suddenly everywhere. In his acceptance speech last Thursday, Vice President Al Gore mentioned ''working families'' nine times. Party officials told other speakers to use the phrase, and they did, over and over. Now the Gore campaign is printing up signs with it and repeating it time and again on the road.

title: Major Bidder For City Trash Agrees to Pay $252,000 Fine
description: The Arizona company bidding on a New York City contract to export most of the city's residential trash has agreed to pay a $252,000 fine after investigators determined that a trash disposal company it acquired last year had violated city rules and overbilled a small number of its city clients.

title: Shakespeare, Still Hiding From the Biographers
description: WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE

title: Patients Are Discovering 'My Doctor, the Author'
description: Each year it seems that more and more physicians are putting aside their stethoscopes for word processors. Indeed, the most casual look at publishers' book lists or major magazines and newspapers demonstrates that an increasing cadre of doctors is writing best-selling works of nonfiction, novels, plays, motion pictures and essays. Even professional conferences are being held to encourage physicians with literary aspirations.

title: YOUNG AND CONDEMNED/A special report.; Whether to Kill Those Who Killed as Youths
description: If the state of Georgia electrocutes Alexander Williams on Thursday, as planned, five people who committed murder when they were 17 will have been put to death this year in the United States. That is more than in any year since 1954, when six teenagers were executed in Florida and Georgia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MARK
description: LEVINE-Mark. On August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Vera; loving father of Carrie Draws, Moacyr Vendramin, and Juliana Vendramin; adoring grandfather of Christopher Draws; dear brother of Scott Levine and Barbara Levine. He will be profoundly missed by his family, friends, and business associates at SRO Entertainment, Inc. Service Tuesday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Cabletron Makes Acquisition
description: BOSTON -- Enterasys Networks, a unit of Internet equipment maker Cabletron Systems Inc. (CS.N), said on Monday it agreed to acquire a small Massachusetts firm for about $170 million in stock to boost its product line for connecting corporations to secure private networks.

title: Mrs. Clinton Sidesteps Race That Has Stirred Tensions
description: Steering clear of a political struggle that has stirred ethnic tensions in New York's Democratic Party, Hillary Rodham Clinton declined today to offer her backing for Representative Eliot L. Engel, a five-term Bronx Democrat who is facing a September primary challenge orchestrated by black and Hispanic leaders.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about an advertisement for PacificHealth Laboratories that exploited the Summer Olympic Games, misidentified the company's advertising agency. It is Linett & Harrison; Alan Taylor Communications is its public relations firm.

title: Russians Blame Cuts in Budget For Sub Fiasco
description: Speaking in somber tones and at times struggling for words, Russia's defense minister, Marshal Igor D. Sergeyev, offered a defense tonight of the military's failure to rescue the crew of the stricken nuclear submarine Kursk. In a nationally televised interview, he told Russians that the armed forces of the once-powerful Soviet empire had been ''robbed and stripped'' in the last decade and were operating on half the budget they required.

title: HYUNDAI LEADER SELLING SHARES
description: In a move that took creditor banks by surprise, Chung Ju Yung, the founder of the Hyundai Group, is seeking to sell his stake in its profitable automotive subsidiary, Hyundai Motor, to foreign investors. Originally, the founder had been expected to sell a large piece of his stake of Hyundai Motor, South Korea's largest automotive company, to domestic creditor banks, but they were demanding what he considered an excessive discount. Hyundai had said earlier that Mr. Chung would lower his stake in Hyundai Motor to 3 percent from 9.1 percent to help spin off South Korea's biggest automaker. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS TO ACQUIRE PYRAMID INDUSTRIES
description: A thermoplastic and electrical products maker, the Lamson & Sessions Company, agreed yesterday to acquire Pyramid Industries, a privately held manufacturer of custom fiber optic conduit systems, for about $52 million in cash. Pyramid, based in Erie, Pa., mainly manufactures conduit used to protect fiber optic cable. In 1999, Pyramid reported sales of $43 million. It employs about 300 people in five locations in Pennsylvania, Arkansas and Florida. Lamson & Sessions, based in Cleveland, makes plastic pipe, conduit and consumer electrical devices. Lamson & Sessions' Carlon unit manufactures outlet boxes, watertight conduit, and fittings for the electrical, telecommunications and construction industries.

title: THERMO TERRATECH TO SELL LANCASTER LABORATORIES
description: Thermo TerraTech Inc., a provider of environmental cleanup services, agreed yesterday to sell its Lancaster Laboratories unit to the investment firm Goldner Hawn Johnson & Morrison Inc. for about $72 million in cash. The unit, based in Lancaster, Pa., provides environmental, food and animal-health testing to industrial and drug companies. Thermo TerraTech is 87 percent owned by the Thermo Electron Corporation. The closely held Goldner Hawn Johnson & Morrison, based in Minneapolis, manages investment funds that own stakes in industrial companies. Its $200 million Marathon Fund will own a majority interest in Lancaster Laboratories. Thermo TerraTech, based in Waltham, Mass., had sales of $307.3 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSCHEL, CHAIM
description: MUSCHEL-Chaim. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Chaim Muschel, beloved father of its devoted Rebbitzin, Faygie Bienenfeld (and Rabbi Yaakov Bienenfeld), and extends heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Shiva, ending at 3 P.M. August 25, will be observed at 1493 E. 9th St. (between N and O), Bklyn. Services at 7 A.M. and 7:30 P.M. Stephen J. Apple, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, NEIL
description: OWEN-Neil. Age 48, died suddenly on August 16, 2000, while hiking the Appalachian Trail in Maine. Beloved husband, partner and best friend of Dee. Cherished brother of Roy and Nell. Devoted uncle of Matthew, Keri, Garth, Evan and Lee. Much loved brother in-law of Guy and Elisa. Treasured friend of Greg and Kenlyn. Neil's intelligence, humor and integrity touched the lives of innumerable friends, colleagues, clients and fellow mountain hikers. All those who knew and loved Neil will profoundly miss his wisdom and guidance. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 15, at 2:30 PM, at The Wainwright House in Rye, NY.

title: WEB MUSIC BATTLE HEATS UP
description: MP3Board.com, a Web site that provides links to and searching of music sites, asked a federal court in New York to declare that Gnutella, a software used to exchange music files via the Web, does not violate copyright law. The request escalates the legal battle between the site and the recording industry. The industry sued MP3Board.com in June in federal court, asserting that the site linked visitors to pirated music. MP3Board contends that it cannot be held liable for merely providing links to sites outside its control. In its latest brief, MP3Board wants the court to establish Gnutella as lawful, which would mean that providing ways to search Gnutella sites was lawful as well.

title: Dark Side Of Quirks In Behavior
description: One of the many odd experiences of being a psychiatrist is discovering that seemingly benign traits can have a dark and even pathological side to them.

title: Open Short Sales Decrease
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange slipped 1.2 percent in the most recent monthly period, the stock exchange reported yesterday.

title: Lena Cymbrowitz -- Brooklyn Assemblywoman, 43
description: Lena Cymbrowitz, a first-term state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 43.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Custody Battle Rages On in Details

title: About the Tables
description: The Times is revising its stock market tables today, listing prices in dollars and cents rather than in fractions.

title: Assessing Honesty in Clinical Drug Trials
description: Clinical drug trials, in which volunteers are given drugs or placebos so that researchers can gauge the effectiveness of a particular treatment, are a linchpin of modern medicine.

title: China's Migrants Find Europe's Open Back Door: The Balkans
description: The chaotic lands of the Balkans have become the latest gateway to Western Europe for tens of thousands of illegal immigrants from China, South Asia and Middle Eastern countries like Iran and Iraq, according to Western diplomats, local officials and the increasing number of refugees who get caught.

title: India Seeks More U.S. Visas
description: NEW DELHI -- India's software industry said on Monday that it had urged Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee to push for a raise in work permit visa limits for technology professionals during his U.S. visit next month.

title: Bush Sees Military Decline And Pledges a Turnaround
description: Gov. George W. Bush sharply attacked the Clinton administration's military policies today, saying that the country's armed forces had plummeted to a state of serious physical and emotional disrepair and that he was committed to reversing the decline.

title: In Reverse, California Acts To Cap Some Electric Bills
description: With electricity rates doubling or tripling for some consumers in San Diego, the California Public Utility Commission took a step back from the recent deregulation of the market today and narrowly voted to cap electric bills for some residential and business customers in that city.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 21 about the lack of research by major drug companies into diseases that affect impoverished Africans referred incorrectly to the discovery that the drug Eflornithine, developed as an anticancer drug, cures African sleeping sickness. It was made through research by several scientists, not by chance. A letter dated July 14 from a researcher pointing out the error was addressed to a vacationing correspondent overseas and received only yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, JOSEPH J.
description: BLOOM-Joseph J. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Joseph J. Bloom, a cherished friend of the Jewish community. Mr. Bloom shared a deep devotion to Jewish and humanitarian causes with his friend and business partner, Irwin Hochberg, former chair of UJAFederation's board of directors. A dedicated philanthropist, Mr. Bloom has left a legacy of hope for all those who have benefited from his generosity. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mr. Bloom's beloved wife, Harriet; his children, Myron and Wendy; his grandchildren, Adam, Ethan, Sara, Rachel, Amy, Debra, and Evan; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Shares Increase as Investors See No Fed Action on Rates
description: Stock prices rose yesterday as investors bet the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates today or the rest of the year. Technology, financial and drug shares led a late surge.

title: ING SALE OF DE BROE EXPECTED
description: The Dutch financial company ING Groep is expected to sell its stock brokerage firm Williams de Broe to eliminate overlap that would result from ING's 127 million pounds ($190.5 million) purchase of Charterhouse Securities. Williams de Broe's senior managers have the right to buy ING's nearly 80 percent stake, held by Banque Bruxelles de Lambert, a subsidiary. Outside parties that may be interested include KBC Bancassurance, a Belgian banking and insurance company, and BNP Paribas, a French bank. A price for Williams de Broe has not been discussed. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDECK, MANFRED
description: LANDECK-Manfred. On Aug. 21, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Elsa, loving father and father in law of Howard and Randye, Robert and Bethamy. ''Opi'' is the dear grandfather of Marissa, Arielle, Ethan and Allary. Funeral Tuesday 9:00am Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave.exit 17 Saw Mill, Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Teenagers Surveyed On Brand Switching
description: Teenagers said they would be likely to switch from one brand or retailer to one that supports a good cause -- if price and quality were equal -- according to the second annual Cone/Roper Cause-Related Teen Survey. The study was commissioned by Cone Inc. in Boston, a division of the Omnicom Group, and conducted by Roper Starch Worldwide in New York.

title: Bilingual Education Wasn't a Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Board to Act on ConAgra Complaint
description: The government said today that it would ask a judge to review whether ConAgra Inc., the second-biggest United States food company, threatened employees who tried to organize a union at its beef-packing plant in Omaha.

title: Polls Show a Postconvention Bounce in Popularity for Gore
description: Six public polls conducted for news organizations since the Democratic convention have all shown Vice President Al Gore leading Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, though in two cases by only a single percentage point, a difference that is statistically insignificant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINES, MARION E.
description: HINES-Marion E. Of Boston and Marstons Mills, died on August 19, in Marstons Mills at the age of 81. Husband of Julie (Viele) Hines, of Boston and Marstons Mills; Father of Sheldon K. Hines of Concord, MA; Julian B. Hines of Boston, MA; Hadley (Hines) Chianese of Cambridge, MA; Brother of Lawrence R. Hines of Sedona, Arizona; C. Lee Hines of Morrow Bay, California. Also survived by three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Kings Chapel in Boston, MA at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Friends of the Public Garden, 90 Mt Vernon St, Boston, MA 02108. Nickerson-Bourne Funeral Home 154 Rt. 6A, Sandwich, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, VICTOR I.
description: MORRISON-Victor I. Jr., by his own hand on August 18th, 2000 in Old Lyme, Connecticut. Born Montecito, California on July 8, 1924 to Col. Victor I. Morrison and Nancy Park Morrison. Predeceased by a sister, Patricia, a brother, Park, and his first wife and mother of his children, Betsy Holmes McLeod of Pittsburgh. Survived by his son Victor III of Hinesburg, Vermont and family Patty Dunn, Park and Zelie Dunn-Morrison; by his son, Park of Rockport, Maine and family, Melissa Chapman, Storrey and Sarah; by his daughter, Susan of Alberquerque, New Mexico and his beloved wife Elsie Paulson Chapman Morrison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, C. PHILIP
description: WILSON-C. Philip. The faculty, staff, and candidates of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. C. Philip Wilson. We extend our condolences to his wife Christine, his children Cynthia, Marc, and Scott, and his entire family. Robert A. Glick, M.D. Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SRYBNIK, JULIUS
description: SRYBNIK-Julius. The Management and Staff of Kerns Manufacturing Corp and Associated Companies mourn the untimely passing of their Partner, Officer and Member of the Board. His wise council and true friendship will be missed by all who knew him. We extend to his wife Evelyn, son Jed, daughter Leslie and his dear brothers Simon and Louis and all their respective families, our most sincere heartfelt sympathy.

title: Last-Moment Snag Stops Ewing Trade
description: The Knicks were on the brink of trading Patrick Ewing, the cornerstone of their team for the past 15 years, but a four-team deal that would have sent him to Seattle unraveled last night. The Detroit Pistons, who were to acquire seven lesser-known players, called off the trade over contract considerations. The Knicks would have acquired Vin Baker from the SuperSonics and Glen Rice and Travis Knight from the Lakers.

title: Russian Music From Russians (Plus a Ringer For the Tenor)
description: At a time when many critics and classical music lovers fret that orchestras around the world are becoming stylistically homogenized, the Russian conductor Valery Gergiev has been a tireless proselytizer for the distinctiveness of the orchestra of the Kirov Opera and Ballet, of which he is the artistic director. Of course informed musicians anywhere can learn to play Russian repertory sensitively. But hearing Russian musicians and singers perform operas that they have absorbed from long tradition and constant renewal can be a revelation.

title: Oral Cancer Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Intels Barrett Short on Substance
description: August 22, 2000

title: U.S. Projects School Growth Throughout the 21st Century
description: The federal government said yesterday that the nation's elementary and secondary schools would enroll a record 53 million students this fall, continuing a decade-long rise, and could expect that number to jump to 94 million by the end of the 21st century.

title: Metro Business; First Union to Buy Tribus
description: The First Union Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank, agreed yesterday to buy closely held Tribus Companies for an undisclosed price to offer more insurance products to businesses in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: With One Foot Out the Door, Ewing Steps Back
description: Patrick Ewing, the stoic 7-foot center who for 15 years tried to be the player to bring a championship to the Knicks, was on the brink of being traded last night before a 4-team, 13-player deal hit a significant obstacle.

title: Losing My Father, One Day at a Time
description: President Clinton recently announced a $50 million research program to advance the early diagnosis and investigate the possible prevention of Alzheimer's, a disease that now afflicts more than four million people in our nation. One of them is my father, and, like others who have seen their parents' mental faculties assaulted by this illness, I was grateful for the president's decision, wishing only that my father were still young enough to benefit.

title: The Big City; Negotiating Sexual Politics On 'Survivor'
description: SEAN KENNIFF, the neurologist from Long Island, was voted off the ''Survivor'' island last week, to the satisfaction of many viewers, especially women. He had seemed the prototypically clueless, unreliable guy.

title: For White, the Term Injury Riddled Is No Clich
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 21  Most of the surgical scars Rick White sees are smaller than his, which wraps around his right elbow, thick and obvious, maybe eight inches long. It is the only sign that something was once wrong with an arm that has quickly become invaluable to the Mets.

title: When Tax Cuts Turn Into 'Warfare'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIG, ROBERT JEFFREY
description: SWIG-Robert Jeffrey. Born in San Francisco on January 20, 1961, Robert J. Swig peacefully passed away in the early morning hours of August 19, 2000 at his Hillsborough home after a short illness. He leaves behind his wife of ten years, Kim Baldwin Swig; their three beautiful daughters, Sarah, Leah, and Rebecca; his twin brother, Kent; his brother, Steven; and his brother-in-law, Ted Parker. He was preceded in passing by his father, Melvin M. Swig; his mother, Marcia Hove Swig; his grandmother and grandfather, Mae and Benjamin Swig; and his sister, Judith Swig Parker. Bob was deeply loved by a large circle of family and friends. He was widely admired for his personal warmth and his ability to enhance the best qualities of his acquaintances. Bob was a devoted family man, and was noted for his generosity and his sincere friendship. Bob was president of Swig Enterprises, a financial and real estate investment firm. Previously, Bob devoted almost 20 years to the hotel business, managing his family's San Francisco Fairmont Hotel and the Fairmont Hotel Management Company nationally. Bob was deeply loved and respected in the hospitality industry. His inspiration made Mason's Restaurant one of the best in San Francisco. During a 5-year period, Bob served as the Swig family's ownership representative for the Fairmont Hotels in the capacity of Director of the Executive Committee. His knowledge of hotel operations and construction was important in his leadership in renovating many of the Fairmont Hotels. Bob was active in charitable activities, serving as vice president and director of the 49ers Foundation and the Columbia Park Boys Club. He was a great supporter of athletics and served as a coach on his daughter Sarah's winning soccer team. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that memorial gifts be made to the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 15125 Holcombe, Houston Texas 77030.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE BANK UNITED
description: Washington Mutual Inc., the largest United States savings and loan association, agreed yesterday to buy the Bank United Corporation for about $1.49 billion in stock to sell more financial services in Texas. Bank United holders will swap each share for 1.3 Washington Mutual shares, valuing Bank United, based in Houston, at $42.66 a share. The stock fell $1.50 a share yesterday, to $40.875, and Washington Mutual was down 75 cents, to $32.0625. Bank United gives Washington Mutual 155 additional branches in Texas. After the purchase, Washington Mutual expects to cut costs by $87 million by 2002, in part through the elimination of 600 to 650 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORN, MILTON J.
description: ZORN-Milton J. August 21, 2000. Beloved husband and best friend of Norma for 48 years. Most loving father of Amy, the late Janet, and son-in-law Steven. Happiest grandfather of Jonah. Dear uncle and brother-in-law, kind friend and colleague of greatest integrity. We are all blessed to have known and loved you. We will not be the same without you. Funeral services Wednesday, 12:00 noon at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale. Contributions to the New York Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation are appreciated.

title: Uranium Offered for Sale on the Internet
description: August 21, 2000

title: History of Medical Art Gets Pre-Columbian Chapter
description: A medical doctor with a scholarly interest in pre-Columbian art appears to have pushed back the date of the earliest scientific medical illustration by several centuries with his study of bizarre two-faced ancient Mexican figurines known to art historians as the ''pretty ladies of Tlatilco.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, VICTOR
description: SHERMAN-Victor. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Victor Sherman, a dedicated leader and valued member of the Executive Committee of our Plumbing and Heating Division. We extend our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Glenda; his daughters Beth and Nancy; his two grandchildren; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair Saul Klausner, Chair, Plumbing and Heating Division Jack Weksler, Co-Chair, Plumbing and Heating Division John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Digging Up The Perfect Potato, and Other Joys
description: Liz Lerman has made a vibrant, provocative career out of fixing on a moment -- an idea, an emotion, an everyday event -- and making it come alive in simple, plain-spoken dance. God is in the details in her work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBRER, JEAN
description: DOBRER-Jean. June 18, 1954August 18, 2000, of Chicago. Beloved wife of Robert Suomala. Wonderful daughter of Kenneth and Florence Dobrer. Treasured sister of Nina Dobrer. Dear aunt of Emily, Amanda, Sussana and Nicholas Hoffman. Dear step daughter of Janet Dobrer. Best friend to so many in Chicago. Her passing leaves a wound that will never fully heal. Memorial donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: INSIDE
description: The Genesis of a Slogan

title: Cook's Lack of Control Proves Fatal for the Mets
description: The crowd started hooting on Dennis Cook's first ball to Dave Magadan with the bases loaded in the bottom of the 10th tonight. The hoots became roars when ball two sailed by. In his second inning of work, Cook had already walked four hitters. The unpredictable Mets left-hander was about to unravel again.

title: NOVARTIS PROFIT RISES 12%
description: The third-largest drug manufacturer in Europe, Novartis A.G. of Switzerland, reported a 12 percent rise in net income for the first half of the year, attributing the growth partly to a pickup in sales of Diovan, a hypertension treatment. The company said profit jumped to 4.19 billion Swiss francs, or $2.43 billion, from 3.74 billion Swiss francs a year earlier. Novartis warned that it expected a slower third quarter than initially expected. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Ex-Intelligence Agent Arrested in Britain on Return From Exile
description: He had lived in self-imposed exile for the past three years, infuriating the British government with a series of disclosures about the country's two ultra-secret security agencies. But today David Shayler, a former security agent who calls himself a patriot and a whistle-blower, returned to Britain to be branded a criminal.

title: Microsoft Reiterates Appeal Should be Reviewed by Federal Appellate Court
description: August 22, 2000

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TELERGY INC., -- Dewitt, N.Y., which is building a high-capacity network of optical fiber throughout the Northeast, reached a $20 million deal to help El Paso Energy Corp. begin a national telecommunications business.

title: Robert E. Thibault -- Times Copy Editor, 69
description: Robert Edward Thibault, a staff editor on the national desk of The New York Times for 31 years, died Saturday in Manhattan. He was 69 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Thomas Rebounds From Poor Showing
description: Dave Thomas streaked up the left sideline, intercepted a short pass from Kerry Collins and broke toward the end zone before the play ended. It was merely a preseason practice outside Giants Stadium, but Thomas needs some positive reinforcement after the cornerback's poor performance Friday against the Jets, and provided that for himself with the play he made against his team's starting quarterback.

title: Focus on Immune Disorders
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Accord Hits New-Economy Notes
description: From wage increases to greater pension benefits to less mandatory overtime, telecommunications union workers in 12 Eastern states from Maine to Virginia and the District of Columbia appear to have been the victors in the strike that ended yesterday for more than half of the 86,000 workers who walked off their jobs 16 days ago.

title: Report Questions Antibiotics for Earache
description: With rates of resistance to antibiotics growing in this country, many doctors have long advocated a more measured hand when it comes to dispensing the drugs.

title: Lynn Townsend, Ex-Chrysler Chief, Dies at 81
description: Lynn A. Townsend, a retired chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, died Thursday at Botsford Continuing Health Center in Farmington Hills, Mich. The cause of death was not disclosed. He was 81.

title: As Timber Prices Rise, So Do Thefts of Trees
description: For those without moral qualms, it has to be one of the last remaining bargains in New York State: Chop down a tree worth hundreds, even thousands, of dollars and -- if caught -- pay a paltry $10 fine.

title: CHILE TO BE INVITED INTO TRADE BLOC
description: The South American common market, or Mercosur, is expected to invite Chile to join the trade bloc in early September. Negotiations will try to bridge the gap between Chile's 9 percent import duty, and Mercosur's tariffs, which start at 15 percent. Mercosur is composed of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, PETER
description: SELIGMAN-Peter. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Peter Seligman, whose tragic death Friday morning stunned virtually all New Yorkers. Our deepest sympathies go to his fiancee, Sara Sinek; to the Seligman family; and with personal condolences to the Konigsberg family, whose work and support on behalf of our organization's mission has enabled us to help millions of people every year. May the legacy of their mitzvot bring them comfort in this time of mourning. Larry Zicklin, Chair, Board of Directors James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: MetroStars Are Upset At Diallo
description: The MetroStars are developing a great deal of animosity for Tampa Bay's Mamadou Diallo, who kneed Mike Ammann in the rib cage and stepped on his face during last Wednesday's game. Ammann is out for the season with injuries that forced him to stay in a Tampa, Fla., hospital until yesterday, when he was finally able to get on a plane home to New Jersey.

title: Medical Schools Discover Value in Dispensing Compassion
description: The late dean of the Harvard Medical School, Robert Ebert, delighted in telling applicants that a would-be student should be first in his or her class, a concert violinist without an ego, an Olympic skating champion who has climbed Mount Everest and has lived in a tree hut in the Amazon, and a relative of Mother Teresa.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. The dollar rose against the euro on expectations the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates unchanged today. In New York, the euro settled at 90.15 cents, down from 90.63 cents on Friday.

title: Article 2000082291941057570 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, DR. JAMES D.C.
description: BLOCK-Dr. James D.C. Died August 18, 2000. Beloved husband of Dr. Angela B. Dellepiane; dear brother of Gloria Putnam; loving uncle of Nelson, Mary Helen, and Catherine. He is also survived by his grandnieces and grandnephews, and his cousins Bruce and Barbara, Edward and Wilmot and their children. He brightened the lives of all his relatives, friends and colleagues. He leaves a deep void in our lives, as well as in the lives of his relatives and friends in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

title: Woods's Great Skill, Unshakable Will
description: To understand the genius of Tiger Woods, you must appreciate not only his skill, but also his will.

title: Aid for Deaf as Possible Cost-Saver, Too
description: Cochlear implants have been used for almost a decade to help thousands of profoundly deaf children, but some two-thirds of insurance companies are often unwilling to pay, citing a lack of evidence that the devices are cost-effective.

title: U.N. READIES TEAM TO CHECK WEAPONS HELD BY THE IRAQIS
description: The United Nations has assembled a new team of arms inspectors that is ready to enter Iraq within weeks, raising the prospect of another confrontation with President Saddam Hussein over his weapons programs.

title: Regulators Raise Questions on Merger of Europe Exchanges
description: Only weeks before shareholders vote on a planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges, British and German regulators said today that the two bourses had not yet devised adequate rules to guarantee the financial transparency of what would be Europe's dominant transnational stock market by far.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 15 about business deals by Pearson P.L.C. of Britain misstated the title of an executive and the unit he runs. Peter Jovanovich is chief executive of Pearson Education, not president of Pearson Publishing. The article also misspelled the name of a Pearson spokesman. He is John Fallon, not Phallon.

title: ReplayTV Withdraws IPO
description: WASHINGTON -- ReplayTV Inc., a media company that lets television viewers ``watch what they want, when they want,'' said on Monday it withdrew an initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: Nancy Padian; Battling AIDS in Africa by Empowering Women
description: Lounging in a high-floor room at the St. Francis Hotel, drinking coffee served in perfect porcelain cups, Dr. Nancy Padian was far from the sad, overcrowded streets of Harare, Zimbabwe, but they and their beleaguered people remained on her mind.

title: Philippines to Drop Charges on E-Mail Virus
description: Philippine authorities dismissed all charges today against Onel A. de Guzman, the 24-year-old college dropout whom investigators had accused of responsibility for a destructive computer e-mail program that wreaked billions of dollars in damage on companies worldwide in May.

title: REPLAYTV POSTPONES OFFERING
description: It is rewind time for ReplayTV, a company that makes digital video recorders. On Friday, the Mountain View, Calif., company withdrew its application for an initial public offering of stock. The offering of 8.5 million shares at $13 to $15 a share, had been simmering on the back burner since January, waiting for investor interest to rebound. Meantime, shares of Replay's main competitor, TiVo, have fallen sharply, to $18.69, after reaching a peak of $78.75 in January. Buzz Kaplin, a Replay executive, said the company wanted to sell more equity stakes, but could not do so with a pending offering. ''A number of opportunities came up, and we didn't want to be wallflowers forever,'' Mr. Kaplin said. Time Warner, NBC and Disney already own stakes in Replay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROOKHORN, HENRY M.
description: CROOKHORN-Henry M. Born on February 1, 1912. Died August 20, 2000. Lifelong resident of Manhattan. Devoted husband of Evelyn nee Rundblad. Loving uncle of Edmund W. Cherished great-uncle of Michael, Erin and Alyssa. Former 47-year employee of NY Telephone Company. WW II veteran, Master Sergeant, Europe Theater, awarded Croix de Guerre medal. Visitation Tueday, 2-5, 7-9, Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Ave., NYC. Interment Wednesday 11 AM, St. John's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTON, SHELLEY J.
description: BARTON-Shelley J. Died August 16. Age 74. Born in Bensonhurst, NY December 21, 1925. WW II Veteran. BS Syracuse University, 1948. Survived and cherished by daughters, Lin and Antigone, wife Priscilla and companion Jean Gatehouse. Music lover and art collector. Veteran NYC publishing executive. Spent the bulk of his career at Fawcett Publications and retired from Petersen Publishings. He was a long time member of the Friar's Club, member of the New York State Veterans Boxing Association. President of the Slivovitz Institute and a regular fight announcer in the New York area. Shelley traveled extensively, was fluent in many languages and for many years conducted group walking tours in Dublin reciting the works of James Joyce. Considered by many to have one of the broadest and most varied circle of friends and interests of anyone in his profession. Shelley leaves behind in addition to his family large group of individuals who loved and admired him for his loyalty and humor. His quick fire NYC brand of wit was unique and memorable. Shelley's distinguished ''turn of the century'' look and style was very much his trademark. Shelley Barton never went out of style. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, WARREN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Warren, 48. Of Scarsdale, NY, on August 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Janet, loving father of Peter & Laura, devoted son of Ruth and the late Seymour Goldstein, adored brother of Joel Goldstein and Arlene Rhodes. Compassionate, intelligent and loving friend. He will be missed by all. Funeral service today 1PM at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, New York.

title: Strike's End Begins Easing Of Tensions; Phone Workers Mixing With Managers on Jobs
description: Roger Doucette's head was spinning as he reported to work yesterday for the first time in two weeks. Like tens of thousands of other Verizon Communications employees, Mr. Doucette had gone on strike at the country's largest local telephone company. Now, as he returned to his job as a customer-assistance representative in Braintree, Mass., he weighed the consequences.

title: Russia's Suspicion of Foreign Sub a Reminder of Cold War Chases
description: Russian officials' assertions yesterday that the submarine Kursk sank after a collision, most likely with a foreign submarine, echoed the kind of suspicions that were common during the cold war, when on more than a dozen occasions, Russian and Western submarines banged into one another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRATH, WILLIAM H.
description: MAGRATH-William H. Of Bronxville, on August 19, 2000. Husband of Elinor Lee Magrath. Brother of Dorothy A. Magrath. Retired traffic manager, Ingersoll Rand. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday, August 23, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLEVIN, JAMES V.
description: SLEVIN-James V. On Saturday August 19, 2000 of Long Eddy, NY, formerly of Wayne, NJ. Before retiring in 1991, he worked for New York Life Ins. Co. for 38 years as a General Manager of the Knickerbocker Office in the Empire State Building in Manhattan. A devoted family man, Jim is survived by his wife of 46 years Patricia (nee Dunigan); son James and his wife Elizabeth along with their children Michael and Lori; daughter Gayle DeNicola and her husband Dante; son Thomas and his wife Kimberly. Also surviving are his mother Bridie (nee Daveny), brothers Jack, Patrick and sister Eileen. His cherished daughter Maureen predeceased him in 1975. Relatives and friends are invited to his visitation at Vander May Funeral Home in Wayne, NJ on Tuesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A funeral mass will be offered Wednesday 11 AM at Our Lady of Consolation RC Church, Wayne. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the St. Benedict's Prep. Alumni Fund, 520 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. Newark, NJ 07102-9128 or Holy Cross Church, Star Route 97, Callicoon, NY 12723 would be appreciated. For more information and a photo visit vandermay.com.

title: Pepper Spray Ends First Lady's Visit
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton's appearance at a community center here ended abruptly this afternoon when a woman in the audience inadvertently discharged a pepper-gas canister in her purse, sending people, many of them coughing, out of the building.

title: For Gore, Life on Mississippi Is Full of Details
description: For Vice President Al Gore these days, there is no devil in the details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLERT, DR. ROBERT
description: ENGLERT-Dr. Robert. Of Lindenhurst, on August 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Merril; loving stepfather of John Busching, Kathleen Busching, Loreen Karpovich, Peter Busching and Jennifer Busching. Cherished son of John; caring brother of John and brother-inlaw of Alice, adored step grandfather of Joseph and Christopher; fond uncle of Christine, John and Ellen. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-10 PM at Lindenurst Funeral Home, Inc, 424 South Wellwood Avenue, Lindenhurst. Religious service Wednesday, Mass of Christian Burial, on Thursday 10 A.M. Our Lady of Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Wyandanch. Interment Breslau Cemetery, Lindenhurst.

title: Marked for Death
description: Using the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers recently peered into the heart of the star cluster M15, an assemblage of several hundred thousand stars about 40,000 light-years distant in the constellation Pegasus, hoping to solve an astronomical mystery. Their target was a pinkish cloud, nestled by the upper left of the cluster's core. Such clouds, known as planetary nebulae, are blasted from dying stars about the mass of the sun, but the stars in M15, some 12 million years old, were thought to be too light to engage in such pyrotechnics. Because more massive stars evolve and burn out faster than lighter ones, astronomers deduced that there should not be any stars as massive as the sun still burning in M15. They suspected that the cloud, named Kuestner 648, would be shown to harbor a double star, but none was detected. The dying star remains a mystery.

title: The Cost of Keeping Gore's Promises
description: There is no doubt that the Clinton-Gore administration's proudest economic accomplishment was balancing the federal budget. Al Gore would like voters to trust him as the guardian of that legacy and of the surplus that has replaced the deficits of the 1980's and early 1990's. Hence, in his campaign, he makes much of his plans to use more of projected surpluses for paying down the national debt than would George W. Bush. Mr. Gore also talks a great deal about the ''cost'' of Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut.

title: Nearly Naked Guy Cloaked in Self-Confidence, and a Tattoo
description: Can rock 'n' roll be serious? Not very, many would say. Rock addresses earthy matters, like flirting and shopping and blowing off steam after a hard work week. It's amateur at heart, silly in its soul. Even ambitious rockers need to leaven their aspirations with wit and humility. Otherwise they'll be branded with rock's scarlet P, for pretentiousness.

title: Simple Method Found to Increase Crop Yields Vastly
description: In a stunning new result from what has become one of the largest agricultural experiments ever, thousands of rice farmers in China have doubled the yields of their most valuable crop and nearly eliminated its most devastating disease -- without using chemical treatments or spending a single extra penny.

title: Singing All About Women, Backed by the Music of Mali

In the music of her country, Mali, the singer is the changeable, impulsive element within orderly pointillistic lattices, an individual carrying a message in a complex social order.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a medical study of an experimental X-ray screening test for diagnosing and treating early stages of lung cancer paraphrased one doctor's concerns about the test incorrectly. The doctor, Barnett Kramer of the National Institutes of Health, says that although the test, known as spiral CT screening, may help cancer detection, whether it will help patients live longer remains undetermined. He did not say that the test does nothing to help patients live longer.

title: Birds and Dinosaurs' Bony Likeness
description: Offering another suggestive, but not yet conclusive, piece of evidence that birds evolved from dinosaurs, researchers have found that the microscopic bone structure of birds resembles those of the dinosaurs thought to be their ancestors.

title: BOOTS SHARES RALLY ON RUMOR
description: Shares of the Boots Company P.L.C., a British drug and beauty retailer, rose 3 percent, to 516 pence, on a report in The Independent on Sunday, a British newspaper, that the company may be purchased for $9 billion by Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the expansion-minded American retailing giant. Analysts said it was hard to see the rationale for such a deal as the two companies pursue markedly different business strategies. Wal-Mart concentrates on large out-of-town retail sites, while Boots' stores are smaller and placed in most of Britain's main urban shopping districts. Both companies declined to comment. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: APBNEWS MAY BE BOUGHT
description: SafetyTips.com, a site that specializes in safety consulting and training, may be near a deal to buy APBNews.com, a faltering Web site covering crime, justice and safety that sought Chapter 11 federal bankruptcy protection last month. APBNews said it had agreed to be purchased for $950,000, but the deal is subject to competition from other bidders and would need the approval of the federal bankruptcy court in New York. SafetyTips.com, based in Waltham, Mass., and backed by Rare Medium Group and Apollo Management, will provide APB with financing for continuing operations. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: CUT-RATE DATA SERVICES

The two Silicon Valley companies plan to charge 0.5 cent to 2 cents for each kilobyte of information handled, compared with services that now cost up to 32 cents a kilobyte. The service could speed the migration of electronic business transactions from private networks to the public Internet. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Washington Expects Delay in Vietnam Trade Deal

title: Officer and Inmates Accused Of Defrauding Other Prisoners
description: Doing hard time at a federal prison in Allenwood, Pa., did not stop two inmates from coming up with a scheme to make a little cash from their fellow convicts, all with the help of a New York City police officer, federal prosecutors said.

title: Beethoven as He Is Rarely Heard

At Bard College last weekend the approach was different: not restraint but bombardment, by means of six concerts supported by lectures, discussions and films, Mr. Kagel's included. Yet perhaps the effect was like what a year's silence would have produced: a freshening of responses.

title: Ford Reduces Output to Help Recall of Tires

title: BOK FINANCIAL AGREES TO BUY CNBT BANCSHARES
description: The BOK Financial Corporation, a multibank holding company, agreed yesterday to buy CNBT Bancshares Inc. for about $91.5 million in cash. BOK will pay $18.22 for each CNBT share. With the acquisition, BOK Financial, based in Tulsa, Okla., will enter the Houston market. CNBT Bancshares, a Houston-based $424 million banking organization, is the parent company of Citizens National Bank of Texas and has six bank operations in the Houston metropolitan area. In Nasdaq trading, CNBT Bancshares went up 56 cents, to $17.06, and BOK was up 6 cents, to $17.38.

Nelson has been unhappy with the way Torre has used him lately, but when Torre brought him in to pitch an inning late in yesterday's wipeout of Texas, Nelson took that as a good sign.

description: With his exit from office just 15 months away, and members of his administration leaving for the private sector, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani faces the classic challenge of finding replacements who will both protect his legacy and sustain the administration's momentum through the lame-duck period. The mayor's decision to replace the outgoing New York City police commissioner, Howard Safir, with the former correction commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, fits these requirements nicely.

title: SPANISH HOTEL TAKEOVER
description: The leading Spanish hotel company, Sol Melia S.A., said it would buy Tryp S.A. for $326 million in cash and stock as part of its strategy to acquire more urban properties in Spain. Until now, the Majorca-based company had concentrated on resort hotels. Analysts said Sol Melia, majority owned by the Escarrer family, is also hoping to make itself more attractive for a potential merger or takeover. Sebastian Escarrer, the vice chairman, told Bloomberg News that Sol had talked to bigger chains. The deal will place Sol among the top 10 hotel chains, owning or managing more than 100,000 rooms in 410 hotels.

title: New Data in Duel of Biotech Corn vs. Butterflies
