title: Stop Arguing and Start Debating
description: With the Republican and Democratic conventions completed, the next potentially decisive event in the presidential campaign will be the debates between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. Both camps have begun arguing over the format and number of debates. Mr. Bush's team wants to consider options other than the nationally televised one-on-one format sponsored since the late 1980's by the Commission on Presidential Debates. The obvious public interest is for Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush to have a chance to face and challenge each other directly, with questions coming from journalists or an audience of citizens. There should be at least three such debates on nationwide television in prime time, beginning as soon as possible.

title: Canadian Company Bids $3 Billion for Wireless Network
description: The Telus Corporation, the largest telecommunications company in western Canada, made a brash move to become the country's biggest wireless telephone network today with an offer worth $3.1 billion for Clearnet Communications Inc. of Toronto.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about organizations that seek to manage some of New York City's lowest-performing schools referred incorrectly to the status of Boys Harbor Inc., a nonprofit group in Harlem. Its application for a charter school license was approved by the trustees of the State University of New York in January and was approved by the Board of Regents in April; the school is scheduled to open in Harlem this fall. Boys Harbor did not fail to get a license.

title: Addressing Silent Cancers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNEN, PHILIP
description: TANNEN-Philip, 74. Passed away August 19, 2000. Survived by wife Janice, daughters Elissa (David), Tracey (Gary) and his grandchildren, Megan, Paul, Zachary, Carly, Sean. ''Too bad it had to end, it was so much fun.'' Private services were held on Monday, Aug 21, 2000. Hillside Mortuary, phone 800-576-1994.

title: Lieberman and Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Man to Face Charge In Beating at Orphanage in 50's
description: A federal judge is allowing a New Jersey man to return to Canada to answer charges that he severely beat a boy in an orphanage where he worked as a member of a Roman Catholic order in the 1950's, according to court records and published reports.

title: Giuliani Selects Cancer Treatment, but Stays Mum
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has settled on a treatment regimen for his prostate cancer. But that is all he wants to disclose for now about how he is trying to beat the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, SHIRLEY
description: SHULMAN-Shirley. On August 20th, 2000. Beloved wife of Irving. Loving mother of Marcia, Robert and Michael. Adoring grandmother of Joshua, Gabriel, Damon, Evan, Gabriel, Zoe, Davy and Hannah. Service Tuesday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: To Protect Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: Herbert Scheftel, 92, a Backer of Pan Am Building
description: Herbert Scheftel, an investor in real estate and television stations, died on Wednesday in New York. Mr. Scheftel, who lived in New York and had residences in East Hampton and Le Touquet, France, was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, CATHERINE
description: O'NEILL-Catherine (nee Early) of Riverdale, N.Y. (native of County Tyrone, Ireland) on August 19, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Daniel O'Niell. Loving mother of Mary Margaret Henshaw, Daniel O'Neill, and Kathleen Flynn. Devoted grandmother (Mamie) of Raymond, Daniel, Christopher, Kerry Marie, Paul, Elizabeth, William, Thomas, Catherine, Brian, John Patrick, Peter, Brian Paul, Margaret, Christine, Kerry and Mary Beth. Cherished greatgrandmother of Bridget, Conor, Daniel, Paul C., Kevin, Paul, Megan, Matthew, Miles, Christine, John and Christopher. Dear sister of Marian Toal and Rose McMahon. Relatives and friends may visit at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Riverdale, N.Y. on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, Riverdale, N.Y. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Returning Luxury to Fifth Avenue
description: One bright afternoon last week, at the Prada store on Fifth Avenue, two young women who appeared to share the same parents and the same attitudes about highly elective surgery, passed a baby and platform shoes back and forth between them. With some fall shoes already sold out, they gave up and moved downstairs to the handbag section. ''I have the Chanel, I have the Louis, I have the Gucci,'' said the redhead to the brunette, as a saleswoman showed them a burgundy bowling bag. ''I want tan,'' said the redhead. ''I need tan.''

title: Article 2000082293973719033 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: 2 of Biggest Pepsi Bottlers Reach $331 Million Deal
description: Furthering a consolidation among bottlers of Pepsico beverages, the Whitman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire PepsiAmericas Inc. for about $331.7 million in cash and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CYMBROWITZ, LENA
description: CYMBROWITZ-Lena. The Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty mourns the untimely passing of a colleague and friend. Lena was the founding Director of our Project Machson and a supporter of all those in need. May Steven, Jennifer and Jay be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Merryl H. Tisch, President William E. Rapfogel, Executive Director

title: ANTIGENICS AGREES TO BUY ACQUILA BIOPHARMACEUTICALS
description: Antigenics, which is developing vaccines for cancer, agreed yesterday to buy Aquila Biopharmaceuticals Inc. for about $40 million in stock to gain access to its infectious disease-fighting products and research. Antigenics will issue 2.5 million shares, swapping 0.2898 share for each Aquila share. Antigenics said the swap values Aquila stock at about $4.67 a share. Antigenics is based in New York and has a research site in Woburn, Mass. Shares of Antigenics rose 31 cents, to $16.19, and Aquila was up 6 cents, to $4.44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZICKLIN, ROBERT
description: ZICKLIN-Robert. Died on August 20, 2000. Beloved husband of Carole, devoted father of Adrienne and Diana, loving father-in-law of David, proud grandfather of Benjamin, cherished brother of Stanley and Gilbert, dearest cousin to Larry and Rita, adored son-in-law of Rosalind Adler and loyal friend to many. A comsulate New Yorker, he lived his life as a gift. We will miss him deeply. Service Tuesday, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donationas may be made to The American Museum of Natural History.

title: Controversy Over Diamonds Made Into Virtue by De Beers
description: A little over a year ago, De Beers, the mining colossus straddling the world's diamond trade, confronted double jeopardy. Human rights groups were accusing it of buying illicit diamonds from African rebels and rulers who used the proceeds to help pay for their wars. The essential mystique of its product, nurtured over decades of artful image-building and brawny cartel management, seemed threatened by association with these so-called blood diamonds.

title: Bush Focuses on Education and Other 'Tough Problems'
description: The Republican presidential campaign of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Dick Cheney began showing two new commercials in 21 states yesterday. One deals with Mr. Bush's education proposals and the other declares that now is the time to deal with ''tough problems,'' such as Social Security, declining moral values and education.

title: BOEING GETS APPROVAL TO BUY HUGHES SATELLITE BUSINESS
description: The Boeing Company has won approval from the Defense Department to buy the Hughes Electronics Corporation's satellite-making business. The Pentagon notified the Federal Trade Commission last week that it had no objections to the $3.75 billion transaction, which will make Boeing the world's largest maker of commercial satellites. Regulators at the F.T.C. and the European Commission are reviewing the purchase to ensure that Boeing does not use the acquisition to push customers to its own launching vehicles. Shares of Boeing, based in Seattle, rose $2.06, to $47.75, and Hughes, based in El Segundo, Calif., rose 25 cents, to $31.13.

title: Loans to Buy AIDS Drugs Are Rejected By Africans
description: The United States' offer of $1 billion in annual loans to finance the purchase of anti-AIDS drugs in sub-Saharan Africa has been rejected by South Africa, one of the countries most devastated by the disease, health officials say. Namibia has also rejected the offer, and other nations in this stricken region are voicing serious reservations, the officials say.

title: Authorities Investigating Death Of Apartments' 'Grandmother'
description: A 65-year-old woman known to her neighbors as the unofficial grandmother of her apartment building on the Upper West Side was found dead in her apartment yesterday with a plastic bag over her head, the police said.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Ice Cubes and Ice Ages

title: Bioengineers Turn to Hen's Teeth
description: Spelling the possible demise for the phrase ''as scarce as hen's teeth,'' a team of researchers at Harvard Medical School and elsewhere has succeeded in making chick embryos grow tooth buds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, HON
description: EDELSTEIN-Hon. David N. The judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York express deep regret at the death of our esteemed colleague and friend. We extend our profound sympathy to Judge Edelstein's family. Michael B. Mukasey, Chief Judge

title: Lady Liberty or Mother Russia?; As Emigres Go Home, Others Defend Life in America
description: The Russians are not, as the old movie would have it, coming. They have gone.

title: Editorial Observer; In Chile, the Balance Tips Toward the Victims
description: Until the last few weeks, testimony about the horrors committed by the Chilean military after Gen. Augusto Pinochet's coup in 1973 has virtually all come from one side, the victims'. The military refused to cooperate with Chile's truth commission, and provided very little information for the families of those who disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOLOMON, LILLIAN RUBIN
description: SOLOMON-Lillian Rubin. The 100th anniversary of her birth. August 22, 1900-December 18, 1994. We miss you, Mother. Horac

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Manager of Hedge Fund Fiasco Seeks to Repair His Reputation
description: John Meriwether is ready to apologize, but not ready to quit.

title: HEARTLAND ADVISORS URGES DONNELLY TO CONSIDER SALE
description: Heartland Advisors Inc., the biggest shareholder of the Donnelly Corporation, with a 27 percent stake, has urged the company, the world's largest maker of automobile mirrors, to consider a sale of the company or other action to increase its stock price. In an Aug. 15 letter to Donnelly's board that was disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Heartland, a Milwaukee-based money manager, said Donnelly's rising profits had not been rewarded in its stock price. Shares of the company, based in Holland, Mich., rose 38 cents yesterday, to $13.63.

title: What do drinking milk and 'Survivor' have in common?
description: THE creators of the long-running ''milk mustache'' campaign saw a natural connection between the need to drink milk and the hit CBS television show ''Survivor.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVELL, ANNE A.
description: COVELL-Anne A. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY, died August 18th. Survived by two daughters, Alice Ballin of Stamford, CT, Ruth Allen of Chaddsford, PA, and one sister, Sylvia Miller of Minneapolis, MN. Burial was held privately.

title: Sale: Web Address, Unused, Not Cheap
description: The Internet address www.flu.com is for sale, and its sellers think it is worth $1.4 million.

title: Simpler Monitoring Device for Diabetics
description: For many diabetics, the task of monitoring their blood-glucose levels is an onerous one.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZICKLIN, ROBERT
description: ZICKLIN-Robert. Dear friend. His wit, intelligence and warmth will be greatly missed. All our love. Shelly, Rory, Simon and Hilary.

title: Neo-Nazis Show No Remorse at Trial, and a German Widow Is Overcome
description: The German widow of an African killed by neo-Nazis broke down today after about an hour spent silently facing the three young men accused of his murder on the opening day of their trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWINSKY, AKIVA
description: LEWINSKY-Akiva. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany (Claims Conference) deeply mourns the passing in Israel of Akiva Lewinsky, our honorary treasurer. Our beloved friend Akiva served tirelessly on behalf of Shoah survivors as Claims Conference vice president and treasurer as well as chairman of our Negotiating and Allocations committees. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his family. May Akiva's memory remain a blessing. Rabbi Israel Miller, president Gideon Taylor, executive vice president Saul Kagan, executive vice president emeritus

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALTERS. The euro dropped against the dollar after a surprise decline in German business confidence. In New York, the euro settled at 89.79 cents, down from 90.15 cents on Monday.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEBATES

title: THE CHEF
description: GROWING up, I lived above my parents' bakery in the Black Forest region of Germany.

title: GOLF: YESTERDAY; 2 Gold Medalists At the U.S. Amateur
description: Jim Salinetti and Jeff Wilson each received a gold medal yesterday at the 100th United States Amateur Championship for shooting the low score during the 36-hole stroke-play competition.

title: Crme Anglaise
description: Because there are egg yolks in creme anglaise, the most important rule is to prevent curdling. If the liquid becomes too hot, it cooks instead of incorporating the enriching and thickening yolks. That results in bits of scrambled eggs in your custard. Therefore, you will need to cook it slowly, stirring continously. Youll strain it at the end, though, to remove any solid bits despite your best efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAVETY, GEORGE W.
description: MAVETY-George W., 63. Died suddenly on August 19, 2000 at his home in Andover, New Jersey. Born in Newboro, Ontario, Canada, he spent many years as a teacher in Canada and the U.S. before eventually becoming involved in magazine publishing and at the time of his death, he was the owner of more than 50 companies, primarily in the publishing field. In the past few years, he had shifted his interests to real estate and owned many commercial and residential properties in the metropolitan New Jersey area. He was a generous benefactor to many humanitarian and philanthropic causes and organizations. Among memberships he held were: American Civil Liberties Union, Amnesty International, Caron Foundation Board of Directors, English-Speaking Union, Friars Club of New York, Hellenic Plato Lodge o. 1129, National Coalition Against the Death Penalty Board of Directors, Periodical and Book Association of America and Yacht Club de Monaco. He is survived by a brother, Philip P. Mavety of Newton, New Jersey, and a sister, Jacqueline Cartwright of Oakville, Ontario, Canada. He was previously married to the late Susan Hawkins and the late Margeurite Laird. He is survived by his wife, Gertrud Hartmann Mavety and their son, Bruce, as well as his children from his previous marriages: Geraldine Mavety, Robert Mavety, Charles Mavety, George Mavety, Jr.; Keith Mavety, Sandford Mavety, their half-brother, David Laird; his companion, Annette McDonald, and their son, Chad Mavety, and his half-brother, Earl Chang; an uncle, Gerald Bell, and an aunt, Mary Wilson, both of Kingston, Ontario, Canada; numerous grandchildren and a host of other relatives & friends. A memorial service will be conducted by Amandus J. Derr, Senior Pastor, at St. Peters Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Ave at 54th Street, New York City, on Thursday, August 24, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Smile Train Foundation, (payable to and mailed to National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, 317 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016.)

title: Mild Heat Wave
description: Green chilies from Hatch, N.M., are making their annual visit to Kitchen, 218 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), and this year the shop will roast these moderately hot peppers for you. All you have to do is peel and dice or stuff them -- a fresh soft cheese would be nice. Roasted or unroasted, they are $3.95 a pound and are available until Sept. 15.

title: The Aromas of the East, Wafting Up and Down Stairs
description: With its shelves, counters and bins laden with grains, nuts, dried fruits, spices and condiments for Middle Eastern and Indian cuisines, Kalustyan's has long been one of New York's most fragrant and exotic markets. The 56-year-old store, at 123 Lexington Avenue (28th Street), recently had a face-lift, getting a spiffed-up entrance, and has expanded up the staircase to the second floor, which had been an office.

title: Knicks Are Still Exploring Trades for Ewing
description: Patrick Ewing is not battling only his aching joints anymore. Public opinion is posting him up, telling him to leave town. His own organization even planned a conference call on Monday night to announce the separation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, DIANE
description: GREENSTEIN-Diane (De-De) Samuels. Tragically taken on August 20, 2000. Beloved wife of Dennis, loving mother of Judd, Lael and Adra, dear daughter of the late Margie and Morris Samuels, sister of Natalie (Bill) Carroll, Ira Samuels, sister-in-law of Enid and Marvin Goldsmith, daughter-inlaw of Gabrielle and the late Joseph Greenstein. Mentor to many nieces, nephews, dear friends and colleagues. Services Wednesday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund, Sierra Club or a charity of your choice.

title: Trials Are Moving From Arenas to Courts
description: While most American athletes are preparing for events like swimming, gymnastics and track and field at the Summer Games next month in Sydney, Australia, a number of them are preparing for the burgeoning Olympic sport of arbitration.

title: Compensation Increases for Net Employees
description: Compensation Increases for Net Employees

title: Far East Prospects Emerging
description: Hideo Nomo stirred quite a fuss when he joined the Dodgers in 1995. And there was always a media sideshow around Hideki Irabu in New York. Now names like Masato Yoshii, Mac Suzuki and Kazuhiro Sasaki dot major league rosters.

title: Lawyers for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mint Joins the Grown-Ups' Table
description: OF all the common herbs used in cooking today, mint seems to have the least cachet. It lacks the versatility of parsley, the accessibility of basil or dill, the trendiness of cilantro and the seductiveness of rosemary. Too often it is seen, but not eaten, as a dessert garnish.

title: So How Bad Were Mets? Even Bell Got to Pitch
description: The first pitch rainbowed in at 47 miles an hour he said it was his eephus pitch -- and Joe Vitiello let it go by. Nobody in professional baseball had ever seen this pitcher, and there was no scouting report.

title: Whitman Puts Limit on Aid for a Newark Arena
description: The long-awaited bargaining over state aid for a new sports arena here has begun in earnest.

title: FRANCE TELECOM PLANS OFFERING
description: The French telephone giant France Telecom S.A. is planning an initial public offering for its mobile unit in its fourth quarter, according to its chief executive, Michel Bon. The company expects to raise 14 billion euros. The mobile unit will include Orange P.L.C., Britain's third-largest mobile operator, which France Telecom acquired for $37.5 billion in June. The sale will be France Telecom's second this year; it raised 1.9 billion euros from selling shares in Wanadoo S.A., its Internet division. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: U.S. Contract to British
description: BAE Systems Applied Technologies, a unit of the British military and aerospace company BAE Systems P.L.C., won a $454.4 million contract from the Federal Aviation Administration, the company said today. Under the 10-year deal, the company will offer research and other services as part of the United States National Airspace System Architecture and Capital Investment Plan. The BAE unit, based in Rockville, will also provide personnel, sites and materials.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the dismissal of an executive by a retail chain misidentified the company. As the article reported, it was Office Depot, not Home Depot.

title: Company Briefly Suspended For Cable-Spool Accident
description: Transit officials said yesterday that they had temporarily suspended a Queens electrical company because of an accident in the subway last week in which a 7,500-pound spool of electrical cable barreled down a staircase and injured two women. The company was involved in an almost identical accident in the subway last year, officials said, and was asked at the time to improve its safety procedures.

title: Forget Social Security, Worry About This Instead
description: It is a projected shortage that is casting a shadow over American health care: a decade from now, exploding demand for registered nurses to care for America's graying population could outstrip supply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, HARRY G.
description: WEIN-Harry G. Died August 21. Cherished husband and best friend of Geraldine for fifty-four years. Adoring father of Steven, Amy and Nancy and father-in-law of Nela, Tom and Dan. Proud grandfather of Julia. Beloved brother of Myron and Leon. Memorial service, Wednesday, August 23 at 10:30 AM at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWD, THOMAS E.
description: DOWD-Thomas E., Jr. On August 21, 2000. Resident of Pearl River, NY. Business representative and trustee of International Union of Operating Engineers Local 14-14B. Beloved husband of Mary, devoted father of Chelsea and Collin, dear brother of Keith and wife Caroline, cherished son of Eileen and Tom, beloved son-in-law of Janice Rogan, beloved brother-in-law of William and Gwyn Rogan of Denver, CO. Reposing at Michael J. Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main St, New City, NY. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral mass on Friday, 11 AM, St. Anthony's RC Church, Nanuet, NY. Cremation private.

title: Policy, Privacy and Protection
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Clinton Defends the Outlay Of $1.3 Billion to Colombia
description: President Clinton today defended his decision to sign a waiver freeing up $1.3 billion in anti-drug assistance for Colombia, saying that the country is improving on human rights even though the government of Andres Pastrana has yet to meet all the conditions imposed by Congress.

title: NEXTEL BUYING CHADMOORE WIRELESS
description: Nextel Communications, a wireless company, agreed to buy the Chadmoore Wireless Group, a provider of mobile-radio services, for $160 million in stock. Chadmoore and its business units provide mobile-radio services in 180 markets in the United States that cover about 55 million people. Nextel, controlled by the cellular pioneer Craig McCaw, will issue Class A common shares for the purchase. Nextel sells walkie-talkie and traditional phone calling service on one handset to customers that include financial trading desks and construction crews. The company said it had 1999 sales of $3.33 billion, while Chadmoore's sales totaled $6.07 million.

title: AOL, Inktomi, Adero Ink Internet Content Deal
description: August 24, 2000

title: Annoyed About Something, and Telling the World
description: The young members of the rock band At the Drive-In look as if they want to be transparently earnest. At the Knitting Factory on Monday, its singer, Cedric Bixler, underfed and lanky, sang in a high and reedy voice, the sound of the new postmacho rock star. He flailed and jumped and vaulted off anything he could find onstage. There's no let-up in this band's music. The performers are constantly at the threshold where planned song form turns into a blur of hyperventilating mania.

title: 3M PLANS TO MAKE THREE ACQUISITIONS BY OCTOBER
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, whose 50,000 products include Post-It Notes and electronic circuitry, said yesterday that it planned to make three acquisitions by October that would add $400 million a year in sales by 2003. The unnamed companies make electronics and telecommunications products, said Harry C. Andrews, executive vice president of electro and communications markets. Minnesota Mining, which was hurt by the recession that swept Asia in late 1998, wants to add sales that will help it to post more consistent earnings growth.

title: Volcanic Rock Dressed for Dinner
description: Roberto Domiziani, left, is a ceramic artist who also makes hand-painted tabletops, above, from volcanic stone that he quarries in Deruta. ''It was my art that brought me to commerce,'' Mr. Domiziani said. He oversees each stone slab as it is dipped in glaze, hand painted by a team of artists and fired in gigantic kilns, which Mr. Domiziani makes available to local artists. The heavy tables cost from about $1,600 for a top 23.6 inches in diameter to nearly $5,000 for one 59 inches in diameter, plus shipping, from www.domiziani.com or by e-mail: ceramica @domiziani.com. Retailers in the United States include Courtyard Collections in Augusta, Ga., (706) 854-9133 and Etruscan Imports in Vero Beach, Fla., (561) 978-0885.

title: U.N. Is Urged to Upgrade Peacekeeping Department
description: A panel of international experts recommended today that the United Nations peacekeeping department, under attack for a series of disasters in recent years, be enlarged and professionalized, with intelligence-gathering functions that were essentially forbidden during the cold war.

title: Assemblyman Says He's Fighting Harder in Rematch
description: As the chairman of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. has long been known for masterminding the strategies of a host of political races in his borough and beyond. And so the thinness of his re-election victory two years ago, by just 677 votes in the Democratic primary, was something of an embarrassment.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think we cannot walk away from the potential to save lives and improve lives, to help people literally get up and walk, to do all kinds of things we could never have imagined, as long as we meet rigorous, ethical standards.''

title: Estrogen Heart Study Proves Discouraging
description: A new study finds that estrogen replacement therapy, which doctors have long hoped will prevent heart disease in postmenopausal women, does nothing to slow the disease's progression in those whose arteries have already been partly blocked by it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 14 about celebrities who attended parties for the Democratic National Convention misstated the location of a fund-raiser given by Stan Lee, the creator of Spider-Man. It was at the home of Ken Roberts, a radio and real estate investor, in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles, not at Mr. Lee's home in Malibu.

title: Blacks and Jews Find Harmony in Retelling of Exodus
description: The story of Moses isn't usually sung and danced by a cast of African-Americans and Jews. Nor is it performed as a work in progress with new casts at every performance. Yet this has been one of the goals of Walter Robinson, a composer from Cambridge, Mass., who has spent the last four years piecing together ''Moses,'' which through black music and dance tells the Old Testament story of the liberation of the Israelites from slavery.

title: Viacom Unit Joins Rivals In Publishing Online Books
description: Simon & Schuster announced yesterday a list of electronic books that it will sell this fall, making it the third major trade publisher to offer books that can be downloaded and read on a computer screen.

title: Energy From Your Sink
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Martin Gets Ready to Play for Pay
description: Kenyon Martin officially signed his contract with a disposable pen from the Ritz Carlton this afternoon in the Nets' Champion Center. And having finished that formality, Martin, the National Basketball Association's No. 1 draft pick, was eager to earn his salary.

title: Biotech Industry Flexes New Muscle; Investors Pump Cash Into Research
description: As a young biotechnology company in 1986, OSI Pharmaceuticals agreed to use its expertise in genes and molecular biology to help Pfizer Inc. discover new drugs for cancer. As in many such deals, OSI agreed to receive a royalty of about 5 percent on the sales of any drugs that made it to market.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: August 25, 2000 Go to article

description: Manhattan

title: Group Fighting Political Correctness on Campus Delights in Ties to Both Parties' Tickets
description: Jerry L. Martin, president of the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, cheered when George W. Bush tapped Dick Cheney as his running mate. He cheered again when Al Gore chose Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.

title: Essay; Pardon Me, But . . .
description: Former President Bill Clinton will never look out at us from behind bars. He will (1) escape indictment by the new grand jury; (2) be acquitted at trial; or (3) be pardoned in advance. With ''Jail to the Chief'' not an option, we can begin to weigh the arguments about prosecution.
