description: Amazon to Launch French Web Site Next Week

title: Hoping People Watch Jail And Won't Want to Visit
description: THE inner workings of at least one piece of the criminal justice system can now be viewed on the Internet 24 hours a day, courtesy of Webcams in the Maricopa County jail in south-central Arizona.

title: AIDS Risk in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Installing a Scanner With Windows 98
description: Q. How difficult would it be for a mere novice to add a photo scanner to a Windows 98 computer?

title: Newton's Alma Mater Is Passing the Hat to Purchase His Papers
description: Cambridge University opened a campaign today to keep the papers of its alumnus Sir Isaac Newton in Britain, seeking donations to prevent part of the scientist's legacy from falling prey to the gravitational pull of outside buyers and market forces as powerful as the natural laws he chronicled.

title: Elliott And Fabini Picking Up The Pieces
description: ''Are you trying to say I'm stupid?'' Jason Fabini said to Jumbo Elliott, his former mentor who is now his backup.

title: Revenge Among the Nerds
description: WHAT do you do when someone stands you up? You stew. You steam. Or perhaps you write a curt note. Douglas Anderson of Manhattan has taken another approach: he sends a virtual voodoo doll.

title: INKTOMI, AOL AND ADERO FORM ALLIANCE
description: Three Internet companies have formed a technology and network service alliance aimed at making the Internet an easier place to navigate. The three, Inktomi, America Online and the closely held Adero, formed a venture, called Content Bridge. Inktomi will provide the network infrastructure technology; Adero will ensure that content is updated and will provide a centralized billing system, and AOL will deploy Content Bridge on its network. Content Bridge will also let Web-operating companies like Digital Island and Exodus Communications improve online delivery of audio, video and software files.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: In New York, Ceramic Pitchers In Shapes Medieval Monks Used
description: Gubbio, a TriBeCa restaurant named for the town in Umbria, is decorated with ceramic pitchers made since the 1800's by the Baffoni family of Umbria. The restaurant also sells the pitchers. The basic shapes date from the 15th century, when local monks used similar pitchers for wine, water and oil, said Giorgio Meriggi, an owner of Gubbio. The two-handled, 12-inch pitcher at left is made for wine ($250). Nine other designs range from 6 inches to 24 inches high, and from $75 to $500. All are available at the restaurant, serving specialties from Umbria at 223 West Broadway (White Street);(212) 334-8077. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Knicks Shop Ewing And Find Frustration
description: General Manager Scott Layden continued to work the phones yesterday as the Knicks sought to put together a deal that would bring Glen Rice to New York and end Patrick Ewing's increasingly ugly relationship with the franchise, its fans and the news media.

title: The Halliburton Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: KODAK TO SELL TROUBLED EASTMAN SOFTWARE UNIT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photography company, agreed yesterday to sell its unprofitable Eastman Software unit to an investment group. Kodak made the sale to permit it to concentrate on film sales and digital photography. Terms were not disclosed. William D. Oates leads the group buying Eastman Software, which is based in Billerica, Mass. Eastman sells computer programs that track and update large amounts of paperwork at insurance companies, banks and governments. Kodak is based in Rochester.

title: Farmhouses or Villas, Rms w/Vus
description: Why not call Umbria home? Jill and Jim Powrie moved to Montecastelli from England over 15 years ago and formed a real estate agency specializing in foreign clients. ''We handle everything on site without the purchaser having to speak Italian or tackle the bureaucracy,'' Ms. Powrie said. Their agency covers the region that includes Todi, a picturesque hill town close to Rome popular with foreigners. (Left, a view from the road between Perugia and Todi.) There are 70-odd properties on their books with notable historical or architectural features, some beautifully restored, others requiring complete renovation. A two-bedroom hillside apartment goes for $119,000, and a castle on 50 acres is $1.4 million. Information: 011-39-075-942-6500 or www.greenumbria.com.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Home Heating Oil Prices Surge on Sudden Drop in Inventories
description: Consumers received another dose of bad news on the energy front yesterday as an unexpected decline in crude oil inventories sent home heating oil prices to their highest in a decade.

title: Raising More Than Consciousness Now
description: BESS GORNICK was an only-in-New-York New Yorker. The kind of woman who, living alone at age 90 in a Manhattan apartment, thought nothing of bounding up to a police officer, with the back of her sweater half-fastened, and demanding, ''Button me!''

title: INTEL AIMING FOR WIRELESS MARKET
description: Intel introduced a chip design intended for use in a wide variety of wireless Internet and networking infrastructure applications. Called the Intel XScale microarchitecture, it has the flexibility to handle requirements for both ultralow power and high performance in devices ranging from Internet-ready cell phones to Internet infrastructure equipment. Intel's XScale is actually a renamed version of the StrongArm architecture Intel acquired from the Digital Equipment Corporation, which was originally based on a design created by Advanced Risc Machines of Britain. The technology is notable for its ability to operate at high speeds while consuming little power, a key requirement for a new generation of battery-powered mobile devices. Intel said the new design would allow the development of new types of wireless devices powered by a single AA battery. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: Clear Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Winslow Using Talents to Fight Heart Disease
description: Kellen Winslow is acutely aware of what is happening in his neighborhood, his town, his country and beyond. He is a Hall of Fame tight end from the San Diego Chargers who can talk about world events as deftly as he can about current National Football League tight ends who are fearless across the middle.

title: NEW RULES ON USE OF HUMAN EMBRYOS IN CELL RESEARCH
description: The National Institutes of Health yesterday issued long-awaited rules that would permit federally financed researchers to work on human embryonic stem cells, cells derived from the very early embryo.

title: Metro Matters; Confession TV Is Legal; Is It Right?
description: THE man with the stringy long hair sits in a grimy room, laughing about pot one moment, swatting at a mosquito the next. He pulls a copy of ''Mein Kampf'' out of a plastic bag, mumbles something about Hitler and numbers, then, his face a blank, tells how he killed a friend and dismembered her body.

title: Op-Art
DVD Toy For Rich Techies
description: FOR a product that is wildly expensive, technically confusing and apparently incompatible with a lot of machines with which it ought to be expected to work, the Panasonic DMR-E10 DVD Video Recorder is actually pretty cool.

title: A Witness to the Revolution Recalls Abbie
description: THE young lawyer had just been fired from his first job for being a troublemaker -- in 1968, preaching union to fellow Legal Aid lawyers was a no-no -- when the stranger telephoned.

title: Land Mine Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullpen Collapses, So Posada and Martinez Save Yankees
description: Twice before on this homestand, the Yankees watched their bullpen squander late leads and produce the demoralizing losses that come with blown saves.

title: Video Dresses Up E-Mail Ads
description: SHEREEF MOUSTAFA has always been cautious about opening e-mail notes containing attachments because he worries about viruses, but when he received a video e-mail message about an Oracle conference, his curiosity got the better of him. He clicked on the e-mail's attachment, and a crisp video began to play almost immediately.

title: COVER-UP HURTS MITSUBISHI STOCK
description: The shares of Mitsubishi Motors fell a day after the company acknowledged that it had systematically covered up customer complaints since 1977 and would widen a recall. Its shares fell 2 percent on Tuesday. Still, analysts said that while the company's image might have been tarnished by the scandal, it would have no immediate effect on its earnings. Miki Tanikawa

title: Levi Strauss is putting its Silvertab line on hip people in exotic places in a multimedia campaign.
description: LEVI STRAUSS is introducing a multimedia campaign to promote its Silvertab line of clothing, part of a continuing effort to stimulate steeply declining sales.

title: ANOTHER SALE BY TRANSCANADA
description: Canada's largest natural gas carrier, TransCanada PipeLines Ltd. of Calgary, is selling its offshore gas production and gathering system in the Netherlands to a subsidiary of Gaz de France for 501 million Canadian dollars ($340 million). Since December, TransCanada has sold $1.9 billion worth of assets, its chief executive, Douglas Baldwin, said. TransCanada went heavily into debt in the 1990's, and Mr. Baldwin, 64, was lured out of retirement in mid-1999. Having tackled the debt -- mainly by selling gas production, gathering and processing units -- he plans to hand his job to a successor next year. Timothy Pritchard

title: Sword of Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about the star cluster M15 misstated the age of the stars there. They are about 12 billion years old, not 12 million.

title: Maytag Is Said To Be in Talks With Electrolux
description: The Maytag repairman may be getting a new boss.

title: CBS Is Surprise Winner in Ratings Contest
description: With parties being thrown to celebrate it, news organizations scheduling special coverage and viewers all over the nation waiting in near breathless anticipation, a summer television series ended last night accompanied by the kind of attention usually reserved for massive national events, on the scale of the Super Bowl or the Academy Awards.

title: Having Extra Incentive to Win a Qualifying Spot
description: A rotator-cuff injury once knocked out Lindsay Lee-Waters at the height of her career. She isn't about to let being nearly five months pregnant stop her.

title: Texas Takes Step on Warming; Some See Shift in Bush's Position
description: Texas' three natural resource commissioners, all appointees of Gov. George W. Bush, said yesterday that global warming was a serious problem and that the state would explore ways to cut its emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

title: Senate Panel Plans to Hold Tire Hearings
description: The Senate Commerce Committee is planning to hold hearings on the Firestone tires that were the subject of a safety recall, a Congressional aide said today.

title: For Immigrants, An Insurance Void
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Training, More Teachers: New Math for Staffing Classes
description: A growing number of states and school districts are short-circuiting the usual route to teacher certification with their own crash courses that put new teachers in the classroom after as little as three weeks.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Name Games At City Hall

title: An Eastern Fantasia, Asleep for a Century
description: TREND-WATCHERS, take note: Lockwood de Forest may be big. Very big.

title: New York City Backs Off Plan To Ban Alcohol At Festivals
description: Less than two weeks after the Giuliani administration announced a ban on alcohol sales along parade routes, city officials have backed off a Police Department proposal to end such sales at street festivals. Instead, yesterday they notified the Feast of San Gennaro, the 11-day festival held in September in Little Italy, that alcohol sales would be permitted but that the number of vendors would be cut in half.

title: Comets Want to Secure Place on Highlight Reel
description: Teresa Weatherspoon's miraculous halfcourt shot that beat the Houston Comets in Game 2 of the Women's National Basketball Association finals last summer was the league's featured promotional clip this year.

title: Let the Defense Debate Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: Earnings at Dillard's Decline 74% in Quarter
description: Dillard's Inc. said today that its second-quarter profit plunged 74 percent as sales at the department store chain declined.

title: Storm Aims at Cuba; Tourists Flee Keys
description: Tropical Storm Debby lost momentum today as it spun westward through the rough mountains of the island of Hispaniola and headed toward the northern coast of Cuba, where the storm was expected to weaken even more before threatening the Florida coast or moving into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: New Acquisitions By Agencies
description: Ogilvy One Worldwide in New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of the WPP Group, acquired the Lacek Group, a relationship marketing agency with offices in Minneapolis; Singapore; and Seoul, South Korea, from Electronic Data Systems in Plano, Tex. Lacek, with 120 employees and revenue estimated at $18 million from clients like Starwood Hotels and Resorts, will become a unit of Ogilvy One.

title: Exploring the Arts Whether as Artist, Viewer or Shopper
description: Umbria -- known as the green heart of Italy for its pastoral countryside and mountain wilderness -- is dotted with picturesque medieval hill towns like Perugia, Gubbio, Assisi, Todi and Spoleto. Perhaps the best way to experience Umbria is by exploring a town like Montone (large photo), where for the last 20 years an American artist and New York City resident, Daniel Lang, below, has spent half of his time. There will be an exhibition of his paintings at MB Modern, 41 East 57th Street, from Oct. 12 through 28, featuring Umbrian landscapes. Below, the view from his terrace in Montone.

title: Can't Have Tutu Much, Serious Or Silly
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo may look nutty, with its male ballerinas, over-the-top stage names and mostly witty choreographic jokes. But on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, the company presented the kind of dream repertory one seldom sees these days. Although this second of two Joyce programs was mostly classical ballet fare by the big guns of Russian and French ballet in the 19th and early 20th centuries, there was also a dollop of dance by that stalwart American avant-gardist Merce Cunningham.

title: Cabinet Member's Death Puts Spotlight on India's Health System
description: The death of a popular and lively leader of India's governing party today has shaken the capital's political elite, many of whom believe that he got faulty medical care at one of New Delhi's most prestigious privately run hospitals.

title: Two Races in New Jersey Get the Presidential Treatment
description: President Clinton flew through the New Jersey suburbs today, shuttling from a horse farm here to a horse track in Cherry Hill -- with a stopover in Princeton that paralyzed the borough's streets at rush hour -- all to help a pair of Democrats facing uphill contests for the House of Representatives in two of the most closely watched races in the country.

title: Diabetes Rises; Doctors Foresee A Harsh Impact
description: The incidence of diabetes increased markedly in the United States from 1990 to 1998, including a 76 percent rise in cases among people in their 30's, researchers are reporting today, and they warn that the disease will take a harsh toll in disability, death and medical expenses in decades to come.

title: Coca-Cola to Award Some Early Bonuses
description: The Coca-Cola Company said this week that it would pay some workers half of their annual bonuses early.

title: Relief for the Hungry
description: To the Editor:

title: Bovine Crimes Strike An Unlikely Cow Town
description: The 500 life-size fiberglass cows that arrived on New York City streets in June have inspired impassioned opinions. Some people welcome the herd, with their imaginative designs by local artists. Others consider the whole cow parade just a hokey import from Chicago.

title: FCB Worldwide Gets More Work for AT&T
description: AT&T expanded its relationship with FCB Worldwide in New York by naming the agency to handle the print work for a new corporate image campaign. The overall theme of the campaign will be coordinated with Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York, the agency that originated the theme, and the agency that is handling the broadcast ads for the corporate account. Billings for the new campaign were estimated at $50 million. FCB and Y.& R. are the two main roster agencies for AT&T.

title: It's $15 Million, but Great for a Party
description: THE tiny lady with the gray bun and the slight Russian accent shook her head, remembering that day, 46 years ago, when she first saw the 16-room rental apartment with the heart-stopping panoramic view of Central Park.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FURNITURE BRANDS INTERNATIONAL INC., St. Louis, the biggest United States maker of residential furniture, said demand for its products slowed this month and it might have to close factories.

title: Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: Creepy Virtual Beings, Attitude Included
description: THE Gillmen in the Sega Dreamcast simulation Seaman do not seem to like me.

title: In Senate Race, Hate-Crime Bill Becomes Focus Of Accusations
description: The campaigns of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio traded charges and insults yesterday over Mr. Lazio's record on hate crimes legislation.

title: Norman Wins in Tuneup
description: After winning his first hardcourt title as an unseeded player in last year's Hamlet Cup, Magnus Norman reached the fourth round of the United States Open before a back injury forced him to withdraw. It was his best showing in a Grand Slam event to that point.

title: FORMER ORACLE PRESIDENT JOINS VENTURE FIRM
description: Ray Lane, who abruptly resigned from the Oracle Corporation last month as president and chief operating officer, said today that he had joined Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the leading Silicon Valley venture capital firm, as a general partner. Mr. Lane, who is 53, joined Oracle in 1991 from Booz-Allen & Hamilton, where he headed the information technology consulting group. ''It's really a lifestyle change for me,'' Mr. Lane said in a telephone interview. ''It's a very individual decision in that for the last 20 years I've spent 75 percent of my life on airplanes, and sat through a lot of unproductive meetings. I loved being the president of Oracle, but if you look at the quantity of time you're stealing from your life and your family, it's huge,'' he said, adding that he has a 19-month-old son and a daughter on the way. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Child Products Recalled
description: Almost three million swings, walkers and bassinets are being recalled because they pose serious hazards, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. The agency said parents should stop using them at once.

title: Ethics Ruling Faults Massachusetts Official
description: The Massachusetts State Ethics Commission found today that Lt. Gov. Jane Swift, who won her office in 1998 less than three weeks after bearing her first child, violated ethics rules by having two aides baby-sit away from the State House.

title: New Programs Remove Unwanted Internet Files
description: Hard-disk space may not be as expensive as Manhattan real estate, but it can be equally precious to computer users who like to squirrel away as many files on their machines as they can. Web browser programs are notorious for hoarding disk space with saved graphics files and other data from previously visited Web sites.

title: Seles Wins Easily
description: Monica Seles cruised to the semifinals of the Pilot Pen tournament in New Haven yesterday by defeating Dominique Van Roost of Belgium, 6-1, 6-2.

title: Former Oracle Executive Joins Top Venture Capital Firm
description: Former Oracle Executive Joins Top Venture Capital Firm

title: G.O.P. Long Shot Offers A Touch of the Radical
description: There are times when Tom Campbell clearly relishes being the un-Republican Republican.

title: A Putin Supporter Recants
description: I voted for Vladimir Putin, despite his K.G.B. past. Just five or six years ago such an act would have been unthinkable.

title: Condos to Rise Above the Heisman Trophy
description: The upper 22 floors of the Downtown Athletic Club building near Battery Park in Manhattan have been sold to a developer who intends to convert them into luxury condominiums, furthering the hectic makeover of the financial district to high-end residential use.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 17 about a decision by Palestinian leaders to reassess their plan to declare statehood on Sept. 13 misstated the timetable for an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement under the Oslo accords of 1993. The accords spelled out a five-year interim process; they did not specify a seven-year goal for a final agreement.

title: United, in Bid to Cut Delays, Mandates Overtime for Mechanics
description: To help overcome delays and cancellations that have plagued it this summer, United Airlines has issued an order requiring mechanics at five airports to work overtime if asked.

title: Mr. Cheney's Options
description: Dick Cheney became wealthy at the helm of the Halliburton Company over the past five years. At today's stock price, the value of his shares, restricted shares and vested stock options granted him during his tenure adds up to more than $30 million. That is compensation awarded to Mr. Cheney for his past service, and is perfectly appropriate, provided he sells these assets if elected vice president and puts the proceeds in a blind trust to eliminate any potential conflicts of interest.

title: Diversity on the Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vacation House Transforms Itself and a Family
description: IF you were to choose a place to construct a high-concept vacation house, it would probably not be Valley Center.

title: APPLE TRADE-IN
description: Owners of the Apple PowerBook 5300 and 190 models can trade in their old computers for a significant discount on one of the company's 400-megahertz G3 laptops if they act quickly. From now until Aug. 31, Apple is offering $700 off the price of a new G3 PowerBook (usually $2,499) for those who choose to send their old 5300 or 190 models back to the company. The 5300/190 series, which was released in 1995, gained a measure of infamy because of a host of design and technical problems, and its overheating -- and occasionally combusting -- battery. Those interested in taking advantage of the offer should call Apple at (800) 767-2775. Although not so dramatic as bursting into flames, the discount seems a much safer way for the 5300/190 series to go out in a blaze of glory.

title: Putting Teachers First
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Defense Debate Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: You Know How to Whistle, Don't You? Use the Smart Card
description: ComSense Technologies, a company in Tel Aviv, has developed a secure way for customers to log on at an online banking or trading site by using a sound bite instead of a password. The new product, called Comdot, consists of a credit card with a flat button on it. When the button is pressed, it sends a sound code to a Web site through any built-in or plugged-in microphone. The sound code is used to authenticate the identity of the cardholder.

title: U.S. Open Draw Yields An Interesting Mix
description: Yesterday's draw for the United States Open generated more speculation about the future than about the first round. Top-seeded Andre Agassi, the defending champion, and No. 4 Pete Sampras might meet in the semifinals; Serena Williams, the women's defending champion, and her sister Venus, the hottest player in the sport, are in opposite halves of the draw and could only meet in the final.

title: A Transformed Russia
description: With a public confession tonight by President Vladimir V. Putin that he feels ''responsibility and guilt'' for the loss of the nuclear submarine Kursk, Russia's political evolution seems to be taking a new kind of post-Soviet turn.

title: Let the Defense Debate Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Intellectual Property Is It, Anyway? The Open Source War
description: THERE'S a war going on. It isn't between ethnic groups, provinces, religions or nations. It is between nimble people who want to think for themselves and big dinosaurs of corporations that want to keep the upstarts penned up and docile.

title: Sword of Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Looks That Never Go Out of Style: Classic Linens for Bed or Table
description: Since 1842, a shop called Busatti Telerie, in Citta di Castello, has carried the finest handmade cotton and linen for tableware, bed linens and upholstery. Many of the patterned designs are the same as were used in Roman and medieval times and are still called by the names of the families they were commissioned for. More than a yard of thick striped linen with decorative borders ranges from $7.50 to $10.30; Busatti Telerie, Via del Popolo, Citta di Castello.

title: Expert Be Not Proud: A Design Pro's Serial Makeovers
description: KAREN FISHER has the usual New York apartment problems. Her home for more than 20 years is small, 500 square feet plus a terrace. Even worse, it's her office as well.

title: QUICKEN PRODUCTS ADDING STAMPS.COM SERVICE
description: Shares of Stamps.com surged 33 percent after Intuit said it would add the online postage provider to the 2001 versions of its Quicken home and business financial software products. Stamps.com, based in Santa Monica, Calif., sells a service that lets users buy postage online and print electronic stamps directly onto envelopes, labels or business documents. Intuit shares rose $8.56, to $54.63, or 18.6 percent, after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $8 million, or 4 cents a share, before investment income and other items. The numbers beat analysts' estimates of a loss of 9 cents a share. Intuit also released a bullish fiscal 2001 outlook, saying it expects 22 percent revenue growth and 30 percent growth in operating income. A First Call/Thomson Financial survey of 16 analysts produced a mean earnings estimate of 70 cents a share for the company's fiscal 2001. Shares of Stamps.com closed at $4.75, up $1.19, or 33.3 percent.

title: Let the Defense Debate Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: Gateway Aims To Be Computer Trainer
description: August 24, 2000

title: Ex-Disco Danny in a Harem
description: Daniel Gwirtzman has an unusually long, supple body and the kind of infectious delight in performing one might expect from a former disco dancer. Mr. Gwirtzman, once known as Disco Danny, assembled a company of 13 engaging dancers for ''Summer Fever,'' performed on Friday night at the Flea Theater. But that was not enough to overcome the essential blandness of the program's 10 pieces, which often looked as if they had been created simply for the pleasure of making another dance and not because of an unignorable idea or piece of music.

title: A New Approach to Forest Fires
description: The Clinton administration will soon unveil a revised approach to forest fires. Preliminary reports suggest that the policy will be smarter than past federal strategies, and much smarter than the recommendations flowing from President Clinton's opportunistic Republican critics.

title: Warm and Fuzzy I.S.P.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Kevin McAuliffe, 50, Press Aide to 3 Mayors
description: Kevin McAuliffe, a speechwriter for three New York City mayors and the editor of a collection of comments by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani published this year, died Saturday. He was 50 and lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexican Leader's Mission

title: National Republican Group Cancels a TV Commercial
description: The Republican National Committee has canceled plans to use a television commercial showing Vice President Al Gore saying in a 1994 interview with NBC that neither he nor President Clinton had lied in their political careers.

title: Lt. Gen. David W. Traub, 97; Coordinated Logistics for D-Day
description: Lt. Gen. David William Traub, a pivotal Army logistics officer for D-Day and in the Korean War, who later oversaw the rapid expansion of the State University of New York system, died on Aug. 16 at a hospital in Lawrence, Mass. A former resident of Loudonville, N.Y., an Albany suburb, he had recently moved to Andover, Mass., to be with family. He was 97.

title: Putting a Stop to the Art In the Name of Activism
description: ANOTHER BEAUTY

title: Come On In, the Swamp Is Fine; Wetland Beauty Restored, Just Off Flatbush Avenue
description: A year ago, the Gerritsen Creek salt marshes on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn were simply ''the creek,'' a fishing spot and informal local dump. They were a place to toss old tires and rusting car hulks, or for teenagers to hide out for clandestine beer parties. Old-timers could do a bit of illegal muskrat hunting or crab netting there.

title: Talks Fail Over Suit On Placing Of Teachers
description: State and city lawyers were trying yesterday to negotiate a settlement of a lawsuit filed by the State Education Department to block the city's Board of Education from assigning uncertified teachers to some of the worst-performing schools. But those talks were unsuccessful.

title: Aid Halted In West Timor After Attack On U.N. Staff
description: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees said today that all aid operations in West Timor had been suspended after the severe beating of three refugee relief workers by pro-Indonesian militamen.

title: Only 2 Developers Express Interest in Building Trading Complex for Stock Exchange
description: New York City officials are finding that the road to building a new trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange can be long and bumpy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the theater director Michael Maggio on Tuesday misstated the title of the last play he directed. It was ''Boy Gets Girl'' by Rebecca Gilman, not ''Boy Meets Girl.''

title: PIPELINE COMPANY ACQUIRES STAKES IN THREE GAS SYSTEMS
description: Northern Border Partners L.P., which owns interstate pipelines, agreed yesterday to buy stakes in three natural gas systems from the Enron Corporation for about $200 million to expand its gas-gathering business in Wyoming. Northern Border will own and operate the pipelines, which collect gas from wells in the Powder River and Wind River basins. Enron, the world's largest energy trader, will provide marketing services. Houston-based Northern Border will get Enron's share of Bighorn Gas Gathering. Together, Northern and Enron bought a 49 percent stake in Bighorn in January from the CMS Energy Corporation. Northern Border will also get Houston-based Enron's stakes in the 106-mile Fort Union Gas Gathering and the 123-mile Lost Creek Gathering system.

title: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages
description: Sue, the world's largest, best-preserved Tyrannosaurus rex, is also the world's largest, best-preserved T. rex to have her own Web pages (www.fmnh.org/sue), part of the Web site of the Field Museum in Chicago, where Sue makes her home. The site features photographs; information on Sue, a 42-foot-long dinosaur; and a chronology of her modern life, from her discovery by Susan Hendrikson in 1990 to her preservation and eventual purchase by the museum in 1997.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 19 about efforts by the American envoy Dennis Ross to revive Israeli-Palestinian talks misstated terms of United Nations Security Council resolutions passed after the 1967 Middle East war. While Resolution 242 called for Israel's armed forces to withdraw ''from territories occupied in the recent conflict,'' no resolution called for Israel to hand over all of east Jerusalem to a future Palestinian state.

title: CARNIVORE REVIEW STANDARDS
description: The Justice Department plans to post standards and specific expectations for an academic review of the Carnivore surveillance system on its Web site (www.usdoj.gov) this afternoon, Attorney General Janet Reno said. The program, used by the F.B.I., can intercept and search private e-mail for specific words and phrases, allowing agents to quickly sift through large numbers of messages. The department is seeking a major university to review the government e-mail surveillance program that supporters call an asset to law enforcement and detractors see as a serious threat to privacy. A final decision on a university is expected by Sept. 15, Ms. Reno said, with the technical review to be completed by Dec. 1. The results will be considered before the department determines how Carnivore will be used in the future. John Files

title: Setup and Programming; Digital Recorders Aren't Quite Plug and Play
description: IT'S been said that connecting a digital video recorder is as easy as hooking up a VCR. Let that be a warning.

title: Arts of Many Cultures, From Quilts to Bridges
description: 'A Promise Unfulfilled'

title: Easy Is as Easy Does
description: To the Editor:

title: Bartle Bogle Executive Leaves for Wieden
description: The top creative executive at the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, which is 49 percent owned by the B Com3 Group, is leaving to join the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy, which is based in Portland, Ore. Ty Montague was named creative director at the New York office, succeeding Stacy Wall, who left earlier this month to join Hungry Man in New York, a commercial and TV production company.

title: Marino Hears Cheering One More Time
description: The onetime Jets quarterback Ken O'Brien, among a host of former players and a sellout gathering of 55,000 fans to pay homage to the retired Miami Dolphins quarterback Dan Marino tonight, recalled one play in particular that defined the man who went on to be the most productive passer in National Football League history.

title: A National Tournament Ends With Two Lopsided Triumphs
description: The finals of the main knockout events at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Anaheim, Calif., last week were both one-sided affairs. The Spingold Teams was won, by a margin of 94, by Rose Johnson Meltzer and Peter Weichsel, both of Los Gatos, Calif.; Alan Sontag of Gaithersburg, Md.; Kyle Larsen of San Francisco; Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif.; and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif. They overwhelmed Roy Welland and Brad Moss, both of Manhattan, Marc Jacobus of Las Vegas, Fred Gitelman of Toronto, and Magnus Lindqvist and Peter Fredin, both of Sweden, who had performed valiantly in ousting four higher-ranked teams in earlier rounds.

title: Leiter Gives Weary Mets Just What They Need
description: When the Mets lost by 15 runs on Tuesday and had to summon an outfielder to pitch, they knew their bullpen would be depleted the next day. Speaking after that game, Al Leiter seemed puzzled when asked if he would have to pitch any differently, to conserve pitches to last deep into the game.

title: Bereft Russia Hears Putin's Mea Culpa on Sub Accident
description: As Russia grieved for 118 seamen lost in the remains of the submarine Kursk, President Vladimir V. Putin moved decisively to contain the incident's political impact, going on national television tonight to take responsibility for what some Russians call a badly botched response.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: Rivera Still Confident, Just Not Invincible
description: Mariano Rivera still jogs in confidently from the left-center-field bullpen with his piercing eyes staring at the mound while Metallica's ''Enter Sandman'' blares throughout Yankee Stadium. This scene usually occurs in the ninth inning, which has almost always been Rivera's special time.

title: Ole C. Risom, 80, Publisher of Children's Books
description: Ole C. Risom, one of the most influential publishers of mass-market books for children, died on Saturday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 80 and lived in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y.

title: Beijing Journal; For a While, Crime Paid. Then Came This Exhibit.
description: The multitudes visiting Beijing's newest museum exhibit are greeted by pretty young guides in neat white dresses. Providing nonstop fact-filled commentary through a half-hour tour, the escorts cheerfully explain highlights of the posters and showcases that fill two large halls of the Military Museum.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- New Orleans, Miami

title: More Web Hits for GOP Than Democrats
description: August 24, 2000

title: From Mostly Mozart, Mostly Bach, With a Phalanx of Thrills and Trills
description: Lincoln Center, which did much excellent work for Bach in the early part of this year, the 250th anniversary of the composer's death, has managed to continue it in recent weeks with a welcome bit of subterfuge, turning much of the increasingly unpredictable Mostly Mozart Festival into a ''Bach Celebration.'' And the centerpiece was a major event, the American debut of the full Collegium Vocale of Ghent, period-instrument band as well as chorus, directed in two concerts by Philippe Herreweghe, ending with Bach's B minor Mass at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening.

title: Summer School Sends 63% To Next Grade
description: Two out of every three New York City students who showed up for summer school will be promoted to the next grade, even though only about 40 percent of those who took the end-of-summer reading and mathematics tests passed them, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages
description: Famous Dinosaur Gets Her Own Web Pages

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: BROOKLYN

title: Verizon Strike Settled in Full After Accord On Overtime
description: Verizon Communications and a union representing more than 35,000 employees in several mid-Atlantic states settled an 18-day strike last night after the company agreed to reduce requirements for mandatory overtime.

title: All 143 Aboard Die In Bahrain Jet Crash
description: All 143 people aboard a Gulf Air Airbus A320 on a flight from Cairo to Bahrain were killed when the jet crashed in the Persian Gulf after circling and trying to land in Manama. Most of the passengers were from Arab countries, including at least 63 Egyptians.

title: Italy, Land of Noble Food, Gets Pushcart Hot Dogs
description: A blue-and-yellow umbrella flapped in the breeze as Andrea Lupo, clad in a blue bathing suit and a deep tan, ordered lunch with mustard, relish, onions and sauerkraut, to a chorus of ''disgusting'' from a clutch of wide-eyed contemporaries.

title: Quest for Free Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose after a government official signaled that Japan might be willing to let its currency and interest rates climb further. In New York, the dollar settled at 107.07 yen, down from 108.29 on Tuesday.

title: Appointer of Justices
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: COACHMEN, MODULAR HOUSING MAKER, BUYS COMPETITOR
description: Coachmen Industries Inc., the largest maker of modular housing in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy Miller Building Systems Inc. for $25.8 million, or $8.40 a share in cash. Miller stockholders could get another 30 cents a share in cash if the company meets unspecified conditions. Coachmen will assume $5.1 million in debt. Until last month, Miller, a maker of modular buildings for commercial use, was in talks to be acquired by Modtech Holdings Inc., a maker of modular classrooms. Shares of Miller Building rose 63 cents, to $8.25. Coachmen rose 13 cents, to $10.63.

title: A Rare Vote For Experience Over Youth; At 77, Arthur Penn Takes His 'Bonnie and Clyde' Skills To the Right Side of the Law
description: Few directors in the 1960's and 70's rivaled Arthur Penn. His Broadway shows included successes like ''Two for the Seesaw,'' ''The Miracle Worker,'' ''Toys in the Attic'' and ''All the Way Home.'' His work in Hollywood was equally celebrated, with inventive movies like ''Alice's Restaurant,'' ''Little Big Man,'' ''The Miracle Worker'' and the enduring classic ''Bonnie and Clyde.''

title: In America; Standing in the Way
description: ''We think there is a parallel between federal involvement in education and the decline in profit over recent years.''

title: MetroStars Tie in a Duel at the Top
description: In a battle of division leaders seeking first place overall in Major League Soccer, it was perhaps fitting that the MetroStars and the Kansas City Wizards fought to a scoreless tie tonight before a crowd of 16,898 at drizzly Giants Stadium.

title: Otis Smith Back With Belichick
description: The Patriots signed cornerback Otis Smith, three days after the Jets waived him to trim their roster.

title: Trial of Suharto Is Set to Start Aug. 31
description: A Jakarta judge said today that the trial of former President Suharto on corruption charges would start on Aug. 31 and that the ex-dictator must appear in court.

title: INCYTE PRESIDENT LEAVES TO HEAD START-UP
description: Incyte Genomics said that Randy Scott, its president and chief scientific officer, will leave day-to-day operations to start an e-health company that is expected to be affiliated with Incyte. Dr. Scott, a co-founder of Incyte, will become its chairman, replacing Jeff Collinson, the original investor in the company. Roy A. Whitfield remains chief executive of Incyte, which sells genomics information and is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Dr. Scott said his new Internet company would provide patients with updated information on research into diseases, including genetic information, and might do testing of genes for patients. The new company, as yet unnamed, is expected to get an investment from Incyte and to use its genomics information. Incyte's shares fell $6.88, to $80.63. Andrew Pollack

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Airlines Requires Overtime for Mechanics

title: Cheney Has Mixed Record In Business Executive Role
description: In 1998, Dick Cheney pulled off what was widely seen as a business coup. Ending years of fruitless talks, Mr. Cheney arranged a merger between Halliburton, the company he ran, and its chief rival, Dresser Industries, creating the world's largest oil field services and construction company.

title: NESTLE'S PROFIT SOARS
description: The world's largest food company, Nestle, posted better-than-expected earnings for the first half of the year, buoyed by increased sales in Asia, Africa, Eastern Europe and Latin America. The Swiss company said first-half net profit jumped 35 percent, to 2.8 billion Swiss francs, or $1.61 billion, from 2.08 billion francs in the period a year earlier. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE CUSTODIAL ACCOUNTS
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire $9 billion in custodial accounts that are administered by Bank of America Private Bank in Los Angeles, a unit of the Bank of America Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The Bank of New York said the acquisition would help it build its private client services business. Bank of America Private Bank said it would continue to concentrate on its investment management business.

title: Mexican Leader Visits U.S. With a Vision to Sell
description: For eight hours each day, in a desolate warehouse with stone walls, some 12 men and a couple of women in this village of squat adobe houses learn to build furniture with circular saws and power drills.

title: The Politics of Fire
description: The fire that burned right up to my house this year was different than those that leveled more than 65 of my neighbors' homes in recent days. I set it myself to give me a bit of buffer against summer's big fires.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Reno Decision Clears Gore of Criminal Jeopardy, Experts Say
description: The decision by Attorney General Janet Reno not to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Vice President Al Gore's statements about his role in 1996 fund-raising activities means Mr. Gore is essentially clear of any criminal jeopardy, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Don't People Want to Control Their TV's?
description: LEONARD LA FRANCE, an engineer in Lake Tahoe, Nev., was intrigued when he heard about a new product for his television, a gadget that would search for the programs he wanted, automatically recording them on a hard drive, and would allow him to put live programs on ''pause'' and skip commercials at the press of a button.

title: Helen C. Ewing Breasted -- Volunteer at Hull House, 90
description: Helen Culver Ewing Breasted, who worked at Hull House in Chicago with Jane Addams, its founder and a family friend, died Sunday at her home in Tamworth, N.H. She was 90 and also had a home in Sewickley, Pa.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; VOLKSWAGEN STRIKERS TO RETURN
description: Union workers at Volkswagen's plant in Mexico agreed to return to work after the federal government ruled the five-day strike illegal and gave union members 24 hours to return to the production lines or risk being fired. The leader of the union, Jose Luis Rodriguez Salazar, said that his members would be back at work but vowed to ''continue the fight from within'' the plant. The government said that the strike over wages, which halted production at the only plant producing the popular new Beetle, was illegal because union leaders did not strictly adhere to Mexican labor dispute procedures when they walked out last Friday morning. Dan Fineren

title: Metro Business; Garment District Site Yields Healthy Profit
description: Max Capital Management Corporation, one of the largest commercial landlords in New York City, sold a 16-story building in the garment district this week to S. L. Green Realty for $50.5 million, $20.5 million more than it paid for the property only three years ago.

title: People
description: * Jack Calhoun, general manager at the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, was named senior vice president for brand management and advertising at Charles Schwab & Co., San Francisco. He succeeds Leonard Short, who is resigning, the company said, to explore new career opportunities.

title: Pack Away Those Lasers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Star Plays Second Fiddle
description: When Jason Sehorn is out with his fiancee, the television actress Angie Harmon, he knows what to expect when fans recognize the couple.

title: About the Tables
description: The Times has revised its stock market tables, listing prices in dollars and cents rather than in fractions.

title: Lasorda Announces U.S. Baseball Roster
description: Saying, We're not going 6,000 miles to lose, Tommy Lasorda, manager of the United States Olympic baseball team, announced the roster for the Sydney Games next month in Australia at a news conference in Los Angeles yesterday.

title: China Arrests Owner of Internet Cafe
description: The owner of an Internet cafe in southern China has been arrested and charged with subversion for posting articles critical of the Communist Party, the latest sign of the government's campaign to tame the explosion of electronic information.

title: Irresistible Lure of Subways Keeps Landing Impostor in Jail
description: If Darius McCollum were a millionaire, he might be excused as an eccentric. If he were a genius, allowances probably would be made as well. But Mr. McCollum is neither. And his unusual problem -- his obsession, as he calls it -- has gotten him in so much trouble that people aren't even laughing anymore.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM IN DEAL FOR X-RAY SERVICE COMPANY
description: Radiologix Inc., a provider of X-ray services, said yesterday that it planned to recapitalize its operations. Under the deal, the privately held New York-based investment firm of Saunders Karp & Megrue would offer $164.4 million in cash and stock for Dallas-based Radiologix. It would also assume $212.5 million in debt. Radiologix's shareholders could either receive $7.25 a share in cash or convert each of their shares into 1.1224 shares of the recapitalized company. Radiologix said 1.1224 shares of the recapitalized company would be worth $8.25. Shares of Radiologix surged $2, or 50 percent, to $6, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Board Approves Final Report on Crash of T.W.A. Flight 800
description: The National Transportation Safety Board approved its final report on the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 yesterday and issued four new safety recommendations to help prevent accidents.

title: Bush Stumbles, and Questions Are Raised Anew
description: Gov. George W. Bush was supposed to be spending this week focusing on education, the issue with which his campaign is wooing women and independent voters.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: SAINSBURY MAY SELL UNIT
description: The British food retailer J. Sainsbury P.L.C. said it was considering selling its Homebase home improvement chain, to focus on its supermarkets. Analysts said the division could be worth more than $1 billion and noted that a sale would help Sainsbury's recovery. The company, once Britain's top-performing supermarket chain, lost its leading position to Tesco in terms of sales and profits in 1995. The chief executive, Sir Peter Davis, took the helm in March and is charged with reversing the profit decline. Sainsbury, along with other British supermarket retailers, has faced price wars that have resulted from Wal-Mart's purchase of the ASDA Group last year. Suzanne Kapner

title: Putting Teachers First
description: To the Editor:

title: Sword of Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert J. Northshield, 78, TV News Innovator, Dies
description: Robert J. Northshield, an innovator in television news who established one of its most enduring programs, died on Monday night in a New York area nursing home. He was 78.

title: Sports of The Times; Cooper's Memorable Journey
description: WHAT had been a routinely sedate news media session suddenly became a raucous and family-like reunion yesterday when Cynthia Cooper bounded out the runway at Madison Square Garden, like a blazing Houston Comet across the New York sky.

title: A Man of Many Stories, Both by Him and About Him
description: Milt Sosin lived for the story.

title: NO CHANGE IN BRAZIL'S RATE
description: Brazil's Central Bank Monetary Policy Committee maintained interest rates at 16.5 percent after an unexpectedly large surge in inflation last month led to fears that the government would overshoot its year-end inflation target. Economists say the cautious stance was attributable in part to uncertainty over the future of international oil prices. The committee has reduced interest rates three times since June. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Article 2000082493332574030 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Let the Defense Debate Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: Intuit Shares Rally on Higher Sales Forecast
description: Intuit Shares Rally on Higher Sales Forecast

title: With Chief Out, Giuliani Faults Buildings Dept.
description: Reacting to the abrupt resignation of the city's acting buildings commissioner, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that there were ''substantive problems'' with the Buildings Department and that the commissioner had made ''the right decision.''

title: Critic's Notebook; Machiavelli, on a Desert Isle, Meets TV's Reality. Unreal.
description: Last summer's cheery television phenomenon, ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' has been displaced this summer by a hit with a more scheming world view. ''Millionaire'' is the feel-good game show that says we're a happy country pulling together, but ''Survivor'' sends a countermessage: trust no one.

title: Visas for Mexican Workers
description: Mexico's president-elect, Vicente Fox, has some provocative if premature ideas about cross-border immigration. His ultimate goal is free movement of labor across an open border. But that is not practical anytime soon. With the more than tenfold gap between United States and Mexican wages, the migration would be all one way, as low-wage Mexican workers competed with the poorest, least skilled Americans. So for now, Mr. Fox would like to see Washington significantly increase the number of temporary visas available to Mexican workers. In exchange, Mexico would strengthen policies to discourage illegal emigration to the United States. That is an experiment worth discussing.

title: Amazon.com Plans to Offer Cars Online
description: Amazon.com, one of the world's largest online retailers, announced today that it would begin offering a car-selling service on the Internet, the latest and potentially most serious in a series of challenges to automakers' ability to control the distribution of automobiles.

title: SPRINT PCS TO OFFER BUSINESS ACCESS
description: Sprint PCS, the wireless-telephone unit of Sprint, said it would offer business users access to corporate e-mail and internal computer networks over its phones, to draw more high-spending customers. The Sprint PCS Wireless Web for Business follows the introduction of a similar service for consumers last August. The business version offers wireless Internet connections that increase speed by about four times, with additional security features. The business service will be available nationwide next month. Sprint PCS and its rivals are using wireless Internet access to bolster sales and phone use as competition cuts prices for mobile-phone plans. Business customers typically spend more time than consumers using wireless phones each month, keeping employees accessible and productive, especially while traveling. Since introducing Sprint PCS Wireless Web, national business accounts have almost quadrupled, Sprint PCS's interim president, Ron LeMay, said in a statement.

title: Land O'Lakes Buys Plant
description: Land O'Lakes Inc., a farmer-owned food and agricultural cooperative, said today that it had acquired a California cheese plant from the Beatrice Group unit of ConAgra Inc. to add to its mozzarella and cream-cheese businesses. Financial terms were not disclosed. The 70,000-square-foot plant in Gustine has 169 employees.

title: Opening Doors at a Hotel With a Palm in the Hand
description: THEY won't beam fresh towels up to the room, but Palm handhelds that can send and receive infrared signals will soon function as check-in desks and even room keys for travelers who stay at some hotels.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about new residential and commercial development in Hunts Point in the Bronx referred incorrectly to a member of Mothers on the Move, a group battling industry in the area. The member, Francisco Perez, is a man.

title: HYUNDAI DEAL IN NORTH KOREA
description: South Korea's largest business conglomerate, the Hyundai Group, said it had signed an agreement to build an industrial complex in North Korea. The Hyundai Asan Company, which handles the conglomerate's North Korean business projects, will construct the complex in Kaesung, a city just north of the border, where the conglomerate plans to make shoes, textiles and other labor-intensive products, tapping in to the low labor costs offered there. Hyundai said it planned to share the costs of the multibillion-dollar project through joint ventures. Samuel Len

title: RCA to Offer E-Books, The Next Generation
description: RCA, which made its name in stereo equipment and televisions, wants to get its consumers reading again. To that end, the company is releasing two new electronic readers, or e-books.

title: Site Invites Shoppers To Wax Eloquent
description: I AM looking for a piano lamp that has a long arm that you can adjust to cast really strong light on sheet music. The lamp has to be small enough to fit on a small shelf, and it should not tip over and fall onto the floor constantly like the last one (which broke). Also, it cannot be ugly.

title: Mother Held After Child, 3, Is Found Wandering Alone
description: On Monday night, Wanda Arroyo took her 3-year-old daughter, Crystal, to Coney Island to look at the stuffed animals on the midway, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Article 2000082491747578174 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gore and Company Making a Serious Play for Florida
description: They used their best Yiddish, not just the Jew but the Southern Baptist as well. The band, a brassy if somewhat anemic quintet (you were expecting the Rolling Stones?), played a medley that ran from ''Rocky Top'' to ''Happy Days Are Here Again'' to ''Hava Nagila.'' And one adoring voter, a lady with silver hair and red lipstick, told America's first Jewish vice-presidential nominee that kissing his hand was ''like kissing the Torah.''

title: Raymond Bid Turned Down By Arbitrator
description: Lisa Raymond's bid to replace Serena Williams on the United States Olympic team was turned down today, but the decision by the arbitrator, Richard Jeydel, did not leave the United States Tennis Association unscathed.

title: Too Late Last Night
description: The two-hour finale of "Survivor" on CBS ended too late last night for coverage in all copies. Full coverage is available at The New York Times on the Web:

title: PLUS: GOLF -- U.S. AMATEUR; Co-medalist Loses In Match Play
description: After two days of medal play, the golfers' expressions were a little more stoic, their gaits a little less pronounced, on the Upper Course at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J., yesterday, the first day of match play at the 100th United States Amateur Championship.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 10 about a slowing in the increase of the nation's prison population misstated the number of federal inmates sentenced on various types of charges in 1998. The article substituted 1990 figures from the Justice Department report. Actually, of the 108,925 inmates in federal prisons in 1998, 63,011 (not 30,470) were charged with drug crimes, 12,656 (not 7,557) were charged with violent offenses and 8,627 (not 7,935) were charged with property crimes.

title: On the Net, Soccer Waits for Prime Time
description: A SOCCER game lasts 90 minutes, but the global passion for the sport is never governed by the clock. And it's a good thing, because watching a European match on American television usually means staying up very late or getting up very, very early.

title: A Long-Discontinued Macintosh Still Thrills Collectors to the Core
description: WHEN the subject is Macintosh, love often turns to obsession. Such is the case for a small group of Apple aficionados who have decided that the one true Macintosh is the Color Classic.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE; When commerce moves online, competition can work in strange ways.
description: THE Internet is supposed to be a consumer paradise, with cutthroat pricing creating bountiful bargains for surfing shoppers. And so far the Internet has been a great place to shop. A survey by two M.I.T. professors, Erik Brynjolfsson and Michael Smith, found that prices on the Internet are 9 to 16 percent lower than in retail outlets.

title: Counselor Led Missing Boys to the River, Police Say
description: As helicopters and rescue boats searched the Hudson River for two teenage boys from a state psychiatric center who were swept away Tuesday, investigators said today that a counselor who had been warned to keep them out of the water had led them down a steep, treacherous path to the river's edge.

title: Beleaguered Indonesian Unveils New Cabinet
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid unveiled a revamped cabinet today in a move to revitalize his faltering administration and tackle acute social and economic woes that are threatening to tear Indonesia apart.

title: Even With School Out It's Work, Work, Work
description: Garrett Mitchell wanted to be outside helping his mother load up the car for the last family vacation before school began. Instead he was inside at his computer, trying to finish his schoolwork.

title: Pack Away Those Lasers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hussein Aide Says Iraq Won't Cooperate With Arms Monitoring
description: As a two-day meeting of international arms inspections experts convened today to review new monitoring operations for Iraq, a leading Iraqi official denounced the inspection commission and vowed again never to cooperate with it.

title: Where Fairies Are as Foolish as the Mortals
description: Immediately, Liz Shipman, the director, gets the emotional center of ''A Midsommer Nights Dreame'' right. In this production by the Kings County Shakespeare Company, no matter what happens in the Athenian court or in the more imposing fairy court of Oberon and Titania, no matter how much amusing confusion Puck produces with his botched enchantments, and no matter how diverting Bottom and his mechanicals contrive to be, the play revolves around the rivalry between Hermia and Helena over which of them will end up with Demetrius and which with Lysander.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: When Lily Met Iris

title: Asian Group Declines to Release Study on Foreign Investment
description: The Association of South East Asian Nations is declining to release a report that warns of dwindling foreign investment in the region, at the request of at least one association member, an association official said today.

title: Fittest of the Survivors
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: KELLWOOD AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF WOMEN'S CLOTHING
description: The Kellwood Company, an apparel and recreational camping products marketer, agreed yesterday to acquire Dorby Frocks Ltd., a privately held women's clothing maker. Kellwood will buy Dorby, which has more than $100 million in sales, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Kellwood's president and chief executive, Hal J. Upbin, said the acquisition would help expand his company's dress business, especially in the juniors market. Dorby, based in New York, makes branded and private-label dresses and career apparel at its two divisions: Dorby and Miss/Lady Dorby. Shares of Kellwood, which is based in St. Louis, rose 6 cents, to $16.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Anchors Revisit O. J. Simpson Trial

title: Ode to Softball and Boys of Summers Past
description: Although ''Fastpitch'' is a documentary about softball, it is more than a film about a dying form of sport.

title: After Close Assembly Races, A Candidate Makes A 4th Try
description: In three successive primary elections, Kimon C. Thermos campaigned vigorously -- and unsuccessfully -- to become the first Greek-American elected from New York City to the Assembly. Mr. Thermos, a lawyer and the president of a Democratic club in Queens, lost the last two contests by razor-thin margins to Assemblyman Denis J. Butler.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A face-lift, a name change and a new chef have turned the pricey, pan-Mediterranean Scarabee into Montparnasse, a good-looking bistro that just wants to be liked. The murky interior has been brightened, sidewalk tables and booths have been added, and attractive French advertising posters now hang from the walls.

title: Louis Kaufman Archive
description: The Library of Congress says it has acquired the personal papers of the violinist Louis Kaufman, including letters from such prominent musicians and artists as Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copland and Milton Avery.

title: Cheney Strongly Defends His Record as Chief of Halliburton
description: Dick Cheney vehemently defended his work in the oil services business today, bristling at any suggestion that he was less than successful as the chief executive of Halliburton and insisting once more that as vice president he would take steps to ensure his retirement package does not pose a conflict of interest.

title: Neighbors Fear Fallout of Aid To Colombians
description: As President Clinton prepares to visit Colombia next week and open the spigot of military aid, the country's neighbors are expressing concerns that a step-up in the fighting here could push coca growing, drug trafficking, refugees and even fighting across their borders.

title: What Makes New York 'the' City and Not 'a' City?
description: A 17th-century poet said that God made the first garden and the first city. But as it turned out, humans gave up the garden and were never quite so happy again. Eventually they moved to Manhattan.

title: 'Chalk'
description: Directed by Rob Nilsson

title: Despite Soaring Prosperity, Poland Still Isn't Sure of Itself
description: In the last 10 years, Urszula Malinowska and her husband have transformed their lives, turning a tiny farm and orchard into a wood-processing factory that employs 35 people.

title: Little Action Expected From Report on Auto Fuel Use
description: A government report to be released as soon as Friday reaches few conclusions about the effects of tightening federal fuel-economy regulations for automobiles, making it virtually certain that the regulations will not be changed by Congress before the end of this year.

title: Pesticides and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREINER, ANDREAS ''ANDY''
description: GREINER-Andreas ''Andy'', killed by a drunk driver in Salt Lake City, Utah on August 10, 2000. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 27 at 12 noon at the Suicide Six Base Lodge in Pomfret, Vermont. In lieu of flowers, friends may make donations in Andy's memory to Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

title: Article 2000082591477455112 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Accounts
description: * Chupa Chups S.A., Barcelona, now distributed and marketed in the United States by the M & M/Mars unit of Mars Inc., to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, St. Louis, part of the B Com3 Group, to handle its account, which had been at the Richards Group, Dallas. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: ALCOA AGREES TO ACQUIRE BRITISH BUSINESSES FROM LUXFER
description: Alcoa, the world's top aluminum manufacturer, said yesterday that it would acquire the aluminum plate, sheet and soft-alloy extrusion manufacturing operations and distribution businesses of British Aluminium, a subsidiary of the closely held Luxfer Holding. Terms were not disclosed. British Aluminium's manufacturing operations are in England and Wales, and the distribution businesses are in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland. The businesses that Alcoa plans to acquire generated about $360 million in revenue in 1999. Alcoa, based in Pittsburgh, is also involved in mining, refining, smelting, fabricating and recycling.

title: News Analysis; Praise and Questions for Summer School Program
description: As New York City's ambitious summer school program got under way last month, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy predicted that about half of the 63,000 students required to attend would do well enough to be promoted to the next grade.

title: ACCUSED SCIENTIST TO GO FREE ON BAIL IN LOS ALAMOS CASE
description: Saying the government case against the Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee ''no longer has the requisite clarity and persuasive character'' needed to keep him in detention before his trial, a federal judge reversed his previous decision today and ordered Dr. Lee released on bail.

title: May Day Redux: Will Decimalization Decimate Profits?
description: A QUARTER century ago, the old order passed on Wall Street. A new system forced price competition where there had been none, and that soon changed the financial landscape in ways no one had expected. Something very similar will begin next week.

title: U.S. Contends Muslim Charity Is Tied to Hamas
description: The State Department has asked the Agency for International Development to withdraw its registration from one of the largest Muslim charities in the United States, saying it has ties to the terrorist group Hamas, government officials say.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: 'God's Army'
description: Directed by Richard Dutcher

title: Boeing 757 Nearly Lands on Closed Runway at Newark, but Air Traffic Controller Intercedes
description: A Continental Airlines plane nearly landed on a closed runway at Newark Airport before dawn yesterday, but an air traffic controller noticed the impending mistake and ordered the plane up before it could land.

title: Alaska Changes View on Carter After 20 Years
description: On a visit Wednesday to the state where his legacy is larger than that of anyone since the man who bought Alaska from Russia for 2 cents an acre, former President Jimmy Carter again had to pass through a knot of people shouting his name and waving placards in his face.

title: Battling For Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn residents tend to be fierce defenders of their home turf. It's a tradition that goes back a long way -- as far back, in fact, as the Revolutionary War.

title: Treasuries Flat in Reaction to Drop in Durable Goods Orders
description: Bond prices were flat yesterday after the government reported a larger-than-expected drop in orders for durable goods in July, suggesting that the Federal Reserve may hold off raising interest rates again this year.

title: Chang Takes 2 Matches
description: Michael Chang helped out in a Long Island soup kitchen this week and yesterday he interrupted his second-round match in the Hamlet Cup to assist a ball girl overcome by heat.

title: Unilever and Procter & Gamble line up campaigns for new entries in laundry detergent.
description: A CAMPAIGN season is usually a time for airing dirty laundry.

title: Organic Growth In Toronto
description: The Toronto International Film Festival turns 25 this year, having shown 5,790 features and shorts, by actual count, since its inception in 1976. This year's edition, which runs from Sept. 7 to 16, will add 300 titles or so to that figure.

title: New Campaign Set By the Air Force
description: The United States Air Force is introducing a new recruitment campaign today in movie theaters nationwide.

title: Politics Runs Through More Than Campaigns
description: THIS town tends to generate hot air of one kind or another year round, and the weather can get spectacularly toasty, even in a coolish summer like this one. Luckily, the city compensates with acres on acres of air-conditioned museum space, and a lot of very good art to fill it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, PHILIP JOHN
description: BURKE-Philip John, former sports writer, Age 65, of Millville, DE, died Wednesday, Aug. 23, 2000 at his residence. A visitation will be held at Parsell Funeral Homes & Crematorium, Atkins-Lodge Chapel, 1449 Kings Highway, Lewes on Sunday, August 27, 2000 from 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Anne's Catholic Church, Rt. 26, Bethany Beach, DE., at 11:00 A.M., on Monday, August 28, 2000. description: SING-An Van. Passed away on August 23, 2000. Beloved father of Nancy, Susan, Lisa, Donald, Celia and Bruce; grandfather to Nicole, Lindsay, Meredith, Andrew, Will, Lara, Jenny, Caitlin, Emily and Jillian. Funeral services are August 26th, 4-7 P.M., at the Hong Kong Funeral Home in Manhattan.

title: Love Phlows Between Phish and Phans
description: Sheer niceness is not a quality you expect to find in a rock concert film. But niceness is precisely the ambience of ''Bittersweet Motel,'' Todd Phillips's bland, unrevealing documentary of the hugely popular cult band Phish on tour in 1998.

description: Across the country, cutting taxes may not be the political weapon it once was, as Gov. George W. Bush of Texas seems to be discovering on the presidential campaign trail. But in New Jersey, where property taxes remain the nation's highest per capita, the idea never loses currency.

description: MACHLIN-Lawrence J., Ph.D. Died August 15, 2000. Beloved husband of Ruth, devoted father of Marc, Dr. Steven, and Paul, fatherin-law of Nancy, Paula and Lisa, adored grandfather of Hannah, Leah, Laura, Jared, Noah and Joshua. Brother of Dr. Stanley and Milton. His enthusiasm and love of life inspired all who knew him.

title: ARRESTS IN PLOT AGAINST EGG
description: British police officials said three men had been arrested and accused of plotting a heist in cyberspace to rob Egg P.L.C., the country's biggest stand-alone Internet bank. Egg, which has 1.1 million customers and is 80 percent owned by the insurer Prudential P.L.C., denied a newspaper report that it had lost money and said it had installed software to help the police track down the hackers. Some investors have expressed worries about security at Web banks. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: China Arrests Evangelicals, Including 3 From the U.S.
description: One hundred and thirty evangelical Christians, including three visiting Americans on a religious mission, were arrested in central China on Wednesday as they attended a revival, according to a human rights monitor and the Americans' pastor in California.

title: A Telephone Contract Set, Service Is Next
description: Verizon Communications and the remainder of its striking workers settled a walkout late Wednesday after an 18-day strike. It will take the company almost twice that long to work through its backlog of repairs and orders.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a visit by Vice President Al Gore and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman to a Jewish community center in Florida misattributed a Yiddish greeting. It was Mr. Lieberman, not Mr. Gore, who said, ''Shalom aleichem''; Mr. Gore said, ''Mazel tov.''

title: Doing the Math of Air Delays; Traffic Grows, but La Guardia Cannot
description: Anthony D. Layne, the terminal duty manager at La Guardia Airport, looked through his van's swishing windshield wipers and sized up the traffic jam of jumbo jets idling before him on the taxiway.

title: Hedge Fund Founder Charged With Defrauding Its Investors
description: Michael W. Berger, a hedge fund manager, was charged yesterday with defrauding 300 people who invested about $575 million in his fund.

title: F.T.C. SUES WEB SITES OVER BILLING
description: The Federal Trade Commission and the New York attorney general have sued the owners and operators of a network of sex-oriented Web sites, including www.playgirl.com and www.highsociety.com, asserting they illegally billed thousands of people for services that were advertised as free, and for charging many others who never visited the Web sites at all. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, contends that Crescent Publishing Group of New York, along with 64 affiliated corporations, routinely charge people who provide credit card information ostensibly required to verify they were over 18 before they could view the sex sites. Telephone calls to Crescent Publishing, and its owner, Bruce Chew, and principal, David Bernstein, were not returned yesterday.

title: Gap Widens Again on Tests Given to Blacks and Whites
description: A gap between test scores of black and white students that had narrowed through the 1980's widened from 1990 to 1999, according to results released yesterday by the federal Department of Education, with the average black 17-year-old reading only about as well as the average white 13-year-old.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO STEADY. The euro was little changed but may strengthen in coming days on expectations that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 90.19 cents, up from 89.96 cents.

title: ZEDILLO ORDERED TO SUBMIT REPORT
description: In a sign of a growing division of powers, Mexico's Supreme Court ordered President Ernesto Zedillo to give Congress details of trust fund operations carried out by the failed bank Banca Union S.A. The court's unanimous ruling that bank secrecy laws do not apply when public funds are used to rescue troubled banks is a victory for Mexico's lower house of Congress. Legislators had requested the information on Union's trust funds to carry out an extensive audit of the government's $76 billion bailout of banks after the 1995 peso crisis. Mr. Zedillo's government had argued that turning over the documents would violate bank secrecy laws.

title: Fassel's Top Assistant Quits
description: Jim Skipper, the Giants' former offensive coordinator who was named assistant head coach during the off-season, has left the team to become the head coach of the Memphis franchise of the XFL, the pro football venture of the World Wrestling Federation.

title: Got a Little List
description: Great wine lists should reflect a restaurant's identity and ambitions while offering bottles that complement the food at all price levels. These 12 places have some of the most interesting wine lists in New York. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Unusual Lineup Makes for Bad Baseball but a Good Victory
description: The ball was launched hard off the bat and appeared headed for center field. Chad Curtis thought he had led off the Rangers' ninth inning with an exclamation, until pitcher Mariano Rivera raised his glove and denied Curtis a leadoff single. The ball knocked Rivera backward, leaving him with an expression somewhere between a smile and a grimace.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Where 'Thwock' Is Beautiful Music
description: As I go down the boardwalk that leads from the No. 7 train toward the National Tennis Center, the gray skies blending with the gray decking, I realize that something's missing. That's it, the scalpers. Because this is one of those 48 weeks of the year when this section of Flushing Meadows in Queens is home to the Casey Stengel M.T.A. rail depot -- you can look it up -- rather than the pathway to the center of the tennis world.

title: Mexican President-Elect Warmly Greeted in Washington
description: Vicente Fox Quesada, the next president of Mexico a land he envisions far closer to the United States, with borders no more than lines on a map -- started laying out his vision to the present and future leaders of the United States today.

description: Technology Briefings

They could be Cinderella's slippers. For in the next hour and a half she will be transported from the world of a senior with her share of aches and pains to that of a fairy princess, dancing waltzes, tangos and rumbas with a series of princely partners.
