description: Harry Bronstein, a veteran New York City official who was instrumental in changes that made it easier for women and members of minority groups to become police officers and sanitation workers, died on Aug. 3 in Los Angeles. He was 83 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: The Big City; Is Food Safe Just Because It's Organic?
description: IN a column last week criticizing the press for alarmist coverage of pesticides, I referred to a danger of organic food. Environmentalists and organic farmers have now criticized that allusion as alarmist. As a devout opponent of bogus food scares, I owe the critics a hearing.

The purchase was a stock transaction valued at $95 million. Website Results, with 36 employees and revenue estimated at $6 million for the first half of this year from clients like eBay and E*Trade, becomes an autonomous division of 24/7 Media. Douglas C. Wagner, 34, continues as president at Website Results. Allison Fass (NYT)

description: In a ruling that justices described as a judicial watershed, the Mexican Supreme Court ordered President Ernesto Zedillo today to turn over to Congress secret banking data relating to questionable financing of Mr. Zedillo's 1994 campaign.

title: Buchanan and Reform Rival Play the Wheel of Fortune
description: In Iowa yesterday, an aide to Secretary of State Chester J. Culver put a slip of paper inside each of two black canisters. On one was written ''Buchanan-Foster,'' on the other ''Hagelin-Goldhaber.'' When the canisters had been placed in a glass bowl on a stand outside his office in the Capitol rotunda, Mr. Culver walked up, stirred them around and lifted one out.

description: The attempt by the United States to repeat as Olympic champion in women's soccer, already made difficult by an arduous schedule, was further threatened yesterday when Michelle Akers announced her retirement from international competition, saying she would not participate in next month's Games in Sydney, Australia.

title: Ford Attacks the Lawyers Pursuing Suits Over Tires
description: Officials of the Ford Motor Company lashed out today at plaintiffs' lawyers suing the automaker and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., accusing them of endangering public safety by calling for a broader recall of tires and of distributing Ford documents out of context to journalists.

title: Strong, Modest and Sincere Behind All the Giddy Cheer
description: Since ''Bring It On'' is a movie about high school cheerleaders, you might expect whatever plot it has to be a flimsy scaffolding for the shameless exploitation of young women in short skirts -- a slice of diet cheesecake, a ''Coyote Not Quite So Ugly.'' And you wouldn't be entirely wrong. Kirsten Dunst, who plays Torrance Shipman, the striving, energetic captain of a Southern California pompom squad, displays her bellybutton in nearly every frame of the picture, and when she's not wearing her cute red and black uniform, she's outfitted in pajamas, a bikini or, when modesty (or the school dress code) demands, a series of colorful sports bras.

description: Someday, perhaps, the Yankees will decide where their next home will be after their lease at Yankee Stadium expires in 2002. Only then will the Mets, who know where they want to put their retractable roof stadium, get their city financing.

title: INTEL LOOKING INTO NEW AREA
description: Intel is forming an industry working group to foster standards and protocols for so-called peer-to-peer computing, particularly in business environments. Popularized by music distribution services like Napster and Gnutella, peer-to-peer computing is a set of technologies that enable the direct exchange of services or data between computers. ''Peer-to-peer computing could be as important to the Internet's future as the Web browser was to its past,'' said Patrick Gelsinger, vice president and chief technology officer of the Intel Architecture Group. By using the collective processing power of the thousands of PC's at Intel in a peer-to-peer network, the company was able to mothball its mainframe computers, saving $500 million, he said. Lawrence M. Fisher (NYT)

title: Air Rage
description: After a summer of record delays and frayed nerves, the nation's flying public is being told the situation is untenable and will be fixed. It is a tale we have heard before, as recently as a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRITT, VERNON III
description: MERRITT-Vernon III, a photojournalist for Life magazine, died on August 17 from an accident at his home in Old Lyme, CT, age 59. Merritt's coverage of the civil rights movement and the early days of the Viet Nam war represent an important-and lastingcontribution to American photography. Merritt, who was from Montgomery, AL, studied journalism at the University of Alabama and graduated from Art Center School in Los Angeles. He returned to the South in 1963. He was among the first to document voter registration drives and Birmingham's segregation protests. His pictures appeared in Newsweek, the Saturday Evening Post, and Life. When Tuskegee schools were ordered to integrate, he joined black students on their first day at their new school. The bus carrying them was waylaid by a white mob, including the local sheriff. Merritt was taken from the bus, beaten, threatened with lynching and jailed. Merritt was one of the first journalists drawn to the war in Viet Nam. He went as a free-lance, his photographs handled by the agency Black Star. In 1965, he was wounded by sniper fire, an injury that left him partially paralyzed for some months. When he recovered and was able to work again, Life magazine hired him as a staff photographer. He remained with the magazine until it ceased publication in 1972. At Life, his work encompassed the breadth of American life-the uninhibited lifestyle of the '60s, the capture of Charles Manson, the home life of the astronauts, an epic essay on the trumpeter swan, the American farmer, and one of his personal favorites-a pampered pig on a pillowy couch. He was an adventurous sailor, a member of the Cruising Club of America, who had recently sailed his sloop Talisman, to Greenland. He is survived by his wife, Linda Stanley of Old Lyme, CT and three children, Kimberley Salido of San Gabriel, CA, Vernon (Kip) Merritt IV of Highland Lakes, NJ, and Blaine Caravaggi of NY, NY. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 9 at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Road, at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave, Montgomery, AL 36104.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, AUDREY
description: HELLER-Audrey. On August 23rd, 2000 at the age of 83. Beloved wife of James Heller, one month before their 60th wedding anniversary. Survived by her devoted daughter, Barbara, and son-in-law, Edgar Freitag, and loving son, Steven, and daughter-in-law, Michelle Heller, and precious grandchildren, Eve Freitag, Harry and Claudia Falk, Elizabeth and Peter Dranoff, Larry and Debbie Freitag, Katherine Heller, Sam Heller, and great-grandchildren, Michael Falk, Andrew Dranoff, Gabrielle and Robert Freitag, and many close and loving sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews, and friends. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Friday, August 25th, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Temple Israel Cemetery.

title: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS NARROWS
description: Japan's trade surplus declined as the economy showed signs of life. The Ministry of Finance said the country's trade surplus in July fell 19.3 percent, to 1 trillion yen, from the corresponding month last year while Japan's surplus with the United States, its biggest trading partner, declined 13.8 percent, to 620.8 billion yen. Economists said the narrowing trade surplus reflected Japan's growing appetite to consume. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Travers Favorites Lack The Name, Not the Game
description: One was a star 2-year-old who is now on the comeback trail from a knee injury, another has done his best running in Canada, the third is trying to become only the fifth gelding to win the Travers Stakes in 131 years. Over all, it's not the most star-studded field in the history of the Midsummer Derby, the oldest race in the nation for 3-year-olds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, BROTHER BARTHOLOMEW ALBERT, F.S.C.
description: CLARK-Brother Bartholomew Albert, F.S.C., 80, of De La Salle Hall, Lincroft, NJ on Aug. 24, 2000. Brother Albert was the founder of Theta Alpha Kappa-the National Honor Society of Religious Studies/Theology and served as President from 1977-2000. His assignments included De La Salle Institute, St. Bernard's School, Bishop Loughlin High School, De La Salle College, and Manhattan College. He is survived by a sister, Dorothy McCarthy and was predeceased by a brother, John. Calling hours will be held at De La Salle Hall, Lincroft, NJ on Friday from 2:004:00 and 6:30 to 7:30 PM. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at De La Salle Hall on Friday at 8:00 PM. A Committal service will be held on Saturday at 10:30 AM at De La Salle Hall followed by interment at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Malboro, NJ. Memorial donations to the De La Salle Nursing Development, care of De La Salle Hall, 810 Newman Springs Rd., Lincroft, NJ 07738 would be appreciated.

title: Abuja Journal; Nigeria's Showplace Awaits 'Big Man' From U.S.
description: The street was wide open, with more lanes than cars, on a quiet afternoon here in Nigeria's shiny new capital. But somehow, Usman Muhammad, an excitable 28-year-old taxi driver, had gotten into a fight with a Peugeot immediately recognizable as a government-owned car.

Elliott, who is now the Jets' backup left tackle, will miss the season opener at Green Bay and will not be paid for that week, losing a total of $29,411.76.

description: Dr. Julian Nance Carsey, a Maryland college president who twice vanished and created a new life for himself, died on Sunday at his home in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 65.

title: When Basketball Is a Matter of Faith
description: Fifty or so basketball players -- college players or college bound -- were shooting in the gymnasium at the State University of New York at Stony Brook last Sunday. Amid the thump of balls, the snap of nets and the morning sunlight streaking in from windows, one would hardly have picked out the skinny, redheaded kid as unusual.

title: A New Kind of Neighbor
description: The elections of July 2 brought the end of 71 years of virtual one-party rule and inaugurated my country's first experience in a democratic rotation of power. Mexico's electoral institutions, built over several rounds of gradual reform, proved their maturity and reliability. The smoothness of our transition, the civility shown by all the political actors and the statesmanship demonstrated by president Ernesto Zedillo are all reflections of our enormous transformation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REPETTI, PETER J.
description: REPETTI-Peter J. Of Short Hills and Spring Lake, NJ, a prominent New York Coorporate Attorney, died Thursday, August 24, 2000, at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, NJ. Until his retirement Mr. Repetti was a member of the law firm Fulbright and Jaworski, formerly known as Reavis and McGrath, for over 50 years. He also served on the Board of Directors of several corporations, notably Pulitzer Publishing Company of St. Louis, Harry M. Stevens of New Jersey and Block Drug Company of Jersey City. Mr. Repetti was also a Knight of Malta. Born in New York, Mr. Repetti graduated from Westside High School in Newark, NJ, The University of Notre Dame and the Harvard Law School, where he was the Editor of the Harvard Law Review. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII. He is survived by his wife of 49 years, the former Joan Campbell, four children, Grace Mailman, Joan, Charles and Christina Long; a sister, Edith Klein; a brother, George; and many nieces and nephews. Visitation will be Sunday 2-4, 7-9 pm at Meehan Funeral Home, 555 Warren Ave, Spring Lake Heights, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church, Spring Lake, Monday 9:30 AM. Burial St. Catharine's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family requests that memorial contributions be made to Turning Point Inc. Relocation Fund, P.O. Box 111, Verona, NJ 07044

description: The Arizona Diamondbacks didn't know when they were well off. They certainly didn't know their place. Win a division championship in their second season of existence, will they? Yeah, we'll teach those uppity Southwesterners.

description: Although the Giants have not gone without a victory in the preseason since the 1971 team went 0-6, Giants Coach Jim Fassel, whose team is 0-3, will not go to extraordinary means to defeat the Baltimore Ravens tonight in the final preseason game.

description: The incidence of diabetes increased markedly in the United States from 1990 to 1998, including a 76 percent rise in cases among people in their 30's, researchers are reporting today, and they warn that the disease will take a harsh toll in disability, death and medical expenses in decades to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKARD, ROBERT K.
description: PACKARD-Robert K. Beloved husband of Bobbie Packard; Cherished father of Lauren (11), Cassie (9) and Sam (6); Loving brother of Dana Packard, Becky Packard and Leslie Martin; Devoted son of John and Barbara Packard. A resident of Hillsborough, CA. He was 42 years old. Mr. Packard was a principal of Texas Pacific Group. He received his MBA from Stanford (1989), B.A. from Harvard College (1980) and J.D. from Harvard Law School (1983). A Memorial Service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in San Mateo on Monday, September 4, 2000, at 4:30 P.M. with a reception to follow at the Packard home in Hillsborough.
