description: Onur Elgin, a Turkish teenager, has no doubts about why he spent his summer vacation studying physics. In fluent English, he explains that he wants to succeed for his school, his country and the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, HILDA
description: FARKAS-Hilda. Died peacefully in her 99th year at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City. Born in Hungary to Salamon and Etelka Buchner. Studied in Berlin, Germany and immigrated to the U.S. as a young woman in 1928. She had seven brothers and sisters, the beloved Rudolf, Aladar, Jeno, Hugo, Kamilla, Mariska and Ella. Hilda was a sensitive lady, devoted to her husband, Dr. Alexander Farkas. She was loved and respected by everyone. She was grateful to her physicians, nurses and associates & her loyal caring staff throughout the last many years of her life. A large extended family, friends and associates are mourning her in New York, California, Holland and Hungary. There are no immediate survivors. A Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone; in August some galleries are open by appointment only. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ROBERT NEIL
description: KAYE-Robert Neil. It is with profound regret that the employees of the Kings County District Attorney's Office and I mourn the passing of our friend and dear colleague, Deputy District Attorney Robert Neil Kaye. Robert Kaye was an extraordinary individual and an expert in criminal justice, who served the people of the State of New York for over 30 years. He distinguished himself serving 3 District Attorneys and the former Mayor of the City of New York, Edward I. Koch. Robert Kaye was a person of impeccable integrity and compassionate humanity. We will miss him deeply and we offer our sincere condolences to his beloved daughter Rebecca and his entire family. Charles J. Hynes, Kings County District Attorney

title: For Now, Experts Discount Radiation Peril From Sub
description: The two nuclear reactors in the sunken Russian submarine Kursk should pose no immediate risk to the surrounding environment and only a moderate risk in the coming decades, naval experts and environmentalists say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: No Lasting Problems Seen For Mitsubishi in Japan

title: E*TRADE BUYING A FINANCIAL START-UP
description: The E*Trade Goup, the online brokerage firm in Menlo Park, Calif., is scooping up another Internet start-up. This time it is PrivateAccounts.com, a Minneapolis-based venture that planned to connect individual investors with well-known money managers. E*Trade did not disclose what it was paying for PrivateAccounts.com, which has not even opened for business. Later this year, E*Trade plans to start charging fees to customers with $100,000 or more that they want managed for them, said Liat Rorer, an E*Trade vice president. Ms. Rorer declined to say whom the managers would be or what the cost would be. E*Trade also just bought the Electronic Investing Corporation, a San Francisco-based start-up that had planned to offer online trading of baskets of stocks. Through these acquisitions, the brokerage firm hopes to broaden its product line and become less dependent on commissions from stock trades. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDER, RUTH
description: WENDER-Ruth. Passed away August 23, 2000. Wife of the late Jerry Wender. Beloved twin sister of Irene Winkelman. Devoted mother of Theodore and his wife Vicki, Jill Spitz and her husband Richard. Adored grandmother of Daniel, Austin, Jenny and Max. Loved by all her family and friends. You will be missed deeply by all.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, AUDREY PRICE MARGOLIS
description: KAUFMANN-Audrey Price Margolis. Formerly of Albany, NY. Died at the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, NY on August 24, 2000. Predeceased by her husbands Matthew Margolis and Albert Kaufmann. Survived by her brother, Dr. William Price (Sydell) of Phoenix, her children, Douglas P. Margolis, Ph.D., Judith Katz (Herbert) of New York, and John Margolis, M.D. (Holly), of Waterville, ME and her granddaughters, Marah Ann Katz and Sarah Elizabeth Margolis. Graduate of Wellesley College, Class of 1935. A leader of many civic and Jewish organizations in Albany, she was especially proud to serve as President of Vanguard Volunteers for the Albany Symphony Orchestra, and as the first woman President of Congregation Beth Emeth, Albany. Services will be held at the Beth Emeth Cemetery, Loudonville, NY on Friday, August 25 at 3PM. Memorial contributions to the Albany Symphony Orchestra, 19 Clinton Ave., Albany, NY 12207 or a charity of one's choice. For information call Levine Memorial Chapel, 1-800-427-0280.

title: Dropping of Ad Exposes a Split On Bush Tactics
description: The cancellation of a Republican Party television advertisement attacking Al Gore's trustworthiness has exposed tensions within the Bush campaign over whether to go negative against the vice president now.

title: Analysts Say Mitsubishi's Problems Shouldn't Linger
description: Mitsubishi Motors has had perhaps its worst week in its history. On Tuesday, the company acknowledged that it had concealed customer complaints for more than two decades, and in a scene that was televised nationally, its president profusely apologized to the transportation minister. Its stock has dropped more than 6 percent this week.

title: Metro Business; Fine Wine Auction Moves to St. Louis
description: Phillips Auctioneers, which began wine auctions in New York in 1998 and suspended them last December, said yesterday it would not resume them here in the fall wine auction season, which begins next month.

title: New Epidemic Proving Fatal To Foxhounds
description: For months, no one could figure out why the foxhounds here were suddenly dying.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Experiment Backs Novel Theory on Origin of Life
description: A maverick theory about the origin of life has received striking support from an experiment that mimicked the violent interactions of deep seated rock and common gases in the Hadean epoch, the days when the earth had just formed as a planet.

title: He Was Only a Fabric Peddler, but He Sure Sold Her a Bill of Goods
description: The moment the star-crossed title characters in Paul Morrison's somber love story ''Solomon and Gaenor'' set eyes on each other, your heart sinks. It is immediately obvious there is nowhere for these young lovers to travel but down an awfully familiar path from clandestine ecstasy to pariahhood to tragedy that could take any of three final twists, all equally predictable. Surrendering yourself to this well-acted film is never a question of wondering when the last shoe will drop, but one of how much you'll allow yourself to identify with its likable but foolish lovers, who break the strict social rules of their claustrophobically dingy community and pay the usual price.

title: Public Interests; A Reality-Television Campaign
description: If George W. Bush were a ''Survivor'' contestant, he would have been Kelly, who made it to the finals with her ability to recall the details of her former teammates' family histories.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the election for governor in the Mexican state of Chiapas, and a related map, misspelled the name of a town where one candidate held a campaign rally. It was Amatenango, not Amen tenango.

title: Where Heritage And Tranquillity Share the Wealth
description: ''Walk your horses or pay two dollars' fine.''

title: A Contract, Almost: Levy and Board Are Hung Up on Housing
description: Three months after the Board of Education voted unanimously to appoint Harold O. Levy as chancellor of the city's school system, Mr. Levy and the board have yet to agree on contract terms, mainly because of differences over how much he will be paid for a housing allowance.

title: BRITISH WATER DEAL
description: In an effort to gain the scale that will allow it to bid for larger projects, Anglian Water, a British water utility, said it was buying Morrison P.L.C., a Scottish construction company, for $:262.5 million, or about $177 million. The cash deal values Morrison at 385 pence a share. The combined company is expected to focus on expanding its reach within the electricity, gas, transport and telecommunications sectors. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Poland is a country doing better than it feels -- it's doing better than it thinks it's doing.''

title: Sensible Rules for Stem Cell Research
description: The Clinton administration issued guidelines this week that would at long last allow federal funding of research on stem cells derived from human embryos. This avenue of inquiry offers the potential for breathtaking medical breakthroughs. Even so, the guidelines are sure to be challenged by pro-life members of Congress who have vowed to block the needed funding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAINIS, BERNARD
description: KRAINIS-Bernard. Aston Magna's Board of Directors, staff and artists mourn the death of Bernard Krainis. One of its founders, he stepped in at a crucial time to ensure the continuity of the Festival. His warmth, kind spirit and magnificent musicianship will be sorely missed by all who were fortunate enough to have known him and to have heard him perform.

title: Metro Business; Frankfurt Flight to End
description: American Airlines will end its daily flight between Kennedy International Airport and Frankfurt, the airline announced yesterday.

title: Plant Orders For Big Items Have Largest Decline Ever
description: Factory orders for aircraft, electrical equipment and other durable goods showed their largest decline on record in July, government figures showed today, suggesting manufacturers may scale back production in the months ahead as the economy slows.

title: Gore Finds His Groove On Postconvention Roll
description: Vice President Al Gore entered a convention hall in Chicago on Tuesday afternoon to a raucous ovation from union carpenters that would have been hard to imagine during the many dark days of his lengthy campaign for the presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HYMAN
description: COHEN-Hyman. Died August 24, age 70. Survived and cherished by his wife of 50 years Mary, sons Peter and Howard, daughter Esther, grandchildren Paul and Max, daughters - in - law Gina and Deirdre, son-in-law Alan and sister Rebecca. Hyman Cohen was a veteran of the U.S. Army. He was an outstanding member of the community. He was known for his boundless energy and commitment to many worthy causes. He served as Vice President of the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center and as Chairman of its Baord of Governers; President of School Board District 21; Vice President of the Brighton Beach Community Group; Treasurer of the Infants Home of Brooklyn; President of the Ocean Front Development Corp, a non-profit organization for the betterment of the community. He was a member of Community Planning Baord Number 13, member of the Board of Governers of the Shore Front ''Y,'' and a member of the Jewish Veterans. For many years he sponsored and organized the annual dinner for the benefit of the New York Aquarium in Coney Island. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn School for Special Children and a member of the Board of Directors of the National Kidney Foundation of New York and New Jersey. He was Chairman of the Kingsborough Community College Foundation. He was a loyal executive of Alexander Muss & Sons for 45 years, primarily as Vice President and General Manager of the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club. He was also an officer of Deere Real Estate Services, Inc. Hy, will be remembered for his generosity, vitality and courage. Services today 10 AM, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, Inc, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, New York.

title: MONY GROUP IS BUYING ADVEST GROUP FOR $275 MILLION
description: The life insurance company MONY Group agreed yesterday to acquire the Advest Group, a financial services provider, for about $275 million in stock and cash. Under the agreement, MONY will issue about 3.9 million common shares to buy Advest. The purchase price will be fixed shortly before closing, using the 10-day average closing price of MONY's shares at that time. Using the current average, Advest holders would receive $31 a share, in their choice of cash, MONY stock or a combination. Shares of Advest dropped $2.25 yesterday, to $29.75; MONY shares fell 31 cents, to $33.44. The deal gives MONY, which is based in New York, Advest's network of more than 500 financial advisers, who serve affluent customers.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Estrogen Heart Study Proves Discouraging
description: Anew study finds that estrogen replacement therapy, which doctors have long hoped will prevent heart disease in postmenopausal women, does nothing to slow the disease's progression in those whose arteries have already been partly blocked by it.

title: An Armed Texas Family Resists the Courts
description: With a revolver and a bowie knife strapped to his hip and a semiautomatic rifle resting next to him on a barbed wire fence, Jonathon Gray pondered the question: Just what would happen if law enforcement officers tried to enter his father's 47-acre homestead?

title: Metro Business; T.W.A. Adds Flights
description: Trans World Airlines will add flights between Kennedy International Airport and three California cities, it announced yesterday.

title: All Deals Are Off, and Ewing Is Still a Knick
description: Three days after planning to announce a trade of Patrick Ewing, two days after some reporters and many fans lambasted the longtime Knicks star as a failure and a boor, and one day after desperately working the phones in search of another deal, General Manager Scott Layden said that the franchise's creaky center would most likely begin his 16th professional season with the Knicks.

title: METRO EARNINGS UP 10%
description: Europe's No. 2 retailer, Metro A.G., said its first-half pretax profit rose 10.4 percent as gains in food wholesaling and consumer electronics offset losses from its four other businesses. Profit from ordinary activities before tax rose to 138 million marks ($64 million) from 125 million marks a year earlier. So far, Metro has pinned its hopes on expansion abroad to escape a seven-year slump in German consumer spending. Sales rose 8.4 percent, to 42.71 billion marks, in the first half, led by a 33 percent jump in Poland.

title: COURT BLOCKS E.ON PURCHASE
description: An Atlanta-based power company, the Southern Company, won at least a temporary victory in its battle to keep a grip on the Berlin electric utility Bewag A.G. A German court blocked E.ON A.G, Germany's second-biggest utility company, from selling its 49 percent stake in Bewag to Hamburgische Electricitats-Werke. Southern, which owns 26 percent of Bewag, wants to acquire full control as part of an effort to bid on the big eastern German power company, VEAG A.G. A court upheld an injunction against E.ON's deal. Edmund L. Andrews(NYT)

title: Sub Tragedy Reveals a New Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Withdraws Its Bid for APBNews
description: August 25, 2000

title: Looking at Ethnic Identity While Looking for Laughs
description: ''Catfish in Black Bean Sauce'' deals with adopted children reared by parents of a different race, but Chi Muoi Lo, the writer and director, plays around with the idea in an unexpected way. The film, full of twists, tries to exploit all the comic streams running through its narrative, a gambit Mr. Lo isn't quite up to seizing. (He has more ideas than he knows what to do with.) And the movie isn't quite as much fun as it could be.

title: On the Road to Freedom With a Nasty Computer
description: After gazing for a while at the super super super computer that is the dominant prop in ''Imperfect Chemistry'' at the Minetta Lane Theater, it seems only natural to wonder how much better the results might have been had it written and composed this new musical.

title: Number of Car Dealers Online Rising
description: August 25, 2000

title: Master of Spin Puts His Craft to Work for Himself
description: EYEWITNESS TO POWER

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP; Mahan Takes Steps Toward Record
description: Hunter Mahan, an 18-year-old freshman-to-be at Southern California who has not even sat in on his first college lecture, took two major steps yesterday in his attempt to break Tiger Woods's record by four months of being the youngest golfer the win the United States Amateur.

title: NEXT LEVEL STOCK LOSES HALF ITS VALUE ON ANALYST REPORT
description: The shares of Next Level Communications lost more than half their value yesterday after Lehman Brothers said Qwest Communications International might reduce purchases from the company, a phone-equipment maker. Next Level dropped $49.81 a share, to $41.75. The decline wiped out more than $4 billion in market value. Next Level had more than quadrupled in the last year on optimism for its equipment that lets phone companies deliver Internet and cable-television services. In June, Qwest bought U S West, which accounts for two-thirds of Next Level's revenue. Qwest will probably not ''move forward aggressively'' with U S West's plan to install the Next Level gear, a Lehman Brothers analyst, Steven Levy, wrote.

title: Pity The Poor Stepmom
description: Last week's report of three studies showing that children raised by stepmothers are likely to receive less food, health care and education than children raised by their biological mothers should not have come as much of a surprise -- especially to mothers. However impolitic it may be to ask, who really believes that stepmothers can possibly replicate the care of the original mother, notwithstanding the moist optimism of movies like ''Stepmom,'' in which the earnest efforts of Julia Roberts are enough to secure a stepchild's happy future?

title: Deal Is Struck On Placement Of Instructors
description: Ending weeks of conflict with the state, the New York City Board of Education agreed yesterday to place up to 400 certified teachers this fall in vacancies at some of the worst-performing elementary schools.

title: GERMAN FACTORY PRICES JUMP
description: German factory prices rose in July at their fastest annual rate in nine years, mainly because of the continuing strength of oil prices. The producer price index rose 0.7 percent from June and 3.3 percent for the year, much faster than analysts' forecasts. The annual rate was the highest since July 1991. But even excluding the rise in oil prices, producer prices rose 0.6 percent for the month and 2.8 percent for the year.

title: Analysts Say AOL Safe on Messaging
description: August 25, 2000

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Circuits on Aug. 17 about a study showing that regular Internet users stay in greater touch with family and friends than infrequent users included incorrect figures from an author of the study. (The study's conclusions were unaffected.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Lazio Distances Himself, by About 40%, From Bush Tax Cut Plan
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio moved to distance himself from Gov. George W. Bush's tax cut plan today, offering his own package of business and personal tax reductions that by his campaign's calculation is nearly 40 percent smaller than the one Mr. Bush has made a cornerstone of his presidential campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCAULIFFE, KEVIN M.
description: McAULIFFE-Kevin M. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Kevin M. McAuliffe, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Face to Face On Rushmore
description: In the late 50's MGM assigned Alfred Hitchcock and the screenwriter Ernest Lehman to make ''The Wreck of the Mary Deare,'' a project of zero interest to either of them. Hitchcock had no fully developed alternative to suggest, but he told Mr. Lehman he wanted to make something that had a chase across the presidential faces on Mount Rushmore. He also envisioned a scene at the United Nations in which the speaker on the podium would declare, ''I refuse to continue until the delegate from Peru wakes up.'' The delegate, of course, is dead.

title: A No-Pressure Arena For Testing All Makes
description: NICK BOBOTIS came to see the Lexus IS 300, but while he was at it, took a test drive in the Acura 3.2TL and the Infiniti I30, something he could never do at a single dealership; nearby, keys in the ignition, sat an Audi A4, a BMW 320i, a Chrysler 300M and a Lincoln LS -- names that constitute much of the roll call of midsize, upscale sedans.

title: Verizon Asks For Patience
description: It will take about a month for Verizon Communications to work through roughly 50,000 delayed repairs and more than 200,000 orders for new service as a result of the strike.

title: Cheney's C.E.O. Record
description: To the Editor:

title: More Diabetes, but Also More Hope
description: Each year the United States spends $98 billion caring for 16 million people with diabetes, and researchers reported this week that the disease is rapidly growing. Although we are able to control diabetes, only rarely do we cure it.

title: Up From the Ashes of a Cuban Cigar Case
description: TWO years ago, on a sultry August morning, Ken Aretsky was playing golf in Southampton and riding high indeed. That regrettable public unpleasantness at the ''21'' Club was long behind him (more about that later). He was loving his life as the doting father of two small children (more about that later, too). And he was basking in critical accolades for having created two successful new Manhattan restaurants, Patroon and Butterfield 81 (much, much more about that later, as well).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANN
description: MILLER-Ann. On August 24, 2000. Beloved wife of Isidore. Mother of Sherry (Ira) Cohen, Robin (Barry) Picker and Phyllis Miller. Grandmother of Brian and Matthew Cohen, and Jason, Rori, Marshall and Craig Picker. Services today 10AM at Midwood Chapel, Coney Island Avenue and Avenue M.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: POTLATCH CORP., Spokane, Wash., a producer of paper and lumber, said it would shut a plywood plant in Jaype, Idaho, and dismiss 215 workers because of falling plywood prices.

title: States Deregulate Energy at Their Peril
description: While reporters ogled celebrities at Barbra Streisand's bungalow during the Democratic Convention in Los Angeles, there was a real display of populism 100 miles to the south in San Diego. There politicians have enrolled two million citizens in a scary economic experiment. This year, San Diego became the first city in California to experience the end of state regulation of electricity prices.

title: BARAK PROPOSES PACT WITH LIKUD IF ARAFAT BALKS
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak said today that if peace talks with the Palestinians failed, he was prepared within ''a few weeks'' to invite Israel's conservative opposition to join in a broad government of ''national unity.''

title: Fighting Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about new information on a 1960's sex scandal in Britain that involved the Duchess of Argyll misattributed a lyric written for ''You're the Top,'' the Cole Porter song inspired by the duchess. The lyric, with a reference to Mussolini, was written by P. G. Wodehouse for the 1935 London production of ''Anything Goes.'' The lyricist was not Porter.

title: Joan Marsh, 85, a Movie Star in Two Eras
description: Joan Marsh, who made her film debut when she was 9 months old, played children's roles in silent films opposite Mary Pickford and returned to the screen in the 1930's and 40's as a glamorous blonde, died on Aug. 10 in Ojai, Calif. She was 85.

title: Suffolk Official Sponsors Plan To Sue I.N.S. to Spur Action
description: Blaming undocumented Hispanic workers for rising crime rates in Farmingville, a Suffolk County legislator wants to bring court action to compel the Immigration and Naturalization Service to move against illegal immigrants in the county.

title: ROLLS-ROYCE STOCK PLUNGES
description: The shares in the world's second-biggest aircraft engine maker, Rolls-Royce P.L.C., plummeted more than 20 percent after the company backed away from promises of double-digit growth next year. The fall was the biggest one-day decline since the stock began trading in 1988. Rolls-Royce, whose customers include Airbus Industrie and Boeing, set off the fall by saying its earnings would be flat through 2001. It reported a 93.5 percent fall in its first-half net income, to $:8 million, or $11.8 million, from $:123 million a year ago. John Rose, the company's chief executive, said he expected the setback in earnings growth to be a one-time event. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Smart African Itinerary
description: President Clinton has devoted unusual energy to strengthening ties between Africa and the United States. But some of Mr. Clinton's past efforts have led him to embrace leaders who were neither democrats nor statesmen. The journey he embarks on today is more promising.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE IS BUYING UNITS FROM CANADIAN RETAILER
description: American Eagle Outfitters, the casual-apparel retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the assets of three units of Dylex Ltd., a Canadian specialty retailer, for $74 million. The units are Thriftys, a retailer of casual clothing for teenagers; Braemer, an operator of 57 women's clothing stores; and National Logistics Services, a warehouse and distribution operation. Thriftys, with 115 stores mostly in Ontario, had sales of $99 million last year. American Eagle, based in Warrendale, Pa., is a retailer of casual clothing, accessories and footwear with 519 United States stores and annual sales of $895 million.

title: Levy Qualifies for Open
description: Harel Levy had lost two previous times to James Blake, but he is no longer the same Harel Levy. Just ask James Blake.

title: TELSTRA PACT IN HONG KONG
description: Australia's biggest telecommunications company, the Telstra Corporation, will invest $3 billion in ventures with Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd., Richard Li's Internet investment arm. Telstra will pay $1.5 billion for 40 percent of a venture that holds mobile phone assets that CyberWorks acquired this month. It will also buy $1.5 billion of bonds convertible into CyberWorks shares and start Internet and entertainment ventures with the Hong Kong company. Telstra hopes revenue from online alliances in Asia will offset sliding market share at home. ''We simply do not have the strength in Asia or the time to grow organically,'' Telestra's chief executive, Ziggy Switkowski, above, said.

title: G.O.P. Sends Clinton Bill to End Estate Tax
description: Shrugging off a veto threat, Republican leaders revved up a red tractor and dispatched a Montana cattle rancher to ride from Capitol Hill to the White House today to deliver their latest tax-cutting proposal, a bill to repeal the federal estate tax.

title: A Top Earner for Cambodia / 'You Haven't Seen Anything Yet' : Angkor Wat:After the War, Here Come the Tourists
description: BANTEAY SREI, Cambodia  Seated in the shade of giant trees that tower above the exquisite temple of Banteay Srei, six amputees, all victims of the war, invasion and civil conflict that wracked Cambodia for decades, played haunting folk tunes on traditional instruments.

title: The Crime of the Ancient Marinaras
description: ''Ju know what I ang? A clee-tchay.'' So says Raul Ventana (Miguel Sandoval), the Hispanic drug kingpin who is the designated heavy in Michael Dinner's slapdash, hyperactive new mobster comedy. ''Ju know what happens to clee-tchays?'' Ventana asks his minions, who look grateful to be back at work after the long hiatus of ''Miami Vice.'' ''They die.''

title: Arthur Newman, 92, a Baritone Heard in 50 Roles at City Opera
description: Arthur Newman, a baritone who sang with the New York City Opera in the 1940's and 50's, died on Aug. 6 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 92.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY MAKES PURCHASE
description: In a deal doubling its revenue, the Bracknell Corporation of Toronto agreed to buy the Able Telecom Holding Corporation for 199.5 million Canadian dollars, or $134.2 million, in stock and assumed debt. The deal gives Bracknell a six-year supplier contract with WorldCom Inc. Bracknell will exchange 0.6 share for each share of Able, which specializes in building and servicing fiber-optic networks. The agreement values Able, based in Roswell, Ga., at $3.09 a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about video e-mail messages misidentified the company that used the technology for a campaign promoting an Oracle Corporation conference. The campaign was created by MindArrow Systems of Aliso Viejo, Calif., not RadicalMail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLURMAN, HERMAN (PROFESSOR EMERITUS)
description: CLURMAN-Herman (Professor Emeritus). Devoted husband of Gloria. Beloved father of Ann Clurman and Judith Clurman Ruben. Dear father-in-law of Cantor Bruce Ruben. Loving brother of David Clurman and Bernice Rieger. Cherished grandfather of Ari Ruben. Services today 10 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Reborn in a Less Romantic Rio, Orpheus Seasons Samba With Rap
description: Carlos Diegues's ''Orfeu'' is based on the play by the Brazilian writer Vinicius de Moraes that also inspired Marcel Camus's 1959 film, ''Black Orpheus.'' Mr. Diegues is one of his country's leading directors. (His earlier films include ''Xica,'' ''Bye-Bye Brazil'' and ''Subway to the Stars.'') He has not so much remade ''Black Orpheus'' as tried to correct it and to bring the mythic resonances of the original play into line with the complicated realities of contemporary Brazil.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Austin, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, DAVID FRANCIS
description: MEAD-David Francis. Suddenly, in New York on August 22, 2000. Gifted composer and accomplished musician, founder of N.Y.C. based jingle house, MEAD MUSIC MAKERS. Adored son of Marian (Co. Laois, Ireland) and the late Walter. Beloved brother of John (and Wendy), Cecily (and Richard Motherway), and Andrea. Loving friend to Deirdre. Devoted uncle to Richard, Alicia and Daniel McDonald, Francesca and Phoebe Flynn, and Alexis and Emily Mead. Dear great uncle, nephew and friend. Services at Old Saint Patrick's Cathedral (Mott Street), Wednesday, August 30th, 4PM.

title: 'Buyers' Clubs' for Medical Services Crop Up
description: A variety of new companies are beginning to offer below-market prices on prescription drugs and services like doctor, dental and eye care and medical tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIN, JEAN
description: LAVIN-Jean. Of Orangeburg, NY. She had a life of spirit, love, courage and artistic talent. It was a privilege and a pleasure to be her child. Mrs. Lavin was the widow of Jack Lavin; beloved mother of Stanley Lavin of Great Neck and Eileen Rogers of Orangeburg, NY; grandmother of Evan and Michael Rogers and Andrew, Elizabeth and Nancy Lavin; great-grandmother of Alana, Stacy, Corey, Mark, Amber & Matthew Rogers & Madeline Sarah Lavin. Funeral Friday, August 25 at 12 PM at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State Street, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Video Game Giants to Fight Battle Royal in United States
description: The home video game industry is about to embark on what is certain to become a bitter and bloody year of new technology and cost-cutting, which many people in the business say will claim one or more victims.

title: Fine Quilts Of Provence: Les Boutis
description: Like a good man, a great antique quilt from Provence is hard to find.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKHEIMER, MARY ''MINNIE''
description: TURKHEIMER-Mary ''Minnie''. On August 20, 2000. Dearest mother of David Turkheimer and Karla Moskowitz and cherished grandmother of Amy, Eric and Stefan. ''And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.'' Services Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Ave. (9th & 10th Sts.), 1 PM Friday, August 25, 2000.

title: Bush Pushes Hemispheric Free Trade
description: Filed at 6:47 p.m. ET

title: Squabble Has Added An Edge to Travers
description: Trainers take jockeys off horses all the time. What is rare is a big-name trainer and a successful jockey snapping at each other in the days leading up to a big race.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JASON, EDITH (NANU)
description: JASON-Edith (Nanu). August 25, 1985. A wonderful wife and mother, always remembered and always loved. Bernie, Jack, Deb and Steven

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, FRANK J.
description: KING-Frank J. Franklin Lodge #

title: Payton and Baker Arrive for Olympics
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24  With the biggest trade in National Basketball Association history officially dead, Vin Baker and Gary Payton were unhappy as they arrived today on their first full day as members of the Olympic men's basketball team.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARETT, LAWRENCE, DR.
description: JARETT-Lawrence, Dr. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our cherished and devoted member Dr. Lawrence Jarett. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Services will be held at Temple Sinai of Roslyn, Friday at 12:00 Noon. Rabbi Michael White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Michael J. Paul, President

title: Feud Among Ulster's Protestant Guerrillas Claims Third Victim
description: A Belfast man gunned down overnight was the third victim this week in a feud among Protestant paramilitary groups that has brought British troops back onto the streets of Northern Ireland, officials said today.

title: Wheeler-Dealer, Tycoon, Trader
description: In his hometown, Li Ka-shing, the tycoon known here as Superman, still vaults tall buildings with ease. But in Europe, where Mr. Li is just another mogul, he seems to have lost his extraordinary powers.

title: American Is Denied Bail
description: Russian officials denied bail today to Edmond Pope, 53, an American businessman held on espionage charges, rejecting his lawyer's argument that Mr. Pope has cancer and needs specialized medical treatment.

title: So, the U.N. Has This Secret Action Unit . . .
description: Ludicrous, impenetrable and headache-inducing: the newest Wesley Snipes film, ''The Art of War,'' is all that and more. In portraying its Chinese villains as devious triple- crossing schemers who have devised levels of treachery that Americans have only just begun to understand and adapt for their own purposes, it is also racist. Oh, those enigmatic Asians! They're so far ahead of us in fiendishness and, of course, inscrutability.

title: Neil Wilson, 44, Tenor Who Sang A Memorable 'Werther' at the Met
description: Neil Wilson, a tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera from 1988 to 1993 and was particularly admired for his portrayal of the title role in Massenet's ''Werther,'' died on Monday. He was 44 and had homes in New York and Berlin.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINUSE, JEAN FAIRSERVIS
description: MINUSE-Jean Fairservis. December 26, 1911-August 25, 1998. You think the dead we loved ever truly leave us

title: NEW MP3.COM HEARING SET
description: Hearings are set for Monday in the copyright infringement trial of Seagram's Universal Music Group against MP3.com, after a ruling on Wednesday by a federal judge that could limit the damages owed by the Internet music start-up. Federal District Judge Jed S. Rakoff ruled that damages would be assessed for copyright violations of each compact disc, not for every individual song that was infringed by Mp3.com, as the recording industry had wanted. Universal and four other major record labels sued MP3.com in January, saying it had made illegal digital copies of songs available on its site. In April, Judge Rakoff ruled against MP3.com, saying it had infringed record company copyrights. MP3.com has settled with four of the record companies. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Odds Are This Gambler's Got Problems
description: In ''Spent'' Max (Jason London) is such an inveterate gambler that he leaves everything to chance. He picks his sports bets by writing team names on a piece of paper, then carefully tearing it up and flinging the scraps into the air. He bets on the teams whose names are on the pieces he grabs. It's as imaginative a way to play out a gambling addiction as has been seen in the movies in a long time. This crazy character moment comes early enough in the picture to make the audience believe there is more such characterization ahead. There isn't, though. ''Spent'' coasts on that gesture and then finally runs out of steam.

title: SYCAMORE NETWORKS SALES SOARS
description: A maker of fiber optic network equipment, Sycamore Networks, which is two and a half years old, reported a fiscal fourth-quarter profit, compared with a year-earlier loss, as sales jumped almost eightfold. Net income in the period ended July 31 was $18.3 million, or 7 cents a diluted share, in contrast to a loss of $9.08 million, or 6 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Sales of $90.4 million were up 53 percent from $59.2 million in the previous quarter and from $11.3 million in the fourth quarter of last year. The company's gear carries and switches voice and data traffic on telecommunications networks.

title: For Debates, Three Isn't a Crowd
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Sounding the Gong in the South China Sea
description: The first premise of game-playing is that nobody rebels against the game itself. That premise worked almost to a fault in ''Survivor,'' the desert-island game show -- let's discard forever the phrase ''reality-based'' -- that ended Wednesday night. If survival had really been at stake, the first thing the 16 contestants would have done last March, when the show was taped in the South China Sea, was take hostage the CBS camera crew and the host, Jeff Probst, and demand $16 million for their release. It would have made better drama and edgier viewing, something like a remake of ''Papillon'' by the producers of ''The Blair Witch Project.''

title: A Life Cut Short by the Nazis Endures in a Painted 'Opera'
description: The short stay on earth of Charlotte Salomon (1917-1943) didn't draw much notice while it lasted. A loner crushed by family tragedy and remembered as unmemorable by schoolmates who survived her, she had few friends. And when she and her unborn child died at Auschwitz, oblivion awaited. Yet she defeated it, leaving behind an astonishing work of art that transformed her life into a poignant opera of paintings, words and music.

title: Sports of The Times; Lasorda Has Higher Calling
description: WHEN he was managing for the O'Malley family, Tom Lasorda used to preach that his blood was Dodger blue. It was a great shtick that earned him considerable television time in his early years.

title: For 'Miss Saigon,' Light at the End
description: THEY call it the Nightmare. That is how the crew refers to the sequence in which the metal embassy fence drops in, the helipad moves down, the sound of whipping blades intensifies, and a life-size chopper descends.

title: Images of Tribal Africa, In a Hollywood Style
description: ''Passages,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, is like a giant walk-in issue of National Geographic magazine: it is entertaining, titillating and, in places, thrilling, but as art and anthropology it is egregious kitsch.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bush Says Rival's Tax-Cut Plan Fails Middle Class
description: Gov. George W. Bush sought to seize the offensive today on the issue of tax cuts, asserting that Vice President Al Gore's plan was so narrow and complicated that it would fail to lower taxes for many middle-class Americans.

title: Sub Tragedy Reveals a New Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: City's Ban on Tour Flights From Seaplane Base Is Upheld
description: The city acted legally last year when it refused to allow an air charter company to fly tour groups from the seaplane base at East 23rd Street, a federal judge ruled this week.

title: CHATTEM AGREES TO SELL BAN DEODORANT LINE TO JERGENS
description: Chattem Inc., the maker of Gold Bond medicated powder and Flexall pain reliever, agreed yesterday to sell the Ban line of antiperspirants and deodorants to the Andrew Jergens Company unit of the Kao Corporation for $160 million in cash. Under the agreement, Chattem will also receive up to $6.5 million in future payments, based on Ban sales in 2001 and 2002. Kao is Japan's largest cosmetics maker by sales. Chattem, based in Chattanooga, Tenn., said it would use about $58 million of the money to repay loans. The remainder will be used for future acquisitions and for the repayment of other loans.

title: Harsh Detention
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Immigration Mailing Roils Rockland Community
description: A mailing from an anti-immigration group has angered residents in Sparkill, N.Y., a mostly white town in Rockland County that has begun to experience an influx of newcomers from other countries, especially Hispanics.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, DAVID
description: DANIEL-David, 58, died on August 13th in Tampa, Fla. He leaves a sister, Charliss Jennings. David wrote brilliantly on dance & music for Vogue, Vanity Fair, The Wall Street Journal, The New Yorker, Stage Bill, and many other publications. We valued his extraordinarily subtle understanding of the art of performance, his complex yet intuitive grasp of musical and theatrical traditions, and his inimitable instinct for the gifts that make an artist a star. David's glittering analysis of dance and music as moment-to-moment experience in New York made him a unique, unforgettable, now muchmissed friend. Joan Acocella, Mindy Aloff, Peter Anastos, Aimee Bell, Joy Williams Brown, Van Cliburn, Arlene Croce, Prudence Crowther, Sharon DeLano, Erich Eichman, Charles France, Robert Gottlieb, Jonnie Greene, Robert Greskovic, Eduardus Halim, Laura Jacobs, Julie Kavanagh, Allegra Kent, Rebecca & Eugene Long, Ross MacGibbon, Delia Marshall, Christopher O'Riley, Jed Perl, Deborah Rosenthal, Robert Tracy, James Wolcott.

title: For Debates, Three Isnt a Crowd
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODER, NORMAN D.
description: BRODER-Norman D. On August 23 at age 86. Longtime volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Beloved husband of Hannah and stepfather of Nan Lehmann and James Rothenberg. Devoted grandfather of Jill, Amy, Karen and Laurie. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, August 25th, 12 noon. Contributions in his memory may be made to Jewish Childcare Association, 120 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005.

title: Enough With the Kompyuta! Let's Makuru!
description: Although English is becoming the dominant language around the world, few outside Japan may be aware of how extensively it has transformed Japanese. Herbert Passin, professor emeritus of sociology at Columbia University, reported on this upheaval in ''Japonica: How to Read the Japanese Language if You Know the English Source Code,'' which appeared in the spring-summer issue of Correspondence: An International Review of Culture and Society. Excerpts follow.

title: American Priest Dies in Kenya, And Authorities Suspect Murder
description: An American priest who made many enemies among the powerful and corrupt in Kenya was found shot to death on Thursday on a rural roadside a few yards from his pickup truck.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Sunday about the front-runners for most valuable player in baseball referred incorrectly in some editions to the two most recent players from New York teams to have won the award in the same year. They were Don Newcombe and Mickey Mantle, in 1956 -- not Sandy Koufax and Elston Howard, in 1963.

title: Lawyer Protests For Andersen
description: A lawyer for Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, denounced the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for apparently leaking the information that Andersen is being investigated for its role in auditing the books of Waste Management Inc.

title: Taking Some of the Chaos Out of Herald Square
description: Perhaps no intersection in the city is as chaotic as Herald Square, where the traffic of 34th Street, Broadway and Avenue of the Americas intersects with tens of thousands of shoppers, tourists and Midtown workers in a compressed patch of streets that defy the rules of sound urban planning.

title: In Speech, Bush Sets Goal of Free-Trade Agreements With Latin Nations
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech on United States policy in Latin America that was delivered on Friday by Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican presidential nominee, at Florida International University in Miami, as released by the Bush-Cheney campaign.

title: Republicans Release Attack Ad Against Gore
description: Two days after canceling one advertisement that attacked Vice President Al Gore on his trustworthiness, the Republicans today released another that sharply criticizes Mr. Gore's plan for a prescription drug benefit for older Americans. It is the first attack commercial of the postconvention campaign.

title: Woman Bludgeoned by Husband Says Sentence Is Too Light
description: At a sentencing hearing for her estranged husband yesterday after a plea bargain was arranged, a millionaire investment executive bitterly accused the state court system of failing to sufficiently punish him for sneaking into her bedroom, bludgeoning her with a steel barbell and later announcing to one of their daughters, ''I've killed Mom.''

title: A Golden Glow Surrounds Some Oldies (Both the People and the Songs)
description: A woman is having lunch with her grown children at an outdoor cafe when she is transfixed by the familiar tune a street-corner guitarist is playing. The children, who are pretty sure that Mom's going dotty, can't understand why she's suddenly enraptured.

title: Clinton Adds Mideast Meeting
description: White House officials said yesterday that President Clinton would add a brief stop in Cairo to his Africa trip to discuss the Middle East peace talks with President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Article 2000082692883349360 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: English-Only Notification Blamed for Low Summer School Turnout
description: An advocacy group said yesterday that low attendance in summer school in New York City had been caused in part by the failure of the school system to communicate with immigrant parents in their native languages in a timely manner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFRICHTER, HARRIET (LUTH)
description: HOFRICHTER-Harriet (Luth) age 84, formerly of Killingworth and North Madison, CT. Funeral services will be held Sunday 2PM at the North Madison Congregational Church. Contributions may be made in her memory to the North Madison Congregational Church, 1271 Durham Road, Madison, CT. 06443, or Madison ABC, PO Box 317, Madison, CT. 06443. Friends may call at The Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Road, Madison Saturday from 3-6 PM.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP; COLLEGE SENIOR IN AMATEUR SEMIFINALS
description: A day after he recorded the greatest come-from-behind victory of his young career, Jeff Quinney did himself one better. Three holes down with six to play, the Arizona State senior won five consecutive holes yesterday to defeat 18-year-old Hunter Mahan, 2 and 1, and advance to the semifinals of the 100th United States Amateur Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, A. INA (NEE MARGULIES)
description: BLOCK-A. Ina (nee Margulies). On August 25. Beloved wife of the late Frederick, devoted sister of Grete Roll and the late Julius Margulies. Loving aunt of Michael and Juliana Roll and their son, Max. Services will be held Sunday, August 27, at 12:45 at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: G.D.P. Grew at 5.3% Rate
description: The economy grew in the second quarter at a 5.3 percent annual rate, as consumer spending increased at the slowest pace in three years and businesses built up inventories, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Correction
description: A New York Times article in editions of Aug. 17 about new information on a 1960s sex scandal in Britain that involved the Duchess of Argyll misattributed a lyric written for "You're the Top," the Cole Porter song inspired by the duchess. The lyric, with a reference to Mussolini, was written by P.G. Wodehouse for the 1935 London production of "Anything Goes." The lyricist was not Mr. Porter.

title: Y.M.C.A.'s Sale of McBurney Will Preserve Housing for Poor
description: The Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York will sell its McBurney building in Chelsea under an agreement that will preserve the old structure's low-income housing and pave the way for the construction of a new health and fitness club on West 14th Street, officials said yesterday.

title: AD AGENCY DEAL IS APPROVED
description: The European Union Commission cleared the purchase by the British advertising concern WPP Group of a United States rival, Young & Rubicam Inc., for $4.7 billion. The deal is expected to close in October. Suzanne Kapner

title: 'Survivor,' and Our Lives Today
description: To the Editor:

title: China Agrees To Free Poet After Protests From Writers
description: A Boston-based Chinese poet who was arrested two weeks ago in connection with a literary journal he edits will be released and deported to the United States on Saturday, an American Embassy official in Beijing said today.

title: LERNOUT CHANGES CHIEFS
description: Europe's top maker of voice recognition software, Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V. of Belgium, said Gaston Bastiaens had stepped down as chief executive and John Duerden had replaced him as the company faces concerns about its Korean sales. Mr. Duerden, a veteran of the Xerox Corporation and Reebok International Ltd., became head of Lernout's health care unit after the company bought the Dictaphone Corporation in May. He had been chief executive of Dictaphone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELTON, WILLIAM R.
description: ELTON-William R. The Graduate Center of The City University of New York expresses sympathy to the family of Dr. William R. Elton, Professor of English since 1969. Professor Elton was a dedicated scholar and devoted teacher of Shakespeare's works and of Renaissance thought. He will also be remembered as a serious poet and an advocate for poetry. Frances Degen Horowitz, President

title: Bush Tax Plan: The Debate Takes Shape
description: In the shorthand of presidential politics, Gov. George W. Bush's tax cut proposal is either an overdue effort to return to citizens what is rightfully theirs, or, as Vice President Al Gore puts it, a risky scheme to reward the wealthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIEL, ELLA
description: PERKIEL-Ella. The American Friends of The Ghetto Fighters' Museum note with sorrow the passing of Ella Perkiel, mother of our friend and Board member, Anita Sarna. May Anita, Mark, and the entire family find comfort in Ella's courageous & loving legacy. Rita Meed, Amy Miller, Alan Pines and Marty Statfeld Executive Board, American Friends' Debbie Nahshon, Exec. Director Simcha Stein, Director, Beit Lohamei Haghetaot

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: California Company Victim Of a Fake Press Release

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIFER, BETTY
description: LEIFER-Betty. Passed away on August 23 at age 85. Mrs. Leifer was a corsetier and homemaker. She is survived by her sons Neil & Howie, a brother Melvin, grandchildren Jodi & Corey & greatgrandchildren Joey & Taylor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ROBERT NEIL
description: KAYE-Robert Neil. Bob will miss you as a college classmate and a law school roommate. We both will miss you as a dear and wonderful friend. With all our love, Bob and Micki

title: Beautiful Pleasure Triumphs
description: As she came out of the final turn, Beautiful Pleasure swung wide, awfully wide, enough to allow her rival Heritage of Gold an opening to run her down for the third time this year. More was at stake today than the Personal Ensign Handicap at Saratoga Race Course. The move endangered Beautiful Pleasure's title as the champion mare.

title: Class Warfare and the Great Unmentionable
description: To the Editor:

title: German Official Pessimistic About Far-Right Violence
description: Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer is pessimistic about the eradication of rightist extremism in the east of Germany. It will take a ''generation and a half,'' he said, to overcome the wounds of an area that reminds him of his youth ''in the twilight zone'' between democracy and authoritarian tradition.

title: Wrestlers' Dispute Mired in Courts
description: The Sydney Olympics begin in three weeks, but the roster of the American Greco-Roman wrestling team remains in a legal chokehold.

title: Serge Lebovici, 85, of France; Studied Mother-and-Child Bond
description: Dr. Serge Lebovici, a major figure in French psychoanalysis known for his work with infants, children and adolescents, died on Aug. 12 in the south of France, where he had gone for a professional project. He was 85 and lived in Paris.

title: TIME WARNER TELECOM ADDS MOST ASSETS OF GST
description: A local phone carrier, Time Warner Telecom Inc., agreed yesterday to buy most assets of GST Telecommunications Inc. Time Warner Telecom said the deal totaled $690 million in cash and assumed debt, but it did not provide more details. The transaction does not include GST's Hawaii assets. GST, based in Vancouver, Wash., filed for bankruptcy protection in May. Time Warner Telecom, based in Littleton, Colo., agreed earlier this year to pay $450 million for the assets, but the deal fell apart. The company is a competitive local exchange carrier, which competes with the so-called Baby Bells in providing local phone service to businesses. It was formed as a joint venture of Time Warner Inc., MediaOne Group Inc. and Advance/Newhouse Partnership and went public in May 1999.

title: William Cashel Jr., 80, Dies; Ex-Campbell Soup Chairman
description: William S. Cashel Jr., the former chairman of Campbell Soup and the chief financial officer of AT&T during its deregulation, died on Tuesday at his home in Amelia Island, Fla. He was 80.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Following Up column on Aug. 13 about waning violence around the Edgecombe Deli in Harlem carried an erroneous credit line. The writer was Tina Kelley.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FIORELLA, CAROL
description: FIORELLA-Carol. When I see Carly smile and the sparkle in her eyes, I know you are here with us. Forever, Abby, Julie, Carly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLSKIN, HERBERT C.
description: POLSKIN-Herbert C., 79 years, of Monroe Township, NJ on Friday, August 25, 2000. Devoted husband of 55 years to Joan Klein Polskin. Beloved father of Howard and Philippa Polskin, Emily & Maurice Zylber, and Judi & Michael Knopke. Adored grandfather of six. Services Sunday 1:00 PM in Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: A Time of Fires, Fatigue, Cash and the U.S.O.
description: They head out before dawn and trudge home after dark, weary and covered in soot, still clutching the shovels and axes that are their weapons out on the battle lines. They sleep as many as 21 to a tent, in makeshift camps pitched beneath smoky, lung-choking skies.

title: Article 2000082691119427761 -- No Title
description: Unable to find template! Trying to Render A62257-2000Aug25

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a coalition proposal by Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel referred incorrectly to the history of direct elections for his office. The 1996 election, won by Benjamin Netanyahu, was the first in which Israelis voted directly for prime minister. The election won by Mr. Barak last year was the second.

title: Gore and Bush, in Florida, Focus on Friendly Crowds
description: It seemed a long way to travel to preach to the choir. Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush each courted Florida voters this week, but spoke mostly to the already converted.

title: Following Lost Season, A Wiser Trojan Returns
description: The legal predicament surrounding Rashard Casey has dominated discussion about Sunday's Kickoff Classic between Penn State and Southern California at Giants Stadium. An accusation of assault, now being investigated by prosecutors, is the reason the Nittany Lions refused to make Casey, their starting quarterback, available today when both teams gathered for news conferences at the Meadowlands.

title: Class Warfare and the Great Unmentionable
description: To the Editor:

title: Victim Is Identified In Dismemberment
description: Body parts found in a suitcase in the Hudson River and a plastic bag in the East River last week are those of a 17-year-old who was living with her boyfriend and infant son in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUSHMAN, SUZANNE (EFFIE)
description: PUSHMAN-Suzanne (Effie). On August 21, 2000, of Bronxville, NY. Services were held on Friday, August 25 at the Westchester Funeral Home Inc. in Eastchester with burial following in Woodlawn Cemetery. Friends may contribute to the Reformed Church of Bronxville in her memory.

title: Article 2000082692929974306 -- No Title
description: Variables.theEditedBody

title: Assessing the Plan
description: Gov. George W. Bush is betting that a $1.3 trillion tax cut will help him win the White House in November. But will it also squander the federal surplus? Will it extend the nation's economic boom, or kill it? Business executives, scholars and politicians assess the Bush tax proposal. Article, Page A8.

title: 'Survivor,' and Our Lives Today; A Changed Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN D.
description: KELLY-John D. On August 24 of Manhasset NY. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Dear father of John, Shawn, Christine, Brian and Timothy. Grandfather of 13. Brother of Ethel Paret. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10AM St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Port Washington, NY. The family has requested that donations on his behalf be made to Little Flower Children's Services of New York, PO Box 9000, Wading River, New York 11792.

title: U.S. Evangelists Are Released Following Detention in China
description: Three American evangelists who were detained in central China on Wednesday along with a large group of Chinese Christians were released on Friday, their pastor in California said, and today they were flying to Hong Kong.

title: Behind First Team, Dayne Gains Ground
description: Running back Ron Dayne had been little more than a mystery through the Giants' first three exhibition games. Dayne, a first-round pick, attracted more attention by trailing most of his teammates in daily wind sprints than by carrying the ball in games.

title: Court Rules Cross-Dresser Can Stay in the U.S. on Asylum Claim
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that a gay Mexican man who dresses and acts like a woman is entitled to asylum in the United States, expanding the circumstances that immigration officials must consider when foreigners ask to stay in the country.

title: 'Survivor,' and Our Lives Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Groh Waits as Decision Time Nears
description: The Jets are expected to make at least some of their final cuts on Saturday, and Coach Al Groh said he used the bye week to scrutinize positions that were especially close. The Jets have to cut nine players to get to the mandatory 53-man roster by Sunday.

title: Campaign Briefing; TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: No public appearances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGARMAN, MORTON
description: SUGARMAN-Morton. July 6, 1920August 17, 2000. World War II veteran. His wife, Lydia, children, Rob and his wife Christine, Nancy, John and grandson Keith will miss this unique, non-conforming, humorous bike rider, world traveler, nature lover and avid reader with a mind like a sponge. Memorial service at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St, Oyster Bay, Sunday, August 27, at Noon.

title: Signs of Life in a Ghost Town; New Admirers Rebuild a Mineral-Spring Retreat
description: The ghost town of the white elephants.

title: A Faulty Fire Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: No Words Capture the Fear
description: A few months ago I was on a plane that almost crashed. For the first three hours it was a routine flight from Boston to Denver, crowded, with sporadic food and beverage service. Then, an hour before our scheduled landing, the pilot announced that one set of the plane's landing wheels would not descend. But, he assured us, he could land the plane safely on two wheels. Although fire trucks would meet us on the ground, he said, there was no need to be concerned. They were simply being cautious. They liked to use occasions like this for practice. Was there really nothing to worry about? I wondered. None of the other passengers seemed particularly concerned.

title: Carl Barks, Father of Scrooge McDuck, Is Dead at 99
description: Carl Barks, the once anonymous ''duck man'' for Walt Disney whose draftsmanship and writing gained him a cultlike following among artists and fans of Donald Duck comic books and of his very own creation, Scrooge McDuck, died yesterday at his home in Grants Pass, Ore. He was 99.

title: VOTE FAVORABLE FOR BP AMOCO
description: Shareholders of the Russian oil company Sidanko approved a plan that would return the assets of an oil-producing subsidiary to BP Amoco, Russia's biggest foreign investor. Shareholders voted to increase Sidanko's share capital by 37.7 percent, which will give a rival oil company, Tyumen Oil, a stake in Sidanko and will allow BP Amoco to retain its 10 percent stake. Last year, Tyumen pushed Sidanko's subsidiary into bankruptcy and bought it at a bargain price over BP Amoco's objections. Under the new agreement, Tyumen will return the assets to Sidanko in exchange for a stake of 25 percent plus one share. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Lazio Defends Tax-Cut Plan As Tool to Spread Prosperity
description: A day after he proposed large tax cuts if elected senator, Representative Rick A. Lazio today fended off skepticism from Democrats and sought to defend his plan as a way to continue and spread prosperity.

title: A Woman of One Name With More Than One Game
description: Voices have prints, the way fingers do. The swirls and tiny cracks in a performer's tone make the singer more than just a skilled anonymous craftsman. Yet discerning the marks that make a singer exceptional isn't as easy as pressing thumb to paper. The ones that stand out cultivate those distinguishing qualities without sacrificing a well-shaped tone.

title: 2 New Cases Of West Nile Are Confirmed
description: Two elderly women have become seriously ill from the West Nile virus, bringing the number of those infected this summer to five, health officials said yesterday as they announced that the city would intensify its spraying of pesticides over the weekend in response.

title: HERCULES, A CHEMICALS MAKER, CUTS DIVIDEND SHARPLY
description: The specialty chemicals maker Hercules Inc. said yesterday that it had cut its quarterly dividend 70 percent to save money. A quarterly dividend of 8 cents, down from 27 cents, will be paid on Sept. 29 to shareholders of record as of Sept. 6. Hercules, based in Wilmington, Del., earlier this summer cited disappointing results at its process-chemicals segment and higher interest expenses in warning that second-quarter results would fall well short of Wall Street's estimates. Wall Street analysts then lowered their expectations to 22 cents from 37 cents a share. Sales fell to $822 million from $833 million. Shares of Hercules were unchanged at $13.50, on the Big Board.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on July 30 based on data from the Campaign Study Group, a nonpartisan research organization, about the 10 largest donors to the Republican National Committee, with an article about large, unregulated donations to the Republican Party, included one company erroneously. Sam Wyly, who founded Maverick Capital, and his brother Charles J. Wyly Jr. together donated $505,000 to the Republicans in this campaign, but they no longer have any relation to Maverick Capital; people connected with the company were not among the party's 10 biggest donors.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR RISES 4 PERCENT. The price of sugar climbed on signs of strong demand in China. Raw sugar for October delivery rose 0.46 cent, to 10.82 cents a pound in New York, the biggest one-day increase since July 17.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARO, EVA
description: CARO-Eva. Dearest mother, forever in my heart and thoughts. I love you. Frances

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, ABRAHAM I.
description: SHERR-Abraham I. On August 25, 2000, at age 90. Beloved husband of the late Jean F. Sherr. Loving father of Rita, Barbara and Alan. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Salem Fields Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Oh, Forget About the Money. Let's Dress Up and Play!
description: You have to feel fondly toward an enterprise that declares pride in its own insignificance, its very name a trumpet flourish of defiance and chagrin. The New York International Fringe Festival -- 12 days of largely unheralded theatrical performances, hundreds of them, sprinkled over the East Side of Lower Manhattan like the contents of a spice rack -- concludes tomorrow. And anyone who sampled it intermittently as I did this week can't help but feel that the joint effort of organizers, audiences, volunteer ticket takers and, of course, performers, is a buoying one for the theatrical world.

title: Few Options on Cheney Option Problem
description: Can Dick Cheney find a way to have his money and still avoid a possible conflict of interest over his options to buy stock in the Halliburton Company, which he headed until the Republican Party chose him as its candidate for vice president?

title: The Humpty Dumpty of Scholarship; American History Has Broken in Pieces. Can It Be Put Together Again?
description: The writing of American history underwent a significant change in the 1960's and 70's, one that remains in place today. Not only did the Vietnam War set off a reaction against national institutions, especially the state, but the growth of ''liberation'' movements also led many women, blacks, gays and other groups to demand their own distinctive, ''usable past.'' Increasingly, younger historians shifted their emphasis from the public life of the nation to the private lives of its citizens.

title: Tribes Agree to Underwrite Proposal for Nation's Largest Indian Bank
description: After two years of planning, 11 Indian tribes or tribal corporations from across the country, including the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, have agreed to commit $1 million each to found the nation's largest intertribal bank ever.

White, Jr. Dear mother of Susan Callahan, Janet Foster and Rosemary White-Traut. Loving grandmother of ten. Reposing at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Highway, West Sayville Sunday 2-4:30 & 7-9:30PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:45AM, at Our Lady of the Snow RC Church, Blue Point. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram. Please make donations in her memory to Academy of St. Joseph, 1725 Brentwood Road, Brentwood or Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, 101 Hospital Rd, E. Patchogue, NY.

description: An American political campaign just doesn't get any better than it has in this convention summer of 2000. We've seen strange ideological bedfellows perpetrate Machiavellian intrigues. The sudden emergence of dark-horse candidates and collapse of front-runners. No-holds-barred debates.

title: Yanks' Utility Lineup Is Futile Against the A's
description: The Yankees are defending their back-to-back World Series championships these days with a whole bunch of folks who had nothing to do with those titles. If you dialed in the Yankees in the fourth inning tonight, this is what you saw: a funky left-hander named Randy Choate pitching, the diminutive Luis Polonia in left field and three other positions manned by utility players.

title: Barak Warns of 'Tragedy' If Peace Pact Not Reached
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak has warned of ''a tragedy'' ahead for Israel and the Palestinians if they fail to reach a peace agreement, and has hinted that he fears a return to the Islamic terrorist attacks that killed scores of Israelis in the mid-1990's.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an experiment in support of a maverick theory about the origin of life was truncated in some copies. The last sentence, quoting Dr. Gunther Wachtershauser of Munich, who proposed the theory, should have read, ''The new results 'greatly strengthen the hope that it may one day be possible to understand and reconstruct the beginnings of life on earth,' he wrote.''

title: L. B. Boyer, 84, Psychoanalyst; Promoted Countertransference
description: Dr. L. Bryce Boyer, a psychoanalyst who advanced the concept of countertransference in doctor-patient communication, died on Aug. 9 in Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Cheney's Predicament
description: Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential candidate, will have a hard time ridding himself entirely of an economic interest in Halliburton and still holding onto the money from his options to buy stock in the company. And the problem will likely arise again when executives leave companies for public service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKIN, JOHN F.
description: MACKIN-John F. 85. Died on August 25, 2000. Formerly of Throgs Neck, Scarsdale and Long Beach Island, New Jersey. He was born on February 3, 1915 to John and Catherine (nee Smith) Mackin in NYC. John was a U.S. Army veteran during W.W.II. Mr. Mackin was a basketball official and baseball umpire at high school and college levels and a member of Catholic High School Athletic Association Hall of Fame. John worked for Metropolitan Life for 44 years, retiring in 1979. He is predeceased by his wife Edith (nee Connelly) Mackin in 1976, three sisters and one brother. He is survived by one son, Joseph Mackin of Hawthorne, NY; three daughters, Peg Adamo of Chappaqua, NY, Mary Grosso of Hingham, MA, Patricia Walsh of Wilton, CT; one brother, Peter Mackin of Yonkers, NY and twelve grandchildren. Reposing, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave, Hawthorne, NY, (914) 769-4404, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Holy Rosary Church, Hawthorne, NY on Monday, 11:00 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimer's Association Westchester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605, would be appreciated.

title: HOME DEPOT TO BUY NCH'S APARTMENT MAINTENANCE UNIT
description: Home Depot Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the NCH Corporation's apartment-maintenance business to expand in the Southern United States its own Maintenance Warehouse unit, which sells repair products to hotels and apartment complexes. Terms for the purchase of N-E Thing Supply were not disclosed. Houston-based N-E Thing, which operates in Texas, Phoenix and Atlanta, has six distribution centers. It publishes an annual catalog of more than 4,000 items. Maintenance Warehouse, based in San Diego, sells repair and operations products like ceiling fans, tools, locksets, vacuums and chemical cleaners. NCH did not disclose the size of N-E Thing's staff or sales.

title: PACIFIC GULF PROPERTIES TO SELL 1,139 OF ITS UNITS
description: Pacific Gulf Properties Inc., an equity real estate investment trust, agreed yesterday to sell 1,139 units at seven of its traditional multifamily properties to three unrelated buyers for $61.2 million in cash and the repayment of approximately $11.3 million of debt. The deal also involves assumption of about $20.4 million of debt. Pacific, based in Newport Beach, Calif., said the company would sell its remaining three traditional multifamily apartment properties, with 492 units. The company owns, develops and manages industrial and multifamily properties, including rental housing for retirees.

title: A Searching Look at Flight 800
description: As flying becomes safer, crashes become harder to explain. That has been the paradox hovering over the investigation of the T.W.A. Flight 800 disaster. In the immediate aftermath of the crash, which killed all 230 people on board, there were theories that the plane had been brought down by terrorists or an errant missile. Now, after one of the most painstaking investigations in the history of aviation, the National Transportation Safety Board has ruled out those possibilities. Instead, the board determined that a ''fuel/air explosion inside the center wing tank'' was the probable cause of the Boeing 747's breaking up in midair off Long Island 12 minutes into its flight from Kennedy Airport to Paris on July 17, 1996. What is not known for certain is what ignited the explosion, though a short circuit in electrical wiring is strongly suspected.

title: On Hair-Trigger Wall Street, A Stock Plunges on Fake News
description: At 10:13 a.m. yesterday, investors in Emulex, a California company that makes fiber optic communications equipment, received some terrible news.

title: Giants Waste Another Lead to Finish the Preseason 0-4
description: No matter how big a lead the Giants might have late in a regular-season game -- if they ever get such a lead -- do not be surprised if Coach Jim Fassel declines to remove his starters.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday's Op-Ed page misstated the country in which Michelin, the tire maker, is based. It is a French company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MEGAPATH NETWORKS INC., Pleasanton, Calif., which sells high-speed Internet services to businesses, said it had bought 1Terabit Inc.'s digital subscriber lines in New York City for an undisclosed price.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Real Confessions
description: Court TV, which has distinguished itself with live coverage of court proceedings, will offer a new and bizarre program this fall. ''Confessions,'' the new entry, will be a 30-minute show, with each episode presenting three videotaped police confessions of people who have committed murders, rapes and other violent crimes. Broadcasting the tapes is legal because they are part of the public record in cases where the suspects were convicted or were found not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: Join In, He Asked Religious Leaders, and 2,000 Will
description: IMAGINE a meeting that put Israel's chief rabbi, an emissary of Iran's top ayatollah, the head of the World Council of Churches and a granddaughter of Mahatma Gandhi together in the same room. An unexpected grouping, to be sure. But it would have only a few of the spiritual figures due to begin meeting at the United Nations on Monday, when 2,000 people from 90 nations and a wide spectrum of faiths gather to spend four days on issues related to peace.

title: Bail Ruling for Scientist Puts Federal Case in Jeopardy
description: Decisions on bail rarely have much influence over the outcome of criminal trials, because they focus on the narrow questions of the risk that the defendant might flee or endanger the community, not guilt or innocence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDIN, PHYLLIS L.
description: HINDIN-Phyllis L. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Bettina and mother-in-law of Lawrence Hertz. Cherished grandmother of Jordan. Loving sister of Dennis Kornfield and the late Barbara Moscowitz. Sister-in-law of Susan and George. Services Sunday 1PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Mets Begin Crucial Series On Right Foot
description: Randy Johnson grudgingly handed Buck Showalter the baseball in the third inning and instantly began inspecting the grass at Shea Stadium. One step, two steps and three steps turned into a dozen quick steps, and Johnson never looked up. He did not need to see anything. Johnson could hear the raucous response to his awful pitching and that was disturbing enough.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Aug. 17 about bicycle computers referred incorrectly to their means of measuring pedal rhythm, or cadence. Only rotations of the crank are tracked, by sensors; gear sizes do not have to be entered into the computer.

title: Greene Sharp in 100; Johnson Wins in Return
description: Some of the world's finest athletes, including a healthier and humbler Michael Johnson, may have been running and leaping here tonight, but in this particular year, the only city that really matters in track and field is Sydney, Australia.

title: European Central Bank Fears Weak Euro's Inflation Effect
description: Europe is hardly in the midst of a major economic boom, but the European Central Bank is increasingly likely to hit the brakes as early as next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDAK, MARJORIE FINK
description: SANDAK-Marjorie Fink. Passed away August 25, 2000 peacefully in her 90th year. Wife of the late Charles Sandak. Dear aunt of Helen and Alan Greene, great-aunt of James, Tina, Michael and Alison.

description: To the Editor:
