description: To the Editor:

title: HONG KONG GREW 10.8% IN QUARTER
description: Hong Kong has extended its recovery, reporting that economic output grew 10.8 percent in the second quarter. The increase is smaller than the 14.3 percent in the first quarter, but the government raised its forecast for full-year growth to 8.5 percent, from 6 percent. Some economists worry that price deflation continues in Hong Kong. The territory's exports surged 17.7 percent -- fueled by the strong United States economy -- and domestic consumer spending rose 5.2 percent. Mark Landler

title: On a Roll at the Right Time
description: For Thomas Engvist of Sweden, it could be coming together at the right time. Engvist, who took the title in Cincinnati earlier this month and then reached the quarterfinals in Indianapolis, defeated Fabrice Santoro in straight sets Friday in Commack, N.Y. The victory propelled him into the Hamlet Cup semifinals and signaled his readiness for next week's United States Open.

title: Lieberman Seeks 'Honest' Tax Cut Debate
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman accused Gov. George W. Bush today of distorting the Democrats' tax cut proposal, saying it was time for ''an honest debate'' on the subject.

title: Two Remedies for School Failures; Making Summer School Mandatory
description: New York City's schools chancellor, Harold Levy, seems to have learned a great deal from the summer of 1999, when his predecessor, Rudy Crew, was rushed by City Hall into requiring students who failed year-end promotion examinations in math and reading to attend summer school. That first session was chaotic and poorly managed. But this year saw dramatic improvements in transportation, staffing, record-keeping and especially attendance, which was substantially better but still lower than it should be. Attendance is unlikely to improve until the state education code is rewritten to make summer school mandatory for students who fail during the regular school year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Dutch Behemoth Invades America; ING Group Makes Its Move in Virtual Banking and Insurance
description: Nearly a year after Congress cleared the way for insurance companies to own banks and vice versa, most American banks and insurers are still on the sidelines, unable, analysts say, to see how to turn the new opportunity into profit.

title: Another Bid Submitted for Doomed Iridium Satellite Venture
description: Another Bid Submitted for 'Doomed' Iridium Satellite Venture

title: 17-Year-Old Is Charged In Fire at Brooklyn Stable
description: A 17-year-old was arrested yesterday afternoon and accused of igniting a Brooklyn stable fire in June that killed 21 horses and sent 30-foot flames soaring into the night sky, the police said.

title: Peace in Burundi Still Elusive As Africa Readies for Clinton
description: In December, Nelson Mandela took on one of Africa's most frightening problems: the tiny and beautiful country of Burundi, where Hutu and Tutsi have taken turns massacring each other by the thousands for the last 40 years. Rumor was that he accepted the task reluctantly, but he has worked hard and pushed enemies near to a settlement.

title: Article 2000082692368893429 -- No Title
description: Class Warfare and the Great Unmentionable

title: GENTIVA HEALTH SERVICES TO SELL STAFFING UNIT
description: The health care services company Gentiva Health Services Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its health care staffing unit to a company consisting of InteliStaf Holdings Inc. and the Carlyle Group for around $67.5 million in cash. Gentiva said the deal excluded certain homemaker staffing contracts and its clinical business solutions unit. Gentiva's health care staffing business accounted for $100 million, or 7 percent, of its $1.5 billion revenues in 1999. Shares of Gentiva, based in Melville, N.Y., rose 19 cents, to $10.50, in Nasdaq trading. The Washington-based Carlyle Group has interests in military contracting, health care, aerospace, telecommunications, information technology, real estate and soft drinks. InteliStaf Healthcare, based in Oak Brook, Ill., offers services to the health care industry.

title: NEW BIDDER FOR RIO ALGOM
description: The British mining company Billiton P.L.C. has agreed to buy Rio Algom Ltd. of Canada for $1.16 billion in cash, topping a hostile $1.02 billion offer from a Canadian rival, Noranda Inc. Mainly a producer of aluminum, coal and zinc, Billiton said Rio Algom would give it ''a significant entry point into the global copper business.'' Billiton is offering 1.7 billion Canadian dollars, or 27 Canadian dollars for each Rio Alom share, 2.50 Canadian dollars more than Noranda's offer. Timothy Pritchard

title: ALONE AT THE TOP
description: Throughout his career, Sanford I. Weill has vanquished rivals and also his closest allies. Now that Citigroup, the world's biggest money machine, is all his, the only person left to outdo is himself. A report by Roger Lowenstein in The Times Magazine.

title: TAKE TO AUCTION.COM MAKES OFFER FOR GREG MANNING
description: An online auction company Take to Auction.com Inc. said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to acquire the specialty auction house Greg Manning Auctions Inc. for $14 a share, about $140 million in stock. Greg Manning's shares rose $1.59, to $9.63, on the Nasdaq. Take to Auction's shares were up 25 cents, to $8, on the American Stock Exchange. Take to Auction.com, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said its offer also provided for the sale of Greg Manning's 48-percent-owned Chinese subsidiary, GMAI-Asia.com Inc., before the consummation of the deal. Greg Manning, based in West Caldwell, N.J., deals in stamps, coins, sports collectibles, fine art, diamonds, movie posters, film and music memorabilia.

title: SALEM COMMUNICATIONS ACQUIRES 8 RADIO STATIONS
description: The Salem Communications Corporation has acquired eight radio stations from Clear Channel Communications for around $185.6 million. Salem Communications, a religious and family radio broadcaster, said late on Thursday that the stations are KEZY-AM and KXMX-FM in Los Angeles, KDGE-FM in Dallas, KALC-FM in Denver, WKNR-AM and WRMR-AM in Cleveland, and WBOB-AM and WYGY-FM in Cincinnati. This acquisition is the largest single deal in the company's history. Salem Communications has more than 70 radio stations. It also operates the Salem Radio Network, a producer of religious programming. Shares of Salem, based in Camarillo, Calif., rose 25 cents, to $13.25, in Nasdaq trading, while the shares of Clear Channel, based in San Antonio gained $1.91, to $76.

title: Congo Leader Hedges on Vow to Allow Access for U.N. Force
description: A week of conflicting signals from President Laurent Kabila of Congo has left the Security Council no closer to knowing when, if ever, a peacekeeping mission can be sent to the country. The council this week decided that United Nations officials who have been in Congo preparing for the peacekeepers could stay until Oct. 15, giving Secretary General Kofi Annan and the council time to reconsider the operation.

title: What They're Saying About the Bush Tax Cut Proposal
description: Not since Ronald Reagan in 1980 has a Republican nominee's promise of a sweeping tax cut played so dominant a role in the presidential race. The New York Times asked a number of business executives, scholars and politicians to assess Gov. George W. Bush's tax plan.

title: Confined In Prisons, Literature Breaks Out
description: A prison cell turned Patrick C. Murphy into a writer. O.K., a bad writer, but, anyway, a writer. Serving time in the 1920's as Lifer 2338 in the Idaho State penitentiary for a crime so heinous he never discussed it, Murphy, in 1928, published ''Shadows of the Gallows,'' a cautionary memoir dedicated ''to every man and woman who has a sincere desire for more light and understanding.'' The book's back cover even carried (admittedly suspect) blurbs, like: '' 'The author and his writings have been known to me for years' -- A penologist.''

title: Seminoles in the Hunt Behind a 28-Year-Old
description: Shortly after Florida State's football players assembled to begin their quest for a second straight unbeaten season, the team doctor was giving his annual speech about the various viruses that could strike them. He showed a slide of a player who lost much of his hair because of a virus. Suddenly, many of the players in the room began pointing at Chris Weinke and chanting, ''Chris! Chris! Chris!''

title: Johnson's Troubles With the Mets Continue
description: On April 15, 1989, a wild 25-year-old Montreal left-hander started against Pittsburgh and could not get out of the second inning. None of the five outs he recorded were strikeouts.

description: ''Our future cannot be separated from the future of Latin America. Should I become the president, I will look south not as an afterthought, but as a fundamental commitment.''

title: SWISSCOM PLANS TO REORGANIZE
description: The leading Swiss phone company, Swisscom A.G., said it would reorganize its business around operational units to focus more on mobile communications and less on fixed-line operations. Its mobile operations will be placed into a separate company, Mobile Com A.G., which it plans to spin off to the public eventually. Meanwhile, Swisscom plans to sell its 50 percent stake in Tesion, a fixed-line operator, to its partner, Energie Baden-Wurttemberg A.G. Suzanne Kapner

title: A Longtime Giuliani Aide To Raise Money for Lazio
description: Bruce J. Teitelbaum, the chief fund-raiser for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aborted campaign for United States Senate, is moving to set up an independent committee to tap money from Mr. Giuliani's national network of contributors, and finance television advertisements on behalf of Representative Rick A. Lazio's campaign, said political leaders knowledgeable about the discussions.

title: 400 Dead in Worst Flooding in India in Years
description: Torrential monsoon rains and raging rivers have caused the worst flooding in decades across broad swaths of north India over the past two months, wreaking havoc in the lives of four million to five million people. And this week, sudden violent downpours caused piteous scenes of suffering in south India, as well.

title: The Costs of Governing Less
description: With the money it takes from us, the government hires regulators who tell us we can't do things we want to do. Little wonder, then, that government is so often the target of profound hostility.

title: Two Remedies for School Failures; Finding Qualified Teachers
description: New York State's education commissioner, Richard Mills, and New York City's schools chancellor, Harold Levy, have reached a compromise on a lawsuit by the state aimed at barring the city from placing uncertified teachers in low-performing schools as of next month. The accord gives the city breathing room but requires it to reach full compliance by 2001. This will not be easy, given a nationwide teacher shortage that could stagger schools statewide unless Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature develop a strategy to produce and recruit high-quality teachers.

title: Ford and Dealers Start Net Retailer That Will Focus on Fixed Prices
description: Responding to a proliferation of Internet-based businesses selling cars, the Ford Motor Company and a council of its 4,200 Ford-brand dealers announced today that they would set up their own online retailer, FordDirect.com, to help customers find Ford vehicles at fixed prices at dealerships nationwide.

title: AON, INSURANCE BROKER, BUYING ACTUARIAL SCIENCES
description: The Aon Corporation, the world's No. 2 insurance brokerage firm, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Actuarial Sciences Associates Inc. for an undisclosed amount of Aon stock to strengthen its consulting business. Aon, based in Chicago, said the employee benefits and compensation consulting firm would become part of its Aon Consulting Inc. Actuarial, a former AT&T Corporation subsidiary based in Somerset, N.J., has more than 600 employees in 11 sites in the United States and Canada. Aon had revenue of $118 million in 1999.

title: Georgia Town Is Still Divided Over the 1915 Lynching of a Jew
description: The oak grove where Leo M. Frank was lynched here 85 years ago, in one of the most infamous cases of anti-Semitism in American history, long ago gave way to suburban strip malls. An inconspicuous commemorative plaque marks the spot, just south of the Big Chicken, a looming metal rooster outside a fast-food restaurant that is the most distinctive landmark in Cobb County.

title: BUSH VOWS TO PUT GREATER U.S. FOCUS ON LATIN AMERICA
description: Charging that the Clinton administration had neglected Latin America, Gov. George W. Bush pledged today to put those countries at the center of his foreign policy agenda and outlined a way of thinking about the region that placed it on a par with American interests in Europe and Asia.

title: Pesticide Makers Are Sued Over Lobster Deaths in 1999
description: About 1,100 lobstermen from New York and Connecticut filed a federal lawsuit yesterday charging that pesticides sprayed last year to kill mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus have devastated the lobster population in Long Island Sound.

title: Hey, Norton, Get a Load of Ralphie Boy
description: The management of the Port Authority Bus Terminal near Times Square believes a half-ton version of the actor Jackie Gleason would make commuting more enjoyable for the 185,000 bus passengers who catch a bus there daily.

title: Srinagar Journal; Behind the Veil, a Muslim Feminist
description: Asiyah Andrabi, conservative Muslim and radical feminist, believes that women should be heard and not seen, so she makes her demands for equal rights from behind the black cloth curtain of an all-enveloping burqa.

title: Accusation of Misconduct Arises at Tailhook Meeting
description: The Navy is facing a new accusation of misconduct at the annual convention of the Tailhook Association, officials said today, nine years after drunken debauchery and sexual assaults at another convention led to resignations, fines and changes in the military's treatment of women.

title: Senior Team From America Favored at World Olympiad
description: The United States will have three teams competing in the World Olympiad, which begins today in Maastricht, the Netherlands.

title: A Touch of Insecurity Amid All the Strumming
description: As an artist, Dar Williams has a little stumble, like the misstep the star in a college play makes before giving the performance of her life. She's a resolutely good girl, but not a perfect one. The catch in her voice and the edge of doubt in her exuberant songs change her fans' feelings for her from admiration to besottedness.

title: Police Say 2 Clucked to Pester Client They Thought Turned Chicken
description: Two former employees of a mortgage brokerage firm near Albany became so annoyed when a New York City woman pulled out of a deal, the police said, that they harassed her for months by calling on the phone and clucking like a chicken.

title: Bodies of Boys Found in River, and Counselor Resigns
description: The bodies of two emotionally disturbed teenagers from Brooklyn who disappeared after jumping into the Hudson River on Tuesday have been found, and the group home supervisor who took them to the river's edge has resigned, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, SHERIDAN
description: ALBERT-Sheridan. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association notes with deep sorrow the passing of a leader of the New York bar, Sheridan Albert. We thank him for his valued service to NYSTLA, as an active member, as President (1978-80) and as dean. NYSTLA extends its sympathies to his family.

title: South Africans Great and Small Pay Tribute to a Man of Gold
description: In this society riven by race, the color line has long been crossed only by the most determined of souls. So when Harry F. Oppenheimer was remembered today, here in the small Anglican church where he worshiped for decades, no one had to ask why so many people from such different walks of life had come to pay tribute to a titan of business and industry.

Baer, grandnieces Susanne Jacoby-Hale and Rochelle Jacoby-Sanchez and greatgrandnieces and nephew Chelsea, Matthew and Sarah Hale survive her. Her large and loving family and the students who studied under her will fondly remember her.

title: Giuliani Threatens Suit Over Ads Featuring Him
description: Angry over the use of his face on billboard advertising as far away as Oshkosh, Wis., Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday repeated a threat to file suit against an animal rights group that is trying to publicize a possible link between milk consumption and various illnesses, including prostate cancer.

title: Trade Support Is Dwindling, Fed Chief Says
description: The protesters who gave voice to the risks and costs of globalization outside meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization over the last year did not make an appearance at the annual conclave of central bankers and economists from around the world that opened here today, but their influence was felt nonetheless.

title: What Has a Set of Wheels And Looks Like a Couch?
description: Like dancers in a ballet, 20 riders circled in front of the Central Park bandshell on their recumbent bicycles one recent Sunday.

title: Introduction
description: Readers were moved by our cover article on the wrongful incarceration of Kerry Sanders. The real ''three strikes and you're out,'' one wrote, is poverty, race and mental illness. Others responded to our article on wrestling and rap music with understanding of, if not approval for, the young fans.

title: A Foot in Two Countries
description: IT looked like a huge tomb rising from the beach. A gray-brown monolith with a shadowy entrance, it had concrete slopes and a flat roof that had been weathered into smoothness. As my husband, James, and I walked along the peaceful four-mile stretch of sands on St. Ouen's Bay on the island of Jersey, we could not keep our eyes from this monumental bunker or the immense stone-and-concrete wall, curving for miles, to which it was connected.

title: Costa Rica Gives Hotels Environmental Ratings
description: The Costa Rican Tourism Institute, which oversees the national tourist board, has created a Web site with a listing of hotels that have been rated for their efforts to improve the environment.

title: When Alzheimer's Strikes Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilderness That's Everyone's
description: MAINE is a place of lakes and bays, hills and islands, weathered people who live in plain and weathered buildings; a place eroded to the bone, both hard and tender. Since the 19th century, when Hawthorne and Thoreau published accounts of sojourns there and Thomas Cole and Frederic Church sent paintings of its coast and mountains south to the cities, Maine has represented an accessible wilderness: America's idea of itself.

title: Stars, Stripes and Insults, Love It or Leave It
description: Inside American Legion Lafayette Post 1906, at 19th Street and Bath Avenue in Bensonhurst, a stained American flag hangs on one paneled wall.

title: Lycra's New Reach: Et Tu, J. Crew?
description: I'VE been dressing myself for 45 years now, and there have been few surprises. The latest was last month. I bought my first piece of tailored stretch clothing: a poplin dress shirt, in a cotton Lycra blend, from Banana Republic.

description: Stephanie Donna Benzaquen, a daughter of Jennifer Pinto Safian and Norman S. Benzaquen, both of New York, is to be married this evening to Stephen Ashe Levey, a son of Leslee F. Levey and Lewis A. Levey of St. Louis. Rabbi Marc D. Angel will officiate at the Pierre in New York.

description: BALBO-Paul. May 14, 1932 to August 17, 2000. Beloved husband, father, son and brother. Served in Korean War, Paratrooper 11th Airborne. Loved his family and his country. Thank you for a lifetime of wonderful memories. Syl & the girls and Joan

title: The Nation; Surprise! Debates May Matter. And Help Bush.
description: GIVEN that both sides are bracing for a down-to-the-wire presidential race, the nationally televised debates between Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore could be especially crucial. For millions of Americans, it may be the first -- and only -- time they eyeball the two rivals for longer than a few-second snippet on the news or in a commercial.

title: Reno Rejects Gore Probe
description: For the third time, Attorney General Janet Reno brushed off the advice of senior advisers and declined to intensify an investigation into Vice President Al Gore's fundraising activities in 1996.

title: A Death in Midstream
description: Excerpt from ''Wishing My Father Well,'' by William Plummer.

title: Japan by Rail Pass
description: To the Editor: Dr. Perri Klass (''To See Japan, Try Rail Pass and Ryokan,'' July 23) has good advice for using the rail pass offered by Japanese Railways. Users should realize, however, that the pass is not good for the fastest bullet (Shinkansen) trains. Also, on rare occasions trains will use the tracks of private lines; if you should be on such a line, the conductor will collect a comparatively small surcharge beyond the rail pass.

title: A Tale of Two Fisheries
description: John Sorlien, a lean, sunburned fisherman in rubber overalls, was loading his boat along the wharf at Point Judith, R.I., not far from the spot where the ''Tuna Capital of the World'' sign stood three decades ago. Back then, you could harpoon giant bluefins right outside the harbor. Today, you would have a hard time finding one within 20 miles. Since the early 1970's, the tuna have declined -- along with cod, swordfish, halibut and so many other species in the ruined fisheries of the Northeast. Sorlien, like the other fishermen in this harbor just west of Newport, is surviving thanks to New England's great cash crop, lobsters, but he wonders how much longer they'll be around. ''Right now, my only incentive is to go out and kill as many fish as I can,'' Sorlien said. ''I have no incentive to conserve the fishery, because any fish I leave is just going to be picked by the next guy.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: One Day in the Life

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RANDELL, JOSEPH
description: RANDELL-Joseph. 8/27/96. Farewell beloved, brilliant teardimmed eyes, where all is love and the soul never dies. Adieu, Z.

title: U.N. Reports Afghan Curbs Hurt Populace
description: As some Security Council members, led by Russia and the United States, move toward increasing sanctions on the militant Islamic government of Afghanistan, a report by the United Nations' relief coordinator there says that the existing economic embargo is having ''a tangible negative effect'' on efforts to help the Afghan people.

title: Keeping the Faith
description: BLOOD OF THE LIBERALS

title: New Rule on Embryo Study
description: The National Institutes of Health issued rules under which the many university biologists it supports may start working with human embryonic stem cells. Biologists hope that through study of the cells they will learn the secrets of how the body develops as well as the means to patch aging tissues with fully youthful cells.

title: Hernandez Gives Yanks A Glimpse of Old Glory
description: The mastery of Orlando Hernandez is fragile, each part of his pitching reliant on the other parts, like a house built with posts and beams. Take away his slider or changeup and the structure of his game falls apart. His fastball looks meaty and mediocre, hitters hammer him.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Making It Big in Hair
description: Tananarive Due's graceful historical novel, THE BLACK ROSE (Ballantine, $25.95), traces the life of Madame C. J. Walker (1867-1919), nee Sarah Breedlove, a penniless girl from Delta, La., who became America's first black female millionaire. This book is based on research and an outline left behind by Alex Haley, who planned to write a novel about Walker; Due, a former columnist for The Miami Herald and the author of two previous novels, has taken the material and made it her own. Walker was orphaned at 6, married at 14 and was widowed a few years later; she was a washerwoman and cook until, in her late 30's, she married a Denver businessman named Charles Walker in 1906. By her death at the age of 51 she was, after starting her own hair care company, extraordinarily wealthy. Sarah's business began with experiments to treat her own hair loss and itchy scalp; thanks to word-of-mouth advertising, the company flourished and eventually employed some 20,000 ''Walker agents'' throughout the country. No retiring mogul, Walker financed a mission school in Africa, stumped for the N.A.A.C.P., sued a movie theater for charging blacks higher ticket prices than whites and built an Italian Renaissance-style palace in upstate New York as her home and as her ''monument to Negro achievement.'' Due's book resists becoming a facile Horatio Alger story: We follow the estrangement between Sarah and her daughter, and watch as Sarah courts the man who would become her second husband, despite our suspicion that he might be a poor companion. ''Maybe when you've lost as much as me, you don't take happy for granted,'' Sarah says. ''You scrape and hoard every piece of happy that comes your way.'' Charles Wilson

title: 32-Story Hotel Is Rising on Baltimore's Harborfront
description: A 32-STORY hotel that will be the city's largest is nearing completion as part of a $500 million redevelopment of a gritty industrial area that links the original Inner Harbor project with two gentrified historic neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 13 about the Spanish dramatist Pedro Calderon de la Barca misstated the year in which the novelist and dramatist Cervantes died. It was 1616, not 1611.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: Intimations; Good Grief And Bad
description: Soon after my ordination to the Catholic priesthood, on my very first ''night on duty'' in the parish where I was assigned, I answered a phone call from a woman whose sister had just died in a plane crash. She wasn't sure whether she believed in God, but she just wanted to talk with someone. I thought about her recently when I heard that ''grief counselors'' would be sent to console the passengers of a cruise that the victims of the Air France Concorde crash had planned to board.

title: Bennett Stepping Out With Studio And Dropping in for a Performance
description: TONY BENNETT certainly lives the good life. And he is about to share some of his sweet fortune with his former hometown of Englewood.

description: EAST VILLAGE

title: Garages Make Supersized S.U.V.'s Even Bigger for Superrich M.V.P.'s
description: IF luxury can be defined as lavishness beyond any pretense of necessity, what could be more of a luxury vehicle than a sport utility with the horsepower of a sports car but the handling of, well, a truck? But does the planet really need supercharged S.U.V.'s with as much as 485 horsepower?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMET, ANNE (BUNKIN)
description: SAMET-Anne (Bunkin). Died August 25th. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Elaine Weitzman (Charles). Loving sister of Dr. Irving Bunkin (Anke). Dear grandmother of Randi Kirsch and Jessica Weitzman. Great-grandmother of Cortney and Blaire Konner. Services Sunday, August 27, 12 noon, Plaza Funeral Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue & 91 Street.

description: MOSELEY-Mary Jane, on August 23. Beloved daughter of Astrid Onstad Talley and Glan Moseley. Dearly loved step-daughter of John J. Talley. Devoted sister of Christine Moseley and Kari Talley and the late Elizabeth Moseley. Services private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Columbia University, Eating Disorder Research, C/O NYSPI Unit 98, 1051 Riverside Drive, NY, NY 10032.

description: Tara Francesca Schoenberger and James Anthony Neumann were married yesterday in Roslyn, N.Y. Msgr. John J. Rowan, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

description: W. won't come out of his room. He's curled up down in Austin around his favorite feather pillow.

title: Unemployment vs. Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00; Bring the Noise
description: Ten years back, I found myself on a witness stand in Alexander City, Ala., talking to a jury about rap music. The owner of a local record store had been charged with violating the city's obscenity ordinance for selling a cassette of 2 Live Crew's ''Move Somethin''' to a police officer. As a music critic, I was supposed to provide something of an art-historical framework for the group's raunchy rhymes and the music's roots in the South Bronx. The city prosecutor leaned in. But the music didn't stay in the ghetto, did it? he asked. He let the implications of his question hang in the air: once the lyrics started spilling out of the grooves and into the real world, there was no telling where they'd take us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, RUDOLPH, M.D.
description: JOSEPH-Rudolph, M.D. 1913-August 22, 2000. Dedicated family practitioner in Freeport, LI. Father of Wendy, Peter, and Jane. Peace.

description: GARY HAMEL is a sophisticated business thinker, the co-author of one of the finest business books ever written. Yet it is not beneath him to include an oath in his new book on innovation. It is meant to elevate the people in the office cubicles into champions of inspired ideas for new ventures:

title: An Animal Keeper Who Lives His T-Shirt Slogans
description: Robert Shapiro was explaining the connection between the two seemingly unrelated enterprises he runs from his crowded storefront on East Fourth Street: a T-shirt design company and the city's premier, which is to say only, shelter for homeless reptiles.

title: Laurie Adlerstein, Moti Novick
description: Laurie Adlerstein, the daughter of Jo Anne and Lee Adlerstein of West Orange, N.J., and Manhattan, was married on Thursday to Alan Mordechai Novick, a son of Dr. Etta Novick and Dr. Isaac Novick of Woodsburgh, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Rosensweig officiated at Mayfair Farms, a caterer in West Orange.

title: WHITE PLAINS: N.Y.P.A. WORKERS TRANSFERRED
description: The New York Power Authority is continuing to transfer employees to White Plains, with 300 workers from its Manhattan offices coming to Westchester by the end of the year. The power authority owns a 17-story building at Main Street and Martin Luther King Boulevard. It leases about 40 percent of that building to other tenants. Jack Murphy, a spokesman for the authority, said the relocations are part of a continuing money-saving strategy. Elsa Brenner

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: The Ethicist; Bus Pass
description: On the bus the other day, I glanced at the woman next to me. She was working on a special-education student's evaluation form, showing the child's name, the school's name and all of the child's problems and diagnoses. She should not have been doing confidential work in a public place. Should I call the school and tell them without mentioning the therapist's name or chalk it up to a momentary lapse in professional judgment? -- C. Cohen, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Welcome to my Planet

title: It's Just A Game, Really
description: Should we conclude from the final verdict of ''Survivor'' that life is a game? Games are metaphors, in that they reframe familiar human events, make them formal, set them apart with beginnings and endings. Games attach some motivation to human activities, along with a certain amount of stage setting: the elegant pieces of a chess set, tennis whites. In the Western tradition, we take it for granted that the purpose of a game is to win.

title: Lire and Francs Via the Web
description: CASH may be making a comeback. Two major companies say they have a brisk business delivering bundles of foreign currency to people who are preparing to travel overseas. In a study last year American Express discovered that people on the road in the United States carry an average of $500. Fat rolls of cash -- how quaint.

description: WORKERS at the 15 retail stores of the Tile Shop do not receive many of the perks that many a new-economy employer may dish up to attract talent. They get no stock options, no nap rooms and certainly no on-site pet care.

description: Riding a wave of success on his prescription-drug plan, Vice President Al Gore plans to dedicate all of next week to a cross-country discussion of health care issues and a comparison of his proposals with those of Gov. George W. Bush.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP; DRISCOLL AND QUINNEY IN AMATEUR FINAL
description: James Driscoll had intended to turn professional next month and play in the PGA Tour's qualifying school this fall. Yet after his 2-and-1 semifinal victory over Luke Donald yesterday at the 100th United States Amateur Championship in Springfield, N.J., Driscoll now faces a dilemma. In advancing to today's final on Baltusrol Golf Club's Upper Course, Driscoll, a 22-year-old from Brookline, Mass., earned an invitation to play at the Masters next April, provided he remains an amateur.

title: Rain, Rain Doesn't Make All Business Go Away
description: It was only 11:45 a.m. and already the lines at the concession stand at the Hoyt's Stone Harbor Five movie theater were snaking perilously around the small lobby. The first show of the day, ''Hollow Man'' in theater two, was still 25 minutes off, but the skies at the Jersey Shore were once again -- ugh! -- cloudy and misty.

title: 'Goodbye' Essay Evokes Memories of Farewells
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese, Sunk in Crisis, Deride Vote
description: Ten years after Syrian forces snuffed out Lebanon's civil war, this battered country is entering a crucial parliamentary election marked by a deepening economic crisis, widespread public cynicism and startlingly open denunciations of vote rigging and Syrian domination.

title: Raina Lampkins-Fielder, Derek Thomson
description: Raina Alayne Lampkins-Fielder, a museum administrator in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Derek Danely Macdonald Thomson, a Web site producer. Khoren Arisian, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn.

title: Ideas & Trends: Like a Placebo; How Estrogen Gained A Healthy Skepticism
description: IT seemed so clear a decade ago. Hormone replacement therapy would protect women's hearts after menopause. After all, their risk of heart disease rises in middle age, around the time their ovaries stop making estrogen.

title: Rosie McGuire and Gordon Weiss
description: TEN years ago, Rosie McGuire and Gordon Joseph Weiss met when they were invited to read for parts in a movie. Besides a devotion to acting and a willingness to survive on tuna fish sandwiches until the next part, they both lived in tiny, rundown studios in Chelsea. After the reading, they ran into each other in the neighborhood laundromat or picking up Chinese food, and while he never appeared interested in her, she pined for him.

title: More Renovations Set For Ossining Strip Mall
description: Breathing new life into an old shopping center, Urstadt Biddle of Greenwich is spending $700,000 to renovate another section of the Arcadian Shopping Center in Ossining and attract new tenants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUEHSEL, VERA M.
description: KUEHSEL-Vera M. Age 91, of Mount Vernon, NY. Formerly of Flushing, NY, died August 25, 2000. Wife of the late William, mother of William P. Kuehsel and Marilyn Daly. Grandmother of four. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY on Sunday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church on Monday at 10:00 AM. Donations to The American Heart Association appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, REESE
description: HAMMOND-Reese, 71. Of Port St. Lucie, FL. on August 10 after a long illness. Retired in 1990 as Director of Research & Education for the International Union of Operating Engineers in Washington, D.C., a post he had held since 1961. He was a fifty year member of Local 94, IUOE in NYC. Prior to 1961, he was a union organizer in the NYC metro area for the IUOE and for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. His commitment to equal employment opportunities and job training were exceeded only by his dedication to racial justice. He is survived by his wife Shirley. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Wilmington, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Reese Hammond Scholarship Fund, Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Ithaca, New York, or Hospice of Martin/St. Lucie Counties, 2030 Southeast Ocean Blvd, Stuart, FL. 34996.

description: To the Editor:

description: PAULSEN-Harold Midskaug. Age 66, of Staten Island, NY, died Friday, August 25, 2000, at home following a long, courageous battle with prostate cancer. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Nancy Baione, Marylinda Schoifet, Geralyn, Michael and Kenneth Paulsen. Survived by eleven grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Visitation on Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Richmond Funeral Home, Staten Island. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Patrick's Church, Richmondtown, Staten Island, on Tuesday, August 29, 2000, 10 AM. Interment Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Prostate Cancer Research Division, 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: T.W.A. Inquiry Ends
description: Four years after Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded over Long Island, killing all 230 people aboard, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded its investigation, the longest and most expensive in its history.

title: N.J. VINES/Cape May; A Big Wine Out of a Tiny Vineyard
description: If Bill and Joan Hayes's five acres of grapes were any closer to the water, they would float away.

title: Accomplished in Two Careers
description: For one role he wears jeans and a baseball cap, and chews on a cigar. For the other, he dons a surgical gown and eschews the cigar. At home in both the medical and art worlds, the painter and plastic surgeon Dr. Roger E. Salisbury wonders why more people can't manage two careers. ''People have trouble understanding the fact that someone can be competent in two different areas,'' he said. In his case, a lifelong interest in art was grafted onto a profession grounded in aesthetics.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: Weiser's article is investigative journalism at its best. The failure to check fingerprints and photographs and the insensitivity detailed in the article are shocking. New York State should settle the lawsuit with not only a substantial financial payment to Kerry Sanders but also an apology, and the goal of making sure nothing like it ever happens again.

title: Word for Word: Inspiring Speeches; Appeals for Support by Susan, Rudy, Richard, Kelly, Al and George W.
description: THE two candidates surveyed their voters and saw a group evenly divided -- loyal stalwarts on each side, swing voters in the middle. Pundits and fans who had followed the race closely had no idea who would win. Even casual observers said it would be neck and neck. The venue was the nerve-racking finale of the CBS hit show ''Survivor,'' in which 16 castaways endured trials, forged alliances and ate bugs in their quest to win a million dollars.

title: The World; In Germany, Getting Together Is Hard to Do
description: IT is an irony of modern German history that national unity was achieved just as the nation-state model in Western Europe was being drained of its political content. The vast new Chancellery under construction in Berlin, resembling an outsized ocean liner on the banks of the Spree, has become an object of some mockery partly because the power actually wielded in the building will be slight. European integration, the creation of a euro currency governed by a European central bank and the might of financial markets have made big inroads on national sovereignty.

title: Clearing the Decks for a Trade Pact's Riches
description: TO explain why he is so excited about the new trade agreement with the United States, Pham Van Tuat clambered aboard the Xin Thu, his new 89-foot wooden fishing trawler, and gestured into its spacious holds. Lower American tariffs for Vietnamese seafood products in the United States, he explained, will mean more demand for tuna and squid. And that is where this $125,000 trawler comes in.

title: Sally-Beth Kruteck, Andrew Siegel
description: Sally-Beth Kruteck and Andrew David Siegel were married on Thursday by Rabbi Kenneth A. Stern at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: 'Hot Hands' Strategy Beats Buy and Hold
description: Mutual fund investors are typically warned not to follow the ''hot hands'' -- that is, to chase recent outstanding performance with frequent trades. The better strategy, they are told, is to buy fund shares and hold them long term. But a recent study turns that advice on its head.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: for BOB TASCA Sr.; On the Front Lines of the Tire Recall
description: BOB TASCA Sr. has kicked plenty of tires in his 73 years. He estimates that he, his sons and his grandson, who own a Lincoln-Mercury dealership in Massachusetts and a Ford dealership in Rhode Island, have sold 330,000 cars and trucks.

title: No-Name Defense Deserves Its Obscurity, Anand Shows
description: Viswanathan Anand of India and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia have been running neck and neck behind Garry Kasparov for the last seven years. Most of this time Anand has been second and Kramnik third, but lately it's Kramnik who has performed marginally better.

title: A Horror Film Fan Makes His Own
description: GLEN BAISLEY'S fascination with horror films began when he sat on his father's lap watching Chiller Theater on television.

title: Don't Get the Rod Out Yet, But Trout May Be Returning
description: Like many elite New Yorkers, trout are picky about their surroundings. Unlike carp, which can thrive in the liquid murk of the urban waterway, trout need a cold, clear stream from a pristine source. No wonder that biologists say wild brook trout have not been seen in the city for 100 years or more.

title: The View From/Stratford; Music Treasure Found Tucked Among Scores
description: LOST treasures, big or small, often turn up unexpectedly. In the last decade, Louisa May Alcott's unpublished and practically unknown first novel was found miscataloged in Harvard's library, and the only 17th-century keyboard pieces surviving in the composer Henry Purcell's own hand were unearthed in England. This year, one page written and autographed by Beethoven in 1817 for string quartet was discovered in a private collection in England as well.

title: It Will Take a Village to Raise This Spire
description: TOWERING 185 feet over Sag Harbor, the steeple that crowned the Old Whalers First Presbyterian Church was visible for miles, the first sight of home for returning sailors in the 19th century, when this village was a booming whaling town.

title: MONTCLAIR TRAIN CONNECTION
description: Demolition began last week on 19 homes and apartment buildings in Montclair, the first step in the construction of the long-debated Montclair Connection, a 1,200-foot section of track that will give residents of Montclair, Bloomfield and Glen Ridge a direct rail line to Penn Station in Manhattan. Debate had centered on the 33 families, who have now been relocated for the connection to be built. Construction of the link is expected to be finished sometime next year. Karen DeMasters

title: BEST SELLERS: August 27, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Prosecution May Be Urged In C.I.A. Case
description: A special prosecutor investigating John M. Deutch, the former director of central intelligence, has told law enforcement officials that he is wrapping up his inquiry and expects to recommend that Mr. Deutch be prosecuted on charges of mishandling classified information, government officials said today.

title: On the Rez, an Entrepreneur to Be Reckoned With
description: LONG one of the major summer attractions on Long Island, the Shinnecock Powwow is also the major revenue-producer for the Shinnecock tribe. This year's powwow, the 54th, is co-chaired by a young entrepreneur whose respect for tradition and flair for retailing has made him the tribe's largest employer and a new-generation leader.

title: Bringing New Order To Sunbeam's Chaos
description: IN the last two and a half years, Jerry W. Levin has managed to bring some order to the chaos that once prevailed at the Sunbeam Corporation, the household appliance maker that installed him as chief executive after the notorious ouster of Albert J. Dunlap in 1998. But it has not been easy.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Nature's Ways

title: At Harvard, a Spotlight on the Romanesque
description: ''Before and After the End of Time: Architecture and the Year 1000,'' an exhibition that was scheduled to open yesterday at the Fogg Museum at Harvard University, is an overview of Romanesque architecture, which preceded the Gothic cathedrals in Europe. Romanesque (meaning Roman-like) was a rediscovery of the masonry techniques of the Roman empire, characterized by rounded arches, domed vaults and cut-stone masonry that emphasize the power of mass, space and gravity, rather than the more ethereal vertical aspirations of the Gothic.

title: Brazil Builds Bigger and Better Telenovelas
description: WHEN a television serial about an 18th-century courtesan went off the air here two years ago, few at the struggling network that had produced the drama, called ''Xica da Silva,'' expected it to have much of an afterlife. But then 150 episodes were dubbed into Spanish and sold to a dozen other countries in Latin America, where the series quickly went on to become a ratings phenomenon everywhere it was broadcast.

title: The Nation; O, To Be Single and Have a Politician Pay Attention
description: THE family values platform has been the stomping ground of Republicans for so long that there has been little room for the Democrats. But last week, riding a wave of strong polls following his family-friendly speech at the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, Vice President Al Gore reiterated his intention to make families, particularly ''working families,'' the focus of his campaign. Mr. Gore projected himself as a devoted husband and father who understands that all families want the same opportunities for their children.

title: Margaritas Slumming With Rum As Tequila Crisis Hits Happy Hour
description: Hold on to your salt. Your margarita is in danger.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Writing on Drugs

title: A New Look For Classes In Summer
description: GAIL DUFFY beamed as her students, clad in an eclectic assortment of costumes, performed lively skits about outer space that conveyed facts about different planets.

title: Ignorant Theory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Sarah Stauderman, Andrew Robb
description: Sarah Dodd Stauderman and Andrew Osborn Robb, both museum conservators in Washington, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Wanda McNeill officiated at the Lutheran Church of the Reformation. The Rev. Dr. Albert P. Stauderman, who is the bride's grandfather and a Lutheran minister, took part in the service.

title: U.N. Readies Iraq Team
description: President Saddam Hussein calls them spies, and doesn't want them back in Iraq. But the United Nations has more than 40 new arms inspectors trained and ready to go. To meet some Iraqi objections, the team is drawn from 20 countries, some of them -- like China, France, India, Russia and Sudan -- considered friendly to Iraq. Only 11 arms experts have been drawn from the United States and Britain. Hans Blix, the leader of the new inspection commission, says he is prepared to wait out the Iraqis, who can't hope to have a decade of sanctions lifted until they cooperate. Barbara Crossette

title: Christians Arrested in China
description: Last Tuesday in Los Angeles, a leader of China's government-approved churches said the country had entered a ''golden age'' of religion. On Wednesday in central China, the limits of that freedom were clear as some 130 evangelical Protestants, including three visiting Taiwanese-American missionaries, were arrested at a revival. The worshipers were from one of several large, fervent Christian groups that refuse to cooperate with official bodies and face police harassment and the jailing of their leaders. By week's end, the Americans had been released but the fate of the detained Chinese was unknown. Erik Eckholm

title: Chilies and Citrus Juice Can Spark Up Fish and Vegetables
description: AS the cuisines of sultry climates demonstrate, sharp seasonings played against a touch of acidity can be hot weather appetite whetters. Chilies and citrus juices are what do the trick.

title: Another Long Shot at Global Cellular Service
description: BERNARD SCHWARTZ has spent much of his life as one of the nation's most revered chief executives. He devoted year after consistent year to delivering record returns while building the Loral Corporation into a top military contractor.

title: Electromagnetic Radiation Is Causing Ill Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Farewell to the House That Dad Built
description: THE little house I grew up in in Scarsdale is gone. We knew that its destruction was a possibility when Mom sold it to a contractor two years ago, but we kept up the hope that he would just renovate it or build an addition. It would look vastly different, but it would still be recognizable as the house my Dad built over half a century ago. Unfortunately, it didn't work out that way.

title: From the Depths, Retail Stocks Look for Air
description: WHAT with a climb in interest rates, poor weather and a hangover from Year 2000 computer problems, retailers' stocks have been about as popular as last year's fashions. The question is whether they are distressed merchandise or a legitimate bargain.

title: A Tradition in Rye: Hanging Out at the Wall
description: A RED BMW came to a stop near the stone wall. Here's Armen. The gold Lexus pulling up, that's Scott. Then a shiny blue Volkswagen convertible. Amy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKHEIMER, MARY B.
description: TURKHEIMER-Mary B. Our condolences to Justice Karla Moskowitz and her family on the loss of her mother. The Metropolitan Womens' Bar Association

title: It's Not Easy on the Greens
description: GOLFERS are often reminded that Westchester has some of the world's most difficult golf holes.

title: Vargas Stops Thompson With TKO in 4th
description: This time, they fought in a ring, a place where words and taunts do not make a difference. It is also a place where Fernando Vargas rules.

title: Storm Raised by Plan For a California Prison
description: This aging farm town has yet to meet the New Economy and is barely on speaking terms with the old one. It had staked its hopes for recovery on the nearby North Kern State Prison, but 10 years later, the prison has not lived up to its promise of lowering the town's 26 percent unemployment rate or boosting business.

title: A Company's Program Led to a Career in Science
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Meeting the Demand for Bagpipes
description: After 45 years as a bagpiper, Jonathan Henken has not grown tired of plaid. Not only does he still love bagpipe music, which he began playing as a lad of 10, but the world at large also appears to have caught the spirit. ''It's not just a Celtic thing anymore,'' said Mr. Henken, who has performed as a soloist at Carnegie Hall and is also pipe major for the Mount Kisco Highland Regimental Band. ''It seems to have become an American instrument.''

title: Sulian Tay, Justin Baldauf
description: Sulian Margaret Tay and Justin Matthew Baldauf were married yesterday by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian minister, at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00; What They Were Thinking
description: Franklin D. Edmonds, James Quillen, Doris Quillen, Atlanta, June 29, 2000

title: HARRISON: AIRLINE DEFIES BAN
description: Starting next month, Atlantic Southeast Airlines is planning 5:59 a.m. flights to Atlanta from Westchester County Airport, defying a voluntary ban on flights between midnight and 6:30 a.m. Out of concern for the airport's neighbors, county officials are urging the airline, a subsidiary of Delta Airlines, to reconsider. ''Legally, the airline has a right to do this,'' said Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew J. Spano. ''We want to come up with a course of action to mobilize public pressure.'' Atlantic Southeast said it sought a 5:59 slot so passengers could reach Atlanta to make other flights. Currently, the airline's earliest flights are at 10:29 a.m. Merri Rosenberg

title: A Plan to Help the Watershed
description: IT is one of New York City's dirty and not-so-little secrets.

title: Article 2000082793782280332 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Campers, Careers And Meeting Mariah Carey
description: When children in Fresh Air Fund programs head out to a farm, they usually meet the likes of Joseph, a rugged old sheep, and Cindy, a black and white cow, two of the farm animals that provide part of the city children's camp encounters with country life.

title: Adding A Name To a Lease
description: Q: I have been living in a rent-stabilized apartment for several years. For the last two years my girlfriend has been living with me. We are committed to each other but fear marriage. Since we both realize our relationship is for the long term, will it be possible to have my girlfriend's name added to my lease? . . . Jerry Omanoff, Manhattan.

title: Hunting for Treasure at Bargain Prices
description: THE entrance to the Costco Wholesale warehouse in Yonkers is stacked high with luggage, lawn chairs and portable radios. But just inside, a jewelry counter appears, and there, from atop the display case, comes a warm red glow: a Cartier box cradling a $4,500 man's Pasha watch.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: Questions for Henry Cisneros; Home Leave
description: Q: You have a new job. What is American CityVista?

title: Cast a Cold Eye
description: WILLIAM PLUMMER talked about his father one Friday afternoon as he headed out to do a little fishing. ''I don't think I would have gotten into fly-fishing if my life weren't so messed up and he hadn't died,'' he said as his Ford Explorer bounced along the cratered dirt road near the South Branch of the Raritan River.

title: When Alzheimers Strikes Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Stumbling Out of the Gate
description: A HOLE IN THE EARTH

title: Friends, Turned Rivals, Battle in Brooklyn
description: After a long friendship so close that they once managed each other's campaigns, Assemblyman Darryl C. Towns and Councilman Martin Malave Dilan have in recent years developed a relationship characterized more by the intensity of their political battles.

title: After the Mall: Luring Shoppers Back Downtown
description: In downtown New Rochelle, in Westchester County, a decaying mall was replaced by an elaborate $194 million entertainment complex that is meant to evoke an idealized image of city life.

title: Test Gap Widens Again
description: After narrowing through the 1980's, the gap between test scores of black and white students widened again between 1990 and 1999, according to national test scores released in a federal report.

title: CHILD CARE WORKER PLEADS GUILTY
description: Wayne Gordon, 36, a child care counselor at the Leake & Watts Children's Home in Yonkers, has pleaded guilty in to criminally negligent homicide and assault in connection with an automobile accident that killed his 17-year-old passenger, Crystal Davis, a student at the residential treatment center. According to the charges, Mr. Gordon was traveling above the speed limit on March 2, when the accident occurred. He faces a maximum of four years in prison when he is sentenced on Oct. 13. Elsa Brenner

title: Hypocritical Arms Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: An Open Border With Mexico?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookend; Important: Read This First
description: Time Warner Trade Publishing is paying John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the General Electric Company, $7.1 million for the rights to his story. This continues G.E.'s long tradition of bringing good literature to life.

title: Q & A
description: Dordogne's Caves

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: For Japanese Stocks, a Question of Half-Empty or Half-Full
description: HAS the Japanese stock market returned to the doldrums?

title: A New Neighborhood For the Black Sitcom
description: SINCE the days of Norman Lear, the sitcom had offered two choices in its portrayal of black life in America: there were families thriving amid upper-middle-class plenty while ever-mindful of their roots, a la ''Cosby,'' or families jovially striving to work their way out of an extremely mild form of urban poverty, a la ''Good Times.'' Both came with a generous portion of sugar coating.

title: Peter John Repetti; Corporate Lawyer, 82
description: Peter John Repetti, a retired law partner of the international firm of Fulbright & Jaworski, died Thursday at a hospital in Neptune, N.J. He was 82 and had homes in Spring Lake and Short Hills, N.J.

title: SOAPBOX; Mmm, Mmm, Genetically Engineered
description: IN the 1960's, Andy Warhol made Cambell's Soup a Pop Art legend with his stylized paintings of the soup can logo. The Campbell's company, based in Camden and hailing from an era when the state was a manufacturing center, has long symbolized New Jersey's pride in a home-grown original.

title: A Tax Cut Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; The Real Thing
description: It's summer, and our long national tomatomare is over! In the dank, dark 9 1/2 to 10 months when you can't get a decent wolf peach in this town, tomato deprivation leads to a depression of almost Scandinavian proportions. Oh, you can find things called ''vine ripened,'' but that only means that this here bad tomato has been on a vine longer than that there bad tomato.

title: The Fed, and the Markets, Get Comfortable
description: As anticipated, the Federal Reserve sat on its hands at its policy meeting last week, leaving the equity markets basking in a place they are so far enjoying: interest rate limbo.

title: Locally, Campaigners Seek Clinton's Glow, Not Distance
description: Watching the procession of New Jersey Democrats cozy up to President Clinton during his visit to the state on Wednesday, you could almost forget that in some parts of the country, many members of Mr. Clinton's own party are eagerly counting the days until he steps off of the presidential stage.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: CLOSE TO THE WIND, by Pete Goss. (Carroll & Graf, $15.95.) Competing in a round-the-world single-handed yacht race, the author (at right) ended up rescuing a fellow sailor and battling six-story waves. Writing here last year, Barbara Lloyd said, ''You are immersed in his passion.'' Another disastrous ocean race, off Australia, is recounted in KNOCKDOWN: The Harrowing True Account of a Yacht Race Turned Deadly, by Martin Dugard (Pocket Books, $13.95). This is ''a melodramatic but nonetheless riveting chronicle,'' Elizabeth Hightower said here in 1999, ''a story that simply won't let go.''

title: Somalis Take Close Look At Election In the U.S.
description: Somalis who speak little English will still giggle and say: ''Read my lips.'' Despite mixed feelings about Americans here, there is strong affection for the father -- as a man who tried to make peace in Somalia -- that has rubbed off on the son this American election year.

title: CLINTON IN NIGERIA TO SHOW SUPPORT FOR CIVILIAN RULE
description: Saying ''the world needs Nigeria to succeed,'' President Clinton arrived here today on a visit intended to nudge Africa's most populous country along in its shaky transition to civilian rule after 16 years of debilitating dictatorship.

title: Crashing
description: MONEY, LOVE By Brad Barkley. 336 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about online home sales misstated the given name of a business professor at the University of California at Berkeley who said the National Association of Realtors had used its Internet presence to protect its profit structure. He is Peter Sealey, not Paul.

title: Shut-Out Nigerians Talk Of Leaders With Scorn
description: Among those standing outside the gates of the hotel where the world's most powerful man had just checked in, anger simmered beneath the hope his visit inspired. President Clinton, soon after his plane had touched down here in the capital of Africa's most populous nation, had been brought to the Nicon Hilton and would soon visit President Olusegun Obasanjo.

title: An Open Border With Mexico?
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Black And White And Sells Medicine?
description: REPLICAS of Max, a small plastic zebra, hang from the stethoscopes of so many pediatricians at the Children's Hospital in Boston that at least one family has asked whether he was the hospital's mascot. But no, Max is a creation of Pfizer Inc., intended to sell an antibiotic called Zithromax. And with Max's help, Zithromax has become a billion-dollar drug in just a few years.

title: Correction Officers Ratify New Contract
description: A FIVE-YEAR wait for pay raises is over for about 770 Westchester County correction officers after rank-and-file members ratified a new labor contract that eliminates a contentious rule on disability leave.

title: All Over the World And in the Village
description: FLORENT

title: Elizabeth Marlantes, Nathan Tyrrell
description: Elizabeth Carol Marlantes, a daughter of Carol and Lorian Marlantes of New York, was married yesterday to Nathan Scott Tyrrell, a son of Linda Tyrrell of Pasadena, Calif., and David Tyrrell of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Robert M. Walker, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Hear the One About Suburban Comedy?
description: I TEACH a course in comedy at New York University, so you would not think this would come as a surprise. But an odyssey through the comedy clubs of New York's suburbs has convinced me that comedy in Hawthorne and Levittown and Southbury is different from what it is in Manhattan, despite the leveling influence of television.

title: Dissident With a Cause
description: M. Lee Pearce has struck again. Last week turned out to be far from the first time that Mr. Pearce, 69, a physician, lawyer and investor in Pompano Beach, Fla., has been a potentially costly annoyance to the Tenet Healthcare Corporation and its predecessor hospital chains. In government filings, Dr. Pearce accused Tenet of lackluster results and said he would solicit proxies to seek four seats on the board. Jeffrey Barbakow, Tenet's chief executive, is among the directors seeking re-election.

title: A Patient Life of Sacrifice, Touching Many
description: I COULD have taken my dirty clothes to a half-dozen closer laundries, but Chow and Lam Laundry was worth the extra two-block schlep. The other places folded with careless abandon, leaving a tangle of unmatched socks at the bottom of your laundry bag.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: I was outraged at the miscarriage of justice described in Weiser's article. We should take a closer look at the justice system in this country as well as at the ''professionals'' who staff these institutions. Especially one who states in a deposition that a wrongly accused person should say, ''Thank you, for two years you guys treated me very nicely.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, HOWARD STANFORD
description: WEISSMAN-Howard Stanford, 81. Died August 16 in Durham, N.C. A native of New York City, he relocated in Durham in 1994 from Vieques, P.R. Mr. Weissman was a publicist in NY. Mr. Weissman is survived by three children, six grandchildren. Memorials to the Jewish Family Service, 3700 Lyckan Pkwy, Durham, N.C. 27707.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELTON, WILLIAM R. (PROFESSOR)
description: ELTON-William R. (Professor). Loving son of the late Mollie and William Ribakoff. Devoted brother of Mildred Boyd and Sylvia Gans. Cherished uncle of David Boyd, Susan Gans and Karen GansSchwartz. He was an accomplished poet, a respected scholar and an esteemed member of the faculty of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. His work was his passion, and he will be fondly remembered by those whose lives he touched. Services will be held on Tuesday, August 29, 12 noon, at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Forest fires cause travel restrictions
description: With about 90 major wildfires and hundreds of smaller ones raging across 13 states, it has been a summer of record fire in the American West. Close to 5.2 million acres have been consumed, and with dry conditions expected to last in many places for several more weeks, perhaps until the first snows of late autumn, anyone traveling near wilderness areas should check fire conditions and travel or camping restrictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDER, RUTH
description: WENDER-Ruth. It is with great sorrow that the Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Wender, a generous supporter of our Women's Campaign. Our deepest sympathies go to her twin sister, Irene Winkelman, herself a devoted contributor; her son, Theodore, and his wife, Vicki; her daughter Jill, and her husband, Richard Spitz; and the entire family. May all who benefited from Ruth's kindness and wisdom be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIDUSS, ELLA
description: FRIDUSS-Ella, 92. On August 23. Beloved wife of the late Eugene; loving and devoted mother of Nicholas and Susan; grandmother of Steven, David, Michael and John; great-grandmother of Amy and Michael. Her children and many friends will miss her generosity, kindness, humor and wisdom.

title: Edward C. Walker, Lava Lamp Designer and a Naturist, Is Dead at 82
description: Edward Craven Walker, Royal Air Force squadron leader, champion of what the British call the naturist way of life and designer of the Lava lamp, a quintessential accessory of the 1960's and 1970's, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Ringwood, England. He was 82.

title: Spa Is Out to Change Image Of an Underpampered Area
description: Harlem is not known as an oasis of peace and tranquillity. But Cynthia Grace hopes her new spa will help change that.

title: In Chicago, Girls Get a Public School of Their Own
description: Kai Penn had always thought about becoming an actress, model and singer, but the sixth grader says her career aspirations will probably change now that she is a student at the Young Women's Leadership Charter School here.

title: Hammers: The Advanced Course
description: HAMMERING nails is such an elementary task that it would seem that no explanation is needed. Yet professional carpenters and shop instructors say that many do-it-yourselfers don't know how to drive nails efficiently. The most common mistake is in holding the hammer too close to the head.

title: Wide World of Tennis Calls to Yonkers Ace
description: THE tennis courts at Andrus Park here on Central Avenue look a little like the surface of the moon. They are full of craters, and the asphalt has a slope to it. But from 1996 to 1998 they were home to the best high school player in the state, Erik Scharf of Roosevelt High School right down the road.

title: Syosset Men Put Brotherly Love on Film
description: THE scene takes place on the Upper West Side of Manhattan between two brothers in search of their identities, caring for each other every awkward, uncertain step of the way.

title: How Cartographers Have Seen the World in Times Past
description: RENAISSANCE cartographers fashioned maps of the world -- even though few ever ventured beyond their studios. How indeed did they do this?

title: A Symphony Helps Its Players Get Work
description: IN medieval times, one could always count on a troubadour to stop by the chateau and provide a little music. There were also trouveres, minstrels, and if one were lucky enough to have a kingdom, most likely an in-house ensemble of court musicians.

title: New Life for East Lynne Company
description: EVEN though the East Lynne Company often put on plays with sizeable casts, for 18 years it was known as a one-man show.

title: POSTINGS: A Guidebook of Lower Manhattan; Walking Tours Of Downtown
description: A 163-page guidebook for walking tours of lower Manhattan is to be published early next month by the New York Landmarks Conservancy. The paperback volume contains descriptions of the physical development and business history of the area and has three walking tours with more than 90 stops.

title: Public Space or Private, a Compulsion to Fill It
description: HORROR vacui -- fear of emptiness -- is the driving force in contemporary American taste. Along with the commercial interests that exploit this fear, it is the major factor now shaping attitudes toward public spaces, urban centers and even suburban sprawl.

title: A Complete Webern, With 'New' Works
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: It Beats Being in School
description: STUDENTS think back-to-school time has all the charm of a finger in the eye, and who can blame them? No one, except by sword's point, would trade frittering away days for the nightly grind of homework. And those who work glamorous gigs like lifeguarding must rank swapping swimsuits for Bunsen burners as the world's worst transaction.

title: Norman Set for Silent Treatment in Final With Enqvist
description: Forget the booming serve, the wicked forehand and the brilliant shot selection. For Magnus Norman, one of the toughest parts about defending his Hamlet Cup title Sunday against his good friend and fellow Swede Thomas Enqvist will come during the crossovers.

title: A Classic Play Infused With the Joy of Living
description: IN the theater of uplift, ''You Can't Take It With You'' is an irreplaceable feel-good play.

title: Complex's Tenants Fight Proposed Cut in Trash Collection
description: The Department of Sanitation has proposed reducing trash pickup at Southbridge Towers, a sprawling Mitchell-Lama complex next to the Brooklyn Bridge at 90 Beekman Street, to three days a week from six. But residents say the complex, which houses more than 5,000 co-op tenants, cannot handle the service cut.

title: Political Briefing; And Lastly, a Word Or Two From the Mrs.
description: Louisianans may practice the quirkiest politics in the nation. Among other things, candidates there are permitted to list their nicknames on the ballot, no small concession in the South, where often as not, the game is the name.

title: Usual Suspects Are Expected to Emerge From Regional Battles
description: Atlantic Coast

title: Swimming Like the Fish to Catch the Fish
description: JUST off Montauk Point, south of the lighthouse, Jason Behan, a 30-year-old charter captain, sits on his 20-foot boat, is named for the fly fisherman Lefty Kreh. The boat is laden with rods, tackle, a cooler and a friend: not a rare sight in this village, where fishing is a leading wage-earner and favorite pastime.

title: A Farm With a Cosmopolitan Soul
description: WHILE the battle to save Manhattan's few neighborhood green spaces rages on, one of the largest community gardens in the country blooms quietly in Brooklyn. Six hundred plots occupy five acres of Floyd Bennett Field, the city's former, and first, municipal airport, best known as the place from which pioneering aviators like Howard Hughes, Jacqueline Cochran and Wrong Way Corrigan flew.

title: ITALIAN DESSERTS
description: Bindi Dessert Services Inc., an importer and distributor of Italian desserts, has purchased a 30,000-square-foot abandoned chemical company building in Belleville and will open its first manufacturing plant in the United States. The Totowa-based company now imports its desserts from Italy. Remodeling the building will start next month and production should start by next summer. Gelato, an Italian ice, and Sorbetto, fruit-based sorbet, will be manufactured at the plant. Cakes and tarts will continue to be imported from Italy.

title: Lions, U.S.C. And Defense
description: The focus has been on the quarterbacks so far, but it may shift to the defenses today when Penn State plays Southern California in the 18th Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium.

title: Modern Op
description: If you want to talk seriously about the painter Bridget Riley, then let's dispose of Twiggy and Mary Quant and the whole 60's Op Art craze. Thirty-five years ago, Riley was the That Girl of contemporary painting. Her suave, buzzing, high-octane black-and-white abstractions woke up sleepy English art and caused a transcontinental sensation. Her first show in New York sold out before it opened.

title: United's Deal With Its Pilots May Soon End Disruptions
description: United Airlines and its pilots reached a tentative contract yesterday that could bring an end to months of disruption that has forced the airline to cancel more than 20,000 flights and has given it the worst on-time record in the industry.

title: BUS MOVIES
description: Riders taking the bus from North Jersey to Atlantic City are likely to watch a movie -- and some ads -- provided by an Englewood Cliffs company called BusTV. Coach USA, the company's largest bus company, started this month showing the Disney movie ''Diamonds'' on Leisure Line, Gray Line, Red and Tan, Short Line, Community Coach and Suburban buses, all based in North Jersey and all owned by Coach USA. Before the feature, passengers watch a safety video and then ads aimed at older audiences, for the Senokot laxative and the Mr. Mobility electric wheelchair, for example.

title: Making a Living Off the Sweet Tastes of Home
description: Standing on 135th Street by the Willis Avenue Bridge recently, Felix Villalona wiped the sweat off his brow, looked up momentarily at the steady river of cars crossing from Manhattan to the Bronx, picked up his machete and got to work.

title: NIGHT LIFE; Wildwood Club Draws Crowd With Effervescent Dance Floor
description: IT involves lots of bubbles, but nobody's calling it good clean fun.

title: Ready for a Natty Newshound?
description: JOURNALISM is no glamour biz. Bad hours, peanut pay. Unflattering lighting. Or so the inmates complain. As for the style sense -- does the word ''shlubby'' mean anything to you? The women are more presentable. The men? Let's just say Dockers and Rockport are their Gucci and Prada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIDBORD, GERTRUDE (NEE KOSLAN)
description: BRIDBORD-Gertrude (nee Koslan) on August 24th. Beloved wife of the late Herman Bridbord. Cherished mother of Ken and Maryanne of Chevy Chase, MD, and Bill and Tzippy of Great Neck, NY. Adored grandmother of Karen, Sharon and Itzhak Johnathan. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, August 27th, 12:30PM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. A woman of valour. She will be missed and remembered forever.

title: A Speedy Internet Path Is Slow as an Investment
description: MOST people who connect to the Internet via a digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., rave about its speed and the fact they can use their phone while online.

title: Jenny Lam, Darrell Low
description: Jenny Gim-Hung Lam, a daughter of Shiu Ling Lam and Wah Tim Lam of Manhattan, is to be married today to Darrell Kee Low, the son of Teresa C. Low and Ernest Kee Low of Elmhurst, Queens. The Rev. Dr. James G. Speer will perform the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, ROBERT
description: SACKS-Robert, 49. Of Manhattan. Son, brother, uncle. Bronx Science, Michigan State, MIT. Member N.Y. Academy of Sciences, Gaming Science Fiction Groups.

title: Nina Cloutier, John Gibson
description: Nina Lauren Cloutier and John Bradley Gibson were married yesterday at the West Side Baptist Church on Block Island in Rhode Island. Richard Kiley, the first warden of the town of New Shoreham there, officiated.

title: The Super Bowl Of Shows Turns 50
description: GOLD is the traditional symbol of 50th anniversaries, but when the world's best-known car show celebrates a half century, chrome wire wheels and $25,000 leather interiors seem more apt.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: INVESTING WITH: Duncan W. Richardson and Jacob Rees-Mogg; Eaton Vance Information Age Fund
description: TO Duncan W. Richardson and Jacob Rees-Mogg, co-managers of the $322 million Eaton Vance Information Age fund, risk is clearly not a measure of financial virility. Investing in the technology, media and telecommunications sector ''does not have to be an extreme sport,'' Mr. Richardson said.

title: Among the Mooks
description: The gallery of photographs on the first pages of RJ Smith's article (Aug. 6) depicted young fans waiting for the wristbands that would allow them to purchase tickets for a Limp Bizkit concert in Detroit. A motley lot they are -- pimpled, puffy, tattooed, posing and clowning for the camera. The caption, however, describes the group as ''fast, white and out of control.'' Out of control? These are teenagers, and the overriding emotion in the images is self-consciousness. Out of control? They're standing in line.

title: The Bark of the Players
description: Early September. Football is just getting underway, and baseball is not yet into postseason. But there are other sports around. One is sheep dog trials. On Sept. 2, 3 and 4, fans can see plenty of broken-field running as border collies dash through Fosterfields Living Historical Farm in Morristown. And there will be the calling of signals as handlers guide the dogs by voice and whistles. And finally, there is the the crowning of a champion, as these are the New Jersey State Sheep Dog Trial Championships. Admission on Labor Day weekend to Fosterfields, 73 Kahdena Road, (973) 326-7645 will be $5; $4 for the elderly; and $3 for those aged 6 through 16. There will also be farmers in period clothing performing chores like spreading manure and churning butter and on Sept. 2 and 3, demonstrations of turn-of-the-century carriages by the Hunterdon Horse and Pony Club. Now that's something you don't get at halftime at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBRER, JEAN
description: DOBRER-Jean. June 18, 1954August 18, 2000, of Chicago. Beloved wife of Robert Suomalaher perfect mate. Wonderful daughter of Kenneth Dobrer and Florence Dobrer.
