Treasured sister of Nina Dobrer Hoffman-the other half of their very special sisterhood. Cherished sister-in-law of Stanley Hoffman, Diane Teitelbaum and Laurie Suomala. Dear aunt of Emily, Amanda, Susanna and Nicholas Hoffman. Dear step daughter of Janet Dobrer. Best friend to so many in Chicago. A brilliant lawyer, she was a woman of principle and valor, who met life head-on with a smile. Her passing leaves a void that will never be filled. We love you, Jeannie, forever and a day. Memorial donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Call of the Wild
description: Goings-on at the annual benefit for Robert Wilson's Hamptons arts center.

title: F5 Networks May Be Acquired
description: F5 Networks May Be Acquired

title: Review of Reviewers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, LILLIAN K.
description: STEIN-Lillian K. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Peter and mother-in-law of Debra. Cherished grandmother of David and Kristen. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Sari Neidell, Glen Cohen
description: Sari Genifer Neidell, the daughter of Suzan and Martin Neidell of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., is to be married today to Glen Daren Cohen, a son of Rita Schoen of Plainsboro, N.J., and Edwin Cohen of New York. Rabbi Darryl Crystal will officiate at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Far From Galleries, Art for Executives
description: ''Alternative art'' and ''Wall Street'' are not generally heard in the same sentence. Yet merging these two worlds is the goal of Margaret Bodell, Caroline Kerrigan and Aaron Goranson, who recently opened the Wall Street Viewing Room at 5 Beekman Street. It is a gallery outside the mainstream in an area known for business suits and ties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENROD, ESTELLE
description: EISENROD-Estelle. Age 85, of Flushing, NY, died August 18, 2000. Buried at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Eisenrod. She graduated in 1934 from Brooklyn College with a BA degree in Latin and French. She was a claims examiner for the New York State Workers Compensation Board. She was an avid student for the past 20 years at The French Institute in NYC. Mrs. Eisenrod was loved and will be dearly missed by everyone. She is survived by her aunt Annette Israel and cousin Rhoda Ezra of Punta Gorda, FL, and cousins Harriet Becker of Commack, NY, Leonard Kaufman of Jacksonville, FL, Lester Kaufman of Flushing, NY, sister-in-law, Belle Galman of Philadelphia; and a host of other loving relatives and friends.

title: Treating Fish With Respect in Huntington
description: LEGAL SEA FOODS is making waves at the Walt Whitman Mall in Huntington Station. From the minute it opened, lines have been snaking out the door. Displaced New Englanders and frequent visitors to Boston have been in the forefront. They know that Legal Sea Foods, the 50-year-old chain that began as a fish market in Cambridge, Mass., is the place for reliable, moderately priced fish and shellfish. For many Long Islanders, no trip to Boston is complete without at least one meal at Legal Sea Foods.

title: Clinton Opens Internet Site to Match Teachers to Schools
description: Clinton Opens Internet Site to Match Teachers to Schools

title: 2000 College Football Preview; THE NEW YORK TIMES PRESEASON TOP 20
description: Because The New York Times computer does not begin ranking teams until it has gathered at least a month's worth of data, this rating is the work of the reporter Joe Drape. The national champion will again be determined on the field -- on Jan. 3 in the Orange Bowl -- as part of the Bowl Championship Series. The series, whose primary goal is to determine the two teams that will meet in the title game, is a rating system that uses the Associated Press media poll, the ESPN/USA Today coaches' poll and eight computer rankings, including The Times's.

title: Katherine Bardel, Robert Hamblet
description: Katherine Cutter Bardel and Robert Seifert Hamblet, both teachers at the Potomac School in McLean, Va., were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert L. Ficks III at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn. The bride wore a wedding gown that was made in 1878 for her great-great-grandmother.

title: No Good Neighbors at This Fence
description: HAVING Suffolk County declare a site a preserve apparently is not enough to protect parkland, at least not in Stony Brook Village.

title: Sir Lynden Pindling, 70, Prime Minister Who Led Bahamas to Independence
description: Sir Lynden O. Pindling, the prime minister of the Bahamas for 25 years whose reputation and relationship with the United States were marred by unresolved accusations of protecting drug traffickers, died yesterday at his home in Nassau. He was 70.

title: A Look at Life Underground
description: COMING this Wednesday to Film Forum is ''Dark Days,'' which explores the homeless community that lives in the train tunnels beneath Manhattan. Dee, a tunnel dweller for a year now, is shown here shaving the head of Ralph, who has lived in the tunnel for three years.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: That an overburdened and cynical prison system could make a mistake is understandable, although I would hope that the magnitude of the error in the case of Kerry Sanders is a gross aberration. What is disturbing, also, is that New York authorities responded with denial and defiance rather than with contrition.

title: ART REVIEWS; Creator's Photos Revive Lost Sculpture Garden
description: 'The Creeks'Ossorio Foundation, 164 Mariner Drive, Southampton. Through Sept. 9. (631) 287-2020. www.ossorio.org

title: Easing Flight Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Lasser, Maxim Shrayer
description: Dr. Karen Elizabeth Lasser, a daughter of Dr. Joan L. Lasser of Providence, R.I., and Dr. Abraham Lasser of Pawtucket, R.I., was married last evening to Maxim D. Shrayer, the son of Emilia Shrayer and Dr. David Shrayer, also of Providence. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman performed the ceremony there in Manning Chapel at Brown University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THIBAULT, ROBERT
description: THIBAULT-Robert. The York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Thibault, associated with the Times since 1969.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 13 about visiting islands in Lake Erie misstated the form of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry's famous message after the Battle of Lake Erie in 1813, ''We have met the enemy, and they are ours,'' and misstated the title of the recipient. The message went by courier, not in a telegram. The addressee, William Henry Harrison, was a general and not yet president.

title: The World; The Extraordinary Every Day of Living Africa
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S brief passage to Nigeria and Tanzania this weekend will provide a thousand pictures. Few, perhaps, will convey the many cultures of Africa that have survived war, disease, the slave trade and the political boundaries and border disputes that are sometimes the cause of often intractable conflict. Africa's ancient ceremonies are the most visible signs of a spirituality that for many modern Africans still molds everyday life.

title: Buy Low, Sell High, in Decimals
description: Ever since 24 brokers signed an agreement to trade with one another beneath a buttonwood tree outside 68 Wall Street in 1792, the New York Stock Exchange has quoted all stock prices in fractions. Tomorrow, that will change.

title: Summer Exhibitions, Ghosts and Wee Folk
description: THE capacious galleries at Real Art Ways in Hartford seem haunted these days. Two of the three summer shows are about ghosts from the past, while the third is overrun by wee folk.

title: Tempering Elation or Worry Over Shift in Momentum Till Labor Day
description: Joe Andrew, the national chairman of the Democratic Party, said his world had transformed this week. ''Now, my phone calls are getting returned that weren't getting returned,'' he said. ''When everything goes right, everything goes right.''

title: The Best Are Black
description: To the Editor:

title: Dueling Kims
description: In a testament to the resourcefulness of capitalists, a South Korean insurance man has found a way to make money from the image of the leader of Communist North Korea, the stern-faced, curly-haired Kim Jong Il.

title: GIBSON PLEADS POVERTY
description: Former Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson asked a federal judge this week for taxpayer support in defending himself against a bribery and fraud indictment in connection with his engineering consulting firm's supervision of work on a $50 million Irvington school rehabilitation project. Mr. Gibson sought to keep the lawyer who has represented him for the last four years as the United State's Attorney's office here has been investigating the Irvington project. But he said that he was unable to afford her fee of $425 an hour. Ronald Smothers

title: A Trickle, Not a Rush, In Tourism to Vietnam
description: TWENTY-FIVE years after the end of the Vietnam War and a month after the United States completed an historic trade agreement with its former enemy, tour organizers in both countries hope that American travelers will finally start to make their way to Vietnam in large numbers.

title: Liberty Subdues Jitters, and Nearly Comets
description: In that woozy, merry, end-of-the-party kind of voice, Dean Martin warbled a hit song years ago in which he was ''goin' back to Houston, Houston, Houston.''

title: Artists Make Traditional Canvas Into the Medium
description: ANYONE stopping by the art exhibition at the Summit Bank corporate center here will never look at hubcaps the same again. Or paper.

title: Byways of the Blue Mountains
description: IT'S a good thing the sidewalks are cement,'' observed the stranger as I passed him on Main Street.

title: G.E. Plans to Leave Westchester Airport
description: Saying its quarters at Westchester County Airport in Harrison are too small for its corporate fleet of aircraft, the General Electric Company plans to lease about 11 acres at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, Jeff DeMarrais, a spokesman for the company, said.

title: Marilyn Dabady, Brian Lynk
description: Dr. Marilyn Dabady, a daughter of Therese and Emilio Dabady of Hollis, Queens, is to be married today to Brian Hamilton Lynk, the son of Alexis Lynk and Dr. Rodney H. Lynk of Lorain, Ohio. The Rev. Stephen Gervais of the Federation of Christian Ministries is to officiate at Chateau Briand, a catering business in Carle Place, N.Y.

title: Vanity With a Cause
description: The international film festival in Venice, Italy, next week may be rife with vanity cases, but only three of them will actually be for sale. At the festival on Thursday, Sharon Stone will introduce the amfAR Collection, cosmetics carriers that she designed in conjunction with Louis Vuitton, offering one of each of the line's three styles at an auction to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research.

title: The Brave, and Now the Few
description: ROBERT GALIONE'S lifelong passion is fighting fires. A New York City firefighter for more than 20 years, he joined the Lakeland Fire Department in 1985, serving as a volunteer firefighter and later as commissioner. On top of working nearly 50 hours a week at a Brooklyn rescue company, Mr. Galione, a 44-year-old father of three, spent 30 hours a week at the firehouse in Ronkonkoma.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, DAVID FRANCIS
description: MEAD-David Francis. Suddenly, in New York on August 22, 2000. Gifted composer and accomplished musician, founder of N.Y.C. based jingle house, MEAD MUSIC MAKERS. Adored son of Marian (Co. Laois, Ireland) and the late Walter. Beloved brother of John (and Wendy), Cecily (and Richard Motherway), and Andrea. Loving friend to Deirdre. Devoted uncle to Richard, Alicia and Daniel McDonald, Francesca and Phoebe Flynn, and Alexis and Emily Mead. Dear great uncle, nephew and friend. Services at Old Saint Patrick's Cathedral (Mott Street), Wednesday, August 30th, 4PM.

title: Daria: Smart, Alienated and ... Dating?
description: IT'S as if somebody made an ''All in the Family'' movie with Archie Bunker as a thoughtful political liberal. Or an ''I Love Lucy'' movie with Lucy Ricardo as an Oxford scholar. And yet there she is: Daria Morgendorffer, MTV's lovable animated teenage girl curmudgeon, with a boyfriend. A boyfriend! As Daria explains to one classmate, who is puzzled by the young man's identity and presence, ''Jodie, hell's frozen over and Tom's here with me.''

title: Book Offers Peek Into Nixon's Mind
description: President Nixon medicated himself with a mood-altering prescription drug in the White House and, depressed by hostile public reaction to the bombing of Cambodia in 1970, he consulted a New York psychotherapist who considered him ''neurotic,'' according to a biography to be published on Monday.

title: One Album to His Name, but It's the Stuff of Legend
description: I TRACE my fascination with Willis Alan Ramsey to a honky-tonk girl from Austin, Tex., a sweet hellion who coveted her reputation as a provider of favors. What she gave me 28 years ago, however, was no mere kiss or long-neck Lone Star. It was a freshly pressed album by Mr. Ramsey that marked both his debut and Austin's emerging musical confluence of hippies and rednecks. Only later would I realize that owning the album was also the equivalent of induction into a secret society.

title: Although Power Rules, Hingis Is Confident
description: Martina Hingis did not bring the Rollerblades for her Central Park skate this United States Open. Too much baggage. She had them when she won her first and only United States Open in 1997, back when she was 16 and unafraid, grinning and winning tournaments as if she were taking an afternoon joy ride. She is still grinning, still the No. 1-ranked player. But no blades.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 9 of Arts & Leisure today about the film ''The Sound of Music'' includes an outdated reference to the opening date for ''Sing-A-Long Sound of Music'' at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan. It is Sept. 6, not Sept. 7.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about plans to redevelop the former Long Island Developmental Center in Huntington misstated its function. It was a residence for the mentally retarded and developmentally disabled of all ages; the Sagamore Children's Center, adjacent to the Developmental Center and still in operation, is a children's psychiatric hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMOND, JANE
description: DIMOND-Jane. On August 26, 2000. Sister of Mrs. Robert H. Pfeiffer & Thomas Dimond & the late Jessie K. Dimond. Funeral private.

title: THEATER; Needed: A Think Tank For Promising Talent
description: ONCE upon a time in America there were musicals that revolutionized the way we told stories through song and dance: ''Lady in the Dark,'' ''Oklahoma!,'' ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''My Fair Lady,'' ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' ''West Side Story,'' ''A Chorus Line.'' The creators of such abundance included Kurt Weill and Ira Gershwin, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Irving Berlin, Cole Porter, Frank Loesser, Lerner and Loewe, Bock and Harnick, Leonard Bernstein and Stephen Sondheim. But -- more than 50 years later in some cases -- we are still trying to grow musicals from that well-plowed field. We are eating our seed corn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDSON, JESSE T., JR.
description: HUDSON-Jesse T., Jr. Age 79. Of Urbanna, VA. Retired Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer with Reynolds Metals Company in Richmond, VA, died Friday, August 25, 2000. He was a member of the Union League Club in New York City. Memorial services will be held Tuesday at 2 PM in Christ Church, Middlesex County, VA.

title: Watching the World, Never Mind the Cars, Go By
description: After five days of rain and clouds, the sun decided to shine over West 80th Street and Broadway one recent afternoon. Shoppers were giddy with the weather, swishing their bags and grinning as they darted in and out of stores. Everyone seemed to have somewhere to be and something to do, and so most overlooked Ethel Berg in the median.

title: Paper Company Moving To a Tower in Stamford
description: International Paper, the world's largest producer of paper products, will move its corporate headquarters from Purchase to a 15-story building in downtown Stamford, which it obtained when it acquired Champion International, a rival paper producer, in late June. The company has 120 workers at its Purchase offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBHAUER, HENRY
description: GELBHAUER - Henry. Loving brother of Raquel and Esther. Devoted uncle of Mark, Victor, Sylvia, Susan, Marie and Margaret. Great-uncle to Danny. Dear friend of many. Services Monday 1:30PM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd corner 66th Avenue.

title: Pruning Season
description: THE ROSE GROWER

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Norwalk Is No Longer 'the Hole in the Doughnut'
description: A CITYWIDE surge of new construction and conversions of older buildings in Norwalk has given the city a vibrancy it has not experienced in decades. Long overshadowed by fashionable towns around it like Darien, New Canaan, Wilton and Westport, Norwalk chafed under the characterization of ''hole in the doughnut.''

title: FIRST PERSON; I Cut My Finger, O.K.?
description: LAST October, in a split second, I became a freak. Inevitably, people would pass me on the street and do a double take. I admit that the beak-shaped plastic cast, punctured with dozens of air holes, on my left arm was odd. (My physical therapist, Lora, who molded it, must have had it in for me.) And it was always protruding out of my coat sleeve. But this is New York. I didn't expect people to care -- or ask so many personal questions.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE TWINS

title: A Collector Whose Passion Is Saving Old Houses
description: LARS SJOBERG dates his obsession with old Swedish houses to 1951, when, at age 10, his mother gave him a book from his grandfather's library on manors and villas from centuries past.

title: Show Heralds the Rugged Beauty of Maine
description: THE current exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art here, titled ''Maine and the Modern Spirit,'' presents both the familiar and the unexpected. Familiar because there are many expected images that conjure up Maine's harsh and beautiful environment, and unexpected because there are more than a few works that, aside from the sense of contemplation and isolation, have a more universal approach to content.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about roommate matching services misspelled the name of one agency. As noted in the article, it was the Gay Roommate (not Roommates) Information Network.

title: Using the Outdoors to Refocus Teenagers
description: IT was nearly midnight and the rain was pouring down as Edith Sierra kept climbing along with a half-dozen other girls. The footing was slippery and the group's safety depended on the steady guidance of expert wilderness counselors.

title: How to Make 200 Million Flip-Flops
description: THE deaths and injuries attributed to failed Firestone tires are horrific, but recalling 6.5 million tires poses another problem: what to do with them once they are taken off Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles and other light trucks.

title: South's Football Fans Still Stand Up and Pray
description: It started slowly at first, a few students holding hands in the bleachers and saying ''Our Father who art in Heaven'' while football players gathered on the North Forrest High School field Friday night. But by the time they got to ''deliver us from evil,'' most of the crowd of 4,500 was standing, proudly reciting the Lord's Prayer, insisting that God cannot be removed even from a Class 4-A high school football game.

title: Looking at a France That's Seldom Seen
description: FOR all of Bertrand Tavernier's reputation for being politically ''engage,'' the veteran French director's latest film did not begin with the ''big idea'' of denouncing poverty and unemployment hidden behind France's stolidly bourgeois facade. Rather, its genesis was an anecdote heard one evening over dinner with his 33-year-old daughter, Tiffany, and her husband, Dominique Sampiero, a poet who had spent 15 years teaching in public schools in run-down communities in the north of the country.

title: NEWARK ARENA OFFER
description: Governor Whitman weighed in last week with a $75 million opening offer on what the state was willing to contribute to the construction of a new arena for the Nets and the Devils in Newark (the site is shown here) and there was a decided groan among supporters of the $325 million project. YankeeNets and Newark and Essex county officials had hoped for a quick agreement on a state contribution of at least $123 million. Ronald Smothers

title: A Book That Speaks to Children
description: ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire'' is working its magic in Westchester.

title: Measure of a Species
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan, the Deserted Isle
description: ''Would the last New Yorker heading out of town before Labor Day please leave the lights on for the tourists?''

title: What City, Please? Vexation in Dialing Can Start With 411
description: Sandra L. Frankel, town supervisor of Brighton, N.Y., just east of Rochester, thinks of dialing 411 as a call for disinformation.

title: Home-Grown Drug Business Booms in Vancouver
description: As Canada's health department looks this fall for a reliable supplier of almost one million marijuana cigarettes for clinical trials, some Canadians say they need to look no farther than ''British Colombia,'' where relaxed attitudes about smoking marijuana have helped turn the province into a major North American producer for some of the drug's strongest strains.

title: The Prince of Peas
description: THE MONK IN THE GARDEN The Lost and Found Genius of Gregor Mendel, the Father of Genetics. By Robin Marantz Henig. 292 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: No Matter The School, Quarterbacks Share Hot Seat
description: There's a superman at Virginia Tech, and an old man at Florida State. There's the passing man at Purdue, a running man at Nebraska and dueling men at Texas. They have little in common except that they are quarterbacks and that the prospects of their teams reaching bowl games or earning a national title are in the care of their feet, their arms and, especially, their heads.

title: L.I.R.R. Expansion: The Other Shoe Drops
description: LONG awaited, the new diesel locomotives the Long Island Rail Road put in service two years ago came with an unannounced feature. The train horns made such a racket that thousands couldn't sleep.

title: Catherine Graetzer, David Leibowitz
description: Catherine Elaine Graetzer, a daughter of MaryAlice Graetzer and Prof. Reinhard Graetzer of State College, Pa., was married yesterday to David Gruskoff Leibowitz, a son of Eileene and Bob Leibowitz of Manhattan. Patrick T. Perkins, the bishop of the Third Ward of the Mormon Church in Manhattan, performed a nondenominational ceremony at Bouterin, a Manhattan restaurant.

title: OPINION; When South Winds Doth Blow . . .
description: TODAY'S weather forecasters will readily admit that they have been seduced by the technology of the trade, from three-dimensional, computer-generated graphics that capture weather fronts to real-time infrared satellite images that promise to foretell the future.

title: When Alzheimer's Strikes Home
description: To the Editor:

title: 30 Hours of Free Opera
description: Why would a seasoned opera diva drive 60 miles to sing at 3 a.m. for no pay to a sleep-deprived audience? Dan Montez, director of the four-year-old Taconic Opera, says it's no mystery. Artists perform gratis at the company's yearly Operathons for two reasons, he said. The 30-hour nonstop free event gets plenty of media attention -- a career boost for singers -- and also lets performers add a notch to their repertorial belts. ''One of the ways I get higher-caliber singers to sing with a new company like my own is they can sing something they don't have on their resume,'' he said. ''Maybe they haven't done a 'Lucia,' for example, and want to try it out on my company before singing it somewhere else.''

title: Aretha Franklin in Atlantic City
description: Aretha Franklin was the first woman elected to the Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame and the youngest recipient of the Kennedy Center Honors. These two honors came on top of all the Grammies and Lifetime Achievement Awards she has received, and each award has helped secure a place in music history for the powerful soul singer.

title: Gunning for Sales
description: Used-car dealers, especially in small towns, have a way of gaining local celebrity through the wild marketing gambits they use to move the metal off the lot.

title: Mori Visit Leaves Indian IT Firms Dreaming of Yen Windfall
description: Mori Visit Leaves Indian IT Firms Dreaming of Yen Windfall

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYER, JACK
description: BAYER-Jack. A philanthropist & devoted father and grandfather, died Wednesday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born in Burlington, VT on December 22, 1907, he married Anne Pilver Bayer in 1936. The two lived in Claremont, NH during the 58 years of their loving marriage. Mr. Bayer owned a number of stores in the New England area and was a tireless fundraiser for UJA. He is survived by his children: Marilyn Fassberg, Deborah Paley, Michael Bayer and Susan Bayer Fishman, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He will be missed by all those he supported in his lifetime.

title: Down the Aisle, Following Tradition
description: MARY MARBACH began dating Dr. Anthony Marano in 1953. They were best friends first, then sweethearts. She was struck by his kindness; he, by her vitality.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: My family was eating lunch on the observation deck at Spring Lake's beach. A loud intermittent buzz coming from behind a low wall was destroying our serenity. Finally, I stood and craned my neck to see what it was. Two lifeguards were taking turns shaving their heads over a trash can.

title: Corrina Birnbaum, Paul Gitterman
description: Corrina Indigo Birnbaum, the daughter of Dale Hansen Saul of Chevy Chase, Md., and Michael Birnbaum of Plainfield, Vt., was married yesterday to Paul Douglas Gitterman, a son of Joanna Morris Gitterman and Joseph L. Gitterman III of Washington Depot, Conn. Justice Marilyn S. Skoglund of the Vermont State Supreme Court officiated at the Lake House in Grand Isle, Vt.

title: For a Surprise, Sunny Flowers
description: Life is full of surprises, and one of the best that I have had this summer is false sunflower (Heliopsis helianthoides). I bought one last year, installed it, and forgot it. I ignored the leaves early in the season, and was shocked by the bright yellow double flowers that look like a cross between a mum and a sunflower.

title: Fan With a Different Story
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sarah Hermanson, Adam Meister
description: Sarah Hermanson, a daughter of Susan and Terry Hermanson of New York, was married yesterday to Adam Paul Meister, a son of Nancy Deeds Meister and Joel S. Meister, both of Tucson. The Rev. David W. Good, a Congregational minister, performed the outdoor ceremony in Niantic.

title: A Hot Company, Thanks to Chilies
description: There is a game people play when they visit Rob Polishooks's home in Summit. It's called ''How many things have chili peppers on them?'' (The answer: 35). There are chili designs on the plates, chilies on the cups, chilies on the napkin holders, a chili welcome rug, not to mention the chili peppers and hot sauces in the closets. The decor is fitting for a man who is the founder and co-owner of Chile Today-Hot Tamale, an East-Hanover-based food business created from the fiery chili pepper.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HOT SPRINGS

title: Filthy Lucre
description: Developing nations often complain that foreign investors drain too much money out of their economies in repatriated profits. Thus the double take when Bulgaria said last Monday that it would expel five foreigners for pouring too much money in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFLER, HERBERT H.
description: HEFLER-Herbert H. Suddenly on August 25th. Attorney and retired senior bank officer, Independence Community Bank. Beloved and loving husband of Alice, father of Stephen, Karen Hefler-Hope, and Michael, deceased. Much loved, much missed. Funeral: Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, 914-834-0144.

title: POSTINGS: 68 Low-Cost Apartments in the South Bronx; A 7-Story Building, in Blue, Yellow and Orange
description: The shortage of modestly priced apartments in New York is well known. So it is hardly surprising that when a lottery was held recently for the 68 new low-cost apartments at 1118 Intervale Avenue, at the corner of East 167th Street in the South Bronx, more than 2,000 applications poured in.

title: Home Was a Tunnel and Neighbors Were His Cast
description: ONE October evening in 1994, a scruffy pod of homeless people sitting around a fire in the dank, dark Amtrak tunnel they lived in beneath Manhattan heard a thin, animated man named Ralph come up with an idea. ''Someone should be making a film about this stuff,'' he said. The others nodded or laughed or agreed or shook their heads at the absurdity of the thought, and the conversation moved on.

title: Runway Makes Dissension Take Off
description: Maryann Scarbowski's horses seem more bothered by one pony's attempt to monopolize a bale of hay than by the drone of a small aircraft overhead. Like their owner and her three boys, the horses have grown accustomed to the sputter and buzz of the planes that fly by every minute or two.

title: A Rehashing
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: The Flags Keep Flying, For Now, at Corner Deli

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: On Language; Lookism
description: Communism is all but dead, and socialism is passe. Capitalism is doing fine, but as an attack word it has been replaced by market economy. Has the suffix -ism lost its sting?

title: Collaborating on an 'Eroica'
description: Beethoven composed the first ''Eroica.'' The Middle Mosel and Washington State collaborated on the second.

title: YONKERS: MORE MONEY FOR SCHOOLS
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has asked the Education Department to release $1.8 million in state aid to the Yonkers schools. Several weeks ago, the school system faced a $26 million budget shortfall. But the governor pledged up to $10 million earlier this month as a down payment on a settlement of the Yonkers school desegregation case, and the district has made other budget cuts to eliminate the shortfall. Yonkers received an $18 million increase in state school aid this year, nearly twice the statewide average of 8.7 percent. Elsa Brenner

title: Settlement in Phone Walkout
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest telecommunications employer, settled a strike by more than 86,000 employees that lasted more than two weeks in 12 Eastern states and the District of Columbia. Union members received a wide range of concessions from the company, which was formed by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation, including higher wages and benefits, stock options, increased job stability and greater freedom to organize in Verizon's fast-growing wireless division. The strike created a backlog of roughly and 200,000 new service orders. Simon Romero

title: Ideas & Trends; One Step Farther From Death
description: In a 5-2 ruling last week, Georgia's Supreme Court stayed the execution of Alexander Williams, a mentally ill death row inmate.

title: A Seminar in Passion, Spanish Style
description: I WAS drunk the first time I danced flamenco, which helped considerably. It was 15 years ago, and I had recently arrived in southern Spain, one of 30 or so American college girls well primed for the modest adventure of a junior year abroad. It was October, and the heat that turns the streets of Cordoba to molten tar had only recently subsided, so that we were just beginning to recognize the beauty of that city's winding alleyways and flowering balconies. We would walk the mile to school each day in small, chattering groups, past shopkeepers who did not yet know our names but who recognized us for what we were: that year's crop of americanas.

title: Among the Mooks
description: Showcasing aggression has become the cash cow of record labels and other media entities. People like Jimmy Iovine and Fred Durst laugh all the way to the bank. Sadly, it is all about money: there really is no message to this outrageousness. If only ''mooks'' could learn just how little their icons care about them.

title: Eat-In Movies
description: Multiplexes offering stadium seating and Tex-Mex snacks are not the only ones adding a little luxury to a movie date.

title: PARK TO BE ENLARGED
description: Three acres of state land, being used by the State Department of Transportation, will be redeveloped into a recreation area to increase public access to Annsville Creek in Cortlandt. The parcel will become part of the 4,254-acre Hudson Highlands State Park, which spans Dutchess, Putnam and Westchester Counties. The site will open to the public next spring. Elsa Brenner

title: Online Publisher Features Author
description: Is revealing a father's affair to the rest of the family an obligation or a betrayal, especially if the father leaves and the family is plunged into poverty in a gritty neighborhood riddled with problems?

title: Bronx Man With a Knife Is Shot in Leg By the Police
description: A 51-year-old Bronx man was shot by the police early yesterday morning when, the authorities said, he brandished a butcher's knife at another man and two officers.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: I don't know which is worse -- the fact that Sanders spent two years in a maximum security prison for a crime he didn't commit, or the fact that almost no one involved gave a damn.

title: The Wheel of Love
description: Marriage has its ups and downs, so what better place to be married than on the London Eye, the 450-foot-high Ferris wheel on the Thames? The Lambeth Council of London recently granted permission for weddings to be conducted in the enclosed glass capsules of the giant wheel, and it is hoped that the first knots can be tied in 2001. Afterward, couples can have their receptions in nearby County Hall, opposite the Houses of Parliament. Fees for the ceremony and prices for receptions have not been determined. Written applications should be sent to British Airways London Eye, Riverside Building, County Hall, Westminster Bridge Road, London, England SE1 7PB.

title: Signs From Above
description: THE BOOK OF MIRACLES The Meaning of the Miracle Stories in Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam. By Kenneth L. Woodward. 429 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $28.

title: A Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Amtrak's Delays
description: To the Editor: Contrary to the impression that obtaining a certificate for an unsatisfactory trip on Amtrak is relatively simple, requiring 15 days or less (''Amtrak's New Approach Comes With Guarantees,'' July 30), my recent experience has indicated that it is not only tedious but almost impossible.

title: Unshaded Wins Travers In Final Yards
description: It was a tale of two owners' boxes as the 131st running of the Travers Stakes roared into the final hundred yards, with two 3-year-olds hip to hip, trading the lead snout by snout. In one box, the trainer Nick Zito and the owner Tracy Farmer stomped their feet and talked to a television screen, urging their colt Albert the Great to please, please hang on.

title: Brandywine Valley
description: The Brandywine Valley never produced a Mark Twain to glamorize its serpentine river, or a Washington Irving to make its folkways legendary. Instead, the valley lays claim to artists -- painters like Howard Pyle and the Wyeth clan -- who found inspiration in its gentle beauty and the simplicity of Quaker farmsteads.

title: Venus Williams Comes Into Her Own
description: Just down the road from her parents' roomy but unassuming Colonial, with its green shutters and patchy lawn, the sawdust has settled on the construction of Venus Williams's gated home in South Florida.

title: Anne Rouse, Matthew Sudduth
description: Anne Willard Rouse, a daughter of Emma Martin Halpert of Philadelphia and Willard G. Rouse III of Phoenixville, Pa., was married yesterday to Matthew Pratt Sudduth, a son of Charlotte Pratt Sudduth of Marion, Mass., and Dr. S. Scott Sudduth of Newfields, N.H. The Rev. Robert W. Woodroofe III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Bretton Woods Chapel in Bretton Woods, N.H.

title: Hudson River Journal; A Duck's-Eye View of Lady Liberty
description: Jessica Sung clutched the chain-link gate and stared at the river. About a dozen people were putting kayaks into the water at Pier 26 in TriBeCa. The air was crisp, the skies blue. All this had inspired Ms. Sung to get up early on a Saturday morning, but not early enough.

title: Habitats/170 East Second Street; Ginsberg Lived Here (You Know, the Poet)
description: WHEN the plaque went up on the East Village building saying that it was where Allen Ginsberg once lived, the two young men who now occupy the poet's old apartment had only this to say:

title: Hardly an Exception
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 13 about the documentary ''Gimme Shelter'' misstated the year in which Brian Jones left the Rolling Stones and later died. It was 1969, not 1968.

title: Looser Rules Are Considered For Bacteria in Students' Beef
description: Agriculture Department officials say they are discussing the possibility of loosening their new standards for preventing salmonella contamination in ground beef used for the nation's school lunch program.

title: Sometimes All You Have to Do Is Ask
description: WHEN it comes to waiting periods for benefits, experts say, companies often have more flexibility than they let on, and job candidates have more leverage than they might think.

title: From a Writer's Life: Book, Film, Musical
description: WHEN Herman Raucher got a call from David Kirshenbaum and Hunter Foster about creating a stage musical from his 1971 film ''Summer of '42,'' Mr. Raucher said he didn't give it much thought.

title: Working in the Spirit Of My Father's Place
description: THERE was a time in Long Island's cultural history when the whole world looked here for the next big trend in rock 'n' roll. That was between 1974 and 1980, the heyday of My Father's Place, a cabaret in Roslyn.

title: An Ample Offer of Help, With Strings Attached
description: IS there a market for a musical about a homely young woman who has plastic surgery and then takes eager revenge on the people who rejected her? Or a show about a Jewish stenographer and a black playwright in early 1950's New York who want to find their part of the American dream? What about a solo musical starring a 1999 Tony Award winner, Kristen Chenoweth, possibly one of the few musical comedy performers today who could carry it off?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FOOL'S GOLD By Jane S. Smith. Zoland, $24.

title: Saw Doctors in Sea Bright
description: Considered the modern heirs to U2's legacy, and Ireland's E-Street Band, the Saw Doctors are a rough and ready outfit who combine melodic pop, blue-collar grit and a punk spirit resulting in a vigorous collection of Irish roots-rock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIGUEROA, HOWARD G.
description: FIGUEROA-Howard G. Of Chappaqua, NY, died on August 25, 2000 at Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 70. Formerly Vice President of I.B.M. Survived by his wife Marie (Binner) Figueroa; daughter Janice Figueroa of Manhattan, NY, and two sons Bruce Figueroa of Norfolk, MA, and David Figueroa of Stoughton, MA; a sister Marcelle Hughes of Honolulu, HI; and five grandchildren. Pre-deceased by one brother Roy Figueroa. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at The Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Chappaqua. Interment Fair Ridge Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Howard G. Figueroa Scholarship Fund at Lehigh University, Alumni Memorial Building, 27 Memorial Drive West, Bethlehem, PA 18015-3086.

title: Black Hats and Vice Presidents
description: BARUCH KLAR is like any impresario. This year's Jewish Renaissance Fair, set for next Sunday in West Orange, will be the best ever, he kvells. Among his headliners are Uncle Moishy and the Mitzvah Men. ''There's no Jewish kid that won't like Uncle Moishy,'' he promises. There will also be jugglers, magicians and a storybook hayride.

title: Online Links Help Find Contractors
description: ECONOMISTS will tell you that one hallmark of a hot economy is an increase in the amount of money homeowners are willing to spend on upgrading, repairing and maintaining their homes.

title: Since When Did I Ask to Help Myself?
description: One of the great paradoxes of our aging service economy is that actual service, with a human face and a helping hand, has disappeared from most American companies. The service that most of us encounter these days is virtual, supplied by voice mail, e-mail, satellite pagers and, of course, the Internet.

description: Here is what the Miami Hurricanes have lots of: quarterback-mauling defenders, speedy receivers, bruising running backs and, as always, confidence. The Canes work hard and are the kind of players that Coach Butch Davis likes.

description: Kimberly Ann Steel and John J. Hagenbuch were married last evening by the Rev. Linda Demorest, a Presbyterian minister, at an outdoor ceremony in Sun Valley, Idaho.

description: GOULD-Alice. 88, on August 25. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Lawrence and Eleanor and mother-in-law of Jane and Kenneth. Loving grandmother of Lance, Eric (and wife, Robin), Andrew, Jeffrey and Laura. Great-grandmother of Ruby and Benjamin. Sister of Rabbi Frank Zimmermann. Lifelong resident of Manhattan Beach, member of Temple Beth-El. Docent at The New York Aquarium and The Brooklyn Museum. Long-time participant in ''My Turn'' program at Kingsborough Community College.

title: 'Youngsters' Reach Broadway Bearing Gifts: Musical Scores
description: IF the 2000-01 musicals season has any unifying theme right now, it is the youthful tilt among those songwriters -- experienced and novice, alike -- who will soon be facing the music on Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, HUGH B.
description: WILLIAMS-Hugh B., 69. August 4, 2000 in Rock Hall, MD. His friendship and brilliance will be deeply missed by his friends, IBM colleagues and classmates (Harvard, '51) and his love and devotion by his wife, Gwyn, seven children, two grandchildren and two sisters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLURMAN, HERMAN
description: CLURMAN-Herman. My Tax Professor at NYU. The person who helped me choose a career, a law school and my first employer. A man of great wisdom and integrity. My biggest honor was when Professor Clurman invited me to join him as an adjunct faculty member. Thank you. My condolences to the family. Alan J. Straus

title: Minor League Ball in Queens: So Far, Everything but Crowds
description: Just before 7 p.m. Friday, George Perez, right-handed pitcher for the Queens Kings, a minor-league baseball team playing in what was, until recently, an exclusively major-league town, strolled into the team's ballpark looking a little forlorn.

The Officers, Trustees and membership of the Brooklyn Bar Association mourn the passing of Sheridan Albert, a distinguished trial attorney, and past president of the Brooklyn Bar Association in 1984-1985. David J. Doyaga, President Avery Eli Okin, Esq., CAE Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERR, ABRAHAM I.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, 11:30 AM. Interment to follow at Salem Fields Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: West Nile Spraying Schedule
description: STATEN ISLAND

title: Chronicling the Homeless, a Photographer Meets Their Fate
description: Salvo Galano used to nail a simple burlap canvas on a wall across from a soup kitchen run by the Church of the Holy Apostles in Chelsea. Then the photographer would wait patiently for the homeless men and women who frequented the place to drift over and pose at his makeshift studio.

title: The Next Wave
description: Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi are going into the twilight of their careers. But at least for one morning, the constant search for America's future ended up on Court 10 during Arthur Ashe Kids Day.

title: Chairman Steps Down At OSI Pharmaceuticals
description: Gary E. Frashier, chairman of OSI Pharmaceuticals in Uniondale (Nasdaq: OSIP), has announced his retirement. He will be replaced by Colin Goddard, president and C.E.O. Mr. Frashier, who also resigned his director's post, had been chief executive from 1990 to 1998, and served as chairman since December 1997. Mr. Goddard was named president in 1997 and chief executive the following year.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Englewood Cliffs Adding CNBC to Corporate Logos
description: A SIGN just off the exit ramp of the Palisades Interstate Parkway leading to this Bergen County community reads, ''The Billion Dollar Mile.'' That's the name given to the stretch of Route 9W that cuts through the borough and that is lined with corporate campuses nestled in the Palisades Cliffs.

title: More Cracks In the Walls Of Valhalla
description: ON the morning of a recent performance of ''Gotterdammerung'' (''Twilight of the Gods''), Wolfgang Wagner, 80 and a grandson of the man who composed the opera, was fighting off a twilight of his own. Mr. Wagner is no god. Small, combative, prolix and not without humor, he sparred with a press corps eager to know more about the star defections and family squabbles that have encroached on his 34-year regime as sole director of the Wagner Festival here.

title: Becoming a Specialty Banker
description: During the 1980's and 1990's, Richard Vague built First USA, where he was a co-founder, from one of the first stand-alone credit-card companies into Visa's largest issuer. But after Bank One bought it in 1997, First USA stumbled against newer and nimbler rivals. Mr. Vague, now chief executive of Juniper Financial, an Internet bank based in Wilmington, Del., left First USA with an important lesson: be a specialist.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEBEL, DEVORA RUTH DENENHOLZ
description: SCHWEBEL-Devora Ruth Denenholz. We mark on the 22nd of August the first year since the sudden passing of Devora Ruth Denenholz Schwebel, beloved wife of Solomon, youngest of the Denenholz Ten who knew her as Dovey : Her sisters and brothers Alma, Amelia, Grace, the late Marshall, Daniel, Richard, Jessica, Reginald, & Victor. She is survived by Solomon, Robert, Paul, and her grandchildren Kate, Laura, Lillian, and Ella. She is irreplaceable, her memory cherished. She lives on in those she loved. AVANTI

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: Benjamin Weiser's article (Aug. 6) was outrageous and frightening: a tale of man's inhumanity to man. Shame on us all.

title: Rebecca Hooper, David Horner
description: Rebecca Jane Hooper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll B. Hooper of Midlothian, Va., was married yesterday to David Bayer Horner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Horner of Washington. The Rev. Dr. O. Benjamin Sparks performed the ceremony at the Second Presbyterian Church in Richmond, Va.

title: Anika Davis, Eliot Pratt
description: Anika Evelyn Davis, an administrator at New York University, and Eliot Forson Pratt, an investment banker, were married last evening in Palo Alto, Calif. James W. Stewart, a retired judge of the Santa Clara County Superior Court in San Jose, Calif., officiated at the First Baptist Church of Palo Alto.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Fairies, Demons and Pigs
description: Sara Rath's album THE COMPLETE PIG: An Entertaining History of Pigs (Voyageur, $29.95) contains enough eccentric pig lore to leave the browser giddy with pleasure. And browsing is in order. While the longer accounts of pigs in history, art and literature are just fine, the reader is constantly delayed by seductive little sidebars, like an entry on singing pigs in the court of Louis XI. (Pigs of assorted sizes and ages were attached to a sort of keyboard; when the keys were pressed, little spikes stabbed the animals, making them vocalize. It seems to have been one of the few things to amuse this 15th-century monarch.) Or instruction on how to say ''oink'' in 19 languages (try ''groin groin'' in French, ''rok-rok'' in Croatian or the unlikely ''buubuu'' in Japanese). Or a list of Italian pig curses, graded by degree of blasphemy (''porca miseria,'' ''pig misery,'' is suitable for use by children). A particularly rich chapter, ''Fairy Pigs, Demon Swine: Folktales, Superstitions and Saints,'' provides a separately boxed story of how St. Anthony Abbot came to have a pig for a pal, thereby qualifying him as the patron of swine and swineherds. The same section also tells us that in some cultures pigs are regarded as such bad news that they cannot even be named -- in some parts of China, the working euphemism is ''long-nosed generals.'' The illustrations, drawn from old posters, drawings and photographs ancient and modern, range from sweetly innocent pink piglets to a terrifyingly fanged wild boar. It is impossible to choose a favorite, but among the species depicted, it is hard to resist the adorably (or horribly) wrinkled Minzhu from China. One supposes that they look as much like long-nosed generals as anything else on God's green earth. Sarah Ferrell

title: Discovering Little Mysteries in the Yard
description: FOR several weeks, there has been a mystery in my garden. It took quite a few days of sleuthing to solve, but I did get the best of it.

title: Reputed Head Of Drug Ring Taken to U.S. After Arrest
description: Wrapping up a huge international anti-drug operation, the United States has brought the reputed leader of an international cocaine smuggling ring to Florida to face federal charges, the United States Customs Service announced today.

title: On the Playing Field, Boys Still Go First
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex and the Village, Much Rawer Than on Cable
description: The popular cable show ''Sex and the City'' was recently filmed in the West Village, but residents and merchants say they already have their own version of the program, and they are not happy about it.

title: Another Consideration When Fans Talk the Talk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Smokey Robinson in Red Bank
description: One of the sweetest, most soulful voices in the American musical canon is that of Smokey Robinson. A crooner, a rocker, he teases and taunts. Bob Dylan, considered by his fans to be the greatest living poet, called Mr. Robinson, ''the greatest living poet.''

title: Finding Comfort
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hispanics Give Attentive Bush Mixed Reviews
description: The scene from the 1998 race for governor hardly suggested a typical Republican tableau: There in Segundo Barrio, one of the oldest and poorest neighborhoods in this isolated border city, Gov. George W. Bush had come to eat Mexican sweetbread and campaign in Spanish accented with a Texas twang.

title: The People's Shah
description: Khomeini

title: In Preserving the Building, Knocking a Hole in the Wall
description: A former tobacco warehouse on Water and Dock Streets has been through a lot in the last hundred years. First, the city sliced off a chunk of the structure to build New Dock Street. Then an owner lopped off three of its five stories. It was struck by lightning, and gutted by the resulting fire. Last fall the landmarked building was almost demolished until preservationists stepped in. Late last month, with stabilization work in progress, neighbors were stunned to discover a 40-foot hole in its waterfront side.

title: Global Calm Prevails, But Is It Deceptive?
description: WHEN central bankers and economists from around the world gathered here two years ago for the annual conference sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, the worldwide economic outlook was bleak.

title: As Mideast Talks of Peace, Soft Voice Urges War
description: As Israel and the Palestinians circle each other in a wary and increasingly fractious quest for a final peace agreement, the spotlight only rarely settles these days on a small, wizened, straggly bearded man in a wheelchair whose antagonism to Israel could one day unsettle or even destroy any deal that establishes a Palestinian state pledged to coexistence with Israel.

title: SUNNYSIDE; Borough's Namesake or Not, a Queen's Image Draws Fire
description: For several years, enemies of a 17th-century queen have delayed the raising of a 35-foot statue of her on the waterfront in Long Island City. But the queen, Catherine of Braganza, who many say is the borough's namesake, has popped up again -- this time in a stained-glass window.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, RUTH
description: ROSENBLATT-Ruth. Age 93, on August 25, 2000. Beloved, loving wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Judith and Carol and George Weinbaum. Cherished Bubby to Eve and Max, Cindy and Mark, Laura and Brett, and Elliot. Great-grandmother to Jonah, Aviva and Hannah. A woman of valor. Please contribute to your favorite charity in Ruth's memory.

title: Louisa Bartle, Austin Clayton
description: Elizabeth Louisa Masterson Bartle, the daughter of Elizabeth Ward Bartle and Judge Harvey Bartle III, both of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Austin Buck Clayton, a son of Dr. Cynthia C. Clayton and Dr. William F. Clayton of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. Marek P. Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa.

title: IN BRIEF: Courts; LAWSUIT OVER JAIL SUICIDE
description: A correction officer did not take preventive action when a 21-year-old county jail inmate said she was suicidal last year, and medical personnel were slow to respond when the inmate followed through on her threat, the woman's family contends in a federal lawsuit. The inmate, Christina Smith, died Oct. 1 after hanging herself with a bed sheet tied to a vent in her cell. The county is also facing a lawsuit from the family of Jerome Stanley, who killed himself at the jail within two days of Ms. Smith's death. Elsa Brenner

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MAX VON SYDOW is so remarkably vulnerable in Bille August's PELLE THE CONQUEROR (1987) that watching him is almost painful at times. It's like seeing an aged fighter, obviously defeated, stagger back for round after round, with a courage dredged up from heaven knows where. Mr. von Sydow plays a destitute Swedish widower who goes to Denmark to make a new life for himself and his little boy, Pelle (Pelle Hvenegaard). But father and son end up as little more than indentured servants on a cruel man's farm, where life is a soap opera of seduction, emotional need, romantic tragedy and revenge - and a little cognac helps everybody get through the day. A drama about dashed hopes and dreams that don't come true, ''Pelle'' won the best foreign language film Oscar - Sunday at 1:30 p.m. on Bravo.

title: Cocaine Thrill Seekers
description: To the Editor:

title: Venus Williams Displays Power at Pilot Pen

She no longer lives in the Crosby Street loft in SoHo that she bought in 1977. She moved to the far West Village in 1996.

Slipping on an orchid-colored leather jean jacket the other day, her eyes grew wide. ''This,'' she murmured, ''is cool, for the Gap.''

description: The Secret Parts of Fortune

description: For Philip R. Berber, what worked in Austin might just work in Africa.

title: New Meijer Complex Opens in Grand Rapids

With the Sept. 15 opening of the two-story addition, the 118-acre botanical garden and sculpture park will be complemented by three indoor sculpture galleries, an 850-seat lecture hall with modern audio-visual equipment, classrooms, a garden shop and a cafe.

title: Jaco's Financial Results Set Record for Quarter
description: Jaco Electronics Inc. of Hauppauge, a distributor of electronic components (Nasdaq: JACO), reported record fourth-quarter results and a revenue increase of 48.8 percent for the year. The quarterly results represent company records for net sales, net income and earnings per share.

description: Tom Hayden is at a new place in this life. And what a life -- radical organizer of Students for a Democratic Society, charter member of the Chicago Seven, freedom rider, grunt in the war on poverty, opponent of the war in Vietnam, Jane Fonda's former husband, unsuccessful candidate for governor of California, mayor of Los Angeles and United States Senator and, for the past 18 years, member in good standing (honest) of the august California Legislature, most recently as a state senator from Los Angeles.

description: Some residents and legislators in the Five Towns have very dated and romanticized views of surburbia [''Is It a House or a Synagogue?'' Aug. 20].

description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: The Polo Look
description: The bucolic Bridgehampton Polo Club is a fashionable promenade on summer Saturdays at the Mercedes-Benz Polo Challenge, where high-goal polo teams compete for attention with higher-goal glamour. Sponsors give parties for 1,200 guests under a tent. This year's fashion statements are one-piece dresses and designer sportswear, accessorized with pedigreed dogs and Fendi bags. Polo fans have the other side of the field.

title: In the Pipeline
