title: Donna McGraw, Jason Weiss
description: Donna Ellen McGraw, the daughter of Eleanor and Edward McGraw of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to Jason Gregory Weiss, the son of Katherine Weiss and Dr. Irwin Weiss of Pacific Palisades, Calif. The Rev. George Herzog, an interfaith minister, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PULSE; Making Grand Exits
description: While hip-hop artists are singing anthems to thongs, and Vogue hawks the tiniest Brazilian bikinis, other mode mavens have been championing the pronounced derriere with an old-fashioned fashion: the bustle. A staple of 19th-century wardrobes, it had been relegated to wedding dresses, but it is now moving from the trousseau to trend-conscious boutiques. At Calypso, 280 Mott Street, ruffled, back-gathered drawstring skirts, starting at $150, have become a signature style. And at Skella, 156 Orchard Street, the designer, Deborah Skell, makes skirts in cashmere, taffeta and corduroy (above) with ties in back that create a bustle effect (prices start at $350). ''I'm batting a thousand with women who say I couldn't wear that because I have such a big behind,'' Ms. Skell said. ''Then they put it on and it makes their waist look small, and their fanny actually disappears.'' At the nightclub Serena, waitresses with willowy waists pair black tank tops and rust-colored skirts with drawstring bustles. ''The rear end is not the feature I want to emphasize, but for a cocktail waitress uniform you can't complain,'' Sophia Martin, a waitress, said. ''It's not like a Hooters' uniform.'' DANA DICKEY

title: Aftreshocks of Sub Disaster
description: The mea culpas began almost as soon as Norwegian divers pried open the hatch of the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk, which went down in 350 feet of water during exercises in the Barents Sea on Aug. 12, killing all 118 people on board. The commanders of the navy offered to resign, as did the defense minister, Igor D. Sergeyev, but Russia's commander in chief, Vladimir V. Putin, declined to accept the resignations.

title: Cover-Up on Auto Defects
description: Japan's automakers, known for quality, hate to show fallibility. But Mitsubishi Motors finally had to admit that since 1977 it had concealed complaints about problems like faulty fuel tanks and brakes. The flaws do not seem to have caused serious accidents, but the company, which recently allied itself with DaimlerChrysler, didn't take them lightly, quickly recalling 88,000 cars and trucks, on top of a recall of 532,000 a month ago. And though Mitsubishi's president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, did not resign, he did bow deeply in apology to the transportation minister. Hubert B. Herring

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, AUDREY
description: HELLER-Audrey. On August 23rd, 2000 at the age of 83. Beloved wife of James Heller, one month before their 60th wedding anniversary. Survived by her devoted daughter, Barbara, and son-in-law, Edgar Freitag, and loving son, Steven, and daughter-in-law, Michelle Heller, and precious grandchildren, Eve Freitag, Harry and Claudia Falk, Elizabeth and Peter Dranoff, Larry and Debbie Freitag, Katherine Heller, Sam Heller, and great-grandchildren, Michael Falk, Andrew Dranoff, Gabrielle and Robert Freitag, and many close and loving sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews, and friends. Services were held.

title: Among the Mooks
description: RJ Smith's article was as interesting as it was disturbing. However, I think the cultural phenomena it highlighted should not be portrayed as ''revolutionary'' when it is really regressive and painfully traditional in its treatment of women. Smith writes, ''There are plenty of women . . . ready to assume their position in the revolution.'' But this ''position'' requires women to be topless, or to be called whores (''hos''). And men, in this so-called revolution, idolize male figures who are characterized as pimps.

title: Drab Films, but Essential Discs
description: KEVIN SMITH is such an engaging personality that I feel guilty finding his movies too sophomoric and one-note. There is a lone exception: his 1994 debut, ''Clerks,'' is a fast, furious, and raucously funny variation on a single joke.

title: WILDLIFE; Caretakers of Wild Animals
description: AT the Somers Animal Hospital here, two veterinary technicians, Jennifer Feeks and Donna Melillo, painstakingly dropped formula from an eye dropper into the gaping mouths of seven newborn opossums. Their mother had been hit by a car.

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday about an actress who is admired in the world of fashion despite appearing to treat it with indifference misspelled her surname. As the article noted, she is Chloe Sevigny, not Segivny.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in companies that support the Linux operating system misstated the loss reported by one such company, VA Linux Systems, in its quarter ended April 28. It was equivalent to 13 cents a share, not 23 cents.

title: The World; Mexicans Wrestle With Their Own Border Issues
description: WHEN Guadalupe Loaeza hears her country's next president urging a more open border between the United States and Mexico, her heart floods with contradictory emotions.

title: Accused Weapons Scientist Is Freed on Bail
description: In December, a federal judge was told that Wen Ho Lee posed such a threat to national security that if he leaked the nuclear weapons secrets he had allegedly taken from the Los Alamos National Laboratory it could tilt the global balance of power. Dr. Lee was held in solitary confinement without bail pending trial.

title: BRIEFING: EDUCATION; TEST SCORES
description: Standardized test scores for New Jersey's public school fourth and eighth graders were released last week, but the Department of Education delayed releasing the fourth-grade language arts literacy scores because of concerns about the writing section of the test. In several writing questions, scores were so low that the Department will review the scores and the grading. The department plans to release the scores, with modifications if necessary, sometime in September. The fourth-grade science scores did not change significantly from the previous year's, and the math scores improved a bit. The state's eighth graders scored well in science and language arts, with more than 80 percent scoring proficient or advanced proficient. Deborah Nussbaum

title: Love's Labors Won
description: Labor Day, and the thoughts of laborers and the fruits of their labors, is tailor-made for the grape, and for wine producers. Once a year, a swig of enlightened chauvinism (emphasisis on ''vin'') is in order. This brings us to the Wolffer Estate '99 dessert chardonnay.

title: Fire at Baptist Church Is Called Suspicious
description: A Baptist church in Morningside Heights was damaged yesterday in a suspicious fire, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUKIND, MORTY
description: RAUKIND-Morty. A man of many virtues and triumphs. Born in Dallas Texas, May 29th, 1934. It was my joy to have been his friend and lover for over 30 years. Morty will be missed by all who knew him, family, friends and business associates. Morty was a special man with great compassion and forthright integrity. Loving father to Lou and Leslye, grandfather to Matthew and Jordyn. Loving son to Nell and brother to Barbara and Will. Loving uncle.

title: A School Where Girls Learn the Value of Sports
description: THE math is simple and impressive.

title: Wallace Wins At Bristol, Again
description: There's a reason Rusty Wallace considers Bristol Motor Speedway in Bristol, Tenn., his favorite track. No one can beat him there.

title: Taking the Sweet Smell of Success To a New Level of Literalness
description: WHAT does the lobby of your building smell of? Disinfectant? Wet dog? If you are one of the 11 buyers of the 13 multimillion-dollar apartments in the Loft SoHo, opening at 30 Crosby Street in the fall, expect ylang-ylang and rose oil.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Mozart's Letters, Mozart's Life

title: Statement Shows Conservative List Of Investments
description: Joseph I. Lieberman's personal financial statement -- which includes the investments of his wife, Hadassah -- shows a conservative list of investments, with the bulk of his net worth coming from mutual funds, a blind trust and real estate.

title: The Rural Life; The Sting
description: I was stung by a honeybee on the back of the head while weeding in the garden one recent afternoon. There was nothing inherently surprising about being stung since upward of 100,000 bees live about 30 feet from where I was working. I could hear the droning of their hives and smell the sweet, waxy scent that emanates from a healthy colony. The air high above my head was thick with bee traffic vectoring downward out of the east at a velocity that is not easily credible unless you have actually seen it. Still, I resented being stung. ''After all I've done for you,'' was my first thought, a sign that I have not quite matured into my role as a beekeeper. But it was not even the sting that I resented. It was the slap of an angry bee -- a suicidal bee -- against my scalp and the knowledge that she had decided at a distance to poison me so quickly that I could not even brush her away first.

title: Suzanne Dick, Seth Leifer
description: Suzanne Kerri Dick, the daughter of Barbara and Stephen Dick of Marlboro, N.J., is to be married today to Seth Craig Leifer, the son of Madge Weitz and the stepson of Emanuel Weitz of Hallandale, Fla. Rabbi Bernhard Rosenberg will perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

title: Filmmaker's Muse: Classic Children's Books
description: WHEN Morton Schindel began his career, he had no strategies for creating an international company from the one-man shop that was the beginning of Weston Woods, a children's video and film company. But there were clues in his past that pointed to his ability to live on a creative and intuitive edge.

title: Feeling Powerless In a World Of Greater Choice; Consumers Grow More Anxious As They Are Cut Loose In Electricity's New Free Market
description: Over the last 20 years, a dogma has taken root in America that says people would be happier and better off if they were all continually shopping for the best deals. Consumers, according to this theory, should be empowered and freed from the old business monopolies and the dictates of fussy bureaucrats.

title: Hanging On for Dear Life Beyond 100 M.P.H.
description: It is difficult to describe the feeling of disorder, but it's something like taking the wheel of a high-performance automobile barreling down the freeway at speeds well beyond the legal limit. The car is weaving through traffic, but the responsibility for maintaining control is being shared with the passenger beside you, who has sole command of the accelerator.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLUKIES, MARTHA (NEE RAAB)
description: CLUKIES-Martha (nee Raab). 27 August 1909-6 April 2000 Widow of C. E. Robert Clukies (Chemical Bank). Sadly missed by daughter Joan Puckett and Family (Victoria BC Canada)

title: Political Briefing; Oregon Vote Outcome Like a Chinese Puzzle
description: Oregon's First Congressional District, covering the state's northwest corner and much of Portland, leans Democratic. But Republicans don't automatically cede the seat. The incumbent, Representative David Wu, a moderate freshman Democrat and the lone Chinese-American in the House, beat his Republican opponent in 1998 by only three percentage points.

title: Madame Prime Minister
description: To the Editor:

title: Wet Summer May Enrich Autumn's Palette
description: State tourism officials and arborists are predicting a spectacular fall foliage season across the Northeast this year, thanks to the same lower temperatures and persistent rainfall that made summer a washout for beachgoers.

title: Reclimbing the Real Estate Charts
description: HIS hair is thinner, though still tinted red, and his posture is slightly bent, but certainly not bowed. Harold Farb, the flamboyant Houston apartment developer who gained national attention for his excesses before he fell hard in the 1980's, is back.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-27-00: Salient Facts: Specialty Dorms; Close Quarters
description: YOU ARE WHERE YOU LIVE

title: In Salzburg, a Benevolent Elder
description: PIERRE BOULEZ'S ''Structures,'' Book 2, for two pianos is music of uncompromising complexity. In this landmark exploration of rigorous serial techniques, composed over several years beginning in 1956, the pianos go at each other nonstop, exchanging volatile volleys of notes with a ferocity that seems almost free-form. At the time of its premiere, in 1961, the work galvanized composers in the avant-garde and in academic circles. Few people could have thought that it would ever reach outside to mainstream audiences. Certainly not audiences at the Salzburg Festival, then the most tradition-bound of all the prestigious international music festivals.

title: Another Look
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Commercial Property column on Aug. 13, about Long Island City, misspelled the surname of an executive who commented on the market. He is Michael A. Burak, not Barak.

title: The Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Joan Jett; Hoop Fan's Jumpin' Anthem Is 'Give Me Liberty, or Else'
description: AT 7 p.m. on Thursday, Joan Jett stood outside the 31st Street V.I.P. entrance to Madison Square Garden, looking fierce and impatient. ''Let's go!'' she said, clapping, glancing at her longtime manager and musical collaborator, Kenny Laguna. ''The girls are already warming up!''

title: Buddhists Seek Asylum for Leader in India
description: Representatives of a major Buddhist order have petitioned the Indian government to grant asylum and freedom of movement to their 15-year-old leader, the Karmapa, who remains under virtual house arrest at a monastery in northern India eight months after fleeing Tibet.

title: Liberty Plays The Foil Again As Comets Win Fourth Crown
description: They traded clutch shots and dramatic moments into overtime today in a classic championship game. In the end, a sign in the raucous and adoring crowd at the Compaq Center summed up the emotions around professional sports' latest dynasty: ''Coop! Is that your final answer?''

title: A Hopi Guide
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Under the Arizona Sun'' (April 23) mentioned Will Tsosie, a Navajo who runs cultural tours in the Canyon de Chelly area. His counterpart on the Hopi reservation is Gary Tso, who can be reached at (520) 734-2567 or Left-Handed Hunter Tour Company, Post Office Box 434, Second Mesa, Ariz. 86043.

title: Tomato Vigil
description: Inspect tomato plants closely for green tomato hornworms. These large caterpillars often go unnoticed until a plant is suddenly stripped of leaves. The best control is daily inspection and handpicking. Leave caterpillars that have puffy ricelike grains on their backs: these are the cocoons of beneficial wasps that parasitize hornworms.

title: Only in, and From, New York
description: Labor Day, rewarding the fruits of labor and laborers, is tailor-made for the grape and for wine producers. Once a year, a swig of chauvinism (emphasizing the syllable ''vin'') is in order. This brings us to Vintage New York, a spiffy wine shop that opened in July.

title: Troubled Man Kills 3 and Then Himself
description: For two years, Mark Cote, a 29-year-old man from Waterbury, Conn., had been seething at a firefighter who he believed had broken up his marriage. The man taunted Mr. Cote continually and accused him of harassment, said Mr. Cote's mother, Rachel Cote.

title: Alone At the Top
description: Sanford I. Weill had just completed his latest coup -- the one that vaulted him into the clear, free of any rivals or pretenders to the crown -- and he was taking the stage at Carnegie Hall, where a single microphone descended from the floodlights. It was the annual shareholders' meeting of Citigroup, which had just earned more than any company had ever earned in a single quarter, and it was Weill's show. He had built the company, ledger by ledger, through a series of deals as remarkable as any in Wall Street history. And finally, it was all his. Even the stage and the velvet-cushioned seats, which, as a trustee and chairman of Carnegie Hall, Weill had restored, were, in a manner of speaking, his.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: I see a recurring pattern in which the criminal justice system is seemingly more motivated to make any conviction rather than the correct one. From judges to district attorneys to prison psychiatrists, there is a disturbing resistance by those in charge to review and reconsider the facts of a case whose circumstances are less than clear.

title: Even in Hawaii, Talk Turns to the Failed Ewing Deal
description: Vin Baker and Allan Houston checked into their hotel rooms tonight, hours before the United States Olympic basketball team met for its first practice in paradise.

title: A Fashion Field Day
description: On these shores, soccer is often associated with minivans and sports bras. But to the rest of the world the game is better known for its sex-symbol superstars with over-the-top style. Now, the look seen in niche magazines like Soccer World is spreading to the mainstream. Spiky gelled hair, splashy team jerseys and sneakers with king-size tongues are being paraded by teens whose parents emigrated from serious soccer countries, as well as by boy bands like 'N Sync, Take 5 and Youngstown, a pop band that adopted soccer style while touring in Europe last year. ''Club kids and wannabe rappers are starting to buy the jerseys because they're tight-fitting, shiny, and the material absorbs sweat,'' said Paul Castro, 17, who was born in Ecuador and works at Shoot 'N Score, a soccer specialty store in Jersey City, which sells hard-to-come-by foreign brands like Kappa and Lotto. Meanwhile, Puma, Dolce & Gabbana and Emporio Armani are introducing soccer-inspired sneakers this fall, with bright colors and oversize tongues. Adidas's classic Sambas are being snapped up by fashion stylists and rock stars, including Dave Grohl, lead singer of Foo Fighters. ''Teens in America are embracing their different ethnic backgrounds,'' said Sammy Lopez, 23, a singer with Youngstown, whose parents were born in Puerto Rico. ''The soccer look is one way of saying, 'I'm proud of where I came from.' '' JULIA CHAPLIN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 'Goodbye' Essay Evokes Memories of Farewells
description: To the Editor:

title: Producing DVD's With Lavish Extras
description: ON a sunny afternoon in the large library of a large house in Bel Air, the director Richard Donner, the writer Tom Mankiewicz and a group of production people from Warner Brothers are watching Mr. Donner's ''Superman'' on a 50-inch television screen. It is doomsday on the planet Krypton and the patriarch Jor-El, played by Marlon Brando, regards his infant son, whom he is about to send to Earth in an escape pod. ''The kid's diapers are worth a fortune,'' Mr. Donner says. ''Brando's dialogue is on them.''

title: As a Senator, Lieberman Is Proudly Pro-Business
description: Joseph I. Lieberman has introduced himself to the American people this month on a decidedly populist note, lashing out against oil companies, assailing industrial polluters and calling for greater government spending on health care.

title: On the Water (and Save Room for Dessert)
description: WHAT a difference two weeks can make in a restaurant's development, as we discovered at Beacon Stamford, a new restaurant on the water in Stamford. Our first visit was not encouraging. Exhausting waits between courses, dishes that didn't match menu descriptions, a tray of water glasses spilled over one guest, and other missteps led us to conclude that this new venture wasn't ready for prime time.

title: Auto Train Hoping To Quicken Delivery
description: The Amtrak Auto Train, which carries automobiles and passengers between the Washington area and the Orlando area, has opened a new station at its northern terminal, in Lorton, Va. Its platform is now long enough to accommodate the entire train rather than half, which was the case previously, and is expected to reduce the time needed by Auto Train staff to unload vehicles. New waiting areas with 450 seats, food service and bigger restrooms are also part of the building.

title: Standard & Poor's 500 Now Includes Keyspan
description: The Standard and Poor's 500 index now includes the KeySpan Corporation (NYSE: KSE) in its natural gas industry group.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL PREVIEW 2000
description: Off the Beaten Path

title: U.S. Regards Egypt as Key To Peace Deal In the Mideast
description: After accusing Egypt of undermining the Camp David summit meeting, the Clinton administration is now focusing on the Egyptian leader, Hosni Mubarak, as a key to finding a solution in the Middle East, particularly on the future status of Jerusalem.

title: Sports of The Times; The Flying Dutchmen Fit Their Nickname
description: JOE GARDI calls his Hofstra University football team the Road Warriors, meaning, they will go just about anywhere for a game.

title: Full Fathom Five
description: GRAVEYARD OF

title: A Lesson in Life, A Donation to a Zoo
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a summer program for high school chemistry students misstated the name of the sponsoring company. It is Ciba Specialty Chemicals, not Ciba-Geigy Specialty Chemicals.

title: South(ern) Orange
description: BEFORE she opened Niecy's, Denise Hampton says, she sat outside the storefront for two days and counted the people going by on Valley Street. It didn't take her long to conclude that the area could support the restaurant she had in mind, a place that would serve the kind of food she remembered from girlhood in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Streetscapes/The Terminal Stores, From 27th to 28th St. and 11th Ave. to the Hudson River; A Full-Block 1891 Fortress With a Medieval Look
description: COLEMAN BURKE has been watching closely as new office tenants pay increasingly higher rents in the area around his full-block 19th-century Terminal Stores complex on the increasingly trendy far West Side of Manhattan. But Mr. Burke seems largely content to continue the ministorage operation he runs in his fortresslike 1891 warehouses on the block between 27th and 28th Street, from 11th Avenue to the Hudson River.

title: Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Argue Over Tax Cuts
description: The debate over the tax cut plans of Representative Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton continued today, with Mrs. Clinton calling Mr. Lazio's proposal ''fiscally irresponsible'' and saying that it was likely to increase the national debt.

title: More Bad News for a Fattening America
description: The incidence of diabetes increased sharply in the United States from 1990 to 1998, a consequence of rising levels of obesity. The trend is ominous: diabetes is already a major cause of blindness, kidney failure and leg amputations, and it greatly increases the risk of heart disease and stroke, the leading causes of death in the United States.

title: God, Caesar and Zoning
description: WITH unanimity and astonishing speed -- 16 minutes elapsed from introduction to passage in the House of Representatives -- Congress has acted to exempt religious institutions from land-use rules that excessively burden religious exercise.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Jay Chiat is best known as a founder of Chiat/Day, the advertising agency that brought you the Energizer Bunny and the Apple ''1984'' commercial. He also commissioned Frank Gehry to design the agency's Santa Monica headquarters, shown here, with its Claes Oldenburg binoculars. Chiat sold the agency six years ago and is now the chairman of Screaming Media, a company that distributes custom content to Web sites.

title: Piazza Stands Tall, But Arizona Strikes For 4 Runs in 10th
description: Mike Piazza got barreled over at the plate so forcefully in the fourth inning last night that he stayed in the dirt for a few extra seconds, like a quarterback who had been leveled by Warren Sapp. When Piazza finally managed to stand up, he squinted, he grimaced and he shook his head back and forth, trying to bring himself back to life.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 27, 2000
description: Weeks

title: Indonesians Differ on Penalties for the Past
description: For Pramoedya Ananta Toer, forgiveness is cowardice. Principle is absolute. The only way to deal with the crimes of the past is to look them in the face, seize the culprits and punish them.

title: When the Life-and-Death Drama Is Real
description: DR. RICK MONTZ sits by the young woman's bedside, his voice gentle as he talks about what lies ahead. ''The findings aren't very good,'' he tells her.

title: Where Oregon Kicks Up Its Heels
description: AFTER singing the national anthem at the opening ceremony of the Pendleton Round-Up in northeastern Oregon last September, all the men in the grandstands returned their cowboy hats to their heads and everybody settled back down into their seats. The rodeo princesses were introduced over the loudspeaker, and a small herd of quarter horses streaked out from a far corner, each in full gallop and bearing a member of the royal court.

title: An Interesting Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: So, These Two Soccer Moms Walk Into a Bar...
description: I TEACH a course in comedy at New York University, so you wouldn't think this would come as a surprise.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As long as the school isn't involved, the students and the fans can get up and say whatever they want. We are not going to let them take God any further away from our country.''

title: County Association Schedules Reception
description: The Westchester County Association will hold its annual government reception Sept. 12 from 5 to 7 p.m. at the MBIA corporate headquarters at 113 King Street in Armonk.

title: Ideas & Trends; Hey, What if Contestants Give Each Other Shocks?
description: LONG before anyone ever heard of reality television, or its most recent efflorescence, ''Survivor,'' a group of scientists began putting ordinary people into unusual situations and observing how they behaved.

title: INSURANCE COMPANY PURCHASE
description: The First Union Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank, agreed yesterday to buy closely held Tribus Companies for an undisclosed price to offer more insurance products to businesses in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania. Tribus, based in Wayne, sells property and casualty insurance, life insurance, employee benefits plans and pension services. First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., will combine Tribus with its Mid-Atlantic Agency in a new unit, Tribus First Union Insurance Services.

title: Marcella Anderlini, Chris Churchill
description: Marcella Elizabeth Anderlini, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Anderlini of Kentfield, Calif., was married yesterday to John Christopher Churchill, a son of Mary C. Churchill of New York and John P. Churchill of Hampton, N.J. P. Terry Anderlini, a cousin of the bride who was appointed a state civil marriage celebrant for the day, officiated at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONNER, GEORGE R., JR.
description: BONNER-George R., Jr. Writer. Of New York City on August 23, 2000. Beloved brother of John R. Bonner, Sr. of Clearwater, FL and Francis W. Bonner, Sr. of Columbus, GA. Dear uncle to his nieces and nephews. Donations in Mr. Bonner's name can be made out to Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, 103 East 77 Street, NYC 10021. Memorial services will be announced at a later date.

title: Melissa McCaffery, Jonathan Abraham
description: Melissa Berry McCaffery, the daughter of Mary Lynn Putney of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Paul McCaffery of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan David Abraham, a son of Judith and Richard Abraham of Canton, Conn. Joaquin F. Alemany, a village justice of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Lincoln the Devil
description: FORCED INTO GLORY

title: Giants Find Many Positives After an 0-4 Preseason
description: The big-name draft choice, running back Ron Dayne, finally looked deserving of a first-round pick. The little-known third-round choice, Ron Dixon, looked like a steal.

title: A Public Library in the Palm of Your Hand
description: PEOPLE may scoff at the notion of curling up in a computer chair with with John Grisham's latest thriller on their screen. But a good novel aside, e-books may be the best thing for doing research since the Dewey Decimal System.

title: Summer Pleasures
description: Summer pleasures is the theme of an exhibition organized by the Schoolhouse Gallery in Croton Falls, which has been installed in the conference and meeting rooms of the Southampton Inn on Long Island.

title: Lives; Home Care
In the Region/Long Island; Renters to Owners: Low-Income Program in Debut
description: EVER since she and her teenage son, John O'Keefe, moved into a two-bedroom ranch on Defense Hill Road here four years ago as a tenant of the Community Development Corporation of Long Island, Carol McGrann has longed to own her home.

title: Finding Art in Random Images Is as Old as Art Itself
description: WHEN Jackson Pollock first lifted his brush from the canvas and allowed paint to drip in tangled skeins across the surface, or Jean Arp and Marcel Duchamp began to experiment with chance procedures, they sought in the accidental and unpredictable the means to shatter the stale conventions of art making. So, too, Surrealists like Andre Masson and Joan Miro, who allowed their pens to wander over the page in the belief that they would discover in those doodles the ghosts of their own repressed imaginations. What these artists -- all currently featured at the Museum of Modern Art as part of the show ''Making Choices'' -- hoped to attain was freedom, from the past, from academic formulas, and the random act was their declaration of independence.

title: Huntington Needs Housing For Low-Income Families
description: What is missing from the debate about a proposed senior-housing development in Melville [''Town Sees Pressure by Suffolk on Houses,'' Aug. 20] is the unquestionable need for homes for low-income families.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Guide column on Aug. 13 about an exhibition celebrating the 70th anniversary of the Westport Country Playhouse misstated the site. It is the Westport Historical Society, not the Westport Country Playhouse.

title: The Proper Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Guillermo C. Sanchez, 75, Internist and Medical Historian
description: Dr. Guillermo C. Sanchez, an internist and medical historian associated with Massachusetts General Hospital for five decades, died on Aug. 17 at his home in West Newton, Mass. He was 75.

title: Hammer and Nails: The Advanced Course
description: HAMMERING nails is such an elementary task that it would seem that no explanation is needed. Yet professional carpenters and shop instructors say that many do-it-yourselfers don't know how to drive nails efficiently. The most common mistake is in holding the hammer too close to the head.

title: In Brewster, Turning a Meal Into a Journey
description: INCREASINGLY, Indian restaurants in the Hudson Valley have been enhancing their menus with commentary on the provenance of some of their offerings. As these kitchens provide dishes from many regions, a bit of history or geography can turn a meal into a journey. At Jaipore, we traveled by fork through a dozen areas, from the Hindu Kush and the Himalayas to Cape Comorin.

title: My Name Is Not Robert
description: Mistakes can happen, of course, but in a nation that gives high priority to human dignity and justice, I would think that an innocent person like Kerry Sanders ought to receive full compensation for his unjust suffering, without quibble or delay. What seems to be happening, however, is that he is facing a chorus of denials, years of legal rigmarole and perhaps, in the end, no adequate payment or accountability. We shall see what happens.

title: BRIEFING: JUSTICE; LIFE WITHOUT PAROLE
description: A prisoner convicted of murder who avoids execution will face life in prison without parole under legislation signed by president of the State Senate, Donald DiFrancesco, who was acting as governor last week. The law was inspired by the case of Thomas Trantino, convicted of murdering two Lodi police officers in 1963. He was sentenced to death, but the United States Supreme Court declared the death penalty unconstitutional. Mr. Trantino, 62, is immune to the legislation and remains eligible for parole. Natania Blumenkehl

title: BackTalk; A Short Career, a Lifetime Commitment
description: Julia called to say goodbye, sounding rushed. She was planning her funeral, the music, the clothes she wanted to be laid out in, the makeup. She asked Andrea Jaeger to send a photograph of her hand prints in a cement block set along a walkway at the Silver Lining Ranch here.

title: All Together Now: The Hills Are Still Alive . . .
description: IN Alain Berliner's forgettable ''Passion of Mind,'' a man spies an incriminating cassette on the stereo of his new girlfriend and forces her to confess: sometimes when the dog bites or the bee stings, she pops in ''The Sound of Music'' and sings along to ''My Favorite Things.''

title: A Stay of Execution For the State's Black Bears
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REPETTI, PETER J.
description: REPETTI-Peter J. The partners and associates of Fulbright & Jaworski LLP are deeply saddened by the passing of Peter J. Repetti, our esteemed former partner, colleague and friend, whose advise and counsel were often sought, willingly given and greatly appreciated. We are most thankful for the fact that his entire legal career was spent with our firm and its predecessor, Reavis & McGrath. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Joan, and his children, Grace, Joan, Charles and Christine and his family.

title: At the Office, My Cluttered Desk Is My Castle
description: If Robert Frost were alive in this age of information, he might be prompted to write, ''Something there is that doesn't love a desk, that sends the worker's hand to clutter it.'' For all the effort that goes into the design of modern office space and furnishings, something deep in human nature seems to drive many people to bury themselves and their desks under all manner of paperwork, books, magazines, mementos and whatnot. To onlookers, the effect is one of chaos, but the mass of mess may sometimes be a mine of inspiration.

title: Bit Players No More: Coral Bells With Flash
description: MANY a gardener grows coral bells, but only a few do so for the sake of their flowers.

title: Abigail Rezneck, Miles Ehrlich
description: Abigail Rebecca Rezneck, the daughter of Beverly Rezneck and Daniel A. Rezneck of Washington, is to be married today to Miles Frederick Ehrlich, a son of Janet L. Ehrlich and Dr. Morton E. Ehrlich of Sacramento. Rabbi David A. Kaye will officiate at the Wye River Conference Center in Queenstown, Md.

title: Rachel Rothman, Adam Cohen
description: Arlene Rachel Rothman, a daughter of Tovah and Robert P. Rothman of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married last night to Adam Jacob Cohen, the son of Carol and Victor A. Cohen of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Sheldon Ezring performed the ceremony at the Temple Society of Concord in Syracuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, SHIRLEY
description: SHULMAN-Shirley. Died at home in New York City, August 20, 2000. The devoted wife of Irving J. Shulman, who is the founder of Daffy's, Inc., the loving mother to, Marcia, Dr. Robert, and Michael, and cherished grandmother of eight, Joshua, Gabriel, Damon, Evan, Gabriel, Zoe, Davy, and Hannah. Born in Toronto, Canada, she studied at the Toronto Conservatory of Music and was an Oakwood Collegiate Pianist. Shirley was honored by, and performed for Sir Ernest McMillian and studied with Viggo Kihl and Grace Gilles. She loved music, the arts, languages and humor, supporting the Carnegie Hall Foundation and the Foundation for the Blind, but her greatest source of pride were her three children. Her philosophy can best be expressed by Oscar Wilde's observation, ''Life is too important to be taken seriously.'' Donations to the Jacob Perlow Hospice 1st Avenue at 16th Street, New York, New York 10003, (212) 420-2517, would be appreciated.

title: Fast-Forwarding Those Campus Visits
description: AS they approach their freshman year of college, our soon-to-be-unaffordable children give us a taste of expenses to come when we take them to visit the schools that have caught their eye. Some of them are in places that might as well be Timbuktu.

title: Life Begins When She Says It Does
description: I LOVED YOU ALL By Paula Sharp. 370 pp. New York: Hyperion. $23.95.

He devoted himself to the pastoral and social needs of all members of the communities where he served and in a special way to the Spanish-speaking communities. Wake at Montera Funeral Home, 1848 Westchester Ave., Bronx, on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Blessed Sacrament Church on Monday, 2-5 PM. Mass of the Holy Eucharist on Monday, at 7:30 PM. Funeral at Blessed Sacrament Church on Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Blessed Sacrament Parish.

description: A picture in the Residential Sales report last Sunday, with the entry for 11 Waverly place in Aberdeen, N.J., was published in error. It was a duplicate of the one that appeared, correctly, with the listing for 49 Boulder Ridge in Greenburgh, N.Y.

description: The Moose That Roared

title: 'Extinct Humans'
description: To the Editor:

title: Is It Back to School, Or to the Loan Officer?
description: How much you think you will spend on back-to-school shopping may be far different from the reality, a new study suggests.

title: Englewood: A Case Study and a Work in Progress
description: For two decades, officials in Englewood, N.J., have been working to revive the western flank of Palisade Avenue, the city's main commercial street. Their painstaking efforts are often cited as a case study in the challenge of suburban redevelopment.

title: Good Times Roll Along At Hotels And Casinos
description: THE great advantage of a hotel,'' George Bernard Shaw once observed, ''is that it's a refuge from home life.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: COLONEL CODY

title: The Ballad of Little Jimmy Scott
description: There are various ways to meet celebrities in this media age, many of them involving publicists looking at their watches and saying that the Musician or the Actor has been unavoidably delayed. So it is a little surprising to be greeted promptly at the airport in Cleveland (Cleveland itself being a departure from standard practice) by the slight, smiling figure of the jazz singer Jimmy Scott. He is holding up a cardboard sign with my last name inked in as if he is an especially cheerful limo driver charged with taking me to see somebody really important. ''Hey, baby,'' he greets me, ''how was the trip?''

title: Yes, Here Is a Restaurant With No Pasta
description: THE new Laguna Grille in Woodbury broke from the gate at a gallop. To enjoy the almost instant popularity it has achieved, just about everything has to be right from Day 1. Its tasty food, modest prices, snappy service and nifty surroundings have resulted in 20- to 30-minute waits for tables, even on normally slow weekdays. (Weekends are a hectic scene.)

title: A PRISON FOR MAURICE RIVER
description: Officials in Maurice River, a rural community on the Delaware Bay, agreed to accept a prison that would house 300 ''sexually violent predators.'' Woodbridge officials had been fighting the plans to build the facility there. Maurice River, already home to two medium-security prisons, will receive $825,000 from the state when the facility opens, and $200,000 a year while it is being built. Andrew Jacobs

title: Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Again Debate Their Dueling Tax Cuts
description: The debate over the tax cut plans of Representative Rick A Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton continued today, with Mrs. Clinton calling Mr. Lazio's proposal ''fiscally irresponsible'' and saying that it was likely to increase the national debt.

title: A Nice Possibility For a Very Long Stroll
description: The opening of the American Discovery Trail, the United States' first coast-to-coast, nonmotorized trail, will be celebrated on Saturday in San Francisco, at Crissy Field in the Presidio. The six-hour event will begin at 11 a.m., with an opening ceremony at 1 p.m. The event will include booths with trail information and the latest outdoor gear, and appearances by people who have navigated all or part of the trail.

title: The Best, and the Worst, of Times
description: IT stood, and how mightily it stood, for the best of times (the New York World's Fair, 1939/40) right after the worst of times (the Depression, still unfathomably called the Great Depression). Or so some people, mostly wide-eyed children, thought, not knowing that the worst of times were yet to come. In the second year of the Fair, a bomb went off at the British Empire Exhibition. Two police officers were killed. Then the Japanese Pavilion was set afire. The arsonists remembered Pearl Harbor.

title: The Nation: Tune In, Turn Out, Turn Off; The Mystery of Nonvoters and Whether They Matter
description: WHAT if they gave an election and everyone came?

title: The Class War Gore Could Lose
description: If it is an economic class war, Mr. Gore has a chance of victory. There is a widespread perception of the growing disparity in wealth, and no one disputes that the tax cut Mr. Bush proposes would greatly benefit the very rich. But a more immediate question is how to keep the good times rolling, and Mr. Bush would claim that the credit for them lies elsewhere than with the Clinton-Gore administration, and that he is the true champion of working families.

title: Nasdaq Can't Soar Until the New-Share Flood Abates
description: THE law of supply and demand is a powerful thing. And right now that power may be why the Nasdaq composite index seems stuck in a maddening sideways groove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, MAURICE
description: SILVERSTEIN-Maurice. Died on August 22, 2000, at the age of 99. Loving brother, dear uncle, great uncle and devoted teacher. Services private.

title: The In-Season Finds Are Producing Nicely
description: Several days after the All-Star Game break, members of the Yankees' brain trust, led by George Steinbrenner, sat around the table in the owner's suite at Yankee Stadium and talked about possible players to pursue to bolster the team's sagging offense. They had a list of 14 players, and a visitor strongly recommended they seek one who was not high on the list.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Mahopac and Mahopac Falls; Former Resort Is Still Taking Life Easy
description: THE first thing newcomers should know about Mahopac and Mahopac Falls, two lake-studded hamlets in the town of Carmel in Putnam County, is how to pronounce their names. The most popular pronunciation of Mahopac rejects the word's Algonquin roots in favor of MAY-o-pac. But the natives beg to differ.

title: Making Noise a Legal Issue Would Skirt Confrontations
description: To the Editor:

title: Unforeseen Side Effects Ruined One Blockbuster
description: PFIZER'S marketers were turning an antibiotic called Trovan into a blockbuster when misfortune struck last year.

title: Woods Ignores the Pain And Pushes His Lead to 9
description: An insect stung Tiger Woods today, but the final two holes bit Phil Mickelson.

title: Style; Barn Again
description: If the boxy, cedar-sided forms of Jay Chiat and Edwina von Gal's weekend house in eastern Long Island evoke the austere simplicity of an old barn, that's because the house is a barn -- at heart, anyway. Although the house is new, its main living space, which is decorated with simple, elegant furniture and art that is anything but rustic, is defined by the rugged posts and beams of an 18th-century barn.

title: When Alzheimer's Strikes Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Among the Mooks
description: The popularity of rap, rap-metal, wrestling and pornography evidence a growing anger and cynicism among the young and not-so-young of working- and middle-class America. But why stop there? What about Letterman, Seinfeld, ''Sex and the City'' and any number of upscale advertising campaigns that evidence a growing hostility closer to home?

title: Still Grasping For Nijinsky's Elusive Legacy
description: JUST over 50 years after his death in London, events around the world are reaffirming the apparently boundless fascination with the dancer and choreographer Vaslav Nijinsky, whose brief career ended at 29 because of the mental illness that gripped him the rest of his 61 years.

title: The World: Into Africa; The U.S. Keeps Looking for a Few Good Men
description: ON his first trip to Africa two years ago, President Clinton dreamed out loud that his journey would be remembered in a hundred years as ''the beginning of a new African renaissance.'' The president singled out four African heads of state whose free-market savvy would help revive the world's poorest continent.

title: Along the Rhine and the Mosel, Flavor and Flair
description: WHEN agricultural lands were parceled out centuries ago along the Rhine and Mosel Rivers in what is now southwestern Germany, grapes for making wine were clearly not a priority. The choicest, easy-to-farm flatlands were planted with crops like cabbage and beets. Grapes were relegated to steep hillsides, some inclining as much as 70 degrees, land that would be insane to try to farm. Yet farmers, mostly monks, persevered, and one of the world's great winemaking regions was born.

title: Video Highlights Church's Fight Against Poverty
description: The video is called ''Operation Meet Your Neighbor.'' The neighbors in this case are three young mothers and an older woman trying with varying degrees of success to get off welfare and start working.

title: Without Licking
description: To the Editor: Susan Sheehan's article ''A Taste for Frequent-Flier Miles'' (Aug. 6) was wonderfully insightful. While the headline on the article noted, ''Unlike green-stamp collecting, there's no glue to lick in earning free air trips,'' these days that's only partially true. You can accumulate frequent-flier miles with S & H greenpoints -- the digital reinvention of S & H Green Stamps -- by going to www.greenpoints.com.

title: Wages of Sin
description: An Obedient Father

title: Early Art Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Policy Loophole Revealed in an Appeal
description: The soap opera-like saga of the Miami Dolphins' J. J. Johnson, who will most likely start at running back, finally ended late last week.

title: Retaining Devotion to a Saint and Her Private Chapel
description: Private Roman Catholic chapels used to be common in this country before World War II, but today there are few left. One of them is in a small yellow building on Fifth Street in Hoboken. The chapel belongs to the Santa Febronia Catholic Society, an organization founded in 1922 by immigrants from the Sicilian town of Patti. Twice a year a priest will go there to say Mass. The chapel has a little loft with an organ, pews, a beautiful altar and statues made in Italy, among them, St. Febronia, St. Anthony and the Madonna of Tindari, one of the rare icons known as black Madonnas whose image can be traced to antiquity. Armando Torre, 72, is the caretaker of the chapel and member of the Santa Febronia Society. He spoke about the society and its chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZBERG, JACK
description: SCHWARTZBERG-Jack. An advocate for liquor salesmen and distillery workers, died August 24, 2000 at the Hallendale Rehabilitation Center. He was 90. A labor leader and champion of workers' rights, Mr. Schwartzberg served 25 years as Vice President of the International Distillery Wine and Allied Workers' Union. He was also a member of the Executive Board of Local 2 of the Liquor Salesmen's Union, where he sponsored incentives to help distillery workers & salesmen. Born in a farmhouse in Manchester, CT. of immigrant parents from what was then Palestine, Jack spent the early part of his life with five brothers and two sisters, attending a one room schoolhouse, and raising prize winning grapes and dairy cattle. In 1929, he left the family farm to move to New York, where he worked as a welder and master sheet metal craftsman. In the years prior to WWII, while working with his hands during the day, Jack donated his evenings teaching mechanical drafting at New York's Mechanics Institute. During the War, he mobilized and ran Brooklyn's Hercules Sheet Metal Factory, which produced most of the first aid kits and cooking utencils supplied to U.S. servicemen in the field. He is survived by son Paul J. Sutton of Manhattan, Neil Schwartzberg of Hollywood, FL, daughter Nancy Miller of Baltimore, brothers Morris and Pat, grandchildren Daniel and Lily Sutton, daughter-in-law Edith Bers Sutton, and a large family in Israel. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers or gifts, a contribution in memory of Jack be made to the not-for-profit Beacon College, 105 East Main St., Leesburg, FL 34748. Funeral service at Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1PM Sunday, August 27, 2230 Hollywood Blvd., Hollywood, FL 33020.

title: Dara Horn, Brendan Schulman
description: Dara Horn, a daughter of Dr. Susan Horn and Dr. Matthew D. Horn of Short Hills, N.J., is to be married today to Brendan Michael Schulman, a son of Sylvia Schulman and Justice Perry W. Schulman of Winnipeg, Manitoba. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner is to officiate at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: McCain Undergoes Operation
description: Sen. John McCain received good news when pathologists found no evidence that a malignant melanoma from his left temple had spread to lymph nodes in his face or neck. The nodes were removed during an operation in which surgeons also found no evidence that another melanoma in his left upper arm had spread.

title: Political Briefing; A President's Picture Makes a Few Waves
description: It seemed like a good political move to Ander Crenshaw, a Republican running for the open seat in Florida's Fourth Congressional District, which covers Jacksonville.

title: Suggestions to Expand Use of a Swimming Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Season of the Bounce
description: The 2000 presidential campaign has produced an unusually intense post-convention period. The tradition that the nominees spend a few sleepy weeks resting before Labor Day seems a thing of the distant past, thanks to an unusual volatility in the polls and increasingly heated exchanges between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush. Even Mr. Gore has got to be a little surprised at the way he has been lifted in voter surveys since the Democrats adjourned their convention. After a smooth run-up to the Republican convention, Mr. Bush has been looking defensive and has even been publicly self-critical about his problems in making the case for his huge tax cuts. The candidates are mischievously making feints into each other's friendly territory -- Mr. Gore in Florida and Mr. Bush in several states carried by the Democrats in recent elections. All told, the voters have reason to believe both men's predictions that this will wind up as a tough, tight race.

title: Paterno Takes Quest and Critics in Stride
description: Joe Paterno once called Alabama Coach Bear Bryant ''the nearest thing we had to a god of football.'' And when Paterno met Bryant for a national championship, Paterno made some mortal mistakes.

title: Unemployment vs. Inflation
description: To the Editor:

description: A 54-year-old urologist in Chatham Township, N.J., was arrested yesterday and charged with killing her elderly parents, prosecutors said.

description: SINGER-Joyce S. Age 81, of Lauderhill, FL, and NYC, died on August 25, 2000. Beloved wife of Leon Singer, loving mother of Ian and Richard, grandmother of Sean, Andrew and Michael, mother-inlaw of Pam and Muriel. We love you and miss you. Private services at home.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 13 about the film career of Alec Guinness misidentified one of the places in which his character in ''The Captain's Paradise'' has separate wives. Along with Gibraltar, the place is Tangier, not Malta.

title: The Irrepressible Ragman of Art
description: WHEN Robert Rauschenberg was a boy, his mother used to make him shirts out of scraps of fabric. Collage shirts. She even made herself a skirt out of the back of the suit that her younger brother, Luther, was being buried in, because she didn't want the material to go to waste.

description: Pushing Pants for Pets

title: Ingrassia Is First Woman To Win the Yonkers Trot
description: Jacqueline Ingrassia established a first in the Yonkers Trot tonight just by getting behind the gate. Then she became the first woman to win the Trot, guiding Goalfish past the favored Approved Action down the stretch at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Two Ballet Styles With Something In Common, Alas
description: TODAY'S ballet world has two poles, and both are in danger of freezing over. Plotless, or abstract, ballets are at one pole; narrative ballets are at the other.

description: Thousands of copies of a new book by a former official White House photographer were confiscated by Chinese customs officials as the books were being prepared for shipment from a bindery in southern China, effectively blocking its release in the United States.

description: HOROWITZ-Ruth B. Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Forest Hills and Cutchogue, NY. Passed away on August 26, 2000. description: Tiger Woods won the race against nightfall, winning $1 million in the process.

description: DaimlerChrysler plans to announce on Monday that it will nearly double production in Alabama, adding another assembly line close to the site where it already builds M-Class sport utility vehicles, auto industry officials and consultants said over the weekend.

title: Swedish Bid for London Stock Exchange Is Expected
description: OM Gruppen, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange, is expected to make a formal offer, which could include a hostile bid, for the London Stock Exchange, which rejected an informal $:800 million ($1.18 billion) proposal last week, executives close to the discussions said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELLY, REVEREND THOMAS J.
description: FARRELLY-Reverend Thomas J. Son of Thomas and Josephine Farrelly, loving brother of Ann Morris and uncle of Robert, JoAnn, Eileen and Maureen, grand-uncle of Justine and Erin. Ordained priest of the Archdiocese of New York in 1961, went to the Lord on August 25, 2000. He served as Associate Pastor of St. Gregory the Great Parish and Pastor of Sacred Heart Parish in Manhattan, and Blessed Sacrament Parish in the Bronx. He devoted himself to the pastoral and social needs of all members of the communities where he served and in a special way to the Spanish-speaking communities. Wake at Montera Funeral Home, 1848 Westchester Ave., Bronx, on Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Blessed Sacrament Church on Monday, 2-5 PM. Mass of the Holy Eucharist on Monday, at 7:30 PM. Funeral at Blessed Sacrament Church on Tuesday, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Blessed Sacrament Parish.

title: Searching for a Star in Generation Next
description: A sedan slithered through the traffic down Broadway on an indelicate approach to Times Square. In the face of the halogen spectacle, the passenger, Marat Safin, snapped out of his groggy state, flung open his eyes like shutters and absorbed the plunge into a mosh pit of celebrity.

title: Accounts
description: SmarterKids.com, Needham, Mass., an online educational store and resource for parents, to Orsatti & Partners, Boston, to handle its account, which had been at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

title: Transportation Bond Act Awaits Details, a Campaign and a Vote
description: It just may be the quietest $3.8 billion in New York political history. In November, voters will be asked to decide the largest bond act in state history, to pay for transportation projects. But so far, there has been barely any campaign for it, and none against it.

title: Norman Wins U.S. Open Tuneup but Feels for a Friend
description: When the double fault smacked into the net to end his match this afternoon, Magnus Norman frowned, picked at his racket strings and walked slowly toward the net, his head down.

title: Floods Force Drivers Onto Roofs of Cars
description: Flash floods along Route 22 and other roads in Somerset County, N.J., stranded at least nine motorists last night, some of whom had to wait on the roofs of their cars in a downpour for firefighters to rescue them, the authorities said.

title: A Big Air Ball: Knicks' Plan Is in Pieces
description: When this summer to forget began, the Knicks had four items on their to-do list, and trading Patrick Ewing was not one of them.

title: Patents; And for the commuter, buses located by satellite, an airship with sails and an amphibious bicycle.
description: FOR generations, urban commuters have stood on curbs in every kind of weather, doing the same dance: bodies tilted, necks craned and eyes scanning the traffic horizon to see if the bus is coming.

title: Article 2000082891067015732 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Military Misrule in Pakistan
description: Last October, Gen. Pervez Musharraf overthrew Pakistan's democracy, promising to eradicate corruption, revive the economy and open the way for ''true democracy.'' He pledged to restrain nuclear weapons development and pursue peaceful diplomacy with India. Ten months later, he has made little progress with the economy or corruption and has put off the return of democracy until at least 2003. Pakistan still has not signed the nuclear test ban treaty and tensions with India over Kashmir are as dangerous as ever. Now General Musharraf has announced plans for a new political system designed to buttress his own power by excluding the country's top politicians. That would compound Pakistan's problems. A speedier timetable for restoring democracy is urgently needed.

title: Essay; Clinton in Cairo
description: Having presided at Camp David over Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak's previously unimaginable concessions -- giving up almost all the West Bank and sharing sovereignty in parts of Jerusalem -- President Clinton goes to Cairo tomorrow. He will plead with Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, to tell Yasir Arafat to grab the deal before an astounded and dismayed Israeli public rises up and tosses out its Great Conceder.

title: DNA Offers Link to Black History
description: Add to the list of the wonders of DNA: the ability, in the not-so-distant future, to help African-Americans figure out where their ancestors probably came from before they were enslaved.

title: New Economy; The German auction of wireless networks uncovered deep fissures in the European telecommunications landscape.
description: IT was a free-market contest of the purest sort, an airwave auction of the kind pioneered in the United States and taken to dizzying new heights in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADELMAN, ANNE
description: NADELMAN-Anne. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Men's Club mourn the passing of the beloved sister of our devoted Trustee, Melvin Stein. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITZ, BERNARD S.
description: LEVITZ-Bernard S. Age 88, of Monroe Township, NJ, and Pembroke Pines, FL, on August 25, 2000. Husband of Florence. Father of Temmie Covar and Lee Epstein. Stepfather of Scott, Ricky and Joel Goldstein. Brother of Mortimer and Nathan. Grandfather of eleven; great-grandfather of two. Services were held Sunday at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ.

title: Lazio, Fund-Raising in Chappaqua, Takes Race to Rival's New Home
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio took his Senate campaign almost literally to Hillary Rodham Clinton's backyard today, appearing at a fund-raiser at a private home four miles from Mrs. Clinton's new house.

title: A Fearless Hampton Lets Mets Breathe
description: The sight of Mike Hampton sliding on the infield grass and swinging as if he were the cleanup hitter yesterday left Bobby Valentine shaking his head. How could the Mets pitcher risk another injury? But the concern in the visiting dugout at Shea did not set in until Hampton remained on the mound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLER, ESTHER
description: WALLER-Esther. Died on July 1, 2000, at the Sarah Newman Nursing Home. She was born on March 30, 1907 in Brooklyn, NY. She lived in Long Beach and Islip, LI, Antrim, NH, and had lived in Bronxville for 20 years. Mrs. Waller was a member of The Reformed Church of Bronxville and was a devoted volunteer of the Red Cross during WWII. She was married to the late Thomas Waller whose grandfather was a former governor of Connecticut. Mrs. Waller is survived by a niece, Susan Mullin of Gulf Stream, FL, two nephews-Richard L. Warwick of Bronxville and Bruce L. Warwick of Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will be held at 6 PM on Tuesday, September 5, at The Reformed Church, Pondfield Rd., Bronxville. Friends who wish may contribute to The Reformed Church in her memory.

title: THE OTHER ECONOMY: Nearly Broke in '95, A City Turns Around; Troy's Fortunes Rebound Sharply, Thanks in Part to New York City's
description: Just five years ago, this small city on the Hudson River was literally broke.

title: Bunny Austin, 94, a Pioneer in Tennis Shorts
description: Bunny Austin, an outstanding English player who introduced shorts to tennis, died Saturday in a nursing home in Coulsdon, England. He was 94 years old.

title: Follow the Games Before the Games
description: From ''the luck of the draw'' to ''dangerous floaters'' tennis players tread lightly about their destiny during a Grand Slam tournament. If you can finesse your way through seven singles matches over two weeks, you are, indeed, a survivor.

title: Short of People, Iowa Seeks To Be Ellis Island of Midwest
description: No one would call Iowa a melting pot. Nearly 96 percent white, this state, striated with farm fields and trim small towns, may have more kinds of hogs and corn than nationalities of people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, JEANNE
description: SILVERBERG-Jeanne. Of Hackensack, NJ, on August 26. Beloved wife of Julian. Devoted mother of Elizabeth and Larry Gelb, and Lucy and Sheldon Smith. Loving grandmother of Adam and Amanda Smith, and Emily, David and Julia Jaffe. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, on Monday, August 28, at 1 PM.

title: Experiment in Serious Newscast Stumbles
description: Last February, the CBS station in Chicago, WBBM-TV, began a bold experiment in local television news: it unveiled a 10 p.m. program that presented its audience with plain old news and information. Gone was the genre's usual reliance on sensationalism and entertainment-world gossip.

title: It's Evil, And Often It's Not So Banal
description: Though Neil LaBute's ''Bash: Latter-Day Plays'' wasn't written originally for television, it translates so well it could have been. The intimacy of this trilogy of one-act monologues, designed as sparely as a SoHo dress store, seems made for television, and not just because one of the actors is Ally McBeal (a k a Calista Flockhart). The characters spill their secrets in a confessional rush, like guests on a talk show.

title: Philippine Rebels Free 5 Foreign Hostages
description: Relieved, bitter and still frightened for their companions, five foreign hostages were released by kidnappers in the southern Philippines today for a reported $5 million ransom.

title: Lieberman Seeks Greater Role for Religion in Public Life
description: Declaring that belief in God is the basis of morality and of the nation, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman called today for a greater role for religion in American public life.

title: Gore, Sensing Edge, Pushes Bush For More Specifics on Health Care
description: Vice President Al Gore attacked Gov. George W. Bush on health care policy yesterday, using a telephone interview to reiterate his own proposals in detail and to mock his opponent's positions as lacking ''a minimal standard of substance for serious debate.''

title: Program Is Hurt by a Lack of Characters
description: ''Survivor'' may have posted ratings last week that surpassed everything this year but the Super Bowl, but ''Big Brother,'' the other reality show on CBS, has muddled along with ratings so pale by comparison that the show has had to fight off the impression that it has been a total flop.

title: The Wooing of Our Judges
description: In a lifetime as a judge, lawyer and lawmaker, I can safely say I've encountered few judges guilty of outright dishonesty. Even when I started practicing law in Chicago in the bad old days, the number of crooked judges was small. But that is not what people believed then or believe now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, DOROTHY S.

title: A Political Pulse-Taker Is Back, Without Missing a Beat

title: Release of O'Sullivan Raises Roster Question

While the release of safety Omar Stoutmire was the biggest -- perhaps the only -- surprise, it was the jettisoning of O'Sullivan, the long snapper, that set up a bigger scramble.

title: U.S. Book Is Seized By China Over Photo

The book was seized because a photo showed the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, whom the Chinese government opposes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELLIN, GREHER, SARAH L.
description: SELLIN-GREHER-Sarah L. Our beloved and inspiring high school history teacher who left an indelible imprint on the lives of so many of us. Sarah Sellin-Greher, a woman of great wit, intelligence, and integrity was a teacher par excellence. She taught us to be aware, to read between the lines and to forever seek the truth by asking critical questions. Since we first shared a double desk at Taft High School, we have cherished her friendship throughout the years. Our condolences to her family and all whose lives she touched. Carol Sackheim Marcus Steven Marcus

title: Singer Revives Memories of Lost Youth and Lost Country
description: In prerevolutionary Tehran, when the pop singer Googoosh got a new haircut, her fans rushed out to get one, too. When she wore a particular style of dress, they would adopt it as well. And this weekend, as she stood before many of those fans for the first time in two decades and broke down in tears, thousands of ecstatic Iranian emigres cried, too.

description: GORDON-Ruth. August 26, in her 90th year, leaves Lewis, her beloved husband of 63 years; adored mother of Fred and Charles Richard; mother-in-law of Susan; cherished grandmother of Justin, Jacqueline, Rebecca; niece, Barbara. Ever mindful of her roots, she built her life around supporting numerous institutions promoting the teachings of Judaism. History teacher at Bronx Science, 40 years. A world traveler, enriched her students with the realities she observed. Funeral August 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIORDANO, NED
description: GIORDANO-Ned. Beloved husband of Linda and father of Joan and Catherine. Passed away suddenly on Friday, August 25, 2000. The quintessential husband and father, Ned was deeply devoted to his family, the most important people in his life. A devout Roman Catholic, member of St. Paul's Church in Brookville and the Church of the Holy Innocents in NYC, in which he served as Lector and Eucharistic Minister, he was also a member of the Knights of the Holy Sepulchre. Among his favorite works was leading a communion service in the Adult Home in Westbury. He was recently accepted into the permanent diaconate training program in the Diocese of Rockville Centre. His love and God shone forth in everything he did. His colleagues and employees at Jordan Fashions in Manhattan loved him dearly for the warmth and personal care that he showed towards them on a daily basis. With his wife, Linda, he was a powerful supporter of the inspirational radio program ''As You Think,'' spearheading the fundraising initiatives for that program. His warm smile and open heart endeared him to everyone he met. His gift for making and keeping friends and for doing anything possible personally to help those in need enriched the lives of countless people the world over. Ned's sudden passing leaves a tremendous void, but his shining character and loving heart inspired all of us who miss him to follow his example. The world is infinitely better for his presence among us. Ned is also survived by his mother and father, Marty and Tina Giordano, his two sisters, Marie and Elizabeth, and his two children, Catherine and Joan, as well as his wife, Linda, of 21 years. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, LI, Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Tuesday at St. Paul's Church in Brookville. Entombment in Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Iran's Silenced Star, Bridging a 21-Year Gap
description: Googoosh kept having to wipe tears from her eyes when she performed on Saturday night at the Nassau Coliseum. So did many of her fans. Googoosh, who was Iran's queen of pop in the 1970's, was performing again after 21 years of public silence and seclusion, the 21 years since Iran's Islamic revolutionary government came to power and banned nearly all music.

She blended unconditional love, responsibility and joy in a unique mixture which enriched our lives and the lives of treasured nieces, nephews and friends. Service at Lincoln Square Synagogue, Monday, 10 AM. Shiva at 55 West End Avenue at 62nd St., Apt. 3E.

description: RAVKIND-Morty. A man of many virtues and triumphs. Born in Dallas, Texas, May 29th, 1934. It was my joy to have been his friend and lover for over 30 years. Morty will be missed by all who knew him, family, friends and business associates. Morty was a special man with great compassion and forthright integrity. Loving father to Lou and Leslye, grandfather to Matthew and Jordyn. Loving son to Nell and brother to Barbara and Will. Loving uncle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIOFF, FLORENCE
description: BENIOFF-Florence. Died August 27 at home in Allentown, PA. She was 92. Born in New Britain, CT, the daughter of Bessie and Samuel H. Edelson and raised in Baltimore, she graduated from Towsen State University as a teacher. She worked as a social worker for the Hebrew Benevolent Society of Philadelphia. She was married for 61 years to the late Shim Benioff. After doing a great job of raising her children, she created and managed The Etcetera Shop at Benioff Furs. She was an avid poker and bridge player, a fabulous cook, and a doting mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She is survived by her son Richard and daughter-in-law Mary Benioff of Lambertville, NJ, and daughter Barbara and son-in-law Stephen Friedman of Manhattan; and grandchildren Christopher, Peter, Andrew, Sarah, Suzy, Caroline, and David; and great-grandchildren Sam, Zeke, Tea, Margaret, Henry, and Hannah. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions to the Florence and Shim Benioff Memorial Scholarship Fund, Cornell University, 303 Day Hall, Ithaca, NY 10483.

title: Protecting the Earth
description: Earlier this month, scientists spotted a patch of open ocean about a mile wide at the North Pole, where the ice is normally six to nine feet deep. This remarkable discovery followed close on the heels of a prediction from Norwegian scientists that the polar icecap could disappear, at least in summer, in 50 years. To most climatologists, the thinning of the sea ice is further proof of the warming of the earth's atmosphere, a potentially disruptive trend that hardly mainstream scientists now dispute.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about a planned Court TV series offering the videotaped confessions of people accused of violent crimes misstated the outcome of a case involving Daniel Rakowitz, who was taped confessing to the murder and dismemberment of a woman in Manhattan in 1989. He was tried and found not responsible by reason of insanity in 1991. He was not judged unfit to stand trial.

description: ''The point is we need more people.''

description: In an effort to give media planners more information about advertising patterns online, a study to be released today found that a majority of online advertisements had short life spans, running three weeks or less.

For several years, he's been noting some of the questions posed about the company's summer season of free opera in Central Park. Here are a few he especially enjoyed from this year's batch:

title: VoiceStream Seeks to Buy Wireless Player
description: VoiceStream Wireless, the United States wireless carrier that is being acquired by Deutsche Telekom, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to buy Powertel, a wireless operator in the Southeast for as much as $5.8 billion, according to executives close to the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROSE
description: WOLF-Rose. Loving wife of 59 years of Marvin. Mother of Diane and Steven Katz, Arlene and Robert Fauser, Sharon and Mark Horowitz. Grandmother of Brian and Nancy, Darren, Chad, Emily and Joshua. Cherished sister of Florence Schoenhut and the late Stanley Howard, and sister-in-law of Betty Howard, and the late Hy Schoenhut. Rose was also a very special and dedicated aunt. She was devoted to her family and spent her life supporting and loving each one of us. We remember her for that love and devotion, and will miss her and love her forever. Please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, NYC. Donations can be made to Simon Wiesenthal Center.

title: Arizona Regrets the Catch Not Made
description: Steve Finley caught the ball this time, 10 1/2 months too late. Finley got back to the center-field fence, dug his cleat into the padded blue wall like a mountain climber and then leaped as if he were Michael Jordan wearing gray and purple and going after an alley-oop pass. It was a phenomenal catch, the best catch that some observers had ever witnessed. But it was too late.

title: Who Needs the SAT?
description: As the class of 2004 arrives on campus this month, more students than ever are coming without the blessing of the SAT. Five years ago, the faculty here at Dickinson, one of America's oldest liberal arts colleges, took the pioneering step of eliminating the SAT requirement for admission. Last spring, Mount Holyoke did the same, joining a minor trend. About 285 accredited colleges have now eliminated the requirement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDFEIN, PAULINE R.
description: GOLDFEIN-Pauline R. Seventeen years since you left us. Your family and friends still miss you. Never to be forgotten, rest in peace. Phi

title: A Literary Pilgrim Progresses To the Past
description: What my dentist cried out one day after finally removing an unsuspected fourth nerve from one of my molars comes to mind each time I try to understand myself as a writer. Do I, as a writer, have what he called a ''hidden nerve''?

title: Yankees Don't Give In to Panic, or to Oakland
description: They talked about situations like this in their meeting Friday -- doing what it takes to win games in the late innings. The Yankees trailed Oakland by two runs in the eighth inning today when center fielder Terrence Long lost a fly ball in California's sun, and Derek Jeter said it was a ''no-doubter'' -- the Yankees were sure they were going to come back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKAY, BARBARA COHEN (NEE GREENBERG)
description: MARKAY-Barbara Cohen (nee Greenberg) ''Bobbie.'' Of Boca Raton, FL, on August 26, 2000. Beloved wife of Robert Markay. Cherished mother of her three daughters and their husbands, Deborah and Barry Kosofsky, Leslie and Eric Rubury, Joanne and Duane Fiedler. Adored Nana of Travis, Carrie, Dale, Jason, Evan, Ross, Brad, David, Jeffrey, Pamela, Lachland and Griffin. Dear stepmother of James Markay, Mitchell and Barbara Markay. Loved by a host of close and dear friends and other loving relatives. Memorial service to be held on Monday, August 28, at Gutterman's, Boca Raton, at noon. The family will receive friends Monday and Tuesday at home. Graveside service to be held on Thursday, August 31, at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY (1-888-536-7426), at 2 PM. Friends and family welcome at the home of Joanne and Duane Fiedler following the service. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to your favorite charity in Bobbie's memory. Her family and friends will miss her smile, humor and kindness and her love of life. She will be missed always and remembered forever.

title: Hurtful Defense Cuts Began Under Clinton, Cheney Says
description: Dick Cheney acknowledged yesterday that the military cutbacks he and Gov. George W. Bush have campaigned against began when he was defense secretary for Mr. Bush's father, but he blamed the Clinton administration for making ''far deeper'' cuts that he said had left the military ''in decline.''
