description: DIMOND-Jane. On August 26, 2000. Sister of Mrs. Robert H. Pfeiffer & Thomas Dimond & the late Jessie K. Dimond. Funeral private.

title: Chechnya Is Quieter, but Still a Deadly Quagmire
description: The Russian-appointed leader of Chechnya gestured toward the crowd that had gathered to wish him a happy 49th birthday at his heavily guarded home in this Chechen town. Some, he noted dryly, could well be rebel agents.

title: Week's Auction Includes 52-Week Bill
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of 3- and 6-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.

title: Sports of The Times; Cooper Leaving Behind A Legacy of Greatness
description: PLAYING for Segovia in the plains in Spain, and for Parma and Alcamo amid the hills of Italy, she had dreamed a fading dream of one day playing professional basketball in America, maybe in Los Angeles where she grew up in Watts -- or, well, anywhere in the States, especially so that her mother, Mary Cobb, could see her play regularly. So that her mother could see that she had truly made something of herself.

title: E-Commerce Report; Internet companies learn how to personalize service.
description: ASK a handful of Internet executives to define the term ''personalization,'' and invariably the conversation turns to the analogy of a shopkeeper who knows not only his customers' names, but how much they can afford to spend and what size shirt they wear.

title: Cooper Retirement Offers Hope as Liberty Laments Lost Chance
description: The celebration echoed through the Compaq Center and filtered hauntingly into the loser's locker room. As though being beaten for the third time by the Houston Comets in the Women's National Basketball Association finals wasn't enough, the Liberty couldn't shut out the sounds of its failure.

title: Lancelot Ware Dies at 85; Mensa Was His Brainchild
description: Lancelot Ware, a British barrister who was the co-founder of Mensa, the society for intellectually gifted people, died on Aug. 15 in a nursing home in Surrey, England. He was 85.

title: Just Imagine a Bach Orchestral Suite as Chamber Music, Just the Way Bach Did
description: Thursday evening's Mostly Mozart concert at Alice Tully Hall was, once more, Boldly Bach, the entire program being given over to the four suites the older master wrote at different times in his career for performances in palaces and cafes. Modern scholarship tends to favor the notion that, like the ''Brandenburg'' Concertos, these works were written for soloists to play, and that was how they were done here by the New London Consort.

title: Military Reserves Are Falling Short In Finding Recruits
description: The nation's military Reserves are increasingly struggling to fill their ranks with new recruits, even as the Pentagon relies on them more heavily than ever to conduct operations around the world, according to military officials and Pentagon documents.

title: Wind River Systems Agrees to Acquisition of ICEsoft
description: Wind River Systems, the maker of software that is embedded in dozens of digital devices, will announce today that it has agreed to acquire ICEsoft, a Norwegian developer of Web-browsing software for Internet appliances, for $24.5 million in cash.

description: Israel Raid Turns Fatal

title: Code Name: Mainstream; Can 'Open Source' Bridge the Software Gap?
description: In a report to President Clinton last year, a group of leading computer scientists warned that the nation faced a troubling ''software gap.''

title: Colombian Port Dresses Up for Clinton Visit
description: At 84, Antonia Sarmiento, nearly toothless and dressed in tattered rags, has seen a lot of tragedy in her life but never a miracle.

title: Long Haymes Wins Champion Account
description: Champion Products in Winston-Salem, N.C., part of the branded apparel group of the Sara Lee Corporation, consolidated its apparel account by naming Long Haymes Carr in Winston-Salem, to handle its JogBra business in addition to the Men's Products business it already handles. Billings for the consolidated account were estimated at $10 million.

title: Bumpy Ride on Vehicle Safety
description: It has been a dismal month for those concerned about motor vehicle safety, but it brightened just a bit last week when two of the world's major automobile manufacturers took corrective action to restore consumer confidence. First the Ford Motor Company decided to cut production of its popular Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles so as to free their tires to help replace those being recalled for safety reasons on existing vehicles. Some 6.5 million Bridgestone/Firestone tires are being recalled after being linked to hundreds of accidents and 46 deaths in the United States alone.

title: Torre Says He Plans To Manage in 2001
description: Joe Torre intends to return as the Yankees' manager next year, the last season of his current contract, and he said today he hadn't ruled out the possibility of managing in 2002 or beyond.

title: The Poor Among Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Fortune for U.S. Teams In First Rounds at World Meet
description: The two United States teams had mixed fortunes at the start of the World Championships here today. In the first session of play the open team outscored Bangladesh 20-10, but the women's team lost 12-18 to Taiwan. In the second round the American open team lost to Hungary 8-22, while the women's team beat Russia by the same score.

title: A 60's Icon Converts Nostalgia Into Novelty
description: Ray Davies turned his acid wit on himself Wednesday night at the Jane Street Theater. Changing guitars, he didn't quite secure the strap, and his instrument crashed to the ground. Mr. Davies affected a perplexed stance. ''I've been a rock star so long, I don't know what to do next!'' he sighed.

title: Lisdoonvarna Journal; In Ireland's Pubs, a Startling Trend
description: From the doorway of his family's pub, Peter Curtin has witnessed dramatic changes in Irish life. He remembers when one man's trip to the United States was considered so unusual that he was sent to the local schools to share what he had seen. He remembers when farmers would come in for a pint of Guinness while clutching the reins of horses poking their noses into the pub.

title: An Island Breeze Revives a Dream; At Long Last, a Bahamian Band Has a Hit on Its Hands
description: When he was 7, Isaiah Taylor began having dreams that he compares to the visions God sent Joseph in the Bible. And his own vision was of leading a group of musicians from his home in the Bahamas to worldwide success.

title: Israeli Soldiers Die in Chaos of Botched Raid
description: ''Friendly fire'' may have been responsible for killing three Israeli soldiers in a bungled West Bank antiterror operation on Saturday, Israeli officials acknowledged today. But they defended the late-night attack on the hideout of a man accused of terrorism who heads Israel's most-wanted list.

title: A Republican Blazes a Trail In the Campaign For Lazio's Seat
description: It was, she says, divine inspiration that cast her into a race that could make her the first black Republican woman ever to serve in Congress.

title: F. C. Bock, 82, Monitor of Nagasaki Bombing
description: Frederick C. Bock, a retired scientific researcher who piloted one of the planes monitoring the drop of the atomic bomb on Nagasaki, Japan, in August 1945, died on Friday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 82.

description: The Pittsburgh Steelers waited 11 games last season to bench quarterback Kordell Stewart. This time, it only took them until the end of the preseason.

description: Canada may impose up to $233 million ($157 million) in sanctions over a six-year period against Brazil to punish the country for illegally subsidizing its jet airline industry, the World Trade Organization says. The size of the sanctions may fall if the two countries settle. Elizabeth Olson

title: The Modern And Its Union Finally Meet In Strike Talks
description: The Museum of Modern Art and the union representing its 250 administrative workers will hold negotiations next week in what will be the first face-to-face talks between the two sides since the union went out on strike four months ago, management and union officials said yesterday.

title: Study Finds Higher Test Scores Among Blacks With Vouchers
description: Black students who switched to private schools from public schools on scholarships that were similar to vouchers performed significantly higher on standardized math and reading tests than similar students who remained in public schools, a study released yesterday says.

title: For Bush, Thrill Was in Father's Chase
description: For months a young woman had been flirting with George W. Bush, resulting in a cash bet among co-workers about whether they would end up having an affair. And now the flirtation had provoked a crisis.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors May Now Eye Costs of Stock Options
description: It is one of the prettiest lies in corporate America. Stock options dispensed to executives and workers are not accounted for as an employee expense, even though they clearly are. So companies that reward their employees with stock options do not include the costs of those programs in their overall expenses, giving their earnings a boost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDGWICK, THE REVEREND HAROLD BEND
description: SEDGWICK-The Reverend Harold Bend, of Boston and Lexington, MA, formerly of NYC, on August 27, 2000. Uncle of Emily Sedgwick Bagwill of Middletown, RI, Catherine Sedgwick Sanders of Cumberland Foreside, ME, Pamela Gibson Farrar of Richmond, VA and Alice Gibson Stothers of Los Gatos, CA. Brother of the late Edith Sedgwick Gibson, Charles and Theodore Sedgwick Jr. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Memorial services in Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston, Thursday, September 7 at 11 AM. Memorial services will also be held in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Stockbridge, Saturday, October 7 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be sent to St. Paul's Church, Main Street, Stockbridge, MA. 01262.

title: Ambitious Choral Work Enlivens Festival Finale
description: In recent years Gerard Schwarz, the music director of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival, has been trying to serve the wishes of loyal audiences who enjoy these summer season offerings of works by Mozart & Company yet also respond to complaints from some quarters that these programs are narrowly focused and unimaginative. This season, the festival's 34th, Mr. Schwarz's balancing act must be deemed successful.

title: VITAL SIGNS: UPDATE; Promise and Problems of Supplements
description: A review of clinical trials over the last decade has found mounting evidence that some herbal medicines can be effective in treating mild psychiatric symptoms.

title: COMPENSATION SET ON ATTICA UPRISING
description: Declaring that inmates beaten in the 1971 Attica prison uprising were treated ''like garbage,'' a federal judge divided an $8 million settlement today to compensate more than 500 inmates and relatives for the abuse that the prisoners suffered.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER EXTENDS DETROIT DIESEL TENDER OFFER
description: DaimlerChrysler, the world's largest commercial truck maker, said yesterday that it had extended a tender offer for its planned $583 million purchase of the Detroit Diesel Corporation, a maker of diesel engines, to Sept. 11. The $23-a-share offer initially was scheduled to end at midnight last Friday. The automaker said on July 20 that it would buy about 18.1 million shares of Detroit Diesel that it did not already own for $423 million and assume about $160 million in debt. About 98 percent of those shares have been tendered, DaimlerChrysler said in a regulatory filing. It already owned about 21 percent of Detroit Diesel, a former General Motors division that was sold to the former race-car driver Roger Penske in 1988.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMUNTZ, MARCEL
description: GOLDMUNTZ-Marcel. On August 27, 2000. Beloved husband of Rita, loving father of Arlette Miller, and her husband, George, and Paul Goldmuntz. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, John, David, Anna, & Ben. Great grandfather of Zachary. Dear brother of Anita Freudman. Services at 12:45, on Tuesday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGRECA, BETTY
description: LaGRECA-Betty. On August 27, 2000, beloved wife of the late Frank, loving mother of Annette and Frank, dear sister of Anthony. Reposing at The Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street, on Tuesday 7-9:30 P.M., and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9:30 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30 A.M. from Saint Luke's Church, Whitestone, New York. Interment is in Saint Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARBERRY, JAMES JOHN
description: CARBERRY-James John, 74, Professor Emeritus, University of Notre Dame, of Brooklyn, NY, on August 27. Carberry, a renowned Chemical Engineering scientist, provided both Notre Dame and the Engineering communities with vision and foresight for more than forty years. Professor Carberry is survived by his daughter, Alison Carberry Kiene, Rockford, IL; his twin grandsons; sisters Jeanne Carberry Brady, Hyde Park, NY and Alice Romanelli, Huntington, NY; many nieces, nephews and great nieces and nephews. Predeceasing Dr. Carberry were his wife, Margaret Bruggner Carberry; his daughter, Maura O'Malley Carberry; and his uncle, John Joseph Cardinal Carberry, former archbishop of St. Louis. Visitation will be from 6:30 to 9PM Tuesday August 29, Sacred Heart Basilica, University of Notre Dame. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30AM Wednesday August 30, at the Basilica. Interment Cedar Grove Cemetery, Notre Dame. Memorials to Hospice of St. Joseph's County, 111 Sunnybrook Court, South Bend, IN 46637-3437. Services by Hickey Funeral Homes, South Bend, IN. 219-289-1000.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Inside: The Business of Entertainment, Media and Technology, a magazine to be started by Powerful Media and Standard Media International, misstated the circulation breakdown of The Industry Standard, whose back-office operations will produce and distribute the new magazine. About 45 percent of the Industry Standard's 200,000 readers receive the magazine free. Not all of them do.

description: IT may still be the self-proclaimed Cognac de Napoleon, but Courvoisier is definitely not just the emperor's brandy anymore.

description: Quietly, the Jets' offense has coalesced behind an offensive line that could be even better than the unit that blocked for the 12-4 team of 1998.

description: When the nude 14-foot bronze statue in front of the Arthur Ashe Commemorative Garden was unveiled last night, some in the crowd were confused over its meaning, while others remarked of its power.

Died at home Saturday, August 26, 2000 following a long, courageous battle with chronic lymphocytic leukemia, Beloved brother of Maureen O'Gorman Wasserman & James M. O'Gorman. Survived by nieces Maura O'Gorman Doerr, Patricia O'Gorman Jepsen, and Denise Wasserman Byle. Also survived by five great-nieces and one great-nephew. He dedicated himself through action & activity to ''Friends in Deed''. Visitation Monday & Tuesday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to Friends in Deed, 594 Broadway, Suite 706, New York, New York 10012.

title: People
description: Casey Jones was named to the new post of executive vice president and managing director for technology at the Grey Global Group, based in San Francisco, with global management responsibility for the Oracle account, which has billings estimated at $100 million, as well as responsiblity for integrated marketing for future technology-related clients. Mr. Jones had been a senior vice president and senior account director at Euro RSCG DSW Partners, Salt Lake City, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Applied Micro Will Acquire MMC Networks
description: The Applied Micro Circuits Corporation, a San Diego-based maker of chips for networking equipment, said today that it had agreed to acquire MMC Networks Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $4.5 billion.

title: PACCAR IS EXPECTED TO LAY OFF UP TO 500 IN OHIO
description: Paccar, the world's second-largest truck maker, may lay off as many as 500 workers at a plant in Chillicothe, Ohio, or almost a third of the factory's work force, as demand slows, a city official said. The layoffs are expected to begin after workers return from a two-week shutdown on Sept. 11, Matt Allen, development director for the southern Ohio city, said company officials told him. Paccar declined to comment. The plant has about 1,600 workers. The company, based in Bellevue, Wash., and other makers of heavy trucks have been hurt as North American production slipped to a 270,000-unit annual pace in the first half from a record 316,000 for all of 1999. Paccar shares rose $1.19, to $42.19.

title: BLUEFLY EXPANDS AOL AGREEMENT
description: Bluefly.com, an Internet retailer that sells designer clothes at discount prices, said it expanded an agreement with America Online, and the company's shares surged 77 percent. Bluefly.com's merchandise will be listed in several categories on seven of America Online's shopping sites, the company said in a press release. More than 20,000 of Bluefly.com's products will be available through America Online's shopping search function. Bluefly.com has relied on links with America Online and other Internet sites to help funnel customers to its Internet store. Shares of Bluefly.com, which is based in New York, jumped $1.50, to $3.44. The shares are still down about 67 percent this year.

title: Alzheimer's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: HOVNANIAN AGREES TO ACQUIRE WASHINGTON HOMES
description: Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., the largest homebuilder in New Jersey, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Washington Homes for $77.4 million in cash and stock, expanding into the Washington, D.C., market. Hovnanian, based in Red Bank, N.J., said Washington Homes' stockholders can either swap each of their shares for 1.39 Hovnanian shares or receive $10.08 a share in cash, a 41 percent premium to the closing price of $7.13 on Friday. Hovnanian said it would also pay off or assume an unspecified amount of debt. Hovnanian fell 50 cents, to $6.56. Washington Homes rose $1.38, to $8.50.

title: Chief of MP3.com Testifies in Music Copyright Hearing
description: With his Internet music start-up facing potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in damages for copyright violations, the head of MP3.com told a federal judge in Manhattan yesterday that he believed he was acting legally when he created an online database of thousands of copyrighted record albums.

title: Lebanese Opposition Registers Gains in Early Vote
description: Opponents dealt sharp blows to the government of President Emile Lahoud and Prime Minister Salim el-Hoss, results of the first round of parliamentary elections showed today.

description: If you want to eat less, add a little air.

title: Transgender Rights
description: People who have had sex-change surgery, cross-dressers and others whose gender identity does not conform to societal norms are often targets of violence and bias that force them to live in fear for their safety or the loss of their jobs and shelter. A bill now before the New York City Council would give this marginalized population basic protection against discrimination in housing, employment and public accommodations.

description: The endless sniffles and ear infections that go along with day care may have some benefit: children with high rates of exposure to other children in infancy are less likely to develop asthma later on, researchers say.

title: New Yorker Imprisoned in Peru Gets New Trial in Treason Case
description: Peru's top military court yesterday revoked the life sentence imposed more than four years ago on Lori Berenson, a New Yorker accused of treason, and granted her a new trial in civilian courts.

title: Start in Fashion? Easier to Go Through the Eye of a Needle
description: Being a young designer in New York -- and the city seems flush with new talent now -- hardly means that one will survive to be an old designer in New York. The fashion business here, especially, functions with a kind of Darwinian magnanimity. Which is to say, either you're good or you're gone.

title: SBC SELLS LEASE RIGHTS FOR 3,900 TOWERS
description: SpectraSite Holdings, a company that builds, manages and leases wireless communications towers in major cities across the nation, agreed to acquire the leasing rights for 3,900 towers from SBC Communications for roughly $1.3 billion. SpectraSite, which is based in Cary, N.C., will pay $983 million in cash and $325 million in stock to manage the towers for 27 years. The company also agreed to build about 800 new towers for SBC of San Antonio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, DOROTHY S.
description: GOLDNER-Dorothy S. On August 26, 2000. Beloved wife of Alfred. Devoted mother of Joanne and Penny, and mother-in-law to Richard Bing and Richard Fields. Cherished grandmother to Jonathan, David and Megan. We love you and will miss you. Services private.

title: Debt Rating of Loews Movie Chain Is Cut
description: Reacting to an announcement from Loews Cineplex Entertainment that it might default on its debt, Standard & Poor's Ratings Services yesterday lowered its rating of the company's bonds to B from BB--.

title: Their Babbling Brook Turned Angry Torrent
description: First there was the deluge that wiped out the narrow private road that was the only access to Peg Ziegler's house and replaced it with a rubble- and rock-strewn stream. Then came the red tape.

title: For Bush and His Opponents, Another Tug-of-War Day
description: Seeking to pull the campaign debate back onto what he considers his turf, Gov. George W. Bush sharply attacked Vice President Al Gore on education policy today, asserting that the Clinton administration had complacently presided over ''a national tragedy'' in the public schools.

description: The second most popular kind of drug used to lower high blood pressure is less effective than other drugs in preventing heart attacks and heart failure, according to a study being reported today.

title: W.T.O. RULES AGAINST U.S.
description: A World Trade Organization panel has upheld an earlier ruling requiring the United States to change an 84-year-old law that penalizes foreign companies for dumping low-priced goods on its markets. Two years ago, the European Union and Japan challenged the 1916 Anti-Dumping Act. A three-judge panel rebuffed United States government arguments that the law was rarely used and had never led to such penalties. The United States has until Oct. 1 to respond to the ruling.

title: Baby Found Abandoned at Subway Station
description: A newborn boy was found abandoned on a subway platform at 14th Street in Manhattan last night, the police said.

title: Endorsements for the Bronx
description: In New York's important primary on Sept. 12, the Bronx has become a particularly intense political battleground under Roberto Ramirez, the borough's Democratic political kingpin and one of the city's senior Hispanic leaders. Mr. Ramirez, who resigned this year from his Bronx Assembly seat, says he wants to focus on promoting other candidates. While this may be little more than an effort to extend his political reach, Mr. Ramirez's interference in the Bronx political scene has also brought a renewed vigor to several primary battles. In some cases, victory in the primary is tantamount to election.

title: Back-of-the-Park Treatment For Fountain of the Planets
description: Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, rich in history, gardens, grassy meadows and cultural centers, is shining now. Tens of millions of dollars have gone into rehabilitation of the parkland and its attractions.

description: The second most popular kind of drug used to lower high blood pressure is less effective than other drugs in preventing heart attacks and heart failure, according to a study being reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIOFF, FLORENCE
description: BENIOFF-Florence. The Cornell University community mourns the passing of Florence Benioff, mother of devoted Cornell alumni Barbara Friedman and Richard Benioff. We express our sincere condolences to Barbara and Stephen Friedman and Richard and Mary Benioff. We also send condolences to Mrs. Benioff's grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Hunter R. Rawlings III, President, Cornell University Harold Tanner, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D., Dean, Weill Medical College of Cornell University Sanford I. Weill, Chairman of the Board of Overseers, Weill Medical College of Cornell University

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Crucial Concessions Made On Minimum Wage Bill

title: Open Water at Pole Is Not Surprising, Experts Say
description: Recent eyewitness reports of open water from melting ice at the North Pole have prompted climatologists and other scientists to make a closer study of satellite imagery and other observations of northern sea ice, past and present. Although striking and unusual, those reports are not as surprising as suggested in a news article on Aug. 19 in The New York Times, which was based on the descriptions and interpretations of two scientists who had just visited there.

title: Indonesia Wants to Redraw Bailout Accord With I.M.F.
description: Two days after he was sworn in as Indonesia's economic czar, Rizal Ramli said today that the International Monetary Fund had become overly involved in the nuts and bolts of the country's economy in the course of its $43 billion bailout.

title: Gimelstob Works the Crowd
description: Justin Gimelstob bounded forward furiously, shocked and screaming, the sound of his voice slicing through the suddenly quiet stadium.

title: Mine to Close, as Tribes Prevail Over Fashion Fad
description: It's a long way from the catwalks of Paris to the craggy forests of the San Francisco Peaks, but the two have been linked for more than a decade by the demand for stonewashed denim: new jeans made to look old by laundering them with pieces of volcanic pumice.

title: Keeping the Lines Open, Receiver Gets His Big Shot
description: A year ago, at a cubicle inside a telephone company's customer service center in Charlotte, N.C., Thabiti Davis dispensed plan-pricing information, routed technical questions and offered general assistance.

description: The United States open team continued to struggle here today in the World Bridge Championships. The team lost a close match to the Netherlands 14-16 but then defeated Russia 20-10.

description: MERCADO-Octavio. 1 year has gone by since we said goodbye. You are part of our daily lives. Lazaro Leon, your sister Carmen, friends and Rickie

But at least the settlement of this case provides the basis for the former inmates to close the book on the past and to focus on the future.''

description: SWANSON-Janet T. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors and Members of the North Fork Women for Women Fund. Inc. mourn the loss of our esteemed Co-Founder, first President and friend on Saturday, August 26. Jan's commitment to women's health, the spirit of her friendship and passion for life will be sorely missed.

title: Side Effects Of a Drug Spur Alert To Users
description: Citing ''rare but serious risks'' from Lotronex, a drug prescribed for women with irritable bowel syndrome, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered that a warning pamphlet be attached to each bottle of pills to alert consumers to early signs of dangerous side effects.

description: August 29, 2000

description: Now that the Mets have caught the Braves, what do they do? Do they storm on by, or do they act like the race dog that catches the mechanical rabbit and goes crazy?

title: Falling Bricks
description: To the Editor:

title: Get the Easy Greenhouse Gases First
description: That North Pole ice has turned liquid may be the least of our problems. New studies have found that all Northern Hemisphere sea ice is melting at a rate of about 15 percent per decade and that the oceans as a whole are warming. Moreover, researchers have just identified a rare manufacturing byproduct, SF5 CF3, that represents the most potent greenhouse gas ever detected. The signs of global warming keep accumulating.

title: Girls, Gym and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Davenport Quietly Advances in U.S. Open
description: While Venus and Serena Williams command the spotlight at the United States Open, Lindsay Davenport has slipped from attention as if she occupied just another anonymous spot in the bracket.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE-Allan. I will never understand why you, so full of life, were meant to leave this world so soon. You live on in my heart and soul and I thank you for all that you taught me. You were the best Daddy ever. Love, Catherine

title: Mexican Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEL RECALLS NEW CHIPS
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it had recalled its fastest chip -- the 1.13 gigahertz Pentium III -- because the chip could cause system errors when running certain programs at a particular temperature and voltage. The problem is with certain circuits of the chip that have been shown to malfunction in laboratory tests running either a standard industry test called Sysmark2000 or a particular Linux compiler, said Michael Sullivan, an Intel spokesman. Intel said it has received no reports from customers, but Dell Computer and I.B.M. have stopped shipping PC's with the processor. Mr. Sullivan said very few of the processors had been shipped to date. Lawrence M. Fisher

title: A C.I.A. Cover-Up on Chile
description: When President Clinton first promised that the administration would declassify secret documents on political violence in Chile, the Central Intelligence Agency pledged to cooperate. Now it is breaking that promise with regard to the most important information -- documents about covert operations to destabilize the Socialist government of Salvador Allende and support Augusto Pinochet's repressive security forces after his 1973 coup.

title: Yet Another Reminder: Forget the Suntan
description: John McCain's unfortunate return bout with melanoma should serve as a wake-up call for the millions of Americans -- especially young Americans -- who still worship the sun, skimp on sunscreen and bare their skin to UV radiation to just within the limits of decency.

title: Alien Earthworms' Offspring Thrive, and Alter Soil, in U.S.
description: Anglers, take note: The night crawler on that hook is an invader. According to recent research by an earthworm ecologist, diggers could tear up approximately the upper half of the North American continent and almost never find an earthworm of true North American descent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBOTTON, GILBERT
description: DeBOTTON-Gilbert. The Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourns the suddenly passing of Gilbert DeBotton, the stalwart benefactor and member of The Executive Council, a prominent member of The Board of Governors, and its Former Deputy Chairman, President of The European Committee of The Weizmann Institute of Science. The Institute extends sincere condolences to his widow, The Honorable Mrs. Janet DeBotton, and to the bereaved family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman, Board of Governors Professor Haim Harari, President

title: That Sinking Feeling, Again
description: Science often rests on chance discoveries. So it is that an American archaeologist studying the origins of Venice has stumbled on clues suggesting that a multibillion-dollar plan to build floodgates to save the city from rising waters is doomed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMAN, MILTON
description: HABERMAN - Milton. Passed away August 28. Loving father of Meyer and Susan and grandfather of Debbie and Laura. Funeral services will be private. Donations may be made to American Cancer Society.

title: U.S. Says Cuba Causes Misery With Its Hard Line on Emigres
description: The State Department accused Cuba today of causing widespread suffering by refusing to allow Cubans to leave the island even if they hold United States visas. Meanwhile, the United States has told a high Cuban government official that he cannot attend a meeting at the United Nations of lawmakers from around the world.

title: Debating Tax-Cut Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKLIN, HELENE (NEE MILICH)
description: ROCKLIN-Helene (nee Milich). Died August 27, 2000, suddenly at home. Her gifts to us, her ebullient spirit, laughter, love of reading and music. Survived by her sons, Edward Rocklin, of California, Peter Rocklin, of New Jersey, Arthur Rocklin, of Maryland, and granddaughter, Rachel.

title: The 'Women's Disease' That Also Strikes Men
description: Dick Richards of Anderson, Calif., goes for his physical every year, and his doctor jots down his height and weight. The doctor does not react to the fact that each year Mr. Richards is shorter.

title: Lieberman Is Asked to Stop Invoking Faith in Campaign
description: The Anti-Defamation League called yesterday for Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, to stop making ''overt expressions'' of religious belief on the campaign trail.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: TODAY'S SCHEDULE
description: TODAY'S SCHEDULES

title: Shared Struggles On Open's First Day
description: Yevgeny Kafelnikov walked onto Court 11 yesterday afternoon as if he were going to the office, wearing a neat white shirt with a navy-trimmed collar, his sandy blond hair cropped short.

title: Questions Raised by a Political Period Piece
description: Marc Blitzstein's musical position paper in defense of labor unions, ''The Cradle Will Rock,'' is a period piece that begs an understanding of its period: the later years of the Depression when unions were exercising fresh muscles and being ferociously opposed by industrialists.

title: Islanders Sign Defenseman
description: The Islanders yesterday signed the 25-year-old free agent defenseman Anders Myrvold, who will be making his return to North America after spending two years in the Swedish Elite League.

title: The Republican Prescription
description: The Republican National Committee began showing a new commercial, ''Priority MD,'' dealing with prescription drugs in nine states yesterday, taking on the issue that has grabbed center stage in the presidential campaign. The Democratic National Committee plans to answer it, starting today, in the same nine states -- Arkansas, Delaware, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, BERTRAM
description: WEISS-Bertram. Age 92. Beloved father of Edward Weiss, beloved brother of Mrs. Amelia Bruce and husband of the late Leah Auster Weiss, died on August 28th at Waterbury Hospital, Waterbury, Connecticut. Funeral services have not been arranged.

title: A Victory of Sorts for Abortion Rights in a Mexican State
description: Abortion rights groups across Mexico celebrated a victory today against resurgent efforts by conservative politicians and church leaders who had sought to chip away at already limited rights to abortion.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Dead Air Here: D'Amato vs. Koch

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; VW WORKERS CUT DEMANDS
description: Union leaders at a Volkswagen plant in Puebla, Mexico, reduced their demands for a pay increase from 20 percent to 17 percent over the weekend, while VW stuck to its offer of a 12 percent increase in salaries. The two sides were scheduled to meet last night in an attempt to avoid another walkout by 12,600 union workers. On Aug. 18, a strike brought production lines at the only plant in the world that produces the New Beetle to a standstill for five days, until the government ordered the strikers to go back to work or face dismissal. Union leaders have threatened to sue the government labor tribunal for abuse of authority. Dan Fineren

title: ATOS TO ACQUIRE PHILIPS UNIT
description: One of Europe's biggest computer service providers, Atos S.A. of France, has agreed to acquire the Origin division of Royal Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands, the leading European electronics group, for $2.4 billion in stock. Philips will acquire 21.5 million shares of Atos Origin, or 48.9 percent of the combined company, with an obligation to reduce the stake below 35 percent within two years. Analysts said the acquisition would give Atos the size it needed to compete with larger rivals like Cap Gemini of France and Getronics of the Netherlands, but at the price of poorer profitability, given recent declines in Origin's revenue and profit.

title: VITAL SIGNS: NOSTRUMS; Breathing Easier? Not With Nose Clip
description: A growing number of athletes are using nasal dilators -- nose attachments that hold the nasal passages open -- in the belief that the dilators allow more oxygen into the body and enhance performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREK, ROSLYN
description: KOREK-Roslyn, 60. Loving wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Jeff, Lawrence and Jodi. Cherished sister of Alvin Weigel. Beloved mother-in-law of Jolie, Melissa and Craig. Loving grandmother of Cydney, Skylar, Jake and Spencer. We love you and will miss you. Friends who wish may contribute to Sloan-Kettering or Columbia Presbyterian in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, SANDOR
description: GREENWALD-Sandor. On August 28, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Anna, devoted father of Myrna and Edward Weisselberg, & Rochelle Greenwald Bonafede, cherished grandfather of Deborah, Joanne, Michael, Dianne, and Joseph. Loving great grandfather. Dear brother of Mary Gluck, Pearl Solner, and Helen Falkowitz. Services on Wednesday, August 30, 2000, 1 P.M. at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Raytheon Struck By Electricians
description: The Raytheon Company, the No. 3 United States military contractor, said today that about 3,000 employees, or 3.2 percent of its work force, had gone on strike at seven plants in Massachusetts after rejecting a contract offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROSE
description: WOLF-Rose. Loving wife of 59 years of Marvin. Mother of Diane and Steven Katz, Arlene and Robert Fauser, Sharon and Mark Horowitz. Grandmother of Brian and Nancy, Darren, Chad, Emily and Joshua. Cherished sister of Florence Schoenhut and the late Stanley Howard, and sister-in-law of Betty Howard, and the late Hy Schoenhut. Rose was also a very special and dedicated aunt. She was devoted to her family and spent her life supporting and loving each one of us. We remember her for that love and devotion, and will miss her and love her forever. Please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, NYC. Donations can be made to Simon Wiesenthal Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOODY, ANNELLE R.
description: MOODY-Annelle R. On August 27, 2000 at age 83. Wife of Rex. Interment is private. Memorial service at St. Jame's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, Wednesday, August 30 at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSON, MURIEL R.
description: HANSON-Muriel R. Died August 23, 2000 in Chatham, MA., at the age of 83. Born on July 7, 1917, she graduated from Vassar College in 1938. Her first marriage to Roberto Rendueles Alsina ended in divorce. She later married Donald P. Hanson, founder and publisher of Woman's Day magazine. After her marriage, she wrote a regular monthly column for Woman's Day and, for several years, served as a Features editor of the magazine. An active member of the Congregational Church, Mrs Hanson wrote a published history of the First Congregational Church of Ridgefield, Connecticut. For many years, she also served as a trustee of the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y. She is survived by two sons, Lars P. Hanson and Donald P. Hanson Jr., a daughter Wendy Gimbel, a sister Margaret Milbrath and seven grandchildren.

title: Changing of the Guard for a Vast Empire; After Whirlwind Expansion, the Met's New Chairman of Asian Art Takes His Time
description: Thirty years ago Asian art led a marginal life at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In 1970 the only Chinese works on view were in a room of early Buddhist sculpture and some cases of ceramics. As late as 1990 Indian art meant an assortment of objects crammed into dimly lighted vitrines on the Great Hall balcony.

title: Personal Spending Rises As Savings Rate Hits a Low
description: Personal spending rose in July at twice the pace of incomes as consumers borrowed to make purchases and the savings rate fell to a record low, government figures showed today.

title: Prayer as Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: PLUS: GOLF; Quinney Wins On the 39th Hole
description: A restless night turned into a beautiful morning for Jeff Quinney, as the 21-year-old from Eugene, Ore., ran in a 30-foot birdie putt on the 39th hole of match play yesterday to defeat James Driscoll and win the 100th United States Amateur Championship.

title: Mexican Environmentalist Is Found Guilty
description: In closing a case that has led to outrage among environmental groups around the world, a district judge in the state of Guerrero sentenced Rudolfo Montiel Flores today to almost seven years in prison for drugs and weapons crimes.

title: More Questions to Ponder
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, TIMOTHY MARK
description: MORRIS-Timothy Mark. Age 47, of Armonk, NY, on August 28, 2000. Beloved son of Joan and George, brother of Christopher and Brian, uncle to Trevor. A graduate of The University of Virginia School of Architecture and The Yale Graduate School of Architecture, he practiced with selected architectural firms and with his twin brother, Christopher. Interment private. Memorial service is at a later date.

title: Istanbul Journal; A City's Young: Flotsam Adrift on Ancient Streets
description: Efes Uyanmaz threaded his way up the embankment, dodging piles of trash and excrement to reach the hole in the wall. Pulling back a dingy sheet that partially concealed the opening, he gestured inside and said, ''This is where we live.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBELL, LOUIS
description: LOBELL-Louis. Died on August 27, 2000; beloved father of Sharon Lobell Comiteau, Arline Lobell Zeldman, Bonnie Bello and Ian Ross Lobell. Beloved grandfather of Robin, Lauren, Jennifer, Chad, Michael, Kristin, and Jason. Greatgrandfather of Zachary, Alexandra, and Juliana Rose. He will be missed & remembered with love always. Services held Wednesday at 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Bush Campaign Balks at Committing to 3 Prime-Time Debates on Major TV Networks
description: Aides to Gov. George W. Bush are balking at a series of three presidential debates proposed by an independent commission, saying they do not want to commit to three sessions that would be broadcast in prime time by the three major networks.

title: Mitsubishi Shares Tumble After Police Raid on Headquarters
description: Shares of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation tumbled today, as speculation mounted that the company's president would resign after the Tokyo police raided its corporate headquarters.

title: Counsel Report On Whitewater Expected Soon
description: Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, said he expected to issue a statement of his findings and conclusions about the Whitewater investigation a few weeks before New York voters go to the polls to choose between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio, her Republican opponent for the United States Senate.

title: Evaluating Pains and Gains Of Weight Lifting Regimen
description: Over the last decade, more Americans have been heading to the weight room.

title: Sparks Signs With Cowboys
description: The former Giants cornerback Phillippi Sparks, who was talked out of retirement by his best friend, Dallas cornerback Darren Woodson, signed a two-year, incentive-laden contract with the Cowboys yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREUSAND, RUTH F.
description: STREUSAND-Ruth F. 82, of Royal Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Scarsdale NY. On August 26, 2000. Retired Attorney for New York State Labor Relations Board. Graduate of Hunter College, Class of 1938 and Columbia Law School, Class of 1941. She was a Master Bridge player and active in Hadassah. Devoted mother of Howard, Lawrence and Judith. Two grandchildren, Nina and Evan. Funeral service will be today, August 29, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens. Donations may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union

title: Hemlines Are Down, but Business Is Up
description: As children return to school these days, producers and purveyors of school uniforms are enjoying an arithmetic lesson of their own: the rising number of cities, including New York, that require or encourage public school students to wear uniforms is adding up to more profit.

title: Scouts' Successful Ban on Gays Is Followed by Loss in Support
description: In the two months since the United States Supreme Court ruled that the Boy Scouts of America have a constitutional right to exclude gays, corporate and governmental support for the organization has slipped markedly.

title: Courthouse Klan-Fighter Takes On Aryan Nations
description: Morris S. Dees Jr., who has won a series of civil rights suits against the Ku Klux Klan and other racist groups in a campaign to put them out of business, came to court here today to try to seize the Aryan Nations compound that has nurtured white supremacists for more than 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, WILLIAM F.
description: BOYD-William F., DDS. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Nassau County Dental Society mourn the death of Dr. William F. Boyd, on August, 27, 2000. Dr. Boyd was a past president of the Society (1976) and served as its Executive Director from 1990 to 1998. His good humor, gentle manner and wisdom will be missed by not only his family and friends, but also by his fellow dentists and the countless people that he helped throughout his professional life. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Arline, daughter Helen and her husband Daniel Popeo, grandchildren John and Margaret Popeo of New Hartford, New York, daughter Virginia and her husband Timothy Brosnan of Garden City, New York. David J. Miller, DDS President Gabrielle K. Wiener, MPA, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREIB, BIRDIE
description: TREIB-Birdie. In loving memory of Birdie Treib, beloved mother of Patricia Neuwirth, grandmother of John & Daniel Neuwirth, motherin-law of Alan Neuwirth and sister of Reina and Mort Adler. Funeral service 11:30AM Wednesday, August 30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

description: Couture for Those Drawn by Horses

title: Digging Beyond Stone for Ancient City's Pulse and Soul
description: On a lunch break from excavations, Bert Smith delivered the news of discovery. The marble head of a man had been found under crumbling steps of an ancient house. The style was right, and the fit. This must be the missing piece to a headless statue of a local governor from the fifth century A.D. that had been recovered years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, JECHIEL MEIR, RABBI
description: GOLDSMITH-Jechiel Meir, Rabbi. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the father of our Gabbai Rishon, Rabbi Sheldon Goldsmith and extends to him and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRN, ROSE
description: BIRN-Rose. Lincoln Square Synagogue mourns with sorrow the passing of Mrs. Rose Birn, mother of our members Shellee Berman and Martin Birn, and mother-in-law of our member and former Rabbi, Saul Berman. May her memory be a blessing. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: Old Friend of China Sees a Blackened Star
description: IT is possible that friendship with a country is not so different from a friendship with a person. You close your eyes to flaws, sometimes significant ones, preferring not to see them, even as others point them out.

title: Using a Pen, L.I. Man Stole 11 Buildings, Authorities Say
description: A Long Island man found a new way to make real estate deals with no money down, prosecutors in Brooklyn said yesterday. He stole the properties with the stroke of a pen, they said, transferring the deeds into his own name by forging the rightful owners' signatures.

title: Major Market Gauges Gain, Flirting With Record Highs
description: Major stock market gauges crept close to record levels yesterday.

title: To Train and Keep Good Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hardaway, in Limbo, Ponders Moving On
description: Tim Hardaway's knees are swollen, ice packs wrapped around them. A grueling practice for the United States Olympic team is over and the Miami point guard is hurting.

title: Bush and the Debates
description: Aides to Gov. George W. Bush are objecting to the three debates that have been proposed by the Commission on Presidential Debates. The aides said they did not want to commit to three debates on prime-time television and wanted a more relaxed, conversational format. They also are concerned about the site of one debate -- near the John F. Kennedy Library in Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOME, NORMAN S. MD.
description: ROOME-Norman S. MD. The Board of Trustees and Medical Staff of Lenox Hill Hospital express their sorrow at the passing of Norman S. Roome, MD, a distinguished member of our Department of Surgery for 27 years. A gifted diagnostician and skilled surgeon, Dr. Roome was highly respected by his peers and patients alike. It was obvious to all those fortunate enough to have known him that he truly loved the art and science of medicine. Dr. Roome took great joy in sharing his knowledge with young physicians who, in turn, valued the opportunity to learn from such a devoted teacher. The entire hospital family honors the memory of this kind and gentle man who exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deep sympathy to his wife Yvonne and family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Allen H. Collins, MD, MPH, President Medical Board Valavanur A. Subramanian MD, Director Surgery

title: Brooklyn Ambulance Crash Kills Father and 13-Year-Old Son
description: A volunteer ambulance responding to a call from a woman with chest pains Sunday night collided with a motorcycle, killing a father and his 13-year-old son, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 19 and a brief report on Aug. 20 in The Week in Review about the sighting of open water at the North Pole misstated the normal conditions of the sea ice there. A clear spot has probably opened at the pole before, scientists say, because about 10 percent of the Arctic Ocean is clear of ice in a typical summer.

description: PENSON-Pearl. We have lost a loving, kind and caring friend of sixty-two years. Jim and Tom, your devotion to Pearl was beyond reproach. Our sympathies to you and your loved ones. Zelinka-Greenman families

description: Mary T. Reynolds, an authority on James Joyce, died on Friday at her home in Washington. She was 87.

description: For the Skidi Pawnee of the Nebraska plains of the early 19th century, the nighttime sky served as clock, calendar, compass and weather channel, all in one.

description: A unit of Novartis A.G., the world's fourth-largest pharmaceutical company, has accused a rival, Abbott Laboratories, of infringing on patents for the drug Neoral, which is used to combat organ rejection in transplant patients.

title: Prayers at Football Games
description: Along with chanting school cheers, students in some Southern high schools are now standing up to recite the Lord's Prayer at the start of football games. Although the stadium prayers seem spontaneous and undirected, they are in fact part of a movement, started by Christian ministries and radio talk show hosts, to promote school prayer. The purpose is to get around a recent Supreme Court decision that banned as unconstitutional school-sponsored student-led prayers that are broadcast over the public address system.

title: Alteon to Acquire Bluetail in Stock Deal
description: August 29, 2000

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL SOARS. Heating oil surged on concern that refiners won't be able to make enough before demand picks up during the winter. In New York, heating oil for September delivery rose 2.94 cents, to 99.88 cents a gallon.

title: Lazio's Attack in Response to a Clinton Atack
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, has released a 30-second advertisement, ''Positive,'' that emphasizes the tit-for-tat advertising campaigns that have been waged in recent weeks over his legislative record. This new advertisement, which is to begin appearing statewide today, responds to a recent one by his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, that questioned his effectiveness as a legislator. That Clinton advertisement was itself a response to a Lazio commercial that promoted bills Mr. Lazio supported or sponsored.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTNER, BETTY
description: GARTNER-Betty. 96 years old. Widow of the late Hyman. Beloved mother of Lloyd and Marvin. Adoring grandmother of five grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. Graveside services will be held today at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island. Shiva will be observed in Jerusalem and in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, MAX
description: ZIMMERMAN-Max. August 27, 2000, in his 90th year. Devoted son, sibling, husband of the late Kate, father of Rita, and the late Joel, grandfather of Charles and Marian. Imbued with a love of, and respect for the young, as well as deeply involved in a life-long quest for social and economic justice, Max's life and values serve as an example to be cited and remembered. Funeral services on Wednesday, August 30th, 2000, at 11 A.M. at Mount Nebo Kendall Memorial Gardens, 5900 S.W. 77th Avenue, Miami, FL.

title: Gore, in Attack on Drug Industry, Focuses on 2 Medicines
description: Vice President Al Gore today escalated his attacks against the pharmaceutical industry, criticizing the makers of two prescription drugs by name, calling for greater competition and promoting his plan for a Medicare drug benefit.

title: Arts Center, Aided by Albany, Is to Rise on Woodstock Festival Site
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the state would help finance plans for a new performing arts and music center on the site of the original Woodstock festival in Bethel, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSCHLAGER, EDNA (NEE COHEN)
description: GOLDSCHLAGER-Edna (nee Cohen). Teacher and educational administrator. On August 27, 2000, at her home. Beloved wife of William, loving mother of Marcia Epstein (Paul) of Gladwyne, PA, and Seth Goldschlager (Isabelle) of Paris, France. Grandmother of Amy and Leonard Feldman, Robin Epstein, Esther, Ezra and Eva Goldschlager. Great-grandmother of Madeline and Benjamin Feldman. Beloved sister of Roseline Dooreck. She was a devoted teacher and administrator at P.S. 173, Queens. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 29, at 1 PM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel at 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Rd.), Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Seth Dooreck Book Fund, c/o Cristine Malhotra, NYU, 25 West 4th St., Room 526, NY, NY 10012 or a charity of your choice. Shiva will be observed at the Goldschlager residence through Friday.

title: Pearl Jam, Progressive As Always
description: ''Do the Evolution'' is a catchy stomper that Pearl Jam tossed into its set on Friday, finishing a three-night stand at Jones Beach. It's also a good description of how Pearl Jam has survived in the age of hype.

title: A Mortal Woods Loses to Garcia, 1-Up
description: Tiger Woods can't win every single time he tees it up. It only seemed that way.

title: Turkish Court Voids Warrant for Islamic Leader
description: In an abrupt reversal, a state security court today dismissed an arrest warrant for an Islamic leader accused by prosecutors of trying to overthrow the secular government.

description: MORSE-Elizabeth Ann. Fifty-four, of Lake Forest, IL, August 26, 2000. Visitation 7:00 P.M to 9:00 P.M. Wednesday August 30, at Wenban Funeral Home, 320 E. Vine Avenue, Lake Forest, IL. Memorial service 11:00 A.M. Thursday, August 31, at Lake Forest Cemetery, N. Lake Road, Lake Forest. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 111 Stewart Ave, Bethpage, NY 11714. Info 847-234-0022

title: EPO Tests Are Approved For Sydney
description: The International Olympic Committee's executive board announced today that it had approved plans to carry out tests for the banned synthetic hormone known as EPO at next month's Summer Olympic Games in Sydney, Australia.

title: Intel Recalls Its Speediest Computer Chip Because of Flaw
description: Intel Recalls Its Speediest Computer Chip Because of Flaw

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOFFETT, LEE
description: MOFFETT-Lee. June 15, 1954 to August 27, 1993. You continue to bring love and joy to us all. Love, Scot

title: Cashing In on a New Era of Opulence; School Seeks Home Buyers Who Want to Live Like Vanderbilts
description: The Lycee Francais de New York, the prestigious school that attracts Europeans and American Francophiles, is selling all six of its buildings on the Upper East Side.

title: VITAL SIGNS: DIAGNOSIS; Staying Vigilant for Signs of Autism
description: All young children should be screened for signs of autism at all routine visits to the pediatrician, the American Academy of Neurology recommended last week in a new set of practice guidelines.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RADIO ONE INC., Lanham, Md., the largest United States broadcaster serving black audiences, said it had completed its acquisition of 12 radio stations from Clear Channel Communications Inc., San Antonio, and AMFM Inc., Dallas, for about $1.3 billion. Including the acquisitions, Radio One owns 51 stations.

title: Bridgestone Asks Venezuelan Dealers to Return Some Tires
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. announced this evening that it had asked its dealers in Venezuela to return unsold 15- and 16-inch light truck tires made there, but the company rebuffed the Ford Motor Company's request for a recall of identical tires already in use in Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador.

title: Clinton to Herald a New Era of Ties on Colombia Trip
description: President Clinton is about to raise the curtain on a new era in United States-Colombia relations with a visit to this Caribbean port on Wednesday, and the acts that follow will probably include shooting at Marxist guerrillas by American-supplied helicopters.

title: X-Rays From Afar Bolster Theory Of a Whirlpool in Empty Space
description: Can empty space be stirred like pancake batter? According to Einstein's theory of relativity, the gravity of a spinning object should tug slightly on the surrounding space and slowly drag it around in circles. Any matter would be pulled along, even though ordinary gravity can only attract matter, not push it sideways.

title: PRICE CUT BY NETPLIANCE
description: The maker of one of the industry's first so-called Internet appliances -- small computers configured just for using the Web and e-mail -- Netpliance, has reduced the price of its i-opener device by $100, to $299. The i-opener 2001 Membership Program includes a monitor, separate keyboard and custom features like a stock tracking program and four e-mail accounts. Customers must also pay $21.95 monthly for Internet access through the company. A few months ago, the company discontinued a $99 introductory price and raised its cost to $399. Customers who paid the higher price can get a $100 credit, the company said. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 19 and a brief report on Aug. 20 in The Week in Review about the sighting of open water at the North Pole misstated the normal conditions of the sea ice there. A clear spot has probably opened at the pole before, scientists say, because about 10 percent of the Arctic Ocean is clear of ice in a typical summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINGERI, NOUSHIE TEYMOURTACHE
description: BERLINGERI-Noushie Teymourtache. On August 26, 2000. Her husband Vincenzo, sons Andrea with Jenny and Alexei with Smadar & sister Patricia will miss forever this extraordinary, beautiful grand lady. Service Thursday, August 31 at 4PM, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations in Noushie's memory may be made to Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, NYC.

title: GERMAN RETAILER SEES PROFIT GROWTH
description: KarstadtQuelle A.G., Germany's largest department-store operator, is forecasting a 15 percent increase in full-year pretax profit as it cuts costs, renovates stores and increases Internet services to attract hesitant German shoppers and rebound from a first-half loss. KarstadtQuelle, created last year when Karstadt's retail business was combined with the Quelle mail-order company, is eliminating jobs and combining purchasing and distribution in an effort to improve profitability. KarstadtQuelle shares rose as much as 0.4 euro, or 1.2 percent, to 33.65.

title: To Train and Keep Good Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Sets Terms for Its Public Offering
description: The leather-goods maker Coach Inc. announced the terms today for its pending initial public offering, which could give it a total market value of as much as $679 million.

title: 30-Year Issue In Biggest Fall In Six Weeks
description: The 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday in its biggest one-day drop in six weeks as stocks rose and as analysts said government debt prices had become expensive after a summer rally.

title: Recordati and Pharmacia in Drug Venture
description: Recordati S.p.A. and the Pharmacia Corporation said today that they would work together to develop drugs to treat overactive bladder and other urological conditions after the Italian drug company discovered potential remedies.

title: Clinton, Visiting Tanzania, Calls for Peace in Burundi
description: President Clinton had hoped to witness the signing of a major peace deal and cease-fire among the warring factions in Burundi, but negotiations to end the country's seven-year civil war bogged down today when some Tutsi minority parties refused to sign an accord with the Hutu majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVAK, RENEE
description: SPIVAK-Renee. The members of the Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of East End Hospice extend heartfelt sympathy to the family of our devoted friend, volunteer and supporter Renee Spivak upon her sudden death. We extend our sincere condolences to her loving husband William, their children, Paula, Jeffrey and Marcy, as well as her brother Joseph Irom. W. Michael Pitcher, President Priscilla A. Ruffin, Director East End Hospice, Inc.

description: New Use for Lard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, RUTH
description: GORDON-Ruth. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, a dear friend who-with her husband, I. Lewis-was a YU Benefactor. Former professionals with the NYC Board of Education, they expressed their dedication to the advancement of Jewish education by establishing the Ruth and I. Lewis Gordon Chair in Jewish Studies at our Bernard Revel Graduate School. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to children, Fred Gordon and Dr. Charles (and Susan) Gordon; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman Board of Directors Bernard Revel Graduate School

title: An Easy Ride for Felons on Probation
description: The violent crime rate in the United States has fallen by about a third since 1993, but it could fall further if we took better control of the millions of criminals who are on probation rather than in prison or jail.

title: Lingering Job Worries Amid a Sea of Plenty; Trying to Cope With Changing Technology
description: Gary Taylor was ready to be a free agent. Just as Internet job-search sites and articles in new-economy magazines encourage people to do, Mr. Taylor had decided to quit his job. In this high-desert city of low unemployment and fast growth, Mr. Taylor, a glass installer, thought he could find something much better.

title: Not-So-New Crop Techniques
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Offers Tips For Hunting Black Bears
description: With New Jersey set to allow bear hunting for the first time in 30 years on Sept. 18 and Sept. 22, state wildlife experts have started holding classes to give hunters tips on finding and killing black bears and hauling carcasses out of the woods.

title: A Woman of Many Faces, Not to Mention Outfits and Wigs
description: When she was a child growing up in South Carolina, Queen Esther recalls in her autobiographical cabaret show, ''Queen Esther: Unemployed Superstar,'' she dreamed of becoming a slinky Las Vegas entertainer like Lola Falana and being a guest star on ''The Mike Douglas Show.''

title: The Kursk Was in Dangerous Company
description: Russia and its navy are justifiably facing criticism for the handling of the Kursk submarine disaster. But simply focusing on the problems in Russia misses a central point: the inherent costs and risks of all nuclear submarines.

title: JAPANESE INSURERS FORM ALLIANCE
description: Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance, Japan's second-largest casualty insurer, and Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance, the No. 2 life insurer, say they will form an alliance to help increase sales and meet growing competition. The two will start selling each other's insurance products and share agents in an agreement that will result in the merger of Dai-Ichi's casualty insurance unit with Yasuda Fire by March 2003, the companies said. The insurers said they had no plans for a complete merger. ''We thought forming an alliance with Dai-Ichi was the best'' to stay ahead of rivals, Hiroshi Hirano, president of Yasuda Fire, said. ''We're aiming to form the strongest insurance group in Japan.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELLY, REVEREND THOMAS J.
description: FARRELLY-Reverend Thomas J. The Board of Directors and staff of the Strycker's Bay Neighborhood Council mourn the loss of Fr. Tom Farrelly, our beloved former President, a fighter for social justice and a champion of housing for the poor in the West Side Urban Renewal Area.

title: Corzine Feels More Pressure To Disclose Tax Returns
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton may have succeeded in pressuring Representative Rick A. Lazio to disclose his tax returns, but the episode could prove embarrassing to her fellow Democrat running for the Senate: Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey.

title: SpectraSite to Purchase Leasing Rights to SBC Towers
description: August 29, 2000

title: Mets Finally Get to Share the View at the Top
description: There has been one poison pitcher for the Mets lately, and Glendon Rusch knows he has been the one. Rusch began the Mets' sprint to first place, which they reached last night when they beat the Houston Astros, 4-2, to pull even with the Atlanta Braves atop the National League East. But any time the Mets stumbled on the way, it seemed as if Rusch put down the tripwire.

title: Sabre Holdings to Buy GetThere, Also Announces Layoffs to Trim Costs
description: August 29, 2000

title: Russians Put Out the Fire In Gigantic Broadcast Tower
description: Dodging falling globs of molten cable, firemen finally put out a searing blaze today that turned the television tower that is Europe's tallest structure, Russia's pride and Moscow's communications hub into a 1,772-foot kitchen match.

title: AOL Government Web Portal Slated for Redesign
description: AOL Government Web Portal Slated for Redesign

title: Hingis Isn't Ready to Revamp Her Game
description: Over the past year, the shots uncoiled by the sculptured Venus and Serena Williams have come at Martina Hingis with the force of uppercuts. But instead of reacting to the sisters' power by putting up a scaffold around her fit but slight physique, Hingis will remain as is.

title: BOTTOMLINE MAKES 2 ACQUISITIONS
description: Bottomline Technologies, an Internet provider of automated invoicing, payments and electronic banking software for companies like Citibank and United Parcel Service, said it would buy the closely held software companies Checkpoint Holdings Ltd. and Flashpoint for about $90 million. The company said the Checkpoint acquisition would allow it to open new distribution channels in Britain and to expand into the rest of Europe. Bottomline, based in Portsmouth, N.H., will pay about $78 million for Checkpoint, based in Reading, England. The company will buy Flashpoint, based in Boston, for about $12 million, including $7.5 million in stock and $4.5 million in cash.

title: VoiceStream To Buy Powertel
description: The VoiceStream Wireless Corporation, a mobile-phone company being bought by Deutsche Telekom A.G., said today that it had agreed to buy Powertel Inc. for about $7.2 billion in stock and assumed debt to fill out its United States network and cut costs.

title: Conflict of Interest Board Rebukes Safir for Free Trip
description: The city's Conflict of Interest Board publicly rebuked former Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday for accepting a free trip to the Academy Awards last year from the chief executive of Revlon.

title: Three Months Into His Senate Campaign, Lazio Releases His Tax Returns
description: After weeks of declining to release his tax returns, Representative Rick A. Lazio tried yesterday to end the swirling speculation about his finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, ANNE
description: METZGER-Anne. 99. Died August 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Radley, and the late Paul, and mother-inlaw of Aase, Cherished grandmother of Juliette, Ingrid, Marianna, Erik and Monique. Greatgrandmother of James Paul. Graveside services on Wednesday 11:00 AM, Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Researchers Raise Fresh Issues in Breast-Feeding Debate
description: A recent study in India suggests that breast-feeding alone may not provide enough sustenance to babies in the developing nations when their mothers are severely malnourished.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MICHAEL, RAYMOND L.
description: MICHAEL-Raymond L. 8/29/99. In loving remembrance, never forgotten. Family and Friends

title: SABRE HOLDINGS SAYS IT WILL CUT 1,200 JOBS
description: The Sabre Holdings Corporation, the largest travel-reservation company, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,200 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, to reduce costs. It also agreed to buy a rival, GetThere Inc., for $757 million to gain business clients. Sabre, based in Fort Worth, will take a $20 million charge in the third quarter for cuts through attrition and dismissals, a move it expects will save about $100 million a year starting next year. Sabre will pay $17.75 a share for GetThere, 46 percent more than the travel reservation company's close Friday. The stock of Sabre fell 94 cents, to $28.81. GetThere climbed $5.06 to $17.19.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AGING; A Healthful Gain When Toto Calls
description: Doctors whose elderly patients are asking to be discharged early from the hospital should consider whether a pet has been left at home, a letter this month in The Annals of Internal Medicine suggests.

title: Capriati Moves On, Calmly
description: Jennifer Capriati tried to serve yesterday as the wind whipped around the darkened Louis Armstrong Stadium during the drizzly first day at the United States Open. Planes roared, thunder boomed and the public address system crackled like gunfire, its startling blasts causing a delay minutes before the rain began pouring down.

title: Judge Agrees to Delay Hearing For 2 Troopers in Shooting Case
description: Prosecutors investigating the 1998 police shooting at the center of New Jersey's racial profiling scandal were granted two more months by a judge today to examine new eyewitness testimony and determine how it might alter their case.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BORDERS GROUP, Ann Arbor, Mich., named Edward Wilhelm, vice president for finance at Borders Inc., to the post of senior vice president and chief financial officer. He succeeds Kenneth Scheve, who is retiring.

title: Tech Giants Weigh In on Napster Controversy
description: August 29, 2000

title: Playoff Opener Is Sept. 15
description: After clinching the Eastern Division title with the 6-4 victory last Saturday night in Dallas, the MetroStars are guaranteed no less than a third-place finish in Major League Soccer and the home-field advantage in the first round of the playoffs.

title: Sports of The Times; Following In the Path Of a Pioneer
description: DAUGHTER hailed mother on the cell phone, in Miami, at the airport, with the flash that was no longer news.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADER MAKES CONCESSION ON MINIMUM WAGE
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert today offered significant concessions to Democrats on a plan to raise the federal minimum wage, moving to end months of stalemate on a popular bill that Republicans feared could damage them at the polls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, ROBERT G.
description: MAYER-Robert G. On Saturday August 26th, 2000, of Chatham Township, NJ, formerly of West Orange, NJ, and Brooklyn, NY. Husband of June Driscoll Mayer and the late Shirley S. Mayer. Father of Robert G. Mayer and J. Ridgeley Weinberg. Grandfather of Ian C., Bret N. and Lyndsey A. Mayer. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a Memorial Service at Wyoming Presbyterian Church, 432 Wyoming Avenue, Milburn on Sunday September 3 at 3:00 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the charity of your choice in his name would be appreciated. For information, The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Milburn Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey.

title: Clemens Is at His Overpowering Best
description: No words were necessary for the Seattle Mariners to confirm to the baseball world tonight that Roger Clemens, even at his advanced age, is a dominant pitcher, one of the best. The swings they produced said everything about the quality of Clemens's overpowering stuff.

title: PANCANADIAN WILL ACQUIRE OIL AND GAS ASSETS
description: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd. agreed to buy oil and natural gas businesses of the Montana Power Company yesterday for $475 million to add fields that will increase its gas production by more than 10 percent. PanCanadian will get properties in Alberta, Montana, Colorado, Oklahoma and Wyoming, as well as three gas pipelines that link Alberta and Saskatchewan to Montana, giving access to United States markets. The fields hold reserves of 550 billion cubic feet of gas and 20 million barrels of crude oil, according to PanCanadian, which is based in Calgary, Alberta. Montana Power, based in Butte, said it planned to invest the proceeds in Touch America, its fiber optic telecommunications business. Montana Power rose 25 cents, to $34.38.

title: Fresh Eyes Find Timeless Magic Within the Desert's Sand
description: With the arrival of photography in the mid-19th century, the desert entered the European imagination. Endless sand dunes in the Sahara became metaphors for the grandiosity of Nature, camel trains and nomadic tribesmen evoked romance and mystery. Of course the first desert photographers were not artists; as explorers and scientists, they were merely bent on recording the unknown and unseen. Yet their work passed one test of art: it made people dream.

title: Children on the Street
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINE, EDWARD
description: PINE-Edward. Beloved father to Harvey and Alan, devoted grandfather to Dianne, and Jill. Loving great grandfather to Zachary and Benjamin. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels at 845-356-8600.

description: To the Editor:

description: The New York Times: AP Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, JUDITH B.
description: SHERMAN-Judith B. On August 29, 2000. Loving wife of 51 years of Paul, devoted mother of Karen and Scott and soon-to-be motherin-law of Kim. Cherished motherin-law of Jim and beloved grandmother of Justin. Fond sister-inlaw of Elaine and her husband Mac. Judy's kindness, selflessness and boundless commitment to helping others will always be missed and remembered. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, Thursday, August 31, at 2:30 PM.

description: EUROPE
