description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOUEL, ARLENE SIMON
description: SHOUEL-Arlene Simon. Devoted wife of Jack Shouel of Bayside, NY, died on August 29. She leaves her son David and daughter-in-law Michele of East Brunswick, NJ; grandchildren Heather and Matthew; sisters Evelyn S. Gilman of West Hartford, CT., and Marilyn Kurland of Rivervale, NJ; niece and nephew Randy Gilman Boll and Henri Boll of Livingston, NJ; Barbara Gilman of Torrington, CT; nephew & niece Barry and Karyn Kurland of Cumberland, ME., and Steven Kurland of Venice, CA; great nephews and nieces Sam, Rachael & Sarah Kurland; Herbie and Adina Bollimovsky. Funeral services will be held at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York, August 31 at 11AM.

title: Words in a Headset Trip the Light Fantastic
description: THEY are all so very curious when Anne Militello lights the lights. Many stop and stare. Some pester her with questions. Others just sit at the curb and watch for half an hour.

title: Hostile Fight Is Under Way For London Stock Exchange
description: OM Gruppen A.B., the owner of the Stockholm stock exchange, began a $1.2 billion hostile bid today for the much bigger London Stock Exchange, touching off the first takeover fight for an exchange.

title: People
description: Steve Dunkley was named to the vacant post of executive creative director at Trone Advertising, Greensboro, N.C. He had been vice president and creative director at the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications.

title: JUDGE ORDERS U.S. TO TURN OVER DATA IN SECRETS INQUIRY
description: A federal judge ordered the government today to turn over what could amount to thousands of pages of classified internal documents to help him determine whether there was evidence that the former Los Alamos nuclear scientist Wen Ho Lee was unfairly singled out for prosecution because he is Chinese-American.

title: THE CHEF; Eberhard Muller
description: WHEN I moved to the United States 18 years ago, corn was a discovery to me, but it seemed shockingly sweet and one-dimensional. I now love all that sweetness, but it took me a while to figure out how to deal with it. Over the years, I have learned that spiciness and acidity are necessary to balance corn sugars. That's why I add chilies to the batter for corn fritters and lime or lemon juice to corn chowder.

title: Clinton Says Disbarment Is Too Harsh a Penalty
description: Even if President Clinton lied under oath to a federal judge about his relationship with a White House intern, disbarment would be too strong a penalty, the president's lawyers said in court papers today.

title: Jones Is Considered Best, And Wants to Prove It
description: The longer Roy Jones Jr. boxes, the more comfortable he feels with his career, and his accomplishments.

title: Democrats Release Their Volley on Prescription Drugs
description: The Democratic National Committee began showing a new commercial dealing with prescription drugs in nine states yesterday, taking on the issue of the month in the presidential campaign a day after the Republican National Committee released its commercial.

title: CBS's 'Black Rock' Building Is Said to Be for Sale
description: Viacom, which acquired CBS this year, plans to sell Black Rock, the elegant granite-clad skyscraper built to symbolize the broadcasting company's view of itself as ''the Tiffany network,'' according to officials involved in the discussions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about charges that Dr. I. Kathleen Hagen murdered her parents, Idella and James Hagen, at their home in Chatham Township, N.J., misspelled the street where they lived. It is Fairmount Avenue, not Fairmont.

title: More 'Band'
description: ABC announced that it will order a second season for a show once thought irretrievably dead: 'Making the Band.'' The network ordered 13 more episodes yesterday and may have it available for mid-season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SYLVIA
description: SHAPIRO-Sylvia. Loving wife of the late Aaron Shapiro and mother of Ted Shapiro, Roberta (Shapiro) Dubner, and Judi (Shapiro) Solomito, passed away the evening of August 28, 2000, at the age of 90. A woman of quiet grace and dignity, she was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother, whose strength and independence will stand as a legacy to her devoted and loving family. She is survived by her sister, Jeanne Vogel, her brother, Nathan Vogel, son, Ted and his wife, Andree, daughter, Roberta, and her husband, Mel, and their two children, Aaron and Adam, and his wife, Kim, daughter, Judi, and her husband, Joe, and their two children, Katie, and Daniel. She will be greatly missed and fondly remembered with love always. Never goodbye. So long, our teacher, our friend, our confidant. The Shapiro Family

title: FINNISH CONCERN BUYS REPAP
description: In its second attempt to buy a production base in North America, the Finnish paper and lumber giant UPM-Kymmene Corporation has agreed to buy Canada's struggling Repap Enterprises for 20 Canadian cents a share, a total of 160 million Canadian dollars ($110 million). Repap's directors and largest shareholders have accepted the offer, which is twice the recent trading price. The assumption of Repap's debt and the cost of good will puts the total value of the purchase at 1.35 billion Canadian dollars ($918 million). In May, the Helsinki company failed with a $5.8 billion for Champion International Corporation. Repap is one-tenth the size of Champion, but its modern coated paper mill in New Brunswick ''will enable UPM-Kymmene to better serve its North American customers,'' said Juha Niemela, the company's president.

title: State Says City Is Checking on Child Abuse Faster
description: Widely criticized and repeatedly sued, the city's child welfare agency is doing a better job investigating child abuse and neglect complaints, a new state report has found.

title: Foster Deal to Buy Beringer Puts Other Wineries in Play
description: The Foster's Brewing Group's $1.14 billion acquisition of Beringer Wine Estates Holdings is likely to prompt a new wave of consolidation among California's premium wineries, analysts and industry executives said today. The deal, they said, effectively puts the ownership of significant independent winemakers in play.

title: CNN's Chief of Domestic News Expected to Announce Resignation
description: Richard N. Kaplan, who has been the president of CNN's United States news-gathering operation since 1997, is expected to announce today that he is leaving the network, executives close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, ANNE
description: METZGER-Anne, 99. Died August 27, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Radley, and the late Paul, and mother-inlaw of Aase, Cherished grandmother of Juliette, Ingrid, Marianna, Erik, Monique and Annabelle. Great-grandmother of James Paul. Graveside services are on Wednesday 11:00 A.M., Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINASH, MARJORIE (NEE SPECTOR)
description: KAMINASH-Marjorie (nee Spector). Died August 29, 2000. Devoted wife of Manny. Beloved mother of Benjamin, Rosanne and Nancy. Dear sister of Ruth and Isabel. Cherished grandmother of Jesse, Joshua, Britt, Maura, Zachary, Liam and Tyler. Services at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, Thursday, August 31 at 12:00 noon.

title: Microsoft to Take New Windows on Unusual Roadshow
description: Microsoft to Take New Windows on Unusual Roadshow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIOFF, FLORENCE
description: BENIOFF-Florence. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the death of Florence Benioff, beloved mother of our distinguished friend and long-time advocate Barbara Friedman, former chair of the Distribution Committee who currently serves on our Board of Directors. Throughout her life she exemplified the highest values of our tradition, which she conveyed with warmth to her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We express our sincere sympathy to her children: Barbara and her husband, Stephen; son Richard and daughter-in-law Mary; and all the members of the family. A woman of valor, she will be missed by all who knew her. May her memory endure for a blessing. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARR, SUSAN PRICE
description: CARR-Susan Price. February 16, 1946-August 30, 1991 (20 Elul). Mother

title: The Braves Give a Shot To a Kiwi
description: Travis Wilson never played in Little League. He never played high school baseball. For that matter, growing up in Christchurch, New Zealand, he never played baseball at all. And yet, in the summer of 1996, the Atlanta Braves sent their Melbourne, Australia, scout to check out Wilson, and a few weeks later they had him under contract.

title: Sound the Warning, Tap the Cymbals, and Shake It All Up
description: For those who have not rocked to the invincible Australian band AC/ DC, allow this critic to instruct you in the pastime enjoyed by millions, including the crowd at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Thursday night.

title: Bush and Gore Stake Claims To Federal Role in Education
description: His campaign has kept careful count. When Gov. George W. Bush goes to Springfield High School in Holland, Ohio, outside Toledo on Thursday, he will be making his 100th visit to a school since he began running for president 14 months ago.

title: Olympics to Police Internet Broadcasting
description: August 30, 2000

title: Aping Biology, Computer Guides Automated Evolution of a Robot
description: For the first time, computer scientists have created a robot that designs and builds other robots, almost entirely without human help.

title: MUSIC SITE MAKING A SHIFT
description: GetMusic, the online site owned by two big music labels, Bertelsmann and Seagram's Universal Music group, is getting out of selling music. GetMusic plans to announce today that it is entering five European countries, but the music sales will be handled by Bertelsmann's BOL unit. GetMusic is also looking for a company to take over the music store it now runs on its original site in the United States, perhaps CDNow, the ailing company that Bertelsmann agreed to buy last month, said Andrew Nibley, GetMusic's chief executive. Mr. Nibley asserted that GetMusic, with 1.2 million users, had strong prospects as a media company, earning money from advertising. For now, it is the No. 1 site for Internet users under the age of 12, thanks largely to its close ties to Britney Spears and N Sync. Saul Hansell

title: Agassi's Extra Concerns
description: Andre Agassi came to this Open occupied with more thoughts than just defending his singles title. In a taped interview with CBS, broadcast after his first-round victory over Alex Kim Monday night, Agassi discussed his sister's and mother's battle with breast cancer and how it has been tough to maintain concentration in preparing for the Open.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Lutece Loses Chef

title: AMAZON.COM TO OPEN FRENCH WEB SITE
description: The online retailer Amazon.com will open a French-language Web site, selling books, music and videos. The new site, Amazon.fr, is the company's third venture outside the United States, after online stores for Britain and Germany. A spokeswoman said the company hoped to serve French speakers outside of France as well. Amazon.com, based in Seattle, will operate the French site from offices in Guyancourt and a distribution center in Orleans. Separately, Amazon.com announced that it had expanded its marketing alliance with America Online. No terms were disclosed. David D. Kirkpatrick

title: A Boy Scout Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tutsi And Hutu Need a Partition
description: This week President Clinton went to Arusha, Tanzania, hoping to witness the signing of a peace agreement ending the genocidal war in Burundi. All too predictably -- and despite the tireless efforts of Nelson Mandela as a mediator -- the only agreement that Burundi's Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups could agree on was essentially meaningless, failing to provide for any genuine sharing of power.

title: Stevenson Also Seeking Maturity
description: Alexandra Stevenson fidgeted on Louis Armstrong Stadium after each unforced error in her first-round match against fourth-seeded Mary Pierce. She wrinkled her nose, smoothed back her curly black hair, which was pulled into a tight ponytail, tugged her cap down over her eyes, and finally, after her worst mistakes of the day, clutched the top of her head with her hands in frustration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Where Judges Learn to Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Hip 'Nightline'
description: ABC's ''Nightline'' is venturing into uncharted territory.

title: Bernard Krainis, 75, Champion of Early Music
description: Bernard Krainis, a noted recorder player and a founding member of the New York Pro Musica Antiqua and the Aston Magna Foundation for Music, two pioneering ensembles for the performance of early music on period instruments, died on Aug. 18 at his home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 75.

title: Judge Orders Texas to Improve Children's Medicaid Programs
description: A federal judge has ruled that Texas' system for administering preventative medicine and certain other health care for children in Medicaid programs is badly flawed, and he has ordered the state to make improvements.

title: Craving Food That Can Kill, or at Least Bite
description: THIS year's most fascinating food book, ''Noodling for Flatheads: Moonshine, Monster Catfish and Other Southern Comforts,'' is not at first glance a book about food. There are no mouth-watering photographs; in fact, the only photo is on the cover, an unappetizing shot of writhing catfish, thorny mouths agape. The lone recipe in 250-odd pages is for ''sugar liquor,'' a potent moonshine distilled from sugar, malt, Fleischmann's yeast and horse feed.

title: Critic's Notebook: Scalpel! Real-Life Drama! Stat!; Tension, Adrenalin Charge but No Scripts as Hospitals Become Stage Sets for Television
description: At 14, Tiffany should be worrying about pimples and braces. But she is also facing a stark choice between possible infertility and possible death. When her father presses her to explain the pain caused by her uterine cancer, she responds in a tone conveying daughterly indulgence and annoyance. ''It's like someone stabbing me from inside,'' she says.

title: Does Religion Have a Public Role?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good Apple
description: I SUPPOSE you could call it an apple epiphany. I was trying a recipe that called for apples, apple butter and apple cider because it's that time of year: the early apples are turning up at roadside stands and farmers' markets. Having grown bored with apples from storage by the end of winter, I look at these with the pleasure associated with the first strawberry of spring or the first peach of summer.

title: Republicans Keep Pressing Census Bureau
description: Even as it seeks to complete the official population count for 2000, the Census Bureau finds itself engaged in a battle with House Republicans over how the bureau is conducting its head count.

title: 'Oz' Steps In
description: When David Chase decided to delay the new season of ''The Sopranos'' to March instead of January, HBO was faced with a hole on its Sunday night lineup. Coincidentally, Tom Fontana, the creator of HBO's other high-rated drama, ''Oz,'' had been told by his production studio in Manhattan that, as he put it, ''They were kicking us out.'' Mr. Fontana's elaborate prison set for ''Oz'' takes up 60,000 square feet and only had a year-by-year lease.

title: Whitman Asks for Health Care and Campaign Finance Laws
description: Cautioning that election-year politics should not be allowed to overshadow New Jersey's pressing public policy issues, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman challenged legislators today to enact modest increases in financing for several health care programs and to tighten campaign finance restrictions when they begin their fall session next week.

title: Women Welcomed Back to Career Path
description: When Gwen Hahn, a stay-at-home mother, decided this summer that it was time to re-enter the work force, she braced herself for rejection.

title: IVAX GETS TENTATIVE APPROVAL FOR GENERIC CANCER DRUG
description: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that it had received tentative regulatory approval for its generic equivalent of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's $1.5-billion-a-year cancer drug Taxol. Shares of Ivax, one of the nation's largest generic-drug makers, have more than doubled this year, partly on anticipation of approval. Ivax shares rose $1.31, to $31.69. The company still faces one more hurdle before it can be cleared to sell its version of the cancer drug. The approval is subject to resolution of legal issues surrounding a Taxol-related patent that emerged earlier this month, the company said. ''We are challenging the listing and validity of this patent and are confident we will prevail,'' said Neil Flanzraich, president of Ivax.

title: Credit Suisse Deal for Donaldson, Lufkin Seen
description: The Credit Suisse Group is expected to announce today that it plans to buy Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a Wall Street investment bank, for about $12.8 billion, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Some See Consolidation as a Sport's Salve
description: While horse racing's marketers have extolled their own performances but called for more consolidation to save the industry, two of the sport's most aggressive executives have driven forward on parallel paths with their own solution: buying and networking racetracks across America.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday in the World Briefing column misidentified the group that said it would try Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, a leader of the militant Islamic group Hamas, who is on Israel's most-wanted list of suspected terrorists. It is the Palestinian Authority that will put him on trial, not Hamas.

title: Fresh Essences, Crystallized
description: GRANITAS are the most primitive frozen desserts, reportedly originating in imperial Rome, where Alpine ice was mixed with fruit juice to make a crunchy, cold treat for the emperors. They have the flavor of sorbet if not the creaminess, and they take very little work and even less equipment to make.

title: Reducing Air Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: Factory Closings in China Arouse Workers to Fury
description: TIANJIN, China, Aug. 29  The brick-walled Meite Packaging factory compound is nearly deserted now, its managers and machines hastily transferred in the last couple of days to a special development zone 30 miles outside this industrial city.

title: DEUTSCHE TELEKOM EXPECTS HIGH COSTS
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., which bid $7.6 billion for a license to offer advance wireless services in Germany, acknowledged today that its profits will be depressed this year as a result of costs in its mobile telephone business. Reporting on half-year results today, the company reported a big jump in net income but one that was caused in large part by special one-time gains like the sale of its stake in Global One. Revenues from its traditional fixed-line telephone business declined almost 13 percent as a result of new competition and sinking prices. Company executives said the mobile business had experienced high costs in recruiting customers and must rapidly begin building new third-generation networks that are expected to transmit data and even video at high speeds. Edmund L. Andrews

title: In the Moral Universe Of Prostitutes' Society
description: THE ROYAL FAMILY

title: New Firm Would Be a Merger Player
description: When investment bankers talk of the competition, they tend to base much of the comparison on one slice of the business: the highflying, much publicized world of mergers and acquisitions. If anything, the expected Credit Suisse acquisition of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette illustrates the importance placed on the multibillion-dollar industry of advising companies on whom they should take over or sell to next.

title: Funny Coincidence: Woody Allen, Meet S. J. Perelman
description: In the recently published ''Most of the Most of S. J. Perelman,'' a portmanteau of Perelmania in the Modern Library Humor and Wit Series, Woody Allen is quoted as saying: ''What happens to you when you read Perelman and you're a young writer is fatal because his style seeps into you. He's got such a pronounced, overwhelming comic style that it's very hard not to be influenced by him.''

title: An Escape to Eden On Vancouver Island
description: SINCLAIR AND FREDERIQUE PHILIP make an unlikely pair. She comes from Cannes, on the lush Cote d'Azur; he grew up on the spare Canadian plains. He likes fish; she likes meat. He is reserved, ironic and intellectual, an international economist by trade; she has an earth-motherly warmth.

title: Ford Facing Ignition Recall In California
description: In a ruling that could deal a blow to the Ford Motor Company, a California judge largely agreed late yesterday with complaints that Ford knowingly installed defective ignition mechanisms in nearly two million vehicles produced from 1983 to 1995.

title: HARMON INDUSTRIES ACCEPTS GENERAL ELECTRIC OFFER
description: Harmon Industries , a maker of train-highway crossing signals, accepted a $386 million acquisition offer from the General Electric Company. Harmon, of Blue Springs, Mo., will become part of GE Harris Railway Electronics, a joint venture between GE Transportation Systems, based in Erie, Pa., and the Harris Corporation, a communications equipment maker in Melbourne, Fla., GE Transportation said. Under the deal, Harmon shareholders would receive 0.527 G.E. share for each Harmon share, or about $31.62 a share, based on G.E.'s Monday closing price of $60 a share. GE Transportation said 93.2 percent of Harmon's shareholders had accepted its offer, which expired on Monday. Originally, G.E., of Fairfield, Conn., offered to exchange 0.542 share for each Harmon share. Shares of Harmon , which had $304.4 million in revenue last year, traded at $31.25 each, down 31 cents.

title: For Prisoner's Parents, a Political Education
description: Wheeling a suitcase behind them, Rhoda and Mark L. Berenson looked like any retired couple off for a vacation as they waited in an American Airlines ticket line at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon. But the man in front of them in line knew otherwise.

title: Business Travel; Big corporate travel-management companies are feeling pretty optimistic these days.
description: I'M sorry, I don't see you in the computer at all,'' the ticket agent at the Continental Airlines counter said. She had been very helpful, tapping away diligently, looking for my name and the electronic ticket that I insisted would be attached to it.

title: Nightmare Society of Wrecked Urban Lives
description: If you asked a sampling of middle-class New Yorkers to describe their worst nightmare, more than a few might reply that it would be to find themselves indigent and homeless on the city's streets. But as Marc Singer's remarkable documentary film ''Dark Days'' illustrates, even the worst nightmare can have descending levels of horror.

title: Sports of The Times; Shot to Be Alone at Top Is Botched
description: WHAT a lovely summer this has been in New York -- at least until Mets started hobbling off the field last night.

title: Clinton Meets Mubarak on Mideast Peace Effort
description: President Clinton tried today to build Arab support for a Middle East peace in an hourlong meeting with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak.

title: Mr. Ray's Ill-Timed Report
description: From the moment he succeeded Kenneth Starr as independent counsel, Robert W. Ray has been aware of the need to conclude the investigations of President and Mrs. Clinton in a fair and timely way, without needlessly disrupting the campaign season. Mr. Ray has dribbled out reports on two elements of a broad inquiry that has lasted more than five years and cost $50 million. Now, according to a story by Neil A. Lewis in Tuesday's Times, Mr. Ray plans to deliver the third and potentially most controversial report in mid-September or shortly thereafter -- in other words, just when the New York senatorial contest between Mrs. Clinton and Representative Rick Lazio is kicking into high gear.

title: Nigeria's Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Renee Orin, 73, Actress in Broadway Musicals
description: Renee Orin, an actress and singer known for her roles in Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 73 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Brazil Begins to Take Role on the World Stage
description: When Henry A. Kissinger visited here as secretary of state in the mid-1970's, his Brazilian counterpart, Antonio Azeredo da Silveira, made a point of escorting him on a tour of Itamaraty Palace, the ultramodern glass and marble headquarters of the Brazilian Foreign Ministry.

title: MARKS & SPENCER'S SHARES FALL
description: Leaked sales figures that were published in a British newspaper sent Marks & Spencer P.L.C. shares reeling to their lowest level since 1990. The Financial Mail published figures showing that general merchandise sales excluding food slipped by more than 6 percent in the week to Aug. 19, compared with a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least one year declined by 7 percent, the newspaper reported. Marks & Spencer, an icon of British retailing, has disputed the importance of the numbers by arguing that one week's results are not conclusive, especially during the summer sale season. Nevertheless, the latest sales results extend a slide that has been gathering steam for two years. Despite the efforts of its new chairman, Luc Vandevelde, the retailer has yet to show substantial improvements. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAULE, QUENTIN F. DR.
description: MAULE-Quentin F. Dr. August 30, 1919-March 16, 2000. Of Maryland and Florida. Died in Sarasota Fla. from Lymphoma Chemo complications. Burial was in Sand Springs, Ok., his birthplace. He received a Doctors Degree in Classical Art History from Berkeley and was an authority on Etruscan Bronzes. He had taught at Universities of Arkansas, Illinois and Fordham. He also worked at Hearst and Time Publications. He retired from the Smithsonian in 1983. In 1942 while attending the University of Chicago he unknowingly worked on the first atomic chain reaction. In 1944 he enlisted in the American Field Service. He donated his art book collection to the University of Arkansas. His love and wisdom are deeply appreciated. Happy birthday David. P.O.Box 297159 Brooklyn,NY 11229

title: CALENDAR
description: Last Call

title: Buying Sirloin? Grill the Butcher
description: A THICK, juicy sirloin steak is an American culinary classic, right up there with cheeseburgers and apple pie. Pound per pound, sirloin far outsells all other steaks bought by home cooks, who prize its relatively tender texture and low price.

title: AT&T Shares Up on Speedy At Home Deal
description: AT&T's stock rose yesterday on the news that the company had incorporated Excite@Home into its operations more quickly than expected, suggesting a speedier move into high-speed Internet services.

title: A Risky American Course in Colombia
description: Colombia's President, Andres Pastrana, deserves American support for his efforts to reduce drug production and trafficking and begin peace negotiations with Marxist guerrillas. Mr. Pastrana's political position is shaky at the moment, and President Clinton's visit to the port of Cartagena today may help reinforce it. But the Clinton trip will also inaugurate a misguided expansion of American support to Colombia's security forces.

title: Going Beyond Sushi, on an Unlikely Street
description: IF West 13th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues were a jungle path, its sidewalks would be overgrown with vines. It doesn't seem to get much foot traffic, and as a consequence, Miyagi, a pretty little Japanese restaurant, seems overlooked. But if you can find your way to its small entryway, the reward is a restaurant of relaxed civility, with food that is tasty, reliable and sometimes exciting.

title: The Game of 'Survivor'
description: To the Editor:

title: First Central Lab for Linux Research Planned
description: Thousands of computer hobbyists and software developers who together honed the Linux operating system from their homes and small offices could soon have their first central physical lab for testing new versions of the operating systems and application programs built to run on it.

title: Ford Chief Executive Declines to Testify in Congressional Inquiry on Bridgestone Tires
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its chief executive and president, Jacques A. Nasser, had declined invitations to testify next week before Congressional committees investigating tire failures, mainly on Ford Explorers. This prompted criticism from one lawmaker who is leading inquiries into the recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires.

title: Nassau County Is to Begin Spraying Against West Nile Virus
description: Nassau County has decided to begin ground spraying of pesticides to fight the West Nile virus, becoming one of the last counties in the metropolitan New York area this year to do so, after finding infected mosquitoes within its boundaries.

title: Clinton Defends Colombia Outlay
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Aug. 30  President Clinton made a one-day visit today to this secure oasis of Colombia to lend backing to the nation's counternarcotics program.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Board Administrator Going to N.Y.U.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Media Talk column in Business Day on Monday about an MSNBC billboard promoting ''The News With Brian Williams'' misstated a comparison between the average audience for the program's 9 p.m. showing and what MSNBC says was its cumulative audience during April. The average nightly audience of 203,000 is one-206th of the cumulative audience of 42 million, which includes the number of different viewers tuned in to at least one minute of any of its showings, including four repeats a night. It is not one-20,500th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, RUTH
description: KURTZ-Ruth. On August 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Michael Kurtz. Dear mother of Dr. Robert S. Kurtz and Daniel Kurtz. Cherished grandmother of Holly, Elizabeth, Amy, Ben, Peter and Michael. Mother-in-law of Ketly and Elizabeth. We all share her cherished ideals. Graveside service Thursday, August 31st, 1:45PM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Mattel Named in Lawsuit Over Toy Patent
description: Mattel Inc. and its Fisher-Price unit are violating a technology patent of General Creation L.L.C. used in Mattel's Winnie the Pooh reading toy, the smaller toy company has contended in a federal lawsuit.

title: Lieberman Explains Call For Bigger Role for Religion
description: Explaining his call for a greater role for religion in public life, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman says he meant it as a matter of public discourse, not public policy, adding that he does not consider those who are not religious to be amoral or unfit for public office.

title: EATON TO SELL AUTOMOTIVE SWITCHES UNIT
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its automotive business that makes switches that control windows and door locks and focus on its drivetrain and specialized sensors operations. Eaton, one of the world's biggest makers of hydraulic equipment, hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to advise it on the sale. Eaton is selling the unit as automakers look to use suppliers that are able to produce entire electronic systems rather than individual components.

title: Turning Baking Into Cooking
description: FOR Philippe Conticini, the executive chef at Petrossian in Paris and New York, lavishing salt on desserts was a hurdle passed long ago. He has since moved on to putting tuna, coconut and lime zest into batter and serving it as cake.

title: When Designated Drivers Piloted Chariots
description: AT Beaucaire, near Nimes in the south of France, the Durand family operates two wineries. One is a typical modern winery producing red, white and rose wines under the Chateau des Tourelles label. The other is a re-creation of a Roman winery that thrived on the site 2,000 years ago and whose remains were unearthed only 20 years ago.

title: Nickelodeon Shifts
description: For the first time in 10 years, Nickelodeon, the top-rated network on basic cable, is changing its look. Starting in early September, executives said yesterday, they will introduce new promotional spots and graphics for its children's programming. They said the spots would be less erratic and more uniform than they are currently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMLEY, ELIZABETH A.
description: GORMLEY-Elizabeth A. Of Florida (formerly of Brooklyn and Elizaville, N.Y.) on August 26, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Donald J. Fond sister of the late Virginia Kilcoin. Sister-in-law of Jane Cosgrove. Loving aunt of Mary Elizabeth Woodburn, Amanda McGehee and Vincent Cosgrove. Funeral from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave. on Friday, 9:45AM. Funeral mass 10:30AM St.Vincent Ferrer Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday 8-9:45AM.

title: Mexico's Answer To the Truffle
description: WHOEVER figured out that this stuff was edible?'' asked one of my guests, who was scooping up a savory mixture based on the culinary oddity huitlacoche. Good question.

title: Book Details U.S. Spying on Wartime Exiles From Germany
description: During the 1930's and 40's hundreds of German writers -- Jews and non-Jews -- fled Hitler and sought refuge in the United States. But though they were given asylum, in the 1940's the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other government agencies spied on them, intercepting their mail and sometimes keeping tabs on their sex lives, reports a book to be published in October by Yale University Press.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEDGWICK, THE REVEREND HAROLD BEND
description: SEDGWICK-The Reverend Harold Bend, of Boston and Lexington, MA, formerly of NYC, on August 27, 2000. Uncle of Emily Sedgwick Bagwill of Middletown, RI, Catherine Sedgwick Sanders of Cumberland Foreside, ME, Pamela Gibson Farrar of Richmond, VA and Alice Gibson Stothers of Los Gatos, CA. Brother of the late Edith Sedgwick Gibson, Charles and Theodore Sedgwick Jr. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Memorial services in Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston, Thursday, September 7 at 11 AM. Memorial services will also be held in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Stockbridge, Saturday, October 7 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be sent to St. Paul's Church, Main Street, Stockbridge, MA. 01262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBELL, LOUIS
description: LOBELL-Louis. Died on August 27, 2000; beloved father of Sharon Lobell Comiteau, Arline Lobell Zeldman, Bonnie Bello and Ian Ross Lobell. Beloved grandfather of Robin, Lauren, Jennifer, Chad, Michael, Kristin, and Jason. Greatgrandfather of Zachary, Alexandra, and Juliana Rose. He will be missed & remembered with love always. Services held Wednesday at 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Experts Doubt New York Plan To Fingerprint for Medicaid
description: When electronic fingerprinting was introduced five years ago, it caught the imagination of politicians who saw it as the ultimate high-tech weapon to fight welfare fraud.

title: NEW VERTICALONE BUSINESS
description: VerticalOne, a unit of the S1 Corporation, is expected to announce today that it will provide account-aggregation services to Yahoo and to Wells Fargo bank, allowing them to provide a single place on the Internet where their customers can keep all of their financial data, like the balances in their bank and brokerage accounts, frequent-flier programs and credit cards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, EVA (BOCIAN)
description: RAPPAPORT-Eva (Bocian). On August 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Jay Perry (Barbara) and Edith (Joseph) Amorese. Cherished grandmother of Marc (Sherry), Matthew, Michelle, David and Lona Allda, and the late Jake. Great-grandmother of Morgan, Abigail and Maxwell. Devoted aunt. Sister of Gerald. Survivor of the Holocust. Executive Director or the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives. Board member of N.A.H.C. Services Wednesday 12 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Donations in lieu of flowers, U.S. Holocust Memorial Museum.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Camera-Obscuring On Campaign Trail

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMMISA, MARIAN A.
description: CAMMISA-Marian A. A resident of Croton-on-Hudson. Died July 22, 2000 at Harlem Valley Hospital Center, she was 83. Miss Cammisa was born in Dobbs Ferry, NY on January 21, 1917 and was the daughter of Frank and Maria Rago Cammisa. Miss Cammisa was a former legal secretary and sang opera at Carnegie Hall and in May 2000 made a television commercial for ''Adopt-a-Pet'' month. Miss Cammisa is survived by one brother Sam Cammisa, two sisters Yolanda Denman and Angela Reilly and several nieces and nephews. Donations may be sent to Pompei Church, Palisade Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522.

title: First, There Was Parrying With Mother
description: Arlene Stevens remembers the day six years ago when her mother dragged her off the couch in their Rochester living room, bundled her into the car and drove her to the local fencing center as she protested loudly the entire way.

title: THE BOSS; Power of Contrary Thinking
description: My biggest passion is flea markets, trash and treasure, vintage stores and bric-a-brac. I'm not a collector of antiques, as such. That's the next level up. One of my most treasured items is a handbag I got in the markets in Marrakesh. It's made out of silver. It's more like a sculpture, really. I was terrified that when I went to, say, India, I would see four million of these things and think, ''Oh my God, here I am thinking it was so special.'' But I've never seen anything like it again.

title: New York Investor and A.I.G. to Increase Stake in Hyundai
description: A group of Western investors, including Wilbur L. Ross, a specialist in corporate rescues, and the American International Group, plan to increase their investment in three financial affiliates of the Hyundai Group to $1 billion so as to gain a firmer hold on Hyundai Securities, South Korea's largest brokerage house.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Transmeta's stock offering may buck a cooling trend.
description: IN January, a semiconductor company called Transmeta promised technology that would allow laptop computer batteries to last a full workday. Though such long-lasting laptops are at least weeks away from their planned delivery date -- Transmeta has signed deals with prominent computer makers, including I.B.M. and Sony -- the company has filed for an initial offering.

title: Metro Business; Hispanic TV Pioneer To Work at WXTV
description: J. J. Gonzalez, the first Hispanic journalist in the New York television industry, will return to the market as the managing editor of ''Noticias 41,'' the award-winning evening news program of WXTV, the local affiliate of Univision, the Spanish-language television network, officials said yesterday. He begins Sept. 4.

title: Lieberman's Revival of the Religious Left
description: When we hear the term ''religious activists'' on the evening news, we think automatically of Jerry Falwell, Pat Robertson and a parade of conservative Christian evangelicals. But now Joe Lieberman, a Jewish, mostly liberal Democrat running for vice president, is talking about God, and as he does so, reviving a potent tradition of a different kind of religious activism, one that that had lain dormant since an assassin's bullet struck down Martin Luther King in 1968. When Mr. Lieberman called for a ''new spiritual awakening'' in America in a sermon Sunday at a black church, he nourished the hope of those more than ready for a rebirth of a nationally prominent religious left.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Hampton, N. H.; Erie, Pa., and Cincinnati

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREIB, BIRDIE
description: TREIB-Birdie. In loving memory of Birdie Treib, beloved mother of Patricia Neuwirth, grandmother of John & Daniel Neuwirth, motherin-law of Alan Neuwirth and sister of Reina and Mort Adler. Funeral service 11:30AM Wednesday, August 30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Many, Many in India Want to Be a Millionaire
description: Maqbool Ahmed has dreams of instant wealth, which ordinarily would require a mighty burst of imagination from a man living in the Bombay slum of Geeta Nagar, a hideous warren of hovels where the air reeks of kerosene and fish, and there are only 24 toilets for 6,000 people.

title: Mets Lose but Hold Share of First
description: Al Leiter pitched and Moises Alou swung and a foul ball came next. It happened nine times in one at-bat in the third inning last night -- on sliders and curveballs and fastballs to all spots -- and if it was painful for a Mets fan to watch, imagine how Leiter felt.

title: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING
description: THE INTEREST GROUPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVAK, RENEE
description: SPIVAK-Renee. The NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, Department for Orthopaedic Surgery mourns the passing of the mother of our respected colleague Jeffrey Spivak. Our heartfelt sympathy to Jeff's father, William, to his sisters Paula and Marcy, and to all members of his family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Chairman William Jaffe, M.D. Vice-Chairman Victor H. Frankel, M.D., PhD. President Emeritus

title: Wife Visits American Held by Moscow
description: The wife of an American who has been in jail here for five months on espionage charges came here today with her congressman to call on the Russian government to let Western doctors examine her husband, who has bone cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREK, ROSLYN
description: KOREK-Roslyn. The Law Firm and staff of Gersowitz, Libo and Korek extend deepest condolences to Jeff Korek our (esteemed) partner, his father Seymour, and their entire family on the passing of Jeff's mother Roslyn. May her memory be a blessing to all those who knew and loved her.

title: Answers to 'Why Aren't We Moving?'
description: While officials of New Jersey Transit know they cannot escape Murphy's Law, they think they can at least warn their riders when it is about to play havoc with their daily commute.

title: Lazio Suggests Mrs. Clinton Lied About His Record
description: Representative Rick A. Lazio charged yesterday that Hillary Rodham Clinton had deliberately distorted his voting record in Congress, and he prepared to unveil an advertisement today that aides said would feature Senator John McCain harshly challenging Mrs. Clinton's fund-raising practices in New York.

title: KEY PRODUCTION IN $22 MILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
description: The Key Production Company, an explorer and producer of oil and gas, agreed to buy a rival, Columbus Energy, for $22.7 million. Columbus Energy shareholders will receive 0.335 share of Key Production for each Columbus Energy share held. That values Columbus Energy shares at about $5.97 each, 10 percent lower than Friday's closing price. The shares did not trade on Monday. Columbus Energy had 3.8 million shares outstanding as of July 12. Key Production will pay $22.7 million in its shares and assume $4.9 million in Columbus Energy debt, said Michael Logan, a Columbus spokesman.

title: South Africa Fears Past Still Breeds Racist Evils
description: The poor of South Africa made their way from remote farms and rural villages last month to testify before the government hearings around the country. And in their painstaking accounts of modern-day wrongs, there rang disturbing echoes of this country's ugly history.

title: Serena Williams Marches On, Then Ducks
description: White lines marked off the court inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, but Serena Williams arrived to defend her United States Open title as if stepping onto a dance floor, wearing a party dress from a Woodstock reunion.

title: There's a New Flavor in Town and It's . . . Salt; Chefs' New Obsession: Grains From the Wild
description: ALL of a sudden, the city's chefs have gone completely salt crazy.

title: India Unsettled by the Prime Minister's Fragile Health
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, the grandfatherly face of Hindu nationalism, is having health problems, and they are creating unease here in India's capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFLER, GERTRUDE H.
description: SCHAEFLER-Gertrude H. Died at home on August 29, 2000 in her 97th year, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Leon Schaefler. Devoted mother of Roberta S. Adler-Lazar, and Kathryn S. Pershan. Fond mother-inlaw of Richard H. Pershan and Nat Lazar. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetary, Saddlebrook, NJ, on Thursday August 31, 2000, at 11:00. The family will be at Kathryn's home, 1435 Lexington Avenue, on Thursday evening, August 31st, from 5:00 to 7:00 to receive callers. Instead of flower, please make a contribution to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHEL, WILLIAM S., JR.
description: CASHEL-William S., Jr. On behalf of the entire Poly Prep Community, the Board of Trustees of Poly Prep Country Day School wishes to express our sadness at the passing of William S. Cashel, Jr., a loyal and dedicated member of the class of '37. We extend our condolences to his widow, Marie and her family and friends.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Aug. 19 about Jesse Sheidlower, who heads the North American office of the Oxford English Dictionary, misstated one of his publishing credits. He was the editor of the book ''The F-Word,'' not its author. The article also omitted part of the title of the reference work from which that book was largely derived. It is The Random House Historical Dictionary of American Slang.

title: Rackets Law Can Be Used Against Police In Los Angeles
description: A federal judge has ruled that the government's anti-racketeering statute, created to deal with drug bosses and organized crime figures, can be used in lawsuits against the troubled Los Angeles Police Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLIMM, JAMES YORK
description: GLIMM-James York. Dr. Glimm, a former Garden City, NY. resident, passed away on August 20, 2000, at home in Milerton, PA., after a heroic battle with colon cancer. He was 58 years old and a son of James M. & Dorothy York Glimm. Dr. Glimm is survived by his wife, Marjorie (Kuentz-Hoffman), his children Bronwen, Gavin, Jordan and Alyssa. Two stepdaughters Coty Hoffman & Kristen Albaugh and his grandchildren Sierra, Ukiah and Kreegan, his sisters Barbara and Nancy Glimm. Contributions may be sent to James Glimm Colon Cancer Awareness Fund at the Arnot Ogden Foundation, 600 Roe Avenue, Elmira, New York 14905.

title: Minority Enrollment Rises In Florida College System
description: The first freshman class selected to Florida's state college system since Gov. Jeb Bush put an end to race-based admissions has shown, instead of a decrease in minority enrollment, an increase of 12 percent.

title: SWISS WIRELESS BIDS
description: The Swiss government has authorized all of the 10 contenders who sought to bid for the third-generation wireless licenses due to be auctioned on Nov. 13. Switzerland anticipates raising as much as $3.5 billion from the sale of the four licenses, the federal communications commission said. Among the bidders are Swisscom A.G., the country's largest phone company, and its smaller rivals, Orange Communications S.A. and a company owned by Diax A.G. and SBC Communications of the United States. A similar wireless license auction in neighboring Germany raised five times the amount expected.

title: Schools Chancellor Orders Community Groups Evicted to Make Room for Classes
description: Seeking to free more classroom space, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday he had ordered the city's 32 superintendents to evict any nonprofit groups, community organizations or police offices from schools if they are not needed for the instruction of students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANSKY, DANIEL, M.D.
description: CHANSKY-Daniel, M.D.-The Queens County Psychiatric Society mourns the loss of its esteemed member and past president and extends heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family.

title: Prime Time Fine, Bush Says, For 3 Presidential Debates
description: Disputing suggestions that his campaign was hesitant to commit to prime-time presidential debates, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that he wanted all of his debates with Vice President Al Gore to be held in evening hours when television audiences were largest.

title: Gilbert de Botton, 65, Money Manager for Rich, Dies
description: Gilbert de Botton, a Swiss banker who helped change the way the wealthy manage their money and became a significant figure in the London worlds of modern art and old-book collecting, died Saturday at his house in the South of France. He was 65.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about children in a Fresh Air Fund program visiting the singer Mariah Carey at a farm in Canada misstated the location of the Copps Coliseum, one of the locations for a film she is making. The coliseum is in Hamilton, Ontario, not Toronto.

title: Industry Groups Education Study Draws Conclusions and Critics
description: August 30, 2000

title: MasterCard is shifting its efforts to market to Hispanics to a new level and another language.
description: HOW do you reach people in the fastest-growing segment of the American population? Simple. Speak their language.

title: Positive Trends Hidden In SAT and ACT Scores
description: THE College Board released new national average SAT scores yesterday. Math is up three points to 514, with verbal scores unchanged at 505.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, JAN ARNHEIMER
description: JACOBS-Jan Arnheimer. Age 83, in Miami Beach, on August 26th. Beloved mother of Jil and Joel Sneider. Devoted grandmother of Emily and Peter.

title: BET IS BUYING 360HIPHOP
description: BET.com, a Web site created in February as adjunct to the Black Entertainment Television cable network, has reached a tentative agreement to buy a key competitor, 360HIPHOP.com. That Web site, started in June by Russell Simmons, the founder of Def Jam Records, is geared to music trends and information. Under the agreement, the two companies will combine business operations, but maintain separate Web sites. BET.com is ranked among the most popular African-American-oriented sites on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNECKE, MILDRED DUNCAN
description: WARNECKE-Mildred Duncan. Of Maplewood, NJ, on Sunday, August 27, 2000. Wife of the late Dr. Rudolph E. Warnecke. Mother of Miss Suzanne Warnecke, Mrs. Robert E. Harris & the late Donald Bruce Warnecke. Also survived by four grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Memorial service will be held in Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple St., Summit, NJ, on Thursday, August 31, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Central Presbyterian Church, Christian Education Fund, Summit, NJ 07901

title: Popular Burmese Leader Tests Wills With Junta
description: Her car has been shunted to the side of the road. The air has been let out of its tires. The military authorities say they are offering her food and medical care, but they are also making sure she is going nowhere.

title: Indonesia Sets the Legal Stage for Suharto Corruption Trial
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 30  As Indonesia prepared to put its fallen leader, Suharto, on trial here Thursday, the government made elaborate preparations, converting the auditorium of a state ministry into a courtroom, enlisting 1,200 police officers for security, and even requisitioning a helicopter to evacuate Mr. Suharto in case of a medical or other emergency.

title: Miscellany
description: ACCENT Marketing Services, Louisville, Ky., part of the Maxxcom unit of the MDC Corp., and Newspaper Services America, Naperville, Ill., part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., are forming a joint venture, MediaVenture, Louisville, to focus initially on direct marketing services for the newspaper industry.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: COCA-COLA CO., Atlanta, named Jeffrey Dunn, deputy group president at Coca-Cola North America, to the post of president at the North America unit. He succeeds Ralph Cooper, who is retiring.

title: Back Seat for Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Queen, Not Prisoner -- Just the President's Wife
description: Laura Bush and Tipper Gore might want to pay a visit to the First Ladies' Hall at the Smithsonian Institution. In this exhibit, usually crowded with tourists, first ladies are known by their china and their clothes, not their resumes. The gowns of the nation's first five first ladies are even displayed on headless mannequins, symbolizing, perhaps, that heads are not really necessary in this role.

title: Giants' Williams To Start At Safety
description: The Giants had targeted Shaun Williams to be their starting free safety even before training camp began. His summer, though, was ruined after a sprained left big toe forced him to miss all four preseason games. Still, on Sunday, in the season opener, Williams will make his first National Football League start.

title: Voters Seize Opportunity to Question Bush Online
description: August 30, 2000

title: A Narrowing Gateway at CUNY: English Skills
description: Business was brisk on Monday at City College's English as a second language department -- the headquarters for teaching English to foreign students.

title: Steak and Chips, and a Side of Politics
description: Back in the old days, before Microsoft met the Justice Department, people in the computer business could not tell a lobbyist from a congressman. (Hint: one wears tasseled loafers.)

title: Condemned Again for Old Crimes; Deportation Law Descends Sternly, and Often by Surprise
description: At 21, Alejandro Bontia had a 16-year-old girlfriend whose mother was angered that her teenage daughter was involved in a relationship. She informed the police, and Mr. Bontia found himself charged with sexual contact with a minor and given four years' probation. Mr. Bontia, a Web designer who is now 34 and married and has a son, never had another brush with the law. The youthful dalliance was, at least in his mind, chalked up to the foibles of adolescence.

title: Caveat Investors
description: It may be tempting to put all the blame for the latest Wall Street hoax on the frenetic pace of today's financial and news cycles. But this was also a case of greed taking advantage of lax vigilance.

title: BILLITON RAISES STAKE
description: The British mining company Billiton P.L.C., one of the largest producers of aluminum worldwide, agreed to increase its stake in an Australian aluminum refinery by buying the majority interest of Alcoa Inc. for $1.49 billion. The deal follows Billiton's announcement Friday that it would buy Rio Algom, a Toronto-based mining and metals distributor, for $1.2 billion. Alcoa must sell its stake in the Worsley aluminum refinery to satisfy anti-trust regulators as part of its acquisition earlier this year of the Reynolds Metals Company, which owns 56 percent of the Western Australia-based Worsley. Billiton already owns 30 percent of the Worsley refinery. Suzanne Kapner

title: MANAGEMENT: Beyond the Glass Ceiling; Women's M.B.A. Program Is Redefining Its Mission
description: They were pioneers, those first women to set foot in a business school. They struggled to be taken seriously in classes and rarely read a positive word about businesswomen in their studies. Then two Harvard Business School professors, fed up with a male culture they thought antagonized female students, as well as female academics like themselves, had a radical idea: a business school just for women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASS, ELI
description: CASS-Eli. Of North Miami, Florida, formerly Brooklyn. Loving father of Russell and Donald, and grandfather of Susan Cass. Passed away after a short illness on August 29. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the United Cerebral Palsy Foundation where Eli spent time volunteering his services to children with cerebral palsy in North Miami.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: In the Name Of China, Not Peace
description: IT was wondrously quiet at Tibet House yesterday morning, which hardly came as a surprise. The cultural center, on West 15th Street, is a place for study, for contemplating sacred art, for silent meditation.

title: Beneath Herald Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Says Key to Drug Fight Is for U.S. to Tame Demand Here
description: President Andres Pastrana said today that Colombia cannot put a dent in international drug trafficking until the United States and other countries do much more to control their citizens' appetite for drugs.

title: Technology Briefings
description: Technology Briefings

title: Gazetteer of Italian Fare, With Eccentricity
description: IN the race to unearth the world's least reclaimable dish, Roc may have scored an upset victory. Meatloaf has gained classic status. Macaroni and cheese can be found in fine Parisian restaurants. Mashed potatoes have been through so many conceptual contortions that they qualify as haute cuisine. It's getting harder to shock. But Roc has succeeded. ''Every Thursday we have spaghetti and meatballs,'' a waiter told me with a sly smile one evening. ''It's a Roc tradition.''

title: Philippine Muslim Rebels Seize American
description: Muslim rebels who thrive on kidnapping seized an American on a remote Philippine island and threatened today to kill him if the United States did not meet unspecified demands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, RALPH
description: ROSENBLUM - Ralph. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Ralph Rosenblum, and offer their deepest sympathy to his wife Lucille, his children and the entire Rosenblum family. Alpine Country Club Harvey Nagin President

title: GATEWAY TRIES TAX PROMOTION
description: Hoping to take the no-tax edge away from pure direct-sales rivals like Dell, Gateway will temporarily absorb the sales tax for consumers who buy desktop and notebook PC's at most of its 290 Country Store locations. The promotion, which began yesterday and ends tomorrow, was started after Gateway executives saw sales spike when states like Pennsylvania and South Carolina offered sales-tax blackout periods to their residents. ''The response to that program was huge, so we decided to extend it to additional states,'' said Brad Williams, a company spokesman. Catherine Greenman

title: GERMAN GROWTH QUICKENS
description: The German economy expanded at its fastest rate in years during the second quarter, further increasing the chance that the European Central Bank will raise interest rates when its board of governors meets on Thursday. The government reported that the economy grew 1.1 percent in the three months ended in June, compared with the quarter a year earlier; that translates to an annualized growth rate of more than 4 percent. Exports remained the biggest source of expansion and received support from the weak euro, which makes German goods cheaper in world markets. But consumer spending expanded as well, suggesting the beleaguered economy may finally be reviving.

title: Rams Are Inspiring Underdogs in Waiting
description: When was the last time you heard these words: Teams are dreaming of becoming the St. Louis Rams.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS TO BUY GYLLING, A BATTERY MAKER
description: Johnson Controls Inc., the largest maker of automotive batteries in North America, agreed to buy Gylling Optima Batteries A.B. of Sweden for about $62 million in cash to expand its product line. The company will offer 20 Swedish kronor ($2.13) for each of Gylling's shares outstanding, about 79 percent more than the 11.2 kronor price when trading was suspended last Wednesday because of the pending acquisition. Johnson Controls did not say how many shares outstanding Gylling has. The Gylling family, which owns 70 percent of the shares, has accepted the offer, Johnson Controls said. The purchase is expected to be completed by Nov. 30.

title: There's a New Flavor in Town and It's . . . Salt; Dessert Traditions Go Over the Shoulder
description: IT takes a certain kind of person to season sweet roasted pineapple with salt, place it atop a salty nut brittle and serve it as a kind of tart. Or to shower a molten chocolate cake with coarse salt when it comes out of the oven. Or to saute cantaloupe, sprinkle it with fleur de sel and serve it with a spoonful of sorbet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLONIM, JAY
description: SLONIM-Jay. Died August 29, 2000. Devoted husband to his loving wife, Evelyn. Caring father to his cherished daughter, Jillian, and father-in-law of Larry. Former Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York and Special Assistant to the Attorney General. He will be truly missed.

title: Mental State Is Considered in Dual Killing
description: The doctor charged last weekend with smothering her elderly parents in Chatham Township, N.J., was being treated for manic-depression about this time last year, court records show. And today, lawyers for the Harvard-educated urologist, Dr. I. Kathleen Hagen, said that they were developing a defense based on her mental condition.

title: Power of Contrary Thinking
description: My biggest passion is flea markets, trash and treasure, vintage stores and bric-a-brac. I'm not a collector of antiques, as such. That's the next level up. One of my most treasured items is a handbag I got in the markets in Marrakesh. It's made out of silver. It's more like a sculpture, really. I was terrified that when I went to, say, India, I would see four million of these things and think, "Oh my God, here I am thinking it was so special." But I've never seen anything like it again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, WILLIAM
description: SCHNECK-William. August 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Sally Shank Bloch. Devoted brother of Helen Laffer and Pepi Kahn. Services private.

title: Teams Battling Over Simpkins
description: The Knicks, still searching for depth in the frontcourt, have an interest in Dickey Simpkins, a free agent who has played most of his six-year career with the Chicago Bulls. Simpkins, a 6-foot-9-inch power forward/center, is best known for serving as a part-time bruiser and screen setter for Michael Jordan during the Bulls' run to the 1996, 1997 and 1998 championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOONAN, MARYANN K.
description: NOONAN-Maryann K. On August 28, 2000 of New York, NY, formerly of Garden City , NY. Beloved daughter of James Noonan and the late Mary Noonan. Loving sister of James C., Marybeth, Brian, Trisha and Daniel. Dear aunt of four nephews. Also survived by many other loving relatives and friends. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St. Garden City, Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's RC Church, Garden City, Friday 11AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Joseph's School, 450 Franklin Ave, Garden City, NY 11530, appreciated.

title: A Second Chance to Save a Franchise
description: While hanging out with his teenage son at a recent San Diego Chargers practice, Alan Ensley, a fan of the team, spoke for a city still waiting for its football savior.

title: Supreme Court Continues Stay Barring Medical Use of Marijuana
description: The Supreme Court continued a ban today on the distribution of marijuana for medical purposes in California, signaling that it might consider the issue in its fall term.

title: Handheld Computer Virus Found
description: Handheld Computer Virus Found

title: I.B.M. Wins Job in India
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had won a multiyear agreement to handle the computing needs of the Tata Iron and Steel Company of India. Terms were not disclosed, but I.B.M. said it believed the arrangement was the largest information technology services contract in India. I.B.M. will manage the company's data center, computer networks, technical support and technology upgrades.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE-Allan. I will never understand why you, so full of life, were meant to leave this world so soon. You live on in my heart and soul and I thank you for all that you taught me. You were the best Daddy ever. Love, Catherin

title: Commercial Real Estate; From Industry to Pastry: A Business Park Evolves
description: The old Atlas Terminals industrial park, on Cooper Avenue in Queens, has long had a knack for reinventing itself. But the park's latest transformation efforts are unlike anything its late founder, Henry Hemmerdinger, might have imagined.

title: A Name and a Date for Sonys New P.D.A.
description: A Name and a Date for Sony's New P.D.A.

title: Organizers Say Alcohol Ban At Parades Is Unfairly Applied
description: Several organizers and participants in the West Indian American Carnival Parade called on the Giuliani administration to allow beer and wine at the annual event in Brooklyn this Monday.

title: Metro Business; Vanguard Adding Flights
description: Vanguard Airlines said yesterday that it would add two daily nonstop flights between La Guardia Airport and its hub at Kansas City International Airport beginning Oct. 1.

title: Americans Advance at Bridge Tournament
description: Both United States teams were in qualifying positions at the World Bridge Championships here today.

title: South Koreans Impatient For Return of Prisoners
description: SEOUL  After Amnesty International reported in 1994 that a former South Korean schoolteacher named Ko Sang Moon was a prisoner in a North Korean concentration camp, Mr. Ko appeared on North Korean television saying he was married and doing fine. His wife in South Korea committed suicide.

title: Rafter, A 2-Time Champion, Is Ousted
description: Patrick Rafter lives on the tortured edge when his matches turn into a test of wills. In the murky hours of midnight at the United States Open, Rafter has crafted such a legacy. He will have to pack it home with him, back to Australia, a sour parting gift from early this morning.

title: WASHINGTON SPLIT DEEPENS IN DEBATE OVER MISSILE PLAN
description: The Pentagon and the State Department are sharply divided over how far work on a limited national missile defense system could proceed before the United States would be required to give formal notice that it was violating a crucial arms control treaty with Russia.

title: Clinton Handled Military Poorly, Cheney Contends
description: ATLANTA Aug. 30  Dick Cheney, the Republican vice-presidential candidate and former defense secretary, delivered a harsh assessment today of the condition of the armed forces under President Clinton, accusing him of "running down" a military that has succeeded in recent conflicts only because of the military buildup of past Republican administrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUFELD, GEORGIA
description: KUFELD-Georgia. On August 29, 2000. Beloved wife and life partner of Henry (Buddy) Kufeld. Sister to Sarayom and Margot Fletcher. Aunt and great-aunt to many adoring nieces and nephews. Friend and guardian of all God's creatures. May her memory be a blessing. Funeral, August 30, at 1:00 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York. The Michaelson, Krause & Kufeld families

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLSTATE CORP., Northbrook, Ill., the nation's largest publicly held, personal life insurance company, said that its subsidiary, Allstate Life Insurance Co., had agreed to acquire Provident National Assurance Co., a part of UnumProvident Corp., a disability and specialty risk insurance holding company based in Chattanooga, Tenn., for an undisclosed amount.

title: BRONFMAN MAY TESTIFY AGAINST MP3.COM
description: The chief executive of the Seagram Company, Edgar J. Bronfman, Jr., is expected to testify today in a federal trial being held to determine the scope of the damages that MP3.com will pay Seagram's Universal Music Group for violating its copyrights with its Internet music service. MP3.com's chief executive, Michael Robertson, concluded testifying before a skeptical Judge Jed S. Rakoff yesterday, saying he had not set out to willfully violate Universal's copyrights when he created an online database of thousands of albums.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unsolicited Offer Is Made For London Stock Exchange

title: U.S. Racketeer Law Applied in Police Suit
description: A federal judge has ruled that the government's anti-racketeering statute, created to deal with drug bosses and organized crime figures, can be used in lawsuits against the troubled Los Angeles Police Department.

title: Drug Wholesaler to Pay $20 Million Fine
description: Bindley Western Industries, a leading drug wholesaler, has pleaded guilty to one conspiracy charge and agreed to pay a $20 million fine to end a federal fraud investigation.

title: 'Arliss' Unsure
description: The only HBO series apparently unsure of its future is ''Arliss,'' the five-year-old comedy about a sports agent. Robert Wuhl, who produces, stars in and writes for the show, is also its unrelenting advocate. On at least two earlier occasions he lobbied hard to keep the show alive and suceeded.

title: RIO TINTO BIDS FOR PARTNER
description: Rio Tinto P.L.C., the London-based mining concern, offered to buy out its minority partner Ashton Mining Ltd. for 612 million Australian dollars, or $350 million, in an attempt to keep its rival De Beers from gaining a foothold in one of the world's largest diamond mines. Rio Tinto's offer, including Ashton's 5-cent dividend, amounts to 1.90 Australian dollars a share, or 17 percent more than De Beers's bid of 1.62 dollars. Rio Tinto and De Beers are angling for Ashton's 38.2 percent stake in the Argyle Diamond Mine; Rio already owns 56.8 percent of the mine. Argyle, which specializes in selling more affordable diamonds, is one of only a handful of mines in the world that skirt De Beers's trading and marketing influence, and Rio Tinto has said that its independence has been crucial to the mine's success. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE BOTTON, GILBERT
description: De BOTTON-Gilbert. The Board and staff of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem are saddened by the death of longtime friend and great supporter, Gilbert de Botton. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Janet and the entire family. Maureen Cogan Chairman, Int'l Council, IM James S. Snyder Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM

title: French Minister Quits Post Over Autonomy for Corsica
description: In perhaps the most daring initiative of his three years in office, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France has won widespread backing in Corsica for a plan to end decades of separatist violence in this Mediterranean island. But his proposal for limited autonomy for Corsicans has caused a crisis in his government.

title: The Wooed at Last Size Up Their White House Suitors
description: Here is how it happened for Joyce Doty: She started the summer already sold on Gov. George W. Bush. Then the conventions rolled around. Suddenly, Vice President Al Gore was looking handsome, sounding smart and intriguing her with the idea that ''maybe he wasn't too corrupted by Clinton after all.''

title: And So It Flows: Tale of the City And How Things Work, or Don't
description: The City Council speaker called a news conference at Columbus Park in Lower Manhattan yesterday to vividly illustrate the findings of a Council study on drinking fountains in city parks. It did not go exactly as planned.

title: Bloody Martini, Anyone?
description: PERHAPS no other drink has been humiliated by interpretation the way the martini and the Bloody Mary have. For the serious drinker these days, even a straight one invites suspicion.

title: That's Why It's Called Labor Day
description: THE time has come to stock up on pens and notebooks and index cards. No, I don't mean back-to-school supplies. I mean back-to-work supplies. My apologies to Julius Caesar and Dick Clark, but the real year -- the work year -- begins in September. Which means its just about time (don't panic, you have until next week) for our collective brains to click back into gear.

title: Brandywine Valley
description: The Brandywine Valley never produced a Mark Twain to glamorize its serpentine river, or a Washington Irving to make its folkways legendary. Instead, the valley lays claim to artists  painters like Howard Pyle and the Wyeth clan  who found inspiration in its gentle beauty and the simplicity of Quaker farmsteads.

Loving grandfather of Daniela and Janna. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St, Englewood, New Jersey, Thursday, August 31st, at 12 Noon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Under Bush, education has come of age for Republicans. On education, Mr. Bush looks more like Mr. Gore than he looks like Mr. Dole.''

title: Despite Tensions, China and Japan Reaffirm Ties
description: During a visit by Japan's foreign minister, Japan and China have affirmed their friendship, resolved to remain peaceful partners and scheduled a visit to Japan in October by Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji.

title: Gore Pitches His Health Care Plan for Uninsured Children
description: Vice President Al Gore kept his campaign focused on health care today by emphasizing his plan for providing access to coverage for the country's 11 million uninsured children.

description: SWIG-Robert. Jaffa Institute records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved brother of our distinguished Board Member and former President of The American Friends of The Institute, Kent Swig. May Kent and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. David Portowicz, Founder-Director Howard Blatt, President, American Friends Dr. Eliyahu Hartman, Vice President, Int'l Affairs

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: A City Revived, but With Buildings Falling Right and Left
description: Things had been looking up in this long-suffering city. Downtown was thriving again, the new mayor was still savoring his honeymoon and this month's Republican National Convention left Philadelphians with a feel-good, ego-boosting bounce.

description: Struggling With Language Translation Software

title: FBI Says Online Auctions Spark Most Fraud Complaints
description: August 30, 2000

title: Pondering Retirement
description: The tensions in Croatia have subsided and his sister's cancer is in remission; therefore, Goran Ivanisevic has little to motivate himself anymore. He cannot even throw a proper tantrum these days.

title: TBWA and Hakuhodo Unify Work for Nissan
description: TBWA in New York and Hakuhodo in Tokyo said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture solely for worldwide advertising communications for the Nissan Motor Company in Tokyo. Billings for the worldwide account were estimated at more than $1 billion.

title: To the Tape For Confessions
description: Early last week Court TV announced it would begin showing a new series featuring the videotaped confessions of murderers, rapists and other offenders.

title: Martinez's Foot Injury Not Serious
description: It looked very bad when Yankees first baseman Tino Martinez emerged from the clubhouse late Monday night flanked by trainers as he headed to a room for X-rays on his left foot.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE POUND WEAKENS. The dollar reached a six-year high against the British pound on speculation that interest rates in Britain may be near a peak. In New York, the pound settled at $1.4560, down from $1.4704 on Monday.

title: Congressional Endorsements
description: Congress has become a crucial battleground this election year with Republicans trying to strengthen their slim majority in the House and Democrats battling to overturn it. New Yorkers are beginning to see some evidence of this struggle in several key primaries to be held September 12.

title: A Slam in Seattle Jolts Nelson and Erases Pettitte's Gem
description: Like Boston's Pedro Martinez, Andy Pettitte flirted with a no-hitter tonight. But unlike Martinez, Pettitte did not engage in any brawls, there were no ejections -- and after Pettitte's no-hitter was broken up in the sixth, he suffered the loss when the Seattle Mariners came back for five runs in the eighth inning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, FRANCES (KRASNOW)
description: LYONS-Frances (Krasnow). Of Needham, MA., formerly of Great Neck, NY, on August 27, at age 82. Teacher of literature, lover of poetry and theater; iconoclastic and non-conforming. Survived by daughter, Deborah, of Gloucester, MA., and son, Daniel, of Boston, MA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Amnesty International.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL DROPS. Heating oil fell amid forecasts for a slight buildup in inventory. In New York, heating oil for September delivery fell 1.29 cents, or 1.3 percent, to 98.59 cents a gallon.

title: Testaverde Is Ready for His Close-Up
description: Vinny Testaverde leans back in a chair, easily crossing the legs that are more closely scrutinized than the Rockettes'.

title: Liberties; Yuppies Unite! Moats and Octopi for All!
description: Al Gore has been doing better. But there's still a lot of skepticism about whether his angry populism can work.
