title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, ERNEST (GUNNY)
description: BARRETT-Ernest (Gunny). Died suddenly August 27. Beloved husband of Sara, adored father of Debbie Barrett, Jo and Bruce Grellong. Cherished grandfather of Paul. Loving brother of William, brother-in-law of Rita Feldman, uncle and great uncle of many nieces and nephews. We love you and will miss you forever. Services Thursday, August 31, 2000, 1 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Deal Near on Police Raises, Nassau County Officials Say
description: Facing a state deadline for submitting a long-term plan to cut spending, the Nassau County executive is near agreement with a county police union on a new contract that would raise police salaries 20.5 percent during the next five years, county officials said yesterday.

title: Ginetta Sagan, 75, Who Spent Her Life Fighting Oppression
description: Ginetta Sagan, a leader of the American branch of Amnesty International who as a girl fought World War II's injustices in Europe and suffered for it, died last Friday at her home in Atherton, Calif., between San Francisco and San Jose. She was 75.

title: Prostate-Cancer Ad
description: To the Editor:

title: City to Sell 13 Lots in Harlem for Housing, at $1 Apiece
description: In their latest effort to rid the city of big tracts of land in Harlem, officials are selling 13 large vacant lots for $1 apiece and expect to receive about 50 applications today from developers offering plans for new housing.

title: Delights of a Familiar Grape: Crisp, Fruity Macon
description: WINE drinkers in this country learn early on about the Maconnais region in southern Burgundy. Its dry, clean white wines are generally reliable and inexpensive, and, for a beginner, offer a fallback when choices are otherwise overwhelming. It's as easy to point to a bottle of Macon-Villages at the wine shop as it is to ask for a glass of chardonnay at a restaurant.

title: BCE EMERGIS AGREES TO BUY INVOICELINK
description: BCE Emergis Inc., which develops software to let people conduct business over the Internet, agreed to buy the InvoiceLink Corporation for $88.3 million to bolster the services offered to financial and health-care companies. BCE Emergis said it would issue half of the purchase price to the closely held InvoiceLink in shares and options on closing, expected next month. The rest will be paid in three installments over three years, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAL, MICHAEL
description: KRAL-Michael. Age 80, of Redhook, NY, on August 11, 2000. Former CEO of Electralloy Corporation, predeceased by his first wife, Mae, and his second wife, Audrey. Memorial Service on September 15, 2000, at 9:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: MOTOROLA TO PAY $160 MILLION FOR PRINTRAK
description: Motorola Inc., the cell phone maker, agreed to buy Printrak International Inc. for $160 million, gaining a maker of software that will improve fire and police dispatching on Motorola's two-way radios. Motorola said it would pay $12.14 for each Printrak share. Printrak, based in Anaheim, Calif., had sales of $109.9 million last year. Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., is one of the biggest sellers of two-way radios for voice and data used by public safety agencies. Motorola shares rose 50 cents, to $36, and Printrak rose 13 cents, to $11.75.

title: Gumshoeing the Web
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Along a Favorite Route, Window Dressers Get a Dressing Down
description: Store windows, each a fantasy world, are ways to seduce the public into entering the shop's inner sanctum and seeking personal fulfillment by buying the fashionable products on view. Unlike the flat world of magazine advertising, the three-dimensional store window, with life- size mannequins and realistic props, has functioned over the years as a small, though frozen, performance space in which passers-by can imagine themselves as players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRACH, MARTIN
description: DRACH-Martin. In Loving Memory of Martin J. Drach. Beloved husband and companion of 64 years to Ethel. Wonderful parent to Ellie and David. Grandpa extraordinare to Gregg, Marc, Robert, Kim and Very Special Papa-Marty to Keith, Dylan, Eli and Amy. Services Friday, 10 AM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: A Pub and a Horse, And a Name to Share
description: The most eagerly awaited race today at Saratoga Race Course probably won't be the feature, the 23rd running of the Albany Stakes. Instead, it might be the fifth race on the card, a mile-and-a-sixteenth affair on the turf for 3-year-old fillies who have never won a race. The reason? The likely favorite is named The Parting Glass, after the popular Irish pub on Lake Avenue in Saratoga Springs.

title: Restructuring At the Bolshoi Costs Director His Position
description: In the latest twist to years of artistic and administrative turmoil, Vladimir Vasilyev was dismissed as director of the Bolshoi Theater, Russia's premier opera and ballet company, in a decree signed on Monday by President Vladimir Putin.

title: Zale Net Up 36% On Jewelry Sales
description: The Zale Corporation, a leading specialty-jewelry retailer, said today that its profit rose 36 percent in its most recent quarter because of higher sales of wedding rings, diamonds and other jewels.

title: France Proposes a Dramatic Package of Tax Cuts
description: PARIS, Aug. 31  Nudged by Germany, and likely providing an example to Italy, France today became the second of continental Europe's big three economies to propose a dramatic package of tax cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENBROEDER, FREDERICK ADRIAN
description: denBROEDER-Frederick Adrian. The Henfield Foundation (of New York City) expresses its profound regret at the death on July 8, 2000 of its Senior Director, Frederick denBroeder of Tucson, AZ. Mr. denBroeder, a well known Art Historian, was particularly praised for his studies of the 18th Century in Rome, until recently an often neglected field. He was born in Detroit in 1935, studied at Kenyon College, took a degree at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, and studied, for several years, at the Courtauld Institute in London. He subsequently was a senior curator at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. He then became an active dealer in old master drawings, retiring in his last few years to Tucson. These were spent in travel and in a growing interest in the study of the art of the South West. He will be sadly missed by many friends and colleagues, not least by us at the Henfield Foundation. J.F. McCrindle for The Henfield Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFLER, GERTRUDE H.
description: SCHAEFLER-Gertrude H. Died at home on August 29, 2000 in her 97th year, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Leon Schaefler. Devoted mother of Roberta S. Adler-Lazar, and Kathryn S. Pershan. Fond mother-inlaw of Richard H. Pershan and Nat Lazar. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Graveside service at Riverside Cemetary, Saddlebrook, NJ, on Thursday August 31, 2000, at 11:00. The family will be at Kathryn's home, 1435 Lexington Avenue, on Thursday evening, August 31st, from 5:00 to 7:00 to receive callers. Instead of flower, please make a contribution to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSIANOFF, PENELOPE
description: RUSSIANOFF-Penelope. Age 82. Peacefully at home in Manhattan, August 28, 2000. A dedicated clinical psychologist in private practice in New York, Penny was a member of the faculty of the New School beginning in 1960. She held numerous professional posts; gave lectures and workshops in the U.S. and abroad; and helped countless people in her therapy practice over the years. Penny is best-known as the author of the best-selling 1982 book ''Why Do I Think I Am Nothing Without a Man?'', & her role as the therapist in the film ''An Unmarried Woman''-as well as her 1989 book ''When Am I Going To Be Happy?'' She is survived by her daughter Sylvia Russianoff Linguiti, her son-in-law, and two grandchildren, all of Philadelphia, and by the two children of her deceased son Charles. Penny will be deeply missed by family, friends, and colleagues for her love of life, sense of humor, and extraordinary capacity for friendship. A memorial gathering will be announced. Contributions may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice or the Leon Russianoff Music Funds at the 92nd Street Y and the Manhattan School of Music.

The former chairman of the board of Altman Stoller Weiss Advertising, Inc., Mr. Altman was a dedicated, active and enthusiastic participant in countless College-related activities. We will miss Mr. Altman's commitment, loyalty and dedication to the College and we extend our condolences to his wife Floria, his daughters Emily and Dara, and his grandchildren. Evangelos J. title: EARTHGRAINS STRIKE IN SOUTHERN STATES EXPANDS
description: The Earthgrains Company, the bakery company, said yesterday that a strike at a plant in Fort Payne, Ala., had spread to five other bakeries where worker contracts have expired. Members of the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers union walked off the job in Memphis and Chattanooga, Tenn.; Atlanta and Forest Park, Ga.; and Mobile, Ala. Earthgrains said 1,565 workers are on strike. It has 22,000 employees and 64 bakeries in the United States. The company said it had been able to maintain production at five of the six bakeries, but analysts expect more work stoppages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, HELEN MARY
description: CALLAHAN-Helen Mary. Passed away on Wednesday, August 30, 2000. She was born on February 1, 1920 to Matthew and Helen Skelly, and was married to the late Daniel J. Callahan for over 50 years. Mrs. Callahan is survived by her daughters Geraldine Greene and Jacqueline Callahan-Stewart, and her son, Daniel M. Callahan. She leaves behind three loving grandchildren Deirdre Callahan, Sean Greene and Christopher Stewart, and will be deeply missed by her brother Joseph Skelly. A life long New York City resident, Mrs. Callahan was a new York City school teacher for 25 years. In retirement, she has been active in various church and philanthropic causes, and truly enjoyed her extensive volunteer work with The Ronald McDonald House. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NY, NY on Thursday, August 31 from 2-5 & 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial to be held at St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72 Street at 2nd Avenue, Friday 10AM. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAYTON, DORIS
description: CAYTON-Doris. Died on August 30. Devoted and beloved wife of Bill Cayton, her loving husband of 58 years. Cherished mother of Brian, Patricia and Merrie. Loved mother-in-law of Meryl and Kurt. Loved grandmother of Vanessa and Gabrielle. Treasured sister of Morton Roberts and his wife Dolores and their children Geri and April. Adored sister-in-law of Harold Goltzer and his children Dana and Eric. She was loved by Dana's children Alyssa and John and Eric's children Andrea and Liz. Doris Cayton was an extraordinary daughter to her deceased parents Minnie and Abe Rothback, and devoted daughter-in-law to the late Esther Cayton. Her cousins and family meant everything to her. She dedicated her life to making her husband's and children's life happy while working full time at home as her husband's trusted and indispensable business partner. Brilliant and beautiful, she always lived her life with dignity and elegance, never having a bad word to say about anyone. She will remain in our hearts forever. Services Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Gore and Bush Battling for Control of the Policy Agenda
description: Sticking to message like epoxy, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush continued their efforts today to set the terms of engagement in their presidential contest, with Mr. Gore promoting his plans to fortify Medicare and Mr. Bush pledging to increase federal aid to college students.

title: Economic Scene; Despite years of prosperity, times are tougher for those in the middle and below.
description: MAKE no mistake about how good the last five years have been to Americans. The usually cautious economists at the Economic Policy Institute point out in their new edition of ''The State of Working America'' that wages went up strongly across the board since 1996, even for low-income workers. In the meantime, low levels of unemployment meant that many who dropped out of the labor force were back at work, and jobs, in general, were more stable. Small wonder that Americans are confident again.

title: For U.S. Open Tennis, a Service Line Umpire That Never Blinks

title: DRKOOP.COM CUTS STAFF BY A THIRD
description: Drkoop.com, the struggling health information Web site, plans to cut its work force by 33 percent, bringing the number of employees down to 80. The cuts come after a group of investors provided the company with a much needed $27.5 million cash infusion last week. Drkoop.com laid off 35 percent of its staff in May. ''Drkoop's tremendous sales and marketing expenses, coupled with the lack of success they've had in getting a significant revenue stream from advertisers has led them to this point,'' said Rachel Terrace, a health analyst with Jupiter Communications. ''When the investors took over, they said they wanted to start running drkoop like a business, and their first order of business, to lay off employees, is not surprising.'' Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: ONLINE RETAILERS CUTTING SOME COSTS
description: Reflecting a shift from costly television ads to less expensive online advertising and marketing, per-customer acquisition costs for online retailers declined to $40 in the second quarter of this year, from a high of $71 in the fourth quarter of 1999, a new survey says. The survey of 66 North American online retailers, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group and Shop.org, a trade association for Internet retailers, also found, however, that acquisition costs were higher in the second quarter than the $35 a customer found in the third quarter of 1999, when the survey was first conducted. Conversion rates -- the proportion of online customer visits that turn into actual orders -- as well as the rate of repeat customers, improved slightly, according to the study. ''These key economic factors are all marginally up, but in aggregate they'll have a significant impact for online retailers as they try to achieve profitability,'' said James Vogtle, the director of e-commerce research at Boston Consulting. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOP, ARNOLD M., M.D.
description: SALOP-Arnold M., M.D. The Board of Directors, Medical Staff, Administration, hospital staff, friends and community of Phelps Memorial Hospital Center mourns the passing of one of its most distinguished physicians, Dr. Arnold M. Salop. An Internist who specialized in Cardiology, Dr. Salop was a highly skilled and gifted physician. In addition to his clinical practice at Phelps, Dr. Salop served the hospital in many important roles. He was Chief of Electrocardiology and established one of the first comprehensive diagnostic cardiology laboratories in Westchester. Dr. Salop also helped found the Intensive Care Units at Phelps. He served as Director of the Department of Medicine and President of the Medical Staff. He later served as the hospital's Medical Director and after his retirement from clinical practice was elected to the Board of Directors, where he chaired the Membership and Development Committee and cochaired the hospital's successful capital campaign. He was always an advocate of high quality patient care and professional excellence. We extend our deepest condolences to his devoted wife Mary Ellen, his children Andrea, Evan and Holly, and the entire Salop family. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester in Croton-On-Hudson, NY on Thursday, August 31st at 9AM. Following the interment, there will be a reception at the James House on the Phelps campus in Sleepy Hollow, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Arnold M. Salop Intensive Care Unit at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center. Henry Hilken, Chairman, Board of Directors Keith F. Safian, President and Chief Executive Officer Kenneth C. Kaplan, M.D., President of the Medical Staff

title: Arthur F. Anders, 96, Hero Aboard U.S. Gunboat in 1937
description: Arthur F. Anders, an officer of the United States Navy gunboat Panay who took command despite serious wounds after Japanese warplanes attacked it on the Yangtze River in China in 1937, died on Sunday at his home in Rancho Bernardo, Calif. He was 96.

title: Diners Journal: Trois Jean
description: Trois Jean, one of Manhattan's handsomest bistros, has ended its long run. In its place an American restaurant has risen with a clean-cut American look (created by Larry Bogdanow), a New American menu (created by Mark Spangenthal, the chef at the Screening Room) and a no-frills American name, the Dining Room.

title: Train Derails in Paris Subway, Injuring 24
description: A mysterious derailment injured 24 passengers in the Paris subway today, but a catastrophe was narrowly averted because the car that had tipped over skidded to a halt only three feet from a train on the opposite track.

title: 200,000 Homes in Illinois To Be Searched for Mercury

If there are B movies, then these are B games.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIPS. The euro held near a record low on speculation the European Central Bank would raise interest rates as much as a half-point today. In New York, the euro settled at 89.24 cents, down from 89.25 cents.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARESTATE JUDGE RULES MICROSOFT CASE CAN GO ON A state superior court judge in San Francisco has allowed the first class-action suit to proceed against the Microsoft Corporation based on allegations that the software company used its monopoly to harm California consumers. Many similar suits have been filed across the country since Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court in Washington ruled that the company had violated federal antitrust laws. In the California case, Superior Court Judge Stuart R. Pollak said an unspecified number of California consumers could be represented in one trial to determine whether they were forced to pay unreasonably high prices for Microsoft Windows, Word and other products. Microsoft said it was reviewing the ruling. No trial date has been set.

title: When Ellis Island Was the Only Portal
description: MOST Americans view the immigrant experience through the bold strokes of struggle and assimilation. They barely notice the underside of immigration -- the rules for inspecting, admitting and excluding newcomers to American shores. For much of American history, this process was handled by state and local authorities. But that changed in the 1890's, when Congress, worried by a flood of immigrants from central and southern Europe, gave the federal government complete jurisdiction.

title: NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE AT PHILIPS
description: Royal Philips Electronics said Gerard Kleisterlee, left, a 25-year veteran of the Amsterdam-based consumer electronics company, will replace the chief executive, Cor Boonstra, when he steps down on April 30. In four years at the helm, Mr. Boonstra streamlined the company and shored up profits by selling lagging divisions. His successor, Mr. Kleisterlee, has held numerous positions within Philips, including running the company's components business in Asia. The departure of the 62-year-old Mr. Boonstra coincides with the resignation of Adri Baan, 57, who will step down as president and chief executive of Philips Consumer Electronics on March 29. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Mr. Lieberman's Religious Words
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman's nomination as the Democratic vice-presidential candidate this month was widely hailed as a breakthrough for tolerance. Now, in a remarkable campaign development, Mr. Lieberman is being criticized by some Jewish leaders and others fearful that his declarations of faith as a devout Jew, and his calls for more religion in public life, are an affront to Americans who are less religious or whose faith comes from a different tradition. Ironically, leaders of the Christian right are defending Mr. Lieberman while asserting that some of their own leaders who seek a bigger role for religion and religious institutions should be absolved of similar charges of intolerance.

title: The Mt. Everest Of Yard Sales
description: THE pin on Mimi Mannix's hat said it all. ''Junk 'til you drop'' it read, which is why Ms. Mannix -- ''spelled like the detective,'' she said -- was outside the Strudel Haus in Covington, Ky., on a Thursday afternoon painting a giant pig. Like a multitude of less colorful people, Ms. Mannix, an Indiana collectibles dealer, and her capacious yellow porker, a mascot long ago rescued from the roof of a Piggly Wiggly grocery store, had come to this musty little town across the Ohio River from Cincinnati to shop.

title: Yesterday's Borscht and Knishes Return as Today's Reading List; Alumni of Faded Catskill Hotels and Bungalows Analyze Summer Experience, Reborn as Writers' Shticks
description: The Catskills have always been synonymous with comedy, with the shtick and shpritz of Sid Caesar, Jerry Lewis and Mel Brooks. But the glorious mountains here and the flavorful summertime crowds they drew have also proved to be a fertile ground for more thoughtful dramas, fiction and films about love, betrayal, even struggles with faith.

title: Mayor Geraldo? TV Anchor Is Thinking About It
description: Geraldo Rivera wants to run for mayor of New York City and he does not mind if that makes people laugh.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Whirlpool Lowers Forecast, Reflecting Anxiety in Industry
description: Whirlpool, the nation's largest maker of home appliances, warned today that its profit would be sharply lower than expected in the second half of the year, partly because of Circuit City's decision to stop selling major appliances at its retail outlets.

title: Friedel and Victorine Added to Men's Team
description: Coach Clive Charles yesterday filled the final two vacancies on his 18-man roster for the Summer Olympics in Australia, naming the United States national team goalkeeper Brad Friedel and the Los Angeles Galaxy rookie midfielder Sasha Victorine to the team.

title: PHILIP MORRIS IS INCREASING DIVIDEND BY 10%
description: Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it was raising its quarterly dividend by 10 percent, to 53 cents a share. Philip Morris, which makes Marlboro cigarettes, Kraft cheese and Miller beer, raised the amount from 48 cents, payable Oct. 10 to shareholders as of Sept. 15. The move offers further evidence that New York-based Philip Morris is less worried about smoking-related lawsuits, analysts said. In June, the company agreed to buy the Nabisco Holdings Corporation for $18.9 billion and announced plans to spin off up to 15 percent of its Kraft Foods unit.

title: Running Mates Sharply Defined: One Low-Key, One High-Profile
description: On Monday in a steamy union hall in Chicago, some 1,300 rowdy Democrats roared the now-ritualistic chant ''Go, Joe, go!'' as Mayor Richard M. Daley and the other big wheels of the Chicago Democratic machine escorted Senator Joseph I. Lieberman to the stage.

title: Sites and Events This Week
description: Sites and Events This Week

title: Israeli Court Upholds Scholar's Rights to Dead Sea Scrolls Work
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that an Israeli scholar had a copyright on his reconstruction of an important Dead Sea Scroll and that his right had been violated by an unauthorized early publication of his work.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Calendula Choices

title: BREWER'S PROFIT FALLS
description: The Tsingtao Brewery Company of China said its first-half profit fell 7 percent, although sales rose nearly 51 percent amid a gain in market share after it purchased a series of small breweries. The company did not explain why its profit fell. Unaudited first-half profit slid to 46.7 million yuan ($5.6 million), or 0.052 yuan per share, compared with 50.2 million yuan, or 0.056 yuan per share, in the same period last year. Sales totaled 1.7 billion yuan. Geoffrey Cheng, an analyst at HSBC Securities Ltd. in Hong Kong. said the brewer's acquisitions have increased its interest expenses.

title: Bryan Twins End Run of Opening-Round Losses
description: When Bob and Mike Bryan drew a seeded doubles opponent in the first round of the United States Open six years ago, they were 17 years old and just happy to be there. The second year, the identical twins from California thought it was strange. When it happened for a fifth straight year they were blown away.

title: Bill Would Make Online Companies With In-State Stores Pay Sales Tax
description: Bill Would Make Online Companies With In-State Stores Pay Sales Tax

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, LILLIAN
description: EDELMAN-Lillian. On August 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Philip. Loving mother of Howard and his wife Brigitte and Fred and his wife Emily. Devoted grandmother of Jody, Michael, Jonathan and Jill. Great-grandmother of Billie, Joseph, Roan and Clea. Services Friday 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Caring Community Senior Center, 20 Washington Square North, NY, NY 10011.

title: Wall St. Primed For More Deals Like the Latest
description: For years, David H. Komansky, the chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, has been predicting that the financial world will one day be dominated by a handful of global giants. That forecast has become accepted wisdom on Wall Street but figuring out who the eventual rulers will be -- and how many of them will be based in the United States -- is not getting much easier.

title: Legal Tug of War
description: Legal Tug of War

title: Preventing Diabetes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOUEL, ARLENE SIMON
description: SHOUEL-Arlene Simon. Devoted wife of Jack Shouel of Bayside, NY, died on August 29. She leaves her son David and daughter-in-law Michele of East Brunswick, NJ; grandchildren Heather and Matthew; sisters Evelyn S. Gilman of West Hartford, CT., and Marilyn Kurland of Rivervale, NJ; niece and nephew Randy Gilman Boll and Henri Boll of Livingston, NJ; Barbara Gilman of Torrington, CT; nephew & niece Barry and Karyn Kurland of Cumberland, ME., and Steven Kurland of Venice, CA; great nephews and nieces Sam, Rachael & Sarah Kurland; Herbie and Adina Bollimovsky. Funeral services will be held at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York, August 31 at 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE BOTTON, GILBERT
description: de BOTTON-Gilbert. It is with sorrow that we note the passing of Gilbert de Botton, a long-time member of MoMA's Chairman's Council. A patron of the arts, he was particularly noted as an outstanding collector of modern and contemporary art, and in the last few years was a moving force in the creation of the Tate Modern. We send our deep sympathy to his wife, Janet, and his children. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: A Wave of the Hand May Soon Make a Computer Jump to Obey
description: WITHOUT a doubt, there are uncounted millions of people who have made rude gestures to their computer screens in moments of desperation. And the computers never respond, which doesn't help matters.

title: WNBC in Venture To Cover Schools
description: In most cities, local newspapers and television stations provide blanket coverage of high school sports, reporting on everything from football games to gymnastics meets.

title: For U.S. Open Tennis, a Service Line Umpire That Never Blinks
description: For U.S. Open Tennis, a Service Line Umpire That Never Blinks

title: Reed Masters Astros as Valentine Hints at Return
description: Minutes after Rick Reed used his no-fuss, no-mess approach to calmly lead the Mets past the Houston Astros, 1-0, last night at Shea Stadium, Manager Bobby Valentine leaned forward in his office chair and said he believes that he will be back managing the Mets next year.

title: 2 Nixon Aides Skeptical About Report That He Took Drug
description: Two aides to President Richard M. Nixon said today that they doubted he ever took the drug Dilantin, an antiseizure medication, despite a new book that says he did.

title: Democrats Conjure Specter of Gingrich
description: This is a new 30-second commercial, called ''Stand,'' which the New York State Democratic Party began broadcasting Tuesday night.

title: Spider-Man Springs Into China With More Than Comics
description: Spider-Man isn't scaling the Great Wall just yet. But Stan Lee, the legendary impresario of Marvel Comic superheroes, was in Beijing this week as an honored guest at a ''friendship banquet'' of leading Japanese and Chinese cartoonists and animators.

title: From Tai Chi to Collard Greens, a Flowering of Diversity
description: IT isn't easy to find the Queens Botanical Garden, unless you live on Main Street in Flushing, or down one of those little one-way streets like Dahlia or Blossom. The 39-acre garden, with its campy, low-slung buildings and boisterous plantings, is tucked into the northeastern corner of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, cinched in by a pretzel of highways: the Grand Central Parkway, the Van Wyck Expressway, the Long Island Expressway. One wrong turn, and you're heading for the Whitestone Bridge, an 18-wheeler on your rear bumper. (You can always take the No. 7 train to the end of the line, and walk eight blocks.)

title: Article 2000083193365076761 -- No Title
description: President Vetoes G.O.P. Plan

title: HEAD OF AMD CHIP UNIT RESIGNS
description: Larry Hollatz, the head of Advanced Micro Devices PC chip group, is leaving to pursue other interests, the company said. Mr. Hollatz, 58, had been vice president for the computation products group, which builds the high-powered Athlon processors now gaining ground against Intel's Pentiums. AMD's president, Hector Ruiz, will take over his duties for now, the company said. Advanced Micro's sales have climbed as Intel could not meet demand during the first half of the year. ''I don't think it's a big issue,'' said Hans Mosesmann, a Prudential Securities analyst who rates the stock a strong buy. ''Hollatz was executing a strategy that had already been developed by the rest of the company.''

title: TELSTRA'S PROFIT SLOWS
description: The Telstra Corpora tion's profit growth slowed in the second half as increased competition offset higher Internet, mobile and data sales at the company, Australia's largest in telecommunications. Telstra's indicated second-half earnings rose 16.5 percent in the six months to June 30, down from 21 percent in the same period a year earlier. The stock fell 1.7 percent to 6.77 Australian dollars. Telstra, which is based in Melbourne, and controls almost 80 percent of the nation's telecommunications industry, has been hurt by new competition, forcing it to cut retail phone charges and improve its services to remain competitive.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARESTATE JUDGE RULES MICROSOFT CASE CAN GO ON A state superior court judge in San Francisco has allowed the first class-action suit to proceed against the Microsoft Corporation based on allegations that the software company used its monopoly to harm California consumers. Many similar suits have been filed across the country since Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court in Washington ruled that the company had violated federal antitrust laws. In the California case, Superior Court Judge Stuart R. Pollak said an unspecified number of California consumers could be represented in one trial to determine whether they were forced to pay unreasonably high prices for Microsoft Windows, Word and other products. Microsoft said it was reviewing the ruling. No trial date has been set.

title: Many Sites Are Trolling For Voters
description: THIS election year, if you visit a Web site created by any group with political interests, you will probably have a chance to register to vote as well.

title: Mice for the Touchy-Feely And for the Short Of Space
description: Consumers make lots of choices about the computer itself -- how fast, how much storage, how much RAM -- but a mouse is taken for granted as just part of the package. You have to have a really good reason to change the default mouse.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Legal Tug of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SAM
description: SCHWARTZ-Sam passed away at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City on August 30, 2000 after a prolonged illness. Loving father of Sheila Paulos and grandfather to Leah Paulos and Daniel Paulos, father-in-law of John Allen Paulos. Beloved companion of Marsha Engelsher. Jean Gibenstein his wife of 56 years died of Alzheimer's Disease in 1997. Born in New York City in 1917, Mr. Schwartz was founder and president of Metropolitan Window Washing Company in White Plains, NY. He lived life passionately with great love for his family and friends. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be held at Louis Hirsch and Sons, Inc., 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York on Thursday, August 31st at 1:30 P.M. Interment is at Cedar Park, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCA, RELLI, CONRAD
description: MARCA - RELLI - Conrad. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

title: Australian Action Reopens Dispute on Human Rights Monitors
description: A decision by Australia to limit its cooperation with the United Nations on human rights reporting has reopened a debate about whether international monitors are sometimes harder on democracies than on closed societies.

title: Addenda
description: Interactive Agency Names Top Officers

title: Charles Atlas Complaint Held as Legal Weakling
description: Charles Atlas might have been one of America's most famous musclemen, ably taking on bullies who kicked sand in his face at the beach. But this week, a federal judge treated his company like a 97-pound weakling and threw it out of court.

title: SONY PLANT PLANS
description: The Sony Corporation said it would spend 100 billion yen ($942 million) over the next five years on a new plant to produce microchips used in mobile phones and digital cameras. Sony will start construction in November in Kumamoto prefecture, on Japan's southern island of Kyushu. The factory will begin production in October 2001. The move is to meet rising demand for cell phones, projectors, digital cameras and camcorders.

title: Program Raises the Specter Of Viruses Attacking P.D.A.'s
description: The first malicious program to attack a Palm organizer appeared on the Internet this week, causing no permanent damage but leading security experts to warn that more harmful incursions are probably around the corner.

title: Swiss Banks Calling Wall St. Home
description: The Credit Suisse Group's planned acquisition of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, following hard on the heels of the deal for PaineWebber by the Swiss banking giant UBS, is likely to provide further illustration of Swiss banking's flair for penetrating Wall Street and managing the cultural clashes that expansion outside Europe often brings.

title: Chicago Makes Another Effort to Disrupt Gangs
description: The corner of 18th and Throop Streets is the heart of Chicago gang territory.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; SATELLITE SWITCHED OFF
description: Solidaridad 1, a Mexican telecommunications satellite that broke down over the weekend, was switched off after the operating company's repeated efforts to restart the central processor failed. The $250 million satellite, built by the Hughes Space and Communications Company, a unit of General Motors, failed Sunday morning and prompted Mexico's only satellite operating company, Satmex, to shift service for more than 100 domestic and international clients to its other three satellites and other orbiters owned by other companies. Solidaridad 1 was operating at half its capacity on a back up computer after the principal central processor broke down last year. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: The Singular Piety of Politics
description: The men who wrote the Constitution faced a choice: Either establish a church, as some of the colonies had done, or provide for religious toleration. They chose the way of nonestablishment. This seemed a good choice, and it worked well throughout most of the 19th century and well into the 20th.

title: Death Penalty In Texas Case Is Overturned, Citing Lawyer
description: A federal judge has overturned the death sentence of a Texas man convicted of killing a 16-year-old boy, citing the ''dismal'' performance of the convicted man's lawyer during his trial as well as the prosecution's failure to disclose to jurors that an important witness was a paid informer.

title: Assessing Honesty in Clinical Drug Trials
description: Clinical drug trials, in which volunteers are given drugs or placebos so that researchers can gauge the effectiveness of a particular treatment, are a linchpin of modern medicine.

title: A camp to teach your children well the secrets of marketing.
description: THE concept of summer camp normally conjures up images of kayaks, campfires, s'mores and color wars. But at a new two-week day camp, children instead find storyboards, video cameras, cut-up magazines and even the ingredients food stylists use to prepare prop ice cream cones.

title: Endorsements for the Legislature
description: New York's legislators have traditionally enjoyed something close to political tenure. In the last election, every incumbent won re-election. But in the Sept. 12 primary, several veteran legislators face real challenges. Here are our endorsements in five races. As in all our primary endorsements, the choices do not assure our endorsement in the general election.

title: Operator Sought for Rebuilt Brooklyn Rail Yard
description: After nearly two decades of planning, New York City and State have completed the $20 million modernization of an old freight yard in Brooklyn, and the city is seeking bidders to revive the cross-harbor rail freight traffic that had largely disappeared since its heyday a half century ago.

title: The Environment, and Our Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: KPN REPORTS FIRST LOSS
description: Royal KPN N.V., the Netherlands' largest phone company, cut its annual earnings forecast and reported its first-ever loss as the former monopoly pays for mobile phone licenses and recruiting customers. Shares of KPN fell 6.4 percent after the company reported a first-half loss of 19 million euros ($16.9 million) in contrast to a profit of 416 million euros a year earlier. The company has been investing in mobile phone businesses in Germany, the Netherlands and Britain as governments sell licenses for so-called third-generation mobile licenses, which allow mobile phones to have access to the Internet. The cut in the profit forecast reflects the cost of acquiring customers for the German mobile operation and the start of Internet operations there, a spokesman said.

title: Rangers Re-sign A.H.L. All-Star
description: The Rangers re-signed center Derek Armstrong, an All-Star for the second straight year in the American Hockey League last season.

title: A Book Review of Sorts, Courtesy of Bill Parcells
description: Bill Parcells still does not sleep well after games, fretting about what he could do as the Jets' director of football operations to improve the team.

title: Classic Beauty, Cubed
description: COME away with me to my desert island, sort of a cross between ''Survivor'' and ''Fantasy Island.'' The fantasy comes into play in that the island would already have a Power Macintosh G4 Cube computer with a 15-inch flat-panel Studio Display, a set of Harman Kardon SoundSticks speakers and a fast Internet connection. Add to that just one luxury item, ''Survivor'' style, and that would be a copy of Culture 4.0, an endlessly fascinating CD-ROM from Cultural Resources.

title: Frankfurt Market Rebuffs Bid by Swedes for London Partner
description: Werner G. Seifert, the head of the Frankfurt stock market, refused to sweeten the terms of a proposed merger with the London Stock Exchange today, dismissing a rival bid of $1.2 billion by OM Gruppen A.B. of Sweden as ''ridiculous and derisory.''

title: Al Fayed to Sue U.S. to Obtain Files on Diana
description: Mohamed Al Fayed, owner of the Harrods department store of London, said today that he would sue the federal government seeking all information it has on the high-speed automobile accident that killed his son Emad Mohamed Al Fayed and Diana, Princess of Wales, three years ago in Paris.

title: Domestic Stage Satisfies This Political Wife
description: ''I CLEAN my own house, I swear!'' insists Pat Lazio. ''Couldn't you tell from the upstairs?''

title: Knoblauch Unable to Play Yet
description: Elbow pain continues to prevent Chuck Knoblauch from participating in a minor league rehabilitation assignment, and Joe Torre seems resigned to the possibility that Knoblauch will not be able to play second base again this season.

description: Manhattan

description: Microsoft Programs Have Privacy Concern

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the daily performance of the stock market misstated the record high for the Dow Jones industrial average. It was 11,722.98 points in January, not 11,287.08 in April.

title: Karabulak Journal; Chechens Have Something New to Dread: Winter
description: An August thunderstorm had just shredded the roof and walls of Raisa Go tsayeva's canvas tent, and she was airing out the bedding and washing the floorboards when a visitor came across her dirt threshold to inquire about conditions in the sea of tents here on the border with Chechnya.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, CLIFFORD D. THELEN REID
description: ROOT-Clifford D. Thelen Reid & Priest LLP mourns the loss of a friend and colleague. Cliff was a leader of the public utility bar. He served as managing partner of the former Reid & Priest for nine years. Cliff was known for his negotiating skills, sense of humor, incisive intellect and photographic memory, which were brought to bear in his representation of clients and his management of Reid & Priest. His partners remember him for his strength of character, fair mindedness, courage and compassion. Cliff was a true and loyal friend and professional. We extend our most sincere sympathy to his wife, Maxine Winifred Carlisle, and family members.

title: Ewing for Howard Is Latest Talk
description: One week after the collapse of a four-way trade that would have sent Patrick Ewing to Seattle, the Knicks have renewed efforts to trade the future Hall of Fame center.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, O. BRUCE, M.D.
description: DICKERSON-O. Bruce, M.D. Of New Canaan, CT, a leader in occupational medicine, on August 28, 2000. Survivors include his mother Juanita Baird, his wife Mimi Haggerty Dickerson, a son John Bruce Dickerson, a brother Lt. Colonel I. Wayne Dickerson and a sister Rita Shalton. Memorial service September 1, 11AM St Mark's Church, Route 124, New Canaan, CT. Contributions may be made to the Bruce Dickerson M.D. Fund at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021 or the Wittingham Cancer Center, c/o Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. 06850.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINA, JEAN
description: MALINA-Jean. On August 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Michael and Anita, and Robert and Fran. Dear sister of Anne. Cherished grandmother of Rachel (Edwin), Stuart (Martha), Toby, Joel (Nancy), Joshua (Melissa) and Nicole. Adoring great grandmother of six. Beloved aunt. Service on Friday 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Many, Many in India Want to Be a Millionaire
description: BOMBAY, Aug. 29  Maqbool Ahmed has dreams of instant wealth, which ordinarily would require a mighty burst of imagination from a man living in the Bombay slum of Geeta Nagar, a hideous warren of hovels where the air reeks of kerosene and fish, and there are only 24 toilets for 6,000 people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSEN KLEIN, MYRNA
description: ROSEN KLEIN-Myrna. Mom, we miss you. You remain forever in our hearts. Wayne and Jef

title: MP3.com Argument Rejected in Music Trial
description: A federal judge rejected an online music start-up's argument yesterday that the Universal Music Group is improperly pursuing a copyright infringement claim against the company as a means of driving a potential competitor out of business.

title: Shifting Patterns That Flow And Stretch in the Open Air
description: One of the missions of Jonathan Hollander and his Battery Dance Company is to present companies that might not otherwise be seen in New York City. One such troupe is the Zig Zag Ballet, a year-old group based in Stamford, Conn., that performed on Tuesday afternoon at Mr. Hollander's Downtown Dance Festival in Battery Park. Founded a year ago by Brett Raphael, Zig Zag is an ensemble of stylish dancers who look ready for anything. That was just as well, given the range of the two works they performed.

title: ALTAVISTA EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: AltaVista said that Andrew Mitchell, its British managing director, had resigned. The news follows the company's botched plans to provide flat-fee Internet access service to British customers. AltaVista trumped competitors by being first to announce that it would provide cut-rate Internet access for a single low-cost payment, but then failed to deliver the service. Unlike the free and fixed-rate services in the United States, those in Britain charge by the minute. AltaVista had planned to take advantage of new rules aimed at loosening the grip of British Telecommunications P.L.C. on the local phone market. ''The mistakes in our planned Internet access service, which we do acknowledge, probably made Andy's departure inevitable,'' said Pierre Paperon, president of AltaVista Europe. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: To the Editor:
