title: I.R.S. Rules That Kidnapped Child Earns One-Year Exemption
description: The taxpayer's question started out poignant, then turned pragmatic: My child has been kidnapped. Can I still take a deduction on my income tax return? The answer this week from an Internal Revenue Service lawyer was matter of fact: only for the year the child was abducted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, RABBI JECHIEL MEIR
description: GOLDSMITH-Rabbi Jechiel Meir. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with great sadness the passing of Rabbi Jechiel Meir Goldsmith, beloved father of our dear friend and colleague, Rabbinic Chaplain Sheldon Goldsmith, an esteemed member of the Department of Pastoral Care and Education at Beth Israel. To Rabbi Goldsmith, his family, and all of his father's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Gail F. Donovan Executive VP and COO Renee Warshofsky-Altholz Administrative Director, Patient Care Services

title: A Drug Plan Fraught With Risk
description: ''We have no military objective,'' President Clinton told the Colombian people in a passionate television address on the eve of his one-day visit here today. ''We do not believe your conflict has a military solution. Our approach is both pro-peace and anti-drug.''

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Favre Free of Pain and Planning to Play
description: Packers quarterback Brett Favre said today that, although he is not 100 percent, the tendinitis in his throwing elbow will not prevent him from starting against the Jets in the season opener Sunday in Green Bay.

title: For the Democrats, No Hill Is Steeper Than This One
description: For the first time in Mississippi's history, state lawmakers were called on early this year to choose the next governor. No candidate had reached the 50 percent plus one required to win the popular vote, and so the election went to the House of Representatives, where the outcome was far more certain. Overwhelmingly Democratic, the House made Lt. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove the winner over his Republican opponent, Mike Parker, a former congressman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMICK, MARIAN R.
description: McCORMICK-Marian R. On August 29, 2000 of Port Washington. Beloved wife of the late Thomas E. Loving mother of Brian and Mark. Also survived by her loving daughters-in-law Susan and Patricia. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Thursday 3-5 & 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday 10:30 am St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington. Interment All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Peter of Alcantara Church.

title: INSIDE
description: Neo-Nazis Convicted

title: Cornhuskers Go Online, Not on TV
description: THERE was a time, not long ago, when football and computers had as much to do with each other as touchdowns and home runs.

title: Labor Board Makes Joining Union Easier for Temp Staff
description: For years it was nearly impossible for temporary workers to join unions, but the National Labor Relations Board issued a ruling yesterday that opened the door for many temps to join unions at their workplaces.

title: Taking Sides in the Napster War; With Copyright Law at Issue, Sites Battle for the Ears and Minds of Music Lovers
description: WHEN John Fix 3rd closes Cornell's True Value hardware store in Eastchester, N.Y., every night at 6, he turns out the lights but leaves the computers running. During the day they perform inventory checks or crunch numbers, but at night, the store's 12 personal computers are connected to Napster, the music file-sharing service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBALATA, VICTOR, MD
description: BARBALATA-Victor, MD. August 30, 2000. Beloved husband of Milly for 60 years. Father of Jeanne, grandfather of Stephanie, Alexandra and Isabelle and brother-inlaw to Sergiu Comissiona. Born in Romania and graduated from University of Bucharest Medical School in 1940. Arrived in the United States in 1959. Senior Clinical Assistant in Medicine, Mount Sinai Hospital. Attending Physician at Kateri Residence. He devoted himself to the care and treatment of his loyal patients in his private practice for over 45 years. His family will miss his intelligence, compassion and wisdom. He will be missed always and remembered forever. Please contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th & Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Bush Advisers and Networks Gather to Discuss the Debates
description: Senior advisers to Gov. George W. Bush met here today with representatives from three television networks to discuss presidential debates that individual networks have proposed.

title: Salinger's Daughter Writes Of Her Father's Obsessions
description: J.D. Salinger's daughter, Margaret, is visiting New York from Boston and staying at the Plaza Hotel, under an assumed name. There are Salinger ''crazies'' out there, Ms. Salinger says, who have written menacing letters to her family. And then there is the possibility that her famously private father will try to stop her from publishing her memoir, ''Dream Catcher,'' due out on Wednesday from Pocket Books.

title: Waiting for Justice in Peru
description: Peru has taken a step in the right direction by revoking the life sentence that a military tribunal imposed on Lori Berenson four and a half years ago after a sham trial. Now it must ensure that the civilian court that will retry the Berenson case observes the basic standards of justice that the military court ignored.

title: Justice Department Official Says Microsoft Schedule Uncertain
description: Justice Department Official Says Microsoft Schedule Uncertain

title: 2 Greengrocers to Give Back Wages to Underpaid Workers
description: Two Manhattan greengrocers have agreed to pay nearly $100,000 in back wages to immigrant workers who sometimes received only $200 for working 72-hour weeks, state officials said yesterday.

title: New Epidemic Proving Fatal To Foxhounds
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y., Aug. 22  For months, no one could figure out why the foxhounds here were suddenly dying.

title: Bitter Primary Contest Hits Ethnic Nerve Among Blacks
description: It is a primary race that has spawned a soap opera-like drama. The bitterness of a feud between two Democrats in the 11th Congressional District in Brooklyn has not only torn apart a longstanding friendship but has also delivered some of that anguish to the doorsteps of other politicians and voters in Brooklyn.

title: DUKE IS ACQUIRING GAS STORAGE COMPANY
description: The Duke Energy Corporation has agreed to buy the natural gas-storage unit of NiSource Inc. Duke Energy Gas Transmission said it would pay $250 million and assume $150 million in debt for NiSource's Market Hub Partners, which stores natural gas in underground salt caverns it owns in Texas and Louisiana. NiSource, based in Merrillville, Ind., is selling the storage unit ahead of a planned $8.5 billion takeover by Columbia Energy Group. Duke, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., expects to complete the purchase this year.

title: SWEDISH VENTURE FUND
description: Three Swedish companies, Ericsson, Investor A.B. and A.B. Industrivarden, along with Merrill Lynch, said they would form a $300 million venture capital fund to invest in mobile Internet start-up firms. The fund will be called Ericsson Venture Partners and will focus on all aspects of mobile Internet technology, including network infrastructure, services and applications. In June, Ericsson, the Stockholm-based telecommunications company, said it would start an incubator and venture-capital company called INN to develop technologies beyond its core telecommunications-equipment business. Industrivarden is one of Sweden's largest holding companies with a portfolio worth about $8 billion. Investor, whose largest shareholder is the Wallenberg family of Sweden, manages about $20 billion in assets. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Drug-War Victory: What's the Value?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKS, JUNE
description: FRANKS-June, On August 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Loving mother of Roberta, David and Michael. Devoted grandmother of Laurie and Larry. Dear sister of Grace Rothstein and Honey Rosen. Services today 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business; ABB Building Power Link
description: ABB Ltd., the world's largest electrical engineering company, said it received a $120 million order to build an underwater transmission system connecting the power networks of Connecticut and Long Island.

title: Suharto a No-Show as Doctors Declare Him Too Ill for Trial
description: The corruption trial of Indonesia's fallen leader, Suharto, got under way here this morning in the converted auditorium of a government ministry building that was crowded with spectators and ringed by police officers, but missing one man: the accused.

title: Intel Again Sues Broadcom Over Patents
description: Intel filed a lawsuit today accusing the Broadcom Corporation of ''a carefully crafted plan'' to build its business in cable and high-speed networking products by violating Intel patents.

title: Article 2000083192459347138 -- No Title
description: By JULIAN E. BARNES

title: Off-Duty Police Driving Cabs? Taxi Panel Says Yes but Officers See an Insult
description: In an effort to build up the ranks of taxi drivers, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission is considering a proposal to encourage police officers to moonlight behind the wheels of yellow cabs, but the plan is being greeted coldly by police officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, HARRIET
description: BLAUSTEIN-Harriet. On August 30, 2000. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Eric Nadel and his wife, Marianne. Step-mother of Gary Alan and his wife, Antoinette, and Ron L. Blaustein and his wife, Estella. Devoted grandmother of Joshua, Emily, Jaime, Ariel, Benjamin, Jacob and Jonathan. Dear sister and friend of Myrna Perline. Services today, 11:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. She was full of life and beloved by all.

title: Legal Tug of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADNER, RITA
description: BADNER-Rita. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of its esteemed member, Dr. Elizabeth Muss, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi, David Yagoda, Chairman, Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: Housewares With the Energy of Youth
description: A RIOT of color and a burst of energy hit the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center last week when the Accent on Design Show came to town. Child-friendly plastic stools, bright children's chairs and affordable hand-blown glass vases in a rainbow of colors are just a few of the new designs that were shown. Some of the high-voltage energy came from the designers themselves, many of them young and marketing their work directly to consumers on the Internet. And since home furnishing trends are said to follow fashion, both are looking youthful this season. ''Co-purchasing -- children shopping with parents -- is a millennial trend,'' said William Strauss, a generational historian and co-author of ''Millennials Rising: The Next Great Generation'' (Vintage Books, September 2000). ''This is an optimistic generation,'' he said, with considerable buying power. Children are being consulted on purchases from computers to home furnishings, he continued, adding, ''Parents want their homes to be kid-friendly.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, HARRY H.
description: JONES-Harry H. Of Sun Valley, Idaho, formerly of Short Hills, NJ. on August 29, 2000, husband of Kathleen Jones (nee McCord), father of Robert C., Julie J. Moore, Cynthia K. Jones, Amy J. Hill and Susan J. McKeon, step-father of Gigi Welsh, John and Reid Welsh, also survived by a brother Carlisle Jones and fourteen grand-children. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 1, 2000 at 11 AM, at Christ Episcopal Church, Short Hills, NJ. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to Bill Jannss, Children Activity Center, P.O. Box 6801, Sun Valley, Idaho 83340.

title: Fire in New Jersey Engulfs Apartments Near Hudson River
description: A spectacular fire last night engulfed a sprawling apartment complex under construction near the Hudson River in Edgewater, N.J., destroyed or damaged at least eight occupied homes across the street, and sent columns of flame 200 feet into the air.

title: IBM-COMPAQ OFFER DATA STORAGE PRODUCT
description: International Business Machines plans to sell a new data storage product as the first fruit of its $1 billion alliance with Compaq Computer. I.B.M.'s Modular Storage Server, for small- and midsize businesses, will be available Sept. 29. A 200-gigabyte version will sell for $70,000. It is an I.B.M. version of Compaq's StorageWorks Modular Array 8000 model but with I.B.M. disk drives.

title: Unit Chief With Big Stake Resigns at Morgan Stanley
description: Peter F. Karches, a longtime top executive of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and one of its biggest individual shareholders, has resigned as head of its businesses that cater to institutional customers.

title: Besmirched 'Deportland' Wrestles With the I.N.S.
description: ''Monstrous'' is the word used by Portland's mayor, Vera Katz. The executive director of the Port of Portland says the city's reputation has been tarred by ''Gestapo-type actions.'' A state senator here says the conduct in question is ''racist and xenophobic.'' And United States Senator Gordon H. Smith, a Republican, put it this way today, ''We don't want Portland to be known as ''Deportland.''

title: Somalis Get Leader; Now They Need a Nation
description: Somalia finally has a government, and its first president in nearly a decade arrived here today escorted by at least 120 pickup trucks carrying more than 1,000 militiamen armed with rifles, rocket launchers, even double-barreled antiaircraft guns.

title: U.S. and Russia Open a Nuclear Swords-to-Plowshares Project
description: American and Russian officials dedicated a 10-acre industrial park today at what was until recently a nuclear-weapons factory east of Moscow. It was the second step in a joint project that American experts hope will provide jobs for up to 4,000 Russian weapons scientists and workers.

title: Religion's Many Faces Meet in New York for Peace
description: One religious leader among hundreds who have come from around the world to New York this week to talk about peace, Dastur Firoze M. Kotwal said he hoped the four-day gathering fosters friendships across faith boundaries, a sharing of viewpoints and ''unity among religions.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROSE
description: WOLF-Rose. Loving wife of 59 years of Marvin. Mother of Diane and Steven Katz, Arlene and Robert Fauser, Sharon and Mark Horowitz. Grandmother of Brian and Nancy, Darren, Chad, Emily and Joshua. Cherished sister of Florence Schoenhut and the late Stanley Howard, and sister-in-law of Betty Howard, and the late Hy Schoenhut. Rose was also a very special and dedicated aunt. She was devoted to her family and spent her life supporting and loving each one of us. We remember her for that love and devotion, and will miss her and love her forever. Services Friday, September 1, 11:15 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Donations can be made to Simon Wiesenthal Center.

title: In America; Children's Champions?
description: George W. Bush and the Republicans have spent much of the presidential campaign promising to look out for the nation's children. They have gone so far as to hijack the phrase ''leave no child behind'' from the very liberal Children's Defense Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, CHARLES M.
description: REED-Charles M., 79, formerly of Erie, PA, and Gorham, N.H. Graduate University of Pennsylvania and Wharton School of Business with a Master's Degree in Business Administration. Employed as a systems analyst, James River Corporation, Berlin, N.H., 19 years, retiring 1985. Burial Friday AM, Erie Cemetery, Erie, PA. Memorial service September 9, 1 PM, at the Gorham Congregational Church, Gorham, N.H.

title: Washington Split Deepens in Debate Over Missile Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The Pentagon and the State Department are sharply divided over how far work on a limited national missile defense system could proceed before the United States would be required to give formal notice that it was violating a crucial arms control treaty with Russia.

title: Torre Can Find No Fault With Nelson After Slam
description: Jeff Nelson robotically reviewed his role in the disastrous eighth inning after Tuesday night's game, sounding like a court reporter reading from a transcript as he slumped in a chair in front of his locker. His vacant gaze betrayed the fact that this was probably the third or fourth time he had combed through the memory of all the pitches he threw, including the fastball that Seattle's Edgar Martinez crushed for a game-winning grand slam.

title: Mary Pierce Beats Maleeva
description: As her mistakes mounted today, Mary Pierce tightened. She slapped easy forehands into the net. She labored chasing after balls.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude rose on speculation that a Saudi Arabian plan to raise output might add too little oil to world supply to meet demand. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 58 cents, to $33.32 a barrel.

title: Report Finds High Risk of Failure In Regents Exams Starting in '03
description: Most students starting high school in New York City next month are at risk of failing the five Regents exams that will be required for a high school diploma starting in 2003, according to a report released yesterday by the public advocate's office.

title: Q&A / Prince Hans-Adam II : Liechtenstein's Future As a 'Clean Tax Haven'
description: Until the 1960s, the tiny principality of Liechtenstein (population 32,000), wedged between Switzerland and Austria, subsisted on income from tourism, the sale of stamps and the export of false teeth. Today, a thriving financial sector has propelled it to top ranking among the world's wealthiest nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, CYRIL
description: MURRAY-Cyril. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our former esteemed member, Cyril Murray. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Nesta, and their family. Richard Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Give Stepmoms a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Closings in China Arouse Workers to Fury
description: The brick-walled Meite Packaging factory compound is nearly deserted now, its managers and machines hastily transferred in the last couple of days to a special development zone 30 miles outside this industrial city.

title: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
description: August 25, 2000 Go to article

title: Economic Indicators Index Falls for Third Month
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in July for a third consecutive month, a sign that higher interest rates may restrain growth in coming months, an industry report showed.

title: Where Horses Are King, Odds Are Against the Workers; Hispanic Migrants Toil for Low Wages, Knowing The Animals Are Worth More Than They Are
description: God may have given people dominion over the animals, but such biblical injunctions mean little for the sleek, toned thoroughbreds that are stabled around the Saratoga racetrack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, EVA (BOCIAN)
description: RAPPAPORT-Eva (Bocian). On August 28, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Jay Perry (Barbara) and Edith (Joseph) Amorese. Cherished grandmother of Marc (Sherry), Matthew, Michelle, David and Lona Allda, and the late Jake. Great-grandmother of Morgan, Abigail and Maxwell. Devoted aunt. Sister of Gerald. Survivor of the Holocaust. Executive Director of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives. Board member of N.A.H.C. Services were held Wednesday 12 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Donations in lieu of flowers, U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum.

title: Sniffing Out Crime by Bits and Bytes
description: MANY of her clients are surprised when Kellie Carlisle, a high-tech investigator in Orlando, Fla., tells them that she really doesn't need to have physical custody of a suspected computer to reach inside the labyrinth of chips and wires for the information she needs.

title: New Jersey and Pentagon Sign Agreement on Cleaning Up Contamination at Military Bases
description: Department of Defense officials and New Jersey environmental regulators signed an accord yesterday in which the Pentagon agreed to finance the cleanup of 550 contaminated sites on current and former military bases around the state.

title: Giants and Fassel to Go With a 'Two-Headed Monster' in the Backfield
description: On Monday, Giants Coach Jim Fassel announced that he was going to have his players wear their road uniforms for Sunday's season-opening home game with Arizona. Today, he announced that he has two starting running backs, Tiki Barber and Ron Dayne, and might introduce both before the game as co-starters at the position.

title: Mexico Is Ordered to Pay a U.S. Company $16.7 Million
description: An international tribunal that worked behind closed doors to arbitrate a cross-border dispute between a United States company and the Mexican government ordered Mexico to pay nearly $17 million in compensatory damages yesterday for failing to protect the company's rights as a foreign investor.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; VOLKSWAGEN TALKS BREAK DOWN
description: The latest round of wage talks between union leaders and management at Volkswagen's plant in Puebla, Mexico, have broken down despite the government arbitrator's announcing late Tuesday night that Volkswagen had raised its offer to 20 percent. Union leaders representing 12,600 workers at the only plant in the world that still produces the VW Bug and its popular successor, the New Beetle, are holding out for a 21 percent rise. But a union spokesman held out the possibility that the two sides could reach agreement when talks reconvene. Dan Fineren (NYT)

title: Williams Is Back From the Precipice
description: There are still four days to go before the regular season begins, but the Jets are very unlikely to experience a comeback any more evocative than the one Kevin Williams has already fashioned this week.

title: GLIATECH BEGINS INQUIRY INTO ALTERED RESULTS FOR STUDY
description: Gliatech Inc. said yesterday that it was investigating altered results from a study of its surgical anti-scarring gel after the changes were noted by government inspectors. Shares in the company, which is based in Cleveland, fell $1.31, to $8.88, yesterday. On Tuesday, the shares plunged 60 percent after Guilford Pharmaceuticals Inc. canceled its planned $246 million purchase of Gliatech, citing Food and Drug Administration concerns. The company said an internal task force of executives who were not involved in the study would investigate. A team of outside legal and regulatory experts would also be involved, Gliatech said. The F.D.A.'s complaints centered on changes in data collected in Gliatech's trial for Adcon-L gel, which is used to prevent internal scarring and pain after spinal surgeries.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE POLLS

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis on Aug. 6 about the rise in arrests for selling the drug Ecstasy misstated the circumstances of the charges against Kenneth S. Gregorio and Brian J. Juliano, two students at Monmouth University in New Jersey. Police investigators accused them of planning to sell it on the Jersey Shore, not on the Monmouth campus.

title: The Environment, and Our Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, WILLIAM
description: SCHNECK-William. August 28, 2000. Beloved husband of Sally Shank Bloch. Devoted brother of Helen Laffer and Pepi Kahn. Services private.

title: Jack Nitzsche, 63, Musician And Oscar-Winning Songwriter
description: Jack Nitzsche, an Oscar-winning songwriter, keyboardist and arranger who worked with musicians like Phil Spector, the Rolling Stones, Neil Young and Miles Davis, died on Friday in Hollywood. He was 63 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Name and a Date For Sony's New P.D.A.
description: After almost a year of dribbling out bits and bytes of information about a collaboration with Palm Inc., Sony announced this week that its sleek, new personal digital assistant would go on sale next month. And the device, which will have lithium-rechargeable batteries and a gray-scale display (color is in the works), finally has a name: CLIE (pronounced KLEE-ay). Advance orders can be placed at www.sony.com/clie. CLIE is an acronym, for communication, link, information and entertainment.

title: CNN Is Seeking A New Strategy; U.S. Operations Chief Quits As Management Is Revamped
description: In 1997, CNN, the 24-hour cable news channel, found itself at somewhat of a dead end.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gap Announces Its Sales Will Decline by 14% in August
description: Gap Inc. stunned investors yesterday evening by announcing after the stock market closed that sales in stores open at least a year, a well-watched industry measurement, would decline 14 percent in August. The numbers were not only well below what most analysts expected, they seemed to truly surprise the normally efficient company.

title: Essay; Vouchers Help Blacks
description: School vouchers make a big difference for black students.

title: Conrad Marca-Relli, Collagist and Painter, Is Dead at 87
description: Conrad Marca-Relli, an American artist linked to Abstract Expressionism and known for making large patchwork collages of cut pieces of canvas, died Tuesday at his home in Parma, Italy. He was 87.

title: A 50-1 Shot a Sprint Surprise For a Young Saratoga Trainer
description: Saratoga once again lived up to its nickname as the graveyard of favorites today when a nondescript 4-year-old colt named Shadow Caster pulled off a stunning upset to take the 21st running of the Grade II $250,000 Forego Handicap.

title: A Night Spent Achingly Close to Home
description: With helicopters hovering overhead, and columns of smoke billowing in the not-so-far distance, Janice Tibus stood barefoot on the sidewalk, wearing plaid pajamas and holding a pair of black sandals in one hand. As she and her family tried nervously to get the phone number of a relative, a man on a stretcher was carried by. ''Dad,'' Ms. Tibus yelled, ''That's Uncle Dennis!''

title: Interactive Agency Names Top Officers
description: Executives are changing posts at R/GA in New York, an interactive agency that is part of True North Communications. Martin Reidy, 43, president and chief operating officer, was named to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Robert M. Greenberg, 52, chairman, who was named to the additional new post of chief creative officer, overseeing accounts like I.B.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSS, BADNER, RITA
description: MUSS-BADNER-Rita. On August 30, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Louis Muss. Loving mother of Elizabeth Muss, Marion Green and Henry Muss. Cherished grandmother of Saundra Green-Rice. Services Friday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Services for the Underserved, 305 Seventh Avenue, 10th Floor, NY, NY 10001

title: Program Raises the Specter Of Viruses Attacking P.D.A.'s
description: Program Raises the Specter

title: Titan Sues to Block Damaging Anonymous Web Postings
description: Titan Sues to Block Damaging Anonymous Web Postings

title: Dokic's Father Banned For Rest of Tournament
description: Damir Dokic, the father and coach of the rising Australian star Jelena Dokic, was barred from the United States Open yesterday after a series of confrontations at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday about GetMusic, an Internet site owned by Bertelsmann and Seagram, misstated the site's plans for music sales. It is considering finding another company to handle sales of compact discs in the United States, but it has not made a final decision to do so, and it still intends to sell music through computer downloads. It is not getting out of selling music.

title: Survival, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Candidate Accuses Opponent of Leaking His Divorce Records
description: In the latest installment in a Congressional race that has become increasingly bitter, State Senator Larry B. Seabrook yesterday accused his opponent, Representative Eliot Engel, of obtaining sealed divorce records and supplying them to the media to embarrass him.

title: Be-Bop-a-Lula, Wildwood's My Baby
description: EVEN the name is perfect right out of the 50's and 60's, when teenagers were watching ''The Wild One'' and ''How to Stuff a Wild Bikini'' at the drive-in, humming doo-wop ballads and spending their summer vacations at this Jersey Shore town, where practically every motel has a plastic palm tree overhanging its car court and every third motel owner is a character deserving of his own sitcom.

title: New Software Being Offered By Microsoft to Catch AOL
description: For years, it seems, nothing in the software world has been more ubiquitous than the America Online discs offering free online hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, INEZ ZUCKER
description: CALLAHAN-Inez Zucker. Wife and adored companion of Joseph Callahan for forty years, died on August 29th after her heroic struggle with cancer. Inez, a terrific raconteur, charmed the world with her beauty, brilliance and extraordinary wit. Like her father, the renowned Ecole de Paris artist Jacques Zucker, Inez was a talented artist; the high-cheek boned velvety beauty came from her mother Nina Zucker. Inez's early childhood was in Paris, Israel and New York. After World War II Inez returned to Paris with her parents and her brother John Zucker. Her friends from her youthful Paris days, Marie-Christiene Choukroun, Barbara Probst Solomon and Joyce Brawer, forever will remember her as an ebuillient girl who danced the tango and pasadobles with a rose pinned in her hair; her brother John and her cousins and closest of friends Meno and Nili Shir and her friend Marvin Raeburn will forever miss her good-humored all-embracing love. A world traveler and linguist, Inez's forty years work with BOAC permitted her and Joe Callahan to have friends not only in New York where they lived and in her beloved Puerta Vallarta, but all over the world. The memorial will be next month.

title: Bottle Caps, the Crown Jewels for One Collector
description: Art and commerce collide in Davide Mascherini's collection of inch-wide bottle caps, or crowns, as he calls them, which can be seen on his Web site (members.xoom.it/davidekorn /index.htm). The site features bottle tops from beverages from 159 countries. Some -- Aruba, Benin, Mali and Togo, for example -- are represented by one cap each. Countries like the United States, Poland and Germany are represented by hundreds of crowns.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, STANLEY
description: BROWNSTEIN-Stanley. June 1, 1932 - August 31, 1999. Always on my mind, forever in my heart. My life and my world are empty without you. You were the very best and I miss you so. Love always, Hilda

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- Toledo, Ohio, and Louisville, Ky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, DONALD MACKAY
description: TAYLOR-Donald Mackay. Died suddenly in Venice, Italy, in the early morning hours of August 27. He was 50 years old. ''Mackay,'' as an actor, polyglot and world traveler, touched many people with his courageous, kind and enormous spirit. His sparkling presence will remain unforgettable. He is survived by his brother, Kenneth C. Taylor of Maryland, and by a myriad of friends, both here & abroad, who consider Mackay their brother. Funeral services will be held in Venice on September 9 and a memorial service will be held in New York at a date to be announced.

title: Metro Matters; Listening To a Change In the Silence
description: SOME issues get the silent treatment in politics. Others elicit cliches. There are reasons, of course. Get past the self-censorship and the platitudes and you're likely to find the most interesting near-debates around.

title: HYUNDAI EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: The head of South Korea's largest brokerage house, Hyundai Securities, resigned, bowing to pressure from the government and creditor banks that had accused him of hindering restructuring efforts at its parent company, the Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest conglomerate. The executive, Lee Ik Chi, 56, has been a close aide to the Chung family that founded Hyundai Group. Creditor banks blamed Mr. Lee, and other executives loyal to the Chung family, for playing a major role leading to the financial trouble at the conglomerate. His resignation will be accepted at a board meeting scheduled for next Monday, Hyundai Securities said. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: The Faith Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAR AND EXIDE JOIN TO DEVELOP STRONGER CAR BATTERY
description: The Lear Corporation says it has agreed to work with the Exide Corporation, an automotive battery maker, to develop more powerful batteries to handle Internet access and other electronic features in cars and trucks. Lear, the largest maker of automotive seats and interiors, and Exide will work on the Exide Select Orbital battery. Terms were not disclosed. Automakers hope to shift to a 42-volt battery standard from the current 14 volts within five years.

title: Suit Charges That Boy Was Illegally Kept in Foster Care as Mother Sought Return
description: A federal lawsuit filed yesterday charges that the city's Administration for Children's Services violated the civil rights of a 5-year-old boy and his mother by holding the child in foster care illegally for two and a half years and denying his mother the chance to plead in court for his return.

title: Yes, There's Such a Thing as Too Clean
description: IT has been a banner season for slobs. As the nation spent the summer watching those telegenic survivors turn desert-island filth into high ratings, researchers in the United States and in England told a different kind of dirty story: a little squalor may be good for the health. Common household germs and dust, it seems, play a vital role in the development of immune systems. In housekeeping terms, this is the equivalent of discovering that chocolate bonbons cure varicose veins.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Gap Says Sales in August To Decline a Surprising 14%

title: Rein In the C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mostly White Party Seeking Voters From A.N.C.
description: The white politicians ventured into this dusty black township, determined to connect.
